These days, in the auto industry, the word coupe has been corrupted; it is difficult to tell what it means anymore.

title: Letter: Questions for Arne Duncan
description: It is unfortunate that Deborah Solomon chose to characterize online education as a horrible alternative to the traditional classroom in her interview with the secretary of education. Solomon shortchanges online education by suggesting that online students are learning from a machine instead of a beloved high-school teacher. Solomon should do her homework: online education connects students with highly qualified, experienced teachers  human beings who become beloved to their online students through message boards, chats, e-mails, videos, Skype and more. The machine is simply a conduit for human interaction. In fact, the 2010 online teacher of the year, Teresa Dove of the Florida Virtual School, credits the online environment with allowing more interaction and feedback to her students, noting that, You might be separated geographically, but spending that one-on-one time with the kids is the biggest asset for an online instructor.

title: Fold-Ins, Past and Present
description: Mad magazine fold-ins from the 1960s to the present, in interactive form.

title: New Sketch of a Madcaps Mad Life
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass.  At 89, Al Jaffee still takes puckish pride in skewering the high and mighty, himself included. I had a thought yesterday, he announced within minutes of meeting a reporter at his summer home a few weeks ago. I must be a bigot, he said, because I hate bigots.

title: Salazar Warns Against Co-Opting of Science
description: In his inaugural address, President Obama promised to restore science to its rightful place in government policy making, reversing what many in the scientific world believed to be the Bush administrations tight control or suppression of science across a range of fields. The Obama administration, the new president promised, would be guided by vigorous and open scientific debate in decisions on biomedical research, climate change, endangered species and other technical endeavors.

title: Photos of the Moment | Rick Owens
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: The Filmmaker Who Does a Job on Wall Street
description: Inside Job, a documentary on the financial crisis by director Charles Ferguson, screens Friday and Monday at the New York Film Festival and opens in theaters on Oct. 8. Narrated by Matt Damon, the movie features interviews with the likes of Nouriel Roubini; Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister; and Representative Barney Frank.

title: Comic-Con to Stay in San Diego Through 2015
description: Moviegoers seeking early looks at Hollywoods latest action and science-fiction franchise films or just a place to dress as their favorite member of the X-Men can continue to look forward to gathering in San Diego each summer. Comic-Con International, the collectibles convention that has grown into an annual must-attend event for the makers and consumers of fantasy entertainment and pop culture, said on Friday that it would remain in San Diego through 2015, The San Diego Union Tribune reported.

title: East Coast Is Soaked by Gusty Storm
description: Driving rain and gusty winds battered the already soggy East Coast before dawn on Friday morning, flooding subway tracks, expressways and suburban streets in the New York metropolitan area, snarling air travel and causing a rush-hour quagmire that threatened to linger even as the worst of the weather subsided later in the morning.

title: Living Together, Separately
description: Emily Nemens and Benjamin Shuldiner have a pair of very different settings, just steps apart.

title: The Fiat/Ferrari Talk
description: We published an interesting article  on Friday by David Jolly, who spoke to both Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Fiat, and to Luca Cordero di Montezemolo, the chairman of Ferrari, at the Paris Motor Show.

title: The Fiat/Ferrari Talk
description: We published an interesting article  on Friday by David Jolly, who spoke to both Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Fiat, and to Luca Cordero di Montezemolo, the chairman of Ferrari, at the Paris Motor Show.

title: Battle Stations! Dior Joins the Navy
description: Apparently no theme is too remote for designers. Dior landed on an imaginary South Pacific naval base, with the runway transformed into a dock and the models sporting sailor caps on their Bettie Page wigs.

title: The Morning Skate: Whos Where for 2010-2011
description: The N.H.L. season begins in seven nights and did you know that Chris Higgins is now with the Florida Panthers? It all starts next Thursday and youve only got seven nights to catch up on this summers roster moves.

title: Dramatic Video of a Standoff in Ecuador
description: As my colleague Simon Romero reports, the chief of Ecuadors national police force resigned on Friday after an uprising by officers angered by benefits cuts held President Rafael Correa captive for more than 10 hours on Thursday.

title: Poparazzi | Auto-Neurotic Stimulation
description: What is the most embarrassing thing youve ever been caught Googling?

title: Switching Gear at the Ryder Cup
description: We knew that clothing was not the strong suit of professional golfers, even if you do not count John Dalys sartorial hallucinations. Phil Mickelsons closet, for example, should be permanently cordoned off by the fashion police. But even for golfers, Fridays clothing travails of the American Ryder Cup team were a new low. It does not take much in the way of common sense to know that if youre traveling to Wales on a little golf trip you should make sure your expensive new rain gear does not instead soak up water like a paper towel.

title: Balancing Act Remains for Jeter and the Yankees
description: When the season ends, the Yankees will initiate a delicate last tango with Derek Jeter, one of the most venerable Yankees this side of Lou Gehrig.

title: The Global Glut in I.P.O.s
description: When it comes to initial public offerings, the reach of many companies is far exceeding the markets grasp.

title: Real Deal Planets, Near and Far
description: Jan 18, 11:11 p.m. | Updated  [Illustrating that science on the edge of understanding is implicitly tentative, the case against Gliese 581g appears to be gaining strength.]

title: Rahm Says Goodbye to the White House
description: Even Rahm Emanuel, it turns out, has a tender side.

title: A Q. and A. With the Filmmaker Charles Ferguson
description: Charles Ferguson, the documentary filmmaker whose acclaimed 2007 movie No End in Sight exposed the mishandling of the war in Iraq, has taken on the global financial crisis of 2008 in his latest movie, Inside Job. Over on Dealbook, Mr. Ferguson discusses the movie, which features interviews with the likes of Nouriel Roubini, an economist; Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister; and Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts. Read more  here.

title: Book Review Podcast: Annie Murphy Pauls Origins
description: This week: the science writer Annie Murphy Paul discusses her new book Origins and the emerging scientific field of fetal origins; Gay Talese talks about the art of nonfiction narrative and his new collection of sports writing, The Silent Season of a Hero; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: At Frontier Diner, Not Much Is Left but Memories
description: There has never been much that could be called a frontier at corner of 39th Street and Third Avenue. There was once an elevated train line there, but these days, no demarcation of neighborhood or mood can be discerned.

title: Margaret Atwood in the Twittersphere
description: Big Think is running an interview with Margaret Atwood, in which she talks about Canadian humor, her creative process, dystopian versus apocalyptic literature, the reasons to preserve physical books despite the rise of the e-reader, and the appeal of blogs and Twitter  which she calls an extension of the diary, the latest improvement in humans ability to communicate rapidly.

title: Margaret Atwood in the Twittersphere
description: Big Think is running an interview with Margaret Atwood, in which she talks about Canadian humor, her creative process, dystopian versus apocalyptic literature, the reasons to preserve physical books despite the rise of the e-reader, and the appeal of blogs and Twitter  which she calls an extension of the diary, the latest improvement in humans ability to communicate rapidly.

title: Weekend Competition: New York Minutes, Glasgow Kisses, Indian Summers
description: This weekend, inspired by New Yorks Indian Summer, co-vocabularists are invited to share descriptive toponyms.

title: Now Online | Ts Fall Design Issue
description: The fall issue of T Design looks at different visions of domestic bliss. We look back at Design Research, the revered godfather of modern design stores. Pilar Viladas visits an airy, open house in Italy by the superstar designer Patricia Urquiola for Patrizia Moroso, the creative director of the cutting-edge furniture company Moroso, while Nicolai Ouroussoff considers a very different dwelling: a seven-sided house in Southern California, by the Los Angeles architect Michael Maltzan for the artists Lari Pittman and Roy Dowell, which spirals around an intimate courtyard, looking inward rather than out. Our Profile in Style focuses on Barnaba Fornasetti, the scion of a legendary design family who has made his own kind of magic. Alexandra Lange spends time with Renate Mller, the German designer of meticulously crafted, whimsical therapeutic toys, and Judith Nasatir peers into the exquisite world of Federico de Vera, the gimlet-eyed proprietor of one of New Yorks most magical design shops. On an entirely different note, Jaime Gross takes a peek at a San Francisco medical marijuana dispensary that is as elegantly designed as any fashion storebringing an often taboo subject out of the shadows. And the endpage features a calendar, by the graphic-design legend Massimo Vignelli, that is still timely after 44 years.

title: Lone $4.1 Billion Sale Led to Flash Crash in May
description: It was a stock market mystery that had everyone guessing for months: just what caused that harrowing flash crash last May?

title: Single Sale of Worth $4.1 Billion Led to Flash Crash
description: A single sale of $4.1 billion in futures contracts by a mutual fund touched off a series of events that led to the so-called flash crash, the sharp stock market decline that shook investors and markets on May 6, federal regulators said Friday.

title: TimesCast | October 1, 2010
description: A hard look at the economics and politics of the TARP program and a preview of a coming story of life at the emergency room at one of the busiest hospitals in the nation.

title: Booker and Christie Meet in the Middle
description: NEWARK  They first met in 2002: Cory A. Booker, then an upstart councilman trying to topple this citys political machine, asked Chris Christie, the chief federal prosecutor in New Jersey, to monitor the election for intimidation and voter fraud.

title: Britain Will Let Chevron Drill Deep in North Sea
description: Britain gave Chevron the go-ahead on Friday for a controversial deepwater drilling project in the North Sea, a sign that the recent accident in the Gulf of Mexico has not shattered that governments support for such projects.

title: Week 5 College Football Matchups
description: Im trying to play it cool. Really I am. Trying to be calm and even-keeled about what is shaping up to be one of the great weekends of college football in recent memory. Alabama hosting Florida in the regular season? Stanford and Oregon going toe to toe in Eugene? The Red River Rivalry? Two undefeated matchups in the Big Ten? A huge showdown in the A.C.C? (Well I actually might be one of the few people looking forward to Virginia Tech/N.C. State.)

title: MTV Programming Chief to Step Down
description: MTVs top programmer is leaving the youth-oriented cable channel along with a top lieutenant.

title: Seedorf Responds: Returning to Amsterdam
description: Two days after supplying an assist in A.C. Milans 1-1 draw against Ajax in Amsterdam, Clarence Seedorf, a Dutch soccer player, checked in with Andrew Keh of The New York Times from Italy to answer questions submitted this week by Goal readers. This is the latest installment in a monthly discussion series with Seedorf; previous discussions can be found here.

title: In Comments, Fed Officials Signal New Economic Push
description: WASHINGTON  Momentum within the Federal Reserve this week continued to build toward resuming purchases of huge amounts of government debt to help the flagging economic recovery.

title: Development Plans Leave a Church and a Block at War
description: It was a day like any other on West 123rd Street in Harlem. The Rev. Arthur Anthony Harris was busy handing out bags of potatoes, tomatoes and cabbage from the steps of the Rescue Mission Baptist Church.

title: The Corner of High Life and High Line
description: WILLIAM PHILLIPS owned Phillips-OShansky Meats on Gansevoort Street for decades starting in the early 20th century. He was a sharp-eyed man, his grandson Jonathan Phillips said, but he would never have imagined the meatpacking district as a place where people would want to live, let alone pay a premium to do so.

title: Mingle, Meet, and Maybe Move In
description: WHAT if your apartment roommate moved out abruptly with no forwarding address, leaving you to pay his half of that months rent? Frantic mass e-mails and Facebook posts have yielded no replacements, and you are tired of dealing with spammers and strangers on Craigslist.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: When a Condo Board Considers a Renter

title: The 30-Minute Interview: Marvin H. Meltzer
description: Mr. Meltzer, 72, is a principal of Meltzer/Mandl Architects, which specializes in designing affordable housing, like the Melrose Court condominium in the South Bronx and Bradhurst Court in Harlem. Meltzer/Mandl has also been involved in higher-end projects; it redesigned 45 Wall Street from offices to luxury apartments.

title: Transit Cuts Bring Uncertainty
description: IT was partly the Port Washington line of the Long Island Rail Road, with its direct, quick and frequent runs into Manhattan, that persuaded Scott McCabe, 28, a financial analyst working in Midtown Manhattan, to move to Port Washington from Hoboken, N.J.

title: Its Five-Link Friday! (More or Less)
description: The Awl looked outside on this sopping first Friday in October and issued a slacker weather alert. While there is certainly nothing better than taking a day off in situations like this, its also true that for New Yorkers who actually have to go to work every day to make ends meet, flooded roads and snarled train service require a warriorlike mentality, the very opposite of slacking.

title: Buying With the Contractor in Tow
description: ARCHITECTS, decorators and contractors are reporting an uptick in business, as new homeowners forge ahead with renovations and upgrades that they might have had to forgo, or at least delay, when houses were selling for far more.

title: Refinancing Into Shorter Loans
description: GRIM headlines about the housing market can make that final mortgage payment seem like a distant dream. But a growing number of homeowners are refinancing into shorter-term mortgages designed to make the dream become a reality sooner.

title: U.N. Report on Congo Massacres Draws Anger
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The United Nations on Friday officially released a much disputed report on massacres in the Democratic Republic of Congo that has drawn the ire of several countries, especially Rwanda, whose forces were accused of possibly committing genocide.

title: In Iraq, New Leadership but Same Reality
description: BAGHDADOperation New Dawn is rising over Baghdad, but all too often the first light of sun is beaten by the first sound of rockets.

title: Living in the Meatpacking District
description: The meatpacking district proper is framed by Gansevoort Street, West 14th Street, Hudson Street and the West Side Piers.

title: Easy Pieces
description: In a season marked by clean, tailored lines and a neutral color palette, the third and latest offering from Uniqlos +J collection, designed by the purists purist Jil Sander, feels more appropriate than ever. A crisp white shirt with a perfectly conceived collar (not straight, not quite a Peter Pan), ribbed cable-knit sweaters without the waist-expanding bulk, and the only suit youll need all season (slim, two-button in charcoal wool) are the ingredients to a seamless fall wardrobe. Wear the pieces individually or layered on top of one another to get the maximum out of a minimalist look. With prices ranging from $20 to $230, its doubtful the clothes will be in store much past next Thursdays release date.

title: Time Capsule
description: A 1935 house in Ridgefield, listed for $1.5 million, retains most of its original features.

title: Old World Meets New Reality
description: RIDGEFIELD

title: Use Your (Rice) Noodle
description: Rice noodles can be a smart, tasty substitute for traditional pasta, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: What Does the Future Hold for Jeter and the Yankees?
description: In Whats a Jeter Worth?, the columnist William C. Rhoden writes that shortstop Derek Jeters next contract will not be about batting average or production. It is about what Jeter means to the Yankees brand, and the deep feeling between player and team.

title: Storied Parisian Spa Arrives in New York
description: La Maison de Beaut (House of Beauty), the iconic Parisian spa started 60 years ago by the Carita sisters, who created Brigitte Bardots and Jean Sebergs signature hairstyles and then founded a skin-care line called Carita, has arrived in New York.

title: More Quantitative Easing on the Way?
description: 2:12 p.m. | Updated

title: Artifacts | Trisha Brown, Off the Wall
description: At 5 p.m. on Wednesday, a camera-phone-wielding crowd gathered at the corner of Madison Avenue and 75th Street as a man on the roof of the Whitney Museum prepared to go off it. Oh, my God, gasped a passerby as the man, the dancer and choreographer Stephen Petronio, achieved liftoff. He let his body fall forward until it was perpendicular to the pavement, and then held perfectly still, looking down at the street and perhaps into his soul as well. After a few moments of awed silence, he began an absurdly casual stroll down the sheer 97-foot granite cliff of the Whitneys side wall, rappelling in slow-motion and pausing, now and then, to let his seemingly weightless feet regain the wall before proceeding to the bottom, where he was greeted with an ovation.

title: Booming Car Sales in China May Bypass Diesels
description: PARIS

title: Trying to Echo Childhoods Rhythms
description: A NEW mother, who is also a television critic, is inevitably asked whether she will permit her child to share her public pleasure. Friends and strangers have posed this question to me repeatedly since my son was born a year ago, and I have yet to formulate a position. I understand how addictive the medium is, but refusing it (as the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends for children under age 2) feels too sanctimonious  and unrealistic. A baby getting increasingly mobile does not sit still during a changing of clothes unless, according to studies conducted in my living room, hes put in front of a TV for a minute or two  whether its iCarly or Harry Reid on Morning Joe. And fathers who love sports tend to feel that ESPN does not count as actual television. There may be toddlers who, though they have never watched a single second of Dora the Explorer, could hand you a nacho and talk third-down conversions.

title: Defendant Ignited Fire, Cheshire Prosecutor Tells Jury
description: NEW HAVEN  A prosecutor at the trial of one of the two men accused of invading a home and murdering a woman and her two daughters contended on Friday for the first time that it was the defendant, Steven J. Hayes, who ignited the fire that killed the girls.

title: A Piece of Her Heart on a 40th Anniversary
description: IN the late summer of 1968, Big Brother and the Holding Company had nearly finished recording Cheap Thrills when Janis Joplin, the bands singer, slipped the drummer Dave Getz a set of lyrics shed handwritten to accompany a piano riff he had been practicing. The song, Cant Be the Only One, with words by Joplin and music by Mr. Getz, was something of a parting gift. Within days, Joplin gathered her band mates in a room at the Chelsea Hotel and announced that she was going solo.

title: Lamborghini Sesto Elemento Showcases Lightweight Carbon Fiber
description: PARIS  Its fitting that the Lamborghini Sesto Elemento made its debut in Paris. The seemingly deconstructed sports car looks like the citys Centre Georges Pompidou on wheels, every working part is open and exposed to the world. Rumored to be the replacement for the current Murcilago supercar, the Sesto Elemento (Sixth Element) is actually a showcase of the Italian sports car companys use of lightweight carbon fiber.

title: A Census of Harlem Meer
description: Census of Harlem Meer, Central Park, circa 10 a.m.

title: Treating Brooklyn
description: Across the United States, emergency rooms are busier than ever. One of the busiest is Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn.

description: This week: the science writer Annie Murphy Paul discusses her new book Origins and the emerging scientific field of fetal origins; Gay Talese talks about the art of nonfiction narrative and his new collection of sports writing, The Silent Season of a Hero; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

description: This week: the science writer Annie Murphy Paul discusses her new book Origins and the emerging scientific field of fetal origins; Gay Talese talks about the art of nonfiction narrative and his new collection of sports writing, The Silent Season of a Hero; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. description: This week: the science writer Annie Murphy Paul discusses her new book Origins and the emerging scientific field of fetal origins; Gay Talese talks about the art of nonfiction narrative and his new collection of sports writing, The Silent Season of a Hero; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Audi Quattro Concept Channels Nostalgia for the Classic Sport Quattro
description: PARIS  For Audi fans in the 1980s, the original Sport Quattro was more fun than Pac-Man and better looking than the highest shoulder pads. Inspired by the German automakers successful rallying program - and the need to manufacture a street-legal version to homologate the car for racing - the Sport Quattro was an instant classic, though only 224 were ever built.

title: Mixed Messages
description: I love signs  not so much the yield or tax not included or no vacancy varieties  but unique, local signs that surprise me with humor or cultural insight, intentionally or not.

title: The Smith to Open a Branch in Midtown
description: Jeffrey Lefcourt and Glenn Harris, who own Jane on West Houston Street and The Smith on Third Avenue in the East Village, will be entering the uptown restaurant mix. They plan to open a big branch of The Smith in the spring at 956 Second Avenue (51st Street), with 10,000 square feet of space over two floors and a zinc bar that stretches for 100 feet. Its an unusual turnaround for the Manhattan real estate scene because it replaces a Rite-Aid drugstore; usually drug stores and banks have replaced restaurants. We have been looking for so long to find the right place to open a branch of The Smith in Midtown so were very excited, Mr. Lefcourt said.

title: A Soggy New York
description: Driving rain and gusty winds battered the already wet East Coast before dawn on Friday morning.

title: Now Showing | Driss Ouadahi
description: Densit, an exhibition of paintings by Driss Ouadahi, opens today at Hosfelt Gallery New York. Ouadahi grew up in Algeria and studied architecture before enrolling at the Kunstakademie Dsseldorf, in the German city that is now his home. His subject matter is the built environment of urban alienation: underground passageways, chain-link fencing, the sterile Modernist high-rise buildings that are home to so many immigrants in European cities. Ouadahis almost pretty color palette makes his screen-like, gridded high-rise facades seem seductive, until you realize that beyond them is a barren, depopulated landscape. His precisely rendered, claustrophobic tiled passages would make Kafka break out in a sweat, and his delicate depictions of chain link cover the canvas to its edges, suggesting a net that leaves no way out. The exhibition continues through Nov. 13. 531 West 36th Street; (212) 563-5454.

title: Humpbacked Porsche Looks Good From Drivers Seat
description: PARIS  A Porsche sporting a whale tail rear spoiler used to be the height of automotive coolness. Originally designed to increase engine cooling and provide extra rear down-force for the 911 Turbo, the unique feature quickly became an over-used cosmetic addition to nearly every spec of 911. Perhaps Porsche is trying to resurrect this cetacean theme, via the distinctly humpbacked shape of the new 911 Speedster shown at theParis Auto Show.

title: An Admirer Of Tight Production, But of Sludge, Too
description: FOR as long as hes been in music, Mark Ronson has had magnetic taste. Mr. Ronson, son of the socialite Ann Dexter-Jones and stepson of the Foreigner guitarist Mick Jones, was raised in London and New York, where he began as a scenester D.J., playing parties, modeling and hanging with the likes of Jay-Z.

title: How Harvard Works

title: Items for the Table That Are Truly Museum Pieces
description: Do you have dinnerware designed by Roy Lichtenstein, Keith Haring and James Rosenquist, and glassware by Sol Lewitt in your cupboard? The Museum of Arts and Design does in an exhibit called Eat Drink Art Design. In addition to the big name pieces, there is simple, beautifully crafted rustic Japanese stoneware alongside equally elegant disposable white Japanese dishes made from bamboo and sugar cane pulp. Scores of plates designed by Peter Ting and produced by Royal Crown Derby in England make up a display called Constellation Manhattan. A surreal silver Melting Teapot by Myra Mimlitsch-Gray is one of the rare, highly impractical pieces on view.Eat Drink Art Design is on the third floor of the Museum of Arts and Design at Columbus Circle through March 27, Tuesdays through Sundays 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., except Thursdays when it stays open until 9 p.m. The disposable Japanese Wasara plates are sold in the museum shop, six for $15.

title: What Does Change Look Like? Making Documentaries About School
description: Overview | What core beliefs drive how we view and assess schools? How do students see their own school? In this lesson, students consider their views about school, then reflect on their education, pinpointing experiences related to hot topics in the current national conversation about education reform. They then make a documentary film that tells the story of their school and shows how it is responding to challenges great and small.

title: Asked & Answered | Olivier Zahm
description: In 1992 Olivier Zahm printed the first issue of Purple Prose, a Parisian literary art zine that over the years has evolved into Purple Fashion Magazine.As founder and editor of the biannual publication, Zahm has remained faithful to Purples mission to foster emerging artists, fashion insiders and sexual creativity. At 47, Zahm is unfazed by his reputation as a louche lady-killer and promotes alternative love lifestyles (translation: open relationships). Nor is he averse to playing against type as witnessed by his recent sharing (some would say oversharing) of his heartbreak over being dumped by the model Natacha Ramsay on on his unapologetically pervy blog, purple-diary. The Moment caught up with Zahm in his New York office to chew the fat about downtown New York culture, fashion, art and sex.

title: Lanvin: Polished Like a Stone
description: The Lanvin spring show was held this evening in a former transportation depot about 20 minutes from the center of Paris, but with Friday traffic and rain and other shows backing up, Lanvins start was delayed more than an hour. I went into the backstage, more like a bunker with long tables and mirrors, and Pat McGrath and her makeup artists were working on the models. It was 5:40 p.m. I said hello to Franca Sozzani, who was also killing time, and then I went in search of Alber Elbaz. Since there was a good sense of show panic, I got past the security guard at the dressing room entrance without any difficulty, and I heard Mr. Elbaz before I actually saw him.

The funny thing is, only humans could have made something this slipshod and nonsensical (yet grindingly obvious)  machines wouldnt know how to insult an audiences intelligence, or abuse its trust, this badly.

Was it for the purpose of revealing the oxymoronic qualities inherent to couture punkthat the heirs to master couturiers Cristobal Balenciaga and Pierre Balmain went safety pin head to head on the second day of Paris Fashion Week,Scorecard wonders? In any event, it was simply more of the superluxe slashed and trashed Bal-same by a different name from Christophe Decarnin  which left critics with the sneaking suspicion that they had been punkd.

title: Citi Counters Critic; Stock Surges
description: Michael Mayo, the analyst who has been a vocal critic of Citigroup, had hisbig meeting with the banks chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, on Friday. But his arguments may not have carried the day, according to several attendees.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Sorting Things Out
description: This Saturday was circled on the schedule by many college football fans at the beginning of the season, with Alabama against Florida and Oklahoma versus Texas looming as two of the years marquee games. But a funny thing happened in September. A few things, actually. Florida, while undefeated, has looked a little sluggish in the first few weeks of the post-Tim Tebow era; Texas appeared lethargic in losing to a seemingly unimposing U.C.L.A. team in Austin last week; and Stanford has developed into a top-10 team behind an explosive offense led by quarterback Andrew Luck. All that means that Stanford at Oregon has become perhaps the most intriguing game of the weekend, with the Cardinal traveling to the always raucous atmosphere of Autzen Stadium to try to prove that they belong in the top tier of the Pac-10. As for Florida, every team in college football wishes they could struggle as well as the Gators. Still, Alabama has been No. 1 since the seasons start and the return of Mark Ingram two weeks ago has made a terrific running game that much more formidable. These teams have been the class of the Southeastern Conference for several years and there is always a chance for an epic game when they play each other.

title: Shotgun Justice Served With a Strut
description: Justice isnt a word you often hear at concerts. At benefit shows, maybe, or at a Public Enemy or Yoko Ono performance. But that word has a depth of meaning that most musicians would probably like to skip altogether.

title: Hobbit Deal Close to Complete
description: The Timess Media Decoder blog reports that Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer are on the verge of an agreement that would allow the director Peter Jackson to begin shooting a two-part version of J. R. R. Tolkiens The Hobbit early next year. The studios have wrestled with their dual ownership of the project over the last year but a financial deal should be in place over the next several days, according to several people who have been involved in the bargaining. Still pending: a labor dispute that has led Mr. Jackson and the studios to say publicly that they would consider moving the films out of New Zealand. People involved with the films said Friday that they expected a resolution to the union dispute imminently. Read more on Media Decoder

title: One Mans Fascination With Miley, Real and Not

Hers a Queen, performed at Dance Theater Workshop in 2009, Mr. Medlyn took inspiration from Britney Spears. On Wednesday night he completed his self-described opus with Brave New Girl at the Chocolate Factory, spotlighting a mouthful: the fictional Hannah Montana and Miley Stewart and the real Miley Cyrus.

title: Life and Death, Stat
description: THOMAS HAZAZ wanted out. Lying on a gurney, his chest covered with heart sensors, Mr. Hazaz was trying to cajole doctors in the emergency room at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn to unplug him. In less than 24 hours, he needed to be in a tuxedo, walking his youngest daughter down the aisle in a Staten Island banquet hall. Mr. Hazaz, 52, a bartender at Embers, a steakhouse in Bay Ridge, kept saying that the pain in his elbows was nothing but overexertion from lifting heavy stuff at work. The professionals, though, suspected a heart attack.

title: Dad Lifts CBS Ratings
description: In its second outing on CBS, $#*! My Dad Says, the William Shatner comedy based on the popular Twitter feed, proved its strong premiere ratings were not an anomaly, as 10.4 million viewers tuned in to the sitcom on Thursday, according to Nielsens estimates. CBSs crime shows delivered the nights largest audiences, with CSI earning 13.3 million viewers at 9 p.m., and The Mentalist drawing 14.6 million at 10. The network also kicked off the night on a high note, attracting 13 million for The Big Bang Theory at 8, no doubt helping to increase the audience for Mr. Shatners new comedy at 8:30. $#*! My Dad Says outperformed all other programming in the 8 oclock hour, including Foxs Bones (9.6 million), ABCs disappointing My Generation (3.9 million) and NBCs comedies Community (4.5 million) and 30 Rock (5.7 million). ABC ranked second for the night, earning solid results for its medical dramas Greys Anatomy (12.2 million) and Private Practice (8 million). Fox was third and NBC fourth, struggling at 10 with The Apprentice (3.7 million).

title: Following Tradition With Three Solid Blows
description: A major part of the job for any music director of the New York Philharmonic is to tend to its traditions as the oldest symphony orchestra in America. And since Gustav Mahler held the job for a brief but formative period from 1909 until his death in 1911, the Philharmonics Mahler tradition is a special case, as Alan Gilbert, the current boss, seems well aware.

title: A Digital Update on the One-Man Band
description: AFTER some 120 logistically grueling, technologically challenging and emotionally exhilarating concerts on his Orchestrion Tour, the famed guitarist and budding robotics whiz Pat Metheny was still trying to explain in plain language just what he was up to with his latest and most unusual venture.

title: Big Hairy Feet, Now in 3-D?
description: So The Hobbit will be in 3-D. That is a measure of how much the movie world has changed in the last year or so. In the dimly remembered recesses of, oh, 2009, people involved with the two-movie version of the J. R. R. Tolkien book, then to be directed by Guillermo del Toro, insisted that 2-D screen technology was just right for a pair of movies that were viewed as being a little more intimate than their sweeping precursors in the Lord of the Rings trilogy. Then came Avatar, Alice in Wonderland, and even the much-maligned Clash of the Titans  one film after another proving that viewers would pay a premium for 3-D, as long as the underlying movie wasnt an utter bust.

title: Gesundheits as Chekhov and Vaudeville Collide
description: The Sneeze, the sketch from which a collection of eight stories and playlets by Chekhov takes its title, evokes classic silent comedy from the schools of Buster Keaton through to Mr. Bean. It involves Mr. and Mrs. Senior Government Official (Bradford Cover and Rachel Botchan) watching a performance of Tchaikovskys Swan Lake, with a low-level counterpart and his wife (Chris Mixon and Lee Stark) seated directly behind them. The offending outburst causes a ticklish pantomime of flying nasal debris, mortification, apology, insult, umbrage and political death, before it crescendos to cardiac arrest. The vignette earns laughs as physical comedy and as a swipe at a rigidly hierarchical society.

title: Letters to Answer, and Logs to Split
description: At Pete Seegers 90th birthday celebration last year at Madison Square Garden, Bruce Springsteen called him Americas granddad, but with a steely toughness that belies that grandfatherly facade. Now 91, he has just written a new song addressing the Gulf oil spill and, in July, released a new album, Tomorrows Children, on Appleseed Recordings.

title: Tech Deals Percolate, but Theres No M.&A. Boom
description: While there have been a number of notable technology deals recently, the sector is hardly experiencing a boom in mergers and acquisitions. The total value of technology deals in the third quarter fell 26 percent from second quarter. Still, the M.&A. market was stronger than in the depressed third quarter of 2009, when the economy was emerging from one of the worst recessions on record.

title: A Mortgage Promotion, in Detail
description: An advertisement for an adjustable-rate mortgage being offered by ING makes some questionable claims about how the rates will change over time.

title: In Mortgage Ad, Two Wrongs Dont Make a Right
description: One of the most important lessons of the mortgage collapse is that potential borrowers need clear explanations of exactly what kind of commitment they are making.

title: As the World Turned for Women in 1905
description: Esther is 35 and worries that shell never marry. Mrs. Van Buren worries that she cant have children. Mayme, a prostitute, claims not to worry about anything anymore but still holds out faint hope for true love.

title: Musharraf, Vowing Return, Announces New Party
description: LONDON  Pakistans former military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, used a meeting on Friday in one of Londons most historic political clubs to announce the creation of a new political party, the All Pakistan Muslim League, and to renew his pledge to return to Pakistan from a self-imposed exile here before national elections scheduled for 2013.

title: Sometimes a Little of This and Some More of That Add Up to a Lot
description: Seven years ago, when City Centers Fall for Dance festival was born, the idea of programming disparate companies in a single evening was new and bubbly. Now, depending on the show, the experience has flattened out, as if there were a seven-year itch. Effort is lauded above all else, and the last thing you expect is a glimpse into a fresh choreographic world.

title: No Mozart, but Plenty of Whimsy
description: Quiz for balletomanes: A pretty heroine is in love with an impoverished but handsome village lad. A wealthy, bumbling suitor arrives, and the heroines parents chase away their daughters charming love interest, obsequiously fawning over the wealthy prospect. After some amusingly depicted obstacles, true love naturally prevails, and the love-struck pair is happy ever after by the final pas de deux.

title: Sarkozy to Propose New Bond With Russia
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France plans to propose a new security and economic relationship between Europe and Russia when he meets with President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany this month in Deauville, senior French officials said Friday.

title: ING Directs Statement on Its Mortgage Advertising
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I take a close look at a mortgage solicitation from ING Direct that fell short, in my opinion, of the kind of disclosure that would make the terms crystal clear.

title: Not Exactly Your Top 40 Reunited
description: The Jazz Passengers wrapped up their first set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night with Reunited, a No. 1 hit for Peaches & Herb in 1979. Some liberties were taken, of course. The song, in its original form, is a lush disco ballad, sticky-sweet enough to spread on a biscuit. Here it began music-box prickly, with plucked violin and mallet-dampened vibraphone. The saxophonist Roy Nathanson recited a few thoughts about the passage of time and then sidled into the first verse:

title: Tom Hanks Uses Web to Plot the Future
description: When Tom Hanks imagines the future, you might think he sees a desk strewn with Oscars, Emmys and the scripts for a dozen more World War II projects. But the far-flung earth that Mr. Hanks will present in a new Internet-based animated series called Electric City will be a more complicated one and yet  not surprisingly, given its creator  an optimistic one.

title: A Musical Home With Three Sides
description: Chick Corea has adopted an array of instrumental formats over the years, from solo piano to full orchestra, occasionally plunging into projects like the Five Peace Band, a fusion extravaganza that traveled the globe last year. His most reliable vehicle, though, has been the acoustic trio. Its in this arrangement  piano, bass and drums  that Mr. Corea seems most at ease, free to dig furrows into a standard repertory or put novel twists on rhythm and form.

title: Just Jeff Daniels and His Guitar
description: THE actor Jeff Daniels has temporarily checked out of what he calls the ambition hotel.

title: Grantas List of Rising Literary Stars Spotlights Spanish-Language Authors
description: Through its periodic lists of the best young novelists, the British literary magazine Granta has built a reputation for spotting and promoting emerging talents long before they become widely known. A 1983 list of British writers included Martin Amis, Julian Barnes, Kasuo Ishiguro, William Boyd, Ian McEwan, Salman Rushdie and Graham Swift, while its similar inventory of American writers in 1996 drew attention to Sherman Alexie, Madison Smartt Bell, Edwidge Danticat, Jonathan Franzen and Lorrie Moore.

title: When the Star Wattage Is High but Movies Shine
description: IN the Hamptons, a certain amount of star wattage is endemic, but when the 18th Annual Hamptons International Film Festival starts on Thursday, the celebrity presence on the east end of Long Island will be even more concentrated than usual. Alec Baldwin, Isabella Rossellini, Bruce Weber, Joel and Ethan Coen, Julian Schnabel and many others are expected to attend the festival, which will include more than 100 films in a number of competitive and noncompetitive categories.

title: Waiting for the Show at Nina Ricci
description: Models spend a lot of time backstage, sometimes in white robes. They rehearse, even though the runways seldom vary. Our photographer Valerio Mezzanotti captured the wait at Nina Ricci on Thursday night, where the room was draped in pink silk. He also caught newcomer Lindsey Wixson.

title: Pelosi to Shake Money Trees for Democrats
description: For Republican candidates, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, is a favorite target these days  the San Francisco liberal and leader of the Democratic incumbents that the insurgent, resurgent G.O.P. challengers want to oust. But as vilified as she may be at times, Ms. Pelosi is planning an aggressive itinerary to raise money for individual Democratic candidates and for her party as whole in the closing weeks of the campaign.

title: The Right Kind of Disclosures for Mortgage Applicants
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I take a close look at an ING Direct mortgage promotion that turned up in the mailbox at Bucks headquarters in Brooklyn. Turns out the company broke one Federal Reserve rule related to adjustable rate mortgage disclosures and didnt meet my own common sense/raised eyebrow standard over all.

title: Leading a Singleton Gives Partner a Welcome Ruff
description: The Friday Swiss Teams at the Long Island Fall Regional in Smithtown, N.Y., eight days ago was won by the husband and wife Stephen Lucas and Lesley Decker Lucas of Woodbury, N.Y., and by Kelley Hwang and Glenn Robbins of Manhattan.

title: Tip of the Week: Getting the Most From a Macs Dictionary
description: To see the Dictionary program that comes with Mac OS X 10.5 and 10.6 display definitions, press the command key and the space bar and then type a word into the Spotlight search bar; you can also open the program from the Applications folder. But like its paper counterpart (the New Oxford American Dictionary), the Dictionary program does much more than word definitions, even without an Internet connection.

title: Recalling the Glory Days of Readers Digest
description: Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Marvelous Invention of Movie Make-Believe
description: What is a movie star? It may be more appropriate to phrase the question in the past tense, as an acknowledgment that the old breed is dying out and also as a valedictory tribute to one of its finest specimens. Because whatever the definition  a great performer; a larger-than-life personality; a sex symbol  the picture next to the dictionary entry might as well be of Tony Curtis in his prime, with his blue eyes, full lips and lush head of hair.

title: At Edge of Whitney, Touching the Void
description: As Stephen Petronio leaned out face-forward horizontally into space on Thursday afternoon, only his feet touching the edge of the roof at the Whitney Museum of American Art, the crowd below gave a stifled gasp. Mr. Petronio was about to begin his short and hair-raising re-enactment of Trisha Browns 1970 Man Walking Down the Side of a Building, and it was a scary, exhilarating sight.

title: Lanvin Says Take Your Pick; Dior Joins the Navy
description: Paris

title: Wuhl, Former On-Screen Sports Agent, Gets Sports Radio Show
description: Robert Wuhl, the comic actor who played a sports agent on HBOs Arliss, will be taking a real job in the business starting in January, when he will host a three-hour sports talk radio show for Westwood One on weekdays from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m.

title: Photos of Survival in an Emergency Room
description: Ashley Gilbertson has taken photographs in emergency rooms throughout the world, including in Iraq and Afghanistan. But what he saw during the week he spent in the Maimonides Medical Center emergency room in Brooklyn shocked him.

title: CNN Fires Sanchez After Critique of Stewart
description: Rick Sanchez, a daytime anchor at CNN, was fired on Friday, a day after telling a radio interviewer that Jon Stewart was a bigot and that everybody that runs CNN is a lot like Stewart.

title: Their Lotus Cant Take Root on a Yoga Mat
description: FOR yogis, few accessories are as ubiquitous as the yoga mat  that precious strip of padding that serves as a cushion, a territory marker and even a rolled-up status symbol, conveying ones membership in the yoga tribe.

title: Women of the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A.
description: About 200 women live at the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A. Some are there temporarily, while others have made it a permanent home. Four residents tell their stories.

title: At the Y, They Take Care of Each Other
description: VALERIE BERGER was nearly 60 but had never had her own place. She split her time between her mothers house and her boyfriends apartment, both in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Then her boyfriend died of a surgery-related infection at age 70, a few years after her mother did. Unable to afford much else, Ms. Berger moved in April 2009 into the Y.W.C.A. in Brooklyn, where she pays $625 a month  including utilities  for her 8-foot-by-12-foot room (a phone, with voicemail, costs $15 extra).

title: Two Weeks, and Two Canceled Shows
description: The second week of the fall television season brought two casualties: Foxs Lone Star and ABCs My Generation.

title: Syrian Actress Tests Boundaries Again
description: DAMASCUS, Syria

title: Soggy Questions About October Dates
description: NEWPORT, Wales  Ryder Cups have been played later than this one, but the early October dates in Wales were causing ample debate in the aftermath of a soggy opening day, in which not one match came close to completion.

title: Ana Meier and Daniel Creighton
description: WHEN she was a child, Ana Meier once announced to her family that she wanted to paint her bedroom pink, a radical idea in her household.

title: The Wedding of Ana Meier and Daniel Creighton
description: On Sept. 25, the couple were married at the home of her father, architect Richard Meier, in East Hampton, NY.

title: Tracking an Athletes Moves, Hollywood Style
description: Orthopedic surgeons at Massachusetts General Hospital are using motion-capture technology to try to improve athletes performance or prevent injuries.

title: House Forecast: As October Dawns, Novembers Math Still Strong for G.O.P.
description: Our House forecasting model continues to show Republicans as having about a two-in-three chance  67 percent  of taking over the House on Nov. 2, similar to the forecast in recent weeks.

title: Settlements Stymie U.S. Envoys Mideast Effort
description: JERUSALEM  The Obama administrations Middle East envoy left Jerusalem empty-handed on Friday after intensive efforts to save Palestinian-Israeli peace talks that have run aground on Israels decision to allow a freeze on West Bank Jewish settlement construction to expire.

title: For a Plus-Size Show, a Slimmer Backdrop
description: You cant resist the upbeat charms of Hairspray at Paper Mill Playhouse, where the cheerful musical about a big-haired girl with outsize dreams is being happily replicated on a somewhat smaller scale than the 2002 Broadway hit that ran for more than six years. Though the scenery is slimmed-down, this fast-paced crowd-pleaser packs every ounce of its original whirlwind appeal.

title: Jet-Lagged, but Eager to Shop
description: One of the glitzy, fine-dining restaurants that brought the flash of Las Vegas to a formerly bereft stretch of western Chelsea about five years ago, Morimoto still packs in a mix of celebrities, downtown creative types, tourists and international businesspeople. It has an eye-popping white-on-white dcor  including an illuminated wall made of 17,500 water bottles  and an over-the-top genre-busting menu from Masaharu Morimoto, one of the stars of Iron Chef America, on the Food Network. But the restaurant, on 10th Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets, also manages a casual ease, which on Tuesday drew in a regular customer indulging in the $120 omakase menu at the sushi bar; co-workers sharing cocktails and snacks in the subterranean lounge; and a neighbor entertaining his parents visiting from Fulda, a small town in Germany.

title: Ukraine: Court Gives President Some of Parliaments Power
description: President Viktor F. Yanukovichs control over the government grew on Friday when the constitutional court handed him some of Parliaments powers. The court overturned changes in the governments structure, adopted in 2004, that had split authority between the president and Parliament. Mr. Yanukovich, above, who took office this year, praised the decision, saying that he hoped to go even further by holding a referendum on a new Constitution. But his opponents said he had rigged the court and was trying to create an authoritarian system. Mr. Yanukovichs allies control Parliament, and he has a loyal prime minister. But if opposition parties make gains in new elections, it will be harder for them to block his agenda.

title: Excerpts From the Ethnic Press
description: Immigrant news organizations, like their mainstream cousins, have been closely tracking local political campaigns. In the following excerpts, El Diario La Prensa celebrates Francisco Moyas victory in the Democratic primary for a Queens Assembly seat, while a Pakistani Web site and the Polish daily Nowy Dziennik report on apathy and feelings of marginalization. KIRK SEMPLE

title: Russian Party Gains in Latvia Amid Economic Bust
description: RIGA, Latvia  When Latvians wrested their country from the Soviet Union two decades ago, their first thought, it seemed, was escape. Unable to physically uproot the country from its tiny plot next to Russia, they sought to integrate as deeply as possible with the West, eventually joining the European Union and NATO while spurning their former colonial masters and marginalizing the Russians who remained here.

title: Will TARP Turn  to Gold?
description: It wasnt fair, but it was necessary.  That comment about the Troubled Asset Relief Program, from Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner in April, seemed about the best that anyone would ever say of it. But with the program officially coming to an end on Sunday, some folks are pushing a different description: profitable.

title: For a Newsman and His Town, the End of an Era
description: Ogdensburg, N.Y.

title: My, for a Young Killer, Youre Cute as a Button
description: The evil-child movie has been with us at least as long as The Bad Seed (1956, gloriously funny) and Village of the Damned (1960, effectively chilling), and Case 39 adds little to the diminutive-demon genre. Radiating a distinctly retro vibe, this throwaway thriller from the German director Christian Alvart tosses a bone to Rene Zellweger, who chews it to a nub as Emily Jenkins, a harried social worker.

title: Burgers With Attitude
description: Smashburger, the Denver-based franchise that recently opened its second and third restaurants in New Jersey, cooks its burgers as the name suggests: squashing a hunk of ground Angus beef with a metal hand press while it is grilled and seared.

title: South Korea: Looking to Germany for Lessons on Reunification
description: Germany and South Korea agreed to set up an expert group to examine how the German reunification model might be applied to the Korean Peninsula, the German Interior Ministry said Friday. A memorandum of understanding signed by Christoph Bergner, Germanys deputy interior minister, and Kim Chun-sig, South Koreas deputy minister in charge of reunification affairs, said Seoul would get access to historic and government documents on Germanys 1990 reunification. We are willing to share our insight and experience gathered with regard to the resolution of the German question, the economic reconstruction of eastern Germany and the development of the new federal states, Mr. Bergner said.

title: A Bit of Vietnamese, a Lot of Thai
description: IT was 8-ish on a Saturday night, the crowd was spilling out the door of Bamboo Leaf, and my heart sank. We didnt have a reservation, but I had assumed Bradley Beach would be deserted after Labor Day.

title: Israeli Soul Food
description: Westchesters food scene has grown more diverse and interesting in recent years, and there is no need to travel to the city for most culinary fixes. But one exception has remained for much of the county: Middle Eastern street food.

title: Crowds Fault Police Actions in Stuttgart
description: BERLIN  Tens of thousands of protesters flooded the streets of Stuttgart in southwestern Germany on Friday chanting Shame on you, one day after the police used pepper spray, water cannons and tear gas to disperse crowds that had gathered to save centuries-old trees from being cut down, German news agencies reported.

title: Sprawling Menu and a Space to Match
description: VILLAGE Social Kitchen and Bar has opened in the space that was Woodys on Main, and before that Luna (and before that a Ford dealership, the spacious dimensions of which remain pretty much intact).

title: Michelle Martin and Justin Esgar
description: Michelle Hope Martin and Justin Taylor Esgar were married Saturday evening in East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald L. Androphy performed the ceremony at the East Meadow Jewish Center.

title: Rosanna Lam and R. Tom Boonyasai
description: Rosanna Lam and Rungtum Tom Boonyasai were married Saturday morning at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Stuart B. Chernoff, a minister of the Spiritual Humanist Church, officiated.

title: Lexi Dauber and Scott Rudolph
description: Lexi Dauber and Scott Evan Rudolph were married Saturday evening at Cedar Hill Golf and Country Club in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz officiated.

title: Lisa Troyano, Patrick Ascolese
description: Lisa Marie Troyano and Patrick Alan Ascolese were married Saturday in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Kris von Maluski, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Parish Church.

title: Jessie Podell, Ryan Pressman
description: Jessie Podell, a daughter of Adina Podell and Dan Podell of Caldwell, N.J., is to be married Sunday afternoon in Glen Ridge, N.J., to Ryan Pressman, a son of Ronni Pressman and Fred Pressman of Bloomfield, N.J. Rabbi Garry Loeb is to officiate at the Womens Club of Glen Ridge, with Cantor Joel Caplan taking part in the ceremony.

title: Purva Bedi and David Stoler
description: Purva Bedi and David Andrew Stoler are to be married Sunday at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan. Jerusha Klemperer, who was ordained by the Church of Spiritual Humanism, is to officiate. She will say some Jewish prayers, and Pandit Krishna Pratap Dixit, a Hindu priest, is to also take part in the ceremony.

title: Elena Stewart, Patrick Turevon
description: Elena Frances Stewart and First Lt. Patrick Veikko Turevon were married Saturday at St. Dominics Church in Oyster Bay, N.Y. The Rev. Gregory A. Schenden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Jordana Horn, Jon Gordon
description: Jordana Horn and Jon Andrew Gordon are to be married Sunday morning at Congregation Bnai Jeshurun in New York. Rabbi Michael S. Friedman is to perform the ceremony, with Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner taking part.

title: Michele Wiles, James McCullough
description: Michele Lee Wiles and James Renwick McCullough were married Saturday at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson, the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Brown and Gust Hookanson
description: Jennifer Lucile Brown and Gust Jeremy Hookanson were married Saturday at the Watermark, a bar and lounge in Asbury Park, N.J. The Rev. Jeffery T. Bassett, a minister of the Living Water Ministries, officiated.

title: Erika Hoops, Alexander Gorodetsky
description: Erika Elisabeth Hoops, the daughter of Maureen L. Hoops and Daniel J. Hoops of Dallas, was married Saturday morning to Alexander Gorodetsky, the son of Tatyana Gorodetsky and Leon Gorodetsky of New York. The Rev. William J. Bergen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Officials in Contador Case Proceed at Deliberate Pace
description: More than two months after Alberto Contador failed a drug test at the Tour de France, officials from the International Cycling Union are clearly taking their time to investigate the matter before determining whether Contador should be charged with an antidoping violation.

title: David Olsen and Leonard Flood
description: David Carlton Olsen and Leonard Joseph Flood were married Saturday at Christ Episcopal Church in Swansea, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Richard E. Bardusch performed the ceremony.

title: Lisa Leigh, Kurt Abrahamson
description: Elizabeth Leigh and Kurt Gunner Abrahamson were married Saturday in a house in Calistoga, Calif., rented for the occasion. William Ericson, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Daisy Sindelar, Grant Podelco
description: Daisy Sindelar and Grant Podelco were married Saturday afternoon at Blackwater Falls Lodge in Blackwater Falls State Park in Davis, W.Va. Murphy Birdsall, a minister with the Universal Brotherhood Movement and a maternal aunt of the bride, led the ceremony, which incorporated Slavic elements, including folk songs and proverbs.

title: Emily Schnure, Eric Bratten
description: Emily Joanne Schnure and Eric Douglas Bratten were married Friday evening at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. OConnor, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Howie and Clifford Dank
description: Elizabeth Wu Howie and Clifford Harris Dank were married Saturday at Chandler Hovey Park in Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. George Westerberg, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and Garrett R. Smith, a leader of Congregation Sar Shalom in Newton, Mass., took part.

title: Diana Benton, Jason Schechter
description: Diana Jarvis Benton and Jason Henry Schechter were married Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Jessica Zimmerman officiated.

title: Samantha Salvant, Richard Aviles
description: Samantha S. Salvant and Richard A. Aviles were married Saturday in Manhattan. The Rev. Jose Humphreys, a minister with the Evangelical Covenant Church, officiated at Turtle Pond in Central Park.

title: Lyssa Sorkin, Benjamin Jacobs
description: Dr. Lyssa Yve Sorkin and Dr. Benjamin Harrison Jacobs were married Saturday evening at Cold Spring Country Club in Huntington, N.Y. Cantor Martha T. Novick officiated.

title: Jessie Podell, Ryan Pressman
description: Jessie Podell, a daughter of Adina Podell and Dan Podell of Caldwell, N.J., is to be married Sunday afternoon in Glen Ridge, N.J., to Ryan Pressman, a son of Ronni Pressman and Fred Pressman of Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Leah Altman, Zack Smith
description: Leah Kate Altman, the daughter of Phyllis Kaplan Altman and Jeffrey N. Altman of New York, was married Saturday evening to Zack David Smith, a son of Maxine Smith and Gary Smith of Los Angeles. Rabbi Steven Z. Leder officiated at the Ojai Valley Inn and Spa in Ojai, Calif.

title: Danielle Rudich, Matthew Wosnitzer
description: Dr. Danielle Sylvie Rudich and Dr. Matthew Scott Wosnitzer are to be married Sunday at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi David J. Small is to officiate.

title: Jennifer Pan, Jared Chung
description: Jennifer Jie Pan, the daughter of Xiangping Liu and Youfang Pan of Carmel, Ind., is to be married Sunday evening to Jared Alexander Chung, the son of Eva Brun of New York and Robert Chung of Berkeley, Calif. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel is to officiate at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

title: Catherine Pullins, Scott Miles
description: Catherine McGuire Pullins and Scott Christopher Miles were married Saturday at the First Congregational Church on Nantucket in Massachusetts. The Rev. Dr. Gary W. Klingsporn, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Erin Reynolds, Daniel Kelsh
description: Erin Marie Reynolds and Daniel William Andrew Kelsh were married Saturday by the Rev. Michael F. Ford at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Monica in Manhattan.

title: Christie Gestal, Amy Gross
description: Christie Mary Gestal, a daughter of Jean N. Christie of Boynton Beach, Fla., and Kenneth L. Gestal of New Canaan, Conn., was joined in a commitment ceremony Saturday to Amy Leigh Gross, the daughter of Joan M. Gross and Alan D. Gross of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Lisa Dion, a work colleague of Ms. Gestals, led the couple in affirming their partnership at the Lodge and Spa at Cordillera, a resort in Edwards, Colo.

title: Tony Maida, Anthony Volpe
description: Tony Richard Maida and Anthony Frank Volpe were married Saturday at All Souls Church, Unitarian, in Washington. The Rev. Robert M. Hardies, the churchs senior minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Hayden Odell, Ryan Brown
description: Hayden Elizabeth Larson Odell, the daughter of Marcia L. Odell and Malcolm J. Odell Jr. of Washington, was married Saturday to Ryan Taylor Brown, the son of Shelley C. Brown and Steven L. Brown of Los Altos, Calif. The Rev. Michael O. Shirley performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass.

title: Shareen Powlett and Ainsley Bailey Jr.
description: Shareen Chauntel Powlett, a daughter of Amelia D. Powlett and Appleton A. Powlett of Orlando, Fla., was married Saturday to Ainsley Damine Bailey Jr., the son of Carol A. Johnson and Mr. Bailey Sr., both of Brooklyn. The Rev. Matthew U. McKie, a Pentecostal minister, officiated at a nondenominational Christian ceremony at the Helen Mills Event Space and Theater in Manhattan.

title: Antoinette Belson, Patrick Devers
description: Antoinette Danforth Belson, a daughter of Janer Danforth Belson and Charles V. Belson of Gates Mills, Ohio, was married there Saturday to Patrick William Devers, a son of Susan Beck Devers and Kevin P. Devers of South Euclid, Ohio. The brides mother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Chagrin Valley Hunt Club.

title: Marisa Katz, Adam Bellack
description: Marisa Sara Katz and Adam Walter Bellack were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Ari J. Goldstein at Historic London Town and Gardens, a museum and park in Edgewater, Md.

title: Ellison Dial, Brian Suthoff
description: Corinne Ellison Dial and Brian Joseph Suthoff were married Saturday by Canon Robert Gambrell Riegel at St. Timothys Episcopal Church in Columbia, S.C.

title: Kate Hammond, Martin Minkowicz
description: Kate E. Hammond, a daughter of Patricia M. Hammond and Robert E. Hammond of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to Martin B. Minkowicz, the son of Grazyna Minkowicz and Bogdan Minkowicz of Nysa, Poland. The Rev. William J. Rueger, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Lauren Gaffney, John Lucarelli
description: Lauren Anne Gaffney and John Anthony Lucarelli were married Saturday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. OConnor, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Stuart E. Clark, a minister of the Reformed Church of America, taking part.

title: Ashley Donnenfeld, Christopher Shackelton
description: Ashley Dawn Donnenfeld and Christopher Scott Shackelton were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Richard H. Berman officiated.

title: Bank of America to Freeze Foreclosure Cases
description: Bank of America, the countrys largest mortgage lender by assets, said on Friday that it was reviewing documents in all foreclosure cases now in court to evaluate if there were errors.

title: Frosty Harvests, a Season in Reverse
description: Meriden, Conn.

title: CNN Fires Rick Sanchez for Remarks in Interview
description: Rick Sanchez, a daytime anchor at CNN, was fired on Friday, a day after telling a radio interviewer that Jon Stewart was a bigot and that everybody that runs CNN is a lot like Stewart.

title: Joblessness, in Theory and in Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paloma Gutirrez, Esa Espinoza-Lucas
description: Paloma Liv Gutirrez and Esa Jaret Espinoza-Lucas were married Saturday in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Rachel Thompson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Rowsley Estate, an event space.

title: Priscilla Alexandre, D. R. Dwyer
description: Priscilla Hill Alexandre, the daughter of Priscilla H. Alexandre of Bernardsville, N.J., and DeWitt L. Alexandre Jr. of Bedminster, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Denis Reed Dwyer, the son of Judy R. Dwyer and Denis J. Dwyer of Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Mathew Fenlon, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Lukes Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J.

title: World War II Memories, and an Instant Connection
description: Just before Benjamin Kleins open-heart surgery, his surgeon told him not to be afraid. Mr. Klein, who is 90, scoffed.

title: Oregon Turns Practice Into Nonstop Sprint With Precision as Goal
description: EUGENE, Ore.  As Oregon began pulling away from Tennessee in the middle of the third quarter last month, a Volunteers defensive end approached Ducks center Jordan Holmes with a plea.

title: After Paladinos Claim Against Cuomo, a Father-to-Daughters Talk
description: Andrew M. Cuomo said Friday that he could deal with the unsubstantiated  and, later, clumsily retracted  claims made by his rival in the race for governor, Carl P. Paladino, that Mr. Cuomo had been unfaithful to his wife.

title: Judge Delays Detainees Trial Over Issue of Witness
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has postponed the first civilian trial of a former detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, until Wednesday.

title: California Tightens Oversight of CT Scans
description: Californias governor has signed tough new legislation tightening oversight of diagnostic CT scans, largely in response to the overdosing of hundreds of patients who underwent brain scans for stroke in 2008 and 2009.

title: California Reduces Its Penalty for Marijuana
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A month before California voters decide the fate of a ballot initiative that would legalize marijuana, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has signed a bill that essentially puts those caught possessing small amounts of the drug on the same level as those caught speeding on the freeway.

title: Official to Face Hearing Over Blog Attacks
description: An assistant attorney general in Michigan has taken a personal leave of absence and may be disciplined for his online attacks on a gay campus leader at the University of Michigan.

title: Seeking Authenticity, Neapolitan Style
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, N.Y.

title: Atlanta Hats? Seattle Socks? Macys Goes Local
description: ATLANTA  Long before it was renamed Macys, the department store of choice here was Richs. Opening just after the Civil War, it drew generations of Atlantans with its coconut cake and the Pink Pig, a Christmastime childrens train.

title: Mexico Seeks to Unify Police to Fight Drugs
description: SANTIAGO, Mexico  The Mexican government is preparing a plan to radically alter the nations police forces, hoping not only to instill a trust the public has never had in them but also to choke off a critical source of manpower for organized crime.

title: Deal Near for Hobbit Films in 3-D
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hobbit is almost out of movie jail.

title: Giants Already Thin Defense Loses Kiwanuka Indefinitely
description: The discovery that Mathias Kiwanuka has a bulging disk in his neck leaves an already depleted Giants defense without its most dangerous and versatile weapon.

title: A Tribute to the Pride of Hofstra University
description: Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Excerpts From the Tea Party Canon
description: The following are excerpts of books that have been influential in the Tea Party movement.

title: The Repercussions of an Empty Wallet
description: They have Crips and Bloods in Kansas City?

title: Chandler, a Swingman, Remains a Constant on a Knicks Team That Is Always Evolving
description: MILAN  They traded his mentors and his friends, the veterans who guided him and the pranksters who kept him laughing. For two straight years, they traded nearly everyone, until one day Wilson Chandler looked up and found a roster of near strangers staring back at him, a dizzy survivor of The Great Knicks Purge.

title: Changes on Reverse Mortgages Will Alter Fee Structure
description: The already complex calculus on reverse mortgages is about to change.

title: Movement of the Moment Looks to Long-Ago Texts
description: The Tea Party is a thoroughly modern movement, organizing on Twitter and Facebook to become the most dynamic force of the midterm elections.

title: Mullin Appreciates Walshs Work
description: MILAN  If Chris Mullin ever becomes a Knicks executive, as has long been speculated, he will surely be thrilled with the roster he inherits.

title: A Show About Iraqi Refugees, to an Audience That Can Relate
description: Tholfikar Altaie, a 28-year-old Iraqi refugee who lives with his family in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, does not always know how to begin explaining to friends in New York the life he left behind in Baghdad. Their curiosity is as vast as the gaps in their knowledge.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Legal Debate Swirls Over Charges in a Students Suicide
description: Dozens of Rutgers University students wore black on Friday to remember Tyler Clementi, a freshman who killed himself after his roommate, according to prosecutors, secretly streamed over the Internet his intimate encounter with another man.

title: The Political Wild Card
description: WILMINGTON  Before she was a Tea Party cause clbre, liberal laughingstock and perhaps the embodiment of a can-you-top-this-for-bizarre political season, Christine ODonnell grew up in a Brady Bunch household of six kids (three Democrats, three Republicans), two parents (one of each) and an appreciation for the dramatic, the eccentric and the media spotlight.

title: Saturday: Producer of Hits
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  We get only one themeless crossword this week, and its a fun one by Barry C. Silk. I found it easier than average for this constructor but with plenty of terrific answers.

title: Lottery Numbers
Too Funny for Words
description: Washington

title: Cuomo Way Ahead of Paladino in Cash, for Now
description: Andrew M. Cuomo will enter the final month of the race for governor of New York with $19 million on hand, according to figures his campaign released on Friday night, far more than the $209,406 his Republican opponent, Carl P. Paladino, reported having.

title: From Picassos to Sarcophagi, Guided by Phone Apps
description: Walk into a crowded museum, and what do you see? People with cameras or cellphones snapping pictures of people looking at objects. The artwork, document or fossil is a tourist site; the photograph is our souvenir. And the looking  for which museums were created  becomes a memory before it has even begun.

title: Judge Backs 2004 Arrest of Protesters
description: A federal judge has upheld the arrest of two protesters who refused to leave a sidewalk across from Madison Square Garden during the Republican National Convention in 2004.

title: Wrights Recovery Has an Air of Whiff
description: After a years sabbatical, David Wrights power numbers have returned to him like an old lost cat. His home runs and runs batted in are back to normal levels after a season in which he managed a career-low 10 home runs. His total bases have not lagged far behind.

title: The Campaign Disconnect
description: One in five American kids was living in poverty in 2009. Across the country, once solidly middle-class families are lining up at food pantries and soup kitchens for groceries or a hot meal. In New York City, a startling indicator of the continuing economic stress is the rise in the number of homes that dont have kitchens.

title: White House Ponders Post-Election Outlook
description: WASHINGTON  Now that President Obama has put the drama of Rahm Emanuels departure as chief of staff behind him, his White House is preparing for a very different relationship with Congress after the midterm elections, when Republicans are expected to gain strength and more top advisers are likely to call it quits.

title: With Another $1 Million Donation, Murdoch Expands His Political Sphere
description: Rupert Murdochs News Corporation is playing a larger and more directly partisan role in this years elections than it is known to have played in any previous American campaign.

title: The Terrible Election Race Race
description: Which state is having the most appalling campaign season?

title: Whats Dumb, Really?
description: Big-city liberals and their blogging buddies love to paint Tea Partiers as yokels with incoherent candidates and language-mauling signs. (Some have even dubbed their misspellings and grammatical gaffes Teabonics.) On some level, this may be true. But there is also a certain hypocrisy to these taunts.

title: New Leadership for Mets Seems Near
description: After the Mets agonized for weeks about whether to retain their manager and general manager, word leaked Friday that Jerry Manuel would not be asked back as manager and that Omar Minaya would lose his role as the top baseball decision-maker, as has been expected.

title: Mr. Cuomos Record
description: New Yorkers elected Andrew Cuomo as the state attorney general in 2006 by a large margin, but even then they were not certain what they were getting.

title: Strikeouts (and Questions) Are on the Rise
description: David Wright, the Mets main run producer, has been striking out at an alarming rate.

title: In California Bid, Whitman Spends Record but Struggles
description: LOS ANGELES  Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor in California, passed a milestone the other day, investing $119 million of her own money into her campaign, breaking a record held by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York.

title: All Politics Is Local
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Replay: Oct. 1
description: A look at the day in sports, from practice for the Commonwealth Games to the waterlogged opening day of the Ryder Cup golf tournament.

title: Religion and Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Maher Airs More Comments by ODonnell
description: Week Three of the Christine ODonnell comic hostage crisis: As promised, Bill Maher pressed on with his Friday night embarrassment-by-installment campaign. Hes trying, and failing so far, to goad Delawares Republican/Tea Party candidate for Senate into appearing on his current HBO show, Real Time, by airing wacky comments from her appearances on his old ABC show, Politically Incorrect.

title: Yankees Are Hoping for Clarity With Solid Pitching
description: BOSTON  A few Yankees were sitting on a couch in the visiting clubhouse at Fenway Park Friday afternoon when a voice from the television started predicting their downfall. What happens if C. C. Sabathia stumbles in Game 1 of the playoffs? Or if the Yankees dont win their division? Watch out for the Twins. Forget about Title No. 28. On it went.

title: Primary Day Problems in New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Closer Look at Rift Between Humanists Reveals Deeper Divisions
description: AMHERST, N.Y.  You can tell something about a man by what he names his dog. At Paul Kurtzs house, I was greeted in his driveway by a pug puppy named John Dewey. The dogs predecessors, I learned, included Voltaire and Bentham.

title: Making Oil Drilling Safer: A View From the Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: An Israeli Speech at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Reading the Labels on Food Before Eating It
description: To the Editor:

title: Back to the Past
description: President Obamas call for sweeping changes in the space program got mugged by lobbyists and pork-minded legislators. An authorization bill for NASA  the National Aeronautics and Space Administration  that cleared Congress will leave the agency mired in past technologies.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: G.E.s Latest Maneuver
description: After decades of legal maneuvering, the General Electric Company finally agreed in 2006 to clean up the industrial pollutants it dumped in the Hudson River from the 1940s to the 70s. The consent decree with the Environmental Protection Agency required the company to dredge the river free of toxic sediment.

title: Events in Connecticut
