description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Bloggingheads: Talk to the Taliban?
description: Steven Walt, left, of Harvard University and Peter Bergen of the New America Foundation debate negotiating with the Taliban.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,294 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Louisiana: Admiral Ends Role
description: Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral leading the federal response to the BP oil spill, stepped down as planned on Friday, transferring oversight duties to Rear Adm. Paul Zukunft. Admiral Allen, left, has been a familiar face on television and a target of criticism and praise for the federal governments actions. He made significant changes in the response command structure, a reorganization that was broadly welcomed by residents and local officials. At a time when he could have enjoyed a well-deserved retirement from the United States Coast Guard, Admiral Allen stepped up to the plate and served his country when his skills and experience were urgently needed, President Obama said in a statement.

title: The Torturous Trials of the Idle Juror
description: The rocky shores of a cold lake. Soot-smudged medieval faces, twisted into grimaces. And then, from yonder trees, a desperate-looking villager being shoved to waters edge, where he is bound at hand and foot and thrown in the water.

title: Waiting for Superman and the Education Debate
description: Take along a handkerchief if you plan to see the new education documentary Waiting for Superman. Steve Barr, a tough-minded charter school developer, told me on Friday that he had already seen the film four times and still cant get through it without sobbing.

title: Joseph Sobran, Writer Whom Buckley Mentored, Dies at 64
description: Joseph Sobran, a hard-hitting conservative writer and moralist whose outspoken antipathy to Israel and what he saw as the undue influence of a Jewish lobby on American foreign policy led to his removal as a senior editor of National Review in 1993, died on Thursday in Fairfax, Va. He was 64 and lived in Burke, Va.

title: With Victory, Zenyatta Would Carry Perfect Mark Into Breeders Cup
description: Last year at this time, Rachel Alexandra and Zenyatta stood atop the thoroughbred racing world and had penetrated the consciousness of casual sports fans. Rachel Alexandra was undefeated in eight races, had beaten the boys three times and had graced the pages of Vogue.

title: Pact Ends California Budget Impasse
description: SACRAMENTO  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and top lawmakers agreed to a compromise to close a $19.1 billion deficit and give California a budget, ending the states record three-month impasse with a vote expected next week on the spending plan, according to legislative leaders.

title: Stephen J. Cannell, Prolific TV Writer, Dies at 69
description: Stephen J. Cannell, one of televisions most prolific writers and series creators, whose work encompassed the The Rockford Files and Wiseguy to The A-Team and The Greatest American Hero, died Thursday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 69.

title: Nonprofit Group Wins Pepsi Contest
description: A nonprofit group that complained that Pepsi had allowed organizations with political agendas to participate in its online giving contest, Pepsi Refresh, won one of the two $250,000 prizes. The group, Arms Wide Open Childhood Cancer Foundation, raises money for alternative therapies and treatments for children with neuroblastoma. The group contended that 16 contestant-groups that were members of the Progressive Slate were political groups tied to the Democratic party and thus violated contest rules. Pepsi disagreed, saying the groups were not advocating for a particular candidate or issue. Eight of those groups won $50,000 prizes.

title: Satyam Says It Received Notice From S.E.C.
description: Satyam Computer Services, which is embroiled in Indias biggest corporate fraud investigation, disclosed that it received a so-called Wells Notice from the United States Securities and Exchange Commission in September 2009. The disclosure indicated that the agencys enforcement division would recommend the filing of a civil suit against Satyam related to financial irregularities by the companys chairman earlier in 2009. The S.E.C. has not yet decided whether to file a suit, Satyam said.

title: Dozens Die in Indonesian Train Crash
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  At least 36 people were killed and dozens severely injured in a high speed collision between two intercity trains in Indonesias Central Java province early Saturday. The cause was likely human error, officials said.

title: Barry Who? Giants on the Verge of a Division Title
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Using young pitching, a breakout catcher and a lineup peppered with veteran castoffs, the San Francisco Giants have put themselves on the doorstep of winning the National League West, needing just one victory over the weekend to clinch the division. And for the first time since George Bush  the first one  was president, they have done it without Barry Bonds.

title: Examining Mantles Running Play From 1960
description: After writing about the discovery of a pristine kinescope of Game 7 of the 1960 World Series between the Yankees and the Pirates in Bing Crosbys old wine cellar, Richard Sandomir followed up Friday with an analysis of a critical base-running play in the games ninth inning.

title: Haider Ackermann: Broken Hearts
description: Even if there had been no Love Me Tender at Haider Ackermanns superb show Saturday morning, the clothes would have still delivered a rare emotional charge. The collection, paced slowly, opened with black motorcycle leather reduced to halters and vests, and a pair of black suede trousers, low and tight, with a billowy silk fold at the waist band, as though the lining had been pulled.

title: Being a Rex Ryan Guy.  Trevor Pryce Explains.
description: Why do players love to play for Rex Ryan?

title: G.M. Said to Scale Back I.P.O. Expectations
description: General Motors has reduced the expected size of its initial public offering from $12 billion to $8 billion, as the automaker faces difficult market conditions, The Financial Times reported.

title: For Porsche, Taking Delivery at the Factory Is an Event
description: For those new-car buyers inclined to travel and to undertake a bit of adventure, the option of a European delivery makes sense  and might even save a bit of money.

title: Trailing Early, Europe Seizes the Momentum
description: NEWPORT, Wales  The Ryder Cup began producing winners and losers on Saturday, and with the backlog of matches from Fridays rain-interrupted session, there was a surplus of both at Celtic Manor Resort.

title: Preemptive Unilateral Disarmament
description: So, why did Tim Geithner feel the need to declare,

title: Why Credit Cards?
description: In my Times column this week, I wrote about what I consider a breakthrough: the Square reader, which snaps into a smartphone or iPod Touch or iPad and lets you take credit-card payments. Yes, you, a non-corporate individual.

title: How The Other Half Thinks
description: Ezra Klein has written in, asking for a post laying out the difference between the more or less Keynesian model Brad DeLong and I work with and the models others have been using  and how their predictions differ. Its a good request, although the truth is that the other side in this debate doesnt necessarily agree on a single model, or even use models at all. Still, I think it is possible to describe the general views of the other guys  and to see how off their predictions have been.

title: Model-Morphosis | Lanvin
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Martha Streck from Women Model Management before (right) and after (left) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar right to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Urban Forager | Fungus on the Lawn? Lets Eat!
description: At the recent annual foray of the Northeast Mycological Federation near New Paltz, N.Y., some amateur mycologists expressed surprise when they learned that we had great mushrooms of our own in New York City.

title: Quick-Change Artist | Melodie Monrose
description: The model Melodie Monrose of Wilhelmina Model Management gets reinvented five times.

title: Now Screening | Lanvin
description: The Spring/Summer 2011 collection from Lanvin at Paris Fashion Week.

title: A Bridge Goes Pink for Breast Cancer Awareness
description: When Chris Bonannos sister learned she had breast cancer two years ago, he was desperate to do something to help.

title: Model-Morphosis | Viktor & Rolf
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Irina Kulikova from IMG Model Management before (top) and after (bottom) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar up to reveal the full transformation.)

title: The Saturday Word: Rally Back
description: Activists are gathering on the Washington Mall today for a rally they hope will provide an antidote to several conservative, Tea Party-inspired, demonstrations held in that same spot, including one organized by Glenn Beck in August.

title: Struggling Woods Sends Shivers Rippling Through a Sports Universe
description: In 1993, the basketball world gasped when Michael Jordan retired so he could try his hand at baseball. Suddenly, the sport that he elevated to new heights had to find a new icon and marketing engine. The replacement, it turned out, was Jordan himself, who returned to the N.B.A. two years later.

title: Split Decisions
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  We havent seen a George Bredehorn Split Decisions puzzle in a while. If youre new to these, read the instructions carefully. If the going is slow, take a break and come back to it later. Its an acquired skill, but its one that helps with solving crosswords as well. Speed solvers often talk about how they get at least as much information from the letters already in the grid as they do from the clues.

title: Photos of the Moment | Maison Martin Margiela
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Catiere.

title: Palestinian Leaders Urge End to Talks With Israel
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian leadership said Saturday that four-week-old direct talks with Israel should be suspended if Jewish settlement construction resumed in the West Bank. It called on the international community to pressure Israel to stop the building but withheld a final decision on the talks until an Arab League meeting on Friday.

title: U.S. Leading in Clubhouse but Trailing on the Course
description: NEWPORT, Wales  At its best, the Ryder Cup can build like a symphony, with complex themes and interdependent rhythms that unfold over the course of three days, a crescendo toward the 12 singles matches, always played  until maybe this rainy week  on Sunday.

title: A Stark Change of Scenery Re-energizes a Top Recruit
description: EL RENO, Okla.  In Nurideen Lindseys West Philadelphia neighborhood, he walked past the haunting reminders of violence every day. Teddy bears, candles and murals etched into sidewalks marked the sites of young lives lost.

title: Claims to BP Fund Attract Scrutiny
description: Kenneth R. Feinberg spent part of his summer barnstorming towns near the Gulf of Mexico, urging people who felt they had suffered financial hardship because of the oil spill to apply for a share of the $20 billion BP fund he was overseeing. The point of the fund was to pay claims rather than litigate them in court.

title: House Majority Still Uncertain, Republicans Say
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans carry substantial advantages as they move into the final month of the fall campaign, but the resilience of vulnerable Democrats is complicating Republican efforts to lock down enough seats to capture the House and take control of the unsettled electoral battleground.

title: Vick Is the Talk of McNabbs Town
description: PHILADELPHIA  The long, winding corridor leading to the Eagles locker room features the sort of dcor professional sports franchises currently favor: glossy action photographs, framed newspaper clippings, heavy plaques and awards extolling the confetti-dotted moments in team history.

title: Postscript to Crosbys Wine Cellar Treasure
description: The discovery of a copy of the broadcast of Game 7 of the 1960 World Series in Bing Crosbys former wine cellar led some readers to raise an interesting question: if Major League Baseball owns the copyright to World Series broadcasts, why did it have to pay the Crosby estate for the rights to televise the game on the MLB Network in December and release a DVD?

title: Scorecard | Lanvin Wins!
description: Come away, come away! John Gallianos Bali sky-Hai costume drama on the third day of Paris Fashion Week had Scorecard flashing back to Lincoln Center  though not to the minimalist whiteout of a few weeks ago, but a bit further back. When it comes to a romantic wardrobe for contemporary power dressing, however, Alber Elbazsmultivalent play on the complex theater of the female persona had critics thinking there are  thankfully  quite a few things you can name that aint anything like a dame.

title: Supreme Court Term Offers Hot Issues and Future Hints
description: WASHINGTON  The new Supreme Court term, which begins Monday, includes cases on some of the most contested issues of the day, including protests at military funerals, illegal immigration, support for religious schools, violent video games, DNA evidence and prosecutorial misconduct.

title: Brazilian Leaders Protge Likely to Prevail in Election
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Though Dilma Rousseff is a political novice and lacks the charisma of her former boss, President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, voters appear likely to make her the first woman to be president of Brazil in Sundays election.

title: Injury Shouldnt Hurt M.V.P. Bid
description: The idea that Josh Hamiltons injury should keep him from winning the American League Most Valuable Player award ignores powerful precedents.

title: Are Giants Ready to Follow a Leader?
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Inside the Giants practice facility, there is a linebacker so brazen he once walked into an offensive team meeting to criticize them and became so fiery his teammates could barely understand him when he yelled at them during practices. His name is Jessie Armstead.

title: Outgrowing Dream, Keller Fulfills Vision
description: At a wine bar last month in Lower Manhattan, Jets tight end Dustin Keller opted for the food sampler. Variety had won again.

title: Bin Laden Resurfaces in Recordings
description: It was an odd call for compassion from a terrorist who has proudly claimed responsibility for mass murder and who Western intelligence agencies say is still active in plotting terrorist attacks.

title: Against Alabama, Pressure Is on Quarterbacks
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  One play in Januarys national championship game between Alabama and Texas that should have caught the eye of Florida quarterback John Brantley, who was sure to watch film this week to get ready to play the top-ranked Crimson Tide on Saturday night.

title: Sniffing .300, Hitters Hunker Down on Last Chances
description: Before his last plate appearance of the 2007 season, with the postseason looming and his catchers body disintegrating like a 72 Impala, Victor Martinez came to the plate and noticed the scoreboard taunting him.

title: Premier Works to Build Broader Coalition in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki reached across sectarian lines on Saturday to appeal to Sunnis to broaden support for his re-election bid, even as a rival coalition representing most Sunnis declared that it would not accept his nomination and refused to join a coalition government led by him.

title: The Shot That Carried All the Way to the Pyrenees
description: From his home run on Oct. 3, 1951, to his death on Aug. 16 at age 86, Bobby Thomson lived 21,502 days and, in that time, heard as many stories of where people were when he won the National League pennant for the New York Giants against the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds. He enjoyed them. He came to know through them that he had struck at just the right moment, that a confluence of technology, geography, history and the particulars of a game had made his homer historic. Though maddeningly diffident, he came to understand that like Neil Armstrong and Lee Harvey Oswald, he had provided a collective experience.

title: Company Stops Insuring Titles in Chase Foreclosures
description: A major title insurance company has stopped insuring homes foreclosed by JPMorgan Chase, another sign that the controversy over the legal practices of the big lenders is starting to influence the housing market.

title: Happy Leading Cubs, if Only for Now
description: The modest office at Wrigley Field does not look lived in, does not bear the personal stamp of its occupant, whose stay might be temporary. But it is a comfortable upgrade from the cramped quarters he shared with six fellow coaches down the hall.

title: Liberal Groups Rally, Challenging Tea Party
description: WASHINGTON  Tens of thousands of union members, environmentalists and peace activists rallied at the Lincoln Memorial on Saturday, seeking to carry on the message of jobs and justice that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. trumpeted at a rally at the same site 47 years ago.

title: Michigan States Dantonio Is Hospitalized With Blood Clot
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio has been hospitalized with a blood clot and will miss Saturdays game with No. 9 Wisconsin.

title: U.S. Drone Attacks Kill 17 Militants in Pakistan
description: Two attacks by United States drones killed 17 militants and wounded three in northern Pakistan on Saturday, a Pakistani intelligence official said, after recent NATO helicopter strikes raised tensions with Pakistan, a country that is crucial to Washingtons war effort in Afghanistan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Very Useful Idiocy of Christine ODonnell
description: ALL it took was some 30,000 Republican primary voters in a tiny state to turn Christine ODonnell into the brightest all-American media meteor since Balloon Boy. For embattled liberals, not to mention the axis of Comedy Central, Saturday Night Live and Bill Maher, shes been pure comic gold for weeks: a bottomless trove of baldfaced lies, radical views and sheer wackiness. True, other American politicians have dismissed evolution as a myth. Some may even have denied joining a coven. But history will always remember her for taking a fearless stand against masturbation, the one national pastime with more fans than baseball.

title: From Avatar Playbook, Athletes Use 3-D Imaging
description: In the endless quest for athletic advantage, a handful of major league baseball teams are engaged in an elaborate, largely clandestine race to master an advanced imaging technology that some baseball officials think could influence the way athletes of all ages train, perform and recover from injuries.

title: Third Party Rising
description: A friend in the U.S. military sent me an e-mail last week with a quote from the historian Lewis Mumfords book, The Condition of Man, about the development of civilization. Mumford was describing Romes decline: Everyone aimed at security: no one accepted responsibility. What was plainly lacking, long before the barbarian invasions had done their work, long before economic dislocations became serious, was an inner go. Romes life was now an imitation of life: a mere holding on. Security was the watchword  as if life knew any other stability than through constant change, or any form of security except through a constant willingness to take risks.

title: At Risk From the Womb
description: Some people think were shaped primarily by genes. Others believe that the environment we grow up in is most important. But now evidence is mounting that a third factor is also critical: our uterine environment before were even born.

title: On the Foreclosure Front
description: The housing mess got a lot messier last week as JPMorgan Chase halted 56,000 foreclosures amid doubts that it had correctly followed laws on the foreclosure process. The announcement came soon after GMAC Mortgage suspended an undisclosed number of foreclosures to gain time to review its legal procedures. There may be more suspensions to come.

title: Diplomatic Knicks, Settled in Milan, Get Ready to Play
description: MILAN  After 24 hours in Italy, Patrick Ewing Jr. sent up an electronic flare.

title: Photos of the Moment | Lanvin
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Found in Translation
description: AS the author of Las Horas, Die Stunden and De Uren  ostensibly the Spanish, German and Dutch translations of my book The Hours," but actually unique works in their own right  Ive come to understand that all literature is a product of translation. That is, translation is not merely a job assigned to a translator expert in a foreign language, but a long, complex and even profound series of transformations that involve the writer and reader as well. Translation as a human act is, like so many human acts, a far more complicated proposition than it may initially seem to be.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 3
description: Sundays political talk shows come with a midterm twist, featuring a debate between Senate candidates in Kentucky and plenty of election chatter.

title: Side Effects May Include Lawsuits
description: FOR decades, antipsychotic drugs were a niche product. Today, theyre the top-selling class of pharmaceuticals in America, generating annual revenue of about $14.6 billion and surpassing sales of even blockbusters like heart-protective statins.

title: Mini to Take On Ford Fiesta in World Rally
description: PARIS  Almost lost in the hoopla around the Mini brands introduction of two oh-so-cute electric scooters at the Paris Motor Show on Thursday was the introduction of the hairy-chested, meat-eating Mini WRC Concept rally car.

title: Mark Zuckerbergs Most Valuable Friend
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.

title: Lotus CityCar: Lost in the Paris Hoopla
description: PARIS  Much was made at the Paris Motor Shows press days last week of the five new models coming in the next five years from Lotus, the heretofore diminutive British carmaker. But lost in all the hoopla around the mass introductions, there was, in fact, a sixth Lotus model on display: The CityCar Concept.

title: Count on Sequels to TARP
description: THE government is pulling a sheet over TARP, the Troubled Asset Relief Program created during the panic of 2008 to bail out the nations financial institutions. With the programs expiration on Sunday, we can expect to hear lots of claims from the folks at the Treasury that it was a great success.

title: As Games Begin, India Hopes to Save Its Pride
description: NEW DELHI  When India won its bid for the 2010 Commonwealth Games seven years ago, the event instantly became an emblem of national prestige. But as the country prepares to open the games on Sunday evening, an opportunity to burnish its global image has instead become a national embarrassment.

title: Iran Says It Arrested Computer Worm Suspects
description: TEHRAN  Iran has arrested an unspecified number of nuclear spies in connection with a damaging worm that has infected computers in its nuclear program, the intelligence minister, Heydar Moslehi, said Saturday.

title: British Nukes vs. British Troops
description: The pledge by Britains coalition government to drastically slash spending is bad economics and bad public policy. Budget tightening is needed, but not this much, this fast or this way. The cuts to be announced this month will put recovery at risk, unfairly squeeze poorer Britons, and make it hard for government departments to work. That includes defense  targeted for a 10 to 20 percent reduction over the next five years.

title: Mr. Bloomberg, Mr. Murdoch, Mr. Colbert
description: It is too late to make a difference this year, but Congress, or at least one subcommittee, finally heard a thoughtful discussion about immigration. Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York and Rupert Murdoch, head of the News Corporation  both billionaires  told the immigration subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee that rational and well-regulated immigration is an economic necessity.

title: Playing With Fire
description: Rearing a child is already a journey through self-doubt and guilt, and now here comes Gever Tulley to say were doing it wrong, and that what we really need to do is hand our young ones power tools and let them lick nine-volt batteries.

title: Does Your Team Have the Four Essential Types?
description: This interview with Paul Maritz,  , president and C.E.O. of the software firm VMware,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Games India Isnt Ready to Play
description: Mashobra, India

title: College Advice I Wish Id Received
description: To the Editor:

title: Online Surveillance
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Service in Boroughs
description: To the Editor:

title: Efficient, Not Sustainable
description: To the Editor:

title: Trimming Government
description: To the Editor:

title: The Survival of the Safest
description: CORPORATE managers struggling to preserve their companies and protect their core employees have inadvertently contributed to a vicious cycle of rising unemployment and plummeting national morale. If we are to break out of this downward spiral, we first need to understand the problem, then deal with it on a huge scale.

title: The Right to Birth Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Can I Change Places?
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Daniel A. Finan gives us a collection of theme answers with Strabismus. Thats the medical term, more or less, for wandering I, and Is wander all over todays theme answers. My favorite is DONT TOUCH THAT DALI for Admonishment at a Surrealist museum.

title: Scholarly Work, Without All the Footnotes
description: A RECENT Sunday Magazine article by the linguist Guy Deutscher seemed to fascinate readers, moving quickly onto The Timess most e-mailed list and staying there for several days.

title: New Labour Leader Heads Back to Britains Center
description: LONDON  Out of power for barely five months, Britains Labour Party set an ambitious goal as it concluded its annual conference last week: fulfilling the pledge of Ed Miliband, the partys new, 40-year-old leader, an intellectual leftist strongly favored by Britains powerful labor unions, to make the governing coalition of Conservatives and Liberal Democrats led by Prime Minister David Cameron a one-term government.

title: Smugglers of Drugs Burrow on Border
description: NOGALES, Ariz.  Drone aircraft patrol the United States-Mexico border from the skies. Fast boats look out for smugglers at sea. And tens of thousands of Border Patrol agents use trucks, horses, all-terrain vehicles and bicycles to stop unauthorized crossers on land.

title: Immigration Law Moves to Center Stage
description: CRETE, Neb.  Nebraska may appear to be an unlikely setting for swelling anti-immigrant sentiment.

title: The Roberts Court, Version 4.0
description: New Haven

title: Correction Officer Is Wounded in a Police Shooting
description: An off-duty New York City correction officer was shot in the arm early Saturday after he ignored orders to drop a loaded 9-millimeter pistol that he had pointed at a group of plainclothes police officers in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: Hopefuls for Calif. Governor Debate
description: FRESNO, Calif.  With accusations about an illegal Mexican housekeeper dogging her campaign, the Republican candidate for governor of California, Meg Whitman, angrily blamed her Democratic challenger, Jerry Brown, for her political problems on Saturday, adding a dose of emotion to a tight race.

title: Lessons in a Large Family
description: IM one of 10 children in my family. My mother, a nurse, was always busy around the house or taking care of a new baby. As the second-oldest child and the oldest girl, I became a surrogate parent to many of my siblings.

title: Wright Puts Three-Run Exclamation Point on Mets Victory
description: In one of the more eventful meaningless games of the season, the Mets clobbered the Washington Nationals, 7-2, behind an emphatic and emotional home run by David Wright on Saturday.

title: Female Marines in Marja
description: Full-time "female engagement teams'" deploy alongside all-male infantry patrols in Helmand Province to try to win over rural Afghan women, who are culturally off-limits to outside men.

title: For Nevada Casinos, Threats in California
description: LINCOLN, Calif.  The Thunder Valley casino, outside Sacramento, has all the trappings of a modern gambling resort: endless rows of slot machines, a high-end spa offering gold-leaf facials and the type of performers  Tony Bennett, Peter Cetera  for whom casinos were seemingly invented.

title: Drug Makers Accused of Ignoring Price Law
description: WASHINGTON  Drug manufacturers often flout a federal law that requires them to provide the government with pricing data needed to calculate discounts on medications prescribed for poor people under Medicaid, federal investigators say in a new report.

title: A Battle Against Prescription Drugs Causes Pain
description: Roland Lorenz has surgical screws in his back and neck and a pin in his upper leg, and when his pain reared up one recent weekend, he knew he needed something strong. He had just been to a pain clinic, where the doctor ordered an increase in his dosage of Percocet, a narcotic.

title: Stretch | The Jocks Throw Down Their Mats
description: As I tilted my body into a triangle pose last week and stole a glance at those behind me at Jivamukti Yoga Center in Union Square, I noticed a lot of guys in the room. Not quite half the class, but close.

title: The Female Marines
description: The women attached to the Second Battalion, Sixth Marine Regiment are called upon to access a part of Afghan society normally forbidden to their male counterparts: Afghan women.

title: A Protest March or an Invasion?
description: POLITICIANS and journalists feared and mocked them. The police boosted their ranks by 200 to control them. Their leaders were hustled off to jail, on a charge that, 116 years later, seems not only anti-American but preposterous: unlawfully stepping on the grass outside the United States Capitol.

title: Of Glamour and Glee
description: Saturday night marked the midpoint of Paris Fashion Week with yet another round of parties, including an event to introduce a collaboration between Karl Lagerfeld and Hogan and a dinner at La Socit for Glamour magazine, not to mention a citywide celebration called Nuit Blanche, during which museums and restaurants stay open all night and half of Paris seems to be on the streets.

title: Trafficking in the Southwest Goes Underground
description: As enforcement efforts have increased and border barriers have been built, tunneling has gained in popularity, with Nogales becoming the capital.

title: Measuring Success by Mission, Not Profit
description: IN May, I moved from a corporate job to nonprofit work. I had been a vice president at a large financial services firm in New York, analyzing risks and recommending investments in tax-exempt portfolios. I specialized in bonds issued by state and local governments; public and private schools, colleges and universities; and other nonprofit organizations. Before that, I was a credit analyst at a bond insurance company.

title: A Code for Chaos
description: IN June, a Belarus-based computer security firm identified a new computer malware program, Stuxnet, which was repeatedly crashing the computers of one of its clients. Then, last month, a German security researcher suggested that the programs real target might be the Iranian nuclear program  and that clues in the coding suggested that Israel was the creator. Since then, there has been growing alarm about the worm, as its target and sophistication have become more apparent. The code has appeared in many countries, notably China, India, Indonesia and Iran. It appears designed to attack a certain type of Siemens industrial control computer, used widely to manage oil pipelines, electrical power grids and many kinds of nuclear plants. The question is: Just how dangerous has this worm and cyberwarfare become?

title: Las Vegas Faces Its Deepest Slide Since the 1940s
description: LAS VEGAS  There are many cities across the country that are beginning to see the first glimpses of the end of the recession.

title: How Arthur Penn Undid Tony Curtis
description: ON Tuesday, the director Arthur Penn died in New York City, the day after his 88th birthday.

title: Next Mets Executive Could Break Familiar Pattern
description: In 2002, when Major League Baseball owned the Montreal Expos, Commissioner Bud Selig asked Fred Wilpon, the Mets principal owner, if he could appoint Omar Minaya as the general manager of the Expos. Wilpon said yes, with one stipulation. He wanted the right to take Minaya back one day.

title: First Look Inside the Proposed Islamic Center
description: Visitors to the upper floors of the Muslim community center planned for near ground zero would walk through lofty spaces  for art exhibitions, for contemplation and prayer, for programs on interreligious dialogue, for a 9/11 memorial  as sunlight streams through irregularly shaped windows between white crisscrossing beams.

title: U.S. Issues Terrorism Alert for Travel to Europe
description: The U.S. State Department issued an alert on Sunday urging Americans traveling to Europe to be vigilant about possible terrorist attacks in a statement that specifically cites the potential involvement of Al Qaida. The British government, meanwhile, raised the threat of terrorism to "high" from "general" for Britons in France and Germany.

title: Ruling Coalition Wins Latvia Vote
description: RIGA, Latvia  Latvians appeared to have re-elected the governing coalition by a wide margin in parliamentary elections on Saturday, according to preliminary results, suggesting a broad public approval of the governments handling of the financial crisis.

title: Arrest Made in Nigeria Bombings
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A day after car bombs ripped through Nigerias independence day celebrations in the capital, Abuja, killing at least 12 people, a former senior leader of the militant group that claimed responsibility has been arrested, Nigerian officials said Saturday.

title: Buy My Stuff  and Theirs, Too
description: J CREW launched an advertising campaign in September, featuring splashy print ads and a photograph of a well-dressed young man on its Web site, sitting atop a ladder. Surrounding him was an assortment of items: umbrellas, medicine balls, a retro-looking trailer, a slab of raw meat.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Corrections
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Ukraine Leads Chess Olympiad; Russia Has Clinched Womens Title
Stage Is Set (Again) for a Blue-Chip Revival
description: EVER since big blue-chip domestic stocks fell out of favor in early 2000, many market strategists have regularly been predicting their imminent return to glory.

title: Blame Falls Short at Belmont; Zenyatta Remains Undefeated
description: This was not how the Jockey Club Gold Cup was supposed to turn out, and the railbirds along Belmont Parks breezeway were letting jockey Garrett Gomez have it in all sorts of colorful and unprintable ways. He had just finished second aboard Blame, a colt who had won his last five races and who many felt was the best male horse in the United States.

title: The Wealth of an Intellect
description: MEASURED by fame and lasting influence, there is no other book on economics that comes close to The Wealth of Nations by Adam Smith. Many aspects of this book, first published in 1776, have become cornerstones of neoclassical economics: the organizing power of self-interest, the invisible hand of free markets and the crucial role of the division of labor are just three examples.

title: Dantonio Maintains Presence, Even While in Hospital
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  Two weeks after having a mild heart attack following an overtime victory over Notre Dame, Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio coached the Spartans game against No. 11 Wisconsin on Saturday from a local hospital instead of the stadium.

title: White House Plans Job Training Partnership
description: As part of efforts to address record-high levels of long-term unemployment, President Obama plans to announce a new national public-private partnership on Monday to help retrain workers for jobs that are in demand.

title: Yanks Split 2 Games With Red Sox
description: BOSTON  The first 161 games were not enough. The American League East title will come down to the final day of the regular season, when the Yankees will send out an exhausted team to play its third game in 24 hours. Maximizing the drama from a captivating season-long race, the Yankees, after splitting a doubleheader with the Red Sox, enter Sunday tied atop the division with the Tampa Bay Rays.

title: Ukrainian Star Puts On a Dominant Display at the Olympiad
description: Every chess game is between just two people, but players can be organized into teams in which individual results are added up in a combined score.

title: Bautista Shortens His Swing and Sends More Balls a Longer Distance
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The change in Jose Bautista from a free-swinging easy out into the leading home run hitter in the major leagues began in the middle of last season, in the weight room at Rogers Centre in Toronto. But not in the way you might think.

title: Bullying, Suicide, Punishment
description: TYLER CLEMENTI may have died from exposure in cyberspace. His roommate and another student, according to police, viewed Mr. Clementis intimate encounter with another man on a Webcam and streamed it onto the Internet. Mr. Clementi, an 18-year-old violinist in his freshman year at Rutgers University, jumped off of the George Washington Bridge, and now the two face serious criminal charges, including invasion of privacy.

title: The Tea Leaves
description: The North Koreans latest attempt at creating brand awareness.

title: A Photo Exhibit, From the Dear Leader
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Secret Sponsors
description: IT was the wisecracking baby who caught my attention.

title: Greener Construction
description: To the Editor:

title: Franzens Message to Fans: That Is a Rough Draft
description: OOPS. Jonathan Franzens new novel, Freedom, has been hailed by critics as brilliant and a masterpiece. But the version released in Britain last week is not quite all that, British newspapers report. Mr. Franzen told an audience at a reading in London that a draft version of his book had been published by mistake. How could this happen? The wrong computer file had been opened and copied, he said, rather than the one containing the final proof. He asked fans not to read the novel until the correct version is published this week.

title: Tax Cuts and Incentives
description: To the Editor:

title: For Posey and Giants Fans, Timing Is Everything
description: It was late spring, and the San Francisco Giants were struggling through a mediocre season.

title: What Steve Jobs Learned in the Wilderness
description: THE saga of Steven P. Jobs is so well known that it has entered the nations mythology: hes the prodigal who returned to Apple in 1997, righted a listing ship and built it into one of the most valuable companies in the world.

title: Your Comments on our Pre-Natal Origins
description: My Sunday column looks at some fascinating research at the intersection of science and sociology. Essentially it argues that the pre-natal experience is particularly important because the brain and physiology are then coming together in ways that will shape a person for decades to come  and that all this has implications for fighting poverty.

title: Fighting Words
description: Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for govenor of New York, and Fredric U. Dicker, a political editor and reporter for The New York Post, got into a loud argument last week over claims of infidelity that Mr. Paladino made about his Democratic opponent, Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Prime Number
description: Married couples 18 and older made up 52 percent of the population last year. made up 52 percent of the population last year, according to the Census Bureau, the lowest proportion since the began collecting data more than 100 years ago. The long-term decline in marriage accelerated during the recession  married couples made up 57 percent of the population in 2000, for instance  with people postponing marriage and choosing to live together instead. People are unsure about their job security, and a lot of people lost their jobs, said Mark Mather of the Population Reference Bureau, a private research group that analyzes census figures. Getting married is obviously a big step and if youre not comfortable about your future, it makes sense that youd postpone a big decision like this.

title: We Got a Mention! Now Lets Panic
description: EARLY in the summer, Nick LaCava and his two partners got something most entrepreneurs wish for, and if these three had it to do over, they would wish for it again. But they say they might be more careful  and prepared.

title: A Proposed Itinerary for Candidate Emanuel
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: House Music, Bred in Chicago, Comes Out
description: Chicago, which is widely considered the birthplace of house music 30 years ago, is again exerting its influence, as the semi-underground genre enjoys its coming-out party.

title: Rep. Quigley, Still in His First Term, Looks at the Mayoral Race, and Sees Possibilities
description: There is something about the seat in the Fifth Congressional District. Maybe it feels like a throne when you sit in it.

title: A Death Sparks a Demand for Care
description: A few weeks shy of his 19th birthday, Damian Turner, a charismatic youth advocate and aspiring musician, was gunned down in a drive-by shooting on Aug. 15  four blocks from one of the best hospitals in the world, the University of Chicago Medical Center in Hyde Park.

title: Picking Up the Pieces, San Bruno Residents Take Stock and Mind the Tourists
description: One sunny afternoon last week, a self-described disaster artist set up a canvas and easel in front of Jerry Guernseys San Bruno home.

title: Health Cost Major Issue in Proposition B Debate
description: Cathy Helton, a secretary with the San Francisco Rent Board, a city agency, said she had never before been a political activist. But now she is, outraged that the Proposition B ballot initiative would force city employees to contribute far more toward their health-benefit costs.

title: Local Intelligence | Pho
description: Bay Area eaters are eagerly gulping down Vietnamese noodle soup, or pho, typically made with beef or chicken broth. Turtle Tower in the Little Saigon neighborhood is one of San Franciscos dozens of pho restaurants. Stephen Pham, the owner, came from Hanoi 20 years ago to what he calls the land of opportunity.

title: Vows: Jen & Gust
description: Jen Brown met Gust Hookanson at her local watering hole where Gust was tending the bar. She was initially skeptical, but when she finally decided to take a leap of faith, love blossomed.

title: For Female Marines, Tea Comes With Bullets
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  They expected tea, not firefights.

title: This Time, Cink Ensures He Wont Be Overlooked
description: NEWPORT, Wales  Overlooked by his captain during the opening ceremony, Stewart Cink looked increasingly indispensable on the Ryder Cups busiest day, rolling in timely putts from near and far on the soft greens and finding a way, with ample support from his rookie partner, Matt Kuchar, to get the better of one of Europes most potent pairs Saturday.

title: Georges Charpak, Physics Nobel Winner, Dies at 86
description: Georges Charpak, who won the 1992 Nobel Prize in Physics for inventing a device to sift through the billions of hurtling subatomic particles liberated by collisions in atom smashers, opening the way for discoveries on the nature of matter, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 86.

title: Georgi A. Arbatov, a Bridge Between Cold War Superpowers, Is Dead at 87
description: MOSCOW  Georgi A. Arbatov, who was the senior Amerikanist in the Soviet Communist Party in the final decades of the cold war and served as the Kremlins voice for a generation of television viewers in the United States, died here on Friday. He was 87.

title: Art Gilmore, the Voice of Coming Attractions, Dies at 98
description: Art Gilmore, whose disembodied voice, introducing television shows and narrating hundreds (if not thousands) of movie trailers, was a trademark of Hollywoods self-salesmanship from the 1940s through the 1960s, died Sept. 25 in Irvine, Calif. He was 98.

title: Anti-Angle Ads
description: A nursing union is out with four spots attacking Sharron Angle in the Nevada Senate race.

title: Routing Florida, Alabama Looks Like a Champion
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Alabama apparently does not want any thoughtful dialogue on the national championship race. The Crimson Tide wants to end the discussion on half of the national championship matchup in January and make itself the plain choice for the title game against any of a half-dozen challengers who all look like underdogs.

title: Buddy Morrow , Trombonist and Bandleader, Dies at 91
description: At 91, Buddy Morrow had to be helped onstage to lead the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra in Ormond Beach, Fla., on Sept. 24, but once the music started, his energy never wavered. He even played the trombone solo on Night Train, which had sold more than a million copies for him in 1952.

title: It Comes Down to the Final Day, Maybe Beyond
description: Entering the final day of the regular season, none of the playoff matchups have been set. Wins by and the Yankees on Saturday ensured that the American League East winner and the A.L. wild card would be determined Sunday. But the situation in the National League is more complicated: two playoff spots are left, and three teams have the chance to claim them. San Francisco needed to win only one game this weekend to clinch the N.L. West, but the Giants to the Padres, cutting their lead in the division to one. The Padres two wins, combined with , resulted in a tie in the N.L. wild-card standings. Here is a look at how Sunday could play out, with the Braves playing the Phillies at 1:35 p.m. Eastern and the Giants hosting the Padres at 4:05 p.m. Eastern:

title: Nurses Union Plans Ad Against Angle
description: The largest union of registered nurses in the country will begin a $200,000 advertising campaign on Monday aimed at defeating Sharron Angle, the Republican challenger to Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader.

title: Oregon on Top of Pac-10, With Sky the Limit
description: EUGENE, Ore.  When Larry Scott took over as the commissioner of the Pacific-10 Conference in July 2009, he knew his league had a perception problem. He sensed one of his biggest challenges would be to convince people that the Pac-10 should be considered more than, as he put it, U.S.C. plus nine.

title: Red Bulls Clinch a Playoff Spot
description: The Red Bulls clinched a berth in the M.L.S. playoffs Saturday night when they beat the Kansas City Wizards, 1-0, then picked up a bonus prize at almost the same moment when Columbuss scoreless tie with San Jose allowed the Red Bulls to move into first place in the Eastern Conference.

title: College Football Photo Replay: Oct. 2
description: The day in photos from the college football field.

title: Dont Reunify Germany
description: WEST BERLIN

title: Italys Museums Stay Up After Hours
description: Tuesday nights in Italy just got more interesting. Through Dec. 28, museums and cultural destinations across the country will be open after hours (7 to 11 p.m.),and free, on the last Tuesday of each month. The initiative, called Martedi in Arte, is sponsored by the Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Activities and is aimed at promoting museums and other cultural institutions, and at offering affordable alternatives during a period of economic crisis.

title: Reverse Mortgage Rules to Change
description: Several big changes are coming to the Federal Housing Administrations reverse mortgage program.

title: Q&A With Andy Van Slyke
description: Andy Van Slyke, a former major league outfielder, once joked that a movie made about him would be named The Summer of 4-to-3. But first comes his first novel, The Curse, written with the St. Louis sportswriter Rob Rains, in which the Cubs are churning toward their first World Series since 1945 before fate intervenes. So much for suspension of disbelief. In Van Slykes version of Chicago tragedy, the charter plane carrying the first-place Cubs crashes, killing the entire organization except for two players. The team is a patchwork of players from other teams who soldier on together, while the crash becomes a backdrop whodunit. Clue: it isnt Steve Bartman.

title: How to Filter Your Facebook Chat List
description: One of my most frequent reader questions is, Can I use Facebook Chat without specific people seeing that I am online? I dont want those people to bother me. I answered this question last year, but Facebook has recently changed its chat interface to allow more selective filtering. Still, there are details to which you should pay attention, lest you accidentally reveal yourself to the very people from whom youre trying to hide.

title: Jimmy Johnson, Survivor
description: Jimmy Johnson was voted off Survivor last week. (No word on whether his hairstyle made it out of Nicaragua.)

title: With One Day Left, Europe Surges at Ryder Cup
description: NEWPORT, Wales  Colin Montgomerie, the European Ryder Cup captain, wanted passion, and he got it. He wanted momentum, and he got that, too. He wanted a tie going into the singles matches with the United States, and he got much, much more on Sunday.

title: The Uncanny Accuracy of Polling Averages*, Part III: This Time, Its Different?
description: This is the third installment of a five-part series on the accuracy of polls and polling averages.

title: Will Blindside Hit Spare Cammalleri Discipline?
description: From The Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out blog, this post includes items on the Rangers Derek Boogaard, Hockey Night in Canada telecasts and other items from around the N.H.L.

title: Celine: Laying the Foundation
description: The plywood that lined the floors and risers at Tennis Club de Paris this afternoon suggested that Phoebe Philo was still working on the fundamentals at Celine. Or, it could have served as a suitable backdrop for her rustic ponchos in knotty cream yarns or caftan tops in either heavy cotton twill or shirting cotton.

title: Frail Casualties in the War on Drugs
description: This morning The Times reports on delays in obtaining painkillers experienced by nursing home patients.

title: Model-Morphosis | Jean Paul Gaultier
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Lindsey Wixson from Marilyn Model Management before (left) and after (right) makeup by Stephane Marais and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: You Can Feel Right at Home Here
description: Laura Shirk-Charles stopped by her next-door neighbors home for dinner the other night in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens in Brooklyn. She ordered salmon sliders right off the menu. To go.

title: Photos of the Moment | Junya Watanabe
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

title: Nurses Enter the Nevada Fray
description: The largest union of registered nurses in the country will begin a $200,000 advertising campaign Monday aimed at defeating Sharron Angle, the Republican challenger to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, in Nevada, with union leaders describing this race as their top priority in this years mid-term elections.

title: Getting Tough on China
description: The modest recent rise in the Chinese renminbi stopped last week. The renminbi is now up 1.7 percent versus the dollar since August and up 2.1 percent since the start of the year.

title: Photos of the Moment | Sonia Rykiel
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

title: Frustrations Aside, Indians Bask in Opening of Games
description: NEW DELHI  In sharp contrast to the run-up to the Commonwealth Games, the opening ceremony started on time Sunday night and appeared to be meticulously planned, with a throbbing musical number that included hundreds of intricately costumed drummers, the worlds largest helium balloon and enormous dancing puppets.

title: And Hes Off
description: 8:17 a.m. | Updated The former chief of staff posted a video Sunday in which he promises to spend the next several weeks listening to the people of Chicago as he prepares to run. Here it is:

title: Live Analysis: Jets Beat Bills, 38-14
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  The Jets slammed an emphatic exclamation point on the first quarter of their season Sunday. They did not beat or best Buffalo, so much as they battered the Bills into an early submission.

title: Photos of the Moment | Jean Paul Gaultier
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: The Music Was Wagners; The Stamina Was Levines
description: BOSTON  When James Levine gave the downbeat to the Act I Prelude from Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg  the first work on the Wagner program with which he opened his seventh season as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Symphony Hall here on Saturday evening  it was with a grand, sweeping gesture that a conductor with serious back problems is unlikely to make without a grimace. And lest there be any doubt that he was up to the task, Mr. Levine continued to use the large, picturesque gestures that were once an important part of his interpretive arsenal but that have given way in recent seasons to more compact, sometimes almost microscopic movements in the style of Fritz Reiner, as he has tried to conduct while managing pain from a number of injuries and illnesses.

title: Yankees Go Down to the Wire
description: BOSTON  With 70 minutes to go before the first pitch, the Yankees did not have their lineup set. Joe Girardi had to check with his players before determining who would play behind Dustin Moseley. Robinson Cano, Brett Gardner and Curtis Granderson played all 20 innings in the field Saturday, and Mark Teixeira and Alex Rodriguez played both games, too, though each was a designated hitter for one game.

title: Vagueness of Alert Leaves Travelers Frustrated
description: The State Department travel alert issued on Sunday in response to reports of a threat by Al Qaeda was anything but precise.

title: Executive Director of Queens Theater Resigns
description: Jeffrey Rosenstock, the founding executive director of Queens Theater in the Park, is stepping down after 21 years, the theater has announced.

title: Kentucky Senate Candidates Debate
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  During Sunday mornings debate between the two candidates vying to be the next senator from Kentucky, there was a revealing exchange reminiscent of a pivotal moment in the Massachusetts senate race earlier this year.

title: Sunday Word: Whose Thumping?
description: The Obama administration and its former chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, are preparing for their first week apart as Republicans and Democrats spar over how bad of a thumping the presidents party will take in November.

title: 'Mrs. Warren's Profession'
description: Sally Hawkins, left, and Cherry Jones in a scene from the Broadway revival of Shaw's play, at the American Airlines Theater. (Video courtesy of the Roundabout Theater)

title: 'El Gato Con Botas (Puss in Boots)'
description: A scene from the co-production between the Gotham Chamber Opera and the Tectonic Theater Project. (Video courtesy of the New Victory Theater)

title: Mondays Singles Pairings for Ryder Cup
description: Heavy rains overnight forced the final session of the Ryder Cup to Monday for the first time. After the completion of fourball and foursome matches Sunday, Europe leads the United States, 9 1/2 to 6 1/2. Here are the singles pairings for Mondays session (all times Eastern):

title: Oregon Jumps Boise State in Polls
description: Congratulations to those of you who had five weeks in the pool for when Boise State would get jumped in the polls.

title: New Leaders for Disneys Interactive Media Group
description: The Walt Disney Company shook up its underperforming Internet and gaming division on Sunday, effectively splitting the unit in two and tapping two outsiders to lead the businesses.

title: Media Decoder: New Leaders for Disneys Interactive Media Group
description: The Walt Disney Company shook up its underperforming Internet and gaming division on Sunday, effectively splitting the unit in two and tapping two outsiders to lead the businesses.

title: A Cameras Lens Isnt Its Most Important Part
description: Photographers are notoriously cranky and opinionated online. Even theyll admit that. I wonder why that is?

title: Commonwealth Games Begin
description: A crowd of about 60,000 packed Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium in central Delhi for the opening ceremony for the Commonwealth Games.

title: Ethnic Wins in Bosnia May Cause Deeper Splits
description: PRAGUE  Fifteen years after the ethnic war in Bosnia ended, an outspoken nationalist Bosnian Serb leader was expected to triumph in elections there on Sunday, reinforcing ethnic divisions and threatening to rip apart the fragile country, according to political leaders and analysts.

title: Saturday Night Live Takes On Rahm Emanuel
description: The SNL version of Rahm Emanuel had the SNL version of Pete Rousereconsidering the White House chief of staff post on Saturday night.

title: Israeli Soldiers Convicted of Using Boy as Shield
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli military court convicted two soldiers on Sunday of using a 9-year-old Palestinian boy as a human shield by forcing him to check bags for explosives in Israels 2008-9 Gaza war.

title: Stumbling to Wild Card, Yankees Turn Focus to Twins
description: BOSTON  When the Yankees emerged bleary-eyed from the dugout at Fenway Park before their game Sunday against the Red Sox, the Green Monster greeted them with an impish jab: the old hand-operated scoreboard listed TAMPA BAY above NEW YORK in the American League East standings, the handiwork of a cheeky stadium worker. A few hours later, Fenways tenants sealed the Yankees fate.

title: Hegel on Wall Street
description: As of today, the Troubled Asset Relief Program, known as TARP, the emergency bailouts born in the financial panic of 2008, is no more. Done. Finished. Kaput.

title: More States Allowing Guns in Bars
description: NASHVILLE  Happy-hour beers were going for $5 at Past Perfect, a cavernous bar just off this citys strip of honky-tonks and tourist shops when Adam Ringenberg walked in with a loaded 9-millimeter pistol in the front pocket of his gray slacks.

title: In No-Trump, Playing to Keep the Long Suit Off the Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA  The biggest world bridge championships are held every four years. The 13th tournament opened here on Friday evening. The highlights were an e-mailed message from President Obama, whose grandparents were avid players, and an amusing speech by Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia.

title: Pop Second-Guessing Itself, Building Up and Coming Apart
description: Menomena tears holes in its songs. One moment, the whole band is bearing down on a fast, burly riff, or filling out a stately melody with classical-piano filigree and echoing guitar; the next, theres just a vocal, a drumbeat and perhaps a few bass notes skulking down below. On Friday night at Webster Hall, Menomena (pronounced men-AH-men-uh), from Portland, Ore., constructed and disassembled its music as if it wanted fans to be as analytical as the band itself: to hear the mechanisms within the songs, to recognize the decisions made within every arrangement.

title: Getting the Grand Tour, and a Performance, Too
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Even though the San Francisco Ballet starts its season in December (with The Nutcracker), the fall dance scene in the Bay Area is already busy. At the Yerba Buena Arts Center there is a three-day conference on different genres of Indian dance. The Smuin Ballet is performing a world premiere by the much-talked-about Trey McIntyre. In Berkeley the Mark Morris Dance Group is offering a triple bill.

title: From Wily House Cat to Lord of the Manor
description: Critiques of the 17th-century French fairy tale Puss in Boots have ranged from appreciations of the wily cats ingenuity and imagination to condemnations of the insinuation that trickery is a valid route to success.

title: Behind That Humble Pitchfork, a Complex Artist
description: The cover of R. Tripp Evanss Grant Wood: A Life does not depict American Gothic, the painting for which Wood is best known. Instead it features a lush green landscape, replete with rolling hillside and curving country road. On that road is a truck colored so prettily, picturesquely red that it suggests a freshly painted barn. There is a nave-looking simplicity to the way this image has been rendered.

title: Two Stars, Two Assertive Drummers
description: The trumpeter Terence Blanchard and the saxophonist Branford Marsalis, in back-to-back sets at Rose Theater on Friday, played what sounded like new music.

title: New CDs
description: TOBY KEITH

title: Day of a Strike Dawns for Detroit Musicians
description: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra has weathered decades of strikes, deficits, criticism over its racial makeup, mediocre concert homes, cuts in state aid and canceled tours.

title: Obama Makes Campaign Ad Debut
description: Along with their daily dose of pigskin, New Orleans Saints fans received a midgame shot of President Barack Obama, when the first general election campaign commercial featuring the president aired on behalf of Louisiana state Rep. Cedric Richmond during the Saints-Carolina Panthers game Sunday.

title: Madison Avenue Plays Ball With Fox
description: In another sign of how eager advertisers are these days to sponsor live sports on television, Fox is reporting strong demand for commercials to appear during its postseason baseball coverage.

title: Monday: Like a Dire Situation
description: I thought this was a cool theme, interesting and different. For the constructor, it has the added advantage of automatically creating symmetrical theme entries.

title: Roman Projections
description: In his column today, Tom Friedman quotes Lewis Mumford on the decline of Rome, and applies it to ourselves. Its a common trope, and I dont have any problem with Tom using it. But I do think we should be aware that the Roman Empire was a very different kind of society from anything existing in the modern world, and that when someone draws morals from Romes decline, the reality of Rome almost never comes into the thing.

title: Smart Selections at an Eclectic Film Festival
description: The hard hats have begun laying tile, but much remains to be done inside the new addition to the Film Society of Lincoln Center that is set to open next spring. Tucked under a recently opened restaurant, the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center rests smack in the middle of the south side of West 65th Street, giving film unaccustomed visibility on this performing arts campus. The Film Societys administrative offices and the Walter Reade Theater will remain across the street and upstairs, the theaters presence signaled by a forlorn black banner that, as you walk east, is partly obscured by a parking-garage sign.

title: When a Mans Castle Is Actually a Tiny Pod
description: A play that comes with a gimmick attached always raises a red flag. Are they giving away beer or passing out festive hats at the door to try to distract you from the fact that the play itself isnt very good?

title: Returning to Realism and Revisiting a Tragedy
description: Traditionalists alarmed by the Metropolitan Operas forays into the digital age can seek solace in Otto Schenks ultraconventional 1989 production of Verdis Rigoletto, which returned to the house on Wednesday evening.

title: A Zaha Hadid Museum Wins RIBA Stirling Prize
description: MAXII, the National Museum of the XXI Century Arts in Rome, designed by Zaha Hadid Architects, based in London, has won the RIBA Stirling Prize, one of Britains top honors in architecture, BBC News reported. Ms.  Hadid, the Iraqi-born designer and the firms founding partner, began work on the $200 million MAXXI, as it is called, above, more than a decade ago. She was awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004 and recently designed the Aquatics Center for the 2012 London Olympics. The annual Stirling Prize also carries a cash award, of about $31,000.

title: A Solid Opening Weekend for The Social Network
description: The Social Network from Sony Pictures Entertainment opened to a strong but not stratospheric $23 million in weekend ticket sales at North American theaters. That result, while easily enough for No. 1, put the film, directed by David Fincher from a script by Aaron Sorkin, on par with recent releases like The Town, which opened with significantly less attention from the news media. Even though it didnt break any records, The Social Network is going to maintain healthy receipts in the weeks to come, said Phil Contrino, editor of BoxOffice.com. The Social Network, which received positive reviews but a slightly less rapturous response in audience exit polls, is considered an early Oscar favorite. Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of GaHoole (Warner Brothers) was second with $10.9 million for a new total of $30 million. Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps (20th Century Fox) was third with $10.1 million for a total of $35.9 million. The Town (Warner) was fourth with $10 million, bringing its total to $64.3 million. Easy A (Sony) rounded out the Top 5 with $7 million ($42.4 million total).

title: Illness Slows New Leader of Chicago Symphony
description: Riccardo Muti, who took over as music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra with much fanfare this season, suddenly pulled out of a gala concert on Saturday night because of stomach pains, an orchestra spokeswoman said. Mr. Muti rehearsed the orchestra in the morning and went to the Symphony Center for the concert  called the Symphony Ball and sponsored by the orchestras Womens Board  when he decided he could not go on, the spokeswoman said. The orchestra went ahead without him without a conductor, performing the Beethoven Violin Concerto with the soloist Anne-Sophie Mutter and substituting Mozarts Symphony No. 34 (which it had recently played) instead of the other works on the program, Rossinis William Tell overture and Liszts symphonic poem Les Prludes.

title: Science Foundation Backs Climate-Change Play
description: The National Science Foundation has awarded a $700,000 grant to the Civilians, a New York theater company, to finance the production of a show about climate change. The Great Immensity, with a book by Steven Cosson (This Beautiful City) and music and lyrics by Michael Friedman (Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson), tells the story of Polly, a photojournalist who disappears while working in the rain forests of Panama. The grant is a rare gift to an arts organization from the foundation, a federal agency that pays for science, engineering and mathematics research and education. The company says it plans to spend the money on the development and evaluation of the show, as well as on a tour and educational programs, including post-show panel discussions with experts in related scientific fields. No performance dates have been announced.

title: Two Weeks, Two Shows Canceled by the Networks
description: The second week of the fall television season brought two casualties: Foxs Lone Star and ABCs My Generation. ABC said on Friday night that it had canceled My Generation, a documentary-style drama about young people 10 years out of high school. The show had drawn a relatively meager 3.9 million viewers to its second episode on Thursday. The network did not immediately announce how it would fill the 8 p.m. Thursday time slot. But it did indicate that it hoped to broadcast the remaining six episodes, perhaps on the Internet. My Generation was the second new network show to be canceled. Fox took the Texas soap opera Lone Star off its schedule on Tuesday, one day after its second episode drew 3.2 million viewers, despite efforts by its creator to drum up interest. Fox has scheduled the returning drama Lie to Me in its place.

title: Comic Strips Think Pink
description: In honor of Breast Cancer Awareness Month, King Features Syndicate has put together a Cartoonists Care newspaper strip event for Sunday. More than 50 cartoonists, including those behind Zits, Dennis the Menace Blondie, left, and Family Circus, will participate and turn their strips pink to increase awareness about the disease. Each strip will include a pink ribbon. Three female cartoonists  Sandra Bell-Lundy (Between Friends), Hilary Price (Rhymes With Orange) and Anne Gibbons (Six Chix)  have also created themed strips. All the strips will be posted Sunday on comicsgopink.com, along with an easy way to donate to a breast cancer charity.

title: Back in Milan, Gallinari Finds His Voice and His Stroke
description: MILAN  The final burst of emotion had nothing to do with sentiment or surroundings or the pulse of the crowd. Danilo Gallinaris parting gesture Sunday was pure competitive zeal  a timely 3-pointer, a triumphant fist pump, a shout.

title: Attention, 49ers! Roddy White Doesnt Give Up
description: Roddy White had seven catches for 104 yards in the Falcons 16-14 victory over the 49ers on Sunday, but neither his statistics nor the result were unusual.

title: Migrant Villages Within a City Ignite Debate
description: BEIJING  The community is walled and gated, an enclosure of rows of crowded low-rise homes and shops, where people live under the gaze of surveillance cameras and apart from the city. The police patrol around the clock, and security guards stop unfamiliar faces to check identification papers. In the morning, only one gate is open, through which parents head off to work and children go to school. At night, the gate is locked, preventing street loiterers from trespassing.

title: Maury Allen, Sportswriter and Prolific Author, Dies at 78
description: Maury Allen, a longtime sportswriter for The New York Post who may have set a record of his own for the number of books on sports he turned out 38  died Sunday at his home in Cedar Grove, N.J. He was 78.

title: Twins Managers Wife Plays Favorites
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Sunday morning in his Target Field office, Minnesota Twins Manager Ron Gardenhire said it didnt matter to him whether his team faced the Yankees or the Rays in the American League division series. But that opinion wasnt unanimous in the Gardenhire household.

title: Firefighters in Queens Wont Rush to All Calls
description: A million times a year, fire trucks are driven into the streets of New York City, usually at breakneck speeds with lights and sirens blaring. The rush is often critical: Firefighters converge on fires, douse the flames and save lives.

title: Film Version of Zuckerberg Divides Generations
description: At what point does ambition, a cornerstone of American commerce, morph into something darker and less celebrated? Over the weekend, people who saw The Social Network, the movie about Facebook and its principal creator, Mark Zuckerberg, were left to ponder that question on the sidewalk.

title: Live Analysis: Giants 17, Bears 3
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It had been a week of soul-searching for the Giants. Their former players questioned the direction of the team and there did not seem to be a unified voice emerging from within the locker room.

title: Runoff Will Decide the Presidency of Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Dilma Rousseff was leading late Sunday in her bid to be Brazils first female president, but election officials said she had failed to come up with enough votes to avoid a second round.

title: Chicago Symphonys New Leader Cancels Concerts After Illness
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestras lovefest with its new music director, Riccardo Muti, came to a sudden halt on Sunday, when the maestro canceled two weeks of concerts to seek treatment in Milan for what the orchestra called extreme gastric distress.

title: U.S. Military Apologizes for Civilian Deaths in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the wake of charges from Afghan officials that civilians were killed in two attacks over the weekend, the American military apologized for one episode in which a child was killed and two other children wounded and said it was investigating the deaths of several civilians in the other episode.

title: In San Francisco, N.L. Pennant Race Ends With a Victory Lap
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A thick layer of fog hung over San Francisco early Sunday, and with it the lingering doubts about whether the Giants could finally put away the San Diego Padres and win their way into the playoffs.

title: 2 Brothers Await Broad Use of Medical E-Records
description: There is no silver bullet for reforming Americas health care system, but medical experts have long agreed that digital patient records and electronic prescribing can help improve care and curb costs.

title: Verizon Wireless to Pay Millions in Refunds
description: WASHINGTON  Verizon Wireless said on Sunday that it would pay up to $90 million in refunds to 15 million cellphone customers who were wrongly charged for data sessions or Internet use, one of the largest customer refunds by a telecommunications company.

title: Suicides Put Light on Pressures of Gay Teenagers
description: FRESNO, Calif.  When Seth Walsh was in the sixth grade, he turned to his mother one day and told her he had something to say.

title: Security in a Lawless Congo
description: In late July, hundreds of armed men gang-raped at least 200 women in Luvungi -- an embarrassment for United Nations peacekeepers who seem to be failing at their most basic task: protecting civilians.

title: Cuomo, Candidate and De Facto Campaign Manager
description: Andrew M. Cuomo was driving his staff crazy.

title: Lehman Omnipresent in Nomuras Push Into U.S.
description: The discreet sign by the door does not say Lehman Brothers. But step inside: a bit of Lehman lives on here in Manhattan.

title: Call to the Bullpen Crackles With a Last Laugh
description: After all the dreary lassitude of this season, Jerry Manuel found a way to change the mood in sad-sack Flushing.

title: Health Cares Lost Weekend
description: Doctors, like most people, dont love to work weekends, and they probably dont enjoy being evaluated against their peers. But their industry can no longer afford to protect them from the inevitable. Imagine a drugstore open only five days a week, or a television network that didnt measure its ratings. Improving the quality of health care and reducing its cost will require that doctors make many changes  but working weekends and consenting to quality management are two clear ones.

title: When Home Has No Place to Park
description: LOS ANGELES  Every day, Diane Butler and her husband park their two hand-painted R.V.s in a lot at the edge of Venice Beach here, alongside dozens of other rickety, rusted campers from the 1970s and 80s. During the day, she sells her artwork on the boardwalk. When the parking lot closes at sunset, she and the other R.V.-dwellers drive a quarter-mile inland to find somewhere on the street to park for the night.

title: Where the Greats of Cricket Are Honored: A Humble Hall Atop a Restaurant
description: HARTFORD

title: The Mets Season Ends, but the Intrigue Continues
description: An item in a Connecticut newspaper on Sunday said that Jeff Wilpon, Bobby Valentine, Omar Minaya and Wally Backman were seen dining recently at a restaurant in Norwalk called Quattro Pazzi, igniting speculation about the Mets future plans until the report was roundly dismissed.

title: More Countries Adopt Chinas Tactics on Currency
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration escalates its battle with Chinese leaders over the artificially low value of Chinas currency, a growing number of countries are retreating from some free-market rules that have guided international trade in recent decades and have started playing by Chinese rules.

title: With Texas Not Ranked, Streaks End
description: Longtime observers of the Associated Press top 25 might have done a double-take on Sunday: for the first time since Oct. 15, 2000, Texas was not ranked.

title: As Wild Card, Yankees Need Right History to Repeat Itself
description: BOSTON

title: Fear and Favor
description: A note to Tea Party activists: This is not the movie you think it is. You probably imagine that youre starring in The Birth of a Nation, but youre actually just extras in a remake of Citizen Kane.

title: No Stopping Movie View of Mark Zuckerberg
description: Millions of the moviegoers who made The Social Network the top box-office draw of the weekend saw an unflattering portrayal of Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook.

title: With High Expectations, Jets Skip the Celebration
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  The Jets trudged deceptively into the visitors locker room at Ralph Wilson Stadium, absent smiles, fist pumps, or any of the usual signs of celebration. Their body language suggested they expected this result.

title: A Silicon Valley Investors Take on a Post-Facebook World
description: In The Social Network, the new movie that tells a fictional version of the founding of Facebook, Silicon Valley is getting the Hollywood treatment  and its about time. It captures a world where big money, oversize egos and raw feelings collide as entrepreneurs compete to create the next big thing. Meanwhile, the established system of investing in start-ups is being turned upside down.
