title: Eagles Look Lost After Vick Is Injured
description: PHILADELPHIA  Michael Vick gingerly pulled on his blue button-down shirt Sunday night, wincing as he tried to extend his right arm through the sleeve.

title: Election Season Puts Politicians in the Pews
description: Eleven months out of the year, the parishioners of New York City can safely attend Sunday services with no reasonable fear of interlopers, television cameras or quizzical members of the press.

title: As Maliki Clings to Power, Iraqs Fissures Deepen
description: BAGHDAD  When Nuri Kamal al-Maliki began his bid for re-election as prime minister  exactly a year ago on Saturday  he pledged to unite a population splintered and suspicious after years of war. He has not, and while he is hardly alone in blame, the consequences could haunt Iraq for years to come.

title: Lottery Numbers
Debate Over Meaning of Standoff in Ecuador
description: QUITO, Ecuador  The clock had struck 9 p.m. last Thursday. President Rafael Correa had been holed up on the third floor of the police hospital here for more than 10 hours after being assaulted by a clutch of rebellious police officers. Dozens still lurked near the entrance, quarreling with security forces that had arrived to free the president.

title: Casinos Now See Online Gambling as a Better Bet
description: Many of the countrys largest casinos, long opposed to gambling games like poker on the Internet, are now having second thoughts.

title: Iran Lifts Ban on Director, Saying He Issued an Apology
description: TEHRAN  Cultural officials have lifted a ban on film production by Asghar Farhadi, an award-winning director, that was imposed after he made public remarks supporting opposition filmmakers last month.

title: Imams Wife Tells of Death Threats
description: One of the people behind the proposal to build a Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan said on Sunday that death threats had been made against her and her husband.

title: Case of Accused Soldiers May Be Worst of 2 Wars
description: WASHINGTON  Over the last nine years, as the Army has cycled hundreds of thousands of soldiers through combat duty in Afghanistan and Iraq, it has also court-martialed 34 on murder or manslaughter charges in the killings of civilians in those conflict zones. Twenty-two were convicted, and 12 acquitted.

title: Westwood Has Europe on a Roll From the Start
description: NEWPORT, Wales  It was not a glorious Ryder Cup Sunday for all the Europeans at Celtic Manor Resort.

title: Race Is on to Claim, Were No. 2!
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Nearly 2,500 miles from the psychedelic blend of yellows and greens that provided the backdrop for Oregons rout of Stanford here on Saturday, top-ranked Alabama put forth a more traditional performance in a blowout of Florida.

title: Flawed Paperwork Aggravates a Foreclosure Crisis
description: As some of the nations largest lenders have conceded that their foreclosure procedures might have been improperly handled, lawsuits have revealed myriad missteps in crucial documents.

title: First Monday
description: The Supreme Court enjoys all but free rein in selecting which cases to review. From the end of one term in the summer until the start of the next, on the first Monday in October, the work of the court is to sift through thousands of petitions from parties that lost in one of the federal appeals courts or highest state courts and are eager for the justices to reverse their fate.

title: With a Squeegee and a Smile, a Relic of an Unruly Past Wipes On
description: Spotting a squeegee man used to elicit a grumble and a lot of useless waving-off gesticulation by the driver. Now a sighting of this rare species sparks a little charge, the way any New York City rarity  a faux Checker cab or a seltzer man  might.

title: Tis No Pity Shes a C.E.O.
description: The delightful surprise of the generally less-than-delightful Mrs. Warrens Profession, which opened on Sunday night at the American Airlines Theater, is that Cherry Jones, in the title role, does not nearly glow. She glitters.

title: A Man for All Factions
description: For decades, the Democratic Party was torn by civil war.

title: Rangers Make Roster Fit, but Forwards Are a Puzzle
description: The Rangers cut two defensemen from their roster Sunday to get down to 25 players, in essence the number they need for their season opener Saturday at Buffalo, but the forward position remains unsettled.

title: Whos In?
description: As the global economic balance shifts, the United States and other of the post-World War II powers say theyre ready to make room. The Group of 8 rich countries ceded to the Group of 20, where the interests of Germany and France must vie with those of India. Despite that, the maneuvering before this weeks meetings of the International Monetary Fund suggest that the big players may not be as ready as they claim.

title: Upstart Winner Challenges Brooklyn Democratic Leadership
description: In a large auditorium at St. Francis College in Brooklyn several days after the primary last month, the usual crowd of Democratic politicians shook hands and patted backs.

title: Lax and Lethal
description: The high price Americans pay for weak gun laws  no matter where they live  is made painfully clear in a new study prepared by Mayors Against Illegal Guns, a bipartisan coalition led by Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York and Mayor Thomas Menino of Boston.

title: For Tea Party Candidate, Time to Temper Message
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Rand Paul, the Tea Party-backed Republican nominee for the Senate, sent a thank-you note on Saturday to Senator Jim DeMint of South Carolina, a father of the Tea Party movement, who was coming to a rally for him in northern Kentucky.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Times Co. to Repay Loan Early
description: The New York Times Company intends to pay back a $250 million loan from the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Hel in early 2012, three years ahead of its due date.

title: Tape Has Angle Assailing Republicans
description: Sharron Angle, the Republican candidate for Senate from Nevada, faces a number of obstacles in her attempt to defeat Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader and perhaps the top target of Republicans this year. High among them is the fact that the November ballot includes an official Tea Party candidate, Scott Ashjian, who clearly threatens to draw votes away from Ms. Angle in what is shaping up to be a very tight race with Mr. Reid. (This despite the fact that Ms. Angle has the support of much of the national Tea Party).

title: 2 Officers Shoot and Kill a Man Carrying a Knife
description: A knife-wielding man in Upper Manhattan was fatally shot by the police early Sunday after ignoring repeated demands to drop the weapon and enduring a strike from a Taser gun, the police said.

title: Public Libraries: Endangered or Saved?
description: To the Editor:

title: Eagles Fans Tell McNabb How They Really Feel
description: PHILADELPHIA  It was the day of Donovan McNabbs return. This is the homeland of the Eagles Fan, terra incognita for anyone not wearing a midnight green jersey. You might expect the hordes to be hostile, their anger stoked by the return of a polarizing player who committed the mortal sin of not winning a championship. But Eagles fans are anything but predictable.

title: Behind the Scenes at a Bomb-Plot Trial
description: Poems that the defendant wrote in prison tracked the genres well-worn themes: injustice, isolation and regret. In neat script on lined paper, the poems, by David Williams IV, were written between December 2009 and August 2010, as Mr. Williams and three other men awaited trial on charges that they had left what they thought were real bombs outside of two Bronx synagogues and had planned to shoot down military cargo planes.

title: Cheap Debt for Corporations Fails to Spur Economy
description: As many households and small businesses are being turned away by bank loan officers, large corporations are borrowing vast sums of money for next to nothing  simply because they can.

title: At Disney, New Leaders in Internet and Gaming
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company shook up its underperforming Internet and gaming division on Sunday, effectively splitting the unit in two and tapping two outsiders to lead the businesses.

title: Transcript
Obsessions With Minutiae Thrive as Databases
description: MANAGING a database doesnt exactly sound like a path to fame and fortune  more like a path to a role in a companys technology department. But the market has been kind to the visionaries who began to collect information online in the 1990s.

title: Ukraine Wins Gold Medal at Chess Olympiad
The Public Trust
description: The Interior Departments Bureau of Land Management oversees about 250 million acres of public land in the West. Much is leased out, some to energy and mining companies, but mostly to ranchers for grazing cattle and sheep. The bureau is supposed to find a balance between the public interest and the interest of the leaseholders  upholding the public interest whenever conflicts arise.

title: Protecting Civil Liberties While Fighting Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Myths About Hunting as Its Practiced Today
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gloomy Portrait of America
description: To the Editor:

title: Mass Rapes in Congo Reveals U.N. Weakness
description: LUVUNGI, Democratic Republic of Congo  Four armed men barged into Anna Mburanos hut, slapped the children and threw them down. They flipped Mrs. Mburano on her back, she said, and raped her, repeatedly.

title: The U.N.s Battle Against Brutality
description: A rebel attack on a Congolese village, which lasted four days and included the rape of at least 200 women, highlights the difficulty of the peacekeeping mission there.

title: Limiting Federal Powers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rising Health Premiums
description: To the Editor:

title: Sizing Up a Cheeseburgers Caloric Heft
description: When people make numerical estimates, they are notoriously subject to the distorting influence of anchors: numbers previously observed that linger in the mind and drag up or down the later estimate. A new study describes a related but opposite effect: when the anchor is in a very different category, it can drive the target estimate away, rather than pulling it closer.

title: One Good Barber Yarn Deserves Another
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts, People and Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Advertising Week Hints at Better Times
description: HERE is a look back at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the seventh annual Advertising Week, which took place from Monday through Friday in New York.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: An Award, Criticism and Perils for Comcast
description: Criticizing Fox News is a year-round sport for many hosts on MSNBC, the cable news channel, and especially for Keith Olbermann, whose verbal spitballs at the Fox host Bill OReilly have occasionally put his parent company, NBC Universal, on edge.

title: Padres Face Uncertain Future
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The San Diego Padres began the season with the 29th-highest payroll in baseball, at just under $38 million  or about two-thirds of what the Yankees spent on the left side of their infield.

title: Ad Group Unveils Plan to Improve Web Privacy
description: As the debate around online privacy and advertiser access to users data continues, a group of the advertising industrys largest trade organizations was to announce on Monday the details of a self-regulatory program that would allow users to opt out of being tracked by its member organizations.

title: Condom Use Is Highest for Young, Study Finds
description: A wide-ranging study of Americans sexual behavior, based on the largest nationally representative survey since 1992, finds that condom use is becoming the norm for sexually active teenagers.

title: Giants Beat Bears and Find a Rhythm
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Back-to-back blowout losses by the Giants had unglued the early season expectations that surrounded the team. A 3-0 start with little dazzle from the Bears brought out the skeptics. Sunday nights game was supposed to solve the mysteries of just what kind of teams the Giants and Bears have.

title: Word of the Day | braggart
description: braggart \bra-grt\ noun

title: Business World Using Commonwealth Games to Assess India
description: NEW DELHI  The Commonwealth Games, which opened here on Sunday, are unlikely to be gripping viewing for sports fans.

title: Treasury Auctions and Bond Issues Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Coming this week are factory orders and pending home sales for August (Monday); the Institute for Supply Management service index for September (Tuesday); Automatic Data Processing employment for September (Wednesday); consumer credit for August and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment and nonfarm payrolls for September and wholesale trade inventories for August (Friday).

title: In Comments, Fed Officials Signal New Economic Push
description: Momentum within the Federal Reserve this week continued to build toward resuming purchases of huge amounts of government debt to help the flagging economic recovery, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

title: Call It a Victory for Maturity
description: Paris

title: Oct. 3: Sports Replay
description: A look at the day in sports for October 3.

title: Accusation Upsets a Province
description: The editors of Macleans, the venerable weekly Canadian magazine, have made provocative covers something of a specialty. But none of their earlier efforts produced quite the same response as an image of Bonhomme Carnaval, the snowman mascot of Quebecs winter festival, jauntily carrying a briefcase overflowing with cash. The bold cover headline on the issue of Oct. 4 was no more subtle: Quebec: The Most Corrupt Province.

title: Michael Wolff to Lead a Stable of Trade Magazines
description: Michael Wolff, the Vanity Fair columnist and troublemaker who seems to relish public feuds and collecting enemies as much as chronicling the folkways of the Manhattan media world, has agreed to become editorial director of a group of trade publications that includes Adweek, Brandweek and Mediaweek.

title: N.F.L. Week 4: Jets Replay
description: Photos from the New York Jets 38-14 defeat of the Buffalo Bills.

title: Lehman Omnipresent in Nomuras Push Into U.S.
description: The discreet sign by the door does not say Lehman Brothers. But step inside: a bit of Lehman lives on here in Manhattan.

title: Giants Defense Delivers Knockouts
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jay Cutlers stall was already empty while the other members of the Chicago Bears were undressing moments after their 17-3 loss Sunday to the Giants. Cutlers night was long over by that time.

title: Is There Still Time to Plant Pink Tulips?
description: PARIS

title: Cheap Debt for Corporations Fails to Spur Economy
description: As many households and small businesses are being turned away by bank loan officers, large corporations are borrowing vast sums of money for next to nothing  simply because they can, Graham Bowley writes in The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | October 4, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Flawed Paperwork Aggravates a Foreclosure Crisis
description: As some of the nations largest lenders have conceded that their foreclosure procedures may have been improperly handled, lawsuits have revealed myriad missteps in crucial documents, Gretchen Morgenson writes in The New York Times.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 4, 2010
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Gary Rubinstein at Math for America from the Times article Told to Eat Its Vegetables, America Orders Fries.

title: More Countries Adopt Chinas Tactics on Currency
description: As the Obama administration escalates its battle with Chinese leaders over the artificially low value of Chinas currency, a growing number of countries are retreating from some free-market rules that have guided international trade in recent decades and have started playing by Chinese rules, David E. Sanger and Michael Wines write in The New York Times.

title: Gerald S. Lesser, Shaper of Sesame Street, Dies at 84
description: Gerald S. Lesser, a Harvard psychologist who as the longtime chief adviser to Sesame Street poured the pedagogy into the show, helping ensure from the start that the new, experimental venture in education by television would be both enjoyable and instructive, died on Sept. 23 in Burlington, Mass. He was 84 and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Court to Look at Sale of Zambian Phone Company
description: Residents of Lusaka, the capital of Zambia, have been grumbling that since a Libyan state company took over the domestic phone company this summer, it is harder than ever to place a call, Matthew Saltmarsh writes in The New York Times.

title: Dick Griffey, Founder of Solar Records, Is Dead at 71
description: Dick Griffey, the founder of the Solar record label  known for bringing a funky, laid back, California sound to soul, R&B and disco in the 70s and 80s  died on Sept. 24 in Los Angeles. He was 71.

title: Morgenson: Count on Sequels to TARP
description: From Gretchen Morgensons latest column:

title: Leadership in Action for Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Big Year for Small Merger Advisers
description: Independent merger advisers should relish their moment in the sun. The busiest among them have grabbed a record share of the American market this year.

title: Zuckerbergs Most Valuable Friend
description: Every Monday a bit before 10 a.m., Sheryl Sandberg, Facebooks chief operating officer, dashes off a quick e-mail to her boss, Mark Zuckerberg. We have a routine, Ms. Sandberg says. I e-mail, Coming in? He replies, On my way.

title: D-Day Bond
description: WHO are the men in this photo?

title: Its Time for Democrats to Attack, Pelosi Says
description: If Washington normally blends the business of government with electoral politics, this week signifies a turn toward an unalloyed electoral brawl.

title: The Week Ahead
description: DEBATES With four weeks to go before the midterm elections, candidates are talking to anyone who will listen. The Senate hopefuls in Connecticut  Richard Blumenthal, a Democrat, and Linda E. McMahon, a Republican  will kick off debate season on Monday night in Hartford.

title: Pakistan Militants Hit NATO Convoy
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  More than a dozen oil tankers carrying fuel for NATO troops in Afghanistan were torched in Rawalpindi early on Monday, not far from Pakistans capital and the headquarters of the military, police officials said.

title: On Start-Ups, Angels and the Real Mark Zuckerberg
description: In The Social Network, the new movie that tells a fictional version of the founding of Facebook, Silicon Valley is getting the Hollywood treatment  and its about time. It captures a world where big money, oversize egos and raw feelings collide as entrepreneurs compete to create the next big thing. Meanwhile, the established system of investing in start-ups is being turned upside down.

title: Wild Things
description: Big cats need plenty of room to roam, and so must designers. They cant be fenced off, or have their creative habitat divided, as Tanzania proposes to do with a controversial highway through the Serengeti National Park. Riccardo Tiscis fashion show for Givenchy on Sunday night might seem a world away from a serious concern in Africa, but the choice of leopard print got me thinking.

title: Times Co. to Repay Slims Loan Early
description: The New York Times Company intends to pay back a $250 million loan from the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Hel in early 2012, three years ahead of its due date.

title: Stage Is Set (Again) for a Blue-Chip Revival
description: Every since big blue-chip domestic stocks fell out of favor in early 2000, many market strategists have regularly been predicting their imminent return to glory, The New York Timess Paul J. Lim writes.

title: Daily Lexeme: Kleptobiosis
description: Todays word, in association with the explicative Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: No Stopping Movie View of Mark Zuckerberg
description: Millions of the moviegoers who made The Social Network the top box-office draw of the weekend saw an unflattering portrayal of Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook.

title: A Family Album: American Soldiers at War
description: Tim Hetheringtons Infidel (Chris Boot Ltd., 2010) is more of a family album than a traditional photojournalism book. There are of course powerful images of life for a platoon in the Korengal valley in Afghanistan that Hetherington and Sebastian Junger documented in the film Restrepo. But there are also thorough catalogs of the soldiers tattoos, their official Army ID photos and the magazine centerfolds in their barracks, and remarkably revealing interviews with seven of the soldiers. The book stands on its own, separate from the movie.

title: VimpelCom in Merger Talks With Egyptian Tycoon
description: VimpelCom, Russias second-largest mobile-phone operator, and the Egyptian billionaire Naguib Sawiris may say as early as Monday that they are closer to agreement on merging their phone assets, two people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

title: Harbinger to Sell 10% Stake in Inmarsat, Report Says
description: Harbinger Capital Partners, the United States hedge fund, is planning to sell a 10 percent stake in British satellite firm Inmarsat worth close to 300 million ($473 million), The Sunday Times reported.

title: Allianz Builds Up $1.4 Billion Deal Fund
description: Allianz, the German insurer, is on the lookout for acquisitions, putting aside a budget of 1 billion euros ($1.4 billion) with which it hopes to buy up general insurers once regulations become clearer, Michael Diekmann, the companys chief executive, told The Financial Times.

title: Still Stuck in Denial on Wall St.
description: From Joe Nocera, writing in his Talking Business column:

title: Better Democracy Through Fraud
description: Todays idea: Sometimes fraudulent elections and other undemocratic practices can actually be good for democracy if they are transitional, two scholars write. Cases in point: Burma, Chile and revolutionary America.

title: BofA Lures Senior Bankers Away From Rivals
description: From DealBook colleague Julia Werdigier:

title: Bidders Said to Line Up for R.B.S. Portfolio
description: At least three potential bidders are casting an eye over a 3 billion portfolio of property loans that could be sold by Royal Bank of Scotland, The Sunday Times reported.

title: LightSquared Raises $850 Million in Debt Issue
description: LightSquared, the wireless broadband and satellite network, said Sunday that it had closed on $850 million of debt in the opening round of a syndicated secured credit facility.

title: Secondary Deals Hide Buyout Shops Shuffle
description: Cinven reaped a 70 percent return on its investment by selling German academic publisher Springer Science+Business Media in December. ATP, one of the private equity firms backers, isnt sure what its made, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Pioneer of In Vitro Fertilization Wins Nobel Prize
description: The Nobel prize in physiology or medicine has been awarded this year to Robert G. Edwards, an English biologist who with a physician colleague, Dr. Patrick Steptoe, developed the in vitro fertilization procedure for treating human infertility.

title: What Would Keynes Say Today?
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: Paris Celebrates Kertsz, an Adopted Artist
description: The photographer Andr Kertsz straddled three identities  Hungarian national (he was born in Budapest in 1894), enthusiastic Paris migr (he posthumously donated his negatives to the Ministre de la Culture), and adopted American (he was a Manhattan resident for 49 years). The exhibition of his work at the Jeu de Paume (1, Place de la Concorde; 33-1-47-03-12-50; jeudepaume.org), which runs through Feb. 6, embraces all three eras, calling itself the first proper retrospective of his work in Europe.

title: Raiders at Home? Its an Empty Feeling
description: If the Raiders ever take another lead this season, and no one is there to see it, will it really count?

title: New Fund-Raising Record Gives Democrats Hope for Midterms
description: Even as Democrats face a difficult October, there are signs that President Obamas 2008 supporters are beginning to wake up.

title: Sanofi Goes Hostile With Genzyme Bid
description: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, turned its $18.5 billion takeover bid for the United States biotechnology company Genzyme hostile on Monday but stuck to the same terms, having failed to persuade the Genzyme board to allow it to conduct due diligence.

title: I.M.F. Warns of Long Road Ahead for Full Reform
description: The global financial system is not fixed yet, a recent analysis by the International Monetary Fund has warned.

title: Rockefeller Group Buys Majority Stake in Europa
description: Rockefeller Group, the United States real estate investor, has agreed to buy a controlling stake in the private property fund manager Europa, in its first British deal.

title: Doerr Brothers Spy Turning Point on Medical E-Records
description: There is no silver bullet for reforming Americas health care system, but medical experts have long agreed that digital patient records and electronic prescribing can help improve care and curb costs, The New York Timess Steve Lohr reports.

title: If Comcast Buys NBC, Will Fox Lose an Adversary?
description: Criticizing Fox News is a year-round sport for many hosts on MSNBC, the cable news channel, and especially for Keith Olbermann, whose verbal spitballs at the Fox host Bill OReilly have occasionally put his parent company, NBC Universal, on edge, Brian Stelter reports in The New York Times.

title: A.I.A. Said to Lower I.P.O. Price
description: The American International Group received a $1 billion commitment from Kuwait Investment Authority for the initial public offering of its Asian unit, the first major investment committed before the offerings roughly $15 billion debut, Reuters reported.

title: G.M. in Pursuit of a Few Good Partners, Report Says
description: General Motors is on the lookout for potential partners as the automaker seeks to lay the course for a successful turnaround, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: British Banks May Need New Bailout, Researchers Says
description: British banks may need another state bailout next year and their borrowing requirements could hit 25 billion ($39.5 billion) a month, an independent research organization said, although the British finance minister dismissed any such scenario, Reuters said.

title: Edwards, Eyeing a Deal, Sees Stronger 2nd Half
description: The Edwards Group, the private equity-backed vacuum technology firm that is preparing for a sale or flotation, said it rapidly recovered from the global downturn and would grow sales and profits further in the second half of the year, Reuters reported.

title: As VW Pushes to Pass Toyota, Deals Will Help
description: Volkswagen wants to challenge Toyota to be the worlds top carmaker, David Jolly and Jack Ewing write for The New York Times.

title: Vick to Mora: There Was Nothing You Could Do, Jim
description: The big news involving Michael Vick on Sunday were his injuries, which threaten to derail his storybook season.

title: What Should the Punishment Be for Acts of Cyberbullying?
description: This is the question an article in the Week in Review asks about the Tyler Clementi case. Just how culpable is an online bully in someones decision to end a life? the article asks. Do you know about this case, and the Phoebe Prince case earlier this year? How tough should the punishment be for those who cyberbullied these students? Why? How do you think incidents like these could be prevented in the first place?

title: Could Fund Flight Cost Britain Nearly $800 Million?
description: As Londons hedge fund managers pick up sticks to escape higher taxes and increased regulation, the exodus could end up costing the British Treasury 500 million ($791 million) annually, according to The Financial Times.

title: The Great Debate: People or Profits?
description: Last week, I attended the Inc. 500 Conference in Washington. Business owners come from all over the country to hear speeches from experts and entrepreneurs, to attend and participate in roundtables and workshops, and possibly to accept an award as one of the fastest growing privately owned companies in America.

description: Memorable plays and milestones, in a season marked by great pitching achievements:

title: Bullish Fund Managers Profited in September
description: September, it seems, has rewarded bullish hedge fund managers, like John Paulson, whose biggest fund posted a 12.4 percent gain during the month, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing an investor.

title: The Bottom and Beyond for the Bills
description: No matter your rooting interest, there is something sad about small-market Buffalo, with its loyal and passionate fans, having such a miserable stretch of seasons. And this could be the worst of them.

title: Jets and Giants Defenses Pitch Shutouts on Third Down
description: The New York/New Jersey football defenses seemingly had a force field to help them on third down on Sunday.

title: Polluted Air and Diabetes: A Link
description: A strong link exists between adult diabetes and air pollution, according to a new epidemiological study by researchers at Childrens Hospital Boston. The long-term study builds on previous laboratory studies that have tied air pollution to an increase in insulin resistance, a precursor to diabetes.

title: The Volatile Caucasus, Calmly and Carefully Assessed
description: Thomas de Waal, among the most able observers of the anxious politics and bitter conflicts that have brewed at the base of the Caucasus range since the Soviet Union broke apart, calls the soaring mountains a magnificent arc that are both a colossal landmark and a powerful barrier.

title: Comparing the Jets 3-1 Starts

description: Forget too big to fail  how about too big to fire? Its led some lenders into reverse head-hunting: seeking another employer for the banker with a prohibitive severance package.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Friends The Simpsons
description: Maybe it was just a wild coincidence that Mark Zuckerberg, the 26-year-old Facebook chief executive and co-founder, said he would donate $100 million to the Newark public schools just before the release of The Social Network, the making-of-Facebook biopic that renders him as a socially maladroit and coldly impersonal Machiavelli of HTML.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Broccoli Panzanella With Walnut Sauce and Basil
description: To Anita Lo, the executive chef and owner of Annisa in Manhattan, the Italian panzanella, a bread salad often tossed with tomatoes, capers, onions and olives, is a summery dish and a good use of day-old bread.

description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Cutler Is Sack-Test Dummy: The View From Chicago
description: After Jay Cutler was sacked nine times in the first half Sunday night, Chicagos newspaper critics gave the Bears offensive line two thumbs down.If Cutler had been been tempted to do the same, he wouldnt have had time to point the digit downward.

title: Cuomo Warns That Angry Vote Could Help Paladino
description: He has called his rival extreme, divisive and demeaning.

title: Suspected Arms Dealer Seems Closer to Extradition
description: BANGKOK  A contentious, four-hour hearing on the extradition of Viktor Bout, a Russian suspected of being an arms dealer, ended inconclusively Monday, but judges appeared to quash the prospect of a lengthy second trial that could have delayed or scuttled Mr. Bouts departure for the United States.

title: Fewer Budgets, Less Spending
description: 9:58 a.m. | Updated

title: Switzerland Proposes Tougher Rules for Biggest Banks
description: A Swiss government panel on Monday proposed rules that would require the nations two big banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, to hold more capital in reserve than international competitors as a way to provide extra insurance against a catastrophic failure, Jack Ewing writes in The New York Times.

title: No Detail Is Too Small for Cuomos Consideration
description: What were reading this raw, chilly (high of only 57!) day:

title: Time Redesigns The Page
description: Time magazine on Monday unveiled a redesigned version of The Page, the political hub spear-headed by Mark Halperin.

title: Paris: Some Lemons
description: Stella McCartneys super-trim, no-nonsense collection could be seen as a response to the boxy, over-layered clothes weve been served in the past day. I refer to the tent shapes at Cline and the leopard-and-chiffon layers at Givenchy, a moment of fashion gluttony in Paris. Ms. McCartney took a more healthful, fresh-air approach today. Her pantsuits, worn with fine buttoned-up polo shirts, were well-tailored, trim but easy, with somewhat high-waist trousers and a pale pastel palette of rose, pistachio, blue and lavender. She showed two or three colors in combination, and it worked. The clothes are a natural follow-up to falls classically slim trousers and crewnecks, and the shoe is now a low-heeled sandal with a single buckled strap at the front and an ankle strap.

title: Panel Says Japanese Power Broker Should Face Charges
description: TOKYO  Ichiro Ozawa, the shadowy power broker of Japans governing Democratic Party, suffered another political blow on Monday when an independent panel said he should face charges for a political financing scandal, weeks after he was defeated in his attempt to become prime minister.

title: The Gathering Storm Over Foreclosures
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Mad Men Recap: Keeping an Eye on Joan
description: Season 4, Episode 11

title: Math, Models, and Mystification
description: In my discussion of alternative models of the crisis, I didnt get around to discussing two fringe sects that buzz around the edge of the debate.

title: Adrienne Stoltz and Brett Johnson
description: Adrienne Blaine Stoltz, a daughter of Jacklyn C. Stoltz and Gregory B. Stoltz of Mystic, Conn., was married Saturday to Brett Matthew Johnson, a son of Brenda LaGrange Johnson and J. Howard Johnson of New York. The Rev. Mark Santucci, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Marks Episcopal Church in Mystic.

title: Goal Looms for U.N.: Ending Energy Poverty
description: The United Nations Millennium Development Goals were adopted in 2000 as a commitment to improve health and education as well as end poverty in less fortunate parts of the globe. The eight goals include targets like universal childhood education, reducing infant mortality and ensuring environmental sustainability.

title: Figure Skating a Most Dangerous Game, Laraque Finds
description: The recently retired N.H.L. enforcer Georges Laraque requires 12 stitches to his forehead  not from a fight, but because his partner in CBCs Battle of the Blades accidentally cut him with her figure skate. Laraques injury occurs on Saturday during a rehearsal for Sundays premiere of the competition portion of the figure-skating contest show, as he and his partner, Anabelle Langlois, practice a maneuver called the Chainsaw. The 97-pound Langlois, swinging from the 275-pound Laraques neck, loses her balance and starts to fall headfirst. As Laraque reaches to break her fall, her skate blade slices his forehead.

title: Two Men Shot Dead in S.U.V. Near Gramercy Park
description: Updated 3:02 p.m. | Two men who had been sought by the police as potential murder witnesses were shot and killed as they sat in a parked sports utility vehicle in the Flatiron district early Monday morning, the police said.

title: Early Word: Supreme Court Back in Session
description: The Supreme Court reconvenes today, but dont blink if you want to catch a glimpse of its newest member, Justice Elena Kagan. She has recused herself from 25 of the 51 cases the court has accepted so far this term because she argued the cases during her 14-month tenure as solicitor general. The Timess Adam Liptak will have the first look at the session later today.

title: New Zealands Prime Minister Weighs In on Hobbit Dispute
description: John Key, the prime minister of New Zealand, has become the latest and arguably the most influential person this side of the wizard Gandalf to seek a resolution in a labor dispute that has hobbled a planned two-film adaptation there of The Hobbit by J. R. R. Tolkien.

title: Monday Reading: Making Doctors Work Weekends
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: McDowell Seals Ryder Cup for Europe
description: NEWPORT, Wales  Moments after Graeme McDowell won the final Ryder Cup point on the 17th green on Monday, something that looked like a Celtic Mardi Gras parade broke out in the Usk Valley. Singing, laughing pockets of elation spread out across the greensward, up the slope next to the 18th green, and in front of the Twenty Ten clubhouse, and in the 18th fairway at Celtic Manor.

title: Jersey Sure
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared descriptive toponyms.

title: Sexual Violence in Eastern Congo
description: An epidemic of rape and sexual violence is attacking the women of South Kivu Province, Congo.

title: Berlusconis Jewish Joke Falls Flat
description: Updated | 11:54 a.m. On Sunday, the Vaticans official newspaper, LOsservatore Romano, denounced Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy for telling a deplorable joke about Jews and the Holocaust.

title: How Difficult Parents Look From the Counselors Side of the Desk
description: 1:35 p.m. | Updated See below for a comment from Karen Felton, one of the high school counselors quoted in this post.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: This will be a big month for drug approval decisions by the Food and Drug Administration. The agency faces deadlines for decisions on several drugs.

title: Deliberations Begin in Connecticut Murder Case
description: NEW HAVEN  After hearing weeks of often gruesome testimony, and with more than 200 pieces of trial exhibits to sift through, jurors on Monday began deliberating the charges against a parolee accused in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., that left a mother and her two daughters dead.

title: Fungus From the Parks
description: Over on City Room, Ava Chin has a post on edible mushrooms in New York City, including chicken mushrooms, oyster mushrooms and giant puffballs.

title: To Sell Apartments, Furnishing Is No Afterthought
description: It wasnt just the swinging chair, strung from the ceiling, that was distracting. When apartment hunters stepped into the third-floor studio for sale at 650 Avenue of the Americas, they found a white leather circular bed with red pillows and a hanging L.E.D. lamp with colors shifting from green to blue. Some said it reminded them of the film 2001: A Space Odyssey.

title: Photos of the Moment | Cline
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

title: Stuyvesant Town Foreclosure Auction Postponed
description: The planned foreclosure sale of the sprawling Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes was suddenly postponed Monday morning, shortly before the 80-acre, 11,226-unit development was to be sold in the eighth-floor rotunda of the Federal Courthouse downtown.

title: A Pretty Edgy Climate Campaign
description: 4:15 p.m. | Updated Hey, in an entertainment universe where a blood-soaked psychopath can be a hero and flesh-munching zombies can be hilarious (to me, too), whats a few exploding schoolchildren?

title: Running Wilde Races for an Audience
description: SANDS POINT, N.Y.  Lunching in the dining room of a Gatsbyesque country club where his Fox comedy Running Wilde was filming on a rainy Friday, Will Arnett was making the best of his opulent settings. He took alternating bites of the chocolate chip pie and carrot cake on his plate, and he joked that he had been transported to work that morning by a driver who takes me to a helicopter that flies me to Boston, and then I take a ferry from there.

title: Actors Injury Attributed to Misfiring of Prop Pistol
description: The Donmar Warehouse in London said on Monday that it would resume performances of Stephen Sondheims Passion on Thursday after an actor in the production was injured by a prop gun during a performance on Saturday. David Birrell, who is playing Colonel Ricci in the Donmar production of the musical, was injured during Saturdays matinee performance and taken by ambulance to a nearby hospital, The Guardian reported.

title: I.V.F. Takes the (Nobel) Prize
description: Motherlode sends its congratulations to Robert G. Edwards, who won the Nobel Prize for Medicine this morning. He is, figuratively, the father of the technology that, literally, has allowed four million babies to be born over the past three decades.

title: Jimmie Johnson Takes Over Sprint Cup Lead
description: With a second-place finish at the Price Chopper 400 in Kansas City, Kan., Jimmie Johnson is back on top of the Sprint Cup standings. So what else is new?

title: Robert Green Earns England Recall and Davies Gets His First Nod
description: Two days after he was victimized for a goal by Clint Dempsey in West Hams Premier League match against Fulham, goalkeeper Robert Green was recalled to the England squad for the first time since gifting a howler of a goal to Dempsey in the 2010 World Cup.

title: The Netherlands Drops de Jong
description: The hard-tackling midfielder Nigel de Jong was dropped Monday from the Dutch national team for two Euro 2012 qualifiers (against Moldova and Sweden) by Coach Bert van Marwijk after his tackle resulted in an opposing player breaking his leg in an English Premier League game over the weekend.

title: The Filter Adds New Places to the List of Great Coffee Bars in New York
description: Today Im updating the Filters recommendations about New York coffee for The Scoop, the Timess guide to New York for iPhone and iPad users, even though the coffee app was launched just last month. In fact, I will update the Filter at least once every month. New Yorks coffee scene is growing and changing every week  the Scoop should help you stay on top of it.

title: Photos of the Moment | Stella McCartney
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Catiere.

title: Integrity at Issue in Connecticut Senate Debate
description: HARTFORD  Richard Blumenthal and Linda E. McMahon questioned each others truthfulness and qualifications to serve in the United States Senate Monday in a televised debate marked by tart exchanges and obvious iciness between them.

title: A Note On Currency Wars
description: Ive seen a number of people  most recently, Yglesias  suggesting that mutual attempts by major economies to depreciate their currencies could be really helpful right now. The intuition seems clear: it gets countries printing money; and theres also the historical argument by Eichengreen that competitive devaluation in the 1930s was actually quite helpful.

title: Dexter Watch: Back to Bloody Business
description: Anyone who thought that last weeks episode of Dexter was short on momentum and long on setup must have felt appeased by Sunday nights hour, yes? Things are picking up and seem to be off to a strong start.
