description: Q.

title: Law Firms Orrick and Akin Gump End Merger Talks
description: The big law firm Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe has seen its share of merger discussions fizzle out in recent years. Add its talks with Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld to the list.

title: Toyota Says 65% of Recall Repairs Are Completed
description: DETROIT  Toyota said on Monday that the rate of complaints about sudden acceleration had fallen 80 percent since April and that dealers had repaired 3.7 million of the six million vehicles in the United States covered by its two biggest recalls.

title: Better to See an Apartment Furnished or Empty?
description: It wasnt that long ago that real estate brokers could easily sell apartments with bare walls and little or no furniture. In the frothy years of 2006 and 2007, apartment buyers were supposed to picture where their fine art collections and antiques would fit (this was when New Yorkers, of course, could afford art collections).

title: Saubers Bright New Mexican Driver, and Sponsor
description: The Sauber team survived after the German car manufacturer BMW pulled out of the team and the sport over the winter. But the car has run this season practically entirely white, with hardly any sponsors, aside from a couple of races with Burger King. Today, the Swiss-based team announced that next season it would be running with sponsorship backing from Telmex, the Mexican telecommunications company, and it will be racing with a Mexican driver as well.

title: Saubers Bright New Mexican Driver, and Sponsor
description: The Sauber team survived after the German car manufacturer BMW pulled out of the team and the sport over the winter. But the car has run this season practically entirely white, with hardly any sponsors, aside from a couple of races with Burger King. Today, the Swiss-based team announced that next season it would be running with sponsorship backing from Telmex, the Mexican telecommunications company, and it will be racing with a Mexican driver as well.

title: What Were Reading: Cheap Gas and Obesity
The Uncanny Accuracy of Polling Averages*, Part IV: Are the Polls Getting Worse?
description: This is the fourth article in a series on the accuracy of polls and polling averages. In the first two installments, we demonstrated that polls have been extremely accurate at forecasting the winners of governors and Senate races in recent years  much more so than you might expect based on intuition alone.

title: On Our Radar: White House Climate Battles
description: A detailed analysis of the collapse of recent climate legislation in the Senate finds that missteps and limited enthusiasm by the Obama White House helped doom the effort. [The New Yorker]

title: Runway Beauty | Guido Palau Sets Hair Trends
description: Guido Palau has had a busy month so far. Those pin-straight hair extensions last week at Cavalli? His. The Jazz Age Marcel wave at Prada last week? Also his. The soft knots at the nape of necks at Nina Ricci, where he made references to both the Edwardians and the 1970s? You get the idea.

title: Monday Matchup, Patriots at Dolphins
description: Patriots at Dolphins

title: An Ailing Muti Leaves Chicago for Treatment
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestras love fest with its new music director, Riccardo Muti, has come to a sudden halt because of Mr. Mutis illness. He canceled his appearances with the orchestra halfway through his one-month fall stint with it so he could fly to Milan on Monday to seek treatment for what the orchestra called extreme gastric distress. Mr. Muti suffered stomach pains over the weekend and canceled a Saturday-evening gala performance at the last minute  the orchestra played with no conductor  and decided on Sunday to consult with his own doctors in Milan.

title: A Gulag Family Reunion
description: Sometimes, the spartan lines of a caption cant begin to tell the story behind the picture they describe. A striking example is the photograph we published in this weekends issue with Serge Schmemanns review of The Victims Return: Survivors of the Gulag After Stalin, by Stephen F. Cohen.

title: A Gulag Family Reunion
description: Sometimes, the spartan lines of a caption cant begin to tell the story behind the picture they describe. A striking example is the photograph we published in this weekends issue with Serge Schmemanns review of The Victims Return: Survivors of the Gulag After Stalin, by Stephen F. Cohen.

title: Want an Arrested Development Movie? Youd Better Watch Running Wilde.
description: During a recent visit to the set of his new series, Running Wilde, we werent necessarily going to ask Mitchell Hurwitz, the creator of the cult comedy Arrested Development, about the long, long awaited possibility of an Arrested Development movie, figuring it comes up in every interview Mr. Hurwitz gives, and besides, he probably has more pressing concerns right now.

title: Mets Make Dismissals Official
description: Over the past 13 seasons, the Yankees have been a model of stability and success with one general manager, two field managers and four championships to their name. Across town, the Mets have struggled to keep up, cycling through three general managers and four managers in little over half that time.

title: Nemesis
description: 1: Equatorial Newark

title: Newark, 1944, When Polio Disrupted the Playground
description: Philip Roths latest protagonist is not one of his self-conscious writer-heroes, like Nathan Zuckerman or Peter Tarnopol, who spend their lives turning sentences around and contemplating the equation between life and art. No, hes a simple Newark gym teacher who in the summer of 1944 is supervising the neighborhood playground, watching the boys play ball and the girls jump rope. In Mr. Roths new novel, Nemesis, its the summer when a polio epidemic sweeps through the city, spreading anxiety and suspicion.

title: Billie Joe Armstrong Adds New Number to American Idiot
description: The Broadway musical American Idiot received a healthy shot in the arm last week as Billie Joe Armstrong, the frontman and lead guitarist for the rock band Green Day, performed in the devilish role of the heroin dealer St. Jimmy for a regular complement of eight performances. A rock opera set to more than 20 Green Day songs, American Idiot grossed $1,092,334 for the week, according to the producers  a significant improvement over the shows weekly average gross of $740,000 since opening on April 20 at the St. James Theater. The maximum possible gross for that week of performances would have been about $1.3 million.

title: Fees to Avoid
description: Have you called 411 recently? If so, you just racked up a needless directory assistance fee. Instead, you could have used free services.

title: Arsonists Damage a Mosque in the West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Arsonists suspected of being radical Israeli settlers damaged part of a Palestinian mosque early on Monday in a village near the West Bank city of Hebron, setting fire to rugs and copies of the Koran and scrawling the word revenge in Hebrew on a wall, police officials and witnesses said.

title: Brennan Book, Many Years in Making
description: WASHINGTON

title: In Sharp Change, Britain Will Reduce Child Benefits for the Middle Class
description: LONDON  The British government said Monday that it would no longer pay a universal child subsidy to wealthier families, opening a campaign that may end up transforming Britains welfare system by reducing benefits to the middle and upper classes.

title: A Daughter Relocates 2,500 Miles Away, and a Mother Flies Home, Alone
description: A few weeks ago, I dropped my younger daughter, Emma, at college to start her freshman year. We hugged long and deeply. Its really happening? Now?

title: Photos of the Moment | John Galliano
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Google TV Announces Its Programming Partners, but the Top Networks Are Absent
description: Google announced on Monday its first content partners for Google TV, its effort to marry two mediums  the Internet and television. But the announcement underscored the difficulties companies face as they try to work their way into the living room.

title: Video Series: Small Business and the Recession
description: Nearly a year after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York deemed the recession over, many small-business owners are still waiting for real signs of recovery. In this video, part of a series of articles and videos that have followed several small businesses in New York City since 2008, one gets a glimpse of how unevenly the economic rebound is playing out across the city and various industries. A bicycle manufacturer in Queens has adapted to changing markets and come out a leaner, more diversified company. Meanwhile, a butcher in the Bronx recently closed shop because of outstanding debt.

title: Cisco Executive Is Named Chief of Skype, as New Owners Build a Leadership Team
description: Skype, the popular Internet video and telephone service, has hired a top official at the networking giant Cisco Systems as its chief executive, Skype said Monday.

title: Considering Some Things Mysterious
description: With so many putting so much on self-promotional, self-debasing display (e.g. the Naked Cowboys presidential run, etc.), it can be easy to lose track of all the things that still remain shrouded in the city, its hidden treasures and sub rosa machinations.

title: Disposophobia
description: A sesquipedalian term for hoarding.

title: Skype Picks New C.E.O. Ahead of I.P.O.
description: 1:04 p.m. | Updated

title: The Claim: A Soap-and-Water Rinse Gets Produce Cleanest
description: THE FACTS The prospect of ingesting pesticides and other contaminants can make supermarket produce seem less than appetizing. Buying organic lowers the risk, but is no guarantee against food-borne pathogens.

title: Even Benefits Dont Tempt Us to Vegetables
description: Eat your vegetables.

title: Scorecard | Haider Ackermann Wins!
description: How to go from still slightly under the radar critical darling to supernova? If Milan taught designers showing on the fourth day of Paris Fashion Week anything, its to break out the Pantone book. Then  at least if you combine your electric blue and saffron with starchitectural volumes  youll take the emotive level of reviews Haider and higher still. Because Scorecard knows critics didnt really get Loewe.

title: In Concert, U2 Spins a New Spider-Man Song
description: Speaking of rock stars with Broadway ambitions: at a concert Sunday night in Coimbra, Portugal, U2 added a new song to its set list called Boy Falls From the Sky. If that title makes your spider-sense  or maybe just your memory neurons  tingle, thats because it is one of the tracks that Bono and the Edge created for the coming Broadway musical Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark. Reeve Carney, who will play Spidey and his alter ego, Peter Parker, in the musical, played the song last month in an appearance on Good Morning America; now you can hear how it sounds when its performed by its composers.

title: TimesCast | October 4, 2010
description: Graham Bowley and David Gillen on why cash-rich companies still aren't hiring, the value of vague terror warnings for travelers and a look back at the discovery of insulin.

title: VW Design Chief Collaborates With Leica
description: Walter deSilva, the head of design for the Volkswagen group, known for his elegant designs for Audi and, before that for Alfa Romeo, has designed a camera for Leica.

title: 11 Arrests in Alabama Bingo Investigation
description: Last spring, reports of a federal corruption inquiry began trickling through the Alabama Legislature as its members argued fiercely over a bill to allow some form of gambling in the state. Several legislators received subpoenas, others acknowledged wearing recording devices and still others said they had received surprise visits from F.B.I. agents.

title: Vicks Injury Clarifies and Complicates Things
description: In the Philadelphia locker room, the quarterbacks are clustered in one corner, but how long they stay that way is one of the Eagles most pressing questions. That became painfully obvious when Michael Vick, who had energized the team in two games as the starter, bruised his ribs in the first quarter of Sundays loss to the Washington Redskins and never returned.

title: As 55 Turns 55, a Dodger Celebrates
description: For people of a certain age who lived in Brooklyn more than half a century ago, Oct. 4 is a day that will live in infinity.

title: The Morning Skate: N.H.L. in Europe, Hockey Night in Canada in the U.S.
description: Once again this season for the fourth straight year, some N.H.L. teams are opening in Europe, with six teams  Carolina, Minnesota, Boston, San Jose, Columbus and Phoenix  beginning their schedule overseas. The first game on the regular season schedule (this Thursday at noon Easter) features the Hurricanes and the Wild from Helsinki.

title: In Connecticut, New Ad Attacks Blumenthals Vietnam Claim
description: Hours before their debate on Monday night, the Republican candidate for Senate in Connecticut, Linda McMahon, released a video showing her opponent, Richard Blumenthal, suggesting that he served in the Vietnam War, though he did not.

title: The Job Is Open. Who Should Run the Mets?
description: Monday is the 55th anniversary of the Brooklyn Dodgers 1955 World Series victory over the Yankees, a moment that Dave Anderson has duly noted in a Sports of The Times column. That day was clearly a big moment in the life of Fred Wilpon, the Mets principal owner, who grew up in Brooklyn as an avid Dodgers fan and high school teammate of Sandy Koufax, and who, of course, modeled Citi Field after Ebbets Field, which is now long gone.

title: Chlos Silent Spring
description: On days when there are shows in the tent in the Tuileries garden, you expect to cross the hard, pebbled ground, wedge your way through the rigid crowd of onlookers and standing-ticket holders, and see something quite different once the show starts. Today, however, at Chlo, the models looked older and more world-wise this time. With their buns and ballet flats, in their streamlined coat dresses and plain white cotton dresses, they looked like young ladies who study dance or music. That is, they looked like an ideal.

title: Sanofis Chief: Genzyme, Give Us a Number
description: In announcing that Sanofi-Aventis was taking its $18.5 billion bid for Genzyme directly to shareholders, Sanofis chief executive wants one thing.

title: For Desserts Without Gluten, Crumbles Take the Cake
description: Lately Ive been thinking about desserts and all the after-dinner delights that my gluten-intolerant friends are missing.

title: Japan Recycles Minerals From Used Electronics
Peach or Nectarine and Blueberry Crumble With Quinoa-Oat Topping
description: Peaches or nectarines and blueberries make a beautiful color combination and a nice package of nutrients. The peaches contain vitamin C, vitamin A, vitamin K, beta-carotene and potassium, while the blueberries have anthocyanins, compounds that some scientists believe may have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.

title: Airline Defends Dancing Flight Attendants
description: Proceeding on the assumption that five million YouTube viewers cant be wrong, Cebu Pacific, the largest airline in the Philippines, has rejected criticism of its plan to have flight attendants perform dance routines while instructing passengers in safety procedures.

title: Sara Lee Rises on Report of Rebuffed K.K.R. Approach
description: Shareholders pushed up Sara Lees stock price on Monday, on a report by The New York Post that the consumer goods giant had dismissed a takeover proposal by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. By early afternoon, Sara Lee shares were still up about 8.5 percent at $14.57.

title: Franzens British Publisher Apologizes for Printing Errors
description: In a case of Freedom meets The Corrections, Jonathan Franzens British publisher has apologized for a printing error that left dozens of spelling and punctuation mistakes in the first edition of his new novel.

title: Its Wisconsin Cheese, So Cook With It
description: The cheese heads from Wisconsin are trying new ways to give the average dairy shopper a head for its cheeses.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Alexander Interactive, New York, formed a unit, Canopy, to specialize in Web design for e-commerce businesses. David Wertheimer, director for strategy at Alexander Interactive, becomes chief executive at Canopy.

title: "Favorite Foods with Chef Michael Symon"
description: Chef Michael Symon prepares pan-roasted shrimp with Wisconsin Parmesan, one of his first signature dishes at his restaurant Lola.

title: East Village Squatters Lose a Leader
description: Throughout much of the 1980s and 90s, a certain segment of the East Village appeared to be in nearly perpetual rebellion. There were the squatters who took over abandoned city-owned buildings. There were the gardeners who reclaimed trash-strewn lots. And there were the anarchists and artists who declared rhetorical war on developers while holding roving protests and sometimes skirmishing with the police.

title: STEM Education Has Little to Do With Flowers
description: If you want to talk about bolstering science and math education in this country, Ill gladly break out my virtual pompoms and go rah. Who wouldnt? Our nations economy, global allure and future tense all depend on the strength of its scientific spine.

title: Where Is the Female Steve Jobs?
description: For American women, the days of overt Mad Men-style discrimination are largely gone. Women outnumber men at universities, have career options beyond the secretarial pool, and are (slowly) narrowing the pay gap with their male peers. So why has this half of the population failed to reach critical mass in leadership roles across industries? She Owns It explored the topic here, and author Gloria Feldt answers the question in her new book, No Excuses: 9 Ways Women Can Change the Way We Think About Power and Leadership. Ms. Feldt, the former president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood, recently spoke with me about why womens progress is stalled, her hope that a female Steve Jobs will soon emerge and the dangers of being a stay-at-home mom. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

title: Model-Morphosis | John Galliano
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Arizona Muse from Next Model Management before (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Julien dYs. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Fremantle Buys Majority Stake in @radical.media
description: FremantleMedia has bought a majority stake in @radical.media, an innovator in the growing field of branded entertainment  the business of incorporating brands and products into the plots of entertainment content like movies, TV shows and video games. FremantleMedia is the production arm of the RTL Group unit of the media giant Bertelsmann.

title: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 11:28 A.M.
description: Art handlers installed Palm Tree/Seascape, a new work by the conceptual artist John Baldessari.

title: Popping Up in Londons Dining Scene
description: For the citys emerging cooks, pop-up restaurants are part recital and part art happening, a chance to dazzle an adventurous audience.

title: What Sanofi Needs to Win Genzyme
description: Sanofi-Aventiss hostile bid for Genzyme could be the start of a long fight between the French drug maker and its biotechnology target.

title: Hazards: Rabies Alert for Travelers to Africa and Asia
description: Public health officials have issued a rabies warning to American travelers after a 42-year-old psychiatrist from Virginia died from exposure to a rabid dog while he was jogging in India.

title: With Media in Tow, Emanuel Embarks on Listening Tour
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff who wishes to be mayor, said he wanted to know what Chicagoans were worrying about. And halfway through Monday  the first day of what he is calling his Tell It Like It Is tour  Mr. Emanuel had certainly heard his share of worries.

title: U.S. Reaches Deal in Credit-Card Antitrust Suit
description: Consumers may see more discounts for using cash instead of a credit card under a tentative deal announced Monday by the Justice Department and the credit card companies Visa and MasterCard.

title: Aiming to Learn as We Do, a Machine Teaches Itself
description: Give a computer a task that can be crisply defined  win at chess, predict the weather  and the machine bests humans nearly every time. Yet when problems are nuanced or ambiguous, or require combining varied sources of information, computers are no match for human intelligence.

title: The Highest Property Tax Burdens in America
description: The typical resident of Westchester County in New York pays more in property taxes than the typical resident of any other major American county, according to a new analysis of Census data from the Tax Foundation.

title: Why Indiscretions Appear Youthful
description: She had every reason to start stealing, or so it seemed at the time. A young daughter at home. Sickly, dependent in-laws. No savings or decent income. She and her husband could barely make the rent, and here she was working at a large department store that was raking in the cash. Who would miss a few items here and there, a jacket, some cosmetics?

title: Re-See | Bodkin
description: New York Fashion Week may be long gone, but for all of those not on the Europe circuit, that means taking a closer look at the collections in the labels showrooms, an appointment better known as re-see. On one such recent visit with Eviana Hartman, the designer behind the eco-conscious label Bodkin, T was thrilled to find that Hartman, now in her fourth season, is expanding into swimwear. I was heading to Mal Pas, Costa Rica, for my first surf trip, says Hartman of her decision to dive into new territory. I couldnt quite find a bathing suit that was me. Her decision was sealed when she stumbled upon a pile of dead-stock gray and mint heather fabric in a Los Angeles warehouse. For now, the swimwear line features only two styles  the two-piece Bodkini and the one-piece twister suit (twisting and knotting is also featured throughout the lively spring/summer clothing collection)  but Hartman is optimistic that it will make a splash with her loyal fan base. If the Bodkin girl isnt already a surfer, she says, she probably wants to be.

title: Rediscovering the First Miracle Drug
description: Every few months some miracle drug or other is rolled out with bells and confetti, but only once or twice in a generation does the real thing come along.

title: How to Stop Rogue Automatic Payments
description: Many of us have at least part of our financial lives on autopilot. Maybe Netflix and your gym automatically bill your credit card each month. Or perhaps youve authorized your credit cards and cable company to pull money directly from your checking account.

title: Phone Carriers Sign On to Bring Service to Subways
description: Cellphone service in the subways: its coming. Eventually. To a few stations. As long as, you know, all goes as planned.

title: Measles Vaccine, 1960
description: The first scientific description of measles dates from the ninth century, and the disease was first mentioned in The New-York Daily Times on Oct. 14, 1851, when the newspaper was not yet one month old.

title: New Show by Stomp Creators Is Canceled
description: The national tour of Pandemonium: The Lost and Found Orchestra, the latest show from the composers Luke Cresswell and Steve McNicholas, the creators of Stomp, has been canceled after fewer than three weeks of performances.

title: Taking Revenge on Borat, Amorous Donkey and All
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Sitting before some editing banks on the second floor of a nightclub here, a Kazakh director named Erkin Rakishev described the weighty task ahead: defending the honor of all Kazakhs by wreaking revenge on the odious movie Borat.

title: UPS Expands Its Hybrid Truck Fleet
description: UPS announced Thursday that it has ordered 130 new diesel hybrid electric delivery trucks to complement its existing fleet of 250 of the vehicles, which are made in two sizes by Freightliner with hybrid drive systems from the Eaton Corporation.

title: In Any Case: Conducting a Mock Trial
description: Overview | What are the main components of a court proceeding? How can holding a mock trial provide insights into curricular material? In this lesson, students learn the key terms associated with the United States court system, then engage with core texts and subjects through the mock trial process.

title: Critics' Picks: Howards End
description: A. O. Scott reviews James Ivory and Ismail Merchant's adaptation of E.M. Forster's novel starring Emma Thompson and Anthony Hopkins.

title: Numberplay: Calculus for the Second Grader
description: 7:40 p.m. | (Updated: Errors Corrected.) Today I want to share with you something that I discovered for myself in my first year of college. It uses math thats so simple that a second grader can do it, and yet it can let you figure out things that you might expect to require calculus. This technique deserves to be better known than it is, so Im doing the first thing that publicists do: giving it a catchy name. Calculus for the Second Grader is only a small exaggeration. Let me show you

title: Cellphone Operator Moves to Expand Beyond Russia
description: MOSCOW  For years, Russian companies have said they have the cash and the ambition to expand well beyond the former Soviet Union.

title: A Sustainable-Food Employment Agency
description: A new Web site for finding jobs in the food business  at the likes of Brooklyn Larder, not Burger King  has launched, goodfoodjobs.com. A national Craiglist for the sustainable set, the site aims to connect job seekers with such diverse employers as Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the Momofuku Restaurant Group, the Monterey Bay Aquarium, and individual farmers.

title: Hazards of Flying: Low Fuel. Ice. Deer.
description: IM a nervous wreck when I fly commercial, which is strange since Im a pilot. I know intellectually that flying is a very safe mode of transportation. Whatever. When Im not the pilot, my life is in someone elses hands.

title: A Specious Species? (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Explorers Best Friends (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheap and Effective (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: In First Marine Census, a Plenitude of Wonders
description: After a decade of research and more than 540 ocean expeditions, scientists presented the world with the first-ever census of marine life on Monday. The census involved the work of 670 institutions and 2,700 researchers and made direct observation of 120,000 marine species, including some 6,000 newly discovered species.

title: Critics Picks: Howards End
description: In this weeks Critics Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at Ismail Merchant and James Ivorys 1992 adaptation of the E. M. Forster novel Howards End. The film stars Emma Thompson and Anthony Hopkins and explores class struggles and relationships in Edwardian England. Among the features Mr. Scott praises are the lovely period clothing, gorgeous cinematography, lavish and historically-appropriate production design and scrupulous fidelity to the literary source.

title: Now Serving | The Taquerias of Colonia Narvarte
description: Mexico City is a well-documented hotbed of contradictions: wealth side by side with poverty, globalization nuzzling indigenous tradition, beheadings alongside leisurely afternoons in lush parks sucking jicama pops. In a city that contains 2,000 official colonias (neighborhoods), even intrepid visitors who come to explore end up sticking to one safe corner of this metropolis. A short taxi ride from the trendy Condesa/Roma area is the colonia Narvarte, a charming middle-class neighborhood where Che Guevara lived while plotting the overthrow of the Batista dictatorship with Fidel Castro. The area is known for its wide avenues with palm-lined camellones (traffic islands) and a somewhat old-fashioned atmosphere, and it also happens to house some of the citys greatest taquerias. Heres where to go.

title: Shift at the Top of Twitter as a Founder Steps Aside
description: Evan Williams, the co-founder and chief executive of Twitter, is stepping down to lead product strategy at the company, Twitter announced on Monday. Dick Costolo, the chief operating officer, will succeed Mr. Williams.

title: Climate Group Regrets Shock Film Tactic (So Does Sony)
description: 6:04 p.m. | Updated There are much more important things to focus on than an utterly misconceived mini movie blowing up kids to recruit carbon cutters, so its welcome that Eugenie Harvey, the director of the 10:10 UK group that commissioned the film, has moved toward closure by issuing a real apology (text below). The rather reluctant regrets note posted on Friday essentially encouraged YouTube visitors to copy and disseminate it by saying, We wont be making any attempt to censor or remove other versions currently in circulation on the internet.

title: Ford to Introduce Focus With an Amazing Race of Sorts
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  Ford announced Monday that it would create a real-time interactive event called Focus Rally: America to help introduce the 2012 Focus compact car, which was scheduled for dealer showrooms early next year.

title: Answers About World War II in New York, Part III
description: Richard Goldstein, an author and historian of the Second World War who was our guest expert on City Room last week, provided the following third and final batch of answers to  readers questions about all aspects of New York and the war. You can find previous installments in this Q & A here.

title: With Tagline, MSNBC Embraces a Political Identity
description: MSNBC, once the also-ran but now the No. 2 cable news channel, has a new tagline that embraces its progressive political identity.

title: Congressional Republicans Start 20-State Ad Blitz
description: Over the weekend, the National Republican Congressional Committee began releasing 27 spots in 20 states, many of which aim to portray Democrats as part of the Washington establishment and link them to the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California.

title: Toiling to Save a Threatened Frog
description: SEQUOIA AND KINGS CANYON NATIONAL PARKS, Calif.  From the summit of Bishop Pass in the Sierra Nevada, elevation 11,972 feet, all you can see are miles of granite peaks against the sky. There is no traffic and no pollution. The natural world seems pure and unspoiled.

title: Accusation Upsets a Province
description: The editors of Macleans, the venerable weekly Canadian magazine, have made provocative covers something of a specialty. But none of their earlier efforts produced quite the same response as an image of Bonhomme Carnaval, the snowman mascot of Quebecs winter festival, jauntily carrying a briefcase overflowing with cash. The bold cover headline on the issue dated Oct. 4 was no more subtle: Quebec: The Most Corrupt Province.

title: Daily Show Correspondent to Marry Iraq War Veteran
description: John Oliver, British comedian of The Daily Show fame, announced that hes engaged to Kate Norley, an Army medic who spent time in Iraq. The couple met in 2008 at the Republican National Convention.

title: Analysts Street-Level View of Citi
description: It is going to take more than a two-hour meeting with Citigroup executives to make a believer out of the financial analyst Michael Mayo, left.

title: Sundance Institute Announces Foreign Venture
description: Sundance is going abroad. As part of an effort to foster crosscultural understanding through cinema, the Sundance Institute said on Monday that it would work with a smattering of other nonprofit arts groups to present 10 independent films in New York and at American embassies and other locations overseas. The program, called Film Forward: Advancing Cultural Dialogue, will consist of five American and five international pictures. (Sundance did not announce any titles but likely candidates are films the organization has heralded in the past, like Winters Bone, about an Ozark womans quest to find her drug-dealing father.)

title: Boozer to Miss 2 Months After Tripping Over Gym Bag
description: Once again, Mom was right: clean up your things before you trip on them.

title: Criticism Flies After State Eases Ban on Art Sales
description: When the New York State Board of Regents met last month to consider making permanent a set of temporary regulations that bar the sale of artwork by museums to cover expenses, approval was widely considered a fait accompli.

title: Ex-Members of Congress Call for Civility
description: Over 100 former members of Congress  many of whom won their own races by pointing out defects in their opponents have written to all members of Congress as well as House and Senate candidates, imploring them to reject excessive partisanship as they enter the home stretch of this highly contentious political season.

title: Readers Find No Consensus on Line-Cutting
description: From Sunday brunch to Shakespeare in the Park, lines are a ubiquitous, frustrating but largely tolerated part of New York life. (This is perhaps why we have our own way of talking about it: on line to the rest of the countrys in line.) Lines are also generally treated as sacrosanct: any effort to cut and head directly to the front is usually met with fiercely righteous wrath from all those who have sacrificed the better part of their day for some scarce, coveted item or experience.

title: H.I.V.: National Institutes of Health Licenses Its Patent on a New Drug for AIDS
description: In a move that gave official American backing to the controversial idea of a patent pool, the National Institutes of Health last week became the first entity to license its patent on a new AIDS drug to an entity loosely affiliated with the World Health Organization.

title: Feingold Ad Says He Fought Insurers
description: In a season when many Democrats are running away from the presidents health care bill  a plan some Republicans having been attacking as Obama care  Senator Russ Feingold of Wisconsin just cut a campaign ad aligning himself with that very topic.

title: Notes From the Underground | CocoRosie
description: When Bianca and Sierra Casady, the sister act known as CocoRosie, recently performed at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, it was a amid an atmosphere of gypsy celebration complete with miscellaneous congratulatory balloons, a massive video projection, several classical musicians, a French beatbox star and a table full of noise-making childrens toys. The duo mostly performed songs from their recent album, Grey Oceans, but were joined intermittently by the performance artist Kembra Pfahler and the poet Rebecca Wright. Brought back to the stage by thunderous applause and the stamping of feet, the Casadys gleefully treated the audience to not one but two encore sets before embarking on the rest of their tour of the United States.

title: Airplane Air Is No Riskier Than Other Enclosed Spaces, Study Says
description: Thousands of flights to Mexico were canceled last year in response to the outbreak of the H1N1 virus there. And the SARS scare in 2003 prompted airports and airlines to adopt emergency measures, among them screening passengers for high fevers as they boarded.

title: The Joker in the Deck: Birth of a Supervillain
description: In comic books, origin stories often involve chance meetings, freak accidents or personal tragedies. Not many of them start on a tennis court in the Poconos. But that is where the career of Jerry Robinson, 88, the man who created the villainous Joker, began.

title: Sweet, Ecstatic, Petulant and in Control
description: Plenty of times on Thursday night it was unclear where Ellie Gouldings squeal stopped and the synthesizers backing her began. At the Hiro Ballroom for her first New York show, she was crowded tightly onstage, flanked by banks of chilly keyboards. But she is no simple machine. A young British singer with a scrappy but pretty voice, she makes music thats a happy car crash of signifiers: part electro-pop, part soul, part blues, part indie rock, part folk. In Britain in the past five years, young female singers  in acts like La Roux, Duffy, Florence and the Machine, and more  have been toying with these styles individually, painting them with shimmering gloss. Ms. Goulding plays all of their games, and well.

title: Debaters Step Into High-Risk Spotlight
description: The Takeway With Michael D. Shear

title: Dance in Review
description: AITANA CORDERO

title: Leafy Carpets of Laughter, Hints of Wartime and a Quirky Coltrane Score
description: Putting together the Fall for Dance festivals five programs cant be easy. There has to be a mix of dance styles, of well-known and unknown names, of length and pace, difficulty and ease. Sometimes it just doesnt work out very well. On Saturday at City Center, the third program seemed ingratiatingly audience-appealing and thin in comparison with some of the vibrant juxtapositions of work that Fall for Dance has presented in the past.

title: Saved, Before Alcoholics Anonymous
description: Of all the old war horses of the American theater, few have been more durable than The Drunkard, W. H. Smiths cautionary tale on the evils of John Barleycorn. The original 1844 staging in Boston was for a temperance crusade and was deadly serious; a 1933 production in Los Angeles was played strictly for laughs and ran more than 20 years. An engaging revival by the Metropolitan Playhouse falls somewhere in between and makes a good case for the pieces being more than a quaint theatrical curio.

title: Catch, Treat, Release
description: Vance Vredenburg, a biology professor at San Francisco State University, is trying to save the Sierra Nevada yellow-legged frog from a deadly fungal disease that has been devastating amphibian populations around the world. In Tuesdays Science Times, Erica Rex reports on Dr. Vredenburgs efforts to inoculate wild frogs with an experimental bacteria treatment in Dusy Basin, in Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks.

title: Training Flights for Bees
description: Q. How are bees able to find their way back to the hive after foraging for pollen?

title: An Unlikely Tony Kushner World Premiere, Courtesy of NYU
description: Virtually every playwright has an unfinished or unresolved script tucked in a drawer somewhere. For Tony Kushner, that play was Henry Box Brown, a one act written in the early 1990s while he was finishing his epic Angels in America, whose two parts went on to win back-to-back Tony Awards for best play in 1993 and 1994.

title: Rajaratnam Takes Stand at Hearing
description: 7:05 p.m. | Updated Almost a year to the day after agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested him on insider-trading charges, the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam took the witness stand at a pretrial hearing in federal district court on Monday, raised his right hand and swore to the tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Somalia, Brussels and Cambodia.

title: Blue Whales With Pearly Whites, Once Upon a Time
description: Blue whales are enormous, magnificent creatures. The largest mammals known to have existed, they can grow to be more than 100 feet in length and weigh more than 100 tons, and they dont even have teeth.

title: Neanderthals Big Loss in Battle of the Elements
description: Homo sapiens may not have pushed Neanderthals to extinction, as some scientists have hypothesized; it may have been the weather that did them in.

title: Dinosaurs Loom Larger After a Study of Limbs
description: As if dinosaurs, some of them anyway, werent big enough, a new study reports that the skeletons we see in museums should be as much as a foot taller than they are now. Dinosaurs, paleontologists write in the journal PLoS One, had thick pieces of cartilage between their joints that increased their height.

title: Potash Deal Report Predicts Loss for Province
description: OTTAWA  The province of Saskatchewan could be hit by substantial revenue losses from a takeover of the Potash Corporation, according to an independent study released by the government on Monday.

title: West 82nd Street, 9:15 A.M.
description: Caption contest! Write your own in the space below.

title: From Heaps of Junk, a Melodious Clang
description: A tall, trim man in chinos and a green checked shirt strode quickly past broken car carcasses, Dumpsters and chunks of unidentified metal.

title: Pieces Twists and Turns Are Literal and Figurative
description: SAN FRANCISCO  I dont hail Oh, Inverted World, a premiere by the choreographer Trey McIntyre for the Smuin Ballet, as any kind of masterpiece, and I dont hail Mr. McIntyre as a genius. But this dance confirms the sense that he is now an important individual voice in ballet choreography. Having seen it once, I wish I could see it again soon, simply to come to terms with the surprises it springs in phrasing and structure.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 4
description: A view of the day in sports, with the Ryder Cup ending in Wales and the Commonwealth Games continuing in New Delhi.

title: Behavior: Losing Fat, as Easily as Closing Your Eyes
description: Trying to get rid of that extra fat? Sleep in.

title: Giles Deacon Joins Emanuel Ungaro
description: Suzy Menkes talks to Giles Deacon about his decision to become the fashion designer for the struggling French fashion house Emanuel Ungaro.

title: Neurofeedback Gains Popularity and Lab Attention
description: You sit in a chair, facing a computer screen, while a clinician sticks electrodes to your scalp with a viscous goop that takes days to wash out of your hair. Wires from the sensors connect to a computer programmed to respond to your brains activity.

title: In Different Hands, an Assortment of Moods
description: The blazing surge to the end of Dvoraks New World Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon was unusually satisfying. Here, as in the whole program, which also offered Brahmss Tragic Overture and Schumanns Cello Concerto, the Vienna Philharmonic was fully in its element after an unusual series of concerts. And encouraged by the young conducting dynamo Gustavo Dudamel, the orchestra played with a kind of gusto that few others can match, those patented string tremolos threatening to spark fire.

title: Send In the Clowns  and the Truth Squad
description: Bozo-gate, anyone?

title: Awareness: Killer of 200,000 Americans, Hardly Noticed
description: Sepsis causes more than 200,000 deaths in the United States each year, yet Americans know little about it: most people questioned online for a new study said they had never heard the term.

title: For NBC, Football Delivers Sunday Night
description: Undercover Boss, 60 Minutes and the season premiere of CSI: Miami lifted CBS to second place in the ratings on Sunday night, trailing only NBC and Sunday Night Football. According to Nielsens estimates, CBSs new installment of Undercover Boss, featuring Kim Schaefer, the chief executive of Great Wolf Resorts, earned the largest nonfootball audience on Sunday with 13.1 million viewers, eking out a victory in the 9 p.m. time slot, ahead of ABCs Desperate Housewives (13 million). CBS began the night in solid fashion as well with 60 Minutes at 7 (12.5 million), followed by The Amazing Race at 8 (10.7 million), while the networks ninth-season debut of CSI: Miami drew 11.8 million at 10. Although final ratings were not expected until Tuesday, preliminary overnight estimates for NBCs Sunday Night Football were higher than those of last weeks game, which drew 18.2 million. Fox and ABC finished in a virtual tie for third place.

title: In Illness, Old Dream Is Realized
description: When I was a boy, I ached to be a scientist. I was the kind of kid who needed to know why and how  right now!  not to mention who, what, where and when.

title: Rail Service Expansion Imperiled at State Level
description: Republicans running for governor in a handful of states could block, or significantly delay, one of President Obamas signature initiatives: his plan to expand the passenger rail system and to develop the nations first bullet-train service.

title: Detroit Musicians Picket Music Center
description: About 60 musicians, many in black concert dress and bolstered by the music of a horn quartet, took to the picket lines outside the Max M. Fisher Music Center in Detroit on Monday as the members of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra went on strike. The picketing players (above, with Karl Pituch on French horn) were to have begun rehearsing for the new seasons first concert. They struck in a dispute with management over the extent of wage cuts and changes sought in work rules at the financially troubled orchestra. The last orchestra strike in Detroit was in 1987.

title: How to Collect Your Verizon Refund
description: If you suspect that you are one of the estimated 15 million Verizon customers to receive credit due to erroneous data charges, you may wonder what you have to do to collect.

title: Augmented Reality: From Baseball Cards to Books
description: In a world of multiple, multi-media diversions, how do you engage kids and keep them reading anything longer than a few lines of a text message? Simon and Schuster, along with the well-known childrens author and illustrator Tony DiTerlizzi, hope theyve found at least a partial answer.

title: Chilean Miners Rescue May Happen Within Weeks, President Says
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The 33 miners trapped nearly half a mile underground in northern Chile may be rescued by Oct. 17, weeks before the governments original predictions, President Sebastin Piera announced in a nationally broadcast radio interview Monday.

title: Rinsing Your Vegetables
description: In todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores the options for rinsing pesticide residue off vegetables.

title: Reinventing the Suitcase by Adding the Wheel
description: MANY thousands of years ago, there were two important inventions, the wheel and the sack. As a traveler, I cant help wondering why it took so long to put rollers on that sack to create wheeled luggage.

title: Sanofi Bid for Genzyme Turns Hostile, and No Sweeter
description: Sanofi-Aventis of France took its $18.5 billion takeover bid for Genzyme hostile on Monday, going directly to Genzymes shareholders in an effort to advance deal negotiations.

title: Teens Are Smarter About Condoms Than Adults Are
description: Teenagers are more responsible about using condoms than adults are, a new study shows.

title: Verizon Comes Clean
description: Last November, I started up one of my patented Pogue Fights for the Consumer campaigns on my blog. I noted that Verizon Wireless was charging $2 a pop every time customers accidentally pressed the up-arrow key on their flip phones  the keystroke that comes hard-wired to mean take me to the Web.

title: Obama Debates Advisers on Tax Cuts
description: President Obama gathered his outside economics advisers at the White House on Monday to talk job training and education but wound up debating the merits of increasing taxes on the wealthy in the middle of a volatile economy.

title: Six New Books for Wine and Spirits Lovers
description: THEY say the book industry is dying, but obviously they must have ignored the piles of new wine and spirits books accumulating on my desk. The business has indeed changed, though. Of the six new-ish books I want to recommend here, two of them are not available in stores, or even at Amazon.com. Self-publishing has moved well beyond vanity works, and now includes some excellent books on wine.

title: Potash Deal Could Be Costly for Canadian Province
description: The province of Saskatchewan could be hit by substantial revenue losses from a takeover of the Potash Corporation, according to an independent study released by the Canadian government on Monday, The New York Timess Ian Austen reports from Ottawa.

title: Weight Classes Aim to Balance Races
description: At 245 pounds and 6 feet 3 inches, Jeffrey West knows he looks more like a football player than a runner. But that hasnt stopped him from competing in nine marathons in the past three years.

title: Synthes to Divest a Subsidiary in Plea Deal Over Spinal Surgeries
description: Synthes, the American subsidiary of a global maker of medical devices, was ordered to divest one of its subsidiaries, Norian, on Monday in what was labeled an unprecedented plea agreement with federal prosecutors.

title: For Giants, a Victory but Not Consistency
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  For the Giants offense, each week has been a process of self-discovery. The picture is not very clear at the quarter pole of the regular season.

title: Climate Video Gets a Thumbs Down From Critics
description: Barely one minute into a short video by 10:10, a British climate advocacy group, two porcelain-skinned middle schoolers named Phillip and Tracy are deliberately blown up by their teacher. Their blood and body parts then scatter across their mates and the classroom in a crimson deluge.

title: Superman Movie Series is Up, Up and Away With a New Director
description: For his next movie, Zack Snyder will once again take to the skies  not with owls, but with one of the most recognizable and enduring heroes in comic books: Superman.

title: The Making of 'Kraft'
description: Lou Mannarino, an audio engineer, finds local sounds in the scrap metal he is using to create instruments for the Magnus Lindberg symphony, "Kraft," for the New York Philharmonic.

title: In Sign of Discord, Iran Blocks Web Sites of Some Clerics
description: TEHRAN, Iran  The web sites of two senior clerics have been blocked by government censors, a possible sign of a hardening political divide at the highest level of Irans religious establishment.

title: Arizona and Its Accidental Governors
description: Arizona has a history of its governors departing early, some out of ambition and others in disgrace. A ballot initiative pushed by an civic group would try to bring order to the chaos of accidental Arizona governors.

title: Apple Challenges Big Award Over Patents
description: Apple is challenging a jury verdict that could force it to pay as much as $625.5 million to a company founded by David Gelernter, a Yale computer science professor, for infringing three patents related to how files are displayed on the iPod, the iPhone and Macintosh computers.

title: Christine O'Donnell's Political Ad
description: Christine O'Donnell, the Republican candidate for the Senate race in Delaware, released her first political ad.

title: Little Ways the M.T.A. Can Ease Riders Pain
description: Barring miracles, and they are in short supply right now, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will vote in a couple of days to raise mass-transit fares. Combined with recent reductions in service, the increases are sure to send New Yorkers straight to the upper reaches of the unhappiness scale.

title: ODonnell Ad Confronts Reports on Her Past
description: Christine ODonnell wants you, the voter, to know that she is not a witch.

title: Greening the Armed Forces
description: The American military, facing increasing insurgent attacks on fuel supply convoys in Pakistan and Afghanistan, is pushing aggressively to develop, test and deploy renewable technologies to decrease its dependence on fossil fuels.

title: 2 E-Books Cost More Than Amazon Hardcovers
description: Readers of e-books may not be able to turn paper pages, lend their copies to friends or file them away on living room bookshelves. But they do have the comfort of knowing that they paid less for them than for hardcovers.

title: Odds Against Third-Party Bid Not as Long as They Seem
description: Thomas Friedmans Sunday column, in which he predicted the emergence of a serious third party candidate in 2012, with a serious political movement behind him or her, is attracting a lot of comment  and criticism  in different parts of the blogosphere.

title: A Marine Life Encyclopedia
description: The first ever census of marine life catalogs nearly 120,000 species, including remarkable creatures like the Christmas tree worm, a hairy crab and several newly discovered species.

title: New Rule for Goalies Short and Tall
description: An N.H.L. rule change in the works for more than two years may do little to stem the long-term decline in scoring, but it will put goaltenders on a level playing field.

title: Toshiba to Offer 3-D TV That Does Not Require Special Glasses
description: CHIBA, Japan  Toshiba, the Japanese electronics maker, said Monday that it would be the first on the market with a TV that displayed images in 3-D without requiring viewers to use special glasses.

title: Coroner Calls for Changes in Luge Training
description: The coroner of British Columbia has ruled that the death of a Georgian luge athlete in a training run before the Vancouver Games was accidental, but he called on the International Luge Federation to do more to prepare athletes to race on unfamiliar tracks and before major competitions.

title: 2 Swiss Banks Facing Higher Capital Standards
description: A Swiss government panel proposed rules on Monday that would require the nations two big banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, to hold more capital in reserve than their international competitors.

title: Removing Blocks to City Bailouts
description: President Gerald Ford refused to help New York in 1975, a rejection immortalized in the headline drop dead.

title: Rushes of Excitement, Sometimes Deserved
description: Paris

title: Its a Tough League for Quarterbacks, as the Giants Proved
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Their Feet May Be Stars in Japan
description: Paris

title: Dealbreaker Sales Talks: A Hot Market for Blogs
description: TechCrunch has done it. PaidContent already did it. Now, it appears Dealbreaker is close to the doing the same.

title: Relatives Tell of Civilians Killed by U.S. Soldiers
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  It was difficult enough for the people of western Kandahar Province. They are beleaguered both by the Taliban, who control the roads, demand taxes and execute anyone suspected of disloyalty, and by the American military, who often show little regard for people and whose demands that locals stand up to the insurgents seem unreasonable.

title: Power Still Off at Twins New Home
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Not much ruffles the aw-shucks manner of Joe Mauer, the Minnesota Twins All-Star catcher and last years American League most valuable player. One subject, however, makes him uncomfortable: how poorly balls travel at Target Field, the Twins new open-air stadium.

title: Turnovers Help Patriots Top Dolphins
description: Chad Henne threw for nearly twice as many yards as Tom Brady. Twice as many touchdowns and 10 more completions, too.

title: In Haiti, Rising Call for Displaced to Go Away
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  As tent camps go, the one on the 28-acre Church of God property overlooking the Valley of Bourdon is almost bucolic, with hundreds of canvas-draped shelters under leafy shade trees and a cohesiveness among residents. But panic is building there.

title: Dolores Wilson, Met Soprano, Dies at 82
description: Dolores Wilson, a Metropolitan Opera soprano of the 1950s who later sang in Broadway musicals, died on Sept. 28 in Englewood, N.J. She was 82 and lived in Englewood.

title: After Growth, Fortunes Turn for Monsanto
description: As recently as late December, Monsanto was named company of the year by Forbes magazine. Last week, the company earned a different accolade from Jim Cramer, the television stock market commentator. This may be the worst stock of 2010, he proclaimed.

title: Paris Accessories: Low Down
description: An eyebrow pencil might be the best accessory for spring, to judge from the makeup at Chlo and Stella McCartney on Monday. The Paris spring shows have given a different direction to accessories than what we saw in Milan. The news here is the flat shoe or low-heeled sandal, often with a metallic element, like the mirrored ankle pieces on Giambattista Vallis low-heeled shoes, which had leopard print or solid color toes.

title: Iraqi Festival Falls Prey to the Forces of Democracy
description: BAGHDAD  Saddam Hussein used to hold the Babylon Festival at the end of Iraqs sweltering summers on the site of the ancient ruins of Hammurabi and Nebuchadnezzar, an hours drive south of the capital. It was agitprop, an annual expression of megalomania and, until the last one in fall 2002, with war already in the air, a forum for railing against the United States.

title: Wilpons First Need to Replace Mind-Set
description: The next day was hanging day the sky was overcast and black  Bob Dylan, Lily, Rosemary and the Jack of Hearts.

title: Afghan Election Official Is Held, Police Say
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After a raft of complaints about fraud in the parliamentary elections in Khost Province, the provincial police arrested the provincial head of the Independent Election Commission on Monday, police officials said.

title: Play-Doh? Calculus? At the Manhattan Free School, Anything Goes
description: The Manhattan Free School in East Harlem is not free, but the principal there practically is. Now in her third year, Pat Werner, a 57-year-old former literacy coach who logged 18 years in New York City public schools, accepted all of $3,000 in salary last year.

title: Paris Fashion Week Accessories
description: The supporting actors in the Paris shows are getting their fair amount of attention on the runways.

title: Antigay Attacks Reported at Stonewall and in Chelsea
description: They are among the bastions of gay pride and culture in New York City: the Stonewall Inn, the Greenwich Village bar where riots against a police raid in 1969 sparked the citys gay rights movement, and Chelsea, the Manhattan neighborhood.

title: In Ads, Democratic Candidates Play Down Party
description: One New York Democrat proclaims that he proudly opposed the federal governments health care overhaul plan. Another one pledges, in the finest Tea Party spirit, to oppose any future financial bailouts. Still another has rolled out three Republicans in three separate commercials, all vouching for his credentials.

title: Breaking Even on A.I.G.
description: I really didnt know what I was walking into, Jim Millstein says about taking one the biggest jobs of his life: unraveling the taxpayers bailout  er, investment  in the American International Group.

title: Young Soldier Both Revered and Reviled
description: BILLINGS, Mont.  Staff Sgt. Calvin Gibbs called to say he did not kill Afghan civilians for the thrill of killing. Nor did he toss severed fingers at the feet of his fellow soldiers to scare them into silence.

title: Literary Criticism Comes to the Movies
description: There are movies based on literary works (Paradise Lost is on the way, I am told), bio-pics about literary greats (Bright Star, The Hours), movies that feature a bit of literary criticism (Animal House, Dead Poets Society, The History Boys), even movies  documentaries  about literary critics (Zizek and Derrida, who are only literary critics occasionally), but no movies I know of about literary criticism as such. None, that is, until Howl, the new movie about Allen Ginsberg starring James Franco, which is not only about literary criticism but is the performance of literary criticism, an extended explication de texte.

title: Cities in Debt Turn to States, Adding Strain
description: Harrisburg, the capital of Pennsylvania, dodged financial disaster last month by getting money from the state to make a payment to its bondholders.

title: 2nd Failed Test Puts Heat on Contador
description: A test new to the antidoping movement was used for the first time at the Tour de France last summer, and now it appears that the three-time Tour winner Alberto Contador  who tested positive for a banned drug at the race  may have more explaining to do.

title: Batters Search for Edge Outside On-Deck Circle
description: On their way to the batters box, major league hitters perform their own individual routines. They rub their bats with pine tar or add weights for practice swings. They stand. They squat. They adjust their equipment or spit into their gloves.

title: Residents of Haiti Tent Camps Face Eviction
description: Almost nine months after the earthquake that devastated Haiti, eviction threats have increased markedly and have become an urgent humanitarian concern, international groups say.

title: Drones Kill Westerners in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  Drone aircraft operated by the Central Intelligence Agency killed several militants with German citizenship in the mountains of Pakistan on Monday, according to Pakistani and American officials.

title: Knicks Leave Hype in Italy for Harder Test in Paris
description: PARIS  The surroundings had changed drastically by the time the Knicks wandered onto the court Monday, and it was not just about the language, the country and the culture. The atmosphere was both lighter and more serious.

title: Giving an Edge to Children of Alumni
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Rediscovers Monets Magic at Grand Palais
description: PARIS  Poor Claude Monet.

title: Jets Smith Does His Job and That of Several Others
description: In nearly three decades of coaching, Mike Westhoff has taught thousands of players with hundreds of different skill sets. He thought he had seen them all. At least until he met Brad Smith.

title: Subway Work on 2nd Avenue Hobbles Stores
description: The noise, dust, barricades and occasional explosions associated with construction of the long-awaited Second Avenue subway are driving away customers from businesses along the avenue and plunging many shops and restaurants into deep financial trouble, two dozen merchants said.

title: Rights Abuses by the F.B.I.: A Look at the History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paladinos Pet Pit Bull Adds Teeth to Campaign
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y.  Duke, an 80-pound pit bull campaigning with Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor, seems to be learning a thing or two from his mad-as-hell master.

title: Yankees-Twins Series Will Pit Two Streaks
description: Two streaks will collide when the Yankees play the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday in Game 1 of their division series. In three previous first-round matchups between the teams, the Yankees have won all five games played in Minneapolis.

title: Lottery Numbers
Skeptical on Holocaust?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ryder Cup Victory a Reflection of European Unity
description: NEWPORT, Wales -- Jos Manuel Barroso, the former Portuguese prime minister who is president of the European Commission, was here for the Ryder Cup opening ceremony last week, expressing his support for the only elite professional team that represents  truly represents  his continent in a major event.

title: Sessions Optimistic About Republican Gains In Memo
description: The expectations game is afoot.

title: Tuesday: Lyric
description: Didnt NO TASTE use to be part of an old beer slogan? No Taste, More Filling. Well, not quite. It might be a good one for oatmeal, however, or maybe even tofu.

title: Comptroller Rivals Debate Wall Street Ties
description: Thomas P. DiNapoli, the New York State comptroller, spent much of his first debate with the Republican challenger, Harry Wilson, denouncing Mr. Wilson as a wizard of Wall Street who could not be trusted to manage the public pension fund or end the corruption that has plagued the office.

title: Anti-Semitism in Sweden
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Military Orders Less Dependence on Fossil Fuels
description: With insurgents increasingly attacking the American fuel supply convoys that lumber across the Khyber Pass into Afghanistan, the military is pushing aggressively to develop, test and deploy renewable energy to decrease its need to transport fossil fuels.

title: Focus as Bomb-Plot Trial Nears End: Were 4 Men Predisposed to Commit a Crime?
description: As he made his final arguments to jurors on Monday, dismissing the idea that four defendants charged with terrorism-related offenses had been entrapped by government agents, a prosecutor displayed a picture that, he said, told the whole story.

title: Bosnians Doubt Vote, and Future, Too
description: PRAGUE  The potential for achieving unity in Bosnia appeared in doubt on Monday after preliminary election results showed deep divisions in the ethnically divided country and election officials said they would investigate accusations of voting fraud.

title: Ousted Mayor Stays in Politics
description: MOSCOW  Yuri M. Luzhkov, the longtime mayor of Moscow who was ousted last week after clashing with his former allies in the Kremlin, says he is not entirely abandoning politics and intends to create an independent political movement to support democracy in Russia.

title: Teaching Water Conservation
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolina Loses in Russia
description: The longtime K.H.L. star Maxim Sushinsky scored twice to help SKA St. Petersburg beat the Carolina Hurricanes in the first game played on Russian soil by an N.H.L. club in 20 years.

title: New Fuel for Local Papers: Medical Marijuana Ads
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  When it hit the streets here last week, the latest issue of ReLeaf, a pullout supplement to The Colorado Springs Independent devoted to medical marijuana, landed with a satisfying thud.

title: Worker Spoke of Jihad, Agency Says
description: WASHINGTON  A New Jersey man accused of joining Al Qaeda in Yemen spoke openly of militant views while working at American nuclear plants, according to a report by the inspector general of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that proposes tightening personnel security rules.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,300 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Missing From Trial: Detainee Statements
description: The current case against Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani could have been bolstered in 2007 when the F.B.I. came to visit him at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Mets Hint at Ticket Price Cut
description: With attendance dropping precipitously for the Mets in 2010, the team is set to announce some kind of pricing incentives for 2011, according to Jeff Wilpon, the chief operating officer.

title: All Eyes on Kagan as Court Opens Its Term
description: WASHINGTON  The beginning of a new term at the Supreme Court can feel like the first day of school. On Monday, when the justices returned to the bench from their summer break, everyone was checking out the new kid.

title: How Not to Fight Colds
description: Charlottesville, Va.

title: Emanuel Into the Fray of Politics in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  It may have been less tense wandering the West Wing.

title: Federal Judge Faces Charges in Drug Case
description: ATLANTA  A longtime federal judge in Georgia was charged Monday with buying cocaine, marijuana and other illegal drugs from a stripper with whom he was having an extramarital affair.

title: Crash Brings Traffic to Halt on Busy Texas Waterway
description: HOUSTON  Oil tankers and cargo ships were lining up in the waters outside the Houston Ship Channel on Monday, as crews with a floating crane worked furiously to repair a damaged 300-foot-tall electrical tower that was blocking entry to one of the countrys largest ports, the Coast Guard said.

title: Recovering Politician, Aspiring ... ?
description: The ickiness factor of Parker Spitzer may subside, but the first glimpse of CNNs latest offering on Monday was hard to watch. Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York and the conservative syndicated columnist Kathleen Parker playfully, almost flirtatiously, discussed the news of the day  Crossfire meets Moonlighting. Last week, Larry King told the duo that they had chemistry  if so, it carries a queasy whiff of sulfur.

title: Avoiding the Party
description: In and around New York, Democrats seldom note in campaign advertisements that they are Democrats, portraying themselves instead as independent-minded opponents of wasteful spending.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Word of the Day | levy
description: levy \le-ve\ verb and noun

title: In Vitro Revelation
description: YESTERDAY, the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to a man who was reviled, in his time, as doing work that was considered the greatest threat to humanity since the atomic bomb. Sweet vindication it must be for Robert Edwards, the British biologist who developed the in vitro fertilization procedure that led to the birth of Louise Brown, the first so-called test-tube baby.

title: The Soft Side
description: By now everyone has an image of Rahm Emanuel. Hes the profanity-spewing political street-fighter. Hes the guy who once sent a dead fish to a political opponent. This past week, Saturday Night Live spoofed him as an abrasive pit bull. On Friday, the White House released Rahm Emanuel back into the wild, Seth Meyers joked during Weekend Update.

title: Cherundolo, U.S. Defender, Has No Plans to Retire
description: For many world-class players, participating in your third World Cup, then returning to your club team for an 11th season and being named captain, would be a fitting denouement to a professional career. But while international stars like Thierry Henry, Carlos Tvez and Nemanja Vidic have announced or hinted at retirement from their national teams, the American defender Steve Cherundolo is playing on with the United States and his Hannover 96 club in the Bundesliga.

title: Thats Where the Money Is
description: Its beyond astonishing to me that John Boehner has a real chance to be speaker of the House of Representatives.

title: What Have They Learned?
description: The six-month federal moratorium on deep-water drilling in the Gulf of Mexico is scheduled to end on Nov. 30. Complaining of job losses, politicians in the gulf and many in industry are demanding that it be lifted now. Senator Mary Landrieu, a Louisiana Democrat, is threatening to block President Obamas nominee for budget director unless drilling is allowed to resume quickly.

title: An Illegal Search, by GPS
description: In a landmark 1967 case, the Supreme Court ruled that evidence from a wiretap on a phone booth was obtained unconstitutionally. Despite the public nature of a phone booth, the tap violated the defendants privacy under the Fourth Amendment. Wherever a man may be, the court explained, he is entitled to know that he will remain free from unreasonable searches and seizures.

title: Confusion Over Secure Communities
description: By 2013, according to an Obama administration plan, everyone in the United States who is arrested and fingerprinted will undergo an immigration check. Suspects names and fingerprints will be run not just through criminal databases but compared against immigration records, too, through a program that is being steadily and rapidly rolled out across the country.

title: Televisa to Buy Stake in Univision
description: 7:28 a.m. | Updated Grupo Televisa, the Mexican television giant, announced on Tuesday that it has agreed to invest $1.2 billion in Univision in exchange for a minimum 5 percent stake and a new content licensing agreement.

title: Wayne Winterrowd
description: Wayne Winterrowd once told me, in an e-mail, that he thought of me when autumn brought pig-killing time around. I was grateful for the thought. And if I ever find myself covering rosebushes with evergreen boughs  while wearing crampons  I will certainly think of Wayne, who reported doing just that a couple of years ago. Like many gardeners around the world, I will be mourning Wayne for a good long time. He died on Sept. 17, age 68, at home in Vermont where he lived with his spouse and co-author, Joe Eck.

title: California: State Furloughs Are Legal, Court Rules
description: In a blow to state worker unions, the State Supreme Court ruled Monday that mandatory furloughs of state employees were legal. In 2009, faced with a $40 billion shortfall in the budget through mid-2010, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger put in place three days a month of mandatory, unpaid furlough for some 200,000 state workers. Employee unions quickly filed multiple lawsuits contending that the governor did not have authority to issue involuntary furloughs. On Monday, the states highest court unanimously upheld the governors legal right to furlough workers through June 30 of this year, saying that the State Legislature had approved such cost-saving measures in last years budget legislation. The ruling comes as legislators and the governor say they have reached an agreement on a budget that is three months overdue, the longest budget impasse in the states history. Until details of the deal are released, which is expected to be Wednesday, it is unclear if this years budget will permit state worker furloughs to continue.

title: Bloggingheads: Taliban Dan
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for Americas Future and William Beutler of The Wikipedian debate a controversial campaign ad.

title: Why the Mets Never Cut Perez or Castillo? No One Asked
description: One of the nagging issues that tormented the Mets for much of the season was what to do with Oliver Perez and Luis Castillo, two players who were rarely used in the second half of the season.

As a jazz singer she seems both familiar and a little recherch.

description: About six months into his job as Treasurys chief restructuring officer for the American International Group, after fearing that he might have stepped into an impossible task, Jim Millstein made a startling assertion to his team: Well probably get all our money back.

title: Greece Presents Austerity Budget for 2011
description: The Greek government, which this year had come under the tutelage of its euro zone partners and the International Monetary Fund after it reached the brink of default, on Monday presented a draft austerity budget for 2011 that promised to raise more tax revenue while ending public-sector salary cuts.

title: Bank of Japan Cuts Rates to as Low as Zero

According to this recent Times article, With the United States midterm elections five weeks away, the Tea Party movement is already the big winner of 2010. What do you know about this group? What is your opinion of it? Would you be interested in joining such a movement? How do you predict it will affect the November elections? Why?

title: A Tale of Many Cities

Seven years later she is a successful photojournalist working in Chechnya with her colleagues Maria Morina and Oksana Yushko, at the newly formed Verso Images collective.
