description: An appeals court dropped spying charges against Hossein Rassam, an Iranian employee of the British Embassy in Tehran who had been sentenced last year to four years in prison after protests broke out over the countrys disputed elections, the mans lawyer told Agence-France Presse on Monday. The lawyer said that because Mr. Rassam had no previous record and held no managerial posts, his sentence was suspended on the condition that he not work for foreign embassies or have ties to political groups for five years. The embassy had called the sentence an attack against the entire diplomatic community in Iran.

title: Spain: DNA Tests Shatter One Mans Dream of Nobility
description: DNA tests have shown that Jos Collado, an orphaned trumpeter from Marbella who has been fighting a 10-year legal battle to be recognized as the rightful heir to the de Larios family fortune, is not the son of the fourth Marquis de Larios, Mr. Collados lawyer, Jos Ortiz, said Tuesday.

title: New York Missed or Ignored Signs on Girl Who Died
description: A 4-year-old Brooklyn girl who weighed 18 pounds when she died in September appears to have gone months without a visit from child welfare workers assigned to monitor her well-being, despite indications that she could be at risk, New Yorks child welfare agency revealed on Tuesday.

title: Breakout Players of the First Quarter of the Season
description: After the first four weeks of the N.F.L season, its time to reorient ourselves from what we thought we knew to what actually happened on the field. Heres a look at some of the surprising players and key statistics.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Fate of Missing Balloonists Clouds Joy at U.S. Festival
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Two accomplished balloonists from the United States recently set out from Bristol, England, with hopes of winning the worlds most prestigious balloon competition. Four days later, they vanished over the Adriatic Sea in stormy weather. No signs of the pilots or their balloon have turned up, and the Italian Coast Guard has called off its search efforts.

title: Florida Lawmaker Is a Proud Firebrand
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Calling voters on behalf of Alan Grayson, the Florida congressman and Democratic firebrand, can require the finer arts of persuasion.

title: Dome-Field Disadvantage Disappears With New Ground Rules
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  When the Minnesota Twins Jason Kubel hit a pop-up against the Tampa Bay Rays on Aug. 5, no one thought it would carry all the way into the postseason.

title: Wednesday: Basslike
description: Although I spent a couple of high school summers working on a cattle farm in New Jersey (I handled the haying chores, collecting the bales, getting them to the barn and stacking them to the rafters), I never dabbled in the fine art of COW TIPPING. Instead of researching the subject, and offering a suburban slickers take on it, perhaps someone here can enlighten us as to this Mischevious rural pastime.

title: Risks and Advantages in U.S. Effort in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama reopened face-to-face talks between the Israelis and Palestinians last month, he pledged that his administration would hold their hands but warned, The United States cannot impose an agreement, and we cannot want it more than the parties themselves.

title: A Sunny Urban Vision of Traveling Underground
description: They dont come much more cheery than In Transit, the optimism-oozing, a cappella musical that opened on Tuesday night at the 59E59 Street Theaters. Though the show is set mostly on grimy subways and populated by beleaguered characters, rarely a minute goes by onstage without a twinkling eye or a toothy smile. Its a testament to the companys pluck that youll smile widely too, even as your inner cynic tells you that its all being laid on a bit thick.

title: Archdiocese to Release List of Schools It May Close
description: By early November, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York plans to release a list of parochial schools that may have to close as part of its plan to cut deficits and resuscitate its faltering grade-school system, church officials said Tuesday.

title: In Hartford, Fiery Exchanges in a Debate for Governor
description: HARTFORD  Displaying an aggressive style befitting his previous life as a Brooklyn prosecutor, Dannel P. Malloy, the Democratic nominee for governor of Connecticut, relentlessly attacked his Republican opponent, Thomas C. Foley, in a debate on Tuesday night over his work in private business and his positions on education, government and other crucial issues.

title: Obama Strains to Get Liberals Back Into Fold Ahead of Vote
description: WASHINGTON  With four weeks until Congressional elections that will shape the remainder of his term, President Obama is increasingly focused on generating enthusiasm within the base that helped put him in the White House two years ago, from college students to African-Americans.

title: Clean and Open American Elections
description: For at least 44 years, it has been illegal for foreign corporations, countries and individuals to make political contributions in the United States for any election, either directly or indirectly. It is even against the law to solicit such contributions. But in this Wild West year of political money, that longstanding ban is being set aside. The United States Chamber of Commerce  one of the biggest advertisers in midterm races around the country  is actively soliciting foreign money, and government enforcers seem to be doing nothing to stop it.

title: Verizon Wireless Says Oops
description: The big phone companies have been campaigning to convince Congress that attempts by the Federal Communications Commission to regulate Internet access like it regulates phones are a costly intrusion that will slow online investment and hamstring progress. And then  oops!  one of the big phone companies reminds us why they should not be allowed to discipline themselves.

title: At Flagging Tribune, Tales of a Bankrupt Culture
description: In January 2008, soon after the venerable Tribune Company was sold for $8.2 billion, Randy Michaels, a new top executive, ran into several other senior colleagues at the InterContinental Hotel next to the Tribune Tower in Chicago.

title: Amherst President Is Expected to Lead New York Public Library
description: At a time when the digital revolution has cast the traditional mission of libraries into question, the New York Public Library is expected to name Anthony W. Marx, the president of Amherst College, as its new president on Wednesday. He would replace Paul LeClerc, who is to retire next year.

title: Civil Justice, Military Injustice
description: Supporters of the tribunals at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who insist military justice, not the federal courts, is the best way to deal with terrorists, should pay close attention to Tuesdays events in a United States District Court in Manhattan. Faisal Shahzad was sentenced to life imprisonment, five months and four days after he tried to blow up his car in Times Square.

title: Lottery Numbers
Yankees Use 3-Pitcher Rotation for Playoffs
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Assembling a 25-man roster for a postseason series is sort of like raiding the supermarket before an approaching snowstorm. You stock up on the staples, but also some cookie dough, a jar of pickles and two boxes of saltines. You might not eat them, but you might be glad they are there  just in case.

title: Cleaner Cars
description: President Obama announced last year the first big increase in fuel economy standards in three decades, plus a new requirement reducing tailpipe emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas.

title: Reds Flamethrower Seems to Be Pushing Limits of Pitching
description: PHILADELPHIA  Jamie Moyer unzipped a small bag at his locker in the Philadelphia Phillies clubhouse on Tuesday. Tucked among the personal notebooks and photographs, he found a weathered envelope, torn on the side. It held a copy of his original scouting report from 1984.

title: Making Pit Stops in Charlotte
description: I know that Nascar is awesome in the same way I know that cricket and Tolstoy novels and contemporary dance are awesome. I personally cant see the appeal, but enough reasonable people disagree with me that I believe in their awesomeness.

title: Onward Christian Moguls
description: WASHINGTON

title: Court Hears Evidence in Saudi Princes Murder Trial
description: SAUDI ARABIA: LONDON

title: Credit for the Recovery
description: EVERY time the United States suffers a recession, trendspotters hasten to identify signs of frugality, extol the rediscovery of thrift and find evidence that Americans are finally (finally!) kicking their demon debt habit. We crack open history books to locate the anti-debt impulse in pre-revolutionary America and troll through quotation collections for ammunition. Ive been around long enough to go through this exercise twice  first in the early 1990s and then in 2001 after the dot-com bust. Here we go again.

title: A Plot Twist at Univision
description: The private equity owners of Univision have scripted a twist worthy of a telenovela.

title: Georgia: Man Sues to Stay in Theater
description: A man who lives in one of Atlantas famous cultural landmarks, the Fox Theater, is suing his landlords for the right to remain there. The theaters board of directors voted in August to change a housing contract for the man, Joe Patten, 83, citing his deteriorating health. He lives in a rent-free apartment as a reward for his role in saving the building from demolition in the 1970s. In a statement, the theater promised that Mr. Patten could stay in the apartment as long as he is able, but not necessarily for life, as the original contract guaranteed.

title: Le Bernardin Gets a 29 in Zagat
description: There is a rarity in the 2011 Zagat New York City Restaurants guide: a restaurant that scored an unconditional 29 for food. The happy recipient of that rating, which had not been bestowed since the original Bouley got it in 1996, is Le Bernardin, a restaurant that has been at or near the top of the rankings since it opened nearly a quarter century ago.

title: Phys Ed: Free the Free Radicals
description: Were all used to hearing that everything we once thought was good for us is not. But even within that framework, the latest science about antioxidants, free radicals and exercise is telling. As many of us have heard, free radicals are molecules created by the breakdown of oxygen during metabolism. Each of us constantly creates free radicals simply by living and breathing. But these molecules are highly reactive and capricious, sometimes attacking other cells and damaging tissue. Wilding free radicals have been linked with a number of diseases and with aging. Exercise, because it requires increased oxygen consumption, also increases the production of free radicals. So, many experts began urging the fitness-minded to pop large doses of antioxidant vitamin supplements, like vitamins C and E, to counteract the presumed damaging effects of the free radicals. Food alone would not supply sufficient levels of the necessary antioxidants, it was thought. The exercising body needed help from vitamins.

title: Dim Outlook for Holiday Jobs
description: As the economy sputters, prospects are dimming for unemployed workers who were banking on a seasonal retail job to carry them through the holidays.

title: Word of the Day | impassive
description: impassive \()im-pa-siv\ adjective

title: Timeless: Babe Ruths Uniform Number
description: On June 13, 1948, the 25th anniversary of the opening of Yankee Stadium, Babe Ruth stood alone at home plate acknowledging the cheers of thousands in a ceremony retiring his number. Nat Fein, a photographer for The New York Herald-Tribune, took a big chance. He didnt line up with the other photographers along the first-base line or alongside the Life magazine photographer Ralph Morse, who took the shot from somewhere near the pitchers mound. Instead, he stood behind Ruth, capturing the stadium and teammates in the same frame. He said of that day: The Number 3 was the thing I was interested in. I felt the only way to tell the story of Babe retiring was from the back.

title: Norman Wisdom, Funnyman, Dies at 95
description: Norman Wisdom, one of Britains best-loved cinematic clowns, who also earned a Tony nomination on Broadway, died on Monday on the Isle of Man. He was 95 and had continued performing until he was 90.

title: Andy Albeck Is Dead at 89; Headed United Artists
description: Andy Albeck, a movie executive whose three turbulent years as president and chief executive of United Artists included the release of both Raging Bull, the Martin Scorsese boxing drama that is often cited as one of Hollywoods finest achievements, and Heavens Gate, the extravagant western directed by Michael Cimino that was one of its most celebrated flops, died on Sept. 29 in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: U.S. Apologizes as Attacks in Pakistan Continue
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Dozens of tanker trucks carrying fuel to Afghanistan for NATO troops were torched near Quetta in western Pakistan on Wednesday, the third major attack on supplies since Pakistan closed a border crossing to Afghanistan a week ago and the first at the only checkpoint that remained open.

title: How Would You Do in a Free School?

Teachers there believe that students learn best when they direct their own education, so though there are classes, students can play video games all day if they like. Would you want to attend a school like this? If not, why not? If so, what do you think you would do with your time? Do you agree that you learn best when you direct your own education? Why or why not?

title: Monetary Versus Fiscal
description: Karl Smith has his own version of the models people are using to think about this crisis. I dont have much disagreement, except that I would group the various non-Keynesian models together as all various attempts to see this as a supply problem: the mishmash mismatch theory is basically a particular form of real business cycle theory, with a particular form of real shock, and recalculation, as far as I understand it, can generate unemployment only via mismatch, so its a subset of a subset. And I see all of these views as refuted by actual experience with interest rates and inflation.

title: Businesses Seek Clarity on Climate Goals
description: In the run-up to the Cancn climate change conference that opens late next month in Mexico, a sizable group of business leaders are fighting to make their voices heard. But this time, it is not to argue that a low-carbon economy is bad for business, they say. The opposite, in fact.

title: Glee': Youve Got to Have Faith (Unless You Dont Want To)
description: This blog got into unexpectedly hot water last week with its unqualified enthusiasm for the Britney/Brittany episode of Glee, and its with some reluctance we have to say that this weeks installment was not one of our all-time favorites. (Your mileage may vary, of course.) The premise was promising and, for network television, potentially provocative: Finns discovery of what he believes is the face of Jesus on a grilled cheese sandwich leads to an exploration of his faith and the religious beliefs of his glee-choir colleagues.

title: The 36-Hour Dinner Party
description: HERES THE CONCEIT: Build a single wood fire and, over the course of 30-plus hours, use it to roast, braise, bake, simmer and grill as many different dishes as possible  for lunch, dinner, breakfast and lunch again. The main ingredients: one whole goat from the McCormack Ranch in Rio Vista, Calif.; several crates of seasonal produce (and a case of olive oil) from Hudson Ranch in Napa; a basket of morels and porcini gathered near Mount Shasta; an assortment of spices from Boulettes Larder in San Francisco; and a couple of cases of wine from Kermit Lynch in Berkeley. The setting: a shady backyard in Napa (but picture suburban subdivision, not vineyard estate), where a big country table stretches out beneath the canopy of a mulberry tree. The cast: three accomplished Bay Area chefs (Mike and Jenny Emanuel  whose kitchen and backyard weve commandeered for the weekend  and Melissa Fernandez), one gifted baker (Chad Robertson), one jack of all culinary trades (Anthony Tassinello) and two amateurs (me and my 17-year-old son, Isaac). The guests: all of the above, plus a rotating crew of spouses, children, friends and neighbors. The fire: almond, oak and mulberry logs burning in a cob oven that Mike Emanuel built with the help of some friends in 2006. A cob, or earth, oven is a primitive, domed cooking device that can be made from layers of mud, clay, straw, stucco, even manure; the earthy mixture, the cob, can endure much higher heat, and hold it much longer, than an indoor oven can. Emanuels incarnation, which he built to bring together family and friends for extended feasts, stands 5 feet tall with a 30-inch hearth and looks like a cartoon character: a visitor from a planet of chubby, eyeless, big-mouthed monsters.

title: Railing Against Rail
description: Jonathan Cohn points out the curious opposition of Republicans to any improvement in our woefully inadequate rail system. As he suggests, this opposition goes beyond issues of cost; theres something visceral about it. What would Dagny Taggart say?

description: Prada, the Italian owner of the eponymous fashion label, is studying an initial public offering in Hong Kong for the first half of 2011, three people familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

title: Q. & A. With Ron Darling
description: Ron Darling won 136 major league games, including 99 for the Mets. He also started seven postseason games, including four in the Mets 1986 championship season. Last year he wrote Complete Game, an inside look at pitching in the major leagues. Darling, 50, is an analyst for the Mets during the regular season, and he will be part of TBSs postseason coverage team with Ernie Johnson and John Smoltz for the American League division series between the Yankees and the Twins. He will also cover the A.L. Championship Series.

DB Burkeman, a 40-something ex-rave D.J. and music industry A&R man, has amassed an impressive trove and brings them together in Stickers: From Punk Rock To Contemporary Art ($35; Rizzoli). title: Understanding and Misunderstanding the Enthusiasm Gap
description: I was an early adopter of the term enthusiasm gap in the context of this years elections, having first applied it in August 2009  a summer of town-hall protests and Tea Party rallies  to describe polling numbers for Democrats in Virginia and New Jersey, which were to vote for governor that year. Those polls suggested that there had been a significant shift in the electorate from the one that gave Democrats their majorities in 2006 and 2008.

description: With the Chevrolet Camaro and Ford Mustang dominating pony-car news in recent months, Chrysler had to pump up the Dodge Challengers macho image. Last week, Chrysler announced it would be putting the Dodge Vipers mammoth 8.4-liter V-10 into a limited production 2011 Mopar Challenger Drag Pak model.

title: New York Philharmonic Adds Concert After Foreign Cancellation
description: The New York Philharmonic will add a concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Oct. 19 to plug a hole caused by the cancellation of a visit to the Republic of Georgia. The orchestra and its music director, Alan Gilbert, will tack on another performance of the program being presented Oct. 14-16, which consists of Brahmss Symphony No. 4 and Violin Concerto (with Pinchas Zukerman as soloist), and Weberns Passacaglia (Op. 1). Brahmss Academic Festival Overture will replace the Webern work in the Oct. 19 concert. The visit to Georgia was to have been the first stop on a European tour but was canceled by Georgias government because of what it called money problems.

title: Jurassic Park Star Takes a Bite Out of Hobbit Labor Fight
description: He has tangled with cold-blooded creatures in the Jurassic Park movies and played both a man of the cloth (on The Tudors) and the spawn of Satan (in the Omen sequel you probably never saw), so maybe Sam Neill has the ideal qualifications to settle a long-running labor dispute that has plagued the planned film adaptation of The Hobbit?

title: Keeping Score: Rays Score Runs With Their Eyes and Feet
description: As the Rangers and Rays series gets under way on Wednesday, you should not be surprised if a Rangers pitcher throws a low-hit gem at some point during the series. The Rays had five games this season when the opposing pitching staffs allowed one or no hits. This includes the May 9 perfect game by the As Dallas Braden and the June 25 no-hitter by the Diamondbacks Edwin Jackson. Add in the three one-hitters thrown at the Rays by Cleveland, Toronto and Boston, and the Rays had the most low-hit games in a single season since 1920 with five.

title: Paris Picks | The Marais Invasion
description: For a long time now, the Haut Marais has attracted indie boutiques and avant-garde designers. More and more, theyre foreign-born. The American modernist Jack Henry made his home at 25, rue Charlot, which is just down the street from Plagg, Barbara Kurdziels shop devoted to Scandinavian fashion, which is just down the street from the Korean designer Moon Young Hees whimsical atelier. And just around the corner on rue Vieille du Temple, the New York design collective Surface to Air opened its new flagship featuring edgy-urbane mens and womens fashion. Foreign flair is suddenly everywhere, and for a city thats infamous for resisting change, its a welcome infusion.

title: When a College Visits Your High School
description: Like salesmen making the rounds, admissions officers from selective colleges spend much of October on the road, pitching their wares to high school students and hoping theyll buy, or at least apply.

title: Polanski Resurfaces at Paris Events
description: Roman Polanski, who was freed from house arrest in Switzerland in July after officials there rejected an extradition request from the United States, is stepping out in public to a round of French cultural events, from a movie museum display to a new Monet exhibition.

title: Vikings Gamble on Moss, Helping Patriots
description: In New England, Bill Belichick wished Randy Moss good luck on the rest of his Hall of Fame receiving career. But it was another part of Belichicks statement  in which the Patriots announced the stunning trade of Moss to the Minnesota Vikings on Wednesday  that offered a more subtle window into how the Patriots felt about Moss.

title: City Has Become Less Deadly for Workers
description: Working in New York City was less dangerous last year than at any time in nearly two decades  unless you were a cabdriver  the federal Labor Department said on Wednesday.

title: Letters: Kafkas Last Trial
description: Elif Batuman does a magnificent job of guiding us through the labyrinthine world of Kafkas literary estate (or what remains of it among the papers of his longtime executor and friend Max Brod) and the highly contentious, occasionally absurd battle to win possession over it. As someone who has conducted research both at the National Library of Israel and at the German Literature Archive in Marbach  the two institutions vying to gain possession of Brods papers  I can see certain advantages in each. Yet to my mind one key difference, the critical edge that Marbach holds over Jerusalem, is not so much the state-of-the-art research facility that Marbach is, but rather that its holdings include under one roof the manuscripts of the greatest modern writers and poets of the German language, Jew and gentile alike. It would seem, given Kafkas universal appeal and his ardent international following among readers and scholars, that this is the most prudent choice.

title: Letters: The Great Connecticut-Country-Club Crackup
description: Matt Bai describes a speech by the Republican Linda McMahon as amazing for its amalgamation of clichs and a complete, almost defiant, lack of substance. He quotes a former governor saying No when asked whether she knew what she was talking about. The few positive things Bai writes about her are oddly tinged: She laughs easily and warmly, with the sense of humor of a woman who had no problem pretending to violently feud with her husband in front of a national television audience.

title: Behind the Scenes of Merrills Downfall
description: Oct. 15, 2010, 3:35 p.m. | Updated The faltering of Merrill Lynch, and its subsequent firesale to Bank of America, remains one of the most classically tragic stories of the financial crisis.

title: On Our Radar: Brazils Green Candidate Gets 20%
description: Marina Silva, the Green Party of Brazils presidential candidate, captures nearly 20 percent of the vote in the first round of balloting. The result was a green tsunami, declared the O Dia newspaper in Rio de Janeiro, where Ms. Silva garnered 32 percent of the vote. Marina Silvas face will not be on the ballot on Oct. 31, but her electoral ghost will decide the second round, the newspaper says. [The Guardian]

title: Diva Franco
description: Is there anything James Franco cant do? The multihyphenates multihyphenate, whose latest offerings include a starring turn as Allen Ginsberg in the movie Howl and Palo Alto (Scribner), a collection of short stories being released on Oct. 19, appears in drag on the cover of the fall issue of Candy magazine. Billed as the worlds first transversal style magazine, the ambisexual publication plays limbo with the markers of gender and high-fashion and is the brainchild of Luis Venegas, the Madrid-based publisher of the cult magazines Fanzine 137 and Electric Youth. In addition to Mr. Francos fashion shoot with the photographer Terry Richardson, the new issue of Candy features a photo spread of Mr. Venegas impersonating Vogue editor in chief, Anna Wintour. Divino!

title: For Dusty Baker, Too Many Perilous Postseasons
description: Philadelphia

title: Shifting Tides in Governors Races: Brown Now 3-to-1 Favorite
description: Jerry Brown is now a 75 percent favorite to become the next governor of California, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecasting model, after accusations circulated widely that his Republican opponent, Meg Whitman, knowingly employed an illegal immigrant as her housekeeper. Last week, Mr. Brown was a 60 percent favorite, and two weeks ago, he was the underdog in the race.

title: This Is Such a Pity: Man Will Pay Weezer to Break Up
description: Its not uncommon to see grass-roots Web campaigns meant to create opportunities and bring people together  like, say, Betty White and Saturday Night Live. But one disgruntled music listener who says he is acting on behalf of Weezer fans everywhere has started an online movement to persuade that band to break up.

title: Report Slams Administration for Underestimating Gulf Spill
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration failed to act upon or fully inform the public of its own worst-case estimates of the amount of oil gushing from the blown-out BP well, slowing response efforts and keeping the American people in the dark for weeks about the size of the disaster, according to preliminary reports from the presidential commission investigating the accident.

title: Smart Taps Nissan for New Compact Car
description: In a bid to compete beyond the microcar segment it helped create, Smart USA announced on Wednesday that it had reached a memorandum of understanding with the Nissan Motor Company to develop a 4-door hatchback for Smarts United States model line. The as-yet-unnamed vehicle is scheduled to go on sale late next year.

title: Spending on Campaign TV Ads Expected to Break Record
description: How many television commercials can $3 billion buy?

title: Owners of Red Sox to Buy Liverpool Soccer Club
description: New England Sports Ventures, owners of the Boston Red Sox, agreed on Wednesday to pay 300 million, or about $476 million, for Liverpool F.C., the storied English soccer club that has faced months of uncertainty about its ownership and finances.

title: Chinese Company Pleads Guilty in Growth-Hormone Case
description: Updated: GeneScience Pharmaceutical, a Chinese drug company, and its chief executive have agreed to plead guilty today to charges of illegally distributing human growth hormones in the United States, according to filings in United States District Court in Rhode Island.

title: What Were Reading: Misunderstanding Lehman
Rocking Crew
description: We loved last weeks J. Crews music video with the Rassle, in which the four members go from hip rockers into dapper dudes. The second video teaches us the tools of the trade in a modern-day style guide that captures the antics of the lead singer, Blair Van Nort, and the drummer, Erik Ratensperger, as they walk us through the differences between the lean silhouette of the perennially popular Ludlow suit and the more traditionally proportioned Aldridge style. We were looking for a way to bring the suits to life, says Jack OConnor, mens style director for J. Crew, and what cooler way than on the Rassle performing outside the Liquor Store in the suits. Even cooler, there is a link to download the bands latest EP for free.

title: Agency Seeks to Tighten Rules for Green Labeling
description: Manufacturers of products that claim to be environmentally friendly will face tighter rules on how they are advertised to consumers under changes proposed Wednesday by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: China Poised to Lead World in Patent Filings
description: 1:02 p.m. | Updated

title: Citigroup Sells Credit Card Portfolio
description: Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague, reports:

title: Falling Incomes, Fine Dining and People on Foot
description: For about a decade now, there have been those who scour the streets in search of signs  muggings, subway graffiti, trash-strewn sidewalks untended by any business-improvement district  that the citys bad old times were returning. So far at least, this has not happened, despite the recession. Even the squeegee men have not returned, though there are a few like David Morales in East Harlem who never stopped plying their trade.

title: Scorecard | Yves Saint Laurent Wins!
description: It makes sense that YSLs return to its masculin-fminin thing would score as we near the end of our four-week international fashion appreciation tour, becauseScorecard is hard pressed to name more than a handful of shows this season that werent, for better or for worse, an homageto the man who first gave women the pants to wear, Monsieur Saint Laurent. But if Stella McCartney didnt want to cast such a long glance back, she might just have looked to Stefano Pilatis spring 2010 collection  because we know the current designer for the house learned then that garden-variety prints dont get you the win.

title: Introducing Dashboard: This Week in Small Business
description: Since 1994, Ive been running my own small business (its a consulting firm that helps clients with customer relationship management). In the early years, the best way to get information was by reading a few self-help business books and visiting a couple of Web sites once in a while. Now it seems as if there are a million Web sites and books and experts all trying to tell me how to succeed. And another million bloggers and pundits interpreting the daily political, economic and cultural news and events that affect my company.

title: TimesCast | October 6, 2010
description: How Florida's Senate race is playing on the national and local scales and Brian Stelter and David Carr on the Google's foray into television.

title: Upside-Down Improv
description: After baking Upside-Down Apple Caramel muffins last week, I started ruminating about upside-down cakes in general, and Ive since become convinced that upside-down cakes may well be the ideal method for combining cake with fresh fruit.

title: Waiting for Super Principals
description: Gail Collins: David, the White House has named this an education week. Its actually been a kind of education year, what with all the controversy over the new documentary Waiting for Superman, and Obamas big Race to the Top initiative.

title: Looking to a Sneaker for a Bands Big Break
description: RIGHT now it is just a shell, the peeling remnant of an old dry cleaner on a graffiti-covered block in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. But soon the 5,200-square-foot space will be transformed into a sleek new recording studio in the heart of the underground-rock capital. And in the latest twist in pops relationship with Madison Avenue, the struggling bands making music there will already be encountering corporate America: the studio is being built by Converse, which will let them record free.

title: TimesCast: The Florida Senate Race
description: The latest edition of TimesCast looks at the Florida Senate race, and analyzes why this election in the Sunshine State attracts so much attention nationally.

title: Welcome Back to Chicago, Rahm
description: Joe Trippi would like to welcome Rahm Emanuel back to the wild, wild Midwest.

title: From Grand New Party to the Tea Party
description: Dave Weigel has a piece up in which he talks to yours truly, Reihan Salam, and David Frum  all charter members of the Republican Party needs a new policy agenda chorus  about why the G.O.P. seems to be making a big comeback despite adopting just about none of our policy suggestions. Im quoted in the piece, but I think its worth making two quick points to clarify my views on the subject.

title: Tennessee Firefighters Watch Home Burn
description: A bizarre incident last week in Tennessee, in which firefighters watched a familys home burn to the ground because they had forgotten to pay a $75 annual subscription fee, has led to a debate about the limits of libertarian visions of limited government.

title: Woman Missing for 10 Days Is Found Dead, Steps From a Police Building
description: The body of a pregnant woman who had been missing for more than a week was found in the Bronx on Tuesday night, in a vehicle that was parked within 100 feet of a building used by the Police Department.

title: Vanguard Cuts Mutual Fund Fees For Some Investors
description: Vanguard is effectively cutting its fees on certain mutual funds by allowing a wider swath of investors to invest in its Admiral shares, which carry lower expenses.

title: Monsantos Income Fell by Nearly Half for Year
description: Executives of Monsanto told skittish investors on Wednesday that earnings per share would grow 13 to 17 percent in the next fiscal year and that the company was on its way to fixing problems in its seed business that have undermined the confidence of Wall Street.

title: Model-Morphosis | Alexander McQueen
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Sigrid Agren from Elite Model Management before (left) and after (right) makeup by Peter Philips and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: When Did the Trade Deficit Start Falling?
description: Continuing our discussion of the renminbi, Dean Baker responds to Derek Scissorss post. Mr. Bakers full post, including a graph, is on Seeking Alpha. Here is an excerpt:

title: Gates Foundation Backs ABC News Project
description: ABC News has entered into an unusual financial agreement with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to back a yearlong project investigating global health problems and their potential solutions.

title: Multiple Realities, Multiple Exposures
description: Justin Maxon was born in California in 1983 and attended San Francisco State University. In 2007, at 24, Mr. Maxon won first prize in the World Press Photo Daily Life category. Two years later, in 2009, PDN called him one of 30 emerging photographers.

title: Quote Unquote | Kanye Calling
description: Kanye West name drops models in his latest song Christian Dior Denim Flow. Would Abbey Lee take Amber Roses sloppy seconds?

title: Elsewhere: Recession Lexicon
description: Brad Tuttle provided readers of Time with a splendid array of recession-era words and phrases. Examples include:

title: BMW Reveals Big New 6-Cylinder Touring Bike
description: BURBANK, Calif.  BMW took the cover off a new touring motorcycle, the K1600 GTL, here Tuesday night at an event held inside a garage that houses entertainer Jay Lenos vast collection of vehicles. The actor Harrison Ford, an avid BMW rider, stopped by to join Mr. Leno for the occasion.

title: Panel Recommends Up to $100 Million for Arts Center at Ground Zero
description: A committee of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation on Wednesday recommended that the corporation allocate up to $100 million for the performing arts center planned for ground zero. The money would come from a pool of some $200 million formerly designated for utility companies. At the corporations Wednesday board meeting, Kate D. Levin, the New York City cultural affairs commissioner, said the money was important to fulfill this critical part of the master plan.

title: Budget Ax Falls on Childrens Mental Health Program
description: For four years, University Settlement, a 124-year-old nonprofit agency that serves immigrants on the Lower East Side, has offered a highly specialized mental health program geared to children under 5.

title: Welcome, Ive Cleaned a Step for You
description: IT may be Brooklyns most televised stoop since the Huxtables. Claire Danes, Hilary Swank and Andy Garcia have sat there. So have Ashanti, Ray Davies and Pete Wentz.

title: Equity Researchs Passage to India
description: Heather Timmons, a DealBook colleague, reports from New Delhi:

title: Which Teams Have the Traits of a Champion?
description: Carlton Chin, a fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method. They have previously written about the N.B.A. finals, the N.F.L. playoffs, and the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Fill-In | Halloween on Discount
A Warm and Cozy Show Set for Park Avenue Armory
description: The Park Avenue Armory, as the venue for the Winter Antiques Show, has seen its share of American quilts. But it has never seen an extravaganza quite like what the American Folk Art Museum will bring to the 55,000-square-foot Drill Hall from March 25 to 30. The museum will present an exhibition of more than 650 red and white American quilts, owned by the New York collector Joanna Rose. In announcing the exhibition, which will be free to the public, the museums executive director, Maria Ann Conelli, described it as an effort to reach new audiences. Ms. Rose and her husband, Daniel, are covering the costs of the presentation and also donating 50 quilts to the museum.

title: Yankees Change, but Postseason Focus Doesnt
description: Minneapolis

title: British Leader Vows End to Heavy-Handed State
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  As the government prepares to drastically scale back its operations with steep across-the-board budget cuts, Prime Minister David Cameron on Wednesday used the occasion of the annual Conservative Party conference here to make an earnest, impassioned call for a fundamental change in the relationship between the state and the people.

title: Finding Team Success With a Little Less Strain
description: I am willing to bet that every retiring youth coach utters prayers of thanks for experiencing the last of three things: the am I going in? screamfests, the losses to the team coached by a Bobby Knight disciple and, finally, the questions from parents about why their child played 30 seconds fewer than another player.

title: Graphic Content | Milton Glaser, Still Questioning
description: At 81, Milton Glaser is still creating significant design at full capacity, which is demonstrated in the exhibition In Search of the Miraculous or One Thing Leads to Another, on view through Nov. 24 at the AIGA National Design Center in New York. Glaser told me that the show is his last hurrah, but I dont believe him.

title: One on One: Caterina Fake, Flickr and Hunch
description: Caterina Fake is a co-founder of the photo sharing Web siteFlickr, which was sold to Yahoo in early 2005. Since then, Ms. Fake has guided a number of Web products, including Etsy, the online marketplace for crafts and vintage products, Dailybooth, which lets users publish daily photographs of themselves, and Hunch,which finds products and places that a users online friends like and then predicts what else the user might like.

title: Stiff Back Sidelines Placido Polanco
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Phillies have won Game 1 in each of their last six postseason series. But if theyre going to do it again on Wednesday against the Reds, theyll have to manage without third baseman Placido Polanco.

title: Justices Take Up Funeral-Protest Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a highly charged case involving protesters objecting to homosexuality who picketed a military funeral.

title: Denial and Speculation Follow Woodwards Hint of a Clinton-Biden Swap
description: 2:23 p.m. | Updated In response to the White Houses pushback against his idea that Hillary Rodham Clinton and Joseph R. Biden Jr. might exchange places, Bob Woodward said this afternoon that the idea of a Biden-Clinton swap is on the table in the sense that any legitimate vote-getting strategy is always on the table in politics.

title: Looking Back and Looking Ahead: Week 5 in Fantasy Football
description: Chet Gresham blogs about fantasy football at Razzball. You can follow him on Twitter @Chetrazzball.

title: Geolocation Services: Find a Smartphone, Find a Customer
description: CHAMIN MILLS has found a new way to give customers a poke.

title: Hungarian Towns Begin Cleanup of Nightmarish Red Sludge
description: KOLONTAR, Hungary  Just before he raced for refuge in the attic of his familys home here on Monday at lunchtime, Krisztian Holczer called his mother at her job at a school near here.

title: Green Beret Is Awarded Medal of Honor Posthumously
description: President Obama on Wednesday awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously to a Green Beret who gave his life to save more than a dozen American and Afghan soldiers in a battle with insurgents in Afghanistan last year. It was the latest in a series of such White House ceremonies at a time of debate about the war.

title: Childish Food
description: Readers, like Di Liu of Chicago, who photographed the dish at the right, are submitting pictures and stories of unusual dishes their children have had them cook  like spaghetti tacos. My brother invented this when he was 8. It is bread, slathered with Prego, and finally topped with Goldfish crackers. The Dining section will display a slide show of selections later this week.

title: Have You Tried Foursquare?
description: In a small-business guide we just published, Kermit Pattison explains, step by step, how to get started with location-based marketing. The guide focuses primarily on Foursquare, the most prominent of the services, but there are many others. Below is a quick rundown of the alternatives. Have you tried any of them? What has your experience been?

title: Senator Jim DeMint and Morality
description: Im stunned by what Senator Jim DeMint says about moral requirements for teachers. Not only is he against gay teachers, but also against single women who sleep with their boyfriends. Not clear what he thinks of those boyfriends having sex before marriage, but they dont seem to alarm him so much. Heres how he was quoted in the Spartanburg, S.C., newspaper:

title: Runways, Then Shop Doorways
description: PARIS

title: Guy Deutscher Responds
description: Guy Deutscher provides a statement below, in response to my Oct. 3 column Scholarly Work, Without All the Footnotes.

title: Trains With Dedicated Tracks Top Subway Rankings
description: Looking for the best subway lines in the city? Find the one that has a track all to itself.

title: The Science of Conception: Studying Fertility and I.V.F.
description: Overview | How does conception work, and what are the major issues related to fertility? What are some of the medical advances that help infertile women conceive? In this lesson, students investigate and create storyboards for animations that explain the process of conception, the issue of infertility and the uses and risks of fertility treatments. They also consider the awarding of the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine to a pioneer in the development of in vitro fertilization, along with the ethical implications of the treatment.

title: A New Version of Windows Live Essentials
description: Last week, Microsoft released a new version of its Windows Live Essentials application suite, which has been in a public beta test for months.

title: A Fund Managers Message Beyond the Pinata
description: Anthony Scaramucci, the hedge fund manager of SkyBridge Capital, made headlines last month when he asked President Obama on television when he was going to stop whacking Wall Street like a piata.

title: West Virginia Sues U.S. Over Mining Restrictions
description: The state of West Virginia sued two federal agencies on Wednesday, seeking to reverse the stricter controls on mountaintop coal mining adopted in 2009 by the Obama administration.

title: Now Open | Raphael Young
description: Its a real ppite dor, this boutique, the shoe designer Raphael Young explains, likening his new store in the First Arrondisement in Paris to a gold nugget. Indeed, Young struck gold with this prime spot on rue Jean-Jacques Rousseau. Its big but well-proportioned, he says. There are rooms on the lower level where weve set up my atelier for special orders, our offices, a small lounge and my studio. Its perfect!

title: Footprint Fossils Offer Earliest Evidence of Dinosaurs Ancestors
description: The earliest known relatives of dinosaurs were the size of a house cat, walked on four legs and left footprints in the quarries in Poland.

title: Cuba Journal: A Taste of Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie and More
description: Over the next few days, Victoria Burnett will be reporting for ArtsBeat on Jazz at Lincoln Centers visit to Cuba.

title: 133 Charged in Puerto Rico Graft Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  In what officials described as the largest investigation into police corruption in the history of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Justice Department on Wednesday announced the indictments of 89 police officers and 44 other people in Puerto Rico on drug trafficking charges.

title: When Sleep Apnea Masquerades as Dementia
description: The woman who came to see Dr. Ronald Petersen, an Alzheimers specialist at the Mayo Clinic, was only in her 60s but complained that she was having trouble concentrating. Her attention was waning, Dr. Petersen recalled. She couldnt follow a television program or stay focused during a conversation.

title: A Soign Kothari Boutique Opens on Madison Avenue
description: SARI-DRAPING tutorials and tea service are among the perks offered by Soign Kothari at her new Madison Avenue boutique, Soigne K at 717 Madison Avenue (at 63rd Street); (212) 486-2890;

title: Issey Miyake Offers a New Bag in a New Space
description: ISSEY MIYAKE is in the details of the new Bao Bao collection (pictured, $615), which builds on his popular Bilbao style. The bag doesnt arrive until November, but already there is a waiting list. It will be sold at the recently renovated Pleats Please at 128 Wooster Street (at Prince Street); (212) 226-3600; isseymiyake.com.

title: Scouting Report
description: POP UP

title: Epaulet Opens a Pop-Up Focusing on Collaborations
description: EPAULET in Brooklyn has opened a pop-up shop on the Lower East Side featuring new collaborations at 151 Orchard Street (at Stanton Street); (212) 477-1018; epauletshop.com. A party will be held tonight, from 7 to 9:30, to introduce the slim-fitting Gitman Vintage for Epaulet shirts (pictured, Loden, Ultraviolet Tartan, $165). Coming: a shawl-collar hand-knit cardigan made in a seven-person workshop on Prince Edward Island ($325); Thorogood No. 685 Boot, handcrafted in Merrill, Wis. ($245); Epaulet & Staple special-edition rivet chinos made with brushed cotton twill from Japan ($165). The store will close Oct. 30.

title: Just 30 Pieces of Glamour
description: JANE MAYLE, who closed her influential NoLIta boutique in 2009, has a 30-piece capsule collection at Sigerson Morrison Laboratory Boutique at 19 East 71st Street (Madison Avenue); (212) 734-2100; sigersonmorrison.com. The collection will be available until Oct. 14 and includes wool coats in textures like soft twills and tweeds, wool boucl and coarse twill ($765 to $875); whimsical print silk dresses ($545 to $645), and bags ($295 to $725).

title: How (Not) to Treat a Stay-at-Home-Dad
description: Matt Villano, a freelance writer and stay-at-home dad in Healdsburg, Calif., is getting used to being the only father in the room. He understands that there will always be mothers who will ignore him, as they cluster together on the other end of the playground. In fact, as he writes in a guest post today, he would prefer to be ignored  particularly if the alternative is way too much attention. (Of course, a no-big-deal middle ground would be nice.)

title: Quote Unquote | Punkd
description: Steve Albini, the pioneer of punk, tells it like it is to GQ.  At least thats one musician we can count on not to start a clothing line anytime soon.

title: Class Struggle and Fabergs Imagination Played Out on a Board
description: In the fall of 1977, George Dean, a Detroit doctor and chess set collector, received a call from a man with a thick Russian accent offering to sell a set made by the legendary jeweler Peter Carl Faberg. Dr. Dean knew that Faberg had made a set in 1905, but the one offered for sale was supposedly made in 1915.

title: Big Issues, Small Answers
description: From the Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out blog:

title: Aroldis Chapman and the Risk of the Fleeting Flamethrower
description: PHILADELPHIA - You dont run much risk of injury by walking down the street. If you run, your risk rises a little. On a bike, its greater. On a motorcycle or a race car, its greater still. It only makes sense: the faster youre going, the greater your risk of getting hurt. Its true for a rotating shoulder, too.

title: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Hungary, Somalia and Mexico.

title: Cisco Rolls Out Umi Home Videoconferencing System
description: So, theres kind of clunky but blissfully free PC video chat on Skype and any number of other Web services. And now theres superhigh-quality chat over your TV from Cisco for $898.88, for a year of service.

title: Its a Celebration, So Lets Squeeze In a Ferris Wheel
description: How do you get to the Park Avenue Armory?

title: A Soft Spot for Public Lands
description: John D. Leshy, a former Interior Department solicitor, likes to say, Theres no square yard of public land that somebody doesnt love.

title: Why Holiday Retail Sales Matter
description: Stephanie Clifford and I have an article in todays paper about the outlook for holiday sales and holiday retail hiring, which is grim (especially when you consider that retailers are entering the season with very lean sales forces).

title: A Twin, a Ranger and, Most of All, a Senator
description: The Minnesota Twins and the Texas Rangers are in the American League playoffs together for the first time. In a general sense, each is bound to two failed Washington Senators franchises. More precisely, their ties go through a man in Huntsville, Ala.

title: Clean Living in the Henhouse
description: NORTH MANCHESTER, Ind.  The stuff doesnt even smell that bad.

title: Egg Farms Fight Contamination
description: Egg farms in northern Indiana show that much is being done in the egg industry to fight salmonella.

title: Mysterious Renminbi Proposals
description: As Chinese officials make increasingly frantic and bizarre statements  other emerging markets have experienced huge currency appreciations, so how is it that having China move modestly in the same direction would be a disaster for the world?  there seems to be a growing consensus that pressure must be placed on China. But how?

title: Case Study | Will the Real Mai Tai Please Stand Up?
description: In the past, Ive had a fairly stock cocktailians response to the concept of tiki and its representative drinks, those kitschy, oversweetened, unnaturally colored mash-ups of various tropical liquors and juices with too many ingredients and too much enforced silliness. Whenever I was asked to produce a mai tai or a planters punch, I would follow protocol and dump a number of rums and mixers together  some pineapple, right? And some O.J., sure, and dont leave out the coconut.

title: Cranking it Down a Notch
description: Sometimes  often  an aim of cooking is to maximize flavor, a pretty easy notion to grasp if not always to execute. But another, more elusive, concept is optimizing flavor. This can mean holding back just when your first instinct is to let er rip. Heres an example.

title: Video Shows Torrents of Sludge in Hungary
description: As my colleague Elisabeth Rosenthal reports, Hungarians are struggling to prevent 185 million gallons of sludge that flooded out of an industrial reservoir on Monday  residue from the production of aluminum  from reaching the Danube.

title: The Market Believes in QE2
description: For the moment at least. Optimism about Fed action has led both to falling long-term interest rates:

title: Whitman and Fiorina Wont Appear With Palin and Steele
description: LOS ANGELES  Its shaping up as two of the more star-studded Republican events of the fall: Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, and Michael Steele, the head of the Republican National Committee, appearing on the same stage  first in Orange County and the following week in Orlando  at what is being billed as final path to victory rallies, intended to raise campaign funds and build enthusiasm among conservatives as Election Day approaches.

title: Halladay: First Postseason No-Hitter since Don Larsen
description: Roy Halladay threw a masterpiece, and he made it look easy. In his first career postseason start, Halladay threw the first playoff no-hitter since Don Larsens perfect game in 1956. Halladay cruised: 104 pitches, 79 strikes, and only three three-ball counts.

title: God and the Details
description: Via Alan Jacobs, I see that the Immanent Frame has gathered a symposium of religion scholars to discuss the recent Pew Forum findings on American religious literacy  or religious illiteracy, more aptly which I discussed a little bit in this space. Jacobs flags these comments, from Calvin Colleges James K.A. Smith:

title: Memo Hints at Name Change for MSNBC.com
description: NBC Universal and Microsoft, the parents of MSNBC.com, are holding high-level talks about a name change, something that could be a risky endeavor for the third most popular news Web site in the United States.

title: New Protections for an Ancient, Ailing Fish
description: The Atlantic sturgeon, an armored, ancient, kayak-size denizen of eastern rivers and coasts, is still ailing despite strict fishing limits, so federal officials on Tuesday proposed giving it protection under the Endangered Species Act. The plan, after a period of public comment, would give endangered or threatened status to five populations of the species grew out of a petition last year by the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: Health Care at McDonalds (Cont.)
description: Aaron Carroll of Indiana University School of Medicine expands on why he thinks the insurance exchanges to be established by the new health care law will give many McDonalds workers better care for less money:

title: Workers Not Saving Enough to Get 401(k) Match
description: Its free money, yet a large percentage of Americans are increasingly leaving it on the table.

title: Ambac Drops $6.1 Billion in Claims Against Lehman
description: Lehman Brothers said the Ambac Assurance Corporation had agreed to withdraw claims worth more than $6.1 billion against the company as part of a global settlement of a dispute over derivatives, Reuters reports.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Nobel Prize for Literature announced Thursday, October 7. Philip Roth spends day eyeing telephone, vacuuming.

title: In Bilbao, Its Not Just the Museum
description: BETWEEN its Norman Foster subway system, Santiago Calatrava bridge and, of course, Frank Gehrys magnificent Guggenheim Museum, washed like a titanium-clad shipwreck on the once gritty shores of the Nervin river, Bilbao has undergone a dramatic transformation over the last 15 years.

title: Bilbaos New Restaurant Scene
description: Bilbao, Spain is beginning to steal some thunder from nearby San Sebastin.

title: Pictures of the Day: Hungary and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Hungary, Somalia and France.

title: Federal Government to Add 100 Electric Cars
description: Last October, President Obama issued an executive order calling on government agencies to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions. Low-hanging fruit for carbon reduction is in the transportation fleet, particularly zero-emission, battery-electric cars, but there arent many on the market, and very few federal agencies have acquired them.

title: Don Hills
description: IN a town where hot spots can have the life span of fireflies, the resuscitation of 19-year old Don Hills seems an evolutionary marvel. Sure, the drag-punk party Squeezbox faded in 2001, and the still-sizzling Misshapes departed in 2007. But last month the dingy club got a reprieve, thanks to Paul Sevigny and Nur Khan, the nightlife gurus who made their name with the Beatrice Inn. Their formula  no bottle service, a draconian door policy, an illicit air  hasnt faltered yet.

title: For Parker Spitzer, a Better Second Outing
description: After its rocky start, the pressure was already on CNNs new prime-time hour Parker Spitzer. It had nowhere to go but up  and up it went.

title: Lee Reprises Role as Postseason Ace for Rangers
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Rangers traded for Cliff Lee in July for games in October. And on Wednesday, Lee delivered the type of performance that he displayed a year ago in leading the Phillies to the World Series.

title: Cold-Case Trial: Two Opposites on Same Side, Facing Down a Killer
description: Last year Michael Connelly took his readers on a slow boat to China. He wrote Nine Dragons, a disappointingly flat and gimmicky story featuring his long-suffering Los Angeles police detective, Harry Bosch. Harrys usual stomping ground is the depraved underbelly of Los Angeles, but Nine Dragons sent him on a touristy detour to Hong Kong. It also used one of the detective novels cheapest tricks, the kidnapping of someone near and dear to the hero (in this case his schoolgirl daughter) to generate suspense.

title: Scientists and Soldiers Solve a Bee Mystery
description: DENVER  It has been one of the great murder mysteries of the garden: what is killing off the honeybees?

title: Continental Sets Date to Start Charging for Food
description: Continental, the last major carrier to offer free meals to its passengers, will start charging most of its domestic economy passengers for food on Oct. 12. First- and business-class passengers will still eat free, as will passengers on many international flights (all intercontinental routes and some others), and on domestic flights of more than six and a half hours.

title: Model-Morphosis | Herms
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Aline Weber from Elite Model Management before (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Odile Gilbert. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Recipe Redux: The Community Cookbook
description: Six years ago, I decided to write a cookbook that would gather the best New York Times recipes ever. I was sure it was a great idea, because the paper  which began publishing recipes in the 1850s has been one of the leading voices in the evolution of American food. But it turned out to be a terrible idea logistically, because The Times has published tens of thousands of recipes. So I turned to the papers readers  you!  a group of people I barely knew, for help, placing a small authors query in the Dining section, soliciting readers most stained recipes from The Times.

title: 1967: Veal Chops Beau Sjour
description: Lotti Morris from Bennington, Vt., wrote:

title: Film Producer on a Roll, With Fingers Crossed
description: LOS ANGELES  Young movie producers are a dime a dozen in Hollywood. Sometimes they find a hit movie before they fade back into obscurity. If theyre lucky, they might land two.

title: The (Mostly Financial) Stars Come Out for Inside Job
description: A passel of financial stars came to Lincoln Center in Manhattanfor a screening of Inside Job, the documentary about the origins and consequences of the financial crisis.

title: West Virginia Sues Over Mountaintop Mining Limits
description: West Virginia says it is filing a lawsuit against two federal agencies that seeks to reverse the stricter controls on mountain-top coal mining adopted in 2009 by the Obama administration.

title: 'Gatz'
description: More photos from the production at the Public Theater.

title: Heroes Welcome
description: SO a dog walks into a bar. Honestly, no joke. The dog is a German shepherd and hes not just any dog, hes a hero. Hes a shelter dog saved from a pound as a puppy and destined for euthanasia until some alert human spotted a spark in him  some cleverness, some drive  and set in motion a series of events that led to him becoming a search-and-rescue animal. Now he is one of those dogs you sometimes see in the news, snout to the rubble in the wreckage of disasters in Haiti, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, at ground zero.

title: Miu Miu: Dancing With the Stars
description: The Paris spring shows closed on quite a high as exhausted, sniffling, shuffling editors and buyers saw the collections of Louis Vuitton, Herms and Miu Miu. On a raised runway, Marc Jacobs seemed to pitch Louis Vuitton to the affluent Asian consumer, or at least acknowledge the considerable influence that China and other Asian countries have on fashion and luxury retailing. Virtually every look seemed dipped in electric-bright colors  fuchsia, red, jade, purple, orange  and then rolled in glitter. The models, their hair smoothed into tight rolls with a flip over one eye, sometimes walked three or four abreast on the catwalk, like shows in the past  and maybe in the future. The clothes, which included a black and white gown with the silhouette of a pandas head, were tempting for their New World sheen. Mr. Jacobs made his campy point without overdoing it.

title: Trouble Over a Gelada Baby
description: Friday, Oct. 1

title: A Printer, Several Computers, Wireless Network. Mix.
description: What do you get when you mix four computers, two operating systems, one printer and a wireless home network? If you are lucky, a convenient way to share the printer among all computers.

title: Could Liverpool Ownership Squabble Trip Up Reds?
description: The news that the New England Sports Ventures, owner of the Boston Red Sox, agreed to buy the Liverpool Football Club appears to be the penultimate chapter in an intriguing sports-business story that started long before Tom Hicks and George Gillett Jr. went looking for a buyer in April.

title: A Steadicam for Your iPhone
description: There are few things more foreboding, more memorable, than those ominous Steadicam tracking shots of little Danny Torrance riding his Big Wheel down the long halls of the Overlook Hotel in Stanley Kubricks The Shining. The way the camera glides smoothly behind him as he pedals his way to freaky twin girls and blood-drenched elevator doors is one of the most enduring shots in all of moviemaking.

title: From Japan, a Reminder That We Are Dust, and to Dust We Return
description: Butoh, the dance form that developed in Japan in the late 1950s, was at first an approach to, or a philosophy about, movement, rather than a particular style. At early performances audiences were shocked by its dark expressionism, its emphasis on the grotesque, the shaven-headed dancers, white-painted bodies and contorted, eerily slow positions. Today that aesthetic is familiar and beloved, and Butohs dreamlike images and pared-down presentation has had a significant effect on Western dance.

title: The Very Familiar New Jersey of Snookis Grandparents
description: Maybe Susan DiLallo and Stephen Weiner just like a challenge. When they wrote the musical comedy Once Upon a Time in New Jersey (Ms. DiLallo, book and lyrics; Mr. Weiner music), they started off with a double handicap: they set it not only in a shopworn time period, the 1950s, but also in a shopworn place, New Jersey.

title: Scorecard | Alexander McQueen Wins!
description: There was a bittersweet symphony in the air on the penultimate day of Paris Fashion Week, and not just on the sound system at the Grand Palais. Which was probably as good foreshadowing as any that on this rather momentous day of untimely debuts, returns to Marienbad, 40th-anniversary retrospectives and sweet reconciliations, Scorecard notes that for the first time ever no designer missed the cut  but a very talented right-hand woman took flight.

title: Fledgling Musicians Spread Their Wings
description: The annual Carnegie Hall performances by the young musicians from the Sphinx Organization are always illuminating, not only because they are the fruits of an inspiring program, but also because the performances are invariably energetic and finely burnished. Sphinx, which is based in Detroit and was started in 1996 by Aaron P. Dworkin, a violinist, is dedicated to getting black and Hispanic students involved in classical music, mainly by training them to play and compose but also through music history courses that help produce informed listeners.

title: Israeli Group Set to Play in Bayreuth
description: The Israel Chamber Orchestra plans to play a concert next summer in Bayreuth, Germany, the city most associated with Richard Wagner, whose music is taboo in the Jewish state because of its embrace by Hitler and because of the composers noted anti-Semitism.

title: The Caucus Click: New Orleans
Live Analysis: Yankees Win Game 1, 6-4
description: The Yankees beat the Minnesota Twins, 6-4, in Game 1 of their American League division series at Target Field in Minneapolis.

title: Spring, Fashions Operatic Season
description: PARIS

title: The Porter Will Kindly Show You to Your Doom
description: Arriving just in time for haunted house season is Hotel Savoy, a site-specific theater piece by Dominic Huber presented by P.S. 122 in association with the Goethe-Institut on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, smack opposite the Metropolitan Museum. Inspired by the Austrian writer Joseph Roths 1924 novel of the same name, the work is essentially a solo performance with a few minor supporting characters. The soloist  surprise!  is you.

title: N.R.C.C. Moves to Secure Million-Dollar Loan
description: A bank loan is not always the mark of trouble. At the end of a political race, it can be a sign of opportunity.

title: With Dresser, G.E.s Just Getting Started
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated General Electric executives have said for months that they would start spending the billions of dollars in cash that the company has been accumulating. That time, it seems, has now come.

title: TVs Future Has Arrived (Almost)
description: Americans used to gather in front of their TV sets on, say, Thursday at 8 p.m. and tune in to Channel 3. The upside: the whole country had a common cultural bond.

title: Crazy Juice, Made with Real DeMint
description: Are you crazy about political advertisements this election cycle? Then check out this new video, released on Wednesday by the campaign of Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada and uploaded to his YouTube channel. Our favorite line: Made with real DeMint, an allusion to Senator Jim DeMint, the South Carolina Republican who has endorsed Mr. Reids Republican opponent, Sharron Angle, a former Nevada assemblywoman. In two words: Crazy Juice. But watch and see for yourself.

title: Guarded Pals in a Critical TV Rivalry
description: Welcome to 8, read the Twitter message from Dan Harmon, an executive producer of Community, to Bill Prady, his counterpart on The Big Bang Theory.

title: Newly Discovered Ted Hughes Poem Is Read on British Television
description: The poet Ted Hughes has always been somewhat overshadowed by his estranged wife Sylvia Plath, whose 1963 suicide at 30 continues to fascinate. That pattern continues even after his death with the discovery of a previously unknown poem he wrote about the night of Plaths suicide. A version of the poem was read on the evening newscast in Britain Wednesday night by Jonathan Pryce, The Guardian of London reported.

title: Photos of the Moment | Louis Vuitton
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kava Gorna.

title: Drug Arrest for Man Involved in Fatal Game in 1994
description: In 1994, a 12-year-old boy named Ronald Herron was playing cops-and-robbers in the Gowanus Houses in Brooklyn when a 13-year-old friend carrying a toy rifle was fatally shot on a staircase by a police officer.

title: Bleaching Hits Caribbean Corals
description: Widespread coral bleaching caused by abnormally high sea temperatures is hitting reefs throughout the Caribbean, according to reports from field researchers in the region. Its just the latest development in what is shaping to be one of the worst years on record for the worlds coral reefs.

title: Emanuel vs. Bloomberg: Facebook Faceoff
description: Whos got more Facebook friends, Rahm Emanuel or Michael R. Bloomberg?

title: A Maverick Conjures Up Some Favorite Madmen
description: The organist Cameron Carpenter began his late-night concert at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday in his preferred manner, mingling with the crowd beforehand and dressed in atypical organist fashion: a bowler hat, black velvet trousers, blue socks, bow tie and a white shirt with glitter on the shoulders.

title: Facebook Now Lets You Take Your Data With You
description: Facebook did something bold today. The worlds largest social network now lets members download all the information theyve ever uploaded into Facebook  their Wall, photos, videos, friends, messages, events and notes  into a Zip file that can be browsed, for example, to see every photo ever uploaded from your account.

title: Recovering Changes From Microsoft Word
Lightens My Sadness, She Livens My Days
description: Time warps, time lines and time signatures: as John Pizzarelli crooned Irving Berlins Count Your Blessings with the tenderness of a father lulling a sleepless child, the voice of his wife and musical partner, Jessica Molaskey, slipped in behind him to sing Jonathan Larsons Seasons of Love, from the musical Rent.

title: F.T.C. Accuses Tax Relief Company of Empty Promises
description: WASHINGTON  Who wouldnt like to settle with the Internal Revenue Service for pennies on the dollar?

title: Shedding Some Light on Darkness
description: A lot of motives might have been at play in The Promise: The Making of Darkness on the Edge of Town: nostalgia, vanity, a desire for documentation or benediction. One thing thats undoubtedly on display, though, is bravery.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: A Computer That Could Drive a Car
description: Researchers at Yale and New York University have developed a supercomputer based on the human visual system. On this weeks Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Eugenio Culurciello, an associate professor of electrical engineering at Yale who has helped create this supercomputer. He says it could someday allow a car to drive itself. Embedded on a single chip, the system runs more than 100 billion operations a second using only a few watts, which Mr. Culurciello says is less power than a cellphone uses. Other potential applications, he says, include motion monitors in assisted living facilities that could summon help should an elderly person fall and all-around vision for soldiers in the battlefield.

title: As Yankees Most Valuable Repairman, Long Revives Struggling Hitters
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The University of Arizona baseball team in 1989 was flush with major league talent. Trevor Hoffman started at shortstop. J.T. Snow patrolled first base. The Wildcats ace was Scott Erickson. But the leader of the team was a 5-foot-7 center fielder named Kevin Long, whom everyone gravitated toward.

title: Mixed Pairs Title Decided, And Fantoni Is Back on Top
description: PHILADELPHIA  The winners of the World Mixed Pairs here on Monday were Donna Compton of Dallas and Fulvio Fantoni from Italy. They nearly failed to qualify for the final three sessions, needing a near-top on the last board to get in. But with no carryover, they played consistently, having session scores of 56.34, 58.34 and 58.45 percent.

title: Specter to Campaign for Sestak
description: Senator Arlen Specter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, is expected to appear on Monday alongside the man who defeated him in the partys primary, Representative Joe Sestak.

title: Shopping With Katie Lydon
description: The British-born interior designer searched for trays, some pretty, others rough-edged.

title: L.A. Design Store Eccola Grows as it Moves
description: In the six years since Kathleen White Almanza and her husband, Maurizio, opened the first Eccola, a Los Angeles store specializing in midcentury modern furnishings from Italy, theyve moved twice, expanding and remodeling each time. We have an affinity for gutting, said Ms. Almanza, a former set decorator. The newest incarnation is a 4,500-square-foot space in a 1916 garage on Beverly Boulevard. We took it down to what it was, which was pretty glorious: old cement floors, gorgeous brick walls and huge windows, she said. We added eight skylights.

title: Standard 41 Introduces a Line of Taibles and Seating
description: Taible is a new line of tables and seating from Andrew Raible, of Standard 41, a midcentury influenced furniture design company in Brooklyn with a 21st-century environmental approach, founded in 2006. I grew up having dinner at a table my father designed and built, said Mr. Raible, a sixth-generation woodworker. I love the idea of tables and the community they create. Hopefully, they stimulate conversation. The first three pieces are the All Yall dining table with 24-karat gold corners (inspired by a talk with a Dallas interior designer who wanted bigger tables with more bling); the Il Palio walnut side table; and the Train to Dijon table (above, with matching chair and bench), which tilts 12 degrees and looks as if it might topple over. I wouldnt mind if people smiled at the design, he said.

title: New From Dempsey & Carroll, Stationery by John Derian
description: Fans of John Derians Old World patterns on dcoupaged dishes and paperweights can now share the designers graphics with friends. Working with Dempsey & Carroll, the stationery company, Mr. Derian has selected six designs from his archives and his current collection to decorate a line of cards and envelopes.

title: In Texas, an Artist Plans to Rotate a House 180 Degrees
description: Sometime later this month, Mary Ellen Carroll, a conceptual artist who has been lecturing for the last few years at Rice Universitys school of architecture, will oversee the 180-degree rotation of a small one-story house in the Houston suburb of Sharpstown, a once-prosperous postwar planned community that has suffered economic reversals. The project, prototype 180, will be streamed live on the Web.

title: A Students New Screen Evokes Waves and Gains Acclaim
description: The wavelike shape of the Phenomena screen may call to mind water, but Sang Hoon Kim, the designer, said his inspiration was actually the way that light moves over time. I wanted to bring that phenomenon into the home, he said, by creating undulating ribs that would reflect light at many different angles.

title: Trays
description: KATIE LYDON, a British-born interior designer living in New York, likes to have a lot of trays around the house  and not just for entertaining.

title: Sales at Mxyplyzyk, Elegant Setting and BoConcept
description: The Elegant Setting, a tabletop and gift store in Southampton, N.Y., is having a fall clearance to Oct. 30, with most items up to 50 percent off (frames in leather, mother-of-pearl and silver, originally $60 to $235, are $30 to $120; and glass and crystal vases, formerly $80 to $300, are $40 to $150); 31 Main Street (Walnut Street), Southampton, N.Y., (631) 283-4747 or theelegantsetting.com.

title: A Seed Library for Heirloom Plants Thrives in the Hudson Valley
description: AS a child, Peg Lotvin used to watch her father, Hank, head out into his garden every fall on a mission. After setting aside part of the bean harvest for his neighbor Flossy, who was reputed to make the best baked beans in all of Ghent, in New Yorks Hudson Valley, he would select the largest, heartiest beans from the crop and put them up to plant the next year.

title: What Did They Ever Do to This Guy? Creator of Weezer Breakup Campaign Explains Himself
description: Why would anyone try to raise $10 million for the sole purpose of persuading Weezer to break up? In a telephone interview on Wednesday evening, James Burns, the architect of the Web-based fund-raising drive covered earlier on ArtsBeat, explained the motivation for what he admitted was a silly campaign.

title: A London Home Makes the Most of an Odd-Shaped Plot
description: An architect with a talent for maximizing space and a limited budget created his own northeast London home.

title: In London, a Big Idea Fit for a Tiny Lot
description: London

title: A Log Home in Chapel Hill
description: The sculptor Patrick Dougherty says his first artwork was his house in North Carolina, handmade from old barn timber, fallen trees and rocks that he dug from the ground.

title: Building With Sticks and Stones
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

title: Israel Braces for Ahmadinejad Stone-Throwing
description: Hezbollahs television station, Al Manar TV, reports that Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad hopes to find time during a visit to Lebanon next week to throw a rock at Israel.

title: Women on the Verge of a Big Broadway Gamble
description: IN the world according to Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, the new Broadway musical about love and abandonment in 1980s Madrid, the gazpacho is laced with Valium, the boyfriends are cads and terrorists, and theater royalty, Patti LuPone, is in full diva glory. Playing a jilted wife fresh from 19 years in an insane asylum, Ms. LuPone glowed in platinum blonde curls and oversize jewels at a recent rehearsal  a wigged-out kinswoman of her Tony Award-winning characters in Evita and Gypsy. And her opening lines in the shows first number, appropriately titled My Crazy Heart, set the tenor of the show to come.

title: Today Show | College Recruiting
description: New York Times reporter Jacques Steinberg and Grinnell College's Dean of Admissions, Seth Allen, discuss recruiting tours by college admissions officers on the Today Show.

title: Stricter Labeling for Green Products
