description: Manufacturers will face stricter rules on how to advertise products that claim to be eco-friendly under a proposal from the Federal Trade Commission, our colleague Tanzina Vega reports.

title: Rolfing, Excruciatingly Helpful
description: A FORMER dancer of 14 years, Anna Zahn is in touch with her body. To gain more flexibility, and to counteract some of the strain from dancing, she has tried a number of remedies: Reiki, acupuncture, yoga.

title: 'Time Stands Still'
description: Laura Linney and Brian D'Arcy James in an excerpt from the Broadway play. (Video courtesy of the Manhattan Theater Club)

title: 2 Stars for a Brooklyn Grocery Kitchen
description: It may not have the opulence of Adour Alain Ducasse or the pedigree of LAtelier de Jol Robuchon. But the Chefs Table at Brooklyn Fare  an 18-seat bar and open kitchen inside a Boerum Hill grocery store  has something neither of those places has: two stars from the new Michelin Guide to New York, making it that books highest-rated restaurant outside Manhattan.

title: Washingtons Fresh Coat of Greasepaint
description: WASHINGTON

title: Soldier Killed Saving Comrades Is Awarded the Medal of Honor
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously on Wednesday to a Green Beret who died to save his fellow soldiers in a pitched battle with insurgents in Afghanistan last year, the latest in a series of such tributes at a time of domestic debate about the war.

title: The Spoils of Happiness
description: In 1974, Robert Nozick, a precocious young philosopher at Harvard, scooped The Matrix:

title: Inside Old Hickorys Curio Cabinet
description: WHEN the set designer Donyale Werle began work on the Broadway production of the musical Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, a hybrid of emo-rock concert and anachronistic history lesson about Americas controversial seventh president, she decided it should be performed in a mash-up environment that matched the genre-bending vision of the shows writer and director, Alex Timbers, and its composer, Michael Friedman.

title: Steered Into the Kitchen, Thanks to Mom
description: William Patrick Harrison was cooking scrambled eggs with freshly snipped home-grown chives by age 8, though at that stage of his culinary education his mother supervised his use of scissors. Two degrees from the Culinary Institute of America later, Mr. Harrison, 23, totes his own self-sharpened knives to his job as a line cook at the River Caf in Brooklyn. He lives with his parents in Glendale, Queens.

title: As Paladino Spends on Campaign, He Often Earns, Too
description: If Carl P. Paladino comes up short in his run for governor against Andrew M. Cuomo, he will not have thrown his money away. At least not all of it.

title: Galleon Wiretap Application Under Scrutiny
description: By PETER LATTMAN

title: Father and Son Found Guilty of Tax Evasion
description: A federal jury in Florida convicted a father and son on Wednesday of hiding a $33 million hotel sale from federal tax authorities while living a lavish lifestyle.

title: For Cyclists in Tuscany, Winning Isnt the Point
description: GAIOLE IN CHIANTI, Italy  On the first Sunday of October, almost 3,500 cyclists took to the hills of central Tuscany, riding vintage bicycles, wearing woolen knits and old-fashioned goggles and eating bread and prosciutto.

title: Drug Maker From China Pleads Guilty
description: GeneScience Pharmaceutical, a Chinese company, and its chief executive pleaded guilty on Wednesday to federal charges of illegally distributing human growth hormone in the United States, capping a three-year investigation.

title: In New Realm, In Command
description: PHILADELPHIA  During each half inning when he was not pitching on Wednesday, Roy Halladay sat alone in the tunnel behind the Phillies dugout and watched his teammates bat on a television monitor. And each time he walked past the pitching coach Rich Dubee, who could see as well as anyone the brilliance that was unfolding on the mound when Halladay was on it, Dubee provided the same insight and tactical suggestions.

title: Web Site to Offer Health Advice, Some of It From Marketers
description: THE expression sharing is caring was coined long before the Internet and social media like Facebook and Twitter made it easier for information, opinions and advertising to be shared among multitudes.

title: Rampant Fraud Threat to Chinas Brisk Ascent
description: BEIJING  No one disputes Zhang Wubens talents as a salesman. Through television shows, DVDs and a best-selling book, he convinced millions of people that raw eggplant and immense quantities of mung beans could cure lupus, diabetes, depression and cancer.

title: Paying Homage to Japans Raw Edges
description: THE eye adjusts, as fashion people say, a truism routinely exploited in defense of styles so extreme that they often affront conventional tastes. It took some adjusting indeed to digest and assimilate the groundbreaking trends spawned in Japan in the early 1980s  a period of fashion revolt that ushered in radical innovations like breastplates and street-sweeping skirts.

title: Unusual Opposition to a Favorite for Nobel
description: BEIJING  With just a day until the Nobel Peace Prize is awarded, the usual whirl of speculation over the winner is in full force, with many human rights advocates contending that an imprisoned Chinese dissident, Liu Xiaobo, has emerged as the favorite.

title: Cathy Horyn's Paris Fashion Week Report
description: Cathy Horyn discusses many of the standout spring 2011 collections.

title: Brutality in Congo: Who Can Stop It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Literatures Path, From Writer to Reader
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Variety Critic McCarthy Lands at Hollywood Reporter
description: LOS ANGELES  Todd McCarthy, fired as Varietys chief film critic seven months ago, has landed  again. Shortly after losing his longstanding job with Variety in a round of cost-cutting last March, Mr. McCarthy joined the IndieWire network of blogs with his newly formed Web site, Todd McCarthys Deep Focus. But Mr. McCarthy is now jumping to the revamped Hollywood Reporter, to join a team being assembled by its new editorial director, Janice Min.

title: MSNBC.com May Change Its Name
description: NBC Universal and Microsoft, the parents of msnbc.com, are holding high-level talks about changing its name, an unusual and potentially risky endeavor for the third most popular news Web site in the United States.

title: Stronger Hezbollah Emboldened for Fights Ahead
description: AITA AL SHAAB, Lebanon  It was from this shrub-ringed border town that Hezbollah instigated its war with Israel in 2006, and supporters of the militant Shiite movement sound almost disappointed that they have not fought since.

title: Beauty Spots
description: YOU LOOK HAPPY For those fed up with cocoa butter, there is this news: Swiss Skin Repair, a company founded by Beatrice De Borg, the former Swiss model, and Dr. Howard T. Bellin, a plastic surgeon, has a new Scar and Stretch Mark Body Cream featuring extract of edelweiss (left), which the company claims will enhance absorption and provide an impressive filling effect. The cream, which is $165, can be found at swissskinrepair.com.

title: A Punch to the Breadbasket as Nebraska Begins a Farewell
description: MANHATTAN, Kan.  The Nebraska Cornhuskers have been making the two-and-a-half-hour trek due south here for nearly a century. Generations of players have looked out the bus windows at the browns and golds of the tabletop plains. They watched Beatrice, Neb., give way to Marysville, Kan., before finally arriving at the home of one their oldest rivals, the Kansas State Wildcats.

title: Bloggingheads: Machines vs. Migrants
description: Sister Simone Campbell, left, of NETWORK and Mark Krikorian of the Center for Immigration Studies debate migrant farm labor.

title: Christies Silence Spurs Worry for Train Tunnel
description: In his first several months as New Jerseys governor, Chris Christie made it clear that he intended to cut the states budget in ways that might surprise and upset some residents. But one big project  a train tunnel to Manhattan projected to cost $8.7 billion  appeared safe.

title: Bear Hunt Training, Minus the Bear
description: TRAVELERS REST, S.C.  Later this month, camouflage-clad hunters and packs of dogs will set off across the densely forested foothills and rushing creeks here in western South Carolina for an age-old rite of fall: bear-hunting season.

title: Teachers Make Mark on Midterms
description: The two most powerful teachers unions are putting millions behind Democratic candidates around the country even though their members have railed against President Obamas education policies.

title: Gay Teenagers Suicides, and a Call for Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Is Yours for the Taking
description: Would you like to break into my apartment right now?

title: Lottery Numbers
Torture for Giants Becomes Triumph
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As the San Francisco Giants crept toward a playoff berth, signs held aloft by fans would appear at their ballpark with a command: end the torture.

title: Election Day Foretold
description: You won! What a nice run of the House, with a big enough Republican cushion to free the more pumped-up partisans to hold investigations of Obamas birth certificate. Let them throw steak scraps at the base, while the rest of you restore Wall Street, the insurance industry and Karl Rove to their rightful places in power.

title: At Yale, Anger Over Tactics Used in Raid of Off-Campus Party
description: NEW HAVEN  It was well after midnight, and the invitation-only party for Yale University undergraduates was reaching a peak. In the upscale nightclub Elevate, not far from campus, more than 100 students in semiformal attire were on the dance floor as Journeys Dont Stop Believing pulsed over the sound system. In a throwback to childhood, a buffet table held platters of chicken nuggets and French fries.

title: Women in Management
description: To the Editor:

title: Facebook Lets Users Interact in Small Groups
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Facebook is trying to become a bit more like the real world.

title: Run for a Seat Thought Safe Turns Into a Battle
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  Gov. Joe Manchin III, the Democratic candidate for the Senate here, could barely contain his frustration during an interview at the Capitol.

title: Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, 6:50 P.M.
Better Than Perfect? No-Hitter in Playoff Debut
description: PHILADELPHIA  In a glass case at Citizens Bank Park is a bronze cast of Roy Halladays right hand. It holds an official baseball, stamped with a hologram, commemorating his perfect game this May.

title: Fiscal Woes Deepening for Cities, Report Says
description: The nations cities are in their worst fiscal shape in at least a quarter of a century and have probably not yet hit the bottom of their slide, according to a report released on Wednesday.

title: Waivers Aim at Talk of Dropping Health Coverage
description: As Obama administration officials put into place the first major wave of changes under the health care legislation, they have tried to defuse stiffening resistance  from companies like McDonalds and some insurers  by granting dozens of waivers to maintain even minimal coverage far below the new laws standards.

title: Runners and Rallies Will Not Share Toilets
description: WASHINGTON  The Marine Corps Marathon here bills itself as the peoples marathon. As the largest marathon in the world that does not offer prize money, it expects a field of 30,000 runners for this years race, on Oct. 31.

title: Democrats in Tight Races Put Focus on Abortion Rights
description: DENVER  Republicans have won points with many voters by promising a conservative overhaul of taxes and spending, but Democrats are working hard in the closing weeks of the campaign to convince voters that a conservative social agenda is waiting in the wings, too, should Republicans be elected in large numbers.

title: Stem Cell Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Playoffs Replay: Oct. 6
description: A look at the day in sports, which was dominated by the baseball playoffs, which in turn were dominated by a pair of starting pitchers.

title: Whiplash Can Follow a Car Crash or a Wedding Announcement
description: Teaneck, N.J.

title: Port Oversight Again an Issue After Charges of Smuggling
description: Workers at the bustling New York-New Jersey port  including the eight longshoreman who were arrested Tuesday on cocaine-smuggling charges  are licensed by an obscure agency that is supposed to ensure that only people of good character find work there.

title: Opening Night: A Walk on the Beach
description: A minister, a publisher and a pundit walked into a bar. Thats no joke. Thats opening night at Southfork Kitchen, a night that was neither the rousing climax of a years work nor the punch line to a funny story. Opening night was, I kid you not, as smooth as mackerel skin. No drama, no calamities, no fireworks. It went as planned.

title: U.S. Tries to Calm Pakistan Over Airstrike
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration scrambled to halt a sharp deterioration in its troubled relationship with Pakistan on Wednesday, offering Pakistani officials multiple apologies for a helicopter strike on a border post that killed three Pakistani soldiers last week.

title: With Higher Fares Ahead, M.T.A. May Spare Drivers
description: Barring a last-minute miracle, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will vote on Thursday to raise fares for the regions subway, bus, and commuter-rail passengers. The biggest burden will be placed on 30-day unlimited MetroCard users, who will be asked to pay $104 a month, up from $89, a 17 percent increase.

title: Missing Woman Found Dead in Vehicle Near Police Building
description: The body of a pregnant woman who had been missing for more than a week was found in the Bronx on Tuesday night in a vehicle parked outside a building used by the New York Police Department.

title: The Seat Not Taken
description: AT least twice a week I ride Amtraks high-speed Acela train from my home in New York City to my teaching job in Providence, R.I. The route passes through a region of the country populated by, statistics tell us, a significant segment of its most educated, affluent, sophisticated and enlightened citizens.

title: A Weekend in Rome
description: After years of hitting snooze, this ancient city might just be waking up.

title: 36 Hours in Rome
description: ROME is the city that oversleeps. Unlike other European cultural capitals, this glorious jumble of history and art changes slowly. But lately, Rome has welcomed some new sparkle. A futuristic museum in the historic center has added color to the citys architectural scene. Around town young chefs are experimenting with local ingredients to create new tastes. Even old palazzos have been given makeovers. After years of hitting snooze, this ancient city might just be waking up.

title: Portis May Miss Six Weeks, Leaving Redskins Thin in Backfield
description: Clinton Portis, Washingtons two-time Pro Bowl running back, will be out at least a month with a groin injury, putting his future in doubt once again.

title: Thursday: Coming Unclued
description: If its a Thursday and its a Blindauer, odds are its tricky. It certainly was today.

title: Before Auction, Lennon Has Brush With the F.B.I.
description: John Lennon has been dead for 30 years, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation is still on the case.

title: Escaped Predator? What Else Is New?
description: A big cat is actually on the prowl in Tigers Be Still, an endearing new play by Kim Rosenstock, but nobodys paying much attention to this alarming problem. A fiercer foe is the grief clawing at the hearts of all the characters, whose afflictions come in many stripes, from debilitating illness to a mothers death to a fathers abandonment. The possibility of being eaten by a wild animal might be greeted with indifference, if not actually welcomed, by the benumbed, bewildered and bedridden characters in this quirk-addicted but heartfelt comedy.

title: Borne Back Ceaselessly Into the Past
description: The most compelling love affair being conducted on a New York stage this season isnt between a man and woman. (Or a man and a man, a woman and a woman or a boy and a horse.) It is between a man and a book.

title: Devils Roster Is Thin
description: To squeeze under the N.H.L.s salary cap, the Devils will take a 20-man roster, the league minimum, into their regular-season opener Friday at home against the Dallas Stars. The league approved the Devils roster, which does not include defensemen Bryce Salvador, who was placed on long-term injured reserve with a concussion, and Anssi Salmela, who had knee surgery and was designated as an injured nonroster player.

title: Heats Wade Recovering
description: The Miami Heat star guard Dwyane Wades right hamstring remains sore, and he says hes undergoing treatment to try to get back on the court as soon as possible.

title: A Room With a View (of Art) for the Night
description: CHEAP pod hotels, homey B & Bs, chic design-forward dens and modern business chains all provide shelter to their respective demographics. But a new batch of hotels in Europe appeals to a high-minded psychographic, doling out the keys to local culture related to literature, art, theater or history  both in their designs and in their locations. Whether it is Stalin-era art and architecture, Portuguese music, Turkish history, Parisian literature or the London stage, if youre bound for Europe for culture, check-in at one of these newcomers affords instant access.

title: A Finnish City Prepares for the Limelight
description: LIFE ON A LEAF, a whimsical yellow house that sits in a wooded park at the edge of Turku in southern Finland, is a lopsided construction with a bright red, blue and green roof and a leaf-shaped floor plan. Inside, its even wackier: curved walls, windows in the shape of teardrops, and a catwalk with a tiny video screen embedded in the floor that shows an endless loop of antlike commuters rushing through Grand Central Terminal in New York.

title: Joining the Locals In Pariss East
description: In the 20th Arrondissement of Paris, the action for residents is off Rue de Mnilmontant.

title: Real Estate Collapse Spells Havoc in Dubai
description: DUBAI  On a sultry June evening in 2007, more than 100 people camped out at the offices of Emaar, a prestigious Dubai property developer, to ensure that they would land a coveted spot in a gleaming new skyscraper scheduled to open this year near the Burj Khalifa, the worlds tallest building.

title: Strategies Clear in Florida Senate Debate
description: The three men competing to be Floridas next United States senator all said the same thing, over and over, in their debate tonight: Im the only candidate at this table who

title: Bright Spots for N.H.L. As the Season Opens
description: The N.H.L. season opens Thursday on the heels of an electrifying Olympic tournament, the continuing rise of charismatic young stars and a third straight postseason dominated by teams from hockey-steeped American cities. There will be challenges, but rather than symptoms of a leagues struggles, they seem to be signs of growing strength.

title: Passionate Fight Over Obamas Former Seat
description: VILLA PARK, Ill.  The prospect of seizing the United States Senate seat here, the one that once belonged to President Obama, is so delicious to Republicans that a party leader found himself dreaming aloud in this Chicago suburb one recent afternoon.

title: Beyond the Usual Stanley Cup Contenders
description: When it comes to Stanley Cup favorites, there are always the usual suspects. After all, the Blackhawks still have Jonathan Toews, Patrick Kane, Duncan Keith and Marian Hossa; the Penguins Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin may skate on the same line; and the Capitals Nicklas Backstrom and Mike Green can still pump in the few shots Alex Ovechkin doesnt take. And who would dismiss the Red Wings Henrik Zetterberg and Pavel Datsyuk?

title: Motorola Sues Apple Over 18 Patents
description: A Motorola unit filed three lawsuits and a trade complaint against Apple, contending the maker of the iPad computer tablet and iPhone mobile phone is infringing 18 of its patents.

title: Revis vs. Moss: Round 2 Is Monday Night
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For the most part, the Jets reacted with a shrug Wednesday to the trade that sent Randy Moss to Minnesota. They had plans to play the Vikings anyway on Monday night.

title: Ex-Diplomat Who Advised Kurds Gets Millions in Oil Deal
description: A British court has awarded between $55 million and $75 million to Peter W. Galbraith, the former United States diplomat who advised the Kurds during the negotiations on Iraqs Constitution, and a Yemeni investor for their stake in a widely criticized oil deal involving Iraqs rich northern fields, the oil company ordered to pay the award said Wednesday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,302 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: New York Asks to Bar Use of Food Stamps to Buy Sodas
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought federal permission on Wednesday to bar New York Citys 1.7 million recipients of food stamps from using them to buy soda or other sugared drinks.

title: Republicans See a Political Motive in I.R.S. Audits
description: WASHINGTON  With growing scrutiny of the role of tax-exempt groups in political campaigns, Congressional Republicans are pushing back against Democrats by warning about the possible misuse of the Internal Revenue Service to audit conservative groups.

title: Eyes Are on Stoudemire as Knicks Conclude Tour
description: PARIS  Amare Stoudemire left the Palais Omnisports late Wednesday in a suit, shirt, tie, scarf and knit cap, which was one suit, shirt, tie, scarf and knit cap more than he was wearing when he set the sports world abuzz.

title: Sherman J. Maisel, Former Fed Governor, Dies at 92
description: Sherman J. Maisel, an economist and former Federal Reserve governor whose research on housing markets shaped decades of federal policy on mortgages, died on Sept. 29 in San Francisco. He was 92.

title: Ad for Attorney General Echoes an Old Opponent
description: Introduce yourself. Question your opponent. Borrow from a former opponent turned supporter: Eric T. Schneiderman, the Democratic nominee for attorney general, did all three in the space of 30 seconds on Wednesday.

title: Deportations From U.S. Hit a Record High
description: Immigration authorities deported a record 392,862 immigrants over the last year, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said Wednesday.

title: Coal Plant Would Get New Controls
description: The Environmental Protection Agency signaled on Wednesday that it would require a New Mexico power plant, one of the largest coal-fired ones in the nation, to install $717 million in pollution controls to curb emissions that spread haze over the Four Corners region of the Southwest, home to national parks like Mesa Verde.

title: Agency Acts to Ease Delay of Pills for Elderly
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration has issued a new guideline intended to help ease the delay some nursing home residents face in receiving certain painkillers and anti-anxiety medications.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Shareholders Applaud G.E.s Shopping Spree
description: General Electrics shareholders seem curiously overjoyed to see the conglomerate back in shopping mode. The company added $4.2 billion to G.E.s market cap on Wednesday, when it spent $3 billion on an energy infrastructure business, confirmed its interest in a British maker of oil pipes and snapped up some of Citigroups more questionable loans. It is a shift from years on the defensive, selling assets. But the celebration looks overdone.

title: Trifecta of Torment
description: We journalists tend to cover politics the way we cover sports:

title: Connecticut on the Ropes
description: HARTFORD

title: Lamentable Speech
description: To the American Nazi Party, Hustler Magazine, and other odious figures in Supreme Court history, add the Rev. Fred Phelps Sr. and the members of the Westboro Baptist Church in Topeka, Kan. Their antigay protests at the funeral of a soldier slain in Iraq were deeply repugnant but protected by the First Amendment.

title: Haiti: U.S. Adds $120 Million in Aid
description: Six months after the Haiti Recovery Fund was established to help the earthquake-shattered country, the United States announced Wednesday that it had signed an agreement to contribute $120 million to the fund. The long-awaited American contribution will nearly double the assets of the fund, which is only one source of reconstruction financing. Although the United States spent more than $1 billion in humanitarian aid to Haiti after the earthquake, it has been slow to honor its pledge to the recovery fund as well as its overall promise of $1.15 billion in reconstruction money. Announcing the contribution at the third meeting of Haitis reconstruction commission, Cheryl Mills, chief of staff to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, said that the United States preferred that 75 percent go toward rubble removal and housing repairs.

title: They Need to Talk
description: Peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians are in danger of unraveling unless Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, show more political courage and sense.

title: Retrenchment, by the Numbers
description: No more stimulus has become the destructive mantra of conservative politicians here and across Europe. Britain has vowed to cut the budget of most government departments by 25 percent to 40 percent over the next four years. Germanys government has adopted its own slash-and-burn austerity plan.

title: Why Firemen Let That House Burn Down
description: No amount of political ranting about limits to government could douse the flames for a homeowner in rural Tennessee who forgot to pay his annual surcharge for fire department protection. Gene Cranick watched his house burn down in Obion County after firefighters from the nearby town of South Fulton arrived. They declined to turn their hoses on because his $75 fee for county residents had not been paid.

title: Senegals Changing Urban Landscape
description: Updated | Dec. 13, 10:30 a.m.

title: No Food Stamps for Sodas
description: SINCE its introduction in 1964, Americas food stamp program has helped millions of struggling Americans put food on their tables in difficult times. During the recent economic downturn, the number of people in New York City receiving this assistance has grown more than 35 percent.

title: Word of the Day | rummage
description: rummage \r-mij\ verb and noun

title: Expensive Questions on Giants Roster
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Giants will not be required to announce their roster for the division series against the Braves until 1 p.m. Eastern on Thursday. But one of the big questions in recent days is whether the Giants three highest-paid players will be on it.

title: G.E.: A Buyer Once More
description: General Electric marked its return to the takeover track with its first major deals since the start of the financial crisis, with G.E. executives suggesting that more are likely to follow in the coming months, Reuters writes.

title: Nets Show the Way From M.S.G. to Newark
description: Terrence Williams stood outside Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, in the heart of Knicks territory, an act the Nets hope their fans will soon follow on their way to Newark.

title: Smaller Firms Could Have Taken on Soured Assets
description: The Treasury Departments program to soak up soured mortgage assets may have unnecessarily excluded smaller, well-qualified fund managers to the detriment of taxpayers, a U.S. bailout watchdog said on Thursday, Reuters reports.

title: Yankees Take Game 1 of A.L. Division
description: The Yankees overcame the Twins early lead in Game 1 of the American League division series to win, 6-4.

title: With Rally, Yankees Prevail Once Again
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Fans rushed through the right-field gates at Target Field when they opened Wednesday evening, the new ballpark radiant and glistening for its playoff debut. It was a symbol of a new era  the move to an open-air palace from a dome, to a pitcher-friendly stadium from a hitters haven  and that, at least, was the Minnesota Twins hope entering another series against their postseason nemesis.

title: World Bank and I.M.F. at Odds Over Hot Money
description: Emerging economies should consider steps to contain fund flows that could cause currency rallies and asset bubbles, the World Bank chief was quoted as saying, but the International Monetary Fund called such actions undesirable, Reuters reports.

title: News Quiz | October 7, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Real Estate Collapse Spells Havoc in Dubai
description: On a sultry June evening in 2007, more than 100 people camped out at the offices of Emaar, a prestigious Dubai property developer, to ensure that they would land a coveted spot in a gleaming new skyscraper scheduled to open this year near the Burj Khalifa, the worlds tallest building, Liz Alderman writes in The New York Times.

title: Payment to End Wells Fargo Inquiry
description: Wells Fargo is paying $24 million to end an investigation by eight states into whether lenders acquired by the bank gave risky mortgages to consumers without disclosing their perils, The Associated Press reports.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 7, 2010
description: Test your vocabulary skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article For the Unemployed Over 50, Fears of Never Working Again.

title: Stephen Pace, Painter and Abstract Expressionist, Is Dead at 91
description: Stephen Pace, whose exuberant style applied Abstract Expressionist scale and directness to figurative painting, died on Sept. 23 in an assisted-living center in New Harmony, Ind. He was 91 and until two years ago had divided his time between homes in Manhattan and Stonington, Me.

title: Fitch Downgrades Ireland
description: Ireland got an unwelcome jolt Wednesday as Fitch Ratings cut its sovereign credit rating to the lowest level of any of the major agencies, citing the heavy burden of bailing out the countrys banking sector, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

title: Vale Said Set to Invest $20 Billion Next Year
description: Vale, the Brazilian mining company that is the worlds largest producer of iron ore, will invest at least $20 billion in 2011, a source close to the company said on Wednesday, Reuters reports.

title: Madoff Clan Denies Role and Seeks Dismissal
description: Nearly two years after the revelation of Bernard L. Madoffs vast investment fraud, family members who were executives at his firm insist they had nothing to do with it, asking a judge on Wednesday to halt a bid to sue them for nearly $200 million, Reuters reports.

title: Daily Lexeme: Boozeroo
description: Todays word, in association with the voluminous Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Pasta + Tacos = Delicious?
description: WHO originated the spaghetti taco, and on WHAT television show?

title: After Loss, Twins Mull Their Yankee Curse
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Michael Cuddyer thought the ball would land foul. But as the Minnesota Twins first baseman watched Mark Teixeiras high fly ball hug the right field line, descend, and finally fall into the seats just inside the foul pole, he tried not to think what most of the agonized Twins fans at Target Field were thinking.

title: Deutsche Publishes Postbank Tender
description: Deutsche Bank published the terms of its tender offer for Postbank on its Web site on Thursday, saying the 25 euro per share bid would expire on November 4.

title: Novelis Seeks to Buy BP Stake in Venture
description: Novelis, a unit of the Indian aluminum maker Hindalco Industries, is in talks to buy BP out of its 60 percent stake in their United States joint venture, Logan Aluminum, for $600 million, the business newspaper Mint reported on Thursday.

title: Can Money Buy You Happiness?
description: A Bucks blog post ponders a recent study from Princeton University that found that people reported an increase in happiness as their incomes rose to $75,000 a year. Then, the impact of rising income on happiness levels off, the post says. What do you think of this finding? How much money do you think you would need a year to be happy? Do you think more money would make you more happy? If so, then how, as the blog post asks, do you explain the fact that there are plenty of people who seem to have very little money and lots of happiness?

title: Gates Foundation Backs ABC News Project
description: From Bill Carter at Media Decoder:

title: Eventbrite Books More Cash
description: From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

title: Goldman Sachs and the Economy
description: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: France Gives Ground on European Union Fund Rules
description: France backed away from its total opposition to a vital part of the European Unions proposed rules for hedge funds and private-equity funds, making a Europe-wide set of laws for the institutions more likely, The Financial Times reports.

title: Site in Hungary Was Listed as Risky
description: BUDAPEST  The storage pond filled with caustic alumina-processing waste that burst and inundated several Hungarian villages this week was on a 2006 watch list of more than 150 industrial sites that were at risk for accidents that could contaminate the Danube River, according to an environmental group.

title: Whitneys Foresight Falters After Citi Prediction
description: Meredith Whitney, the bank analyst who jumped to celebrity from obscurity by correctly predicting Citigroups dividend cut, is having less success divining stock market winners and losers, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Former Jefferies Fund Manager Convicted of Fraud
description: A former hedge fund manager in New York has been convicted on federal charges that he participated in a $7 million insider-trading fraud, The Associated Press reported.

title: Betfair I.P.O. Values Company at Up to $2.3 Billion
description: Betfair, the worlds biggest Internet betting exchange, set an indicative price range for its initial public offering of between 11 and 14, valuing the company at almost 1.5 billion ($2.3 billion) at the top end, The Telegraph reported.

title: Blackstone Stands by Its Dynegy Bid
description: A Blackstone Group executive tamped down expectations of a higher bid for Dynegy, saying that its $4.7 billion bid for the power producer was a full and fair price, not to mention a steep premium, Reuters reported.

title: Time May Be Genzymes Best Defense
description: Time may be Genzymes best defense against a $18.5 billion hostile takeover bid from Sanofi-Aventis, after Genzyme shed protections that could have helped deflect an unwanted suitor, Bloomberg News reported.

title: CNOs White Elephant, Le Chateau, Finds Buyer
description: Le Chateau Renaissance is a seven-bedroom mansion in Indiana. As well as the bedrooms, the property has nine fireplaces, two swimming pools, a walk-in closet big enough to live in, and now, a new owner.

title: Newsweeks Price Tag: $1
description: So just how much did Sidney Harman pay for Newsweek? The bargain-basement price of $1.

title: When Colorful Fashions Reigned at Wimbledon
description: With the U.S. Open behind them, tennis fans can still find something to satisfy their appetites until Grand Slam season starts again. On the grounds of Wimbledon (Church Road, Wimbledon; 44-208-946-6131; wimbledon.org) a year-round museum is devoted to the joys and history of the sport  and one of their current exhibits showcases Ted Tinling, the popular and controversial designer of tennis dresses for most of the top female players, including Billie Jean King and Margaret Court.

title: Renault Sells $4.2 Billion Volvo Stake
description: Renault, the French carmaker, said Wednesday that it was selling more than 300 million shares of the Swedish truckmaker Volvo AB to institutional investors to raise more than 3 billion euros, or $4.2 billion, with plans to use the money to reduce its debt by divesting the nearly 15 percent stake in the company.

title: Revisiting Jets Timid Play Against Ravens
description: The Jets opening loss to the Ravens might as well have been four years ago, not four weeks ago.

title: Charting Mark Sanchezs Progress
The Almanac as Early iPhone
description: Todays idea: The Old Farmers Almanac deserves new respect as the iPhone of early America, a scholar argues.

title: WaMu Bank Bondholders Settle for $335 Million
description: A group of Washington Mutual creditors have signed on to a settlement that pushes the banks reorganization plan a step closer to approval, The Associated Press reported.

title: K.K.R. Biggest Spender on Deals for Past 5 Years
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company has committed more money to buy companies over the past five years than any other private-equity firm in the world, according to data compiled by Bloomberg News.

title: Warburg to Invest $150 Million in National Penn
description: Warburg Pincus, the private-equity firm, will invest $150 million in National Penn Bancshares for a 16.4 percent stake in the company, an operator of banks in Pennsylvania and elsewhere, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Permira Takes Stake in Medical Device Maker
description: Permira is taking a majority stake in Creganna-Tactx Medical, an Irish medical device maker, in the British private-equity firms first health care deal in a decade.

title: Statoil Seeks $850 Million From Fuel and Retail I.P.O.
description: Statoil, Norways largest oil and gas company, aims to raise 3.84 billion kroner to 4.92 billion kroner ($850 million) by selling shares in its gas station and transport fuel unit, Bloomberg News reported.

title: European Central Banks Hold Rates Steady
description: The European Central Bank signaled Thursday that it would stick to its policy of gradually removing extraordinary economic stimulus measures, even as other monetary authorities appeared to be moving in the opposite direction.

title: 3 Newspaper Groups Back Ongo, a News Start-Up
description: Ongo, an online news venture based in Silicon Valley, has nabbed $12 million in financing from three of the countrys largest newspaper groups.

title: Flood of Campaign Cash Becomes the Issue
description: In January, during his first State of the Union address, President Obama predicted that a U.S. Supreme Court decision would open the floodgates of money into campaigns. He warned against elections that are bankrolled by powerful interests.

title: New LED Display to Give New York Taxis Ads More Pop
description: The latest upgrade to the glowing signs atop New York City taxi cabs, which have been strutting their advertising stuff for more than 30 years, borrows technology from the latest flat-panel television sets. They will be lighted by LED.

title: Key Matchups: Euro 2012 Qualifiers
description: The outstanding matchups in Euro 2012 qualifiers on Friday and Saturday, with home teams listed first:

title: Lehman Push Is Said to Lack Legal Grounding
description: As Lehman Brothers bankruptcy estate battles Barclays Capital over the deal that handed over much of the fallen investment bank to its British rival, a Bloomberg News columnist sees a few fundamental flaws in Lehmans case.

title: Eola Property Trust Plans $675 Million I.P.O.
description: Eola Property Trust is seeking to raise as much as $675 million in an initial public offering, the company said Wednesday.

title: Was Belichick Right to Trade Moss?
description: Don Banks of Sports Illustrated has it right. Everyone has an opinion on the Randy Moss trade  and feel free to share yours in the comments section  but it would be interesting to know what one person in particular is thinking.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Wall Streets gender gap, and its hormonal explanation: You put on a trade, you get it right, you make a big win, your testosterone levels go up, you get more confident, you want more risk and this thing feeds on itself.

title: Paladino to Broadcast Message Across State
description: Carl P. Paladino, the Republican candidate for governor, has quietly purchased several minutes of television time to broadcast a synchronized message across the state on Thursday, his campaign said.

title: Mario Vargas Llosa Wins Nobel Literature Prize
description: Mario Vargas Llosa, the Peruvian writer and author of novels including The Time of the Hero, The Green House and Conversation in the Cathedral, won the 2010 Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday. In its citation, the Swedish Academy hailed Mr. Vargas Llosa, 74, for his cartography of structures of power and his trenchant images of the individuals resistance, revolt and defeat.

title: Week 5 N.F.L. Game Probabilities, and Home Fields Value
Vargas Llosa Takes Nobel in Literature
description: The Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa, whose deeply political work vividly examines the perils of power and corruption in Latin America, won the 2010 Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday.

title: Man Group Jumps on Bid Speculation
description: Man Group, the hedge-fund manager buying GLG Partners, rose the most in more than four months amid speculation that an unidentified United States bank may make an offer for the firm, Bloomberg News reports.

title: It Isnt Just Chinas Currency
description: The fourth post in our renminbi series comes from Clyde Prestowitz, a former Reagan administration official who runs the Economic Strategy Institute.

title: Hevesi Pleads Guilty in Pension Case
description: Former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, once considered a leading voice on corporate governance and ethics, stood before a judge on Thursday and calmly explained how he took part in a sprawling corruption scheme involving New York States $125 billion pension fund while serving as its sole trustee.

title: Europe Weighs Limits on Bankers Pay
description: European Union authorities are set to clamp down on compensation in the finance sector as delegates from the unions 27 member states meet in London to write up new rules to limit bonuses, The Financial Times reports.

title: Night Watch: Talk of Witches and an Apology
description: Prepping for his Wednesday night appearance on CBSs Late Show With David Letterman, the White House senior adviser David Axelrod probably knew that there would be a joke about the presidential seal falling off a lectern on Monday while President Obama was speaking.

title: September Sales Topped Forecasts for U.S. Retailers
description: Back-to-school sales that were stronger than expected have retailers cautiously hoping consumers are back and gearing up for a robust holiday shopping season.

title: Hevesi Pleads Guilty to Felony
description: 12:52 p.m. | Updated Former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi pleaded guilty on Thursday to steering millions of dollars in state pension money to an investment firm in return for kickbacks that included travel and other expenses, and campaign funds, The New York Timess William Rashbaum and Danny Hakim reported.

title: Who Owns A.I.G. (a Continuing Story)
description: The federal governments exit plan from the American International Group involves one of the largest corporate reorganizations in history. It contemplates the conversion and sale of $49.1 billion in the governments preferred share ownership interests, the $15.5 billion sale of A.I.G.s Alico subsidiary to MetLife, the approximately $15 billion initial public offering of the companys American International Assurance subsidiary and the repayment of a $20 billion loan to the Federal Reserve.

title: Tunnel Of Idiocy
description: Many reports that Chris Christie is about to scuttle the second rail tunnel under the Hudson. If so, its arguably the worst policy decision ever made by the government of New Jersey  and thats saying a lot.

title: Its All in the Game: A Monopoly Tribute to The Wire
description: A week ago it seemed as if the television producer David Simon had reached the pinnacle of his achievements when he was named the winner of a MacArthur Foundation genius grant. But a British comedy publication has given him perhaps a higher honor by creating a Monopoly board inspired by his HBO series The Wire.

title: Food Stamps Wont Buy Sodas, if the City Has Its Way
description: Happy M.T.A. fare increase day. Heres what were reading this drizzly, windy morning:

title: Hello Again: A Field Guide to Parents Weekend
description: Bloggers Note: Periodically on The Choice, we look past the college search to the college experience itself. No matter how old (or young) their children, I suspect many parents will relate to this essay. Jacques Steinberg

title: The Mom-Bomb
description: The effect of motherhood on the pay of female managers.Writing for Fox 5 Money, Melanie Alnwick observed, theres a new word in Washington to describe womens pay  the mom-bomb:

title: Poetry Pairing | October 7, 2010
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Thai Leader Defends Crackdown as Way to Ensure Stability
description: BRUSSELS  Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva of Thailand acknowledged that a continuing crackdown against the opposition might have led to possible human rights abuses in his country, but he insisted that the emergency policies were necessary to ensure stability.

title: M.T.A. Approves Transit Fare Increases
description: Updated, 11:31 a.m. | The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted 12 to 2 this morning to approve a package of fare increases for its subways, buses and commuter railroads, the third time in three years that New Yorkers face a stiff rise in the cost of getting around.

title: Folksy Ad Not So Folksy After All
description: 2:25 p.m. | Updated Kevin McLaughlin, a spokesman for Mr. Raeses campaign, emailed the following statement this afternoon: The ad is ridiculous and I am happy to say that no one with the Raese campaign had anything to do with it. As a matter of fact, we asked that it be taken down long before it went public. But this race isnt about TV ads, its about the future of West Virginia. Joe Manchin is desperate to avoid talking about the issues because he knows when we do that West Virginians overwhelmingly dont want him in Washington rubber stamping President Obamas radical agenda.

title: For Comics Fans, City Leaps Off the Page
description: EVERYONE knows that the Comic-Con International in San Diego is like a nerds-are-cool Woodstock, where freak flags are waved proudly and Hollywood sweats to build buzz for its releases. But New York is the birthplace of comic books, and the New York Comic Con, at just five years old, has become a respectable contender as the it place for a pop-culture celebration.

title: For One Bookmaker, All Bets Are Off for British Literary Prize
description: Had you been inclined to wager on the winner of the 2010 Nobel Prize in Literature based on the odds set by Ladbrokes, the British bookmaking chain, you might have put your money on the Swedish poet Tomas Transtromer, the Syrian poet Adonis, the Kenyan novelist Ngugi wa Thiongo or the South Korean poet Ko Un. And you would have come home with a big fat goose egg when the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa (who was given 25-1 odds by Ladbrokes) was named the winner on Thursday morning.

title: Photos of the Moment | Alexander McQueen
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

title: Thursday Reading: Start of Fees for Food on Continental Flights
description: A variety of consumer-focused stories appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Early Word: Money Matters
description: From the global economy to the world of politics, money is driving the conversation in Washington this Thursday.

title: In Fierce Opposition to a Muslim Center, Echoes of an Old Fight
description: Many New Yorkers were suspicious of the newcomers plans to build a house of worship in Manhattan. Some feared the project was being underwritten by foreigners. Others said the strangers beliefs were incompatible with democratic principles.

title: Maldives President Installs Solar Roof
description: President Mohamed Nasheed of Maldives, a sun-baked nation of 1,200 low islands south of India, donned jeans and a hard hat earlier today and helped install 48 donated solar photovoltaic panels on the roof of his official residence in the crowded capital, Male (the photo below, taken by Mohamed Ali, is from the government Flickr.com photo stream). Just last year Nasheed donned scuba gear for an underwater cabinet meeting ahead of climate talks in Copenhagen.

title: Keeping Score: The Parallel Paths of Halladay and Lee
description: Neil Paine is an analyst at Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

title: On Our Radar: Virginias Second Subpoena on Climate Research
description: Virginias attorney general, an outspoken climate change skeptic, continues his investigation of the former University of Virginia climate researcher Michael Mann, issuing a second civil subpoena demanding documents related to a state-funded grant application, which he contends was marred by fraud. A previous subpoena had been rejected by a state judge, who concluded that Attorney General Ken T. Cuccinelli had failed to provide any justification for suspecting that fraud had been committed. [Washington Post]

title: Woman Falls Eight Stories on Staten Island
description: Updated, 1:05 p.m. | A young woman fell from an eighth-floor window of a public housing building on Staten Island, fire officials said. We erroneously reported that she had died, but fire officials say she is in serious condition with multiple fractures and broken bones. The full extent of her injuries was not immediately known. Police officials say the woman is 19, but they have not released her identity.

title: Turku: A European Capital of Culture
description: Turku is Finlands fifth-largest city, but it is one of its most inviting.

title: Popcast: Nellie McKay and Bruno Mars
description: This week on Popcast, The Timess music podcast, Nellie McKay plays two songs on the ukulele from her new album, Home Sweet Mobile Home (Verve). (We are proud to note that this is our third ukulele performance on Popcast. Last year we had a session by Arms, the group led by Todd Goldstein of Harlem Shakes, and in May we had a visit from the otherworldly-voiced Jonsi of Sigur Ros.)

title: Ayrton Senna Movie to Open in Japan
description: The documentary on the life and career of Ayrton Senna, the great Brazilian Formula One racecar driver, will have a special screening in Suzuka, Japan, on Thursday, as teams prepare for the Grand Prix of Japan, according to The Globe and Mail. The film opens in theaters across Japan on Friday.

title: Keeping It Kosher
description: IS HE COMING BACK? Clara Santos Perez was peering out the windows and across the street, where an imposing man in black stood, his face turned in her direction.

title: Giving the Honeybee Its Due
description: Insects are not the warmest and fuzziest members of the animal kingdom. Your average mosquito, not to mention bedbugs or lice, just cant compete in the sweepstakes of human affection with a soulful dog, its head nuzzled in your lap, or the anciently wise demeanor of the average house cat.

title: Cuba Journal: Jazz at Lincoln Center Players Dance to Students Beat
description: Over the next few days, Victoria Burnett will be reporting for ArtsBeat on Jazz at Lincoln Centers visit to Cuba.

title: Montreal Chef Is Coming to Fedora
description: A second veteran of Martin Picards quirky Montreal restaurant Au Pied de Cochon is coming to New York. Medhi Brunet-Benkritly, who worked for four years there, and at Toqu before that, will be the chef at Fedora, the venerable Greenwich Village bistro that Gabriel Stulman, an owner of Joseph Leonard, and his partners bought and are renovating, to open in November.

title: Woman Arrested in Colorado After Destroying Artwork
description: A Montana woman was arrested Wednesday at a Colorado museum after she destroyed an artwork that some observers say depicts Jesus engaged in a sex act. The Denver Post reported that Kathleen Folden of Kalispell, Mont., was taken into police custody after she entered the Loveland Museum/Gallery in Loveland, Colo., and destroyed a work called The Misadventures of Romantic Cannibals, a lithograph by Enrique Chagoya. The police told The Post that Ms. Folden had used a crowbar or similar tool to break the plexiglass in front of the work and then tore it up. She has been charged with criminal mischief, a felony punishable by a fine of up to $2,000.

title: Next on The Gelada Bachelorette
description: Saturday, Oct. 2

title: Readers Potluck Dishes
description: A few weeks ago, we asked you to submit recipes and photos of your go-to potluck dishes. We received more than 350 entries, which came from around the world and varied fromShanghainese style belly pork to triple chocolate pecan bites. It was really tough to narrow it down to our top 20, not to mention the five we selected as editors picks, but after much debating, testing and tasting, we managed to make the call.

title: The D.E.A. Changes a Policy on Painkillers
description: Following a report in The Times that nursing home residents were being forced to go without necessary painkillers, the federal Drug Enforcement Agency on Wednesday issued new rules designed to expedite the dispensing of these drugs in long-term care facilities. Read the full article, and share your thoughts in the comments section.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A man plays a violin in downtown So Paulo, Brazil.

title: What You Can Get Free
description: What do passport photographs, workouts and e-books have in common? You can easily get all three at no cost, according to Kiplinger.com, which recently released its fourth annual list of 33 quality freebies.

title: Personal Income Drops in New York Region
description: Driven by declines on Wall Street, total personal income earned by residents of metropolitan New York fell last in 2009 for the first time in 40 years  by 4.1 percent  according to the latest data from the governments Bureau of Economic Analysis.

title: New Study Names Honda as the Greenest Automaker
description: Honda has the greenest vehicles in the United States, with Toyota and Hyundai tying for second place, according to a study released on Thursday by the Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit advocacy group.

title: Corruption in Afghanistan: An Aid Workers Experience
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  I was talking to a friend about the challenges of working in an environment of endemic corruption, and I remarked that it takes so many forms here, causing his eyes momentarily to roll back into his head.

title: After 25 Years, Johnson to Leave Page Six
description: Richard Johnson, who has edited The New York Posts Page Six gossip column for nearly 25 years, is leaving the New York tabloid for a job in Los Angeles.

title: Modified Corn Aids Nearby Farmers, and Vice Versa
description: A long-term study of corn production in the Midwest has found that the widespread use of varieties engineered with a bacterial gene that kills insect pests has had big benefits in adjacent fields of conventional corn  cutting infestations there and boosting farmers income by billions of dollars. The paper, Areawide Suppression of European Corn Borer with Bt Maize Reaps Savings to Non-Bt Maize Growers, is being published in the Oct. 8 edition of the journal Science.

title: Theater Talkback: From Seat to Stage
description: To be sure, begins a frantically comforting passage in a press release for Hotel Savoy, the new show from P.S. 122 at the Goethe-Institut, this is not a performance predicated on traditional audience participation. There is no pressure for visitors to perform, there is no stage to be thrust upon.

title: Indonesian Military Joins a Local Terrorism Fight
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia has sent its military to fight local militants for the first time in nearly a decade to send a strong message to the insurgents, who are shifting from suicide bombings to armed attacks on the government, the countrys antiterrorism chief said Thursday.

title: An Aftermarket GPS, Sony-Style
description: Not every driver likes the suction-cup aesthetic of aftermarket GPS systems. And for those who have space in their dashboard, Sony has two new models that combine audio features with full-service navigational abilities.

title: Is Arenas Seeing the End With Wizards?
description: The Wizards All-Star guard Gilbert Arenas is known for his interesting statements. They can range from funny to odd, and never fail to get a reaction.

title: Hot Lips
description: Franois Narss makeup can be described as dramatic, but his limited-edition Bento Box lipstick set takes the concept literally. Inspired by a porcelain pot of lip stain used for kabuki actors that Nars found in Japan 10 years ago, the set of two cups of hand-poured color comes in a handsome wooden box with a wisteria-handled lip brush. Ive always been fascinated with the concept of kabuki makeup, Nars says. Its about symbolism and using color to create drama. The lipstick application is as seductive as its presentation. You dip the brush into the cup, around the perimeter, to pick up product, and simply paint, he says. Its a beautiful process. Unless you want to look like a Japanese theater character, however, Nars recommends using a little restraint: Its highly pigmented, so I suggest starting out light and building for desired intensity. It seems intimidating, but the texture is creamy and light and will move easily. The set will be available for $125 beginning November 1 at Saks Fifth Avenue and Barneys New York, or go to narscosmetics.com/bento to pre-order.

title: Euro Clashes and Friendlies Offer Compelling Soccer Plot Lines
description: The international furlough means the worlds top leagues will go dark this weekend while their best players don the jerseys of their national teams. Most of the compelling games will be played in Europe, where teams will continue the Euro 2012 qualifying campaign. (Rob Hughes suggests these games to watch.) Elsewhere, teams will play friendly matches, including the Americans Oct. 9 exhibition against Poland and their Oct. 12 match with Colombia.

title: Finally, a Chance to Dress Up Again
description: WE all age, and that includes drag queens, even with their limitless tools of illusion. So it was on Saturday night when Joey Arias, the gender-bending chanteuse who swanned across downtown during the 1990s, celebrated his birthday with fellow disco demimondes.

title: Dont Look Back, Brooklyn; Houston Is Gaining on You
description: It would still be the fourth largest city in America, but for how much longer?

title: U.S. Believes Arab States Wont Scuttle Mideast Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration believes it has persuaded Arab states not to scuttle the fledgling Middle East peace negotiations, officials said Thursday, despite the Israeli governments refusal to freeze Jewish settlements and a vow by the Palestinians to walk away if Israel did not.

title: Scene City: Happy Birthday, Joey Arias
description: On a recent Saturday night, Joey Arias, the gender-bending chanteuse who swanned across downtown during the 1990s, celebrated his birthday with fellow disco demimondes.

title: Nearly 5 Jobless Workers Per Opening in August
description: There were slightly fewer than five unemployed people for every job opening in August, according to a Labor Department report. The ratio was largely unchanged from July but below its highs from last fall.

title: Numerology Meets Filmmaking in One Day on Earth Project
description: What will you be doing on 10-10-10? The organizers of One Day on Earth dont care what the answer is as long as you videotape yourself doing it.

title: Who Maimed the Economy, and How
description: As I was watching Inside Job, Charles Fergusons meticulous and infuriating documentary about the causes and consequences of the financial crisis of 2008, an odd, archaic sentence kept popping into my head. The words come from the second chapter of The Scarlet Letter and are spoken in frustration and disgust by an old Puritan woman who watches Hester Prynne, publicly disgraced but without any sign of remorse, making her way from Salems prison to a scaffold in its market square. She has brought shame upon us all, the anonymous woman remarks. Is there not law for it?

title: What Were Reading: Drug Testing for the Unemployed
Gloves Off in Colorado House Race
description: The advertising battle is heating up in Colorados Fourth District, where Representative Betsy Markey is locked in a fierce battle in her bid for a second term.

title: Timescast | October 7, 2010
description: Caustic mudslide in Hungary, why the Supreme Court may be deadlocked and a look at the new old Rome.

title: Which Pitcher Would You Rather Have, Lee or Halladay?
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Yes, the Rays and Rangers saw it, too.Roy Halladays no-hitter for the Phillies against the Reds may have come in the National League playoffs, but Halladay spent 12 years pitching in the American League. Plenty of Rays and Rangers have struggled to get hits off of him, too, over the years.

title: Forecast Sees Drug-Sales Growth Overseas
description: The global drug market will grow 5 to 7 percent in 2011, to $880 billion, as higher spending in nations like China, Brazil and India makes up for slow growth and patent losses in the United States, according to a forecast released Wednesday by IMS Health, an industry data company.

title: Time Dwindles for 3Ms Offer for Cogent
description: The 3M Companys tender offer for Cogent expires Thursday at midnight. It is going to be a nail-biter.

title: The Morning Skate: 30 Teams Worth of Questions
description: All around the world, the puck drops on the 93rd N.H.L. regular season today, a premiere that stretches across nine time zones.

title: Medical Student Distress and the Risk of Doctor Suicide
description: Several years ago, I learned that a physician in a town not too far from where I was practicing had committed suicide. Neither I nor my hospital colleagues knew him, but according to the story we heard, he was the father of young children, was respected by doctors and patients alike and had struggled privately with mental illness since medical school.

title: When Doctors Get Depressed
description: In todays Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen discusses the alarmingly high rates of depression and suicide among doctors.

title: Sharp Jabs as Rivals for Senate Debate Again
description: NORWALK, Conn.  The Republican candidate, Linda E. McMahon, and her Democratic opponent, Richard Blumenthal, traded harsh attacks on Thursday in a debate that underscored the increasingly combative tone of the Senate race in Connecticut.

title: Now Reading | Handcrafted Modern
description: Of all the houses that designers create, their own are often the most interesting, since they tend to be the most revealing. Leslie Williamson, a San Francisco photographer, assumed that this was true of Modernist designers, too, but had a hard time finding books on the subject. Thus, Handcrafted Modern: At Home With Midcentury Designers (Rizzoli) was born. An intimate look at 13 houses and one apartment (that of the furniture designer Vladimir Kagan), Williamsons book visits the homes of masters of studio furniture like Wharton Esherick, George Nakashima and J.B. Blunk; industrial designers like Russel Wright, Charles and Ray Eames, and Irving Harper; and the architects Walter Gropius and Albert Frey.

title: Four French Horn Players Take On Lady Gaga, Queen and More
description: The publicity photos make them look like either the Four Hornswomen of the Apocalypse or neon-colored aerobics instructors. They go by the stage names Freedom Barbie, Velvet Barbie, Jungle Barbie and Attila the Horn. They play arrangements of songs by Lady Gaga, Michael Jackson, Queen and other pop acts.

title: A Horse Overhead
description: An interactive look at the set of the Broadway musical Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson.

title: Honda Is Greenest, Study Suggests
description: Our friends at the Wheels blog report that Honda has the greenest vehicles in the United States, according to a study released on Thursday by the Union of Concerned Scientists. The automaker barely edged out Toyota and Hyundai, which tied for second place. The results were based on the fleets impact on global warming.

title: A Moderate Voice Is Silenced in Pakistan
description: A spokesman for the Taliban in Pakistans Swat Valley claimed responsibility this week for the murder of an outspoken critic of the Islamist militants, Dr. Mohammad Farooq Khan, a religious scholar and educator who was gunned down along with his assistant on Saturday.

title: Waiting for Luggage With Vargas Llosa
description: QUITO, Ecuador  Flying above the Andes allows time for many things: typing away on a laptop, dozing off or daydreaming as one gazes below at the jagged peaks that run up and down South Americas spine. But on one such flight in 2008, I had trouble concentrating on any of them.

title: Drafting a College List in a Tough Economy
description: A few weeks into senior year, anxious students start asking, Am I applying to enough colleges?

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Creative Accounting in California
description: Why worry about budget deficits when you can merely assume they wont exist?:

title: Christie Halts Train Tunnel, Citing Its Cost
description: The largest public transit project in the nation, a commuter train tunnel under the Hudson River to Manhattan, was halted on Thursday by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey because, he said, the state could not afford its share of the projects rising cost.

title: Poetry on Film: Interpreting Howl in the 21st Century
description: Overview | How can poetry both reflect and transcend the era in which it is written? How can looking at a poem from multiple perspectives illuminate its meaning? In this lesson, students consider a film about Allen Ginsbergs Howl, study the poem and express their ideas about poetry, their generation and life in writing and on film.

title: The Search for an Internet Business Continues
description: Its been one year since my brother-in-law, Dan, began his search to buy the perfect Internet business. In those 12 months, he has reviewed hundreds of listings, made inquiries on about 50 and submitted six offers. None of them resulted in a deal.

title: Thelonious Monk, Created Wry Jazz Melodies and New Harmonies
description: Thelonious Monk, the pianist and composer whose wry, angular melodies and unusual harmonic progressions are among the most striking contributions to the jazz repertory, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital in New Jersey at the age of 64. He had suffered a stroke on Feb. 5.

title: Agnew Quits Vice Presidency And Admits Tax Evasion In '67; Nixon Consults On Successor
description: Washington, Oct, 10--Spiro T. Agnew resigned as Vice President of the United States today under an agreement with the Department of Justice to admit evasion of Federal income taxes and avoid imprisonment.

title: Maldives Leader Gets a Solar Roof
description: The president of Maldives, an island nation that is deeply concerned about global warming and rising seas, has had 48 donated solar panels installed on his roof, Andy Revkin reports at his Dot Earth blog. The point was to lend support to global efforts to rein in greenhouse gases from fossil fuel emissions through steps like embracing solar energy.

title: Mrs. Roosevelt, First Lady 12 Years, Often Called 'World's Most Admired Woman'
description: Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was more involved in the minds and hearts and aspirations of people than any other First Lady in history. By the end of her life she was one of the most esteemed women in the world.

title: Astronauts Carry Out Early Maneuvers on 163-Orbit Journey
description: Cape Kennedy, Fla., Oct. 11--Three American astronauts rocketed into orbit today for the first manned test flight of the Apollo spacecraft, which may some day fly men to the moon.

title: Testing Videos on Cellphones  With Flash
description: Update: An earlier version of this post incorrectly stated that videos from nytimes.com cannot be viewed on Apples iPhone or iPad.

title: A Second Season of Craigslist TV
description: Craigslist, the repository of all things classified, is extending its foray into the realm of video with the start on Thursday of a second season of a Web series that the company calls Craigslist TV.

title: Of Tactics in Public Housing, and Recommended Reading
description: Policing tactics in New York City Housing Authority developments are under a microscope.

title: Verizon Expects a Lot More Devices for Its Old Network
description: By now, the rumors of a Verizon iPhone are as common (and tired) as Lindsay Lohans repeated stints in jail. But as the latest round of speculation blazes through the Web, one detail doesnt seem to add up. Why would Verizon unveil a sleek new Apple device running on its aging 3G network?

title: American Ballet Theater to Visit Moscow
description: First Cuba, now Russia. American Ballet Theater has added Moscow to its touring itinerary for the 2010-11 season, the company announced Thursday. The March engagement, part of the Mstislav Rostropovich Week Festival, will include the premiere of a new work by Benjamin Millepied commissioned by the festival. American Ballet Theater last performed in Moscow in 1960. That was also the last time it appeared onstage in Havana, where the company will be returning next month.

title: Elmer Sperry Dies; Famous Inventor
description: Elmer A. Sperry, inventor, died yesterday morning at St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, from complications which set in after he had recovered from an operation for gallstones six weeks ago. He was in his seventieth year.

title: ROBERT E. LEE.
description: Richmond, Oct. 13--Richmond presents today a scene of mourning hardly witnessed in this generation. The stores and public buildings are all closed. The bells in all parts of the city are tolling. On many doors are pictures and photographs of Gen. Lee, draped in crape, with evergreen. The citizens are standing in groups on the principal thoroughfares and talking in subdued tones of the sad event. The feeling that he ought to be buried here, at the State's expense, is universal, and the Legislature, in making this request of his family, reiterated the public desire. The City Council met this afternoon, at the call of the Mayor. Gov. Walker sent the following Message to the General Assembly:

title: Milan in Bloom
description: For an international style capital, home to A-list designers who set the trends and dominate the news, Milan gets no respect. The fashion pack descends four times a year and complains about the weather, the traffic. They shop, pillaging the stores on Via Montenapoleone, and then they leave, in a hurry to get to Paris. Even the Italians dislike Milan. Or rather, the Italians in particular dislike it. Any native of Rome or Florence or Bologna will tell you that all people do there is work work work, that its gray, industrial, unwelcoming, without a soul. Ive heard nicer things about Cleveland.

title: Making a Movie Into a Musical
description: Bartlett Sher, the director of "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown," talks about turning Pedro Almodovar's movie into a musical.

title: Lenny Bruce, Uninhibited Comic, Found Dead in Hollywood Home
description: Hollywood, Aug. 3 (AP)--Lenny Bruce, the controversial nightclub comedian whose acts were sprinkled with four-letter words and pungent social satire, died tonight in his home on Hollywood Boulevard. He was 40 years old.

title: BIGGEST PACIFIC AIR FLEET BOMBS RABAUL; WRECKS 177 PLANES, 123 SHIPS IN SURPRISE; BADOGLIO, DECLARING WAR, RALLIES ITALY
description: Algiers, Oct. 13--Italy declared war on Nazi Germany, her former Axis partner, at 3 P.M. today, Greenwich time [11 A.M. in New York].

title: Debating the Future of Television
description: Apple and Roku approach Internet television from very different perspectives. The products from both companies have shortcomings.

title: Dwight David Eisenhower: A Leader in War and Peace
description: Military leadership of the victorious Allied forces in Western Europe during World War II invested Dwight David Eisenhower with an immense popularity, almost amounting to devotion, that twice elected him President of the United States. His enormous political success was largely personal, for he was not basically a politician dealing in partisan issues and party maneuvers. What he possessed was a superb talent for gaining the respect and affection of the voters as the man suited to guide the nation through cold war confrontations with Soviet power around the world and to lead the country to domestic prosperity.

title:
Martin
Luther King Wins The Nobel Prize for Peace
description: Oslo, Norway, Oct. 14--The Nobel Peace prize for 1964 was awarded today to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Khrushchev Ousted From Top Posts; Brezhnev Gets Chief Party Position And Kosygin Is Named New Premier
description: Moscow, Friday, Oct. 16--Premier Khrushchev has been deprived of political power in the Soviet Union.

title: Prof. Nietzsche Dead
description: Weimar, Aug. 25.--Prof. Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the philosopher, died here today of apoplexy.

title: Losing a Father
description: When Meera Oliva last wrote for Motherlode, she shared thoughts about her son, Elan. The boy was born with a cleft lip, and, several days before the surgery, Oliva described how she would miss his imperfect smile, even though she knew the repair was necessary and the timing was right. (Elans doing wonderfully, she reports, with  just the slightest scar to show where his cleft once was, and we love his new smile just as much as we loved the old one, which we do still miss from time to time.)

title: Simulate This: Will Wright Wants to Give You Control Over a TV Series
description: Will Wright, who let players control families and metropolises in the computer games The Sims and SimCity, now wants to let players control a television series.

title: Pogues Posts: Flash on Phones
description: David Pogue examines how well cellphones run Adobe Flash in a post on his blog. Flash, he writes, is available on an increasing array of Android smartphones, but not, of course, Apples iPhone.

title: Jeb Bush Heads to Harvard
description: Jeb Bush, the former Republican governor of Florida, will be coming north after Election Day to spend a week at Harvards Institute of Politics.

title: Fall Maintenance
description: Despite the recent tropical rainfall events and microcells that have uprooted 100-year-old oaks in the Northeast, the early fall weather has generally been friendly to local beehives. The weather has been hot, and fall flowers, like goldenrod, have thrived. As I strolled through the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens the other day, scouting with a colleague to prepare for a coming school field trip, I was jealous that local Brooklyn beekeepers had it so good, as hundreds, if not thousands, of honeybees mingled with native pollinators on lush native flora in the park.

title: President Falls Far Short of Expectations, Poll Says
description: A CBS News poll out today suggests widespread disappointment with President Obama, as two-thirds of Americans say he has been an average or poor president, far below their expectations.

title: Sufi Shrine in Pakistan Is Hit by a Lethal Double Bombing
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  A nearly simultaneous double explosion that may have been the work of suicide bombers struck a crowded Sufi shrine in Pakistans main port city of Karachi on Thursday evening, killing at least 7 people and wounding 65, officials and rescue workers said.

title: South Park Targets Nascar in Season Premiere
description: In sending up Nascar and its fans for the premiere episode of its 14th season, South Park, the animated show on Comedy Central, pulls out a big whopping club.

title: A New, Shorter Format for Labor Day Telethon
description: Next year, the Muscular Dystrophy Association will dramatically cut back its annual Labor Day Telethon.

title: Obama to Veto Bill That Could Speed Foreclosures
description: WASHINGTON  As slipshod bookkeeping by some big mortgage lenders continued to rattle the housing market on Thursday, another major lender indicated it would suspend sales of foreclosed homes and White House officials said President Obama would not sign a bill that critics suggested could facilitate foreclosure fraud.

title: Microsoft Revives Windows 7 Family Pack
description: Microsoft has resurrected the Windows 7 Family Pack Upgrade, but only while supplies last.

title: What Did Microsoft and Adobe Chiefs Talk About?
description: Steven A. Ballmer, Microsofts chief executive, recently showed up with a small entourage of deputies at Adobes offices to hold a secret meeting with Adobes chief executive, Shantanu Narayen.

title: A Roy Halladay Blog Made of Dreams
description: Soon after the Phillies traded for Roy Halladay in December 2009, a 33-year-old accountant from south Philadelphia had a dream about spending an entire day at the zoo with the former Blue Jays ace. The accountant used the dream as inspiration to begin a blog on the 2010 Phillies called I Want to Go to the Zoo with Roy Halladay.

title: Spending on Housing and Transportation Fell in 2009
description: The two largest components of consumers budgets  housing and transportation  fell in 2009, according to the Labor Departments latest Consumers Expenditures survey.

title: Abandon All Hope
description: At some visceral level, I guess I was expecting Christie to back down at the last minute  expecting that there would be a still, small voice in his mind saying, If we cant do even this  if we cant follow through on a project so obviously needed, so clearly in the interests of the state and the nation  what hope is there for America?
