title: Siemens Wins Battle of Fast Trains
description: PARIS  In an effort to prepare for competition on cross-Channel rail traffic, Eurostar said Thursday that it had awarded a hotly sought contract to upgrade its aging fleet of fast trains to a Germany company, Siemens.

title: While Europe Scrimps, European Union Spends
description: BRUSSELS  In Greece, taxes are up and so is the age of retirement. In Spain, civil servants have taken pay cuts. In Britain, spending on welfare, the military and education could be chopped by a quarter.

title: Ignoring Boundaries and Borrowing Freely
description: Back in 1985, when the Museum of Modern Art inaugurated its New Photography series, appropriation was very much in vogue. Richard Prince, Sherrie Levine and other re-photographers delighted and outraged viewers with their canny absorptions of other artists work. So its fitting that New Photography 2010, which marks the 25th anniversary of the series, is all about post-appropriative practice.

title: Illinois Voters, Unhappy With Candidates, Show Few Signs of Committing
description: We havent written as much about Illinois as some other Senate contests  but it may be taking on an increasingly important role as some other races that had once looked to be competitive, like Connecticut and Missouri, now show a clearer advantage for one or another party.

title: Quote Unquote | Conspicuous Consumption
description: Karolina Kurkova was surprised to discover what the contestants on Americas Next Top Model ate. And we are surprised that none of them ever become top models?

title: Theater Listings: Oct. 8  14
description: Theater

title: Transit Economics
description: The usual suspects on the comment board are, inevitably, arguing that rail transit should pay for itself. The obvious response is that road transit doesnt; why should only public transit have to self-finance, when private vehicles generally drive on free roads built and maintained out of taxes?

title: How Did This Pass?
description: There is a report today that President Obama will pocket-veto a bill that seems to have sailed through Congress with virtually no debate.

title: Tracking Corporate Outsourcing of Jobs
description: For people already angry at American companies for moving so many jobs overseas, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has introduced a new Web site that will help make people even angrier.

title: Dont Mess With J.R.: Citi Gets Hit for $11.6 Million
description: Call it J.R. Ewings revenge.

title: Offbeat Istanbul
description: TK

title: Virtual Test Drive Offers Vroom, Vroom
description: Who said you cant teach the proverbial old dog new tricks?

title: Readers (and Another Novelist) Respond to Vargas Llosas Nobel Victory
description: This mornings announcement that the Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa has won the Nobel Prize in literature, the first for a writer in the Spanish language in two decades, has generated a strong reaction from readers. Below are some of their comments. Read more here.

title: Plouffe Says Palin Running for President Would Be Lucky
description: David Plouffe, the manager for President Obamas 2008 campaign, said today that he doubts Sarah Palin will run for president next year, saying something tells me we wont get that lucky.

title: Canels: The New Madeleine?
description: Thanks to its fame as a literary device, the tiny madeleine has an outsize reputation. But France has as many varieties of pastries as it has cheeses (though, to our knowledge, no one has ever linked them to a resistance to being governed). Two of them, the canel, a custardy confection with a caramelized crust from Bordeaux, and the financier, an almond-flour tea cake that was first sold in the area around La Bourse (traders prized them as a convenient snack, hence the name), are favorite afternoon treats with the French.

title: A Video For Chris Christie
description: Too late, I guess. But worth trying anyway.

title: The Return of the Disturbing Mushroom
description: As our Urban Forager, Ava Chin, reminds us, this is high season for mushrooms in the Northeast. And few are faring better this fall than the Disturbing Mushroom of Lincoln Place, a fungus growing in an empty street-tree pit in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Devils Have Put Together a Formidable Top Line
description: NEWARK  Three players stand out at any Devils practice, and not because they are the only ones wearing white jerseys. Two of them, Ilya Kovalchuk and Zach Parise, are wings who have become renowned as prodigious scorers.

title: First Couple Are Ohio Bound
description: Democrats in Cleveland will get a political twofer later this month: a joint campaign appearance by President Obama and his wife, Michelle.The first couple will visit the city on Oct. 17 to stump for Ohio Gov. Ted Strickland, who is in a tough race for re-election against John R. Kasich, a former Republican congressman. On Monday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was in Youngstown headlining a rally and fundraiser for the Democratic governor.

title: A Craftsmans Biography, Carved Into His Furniture
description: John Shearer eked out a living as a furniture maker in Maryland and Virginia from about 1790 to 1820. That is pretty much all scholars know about him, except that he probably was a Scottish immigrant; he inscribed furniture with references to Edinburgh; and he misspelled slogans proclaiming his loyalty to the British crown.

title: Money Guaranteed, but a Spot on Giants Roster Is Not
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If the Giants needed another reminder that the $126 million, seven-year contract they lavished on Barry Zito was not a very good investment, they got one Thursday when he was left off the 25-man roster for San Franciscos National League division series with the Atlanta Braves. Game 1 is Thursday night.

title: The Botox Special
description: Allergan, the maker of Botox, agreed last month to pay $600 million to settle criminal and civil charges that it had illegally marketed the drug for medical uses  like headaches and pain not approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Pregame Huddle: Title Contender Outlook
description: Will any team stand in the way of No. 1 Alabama? And can Boise State get back into the national title conversation?

title: The Everglades in Peril
description: Suburban sprawl in South Florida has done extensive damage to the fragile Everglades ecosystem.

title: G.M.s Wage-Cutting Deal Clears Way for a Small Car
description: ORION TOWNSHIP, Mich.  General Motors is trying to do what no other automaker has accomplished before  make money on a low-price subcompact car built in the United States with unionized labor.

title: Obama Calls for Voters to Outweigh Outside Money
description: CHICAGO  President Obama used twin campaign appearances on Thursday to lash out at the private money that has filtered into Republican coffers for the November election campaign, suggesting that some of it came from abroad, and urging the Democratic Party faithful to symbolically drown out the cash with their millions of voices.

title: What a Microsoft-Adobe Merger Might Look Like
description: Thanks to our colleague Nick Bilton at Bits, we now know that the chief executives of Microsoft and Adobe Systems met recently to discuss, among other possibilities, a potential merger of the two tech giants.

title: DC Comics to Lower Prices
description: Fans of DC Comics will have reason to celebrate in January. The company, a division of Warner Brothers Entertainment and Time Warner, announced plans to lower the price of all standard 32-page continuing comic book titles to $2.99 from $3.99.

title: In Relief, Yankees Bullpen Lines Up Just Right
description: MINNEAPOLIS  As he so often has in the past, Mariano Rivera recorded the most important out in the Yankees Game 1 victory Wednesday night. Getting Denard Span to ground out with two on and two out in the eighth inning improved the Yankees win probability by 13 percent, according to baseball-reference.com, to 92 percent over all.Their second most important out came from someone whose brightest career postseason moment also came against the Twins in last years American League division series. Derek Jeter started calling Dave Robertson Houdini last year after he escaped a bases-loaded, no-out jam in the 11th inning of Game 2.This time, Robertson was asked to get only one out, but what an out it was, striking out Jim Thome and thwarting a two-on, two-out rally in the seventh. Robertson threw three straight curve balls to Thome. The second dropped over the plate for a called second strike. The third bounced in front of the plate and drew a feeble swing.That was a beautiful sequence, Alex Rodriguez said. He came with the fastball then threw him three nasty breaking balls.Omitting a second left-handed reliever was a calculated risk by Joe Girardi, who, with left-handed starters set to pitch in four of five games, figured that Boone Logan would be sufficient to navigate through Joe Mauer, Thome and Jason Kubel. To start the seventh, Girardi went with Logan, who got two outs but gave way to Robertson after Mauer singled.The Yankees had seven more outs to get, but the bullpen was set up almost perfectly. Kerry Wood matched up well with the bottom of the Twins order, which had right-handed hitters in three of four slots, and the Yankees never have to worry about matchups when Rivera came in. Every one is in Riveras favor.If a save situation arises again Thursday, Girardi will obviously turn to Rivera again, though he was uncertain whether he would ask him to pitch multiple innings for a second straight night. Riveras struggles last month began on Sept. 11, when he surrendered two ninth-inning runs in Texas, the night after working two innings, and Girardi said he was cognizant of a possible link.I would prefer not to do it tonight, but I said that last night, Girardi said.

title: Letters: Scholarly Work
description: My assistant and I go through all the letters sent to the Public Editor. Starting this week, we will post selected letters responding to my columns, beginning with the group below. This weeks letters are in response to my most recent column, Scholarly Work, Without All the Footnotes.

title: Inside 'Marwencol'
description: The photography of Mark Hogancamp, the subject of the documentary "Marwencol."

title: When Utilities Charge for Credit Card Payments
description: Like many Bucks readers, I dont give many service providers the privilege of siphoning money directly from my checking account. Several companies automatically charge my credit card each month, but only a sacred few  a student lender and an insurer  are allowed to pull money directly.

title: The Man Who Repairs Time
description: When Marcel Zalaznick goes on vacation, a once-a-year event, he hangs a sign outside his watch-repair store on 30th Avenue that says, Gone fishing. Mr. Zalaznick, 59, is the proprietor and the sole employee of Grand Jewelers, a type of small business that feels like a rarity these days. It has been in the same spot in Queens for a long time, it turns a (modest) profit, and it is unaffected by the whims of the commercial real estate market because its owner is also its landlord.

title: The Edit | Wait and See Boutique
description: Once a design consultant for Etro and Missoni and the creator of her own high-end knitwear line, Uberta Zambeletti personifies both Milans scrappy entrepreneurial side and its affinity for bourgeois, slightly bohemian luxe. Now she is channeling her finely edited high-low sensibility at Wait and See, the boutique she just opened in a former convent near the Duomo. Milan is so full of brands, but its either cute little dresses or Balenciaga, with no in-between, she says. You should be able to get a great, affordable dress without having to go to Zara. Wait and See carries jeans, sparkly platform shoes, organic potpourri and evening wear, with prices ranging from about $3 to $1,300. Among Zambelettis favorites: Sandrina Fasolis cocktail dresses, Owen Barrys sheepskin coats, Isaac Reinas leather and silicone handbags and the American label Hazel Browns soft leather pants. Everything has a bit of an edge to it, she says, but nothing is too extreme. Via Santa Marta 14; 011-39-02-7208-0195; waitandsee.it.

title: Was Halladays Gem The Greatest Philly Sports Moment Ever? Mike Schmidt Says So
description: PHILADELPHIA  Somewhere in an old cardboard box, I have a VHS cassette from 1986 called The Greatest Moments in Philadelphia Sports History. I was 11 years old then, living in the Philadelphia area, and there was no doubt what would be the No. 1 moment: Tug McGraw striking out Willie Wilson to win the 1980 World Series.

title: Grim And Grimmer
description: EPI has the video of Tuesdays discussion on fiscal policy.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Kashmir.

title: Rangers Tim Kennedy Finds Salary Cap an Unforgiving Opponent
description: BUFFALO  The small room where you order and pick up your pies at Imperial Pizza on the south side of this city is a shrine to the two N.H.L. players the neighborhood has produced.

title: A Demand for Action on PCBs in Schools
description: Members of Congress and a state assemblywoman from New York City, the United Federation of Teachers and other groups have announced a plan to tackle the problem of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, in the citys public schools. They asked the federal Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday in a letter to step in immediately and conduct thorough testing of the schools and establish firm guidelines. The letter was signed by all 13 members of New York Citys House delegation.

title: The Caucus Click: Levittown, Pa.
Grazing in Dark Woods of the Human Soul
description: Death and grief and spiritual renewal, the brutality of war and the moral responsibility of those who bear witness to it: mighty themes are chewed over exhaustively in The Deer House, a dance-theater work from Jan Lauwers and the Brussels-based Needcompany. The piece is making its American premiere as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: House Tour: Woodstock, N.Y.
description: HOW MUCH $335,000. Taxes: $3,069.

title: Over-the-Top Style Meets Some Good-Hearted Sense
description: As Lainie Kazan recounted her life at Feinsteins at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening, it was as though the turning point in her career in the mid-1960s happened only last week. That was when she was an understudy for Barbra Streisand in Funny Girl and waited more than a year to step into the role of Fanny Brice. As she recalled, the day came, the press was invited, and Ms. Streisand appeared at the last minute.

title: PNC Said to Be Latest Lender to Suspend Foreclosed Sales
description: The PNC Financial Services Group has suspended sales of foreclosed homes for 30 days, according to a title insurer that received the memo from the bank, becoming the fourth major lender to impose a moratorium.

title: Picturing a Mind-Blowing World Made of Drugs
description: Is cosmic consciousness for real? I mean, if you have a religious vision, do you perceive a truly existing, transcendental dimension that is hidden from everyday awareness? Or is mystic revelation the illusory product of unusual neurochemical activity in your brain?

title: Broad Call for Faster Action on School PCBs
description: A coalition of elected officials and unions called on Thursday for faster action from the city and federal government to monitor and, if necessary, remove hazardous chemicals known as PCBs from as many as 700 city schools, calling the problem a serious health threat.

title: Russian Students Strip for Putins Birthday
description: Two groups of female Russian journalism students have produced dueling calendars to mark Prime Minister Vladimir Putins 58th birthday on Thursday.

title: App Smart Extra: Checking the Score
description: This weeks App Smart column looks at applications for youth sports coaches who want to improve the performance of their team. A new app will help parents and other spectators track the games themselves.

title: Putting Faith in Speed and Sinew
description: Diane Lane might be the two-legged star of Secretariat, a gauzy, gooey, turf-pounding, Bible-thumping tribute to the celebrated 1970s thoroughbred from the wonderful weird world of Disney. But the bigger and truer stars of this enjoyable, sometimes accidentally entertaining movie are the five horses that take turns playing Secretariat  one was used for running, another posed for the cameras  along with the memory of that original breathtaking beauty. This was a champion whose races thrilled the usual society swells and off-track gamblers along with a larger public swept up by the story of the big red horse who could and did.

title: Pairing Up to Tango, in Every Combination
description: When Anton Gazenbeek talks about dancing tango, his words suggest that hes referring to more than just fancy footwork.

title: Game 2 Analysis: Yankees 5, Twins 2
description: Andy Pettitte pitched seven strong innings as the Yankees beat the Minnesota Twins, 5-2, on Thursday night in Game 2 of their American League division series.

title: Best School Day Ever: Johnny Depp Comes to Class
description: Which member of the Pirates of the Caribbean team is so super-nice that he took a break from making the latest movie to appear in person at a school in the London borough of Greenwich to meet a student who had written him a fan letter? The cinematographer Dariusz Wolski? The boom microphone operator Jeffrey A. Humphreys? How about its A-list megastar Johnny Depp, who, BBC News reports, came in character as Jack Sparrow himself?

description: Classical

title: A Fifth Avenue Enigma
description: MARTHA STEWART owns an apartment in the building. And you could easily run into other notables in the elevator or the lobby. You could buy an apartment on the sixth floor, with about 4,800 square feet of space, overlooking Central Park at 72nd Street, from people who have hung a Warhol in their maids room, and where Halle Berry and Cindy Crawford were once frequent cocktail party guests.

description: Three decades ago, the actor Larry Wilcox played Officer Jon Baker on the popular television show CHiPs. But more recently, he has been on the other side of the law  at least according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Kashmir.

title: Rediscovering an Earthy Master
description: Man, Myth, and Sensual Pleasures: Jan Gossarts Renaissance at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a big deal. It is the first survey in this country devoted to the supple, mercurial, groundbreaking art of Gossart (1478-1532), the perennially underestimated Flemish master also known as Mabuse.

title: Week 5 Fantasy Football Matchups
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 5. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: Mario Vargas Llosa Speaks About the Nobel Prize, Literature and More
description: Mario Vargas Llosa thought a semester teaching at Princeton would give him some time off from the attention he attracts in Lima and Madrid. But his sojourn turned very public this morning when the Swedish Academy announced he had won the Nobel Prize in Literature.

title: The Man Who Repairs Time
description: When Marcel Zalaznick goes on vacation, a once-a-year event, he hangs a sign outside his watch-repair store on 30th Avenue that says, Gone fishing. Mr. Zalaznick, 59, is the proprietor and the sole employee of Grand Jewelers, a type of small business that feels like a rarity these days. It has been in the same spot in Queens for a long time, it turns a (modest) profit, and it is unaffected by the whims of the commercial real estate market because its owner is also its landlord.

title: Art and News, Intersecting in the Digital Age
description: After steady assault from Twitter, Facebook and Blogger Nation, we have come to this: The Last Newspaper. Or so the title of the New Museums big fall show seems to tell us. In reality the situation isnt quite that dire. All of us partial to news in hard copy (not to mention those of us who have indoor pets) can relax, kind of, for the moment.

title: Grand Jewelers
description: Times have changed since Marcel Zalaznick graduated from watchmaking school in 1973, but timepieces still need repair.

title: From a Mysterious Mansion to a Ralph Lauren Store
description: THE super-luxe new Ralph Lauren palazzo, at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and 72nd Street, is scheduled to open in mid-October. But across the street, hidden for months behind a veil of netting, is the old store, a limestone mansion with a mournful past, built in 1898 by an heiress who never lived in it.

title: Childrens Events
description: For Children

title: Electric Cars, Packed With Middle-Class Benefits
description: In Fridays Times, Bill Vlasic reports on the perks of being an electric car pioneer.

title: The Urban County Fair
description: A tour of Oaklands Eat Real Festival.

title: Food Groups
description: The D.I.Y. movement has never tasted (or looked) better.

title: Spare Times
description: Around Town

title: Rediscovering the Natural Side of the Bronx
description: ON a recent sunny Saturday in the Bronx, a handful of women taking a tour of the borough paused to gawk while a guide pointed out a pothole.

title: Scorecard | Miu Miu Wins!
description: Oh, hey there, Marc Jacobs. One hundred forty-six shows and 1,309 reviews (23 days, that is) since Scorecard last checked in with your maybe-the-wrong-side-of-pastiche for your signature line, you spelled it out for critics with the Sontag citations in the show notes for your disco heaven redux at Vuitton that you are no Elie Saab fame monster  but aNew York Intellectual. Too bad, then, that a designer rocking banana earrings since Milan had to come along with slyly subversive starlet wear for the Twi generation seated front row at Miu Miu. This is the way that Paris Fashion Week ends: not with a bang but with a giggle.

title: Now, PNC Is Said to Halt Foreclosed Sales
description: The PNC Financial Services Group has suspended sales of foreclosed homes for 30 days, according to a title insurer that received the memo from the bank, becoming the fourth major lender to impose a moratorium, David Streitfeld of The New York Times reports.

title: How to Record Phone Calls With Google Voice
description: Have you ever wished you could replay a phone call after its over? Googles free call-handing service, Google Voice, will record calls as MP3 audio files for free, with a few caveats.

title: Nice Daguerreotype!
description: At age 37, I find myself unexpectedly single again. So I joined Match.com, where Ive chatted with a lot of pretty women  many of whom turn out to be far less pretty (and much older) than their online pictures make them out to be. Is this normal? Is there an etiquette for asking how recent somebodys online pictures are? Jason, N.Y.C.

title: Mets Rodriguez Looks for Plea Agreement
description: A lawyer for Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez and the Queens district attorneys office are negotiating a plea agreement that could spare Rodriguez prison time, both sides said Thursday after a court hearing.

title: A Storyteller Enthralled by the Power of Art
description: At first glance, Mario Vargas Llosas novels seem like a one-man miscellany of subjects and styles: There are harrowing narratives based on historical events like Rafael Trujillos tyrannical rule over the Dominican Republic (The Feast of the Goat) and a 19th-century religious uprising in the backlands of Brazil (The War of the End of the World).

title: More Superheroes From Stan Lee
description: Stan Lee has long proved his superhuman ability to churn out comic characters. But this is starting to get a little nuts. On Thursday came word that Mr. Lee, 88, has agreed to create 30 superheroes for the National Hockey League, one for each team. On Friday, he will announce the creation of another character: Airwalker, a member of a C.I.A. group that tackles the worlds deadliest killers with the aid of miniature rocket packs developed by his scientist brother. The Airwalker comic, which will arrive in traditional and digital form in the first quarter of next year, is from Stan Lee Comics, A Squared Entertainment and Archie Comics. The three are also behind Stan Lees 7, a series Mr. Lee announced in July.

title: Obama Plans to Veto Foreclosure Bill
description: White House officials said Thursday that President Obama would not sign a little-noted measure that suddenly gained attention amid questions about some big lenders slipshod bookkeeping on home foreclosures, Jackie Calmes of The New York Times reports from Washington.

title: A Coming-of-Age Tale, Set Among the Sad
description: For a movie set in a psychiatric hospital, Its Kind of a Funny Story, Anna Boden and Ryan Flecks adaptation of the novel by Ned Vizzini, is disarmingly gentle, sweet and whimsical. The New York mental institution where most of the action takes place is hardly the allegorical hellhole of One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest. It is overseen not by a tyrannical Nurse Ratched, but by the wise and patient Dr. Minerva, played with a benevolent glow by Viola Davis. Instead of Grand Guignol visions of madness, there is a mood of shuffling, whispery melancholy. This hospital, Argeron, feels like an oasis where the sad can congregate in safety and do their best to make one another laugh.

title: Goal of the Year?
description: A gem of a goal. There is no other way to describe Matthew Burrowss crazy-sick back heel that gave Glentoran F.C. a 1-0 win against visiting Portadown on Tuesday, taking Glentoran to the top of the standings in Northern Ireland.

title: Master Chefs at a Misers Price and More
description: What is a hero? For some, its a graffiti artist who turns tags into sculptures. For others, its a chef who dares to cook with real butter. For misers, its both, and more, at heroically low prices.

title: Ads Call Colberts House Testimony No Laughing Matter
description: As Stephen Colbert prepares for his triumphant return to Washington for his Rally to Keep Fear Alive on Oct. 30, the political right is using his last appearance in the capital to try to keep Democratic incumbents from returning after Nov. 2.

title: Futuristic Face-Off Caps a Four-Part Program
description: Four companies. Four dances. In a new Fall for Dance program, which one will fall first? On Wednesday night, we waited until the bitter end.

title: Sell Yourself, Rahm. Surely, You Already Know the City.
description: After the second day of Rahmapalooza, the candidates blog offered this update:

title: Staring Down Death And Lust With a Sly Eye
description: A smart aleck lurks within many a rock primitivist, insisting on the difference between simple and simple-minded. Thats the situation with the Vaselines, the regrouped Scottish band that headlined Webster Hall on Wednesday night after releasing its second album, Sex With an X (Sub Pop), in the course of 23 years.

title: G.M. to Build Small Cars in Lake Orion Plant
description: 9:41 a.m. | Updated

title: Blackhawks Enter Dismal Sports Landscape
description: Like fidgety children on a car trip, the youthful Blackhawks were are we there yet? restless Sunday for much of the exhibition finale against the St. Louis Blues at the oddly sedate United Center.

title: On His Own, Finding His Range Again
description: No one wants El DeBarge to fail. Not his family. Not his fans. Not even the enablers he turned to during the darker parts of the last two decades, when he struggled with addiction to a range of substances, from heroin to crack.

title: Finding Love Over Dirty Diapers and Sippy Cups
description: Its enough to say that the bland romantic comedy Life as We Know It, in which there is not a single deviation from formula, is well made for its corporate type. One sign that the movie, directed by Greg Berlanti from a screenplay by Ian Deitchman and Kristin Rusk Robinson, has its unimaginative head on straight is that its lead characters actually have jobs that the film explores in some depth.

title: Party Hopping | Divide and Conquer
description: Its a hoary old chestnut, but New York truly is the city that never sleeps  at least not while there is an opening in town. Last night, Ts fashion department split up and hit the streets. The Garment District showroom of Loden Dager, the American mens-wear clothing label, threw a friends and family shopping event. In SoHo, Uniqlo celebrated the launch of the +J collection, designed by Jil Sander, by allowing guests to pre-shop without the public frenzy. Nearby, the Romanian footwear import Musette hosted fashionable feet at the opening of its first Stateside store. And across town at the Earnest Sewn boutique in the Meatpacking District, David Yurman feted his son Evans latest mens jewelry collection. Yurman the Youngers offerings included a line of sterling silver bracelets with intricate wave carvings and identification tags with classic onyx inlays. The inspiration was Japanese prints and ornaments, he said. I wanted to bring craftsmanship to modern times with antiquated, traditional techniques. I feel like that is something that is lacking.

title: M.G.M. Outlines Its Bankruptcy Plan
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the beleaguered film studio, introduced on Thursday a bankruptcy plan under which it would hand over control to its lenders, a group comprised mainly of hedge funds.

title: Charter Education Expanding in Chicago
description: From a windowless basement office on Chicagos West Side, Greg White is trying to answer public educations $2 million-dollar question: What is the top priority for a school in Chicagos cash-strapped district?

title: Brighton Beach Reality Show to Become Reality
description: The Russians are coming to reality TV. Brighton Beach, an in-depth exploration of the personal dramas of Russian-Americans in Brooklyn whose gestation we documented in March, has been picked up by the Lifetime network.

title: Man, Myth, and Sensual Pleasures
description: Images from a new exhibition of works by Jan Gossart, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: As Daleys Tenure Nears End, Aldermen Seek New Opportunities
description: Mayor Richard M. Daleys decision not to seek re-election next year raises the prospect of a major shift in the balance of power in City Hall.

title: Offense Disappears, and the Rays, Down Two Games, May Soon Follow
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Rays finished the regular season with the American Leagues best record, but their hitting statistics made their success look like a magic trick. The Rays .247 batting average was the worst for a playoff team in nearly 30 years, and they struck out 1,292 times, more than any playoff team in history.

title: M.G.M. Looks to File for Bankruptcy Protection
description: LOS ANGELES  The next chapter for Hollywoods storied film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer: Chapter 11, if the company has its way.

title: House Democrat Voices First No Vote for Pelosi
description: Representative Bobby Bright, a conservative Alabama Democrat in a tough fight for re-election, became the first incumbent member of his party to say definitively that he would not support Nancy Pelosi for speaker next year if the Democrats retain control of the House. His statement illustrated the lengths some Democratic lawmakers are going to distance themselves from the speaker, who has been cast by Republicans as the embodiment of excessive liberalism.

title: Family Opened Up the Door to John and Yoko
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: I.M.F. Chief Steps Into Dispute Over Chinas Currency Policy
description: WASHINGTON  The head of the International Monetary Fund urged China on Thursday to allow its currency to rise in value, an attempt to keep a contentious issue between the United States and China from broadening into a bitter international dispute.

title: Lennons Teenage Years: Rocking and Roiling
description: At its most obvious, the title of Nowhere Boy, a prettily photographed melodrama about a tumultuous period in John Lennons adolescence, is a reference to his song Nowhere Man. Included in the Beatles 1965 album Rubber Soul, the masterwork that pointed to new horizons (This was the departure record, Ringo Starr said), it has lyrics worthy of Samuel Beckett (Hes a real nowhere man/Sitting in his nowhere land) and a strong melancholic undertow. The song is often seen as autobiographical and, somewhat repellently, its title has been used to describe both Lennon and his killer, Mark David Chapman.

title: Glory and Misery on the Way to Stardom
description: Acceptance speeches are definitely a lot better to give than to receive. But Patti LuPones 60 seconds of glory at the Tonys after her win for Gypsy constituted one of the highlights of that years telecast. Cradling the twirling medallion, she began with a sly joke. Its such a wonderful gift to be an actor who makes her living working on the Broadway stage, she said, and then every 30 years or so, pick up one of these.

title: Lovely in Twin Cities, With Usual Fall
description: Minneapolis

title: Mark Zuckerberg at the Movies
description: On Wednesday night, Mark Zuckerberg invited some 400 people to watch a movie. No, not that movie. This was Mark Zuckerberg the philanthropist, not Mark Zuckerberg the Facebook chief executive. And in line with his philanthropic giving in support of education reform, the movie was Waiting for Superman, a poignant documentary about Americas failing public schools.

title: Rangel, Waters Ethics Trials Set
description: The chairwoman of the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct has scheduled hearings for next month in the separate cases of Representatives Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, and Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, who have been accused of ethics violations.

title: Tackling Redistricting With Money and Zeal
description: Charles T. Munger Jr., wearing a smooth herringbone blazer and a bow tie, sat in a downtown Palo Alto office one recent morning and discussed his decision to give $7 million to support Proposition 20, a ballot initiative that would wrest Congressional redistricting powers from legislators and hand that control to a citizens panel.

title: Video: Title Contender Outlook
description: Will any team stand in the way of No. 1 Alabama? And can Boise State get back into the national title conversation? Reporter Pete Thamel gives The Quads Paul Myerberg a well-deserved break in this weeks edition of the Pregame Huddle.

title: Showcases for Locally Made Documentaries
description: When Chris Metzler decided to make the change from narrative filmmaking to documentary in 1999, friends advised him to move to San Francisco to find a like-minded community.

title: Upright Parole Officer With a Target on His Back
description: Edward Norton looks good behind bars. In Stone, a brooding, low-key intrigue, Mr. Norton wears cornrows and tattoos, and much as he did in his screen debut, Primal Fear, keeps his performance in check. He plays the title character in the new movie, an arsonist turned inmate whos grown weary of waiting to be released. As far as Stone can tell, or as far as the movie initially suggests, the only thing standing between him and the outside world is an unsmiling parole officer, Jack Mabry (Robert De Niro), who, when hes not shuffling papers, listens  in his car and at home  to Christian talk radio.

title: More Sex, Please, Were British Rustics
description: Tamara Drewe, directed by Stephen Frears and written by Moira Buffini, plants its cheeky flag at the crossroads of sex farce, pastoral and high literary polish. The spot of territory it claims, which could only be in England, is a picturesque rural village populated by recognizable types, not all of them traditional rustics.

title: Judge Rules Health Law Is Constitutional
description: A federal judge in Michigan on Thursday dismissed one of more than 15 legal challenges to the new health care law, becoming the first to rule that the law is constitutional.

title: Political Points: Guilt-Trips and Midterm Losses
description: Click to Listen

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Editor Out as New Owners Take Control
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer has been through a lot in the last few years: bankruptcy, two new owners and layoffs, just to name some of it.

title: Heres the Pub, Church and Field for Public Sex
description: PUTTENHAM, England  There was the man they called Bob the Builder, who wore only a hard hat. There was the naked sunbather who remarked, Nice day for it, isnt it? to a woman taking a walk. And there was the moment, Jules Perkins said, when the dizzying array of sexual forces that have somehow descended on her blameless Surrey village came together all at once, like a scene from a one-size-fits-all X-rated film.

title: Contract Lengths and Guarantees May Be N.B.A.s Targets
description: PARIS  It took two years of furious roster shuffling and careful bookkeeping for the Knicks to land a star player and create the chance for a rebirth. Their endeavor provides some hints about where the N.B.A. might be heading in its labor negotiations.

title: Richardson Shapes New Mexico Race
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Although Gov. Bill Richardsons name is being sullied on the airwaves and in campaign debates up and down this border state, Susana Martinez, the Republican candidate to replace him, is not  technically at least  running against him.

title: Death by Chicken Tikka, in Service of Romance
description: Four gastronomic murders (a chicken-tikka kebab in the neck, suffocation by naan) have hit Southall, an Indian neighborhood in London, and the hunky cop Raj Murthy (Sendhil Ramamurthy, from Heroes) is sent undercover to investigate. The perpetrator is Mrs. Sethi (the venerable Shabana Azmi), a widow whose passionate defense of her full-figured daughter, Roopi (Goldy Notay), has taken a homicidal turn. Mrs. Sethi, you see, feels she cannot join her husband in death until she has married off Roopi, whom the victims made the mistake of mistreating.

title: G.O.P. Senate Odds Improve for Third Consecutive Week
description: Democrats are on the verge of locking up several Senate races in the Northeast, including one in Connecticut that some analysts had considered a toss-up. But Republicans have gained ground overall in this weeks Senate forecast by virtue of improved polling in Nevada and West Virginia. Their odds of taking over the Senate on Nov. 2 have now improved to 24 percent  up from 22 percent last week and 15 percent three weeks ago, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast model.

title: Hevesi Successor Cleared in Inquiry
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos office said Thursday that it had cleared the current state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, in its pension investigation.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,306 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Sex on the Run? No, We Parked
description: TEN years ago I worked briefly as a production accountant on a television show called Welcome to New York, a sitcom starring Jim Gaffigan as a TV weatherman and Christine Baranski as his city-slicker boss.

title: Addressing Your Cats ... Ahem ... Solid Waste
description: BECAUSE consumers know perfectly well what function cat litter serves, brands have not been compelled to spell out what Fluffy does in the litter box, and instead dwell on what the products do: reduce odor. Now, however, Arm & Hammer, which makes Multi-Cat and Super Scoop cat litters, is introducing a new variety, Double Duty, and to highlight its unique selling point, the brand decided there was no room for euphemism.

title: Model Town as Safe Haven
description: Four years in the making, Marwencol emerges as a number of things: an absorbing portrait of an outsider artist; a fascinating journey from near-death to active life; a meditation on the brains ability to forge new pathways when old ones have been destroyed. Woven together by Jeff Malmberg  if not seamlessly, then with illuminating patience  these disparate strands honor an individual as unique as the miniature universe on which he depends.

title: Afghans Linked to the Taliban Guard U.S. Bases
description: WASHINGTON  Afghan private security forces with ties to the Taliban, criminal networks and Iranian intelligence have been hired to guard American military bases in Afghanistan, exposing United States soldiers to surprise attack and confounding the fight against insurgents, according to a Senate investigation.

title: The Closing Flourish Is the Campy Kind
description: Paris

title: Visiting New York, Seeking Vengeance
description: Several varieties of creepy run through As Good as Dead, a gruesomely alluring tale of long-simmering revenge, but the guy you especially dont want showing up at your door is Frank Whaley.

title: Mexican Leader Pushes Police Overhaul
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexicos sweeping plan to revamp the nations local police departments, a bid to deter corruption and infiltration by drug trafficking organizations, moved forward this week when President Felipe Caldern made a formal proposal to Congress.

title: A Normal Flu Season Unfolds
description: Flu activity in the Southern Hemisphere, where the flu season is ending, has been typical, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Thursday. All three types of flu that normally circulate are present, although the H1N1 swine flu strain that caused last years pandemic has replaced the seasonal H1N1 strain that circulated before 2009. The seasonal flu shots now available in the United States are a good match for all three, and the agency urged shots for everyone over 6 months old, and particularly for pregnant women, young children, health care workers, parents of infants and people with conditions like asthma, diabetes and heart disease.

title: Washington: Court-Martial Recommended in Afghan Killings
description: An Army investigating officer has recommended court-martial proceedings for Specialist Jeremy N. Morlock, one of five American soldiers accused of killing three Afghan civilians this year. Specialist Morlock and other soldiers have said in sworn statements that the killings were staged to look like combat deaths. Lawyers for Specialist Morlock have argued that he was heavily medicated with prescription drugs at the time of the killings and the statements. The recommendation for court-martial follows an investigative hearing last week. A final decision on whether to refer him to court-martial will be made by the commander of the Stryker brigade in which the soldiers serve. The other soldiers await investigative hearings.

title: Junk Bonds Are Back on Top
description: Jim Casey remembers the fast times when Michael R. Milken ruled Wall Street as the billionaire king of junk bonds.

title: A Study in Middle East Nonviolence
description: American audiences watching the documentary Budrus, about a pioneering effort in nonviolent protest by Palestinians in the West Bank, will find many of the images familiar. The marching, the chanting, the nerve-racking encounters between protesters and jumpy, heavily armed young policemen and soldiers: its Eyes on the Prize with olive trees.

title: Outside Court, a Failure to Be Fearful
description: Not one, not two, but three terrorism cases weaved their way simultaneously this week through the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan. You can make that four cases if you go back two weeks to include a Pakistani woman, Aafia Siddiqui, who received a super-long prison sentence for trying to kill Americans in Afghanistan.

title: S.&P. Says Cost to Care for Elderly Will Spiral
description: Credit analysts at Standard & Poors said on Thursday that the cost of caring for the worlds aging populations would be on an explosive path and could swamp the budgets of many countries in the next 40 years unless governments accelerated belt-tightening efforts that are already proving highly unpopular.

title: Picture Books No Longer a Staple for Children
description: Picture books are so unpopular these days at the Childrens Book Shop in Brookline, Mass., that employees there are used to placing new copies on the shelves, watching them languish and then returning them to the publisher.

title: Mets Move Forward With G.M. Search
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets will begin interviewing candidates to be their next general manager early next week.

title: The Editor of Page Six Is Departing After 25 Years
description: New York gossip will never be the same.

title: Rumors Are Gone; Now the Hornets Test Begins
description: WESTWEGO, La.  Chris Paul played pickup games in Miami, Las Vegas, Washington and cities in between this summer, testing his surgically repaired knee and resting his concerns.

title: Preparing for Sightlessness
description: In Going Blind, a documentary pegged to his own glaucoma, Joseph Lovett seems largely interested in convincing himself that losing his sight wont be so bad. That leaves the film feeling less like a hard look at the fears and challenges of being visually impaired and more like a cheerleading exercise.

title: Poor Prospects for New Climate Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  With wounds still raw from the chaotic United Nations climate conference in Copenhagen last December, negotiators are making final preparations for next months meeting in Cancn, Mexico, in a surly mood and with little hope for progress.

title: Postseason Begins; So Do Calls for Replay
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Day 1 of the postseason began with a disputed call in the first inning of the first division series game at Tampa Bay, and it ended with another in the last inning of the last game at Target Field. Symmetry, in this case, was not good.

title: Make Wall Street Risk It All
description: Two years after the near collapse of capitalism, we certainly have our fill of financial reforms. The 2,200-page Dodd-Frank Act, which President Obama signed this summer, creates an Orwellian alphabet soup of new agencies, oversight boards and offices intended to protect us from ourselves.

title: Phillies Ruiz Quietly Built Toward Perfection
description: PHILADELPHIA  The clubhouse is not a place for reflection. Players live in the moment, preparing for the next game. They have little interest in taking stock of their achievements. Usually.

title: An Exploitation Film, Remade
description: A title like I Spit on Your Grave has a lot to live up to, even had it not belonged to one of the classics of exploitation cinema: Meir Zarchis sickening  and visually horrendous  1978 rampage, originally titled Day of the Woman. Mr. Zarchi returns as an executive producer for Steven R. Monroes remake, which may be one reason that Stuart Morses screenplay takes few liberties with the story. Those he does take, however, are a significant improvement.

title: California Lawmakers Pass Overdue Budget
description: LOS ANGELES  Faced with huge budget deficits and a stubbornly sour economy, California lawmakers Friday approved a $126 billion state budget  100 days late  including a $3.5 billion cut to the beleaguered public school system. It was a deadline-breaking record that served as a reminder of the problems that have paralyzed California government as it struggles through one of the grimmest fiscal crises in its history.

title: Favre and Sanchez Meet at a Hectic Intersection
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Before Brett Favre, the Jets practiced in an outdated facility on Long Island, played in a stadium named for another team and worked for a reclusive owner, all in the large shadow of the Giants.

title: Paladino Tries to Reset His Campaign for Governor
description: Seeking a reset of his faltering campaign for governor, Carl P. Paladino bought a three-minute advertisement on local television stations in Buffalo on Thursday to try to persuade New Yorkers that he is a serious candidate for governor, despite recent flare-ups and angry outbursts.

title: Chicago Democrats Come Out for Obama  Except for One
description: CHICAGO  There were a lot of heavy-hitting Chicago Democrats at the Drake Hotel on Thursday night for a fund-raiser attended by President Obama.

title: Some in G.O.P. Find Soft Spot for Bill Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  Many Republicans with a deep animus for President Obama find their hearts aflutter with the memory of a former leader. He was a compassionate conservative, a guy who cared about free trade, a man who reached across the aisle.

title: Plan to Ban Food Stamps for Sodas Has Hurdles
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may face legal and political hurdles in carrying out his ambitious plan to bar food-stamp recipients from using their benefits to buy sugar-sweetened drinks, food policy experts said Thursday.

title: Old Brooklyn Advice for Reds: Fuhgeddaboudit
description: PHILADELPHIA  There are no training manuals on how to recover from a no-hitter in the postseason. Only scant evidence exists because only once before has a team had to rebound from one.

title: They Unpaved Paradise
description: City limits, property lines and state borders appear clear and inviolable on a map. But things are trickier on the ground, and even more so on the water, where such neatly drawn lines are bypassed by flooding rivers or wandering runoff. Water, particularly in ever-shifting wetlands, meanders between civilization and wilderness, reminding us that both are conduits in a larger circulatory system.

title: The Beagle Vanishes
description: This is the fourth in a series.

title: A Fishing Paradise Gains a Deadly Reputation
description: HOUSTON  For decades, Falcon Lake was known primarily as an anglers paradise, a tranquil reservoir straddling the border with Mexico where a clever fisherman could catch enormous largemouth bass. These days, however, the lake is developing a reputation for something else: piracy.

title: Flawed Foreclosure Documents Thwart Home Sales
description: OCALA, Fla.  Amanda Ducksworth was supposed to move in to her new home this week, a three-bedroom steal here in central Florida with a horse farm across the road. Instead, she is camped out with her 7-year-old son at her bosss house.

title: Who Will Rescue Americas Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Playoff Photo Replay: Oct. 7
description: The Texas Rangers beat the Tampa Bay Rays, 6-0, to take a 2-0 lead in their American League division series.

title: Science Fiction for the Great Recession
description: Jim is two or maybe three movies in one. Theres an angry downsizing drama, a sort of Falling Down for the derivatives age, that overlaps with a cautionary tale about modern medicine and genetic engineering, and these connect in a hazy way to a dystopian science-fiction fantasy set on a future earth populated by clones. What they all share is a reliance on clich and a limited visual imagination that is aggravated, in the science-fiction segments, by the films minuscule budget.

title: Dealing With China
description: To the Editor:

title: Christie Helped Lose Grant for Schools, Ex-Official Says
description: Before rejecting a compromise with teachers that would have won New Jersey a $400 million federal education grant, Gov. Chris Christies main objection was that it would appear that he had given in to the teachers union, a former education commissioner testified on Thursday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Phillips Talbot, U.S. Envoy in Cold War, Dies at 95
description: Phillips Talbot, an American diplomat who helped mediate crises in South Asia and the Middle East during the cold war, died on Oct. 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

title: Ghailani Case Ruling Spurs Debate on Trials Value
description: When a federal judge barred prosecutors on Wednesday from using a crucial witness in the first civilian trial of a former Guantnamo terrorism detainee, the ruling  widely perceived as a major setback for the government  contained an unusual observation.

title: The Ex-Con and the Priest
description: Moon-faced, mannish and with the shoulders of a hod carrier, Leila (Kaarina Hazard) is not your average movie heroine. Mysteriously pardoned after serving 12 years of a life sentence (for what, we can initially only imagine), Leila grudgingly accepts a position as personal assistant to Father Jacob (Heikki Nousiainen), a blind priest holed up in a rundown rural rectory.

title: Expanding Control, Taliban Refresh Stamp on Afghan Justice
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Taliban court had already scheduled the sentencing of a young Afghan aid worker named Attiqullah, when NATO forces raided the Taliban prison where he was being held in mid-August.

title: Texas Two-Step Helps Yankees Series Bid
description: MINNEAPOLIS  On his first day with the Yankees after 11 seasons as a leading man with Houston, Lance Berkman ambled into the visiting dugout at Tropicana Field in July and made a promise. In his Texas twang, Berkman said that he was not looking to crow like a rooster or anything. He just wanted to fit in.

title: An Inevitable Slide for Americans Standard of Living
Cuomo and Paladino to Debate at Hofstra, With 5 Other Candidates
description: Andrew M. Cuomo and Carl P. Paladino will debate after all  but they wont be alone.

title: Prosecutors Will Examine Citys Role in Girls Death
description: The Brooklyn district attorneys office has opened a rare and wide-ranging criminal investigation into the actions of the city and outside health and social service providers responsible for the well-being of Marchella Pierce, the 4-year-old girl who weighed 18 pounds when she died last month.

title: MGM Is Rallying Support for a Reorganization
description: LOS ANGELES  The next chapter for Hollywoods venerable film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer: Chapter 11, if the company has its way.

title: Loose Connections That Lead to Horror
description: Red White & Blue, the latest feature from the British director Simon Rumley, builds a triptych of character studies into an engrossing  and profoundly distressing  tale of random connection and specific revenge.

title: Knicks Form Quick Bond; Results May Take Longer
description: PARIS  It was 6:45 a.m. Thursday when the line began forming inside the luxury hotel on Rue de Castiglione. The Knicks were just another party of bleary-eyed travelers, waiting to reconcile room charges and begin the long journey home.

title: Months After Cutbacks, M.T.A. Approves Higher Fares
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved a package of fare increases on Thursday for its subways, buses and commuter railroads, the third time in three years that New Yorkers will face a sharp rise in the cost of getting around.

title: Lee and Halladay Are Linked by More Than a Trade
description: Cliff Lee and Roy Halladay will always be linked through the Philadelphia Phillies, who essentially swapped one ace for the other last December. But their connection goes deeper than that, especially in light of their stellar performances on Wednesday.

title: To Cut Costs, Islanders Consider Radio Deal With Hofstra
description: Radio and television broadcasts are the lifeblood of any sports team, a way to reach fans who cannot get to the stadium or arena.

title: Making Congress All It Can Be
description: The attraction of reading what a sitting Supreme Court justice has to say about interpreting the Constitution is undoubtedly what has turned Justice Stephen G. Breyers new book, Making Our Democracy Work, into a surprise best seller. Commentators and reviewers have also emphasized the Constitution-related passages in the book, particularly Justice Breyers cogent analysis of why originalism falls short and why the interpretive goal should be to engage with the framers deepest values rather replicate their 18th-century frame of reference. His point, as the books title suggests, is for judges to make their way through the mists of history to a Constitution that works today.

title: Canada: Ex-Commander of Air Base to Plead Guilty to Dozens of Charges
description: The former commander of Canadas largest air force base will plead guilty to the murder of two women, two sexual assaults, two charges of unlawful confinement and 82 counts of breaking and entering, mainly involving thefts of womens lingerie, his lawyer told a civilian court in Belleville, Ont., on Thursday. Col. Russell Williams, above, who occasionally piloted Canadian government flights carrying the prime minister and other dignitaries, is accused of carrying out the killings in a village near Canadian Forces Base Trenton, which provides logistical support for Canadas military mission in Afghanistan. Many of the break-ins occurred in Ottawa, where Colonel Williams also lived. The Ottawa Citizen reported that about 500 pieces of womens undergarments were seized from his townhouse there.

title: France: Full-Face Veil Ban Approved
description: Frances top legal authority, the Constitutional Council, on Thursday approved a law banning full-face veils in public. The council said that the law was constitutional, but that it could not be applied in public places of worship because of the freedom of religion. The decision is the last hurdle for the ban, which has been criticized as stigmatizing Muslim women and violating individual freedom. The law, which will take force next year, sets fines for women who cover their faces in public and criminal penalties for those who force women to wear the full veil. The law is expected to be challenged in the European Court of Justice for violating European human rights law.

title: The Ability to Push for Candidates, Not Just Issues
description: The Supreme Courts landmark ruling in Citizens United has absorbed the bulk of the attention when it comes to recent changes on the campaign finance landscape.

title: Money Talks Louder Than Ever in Midterms
description: The dominant story line of this years midterm elections is increasingly becoming the torrents of money, much of it anonymous, gushing into House and Senate races across the country.

title: Popular Gift for Paladino: Bats to Fight Corruption
description: BUFFALO  Carl P. Paladino often speaks of clobbering the ineffective state government in Albany with a baseball bat. Now, he may actually be able to do so.

title: Boy, 4, Is Killed by a Bus in Brooklyn
description: A 4-year-old boy was killed and his mother was badly injured Thursday evening when they were hit by a bus in Brooklyn after the boy darted into the street, the police said.

title: Milka Planinc, Former Yugoslav Premier, Dies at 85
description: PRAGUE  Milka Planinc, the prime minister of the former Yugoslavia in the early 1980s and its first female premier, died Thursday in Zagreb. She was 85.

title: Jets Jenkins Will Try to Return From Third A.C.L. Tear
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Ive been meeting once a week with Kris Jenkins since he tore his anterior cruciate ligament for a third time, against Baltimore in Week 1. On Thursday, inside an interview room at the Jets facility, Jenkins ate chicken wings and smiled as he announced: Ive made a decision. Im coming back. I have to. You know why? Its my choice. I choose to. I dont need any more money. I dont need anyones approval. I still want to leave my mark.

title: South Africa: Leaders Approval Falls
description: Battered by a strike by public employees that crippled hospitals and schools and the perception that his 28-year-old son was using political connections to get rich, President Jacob Zumas approval rating among urban adults plunged to a new low of 42 percent, according to 2,000 face-to-face interviews conducted last month in seven cities by TNS Research Surveys. The poll has a margin of sampling error of about plus or minus 2 percentage points. The result suggests that the glow from the successful World Cup this summer has already worn off for Mr. Zuma, in office since May 2009.

title: Duke Winces as a Private Joke Slips Out of Control
description: DURHAM, N.C.  For nearly two weeks, many here on the Duke University campus had been aware of a certain senior thesis that a recent graduate wrote, apparently as a private joke, about her sexual exploits with 13 student-athletes.

title: Friday: The Great Pretender
description: Todays puzzle was a smorgasbord of surprises and cleverness, with snippets of information thrown in from many walks of life. Id categorize it as a What was your favorite clue? type of puzzle. In my case, top honors goes to What can give you a heads-up? for COIN TOSS.

title: Wounds of War Run Deeper Than Ever
description: That a good play can sometimes make you feel bad is fairly obvious. If you make it to the sanguinary close of one of Shakespeares tragedies with nary an inward wince, for example, something is definitely amiss. It was about halfway through my latest visit to Donald Marguliess Time Stands Still, which reopened on Broadway on Thursday night at the Cort Theater, after a summer hiatus, that my inward wincing became pretty unbearable.

title: Ethics Head Sets Dates for Hearings
description: The chairwoman of the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct has scheduled hearings for next month in the separate cases of Representatives Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, and Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, who have been accused of ethics violations.

title: Examining an Activists Death
description: Rachel, Simone Bittons fascinating if uneven documentary about Rachel Corrie, the activist killed in Gaza in 2003, shares a goal with My Name Is Rachel Corrie, the controversial Off Broadway play from 2006. Both lionize this 23-year-old protester from Olympia, Wash., who was crushed under a mound of dirt pushed by an Israeli bulldozer clearing a Palestinian area.

title: Holiday on Monday Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Democrats Defend Mass. Seat Once Deemed Safe
description: In a post-Scott-Brown world  where tea parties and pickup trucks can win the hearts of those thought to be the countrys most liberal voters  Massachusetts is no longer a Democratic safe haven.

title: A Love Triangle Without the Bollywood
description: Bombay Summer sounds like a Bollywood film, but the only singing or dancing takes place on battered LPs (good) or in a cocaine-infested nightclub (bad). Written and directed by Joseph Mathew-Varghese, who is based in New York, its the rare film set in India that speaks the melancholy language of the international art house.

title: Bloggingheads: Hidden Puppet Masters
description: Todd Gitlin of Columbia University and David Weigel of Slate discuss conspiratorial thinking in American politics.

title: Pakistani Army Chief Orders Video Inquiry
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The chief of the Pakistani Army said Friday that he had ordered an inquiry into an Internet video that shows men in Pakistani military uniforms executing six young men in civilian clothes.

title: The Last Newspaper
description: Images from an exhibition at the New Museum.

title: Using a Workout to Rest Up
description: AS a six-day-a-week exerciser who favors high-intensity workouts, I consider the seventh day enough rest. But it turns out that moving even more might be a smarter way to let my muscles recover and help me to push myself harder in the gym.

title: Coverage for I.V.F.
description: To the Editor:

title: Egg Inspections: The View From the F.D.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Offer to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: The Experiments in Guatemala
description: A medical historians discovery that American researchers in the 1940s deliberately infected hundreds of people in Guatemala with syphilis or gonorrhea has provoked outrage in both countries. President Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton rightly apologized to President lvaro Colom of Guatemala. More will be needed to make amends, beginning with a planned investigation of this appalling breach of medical ethics.

title: The Chamber of Commerce
description: To the Editor:

title: Recusals and the Court
description: Justice Elena Kagans seat was empty when the second case of the new term of the Supreme Court was called for oral argument on Monday. Because of her previous job as President Obamas solicitor general, she has, so far, recused herself from 25 of 51 cases accepted.

title: New Yorks Pension Scandal
description: Alan Hevesi, the former comptroller, has provided the best argument to stop giving one person the power to invest New York States $125 billion pension fund.

title: The Facebook Searchers
description: In 1952, two-thirds of Harvard applicants were admitted. The average verbal SAT score for incoming freshmen was 583. If your father went to Harvard, you had a 90 percent chance of getting in.

title: The End of the Tunnel
description: The Erie Canal. Hoover Dam. The Interstate Highway System. Visionary public projects are part of the American tradition, and have been a major driver of our economic development.

title: Hard Truths on the Spill
description: In May, President Obama asked a blue-ribbon commission to determine the causes of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, find out what worked and didnt in the governments response and identify ways to make drilling safer. He asked for frank talk, and hes getting it.

title: Game 2 Replay: Yankees 5, Twins 2
description: An impressive game from Lance Berkman and Andy Pettitte brought the New York Yankees to 2-0 against the Minnesota Twins.

title: Quarterback Dazzles for Cornhuskers
description: MANHATTAN, Kan.  From Ogallala to Alliance and from Omaha to Norfolk, Nebraskans are starting to utter the name of Taylor Martinez alongside some of the most potent and beloved of Cornhusker quarterbacks. Turner Gill. Tommie Frazier. Eric Crouch.

title: Tributes to a Young Suicide Victim at a Hometown Forum
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.  After all the anti-bullying pleas, the celebrity testimonials and the huge gatherings at Rutgers, an event to honor Tyler Clementis life and reflect on the meaning of his death was held in his hometown on Thursday night in an old stone church.

title: Cuddyer and Twins Struggle for Answers
description: MINNEAPOLIS  When reporters entered the Twins clubhouse after their 5-2 loss to the Yankees on Thursday night, first baseman Michael Cuddyer stood at his locker, prepared for the onslaught of difficult questions.

title: Guard Held in Sexual Attack on Transgender Inmate
description: A New York City correction officer was arrested and charged on Thursday with forcing a transgender inmate to engage in a sex act with him at a Manhattan jail.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Shareholders Applaud G.E.s Shopping Spree
description: From Reuters Breakingviews:

title: A Bacon Cricketer With a Back Story
description: The Francis Bacon that Dr. Paul Brass knew was altogether different from the raucous, hard-drinking artist whose canvases depict distorted figures screaming to be freed from their frames.

title: Word of the Day | potentate
description: potentate \po-tn-tat\ noun

title: Roy Ward Baker, Prolific British Filmmaker, Dies at 93
description: Roy Ward Baker, an undersung British filmmaker who directed A Night to Remember, a vivid black-and-white rendering of the sinking of the Titanic revered by history and movie buffs alike, died on Tuesday in London. He was 93.

title: Money in the Midterms
description: Following a Supreme Court ruling and other decisions, politically linked groups feel empowered to make direct appeals for or against electoral candidates.

title: With Lincecum Pitching, a Lead Feels Insurmountable
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Tim Lincecum climbed atop a small stage Wednesday and sat down to answer questions from the news media, moments after Roy Halladay finished off his no-hitter in Philadelphia.

title: After Betfair, Moneybookers I.P.O. Planned
description: Investcorp, the Bahrain-based investment bank, plans to float Moneybookers, the fast-growing European online payment firm it tried to sell last year, four people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Thursday.

title: Bill Clinton: Life After the White House
description: An interactive timeline of former President Bill Clintons years since leaving office.

title: News Quiz | October 8, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: HSBC Told to Increase Money-Laundering Controls
description: HSBC North America Holdings has been ordered to improve its compliance with money-laundering laws, federal regulators said Thursday, The Associated Press reports.

title: Junk Bonds Are Back on Top
description: Jim Casey remembers the fast times when Michael R. Milken ruled Wall Street as the billionaire king of junk bonds, Nelson D. Schwartz writes in The New York Times.

title: Flawed Foreclosures Thwart Home Sales
description: Amanda Ducksworth was supposed to move in to her new home this week, a three-bedroom steal in central Florida with a horse farm across the road. Instead, she is camped out with her 7-year-old son at her bosss house, Andrew Martin and David Streitfeld write in The New York Times.

title: New U.S. Options Exchange Is Planned
description: The International Securities Exchange is planning to start a second exchange for trading American stock options, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the situation.

title: States to Get $1.5 Billion for Small Business
description: The Treasury Department on Friday announced a $1.5 billion lending initiative to promote small businesses at the state level, Reuters reports.

title: Test Yourself | History, Oct. 8, 2010
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question, about the Oct. 8, 1982, ban on all labor organizations in this Eastern-bloc country.

title: Soros Says Finance Remains Too Connected
description: George Soros said Thursday that the United States financial regulation bill did not address the problem of a banking system that was too connected to fail.
