title: U.A.E. Says BlackBerry Dispute Is Resolved
description: The United Arab Emirates backed off a threat to cut crucial services on BlackBerry smart phones Friday, just days before the ban on the device made by Research in Motion was set to take effect, The Associated Press reports.

title: A Dinner to Please the Persnickety Parent
description: This week readers want different ways to celebrate birthdays. As always, send your restaurant questions to dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: Rose Center 10th Anniversary Celebration

title: To What Writer Would You Award a Prize?
description: This week, the Nobel Prize in Literature was awarded to the Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa. If you were in charge of giving a prize to a writer, what would the prize be for and to whom would you give it? Pretend that you could give it to any writer you like for any reason at all. For instance, you might choose to give a prize for best characters to a favorite childrens book writer, or you might give an award for best play-by-play to a sportswriter, or most realistic dialogue to a writer of young-adult books. Whom would you like to honor? Why?

title: Norris: How Did This Pass?
description: From Floyd Norriss blog:

title: SocGen Open to Solution on Kerviel Fine
description: Socit Gnrales chief of communications, Caroline Guillaumin, told French radio on Thursday that making Jrme Kerviel, whose 50 billion euros in rogue trades led the bank to take huge losses in 2008, pay the 4.9 billion euro fine decided Tuesday by a French court was out of the question.

title: F.D.I.C. Is Said to Plan New Liquidation Rules
description: The federal banking regulator is expected to propose new rules for seizing and dismantling large financial firms on the verge of collapse, Reuters said, citing a report in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Potash Scoffs at BHP, While Sinochem Waits
description: The chief executive of the Potash Corporation went on the offensive against its unwanted suitor on Thursday, confidently describing BHP Billitons $130-a-share hostile bid as non-starter even though a competing offer has yet to emerge.

title: Vodafone Buys Two Expense Management Firms
description: Vodafone is spending $9.7 million to buy two firms specializing in managing telecom expenses, The Associated Press reported.

title: Nobel Peace Prize Given to Jailed Chinese Dissident
description: BEIJING  Liu Xiaobo, an impassioned literary critic, political essayist and democracy advocate repeatedly jailed by the Chinese government for his activism, has won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of his long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China.

title: Plane-Crashing Money Manager Gets 10 Years
description: A judge Thursday ignored pleas for leniency from an Indiana money manager who conned friends into investing in a fund that didnt exist and tried to fake his death by parachuting out of a plane and crashing it when the scheme started to fall apart, The Associated Press reported.

title: Philadelphia Paper Shake-Up on Eve of Court Sale
description: The editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer has stepped down on the eve of a bankruptcy courts $139 million sale of the newspaper company to creditors, The Associated Press reported.

title: Actelion Is Said to Explore Potential Sale
description: Actelion, a Swiss biotech drug maker, has formed a special board committee to explore a potential sale of the company, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing unnamed sources.

title: Ahmad Bradshaw Misses Another Practice
description: When Ahmad Bradshaw missed practice on Wednesday because of a sore ankle, he played down the seriousness of the injury. But there are new questions about his status for Sundays game against the Houston Texans after he sat out again on Thursday. Hes a little better, Coach Tom Coughlin said. I think well get him tomorrow.

title: When Flemish and French Art Met
description: Following up its exhibition of Flemish painting last year, the Muse Jacquemart-Andr in Paris has opened a new show that highlights the cross-fertilization of Flemish and French art.

title: The Uncertainties of Pay-for-Performance
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Making an Amends
description: Meg e-mails: I am a member of a 12-step program in which the eighth and ninth steps refer to making amends. When people share their experience with these steps, they often talk about making an amends as if it were a combination of singular and plural. I find this so annoying that I may need to make amends for interrupting people to correct their grammar. But perhaps I am in error. Could you please advise as to the correctness of making an amends?"

title: U.S. Chamber Threatens to Challenge Overhaul
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce is mounting a new legal attack on the Obama administrations regulatory policies just weeks ahead of Congressional elections, telling voters that Democrat-driven regulation is hurting the economic recovery.

title: Asian I.P.O.s Reflect Growth and Liquidity
description: Initial public offerings from the logistics unit of the Singapore wealth fund G.I.C. and a Philippine budget airline drew strong demand from investors, underscoring how Asias robust economic growth and rising currencies are acting as a magnet for capital, Reuters reported.

title: Favre Says He Hopes Jets Fans Appreciated His Effort
description: Eagles fans once jeered Santa Claus, so Brett Favre probably wouldnt be surprised if some equally intense fans booed him Monday night at New Meadowlands Stadium.

title: Iceland Banks May Forgive $2 Billion in Debts
description: Icelands banks may come under pressure to forgive about $2 billion in mortgage debt after protests this week prompted the government to consider proposals from the islands homeowner protection group, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Carlyle Betting Patience Will Pay Off in India
description: The Carlyle Group is betting that patience will be rewarded in an Indian market where global players have had to content themselves almost exclusively with deals for minority stakes, Reuters reported.

title: Who Maimed the Economy, and How
description: From A.O. Scotts latest movie review:

title: Is Gold Rally Due for Correction? Ask Gartman
description: The gold markets fierce rally this week could be due for a correction if the telephone on the desk of the hedge fund manager Dennis Gartman remains true to form as a leading indicator.

title: Nobel Prize Is Seen as Rebuke to China
description: BEIJING  Few nations today stand as more of a challenge to the democratic model of governance than China, where an 89-year-old Communist Party has managed to quash political movements while creating a roaring, quasi-market economy and enforcing a veneer of social stability.

title: I.L.F.C. Pays Back $2 Billion in Debt
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation, the jet-leasing unit of the bailed-out insurer American International Group, said Thursday that it had paid back $2 billion in loans, which it needed during the financial crisis of 2008.

title: Bit.ly Gets $10 Million in 2nd Round
description: Bit.ly, the start-up behind many of the shortened links you probably see in Twitter, announced Thursday it had raised $10 million in a second round of financing, VentureBeat reported.

title: Sheik Hedges Barclays Stake With Nomura
description: The investment fund of Abu Dhabis Sheik Mansour bin Zayed al Nahyan decided to hedge its investment in Barclays against any potential future drop in the value of the British bank, Julia Werdigier writes for The New York Times.

title: Things Ive Been Thinking About This Week
description: Heres whats on my mind right now:

title: Reviewer Spotlight: Miguel Syjuco
description: Miguel Syjuco, the author of the novel Ilustrado, makes his debut in the Book Review this weekend with his review of How to Read the Air, Dinaw Mengestus second novel. Both of these writers use the immigrant experience to explore themes of family and homeland, politics and identity. In an e-mail conversation, I recently asked Syjuco about his own writing, and the questions and subjects currently driving his work.

title: Reviewer Spotlight: Miguel Syjuco
description: Miguel Syjuco, the author of the novel Ilustrado, makes his debut in the Book Review this weekend with his review of How to Read the Air, Dinaw Mengestus second novel. Both of these writers use the immigrant experience to explore themes of family and homeland, politics and identity. In an e-mail conversation, I recently asked Syjuco about his own writing, and the questions and subjects currently driving his work.

title: Transylvania: Green, Not Blood-Red
description: Todays idea: From from a mythical place of blood-red terror, Transylvania is a study in centuries-old green living largely unsullied by modernization, an article says.

title: How Do Democrats Make a Final Economic Pitch?
description: 12:43 p.m. | Updated The release of the jobs report Friday morning sparked a fresh round of rhetoric as both parties attempt to spin the numbers to their advantage in the three weeks left before election day.

title: Wall Street Tailor Looks West
description: Mitchells stores , a Connecticut clothier to hedge funds and corporate chiefs, prospered with Wall Street until the financial crisis battered sales. Now, the group sees its California counterpart as the path to growth, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Complaint Box | Twin Discrimination
description: When youre outnumbered, you learn to up your game  fast. I had twins almost three years ago and decided to stay home with them. I needed to play zone defense if I was ever going to get out of the house.

title: Week 5 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Chiefs (3-0) at Colts (2-2)Sunday, 1:00 p.m.Line: Colts by 7 1/2Peyton Manning could take the field with the cast of Modern Family and still produce a 12-win season. At least thats the perception. Indianapolis has lost two divisional games and all of its experienced safeties are injured, but there has been little hand-wringing about the teams playoff chances. So what if the rookie Brandon King and the off-the-street free agent DaJuan Morgan have replaced Bob Sanders and Melvin Bullitt in the secondary? As long as Julie Bowen and Eric Stonestreet arent covering deep zones in the cover-2 and Manning isnt scaring those cute kids with his noisy audibles, everything will be just fine.

title: Afghan Governor Is Killed in Blast at Mosque
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In an audacious attack, insurgents assassinated the governor of Kunduz Province on Friday by bombing the mosque where he attended the weekly Friday Prayer, according to Afghan officials.

title: Abu Dhabi Fund Hedges Barclays Stake
description: LONDON  The investment fund of Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed al Nahyan of Abu Dhabi has decided to hedge its investment in Barclays against any potential drop in the value of the British bank.

title: China-U.S. Trade: A Big Outlier
description: Continuing our look at the Chinese renminbi, through the views of different economists

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Return to Oz
description: The collected edition of The Marvelous Land of Oz, the comic-book version of the L. Frank Baum novel, touches down at No. 5 on the New York Times hardcover list this week. The book is a sequel to The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, by the writer Eric Shanower and the artist Skottie Young, which made its debut at No. 9 on the graphic novel hardcover list in September 2009.

title: Q. & A. With Bernie Williams
description: Bernie Williams, a four-time World Series winner with the Yankees, is now a guitarist with another nine-man team, a jazz band. Informally known as Bernie Williams and the All-Star Band, the group will appear on Oct. 23 at the Lafayette Theater in Suffern, N.Y. Williams, 42, is also a spokesman for the Priceless NYC Reserved by MasterCard, a program that offers items like Yankees playoff tickets to cardholders.

title: More Taxes in Finance, European Commission Says
description: The European Commission has spelled out its vision for taxing the financial sector, saying it would help fund development, fight against climate change and better combat the global economic crisis.

title: U.A.E. Halts Plan to Ban BlackBerry
description: HONG KONG  The United Arab Emirates, one of several countries that have threatened to suspend services for the Blackberry smartphones this year, on Friday backed away from a ban that was to have come into effect on Monday, after reaching an agreement with the popular messaging devices manufacturer, Research In Motion.

title: Rio Tinto Is Said to Be Interested in Potash Sector
description: The mining company Rio Tinto is interested in possible bolt-on acquisitions in a range of sectors, including potash, an executive said on Thursday, Reuters reported.

title: Big Union Wins Vote Against a Rival in California
description: The Service Employees International Union decisively defeated a rival union that was seeking to persuade 43,000 employees who worked for Kaiser Permanente in California to switch unions, the National Labor Relations Board announced Thursday night.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: The chief technology officer of AOL, Alexander Gounares, says the company may add more online media to its stable, after buying TechCrunch last month.

title: Christie Scraps Tunnel Project
description: Good Indian-summerish morning (forecast high: 77). Heres what were reading:

title: Buffett Says Rivals Dont Know the Business
description: Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaways billionaire chairman, said he avoided acquiring companies from leveraged-buyout firms because they focused on exit strategy, Bloomberg News reported.

title: An Every Village, Awash in Misery
description: Often the damaging environmental effects of industry dont feel real to faraway consumers. The carbon dioxide that spews into the air from power plants is invisible even to those who are close at hand. When the Deepwater Horizon oil spill disaster began last spring, few could see the impact a mile under water, conveyed only belatedly by cameras when BP decided to release the footage.

title: Faith in Fed Pushes Dow Past 11,000
description: If the economy is looking down, why is the stock market looking up?

title: The Office Butchers Sweeney Todd (in a Good Way)
description: Happy 80th birthday, Stephen Sondheim! The gifts youve been receiving for the occasion this year keep getting better and better: a Broadway revue of your unparalleled body of work; a new series of Kennedy Center grants established in your honor; a Broadway theater with your name on the marquee. And if you were watching television on Thursday night and not working on a crossword puzzle, maybe you got to see a network sitcom make mincemeat of one of your best-known works. (Youre still a national treasure, anyway.)

title: Public Jobs Drop Amid Slowdown in Private Hiring
description: In the one-two punch long feared by many economists, hiring by businesses has slowed while government jobs are disappearing at a record pace.

title: Jailed Chinese Dissidents Final Statement
description: Updated | 4:32 p.m. On Friday, Liu Xiaobo, a Chinese dissident currently serving an 11-year term in jail, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, as my colleagues Andrew Jacobs and Jonathan Ansfield report from Beijing.

title: Move Over, Carbon, Humans Are Jolting Nitrogen, Too
Another View: Its Time for Obama 2.0
description: Bill George, a Harvard business professor, argues that President Obama needs to revamp his economic policies and bring business executives into his administration.

title: Night Watch: Faux Folk
description: Theyre not really from West Virginia. They just play them on TV!

title: Excerpts From Vargas Llosas Books
description: Two related themes Michiko Kakutani writes, thread their way through all the novels of Mr. Vargas Llosa, who won the Nobel literature prize Thursday. These themes are a fascination with the human craving for freedom (be it political, social or creative) and the liberation conferred by art and imagination.

title: 4-Star Spaghetti Tacos?
description: Joseph Bastianich, whose Del Posto just won four stars from the Timess Sam Sifton, is inspired by the idea of spaghetti tacos, a dish first made on the Nickelodeon program, iCarly, Grub Street reports.

title: Note to Applicants: Admissions Officers Do Read What Your Teachers Say
description: Martha C. Merrill is the dean of admission and financial aid at Connecticut College.

title: Caff Society
description: Theres more to Milan dining than Da Giacomo and Fioraio Bianchi Caff. These local favorites will get you off the eaten path.

title: Biggest Local Cuts in 30 Years
description: Local governments are cutting jobs at the fastest rate in almost 30 years.

title: The Week Ahead: Oct. 10  16
description: Art

title: Brown Campaign Apologizes to Whitman Over Slur
description: The Los Angeles Times released a recording on Thursday night of a voice-mail message left by Jerry Brown, the Democratic candidate for governor in California, in which an unidentified person apparently can be heard suggesting that his opponent, the Republican Meg Whitman, is a whore.

title: Sanofi Disputes Genzymes Account of Deal Meeting
description: The battle between Sanofi-Aventis and Genzyme is quickly becoming a war of words.

title: Looking Back, Even More Jobs Lost
description: Joshua Shapiro of MFR Incorporated points out that todays jobs report also contained revisions for the March 2009-March 2010 period. Those revisions show that the job market was in even worse shape than previously thought.

title: The Cow-munity
description: A FEW YEARS AGO, two teachers at a prep school called the Albuquerque Academy discovered their mutual appreciation for local food. And in New Mexico, beef is about as local as it comes. So Sarah Councell, who teaches experiential education, and Casey Citrin, the chairwoman of the English department, decided to share a steer. They didnt really know each other. They just wanted local beef for a good price and a steady supply of it. They looked online and found the Ranney Ranch, run by a family that has been raising Angus cattle on 18,000 acres since 1968. The animals are small, maybe 600 pounds, and are sent to slaughter the day they stop weaning. It makes for exceptionally lean but tender beef.

title: A Maine Island Becomes a Seafood Magnet
description: One woman has put the fisherman of Deer Isle, Me., on the culinary map with her seafood supplying business.

title: The Catch
description: THOUGH WE HAD agreed to meet at 9 a.m., Ingrid Bengis-Palei woke me at 7, shouting from the bottom of the stairs leading to the apartment where I was staying above her barn on Deer Isle, Me. She had orders for 600 oysters, a third of which had to be overnighted to Beverly Hills to Bouchon, owned by Thomas Keller, one of the two dozen high-end chefs who buy oysters, crab, clams, scallops, mussels and lobsters from Ingrid Bengis Seafood. Those oysters had to be acquired, iced, packed and shipped by 3:30 that July afternoon, and she wanted to leave plenty of time. The easy part is when its a beautiful day and everybody does what theyre supposed to do, said Bengis-Palei, dressed in a yellow slicker to ward off the drumming rain, as she sped in her Subaru station wagon over the islands narrow, wet roads. But usually a crisis of one kind or another comes up.

title: On This Farm There Was Animosity
description: I dont care if its good for you, because to me kale has always been a four-letter vegetable. We seemed to have a lifetime supply this summer courtesy of the local community-supported agriculture farm. When Ira, my spouse, told me he signed us up for $575 last spring, I balked at the cost. Did it really make sense? Our little Long Island weekend town already has a farm stand and a grocer with local produce.

title: Growing Together
description: When I began writing about American farmers and food artisans for this magazines Field Report column two years ago, I set out to learn the story behind the people whose ingredients were driving chefs to create great dishes. Little did I know it would become a column about communities  of producers, of customers, of eaters and enthusiasts.

title: A Mealtime Manifesto
description: Although known as an environmental activist, you take up a less divisive cause in your new book, The Family Dinner, a cross between a cookbook and a parenting manifesto.  Ive got two teenage girls and have found parenting unbelievably challenging. At one point I said to myself, I have to get some happy family moments. And so I zeroed in on family dinner as the perfect time to accomplish that.

title: Shared Tastes
description: For some, the old clich that you are what you eat has taken on increasingly complex implications: food choices can be a stand-in for social, ideological, even political identity and beliefs. Eaters can form communities of a sort, and businesses are built catering to them. Surely this has contributed to the interest in incubator programs designed to give new opportunities to aspiring food entrepreneurs. The concept has all the foodie do-gooder trimmings, often involving local cooks making cuisine linked to their immigrant backgrounds.

title: Paying for a Prisoners Food
description: As a desk sergeant in a suburban police department, Im responsible for seeing that prisoners are fed. When a prisoners religion prohibited him from eating our standard meal, an officer found an acceptable meal at a local restaurant, to be paid for by taking up a collection among the precinct crew. When we explained the situation to the restaurant staff, they refused payment, saying it was their religious duty to help a fellow practitioner. Could we ethically accept this donation? A. G., LONG ISLAND

title: Summer of 44
description: I wrote Roth off. Back in my early 20s, in a fit of literary conscientiousness, I undertook to sample his work. At the point when my nose could wrinkle no further in distaste, I was struck by a relieving epiphany  Oh: these are for boys  upon which I resumed my reading life unburdened by any expectation of venturing deeper into Rothiana.

title: Pie + Design = Change
description: ON A SUN-SPLASHED afternoon in August, blueberry pies and peach pies cooled on wire racks inside PieLab, a white brick cafe with floor-to-ceiling windows on Main Street in Greensboro, Ala. Behind a counter made of planks salvaged from abandoned sharecropper shacks, two young women slid pie tins into a double oven stack. At trestle tables, beneath industrial pendant lights, four young men, on lunch break from their G.E.D. classes, dug into slices of taco pie and made weekend plans.

title: Hope in a Pie
description: Graphic designers are trying to revive an impoverished county in Greensboro, Ala., with an all-butter crust.

title: Gimme a Z! Gimme an L! Gimme a B!
description: One of the truly frustrating aspects of economic discussion since the crisis began has been the consistent unwillingness and/or inability of many of my colleagues to wrap their minds around the fact that short-term interest rates are up against the zero lower bound  and that therefore (a) normal monetary policy isnt available (b) comparisons with fiscal policy when monetary policy was available tell you little.

title: Donilon to Replace Jones as National Security Adviser
description: President Obama will announce on Friday that Gen. James Jones, the national security adviser, is resigning and will be replaced by his deputy, Thomas E. Donilon, senior administration officials said.

title: Gameification
description: Turning into a game elements of ones electronic life  from to-do lists to blogs.

title: Pregame Huddle: State of the Pac-10
description: How far will U.S.C. fall? Is Oregon for real? Pete Thamel breaks down the Pac-10 heading into this weekend's games.

title: Chronicle of a Slowdown Foretold
description: The usually well-informed Ezra Klein says something odd this morning:

title: Border Songs
description: In 2007, Dinaw Mengestu made a forceful debut with The Beautiful Things That Heaven Bears. It was an indelible novel about African immigrants in Washington, D.C., struggling to find a place in an America whose idealized promises succumb to everyday realities. Mengestus skillful sensitivity turned observations from his life into a broader narrative, earning him deserved accolades.

title: Up Front: Miguel Syjuco
description: Like the Ethiopian-American writer Dinaw Mengestu, whose second novel, How to Read the Air, he reviews in this issue, Miguel Syjuco  a Filipino living in Montreal  is a novelist who has used the immigrants perspective to explore themes of family and homeland, politics and identity.

title: Accounting for Taste
description: You never know when someone online might go into raptures over Chinese soup dumplings. In real life Ive been buttonholed plenty of times by soup-dumpling rhapsodizers. I should have expected to find hymns to dumplings on the Web too. Restaurant-obsessed people seize on slim pretexts to go on at length about where to get soup dumplings, where the soup dumplings are much better than that other place you had them, how you have to consume them on spoons using complex protocols to avoid squirting and scalding and, finally, how you must behold soup dumplings for an hour of awestruck contemplation and then stuff a mattress with them and sleep on a bed of them for a year or you will never get the full effect of the sexy incredibleness that is the soup dumpling.

title: 36 Hours in Rome
description: Rachel Donadio, The New York Times's Rome bureau chief, spends a weekend exploring some of the avant-garde cultural and culinary attractions of the ancient capital.

title: Spurs Downsizing Their Roster
description: To the average sports fan, an N.B.A. team seems steeped in money. The players make millions, fly on a private plane and stay at luxury hotels, and the teams big arena charges big bucks for parking, tickets and food.

title: MacKenzie Hires Senior Executive From Altman
description: MacKenzie Partners, one of the big proxy solicitor firms, said Thursday that it had hired Paul Schulman from the Altman Group as a senior vice president.

title: A Canvas You Can Paint With Cash
description: THE road to cheap automotive thrills is pockmarked with caveats and compromises. Manufacturers seeking customers for budget-performance cars will mate an eager engine to a laterally stiff chassis, only to imbue the surrounding sheet metal with the charisma of a gym locker. In other cases, a deceptively stout steering wheel might engage the rack and pinion with all the exuberance of a limp handshake.

title: Comparing Recessions: Job Recovery
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: Sanchez Apologizes for Offensive Comments
description: The fired CNN anchor Rick Sanchez said he screwed up last week when he called Jon Stewart a bigot and made comments that some viewed as anti-Semitic.

title: The Beat Generation and the Tea Party
description: The counterculture of the late 1950s and early 1960s appears to be everywhere these days. A major exhibition of Allen Ginsbergs photography just closed at the National Gallery in Washington. A superb book, by the historian Sean Wilentz, about Ginsbergs dear friend and sometime influence Bob Dylan recently made the best-seller list. Howl, a film about Ginsberg and the Beats, opened last month. And everywhere around us, the streets and airwaves hum with attacks on government authority, celebrations of radical individualism, inflammatory rhetoric, political theatrics.

title: Friday Reading: Some Potluck Dish Ideas
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Last U.N. Climate Extravaganza?
description: In an article in Fridays paper, Elisabeth Rosenthal and I describe the bad mood and poor prospects pervading the run-up to the next big United Nations climate change conference, which opens at the end of November in Cancn, Mexico.

title: 2011 Scion tC
description: Scion has long hitched its cheap-speed ambitions on the tC.

title: Japan Gets the Best of Argentinas A-Team
description: Rafael Nadal, the No. 1 tennis player in the world, sped through his quarterfinal match at the Japan Open to make it to Saitama to watch his friend, Lionel Messi, and Argentina take on Japan in an international friendly. But while Nadal easily dispatched Dmitry Tursunov ( 6-4, 6-1), Messi and Co. lost, 1-0, the Blue Samurai.

title: Former Dora the Explorer Star Speaks Up and Sues Nickelodeon
description: What are some things you can find in a courtroom? You can see judges, you can see gavels, you can see bailiffs, and you might soon see Caitlin Sanchez, a 14-year-old former star of the animated series Dora the Explorer, who is is suing Nickelodeon, MTV Networks and Viacom, saying she is owed millions of dollars for her work on the show.

title: Concerns on No-Fault Divorce, and a Conviction Stands
description: While no-fault divorce was signed into law in New York this summer with great fanfare, the bill included numerous unheralded provisions that have left many divorce lawyers uneasy.

title: What the Dog Saw
description: Murder takes a capital M when it appears in most novels, bossing the story around in myriad ways. The guiding principle is that murder (even manslaughter) will out, and the dire secret of the crime will squirm noisily around, leaving clues until its circumstances are discovered. We see a murder in a novel, and then we watch and wait until the layers of plot are revealed through a satisfying, often surprising, set of procedures that make us appreciate how clever the detectives (official and unofficial) can be. But while someone is killed right up front in Scott Spencers 10th novel, Man in the Woods, the murder doesnt operate as a motor for the action; instead, it glows like something toxic in the daily lives of the characters. Its as much a question as an act: What if you killed a stranger who had few ties to the world  a person no one might miss?

title: Chinese Dissident Awarded Nobel Peace Prize
description: Liu Xiaobo, 54, is the first Chinese citizen to win the Peace Prize and one of three people to have received it while incarcerated.

title: Lost in America
description: Immersed in factual nuance, exacting about sequence and presentation, the historian never steps to the side in his work to register amazement at circumstance, never says, Look! For this we have the other arts, fiction front and center, though it doesnt quite do for the novelist to make such a bald declaration either. Rather, he aims to recreate a world so the reader is quietly overtaken by it.

title: Art and Action
description: The biggest surprise about Milans galleries is how few Italian artists show there. Scattered about town or gathered in a few clusters, they wield enough international clout to make up for the time it takes to travel between them. Most ambitious is the Naples-based Lia Rummas new temple to minimalist cool at Via Stilicone, 19. One of the largest commercial galleries in Europe, it opened last May and has attracted a fashionable clientele. Its triple-height space, designed by CLS Architetti, easily accommodates anything the artists on its blue-chip roster (Marina Abramovic, Andreas Gursky, Anselm Kiefer, Ettore Spalleti, Vanessa Beecroft) can think up.

title: Frozen in Time, a Palace Worthy of the Packard
description: DAYTON, Ohio

title: Keeping Score: Did Lincecum Pitch Better Than Halladay?
description: 2:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Anatomy of an Uprising
description: Trying to describe the ideas of the Tea Party movement is a bit like a blind man trying to describe the elephant. The movement, like the elephant, exists. But no one, not even the Tea Partiers themselves, can seem to get hands around the whole of it. Jonathan Raban, who attended the first National Tea Party Convention and wrote about it in The New York Review of Books, was struck by how little agreement there was among members as they talked about their grievances and aspirations. And yet the Tea Party uprising is the most visible and energized political phenomenon of the last year. Whether it will remain a viable movement remains to be seen, but it shows no sign yet of running out of steam.

title: Government Helps to Insure Children, Even Above the Poverty Line
description: THE last few years have not been easy for Dean McCrea.

title: Tenement Long Outlasts Fight Against Skyscraper
description: A lonely little red building sits on a short block a stones throw away from Lincoln Center. Five stories tall, crisscrossed by fire escapes, it looks as if it escaped from the Lower East Side. Skyscraping apartment towers loom over it like bullies ganging up on an old lady. A parking garage and a flyspeck of green space surround it like a moat.

title: Health Insurance for Children
description: In todays Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about the various ways parents can find health coverage for their children, even if they think they cant afford it.

title: Halloween Judgments
description: Ellen Seidman, an editor at Redbook, wrote an essay in the October issue that she thought was about flexibility and compromise. Instead she has found herself in a conversation that is about something else entirely.

title: The Early Word: 9.6 Percent
description: The countrys jobless rate held at 9.6 percent in September, the Labor Department said Friday in its last jobs report before Election Day.

title: Faces in the Crowd
description: Heather Sellers owns all the ingredients for a tough-childhood memoir: the schizophrenic mother, the alcoholic, cross-dressing father. But this is not a memoir in the sliced and bleeding vein of Running With Scissors. Nor is it, despite Sellerss timbre of forgiveness and love, a Glass Castle clone. You Dont Look Like Anyone I Know does not read like any memoir you know, largely because of a condition you may not know and certainly cant say: prosopagnosia.

title: Punk Days
description: One night in 1985, a teenage Kristin Hersh got inspired to pick up her guitar and compose a tune for her punk band, Throwing Muses. So I wrote a dumb little song about smack freaks, unemployment and holocausts, she remembers in her memoir, Rat Girl. It was only a minute long cause I got bored, but it was funny. The song, Hate My Way, rants about the aforementioned topics as well as God (its all his fault), her father (no, its his fault), school (to blame), society (totally to blame) and wanting to die (although she doesnt want to want to die). And that was the bands pop song.

title: Tesla Recalling 439 Roadsters for Fire Hazard
description: Tesla Motors is recalling 439 of its electric sports cars because of a possible fire hazard involving the 12-volt electrical system, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: First U.S. Open Tennis Stadium Will Not Be Sold
description: Members of the West Side Tennis Club in the Forest Hills Gardens enclave of Queens, voted Thursday night not to sell the storied stadium where the first United States Open tournaments were played. Now the club, which has operated in the red for years, will have to figure out what to do with the place.

title: The Other Side of the Water
description: The figure of the Haitian living abroad is one that evokes bitter comedy and, often, envy among Haitians living in Haiti. Haitian Haitians can quickly spot someone from what is called the diaspora visiting Port-au-Prince. A Haitian friend once told me that the big difference, aside from a visible discrepancy in wealth, is that someone from lt b dlo (or the other side of the water, which means abroad in Haitian Creole) walks with purpose and studied intent, as if he or she has a destination in mind at every moment. Island Haitians can find such goal-oriented behavior strange, unreal, even ridiculous, since the poverty of life in Haiti means that goals are often unachievable.

title: Largest U.S. Bank Halts Foreclosures in All States
description: Bank of America, the nations largest bank, said Friday that it was extending its suspension of foreclosures to all 50 states.

title: Predicting the 2010-11 N.H.L. Season
description: Any so-called expert can make vague predictions about the most obvious aspects of the new hockey season. In fact, playing it safe has become an annual tradition for hockey pundits.

title: Americas Packard Museum
description: What began as the citys premier Packard dealership is now a center for all things Packard.

title: The Inconstant Gardener
description: Jason Elliots first novel may be the ideal thriller for the age of C.S.I. Forget Bondian femmes fatales and Bournian superassassins, and prepare to learn a great deal about steganographic code-making, the differences in the safety catches of various Soviet-era firearms and which side of a car to fling yourself out of should you come under roadside attack. Its safe to say that The Network is the first spy thriller in which the climactic action scene is decided in large part on the basis of whose vehicle has superior gear differentials. And yet, its a lot of fun, this mix of spy chic and bergeek.

title: Celebrating A Gift From Bali: Delicious Confusion
description: NO longer quite the inaccessible Shangri-La of antique travelogue, Bali remains, for artists of all kinds and seekers of a spiritual bent, an isle of pristine enchantments. To musicians with or without the cosmic baggage, the fascination lies in the intricately layered pulse and shimmer of the gamelan, the indigenous form of orchestral ensemble, dominated by percussion and associated for centuries with Balinese ritual and devotion.

title: Mirror, Mirror
description: Just because something happened to you doesnt make it interesting. Anyone who has suffered through an overly indulgent blog post or cocktail-party anecdote is familiar with this thought, which also roughly captures the risk of first-person fiction. And thats what makes Vida, Patricia Engels understated first collection of stories, so arresting: Engel never strays from the even-keeled perspective of Sabina, the daughter of Colombian immigrants, an unambitious young woman from New Jersey to whom nothing truly horrible or truly wonderful happens. But by the end of her book, Engel has, with apparent ease, entirely overcome her readers skepticism.

title: Lotus Designer Shows Up With a 6-Pack
description: DANATO COCO seems to have been busy since he became design director for Group Lotus in January. Most designers would be happy to be credited with two or three cars in their careers, but he delivered six new designs last week at the Paris Motor Show. Not since Chanel has a designer named Coco had so many new models at once on the runways of Paris.

title: S.B.A. Lending Catches Up With Demand  for Now
description: That did not take long.

title: Grim News for Those Out of Job Market
description: Amid the grim news about local government losses and feeble private sector growth, todays jobs report shows that those who arent even counted in the official unemployment rate fared uniformly worse in September.

title: All the Swans At This Lake Are Male
description: LONDON

title: Finding Brahms in Schoenberg
description: BRAHMS THE PROGRESSIVE is the title of an insightful essay that Schoenberg first presented as a radio talk in 1933 in honor of the Brahms centenary. At the time to speak of Brahms as a progressive was counterintuitive. Brahms was a Romantic of course. But if anything, he was regarded as the Classicist among his generation of German Romantic composers.

title: Making Sense of Complex Controls
description: LOOK inside the 2011 Ford Fiesta and you will see dashboard controls that have been modeled after the keypad of a cellphone. In some ways, that makes perfect sense: Fords market research suggested that young buyers were more attached to their mobile phones than to their means of mobility.

title: Arvo Prts Fourth Symphony
description: ARVO PRT: SYMPHONY NO. 4,

title: Bedeviled
description: May you be in heaven a half-hour before the Devil knows youre dead. This familiar Irish toast implies that its possible to stay a step ahead of Satan. Not so in Patrick McCabes new novel, The Stray Sod Country, where a host of malignant spirits haunt and taunt the residents of an Irish hamlet called Cullymore.

title: Songs for the Feet, And Even the Heart
description: DJ Nate

title: For Housewives, Wallflowers Need Not Apply
description: AFTER five incarnations of The Real Housewives series, its safe to say that Andy Cohen knows his way around women. As senior vice president for original programming and development for Bravo and the host of the cable networks self-referential Watch What Happens Live, he helps to stir the pot, overseeing the catfights, the marital meltdowns and even the fisticuffs that have become de rigueur among the ladies who lunch and feud in Orange County, New York City, Atlanta, New Jersey and Washington.

title: Protectionism by China Is Biggest Since World War II
description: C. Fred Bergsten  the director of the Peterson Institute for International Economics and one of the most prominent proponents of pushing China to revalue its currency  wraps up our discussion of the renminbi for this week. Well continue next week. Heres Mr. Bergsten:

title: Getting to Five
description: The story of this book is really two stories, and only one of them is about Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. As Seth Stern and Stephen Wermiel explain in an authors note, Brennan first agreed to cooperate on a biography with Wermiel, then the Supreme Court correspondent for The Wall Street Journal, in 1986. Brennan granted more than 60 recorded interviews in chambers and gave Wermiel access to tens of thousands of pages of records, including case files, correspondence and the coveted case histories his clerks had prepared each term. Wermiel completed part of the book before Brennans death in 1997, then, as he explains, put the project aside. He came under criticism, most notably from Jeffrey Toobin of The New Yorker, for his unparalleled access to documents closed to other researchers and for what little he has managed to make of it. That was in 2004. In 2006, Wermiel brought Stern, of Congressional Quarterly, to the project and, their note continues, it was Stern who reorganized the vast amounts of material and drafted most of the chapters.

title: In Baghdad, Its Business as Unusual
description: BAGHDAD  Overlooking a conspicuously unfit-for-purpose road stands a modern womens boutique, its spotless marble tile flooring a contrast to the good for nothing graveled highway. As soon as irritable customers pass through the sparkling double-glass doors they leave the outside squalor behind, and their mood instantly changes.

title: Liu Xiaobo and Chinese Democracy
description: Congratulations to Liu Xiaobo for winning the Nobel Peace Prize  and to the Nobel committee for giving it to him. China has countless dissidents and people pushing for democracy, of course, but theres a reason Liu rose to the top in Nobel estimations. He has combined relentless courage and persistence in pushing for democracy over 21 years with a broad vision of democracy, all tethered to moderation and willingness to work with Communist Party leaders.

title: If Walls Could Talk
description: Many adults have a fantasy that if they could go back to college  now that the desire to party, drink and sleep around has faded to a burnished memory  theyd get so much more out of it. The publishing industry often reflects this wish. Every season brings offerings that are right at home on anyones continuing-ed syllabus: innovative, original ways to study world history through lenses trained on the minutiae of salt or cod, earthworms or spices, tea or telephones. Now, finally, for those of us who wrestled with Rocks for Jocks, pined amid Physics for Poets and schlepped through college on 101s of any and every subject  the beloved survey courses  heres that most popular professor, Bill Bryson, with a fascinating new book, At Home: A Short History of Private Life.

title: Cake Man Raven Is Shut Down
description: Cake Man Raven, the celebrated and well-connected Brooklyn baker who has blanketed much of the city in red velvet cake from his shop in Fort Greene, was shut down by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene this week for sanitary violations that it said included the presence of flies, lack of a hand-washing station near the food preparation area and toilet room, and the supervisor of operations lack of a food protection certificate.

title: The Convert
description: The years since the end of the cold war divide into two very different ages. The first, the 1990s, was dominated by the rise of free markets and free trade across the globe. The second, since 9/11, has been defined by terrorism, counterterrorism, war and Islamic radicalism. Bill Clinton is the symbol of the first decade and George W. Bush of the second. Tony Blair is the only major political figure to span both eras, beginning his political life in the corridors of Davos and ending it in the mud flats of Basra. He tells both tales in his engrossing memoir, A Journey, but they never fuse into one larger story.

title: Week 6 College Football Matchups
description: What did I learn last week? Well, I learned that Alabama is much better than Florida. I learned that Oregon cannot be stopped on offense. I also learned that in college football its not always the games that are circled on your calendar that end up providing the most drama. Case in point, last weeks LSU/Tennessee game and the Michigan/Indiana game. Those two games went down to the wire in thrilling fashion, but the marquee games provided little late game intrigue.

title: Cahill Files Lawsuit Against Former Aides
description: 5:54 p.m. | Updated  First Timothy Cahills top aides quit his campaign, followed by his running mate, Paul Loscocco, who proclaimed that Mr. Cahill, an independent candidate in the Massachusetts governors race, had no shot at winning. In another twist of the knife, Mr. Loscocco promptly endorsed Charles Baker Jr., the Republican.

title: Man-Eater
description: The large and malevolent tiger at the center of this nonfiction hunting tale bears a striking resemblance to its fictional seafaring predecessors: the white whale and the movie-star shark (both of which, by the way, are said to have been inspired by real creatures).

title: Pumping Up the Self-Control in the Age of Temptations
description: I HAVE a cold and a headache, and I just want to go to bed. But knowing that my editor is relying on me (and Im relying on my next paycheck), I muster my willpower to stay at my computer and finish the column.

title: Altering the Capitals Skyline
description: A look at Bing Thoms renovation of the Arena Stage theater complex in Washington.

title: On Our Radar: More Safety Violations for Massey Coal
description: A surprise inspection uncoversmajor safety violations at another Massey Energy Company coal mine in West Virginia. Last year an explosion at a Massey coal mine in the state killed 29 workers. The latest violations, discovered on Sept. 28, could have caused a similar explosion, officials say. This is a reflection of the problem that we have in this mining industry with some who, regardless of what you do, ignore the mine law, said Joe Main, the director of the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration. There is absolutely no justification to be operating a mine in this condition. [The Associated Press]

title: The Rosenbergs Revisited
description: Walter and Miriam Schneir were aboard a train crossing a 15,000-foot peak in the Andes in 1959 when a fellow passenger, a Peruvian Franciscan friar, paused and asked whether they were Catholic.

title: Long After Death, Lennon Remains an Inspiration
description: John Lennon would have turned 70 on Saturday, and the anniversary has occasioned a flood of events and releases to commemorate the songwriter and his work. In a way, Lennons stature  the reason for the celebrations  makes some of them seem beside the point. Since he was murdered outside the Dakota, 30 years ago in December, Lennon has remained a powerful presence in the culture, both for his songwriting and performances as a Beatle and for his post-Beatles life as a peace crusader, born-again feminist and alternately strident and affecting solo artist. Do we really need to be reminded about John Lennon?

title: Widow of Last Lecture Professor Will Write a Memoir
description: The Last Lecture will not be the final chapter in the story of Randy Pausch, the computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University who turned his ruminations on life and his own impending death into a wildly popular oration and that best-selling book.

title: Crisp Fall Desserts (Without the Gluten)
description: Crumbles are an easy way to turn simple fruit into a decadent, crispy dessert. And for the growing number of diners who cant tolerate the gluten in wheat, its easy to make crumbles that are gluten free without sacrificing taste, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Health Department Shuts Cake Man Raven
description: The Local reports that the health department shut down Cake Man Raven Confectionery for a variety of violations, including a failure to have a hand washing facility near the food preparation area and toilet room, and not having a food protection certificate for its supervisor of operations. Raven  Raven Patrick DeSean Dennis III, a celebrity favorite  has also been accused of cheating his workers on pay.

title: Death March
description: In his second novel, Mark T. Mustian appears to confront an enormous subject: the Turkish deportation of Armenians during World War I, when hundreds of thousands died amid a hellish march into Syria  an expulsion that has, outside Turkey, often been labeled as genocide. But in truth, Mustian, a writer and lawyer from Tallahassee, Fla., who is himself distantly of Armenian heritage, tells a story that probes a timeless array of lifes general adversities: the tricks of memory that enable us to carry on with our daily existence; the brash decisions and subsequent regrets of the young; the ever present need for forgiveness; the way a single event can be subject to many interpretations. Mustian embodies the intractability of these difficulties in the image of an Armenian girl with mismatched eyes, the light eye questioning, the dark eye confirming. She sees the past and the present, the good and the bad, our side and theirs. Her mystery is lifes mystery.

title: Religious Persuasion
description: At first glance, the authors of American Grace would seem to suffer from very bad timing. Between the completion of their manuscript and its publication, the dispute over the Islamic center in Lower Manhattan erupted, followed by the Koran-burning controversy, and somewhere along the way a New York cabdriver was stabbed, apparently for being a Muslim. All this gives a quaint air to their declaration, in the books first chapter, that America peacefully combines a high degree of religious devotion with tremendous religious diversity. And it seems to render moot one of their main goals: to illuminate the source of this interfaith tolerance.

title: Editors Choice
description: ORIGINS: How the Nine Months Before Birth Shape the Rest of Our Lives,  by Annie Murphy Paul (Free Press, $26.) Pauls balanced, common-sense study of the emerging field of fetal origins research is structured around her own pregnancy.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE UNNAMED,  by Joshua Ferris (Reagan Arthur/Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.99.) The hero of Ferriss second novel cant stop walking  for miles and miles, away from his work at a high-powered law firm, away from his loving wife and troubled daughter. No doctor or psychiatrist has been able to diagnose his  walking thing, which becomes progressively worse. What does it mean? our reviewer, Jay McInerney, asked. Tims affliction might be a metaphor for addiction, for careerism. But he found fault with Ferriss descriptions of the heros misadventures: not bad writing, but . . . not good storytelling.

title: Blucher! Neighhhh!
description: Oh, dear. Brad DeLong is right: the CBPP transcript (pdf) of Jan Hatzius, Marty Feldstein, and yours truly being gloomy does keep calling Marty Feldman instead.

title: Inside the List
description: SLAM BOOKS: Obamas Wars, Bob Woodwards fly-on-the-wall account of Barack Obamas decision to send 30,000 more troops to Afghanistan, hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1  the 16th consecutive book by Woodward to make the list in hardcover. Woodward depicts the administration as deeply divided and riven with suspicions (as Michiko Kakutani of The New York Times put it in a recent review), but thats a compliment compared with the portrayals of Obama in the rest of this weeks political best sellers, including Dinesh DSouzas Roots of Obamas Rage (anti-American zealot), David Limbaughs Crimes Against Liberty (socialist evil genius) and Bill OReillys Pinheads and Patriots (pinhead). If the Democrats tank in the midterms, however, Obama may be able to take comfort in another new title, ------ Finish First, Tucker Maxs follow-up to his surprise smash, I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell.

title: Silent Pictures
description: Long before graphic novels earned a dedicated section in bookstores  indeed, before the term graphic novel was even coined  the American wood engraver and illustrator Lynd Ward (1905-85) created six enduring examples of the form. Ward was one of only a handful of artists in the world who bucked literary convention by eliminating all words but the title from standard narrative works. His novels often contained more than 100 pages, with one image per right-hand page. The pictures, influenced by German Expressionism, were dark and melodramatic, as though taken directly from an early film noir storyboard. Wards thematically related sequences and cinematic pacing bridged the divide between mass comics and the more rarefied illustrated book. Now this groundbreaking work, originally published between 1929 and 1937, has been collected in Six Novels in Woodcuts, the first graphic fiction from the Library of America.

title: Someone on the Line
description: On Friday afternoon, the federal Administration on Aging unveils its new, improved elder care locator. The major change: anyone who dials the toll-free number, (800) 677-1116, from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Eastern time on weekdays should get an actual human on the line, ready to answer questions about government services and refer seniors and caregivers to local agencies that can help.

title: New York City Ballet | Plainspoken
description: A calm, gentle breeze seemed to permeate its way onto the stage last evening at the New York City Ballet Fall Gala. And members of high society seemed all the more pleased to leave their winter coats at home in place of a stunning assortment of gowns as they made their way into Lincoln Centers David H. Koch Theater. The spotlight was on the principal dancer Benjamin Millepieds world premiere of Plainspoken, set to music by the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer David Lang, with costumes by Karen Young.

title: Bill Ackman, Meet Howard Hughes
description: Its been a busy day for the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman. Along with disclosing his 16.5 percent stake in J.C. Penney, Mr. Ackman has revived the ghost of Howard Hughes.

title: Weekend Competition: Better Book Titles
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to suggest more realistic titles for already published books.

title: Reid Receives Two G.O.P. Endorsements
description: 5:11 p.m. | Updated Harry Reid can now boast a second Republican feather in his cap, of sorts. Less than 24-hours after earning the endorsement of Bill Raggio, a highly influential Republican and Nevada state senator, the Senate majority leader on Friday landed the support of Dema Guinn, the wife of the former governor who died unexpectedly this year.

title: Timescast | October 8, 2010
description: Jobs report portends long slog to economic recovery, the media await the surfacing of 33 Chilean miners and reader questions about the all electric Nissan Leaf answered.

title: His Latest Trick? Staying Sober
description: REGRETS, Steve-Os had a few. Not among them: holding a lit firework in his derriere, attaching a leech to his eyeball, inserting a hook through his cheek and swimming with sharks, or any of the other stunts he performed as part of the Jackass cast.

title: The Crowd Around the Gold Counter
description: Gold evokes emotions from investors like few other investable assets. Whether it is increasing or decreasing in value, people usually have an interest in it beyond its intrinsic value as an investment.

title: U.S. Calls for Withdrawal of United Nations Prize Financed by a West African Dictator
description: PARIS  The United States has put forward a resolution at the board meeting of the United Nations main cultural and education organization calling for the withdrawal of a lavish prize offered by an African dictator and the return of the money, European diplomats said Friday.

title: Raisins Give Hope to Afghan Farmers
description: KABUL  Raisin Producer Cooperative Center No. 2 stands alone astride the highway in Parwan Province, an hour north of Kabul. Inside the clay-colored building with a cheery yellow gate, a group of Afghan raisin farmers sits cross-legged on the tan carpet, talking about the past  and the future.

title: White Plains, 10:35 A.M.
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate for governor, accepted the endorsement of Planned Parenthood Advocates of New York at a rally on the steps of the Westchester County Center.

title: Afghan Raisins for Export
description: Raisins grown in Parwan Province, Afghanistan, will once again land on food shelves in Britain thanks to an unusual alliance among Afghan farmers, a U.S. aid organization, and a British food producer.

title: Two Ejections and a Renewal of the Replay Debate
description: Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, has said he is open to future discussions about expanding the use of replays to review umpires calls.

title: Ex-Bank Chief Pleads Guilty to TARP Fraud
description: A former New York bank president, whom prosecutors accused of trying to steal millions from the governments $700 billion banking bailout program, pleaded guilty on Friday to fraud, embezzlement and bribery.

title: The Tensions of the Championship Showdown
description: The first two practice sessions of the Japanese Grand Prix were particularly interesting on Friday against the backdrop of the four-race run to the drivers championship title that has just begun.

title: The Tensions of the Championship Showdown
description: The first two practice sessions of the Japanese Grand Prix were particularly interesting on Friday against the backdrop of the four-race run to the drivers championship title that has just begun.

title: From Stuyvesant High to Nascar Combine
description: To the average New York City helicopter parent, Julia Landauers scholastic trajectory would be the stuff of daydreams. Last spring, she graduated from Stuyvesant High School. This summer, she reported to Stanford University, where she is fashioning her own undergraduate concentration within the Management Science and Engineering department.

title: A Night for a Rhapsodic Violin And an Old Brake Drum
description: On Thursday night, right behind my regular seat at Avery Fisher Hall for the New York Philharmonic, there was an ominous shiny steel tank labeled Refrigerated Liquid Nitrogen. Two full rows of seats behind mine had been removed to accommodate this (presumably empty) tank, a makeshift percussion instrument for the Philharmonics performance of Magnus Lindbergs Kraft, in its New York premiere, conducted by Alan Gilbert.

title: Manufacturings Brief Rebound
description: The brief spring for manufacturing could be over.

title: Photo Journalism
description: Photography is relevant because it sits at the axis of true, false and fake, said Massimo Torrigiani, the Milan-based publisher and editor-at-large behind the year-old magazine Fantom. The English-language quarterly, which is edited by Cay Sophie Rabinowitz and Selva Barni, explores the uses and abuses of photography  artistic, commercial, scientific, etc.  with essays, interviews between photographers and picks from curators and gallery owners. Fantom is riding two trends that Torrigiani finds exciting: the return of intellectual debate in the art world and the emergence of cool independent magazines in Milan like Apartamento and Mousse. And, of course, it makes debate look great.

title: Arthur Penn, a Director Attuned to His Country
description: BONNIE AND CLYDE was the movie on everyones lips after Arthur Penns death on Sept. 28 at 88, but there was more to his legacy than this exuberant 1967 gangster joy ride that shook up critics and audiences alike. It was the movie of its tumultuous moment, jolting in its violence and vitality. Critics were appalled or blissed out, and wrote about it and wrote about it until it became a veritable fetish. In time it became something other than a great film, something beyond a sexually bold, violent cinematic exorcism of the generational divide. It also became the first shot in New Hollywoods war against Geezer Hollywood.

title: Preview: Alabama at South Carolina
description: Penn State, Arkansas and Florida showed how the football can be moved against Alabamas defense in the middle of the field. There are pass plays to be made behind linebackers and in front of safeties.

title: A Sweeping Tale of a Terrorist and His Time
description: EVERYTHING about Carlos, the new film from the French director Olivier Assayas, is large and ambitious, from its length  about five and a half hours  to its subject matter: the rise and fall of the international terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal. But thats not how things started.

title: Al Pacino to Take On Phil Spector in HBO Movie
description: LOS ANGELES  Its not quite a monster movie, but it has some of the same elements: an outsize character, a mysterious death, plenty of metaphor for mankinds destruction. And lots and lots of excessively teased hair.

title: Boehringer Stops Work on a Female Viagra
description: The German drug maker Boehringer Ingelheim announced Friday that it had stopped work on a pill for low libido in women, the latest setback in the controversial efforts to produce a female Viagra.

title: The Latest Rush to Gold
description: Gold was trading at more than $1,300 an ounce on Friday, after a steady march upward over the past year. As Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week, the rise in gold prices is once again inspiring sharply divided opinions. Is this the next bubble that is destined for a painful collapse? Or has the precious metal found a permanent  even expanded  place in portfolios?

title: Civilian Replaces General in Key Foreign Policy Job
description: WASHINGTON  In speeding the replacement of the national security adviser, Gen. James L. Jones, with his deputy, a foreign policy aide with deep political experience, President Obama has given civilian and political advisers a bigger voice in the hard choices of the coming months, including how quickly to withdraw American troops from Afghanistan.

title: Bank of America Halts Foreclosure Sales
description: Bank of America, the countrys largest bank, said Friday that it was halting all foreclosure proceedings and sales of foreclosed homes indefinitely, David Streitfeld of The New York Times reports.

title: Tracking Campaign Money: A Guide
description: Court rulings and rule changes this year loosened some restrictions on campaign support and spending. Heres how.

title: Student Crossword | World Explorers
description: Complete our Student Crossword to see what you know about famous explorers and expeditions. You can find the answers here.

title: Resources | World Explorers
description: To commemorate the observation of Columbus Day, weve collected Learning Network lessons and features on explorers and exploration, along with related resources from The Times and around the Web.

title: Seven Arrested in Bronx in Antigay Attacks
description: 11:21 a.m. | Updated  Click here for the final, fuller version of this article that appeared in the newspaper.

title: A New Sifty Fifty!
description: Well, not an entirely new one. As fall swings into gear, I have updated my list of favorite New York restaurants on The Scoop, the Timess iPhone guide to New York, in order to bring a few new favorites into the light. (Some old ones, too.) Accordingly, a number of restaurants have fallen off the list. Will they ever be back? Probably! Or not. Or both. As Kanye West says over on the Twitter machine (where you can follow him  or me), #ITSAPROCESS.

title: Next Harry Potter Movie Will Not Be in 3-D
description: Visual-effects artists may be wizards in their own right, but they wont have enough magic to present the next installment of the Harry Potter movie franchise in 3-D after all. On Friday, Warner Brothers Pictures said that Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1, the first of two films adapted from the final novel in J. K. Rowlings best-selling Harry Potter series, will be released in 2-D and in Imax theaters, but will not be shown in 3-D.

title: Schoolboys Meet Again, With More on the Line
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There were times when Jason Heyward, the Braves young slugger, stepped to the plate Thursday night and was serenaded with chants of Poseys better.

title: Did Whale Wars Leader Sink Boat for Publicity?
description: News reports are probing whether Paul Watson, who has turned a longstanding anti-whaling campaign into popular television entertainment with Whale Wars, ordered the intentional sinking of a million-dollar protest boat after it was damaged in a collision with a Japanese vessel early this year. 2:49 p.m. | Update  Watson posted a comment on Dot Earth Friday night offering a detailed defense.]

title: Arab League Offers Reprieve on Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Arab League ministers meeting in Libya walked a diplomatic tightrope on Friday, issuing a statement that put the Israeli-Palestinian peace process on notice but also giving American brokers another month to resolve an impasse over Israeli settlement construction and restart the talks.

title: Another Dimension of Idiocy
description: JACKASS 3D, which arrives in theaters on Friday, marks the improbable 10th anniversary of the MTV phenomenon, part fraternity hazing ritual and part extreme sports stunt. Those who loathe Jackass  which brought the world beer enemas and urine snow cones and thrust its merry band of dolts into reptile lairs and shark-infested waters  have called it disgusting and irresponsible: an incitement to copycat idiocy, if not a sign of the end of Western civilization. Fans of the franchise, which began as a television series (from 2000 to 2002) and spawned two earlier features (Jackass the Movie in 2002 and Jackass Number Two in 2006), counter that it is comic anarchy at its freest, as cathartically funny as it is monumentally stupid.

title: Quote Unquote | Skirting Disaster
description: Kanye West explains why he put his clothing line on hold. Apparently something good came out of Lindsays failed stint as a fashion designer.

title: On DVD, Essential Bugs Bunny Collection
description: CERTAIN cultural phrases become so embedded in our subconscious that they will interrupt our own final rites. Maybe you hear whispers of Dickinson when sandwiched in a packed subway. (Im nobody! Who are you?/Are you nobody, too?) Maybe a jolt of Shakespearean bravado sounds in your head as you join the line at Dunkin Donuts (We few, we happy few, we band of brothers.) Or maybe, like me, you stare into the morning mirror to be greeted with:

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Women on the Verge, Dan Barry on Bugs Bunny and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Flying Fewer Planes, Airlines Find Stability
description: VICTORVILLE, Calif.  For the first time since their industry was deregulated in the late 1970s, airlines in the United States have managed to hold the line on the number of planes they fly.

title: Week in Pictures, Oct. 8
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: A Gehry Sculpture for Rent
description: With its undulating walls of stainless steel, the new 8 Spruce Street tower designed by Frank Gehry will have over 600 apartment layouts.

title: From Texas, Harvard Captain Finds His Way
description: BOSTON  Collin Zych, a senior free safety at Harvard, wakes up on a typical autumn Sunday feeling the aftershocks of most of the hits he made in the game the day before. He carries bumps and bruises, and his shoulders tend to ache.

title: Nairobi Nights
description: Until the Tribe opened in Nairobi two years ago, boutique hotels were almost unknown to the Kenyan capital, where accommodations tend to be more shabby than chic. Travelers dubbed the high-tech, 137-room lodge serving the diplomatic community in the parklike Gigiri suburb the Soho House of Nairobi. That was partly because Mark Somen, its general manager, is a former director of that New York club. A Kenyan native and a believer in deluxe creature comforts like flat-screen TVs, organic food and fine linens, he gave the Tribe the look and feel of a hip resort and turned the stylish bar and lobby into a thriving nightspot.

title: Book Review Podcast: Making Sense of the Tea Party
description: This week: Kate Zernike discusses Tea Party politics; Sam Roberts talks about new findings in the Rosenberg spy case; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has bestseller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Ex-Head of Park Avenue Bank Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: The former chief executive of the Park Avenue Bank on Friday became the first person to be convicted of trying to defraud the federal bank bailout program after pleading guilty to numerous criminal charges, including securities fraud, bribery and embezzlement.

title: Lessons From Female Owners Around the World
description: The number of businesses owned by women is growing worldwide. And while many of these ventures  particularly those in developing countries  face hurdles that are unimaginable in the United States, they also experience some universal challenges. This is evident in the stories of female owners from countries as geographically, politically and socially diverse as Afghanistan and Mexico.

title: Allie Compton and Chris Ryan
description: HIS life is a fast-moving swirl of punk rock stagecraft, two-wheeled protests, film projects and occasional bits of street theater.

title: Silver (Yawn) Is the Most Popular Car Color, Again
description: Car paint comes in wide range of colors, from Denim to Cognac to Wicked (i.e., green), but that marketing creativity isnt matched by customer preferences  which, according to a new report, remain silver, black and white.

title: Low Back Sprain Sidelines Nets Troy Murphy
description: The Nets announced Friday that Troy Murphy would be sidelined indefinitely after a magnetic resonance imaging examination confirmed that he had sustained a low back sprain. The development heightens the Nets need for Derrick Favors, the third overall pick in the draft, to acclimate quickly to the N.B.A.

title: Cuba Journal: A Mixing of Styles in Havana
description: What happens when you put some great American jazz musicians onstage with the biggest names in Afro-Cuban music?

title: CHiPs Actors Journey in the Land of Penny Stocks
description: 5:34 p.m. | Updated  Larry Wilcox became famous for playing Officer Jon Baker on the hit television series CHiPs decades ago. But what about his most recent role  as the president and chief executive of a California company called the UC Hub Group?

title: The Playground Gets Even Tougher
description: SCARLETT made for a good target. The daughter of a Williamsburg artist, she wore funky clothing to her East Village school, had a mild learning disability and was generally timid and insecure. Lila, the resident mean girl in Scarletts kindergarten class, started in immediately.

title: The Morning Skate: Young Oilers Debut Promises Fun Season
description: Who before the season was willing to take the Edmonton Oilers seriously? Not too many come to mind. TSN, for example, ranked them last in their preseason rankings of N.H.L. clubs. Hockey Night in Canada was a bit more charitable

title: Coping With an Unfinished Life
description: SOUTH PASADENA, Calif.

title: Now Trading | Manly Goods
description: With its hunting-cabin vibe, its selection of rugged mens wear and its hodgepodge selection of duck-related artworks (paintings, lampshades, knickknacks), walking into Palmer Trading Company is like stepping back in time  with the settings on the time machine switched to manly and Americana. Or maybe its more like visiting your hermit great-uncle who digs hunting.

title: Alderson to Interview for Mets General Manager Job
description: Sandy Alderson, the longtime baseball official, said in a telephone interview on Friday that he is scheduled to meet with the Mets owner Jeff Wilpon in New York next week to discuss the teams general manager vacancy.

title: Philip Roths Literary Javelin
description: Longtime readers of the Book Review may recall George Plimptons classic 1992 essay The Smaller the Ball, the Better the Book, which held that when it comes to sports literature, there is an inverse relation between the size of the thing people are trying to hit and how much fun it is to read about it.

title: Philip Roths Literary Javelin
description: Longtime readers of the Book Review may recall George Plimptons classic 1992 essay The Smaller the Ball, the Better the Book, which held that when it comes to sports literature, there is an inverse relation between the size of the thing people are trying to hit and how much fun it is to read about it.

title: North Koreans Have the Honor of Serving Leaders Son, Senior Official Says
description: In an interview with Associated Press Television News on Friday, a senior North Korean official seemed to confirm that Kim Jong-un, the youngest son of the countrys dear leader, Kim Jong-il, will eventually succeed his father.

title: Carbon-Cutting Party Set for Sunday
description: Some prominent climate scientists, like James Hansen of NASA, think the safe threshold for carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is no higher than 350 parts per million. Beyond this point, they say, we risk severe climatic consequences: melting ice caps and glaciers, rising seas, and a sharp increase in heat waves, droughts, crop failures and extreme weather events.

title: Handbags at Dawn
description: The pre-release of four styles from the Mulberry for Target line sold out within minutes on GiltGroupe.com in August, proving the publics desire for the English luxury houses leather goods. Now, the stellar collaboration is having its official introduction, in Target stores and on target.com, today. Priced from $14.99 for the mobile-phone-friendly Mini Messenger to $49.99 for large satchels and totes, the collection features 18 pieces available in leather and denim, including a winning pink leopard print. Says Emma Hill, Mulberrys creative director, Leopards are king this season.

title: Book Review Podcast: Making Sense of the Tea Party
description: This week: Kate Zernike discusses Tea Party politics; Sam Roberts talks about new findings in the Rosenberg spy case; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has bestseller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Book Review Podcast: Making Sense of the Tea Party

description: To the Editor:

title: Citadels $100 Million Payout Under Fire
description: 4:28 p.m. | Updated In a filing unusually venomous even for the ruthless world of bankruptcy court, a hedge fund has attacked Citadel Broadcastings executives and board just months after the radio company exited Chapter 11.

title: Origins of Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Stopped the Rain
description: To the Editor:

title: Coffee, TV or Wi-Fi?
description: The politicians have it all wrong. We are not addicted to foreign oil. We are addicted to Wi-Fi, the wireless networking technology that holds our youth in its wavy grip.

title: A Complicated Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Toys Without Borders
description: And to think that Betsy Wetsy shares the same phylum as Kaori the Nurse. Both are dolls, of course, but Kaori is a limited-edition designer toy meant for grown-ups who can afford four figures for a cuddly five-inch work of art. The scope of these plastic critters, which range from the abstract to the downright lewd (see Cathy Cowgirl, the heifer with big teats), is wonderfully surveyed in I Am Plastic, Too (Abrams, $45), by Paul Budnitz, the designer and collector behind the art-toy company Kidrobot. What began in 1996 with some handmade toys by two Chinese artists in Hong Kong has now spread west with collectors lining up for hours to buy the latest releases. Globalism strikes again!

title: Plenty of Ideas for Making the Subway Better
description: With New Yorkers being asked once again to pay more for less transit service, the NYC columnist, Clyde Haberman, asked readers to suggest low-cost ways for the perpetually cash-starved Metropolitan Transportation Authority to make taking the subway a more pleasant experience.

title: Tapping The Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Based on a True Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Ten, Ten, Ten, the Pitchmen Say, 10 Times Over
description: Marketers are always looking for ways to latch onto big events and other things that get consumers talking, the better to stand out amid the clutter. Such efforts to borrow interest seem to be increasing in this age of social media, as people make marketing moves  like the new logo redesign for Gap  the subjects of posts, comments and chats.

title: Living in Borough Park, Brooklyn
description: In Borough Park, Brooklyn, religious tradition and ritual touch nearly every aspect of neighborhood life.

title: In New York, a Rivalry Shifts Into High Gear
description: FOUR years ago, three women opened a candlelit cycling studio called SoulCycle in the back of a lobby on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, charging $27 a class. At the time, stationary cycling was a ho-hum staple of traditional gyms, and this place had no showers, and no room to maneuver in its cramped hallway.
