What self-respecting Manhattanite would pay a premium to pedal 45 minutes to nowhere?

title: Abbott Labs Withdraws Meridia From the Market
description: The diet drug Meridia is being withdrawn from the market because it can increase the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

title: Reds Have to Deal With Another Roy
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Cincinnati Reds will soon be back on the field for Game 2 of the National League division series, which could be the best way for them to put the memory of Roy Halladays no-hitter in Game 1 behind them. But the Reds still have to deal with Roy.

title: On the Street | In Paris at Chanel
description: Guests attending the spring 2011 Chanel show in Paris wore nothing else but, well, Chanel.

title: 3M Gains 52% of Cogents Stock
description: The 3M Company said on Friday that it had received 52 percent of Cogents shares in its tender offer for the fingerprint identification company, despite opposition from some shareholders who thought 3M should make a higher bid than $10.50 a share.

title: Acrostic
description: Print on one page (PDF) | Printable clues

title: Acrostic
description: Print on one page (PDF) | Printable clues

title: Outflanked on Right, Coulter Seeks New Image
description: I WROTE a new speech for the gays and I dont have it memorized yet! said Ann Coulter, as she ducked into a hallway in the Union Square apartment of the venture capitalist Peter Thiel on a recent Saturday night, flicking a half-empty packet of Habitrol gum between her fingers. She was there to speak at Homocon 2010, a party for the one-year anniversary of GOProud, the Washington-based advocacy group for gay conservatives.

title: Heres Looking at Bogie, Kid
description: A NEW boxed set from Warner Home Video, Humphrey Bogart: The Essential Collection, reminds us of how many movies Bogart made, and how few of them actually feature Bogie, that wincing, faded idealist who remains one of the most popular and resonant figures in American movies.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Celebrity chefs are crowding Manhattan this weekend for the New York City Wine and Food Festival, which runs through Sunday. Most of the dinners, wine and food tastings, cooking demonstrations and hands-on classes take place in the meatpacking district. Many popular events are sold out, but there are still tickets available, $10 to $275. The proceeds benefit Share Our Strength and the Food Bank For New York City.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Afghanistan and Russia.

title: Dancing With the Council
description: Councilwoman Letitia James hasn't danced for 20 years. But she's putting on her dancing shoes, and gearing up for competition, along with other community and business leaders.

title: Is Gossip Good for You?
description: THE GIST Gossiping can be beneficial.

title: Now Queen of the Firing Range
description: ON a recent morning at the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown Manhattan, Helen Mirren sat in a plush old armchair and poured herself a latte from a silver pot resting on a silver tray. Wearing a fine-knit salmon-colored cardigan and with her head held high and knees pressed together primly, Ms. Mirren seemed the embodiment of regal, a word so frequently attached to her that she has grown to dislike it. Upon further inspection, though, certain complicating details emerged. Black pencil ringed her eyes punkishly. Glinting, oversize zippers sawed diagonally up the sides of her skirt, trimmings a touch more dominatrix than dame. And that jagged black abstraction just below her left thumb? A tattoo she got years ago after more than a few drinks.

title: Now Showing | Tony Cox White Trash Mystic
description: That an exhibition called White Trash Mystic is opening in a pop-up gallery space in the new luxury-condominium building at 211 Elizabeth Street (where the actor Gabriel Byrne reportedly coughed up more than $3 million for a two-bedroom) is either ironic or, well, just plain trashy. But for the shows artist, the former professional skateboarder Tony Cox, the liminal space between the citys high-end art scene and the culture that some people disparagingly call white trash is a rewarding creative zone.

title: Game 2 Final: Phillies 7, Reds 4
description: The Reds committed the fewest errors in the National League during the regular season, but they committed four of them  including two on one play  as the Phillies beat them, 7-4, to take a two-game lead in the best-of-five playoff series.

title: Of a Certain Age, With Vitality and Style
description: ON THE SCREEN At first glance, Advanced Style looks like an ordinary street-fashion photo blog. The mostly vertical images of pedestrians in dapper suits and fanciful skirts mingle with short descriptions of the clothing and back stories about the wearers.

title: Chinese Leader Denies Using Mineral Exports for Political Ends
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China has told European political and business leaders that China has not imposed any bans on exports of industrial minerals for political purposes, and that it does not intend to stop exports in the future, according to a report on Friday in China Daily.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Afghanistan and Russia.

title: Christie to Review Options on Tunnel
description: The planned rail tunnel under the Hudson River may not be quite dead yet.

title: Casting Doubt on Single-Trade Spark in Flash Crash
description: Graham Bowley, a DealBook colleague, reports:

title: Anti-Incumbent Fervor Skips Tennessee District
description: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  Amid the rolling hills of Tennessees Fourth Congressional District, which wraps around the states rural middle like a cigar band, it is difficult to find a lot of enthusiasm for the Obama administration. The residents of the district  farmers, factory workers, small business owners  are abidingly conservative.

title: Housekeeping
description: For new commenters: no obscenities, this is the Times. Also, to prevent trolls from hijacking the discussion, I have a length limit  trying to get it automated, but pending that, a quick and dirty rule of about 3 inches on my screen. So if you wonder why your comment didnt make it, thats why.

title: Death Reclaims His Fractured Psyche
description: In 2005, the entertaining terror-in-the-skies thriller Red Eye indicated that Wes Craven still had his horror mojo, a decade or two or three after Scream, A Nightmare on Elm Street and The Hills Have Eyes.

title: Gay Harassment and the Struggle for Inclusion
description: Weeks before she had any reason to know the name Tyler Clementi, the Rev. Audrey M. Connor was planning a celebratory day of worship at her church in Lynchburg, Va. It would take place this Sunday, the eve of a gay-rights event called National Coming Out Day. There would be prayers, songs and testimonies by three congregants who had successfully emerged from the closet.

title: Dont Put on Lead the Defender Wholl Find the Unwanted Shift
description: PHILADELPHIA  The knockout stages of the womens McConnell Cup and the open Rosenblum Cup have begun here.

title: Its Got a Good Beat and You Can Sign Bills to It
description: What music does President Obama have playing in the background when hes sweet-talking the First Lady? We found out Friday, as singer-songwriter Stevie Wonder joined Mr. Obama for a bill signing in the East Room of the White House.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Scream Sorbet
description: Sorbet may have its charms, but, lets be clear, its no ice cream. Thats one stigma with which the dairy-free, (usually) fruity substance has been marked. According to Noah Goldner, one of three principles behind Scream Sorbet, theres another issue: Theres a surprisingly large percentage of the population that clearly doesnt know theres a difference, sort of the same way a lot of people dont know where Florida is.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Of New Roommates and New Leases

title: This Time Around, Something Citified
description: AFTER the younger of her two children left for college a year ago, I was empty-nesting like crazy, Kathi Homenick said. She was eager to leave her two-story detached wood frame house on a lovely, leafy street in Bayside, Queens. With the kids gone, there was no reason to stay in a neighborhood that seemed way too suburban.

title: A Long Winter Awaits Some Sellers
description: THE five-bedroom four-bath farm ranch on more than 2.5 acres that Margaret Trautmann owns in Upper Brookville has been on the market for nine months. Originally listed at $1.695 million, the 51-year-old slate-roofed house has since had its price cut by $100,000.

title: James D. Stanton
description: Mr. Stanton, 58, is the president of the World-Wide Holdings Corporation, which was started by his father, Frank, and Victor Elmaleh, who serves as the chairman.

title: Borough Park, Brooklyn
description: IN late September, during the final days of the weeklong holiday of Sukkot, young boys in white shirts and black hats could often be seen lining the streets of Borough Park, a large neighborhood in southwest Brooklyn. Standing behind folding card tables arrayed with long, thin willow branches to be waved in synagogue, they called out in Yiddish, hoping to attract customers from among the crowds of shoppers who exited, bags in hand, the kosher markets of 13th Avenue.

title: Preventing Credit Score Dings
description: IF youre looking to refinance or buy a home, potential lenders and mortgage brokers will be checking your credit scores. And if those scores are being verified, chances are they are going down.

title: The Dollar Made Them Do It
description: IN boom times and bust, international buyers play an integral role in the Manhattan residential marketplace, stabilizing prices in lean years and driving demand when the market is ascendant. They make up an estimated 10 to 15 percent of all sales in the city almost every year, brokers say.

title: A Fair-Housing Inquiry in Darien
description: THE United States Department of Justice is investigating the Fairfield County town of Darien for possible violations of the Fair Housing Act.

title: Wall-to-Wall Memories, Built-In Baby Sitter
description: STANDING in front of a small brick apartment house on Netherland Avenue in the South Riverdale section of the Bronx, Matt Bergin can trace the lives of nearly every member of his family.

title: Building Good Will and More
description: TIMES being tough for New Jersey real estate, the news is mostly hard to take; but this concerns some news that isnt.

title: Have You Heard the One About Mayor Bloomberg?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has charmed New Yorkers, or tried to, with his borscht-belt brand of humor, peppering news conferences with cranky wisecracks and Catskills-worthy puns. Now he is taking his act to a national audience.

title: Dear FloFab: My Friends Brought Bacon Double Cheeseburgers Into My Kosher Home
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Out of the DVR and Onto the Stage
description: The nearly three-hour So You Think You Can Dance live tour came to Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, greeted by screaming, merchandise-bedecked multitudes. They had come to see winners and finalists from the last seven seasons of that reality television competition; these young dance celebrities, having vanquished a slew of opponents and genres, are now enjoying their victory lap.

title: Print Publishers Give Marketers More Ways to Reach Men
description: Among the reasons that the nontraditional media are thriving is that men are big fans of going online to watch video and read sports and news articles. Still, the appeal of print as a medium remains, as evidenced by start-ups of magazines aimed at men.

title: Apple Plans to Offer iPhone on Verizon
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facing intense competition from phone makers wedded to Googles Android software, Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, finally plans to make the iPhone available on Verizon Wireless, the largest wireless carrier in the United States.

title: G.E. Keeps Shopping for Energy Assets
description: General Electrics recent multibillion-dollar acquisition spree may just be getting started. The conglomerates GE Energy Financial Services unit has recently been taking a hard look at several energy companies that operate in the Gulf of Mexico, aiming to possibly acquire some or all of their assets, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: Ryan Seacrest Backs New Cable Effort
description: Ryan Seacrest, the host of American Idol and co-host of E! News, is backing a proposed entertainment cable channel with AEG, the events promoter, and CAA, the talent agency.

title: Setting Life and Loss to Song, and Seeking a Stamp of Approval
description: There are 30 shows in the New York Musical Theater Festival, so you have a one in 30 chance you came to the right show, said David Rossmer, addressing the audience at the start of V-Day, which he and Steve Rosen wrote and perform.

title: Serving Up Style and Atmosphere
description: OPEN only since June, Moderne Barn has swiftly acquired a reputation for outstanding contemporary design. The Livanos family of restaurateurs has always decorated its restaurants with style, and this newest addition to its string  including City Limits Diner in White Plains, Burger Deluxe in Wayne, N.J., and Oceana, Molyvos and Abboccato in Manhattan  is no exception. The Barn is a seductive place.

title: Student Says He Found an FBI Tracking Device on His Car
description: A 20-year-old college student in California says that during a visit to his mechanic for a routine oil change, the mechanic found a suspicious wire sticking out at the right rear of his car. The garage owner pulled on it, and detached a GPS transmitter that had been attached to the chassis with a magnet. According to Wired.com, the student, Yasir Afifi, who attends Mission College in Santa Clara, recognized it as a GPS tracking device and posted photos of it on the Reddit site.

title: How Flin Flon Explains the World: Kevin Lowe Tries to Save a River
description: Canada seems lost in a political tailspin: a deadlocked minority government, a largely ineffective opposition, a ruling party  Stephen Harpers Tories  struggling to pass legislation that is usually controversial to begin with.

title: Boehner Campaigns in Ohio, Evoking Twisted Sister a Bit
description: Youve heard Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, wants to be speaker. Did you also know that he is running for re-election?

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 8
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include political campaigning in New York and Connecticut, a memorial service for firefighters, and New Yorks oldest Roman Catholic church.

title: Chic in Review | Rachel Zoes New Project
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Southern Barbecue, Up North
description: Mamas Southern Style B.B.Q. II, in the Vauxhall section of Union is a hidden hole-in-the-wall that attracts a steady clientele with its combination of Carolina-style barbecue and other Southern staples like fried chicken. Christopher Finnick and his wife, Nakeya, are the owners, with family members helping out.

title: Infused With the Taste of Orange-Yellow
description: MONTCLAIRS thriving restaurant scene offers tastes of nearly every region of the world in six square miles. But South America has been woefully underrepresented. In May, with the opening of Costanera, the town finally got what places like Kearny and Paterson, catering to their clusters of immigrants, have long enjoyed in abundance: authentic Peruvian cuisine, with its distinctive flavors.

title: The Caucus Click: Philadelphia
Battle of the East End Reds
description: Long Islands increasingly vocal merlot vs. cabernet franc debate  which should be considered the regions signature red?  came to mind recently when I tasted wines made by Ospreys Dominion, in Peconic.

title: A Smokehouse Outpost in a Shopping Center
description: LONG ISLAND has never been barbecue territory, but in the past few years it has experienced a miniboom of barbecue places. Among them is Dixies Smokehouse in Kings Park, which has had good word of mouth since it opened in July 2009.

title: Coffee, Tea and a Goddess
description: The teapot silhouette on a peach-colored inset just outside Bartlebys Cafe seems incongruous for a place that prides itself on freshly roasted, hand-ground coffee. Yet Bartlebys, which opened in 1999, is as much a fine teahouse as it is a coffee shop.

title: Sebold Takes Job as a Book Editor
description: Alice Sebold, the author of The Lovely Bones, has taken a part-time job as editor of Tonga Books, a new imprint of Europa Editions, a small New York-based publishing house. The new imprint is to publish three or four novels a year, with an emphasis on titles that are dark, cutting-edge or otherwise outside the publishing mainstream. Sympathetic characters rock, a news release said, but we dig the nasty ones as well. Tonga cannot pony up the big bucks, the release also said. All advances will be in the four figures. Ms. Sebold, who has never been a book editor, said in a telephone interview that she was still a little stunned that she had agreed to the proposal from Sandro Ferri and his wife, Sandra, the founders and owners of Europa. She added that she hoped to attract first novelists as well as veteran writers who are having trouble getting published these days because their books dont sell a gazillion copies. The initial Tonga book, scheduled for the fall of 2011, is You Deserve Nothing, a first novel by Alexander Maksik, who is currently studying at the Iowa Writers Workshop.

title: Whats The Spell For Making a Film 3-D?
description: Although Warner Brothers announced early this year that the final two Harry Potter films would be released in 3-D, the first of them will not. In a statement on Friday Warner Brothers said it had decided to release Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 on Nov. 19 in 2-D for both conventional and Imax theaters. Despite everyones best efforts, we were unable to convert the film in its entirety and meet the highest standards of quality, Warner said in a statement. This year Warner was criticized by fans, media types and industry executives for releasing Clash of the Titans in a 3-D version that did not measure up to the expectations of some. The final installment in the Potter series, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2, will be released on July 15, 2011, in both 2-D and 3-D, Warner said.

title: Flavors of the Mideast and North Africa
description: AT first glance, it seems that Bespoke, formerly owned by the New Haven restaurant mavens Arturo and Suzette Franco-Comacho, has changed little. The new proprietors, Lauren Kendzierski and her father, John Kendzierski, have wisely retained the Franco-Comachos elegant dcor, including that incredible onyx fireplace that still dominates the mezzanine. Even the steel-gray menu jackets are the same, though they have begun to look worn around the edges.

title: Secretariat Horses Learn Hollywoods Ways
description: Its not easy being an innocent young horse in Hollywood. Just ask the five creatures who collectively played the title character in Secretariat. To film that drama, which arrived in theaters on Friday, Walt Disney Studios used a group of horses. One was better for close-ups. One was better for racing sequences. You get the idea. But none of them made it into the credits of the film. And while Disney divulged the names of two of the horses to reporters  Trolley Boy, a 6-year-old from Kentucky, and Longshot Max, a 7-year-old from Oklahoma  the studio refused to identify the other three. A case of equine inequality? Disney didnt put any of the horses in the credits, a studio spokeswoman explained, in the interest of time. It had been decided that the scroll could last only 4 minutes 30 seconds and there wasnt room for them. It sounds as if some horses needed better agents. As for the three mystery horses, the somewhat fuzzy explanation involves control. While a professional animal trainer, Rusty Hendrickson, has custody of Trolley Boy and Longshot Max, the other three  used primarily as racing doubles  were sold after filming. Disney, thinking only of the animals, perhaps, did not want the new owners to be able to exploit the horses potential celebrity for personal gain.

title: Mind Over Other Matter
description: The Mentalist earned the most viewers in prime time on Thursday night as 14.3 million tuned in to that crime show, according to Nielsens estimates. The CBS series easily outperformed its 10 p.m. competitors, Private Practice (8 million) on ABC and The Apprentice on NBC, which attracted a disappointing audience of just 3.8 million viewers. CBS led the night over all, with ABC placing second and Fox third, garnering 9.1 million viewers for Bones at 8 but only 5.2 million for Fringe at 9. NBC lagged behind in fourth place.

title: Character Assassins Explores the Wages of Criticism
description: Maybe its just because of the dapper characters in old movies like All About Eve, but theater critics  fictional ones, at least  sometimes seem to belong to another era.

title: Bam! Pow! A Loud Young Rapper Rekindles Raps Old Fighting Spirit
description: The beats and the lyrics matter on Flockaveli, the debut album by the Atlanta rapper Waka Flocka Flame, but everything important about this album is captured in the ad-libbed vocal interjections sprinkled throughout, which approximate the fight captions of old Batman episodes: Bam! Pow! Whap! Boom! Oof!

title: Tales of Motherhood, With a Rock Beat
description: Five disparate housewives, bonding in their long-suppressed desires to be rock stars, form a band soon to become famous as MoM. Eight years later, the women return to the high school gym where they first performed to sing about their subsequent highs, lows and wife-mother-superstar throes in MoM A Rock Concert Musical.

title: Israelis vs. Palestinians: The 90-Minute Version
description: The journalist Lawrence Wright possesses a knack for clarifying complicated problems. Obviously this comes in handy in his regular line of work, but it is just as useful in his secondary vocation, as a public raconteur trying to elucidate thorny topical issues from the unlikely pulpit of an Off Broadway stage.

title: More Serves and Volleys In Adams Photo Dispute
description: Rick Norsigian, the man who says he found the lost negatives of the landscape photographer Ansel Adams, fought back on Friday against those who have suggested that at least some of the images may have been created by an unheralded photographer, Earl Brooks.

title: TD Ameritrade Waives Trading Fees on 101 E.T.F.s
description: The pricing wars among online brokerages continue to escalate.

title: Kuang Chiang, Adam Supple
description: Kuang Hua Chiang and Adam Christopher Supple were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. David A. Davis at Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Thomas G. Benz, a Roman Catholic priest, participated.

title: Tiffany Kary, Dennis Berman
description: Tiffany Kary and Dennis K. Berman are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Jonathan Infeld at the Cecil Green Park House in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Laura DeRossi, Jack Sousa
description: Laura Buckley DeRossi and Jack Hart Sousa are to be married Sunday at the Lake George Club in Diamond Point, N.Y. Harry Demarest, a town justice of Bolton Landing, N.Y., is to officiate.

title: Darren Rosenblum, Howard May
description: Darren Ira Rosenblum and Howard Philip May were married Wednesday at the Town Hall in Greenwich, Conn. Jonathan D. Hunt, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated. On Saturday, the couple held a celebration of their marriage led by Rabbi Sarah H. Reines at Chez Josephine, the New York restaurant.

title: Cheri Simpkins, Wendell Gardner
description: Cheri Nicole Simpkins and Dr. Wendell K. Gardner are to be married Sunday at Latrobes on Royal, an event space, in New Orleans. The Rev. Ronald E. Jones, a Baptist minister who is also the mayor of Garland, Tex., is to officiate.

title: Laura Goodman and Joseph Jacobs
description: Laura Michele Goodman, the daughter of Katherine Komaroff Goodman and James N. Goodman of New York, is to be married Sunday to Joseph Brett Jacobs, the son of Anne R. Jacobs and Michael A. Jacobs of Overland Park, Kan. Cantor Daniel Neiden is to officiate at the Ritz-Carlton, Laguna Niguel, in Dana Point, Calif.

title: Violet Dease, Terence Lee
description: The Rev. Violet Lynette Dease and the Rev. Terence Alexander Lee are to be married Sunday at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Manhattan. The ceremony is to be performed by the Rev. Dr. Calvin O. Butts III, the churchs pastor, with assistance from the Rev. Darryl F. James, an Episcopal priest.

title: Courtney Knowlton, Terence Li
description: Christine Courtney Knowlton, the daughter of Lisa and Oliver Knowlton of Denver, is to be married Sunday to Terence Kuan-Feng Li, the son of Mimi Yin Lam and Peter S. Li, both of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. Al Wulff, a friend of the couple who received authorization from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to solemnize the marriage, is to officiate at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Miriam Palmer-Sherman, David Vaisberg
description: Miriam Anne Palmer-Sherman and David Zachary Vaisberg are to be married Sunday at Congregation Bnai Jeshurun in New York. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon is to perform the ceremony, with Rabbi Lawrence A. Englander taking part.

title: Christine Benson, Peter Schwartzstein
description: Christine Maclear Benson and Peter George Schwartzstein were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. Gilbert W. Bowen, a Presbyterian minister, at Kenilworth Union Church in Kenilworth, Ill.

title: Jennifer Lunney, Hugo Jaff
description: Jennifer Alexandra Lunney and Hugo Michael Alexander Jaff were married Saturday in Big Sur, Calif. The Rev. Brian Lyke, a Presbyterian minister and the brides godfather, officiated at the home of Mary Ellen Klee, a friend of the brides family.

title: Emily Grant and Matthew Turner
description: Emily Hope Grant and Matthew Demetri Turner, both Marine captains, are to be married Sunday in Brooklyn. The Rev. John K. Lardas, a Greek Orthodox priest, was to perform the ceremony at SS. Constantine & Helen Cathedral, where he is the presiding priest.

title: Eleni Gage, Emilio Baltodano
description: Eleni Nicholas Gage, a daughter of Joan Paulson Gage and Nicholas Gage of North Grafton, Mass., is to be married Sunday on the Greek island of Corfu to Emilio Sebastian Baltodano Oyanguren, the son of Carmen Oyanguren and lvaro Baltodano Cantarero, both of Managua, Nicaragua.

title: Katherine Goldstein-Breyer, Judson Coplan
description: Katherine Anne Goldstein-Breyer, the daughter of Sydney R. Goldstein and Judge Charles R. Breyer of San Francisco, is to be married Sunday to Judson Laver Coplan, the son of Tina Laver Coplan and Michael A. Coplan of Chevy Chase, Md. Fern M. Smith, a retired federal district court judge, is to officiate at the home of the brides parents.

title: Rebecca Culley and Peter Lee
description: Rebecca Durie Katherine Culley and Peter Kim Lee are to be married Sunday morning in Manhattan in a small private ceremony in the home of the brides mother, Sarah Billinghurst, and stepfather, Howard Solomon. Mr. Solomon, who became a Universal Life minister for the wedding day, is to officiate. On Sunday afternoon, Mr. Solomon is to repeat the ceremony before 250 friends and family members at the weekend home that he and the brides mother share in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: Eva Labson and Kevin Blum
description: Eva Louise Labson, the daughter of Rebecka Snell Labson and Victor F. Labson of Lakewood, Colo., is to be married Sunday to Kevin Thomas Blum, a son of Frances Kacir Blum and Arthur M. Blum of Quincy, Mass. Rabbi Adam Morris is to officiate at the Winterthur Museum and Country Estate in Winterthur, Del.

title: Molly Niles, Alan Renshaw
description: Molly Virginia Niles and Alan Jeffrey Renshaw are to be married Sunday in the office of the Rev. Robert M. Bock, a Disciples of Christ minister, at the First Christian Church of North Hollywood in Los Angeles, where he is the senior pastor. On Oct. 16, Pastor Bock is to perform a ceremony in front of friends and family at Brisa Mar Palapa, a party space in Sayulita, Mexico.

title: Pary Anbaz-Williamson, Quinn Bradlee
description: Pary Anbaz-Williamson and Josiah Quinn Crowninshield Bradlee are to be married Sunday in Washington. The Very Rev. Samuel T. Lloyd III, an Episcopal priest, is to perform the ceremony at the National Cathedral in Washington, where he is the dean.

title: Aimee Carlson, Trevor Moore
description: Aimee Carlson and Trevor Moore were married Saturday evening in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Norman E. Walter, a Baptist minister, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Kirsten Hogan, Michael Ricci
description: Dr. Kirsten Winifred Anne Hogan and Michael Anthony Ricci were married Saturday in Clarksville, Md. Msgr. Joseph L. Luca performed the ceremony at St. Louis Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

title: Tanasha Sylvester, Ashley Simela
description: Dr. Tanasha Sylvester and Dr. Ashley Simela are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Dr. Douglas Gerdts at the First and Central Presbyterian Church in Wilmington, Del.

title: Emily Ramshaw, David Hartstein
description: Emily Ramshaw, a daughter of Mary Leonard and Gregg Ramshaw of Pittsburgh, was married Friday to David Hartstein, the son of Barbara Hartstein and Alan Hartstein of Hewlett, N.Y. Judge Charlie Baird, of the 299th District Court, officiated in his chambers at the Travis County Courthouse in Austin, Tex. On Oct. 16, Paul E. Lehner, a friend of the couple, is to lead a ceremony including Lutheran and Jewish wedding traditions at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center in Austin.

title: Sabrina Hossain and Byron Athans
description: Sabrina Sheikh Hossain, the daughter of Hung Sook Oh and Anwar S. Hossain of Bedford, N.Y., was married Saturday to Byron Carver Athans, a son of Susan Carver Athans and Dr. Robert J. Athans of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Gilbert Martinez officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle in New York, where he is pastor.

title: Michelle Tang, Richard Lee
description: Michelle Tang and Richard Jin Lee are to be married Sunday at Astra, an event space in Manhattan. The Rev. Eugene Kim, a United Methodist minister, is to officiate.

title: Kristen Arnold, Jason Bell
description: Kristen Laura Arnold and Jason David Bell were married Saturday by the Rev. Monsignor William J. Reilly, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

title: Warisara Chindapol, Daniel Slotnik
description: Warisara Aez Chindapol, a daughter of Amara and Worawit Chindapol of Bangkok, is to be married Sunday to Daniel E. Slotnik, a son of Diane Reverand and Sol V. Slotnik of New York. Rabbi Rene Feller is to officiate at the Yale Club in New York.

title: Courtney Burke, Matthew Maron
description: Courtney Mary Blaise Burke, a daughter of Rosemary M. Burke and Thomas D. Burke of Larchmont, N.Y., was married Saturday in Tarrytown N.Y., to Matthew Russell Maron, the son of Amy S. Maron and Lonnie R. Maron of Rockville Centre, N.Y. The Rev. Mark Connell, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Reformed Church of the Tarrytowns, with Rabbi Alan Block taking part.

title: Peyton McNutt and Elizabeth Healey
description: Peyton Leigh McNutt and Elizabeth Rebecca Healey are to be married Sunday evening. J. Mary Sorrell, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, is to officiate at the Jacobs Pillow dance theater center in Becket, Mass.

title: Eden Cruz, Stephen Zeek
description: Eden Grace Maddatu Cruz, the daughter of Estelita Maddatu Cruz and Ephrem E. Cruz of Flushing, Queens, is to be married Sunday to Stephen Thomas Zeek, the son of Lisa R. Zeek and Walter F. Zeek of West Chester, Ohio. The Rev. Eric J. Knapp, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Xavier Church in Cincinnati.

title: Meg Nakamura, Aaron Bouska
description: Meg Emily Nakamura and Aaron Thomas Bouska are to be married Sunday evening at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Tom Martinez, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to officiate.

title: Kendra Perkins, Edwin Norwood III
description: Kendra Emel Perkins and Edwin Frederick Douglas Norwood III are to be married Sunday at the City Club of Washington. The Rev. Dr. Walter A. Smith III, a Baptist minister, is to officiate.

title: Margaret Katz, Reed Cordish
description: Margaret Litman Katz and Reed Saunders Cordish were married Saturday evening by Rabbi David Wolfman at their home in Baltimore.

title: Cinnamon Chambers, Taj Lewis
description: Cinnamon Chambers and Taj Yusef Lewis are to be married Sunday evening at the Waters Edge Resort and Spa in Westbrook, Conn. The Rev. Ashley J. Johnson, a minister at Urban Hope Refuge Church in Hartford, is to officiate.

title: Lauren Levy, Scott Neustadter
description: Lauren Rachelle Levy and Scott Eric Neustadter were married Saturday evening at Congregation Temple Sinai in New Orleans. Rabbi Edward P. Cohn performed the ceremony.

title: From Girlhood Trials to Onstage Triumph
description: WHEN Elaine Del Valle was a little girl, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn in the 1980s, she lived in an apartment that required only one key to open the front door. But her mother had several others made up and put on one key chain, so Elaine could carry them to use as a weapon if the need arose.

title: Alexis Ginsberg, James Weiss
description: Alexis Warner Ginsberg, the daughter of Janet Roberts Ginsberg and Marc Charles Ginsberg of Bethesda, Md., was married Saturday evening to James Bendiner Weiss, a son of Nancy Bendiner Weiss and James Alfred Weiss of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Rabbi William Rudolph officiated at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

title: Christine Turner and Scott Sasso
description: Christine Faith Turner and Scott Alexander Sasso were married Saturday at the weekend home of an aunt and uncle of the bride, Diana Owyang and George Silberschatz, in Occidental, Calif. Dr. Molly Joel Coye, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Melanie Adelman, Damon Kinard
description: Melanie Alyse Adelman and Damon Kinard are to be married Sunday evening at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in New York. Barbara A. Michaels, a Universal Life minister, is to lead a ceremony incorporating Jewish and African-American traditions. Last May, Rabbi Judith S. Lewis assisted in a ketubah-signing ceremony at the home of the brides maternal grandmother, Shirley Kligman, in New York.

title: Sarah Abrams, Joshua Beraha
description: Sarah Abrams and Joshua Isaac Beraha are to be married Sunday evening at the Lansdowne Resort in Leesburg, Va. Rabbi David Kalender is to officiate, with Rabbi Wayne M. Franklin participating.

title: Emily Essner, David Delbos
description: Emily Anne Essner and David F. Delbos were married Saturday evening at Skylight One Hanson, an event space in Brooklyn. Rabbi Howard Laibson officiated.

title: Channing Powell, Jonathan Soverow
description: Elizabeth Channing Powell, a daughter of Nancy Landry Powell and Earl A. Powell III of Easton, Md., was married at her parents house Saturday evening to Dr. Jonathan Edward Soverow, a son of Maliheh Soverow and Dr. Gary Soverow of McLean, Va. Sandra Day OConnor, the retired Supreme Court justice, officiated.

title: Teacher and Student(s), in a Comedy of Manners
description: To be an American etiquette teacher in 1967, when hippies and the Summer of Love reigned, was probably a thankless job. To be a 9-year-old boy forced to take an etiquette class that year must have seemed like a fate worse than violent death. Mrs. Mannerly, Jeffrey Hatchers gentle two-actor comedy now playing at Penguin Rep, sympathizes with both sides of the situation.

title: In the Attic With Anne Frank
description: So thats where it happened.

title: Reverend Billys Revelation: A Role for Money
description: Two weeks ago Reverend Billy, the performance artist and activist best known as the leader of the Church of Stop Shopping, was plying his trade, public proselytizing. He and 15 members of the churchs choir traveled from New York to Washington to stage a protest as part of Appalachia Rising, a campaign to end mountaintop-removal coal mining. They gathered around a mound of symbolic dirt in the lobby of a bank that they say finances mountaintop removal, shouted Hallelujah! and sang folk songs. Reverend Billy was arrested for what his wife and performance partner, Savitri D, guessed was the 50th time.

title: Still a Lot to Mine From Ellas Life
description: If Ella, the Long Wharf Theaters first production of the season, has a message about Ella Fitzgerald, it is that she was terribly unattractive and a horrible mother. Whether true or not, these attributes are treated as givens in this show. So maybe the producers should have a makeup artist drab down their star, Tina Fabrique, or recast the role.

title: In Illinois, Questions About Trust Are Front and Center
description: The Senate contest in Illinois has been in a stalemate for months, with questions of trust about both candidates hovering in the background.

title: Ackman Buys Into Penney and Fortune
description: 6:44 p.m. | Updated

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 8
description: A slide show of images of cultural events this week.

title: Classic Scones
description: Mark Bittman bakes traditional English scones, which are light, flaky and barely sweet at all.

title: Applying Broad Strokes to a Time of War
description: The great American art critic Clement Greenberg once described kitsch as a debased and academicized version of genuine culture, offering familiar images that demand little of the viewer. Norman Rockwell and Ilya Repin, a late 19th-century Russian realist, were Greenbergs primary examples.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 8
description: More Photographs

title: California Budget Wins Approval
description: LOS ANGELES  After an all-night session of legislative wrangling, the California Legislature on Friday morning approved a nearly $126 billion budget that imposes a new round of cuts on the states public school system, but includes changes in the public employee pension system and Californias budget process that officials said could help avoid another budget crisis.

title: What Do Women (or Men) Want? A Galas Question
description: If I were an examiner instead of a critic, Benjamin Millepied might well be my favorite living ballet choreographer. Id bring lots of other dance makers (some of them much more famous) to see his work and say, Look how much he knows about spatial and temporal structure, and about groupings! Look how each piece stretches him in an impressively new direction! Look how chic, how now, his every work is, but always in a different way! Note how his men dont endlessly manipulate their women! Id give him prizes galore.

title: Nightclub Tradition Gets a Jolt Of Youth
description: Stately grandeur and youthful intensity: the annual New York Cabaret Convention at the Rose Theater has never lacked for great ladies and refined gentlemen. But as for youth (performers under 50), it has always struggled to forge a credible connection between a nightclub tradition nearly done in by rock n roll and television and the idea of a future. This year was different. All it takes to demonstrate that somehow or other the tradition goes on is a couple of exceptional rising talents. And at the conventions opening-night gala on Thursday, two singers  T. Oliver Reid and Amanda King  leapt out from the pack.

title: An Unseen Evil Still Ensnaring Countless Souls
description: CINCINNATI  Peer through a circular hole into one of the displays in the permanent exhibition Invisible: Slavery Today, opening on Saturday at the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center here, and you see a tawdry room the size of a closet. On the floor a stained mattress is scrawled with the words: At sixteen, her new life had begun. The irony stings. Around the portals opening, a seemingly handwritten account tells of Margos abusive father, the promises of escape offered by Lenny and her delivery into sexual slavery.

title: Weekly Pick Em: The Grind
description: Last Saturday brought a wealth of marquee matchups, including Florida-Alabama, Stanford-Oregon and Texas-Oklahoma. At first glance, this weekend doesnt look as glitzy. But thats only because teams are now into the grind of conference play, where each week brings a familiar opponent and the chance to be lulled into complacency. Alabama has one of the more absurd conference schedules in recent memory, with South Carolina the first of six SEC opponents that will be coming off a bye week when they face the Tide. That will make the Tides road through the league that much more difficult. Florida will try to bounce back from being handled easily by Alabama when it faces Louisiana State in the Swamp. The Tigers, through a combination of good defense and horrendous clock management, are 5-0 but being treated like they are underachievers. A win against the Gators could give them some credibility. Elsewhere in Florida, Florida State and Miami will play the latest installment of a rivalry that was one of the best in college football over the last quarter century. While that rivalry has lost some of its luster, Michigan-Michigan State has gained some glitz thanks to the outsize performance of Denard Robinson this season. Coach Mark Dantonio is expected to return to the Spartans after missing two games after having a mild heart attack. In the Pac-10, Stanford is coming off a loss to Oregon and Southern California is hoping to prove that it still deserves to be considered one of the conferences top teams. There is plenty to be excited about now that conference play has started in earnest and the history and familiarity between teams always makes prognosticating that much more difficult. As always, if you agree, disagree or simply find the picks laughable, feel free to let us know.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Very Proper Scone
description: MOST scones in this country are overly sweet and loaded up with some ridiculous combination of raisins, apples, cherries, chocolate chips, almonds, ginger and perhaps a few other ingredients. Traditional English scones are actually barely sweet, though theyre usually eaten with sweet jam and clotted cream, which is not easy to find here. In general theyre lighter, flakier and tastier than what you buy. And theyre easy to make.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Air Products Wins Round in Battle With Airgas
description: Despite some last-minute chatter in arbitrage circles that Airgas had turned the corner and a very good presentation by Ted Mirvis of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, Air Products and Chemicals won an important decision in Delaware Chancery Court late Friday in its takeover quest for Airgas. Chancellor William B. Chandler III ruled that a new corporate bylaw that would move up the Airgas annual shareholders meeting to January was valid under Delaware law.

title: Roosevelt Islands Flying Buses to Return Soon
description: In the company of 109 other daredevils, youd step into a giant glass bubble. As the bubble is suspended, somewhat unconvincingly, from a length of wire, youd all be pulled up off the ground and out away from solid land. Higher, farther, higher, farther  until you were dangling 230 feet above the East River.

title: Top-Rated Place to Eat Is Home
description: Tim and Nina Zagat, co-founders and co-chairmen of the Zagat Survey, dont cook much during the week. When you spend your days expanding and perfecting your empire of restaurant and leisure guides  like the 2011 Zagat Survey, released on Wednesday  it would be wrong to whip up some pasta at home instead of heading out to, say,  the Mark Restaurant by Jean Georges. That changes on weekends, which Mr. and Mrs. Zagat (pronounced zuh-GAHT) spend at their country home in Millerton, N.Y. On Sundays, Mrs. Zagat, 68, makes soups and jams, and when there are guests  often their two grown sons and daughter-in-law  she prepares lavish breakfasts. Mr. Zagat, 70, enjoys them.

title: An Optimistic Seller of Disaster Plans
description: NO, Catherine Hooper did not live through Hurricane Katrina, and while she did see the second plane hit the World Trade Center, she viewed it from the treadmill at her gym, where she was watching television. But Ms. Hooper, a 5-foot-1, 99.6-pound disaster-preparedness entrepreneur in a Christian Dior dress, has had some riveting firsthand experience.

title: When the City Defined Whos Who
description: ETHAN MORDDEN mulled titling his latest social and cultural history From Mrs. Astor to Truman Capote, or the Rise of New Yorkism in American Life. Instead, he settled on a more generic (and inviting) title with a more specific subtitle: The Guest List: How Manhattan Defined American Sophistication  From the Algonquin Round Table to Truman Capotes Ball (St. Martins Press, $29.99).

title: What the Squirrels Know: Acorns for Dinner
description: THE assault began in early September. Thats when my 60-year-old mother, an avid gardener, began laying mulch under the shrubs at her home in Westchester. She had her shovel in hand when  thunk!  a white oak fired its first shot. For the next several weeks, the century-old tree would rain acorns on her head like a Newtonian nightmare.

title: The Tiger
description: Prologue

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY QUIDDITCH TEAM started Monday, with a surprising turnout of 95 students. To those who somehow slept through the Harry Potter craze, quidditch is that fantastical sport played by wizards and witches on flying broomsticks. But there is an earthly game known as Muggle Quidditch, adapted for a grassy field, in which players use volleyballs, basketballs and dodge balls instead of quaffles. We didnt really get any big bruisers  they were mostly nerds, said the clubs founder, Sarah Landis, 20, a sophomore from New Jersey. A lot of them have never played sports before. Ms. Landis said the players hoped to persuade the university to bestow official team or competing club status by doing well next month in the fourth annual Quidditch World Cup, in Manhattan.

title: Vows in the Park? Expect Joggers
description: THE wedding of Leila El-Azem and Samuel Butt in Fort Tryon Park had an international guest list of 136  college friends from the Midwest; uncles from Paris and London; family friends from Geneva. But there were many other witnesses, as well: women of a certain age who turn out every weekend to watch nuptials in the park; a 29-year-old bride planning to exchange vows in the same spot this Sunday ; and Alexis Guichardo, who took his own wedding photos in the park 30 years ago and said he just loved the whole ritual of weddings.

title: A First Look at Denard Robinson
description: Jeff Genyk had his jaw-dropping Denard Robinson moment long before everybody else.

title: Ruling Limits States Power in School Suspensions
description: In a ruling that puts new restraints on get-tough zero tolerance discipline, the North Carolina Supreme Court ruled Friday that schools must provide strong reasons for denying alternative schooling or tutoring to students after they are suspended for misbehavior.

title: A Real Scone
description: A real scone is not yet another form of cake; its closer to a biscuit, though a tad sweeter and richer, designed to be eaten (in England at least) with jam and something creamy. Check out this weeks Minimalist column for more.

title: Create Dangerously
description: Chapter One: Create Dangerously: The Immigrant Artist at Work

title: Giants Phillips Has Sprained Knee
description: Giants safety Kenny Phillips has a sprained medial collateral ligament in his left knee  the same knee that required microfracture surgery last year  leaving him questionable to play at Houston on Sunday.

title: How Do You Test a Battery?
description: Ill say one thing for the Fandroid army: when they dont like something, they let you know.

title: William M. Birenbaum, College Leader, Dies at 87
description: William M. Birenbaum, a nationally known university administrator who helped rescue Antioch College from looming insolvency during his tenure as president there in the 1970s and 80s, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 87 and also had a home in Wellfleet, Mass.

title: After Two Months, A Possible Rescue
description: Engineers have nearly completed a rescue shaft.

title: N.F.L. Is Reviewing Claims About Favre and Jets
description: The N.F.L. has begun reviewing allegations made in an article published by the Web site Deadspin.com that Brett Favre sent graphic photos and suggestive messages to a sideline personality, Jenn Sterger, while both Favre and Sterger were employed by the Jets.

title: A Double Standard at H.P.
description: And so it came to pass that on the 55th day  55 days, that is, after firing its chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, for playing footsie with a consultant and fudging his expense accounts  the board of directors at Hewlett-Packard proudly announced it had found a new man to lead the company out of the wilderness.

title: Voting Test Falls Victim to Hackers
description: Hackers infiltrated the District of Columbias online voting system last week. They changed all votes for mayor to Master Control Pro and elected HAL 9000 the council chairman. The blaring University of Michigan fight song played whenever a new ballot was successfully cast.

title: UConn Punishes Itself, Not Calhoun
description: The University of Connecticut responded on Friday to the N.C.A.A.s findings of major violations in its mens basketball program, admitting its transgressions, imposing penalties, but at the same time going out of its way to separate the Hall of Fame coach Jim Calhoun from involvement in the recruiting scandal.

title: Obamacare Passes Its First Test
description: Are you one of the 46 million Americans without health insurance? Well, you may not have that, uh, luxury for much longer. A federal judge in Michigan on Thursday dismissed one of more than 15 legal challenges to the new health care law, becoming the first to rule that the law is constitutional, reports The Timess Kevin Sack. The central question, which may ultimately fall to the Supreme Court, is whether the Commerce Clause of the Constitution gives Congress the authority to require citizens to obtain a commercial product, namely health insurance. Starting in 2014, the law will require most Americans to obtain health insurance

title: At Europes Helm, a Steady Hand With Little Pomp
description: BRUSSELS

title: Reader Photos: What the Kids Want to Eat
description: Readers submitted pictures and stories of unusual dishes or snacks they cook for their children.

title: Regulators Seek Curbs for Bank Bonuses in Europe
description: LONDON  Bankers should not receive more than half of their bonuses in cash and as much as 60 percent of the payment should be deferred depending on their position at the bank, according to European draft guidelines published Friday.

title: China Central Banks Chief Backs Gradual Rise in Currency
description: WASHINGTON  The head of Chinas central bank said Friday that he favored letting the Chinese currency rise in value, but only gradually, as exchange-rate tensions overshadowed an international meeting of finance ministers and central bankers.

title: Kickers Form Bond and Find Sorority
description: Shortly after setting the record for most total points by a female kicker in college football two Saturdays ago, Brittany Ryan was contacted by Tonya Butler, whose record she had broken.

title: Fired CNN Anchor Rick Sanchez Calls His Remarks Careless
description: Rick Sanchez, the CNN anchor who was fired, said Friday that he screwed up last week when he called the comedian Jon Stewart a bigot and made comments that some viewed as anti-Semitic.

title: Interview With Liu Xia
description: An interview with the wife of Liu Xiaobo, the jailed Chinese dissent who was awarded the Nobel peace prize on Friday.

title: Raese in Rubber-Stamp Critique of Manchin
description: John Raese, the Republican Senate candidate in West Virginia, has released an advertisement that looks to brand his Democratic opponent, Gov. Joe Manchin III, as a would-be rubber stamp for the Obama administration, the latest in a string of Republican efforts to link the governor to the president.

title: Robinson Runs, and Michigan Holds Its Breath
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Publicly, Denard Robinsons coaches and teammates are confident that Robinson, Michigans sophomore quarterback, is rugged enough to take the pounding defenses dish out each Saturday. They admire his ability to ignore lingering pain in his left knee.

title: Mayors Soda Plan and His Companys Policy Differ
description: Bloomberg L.P., the media and financial information company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has one perk its employees almost universally love: free snacks.

title: Pamela Geller: In Her Own Words
description: The following are excerpts from an interview with Pamela Geller, a conservative blogger who has been vocal in opposition to the Islamic center and mosque to be built near ground zero. Anne Barnard and Alan Feuer interviewed Ms. Geller on Sept. 28, 2010.

title: In Somalia, Signs of Discord Appear in a Militant Group
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The movement of Islamist fighters out of towns in southern and central Somalia in recent days, along with comments by government officials and insurgents, suggests that rifts have developed within the leadership of the countrys most powerful militant organization, the Shabab.

title: After Foreclosure, a Focus on Title Insurance
description: When home buyers and people refinancing their mortgages first see the itemized estimate for all the closing costs and fees, the largest number is often for title insurance.

title: Title Insurance: Share Your Experiences
description: So now we finally know what this title insurance stuff is for.

title: Projected Republican Gains Approach 50 House Seats
description: It has become fashionable to speak of a Democratic comeback, but were not really seeing one in our forecasting models. Certainly there are some individual races  particularly on the East and West Coasts, as well as some gubernatorial contests outside these regions  that look better for Democrats than they did a few weeks ago. But were showing Republicans gaining ground where they need to gain it to maintain decent chances of taking over the Senate. We also show improvement for them in the House forecast this week.

title: Past Equestrian Scandals Lead to Clearer Drug Rules
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Armed with harsher penalties and more investigative muscle, equestrian officials and drug stewards are keeping a close eye on the horses competing here at the World Equestrian Games after incidents at the past two Summer Olympics resulted in the disqualification of eight competitors.

title: Topic of Foreign Money in U.S. Races Hits Hustings
description: WASHINGTON  Ever since he raised the issue in his State of the Union speech nearly nine months ago  prompting head-shaking by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. of the Supreme Court  President Obama has been warning about the danger of foreign money creeping into elections as a result of the courts landmark campaign finance ruling.

title: Killing of Doctor Part of Taliban War on Educated
description: MARDAN, Pakistan  Farooq Khan, doctor to the poor, scholar of Islam and friend of America, represented everything the Islamist extremists hated.

title: Campaign Gaffes Highlight 2 Jerry Browns
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On Wednesday night, at a party held for young San Francisco Democrats, Jerry Brown took the microphone and gave the kind of stirring, if somewhat eccentric, speech that has defined his 40 years in politics.

title: Yanks Secret Versus Twins? Take a Trip to the Bullpen
description: Delve into the Yankees recent playoff history with the Minnesota Twins, and a distinct pattern emerges: each game has its own rhythm and flow, and yet it ends the same way as every other.

title: Dominant Starters Are Taking Control
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Shares in Micron Rise After It Posts a Profit
description: Micron Technology, the computer chip maker, rose 7 percent Friday after it reported a 90 percent increase in fourth-quarter sales. The company reported its first annual profit in four years after the markets closed on Thursday. Micron said net income was 32 cents a share, after a loss of $100 million, or 12 cents, a year earlier. The company said sales in the period, which ended Sept. 2, almost doubled to $2.49 billion. Stock in Micron, which is based in Boise, Idaho, rose 48 cents, to $7.59 a share.

title: Tenant Accused of Cheating Subletters in Public Housing
description: The Craigslist posting was no different from dozens of others: Someone was renting out a room in the hipster haven of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for $400 a month, utilities included. The listing noted the hardwood floors and quiet peaceful area. The price to move in was $800 cash, a months rent plus a security deposit.

title: Arizona Is a Haven for Refugees
description: PHOENIX  Here in Arizona, illegal immigrants get the boot. But refugees get the welcome mat.

title: Umpires and Players Will Meet
description: Players and umpires have scheduled a meeting for Dec. 3 to discuss complaints about umpiring, baseball officials said.

title: Twins Starter Has Been There Before
description: It all happened so fast. In one breath, Brian Duensing remembered hustling to the bullpen at the Metrodome in the 10th inning of the Minnesota Twins divisional tie-breaker game with Detroit last October in case he had to pitch in relief.

title: Activism of Thomass Wife Could Raise Judicial Issues
description: RICHMOND, Va.  As one of the keynote speakers here Friday at a state convention billed as the largest Tea Party event ever, Virginia Thomas gave the throng of more than 2,000 activists a full-throated call to arms for conservative principles.

title: Lured Into a Trap, Then Tortured for Being Gay
description: He was told there was a party at a brick house on Osborne Place, a quiet block set on a steep hill in the Bronx. He showed up last Sunday night as instructed, with plenty of cans of malt liquor. What he walked into was not a party at all, but a night of torture  he was sodomized, burned and whipped.

title: Penguins Depth Is in Question
description: From The Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out blog:

title: In Bomb Case, Turmoil Over What Jurors Saw
description: The trial of four men accused of trying to bomb synagogues in the Bronx and shoot down military transport planes was thrown into turmoil on Friday after the judge learned that evidence the jurors were not supposed to consider ended up in the jury room.

title: The Titan and the Pfc.
description: Eddie Fisher dead at 82.

title: 10/10/10: They Love Just Thinking About It
description: Sunday is the big day for saying I do.

title: Attorney General Rivals Are True to Form in Debate
description: The first debate between the major party nominees for attorney general of New York unfolded on Friday fairly predictably:

title: With Drilling Near End, Chile Rescue Enters Risky Phase
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  After more than two months living nearly half a mile underground, the 33 miners trapped below this scorching desert could be just a few short days from emerging into what will seem like a blinding sun.

title: Dont Try Terrorists, Lock Them Up
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Christine ODonnell: The Girl Next Door
description: Christine ODonnells crusade to convince voters shes just like them continues.

title: A Day Off to Regroup? Not for the Twins
description: In 1986, the heavily favored Mets lost the first two games of the World Series at home. The Red Sox shut them out in the first game and beat them, 9-3, the next day.

title: Outraged, and Outrageous
description: PAMELA GELLERS apartment, in the fashion of the blogosphere, doubles as her office. It is a modern full-floor unit in a high-rise on the East Side of Manhattan that could belong to a socialite or the editor of a lifestyle magazine. There is ample light and a tasteful lack of clutter. The kitchen appliances are made of brushed steel; the countertops are slate. In the earth-toned living room hangs a painting, in vibrant colors, of a woman in a swimsuit.

title: Saturday: Quads
description: Crosswords with full-width stacks can sometimes be a little easier to solve, but that wasnt the case for me today. I finally got everything (well, the No. 48 square remained blank), but it took a fair amount of hopping around and piecing together to get there.

title: Democratic Republic of Congo: Trial of Warlord Must Continue
description: In the latest twist in the case against the Congolese warlord Thomas Lubanga, appeals judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague ruled on Friday that Mr. Lubanga could not be released and that his war crimes trial, halted in July by a lower court ruling, must continue. The trial has been bogged down in disputes between the prosecutors and the bench. The lower court had ruled that Mr. Lubanga could not get a fair trial because the prosecution was refusing to hand over information to the defense, but the appeals judges called that too drastic a measure. Mr. Lubanga, an ethnic Hema, had pleaded not guilty to charges of enlisting and conscripting children under 15 to his Union of Congolese Patriots to kill members of the rival Lendu tribe in Congos 1998-2003 war.

title: Bloggingheads: What if Obama Fails?
description: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate the impact of Barack Obama's presidency on African-Americans.

title: Phillies Take 2-0 Series Lead Over the Reds
description: PHILADELPHIA  In Game 1 of this division series, Citizens Bank Park was the stage for one of the playoffs finest pitching performances, a no-hitter by Roy Halladay that was within one pitch of being a perfect game. Game 2 devolved into one of the playoffs sloppiest games, a ragged affair that bore no resemblance to the near perfection on display two days earlier.

title: U.N. Delegation Presses Sudan to Allow a Referendum and Avert a New Civil War
description: WASHINGTON  After languishing as what many experts worried was the worlds most neglected foreign-policy problem, Sudan is now in the spotlight: a high-level delegation from the United Nations Security Council arrived in the capital, Khartoum, on Friday, to press the government not to disrupt a coming referendum that is considered likely to result in partition.

title: Lottery Numbers
Mr. Paladino and the System
description: Carl Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor of New York, portrays himself as a business-hardened outsider who would reform Albanys corrupt and bloated bureaucracy and drive out the pay-to-play special interests. Im just a regular guy from Buffalo, he says.

title: Pickets at a Funeral: Testing the Limits of Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Awful, Awfuler, Awfulest
description: I recently wrote a column on the pressing question of which state is having the most terrible election this year. Nevada won. Immediately, there were outcries from voters who believed their state had been unfairly overlooked on the dreadfulness meter.

title: Why Is the Seat Next to Me Empty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Spring Cleaning for Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: The Design of the Islamic Center Near Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: High Cost of Crime
description: When times get hard and talk turns to spending and budgets, there is one area that gets short shrift: the cost of crime and our enormous criminal justice system. For instance, how much do you think a single murder costs society? According to researchers at Iowa State University, it is a whopping $17.25 million.

title: Liu Xiaobo
description: China warned the Norwegian Nobel Committee not to honor the democracy activist Liu Xiaobo. The committee didnt listen. On Friday, Mr. Liu  who is locked in jail on an 11-year sentence for spurious subversion charges  became the first Chinese to win the Peace Prize.

title: Policy at Its Worst
description: We can go to war in Iraq and Afghanistan, and threaten to blow Iran off the face of the planet. We can conduct a nonstop campaign of drone and helicopter attacks in Pakistan and run a network of secret prisons around the world. We are the mightiest nation mankind has ever seen.

title: The September Report
description: There was no good news in the September employment report. The economy lost another 95,000 jobs last month, as a modest gain in private-sector jobs was swamped by big losses in government jobs.

title: A Mets Candidate Used to Authority
description: Of the various general manager candidates on the Mets list, Sandy Alderson stands apart.

title: Optimism for Offense as Rangers Start Anew
description: BUFFALO  The Rangers open their 85th season on Saturday with an intriguing four lines. But it would be a mistake to think those combinations will stay intact for long, given how frequently Coach John Tortorella juggles lines, and with the expected return of Chris Drury and Vinny Prospal from the injury list this month.

title: U.S. and South Korea Reaffirm Ties
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and his South Korean counterpart on Friday reaffirmed the close partnership of the two nations, even as they warned of potential instability as North Korea moves opaquely toward a transition of power atop its dictatorial government.

title: It Gets Better Starting Now for Gay Youth
description: Whenever Daniel Derraugh, who is 12 and gay, gets depressed about life, he thinks ahead. Way ahead. I think about my retirement plans, said Daniel, who lives in Wallingford, Conn. When Im retired from being famous and I move somewhere in California, somewhere warm and sunny, like Malibu near the beach. He smiled, thinking about a brilliant future spent reflecting on past glories.

title: U.N. Weighs How to Answer a Knock on Earths Door
description: UNITED NATIONS  There is no United Nations special envoy for space aliens, lets get that straight from the outset, nor even an official designated to pick up the phone should one call.

title: Finding the Funny Amid the Sacred and the Professed
description: Can you say the word breast in a sermon? If so, how often?

title: U.S. Team, Drawing on the Recent Past, Looks Ahead
description: Bob Bradley has a new contract and a new mission, but Bradley, the United States national team coach, is caught in a strange sort of limbo.

title: Challenge to Immigration Law Is Upheld
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled Friday that one of the main lawsuits seeking to overturn Arizonas new immigration law could go forward, despite efforts by Gov. Jan Brewer and several sheriffs to have the suit thrown out. But the judge, Susan R. Bolton, dismissed some portions of the suit, filed by the National Immigration Law Center and other advocacy groups, including their claim that the law would restrict immigrants rights to travel and to use a foreign language.

title: Albertina Walker, Soulful Gospel Singer, Dies at 81
description: Albertina Walker, a gospel singer with a lush contralto voice whose group, the Caravans, recorded a string of hits in the 1950s and 1960s and nourished the careers of such greats as the Rev. James Cleveland, Inez Andrews and Pastor Shirley Caesar, died on Friday in Chicago. She was 81.

title: Marshall Flaum, Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 85
description: Marshall Flaum, an award-winning documentary filmmaker whose movies over a 55-year career examined show business, nature and historical subjects, died Oct. 1 in Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: A Shoemaker That Walks but Never Runs
description: SantElpidio a Mare, Italy

title: Tod's: A Shoemaker That Walks but Never Runs
description: Tods, the luxury Italian shoemaker, has become a multibillion-dollar multinational, but its operations still ooze with Old World tradition.

title: William Norton, Writer Wilder Than His Movies, Is Dead at 85
description: William Norton, a Hollywood screenwriter whose own life story would stretch the credibility of most screenplays, died Oct. 1 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 85.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Whale Wars Leader Responds on Boat Sinking
description: [June 2, 11:52 p.m. | Updated  I interviewed Paul Watson on the eve of the opening segment in the new season of Whale Wars. The video below is part one.]

title: After 15 Years, Wait Is Over for Mike Sweeney
description: PHILADELPHIA  Mike Sweeney waited longer than any other active player, when measured by service time, to appear in the postseason. He finally stepped onto the stage Friday night in the seventh inning of Game 2 of the Phillies division series, and before him was the hardest throwing pitcher he has ever seen: Aroldis Chapman of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: A Long Wait for a Clean Creek
description: In 1881, New Yorks special committee on Effluvium Nuisances reported that intolerable stenches were coming from the area known as Newtown Creek. On its banks were mills and offal rendering shops, oil refineries and fertilizer factories. Over the years, industry thrived in the area, leaving tons of toxic residues.

title: Jocketty Could See Minaya Working With Alderson
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Omar Minaya was fired by the Mets on Monday, he said he would consider coming back in the right circumstances, but it would be hard to imagine what those circumstances might be. Perhaps they would include working with a highly respected baseball statesman like Sandy Alderson.

title: N.L.D.S. Photo Replay: Oct. 8
description: Photos from the National League divisional playoff series.

title: Paladino Serenades a Former Target
description: HOLLEY, N.Y.  It was not so long ago that Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor, was comparing the chairman of the states Republican Party, Edward F. Cox, to Pontius Pilate. But on Thursday night, Mr. Paladino led Mr. Coxs 64th birthday serenade.

title: France: Sarkozy and Pope Meet Over French Actions Against Roma
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy met Pope Benedict XVI in the Vatican on Friday after some senior church officials, including local bishops, criticized Frances dismantling of illegal migrant camps and its deportation of Roma migrants from Romania and Bulgaria who had overstayed their permitted time in France. Mr. Sarkozy requested the meeting with the pope, who had personally appealed for the acceptance of legitimate human diversity. The half-hour meeting focused on international issues and the ethical and social dimensions of economic problems, according to the Vatican. Mr. Sarkozy then visited a chapel where Cardinal Jean-Louis Tauran said a prayer for France, which included an appeal for the welcome of the persecuted and immigrants.

title: Late Home Run Boosts Braves to Win Over Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Back in another lifetime Rick Ankiel authored one of the more bizarre chapters in playoff history when he stood on the pitchers mound and threw pitch after pitch that seemed to hit everything but the catchers glove.

title: Holiday on Monday: Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Why the N.F.L. Is Investigating Brett Favre
description: No woman has put her name behind claims of sexual harassment by Brett Favre. We have to start there, and with a presumption of innocence. But accusations that Favre sent suggestive messages and photos to the Jets sideline personality Jenn Sterger in 2008 are well past the whispering stage and seem likely to become a major distraction. The N.F.L. is investigating.

title: The Mortgage Morass
description: After the Asian financial crisis of 1997-1998, it was often said that a key barrier to recovery was the uncertain state of property rights: so much debt had been run up during the boom, and there had been so many defaults in the bust, that it was no longer clear who owned anything. Plus, these countries lacked clear legal procedures, and in general suffered from insufficient rule of law. All this was said, of course, in a tone of superiority: we Americans had solved such problems.

title: Drill Reaches Miners in Chile, but Risks Remain
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  It was a moment of euphoria.

title: Rodriguez Reflects on Coaches and Health
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  One week after having his return temporarily postponed by a blood clot in his leg, Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio is expected to resume his duties for Saturdays game between No. 18 Michigan and No. 17 Michigan State (both 5-0, 1-0 Big Ten).

title: Video: State of the Pac-10
description: How far will U.S.C. fall? Is Oregon for real? In a special bonus edition of the Pregame Huddle, Pete Thamel breaks down the Pac-10 heading into this weekends games.

title: The People of Levittown, Pa.
description: A look at some of the people Representative Patrick Murphy spoke to in a door-to-door political campaign.

title: Door-to-Door in Levittown
description: LEVITTOWN, Pa.

title: Allies in War, but the Goals Clash
description: WASHINGTON

title: Saturday Word: Education, Jobs and Palin
description: Just over three weeks before voters go to the polls, President Obama warned that if Republicans had their way, they would cut education spending, imperiling the future of the American economy. In his weekly address, Mr. Obama acknowledged the massive national debt, but said cutting education is not the way to save, pledging  as he has for a number of weeks  to continue his investments in public schools, community colleges and student loans.

title: On Guadalcanal, Studying Evolution
description: Three short hours from the cosmopolitan city of Brisbane, Australia, and a world away, I have arrived in the Solomon Islands. Stepping from the crisp tubular world of jet travel into the familiar thickness of tropical air, I descend the gangway into a place that once echoed with the thunder and stench of the Battle of Guadalcanal, a place first visited by American Museum of Natural History biologists nearly a century ago during an expedition that really did change the world, and a place still alive in a timeless blend of biological and cultural wonder that inspired my career as a biologist.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Whiskey, Wine and Moonshine, Born in the County of Kings
description: To Grandpa Tom.

title: A Musical Trip to Middle Earth
description: The low brasses growled as a hideous legion of Orcs marched through the dim light. Noble trumpet lines soared to accompany the heroes galloping across the countryside. Ethereal choral vowels floated by as men and at least one elf died slow-motion deaths in battle.

title: Grown-Up, but Still Irresponsible
description: THEY have sex with friends, acquaintances and people theyre casually dating. Many have never been tested for H.I.V. or any other sexually transmitted disease, but they rarely use condoms. Who are they?

title: Shuttle Campaigning, Iraqi-Style
description: BAGHDAD

title: Less Demand for Dominicans as M.L.B. Scrutiny Increases
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic  New rules aimed at curtailing steroid use and age fraud among baseball prospects in the Dominican Republic have reduced the number of elite Dominican teenage players being signed to contracts by Major League Baseball teams and the size of their signing bonuses.

title: Moss Trade Shows Perils of Patriots Way
description: Pro football is still buzzing over the blockbuster trade that sent Randy Moss, one of the best receivers in history, to Minnesota from New England.

title: Pakistan Will Reopen Route to Supplies for NATO
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Pakistan announced Saturday that it was immediately reopening its main border crossing with Afghanistan and that it would allow NATO to resume shipping supplies through it after a 10-day blockade left hundreds of fuel tankers and other trucks open to attacks from militants.

title: S.B.A. Makes Small Businesses Bigger (the Easy Way)
description: The enlarging of small business has begun.

title: Leaving the Pictures Behind
description: Picture books are failing. Publishers, it was reported last week, have cut down on the number of new titles, and sales are suffering.

title: Prime Number
description: 11.7: THE AMOUNT, IN BILLIONS OF DOLLARS, pledged by 40 countries over the next three years to pay for treatments for millions of AIDS patients around the world. The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria had hoped to raise $20 billion to catch up with the growing epidemic, and needed at least $13 billion to continue putting patients on treatment at current levels. An estimated 33 million people are infected worldwide, a number that grows by a million people a year after adding new infections and subtracting deaths.

title: Acrostic: Eight Letters
description: Is an acrostic a literary work? Not in the usual sense, but it is a creation that requires many editorial choices. First is picking an interesting quote. Second is in the choice of vocabulary for the answers. Third, and most obvious, are the clues.

title: For the Nets, First Brooklyn and Then the World
description: The Nets might be an odd choice to be the N.B.A.s ambassador overseas. With 12 wins last season, they are often a forgotten team even in New Jersey, where they fail to sell out their home games and live in the shadow of the cosmopolitan Knicks.

title: Not Exactly Rock n Roll...
description: PHIL COLLINSS COLLECTION OF MOTOWN CLASSICS wasnt the only nostalgia act on the pop charts last week in Britain, The Guardian reports.
