A legend of a different sort  Winston Churchill  claimed the No. 4 spot with Reach for the Skies, an album that sets recordings of two of the wartime prime ministers most famous speeches to music by the Central Band of the Royal Air Force. Whos buying all those albums? Members of Churchills original fan club are now in their dotage, so gems like The Finest Hour and The Few must be inspiring a younger generation.

title: No Windup, Then the Pitch
description: ROY HALLADAY, A RIGHT-HANDER for the Philadelphia Phillies, pitched a no-hitter last week, beating the Cincinnati Reds 4-0 in Game 1 of their division playoff series. It was only the second no-hitter in postseason history since Don Larsens perfect game for the Yankees in the 1956 World Series.

title: Trouble in the Hive
description: Human beings and honeybees go way back, probably to some unrecorded, fateful day thousands of years ago when a forager stumbled upon some golden goo in the woods, stuck a finger in to taste, and realized that the bears were on to something good.

title: Farnsworth and Ankiel Cap Tough Journeys
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the waning hours before the July 31 trading deadline, Kyle Farnsworth and Rick Ankiel were in a hot tub in the Kansas City trainers room discussing whether they would be dealt from the floundering Royals.

title: Johnny Edgecombe, British Scandal Figure, Dies at 77
description: Around lunchtime on Dec. 14, 1962, Johnny Edgecombe, a small-time hustler and jazz promoter angry at being jilted, fired six or seven shots at the London apartment where Christine Keeler, his former girlfriend and a sometime prostitute, was staying.

title: Putting Foot to the Ball Can Often Be a Test of Will
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Becky Dodge speaks with her 23-year-old son, Matt, once a day. He often calls on his drive to or from work, sometimes to vent frustrations about his new job. Other days, she has stayed up until 1 a.m. waiting to hear from him.

title: Charting a Path Between Hope and Fear
description: THE financial markets have seemed on the verge of something big for months, with investors divided about whether the breakthrough would be a result of something good or something bad.

title: Sold on Pork Bellies (and Other Commodities)
description: IN 2005, K. Geert Rouwenhorst and Gary B. Gorton, now finance professors at Yale, published a paper about the investment benefits of an asset class that was then the province of specialists: commodities. Contrary to the prevailing conventional wisdom, the researchers suggested that pork bellies, coffee and crude oil had a place in individual portfolios alongside stocks, bonds and cash.

title: Fighting Words
description: On Thursday, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey halted construction of the largest public transit project in the nation, a multibillion-dollar commuter train tunnel under the Hudson River to Manhattan. The governor said the state could not afford its share of rising costs for the tunnel, known as Access to the Regions Core.A day later, after an outcry, Mr. Christie agreed to a two-week review of the project.

title: Rescue Tunnel Reaches Miners
description: Chilean rescuers finished drilling an escape shaft for 33 miners trapped underground after a cave-in over two months ago.

title: DNA Testing of Prospects Continues Under New Rules
description: After it was revealed last year that investigators for Major League Baseball were using DNA testing on teenage prospects and their parents to verify the players ages to combat identity fraud, genetic experts roundly criticized the practice and raised questions about its legality.

title: New Test, Introduced Without Warning, Could Give Antidoping Officials an Edge
description: Antidoping scientists who conducted the drug testing at this summers Tour de France used their best weapon: the element of surprise.

title: A Stimulus Plan, Disguised as Censorship
description: IVE been thinking a lot lately about Operation Dark Heart.

title: Is the Time Now Right for Payout Funds?
description: IT seemed an idea whose time had arrived: mutual funds specifically designed to transform the nest-egg accumulations of the first baby-boom wave into a stream of retirement income.

title: A Fearless Prediction by Yanks Cano
description: The ninth-inning double play that drained the faith from the Target Field crowd Thursday night was scored 6-4-3, as routine as one gets. But far from Minneapolis, in a home on the north side of Newark, the mere television image of Robinson Cano stepping on second base and firing across his body to first immediately unleashed the sweetest of childhood memories.

title: Hungarys Premier Warns of New Spill of Caustic Sludge
description: Hungarian officials on Saturday ordered the evacuation of a village in the shadow of the industrial reservoir that spilled caustic red sludge into the surrounding countryside last Monday, after discovering that cracks in the reservoirs northern wall had widened overnight, raising the possibility of a second spill.

title: Blazing Three Trails to Red-Hot Sectors
description: PRECIOUS-METAL and emerging-market stock funds have been generating more interest than Lady Gagas get-ups. New investor money has been pouring into both fund types. And little wonder: they provided double-digit returns through the first nine months of this year, while many other fund categories had small to middling gains.

title: Funds Tax Bills Are Looking Light
description: THE fourth quarter means eating Thanksgiving turkey, shopping for Christmas gifts and, in the world of mutual funds, perhaps getting a tax bill. Securities laws require that mutual fund managers pass on to their investors nearly all of the realized capital gains they accumulated during the year. Most funds do so in November and December.

title: Mercedes Recalls 85,000 Recent Cars for Steering Problem
description: Mercedes-Benz is recalling 85,000 of its 2010 and 2011 models because a steering problem could make the vehicles difficult to control.

title: For the Chiefs, Three Wins Are Little More Than a Good Start
description: When Todd Haley was growing up in Pittsburgh, the son of one of the men most responsible for building the Steelers dynasties of the 1970s and 1980s, he used to ride to home games in the back seat of Tom Moores car, trying to stay quiet so he would not annoy the reticent Moore, a longtime N.F.L. assistant.

title: When Troubled Assets Are the Attraction
description: TROUBLED assets and mutual funds are terms that arent often yoked together, at least not in marketing campaigns. Yet three new closed-end mutual funds have made investing in such assets a selling point.

title: For Top College Teams, a Marathon on Skates
description: With little fanfare, except possibly in outposts like Grand Forks, N.D.; Madison, Wis.; and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., the N.C.A.A. Division I mens college hockey season is concluding its first full weekend of play. Technically, games began Oct. 2, the first official day of practice, when Mercyhurst tied Michigan, 4-4.

title: Filling Buckets, Avoiding Debt
description: THE financial planner Raymond J. Lucia boasts in The Buckets of Money Retirement Solution (Wiley, $24.95) that he has helped thousands of people invest more than $2 billion by showing them how to use the method of the books title.

title: Drill Reaches Chile's Trapped Miners
description: A drill breaks through and reaches 33 miners trapped for more than two months.  NBC's Kerry Sanders reports.

title: A Big-Picture Way to Run a Portfolio
description: THERE may be something to that adage about the devil being in the details. The strong interest in world allocation funds suggests that investors think so, anyway  or maybe that they just think details are devilishly difficult for money managers to get right.

title: Rain Delays Qualifying in Japan
description: The last time qualifying was canceled on Saturday and set for Sunday morning because of bad weather was at Suzuka in 2004. Back then. a typhoon made it impossible to drive on one of the toughest tracks in the series  actually, I seem to recall that by the time of qualifying the sun had started to come out and they might just have been able to run. But the circuit was practically empty of people as we had been advised long before that it would not be possible to race, the typhoon would hit.

title: Rain Delays Qualifying in Japan
description: The last time qualifying was canceled on Saturday and set for Sunday morning because of bad weather was at Suzuka in 2004. Back then. a typhoon made it impossible to drive on one of the toughest tracks in the series  actually, I seem to recall that by the time of qualifying the sun had started to come out and they might just have been able to run. But the circuit was practically empty of people as we had been advised long before that it would not be possible to race, the typhoon would hit.

title: Kidnapped Scottish Aid Worker in Afghanistan Is Killed During Rescue Raid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A Scottish aid worker who was taken hostage two weeks ago by the Taliban in eastern Afghanistan was killed by her captors early Saturday during an unsuccessful rescue raid, according to the British Foreign Office.

title: Hey, Mirko Vucinic, Show Us Your Underalls
description: Mirko Vucinic is probably the most famous soccer player in Montenegro. He scored the first goal in the first game after the Balkan nation became independent, in March 2007 against Hungary.

title: Look Ma, No Hands
description: John Markoff rides through Mountain View, Calif., in the back seat of a car driven by Google's artificial-intelligence software.

title: Convicted Editor of Indonesian Playboy Surrenders

title: An X-Ray of Dysfunction
description: I still find it amazing that with all the climate, security, health and financial interests America has in reducing its dependence on oil, our Congress could not work out an energy bill over the past two years  especially when China, Japan and the European Union are all hurdling ahead on clean-tech. The fact that we failed to pass an energy bill  cap-and-trade, a carbon tax, efficiency standards, I dont care which  is actually a reflection of a broader U.S. power failure. It is the failure of our political system to unite, even in a crisis, to produce the policy responses America needs to thrive in the 21st century. As the Wall Street Journal columnist Gerald Seib once noted: America and its political leaders, after two decades of failing to come together to solve big problems, seem to have lost faith in their ability to do so. A political system that expects failure doesnt try very hard to produce anything else.

title: Test Your Savvy on Religion

title: Lord of the Internet Rings

title: Facebook Politicians Are Not Your Friends
description: THE Social Network, youre understandably sick of hearing, is a brilliant movie about the Harvard upstart Mark Zuckerberg and the messy birth of his fabulous start-up, Facebook, circa 2004. From the noisy debate over its harsh portrait of Zuckerberg, youd think its a documentary. Its not. Its genre is historical fiction  with a sardonic undertow. The director David Fincher and the screenwriter Aaron Sorkin are after bigger ironies than the riddle of Zuckerberg, a disconnected geek destined to spawn a virtual community of 500 million friends. You leave the movie with the sinking feeling that the democratic utopia breathlessly promised by Facebook and its Web brethren is already gone with the wind.

As the United States Supreme Court heard arguments last week over a small church that pickets the funerals of dead soldiers, comparisons quickly emerged to an earlier test of the bounds of the First Amendment: a 1977 decision that American neo-Nazis had a right to march through a Chicago suburb where many Holocaust survivors lived.

title: Lottery Numbers

That would be when their lineup would jell and their pitching would thrive  when they would morph back into the Yankees. They waited. And they were right. The Yankees are back where they started their championship run of 2009, with a three-game sweep of the Minnesota Twins and loads of confidence heading into the American League Championship Series.

Damon Albarn, the English songwriter and singer behind Gorillaz music, shared the stage with more than three dozen performers, including rappers, singers, a brass band, a string section, an Arabic music ensemble and guest stars like Lou Reed, the rappers De La Soul and Mos Def and the soul singer Bobby Womack. The video screen overhead had additional faces: the four cartoon characters, devised by Jamie Hewlett, who are nominally Gorillaz official members.

title: Savoy, London Landmark of Luxury, Reopens

Sitting on the bend of the Thames River, its riverside rooms afford views (which inspired artists like Monet and Whistler) of the Houses of Parliament to the west and St Pauls Cathedral and beyond to the east. Of the hotels 268 guest rooms and suites, two-thirds have riverside views.

title: Number of Competitive House Races Doubles from Recent Years
description: The House forecast that we released on Friday establishes an over-under line for Republican gains at a net of 47 or 48 seats. But, as I noted at the end of the article, the confidence interval on this forecast is very wide. Its margin of error is about 30 seats  meaning that a gain of as few as 17 seats, or as many as 78, is entirely possible  and there is a small chance of even larger or smaller gains.

title: Power Balance May Change In the Lame-Duck Senate

title: In Vietnam, Gates to Discuss Maritime Claims of China
description: HANOI, Vietnam  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates landed Sunday in Vietnam, where the narrative of a past war with the United States has faded as the leadership here openly seeks American support to counter an increasingly assertive China.

title: Shared Concern About China Aligns U.S. and Vietnam
description: HANOI  A visit to Vietnam this week by the secretary of defense, Robert M. Gates, is the latest step in a bilateral relationship that is at its warmest since diplomatic ties were established 15 years ago.

title: A Global Warming Work Party
description: The 350.org network organized by Bill McKibben, the writer and climate campaigner, is having a work party all day today. The aim is to get people doing the small things  planting trees, installing solar water heaters, fixing drafty buildings, calling elected officials  that can provide the foundation for a long-term shift in habits and plans related to limiting human-driven global warming.

title: French Unemployment
description: OK, thats weird. I just taped This Week, which included an interview with Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister. In her defense of austerity, she asserted that unemployment in France is down from 9.6 to 9.3. But I looked it up on Eurostat (pdf), which has French unemployment in August at 10.1, up from 9.6 a year ago.

title: The Elusive Youth Vote
description: President Obama will continue his attempts to engage younger voters this week, holding a rally with a musical guest, the Roots, in Philadelphia on Sunday and a town-hall-style meeting on MTV on Thursday. Younger voters were among the Democrats strongest supporters in 2008, and they have the highest approval ratings of the president. But in the last two midterm elections, only one in four people under age 30 voted, about half the rate for recent presidential elections. And, according to a poll by the Pew Research Center in September, young Democrats are currently even less engaged than they were in 2006.

title: Sunday Morning Uplift

description: ELLSWORTH, Maine  Heres hoping that James Levine slept well on Saturday night. He must surely have needed it.

description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  If Cliff Lee could characterize himself, he said on Sunday, he would use the words extremely competitive. Evan Longoria, the star third baseman for the Tampa Bay Rays, called him a warrior.

title: Sampler of Classical and Contemporary
description: The final Fall for Dance program was a reminder of how good this festival at City Center can be at offering a wide, unpredictable range of dance in satisfyingly textured combinations. Two of the four works on Friday were ballet, danced by large-scale companies, yet neither was a gala-style or predictable example of that genre. And the two contemporary pieces that bookended the classical offerings suggested both the differences between European and American sensibilities and the enormous range of individual choreographic styles.

title: Fall for Dance

description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli cabinet on Sunday approved a contentious draft amendment to the countrys citizenship law that calls for non-Jews seeking to become citizens to pledge loyalty to Israel as a Jewish and a democratic state.

title: Social Network Stays No. 1
description: Smart beat sentimental at the weekend box office, albeit by a slim margin. The Social Network, right, the drama about the founding of Facebook, from David Fincher and Aaron Sorkin, repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America. The Social Network (Sony Pictures Entertainment) sold an estimated $15.5 million for a new total of $46.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. Close behind with about $14.6 million was the romantic comedy Life as We Know It, starring Katherine Heigl and Josh Duhamel. Although critically panned, Life as We Know It (Warner Brothers) received an A-minus score from audiences in exit polls. Secretariat (Walt Disney Studios) pulled up in third place with about $12.6 million. The studio now must hope that older moviegoers, usually reluctant to come out on opening weekend, will heed the films upbeat reviews in the weeks ahead. Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of GaHoole (Warner Brothers) clung to life in fourth place with $7 million for a new total of $39.4 million. Wes Cravens My Soul to Take (a Universal Pictures release of a Rogue production) disappointed with fifth place and $6.9 million.

title: End May Have Arrived for Braves Wagner
description: ATLANTA  Closer Billy Wagner, the latest injured Atlanta Braves, may have pitched his last game in the major leagues. Wagner, 39, strained his left oblique muscle in Friday nights dramatic 5-4 win over the San Francisco Giants in the National League division series and has been put on the disabled list.

title: In Defense of Nave Reading
description: Remember the culture wars (or the 80s, for that matter)? The Closing of the American Mind, Cultural Literacy, Prof Scam Tenured Radicals? Whatever happened to all that? It occasionally resurfaces, of course. There was the Alan Sokal/Social Text affair in 1996, and there are occasional flaps about winners of bad writing awards and so forth, but the national attention on universities and their mission and place in our larger culture has certainly shifted.

title: In Lifes Latest Chapter, Feeling Free Again
description: LONDON  Last year, when she was 91, the editor and writer Diana Athill moved from her beloved apartment into an old persons home, as she calls it. It was the most painful decision she had ever made, and it might have been a terrible diminishment, the reduction of a long, full life into something small enough to fit into a tiny room off a communal corridor.

title: In Havana, Jam Sessions With a Master Trumpeter
description: HAVANA  Wynton Marsalis pulled a young Cuban trumpeter aside as he left the Mella Theater here on Wednesday after a Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra concert. The band was here for a residency that ended over the weekend, and Mr. Marsalis had seen 17-year-old Kal Rodrguez play a few nights earlier at an official reception for the American musicians.

title: When the Artists Voted for the Politics of Order
description: Boilerplate is safe box office, and weve gotten our share lately. So its great that the Guggenheim Museum is giving us the opposite in its major fall exhibition, Chaos and Classicism: Art in France, Italy, and Germany, 1918-1936.

title: Reveling in the Rapid Fires, Then the Retreats, of Flamenco
description: Passion and intensity are words often associated with flamenco. The forms great musicians and dancers bring a certain heat to the stage, a burning austerity often characterized as authenticity.

title: Those Perpetual Bedfellows, Religion and Politics
description: When I was in college, the conventional wisdom held that outside of religious colleges, professors of theology tended to be nonreligious people. We had no evidence, but it was a notion that appealed to undergraduate contrarianism.

title: Holiday on Monday: Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Deadliest Catch Reels in Three of Its Stars
description: Just in time for the start of the king-crab fishing season, three stars of the Discovery Channels Deadliest Catch have rescinded their threat to quit that reality show. The captains Sig Hansen and Andy and Johnathan Hillstrand, left, said at the end of September that they could not be on the show anymore, apparently because of Discoverys decision to sue the Hillstrands for allegedly refusing to finish a special show called Hillstranded. But the men were still under a separate contract for Deadliest Catch, and on Friday they said in a statement: Were happy we worked everything out with Discovery. A deals a deal. Discovery declined to say whether the lawsuit had been dropped.

title: Chinese Treasures Boost Asian-Art Auctions
description: Sothebys in Hong Kong made record sales at its biannual Asian auctions last week, bringing in $400 million in sales of Asian art, jewelry and wine, Reuters reported. The auctions can serve as an indicator of the health of Chinese and Asian art markets, and this years sales exceeded those of 2009. The high numbers were attributed to sales of Chinese imperial treasures from private collections. A vase from the Qianlong period, above, which sold for $32.5 million, including fees to Sothebys, was the highest price ever paid for a Chinese porcelain piece at auction. An imperial white jade Qing Dynasty seal broke the record for white jade at just under $16 million.

title: Monday: Shifting Crust
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  How do constructors come up with puzzle themes? You might be able to guess where this one came from. The constructor Robert Fisher makes his New York Times debut today and I have some notes from him. Further down, theres an important announcement about how we will be distributing electronic crosswords from now on.

title: Brits Off Broadway to Start Seventh Season
description: This falls Brits Off Broadway festival will include a play by Edna OBrien, below, starring the Academy Award nominee Brenda Blethyn (Secrets and Lies), a one-man show about the life and work of Peter Sellers, and the latest work by 83-year-old writer Peter Nichols (A Day in the Death of Joe Egg), the organizers at 59E59 Theaters will announce Monday. The seventh annual festival, scheduled from Nov. 3 to Jan. 2, will begin with the Welsh company Clwyd Theatr Cymrus production of Hywel Johns dark fable Pieces. Next up will be Personal Enemy, a so-called lost play by John Osborne and Anthony Creighton; it was written and performed in the 1950s, but copies disappeared soon afterward and were discovered only in 2008, according to 59E59 Theaters. Mr. Nicholss play Lingua Franca is centered on the character Steven Flowers from his earlier work Privates on Parade, while Carl Caulfields show Being Sellers will look at the famed actor of Lolita and the early Pink Panther movies. Among the other productions will be Ms. OBriens play Haunted, about an elderly man and the two women (one played by Ms. Blethyn) who meant the most to him. Information about all of the productions and performance dates is at britsoffbroadway.com.

title: Shubert Grants Grow Despite Recession
description: The Shubert Foundations grants to arts organizations have increased to $18.2 million this year, up from $17.6 million in 2009, according to a report being released by the foundation this week. Grants ranging from $5,000 to $275,000 have been given to around 450 companies nationally by the nonprofit organization. Theater companies in 42 states received most of the money, around $13 million, while dance companies received $2.5 million. The remainder was distributed to other performing arts groups, professional theater training programs and charitable agencies. In New York, Lincoln Center Theater was one of the top beneficiaries, receiving $275,000, along with American Ballet Theater ($200,000) and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater ($155,000). Smaller companies like Elevator Repair Service were awarded around $5,000.

title: Footnotes
description: Michelle Williams has been cast as Marilyn Monroe in My Week With Marilyn, a film about Monroes time working with Laurence Olivier in London in 1956 on the set of The Prince and the Showgirl, Reuters reported. Kenneth Branagh will play Olivier. ... The British rocker Billy Idol has promised quite a bit of rebel yelling in a memoir he is writing about his musical career, The Associated Press reported. Touchstone, a division of Simon & Schuster, announced that it would publish Dancing With Myself in late 2011 or early 2012. ... In addition to traveling through time, the cast of the BBC sci-fi show Doctor Who, seen on BBC America, will be traveling to the United States. The channel announced on Sunday that it would film part of the Season 6 opener, set in the United States in the late 1960s, in Utah in November. The first block of the new season will be shown next spring.

title: Wife Detained After Visiting Nobel Winner
description: BEIJING  The wife of this years Nobel Peace Prize winner, Liu Xiaobo, was allowed to meet with her husband on Sunday at the prison in northeastern China where he is serving an 11-year sentence, but she was then escorted back to Beijing and placed under house arrest, a human rights group said.

title: The World This Week
description: A discussion of convicted former trader Jerome Kerviel; Washington's accusation that China has deliberately undervalued the Yuan; Europe's terror alert and; Desmond Tutu's announced retirement.

title: Putins Party Wins in Russias Local Elections
description: NOVOSIBIRSK, Russia  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putins ruling party triumphed easily in regional elections here in Siberia and elsewhere in Russia on Sunday, demonstrating that its standing has not suffered, despite several challenging months for the government.

title: Obama Ratchets Up Tone Against G.O.P.
description: PHILADELPHIA  With his party facing losses in next months election, President Obama pressed his argument Sunday that the opposition is trying to steal the election with secret special-interest money, possibly including money from foreign companies.

title: Brooklyn Stars Put On Their Dancing Shoes
description: Kym Hampton leaned against the wall of Studio D at Mark Morris Dance Center in Fort Greene last Friday evening and let out a whoop.

title: Convincing Win Over Texans Gives Giants a Boost
description: HOUSTON  It has been exactly a year since the Giants avoided the peculiar vertigo that has marked their recent history. Up and down they have gone, the offense surging while the defense collapsed last year, the offense sputtering while the defense rebounded this season, the offense and defense even occasionally falling apart all at once  as happened against Indianapolis three weeks ago.

title: Game 3 Final: Phillies 2, Reds 0
description: Cole Hamels pitched a shutout, and Chase Utley hit a solo home run as the Phillies beat the Reds, 2-0, to sweep their National League division series.

title: Bloomberg Plans a Data Service on the Business of Government
description: Ambition and confidence have never been in short supply at Bloomberg L.P.

title: A Vanishing Journalistic Divide
description: If you were going to pick an epicenter for mainstream media, The Washington Posts Howard Kurtz would not be a bad place to land. With his running scorecard on Beltway journalists, his interviews of other scorekeepers on his Reliable Sources show on CNN, and his ceaseless fascination with network news, Mr. Kurtz embodied the folkways of the traditional press.

title: Paladino Laces Speech With Antigay Remarks
description: The Republican candidate for governor, Carl P. Paladino, told a gathering in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Sunday that children should not be brainwashed into thinking that homosexuality was acceptable, and criticized his opponent, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, for marching in a gay pride parade earlier this year.

title: After Building an Audience, Twitter Turns to Ads
description: Twitter at last looks serious about making money.

title: Hoping to Stir a Revival of Basketball in Russia
description: MOSCOW  The Nets dropped into Moscow on Sunday for a one-day visit meant to raise their profile in the home country of their new owner, the Russian billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov.

title: After Election, Coalition Seems Likely in Kyrgyz Parliament
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Supporters of the government that took power after an uprising in April appeared to be on the way to winning seats in a new Parliament, but were likely to be compelled to form a coalition with at least some figures from the previous government, according to preliminary results from an election in Kyrgyzstan on Sunday.

title: New Web Code Draws Concern Over Privacy Risks
description: Worries over Internet privacy have spurred lawsuits, conspiracy theories and consumer anxiety as marketers and others invent new ways to track computer users on the Internet. But the alarmists have not seen anything yet.

title: Code of Silence After a Brawl in the Suburbs
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

title: Documentary Film Company Takes On Fiorina
description: Brave New Films, the documentary film company behind a series of damaging anti-McCain viral videos in the 2008 presidential campaign, has put its sights on Carly Fiorina, the Republican candidate for Senate in California.

title: U.S. Presses Iraqi Leaders to Broaden Coalition
description: WASHINGTON  Faced with a shifting political landscape in Iraq after months of impasse, the Obama administration has intensified pressure on the countrys political leaders to form a broad coalition government that, while unwieldy, would marginalize a fiercely anti-American party now poised to wield more influence than ever.

title: CBS Is a Network on a Roll
description: Three weeks into a new television season, the usual carnage is becoming apparent, with new shows collapsing and crises appearing all over network prime-time schedules.

title: Giants Take Advantage of a Braves Miscues
description: ATLANTA  Braves infielder Brooks Conrad, who has spent most of his professional career in the minor leagues, won a game for Atlanta in May by hitting a grand slam in the bottom of the ninth inning.

title: A Childrens Channel Retools
description: WITH imports of European cartoons, a smattering of Hasbro ads and a rerun of the movie Garfield, Hasbro and Discovery Communications unveiled a new television brand for children on Sunday, called The Hub.

title: Rolling Out Speedier Bus System, to Glitches and Grumbles
description: It has been hailed as the next generation of New York City public transport: a European-style rapid-transit bus system that operates in exclusive traffic lanes and requires passengers to buy tickets from sidewalk kiosks so trips will not be delayed by a single rider struggling for exact change.

title: Transcripts on 73 War, Now Public, Grip Israel
description: JERUSALEM  For many Israelis, the 1973 Arab-Israeli war was their single most terrifying moment, when a woefully unprepared nation, deluded into believing that its neighbors regarded it as impregnable, suffered a devastating attack and struggled back to victory at enormous cost with last-minute American help.

title: Nevadas Runaway Offense
description: The University of Nevada entered the top 25 for the first time in more than a half-century this season, features a fringe Heisman Trophy candidate in the dynamic quarterback Colin Kaepernick, and has a late-season game with Boise State that could affect the national title race.

title: On New York School Tests, Warning Signs Ignored
description: When New York State made its standardized English and math tests tougher to pass this year, causing proficiency rates to plummet, it said it was relying on a new analysis showing that the tests had become too easy and that score inflation was rampant.

title: Sluggish Economy Curtails Prospects for Building Nuclear Reactors
description: WASHINGTON  Just a few years ago, the economic prognosis for new nuclear reactors looked bright. The prospect of growing electricity demand, probable caps on carbon-dioxide emissions and government loan guarantees prompted companies to tell the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that they wanted to build 28 new reactors.

title: Floating at the Edge of a Dream
description: DETROIT  The stellar record of the amateur boxer Erick De Leon, who is undefeated in this country for three years in his weight class, should make fighting for the United States in the 2012 Olympics a natural next step. Instead, De Leons biggest fight is not in the ring, but with the United States immigration system.

title: Rift Endangers Power-Sharing Deal in Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG  After months of putting an optimistic face on his power-sharing deal with Zimbabwes autocratic president, Robert Mugabe, Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai erupted last week with frustration at Mr. Mugabe and the countrys troubled progress toward democracy.

title: Film Society of Lincoln Center Names a New Theater
description: The largest of the Film Society of Lincoln Centers two new theaters will be named the Francesca Beale Theater in honor of a recent gift, the society said. The society planned to make the announcement on Sunday night, after a screening of Clint Eastwoods Hereafter on the closing night of the New York Film Festival. The naming gift  the amount was not disclosed  helps the society complete the private phase of a $41 million capital campaign for its new Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center, scheduled to open next spring. The society, which has raised $37 million so far, will now start a public campaign to raise an additional $4 million. The new film center will add two theaters to the existing Walter Reade Theater, along with a new amphitheater and a cafe.

title: Fears of More Red Sludge in Hungary
description: DEVECSER, Hungary  In this small agricultural town, nestled along the front line of the environmental catastrophe shaking this proud central European nation, Otto Kovacs, like many residents, said he was determined not to join the growing ranks of the sludge refugees.

title: Iranian Officials Warn of Unrest Tied to Subsidy Cuts
description: TEHRAN  After suppressing the political protests that followed last years disputed presidential election, Irans security forces are now on the alert for a new kind of domestic threat  strikes and civil unrest provoked by planned cuts in fuel subsidies.

title: Cincinnati Is a Party as the Reds Get Ready
description: CINCINNATI  A sunny, warm Sunday turned into a daylong festival in the Queen City, with all three major sports stadiums along the banks of the Ohio River in use and drawing big crowds.

title: Finding Your Way Through the Mall or the Airport, With a Cellphone Map
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Mobile phone maps have guided people through streets and alleys around the globe. But when those people step into a sprawling building, they can get lost.

title: Easy for Yanks, but Tricky Choices on Pitching
description: The Yankees have won four straight postseason series without using a fourth starter, and as they prepare for the American League Championship Series it is natural to ask: will they try to make it five? That is one of the leading questions Manager Joe Girardi and his staff will be debating in the coming days as they await the winner of the Rangers-Rays division series.

title: Carnival Air Fills Chilean Camp as Miners Rescue Nears
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  Clowns dance and pass out caramels. The wives and girlfriends of the 33 trapped miners are picking out sexy lingerie and getting their hair and nails done to receive their men. And relatives of the miners trapped nearly half a mile underground for more than two months have learned a new phrase  motor home  from their hundreds of new journalist friends.

title: Taming the City of God
description: Years of hatred and mistrust are thawing in some of Rios most violent slums.

title: In New York Governor Race, Two Italian Identities
description: Strategy sessions have been held at a restaurant called Sinatras. Sopranos-style gold chains have shown up in campaign advertisements. Ethnic-tinged terms, like goumada, and wisecracks about Sicilian grudges have been bandied about. And television news crews from Italy have descended on the candidates.

title: Guns in Bars: A Debate Over Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Tomlinson Countering Doubts With Yard After Yard
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On the eve of training camp, the first night of the second act of his Hall of Fame career, LaDainian Tomlinson was summoned by a knock to the door. There stood his new Jets coach, Rex Ryan, who presented a thick stack of paper as a housewarming gift.

title: Lottery Numbers
Currency Rift With China Exposes Shifting Clout
description: WASHINGTON  At a private dinner on Friday at the Canadian Embassy, finance officials from seven world economic powers focused on the most vexing international economic problem facing the Obama administration.

title: In Pennsylvania, Anger Fuels a Race for Senate
description: BROOMALL, Pa.  The voters of Pennsylvania are angry at Washington. And Pat Toomey, the Republican nominee for United States Senate, is glad to stoke the fury.

title: The Shore Is Alive With the Sound of Turbines
description: To the Editor:

title: Felton Finding His Fit With Stoudemire
description: Of all the hellos the Knicks have said this preseason in familiarizing themselves with one another, one of the most important new relationships on the team originated nearly a decade ago. As high school players, forward Amare Stoudemire and point guard Raymond Felton occasionally crossed A.A.U. and summer-camp paths, sometimes playing together.

title: Drugs in Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside City of God
description: Officials in Rio de Janeiro have deployed new peace police units to the slum as part of an ambitious plan to wrest control of the citys slums, or favelas, from drug gangs.

title: In Rough Slum, Brazils Police Try Soft Touch
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Leonardo Bento longed for vengeance after a policeman killed his brother five years ago. So when he heard that the new peace police force in the City of God slum was offering free karate classes, Mr. Bento signed up, hoping he would at least get to beat up the karate instructor.

title: Packers Are Trending Downward
description: To say that the Packers are hurting is an understatement. Green Bay, which entered Sundays game against the Redskins with injury concerns at running back, safety and linebacker, can now add tight end and  most troubling  quarterback to that list.

title: From Wedding Halls to Horse Tracks, a Special Date
description: October 10, 2010  10/10/10  came and went largely unmarked in New York, unless you were getting married or placing a bet.

title: An Expanded Reading List for the Tea Party
description: To the Editor:

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Provocative Image of Christ Sets Off a Debate Punctuated With a Crowbar
description: LOVELAND, Colo.  For once, the quaint museum on Lincoln Avenue was all quiet. A sign inside was the only indication of the recent trouble.

title: Despite Army Efforts, Soldier Suicides Continue
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  At 3:30 a.m. on a Saturday in August, Specialist Armando G. Aguilar Jr. found himself at the end of his short life. He was standing, drunk and weepy, in the parking lot of a Valero station outside Waco, Tex. He had jumped out of his moving pickup. There was a police officer talking to him in frantic tones. Specialist Aguilar held a pistol pointed at his head.

title: In Higher Education, a Focus on Technology
description: The education gap facing the nations work force is evident in the numbers. Most new jobs will require more than a high school education, yet fewer than half of Americans under 30 have a postsecondary degree of any kind. Recent state budget cuts, education experts agree, promise to make closing that gap even more difficult.

title: From Tea Party Advocates, Anger at the Federal Reserve
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, having weathered criticism of its regulatory failings and interest rate decisions in the years before the financial crisis, is facing a new source of anger: the Tea Party movement.

title: The Sound of Music, the Blu-ray Treatment
description: LOS ANGELES  When in doubt, roll out the von Trapps.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: Bond markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Columbus Day. The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Illinois Senate Debate Focuses on Integrity of Candidates
description: Questions about personal integrity dominated a televised debate on Sunday between the two candidates running for the Illinois Senate seat that was vacated by President Obama.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,309 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

title: Baseball Replay, Oct. 10
description: A look at three division series games Sunday, between the Tampa Bay Rays and the Texas Rangers; the San Francisco Giants and the Atlanta Braves; and the Cincinnati Reds and the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Giants Replay: Oct. 10
description: Plenty of passing and a powerful defense carried the Giants to a 34-10 victory over the Texans.

title: Democrats Vie for Votes, and Their Partys Largess
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Embattled Democratic lawmakers must fight this week to impress two audiences: voters, and party leaders back in Washington now deciding where to invest for the campaign homestretch.

title: William C. Patrick III, Expert on Germ Warfare, Dies at 84
description: William C. Patrick III made enough germs to kill everyone on earth many times over. Then, after putting aside those living weapons, he worked for nearly four decades to build defenses against them, to better protect the United States from biological attack.

title: Degrees of Debt
description: Denver

title: Hey, Small Spender
description: Heres the narrative you hear everywhere: President Obama has presided over a huge expansion of government, but unemployment has remained high. And this proves that government spending cant create jobs.

title: Grading School Choice
description: In this falls must-see documentary, Waiting for Superman,  Davis Guggenheim offers a critique of Americas public school bureaucracy thats manipulative, simplistic and more than a little bit utopian.

title: Unpublished Stieg Larsson Book Is Confirmed
description: Remember that mysterious, unpublished, unconfirmed manuscript of the fourth book in Stieg Larssons best-selling Millennium series? Its actually the fifth book.

title: Two Words: Wasteful and Ineffective
description: New York State will spend an extraordinary $170 million this year on 21 juvenile facilities. The system has more than 2,000 employees to oversee fewer than 700 children.

title: Balkans, Past and Future
description: Bosnia, Serbia and Kosovo have come a long way since the 1990s. Serbia is no longer a rogue aggressor. Bosnia is no longer a killing field. And Kosovo, once a terrorized province of Serbia, is now an independent state. Washington and, in particular, former President Bill Clinton deserve a large share of the credit.

title: Hamels Dashes Hopes as Phillies Sweep Reds
description: CINCINNATI  The banner was draped over the railing of the upper deck in left field, its red block letters crystallizing the hopes of towel-waving Cincinnati Reds fans who jammed Great American Ball Park in record numbers for Game 3 of the National League division series. It read, We Still Believe.

title: A Station Defects From PBS
description: The financial strains on public television came into stark view on Friday when KCET-TV, Los Angeless main public station, said it would leave PBS on Jan. 1 and become the nations largest independent station.

title: Whose Advantage?
description: Some of the private health plans that participate in Medicare will be dropping out next year, but dont blame health care reform. Most are unwilling to meet the sensible requirements of a 2008 law that they do more to earn the federal subsidies that have fueled their rapid growth.

title: Whats Your Timeline?
description: My grandmother was born 100 years ago in the city of Pachuca, an hours drive north of Mexico City. She died more than 10 years ago. But last week, as Mexico became one of the few countries ever to sell century bonds, I couldnt help picturing her as a baby, swathed in cloth diapers, a turbulent century set to roll out before her.

title: Freed Journalist Laura Ling Will Host E! Investigates
description: Laura Ling, who was detained in North Korea with a colleague from Current TV last year, is restarting her television career at a channel much closer to home  E!, the entertainment channel.

title: TPGs Headache in Russia
description: The public travails in Russia of David Bondermans buyout fund, TPG, are enough to scare other private equity firms away from the country. TPG is in a nasty, even violent, battle for control of the St. Petersburg hypermarket chain Lenta. For a $110 million investment, it might seem a case study in why Russia is too much trouble. But even so, the risks might be worth it.

title: Bronx Attackers Ultimatum: Be Hit With a Bat, or a Pipe
description: After he had been punched, kicked and stripped of his clothes and jewelry, the 17-year-old man was given a choice: the bat or the pipe.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Solomon Burke, Influential Soul Singer, Dies at 70
description: Solomon Burke, a singer whose smooth, powerful articulation and mingling of sacred and profane themes helped define soul music in the early 1960s, died on Sunday at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam. He was 70 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Should Brooks Conrad Have Been in the Game in the Ninth Inning?
description: Braves Manager Bobby Cox is retiring after this season, and nothing that happens in this National League division series between Atlanta and San Francisco is going to change Coxs standing as one of the great managers in baseball history.

title: Short Attention Spans for Web Videos
description: After watching an online video for a full minute, 44.1 percent of viewers will have clicked away, according to Visible Measures. But an outsize slice of that loss occurs in the first 10 seconds, during which 19.4 percent of a videos audience defects.

title: News Quiz | October 11, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: S.B.A. Makes Small Businesses Bigger
description: From Robb Mandelbaum at Youre the Boss:

title: Kramnik Wins Again, Carlsen Loses Again in Bilbao Final
Chinese Pharma Set to Raise $741 Million
description: Sihuan Pharmaceutical Holdings Group, Chinas largest cardio-cerebral vascular drugmaker, seeks to raise up to $741 million through its Hong Kong initial public offering, according to a term sheet seen by Reuters on Monday.

title: White House Aide Doubts Need to Halt Foreclosures
description: A top White House adviser questioned the need on Sunday for a blanket halt to home foreclosures, even as pressure grows on the Obama administration to do something about growing evidence that banks have used inaccurate documents to evict homeowners, The Associated Press reported.

title: Ryan Seacrest Backs New Cable Effort
description: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

title: Daily Lexeme: Subitize
description: Todays word, in association with the inestimable Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: AIAs $21 Billion I.P.O. Said to Meet Huge Demand
description: American International Group has received strong demand for the mega I.P.O. of its Asian life insurance business, AIA Group, with the offer covered more than five times in the first week, sources with direct knowledge of the matter told Reuters.

title: Morgenson: Its Not Nice to Mess With J.R.
description: From Gretchen Morgensons latest column:

title: Blow the Whistle. Then Worry and Wait
description: Sitting in a Minneapolis mansion and listening to a charismatic investment manager describe a currency trading system that kept earning handsome returns year after year, Arthur F. Schlobohm IV was certain he had stumbled onto a Ponzi scheme, Edward Wyatt writes in The New York Times.

title: John Hos Janchor Returns 21 Percent
description: Janchor Partners Pan Asian Fund, run by the former Asia leader of the Childrens Investment Fund Management UK, returned 21 percent after fees in the first nine months of the year, according to an e-mail sent to investors and seen by Bloomberg News.

title: Rivals Scramble to Derail BHPs Potash Plans
description: BHP Billitons $39 billion bid for the Potash Corporation may be threatened by rival bids, Reuters says, with Sinochem of China and a Canadian pension fund working on plans.

title: After Building an Audience, Twitter Turns to Ads
description: Twitter at last looks serious about making money.

title: White House Finds Itself Defending Banks
description: The swelling outcry over fast-and-loose foreclosures has thrust the Obama administration back into the uncomfortable position of sheltering the banking industry from the demands of an angry public, The New York Timess Binyamin Applebaum writes.

title: Microsoft Deal in Europe Barely Affects Browser Market
description: When Europe settled an antitrust case over Web browsers with Microsoft in December 2009, it hoped to dislodge the worlds biggest software maker from its dominant position in that market by requiring it to offer rivals products.

title: A Big-Picture Way to Run a Portfolio
description: There may be something to that adage about the devil being in the details. The strong interest in world allocation funds suggests that investors think so, anyway  or maybe that they just think details are devilishly difficult for money managers to get right.

title: Cnooc in $2.2 Billion Deal With Chesapeake Energy
description: Cnooc, one of the largest Chinese state-run oil companies, has agreed to buy a third of Chesapeake Energys oil and gas assets in a south Texas shale deposit for $1.1 billion, in a deal that will ultimately be worth double that amount. It is the largest Chinese purchase of United States energy assets ever and the latest in a string of similar deals by Beijing around the world.

title: Schwarzenegger Goes to Russia
description: Russias ambition to become a hi-tech economy will be under scrutiny this week when Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger of California and a host of prospective investors from Silicon Valley look for opportunities at the countrys flagship technology hub, Reuters reported.

title: TPGs Headache in Russia
description: From Reuters Breakingviews:

title: Social Gaming Sector Braces for Deal Wave
description: Gentlemen, start your engines: the fledgling social gaming industry is revving up for a new wave of acquisitions and consolidation this coming year.

title: Bankers Say Regulatory Crackdown Must Move Slowly
description: A global crackdown on bank oversight could undermine a fragile economic recovery if governments move too fast and fail to cooperate, international bankers warned at a conference on Sunday.

title: Do 49ers Need a New Coach, and Quarterback?

The blogs end is a result of limited resources in a medium where any number of worthy projects are possible, and where new priorities continually emerge. Thanks to all our readers and commenters, and regrets.

title: This Week in Small Business: Bankruptcies, Waivers and iPads
description: MAYBE I SHOULD HIRE SOMEONE. Intuits small-business employment index for September shows slowing job growth, reporting that for small businesses with fewer than 20 employees, only 27,000 new jobs were created. Compensation also declined. Its a disappointing number, but its not unexpected, Joel Prakken, chairman of Macroeconomic Advisors, told CNBC. G.D.P. growth has slowed to below the growth rate of productivity, and its inevitable that youd have this deceleration in jobs. The overall unemployment rate stayed close to 10 percent. Even the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 made little impact according to research by Mitchell Petersen, a professor of finance at the Kellogg School of Management. Anyone out there hiring?

Habbaniya was built in the era of Saddam Hussein, whose 1982 official tourist guidebook boasted that it was at the time the largest tourist village of the kind in the Middle East.

title: Rays or Rangers? Should the Yankees Care?
description: To a man, the Yankees said they had no rooting preference in the Tampa Bay-Texas series, and since there was no sodium pentathol readily available in the postgame celebration Saturday night, well have to take their word for it. Do I believe them? I do, even if facing Cliff Lee in the playoffs sounds as appealing as taking a bath with piranhas.

title: Notes From the Underground | All Tomorrows Parties
description: When I checked in at the press desk for All Tomorrows Parties, I was given the following directive: The rule at ATP is, there are no rules  just dont caught. So when Iggy Pop took to the stage on opening night, so did I. I scaled a wall of speakers 20 feet high and dangled by one arm as I snapped away. And mysteriously, I did not get thrown out.All Tomorrows Parties is the ultimate insiders festival. Created in England in 1999, it exists without corporate sponsorship or mainstream headliners, playing host to a slew of avant-garde noise music, indie rock and underground hip-hop acts. An annual event in the States since 2008, it is the rebel yell of alternative concert programming, democratically housing the bands in the same hotel as the fans and turning its nose up at industry money.

title: Planned Adam Lambert Concert in Malaysia Draws Protest
description: A fundamentalist Muslim party in Malaysia is demanding the cancellation of a concert by the pop-rock star Adam Lambert planned for Thursday, saying the singer and his show will promote gay culture, Reuters reported. Mr. Lambert, an American Idol runner-up who is openly gay, and who is scheduled to perform at the Putra Indoor Stadium in Bukit Jalil, near Kuala Lumpur, has met with opposition from the Pan Malaysian Islamic Party, which is that nations second-largest political party. Nasrudin Hasan, a youth leader for the party, was quoted by Reuters as saying that Mr. Lamberts shows are outrageous, with lewd dancing and a gay performance that includes kissing male dancers, which is not good for people in our country. The party, which has previously protested shows by artists like Beyonc, Rihanna and Mariah Carey, also said it would send many of its members and supporters to proselytize at the concert if it went forward. A representative for Malaysias arts, culture and heritage department said Mr. Lambert had agreed to abide by performance guidelines, which include not removing his clothing and maintaining a distance of about 25 feet between his stage and the audience.

description: For the second straight year, Sebastian Vettel made winning the Japanese Grand Prix look easy. The Red Bull Racing driver started on pole  ahead of his teammate, Mark Webber  and stayed in front wire to wire for his third win of the season. More importantly, Vettel jumped from fourth to second in the championship, with only three races remaining.

Yes, the reporting involved determining some of the worst smells found in New York homes (cats, smoke, Subway sandwiches) and how much they influence sales and leases. And were not just talking about a few clichd household odors: At one West Side condo tower, the lobby is overwhelmed by the, um, aroma pouring in from a neighboring truffle store.

title: House of the Rising Son: Site of Bob Dylans Bar Mitzvah for Sale
description: How many Hebrew school classes must one boy take before you can call him a man? The answer, my friends, may be contained within an unusual piece of Bob Dylan memorabilia that has been posted for sale on Craigslist: the building that was once the synagogue where the singer-songwriter had his bar mitzvah. The Duluth News Tribune reported that the structure at 2320 West Second Street in Hibbing, Minn., which was formerly the Agudath Achim Synagogue where the young Robert Zimmerman was first called to read the Torah in 1954, was put on sale a few months ago by its owners. (They have since turned to Dylan fan sites and the news media in hopes of finding a buyer.)

title: Thats So 19th Century: Demi Moore Rethinks Her Art Collection
description: The manner in which the 19th-century artist William Bouguereau depicted women  with a combination of gentleness, serenity and strength  as Demi Moore put it, is what drew the actress to his work. So in 1995, when Frre et Soeur, an 1887 canvas of a young girl carrying her baby brother, came up for sale at a Christies auction in New York, she bought it for $178,500. It wasnt all she purchased at that sale. Ms. Moore also snapped up a painting by the Belgian artist Alfred Stevens, from 1883, called Mre et Ses Enfants, for $200,500.

title: Rushdie Writing Memoir About Years in Hiding
description: Salman Rushdie is writing a memoir that will recount his years in hiding after the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered Muslims to kill him because of what he called blasphemy in Mr. Rushdies novel The Satanic Verses, according to Reuters. Im beginning to write this memoir, Mr. Rushdie told the news agency. So far I feel that Im right: Im not getting churned up and upset, Im just writing it and Im feeling quite pleased to be writing it. Mr. Rushdie, 63, has frequently spoken of the death sentence, issued in 1989 as a fatwa, an Islamic religious ruling, but has devoted most of his time since then to writing fiction: in recent years, The Enchantress of Florence and Shalimar the Clown. His childrens book Luka and the Fire of Life will be published next month. The memoir could be completed by the end of 2011.

title: A Fine Italian Hand
description: Wait, Maurizio Cattelan says in his low, conspiratorial, Italian-accented voice. I have something for you. Its a warm July evening, and I am walking along the Hudson with the art worlds most famous prankster, so I feel a double twinge of apprehension and curiosity when he reaches into the cotton bag at his side. Out comes a strange object: a life-size orange hand from which all the fingers except the erect middle one have been broken off. Obscene, goofy and eye-catching, the one-fingered hand looks like a cross between a gag-store novelty and a sex toy. To anyone else, it might well be a joke. To Cattelan, its something entirely serious: a prototype for his next sculpture, which is to say, his next test of the publics equanimity. Cattelan passes the hand to me, and we continue strolling, talking about his plans. This being New York, pedestrians and joggers studiously avoid glancing at us, two men contemplating a rude, inexplicable object.

title: Dexter Watch: Suspicions Are Growing
description: Lets just say you are a vigilante serial killer and single parent who keeps odd hours and also has a day job, what are you looking for in a nanny? Sunday nights episode of Dexter had as one of its many subplots Dexters search for a proper caregiver to help him with baby Harrison. With Debs assistance he found one pretty quickly  more quickly than todays average helicopter mom, but lets not quibble with details. (No, lets keep quibbling: what are the chances of finding a nanny that quickly and one who seems to be Irish, in the middle of Miami?)

title: C-4 Explosives Found in East Village Cemetery
description: 10:09 p.m. | Read the latest updates on this story.

title: Yankees Decide on a Four-Man Rotation
description: Although the Yankees will not meet until Tuesday to discuss their roster for the American League Championship Series, General Manager Brian Cashman said on Monday that they would go with a four-man rotation. That means that A. J. Burnett, whose poor performance in the regular season cost him a potential start in the division series against Minnesota, will start Game 4.

title: Raising a Glass to Wall Streets Top Women
description: For at least one night this week, more than a few Wall Street executives put on a smile  and a ballgown.

title: Fed Nominee Blocked By G.O.P. Wins Nobel Prize
description: For months, Republican senators have blocked the nomination of the economist Peter Diamond to the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. Senator Richard Shelby, Republican of Alabama, has said Mr. Diamond does not have sufficiently broad experience.

title: Get a Bargain  and Duck Taxes
description: Looking for a bargain in luxury real estate? Or for a way to avoid paying American taxes? Youll be happy to know that someone stuck with a huge waterfront mansion in Grand Cayman plans to auction it on Nov. 3, the day after the election. Previously listed at $19.8 million, the promise is that it will be sold to the high bidder, without reserve.

title: Get a Bargain  and Duck Taxes
description: Looking for a bargain in luxury real estate? Or for a way to avoid paying American taxes? Youll be happy to know that someone stuck with a huge waterfront mansion in Grand Cayman plans to auction it on Nov. 3, the day after the election. Previously listed at $19.8 million, the promise is that it will be sold to the high bidder, without reserve.

title: Fifth Avenue, 12:09 P.M.
Bring On the Stink Bugs
description: Have stink bugs met their noxious match?

title: Fifth Avenue, 12:29 P.M.
Hotels Use Downturn to Spruce Up
description: The hotel industry in the United States, still in the doldrums from the slowdown in leisure and business travel, is generally not taking on many major redesigns or other big projects. But there are exceptions.

title: TimesCast: West Virginias Influence
description: Nate Silver appeared in the first installment of The Caucus, a TimesCast segment offering daily insight into whats shaping the midterm elections. Nate spoke with The Timess Megan Liberman on the latest in the West Virginia Senate race, and how the results of this surprisingly competitive contest could affect the make-up of the Senate.

title: Russia Asks Schwarzenegger to Help in a Tough Task
description: SKOLKOVO, Russia  Perhaps frustrated by what at times can seem like his own one-man effort to bring his unwieldy country into the 21st century, President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Monday turned to a seasoned fighter of government bureaucracy and other dark forces.

title: Disney Revs Up Tron Promotional Campaign
description: Borrowing a marketing ploy from 20th Century Fox and Avatar, the Walt Disney Company said it would preview more than 20 minutes of its forthcoming Tron: Legacy free at Imax theaters around the world. Fox and Imax created this model by showing about 15 minutes of Avatar a few months before that movies release. The Tron promotional screenings will take place Oct. 28 as stand-alone events. Tickets will be distributed on a first-come basis starting Tuesday; information on how to get one can be found at facebook.com/tron. Disney is pushing the science-fiction themed Tron: Legacy, which opens Dec. 17, with everything in its marketing arsenal, including a huge array of related merchandise (rolling out in stores this month) and a continuing nighttime street party at one of its California theme parks.

title: Salt Infusion Could Be a Remedy for Damaged Cells
description: It turns out a dash of salt can really do a body, especially a tail, some good.

title: The Dwindling Options for Airgas
description: The legal victory won by Air Products and Chemicals on Friday evening in its battle with Airgas was accompanied by some last-minute drama in Delaware Chancery Court. Earlier that Friday, Chancellor William B. Chandler III had made some remarks that arguably could have been interpreted as supporting Airgass claims. Some arbitragers certainly interpreted it as such. Airgass stock subsequently fell about a dollar a share.

title: When a Dogs Dish Seems Half Empty
description: Dogs can be worried and pessimistic just like people, researchers report in a new study in Current Biology. And they arent talking about basset hounds: those dogs just look as if they expect the worst.

title: Fashion Week Finale | Accessories Report
description: Its time to bid your Fashion Week farewells and au revoirs as the shows come to a close. Designers may enjoy a moment of satisfied rest, but editors are busier than ever. This seasons collections ditch the pointy-toe kitten heels and full housewife skirts. (And werent we all a bit exhausted of the 50s!) Instead, they offer everything from the polished refinement of a sleek Row suit and Audrey-like crimson ballet flats to Prada and Balenciagas 90s homage to grunge, with Dr. Martens-esque footwear.

title: Joints Key to Bats Complicated Flight
description: The scientific order for bats, Chiroptera, appropriately translates to hand wing. And like human hands, bat wings are fleshy and have myriad joints. In contrast, bird wings have only a few joints, and those of winged insects contain a single joint.

title: Fed Official Concedes Risk of Low Rates, but Signals No Shift
description: WASHINGTON  Federal Reserve officials have no choice but to try to contain future bubbles and credit binges and limit their damage to the economy, the central banks vice chairwoman said on Monday, detailing the Feds newly broadened mandate to promote financial stability.

title: Cough Control
description: Q. I have wondered why musical and stage artists never sneeze or cough while performing. Is there a biological explanation?

title: In China, Beware of Alpha Cats in the Cargo Area
description: IVE been traveling for business longer than I care to remember.

title: Taking Early Retirement May Retire Memory, Too
description: The two economists call their paper Mental Retirement, and their argument has intrigued behavioral researchers. Data from the United States, England and 11 other European countries suggest that the earlier people retire, the more quickly their memories decline.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: In which I answer questions about Canton, Kansas and dining alone. Keep the queries coming!

title: Fisk University in New Bid to Gain Approval to Sell Art
description: In an effort to earn court approval to sell a $30 million share in its Stieglitz Art Collection to an Arkansas museum, Fisk University has agreed to terms requested by the chancery court in Nashville, The Tennessean newspaper reported. The university, which has longstanding financial difficulties, is seeking to share ownership of the collection with the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark.

title: German Politician Makes Anti-Immigrant Remarks
description: BERLIN  Remarks by a leading German politician that Turkish and Arab migrants were no longer needed in Germany were strongly criticized on Monday by the Turkish community here and by Chancellor Angela Merkels top official responsible for integration policy.

title: Sink Unveils Two-Minute Ad Hitting Scott
description: 4:50 p.m. | Updated MIAMI  Florida Democrats have started running a new ad against Rick Scott, the Republican candidate for governor, which gives the Americas Most Wanted treatment to his history of running health care companies accused of fraud.

title: Physician Revives a Dying Art: The Physical
description: STANFORD, Calif.  For a 55-year-old man with a bad back and a bum knee from too much tennis, Dr. Abraham Verghese was amazingly limber as he showed a roomful of doctors-in-training a twisting, dancelike walk he had spied in the hospital corridor the day before.

title: Understanding Ba Ba Ba as a Key to Development
description: As a pediatrician, I always ask about babble. Is the baby making sounds? I ask the parent of a 4-month-old, a 6-month-old, a 9-month-old. The answer is rarely no. But if it is, its important to try to find out whats going on.

title: Now Viewing | Buildings on Film
description: Architecture film buffs, take note: the Architecture and Design Film Festival opens Thursday evening at Tribeca Cinemas and runs through Oct. 17. The first of its kind in the United States, the festival (for which T is a media partner) was founded by Kyle Bergman, who produced the play The Glass House, about the human dramas behind Mies van der Rohes Farnsworth House and Philip Johnsons Glass House. After the opening night  at which Makoto Yabukis short film White Box will be shown with Olga Sptovs Eye Over Prague, a documentary on Jan Kaplickys ill-fated design for the National Library in Prague  the festival will present a variety of feature-length, short and documentary films. Among them are Citizen Architect: Samuel Mockbee and the Spirit of the Rural Studio; Contemporary Days, Murray Grigors film on the postwar British design pioneers Robin and Lucienne Day; Studio Gang Architects: Aqua Tower, about the cutting-edge Chicago apartment tower designed by Jeanne Gang; and Saving Lieb House, Jim Venturis account of his and the architect Frederic Schwartzs successful efforts to rescue a 1969 house designed by Venturis parents, Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown. Panel discussions will feature speakers like Paul Goldberger, the architecture critic for The New Yorker; James Sanders, the architect, filmmaker and author of Celluloid Skyline; and Cameron Sinclair, the co-founder of Architecture for Humanity.

title: What China Seeks in Chesapeake Shale Deal
description: Chinas $2.2 billion investment in the Texas oil patch may be small, but the deal with Chesapeake Energy involves a potential transfer of technology and intellectual knowledge to Beijing that some people in Washington may find uncomfortable, and that unease could trip up the deal.

title: The Calm Before the Brain Injury Was Discovered
description: During the horrendous heat wave in July, when all of us in New York were not quite ourselves, I started feeling funny. I was sleeping too much; my right foot was dragging; my typing was skewed; I lost interest in reading the paper, about which I am usually obsessive.

title: Child Abuse Investigations Didnt Reduce Risk, a Study Finds
description: Child Protective Services investigated more than three million cases of suspected child abuse in 2007, but a new study suggests that the investigations did little or nothing to improve the lives of those children.

title: Studying the Ice Cream Headache
description: Although people often talk about ice cream headaches or brain freeze after gulping a cold drink, the phenomenon doesnt afflict everyone. According to todays Really? column, only about one in three people experience it.

title: Netanyahus Moves Spark Debate on Intentions
description: JERUSALEM  An offer on Monday by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to freeze West Bank Jewish settlements in exchange for Palestinian recognition of Israel as a Jewish state  instantly rejected by the Palestinians  was the latest complex maneuver engendering debate about his intentions.

title: All of Our Warped Financial Expectations
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: In France, a Paradox in Equality for Women
description: Birth control and abortion are legal and subsidized in France, and women have overtaken men in education and are catching up in the labor market. But few make it to the top of business or politics.

title: Safety: Scrutiny for Hair-Straightening Treatment
description: A popular hair-straightening treatment is under scrutiny after lab tests by Oregons occupational health agency found significant levels of formaldehyde in a smoothing solution made by the beauty company Brazilian Blowout.

title: Amid Rancor, Late Rally Lifts Islanders Over Rangers
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Only two games into the season and already the Rangers-Islanders rivalry is spiky with controversy. A player directed a vulgar gesture at an opponent, a coach stormed out of the postgame news conference and the Islanders overcame a late deficit Monday with three goals in the final 4 minutes 24 seconds to win, 6-4.

title: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from India, Afghanistan and Chile.

title: Tangled Tale of American Found in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As an American military patrol walked through a rural, Taliban-dominated district of Kandahar Province recently, a man wearing local clothes came toward them shouting, Dont shoot, I am an American!

title: Africa: $130 Million From United States to Train Doctors in a Dozen Countries
description: The United States will donate $130 million to African medical schools to improve medical education on the continent, the Obama administration announced last week. The donations, to be made over five years, will go to about 30 medical schools and teaching hospitals in a dozen countries, and to about 20 American medical schools that have agreed to collaborate with them.

title: A Demon Blogger Profiled Again, and Pee-Wee Takes Manhattan
description: The trouble with profiles of blog moguls who mostly write about the media is that there isnt really much of an audience for them. The insiders, who might be expected to be interested, already know all about the subjects peccadilloes, while outsiders could be fairly said to not care a wink.

title: Moonlighting as a Conjurer of Chemicals
description: Sir Isaac Newton was a towering genius in the history of science, he knew he was a genius, and he didnt like wasting his time. Born on Dec. 25, 1642, the great English physicist and mathematician rarely socialized or traveled far from home. He didnt play sports or a musical instrument, gamble at whist or gambol on a horse. He dismissed poetry as a kind of ingenious nonsense, and the one time he attended an opera he fled at the third act. Newton was unmarried, had no known romantic liaisons and may well have died, at the age of 85, with his virginity intact. I never knew him to take any recreation or pastime, said his assistant, Humphrey Newton, thinking all hours lost that were not spent on his studies.

title: Letters: Being Glenn Beck
description: Beck is at the apex of a couple of iconic American inventions: self-victimization and hyperhucksterism. In Mark Leibovichs article, Beck claims that he needs to live behind a six-foot wall but doesnt acknowledge the connection between his hateful words and his (perhaps real) vulnerability. We can perhaps forgive his contradictions  if not his venality  because his life-as-vaudeville-show is part of a long tradition in America: hes laughing all the way to the bank.

title: At Lani Kai, the Taste, and Scent, of the Tropics
description: Are there any orchids or bromeliads left in the city, now that Julie Reiner and her partners have fully decked out Lani Kai, their new Hawaiian-style cocktail lounge? This taste of the tropics, which has replaced Tailor, offers an extensive drink list, from classics like planters punch and the mai tai, to an array of aromatic inventions, including Hawaiian iced tea spiked with orange vodka, South Maui sangria with white wine and litchi juice, and the Lone Palm, combining gin with melon, ginger and basil.

title: A Jets Fans Thoughts on  Brett Favre
description: To the question: Should Jets fans boo or cheer Brett Favre when he appears on the field in a few hours?

title: In Hungary, Mogul Finds Fertile Area for Software
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On a whim, Michael Simon sprinted off to Hungary after finishing business school in St. Louis. Twenty years later, he has carved out an unusual niche as perhaps Hungarys most successful software entrepreneur.

title: In Latest Ad, Manchin Takes Aim
description: West Virginia Gov. Joe Manchin III, the Democratic Senate candidate, may have been deeply offended by his Republican opponents recent ad that used hicky actors to play West Virginians.

title: Off the Menu: Lexington Brass
description: Eugene Remm and Mark Birnbaum, who own Abe & Arthurs in the meatpacking district, plan a new American brasserie-style restaurant, Lexington Brass, to open this winter in the 48Lex hotel at 517 Lexington Avenue (48th Street).

title: A Little Bit Tchaikovsky, A Little Bit Rock n Roll
description: The violinist Alexander Markov lives a double life, musically. He has made his career mainly as a classical player, with a prize at the Paganini International Violin Competition in 1982, an Avery Fisher Career Grant in 1987 and recordings on Erato. But he has also been nourishing his inner rock star, playing electric violin in his own band.

title: B.C.S. Projection Puts Boise State at No. 1
description: The first Bowl Championship Series standings do not come out until Sunday night, but one projection gives Boise State reason to be happy  at least for a little while.

title: G.M. Officially Introduces 2011 Chevrolet Volt Amid Controversy
description: General Motors began its official press introduction of the 2011 Chevrolet Volt  on Sunday. Yes, that would be the same vehicle G.M. has been introducing with a barrage of auto show appearances and news releases since 2007.

title: Is Chemo Brain Really Cancer Brain?
description: Much has been written about chemo brain, the foggy thinking and forgetfulness that afflicts many cancer patients after treatment. Now, new research suggests the cognitive problems associated with chemotherapy may also be caused by other types of treatment or even the disease itself.

title: Vain Glorious | Doux Mes Crme Caroline
description: What: Crme Caroline, a multitasking organic moisturizer for dry and hypersensitive skin.

title: Trials Caused by a Pornographic Film Are Brought to Life
description: When your subject is the most notorious hard-core pornographic film ever made, surely puerile sexual innuendo becomes superfluous? Apparently not to the creators of The Deep Throat Sex Scandal, who begin ladling it out even in the preshow cellphone announcement.

title: Loud and Middle-Aged, But Its Not a Reunion
description: Michael Gira spent a lot of time onstage at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple on Friday making circular motions with his right hand. The patterns were mostly parallel to the ground: whirlpools, force fields, tornados.

title: Microsoft Introduces (and Pins Its Hopes on) Windows Phone 7
