description: Microsoft on Monday formally unveiled its Windows Phone 7 mobile operating system, which it hopes will give it a greater presence in the rapidly expanding market for smartphones.

title: Stem: Fighting Word (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Selective Memory (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Movement to Fill Every Corner of a Space
description: As you enter the Center for Performance Research auditorium (in Williamsburg, Brooklyn) for the performance of Anne Zuerners near the far, four dancers are seated against a wall, with the audience (most on a slightly raised dais) facing them. Later, however, the dance moves around to the area on the audiences left, and people choose whether to adjust their seats or watch the dance over a shoulder. Finally, the performance enters a third zone, and the audience adjusts seats again.

title: Miracle Drug, but No Cure (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stand-Up Comedian Walks Into Some Sketches
description: Nick Swardson wields comedy like a blunt instrument: the harder he swings, the funnier he is. The high point of the first episode of Nick Swardsons Pretend Time, a new series beginning on Tuesday night on Comedy Central, is a sketch not everyone will want to watch. Mr. Swardson plays a doughy corporate human-resources manager giving a sexual harassment seminar to the employees of a Mexican donkey show. A performance is in progress behind him.

title: Investigation of Cemetery Explosives Continues
description: Police officials and bomb squad officers continued their investigation late into the afternoon of the package of C-4 explosive recovered in New York City Marble Cemetery in the East Village. Read the latest updates.

title: West Virginia Poses Dilemma for Democrats: Must-Win or No-Win?
description: Megan Liberman and I talked about the horse-race aspects of West Virginia in todays TimesCast: suffice it to say that, from an electoral perspective, its as important a state as any in terms of Democrats ability to hold the Senate.

title: Where Having It All Doesnt Mean Having Equality
description: PARIS  Could there be anything more French than this workout?

title: We Three Things | The ATL
description: Atlanta can seem like mainstream city, a hub better known for its airport, housewives and Coca-Cola headquarters. But at its power core are deep-rooted music and art scenes that exert an illuminating influence over the rest of the countrys cultural landscape.The Dust-to-Digital founder Lance Ledbetter is a musical defibrillator. He scours the country hunting down lost, nonprofessional and obscure American folk, bluegrass, gospel and jazz music, which he rereleases accompanied by lush illustrated books  box sets full of raw cotton and the enthusiasts true love.

title: Taking Aim, Literally, at a Dead Climate Bill
Down to the Seas Again, With Remote in Hand
description: The one knock you can lay on Sid Meier, one of the legends of video game design, is that he hasnt seemed to have had a big new idea in a long time.

title: High Art
description: Photos from a marijuana farm and artists' collective in California.

title: Key House Races in the 2010 Elections
description: Analysis of key house races in the 2010 elections.

title: The Caucus Click: Dickson City, Pa.
Violinist Cancels Recital Over Detroit Strike Tension
description: Sarah Chang, internationally known violin soloist, meet Detroit, union town.

title: In California, Pot Is Now an Art Patron
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif.  Nonprofit arts groups tend to spend much of their time scrounging for grants and praying for corporate largesse. But one art foundation taking shape on 120 acres in the high oak chaparral of Sonoma County has different kinds of worries these days: spider mites, bud rot and the occasional low-flying surveillance visit from the local Sheriffs Office.

title: Honoring a Jazz Pianist and Mentor (Without Using a Single Jazz Piano)
description: Jaki Byard was a jazz pianist of rumbling mastery, quick humor and sprawling erudition, never as prominent as he should have been, though he was hardly unheralded in his time. Since his death in 1999, his legacy has been burnished by some posthumous live recordings and, no less effectively, by the continuing testimony of his students, several generations of whom he mentored in music schools across the Northeast.

title: The Caucus
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Nate Silver discuss the West Virginia Senate race.

title: Waiting for the President  Under an NBA Stars House
description: Reporters who trail the president are used to waiting in interesting places during closed-door fundraisers and other events.

title: Bodies Like Statues, Beginning to Move and Then Set Free
description: Is the performer the object or is the object the performer? Cecilia Bengolea and Franois Chaignaud posed that question over the weekend at Danspace Project in Sylphides (on Thursday and Friday nights) and Pquerette (on Saturday afternoon). Like the collaborators, both pieces are as audacious as they are important.

title: Betting on Becoming a Grandmaster
description: Can anyone become a grandmaster? Will Taylor, a 20-year-old English player, is literally betting that he can.

title: A Quartet Mixes It Up With Younger Voices
description: Before Friday night the Kronos Quartet had never played at Le Poisson Rouge, the Bleecker Street nightclub that has served as an epicenter for adventurous music ever since it opened just over two years ago. But Fridays concert, the first of two that the quartet presented at the club over the weekend, felt more like a homecoming. Sold out well in advance, both events were crammed to capacity with friends and fans.

title: To Hear Shakespeare, Perchance to Dream of Him
description: Is this a Macbeth which I see before me?

title: Men Who Play Nazis for Fun Try to Explain
description: The revelation that Rich Iott, a Republican candidate for Congress from Ohio, was an active member of a group dedicated to understanding the experience of soldiers who served in the Nazi Waffen SS by dressing up in their uniforms  and staging recreations of their battles  has forced historical re-enactors to defend their hobby.

title: On Campaign Trail, Biden Comes Home
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  As he campaigns for Democrats around the country, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. likes to say that the the longest walk up a short flight of stairs that a man can take is the one to tell the kids he has lost his job. Invariably, Mr. Biden follows up by recounting how own father took just such a walk when the family lived in this hardscrabble town.

title: Remembering Marcel Lapierre, A Beaujolais Trailblazer
description: Marcel Lapierre, the Morgon vigneron who was instrumental in reviving the reputation of Beaujolais, died Sunday night after a long battle with melanoma. Lovers of Beaujolais, and lovers of wine in general, will miss him.

title: U.S. Alarmed by Harsh Tone of Chinas Military
description: BEIJING  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates met his Chinese counterpart, Liang Guanglie, in Vietnam on Monday for the first time since the two militaries suspended talks with each other last winter, calling for the two countries to prevent mistrust, miscalculations and mistakes.

title: A Wall St. Rivalry, for a Title and for Charity
description: People in finance are usually more accustomed to competing for corporate clients and underwriting contracts. But this time, they fought it out for the title of Wall Streets best athlete.

title: Turkey Legs, Hockey Sticks and Canadian Patriotism
description: How does turkey taste with a side of hockey?

title: Supreme Court to Consider Vaccine Case
description: The safety of vaccines is at the heart of a case expected to be heard on Tuesday by the United States Supreme Court, one that could have implications for hundreds of lawsuits that contend there is a link between vaccines and autism.

title: Flash Trading: Driving the Leibowitzes Apart
description: High-frequency trading has been a flash point of finance for months now, attracting critics and defenders in almost equal measure.

title: Alaa: Double Take
description: See slide show >>

title: Preclearing Customs, a Prized Advantage
description: THERE are significant benefits to the United States Customs and Border Protection preclearance program, which allows passengers bound for the United States to clear customs at one of about 15 airports mostly in Canada and Ireland. The biggest benefit is that a passenger can pass through customs quickly and arrive in the United States without having to stand in one of those long, dreary lines at, say, Kennedy International Airport.

title: For Democrats, Even Safe Seats Are Shaky
description: ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio  Republicans are expanding the battle for the House into districts that Democrats had once considered relatively safe, while Democrats began a strategy of triage on Monday to fortify candidates who they believe stand the best chance of survival.

title: Political Math: What Percentage Equals Lockstep?
description: In numerous races across the country this year, Republican hopefuls have been hammering incumbent Democrats in Congress for voting in lockstep with Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House speaker, more than 90 percent of the time.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Walkabout'
description: A.O. Scott looks back at Nicolas Roeg's film about the persistent dream of innocence.

title: When 50 Percent Off Just Wont Do
description: WHEN it comes to wooing wary shoppers, many retailers are playing the percentages.

title: Oracle and I.B.M. Agree to Java Pact
description: Millions of software developers uneasily held their collective breath when Oracle bought Sun Microsystems earlier this year. The deal handed Oracle the role as the corporate steward of Java software technology, initially developed by Sun in 1995.

title: Europe May Ease Jet Carbon Fees
description: BRUSSELS  The transportation chief of the European Union said Monday that airlines based in the United States could receive an exemption, at least in part, from European carbon regulations if Washington moved to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at home.

title: Testing the Limits of Loose Money
description: Sound monetary policy begins at home. The prime goal of the Federal Reserve is to nurture a healthy national economy. But it would be nave to ignore the influence that Fed policy has on markets around the globe. And at present the Fed risks blowing global bubbles, with potentially damaging effects.

title: 2nd Teamsters Candidate to Challenge Hoffa in 2011
description: Sandy Pope, president of a Teamsters local in New York City and one of the most prominent women in the union, announced on Monday that she would challenge James P. Hoffa for the presidency.

title: Live Analysis: Jets 29, Vikings 20, Final
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The story lines before the Minnesota Vikings trip here on Monday night dominated the headlines in New York and attracted national attention. But all of it overshadowed something: that the Jets continue to hum along.

title: Ohio Attorney General Fights Against Wall Street
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Back East, at the corner of Broad and Wall Streets, the view is swell. The Dow is soaring, and bankers look pleased.

title: KKR Strikes Pipeline Deal
description: A partner at Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company recently told us that the firm had a number of deals in the pipeline. Little did we know that one of those deals was a pipeline.

title: Cromartie Stands in for Revis in Rematch
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Randy Moss and Darrelle Revis have crafted a personal rivalry that transcends the colors on their uniforms. Whether Moss is in New England or Minnesota, Revis seems to relish the opportunity to cover him.

title: Back in San Jose, and Now Back in the Playoffs
description: Only one playoff berth in Major League Soccer remains to be claimed after the Seattle Sounders and the San Jose Earthquakes clinched spots last weekend.

title: A Mistake the Police Wont Forgive
description: A week ago, Sgt. Osvaldo Hernandez ended his second tour of Army duty in Afghanistan, a tough seven-month stretch, and immediately hit lifes reset button.

title: 9th Suspect Is Arrested in Attacks in the Bronx
description: The ninth suspect accused of beating and torturing three Bronx men in antigay attacks was taken into custody on Monday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: Arizona Rethinking Open Range Laws
description: PHOENIX  They have startled the residents of Ahwatukee, a bedroom community in southern Phoenix. They have tramped on lawns and damaged vehicles in Rio Rancho, a neighborhood of tract homes outside Albuquerque. A Border Patrol agent lost his life crashing into one of them near the Mexican border in Texas.

title: Agendas of Paladino and Rabbi Meld
description: Carl P. Paladinos introduction to the world of conservative Jewish politics began with an unsolicited early-morning phone call three weeks ago to his campaign manager, Michael R. Caputo.

title: N.F.L. Is Compelled to React
description: Deadspins mission is to be everything the mainstream news media are not: snarky, mean spirited and unbound by more rigorous principles of old-line journalism. In that spirit of online mayhem, the sports blog last Thursday posted photographs of what it purports to be Brett Favres genitals, shots that it said he sent while still the Jets quarterback to Jenn Sterger, a former game-day host for the team. So far, the story has been viewed 1.9 million times.

title: Knicks May Try Rookie Center On First Team
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The directives that CoachMike DAntoni offered Timofey Mozgov, the Knicks rookie center from Russia, are simple, with little room to be lost in translation.

title: Maurice Allais, Nobel Winner, Dies at 99
description: Maurice Allais, who won the Nobel in economic science in 1988 for his influential insights into markets, risk, interest rates and myriad other economic phenomena, died Saturday at his home near Paris. He was 99.

title: Los Angeles TV Station Severs Ties With PBS
description: LOS ANGELES  Tim Muskatell was weaned on KCET, Los Angeles flagship PBS station, where he tuned in for landmark programs like Sesame Street. Now 41 years old and without a cable subscription, he said he still relied on KCET for documentaries and shows like the Masterpiece series.

title: For Favre, Its Finally the Point of No Return
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: A Foreclosure Tightrope for Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  The swelling outcry over fast-and-loose foreclosures has thrust the Obama administration back into the uncomfortable position of sheltering the banking industry from the demands of an angry public.

title: Russia Is Seeking to Build Europes Nuclear Plants
description: MOSCOW  The Russian nuclear industry has profited handsomely from building reactors in developing countries, including India, China and Iran. Now it is testing the prospect of becoming a major supplier to the European Union, too.

title: Unrepentant, Paladino Calls Gay Parades Disgusting
description: Despite an uproar over his remarks about gays, Carl P. Paladino appeared on national television on Monday and expressed revulsion at gay pride parades.

title: Female Factor
description: Katrin Bennhold reports on the advancement of French women helped by state social policies.  But despite the high levels of education and employment, the glass ceiling remains.

title: Carla Cohen, Owner of Washington Bookstore, Dies at 74
description: Carla Cohen, whose independent bookstore, Politics and Prose, sat at the nexus of Washingtons literary and political scenes and became a requisite stop for authors passing through town, died Monday at her home in Washington. She was 74.

title: Worrying Over China and Food
description: Are the Chinese coming?

title: Starting Over: Burnett Rejoins Yanks Rotation
description: The Yankees have made the playoffs 49 times, but there is a simple reason that 27 flags ring the top of Yankee Stadium: nothing less than winning the World Series is acceptable.

title: For Pena, Rebirth Is All in the Timing
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: The True Mission of Crisis Pregnancy Centers
description: Imagine a young woman riding the subway, consumed by her thoughts: she is pregnant, considering abortion, but unsure of where to turn. She looks up midcommute and notices a sign with three bold words, one beneath the other: Free abortion alternatives. At the bottom of the sign are several phone numbers that will lead her to any one of 12 E.M.C. FrontLine Pregnancy Centers around New York City.

title: The Crisis of the Humanities Officially Arrives
description: In a response to last weeks column on Howl, the movie about Allen Ginsbergs famous poem, Charlie from Binghamton asked, What happened to public investment in the humanities and the belief that the humanities enhanced our culture, our society, our humanity? And he speculated that it will be a sad, sad day if and when we allow the humanities to collapse.

title: Inspectors in Rearview as Food Trucks Rule Road
description: LOS ANGELES  This is the place where food trucks really first took to the streets, catering to fanatical customers who relished  along with the food  the renegade and slightly outlaw nature of the whole business.

title: Scotland Not Afraid of a Stooshie With Critics or Spain
description: Oct. 12, 5:22 p.m. |Spain 3, Scotland 2

title: Giants Rally Ousts Braves and Ends Coxs Career
description: ATLANTA  Bobby Cox bit his lip, trying to stifle any tears that wanted to drip out. He was forced to change the subject to keep from becoming too emotional in his last news conference as the Atlanta manager.

title: Races Range From Odd to More So
description: WASHINGTON  Revelations that Rich Iott, a Republican Congressional candidate from Ohio, once whiled away time dressing up as a Nazi have not been fortunate for his candidacy. He has been abandoned by a prominent member of his party, castigated by critics and may well be doomed as a politician.

title: A Soprano Hailed as La Stupenda
description: Joan Sutherland, a soprano known for her vocal charisma and for singing the title role in Lucia di Lammermoor, died at 83.

title: New Yorkers Anger at Politicians Doesnt Fuel a Surge in Voter Registration
description: Despite professed outrage over dysfunctional politicians, few unregistered New Yorkers have been motivated enough to register to vote in November, according to election officials.

title: Lottery Numbers
Outlaw Canceled by NBC
description: The NBC drama Outlaw became the third show of the new television season to be canceled. The network announced Monday that the program would be moved from Friday to Saturday night for the remaining four episodes that have been produced.

title: This Years Giants Arent Afraid to Work a Little Overtime
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the rhythm of life in the N.F.L., there are certain abiding truths. Most games are on Sunday and players are off on Tuesday.

title: Relying on Pitching, Phillies Save Big Celebration
description: CINCINNATI  Off to the side, safely away from the gathering mess in the middle of the Philadelphia Phillies clubhouse  empty Champagne bottles, spent corks, twisted wire and ice cubes  pitcher Roy Halladay savored the first playoff championship celebration of his 13-year career.

title: Two Draws, One a Marathon, Preserve Status Quo at Bilbao Masters
Offering Donors Secrecy, and Going on Attack
description: The American Future Fund, a conservative organization based in Iowa, has been one of the more active players in this falls campaigns, spending millions of dollars on ads attacking Democrats across the country. It has not hesitated to take credit for its attacks, issuing press releases with headlines like AFF Launches TV Ads in 13 States Targeting Liberal Politicians.

title: Explosives Abandoned In Cemetery Are Mystery
description: The New York City Marble Cemetery has long had an air of mystery. Practically hidden between apartment buildings and brownstones, the leafy urban pocket was once the resting place of President James Monroe. A fire long ago destroyed records showing some of its other early inhabitants. The cemeterys Web site welcomes amateur genealogists to help fill in the blanks.

title: For G.M., Mets Ponder Another Teams Assistant
description: When the Mets interview Rick Hahn on Tuesday for their general manager opening, he will have one distinct advantage over other candidates. Hahn, the assistant general manager of the Chicago White Sox, attended the University of Michigan, the beloved alma mater of Fred Wilpon, the Mets principal owner. That should prove beneficial.

title: Tuesday: Something in Common
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  We first met Jos Chardiet, who is 16, at his debut puzzle on July 6 (Across Lite, Solution, blog). This time we have a much more ambitious theme that takes us through the months of the year in order. Take a look at the starred answers because theyre nicely done  symmetrically distributed, and each three-letter abbreviation is at the start of the longer answer. Roundabout, for one is a good clue for JUNCTION and the problem of starting a word with SEP that doesnt look like SEPTEMBER is nicely solved with the Cosmetics chain SEPHORA.

title: Sham Candidacy Is Charged in House Race
description: CINNAMINSON, N.J.  Adam Haraburda grinned at the sight of the local celebrity running for Congress, happy for a chance to stop and chat with the candidate. But that did not mean he had decided how to vote.

title: In China, a Villages Silk Goes Out of Fashion
description: The name Jili used to be synonymous with silk in China. Now the villages homespun fortunes are fading as young people leave for the cities.

title: Silk Craft Fades in Village That Clothed Emperors
description: JILI, China  There was a time when clean water, mulberry trees and tiny, squirming, milky-white larvae made this village one of the most famous in all of China.

title: Two Arrested While Interviewing Condemned Iranians Son
description: TEHRAN  Irans chief prosecutor said Monday that the police had arrested two foreigners masquerading as journalists who were caught in midinterview with the son of a woman convicted of adultery and murder and sentenced to death by stoning.

title: Mine Saga in Chile Captivates Bolivians
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  Impoverished in his Bolivian homeland and desperate for a job, Carlos Mamani had been working at the mine here in Chiles barren northern desert for just five days  before disaster struck.

title: Marcel Lapierre, Beaujolais Producer, Is Dead at 60
description: Marcel Lapierre, a Beaujolais grower and producer who played a leading role in rejuvenating the diminished reputation of the regions wines, died Sunday in Lyon, France. He was 60.

title: China: Prominent Doctor Sentenced in Attacks on Critics
description: A prominent doctor was sentenced to five and a half months in jail for orchestrating a revenge attack on two writers who had accused him of fraud, state media reported on Monday. According to the police, Dr. Xiao Chuanguo, a urologist from Wuhan, confessed to paying four men a total of $15,000 to assault Fang Xuanchang, a science writer, and Fang Shimin, a blogger whose Web site is dedicated to exposing academic and scientific fraud. They had written critically about a nerve-rerouting procedure Dr. Xiao pioneered and practiced on hundreds of patients with incontinence. The attacks were carried out with pepper spray, a hammer and an iron rod; both victims have recovered. During a closed-door trial on Sunday, the four attackers received terms ranging from one and a half months to five and a half months, according to the official Xinhua news service, which said Dr. Xiao would appeal his sentence.

title: Closing the Case on the Cole
description: TEN years ago, Qaeda terrorists blew a hole in the side of the Navy destroyer Cole in Yemen, killing 17 sailors. Yet the attacks mastermind still hasnt been prosecuted, and many of the men tried and imprisoned for the bombing are again free.

title: At Synod With Mideast Bishops, Pope Condemns Terror Ideologies
description: Pope Benedict XVI opened a two-week synod of Catholic bishops from the Middle East on Monday by condemning terrorist ideologies carried out in Gods name. In off-the-cuff remarks to the bishops and other religious leaders who convened for the synod, the pope said that these acts of violence have nothing to do with God and instead everything to do with false gods that must be exposed. The aim of the synod, which ends Oct. 24, is to discuss problems faced by Christians living in the Middle East, where the Catholic Churchs members have been dwindling because of war, and economic and social conflict. It also hopes to foster better communication between the Catholic churches there and Rome, as well as improve interreligious dialogue with Muslims and Jews.

title: Turkey: Members of Judicial Board Resign in a Power Struggle
description: Seven of the 12 members of the Senior Board of Judges and Prosecutors resigned on Monday amid a power struggle between the staunchly secular judiciary and the religiously conservative government in Turkey. The board chairman said members were frustrated at not being allowed to perform their duties since the government proposed a referendum calling for major structural changes to the board, which is in charge of appointing and dismissing magistrates. The referendum passed a month ago. A Justice Ministry statement denied the claims and said the resignations were an effort to influence the election of new board members.

title: Hail and Heavy Rain Batter Parts of Region
description: Weeks after a severe storm tore through parts of New York, another blast of foul weather visited the city, with hail falling in some neighborhoods, curtailing subway service and delaying the Jets-Vikings football game.

title: Inquiry in Fatal Hit-and-Run Looks at Firefighters S.U.V.
description: A Brooklyn firefighter has been placed on administrative duties while the police investigate whether his sport utility vehicle was involved in a fatal hit-and-run accident early Sunday, a Fire Department spokesman said on Monday.

title: The First Marty McFly
description: In this clip from the Back to the Future 25th Anniversary DVD collection, Robert Zemeckis, Steven Spielberg and Bob Gale discuss why they replaced the actor Eric Stoltz as Marty McFly.

title: Terror Trials and the Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Flooding in Park Slope
description: A view of flooding at Ninth Street and Sixth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, about 9 p.m. on Monday night. (Video: Angela Jimenez)

title: A Healthy Initiative? Or a Nanny State?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nobel Prize and China
description: To the Editor:

title: The Suicides of Gay Teenagers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Leasing of Public Lands
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE

title: Offshore Wind Power Line Wins Backing
description: WASHINGTON  Google and a New York financial firm have each agreed to invest heavily in a proposed $5 billion transmission backbone for future offshore wind farms along the Atlantic Seaboard that could ultimately transform the regions electrical map.

title: Word of the Day | ominous
description: ominous \-m-ns\ adjective

title: The Paralysis of the State
description: Sometimes a local issue perfectly illuminates a larger national problem. Such is the case with the opposition of the New Jersey governor, Chris Christie, to construction of a new tunnel between his state and New York.

title: So Utterly Inhumane
description: You have to believe that somebody really had it in for the Scott sisters, Jamie and Gladys. They have always insisted that they had nothing to do with a robbery that occurred near the small town of Forest, Miss., on Christmas Eve in 1993. It was not the kind of crime to cause a stir. No one was hurt and perhaps $11 was taken.

title: The Latest Crisis
description: Another crisis is roiling American-Pakistani relations after NATO helicopters mistakenly fired on a border post and killed Pakistani soldiers last month. Islamabad then closed a major supply line for NATO troops in Afghanistan; last week, extremists torched fuel trucks waiting at the border crossing. A new White House report said that Pakistans Army is refusing to go after Taliban groups targeting American forces.

title: Politically Crude
description: Carl Paladinos bigoted remarks about gay people were bad enough by themselves  another dip in his low-road campaign for governor of New York. But when you consider his timing, they were shockingly irresponsible.

title: Justice Thomas and His Wife
description: Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court, is the founder and chief executive of Liberty Central, a nonprofit organization set up to restore the greatness of America, in part by opposing the leftist tyranny of President Obama and Democrats in Congress. Its first contributions of $500,000 and $50,000 came from undisclosed donors. The size of those gifts, their anonymity and their importance to the organization raise a serious issue of ethics for Justice Thomas.

title: A Nobel Prize for Peter Diamond
description: It has been a big year for Peter Diamond, 70, the renowned professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In April, Mr. Diamond was nominated by President Obama to serve on the seven-member board of governors of the Federal Reserve. On Monday, he became one of three recipients of this years Nobel in economic science.

title: Baseball Replay: Oct. 11
description: The San Francisco Giants edged the Atlanta Braves 3-2 to clinch the National League Division Series 3-1.

title: Bloggingheads: Christians and Gay Rights
description: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Robert Jones of the Public Religion Research Institute discuss changing public opinion of gay rights.

title: Jets Replay: Week 5
description: Images from the Jets game against Brett Favre and the Minnesota Vikings at New Meadowlands Stadium.

title: Defense Seeks Mistrial in Synagogue Bomb Case
description: Lawyers for four men charged in a plot to bomb Bronx synagogues and shoot down military planes asked the judge in the case on Monday to declare a mistrial because jurors were allowed to see evidence that was not admitted during the trial.

title: News Quiz | October 12, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Ohio Attorney General Fights Wall Street
description: Back East, at the corner of Broad and Wall Streets, the view is swell. The Dow is soaring, and bankers look pleased.

title: Offshore Wind Power Line Wins Praise, and Backing
description: Google and a New York financial firm have each agreed to invest heavily in a proposed $5 billion transmission backbone for future offshore wind farms along the Atlantic Seaboard that could ultimately transform the regions electrical map.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 12, 2010
description: Test your reading comprehension skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article Doctors Orders: Eat Well to Be Well.

title: Sorkin: Worrying Over China and Food
description: The prospect that a group backed by China may make a takeover offer for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan that rivals a $38.6 billion hostile bid from BHP Billiton has Washington lawmakers, Canadian regulators and Wall Street bankers talking, The New York Timess Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

title: Jets Win Fourth Straight, Spoiling Favres Return
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets and Minnesota Vikings endured two lightning delays before the first snap on Monday night and finished the strangest of slugfests early Tuesday morning. In between, Brett Favre made history, Randy Moss made his Vikings debut and Darrelle Revis made his return to the Jets defense.

title: In Hungary, Mogul Finds Fertile Area for Software
description: On a whim, Michael Simon sprinted off to Hungary after finishing business school in St. Louis. Twenty years later, he has carved out an unusual niche as perhaps Hungarys most successful software entrepreneur, Ashlee Vance reports in The New York Times.

title: Analysis: A Foreclosure Tightrope for Democrats
description: The swelling outcry over fast-and-loose foreclosures has thrust the Obama administration back into the uncomfortable position of sheltering the banking industry from the demands of an angry public, Binyamin Appelbaum writes in The New York Times.

title: Ask C.J. Chivers: The Gun
description: C. J. Chivers, a Times correspondent and frequent contributor to At War, often from his embeds in Afghanistan, has written a book, The Gun, that is being released on Oct. 12. He will be answering readers questions over the next several days. Please submit your questions below in the comments box. UPDATE: Follow the Q&A here.

title: Daily Lexeme: Breviloquence
description: Todays word, in association with the commendable Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Degrees of Debt
description: From Jeremy Dehn, a professor of film and video production, on The New York Timess Op/Ed page:

title: Citi Cuts Foreclosure Work With Investigated Firm
description: Citigroup said it stopped steering foreclosure work to a Florida law firm whose court filings to support home seizures were under investigation by the states attorney general, Bloomberg News reported.

title: A Disputed Nobel Peace Prize
description: WHO is Liu Xiaobo?

title: French Strikes Disrupt Air and Rail Travel
description: PARIS  In the latest expression of discontent over government austerity moves across Europe, French transport and energy workers, teachers and civil servants took to the streets on Tuesday to protest plans to reform the countrys pension system  the third such strike here in just over a month.

title: Japanese Company to Buy iPhone Game Developer
description: DeNA, the Japanese social gaming giant, said Tuesday that it would acquire Ngmoco, a Silicon Valley iPhone game developer, for $400 million  one of the largest deals ever involving an iPhone application developer and another sign that the iPhone is fast becoming the hottest gaming device on the market.

title: The Ghetto, the Nazis and One Small Boy
description: They are photographs that crystallize moments of our shared history: the exuberance and relief of victory captured by an American sailor bending over to plant a kiss on a woman in a white dress in the swirl of Times Square on Aug. 14, 1945; the horror of savage weapons seen on the anguished face of a 9-year-old Vietnamese girl fleeing down a road after a napalm attack; the terror produced by a monstrous tyranny as a child with a newsboys cap raises his arms in surrender during a roundup of Warsaw Jews.

title: France Hits Back at U.S. on Hedge Fund Rules
description: The French economy minister, Christine Lagarde, rebuffed United States criticism that demands for tough new European Union rules on hedge funds were protectionist but she also extended an olive branch, signaling she was ready to compromise, Reuters reported.

title: How Do Your Parents Teach You to Behave?
description: Two recent Times articles suggest that some behavior of concern to schools  bullying among elementary-school children and lack of responsibility-taking among high school students  is, at least partly, driven by parents. Have you witnessed students who are apparently emboldened by their parents to mistreat others or flout rules? What do your parents teach you about how to treat your peers and act at school?

title: Is Diageo Rooting for Ackman Against Fortune?
description: From Reuters Breakingviews:

title: Is Wall Street on Track for Record Pay?
description: 7:46 a.m. | Updated Total Wall Street compensation is on pace to reach $144 billion for 2010, a record for the second consecutive year, a study by The Wall Street Journal finds .

title: Liverpool Court Battle Starts as New Bid Looms
description: The legal battle to force Tom Hicks and George Gillett Jr. to sell Liverpool F.C. to New England Sports Ventures, which also owns the Boston Red Sox and is run by the hedge fund manager John W. Henry, reaches Londons High Court on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Petronas Chemicals Plans $4 Billion I.P.O.
description: Petronas Chemicals is looking to raise as much as $4 billion (2.5 billion) in a Malaysian initial public offering, exceeding earlier estimates of over $2 billion as it hopes to tap strong global investor demand for Asian stocks, Reuters reported.

title: California Selects Buyer for 11 State Properties
description: California announced Monday it was selling 24 government office buildings  including the Ronald Reagan State Building in Los Angeles and the San Francisco Civic Center  to a group of private investors for $2.3 billion.

title: BlackRock Still Bullish on India and China
description: BlackRock, the worlds biggest asset manager, expects many countries to impose capital controls on hot money, predicting the foreign fund flows to Asia that have pushed up regional currencies to continue for the next six months.

title: Ukraine Bus Driver Pulls Into Train Path, Killing 41
description: MOSCOW  Ignoring flashing lights, a warning siren and the terrified screams of passengers, the driver of a commuter bus in central Ukraine pulled into the path of an oncoming train on Tuesday, Ukrainian officials said, causing a crash that killed at least 41 people, including 3 children, and left at least 10 people in critical condition.

title: Calpers Cuts Ties With Adviser Hit by Pay to Play
description: 1:19 p.m. | Updated

title: A New Asylum for Prague Cyclists
description: Cracked cobblestones, hurried drivers and a dearth of bike lanes make cycling in the center of Prague a perilous affair. The self-proclaimed bike activist Martin Kontra wants this to change.

title: The Spousal Safety Net
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: Bonus Time May Not Come Early for Wall St. Banks
description: Large Wall Street banks are unlikely to accelerate bonus payouts, even if doling out bonuses in December would cut the tax bills of employees, Reuters said, citing compensation experts.

title: Rival Bidders Join to Buy Sea Island for $212 Million
description: Competing bidders ended up banding together Monday to negotiate a deal to jointly buy the Sea Island Company for $212.4 million at an auction intended to settle the Georgia luxury resort operators bankruptcy case, The Associated Press reported.

title: Lions Gate Said to Propose Merger With MGM
description: Lions Gate Entertainment has made a merger proposal to bankrupt film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, The Los Angeles Times reported, citing people close to the matter.  Carl C. Icahn, a major backer of Lions Gate, was previously reported to be urging such a move.

title: EDF Said Prepared to Back Constellation Sale
description: Electricite de France, the largest shareholder in Constellation Energy Group, would support the sale of the company as relations between the partners sour, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: Punch Taverns to Sell 1,300 Pubs
description: Punch Taverns, a British operator of more than 6,700 pubs, said it would accelerate plans to dispose of weaker outlets and focus on food, news that pushed its shares down the most since May, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Obama Message in Flux as Election Day Nears
description: With three weeks left until Election Day, President Obama holds the Democratic Partys biggest political weapon: the White House megaphone.

title: What Exactly Is a Coachable Entrepreneur?
description: Previously, Catherine Mott, an angel investor, stressed the importance of investing in coachable entrepreneurs who surround themselves with solid management teams. As chief executive and founder of BlueTree Allied Angels in Wexford, Pa., Ms. Mott says she knows one when she sees one. But during a recent conversation, I asked her to try to specify what she looks for when investing in start-ups. A condensed version of our conversation follows.

title: Apology and Interception for Favre
description: A decisive late-game interception almost seemed like a Brett Favre cliche, but the second half of Vikings-Jets and the off-the-field happenings did not lack spice. Lets go to the links:

title: Investors Pour $11 Billion into Hedge Funds in Aug.
description: Hedge funds received net deposits in August of $11.3 billion, the largest since February, as investors increased their appetite for risk, Bloomberg News reported, citing data from TrimTabs Investment Research and BarclayHedge.

title: Icahns Stock Buy Suggests Battle for Dynegy
description: Hedge fund filings show that investors like Carl C. Icahn and Douglas A. Hirsch are betting on Blackstone upping its $4.7 billion bid for Dynegy, and may put up a fight if it resists.

title: Are Activist Investors Primed for a Rebound?
description: Is it comeback time for activist investors?

title: Cairn Chairman Admonishes India on Vedanta Deal
description: Cairn Energy chairman, Bill Gammell, has said that the way the India government deals with the proposed $9.6 billion sale of his companys Indian energy business to Vedanta will be a key pointer for future foreign investment in the country, The Financial Times reported.

title: Harbin Chief and Baring Team Up on Buyout Bid
description: The chief executive of Harbin Electric and Baring Private Equity Asia Group have teamed up to table a buyout bid that values the Chinese producer of electric motors at $752.2 million.

title: An Undersea Trench for Wind Power?
description: In Tuesdays paper, I write about a proposal for a 350-mile undersea cable system that would carry energy from numerous Atlantic wind farms back to shore. It presents some interesting technical twists.

title: Private Equity-Backed I.P.O.s Hit Slow Down
description: Bankers who hoped for a rush of private equity-backed initial public offerings this year may have to rein in their expectations.

title: What Entrepreneurs Want
description: From VentureBeat:

title: Clinton, Citing Work With Obama, Urges Unity in Bosnia
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  For Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, Tuesday was a precarious balancing act.

title: Loose Connections
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Loose Connections
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Jets Are Good, but Super Bowl Good?
description: We are right on schedule. We want to have the best record in the National Football League.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan at Monday nights postgame news conference.

title: The Back to the Future That Might Have Been
description: The Back to the Future films have given us glimpses of times and places that could have been, from a comical 2015 populated with flying cars and hovering skateboards to an alternate 1955 where Michael J. Fox invented rock n roll. But how might history have turned out if the first Back to the Future movie had starred Eric Stoltz, as its filmmakers originally planned? In this clip from the Back to the Future 25th Anniversary DVD collection, the director Robert Zemeckis, his co-screenwriter, Bob Gale, and executive producer Steven Spielberg discuss how they made the heavy if cinematically momentous decision to replace Mr. Stoltz with Mr. Fox, and show early footage that was shot with Mr. Stoltz in the role of Marty McFly.

title: U.S. and China Soften Tone Over Disputed Seas
description: HANOI, Vietnam  The United States and China sought to defuse tensions over disputed territorial seas on Tuesday, with Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates urging nations to honor historic rights of free transit through international waters and his Chinese counterpart saying the region had nothing to fear from Beijings armed forces.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: From Slates review of The Social Network: Aaron Sorkin explains that the filmmakers went to great pains to discern what kind of beer [Facebooks founder, Mark Zuckerberg] was drinking on a Tuesday night in October seven years ago. In reality, the name of the beer Becks  can be uncovered with a simple Google search. Sorkins sincerity is harder to locate.

title: Varvatos Said to Seek Buyers
description: John Varvatos, the hip menswear label currently owned by the VF Corporation, is in talks with potential buyers about taking over the company and helping pay off its debt, The New York Post reported Tuesday, citing unnamed sources.

title: In Greece, Repayment Talk Drives Bonds
description: LONDON  With its austerity program well under way, Greece held a successful bond sale on Tuesday amid a growing debate about whether the country should be given more time to repay the international bailout loans that saved it from bankruptcy.

title: In a Takeout Container, a Trek to the Stratosphere
description: Luke Geissbhler has raised the bar in the cool-dad competition.

title: Pfizer to Buy King Pharmaceuticals for $3.6 Billion
description: 2:25 p.m. | Updated Pfizer stepped up the consolidation in the drug industry on Tuesday with a $3.6 billion deal to buy King Pharmaceuticals, a maker of pain medications.

title: Payard Chef to Take Over Benoit
description: Philippe Bertineau, who had been the executive chef at Payard Patisserie and Bistro, which closed in 2009, and had more recently been at Balthazar, will take over the kitchen at Benoit, Alain Ducasses restaurant in Midtown, a branch of a venerable Paris bistro. He will start on Oct. 25, replacing Pierre Schaedelin, who was the chef and a partner, and who will be pursuing other ventures. Mr. Bertineau plans to revise Benoits menu, adding dishes like an upside-down cheese souffle and crispy pigs trotters.

title: No Twin Discrimination, but No Special Treatment, Either
description: By multiplying every daily parenting difficulty by two, raising twins can be a tough business. So it was with a feeling of adding insult to injury that Susannah Meadows wrote about her dispiriting experience with twin discrimination at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden in last weeks Complaint Box.

title: TriBeCa Bar Will Have Its Own Iceworks
description: Weather Up, Kathryn Weatherups latest eponymously named cocktail bar  set to open at 159 Duane Street in TriBeCa in early November  is one saloon that will never have to send out for ice.

title: Play Inspired by Beckett Heading to His Turf
description: Its perhaps fitting for a play inspired by Samuel Beckett that a) its life seems to just go on and on and b) it will soon be performed in Dublin, where Beckett was born. Krapp, 39, the solo show written and performed by Michael Laurence that was presented in the New York International Fringe Festival in 2008 and Off Broadway for a critically lauded extended run in 2009 will be staged in Dublin and London this fall.

title: Planners of New Stadiums Keep Soccer in Mind
description: London

title: Study Says Teenagers Need More Driver Training From Parents
description: According to a new study that highlights the crucial role parents play in teaching their children to drive, parents are not giving their teenagers enough experience behind the wheel in challenging situations like bad weather, at night, on highways or in heavy traffic before they obtain their licenses.

title: A Look at Crisis Pregnancy Centers
description: The hail is gone, but rain may return later. Heres what were reading:

title: Adam Lambert Says Hell Follow Rules for Malaysian Concert
description: Adam Lambert said on Tuesday that he would comply with the restrictions placed on a concert he is to perform Thursday in Malaysia, adding that his main goal is to keep people entertained  not to make them uncomfortable, The Associated Press reported.

title: The Early Word: Now on Skype
description: President Obama is scheduled to spend part of his Tuesday meeting with finalists in a youth entrepreneurship competition in the Oval Office, and holding a town-hall-style meeting at George Washington University sponsored by the Democratic National Committee.

title: Night Watch: Campaign Craziness and Foreign Funds
description: Three weeks before the midterm elections, there are so many strange-but-true story lines that Jon Stewart compiled them all into a single Indecision 2010 segment on Monday night.

title: Beijing Calls Nobel Insult To People Of China
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government continued its vilification campaign against the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to a jailed dissident, Liu Xiaobo, by canceling another meeting with Norwegian officials and denouncing the award as an affront to the Chinese people and a ploy to try to change the countrys political system.

title: Wall Street Takes Fed Minutes in Stride
description: Shares on Wall Street rose slightly on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve revealed some of its disagreements about providing additional stimulus to the lagging economy.

title: The Ten Month Mamas
description: Mothers whose babies were born after ten months.

title: Urban Fervor: 30 Rock Shares Details of Its Live Episode
description: What can we tell you about Thursdays episode of 30 Rock? Not much more than what NBC has been saying since the summer: for the first time, the show will tap into the Saturday Night Live experience of its creator and star, Tina Fey, and co-stars like Alec Baldwin and Tracy Morgan, and will be performed live at the shows namesake headquarters in Manhattan (instead of being filmed at its familiar studios in Long Island City). What can Robert Carlock tell you about the live episode? Probably a whole lot more since hes an executive producer and show runner of 30 Rock, not to mention an SNL veteran himself.

title: Chargers Record:  The Best 2-3 Youll Ever See
description: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

title: For Tsunamis, a New Tectonic Suspect
description: Major coastal cities, including Los Angeles and Istanbul, are at much greater risk of tsunamis than previously thought, new research by geologists studying the recent earthquake in Haiti suggests.

title: In National League, Dominant Pitching Is the Story
description: The two National League division series had more than their fair share of stellar pitching performances.

title: At Home in the World
description: When did Italian design take over the world? Suddenly, its everywhere: in hotels from Milan (of course) to Tokyo; in shops, restaurants and airport lounges; and even at The New York Times, where cutting-edge Italian furniture can be found throughout the building. At a time in which design has become more international than ever  provocateurs from the Netherlands, Japan and Brazil are just a few of the players whove shared the field in the last decade  Italys reach is global.

title: Tuesday Reading: The Downside of Early Retirement
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Nancy Sinatra Gets Her Dad into the Wine Business
description: In the wine business, the quality of the marketing is often as important as the quality of the grapes, and sometimes even more so.

title: Fill-In | An Improbable Baseball Factory
The Blessings of a B-Minus
description: Little kids, little problems, the Russian version of the proverb says.

title: Traveling
description: Limited posting and delayed comment moderating for the next few days.

title: Singapore Billionaire Makes Rival Bid for Liverpool
description: The day after a courtroom battle over the fate of the Liverpool Football club mounted, and almost a week after New England Sports Ventures, owners of the Boston Red Sox, agreed to pay 300 million, or about $476 million, for the storied English soccer club, a Singapore billionaire has made a rival bid to buy the team.

title: From Brooklyn to the Stratosphere
description: The Science section has a profile this morning of Luke Geissbhler, the cinematographer from Park Slope and mastermind of the archly named Brooklyn Space Program who launched a weather balloon attached to a video camera from a park near Newburgh, N.Y. The balloon reached an altitude of 100,000 feet and took some amazing NASA-like footage before tumbling back to earth. Read the article in Science.

title: What the Kids Want to Eat
description: Inspired by last weeks story on the popularity of spaghetti tacos, we asked readers to submit photos of the food their children ask them to cook. Here are the results.

title: Actors Warn Against Hobbit Boycott as Costs Mount
description: It may not hold as much sway in J. R. R. Tolkiens universe as, say, the the Council of Elrond or the Fellowship of the Ring, but a group of actors in New Zealand is calling on an actors guild there to drop its opposition to a filmed adaptation of The Hobbit that Peter Jackson is preparing.

title: 30-Mile Logjam on Malaysian River Hints at Forest Crimes
description: Its hardly news that the rich virgin rain forests on both the Malaysian and Indonesian sides of Borneo are being steadily sheared away, enriching a few while ravaging unique ecosystems. In fact, its such a persistent issue that headlines are rare.

title: Microlender Says Chief Was Ousted Over Differences
description: MUMBAI, India  SKS Microfinance, which recently became the first Indian microlender to sell shares in the stock market, should be enjoying a honeymoon right now.

title: Best Buy to Start E.V. Charging Pilot Program
description: Automakers and charging companies often talk about big-box stores as the ideal location to plug in electric cars for the obvious reason that people can charge while shopping. But although Costco installed some chargers years ago, new commitment on the part of the major chains has been lacking.

title: The Takeaway: Messaging
description: Click to Listen

title: Studying Tropical Genetic Blood Diseases
description: Sir David Weatherall, 77, an Oxford researcher-physician, was among the first to use the tools of molecular biology to understand thalassemia. He was in New York to receive the Lasker-Koshland Special Achievement Award for “50 years of international statesmanship in biomedical science.” A condensed version of conversations with him follows:

title: Biden Challenges Chamber of Commerce
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. called out officials at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Monday night, daring them to prove that the money they are spending on political campaigns does not come from foreign sources.

title: Lauded Harlem Schools Have Their Own Problems
description: President Obama created a grant program to copy his block-by-block approach to ending poverty. The British government praised his charter schools as a model. And a new documentary opening across the country revolves around him: Geoffrey Canada, the magnetic Harlem Childrens Zone leader with strong ideas about how American education should be fixed.

title: White House Is Lifting Ban on Deepwater Drilling
description: 1:50 p.m. | Updated

title: What Were Reading: Believing the Impossible
Left Out in the Cold by Revival of Old Rules
description: SULANG, INDONESIA  Made Rai is a frail man with lank white hair and eyes that are glazed with a milky film. He estimates that he is in his 80s: much too old to recount with confidence just how his family started feuding with this Balinese village. He is, however, fully aware of the feuds results.

title: Paladino Admits to Some Missteps
description: Still beating back accusations that he was biased against gay people, Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor, said on Tuesday that he had made some mistakes in communicating his ideas on the campaign trail.

title: Drilling Moratorium to End
description: The Obama administration plans to announce Tuesday afternoon that it is lifting the moratorium on deepwater oil drilling, after putting in place new rules intended to tighten safety, the Caucus blog reports.

title: Bringing Home Baby, Your Electric Car
description: SO youre thinking of buying or leasing an electric car, and youre taking a hard look at the garage, filled with many years of accumulated junk and sporting a single 110-volt socket on the wall.

title: The Great Heap Forward
description: Its typical of the murky legend that has accumulated around Walter Albini that no one can even agree if the design college he attended in 1957 in Turin, Italy, at the age of 16 was an all-girls school that he somehow charmed his way into  or if he simply happened to be one of the few guys at an institution with a lot of women.

title: Paladino Admits to Some Missteps
description: As Javier C. Hernandez reports on our City Room blog, Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for New York governor, said on Tuesday that he had made some mistakes in communicating his ideas on the campaign trail. In a radio interview, Mr. Paladino said that he had definitely stepped on my message in recent weeks, noting the uproar over his recent comments that children should not be exposed to homosexuality in schools and that gay pride parades were disgusting.

title: Nuggets React to New Rules on Bad Behavior
description: The word is out: this season N.B.A. players really need to watch every gesture, word and emotional outburst  or else.

title: Special Bulletin: Fractions Have Denominators
description: Ive been getting some mail over yesterdays column, with angry correspondents posting charts like this, showing government spending as a percentage of GDP, to claim that government spending has too surged:

title: What Not to Tell Facebook Friends
description: In a recent Bucks post, Dont Tell Facebook Friends That Youre Going Away, Ron Lieber advised readers not to share their vacation status or birthday on the social networking site. Why? Such information can be useful to burglars and identity thieves.

title: No Mistrial in Bronx Synagogue Bomb Plot
description: The four men charged in a plot to bomb Bronx synagogues and shoot down military planes had their request for a mistrial denied on Tuesday.

title: The Shooting at Fort Hood
description: An Army psychiatrist about to be deployed to combat zones overseas killed 13 and wounded 28 others at Fort Hood in Texas.

title: Justices Turn Down Appeal Over Speech Ejections
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday let stand a decision dismissing a lawsuit filed by two people who were ejected from a speech by President George W. Bush in 2005. They had arrived in a car bearing a bumper sticker that said No More Blood for Oil, and they claimed that their First Amendment rights were violated when they were marched out of the event.

title: Trapped 68 Days, First Chilean Miners Taste Freedom
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  With a look of sturdy calm, the first of the 33 miners trapped nearly half a mile underground stepped out of a narrow rescue capsule and onto the surface at 12:11 a.m. on Wednesday, hugging his family, the nations president and the workers who helped free him before being carted away on a stretcher, giving a thumbs-up as he left.

title: The Arts Meet the Beach in Sarasota
description: Culture vultures dont regularly flock to the beach. But Sarasota, Fla., is making a bid for arts fans as well as escapists with its second annual Ringling International Arts Festival from Wednesday through Sunday.

title: Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, 11:26 A.M.
Cars Born to Run With Smartphone Apps
description: MOST auto dealers will tell you that more buyers ask about how to connect an iPhone to a car or about the latest collision avoidance systems than they do about how quickly a car goes from zero to 60. So automakers are pumping up the technology.

title: Obama to Campaign in States He Won in 2008
description: President Obama will be on the campaign trail much of the next three weeks, focusing entirely on states that he won two years ago as he tries to help Democrats counter Republican momentum heading into crucial midterm elections.

title: Is Your Dog a Pessimist?
description: Does your dog droop when you leave the house? It may be a sign that your pet is a pessimist.

title: End Times: Hail and Bowery Sweatshirts Edition
description: There are not two but three certainties in life: death, taxes and weather stories. And with the kind of weather thats been buffeting the city in recent months, traditional media and bloggers alike were more than ready for a little bout of quarter-sized hail.

title: Sketching the Famous as They Sat in Court
description: John J. Gotti had been wounded. Not by a gun, but by a crayon.

title: Secrets Behind the Maple Leafs Turnaround
description: The Toronto Maple Leafs are the feel-good story of the young N.H.L. season, having already doubled their win total from last October. Granted, some would say thats not all that hard, given that they managed only one win last year. But even so, the Leafs have been a far better team so far this season than anyone expected. Whats going on?

title: TimesCast | October 12, 2010
description: The Obama administration's evolving campaign strategy; Jim Rutenberg answers reader questions on anonymous donors; and a dangerous form of escapism in Gaza.

title: The South Korean Grand Prix Is On
description: The Korean International Circuit announced today that the Korean Grand Prix circuit had passed inspection and would take place as scheduled on Oct. 24, for the first time ever. Charlie Whiting, the technical delegate from the International Automobile Federation, inspected the new circuit in Yeongam, South Korea, this week to make sure it was up to the standards of his group.

title: The South Korean Grand Prix Is On
description: The Korean International Circuit announced today that the Korean Grand Prix circuit had passed inspection and would take place as scheduled on Oct. 24, for the first time ever. Charlie Whiting, the technical delegate from the International Automobile Federation, inspected the new circuit in Yeongam, South Korea, this week to make sure it was up to the standards of his group.

title: Your Comments on Admissions Essays
description: One of the pleasures of editing The Choice occurs when readers lob in level-headed comments borne of experience. Many of the responses to Dave Marcuss post on Monday about essay-writing would have surely helped me as a high school senior applying to college (yes, a long time ago, in the mid-1980s) and may yet help my own children, whose college application deadlines are, mercifully, still years away.

title: Glenn Close to Appear in The Normal Heart
description: The major female role in Larry Kramers Normal Heart has been filled for the starry Broadway reading that Joel Grey is directing Monday evening at the Walter Kerr Theater. Glenn Close, who has three Tony Awards (Sunset Boulevard) and three Emmys (Damages) to her name, will play Dr. Emma Brookner, the physician in a wheelchair who anticipates the AIDS epidemic and encourages the central character, Ned Weeks (to be played by Joe Mantello), to warn others of the disease.

title: Not a Hint of the Storms in the Offing
description: Condoleezza Rices memoir, Extraordinary, Ordinary People, ends where most readers would probably rather it began: with the 2000 election, the recount in Florida and the Supreme Court ruling that put George W. Bush in the White House.

title: Training the Afghan Army
description: Efforts to produce viable Afghan security forces are picking up speed.

title: Transparent Fashion at Alaa
description: Cathy Horyn on Azzedine Alaas spring 2011 collection.

title: Bright Futures in Design, Tilting Female
description: COULD the car of the future look like a flock of metal butterflies, flying in formation? That is the vision of a young German designer.

title: Angle Raises $14 Million
description: 2:27 p.m. | Updated  Sharron Angle, the Republican challenging Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, raised $14 million from July 1 to Sept. 30, a staggering figure that should give her more than enough money for the final weeks of this tight race. The fund-raising figure is the latest evidence of the ability of the Tea Party movement to generate huge waves of cash for a favorite candidate.

title: Gains in Afghan Training, but Struggles in War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Long a lagging priority, the plan to produce many more highly trained Afghan troops is moving this fall at a rapid pace.

title: Transformers Bumblebee Crashes Into Police S.U.V. While Filming
description: A police S.U.V. was speeding to a crime scene in Washington on Monday when it was hit by a bright yellow Chevrolet Camaro. The crunch was captured by several video cameras, like the one that shot the footage above.

title: Critics Picks Video: Walkabout
description: A.O. Scott explores how life in the modern world can sometimes make us long for simpler times with this weeks Critics Pick, Walkabout. This Nicholas Roeg film tells the story of a teenage girl and her brother who are abandoned by their father in the middle of the Australian desert. They are befriended and saved by a young Aborigine. Mr. Scott is captivated by the films visual beauty, but beyond that he says Roeg uses the camera; wide shots, close-ups, colors and textures; to create a sense of unmediated perception as if we were seeing the world for the very first time. Have you seen Walkabout? Please share your thoughts.

title: 'A Life in the Theatre'
description: Patrick Stewart and T. R. Knight in an excerpt from David Mamet's play, which opened on Broadway at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: For Years, Chronicling the Courtroom
description: The work of Marilyn Church, a courtroom artist since 1974, has documented the great passions that have gripped Americans  Vietnam, terrorism, the right to die, the gusher of violent crime, Wall Street greed.

title: Welcome to the New York City Marathon Blog
description: With another stellar field expected for the 2010 New York City Marathon, reporters and editors from The New York Times, as well as running aficionados at all levels of the sport, will be contributing to the conversation in the run-up to the Nov. 7 race.

title: Car Wash to Pay Workers $1.7 Million in Owed Wages
description: A car wash in Upper Manhattan agreed to pay its employees more than $1.7 million for five years worth of underpaid wages, under a settlement announced Tuesday by the state Labor Department.

title: Jerry Seinfeld and Colin Quinn Prepare for Broadway, Trade Quips, Yada Yada Yada
description: You didnt think Jerry Seinfelds directorial debut would just quietly tiptoe its way onto Broadway, did you? On Tuesday afternoon, he and Colin Quinn, the star and writer of Colin Quinn Long Story Short, which Mr. Seinfeld is directing for its coming run at the Helen Hayes Theater, convened at the Snapple Theater Center in Midtown Manhattan, ostensibly to offer a preview of the show to journalists but primarily to crack jokes about the production and each other. The give-and-take between Mr. Quinn and Mr. Seinfeld, conducted on the stage where The Fantasticks is performed, was moderated by Anderson Cooper, the CNN and CBS news personality, who proved pretty adept with the one-liners himself.

title: Suspensions End, and Roethlisberger Warms Up
description: The detention-room door swung open for several suspended N.F.L. players in Week 5, but the one everyone has been waiting for has yet to walk through.

title: Q&A: Morocco for Two Professors
description: My husband and I are professors and hope to take a two-week international trip in mid-December or early January. Were interested in one that will involve archaeological ruins, interesting cultural experiences and intense natural beauty. The places weve discussed so far are Turkey, Peru, Morocco and Vietnam/Cambodia.E. S., Burlington, Vt.

title: HIICs
description: Acronym used to describe the U.S., Europe, the U.K. and Japan: Heavily Indebted Industrialized Countries.

title: Doubling Down in Texas
description: Democrats are doubling down in Texas.

title: Fed Minutes Lend Weight to Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve provided more evidence on Tuesday that a critical mass of officials at the central bank favored additional actions to reinvigorate the lagging recovery.

title: The Caucus
description: The Times's Michael D. Shear and Richard W. Stevenson take a look at the Obama administration's evolving campaign strategies for the midterm elections.

title: Luxury Sector Is Buoyed by Sedate Models
description: THE idea that luxury car sales are outpacing the industry at large may spark a knee-jerk reaction: The rich seem to be sailing right along in a bumpy economy.

title: The Fabric of Her Life | Louise Bourgeois at Hauser & Wirth
description: Louise Bourgeois was reportedly a notorious hoarder. The artist, who died this year at the age of 98, accumulated all manner of tablecloths, napkins, clothing and bed linens  a lifetimes worth of material, really  which she began to cut up and reassemble into drawings in the mid-1990s. Her Collyer Brothers tendencies aside, Bourgeois no doubt found precarious comfort in the nest of this critical mass; she grew up surrounded by textiles in her parents tapestry restoration workshop, and the act of sewing, she said, was her attempt to keep things together and make them whole. In this context, the more than 70 pieces in Louise Bourgeois: The Fabric Works, an exhibition that aptly christens Hauser & Wirths new space on Savile Row in London, are as poignant as they are vibrant. But taken purely at face value, these pieces make one lament the fact that Bourgeois never moonlighted as a textile designer.

title: TimesCast: Obama the Campaigner
description: The Timess Michael D. Shear and Richard W. Stevenson discuss how President Obamas most consistent political theme of the year has been in flux in the final stretch before the elections as the White House searches for a way to frame the message so it connects with voters.

title: Girardi: I Think We All Felt That A. J. Was the Guy for the Job
description: Once the Yankees decided to use a four-man rotation in the American League Championship Series, Manager Joe Girardi said there was little doubt who their fourth starter would be.

title: Discount Stores Crop Up in Manhattans Elite Neighborhoods
description: Benefiting from falling commercial rents and recession-driven demand, discount clothing stores are emerging from the fringes of New York real estate and opening branches along fashionable avenues and in luxury developments.

title: Gap Inc. Puts GAP Back in Logo
description: Days after unveiling a new logo for its Gap stores, Gap Inc. has bowed to overwhelming negative comments online and brought back the previous logo.

title: Hyundai Took on Toyota. Now for BMW.
description: JOHN HARMON used to drive high-end models by BMW, Cadillac, Mercedes and Jaguar.

title: Credit Is Good? Then Deals Abound
description: AS the auto industry claws its way back from the dark days of the recession, financing rates continue to fall for new cars, making them competitive against used cars, and leasing deals are returning.

title: Internet Advertising Revenue Increases
description: Advertising revenue on the Internet just broke a record, according to the Interactive Advertising Bureau and PricewaterhouseCoopers.

title: Stuyvesant Town Auction Postponed Again
description: Its hurry up and wait at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the financially troubled apartment complexes on 80 acres overlooking the East River.

title: MGMs Challenge in a Prepackaged Bankruptcy
description: 4:13 p.m. | Updated Stephen J. Lubben writes about bankruptcy and debt issues for DealBook.

title: On Our Radar: Big Fines for Lead Producer
description: Doe Run Resources, the nations largest lead producer, agrees to pay a $7 million fine and spend around $65 million to resolve violations of federal clean air standards. The St. Louis-based company will also close its Herculaneum, Mo. lead smelter, which emits 30 tons of lead annually. [Greenwire]

title: The Little Cars That Moved Europe
description: THIS little car has come a long way.

title: White House Lifts Ban on Deepwater Drilling
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration lifted the moratorium on deepwater oil and gas drilling on Tuesday, but it will be weeks or months before drilling resumes while industry and government regulators scramble to meet strict new rules intended to prevent another disaster like the Deepwater Horizon explosion and spill.

title: More Retail Buyout Chatter: Is OfficeMax Next?
description: After Gymboree announced Monday that it would sell itself to Bain Capital for $1.8 billion, analysts were quick to note that the childrens clothing store would probably not be the only specialty retailer to be scooped up in the next few months. That raised an inevitable question: Who might be next?

title: Two New Options in Florida for Gay Travelers
description: Two properties in south Florida  one new, the other reopening after an extensive renovation  are the latest entrants in the growing field of gay hotels and resorts. And while one is emphasizing large-scale luxury and the other boutique comfort, they both have the same goal: to be a place for gay tourists and locals to feel comfortable and welcome.

title: Pairings: Short Ribs in Broth With Squash and Shiitakes
description: It was definitely autumn. We were to be guests at a dinner party, the first of the season, at which the hostess set the table indoors. I would bring the main course for eight to accompany several bottles of zinfandels from Sonoma.

title: Zinfandel Steps Back From the Abyss
description: SAD to say, I dont drink much zinfandel these days. That wasnt always the case. When I first awakened to the joys of wine back in the 1980s, I was excited about zinfandel. All right, I was excited about any wine, but zinfandel in particular intrigued me. It was full of gorgeous fruit, yet rarely too tannic or too sweet. The grape was singular, grown almost nowhere but in California. It was pure pleasure, and I remember enjoying many wonderful bottles with friends.

title: Micro Machines
description: The flair of microcar designers is evident in startling details.

title: The Four-Star Roach
description: Until the scream punctured the air at roughly 9 p.m., patrons and executives of the restaurant said, Monday night was quiet and glittery as usual at Jean Georges, Jean-Georges Vongerichtens four-star kitchen and dining room on the first floor of 1 Central Park West. Diners were tucking into yellowfin tuna ribbons or gently smoked squab, talking cheerfully as staff members padded silently through the elegant, carpeted room.

title: For Baseball Archivists, a Tag Ends Every Play
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.  Most baseball fans saw it as a dribbler in front of the plate, a throw to first and the completion of a no-hitter for Philadelphia Phillies pitcher Roy Halladay.

title: Egyptians Sentenced for Negligence in Van Gogh Theft
description: Eleven employees of Egypts cultural ministry were sentenced to three years in prison for negligence that led to the theft of a valuable van Gogh painting from a Giza museum in August, Reuters reported. Among those employees whose sentences were announced Tuesday was Mohsen Shaalan, a deputy culture minister who heads the fine arts division of the ministry.

title: New Tool to Test Home Listings
description: ZipRealty, a nationwide residential real estate brokerage, recently released a new tool on its Web site aimed at helping potential home sellers decide whether to put their home on the market.

title: More Power, Less Fuel? It Can Be Done With Gas
description: FOR now, the internal combustion engine is holding its own.

title: A Tarnished Anniversary for the Suburban
description: An anniversary can be such a fabulous thing, although there is always the concern that something will tarnish it. And that brings us to the 75th anniversary of the Chevrolet Suburban.

title: Organic, Slow or Local: Exploring Food-Based Communities
description: Overview | How do communities and beliefs shape how and what people eat? And conversely, how do food values and preferences help people find and create communities? In this lesson, students examine communities that come together around shared beliefs about food and food production, and then construct their own philosophy of food.

title: Honoring Sutherland Via Satellite Radio
description: The Metropolitan Opera is honoring Joan Sutherland, who died on Sunday, with a full day of broadcasts of her recordings. The live recordings, taken from the Mets archives of its radio transmissions, can be heard this coming Sunday on the houses Sirius XM channel. They will range from a Lucia di Lammermoor of 1961 to a Trovatore of 1987, and include performances of La Sonnambula, Norma, I Puritani and Esclarmonde. The Met also said it was dedicating its performance of Les Contes dHoffmann Tuesday night to the soprano.

title: Where Are the N.R.A.s Ads? Everywhere.
description: All this talk of newfangled outside groups receiving money from anonymous donors has overshadowed some of the more traditional players. But one of them, the National Rifle Association, is coming in big.

title: DAntoni Adjusts Knicks Game-Day Schedule
description: The Knicks will probably not win an N.B.A. championship this season, but at least they can dream about it, without an alarm clock disrupting their R.E.M. cycles.

title: Chamber of Commerce Vows to Ramp Up Political Activity
description: The president of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce vowed Tuesday to ramp up his groups political activity in the face of what he called a smear campaign by the White House aimed at stemming Democratic losses in the midterm elections.

title: Mutis Ailment Said to Be Caused by Exhaustion and Stress
description: Exhaustion and stress were behind the stomach pains that caused Riccardo Muti to cancel two weeks of concerts at the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the orchestra said on Tuesday. Mr. Muti, who is in his first season as the orchestras music director, flew to Italy on Oct. 4 to consult with his doctors in Milan and undergo tests.

title: Silicon Valleys Solar Innovators Retool to Catch Up to China
description: FREMONT, Calif.  A few years ago, Silicon Valley start-ups like Solyndra, Nanosolar and MiaSol dreamed of transforming the economics of solar power by reinventing the technology used to make solar panels and deeply cutting the cost of production.

title: Hail Got Our Attention, but It Could Have Been Worse
description: Grapes. Gumballs. Molars and rabbit droppings. But thankfully, not pumpkins.

title: A Winning Formula for Nascar
description: BOB LATFORD was a genial public relations man with a battered, bulging briefcase, a love for auto racing and the ability to crunch numbers with only the aid of a ballpoint pen and a stack of bar napkins  or so the famous story goes.

title: Nice Supercar. Now Eat My Dust.
