description: ULTRA high-powered sports cars  supercars  are considered by many to be the highest expressions of vehicular performance. Schoolboys, young and otherwise, dream of Ferrari Enzos, Porsche Carrera GTs, Lamborghini Gallardos, Ford GTs and Corvette ZR1s.

title: Ellens Lemon Basil Salad Dressing
description: Ellen Greenblatt, a friend who lives in Berkeley, Calif., shared this recipe with me. Toss a green salad with this dressing, and no additional herbs will be necessary. It is perfect for chicken salad or drizzled over a cooked chicken breast; use it over shrimp, salmon or sliced tomatoes.

title: Ruthless Czar, Haunted by Doubts
description: It would not have been surprising if the director Stephen Wadsworth had said No, thanks when the Metropolitan Opera contacted him in July to rescue the companys new production of Mussorgskys Boris Godunov. This was to have been the Met debut of the renowned German director Peter Stein. The concept and designs had long been settled on, and the sets and costumes were nearly completed when, three months ago, in a huff that seemed from all reports unwarranted, Mr. Stein quit, citing frustration with bureaucratic complications regarding his visa.

title: Chile Mine Rescue Operation Complete
description: After more than two excruciating months, the rescue of the 33 Chilean miners trapped in a collapsed mine is complete.

title: Detroit Refueled
description: IT wasnt long ago that American consumers were wondering whether Detroits troubled auto companies would survive, much less prosper again.

title: Phillies Beat Yankees, in Ticket Price
description: For once, the Yankees may not be the hottest  or most expensive  ticket in baseball.

title: The Morning Skate: Early Days, Many Controversies
description: The N.H.L. season is not yet a week old, but controversy is in midseason form. If you think theres as much to cry about as cheer about so far, well, youve got company. The Panthers, for example, felt victimized in their season opener Sunday against the Oilers when Shawn Horcoff looked to perhaps kick the winning goal in with his right skate (at about 1:25 in the video below, and sorry for the commercial)

title: Dodd Backs Warren for Consumer Bureau, but
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut and one of the architects of the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory law, said Tuesday that the White House was likely to nominate a director for the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in the coming days, but he was doubtful that a nominee would be confirmed before the new Congress takes over in January.

title: Provenal Tomato and Basil Soup
description: I learned to make this soup years ago when I lived in France. If there are no fresh tomatoes at hand, use canned. The soup is delicious and silky if you thicken it with tapioca.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from France, Afghanistan and Chile.

title: Extraordinary, Ordinary People
description: Chapter One: Starting Early

title: High School Raises Cancer Awareness
description: This past weekend, the N.F.L. swirled pink into their sweat bands and quarterback hats, shoes and jerseys to raise awareness of breast cancer.

title: The Samurai Shopper | My Favorite Nose
description: Enthusiasts, gasbags and connoisseurs roam the cultural landscape with foghorns, advocating this, decrying that. We stay alert, in case profoundity happens. But yammering happens, too, and tempts us with clichs like de gustibus non est disputandum. Theres no accounting for taste, and taste depends on a variety of factors. One mans pork belly is another mans tempeh.

title: Making the Dream Trip a Reality
description: ITS a dream anyone with a passport fantasizes about once in a while: ditching everything to travel the world for a year, or at least long enough to forget about office life.

title: Why Dont Republicans Believe in Climate Change?
description: Ron Brownstein and Bill McKibben both have pieces up lamenting the ascendancy of climate change skepticism in the Republican Party. While McKibben ponders the intellectual roots of this phenomenon (a subject I touched on, as he notes, in a column earlier this year), Brownstein points out that the G.O.P. is an outlier among the developed worlds right-of-center parties:

title: Anatomy of a Roach Attack
description: It is among the worst nightmares of diners and restaurateurs: a roach on the table. When it happens, there are screams. And so there were at Jean Georges on Monday night. But then a finely honed roach-removal-and-memory-erasing plan went into effect. Free Champagne was involved. City Room pal Sam Sifton, over at Diners Journal, recounts the incident in all its creepy, crawly detail. Go read it.

title: Defendant in Court for Hearing at Ft. Hood
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan returned Tuesday to Fort Hood in a wheelchair and combat fatigues for a pretrial hearing 11 months after he opened fire in a base processing center, killing 13 people and wounding 32 more.

title: Latest Updates on the Rescue of the Chilean Miners
description: On Tuesday and Wednesday, The Lede provided updates in real time on the final stage of the rescue of 33 Chilean miners whose entrapment in a collapsed mine shaft ended after 69 days. The live coverage included a video feed from the mine (now concluded) and reports from our colleagues Simon Romero and Alexei Barrionuevo, who were at the San Jos mine, near the Chilean city of Copiap, along with family members of the miners and more than 1,400 journalists. To follow the rescue as it unfolded, read up the page below.

title: Looking for Answers in the Debate on Standardized Tests
description: Pop Quiz:

title: Schwarzenegger Endorses Crist
description: Modern love is expressed via Twitter, and so it was that Californias governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, tweeted his affection for Floridas governor and embattled Senate candidate, Charlie Crist, while in London.

title: At Stadium, but Far From Roar of Crowd
description: Everybody likes to go behind the scenes. About half the fun of being a journalist is having somebody open a door and give you a story or a fact.

title: Explosives Found in Cemetery Are Many Years Old
description: The C-4 explosives recovered in an East Village cemetery over the weekend were made more than a dozen years ago, initial police tests show.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from France, Afghanistan and Chile.

title: Howard Jacobson Wins Booker Prize
description: The Manchester-born author Howard Jacobson won the Man Booker Prize, Britains most prestigious literary award, on Tuesday night for The Finkler Question, a witty novel about a friendship between a radio producer and a philosopher and the questions of religion it brings. Mr. Jacobson, 68, beat out C, by Tom McCarthy, widely considered the favorite to win. The Man Booker Prize is given every year to a novel by an author in Britain, Ireland or the Commonwealth nations.

title: SarahPAC Spreads Its Wealth
description: Sarah Palins political action committee raised more than $1.2 million during the last three months, giving her the freedom to spread her wealth to like-minded candidates.

title: Obamas Haste On Resumed Offshore Drilling
description: In the face of Americas oil addiction two things seem to fade fast  the wallet shock of $4-a-gallon gasoline and the political impact of an oil spill, once its stanched.

title: In Ethiopia, a System Built to Go the Distance
description: When Haile Gebrselassie, the world-record holder from Ethiopia, competes in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7, he will be both a star and a growing anachronism.

title: What to Do About Phantom Charges on Your Phone Bill
description: The news of Verizons phantom charges and pending consumer payout has sent smart consumers to pore over their phone bills. But before your blood pressure peaks, be aware that one apparent phantom charge is harmless and carries no cost, though another, which appears to be a scam, shouldnt be ignored.

title: Violent Fans Force Italy-Serbia Match to Be Suspended
description: Oct. 12, 11:32 a.m. |UEFA Investigating

title: Whos the Unnamed and Frustrated Wall St. Chief?
description: It doesnt take an in-depth investigation to figure out that many top Wall Street executives arent too pleased with the Obama administration. But whod be so bold as to venture their opinion semi-publicly?

title: Young Patriots
description: Like a latter-day John Hughes, Hedi Slimane is smitten with American adolescence. Since moving to Los Angeles after stepping down as the influential designer of Dior Homme, Slimane has exalted an idealized version of youth in his myriad photography and art projects. In I Love U.S.A., a new video shot exclusively for the fashion e-commerce site thecorner.com, Slimane turns his lens on two teenagers he discovered at the Coachella rock festival. The premise of the improvised storyline is undeniably abstruse  the star-crossed lovers are a confused cheerleader and her cello-playing paramour, who wears a wolf mask  but as tender as any lingering shot of Molly Ringwalds face.

title: 'La Bete'
description: Mark Rylance, David Hyde Pierce and Stephen Ouimette in an excerpt from the Broadway revival of David Hirson's play. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Attention, Ladies: After Heartbreak Can Come Redemption
description: Mary J Blige lives to sing about obstacles overcome, so maybe she was just setting herself one more obstacle with the way she built her set at Radio City Music Hall on Monday night.

title: Fame to Affect Adjustments for Miners
description: The ordinary miners are long gone, left behind in another lifetime.

title: A Wall of Coverage Planned for Mine Rescue
description: Cable news networks in the United States are on standby for the mine rescue in Chile that has captured the worlds attention, and some say they will provide wall-to-wall coverage when the rescues are under way.

title: The Broadway Thats Forever Buoyant
description: Exclamations of adoration regularly erupted at Fridays opening-night performance of Marilyn Mayes new show, Her Own Kind of Broadway, at the packed Metropolitan Room. Ms. Maye, who at 82 personifies a hardy, upbeat show-business trouper, swung Broadway standards in a dark, honeyed voice untouched by the years; she even shimmied and executed a single high kick precisely timed to a drumbeat.

title: Evolving Movements That Flow Through Time and Into Infinity
description: The premise of Russell Dumass dance for the time being, performed at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Sunday, is that it is not the finite, finished artwork that we, as audiences, are accustomed to seeing (or at least think that were seeing). Not that dance is anything but polished and accomplished. Its smoothly unfolding flow of movement holds no improvisation or uncertainty.

title: Casting an Opponent as The Taxman
description: Chris Coons is The Taxman.

title: Baroque Styles Evolution Is Traced Across Europe
description: Last year the Juilliard School had some listeners puzzling over the name of its new resident period-instrument ensemble, JuilliArd415, which plays on the A in Juilliard and the fact that a common Baroque tuning put the pitch of an A at 415 cycles per second rather than at the higher, modern pitch, 440.

title: The Finkler Question
description: Chapter 1

title: Bad Day for Former No. 1 Quarterback Picks
description: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

title: After Paladinos Remarks, a Barrage of Comments
description: Earlier this week, Carl P. Paladino, the Republican candidate for New York governor, defended comments he had made criticizing homosexuality, including some in which he said the citys gay pride parade was not a place for children  he said the parade featured participants grinding at each other and doing these gyrations, something he called disgusting.

title: Amazon Introduces a Format for Shorter E-Books
description: E-readers and smartphones have brought big changes to the publishing industry, but Amazon.com is aiming to bring some more with a new format for shorter and cheaper e-books.

title: Jay-Z: Please Vote, Young Men and Women
description: Jay-Z is looking for an encore.

title: Seoul Feud
description: In Korea, at the World Knowledge Forum. First up, a panel with Niall Ferguson.

title: Japanese Game Maker on a Buying Spree
description: TOKYO  DeNA, a Japanese social game company, said on Tuesday that it would acquire Ngmoco, a Silicon Valley iPhone game developer, for $400 million  one of the largest deals involving an iPhone software company and another sign that Apples products are fast becoming the hottest mobile game devices on the market.

title: The Necessity of Conservation, and of Eating Ripe, Green Bananas
description: The capital city of the Solomon Islands, Honiara, really ticks to a different clock. For all its hustle and bustle, rattling trucks, scampering feet, laughter and clamor, Honiara is on Solomon time. As hard as you may try to keep a tight schedule, time in the Solomons tends to open up and swallow itself.

title: George Clooney at the White House
description: Rarely has the power of a celebrity to draw attention to an issue exerted such a pull as on Tuesday, when White House reporters called an end to the daily briefing by press secretary Robert Gibbs to catch the actor George Clooney as he left a meeting with President Obama about the crisis in Sudan.

title: Interstellar
description: The Theory of Interstellar Trade has now been published, 32 years late.

title: Plan B Turns Out to Be Fastest Path for Rescue
description: In the days immediately after the discovery that 33 workers trapped at the San Jos Mine were alive, Chilean officials cautioned that it might take up to four months to reach them with a rescue hole.

title: From Waitress to Brothers Savior, Then Hollywood Hero
description: BRISTOL, R.I.  Betty Anne Waters still greets her lunch customers here as they tuck into pints of Guinness and Reuben sandwiches at Aidans, a pub hard by the harbor in this small, boat-building town.

title: Blackface and Bigotry, Finely Tuned
description: NO star actors. (Check.) A complex cast of characters. (Check.) A plot based on a low moment in American history. (Check.) Songs that satirize racism, anti-Semitism, and execution by electric chair. (Check.) And all told by resurrecting one of theaters most controversial storytelling devices, the minstrel show. (Check.)

title: Europe Considers a Curb on Deepwater Drilling
description: LONDON  As the United States lifted its moratorium on deepwater oil drilling Tuesday, the European Commission was on the verge of proposing a curb on drilling in extreme conditions until an inquiry into the causes of the fatal explosion at a BP rig in the Gulf of Mexico was completed.

title: Pushing the Spotlight Away From Herself
description: UNLIKE most playwrights, who get to hide in the back of the theater on opening night  if not in a bar around the corner  Lisa Kron has spent most of her career performing in her own plays, which have frequently been autobiographical, including 2.5 Minute Ride, about her father, and Well, about her perpetually unwell but nonetheless redoubtable mother, which had a Broadway run in 2006.

title: Memphis Box Office Surpasses $1 Million Mark
description: Ever since winning the Tony Award for best musical in June, Memphis has been rising in box-office rankings of Broadway, and last week the show passed a milestone: Memphis grossed more than $1 million for the standard eight performances for the first time since previews began on Sept. 23, 2009.

title: A Multitasking Nun in Medieval Germany
description: Vision, Margarethe von Trottas sympathetic imagining of the life of the 12th-century Benedictine nun Hildegard von Bingen, opens with a prologue that establishes a contemporary secular distance from the films devotional medieval ethos. The members of a millennialist sect anticipating their last night on earth prostrate themselves in an abbey overnight only to awaken in the bright morning sun to discover that the world hasnt ended.

title: A Final Rescue Phase
description: For the remaining trapped miners, a short trip to the surface is at hand.

title: Xiao Ye
description: EIGHT in the evening at Xiao Ye, Eddie Huangs new restaurant on Orchard Street on the Lower East Side, and hip-hop was bouncing off the black-painted walls of the long, narrow dining room. Young men and women ate dumplings and slurped noodles, drank Taiwanese beer. They talked smack about football and architecture, smartphones and music.

title: How to Keep Facebook Groups From Taking Over Your Life
description: Last week, Facebook added a feature that seems years overdue: Members can now create small, private groups of friends.

title: Reviewing Xiao Ye
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: C.D.C. Girds for Climate Change
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have announced their first-ever direct grants to states and cities to study the potential effects of climate change in the United States.

title: Off the Menu
description: BAR BASQUE This sprawling restaurant in the Eventi Hotel, including an area with a roof that can roll back in Costa Brava weather, takes its Spanish food seriously. The executive chef, Yuhi Fujinaga (right), worked at Eighty One, Alain Ducasse and Lespinasse and, more to the point, in Spain. The  la carte menu emphasizes the Basque country but touches on other regions. Prix-fixe dinners will be prepared by guest chefs from Spain, starting with Daniel Garcia from Bilbao, from Thursday to Oct. 30. (Opens Thursday): 839 Avenue of the Americas (29th Street), (646) 600-7150.

title: About as High Tech as a Pizza Stone Can Get
description: Theres a great deal to like about the Emile Henry ceramic pizza stone from France. It can hold a 12- to 14-inch pizza in the oven, on a grill or on a stove top. It is glazed to make removing the pizza easy and, with its handles, can go to the table (on a trivet). All that is without discussing the designer colors: fig, black, red and olive. The technology is said to leave a certain porosity in the material so dough moisture is absorbed, making for a crisper crust. At 425 degrees in the oven, the crust browns nicely without overcooking the topping. The stone even doubles as a plancha on the grill, withstanding up to about 700 degrees. The maker says the pizza can be cut directly on it without damaging the surface. With some hesitation, I tried it. Not a scratch.

title: Dining Calendar
description: French Toast Samples

title: A Vegas Wedding for China and Mexico, Under the Chef Jos Andrs
description: WASHINGTON

title: Fiber Meets Flavor in New Whole-Grain Pastas
description: IVE made several concessions at my table in the name of good health, and most of them are positive. I like brown rice nearly as much as white, and a crusty whole-grain boule even more than most pale baguettes. Quinoa and millet have happily entered my dinner rotation, and whole-grain polenta is a sweet, corny delight.

title: Tri Tip Grill
description: 30 Rockefeller Plaza (49th Street), Concourse Level, (212) 664-1003, tritipgrill.com.

title: Pico de Gallo
description: Adapted from Jos Andrs

title: Jeffreys Grocery Lets You Sit and Eat
description: Restaurants with little market areas continue to proliferate. The latest, Jeffreys Grocery, opened by Gabriel Stulman and his partners, is serious and well stocked, with a little restaurant attached. It could almost be a movie set in its nostalgic perfection, were it not for the merchandise on display. Who had pink carrots in the old days? Purple potatoes? Bunches of lovage? Fat, round golden zucchini? The goods are from local farms, notably from Brooklyn Grange in Queens, and Cato Corner Farm in Colchester, Conn., which also supplies cheeses and veal. Free-range eggs come by the half-dozen in mixed colors. The shelves hold a well-edited selection of staples and condiments, including decidedly unlocal but delicious chocolate bars from Montreal. Some prepared foods  from the kitchen that supplies the raw bar, salads and sandwiches for the informal dining area beyond the retail store  are also sold. Whos Jeffrey? Its Mr. Stulmans father. (The name of Mr. Stulmans restaurant, Joseph Leonard, comes from his grandfathers.)

title: San Matteo Pizza and Espresso Bar
description: 1739 Second Avenue (90th Street), (212) 426-6943.

title: Fair Caf Liqueur Has Elegant Coffee Flavor
description: Fair Caf liqueur is not syrupy, like some others, but has an elegant, balanced flavor. The drink is distilled in the Cognac region of France, with coffee from a farmers cooperative near Chiapas in southern Mexico and Fair Trade sugar from Malawi. Its good on its own after dinner, especially with some chocolates to nibble, and it can deepen the flavor of dark rum in a cocktail. Or soak raisins in it for garnishing coffee ice cream.

title: Ties to Galleon Founder Tarnish a Legacy
description: Be careful who your friends and business associates are  especially if one of them is Raj Rajaratnam.

title: How to Make the Grim Appear Artfully Beautiful
description: Jay Rosenblatt makes friendly art films. Their subject matter may be grim  suicide, grief, violence, murderous dictators  but his constructions of found footage and appropriated narration are inviting and accessible. Hence they turn up in mainstream environments like the Sundance Film Festival, Film Forum and Cinemax (where theyre called shorts or documentaries, art and experimental being words a programmer would rather not hear).

title: Dancing With the Stars? Not if Theres Dancing in the End Zone
description: Football has become the blunt instrument of television ratings, pounding everything around it into mush. That point was proved again Monday night when an especially strong Monday Night Football game on cables ESPN, between the Jets and the Vikings (led by the scandal-tinged Brett Favre), dominated even the strongest night of network television.

title: At Google, Mayer Takes a New Job
description: Marissa Mayer, who has been Googles vice president of search products and user experience, has a new job  overseeing geographic and local services, the company announced Tuesday.

title: Left Behind
description: A growing number of photographers are using their craft to document the hidden side of the foreclosure crisis.

title: Perfect Dancing
description: Jennifer Grey (with Derek Hough, above), on Monday earned the first perfect 10s  for her tango  from the judges this season on Dancing With the Stars, as that ABC reality series topped another night in the ratings with 19.8 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The show lifted the network to first place over all. CBS ranked second, earning its best ratings in the hour at 9 for Two and a Half Men (13.2 million) and Mike & Molly (10.8 million). Fox was third, with Lie to Me (5.5 million), at 9. NBC placed fourth, earning its best results in that same hour with The Event (6.5 million).

title: BP and Arco Stations to Get Electric Fast Chargers
description: The charging company ECOtality, which on Monday announced a plan to put chargers into 12 Best Buy stores on the West Coast, has a new partner: the oil company BP.

title: The Obama Car Joke Gets Souped Up
description: The audience is getting into the act.

title: Howard Jacobson Wins Man Booker Prize for The Finkler Question
description: Howard Jacobson won the Man Booker Prize, Britains most prestigious literary award, on Tuesday night for The Finkler Question, a comic novel about friendship, wisdom and anti-Semitism.

title: N.F.L. Backs Program for Ex-Players in Need
description: Almost exactly one year since Gay Culverhouse sat before a Congressional committee and blistered the N.F.L.s treatment of its retired players, the league announced Tuesday that it would support her Players Outreach Program to help identify and assist former players in need.

title: Hit in Face by Puck, Playing It Safe for Now
description: Ian Laperriere, the pugnacious 36-year-old forward for the Philadelphia Flyers, said this week that he would not play again until he felt better. Considering that Laperriere is the type of player who has often used his face to block slap shots, that is a big sacrifice.

title: The Caucus Click: Huntersville, N.C.
Top Architects Transform M.I.T.s Campus
description: A 10-year plan costing $1.4 billion has transformed the area with 10 buildings by architects like Frank Gehry, Steven Holl and Fumihiko Maki.

title: Judge Orders U.S. Military to Stop Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered the United States military to stop enforcing the dont ask, dont tell law that prohibits openly gay men and women from serving.

title: M.I.T.s Makeover for the 21st Century
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Not so long ago, the campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was a hodgepodge of bunkerlike academic buildings, converted World War I-era factories, parking lots and even an occasional Quonset hut. But a 10-year development plan, nearly complete at a cost of $1.4 billion, has set a new mood  avant-garde  with 10 buildings by architects like Frank Gehry, Steven Holl and Fumihiko Maki, as well as a revamped streetscape.

title: All 33 Miners Rescued
description: After a long and successful rescue operation, all of the miners and emergency workers have been removed from the mine.

title: Arrest Expands Suspect Pool in Bronx Attacks
description: A 10th suspect has been arrested in an antigay attack that unfolded over two days in an unoccupied apartment in the Bronx, officials said on Tuesday.

title: A Climate Proposal Beyond Cap and Trade
description: WASHINGTON

title: Modest Gains for Democrats in Gubernatorial Forecast
description: Although weve been skeptical about the notion that the overall political environment has improved by any discernible margin for Democrats, there are some exceptions in gubernatorial elections around the country. In recent weeks, Democrats have moved into the lead in the gubernatorial race in California, while closing their deficits in other states where they once trailed badly. Likewise, while there were relatively few shifts in this weeks gubernatorial polls, the exceptions generally benefited Democrats.

title: How to Spend on Clean-Energy Research
description: 11:51 a.m. | Updated with link to proposal from three institutes.

title: North Korea: Leaders Eldest Son Faults Power Transfer to Brother
description: The eldest son of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, told Japanese television on Tuesday that he opposed the recently announced generational transfer of power to his younger half-brother. In a rare sign of discord within the secretive North Korean ruling family, Kim Jong-nam, 39, told TV Asahi that he is against third-generational succession. However, he also said there might have been unspecified internal factors that made the succession of his brother Kim Jong-un necessary. Once the presumed heir, Kim Jong-nam apparently fell out of favor after he was detained while trying to enter Japan on a false passport to visit Tokyo Disneyland. He now lives in China and Macao, where he gives interviews, but only for a hefty fee.

title: Rising Corn Prices Bring Fears of an Upswing in Food Costs
description: First it was heat and drought in Russia. Then it was heat and too much rain in parts of the American Corn Belt. Extreme weather this year has sent grain prices soaring, jolting commodities markets and setting off fears of tight supplies that could eventually hit consumers wallets.

title: How Marriage Survives
description: Washington

title: Canada: Airline Dispute Causes Eviction From Arab Air Base
description: A dispute over airline landing rights has led to Canadas eviction from an air base in the United Arab Emirates that is an important logistical hub for its military mission in Afghanistan, the Canadian defense minister, Peter MacKay, said Monday. Emirates officials said that continuing the lease was contingent on allowing Emirates Airline and Etihad Airways more than the current three flights each per week. Air Canada opposes additional flights, fearing the two airlines will use them to compete with Canadian air service to Asia, Europe or elsewhere in the Middle East.

title: The Many Faces of Antigay Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Boris Godunov at the Met
description: Photographs from the new production of Mussorgsky's opera.

title: From Ring to Social Network, Were Human
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Vietnam Build Ties With an Eye on China
description: HANOI, Vietnam  A visit to Vietnam this week by Robert M. Gates, the United States defense secretary, is just the latest step in a bilateral relationship that is at its warmest since diplomatic ties were established 15 years ago.

title: Arrests of 2 Germans in Iran Take on Political Overtones
description: BERLIN  Germany and Iran faced off Tuesday over the case of two Germans arrested in Iran over the weekend while interviewing the son of a woman whose sentence to death by stoning raised an international uproar.

title: At the Brooklyn Botanic Garden: Twins, Come On In!
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany, Unscathed, Is in Eye of Terrorism Scare
description: HAMBURG, Germany  This wealthy port city advertises its bustling canals and bridges and its towering 19th-century churches to draw visitors from around the world.

title: A Green Product, Laying Claim to the Yellow, Red and Orange
description: WHEN it comes to sponsorships, brands tend to attach their names to sporting events and arts festivals, but Marcal Small Steps, the paper products brand, has taken the unusual step of laying claim to a seasonal phenomenon, declaring itself the Official Sponsor of Fall Foliage.

title: Sony Unveils the First Google TV
description: A new line of Sony televisions introduced Tuesday allows people to use the Internet while watching their favorite shows  minus the set-top box that competing systems require. And they will be the first TVs on the market to run Google TV, Googles new operating system for Internet-connected televisions.

title: All Eyes (Especially the Yanks) Are on Cliff Lee
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

title: The Troubled Tribune
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Will Now Be Excused From Meal
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks probably will not win a championship this season, but at least they can dream about it, without an alarm clock disrupting their REM cycles.

title: Paladino Apologizes for Remarks About Gays
description: BUFFALO  Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee for governor of New York, apologized on Tuesday for delivering comments that offended gay people, even as his campaign manager provoked a new controversy by calling the Democratic nominee, Andrew M. Cuomo, oily.

title: U.S. Sues To Ensure Military Votes Are Counted
description: WASHINGTON  The Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department sued New York State on Tuesday to guarantee that state election officials take extra steps to count absentee ballots cast by military service members and other overseas voters in the Nov. 2 election.

title: In West Bank, Peace Symbol Now Signifies Struggle
description: TURMUS AYA, West Bank  Palestinians from villages like this one in the West Bank governorate of Ramallah still remember when the olive harvest was a joyous occasion, with whole families out for days in the fall sunshine, gathering the years crop and picnicking under the trees.

title: Military Base Likely Source of Explosives at a Cemetery
description: The mysterious military-grade explosives that were found in an East Village cemetery over the weekend are more than a dozen years old and were most likely stolen from a military base, the police said Tuesday.

title: Civilian Cargo Plane Crashes in Mountains East of Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A civilian cargo plane trying to land at Kabuls international airport crashed into the nearby mountains Tuesday night, and Afghan and NATO officials said they feared that there were no survivors among the eight people aboard.

title: Recipes for Pasta Dishes and Sauces
description: From The Times, more than three dozen ways to adorn your pasta.

title: A Long Road Ahead in Regaining Lost Jobs
description: At the current pace of job growth, it will take years to recover all the jobs lost since Dec. 2007.

title: Across the U.S., Long Recovery Looks Like Recession
description: This is not what a recovery is supposed to look like.

title: Transgender Woman Sues L.P.G.A. Over Policy
description: A transgender woman filed a federal lawsuit Tuesday against the L.P.G.A., arguing that its requirement that competitors be female at birth violates California civil rights law.

title: So Many People at a Parade, and Yet, Somehow, One Stands Out
description: Scene: Columbus Day Parade, Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. 12:15 p.m.

title: Reactions to Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: A federal judge has ordered the United States military to stop enforcing the dont ask, dont tell law that prohibits openly gay and bisexual soldiers from serving, as reported by John Schwartz in The New York Times. Below, gay serving and former service members give their reactions:

title: N.Y. Faces $200 Billion in Retiree Health Costs
description: The cities, counties and authorities of New York have promised more than $200 billion worth of health benefits to their retirees while setting aside almost nothing, putting the public work force on a collision course with the taxpayers who are expected to foot the bill.

title: Uphill in Wisconsin
description: When it came to the actual details of governing, Senator Russ Feingold, a Democrat of Wisconsin, trounced his Republican challenger, Ron Johnson, in a debate in Wausau, Wis., on Monday night. He knew that the new health care law will not reduce Medicare spending but will slow its staggering rate of growth. He knew that a vast majority of small businesses would not pay higher taxes if rates went up on the wealthy and that global warming isnt caused by sunspots. He knew that without the 2009 stimulus there would be at least 1.5 million fewer people with jobs.

title: New Yorks Debate Gap
description: As things now stand, Andrew Cuomo, the Democratic nominee for governor of New York, and Carl Paladino, his Republican opponent, will participate in just a single debate before next months election. Well not exactly a debate. More like a group news conference.

title: The Jets Understudies Grabbed the Spotlight
description: The final blow in the Jets latest victory came from two players who reside near the bottom of the roster and exemplify the depth crucial to the teams four-game win streak.

title: First-Round Victory on Health Reform
description: The first federal court decision on the constitutionality of the new health care reform law upheld its validity and dealt a well-deserved setback to opponents who are trying to overturn it. We can only hope that judges presiding over 15 or more other legal challenges follow the lead of this first major ruling.

title: Vice President Tries to Energize Democrats
description: PITTSBURGH  Joseph R. Biden Jr., unyielding optimist, Democratic cheerleader and vice president of the United States, wants Americans to know that the midterm elections will not be a Republican rout. And after Democrats win in 2010, Mr. Biden says, he will be on the ticket with President Obama in 2012  all that buzz about Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton replacing him notwithstanding.

title: A Conditional Go-Ahead
description: The Obama administrations decision to lift its moratorium on deep-water oil drilling in the Gulf of Mexico came with a vital condition: Each company and each rig must first demonstrate that it can contain a blowout and meet a host of other essential new safety regulations.

title: Questions Linger on Recruits Eligibility
description: Three days before official practice begins, Kentuckys national title hopes could hinge on the freshman center Enes Kanter, a star recruit from Turkey whose eligibility remains in question.

title: Nike to Replace Reebok as N.F.L.s Licensed-Apparel Maker
description: The N.F.L. said Tuesday that Nike would become the leagues exclusive maker of licensed on-field apparel including uniforms, clothing worn on the sidelines and fan gear. Nike replaces Reebok, whose agreement is expiring.

title: Robert Tishman, Real Estate Developer, Dies at 94
description: Robert V. Tishman, a real estate developer whose companies  bearing the family name since the 19th century  etched their mark on the skylines of cities around the nation, including construction of the World Trade Center, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Game 7 of 1960 World Series Will Air
description: MLB Network has set Dec. 15 as the day it will televise the recently discovered broadcast of Game 7 of the 1960 World Series, which was won by the Pirates on Bill Mazeroskis game-winning home run against the Yankees Ralph Terry.

title: Trial of Man Once Held at Guantnamo Opens
description: In the first civilian trial of a former Guantnamo detainee, the word Guantnamo was not uttered in front of the jury as the case began on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Judge Denies Bid for Mistrial in Synagogue Bomb Case
description: A federal judge on Tuesday denied requests for a mistrial from four men charged with plotting to bomb Bronx synagogues and ordered jurors to continue their deliberations.

title: Humanity Is Drawn to Scene of Rescue
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  In the unlikely community that has coalesced here in recent weeks, a television crew discussed coverage in Mandarin. A Roman Catholic priest lamented how money corrupted the human spirit. A clown named Rolly pondered the meaning of sacrifice in the Atacama desert, arguably one of the driest places on Earth.

title: State Is Likely to Ease a Rule on Extra Help for Students
description: The New York State Board of Regents is set to excuse school districts from a requirement to provide extra help to all students who fail the states standardized exams, a number that grew by hundreds of thousands after the state made the exams tougher to pass this year.

title: Intel Tries Anonymity, for a Change
description: An average laptop contains about 1,800 components, but only one garners much brand awareness from typical consumers: the chip made by Intel.

title: E.M.T. Accused of Failing to Help Pregnant Woman Is Arraigned in Her Death
description: An emergency medical technician accused of not helping a pregnant woman who collapsed and later died was arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court on Tuesday on a misdemeanor charge of official misconduct.

title: Picturing the Crisis
description: One of the ways we remember an economic crisis is through images. Think of the Great Depression, told through the black-and-white portraits of men in bread lines, or wearing placards that beg for work; of a Wall Street suit hocking his car to pay for food; of Hoovervilles.

title: Rival Bid for Liverpool
description: The marriage of the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool F.C. may be delayed. A week after the owner of the Red Sox, New England Sports Ventures, bid for the storied but financially troubled English soccer team, a rival offer has emerged. Peter Lim, a billionaire from Singapore, has offered 320 million, or about $509 million, 20 million more than New England Sports Ventures. Lim said he would buy the team using his own money, which would erase the teams debts. More at nytimes.com/sports.

title: Mantle Biography Delves Into Traumas and Myths
description: Jane Leavy, Mickey Mantles new biographer, admits her bias: she loved him as she grew up in Roslyn, N.Y., on Long Island, and always took his side when she debated her father over who was better: Mantle or Willie Mays. Facts, statistics, nothing mattered, she said. Mickey was my guy.

title: At Obama Forum, Friends Not Fireworks
description: Even President Obama called one of the questions a softball but the same could be said of the other queries he got on Tuesday night at a town-hall-style meeting streamed over the Internet to mobilize supporters nationwide for the elections three weeks away.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 12
description: A view of the day in sports, including cold water and soccer fireworks.

title: Burnett Is Hoping to Regain His Postseason Magic
description: Game 2 of the 2009 World Series was a seminal moment in the long and winding career of Allan James Burnett, an I-told-you-so of a seven-inning performance that featured his curveball at its most dazzling, his fastball at its most lethal. His tempo was quick, his mind blank. His confidence reached the upper deck of Yankee Stadium.

title: Tribune Executive Sends Explicit E-mail, Then Apologizes
description: File this under managerial donts.

title: Musicals Born on Broadway Cause Jitters
description: Broadway may keep theater fans on the edge of their seats this season: four major musicals are opening without any out-of-town tryouts or earlier runs where kinks are usually ironed out, giving audiences a rare chance to see a show jell  or not  from night to night.

title: Stand Against Earmarks Grows Lonely as Home State Sees a Need
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C.  Mike Murphree is as sympathetic as anyone to Senator Jim DeMint and his crusade against earmarks, those pet projects financed by Congress, usually out of the public eye. Mr. Murphree is chairman of the Charleston Tea Party and sees earmarks as a root cause of overspending and political corruption.

title: GMAC Mortgage Expands Review of Its Foreclosures
description: Amid growing inquiries by law enforcement into dubious paperwork by home lenders, one of the nations largest, GMAC Mortgage, said Tuesday that it was expanding its review of foreclosures to all 50 states.

title: For North Dakota Cattle, a One-Way Trip to Asia
description: More than a hundred cows boarded a plane in North Dakota on Tuesday with a one-way ticket to Kazakhstan.

title: Build Em and Theyll Come
description: Kishore Mahbubani, the dean of the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy at the National University of Singapore, is over for tea and I am telling him about what I consider to be the most exciting, moon-shot-quality, high-aspiration initiative proposed by President Obama that no one has heard of. Its a plan to set up eight innovation hubs to solve the eight biggest energy problems in the world. But I explain that the program has not been fully funded yet because Congress, concerned about every dime we spend these days, is reluctant to appropriate the full $25 million for each center, let alone for all eight at once, so only three are moving ahead. But Kishore interrupts me midsentence.

title: Wednesday: You Are Here
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Earworm alert! That Glen Campbell song at 57 Across does tend to get stuck in ones cranium. Its a gentle ballad about a really big football player who hunkers down near a football, waits for it to be snapped, and then bangs as hard as he can into the nearest player wearing different-colored clothes. Or, at least thats the clever conceit of this Wednesday crossword by Alan Arbesfeld. Other theme answers are about other linemen  a CENTER on a spree, a hostile and antagonistic END, and a GUARD for a soccer legend.

title: From Mamet, a Backstage Bouquet
description: The words delicate and David Mamet seldom appear in close proximity. Mr. Mamet, after all, is widely regarded as the macho man of American theater, a two-fisted dispenser of high-testosterone dialogue and ugly truths. As a playwright, he has never been a doily maker.

description: The marriage of the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool F.C. may be delayed.

title: Lottery Numbers
Chileans in New York Cheer Miners
description: It was business as usual on Restaurant Row in Manhattan on Tuesday night as the theater crowd nibbled on entrees and clinked glasses. But inside Pomaire, a Chilean restaurant on West 46th Street, toasts had an altogether different meaning as patrons gathered, transfixed by the evenings main attraction: the daring effort to rescue 33 men trapped inside a mine in northern Chile.

title: After 28 Years, a Congressman on the Ropes
description: FORT MILL, S.C.  Representative John M. Spratt Jr., a Democrat who has managed to be elected and re-elected in this increasingly red district since 1982, climbed slowly to the podium at a Democratic Party fish fry on Monday night. A couple of hundred party loyalists had finished their Calabash fried shrimp and rose to give him a standing ovation.

title: Same Names, Changed Turf

description: NEW ORLEANS  Standing on the sidewalk a couple of Sundays ago, outside one of the black churches he was visiting in his district, Anh Cao, the unassuming Vietnamese-American former seminarian who is running for re-election to Congress as a Republican here, considered the days big news.

title: Four Tough House Races

title: Classic Candidate Differences Present a Stark Choice
description: IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich.  Differences between the Democratic and Republican candidates to succeed Representative Bart Stupak are as big as the vast expanse of northern Michigan that he has represented for the last 18 years.

title: California: 11 State Buildings Are Sold to Shore Up Budget
description: A Texas investment company will buy 11 state buildings to help close a $19 billion budget deficit, California officials said Monday. The company, California First L.L.C., will pay about $2.33 billion for structures including the San Francisco Civic Center, the Ronald Reagan State Building in Los Angeles and five buildings in Sacramento, producing desperately needed revenues, said Ron Diedrich, acting director of the Department of General Services. The state will lease the buildings for 20 years, during which time it can buy them back.

title: Ups and Downs of Foreign Capital
description: Hot money (money in pursuit of short-term gains) is the bugbear of policy makers in many developing economies. Ask Brazil or, indeed, Thailand, which just imposed a 15 percent withholding tax on interest and capital gains earned by foreign investors on Thai bonds. One worry is that booming currencies will become uncompetitive; another is that easy-come, easy-go money will make economies vulnerable to booms and busts.

title: In Puerto Rico, a Rental Car as a Bed and a Closed Cafe for Lunch
description: Failure was overdue. Four months of near nonstop traveling had gone amazingly well. Cheap lodging appeared from thin air, restaurant recommendations from strangers yielded culinary gems, buses and planes ran on time.

title: Washington Schools Chancellor to Resign
description: WASHINGTON  Michelle A. Rhee, the Washington schools chancellor whose confrontations with the teachers union made her a polarizing symbol in school reform battles nationwide, is stepping down, a city official said.

title: Vaccine Case Before Justices Turns on the Language of a Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday struggled to divine the balance Congress had meant to strike in a 1986 law that established a system to compensate people injured by vaccines while barring some, but not all, lawsuits against vaccine manufacturers.

title: For Politicians and Pundits, Tough Year for Predictions
description: An unusually large number of House races are competitive this year, contributing to an environment of uncertainly for candidates and political analysts.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  With the stakes  and tempers  running high, Meg Whitman and Jerry Brown clashed on issues both substantive and scandalous in the final debate of the hard-fought and closely watched California governors race on Tuesday night.

description: Behind the scenes with President Barack Obama.

title: Education of a President
description: On a busy afternoon in the West Wing late last month, President Barack Obama seemed relaxed and unhurried as he sat down in a newly reupholstered brown leather chair in the Oval Office. He had just returned from the East Room, where he signed the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010  using eight pens so he could give away as many as possible. The act will be his administrations last piece of significant economic legislation before voters deliver their verdict on his first two years in office. For all intents and purposes, the first chapter of Obamas presidency has ended. On Election Day, the next chapter will begin.

title: Robert Goodnough, Painter Who Eluded Categories, Dies at 92
description: Robert Goodnough, a painter whose stylistic evolution from vibrant, Cubist-inspired abstractions to Color Field canvases made him one of the least definable members of the second-generation Abstract Expressionists, died on Oct. 2 in White Plains. He was 92 and lived in Thornwood, N.Y.

title: F.C.C. Wants to Stop Cellphone Bill Shock
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission will propose rules on Thursday requiring mobile phone companies to alert customers by voice or text message when they are have reached monthly usage limits and are about to incur extra charges, the commissions chairman said Tuesday.

title: Phys Ed: Do Marathons Hurt Your Knees?
description: About this time every year, with the fall marathon season at its zenith, racers in training begin to hear the refrain, You are going to ruin your knees. The idea that distance running inexorably leads to arthritis is deeply entrenched, despite the publication of a number of recent studies (detailed in a Phys Ed column last year) that have found otherwise. In one representative experiment, the knees of experienced marathoners, with multiple races behind them, were scanned with magnetic resonance imaging technology, and then scanned again 10 years later. The runners knees were and remained robust throughout that time, with few significant cartilage abnormalities. The only truly unhealthy knee in the study belonged to a former marathoner, who had quit the sport. In the years since he stopped running, his joint had deteriorated badly.

title: French Transport Workers Extend Strike

title: Timeless: Warm Cats, Cold City
description: Carl T. Gossett Jr.s name appeared in agate-type letters as credit lines beneath his photographs in The New York Times for nearly 40 years. He covered the Nuremberg war-crime trials in the late 1940s and the 1956 uprising in Hungary. In 1964, he took an exhilarating picture of ecstatic teens reacting to the arrival of the Beatles in New York City.

title: Robo-Signers Wanted: No Experience Needed

title: For Samuelson, Its One Finish Line After the Next
description: Joan Benoit Samuelson is a goal oriented woman. The 53-year-old mother and Olympic gold medalist set out to run a sub-three-hour marathon and, like she has done with so many other feats, accomplished it last Saturday when she completed the Chicago Marathon in 2:47.50. As Jere Longman reported, it was the fastest time for a woman age 52 and older, but was short of the 2:46 she needed to qualify for the Olympic trials.

title: Midterms Are a Test for Obamas Ground Game

title: Face Time | The Thunderbolt by MB&F
description: Its billed as an horological machine, not a watch. In any case, the Thunderbolt, a tribute to aeronautics, is the newest creation in a series of highly complicated timepieces from the five-year-old Geneva-based company MB&F, founded by Maximillian Bsser, a veteran of the Swiss haute watch world. The Thunderbolts twin pods, which house a power reserve and hour/minute indicators, was inspired by the 1970s-era A-10 aircrafts two cylindrical jet reactors. More than 200 hours are required to carve, finish and polish the block of titanium and solid sapphire crystal into these sleek engines. With dials perpendicular to the wearers wrist, it makes for the perfect pilots watch  or, for those ground-bound, an on-time driver.
