title: Limited Edition Chevy Camaro Convertible at Neiman Marcus
description: Nestled in the pages of the Neiman Marcus Christmas Book, the over-the-top extravaganza of price-is-no-object presents, between a $17,500 Leica M9 and a $4,500 electric tricycle is the Chevrolet Camaro Convertible. The car does not hit showrooms until February, but the eager consumer may order one of 100 limited edition Neiman Marcus versions for $75,000 next week (for delivery next spring).

title: Arts Become Latest Luxuries Monaco Offers
description: MONACO  A new opera and a couple of new exhibitions in spanking new museums have opened here in recent days, evidence of Monacos latest bid for cultural prestige. The opera was mostly a private venture, but the museums belong to the principality, where lately Princess Caroline, a longtime champion of culture, has settled again and is making the arts a priority. Even the Oceanographic Museum, one of Europes treasures and closest to the naturalist Prince Alberts heart, dipped its foot in the water this summer with a show mixing some of Damien Hirsts pickled animals and gigantic dot and spin paintings among the stupendous antique displays of nautical equipment and undersea creatures.

title: Night Watch: Poll Numbers and Campaign Financing
description: Cable news on Tuesday night was mostly swallowed up by the first rescues of the miners in Chile, and the political headlines that remained were largely about poll numbers and campaign-finance figures.

title: That Was No Lady, That Was My Wife
description: There are several ways to look at Jeff Koonss so-called sex pictures from nearly 20 years ago, a series known more formally as Made in Heaven Paintings, which is currently ensconced in the town-house gallery of Luxembourg & Dayan on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. All are equally interesting and, in different ways, aesthetically unfulfilling.

title: Wednesday Reading: Marriage Rates and the Recession
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that can hit your wallet.

title: Tribune Memo Lands With a Thud at Headquarters
description: The memo on Monday from Lee Abrams, the chief innovation officer at The Tribune Company, began innocently enough:

title: Lockheed to Sell Enterprise Integration Unit
description: Lockheed Martin announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell its enterprise integration group to the private-equity firm Veritas Capital for $815 million in cash.

title: Floccinaucinihilipilificationism: A Word as Big as the Man
description: He advised four presidents, twice served as a United States ambassador and had a tenured chair at Harvard, all before becoming a four-term senator from New York.

title: A Hero or Just a Parent?
description: During the discussion here last week about the challenges of parenting a disabled child (Is It Harder to Have a Child with Down Syndrome?), I heard from Stacie Lewis. An American living in London, Lewis has an 18-month-old daughter named May, who has severe brain damage, caused by lack of oxygen at birth.

title: Paris Exhibition Honors Nmirovsky
description: PARIS  The Memorial of the Shoah on Wednesday unveiled a vast exhibition in tribute to the French Jewish writer Irne Nmirovsky, a rare collection including a series of letters she sent months before her arrest and deportation to Auschwitz and an original audio recording of an interview she gave in 1939.

title: Kennedy Center to Honor Anniversary of John F. Kennedys Inauguration
description: On the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedys inauguration on Jan. 20, the Kennedy Center in Washington will honor him with a star-studded concert, kicking off three weeks of related performances and events. Diane Sawyer and Mike Nichols will co-host the concert, which will include appearances by Julie Andrews, Harolyn Blackwell, Herbie Hancock, Yo-Yo Ma, the Manzari Brothers, Terrence McNally, Lorne Michaels and Brian Stokes Mitchell. American Ballet Theater will perform The Dying Swan, and Christoph Eschenbach will conduct the National Symphony Orchestra in the world premiere of a composition by Peter Lieberson that features narration, drawn from Kennedys speeches and writings, to be spoken by Morgan Freeman.

title: Ciao, Amore
description: Cesare Rimini is a lucky man. He used to drive a Ferrari but sold it because Italian laws wouldnt let him drive fast enough. These days his hobby is wine. He makes it, but not for sale, just to give lucky friends. One bottle of his wine costs more than a bottle of Dom Prignon, says his daughter, Alessandra, with a laugh.

title: Show Us Your City: Neils Historic, Artistic Philadelphia
description: A few weeks ago, we asked readers to give us the local point of view by submitting a short travel video that shows why their city, town or neighborhood is amazing. Well, the Show Us Your City submissions have started to roll in. First up, Neil Nandi shares his love of history and art by visiting some of Philadelphias best attractions.

title: 36 Hours in Santa Monica, Calif.
description: WHEN Angelenos think of the perfect beach town, they think of Santa Monica. Venice (to the south) has its countercultural charms, and Malibu (up north) is celebrity central, but only Santa Monica feels homey. Residents enjoy cultural institutions, athletic facilities, and stores and restaurants of the highest order. Now, theres even more. In August, Santa Monica Place, a sprawling indoor-outdoor mall a few blocks from the beach, reopened, with offerings both high (Louis Vuitton and Tiffany) and low (a food court with priceless sunset-over-the-ocean views).

title: A Weekend in Santa Monica, Calif.
description: When Angelenos think of the perfect beach town, they think of Santa Monica.

title: Amazon Awakening
description: ILLUMINATED by a single candle, the shamans weathered face appeared kindly, like that of a sympathetic doctor, with painted red marks also suggesting a calm, fierce authority  both qualities that I would rely on during the dark and uncertain hours ahead. He sat on a wooden stool carved into a tortoise, and wore turquoise beads around his neck and a crown of crimson feathers. A table beside him displayed the modest tools of the ceremony: a fan of leaves, jungle tobacco, a gourd bowl and a clear plastic soda bottle containing an opaque, brown liquid.

title: Into the Amazonian Rain Forest
description: A local tribe has been using tourism as a means to preserve and protect its way of life.

title: Overnight in Anderson Valley, Calif.
description: Cradled between ridges of coastal redwoods and inland oaks are grapevine-draped hills.

title: California Farmland, Known for Its Drinks
description: EVEN before the first sip of wine, I was drunk on the smell of baked earth and California bay leaves. It was August and the air was hot and dry, and specked with tiny white butterflies. The hills were shrouded in straw, with green vineyards creeping up their sides. The scene was intoxicating.

title: A Desert Blooms Along Chinas Silk Road
description: AS the sun began its long descent late one afternoon in the Taklamakan Desert in the Xinjiang region of northwestern China, my traveling companions and I mounted a train of camels and wondered aloud if we would ever emerge from the dunes that stretched to the horizon. The last sign we had seen before leaving the lonely strip of asphalt was not encouraging: Entering the desert, the faded Chinese characters said, please be careful.

title: Along Xinjiangs Ancient Route
description: Much of this remote province remains a world apart from China.

title: Austrian Vineyards Are All in the Family
description: ON a July afternoon, lunch at the Denk Family vineyards heuriger  one of a number of hilltop village wine gardens in the Wachau Valley of Austria, about 50 miles west of Vienna  was served family style under a walnut tree overlooking the valley. My group had been cycling and sipping our way through local vineyards all morning; we were famished, and we were tipsy. We filled our plates with grilled meats and cold salads and washed everything down with more wine from the Denk vineyard.

title: Northwest Hotels Go Eco-Plus
description: THE Oxford Hotel is just three blocks from Drake Park in Bend, Ore., a popular gathering spot where couples and families picnic and teenagers lazily hand-paddle down the Deschutes River on air mattresses. But its mattresses of another sort that are notable at the hotel. They are all-natural  no polyester or off-gassing here  and are purchased from a supplier less than three miles away.

title: Where Restaurants Plead Their Case
description: New Yorks restaurants sprawl across a vast territory, from the pristine precincts of the multicourse tasting menu to the gritty backwaters of the takeout joint. But there is one grim corner where they all come together: the health department tribunal, a little-publicized court system that metes out penalties for violations of the city sanitary code.

title: Lazard Hires Cazenove Ex-Chief
description: 2:42 p.m. | Updated Lazard said on Wednesday that it has hired Naguib Kheraj, the former chief executive of JPMorgan Cazenove, as a deputy chairman and a senior member of its financial advisory team.

title: Former N.B.A. Star Selling at Trump Place
description: The former N.B.A. all-star center Dikembe Mutombo, who has invested millions in philanthropic causes in his native country, Congo, is selling his $4.5 million apartment at Trump Place. It is being listed by Heather E. Stein of Brown Harris Stevens.

title: Case Involving Former Curator Marion True Ends
description: ROME  The court case against Marion True, the former curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, ended abruptly on Wednesday, after a court in Rome ruled that the statute of limitations had run out on allegations that she had received stolen goods from Italy and conspired to deal in looted Italian artifacts.

title: Nominees for National Book Awards Announced
description: 12:09 p.m. | Updated

title: How to Protect Data After Laptop Theft
description: My trip to Beijing a couple of weeks ago was going fine until the cab driver dropped us off at the airport. He took our luggage out of the trunk and then got back in the car and drove away  with my laptop and a bag full of fabric still in the front seat, where the hotel bellman had placed them.

title: The Human as Bigfoot
description: I hear in the chamber above meThe patter of little feet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, The Childrens Hour

title: When the Nurse Disagrees With the Doctor
description: A recent conversation with a physician at my hospital was laced with tension about the different roles of doctors and nurses.

title: The Cap-and-Trade Blame Game
description: How much blame do President Obama and his staff deserve for the failure to pass climate legislation this year?

title: Angel Probably Wont Return to Red Bulls
description: The halftime show on ESPN2 during the friendly match Tuesday night between the United States and Colombia was pretty nondescript, except, of course, for the interview of Red Bulls striker Juan Pablo Angel  one of the clubs three designated players.

title: Franks Plane Ride Draws Criticism From Rival
description: As chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts is one of the most powerful legislators around when it comes to financial regulation.

title: Is Whats Ailing For-Profit Colleges Evident Throughout Higher Education?
description: Marc Bousquet, who blogs for The Chronicle of Higher Education, worries in his latest post that the harsh federal spotlight currently illuminating the excesses of for-profit colleges is missing similar problems at nonprofit institutions.

title: Quote Unquote | News Feed
description: Phoebe Philo tells the Financial Times about that she will never have a Facebook account. Mark Zuckerberg just shed a tear. Not.

title: Friendly Officers, Gambling Birds and Future Gods of Guitar
description: Times Up, the bicycling advocacy group closely linked to the citys monthly Critical Mass rides, wants everyone to remember that the police and cyclists werent always antagonists. Indeed, as a video the group posted on Monday attests, police officers used to help clear the way for Critical Mass rides back in May 1999. On bikes!

title: Hungarian Arrested in Sludge Spill Is Freed
description: BUDAPEST  The managing director of the company linked to Hungarys red sludge disaster was released from custody without charge, his lawyer said Wednesday, citing a lack of sufficient evidence.

title: All 50 States Start Inquiry Into Foreclosures
description: As the nations attorneys general announced a joint investigation into flawed paperwork filed to support home foreclosures, federal housing regulators urged lenders Wednesday to vet their foreclosure procedures and fix them.

title: Eyes on the Prize | Design That Does Good
description: Design isnt only about the latest cutting-edge chair or yet another must-have coffee maker. As demonstrated by the winners of two different design awards, it can sometimes make a fundamental difference in the quality of peoples lives  and can even make the difference between life and death. Just look at Longreach, the winner of the 2010 James Dyson Award. The compact, easy-to-handle buoyancy deployment system, which was designed by Samuel Adeloju, shoots an emergency buoyancy aid up to 500 feet out to sea  which could prevent some of the 150 deaths that occur each year in the United States alone when swimmers are swept out to sea by currents or riptides.

title: Research First, Cap and Trade Next
description: Updated at 2 p.m.

title: Nascar No. 37 Car Will Race With Andy Griffith Paint Scheme
description: Dave Blaney is not in contention for the Nascar Sprint Cup, but his stock car will probably get a lot of attention Saturday night during a race at the Charlotte Motor Speedway. Mr. Blaneys car will carry a paint scheme designed to evoke memories of one of the most legendary Fords to roam the North Carolina countryside, at least on television.

title: Goodbye, New York. Thanks for Breaking My Heart.
description: Two years ago, Christopher Solomon moved to New York City from the Pacific Northwest and wrote about it in the City Weekly section of The New York Times. Things didnt quite work out as he had hoped.

title: Fee Dispute Could Disrupt Fox Programming
description: Cablevision customers in the New York metropolitan area may lose access to Fox programming this weekend if the cable company cannot come to new terms with News Corporation, the owner of Fox.

title: Penney Hires Goldman for Defense Against Ackman
description: J.C. Penney has hired Goldman Sachs as an adviser as the retailer braces for a possible battle from the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman, Womens Wear Daily reports.

title: Vietnam Smackdown
description: Richard Blumenthal has said repeatedly that he misspoke about his service in the Vietnam war, but Linda McMahon isnt about to let him  or any of Connecticuts voters  forget it.

title: Plotting the Course of Alzheimers
description: Many Web sites offer help for stressed caregivers in general and information on Alzheimers disease in particular (the Alzheimers Association site is particularly comprehensive). But they dont fully harness the Webs interactivity to provide specific, tailored advice regarding Alzheimers  recommendations that necessarily change as patients behaviors and symptoms shift.

title: Manny Harris Has Impressed the Cavaliers
description: There are many cautionary tales of college stars who left early to pursue fame and a big payday in the N.B.A. When things do not work out and there is no fairy tale ending, critics are left to wonder what could have been if the player had stayed in school.

title: The Rising Incidence of Thyroid Cancer
description: Its easy to crunch the numbers on thyroid cancer and assume it is a disease fast on the rise. Incidence has more than doubled since the early 1970s, and for women, it is the cancer with the fastest-growing number of new cases.

title: TimesCast | October 13, 2010
description: The Chilean rescue goes viral; President Obama on his first two years in office and Favre scandal moves from fringe to mainstream media.

title: China Cheers Rescue Halfway Around the World
description: SHANGHAI  In a country where mining tragedies are common, there was jubilation Wednesday at a rescue operation that was attempting to lift 33 miners to safety after a lengthy ordeal in Chile. And there was a sense that China was not just sympathetic but had contributed something.

title: As China Advances, Solar Start-Ups Strategize
description: In an article in The New York Times on Wednesday, I wrote about how high-tech Silicon Valley solar companies are retooling their strategies to compete with low-cost Chinese manufacturers.

title: What to Ask About Thyroid Cancer
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: When Procreation Is a Matter of Real Estate
description: The choice to have sex has everything to do with location, at least for tiny freshwater creatures called rotifers.

title: Why a Pantry?
description: Daily, it seems, I find myself preaching the benefits of a well-stocked pantry, and of cooking a pot of beans and a pot of grains once a week or so. Heres a good example of why.

title: Selected Studies: Thyroid Cancer
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Hot Wax
description: Barbour, the U.K.-based outerwear company and holder of the warrant to supply waterproof and protective clothing to Englands royal family, has created a limited-edition collection of boots with the New England-based shoemaker Rockport. The signature rain-resistant waxed cotton used in Barbours weatherproof jackets has been hand-stitched to rough, textured leathers in three styles of boots that incorporate the advanced technology in walking comfort for which Rockport is known. Though a bit rugged for most workplaces, theyre a perfect match for the tweed pants and suits now hitting stores for the coming winter  and will most certainly weather any storm, be it in a peat bog or a concrete canyon.

title: When Will It End?
description: Campaign-weary Americans may believe theyll finally know on Nov. 2 whether Republicans or Democrats will control the next Congress, but it is possible that things may not be that simple.

title: The Many Faces of Thyroid Cancer
description: Dr. Steven Sherman is the medical director of the endocrine center and chairman of the department of endocrine, neoplasia and hormonal disorders at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. Here are the five things he thinks everyone should know about the disease.

title: Q&A With C.J. Chivers About The Gun
description: C.J. Chivers is answering your questions about his book, The Gun. The most recent questions and answers appear at the top of this post.

title: Will the Real Producer Please Stand Out
description: LOS ANGELES  Think of it as a Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval for the calfskin loafers set.

title: Finding Clarity in Ambiguity
description: Matt Eich, a freelance photographer based in Norfolk, Va., is a founding member of Luceo Images. Mr. Eich, who was born in 1986, focuses on the sense of identity found within communities. This year, he was named one of PDNs 30 emerging photographers to watch. He has also received awards from Pictures of the Year International. His conversation with Amanda Rivkin has been condensed.

title: Indie Video Arcade Pops Up in Midtown
description: Theres not a lot of free-spirited stuff going on in Midtown, Todd Patrick, the music promoter better known as Todd P, said the other day in the Showpaper 42nd Street Gallery, his new pop-up gallery near Grand Central Terminal. Eager young volunteers were hanging puppets in the window while two installation artists playing a fencing-themed video game exchanged articulate insults. So its nice to provide a place like this for people to come and hang out, he said.

title: 18 Iran Guards Killed by Blast at Their Base
description: TEHRAN  An explosion on Tuesday at an Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps base in a remote area of southwestern Iran killed 18 members of the powerful military organization and wounded 14 more, Iranian state news media reported on Wednesday.

title: How Is Technology Changing Your Classroom?
description: Teachers!

title: NATO Helping Afghan-Taliban Talks
description: BRUSSELS  NATO forces are facilitating efforts by the Afghan government to seek a reconciliation deal with insurgents, including a pledge to guarantee safe passage for Taliban leaders who have attended initial peace talks in Kabul, a senior NATO official said Wednesday.

title: Quote Unquote | Would You Like Fries With That?
description: The super model Lara Stone traces her career trajectory for Vogue UK. Um, like we believe her.

title: The Rescue on TV: Elation and Elvis
description: It was compared to a moon shot, to the airliners emergency landing on the Hudson and even to the World Cup, but for viewers awaiting the rescue of 33 Chilean miners, the vigil of Tuesday night and Wednesday was more like a difficult delivery: a long, tense and at times tedious labor, followed by the sudden, surprising whoosh of life.

title: Kebede Teases, but Tough Marathon Double Is Not in His Plans
description: Tsegaye Kebede of Ethiopia teased marathon manics Sunday after his second-place finish at the Chicago Marathon when he did not immediately discredit claims that he might run the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7. Kebede trails Samuel Wanjiru by 10 points in the race for the 2009-10 World Marathon Majors title and would have to finish at least in second place in the final race of the series in New York to win the top prize of $500,000.

title: Buddymoon
description: A honeymoon taken with friends, or two platonic friends vacationing together.

title: Documentaries (in Name Only) of Every Stripe
description: ALL I want is the truth. Just gimme some truth! John Lennon sang. Lennon, who would have turned 70 last weekend, is the subject of Michael Epsteins new documentary, LENNONYC, shown at the recently concluded New York Film Festival and slated for broadcast on PBS next month. Mr. Epsteins film is part of a surge of documentaries, some shown on television, some released in theaters, that try to answer Lennons plea while demonstrating just how tricky the pursuit of cinematic truth can be.

title: Ask an Expert About Thyroid Cancer
description: Oct. 21, 2010 2:49 p.m. | Updated Thanks for all your questions. See Dr. Tuttles first set of responses in Toxins, Genes and Thyroid Cancer.

title: U.S. Moves Against Illegal Fishing
description: A new federal rule will allow the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to bar entry at American ports to any foreign fishing vessel that has been listed as having taken part in illegal, unreported or unregulated fishing. The rule takes effect in two weeks.

title: A Bit More Ethanol in the Gas Tank
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration made a gesture of support for the ethanol industry on Wednesday, with a declaration by the Environmental Protection Agency that gasoline retailers can sell fuel blends containing up to 15 percent ethanol for use in late-model cars.

title: 44 Charged in Huge Medicare Fraud Scheme
description: An Armenian-American crime syndicate stole the identities of doctors and thousands of patients and used them and more than a hundred spurious clinics in 25 states to bill Medicare for more than $100 million for treatments no doctor ever performed and no patient ever received, the federal authorities announced on Wednesday.

title: In Chicago, Village Life in a Big City
description: Over the years, Andersonville, a neighborhood that sits far north on the Chicago city map, has retained its mom-and-pop charms.

title: Gran Turismo 5 Is Delayed Again
description: The announcement from Sony on Wednesday morning has a familiar whiff: Gran Turismo 5 delayed.

title: Berlin Tie Guy
description: It may be 11 in the morning on a Saturday in Berlins rough-around-the edges district of Kreuzberg, but Jan-Henrik Scheper-Stuke is decked out in an eye-catching yellow bow tie. A matching silk pocket square tucked into his natty blazer shimmers as he flips on the light switch in the Edsor Kronen factorys showroom. Spinning on his heels, Scheper-Stuke, who is 28, does a little Fred Astaire-style backward kick, then turns back around, brandishing a swath of purple and gold Italian silk. Then he jumps, with practiced agility, right up onto the sample table. See? he says, holding a rich, lime-green paisley up to one of the sworls in an antique wool fabric hanging behind glass on the wall. For this print, this was the inspiration.

title: The Caucus
description: The Times's Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker discuss Mr. Baker's Times Magazine piece on the first two years of the Obama presidency.

title: R.F.K. Jr. Endorses Crists Senate Campaign
description: DEERFIELD BEACH, Fla.  Robert F. Kennedy Jr. told a bagel-noshing crowd of Florida voters here today that Marco Rubio, the Republican candidate for Senate, was a Tea Party crackpot, a radical, and a sock puppet who speaks for a corporate plutocracy threatening to crush our democracy.

title: Emerging From Escape Shaft, a Pageant of Spirit
description: Victor Zamora held his pregnant wife, Jessica, in a tender, extended embrace. The moment  after his 69 days of dark separation, and in the penetrating glare of the sun and the worlds attention  was theirs alone.

title: White House Meeting for Black Journalists Doesnt Stay Off-The-Record for Long
description: The White House is usually quite good at keeping a muzzle on the media after one of its off-the-record sessions with President Obama and senior members of his administration.

title: Morning Joe Team Is Working on a Prime Time Show
description: Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski of the cable news channel MSNBCs Morning Joe are helping to develop a prime time show, Young Turks, for the flagship NBC network. Mr. Scarborough and Ms. Brzezinski are consulting producers on the potential show, Variety reported Wednesday. An MSNBC spokesman confirmed their involvement.

title: Tribune Suspends Lee Abrams for Memo
description: After sending out a memo containing some questionable links, Lee Abrams has been suspended from his job as chief innovation officer for The Tribune Company. The memo follows:

title: A Grand Homecoming and a Questioned Suspension
description: From The Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out, this blog post discusses the Lightnings visit to Montreal, where the Tampa Bay stars Vinny Lecavalier, Martin St. Louis and Simon Gagne and their new coach, Guy Boucher, have roots, and the two-game suspension handed down by the N.H.L. to the Blackhawks Niklas Hjalmarsson for his hit from behind on the Sabres Jason Pominville.

title: Swiss Wine Center Offers Tastes and More
description: Long known for its precision watches, delicious chocolates and soaring mountains, Switzerland also produces an array of white and red wines, although few are exported to the United States. One of the main wine regions is Lavaux, marked by terraced vineyards that hug the slopes overlooking Lake Geneva. (The vineyards, which date to the 11th century, are a designated Unesco World Heritage site.) So it should come as no surprise that a tasting room, multimedia center and shop called Vinorama, which opened in mid-May in the town of Rivaz, is now giving visitors access to the flavors of the areas grapes.

title: A Transgender Voice
description: Jamie Clayton, a student in the Act Out class for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender students, talks about her life as a transgender woman. (Video courtesy of Brad Calcaterra)

title: Michelle Obama Hits Campaign Trail With Soft-Sell Message
description: MILWAUKEE  Michelle Obama burst back onto the campaign trail Wednesday with a highly personal, soft-sell appeal intended to prod Democratic voters  especially women  to set aside whatever disappointment they may have in her husband and go to the polls to finish what weve started.

title: Tasting Whole Wheat Pasta
description: While Melissa Clark was researching her article on whole wheat pasta, she had Anna Klinger, chef and a co-owner of Al di L in Park Slope, Brooklyn; and Emma Hearst, chef and a co-owner of Sorella on the Lower East Side, taste some of the pastas in her kitchen in Brooklyn. I was there too.

title: TimesCast: Education of a President
description: The Timess Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker discuss Mr. Bakers recent interview with President Obama for a Times Magazine article on the first two years of the Obama presidency.

title: On Our Radar: A Solar Jobs Census
description: A solar jobs census tallied 93,000 solar power industry jobs in the United States as of August, and it projects industry job growth of 26 percent in 2011. Roughly half of solar employers planned to add employees next year, compared with just 2 percent for the private industry economywide. The report, which surveyed 2,300 solar companies, was partly financed by solar power industry groups and conducted in partnership with Cornell. [Portfolio.com]

title: Clash of the Titan: Spielberg Movies Will Duel
description: So its Spielberg vs. Spielberg for the holidays in 2011. On a morning conference call Stacey Snider, the DreamWorks chief executive, told reporters on Wednesday that War Horse, directed by Mr. Spielberg, was being moved by DreamWorks and Disney to a release date of Dec. 28, 2011. That puts it on track for a release just five days after Paramount Pictures is scheduled to release The Adventures of Tintin: Secret of the Unicorn, also directed by Mr. Spielberg. A Paramount spokeswoman did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment on the move.

title: Pictures of the Day: Chile and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Chile, South Africa and Afghanistan.

title: Reader Idea | Science Literacy and the Study of Clouds
description: This school year we are publishing a series of great ideas weve received from readers for teaching with The Times. Each idea is archived here in the blog, and goes out to thousands of subscribers in that days lesson plan e-mail.

title: Grass Fed | Ren Redzepi Speaks
description: This week, Peter Meehan concludes his epic Grass Fed postings on Ren Redzepi of Noma in Copenhagen. For last weeks, click here.

title: Keeping Score: A Matchup for the Ages
description: When the Giants Tim Lincecum and the Phillies Roy Halladay take the mound in the opener of the National League Championship Series on Saturday night, the matchup of aces will take its place among the best in postseason history.

title: Perez Hilton Vows to End Celebrity Insults
description: Perez Hilton, one of the Webs best-known gossip bloggers, says he will stop attacking celebrities and scrawling insults on photos of their faces.

title: Summit for Black Journalists Doesnt Stay Off-The-Record for Long
description: The White House is usually quite good at keeping a muzzle on the news media after one of its off-the-record sessions with President Obama and senior members of his administration. But not this week. Read more about the summit, and lack of attention it received, at Media Decoder.

title: Country Rules Again on Billboard Chart
description: For a second week in a row, country rules the Billboard album chart.

title: Big Spending by Republican-Friendly Groups
description: Republican groups outside the official party are getting inside the 2010 midterms, spending millions of dollars on ad buys with less than three weeks until the election.

title: Obama, the Attack Dog
description: David Brooks: Gail, I must say this has been a tough week for those of us who personally admire President Obama and his advisers.

title: The Firm Some Investors Like Best
description: Among investors who make their investment decisions without the help of an investment adviser, those who invest with Vanguard were most satisfied with their firm, according to a recently released study by J.D. Power and Associates.

title: F.D.A. Issues Warning on Bone Drugs
description: Updated: The Food and Drug Administration issued a warning on Wednesday linking long-term use of popular osteoporosis drugs to an unusual fracture of the thigh bone.

title: Facebook and Microsoft Team Up on Social Search
description: Bing just got a little more help from its friend, Facebook.

title: Bail Set for Student Accused of Slashing Muslim Cabby
description: The film student accused of slashing a Muslim taxi driver over the summer can get out of jail if he is able to post the $500,000 bail a judge set on Wednesday.

title: Vain Glorious | Ten Good Years = Ten Good Deals
description: Who: Anthony Logistics mens skincare company.

title: Pictures of the Day: Chile and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Chile, South Africa and Afghanistan.

title: Obama Salutes Chile and Rescue
description: Following are comments of President Obama this afternoon in the Rose Garden, as he started a previously scheduled event about a tax credit for college education.

title: Cap and Trade: The Buck Stops Where?
description: At the Economix blog, our colleague David Leonhardt examines differing perspectives on how much blame should be apportioned to President Obama and his staff for the failure to pass climate legislation this year. He also sizes up the prospects of passing legislation promoting clean energy research, which some see as a prerequisite for any cap and trade bill.

title: Stanford Loses Bid to Make Insurer Pay Legal Fees
description: Lloyds of London, the insurer, will not be on the hook for paying for the legal defense of the jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford after all.

title: Palestinian Parkour
description: Three young men in the Gaza Strip hope to escape the extreme poverty of the area by dedicating themselves to parkour, the acrobatic sport with French roots.

title: Animators Amok in a Curiosity Cabinet
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: As Apples Stock Tops $300, It Hints at Mac News
description: It seems nothing can stop Apple right now.

title: Turning Business Owners Into Stars of Their Own Stories
description: ONCE upon a time in Chicago, there lived a man named Abe. He owned a neighborhood pharmacy, Polin Drugs, and worked behind the counter. His father and two sons lent a hand. When people could not afford doctors during the Great Depression, they scraped by on Abes free advice. He kept the doors open until midnight. He knew his customers by name.

title: A Surge in Ratings as First Miners Appeared
description: More than 10 million people were watching CNN, Fox News and MSNBC as the first of 33 miners was rescued in Chile on Tuesday night, the beginning of the end of a two-month ordeal for the men trapped underground.

title: Making Movies With Laptops and Ingenuity
description: GARETH EDWARDS knew the power of the green screen, the blank matte used by special-effects artists to create computer-generated imagery. But he rejected it for his new science-fiction movie, Monsters. He learned from experience: A special-effects engineer with a background in television, Mr. Edwards once constructed a massive green screen to manufacture battles digitally in the hourlong BBC movie Attila the Hun, which he also directed. The vast crew needed, though, quickly overwhelmed him.

title: G.M. and Utilities Want to Install 5,300 Electric Chargers in Michigan
description: DETROIT  While Michigans history is inseparably linked to the gasoline engine, General Motors said on Tuesday that more than 5,300 home and workplace electric-vehicle charging stations would be installed in the state to meet the demands of an emerging fleet of plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles.

title: Whitacre Sees $20-$25 Share Price in G.M.s I.P.O.
description: Edward E. Whitacre Jr. the chairman of General Motors, said Wednesday that the automakers shares were likely to be priced at $20 to $25 in G.M.s initial public offering in November.

title: My Mom Is on Facebook
description: Weve talked about how parents might handle things when their children want to join Facebook.

title: Field Report: Market Share
description: In New York City, the push to eat locally can go only so far, allowing diners the occasional gotcha moment at restaurants that promote their sourcing. When I tasted the smooth, rich polenta at Robertas, a restaurant in Brooklyn that grows vegetables out back, I was sure Id caught them. Anson Mills, right? I asked the chef, Carlo Mirarchi, name-checking the South Carolina gristmill of choice. Hed got me: Cayuga Pure Organics, upstate. O.K. . . . Did the staff forager at Print, an upscale locavore restaurant, find the nutty freekeh (roasted green wheat berries, a Middle Eastern specialty) that anchors its vegetable plate at Kalustyans, across town? Cayuga Pure Organics again. The heirloom beans at Gramercy Tavern? Exactly.

title: Douglas Sirk Without Tears
description: THE director Douglas Sirk has become identified almost exclusively with the lushly produced, emotionally extravagant and flamboyantly hued melodramas he made near the end of his Hollywood career, movies like All That Heaven Allows (1955), Written on the Wind (1956) and Imitation of Life (1959).

title: Chicken With Freekeh
description: 1 medium chicken (about 3 pounds)

title: Spelt Sabls
description: 1 cup (4.5 ounces) unbleached all-purpose flour

title: Eastwood Breaks Another Mold
description: ALMOST every fall lately, it seems, Clint Eastwood drops a little surprise on the moviegoing public: an unheralded, modestly budgeted film about a subject that hardly seems to fit the Eastwood mold. In 2004 there was Million Dollar Baby, about a female boxer; in 2008 there was Gran Torino, about a bigoted Korean War vet, played by Mr. Eastwood himself, who forms an unlikely, heartwarming friendship with a young Hmong boy. His latest film, Hereafter, which opened Friday in New York and will be released nationwide a week later, ventures into supernatural territory, which is about the last place youd expect to find Mr. Eastwood. Hereafter concerns itself with just what the title suggests: what we can look forward to after we die.

title: A Head Full of His Dreams
description: Antwerp

title: India a Hit for Foreign Investors
description: MUMBAI, India  Two years ago, when the crisis on Wall Street reached its pinnacle, the high-flying Indian stock market fell with a thud as foreign investors took nearly $5 billion out of the country.

title: Asked & Answered: Danny Clinch, Rock Photographer
description: Judging by the company he keeps, the rock photographer Danny Clinch has led a supremely charmed life: he started his career working for the shutterbug legends Mary Ellen Mark, Annie Leibovitz and Steven Meisel, before setting off on his own. Since then, he has shot his way through a good portion of the popular music pantheon, including Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen, Run-DMC, Tupac Shakur, Radiohead and Johnny Cash. The Moment recently caught up with photographer, harmonica player and filmmaker fresh off his latest assignment a shoot for Dewars scotch. Starting on Thursday, Oct. 14, Clinchs photos can be seen at the Morrison Hotel Gallery in SoHo as part of the exhibition From Darkness to a Dream: The Images of Bruce Springsteen.

title: Finding Traces of Cinema in a Real-Life Rescue
description: Kirk Douglas starred as a former big-time New York City newspaper reporter in possibly the greatest man-stuck-in-hole-while-media-watches movie of all time, Billy Wilders Ace in the Hole, which came out in 1951. On Wednesday, like many of us, he watched as Chilean miners emerged from the earth one by one. City Room gave him a call and asked if it brought back memories.

title: In a Page Six Reign, Stars and Scars
description: FEW newspaper columns survey the citys cultural skyline as panoramically as Page Six, The New York Posts marquee gossip page, which reports equally on the goings-on in downtown dive bars, corporate boardrooms and uptown penthouses.

title: Is Samsungs Galaxy Tab a Worthy Rival?
description: The first time I laid my eyes on my shiny new iPad, I was smitten.

title: Surviving on the Front Lines
description: At the New York Times Small Business Summit, two business owners discussed networking, hiring and firing, and the role of luck.

title: To Hone Message, White House Revives the Gaggle
description: As he came to the end of his morning session with reporters, Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, was asked about Karl Roves charge that the president has an enemies list. Mr. Gibbs scoffed and said it was unfounded.

title: Sharing Online, but With More Than 140 Characters
description: The singer and guitarist John Mayer, whose prolific posts on Twitter drew nearly four million followers, shocked fans in mid-September by closing his account.

title: Can Paul Rabil Make Lacrosse Sexy?
description: PAUL RABIL, the LeBron James of lacrosse to loyal fans, was shooting. He can fire the ball at up to 111 miles an hour, faster than a slap shot in hockey and only slightly slower than an archers hurtling arrow. But this time the shot missed, hitting the top goal post and ricocheting out toward the stands. A little girl in the line of fire screamed in an accelerating crescendo, I dont want to get hit, I dont want to get killed! The ball sailed harmlessly overhead. Calming down she asked, Who shot that?

title: Witnesses Recount Horror at Ft. Hood
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  The first few of dozens of witnesses to the 2009 massacre on this sprawling Army base gave chilling testimony on Wednesday in a pretrial hearing for Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, who is charged in the attack.

title: Every Finger Tells a Story
description: THREE years ago, Sharmadean Reid, a London nail salon owner, was watching the American Music Awards when she saw Beyonc Knowles with a manicure that made her nails look as if theyd been plated with gold. I paused the television, she said. I was like, What is on her nails? Gimme now.

title: Work Wear Rebuilt for Idle Time
description: WHEN spies see each other across a room, do they flinch? Do they regard each other with quiet admiration, respecting their attempts at subterfuge?

title: Huddy, Rap Promoter, Dies in Car Crash
description: Andre Hudson  also known as Huddy or Huddy 6 a local celebrity on the Harlem rap scene who was a confidant to some of the biggest names to come out of the neighborhood, including the late Big L, Camron and Jim Jones, was killed in a traffic accident on the George Washington Bridge early Wednesday.

title: When Comic Books and Catwalks Collide
description: Who are you wearing? That overly familiar red-carpet question took on a bizarre resonance last weekend at Comic Con, a New York City convention for rabid devotees of comic books and graphic novels, film animation and video games.

title: Too Long At the Fair
description: Jack Shafer has some fun mocking the perennial journalistic lament that this or that star athlete has stayed in the game too long, that he should have gone out on top when he had the chance, that hes embarrassing himself, etc. Heres Shafers rebuttal:

title: In Rescue, from One Tight Situation to Another
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  Some of the miners rescued here said they were touched by God. Others said they were pondering new careers, like Victor Segovia, who is writing a book about the ordeal. Yonni Barrios, 50, the electrician who was tasked with keeping health updates on the 33 men during their time underground, emerged with a bit more sizzle.

title: Portable Art, Data Not Included
description: MOST of us think of them as cheap, utilitarian doodads that are about as aesthetically striking as thumb tacks and binder clips. But a new breed of flash drives  those matchbox-size storage devices that plug into your computers USB port  is challenging that no-frills image.

title: The Mine Rescue: H. Sapiens at Its Best
description: The combination of endurance, audacity, innovation and courage on display at the mine head in the Atacama Desert of Chile over the last two months  and particularly the last few days  is humanity at its absolute best.

title: Signing Up as an Organ Donor, the Easy Way
description: Last September in this newspaper, the economist Richard H. Thaler wrote an article calling on Steven P. Jobs of Apple to create an app that would enable people to quickly register to donate organs. Mr. Jobs didnt answer the call, but Raymond Cheung, an independent app developer, did.

title: Local Efforts to Help the Earth
description: EVEN as some saw The Unbearable Heaviness Of Being this summer as evidence that the globe is indeed warming, the attempt to live greener still engenders some dispute. An 82-year-old woman behind the effort to ban the sale of bottled water in Concord, Mass., plans to keep up the fight, despite challenges from the bottled water industry and the states attorney general. Raleigh, N.C., is a candidate for the Nice Try award, after a measure to outlaw garbage disposals there was repealed, preserving every citizens right to add even more gunk to the municipal water system.

title: What Henry (Could Have) Heard: Night at the Frick
description: The passion of the industrialist Henry Clay Frick for the visual arts is well documented, his legacy preserved in the Frick Collection on Fifth Avenue. Less well known is his patronage and love of classical music, explored during a program called A Gilded Age Evening in New York in the museums music room on Tuesday.

title: Financier Is Said to Accept a Ban in Pension Case
description: Steven Rattner, who oversaw the Obama administrations overhaul of the auto industry, for months resisted a settlement with regulators over his role in New York pension fund kickbacks because he did not want to be banned from the securities industry.

title: Truthiness
description: Around 4 p.m. on Oct. 17, 2005, Stephen Colbert was searching for a word. Not just any word, but one that would fit the blowhard persona that he was presenting that night on the premiere episode of Comedy Centrals Colbert Report. He once described his faux-pundit character as a well-intentioned, poorly informed, high-status idiot, and the word he was looking for had to be sublimely idiotic.

title: Rattner Said to Settle S.E.C. Charges in Pension Case
description: Steven Rattner, the former car czar, has agreed to a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over kickback claims involving the New York State pension fund, The New York Times reported on Wednesday.

title: Chasing a Fast-Fashion Knockoff
description: IT happens every season: the knockoff that sends me scrambling; the capsule collection that leads me on a treasure hunt, online and off; the bargain that Im willing to fly overseas for. Logic has nothing to do with it.

title: Melding Incongruities, as Only Those With a History Can
description: The guitarist John Abercrombie takes a measured, self-possessed approach to improvisation, so much so that its easy to underestimate the considerable chance taking in his playing. During the late set at Birdland on Tuesday night he played seated, using his thumb rather than a pick, and with only the rarest applications of pedal distortion. His demeanor was workmanlike, engrossed and inward turning, even as his solos flowed far and wide, moving forward in graceful and often unpredictable ways.

title: A Romeo Who Struts, A Juliet Who Glitters
description: Charles Dutoits position as chief conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra was always meant to be an interim job, a way for both the ensemble and Mr. Dutoit to capitalize on their longstanding relationship while the management searched for a music director to succeed Christoph Eschenbach.

title: Just Give Me Your Tired, Your Poor and Their Money
description: If the aim of black comedy is to get under the audiences skin by gouging inappropriate humor out of uncomfortable situations, then the savagery of Microcrisis is impressive indeed.

title: Neglected Gadgets on Stage
description: Ordinarily, this column is about electronics, or software, or tech culture.

title: Sworn Statements Ordered in Massachusetts Case
description: More drama in the Massachusetts governors race: A judge on Wednesday ordered three former aides to Tim Cahill, the independent candidate, to submit sworn statements on whether they shared campaign secrets with Mr. Cahills Republican opponent.

title: Journey to Kolombangara Island
description: Sunday, Oct. 10

title: Primped and Pampered Princesses of La-La Land
description: Homogenized landscapes no longer shock. Americans have become used to retail sprawl, those swaths of stores  T. J. Maxx, Starbucks, the Gap, Bed Bath & Beyond  that sprout up all over without local roots or regard for regional differences.

title: Rome Trial of Ex-Getty Curator Ends
description: ROME  The case against Marion True, the former curator of antiquities at the J.Paul Getty Museum, ended abruptly on Wednesday, after a court here ruled that the statute of limitations on her alleged crimes  receiving artifacts stolen from Italy and conspiring to deal in them  had expired.

title: Man of Steels Industrial Web, Mirroring Nature
description: Treadwell, N.Y

title: 6 Women Accuse Citigroup of Gender Bias
description: 9:37 a.m. | Updated Citigroup reviewed the lawsuit and responded Wednesday evening with a statement addressing the womens claims.

title: Take Heed: The Lyrical Poet Is on the Real Estate Scene
description: After his chart-topping hit, Ice Ice Baby, Rob turned his focus on a new hobby, buying land and flipping houses.

title: Oil Drilling and the Senate Clinch Hold
description: Its the hold that wont let go.

title: An E15 Quandary for Service Station Owners
description: 2:37 p.m. | Updated

title: Life Choreographs Art
description: FEW may associate the word innovation with the American Ballet Theater, a company that is synonymous with The Nutcracker, a work it has performed year in and year out. But on Tuesday night at the Rose Hall at Lincoln Center, dance stars, fashion luminaries and bright lights in the citys social stratosphere came out to celebrate the companys wild side: four works by young ballet dancers who had won a competition to choreograph their own pieces.

title: Old-School Electronica to Trip the Mind, Tickle the Eye and Sway the Body
description: Melancholy turns plush in the music of Kruder & Dorfmeister, the self-effacing Austrian electronica duo that performed at the Best Buy (formerly Nokia) Theater on Tuesday night, their first New York City appearance in nine years. The set moved chronologically through what their M.C., Earl Zinger, promised as their past, present and future. Their mission hasnt changed; as Mr. Zinger sang, it was to make your mind unravel and your body feel motion.But the tempos have picked up.

title: Scouting Report
description: POP-UP

title: A Rescue Mirrors the Movies
description: A Wednesday article about Chilean miners being rescued from the San Jos Mine in some ways mirrored the dilemma that Kirk Douglass character faced in the 1951 film Ace in the Hole. City Room spoke to Mr. Douglas about the rescue. More from City Room.

title: The Caucus Click: Outside Castle Rock, Colo.
A Whale of a Journey, Captured in Photos
description: If you cruise the Web you can find long-lost friends, high school sweethearts and ... far-traveling humpback whales.

title: Theater Talkback: When Page Meets Stage
description: Nobody goes to the theater to read. In our time at least, reading is usually a private, passive activity, experienced as an individual internal dialogue with a writers words. But a recent visit to Gatz, Elevator Repair Services word-for-word adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgeralds Great Gatsby at the Public Theater, set me to thinking anew about shows that meld the experiences of the reader and the theatergoer.

title: Love and Pain Relief
description: Love really can be a drug, according to new research that shows feelings of intense love can relieve pain.

title: Video Highlights: Life on the Front Lines
description: At the recent New York Times Small Business Summit, two contributors to this blog, Jay Goltz and Paul Downs, took part in a panel discussion about life on the front lines of small business.

title: Legal Tug of War Over Calder Sculpture
description: A huge motorized sculpture in Chicago by Alexander Calder, which has greeted and loomed over visitors to the tallest building in the country for 36 years, is at the center of a lawsuit that may put its future location in question. The owners of the 110-story Willis Tower, formerly the Sears Tower, want to keep the sculpture, The Universe, in the lobby, and are asking a Cook County Circuit Court judge to block the buildings former owner, Sears, Roebuck & Company, from buying it. The two sides disagreed about whether a 1994 option agreement that would allow Sears to purchase the art for half its appraised value was still valid in July, when Sears notified the current owners, 233 S. Wacker LLC, of its intent to buy. (The original agreement includes a clause terminating the option to buy upon the sale or transfer of the legal title to the tower property.) The Universe is 33 feet tall, 55 feet wide and weighs about 16,000 pounds; the plaintiffs lawyer, George B. Collins, said it would cost around $250,000 to move the sculpture. But we dont plan to move it, Mr. Collins said. We plan to win the case. Kim Freely, a spokeswoman for Sears, declined to comment.

title: Trade Officials Ponder Chinas Rare Earth Stance
description: BEIJING  As a three-week-long Chinese suspension in exports of crucial minerals to Japan continues, American and Japanese trade officials have been considering whether to file cases against China at the World Trade Organization.

title: Clash Of the Titan: Spielberg Films Will Duel
description: So its Spielberg versus Spielberg for the holidays in 2011. Stacey Snider, the DreamWorks chief executive, said in a conference call that War Horse, directed by Steven Spielberg, was being moved by DreamWorks and Disney to a release date of Dec. 28, 2011. That puts it on track for a release just five days after Paramount Pictures plans to release The Adventures of Tintin: Secret of the Unicorn, also directed by Mr. Spielberg. A Paramount spokeswoman did not immediately respond to an e-mail seeking comment. Asked about the potential collision, Ms. Snider said, We think theres room for a couple of holiday films during that season. War Horse had been scheduled for release in August 2011, and the move pushes that movie into the film awards season but will leave Mr. Spielberg in a bit of a bind as he presumably works to promote both films.

title: After Losing the Trick, Winning the Battle
description: PHILADELPHIA  At the world championships here on Monday, the Senior Teams was won by Garey Hayden and Reese Milner from the United States and Paul Hackett, Gunnar Hallberg and John Holland from England. In the 48-board final they defeated Victor Markowicz and Victor Melman from the United States, Julian Klukowski and Jerzy Russyan from Poland, Roald Ramer from the Netherlands and Shalom Zeligman from Israel by 72 international match points. The three English representatives won last years World Senior Teams in So Paulo, Brazil, defeating Markowicz, Klukowski and Russyan in that final.

title: When iPhoto Meets Kindle
Shifting Time Zones on Online Calendars
description: Today, from the reader e-mail bag, a calendrical conundrum, posed and solved:I live in Atlanta, Ga., and I dont travel often.

title: Next Stop, Brooklyn
description: A Barneys Co-op branch promises to draw even more shopaholics to the already burgeoning neighborhoods of Cobble Hill and Boerum Hill.

title: Pass-Happy Broncos Are Actually Quite Unhappy
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Denver Broncos have one of the most productive passing offenses in the N.F.L., and perhaps the most surprising. They have thrown for a 333-yard average this season, second best in a league that values passing more than ever.

title: Group Seeks Food Label That Highlights Harmful Nutrients
description: Tell us how your products are bad for us.

title: Earth Is Parched Where Syrian Farms Thrived
description: AR RAQQAH, Syria  The farmlands spreading north and east of this Euphrates River town were once the breadbasket of the region, a vast expanse of golden wheat fields and bucolic sheep herds.

title: High Court Weighs Death Row Inmates DNA Query
description: WASHINGTON  In the course of an hourlong argument at the Supreme Court on Wednesday about a death row inmates quest to test DNA evidence, the justices asked neither of the questions that people without legal training might have thought crucial: Why wont Texas prosecutors consent to the testing? And could the results show that the inmate, Henry W. Skinner, is innocent of the triple murder that sent him to death row?

title: Cat People Are People, Too
description: I only have the one and shes a rescue so its O.K.

title: The Tools You Really Need to Maintain Your Home
description: I DONT love working on my house.

title: Edward Fields Updates Designs From Its Archives
description: Wavelength I, one of 11 new rugs from Edward Fields Carpet Makers based on designs from its archives, is an update of a pattern created in the 1970s. It was part of a category of free-form designs  strong colors and big-scale motifs, said Yasmina Kossmann, the design director. They were done in wool, a high-cut pile, like a shag. It was the era of really heavy, comfortable rugs.

title: A Comedy Writer on Her New Career Making Mosaics
description: Sybil Sage, a veteran television comedy writer (for The Mary Tyler Moore Show, Maude, Alice and other gems from the written age), had been making objects with pique assiette  a French mosaic technique using broken plates  for years as a hobby, whacking china into shards to put on frames, vases and furniture for friends like Gene Wilder, Teri Garr, Lily Tomlin and Larry Merchant. She and her husband, Martin, who is also a comedy writer, had retired from television some years ago, and Ms. Sage said life was chugging along happily until 2008, when their savings were wiped out.

title: An Austin Architect Turns Builder to Get a House Done
description: Austin, Tex.

title: New Lamps From David Weeks
description: It has been eight years since David Weeks designed his first lighting collection for Ralph Pucci, but with this one  his fifth  he has finally hit his stride, he said. There are four different directions, Mr. Weeks said, and they feel well conceived and less forced this time around. My progression is at a slow pace, so it makes sense it would take this long.

title: A New Monograph on Muji
description: Muji, the Japanese manufacturer, is known for the artful modesty of its products. In fact, the company has earned a cultish following for housewares so spare and generic they turn anonymity into a high aesthetic.

title: Dwell Studio Opens a Shop at ABC Carpet & Home
description: Dwell Studio, the home accessories and furniture manufacturer, is opening its first shop, in the bedding department at ABC Carpet & Home, on Oct. 19.

title: Stretch Pants, Vertically Speaking
description: IF you are looking for a fresh fashion muse, or a way to fritter away a few minutes on YouTube before your 10:30, you can kill two birds with one stone named Shelley Hack. Sure, there are clips of the ginger-haired actress in her most famous role, as the Boston-bred Tiffany Welles on Charlies Angels, but thanks to YouTube, her greatest achievement can now be appreciated: her glamorous ads for Charlie, the 1970s Revlon fragrance. Ms. Hack was breeziness incarnate, and demonstrated once and for all the fine art of wearing wide-leg pants. And given the return of the style this fall, most inspirationally on the Chlo runway, the ads should be required viewing, not merely to savor that Charlie je ne sais quoi, or to get the jingle, sung by Bobby Short, stuck irrevocably in your head, but to get the look down. Herewith, some tips.

title: Ann Patchetts Nashville Home
description: The pink brick house on a tree-lined street is a calm home base for the novelist.

title: A Novelists Prime Nesting Place in Nashville
description: WHEN I was growing up, the joke in my family was that we moved every time the vacuum cleaner bag was full. We hoped that discontent could be cured by the packing and unpacking of boxes and so we tried it often. The most consistent home of my childhood belonged to the Wilsons, distant cousins by marriage, who let me stay with them for long stretches while other family members traveled. It was from their snug house that I rode my bike the two blocks over to Whitland Avenue, where I live now.

title: The Annual Kips Bay Decorator Show House
description: After a six-month delay, the show house opened Thursday on the Upper East Side.

title: Almost a No Go, the Kips Bay Decorator Show House Opens
description: IN New York City, real estate isnt personal, its all business: in a face-off between a childrens charity and a record-breaking deal in a down market, whom would you put your money on? Last March, the Kips Bay Boys & Girls Club took it on the chin, when the property where its organizers had planned to hold their annual decorator show house the next month was sold.

title: Long, Lean Lines
description: Mastering the fine art of wearing wide-leg pants.

title: Tumblr, Customized
description: The free blogging site Tumblr  easy to join and easy to use  makes reblogging and sharing snippets of information easy. And theres no 140-character limit.

title: A Modernist Home in Austin
description: The architect Burton Baldridge didnt just design this home  he built it too, while cutting costs.

title: Vague, Opaque and Ambiguous: Israels Hush-Hush Nuclear Policy
description: In 1986 a former technician in the Dimona nuclear reactor in Israel revealed to The Sunday Times of London everything he knew about Israels clandestine nuclear weapons program. It caused a worldwide sensation, with experts estimating Israels arsenal at more than 100 atom bombs.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Jackass 3-D. The heartwarming tale of an Ohio congressional candidate who donned an SS uniform for re-enactments.

title: Ohio Democrat Fights Party Leaders
description: The Democrat from Cincinnati is fighting back.

title: Making Peace by Serving Wings
description: IT was 2:30 p.m. on a recent Friday, and Darryl Strawberry was sitting in a brick-walled sports bar in Douglaston, Queens, down a cul-de-sac near the Long Island Rail Road station. There was no entourage, no adoring fans  just a half-finished milkshake and the remains of a plate of Philly cheese steak egg rolls.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

title: Rabbi Breaks With Paladino Over Apology
description: Well, that didnt last long.

title: Boehner Makes Pledge in Missouri Race
description: Republicans are asking voters in central and western Missouri to oust Representative Ike Skelton, the veteran Democrat seeking an 18th term.

title: Roberta Freymann Is All Over the Map by Design
description: FOR years the designer Roberta Freymann was one of the Upper East Sides best-kept secrets, quietly purveying international resort wear to a select coterie that included the actresses Isabella Rossellini and Cecilia Peck; the socialites Jennifer Creel, Heather Mnuchin and Carolynn Rockefeller; and the photographer and Italian aristocrat Priscilla Rattazzi.

title: Sales at Blu Dot and More
description: Kings Road Home, the home furnishings company, is closing its SoHo shop and having a sale, with discounts of up to 75 percent on all items, through Nov. 15 (the Bobby dining table, originally $4,485, is $3,060; the Suar wood scoop bench, regularly $2,500, is $1,250; the Casa Modern NY coffee table, originally $2,100, is $525); 42 Wooster Street (Grand Street), (212) 941-5011, kingsroadhome.com.

title: Another Democrat Says No to Pelosi
description: Representative Jim Marshall of Georgia has added his name to the list of Democratic congressional candidates who have said they would not back Nancy Pelosi for speaker if their party keeps control of the House.

title: Closet Organizers
description: JAMES AGUIAR, a former host of Full Frontal Fashion who now covers fashion shows for the Web site First Comes Fashion, recently expanded his storage space at home.

title: From 10,000 Meters to 26.2 Miles in New York
description: PHILADELPHIA  Shalane Flanagan has yet to run a marathon, but she has already felt the electric energy that envelops race morning. Flanagan rose before dawn along with the runners of the 2009 Boston Marathon to make sure she could ride in the press truck that is driven ahead of the leaders. She embraced the runners nervous anticipation.

title: Shopping With James Aguiar
description: A former host of Full Frontal Fashion hunted for closet organizers.

title: Shunned for the Senate, Martha Coakley Hits the Massachusetts Trail Anew
description: WEYMOUTH, Mass.  It is enough to give any Massachusetts voter a throbbing sense of dj-vu: Martha Coakley back on the campaign trail, extending her hand with her trademark clipped, Nice to see you.

title: EMC Takes a Big-Data Swipe at Oracle, H.P. and I.B.M.
description: Big data is like the testosterone of business computing right now. It has put technologys largest players on an aggression bender.

title: Washington Chancellors Departure Isnt Expected to Slow Public School Change
description: With Michelle Rhees decision to resign Wednesday as the Washington schools chancellor, the movement to shake up the nations public schools is losing perhaps its most visible leader.

title: An End to Israels Invisibility
description: NEARLY 63 years after the United Nations recognized the right of the Jewish people to independence in their homeland  and more than 62 years since Israels creation  the Palestinians are still denying the Jewish nature of the state. Israel can name itself whatever it wants, said the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, while, according to the newspaper Haaretz, his chief negotiator, Saeb Erekat, said that the Palestinian Authority will never recognize Israel as the Jewish state. Back in 1948, opposition to the legitimacy of a Jewish state ignited a war. Today it threatens peace.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Privacy and HTML 5
description: The language thats the backbone of the Web is changing, and its latest version, HTML 5, is already being used to create new ways of experiencing online content. But HTML 5 is also raising privacy issues. On this weeks Tech Talk podcast for The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a media reporter for The Times who has examined the implications of this new technology. Ms. Vega says that while HTML 5 offers benefits, like being able to use Web apps like e-mail when youre offline, it can also collect personal data that it stores on computer hard drives, including Web-browsing histories, blog text, photos and messages. And deleting HTML 5s so-called local storage can be tricky.

title: Time to Forget Yanks-Rangers Season Series
description: When the Yankees swept a three-game series from Texas in mid-April, the Rangers started two pitchers, Scott Feldman and Rich Harden, who are not on their playoff roster, and another, C. J. Wilson, who lost when his defense collapsed behind him. Josh Hamilton, a leading candidate for most valuable player, left New York hitting .220.

title: Israeli Minister Exposes Rift With Netanyahu
description: JERUSALEM  This week, Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman of Israel gave a dinner for the foreign ministers of France and Spain, who were here urging a West Bank settlement freeze to improve the chance for peace with the Palestinians. When the meal was over, Mr. Lieberman spoke.

title: Osteoporosis Drugs May Be Linked to Fractures
description: Certain drugs used to treat the bone-thinning disorder osteoporosis may increase the risk of a rare type of break in the hip or thighbone, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday. The drugs, in a class called bisphosphonates, are Fosamax, Fosamax Plus D, Actonel, Actonel with Calcium, Boniva, Atelvia, and Reclast (and their generic products). The types of break account for less than 1 percent of all hip and thigh fractures, and it is not certain that the drugs are to blame, but many people with these injuries have been taking the drugs. Warnings will be added to the drug labels. Patients are advised not to stop the drugs without consulting their doctors, and to tell a doctor if they develops hip or thigh pain while taking the medicines.

title: Raising Capital and Using It Well

The British bank, which specializes in emerging market lending, is planning a rights issue of $5.2 billion, net of fees, which comes just as stock markets in Asia are pumped up on cheap money from the West. The banks own valuation, long at a premium to peers, is looking distinctly high.

title: As Populations Age, a Chance for Younger Nations
description: YOU MAY KNOW that the worlds population is aging  that the number of older people is expanding faster than the number of young  but you probably dont realize how fast this is happening. Right now, the world is evenly divided between those under 28 and those over 28. By midcentury, the median age will have risen to 40. Demographers also use another measure, in addition to median age, to determine whether populations are aging: elder share. If the share, or proportion, of people over 60 (or sometimes 65) is growing, the population is aging. By that yardstick too, the world is quickly becoming older. Pick any age cohort above the median age of 28 and youll find its share of the global population rising faster than that of any segment below the median. By 2018, 65-year-olds, for example, will outnumber those under 5  a historic first. In 2050, developed countries are on track to have half as many people under 15 as they do over 60. In short, the age mix of the world is turning upside down and at unprecedented rates.

title: Mr. Strummy-Strum Tries a Synth Sound
description: FROM the window of his waterfront office in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, Sufjan Stevens can see traffic creeping along Manhattans eastern edge, just across the river. He can see the party boats and barges float by, joined occasionally by groups of kayakers. And he can see the workers at the Con Edison power plant across from his building. It looks like the set of an old sci-fi movie and emits, he says, a high, crinkly buzzing sound. Many a day has gone by where Ive done nothing but just watch, he said. He keeps a pair of binoculars on the windowsill, but doesnt really use them to spy.

title: Shakira Conquers New Arenas
description: IT was just another day in New York City for Shakira, toggling between pop star and do-gooder. She spent the early morning of Sept. 23 at Rockefeller Center for a five-minute interview on Today to promote her new album, Sale el Sol (The Sun Comes Out). Asked how she gets her hips to move the way they do, she replied, with a giggle, A magician doesnt reveal the tricks.

title: Saloni Milano NYC
description: Milans annual design week, Salone Internazionale del Mobile, turns 50 next April. As part of the global run-up to the festivities, New York will host I Saloni Milano in New York, a six-week program starting Nov. 29 that will bring a taste of the design worlds reigning extravaganza to Manhattan. Its a mini-Salone, in which 20 Italian furniture showrooms (including B&B Italia, Flos and Poltrona Frau) will host Italian Christmas exhibitions; the director Peter Greenaways Milan-centric video installation, Leonardos Last Supper: A Vision (above), which was seen at the Salone in 2008, will take over the Park Avenue Armory; and the theater visionary Robert Wilson will create video portraits of Roberto Bolle, who dances at La Scala, interacting with an assortment of iconic design objects (Nov. 30 through Dec. 18 at Center 548). Design has always been close to Wilsons heart. When I was 8 years old, he says, in the middle of the night I took all the plates and glasses out of the kitchen closet and put them back in the shelves in a designed order. Perfetto.

title: Younger Than That Now: Revisiting Bob Dylans Witmark Demos in Film
description: If every Bob Dylan song tells its own story, how do you tell the story behind the making of some of those earliest songs, and do it in under six minutes? That was the task presented to Jennifer Lebeau, a director and producer who created the documentary short above to promote the release of The Witmark Demos: 1962-1964, the latest entry in Mr. Dylans Bootleg Series of albums.

title: The Great Tenor Hope (Just Ask Him)
description: London

title: City Ballet Arrived Early, With Revelations
description: NEW YORK CITY BALLETS first fall season at Lincoln Center has come and gone, along with talking dancers and conductors. (We, and they, survived.) Until this year, when New York City Opera ceded the time slot, audiences had to wait until late November and The Nutcracker to see the company, and City Ballet often toured abroad at this time. It was invigorating to have its performances as part of the general cultural rush of the fall, and the season, which ended last Sunday, was intriguing in ways both usual  the charting of dancers progress, debuts in roles, new work  and, in at least one case, unexpected.

title: Push on Talks With Taliban Confirmed by NATO Officials
description: BRUSSELS  The United States is helping senior Taliban leaders attend initial peace talks with the Afghan government in Kabul because military officials and diplomats want to take advantage of any possibility of political reconciliation, Obama administration and NATO officials said Thursday.

title: Forget the Downturn; Punish the Lazybones
description: IN the new ABC series No Ordinary Family an affluent couple, Jim and Stephanie Powell (Michael Chiklis and Julie Benz), living with their teenage children in Modernist splendor in Los Angeles, struggle with the pressures of careerism. Stephanie is a research scientist who works 80-hour weeks and answers to barracudas. Shes the kind of person who, with the best of intentions, will plan to meet you for dinner at 8, call at 8:10 to say that shes running late and then realize at 10:15 that she wont be able to make it until possibly the next leap year. She rarely has time to talk to her husband and doesnt realize that her son has learning difficulties. All of this is presented as a problem in need of a solution.

title: Oslo Court Sentences Traders for Beating Machine
description: An Oslo court has fined and sentenced two Norwegian day traders under the countrys securities trading act for unlawful market manipulation in a ground-breaking case that pits human investors against the automatic wagers of algorithms.

title: Thursday Reading: Car Deals (if Credit Is Good)
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Planning for an Attack, and Arguing Over the Fifth Man
description: The elite units of the New York Police Department will convene on the departmental range in the Bronx on Thursday for a preparedness exercise for an attack like the one in Mumbai in November 2008.

title: Irans President Praises Hezbollah
description: BINT JBAIL, Lebanon  He never did throw any stones. But the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, clearly relished the moment as he stood a few miles from the Israeli border and delivered a fiery speech in support of his Hezbollah allies on the second day of his first state visit here.

title: Pity the Fool Who Doesnt Invest in Gold
description: The price of gold continues to rise, so it is only fitting that  of all people  Mr. T is cashing in.

title: Price Tag
description: Words daubed in Hebrew on Palestinian property allegedly vandalised by militant Israeli settlers.

title: TVs Solution to Schools Tough Reality
description: IN Waiting for Superman, the recent critically acclaimed documentary about American schools, Davis Guggenheim, the director, lingers on so-called dropout factories and academic sinkholes in poor neighborhoods. Even the facades of the school buildings seem to spell out failure, with overgrown brush, crumbling entryways and darkened windows. The schools resemble prisons.

title: Chamber Musics Busy Power Couple
description: ON a wall of Wu Han and David Finckels office at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is a handwritten chart detailing the organizations ethos. Large and small circles, each containing a goal or a directive, spill over the page in a complex web, with more cosmic injunctions  Present the Repertory, Serve the Art and Sustain the Audience  written in large print in the center.

title: Conservative Conservatives
description: Simon Johnsons post this morning mentioned that British politicians are more serious about cutting government spending than their American counterparts. For some good detail on Britain, check out Ruth Marcuss column in Wednesdays Washington Post.

title: Younger Folk, Older Folk, Noises Tempered and Psychedelic
description: Bob Dylan

title: Poetry Pairing | Oct. 14, 2010
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Democratic Contest: Go to Vegas, Meet Obama
description: Campaigns are all about selling the candidate. And nobody has been better at that than Team Obama, which is once again raffling off a chance to meet the president in person.

title: On Our Radar: Skepticism on Carbon Offsets
description: Skepticism runs high on the Clean Development Mechanism, a carbon offset program created by the Kyoto Protocol. The program allows companies in industrialized countries to earn carbon credits by sponsoring greenhouse gas reduction projects in developing countries. Large numbers of credits have been given for the construction of hydroelectric dams in China, however, which experts call an abuse of the system. [The International Herald Tribune]

title: The Week Ahead | Oct. 17  23
description: Pop

title: Night Watch: Senate Debates and Dont-Ask, Dont-Tell
