description: Almost every day now, a local debate makes national news. On Wednesday it was the face-off between two Senate candidates in Delaware, Chris Coons and Christine ODonnell, part of which was televised live by CNN.

title: Reporting From the Womens Forum
description: This week I travel to Deauville, France, to attend the sixth Womens Forum for the Economy and Society, an annual meeting that brings together influential women  and men  from around the world. Described as Davos for Women, the forum was founded by French entrepreneur Aude de Thuin, who saw a need to give voice to the other half of the population after she failed to receive an invitation to the predominantly male gathering in the Swiss Alps. The 2010 forum will focus on change in politics, the economy, the environment, global health, and the steps necessary to enable progress in all by facilitating full participation by women.

title: Wal-Mart to Buy More Local Produce
description: The local-and-sustainable food movement has spread to the nations largest retailer.

title: Video of the Rescues and Celebrations in Chile
description: Updated | 1:27 p.m. As my colleagues Alexei Barrionuevo and Simon Romero report, the 33 miners who were finally rescued on Tuesday and Wednesday from the collapsed mine San Jos mine, near the Chilean city of Copiap, have begun to tell their stories.

title: Hedge Fund Links Donors to Attorney General Nominee
description: One in four dollars raised by Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Republican candidate for New York attorney general, can be traced to a $17 billion hedge fund whose chief executive has emerged as a staunch and influential defender of Wall Street this election year, campaign records show.

title: Spark Capital Raises a New Fund
description: Spark Capital, the Boston-based venture capital firm that has investments in Twitter, Tumblr and Boxee, has created a new fund to invest in Web and digital media companies.

title: Municipal Bonds
description: I moved to Milan in 1949, when my parents left Piacenza to take advantage of the opportunities for work and advancement that Milan offered after the war. In spite of the depth of the attachment that I feel to the city in which I have built my career, I am always aware that Milan does have its shortcomings and that it lies at times in thrall to a prevailing mood of melancholy, which has perhaps altered its character and diminished its sense of optimism, its capacity to think big and retain the confidence to accomplish its ambitions. As the Italian capital of financial activity and the world capital of fashion, design and opera, Milan derives its unique strength, I believe, from its capacity to promote a continuous flow of creative ideas and harness them into successful commercial ventures. I love this city most when its sense of discipline is evident, expressed through its citizens work ethic and ability to plan on a large scale. I also love its rational approach  one driven by passion and generosity. (Its no coincidence that Milan is the center of the nations charitable sector.) I hope that the optimism and the characteristic determination of the Milanese will provide a much-needed stimulus to the public sector, because the greater ones love for a city, the more one expects from it. From this perspective, Expo 2015 could be the turning point, the opportunity to boost Milans prestige and provide the perfect arena to reassert our claim to greatness.

title: Kelli OHara to Star in Encores! Bells Are Ringing
description: Trading in her Navy uniform from the acclaimed Broadway revival of South Pacific for a 1950s telephone headset, Kelli OHara will star next month in the New York City Center Encores! concert production of Bells Are Ringing, the Comden and Green musical with a score by Jule Styne, Encores! announced on Thursday.

title: Another View: Lessons From Pecora Were Ignored
description: Michael Perino, a professor of law at St. Johns University School of Law, is the author of The Hellhound of Wall Street: How Ferdinand Pecoras Investigation of the Great Crash Forever Changed American Finance (Penguin Press), which is out Thursday.

title: Nascar Announces Second Hall of Fame Class
description: Even though David Pearson won more top-series races in his career than anyone except Richard Petty, he was not included last year among the first five inductees into the Nascar Hall of Fame in Charlotte, N.C.

title: When to Push Through the Pain Is a Difficult Question
description: Training for a marathon is a delicate balancing act for athletes who must push themselves beyond certain limits, but know when to listen to their bodies. Injuries, small and large, can derail the efforts of amateur runners or some of the best in the marathon business. This week, the two-time champion Martin Lel of Kenya and his compatriot Robert Cheruiyot announced they would pull out of New York because of injuries. Lel, who won New York in 2003 and 2007, has a leg injury. Cheruiyot, the four-time Boston Marathon champion who finished second in New York last year, has a groin-muscle injury.

title: IPad Coming to Verizon Wireless and AT&T Stores
description: Apple said Thursday that Verizon Wireless would begin selling the iPad at its stores on Oct. 28.

title: Popcast: Sufjan Stevens and Doug Paisley
description: This week on Popcast, The Timess music podcast, Melena Ryzik discusses her Arts & Leisure profile of the singer-songwriter Sufjan Stevens, who found indie fame in the middle of the last decade with albums that had lush folk sounds and firm geographical themes (Michigan, Illinois). But for his latest, The Age of Adz, Mr. Stevens made some big changes, adding layers of electronics and taking inspiration from an obscure outside artist, Royal Robertson.

title: Objects Identified: Men, Aliens and Narcissism Edition
description: Where are all the good men hiding?

title: Food Photography: The Elements of Styling
description: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce.

title: Yankees Want Steinbrenner Letters Kept Private
description: The 19 letters describe a 60-year-old story of the friendship between a collegian named George Steinbrenner and Mary Jane Elster, a girl two years his junior.

title: Keeping Score: Rangers Emerge From A-Rods Shadow
description: No matter how far the Texas Rangers go in these playoffs, they will have already passed two milestones of sorts when they take the field against the Yankees on Friday night.

title: Fasten Your Seat Belts and Embrace the City
description: I dont think the woman who flashed us the other night on West 57th Street by lifting up her shirt was in the cast of the new bus ride/city tour/improv show/New York experience called The Ride. But Im only guessing, because one business-suited passerby on 42nd Street was so intoxicated by the Broadway melodies being broadcast by our passing bus that he dropped his briefcase and leapt into a vaudeville tap-dance routine right out of a 1930s musical. And a late-night deliveryman on East 43rd Street was so caught up by the passing tours blaring hip-hop soundtrack that he spun and flipped into a virtuosic break-dance routine.

title: Restaurant Review: The Corson Building in Seattle
description: You can learn a lot about what sort of restaurant the Corson Building is by taking a trip around its Web site. One section, What We Do, is a manifesto of sorts. We work to celebrate food and the daily nourishment it provides, it reads. And there are prominent references to the food writer Angelo Pellegrini, whose philosophy, Corsons co-owner and chef Matthew Dillon said, was about taking the gourmet out of it, and just having dinner.

title: Hotel Review: Allison Inn & Spa in Newberg, Ore.
description: THE BASICS

title: Now Showing | Linder Sterlings Fashion Turn
description: Anyone who smears raw steak on themselves in public  a gesture of both feral sexuality and absurdity  owes a debt to the Liverpool-born feminist punk artist Linder Sterling. Linders menstrual jewelry (made from absorbent cotton and red nail polish) turned tampons into pretty punk-feminist totems. Her arresting collages from the 70s give girly pop teeth. (See her cover for the Buzzcocks Orgasm Addict.) And her ethereal wailing, crying and laughter as a member of the British punk band Ludus were the expression of her interest in ritual, religious ecstasy and the torment from her art.

title: Paul Reiser Raises a New Book, Familyhood, Alongside a New Sitcom
description: First came Couplehood, then came Babyhood. So where does Paul Reiser go next for the third installment of his best-selling -hood book series? Familyhood, of course.

title: Dont Wear One Colleges Sweatshirt When Visiting a Rival Campus, and Other Tour Tips
description: When I visited college campuses about three decades ago, I put on jeans and sneakers, slung a backpack over my shoulders and rode Amtrak to New Haven, Providence and Boston with a vague schedule.

title: Tribute Planned for Alicia de Larrocha
description: Alicia de Larrocha, the great Spanish pianist who died a year ago, will be memorialized in a ceremony at the Manhattan School of Music at 3 p.m. on Oct. 24, the conservatory said. Spains consulate general is also sponsoring the event. Speakers will include Ms. de Larrochas daughter, the consul general, the president of the school and record company figures. Performers will include the pianist Joaquin Achucarro, the guitarist Jorge Caballero, the soprano Theresa Santiago and the American String Quartet, the school said.

title: Farewell, GOOG-411
description: Oh, its a sad day in techland.

title: Pfizer Accused of Lack of Disclosure
description: Previously unpublished data from Pfizer shows its antidepressant drug reboxetine is ineffective and potentially harmful, according to a German research groups report Wednesday, triggering another round of debate about how much information should be publicly disclosed.

title: Beard Awards Will Not Distinguish Between Online and Print Journalism
description: Do you write about food online or in print, for a magazine or a newspaper? It no longer matters to the James Beard Foundation.

title: Going Beyond Clich: How to Write a Great College Essay
description: Overview | What makes a college essay work? How can writers reveal themselves through writing? In this lesson, students explore sample college essays and then consider advice about what separates a great essay from a mediocre or ineffective one as well as essay-writing tips. Finally, they write essays based on the piece of advice that resonated with them.

title: What Were Reading: The Burger King Kids
Could Main Street Break a Bank?
description: If you spot copies of an adult magazine being passed around bank offices this month, it may not be what you think.

title: Fewer People Choose Cobra Subsidy Option
description: Is the cost of health insurance so out of reach that even when the federal government helps out, many people still cant afford coverage? According to a new analysis by the Employee Benefits Research Institute, the answer may be yes.

title: OReilly Comments Lead to Walk Off at The View
description: An interview with the Fox News host Bill OReilly on the ABC daytime show The View turned heated on Thursday morning, prompting the shows co-hosts Whoopi Goldberg and Joy Behar to walk off the set for a short time.

title: Chefs Show Their Kitchen Battle Scars
description: Thirteen chefs share stories of kitchen cooking accidents and culinary scars in the latest issue of The New York Times Magazine. Its an entertaining glimpse into the fast-paced, intense and even abusive world of culinary excellence. But some of the lessons also are relevant to home cooks. Among the culinary cautions offered by the chefs:

title: Where the Crisis Has Wreaked the Most Damage
description: As my colleagues Michael Powell and Motoko Rich detailed recently, the financial crisis has caused longer-term pain that is expected to last well beyond the confines of the financial panic itself. It has wrought a sort of economic reset, slowing down growth for years to come.

title: Worlds Fittest Gold Bug: Mr. T
description: I pity the fool who misses this most excellent Bloomberg Television interview:

title: Chinese Fans Greet an Older, Slower Yao With Same Gusto
description: It was the welcome normally reserved for a rock star: screaming fans, waving arms, and a surge of excitement.

title: An Odd Couple: Yahoo and Goldman
description: Yahoo, which is reportedly the target  or not  of a potential takeover by AOL and private-equity firms, has been holding meetings with its bankers to prepare itself in the event it receives an offer, people close to the company said.

title: Book Shelf | DC Comics Turns 75
description: They say you should not judge a book by its cover, but maybe no one told the folks at DC Comics or Quirk Books, who have teamed up for DC Comics: The 75th Anniversary Poster Book. Inside are 100 covers from the DC archives from three-quarters of a century. The slide show contains some of our favorites from the $40 book.

title: Pogues Posts: Farewell, GOOG-411
description: Its a sad day in techland, writes David Pogue on his blog.

title: Torn Between 2 Phones, Again: Android vs. Windows Phone 7
description: Earlier this year readers who were unhappy with Apples closed app ecosystem and frustrated with AT&Ts spasmodic service asked via e-mail and Twitter if the Android platform could be a real competitor to the iPhone. In a blog post I compared GooglesNexus One phone running the Android operating system to the venerableApple iPhone.

title: Running for a Cause: Commitment Challenge
description: For four years, I talked about running the New York City Marathon. But each year I ended up curbside, coffee cup in hand, watching waves of people push themselves to the finish. I would leave the race and say to friends, Id really like to run the marathon while I live in New York.

title: For Every Rescued Miner in Chile, Hundreds Far Less Lucky
description: Skip this post if you prefer to bask in the happy ending that played out on your TV screen all day on Wednesday as 33 miners in Chile stumbled out of a tiny hole in the ground.

title: TimesCast | October 14, 2010
description: Ahmadinejad visits Lebanon; Delaware Senate candidates face off and talk of the next Pavarotti.

title: 66 Years Later, a Bronze Star
description: For more than 50 years, George Vujnovich was a mild-mannered salesman working away at his small business in Queens and living a quiet life on a quiet block in Jackson Heights. He never spoke, even to his closest friends, about his secret role organizing one of the greatest rescue missions of World War II.

title: Mozilla Taps SAP Executive as New Chief
description: Mozilla, the maker of the open-source Firefox Web browser, said Thursday that it would appoint Gary Kovacs, a veteran software executive, as its new chief executive. The appointment ends a nearly six-month search that began after John Lilly, who has been Mozillas chief executive for the last three years, announced that he would leave to join Greylock Partners, a venture capital firm.

title: Q&A: Where to Go Near Tuscany for Christmas
description: Based on the enticing Travel section article Tuscany Without the Crowds (March 7, 2010), my husband and I are planning a week in the Val dOrcia after Christmas. The problem is: we fly into Milan the week before and dont know where to go over Christmas (we will be in Milan for several days at the end of the trip). Weve never been to Venice. Any ideas?

title: British Judge Refuses to Throw Out Suit Accusing Rowling of Plagiarism
description: J. K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter books, still cannot make a years-old plagiarism charge disappear. A lawsuit in a British court accusing Ms. Rowling of partly copying a 1987 book, The Adventures of Willy the Wizard, by Adrian Jacobs, may go to trial now that a judge has turned down an application by Ms. Rowlings lawyers to dismiss the case, according to Reuters.

title: Chilean Miner to Be Invited to New York Marathon
description: A variety of windfalls  perhaps including book and movie deals and trips to Greece and Graceland may be on the way for the 33 miners who emerged after being trapped for more than two months beneath the Chilean desert. But already, less than 24 hours after the completion of the globally televised and celebrated rescue, one miner has attracted a singular solicitation: an invitation to the New York City Marathon.

title: Grand Jury to Look Into City Role in Brooklyn Girls Death
description: The Brooklyn district attorneys office impaneled a special grand jury today to look into the death of 4-year-old Marchella Pierce and subpoenaed records from the citys Administration for Childrens Services as well as from a city contractor and a hospital that had roles in her care, the office said.

title: Securing Your Laptop Before It Gets Stolen
description: If your laptop happens to be stolen, as mine recently was, it can be a big hassle to protect your data after the fact. Thats why its important to know how to secure your laptop before its gone.

title: Week 6 N.F.L. Game Probabilities
Afghanistan: The Problems With Partnering
description: PASHMUL, Afghanistan  From inside the outpost, the sounds of a gunfight were unmistakable. First the clatter of assault rifles and machine guns, then the sound of rocket-propelled grenades exploding a few hundred yards away. Finally, the report of an 82mm recoilless rifle firing off one big shell, then another, then a third.

title: Steve Fossetts Land Speed Racer Is Up for Sale
description: Steve Fossett, the millionaire businessman and adventurer perhaps best known for circumnavigating the world nonstop in a hot air balloon, was preparing to break the absolute land speed record  763 miles per hour  when he died. He was declared dead after the single-engine plane he was piloting disappeared over the east-central mountains of California in September 2007. (The plane and Mr. Fossetts remains were later discovered near Mammoth Lakes, Calif.)

title: Artifacts | Frieze-Dried London
description: Art people have their rituals, especially when it comes to international trade shows. The moment they hit a host town  say, London, where the eighth annual Frieze Art fair opened to V.I.P.s yesterday  they adopt a pattern of social behavior calculated to produce a buzz. Galleries, museums and auctions houses do their best to whet everyones appetite for spending money with openings and parties, and visiting dealers, collectors and curators try to be first to spot art that will make the world feel fresh and new.

title: Punch, the Drink of Dickens, Redeemed
description: Ask David Wondrich how he became so fascinated with punch  as in the liquid curse of many a holiday party, ladled out in portions too stinting to dull the pain of forced conversation and obligatory merriment  and suddenly youre in England. In the middle of the 19th century. At Charles Dickenss house.

title: Third-Quarter G.D.P. Forecast Revised Down
description: Speaking of slow growth, Macroeconomic Advisers, a respected forecasting firm, has just downgraded its estimate for third-quarter annual output growth to a measly 1.2 percent.

title: Derek Jacobi, Alan Rickman, Geoffrey Rush To Take BAM Stage in the Spring
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music has organized a particularly theater-heavy line-up for its spring 2011 season, including a Donmar Warehouse production of King Lear starring Derek Jacobi; the Abbey Theaters staging of Ibsens John Gabriel Borkman, with Alan Rickman and Fiona Shaw; and an Australian mounting of Gogols Diary of a Madman starring Geoffrey Rush.

title: Police Shoot Bank Robbery Suspect Near Penn Station
description: Updated, 5:47 p.m. | One day after being released from federal prison, a 69-year-old man was shot and wounded by a police officer after trying to hold up a bank branch steps from Penn Station on Thursday afternoon, police officials said.

title: Just When He Thought His Suffering Was Over, an Invitation to More
description: After running underground for two months to preserve his sanity and his body as he awaited rescue along with 32 other miners in the Chilean desert, Edison Pea may have earned himself a unique reward: a seat at the New York City Marathon or, if he desires, an entry.

title: Reader Rejoinders
description: An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words  generously emailed by co-vocabularists.

title: ArtsBeat: OReilly Comments Lead to Walkout at The View
description: Dave Itzkoff reports that an interview with the Fox News host Bill OReilly on the ABC daytime show The View turned heated on Thursday morning, prompting the shows co-hosts Whoopi Goldberg and Joy Behar to walk off the set for a short time.

title: The Doctor Is In (but Shouldnt Be)
description: One winter toward the end of my training, I came down with a cold. At first, the constant coughing and runny nose made me miserable; then they became tiring. To decrease the chances of spreading my germs, I had to tie on a mask every time I came into contact with patients, wash my hands so frequently my skin became raw and wipe down the phone receivers with alcohol when I answered a page. Unable to scratch, wipe or blow in the operating room without contaminating my hands, I learned that for a surgeon with a runny nose, there are no palatable options for the uncontrollable nasal effluvium; I had to wear two masks every time I scrubbed up for a case.

title: Why Doctors Should Take Sick Days
description: As many as 80 percent of physicians continue to work when they are sick, even though they would have excused patients in the same condition, writes Dr. Pauine Chen in this weeks Doctor and Patient column.

title: ONeal: Not Playing, Still Talking
description: Shaquille ONeal still commands the room, even at age 38, even in street clothes, even on nights when he never leaves the bench.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Lebanon, Afghanistan and Greece.

title: Screen Test: Margareth Mad
description: The Italian actress on working with Sophia Loren, her role in "Baaria" by Giuseppe Tornatore and what she loves about Milan.

title: Striking Detroit Musicians Concert to Be Televised
description: The striking musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra have won a small propaganda coup. A local television station, WADL-TV38, has decided to broadcast one of their concerts, a program on Oct. 24 at a church in the affluent Detroit suburb of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The musicians went on strike on Oct. 4 over wage and benefit cuts and work rule changes at the financially troubled orchestra. They have been playing concerts on their own, to earn publicity and money to support the strike, a common practice in such disputes. The program features Vivaldis Four Seasons and Brahms Symphony No. 2, conducted by Joseph Silverstein.

title: The Caucus
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Frank Bruni discuss how the two Delaware Senate candidates, Chris Coons and Christine O'Donnell, during their debate on Wednesday night, embodied the difficulties each of their political parties is facing this election cycle.

title: India Declares Commonwealth Games a Success
description: NEW DELHI  The Commonwealth Games, which opened 12 days ago with the world bracing for the worst, managed to conclude on Thursday without any of the predicted embarrassment or disaster. Stadiums did not collapse. Terrorists did not strike. Fears of disease went mostly unrealized. And the closing ceremony was a stirring success.

title: Electric Youth
description: For its first collaboration with the watchmakers TKO Orlogi, Henri Bendel is turning back the clock to the 90s slap band craze. Like those fun bracelets of yore, the watchs interchangeable straps come in a range of neon colors. At only $50 a pop, the watches are a wallet-friendly alternative to Balenciagas eye-catching timepieces on the runway for spring.

title: Bypassed Cellphones: Biased Polls?
description: On Wednesday, Pew Research issued a study suggesting that the failure to include cellphones in a survey sample  and most pollsters dont include them  may bias the results against Democrats. Pew has addressed this subjecta number of times before, and in their view, the problem seems to be worsening. Indeed, this is about what you might expect, since the fraction of voters who rely on cellphones is steadily increasing: about 25 percent of the adult population now has no landline phone installed at all.

title: TimesCast: The Debate for Delaware Senate
description: The Timess Megan Liberman and Frank Bruni discussed the debate Wednesday night between the two candidates for Delawares Senate seat, Chris Coons and Christine ODonnell.

title: The Young Guns of Finance
description: DealBook loves lists, and Fortune magazine gives us a scrumptious one today with its 40 Under 40ranking of businesss hottest rising stars. (This reporter has about one month until his 40th birthday  and, alas, has never made this illustrious list  so our exuberance is somewhat muted this year.)

title: We Are Not Alone
description: Heres whats happening on the U.F.O. front Thursday afternoon, a day after silver objects hovered briefly in the skies over western Manhattan.

title: And Now, a Grand Prix in Russia
description: The rumors were rife at the Japanese Grand Prix that Formula One was about to announce a deal to race in Russia.

title: And Now, a Grand Prix in Russia
description: The rumors were rife at the Japanese Grand Prix that Formula One was about to announce a deal to race in Russia.

title: Rescue May Redeem a Troubled Past for Chilean City
description: COPIAP, Chile  Though the vuvuzelas have quieted down, this desert city is still basking in the daring rescue of the 33 men trapped deep in a copper and gold mine nearby for more than two months. And for some, the triumph was a striking contrast to another set of events here in Copiap  also involving its miners  from a much darker time in Chiles history.

title: Pazzo Palazzo
description: The Italian designer Mauro Orietti-Carella believes in combining the old and the new. Several years back, he brought fresh life to Zagliani, a venerable but musty manufacturer of crocodile bags, by applying techniques he perfected in his former life in medical school, where he studied skin reconstruction  injecting the material with silicone and resin so that its stiffness gave way to a buttery softness. (The company is preparing to open its first stand-alone store, on Madison Avenue.)

title: The Morning Skate: Early Turnarounds Mark First Week
description: Its still early in this N.H.L. season but its impossible to ignore the turnarounds and successes of last years non-playoff teams so far. They have combined for 19 wins, while losing 12 in regulation and two after regulation, which is 40 of a possible 66 points. Meanwhile, last years playoff teams have won 22, lost 18 in regulation and nine after regulation, getting only 53 of a possible 98 points.

title: Actors Equity Association Names Mary McColl New Executive Director
description: Actors Equity Association, the union of more than 49,000 theater actors and stage managers, announced on Thursday that Mary McColl would become its new executive director in January 2011. In that role Ms. McColl, currently the executive director of the Cowles Center for Dance and the Performing Arts in Minneapolis, will oversee the collective bargaining process for more than 30 national and regional contracts and act as the unions representative with other labor groups and government officials. Before her position in Minneapolis, Ms. McColl was the director of labor relations for the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers. She succeeds Carol Waaser, who has served as acting executive director since November 2009, and who plans to retire next year after 26 years on the staff of Actors Equity.

title: Andy Rooney's Fall Cleaning
description: David Pogue looks at a wireless speaker for bicycle handle bars, a desk frame for an iPhone, a projector, a PrintStik, a case for an iPad and stickers for wires.

title: Judge Overrules Terror Suspects Request on Evidence
description: DETROIT  Overruling the wishes of a Nigerian man accused of trying to use explosives in his underwear to blow up a transcontinental airliner over Detroit last Christmas, a federal judge on Thursday ordered that the mans standby lawyer receive documents related to the prosecutions case. The defendant, Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, also waived his right to a speedy trial.

title: How to Bargain at Marketplaces
description: As part of my business schools program, my classmates and I recently went to China. On our trip home, many of us were carrying or wearing much fancier accessories than we had gone with. Think Rolex watches, Louis Vuitton bags and Gucci sunglasses  all knockoffs, of course.

title: Are You Sure You Dont Want to Retire?
description: Thank goodness for Dashboard, Gene Markss new blog channel here at Youre the Boss. If not for his efforts to mine the information superhighway for the rest of us, I would have missed a recent Gallup poll declaring that nearly half of small-business owners may never retire.

title: Democrats Press Attack on Secret Money
description: National Democratic officials have decided that their attacks on undisclosed corporate money are working, and they have decided to intensify the argument in the final days of the midterm campaign.

title: Real-Life Design: Erecting Solutions to Social Problems
description: Architecture is rediscovering its social conscience. Thats the message behind Small Scale, Big Change: New Architectures of Social Engagement, an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Small Scale, Big Change
description: Photographs of a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Behind the Growing Number of Tender Offers
description: The tender offer is definitely back. According to Factset Mergermetrics, tender offers were used in 22.95 percent of friendly public deals in 2010. This compares with only 7.59 percent of such deals in 2006. The tender offer has not seen such heights since the 1980s.

title: From Darkness and Mine Dust to Sea and Sand
description: ATHENS  Beyond the hugs theyve received from their president and the celebrity treatment theyve gotten from media around the world, the 33 miners rescued this week have been offered something they might desperately need after more than two months of confinement underground: a vacation.

title: New Climate Fight, Same as the Old One?
description: The decade-long effort to pass comprehensive climate legislation framed around a declining cap and trading for carbon dioxide emissions died an ignominious death. Now new proposals focused on a substantial ramp-up of investments in energy innovation are percolating  and instantly being attacked. Keith Kloor has nicely woven together links to relevant coverage and commentary in a riff titled The Post Partisan Power Play.

title: Europe Walks a Fine Line on Regulation of Cloning
description: BRUSSELS  European Union regulators are getting ready to propose rules on cloned livestock that would be stronger than those in the United States with regard to actual clones, but would seek to avoid trade tensions by allowing imports of food produced from their offspring as well as imports of semen and embryos from clones for breeding.

title: Dumpster Dips
description: Trash containers have been turned into swimming pools in Brooklyn.

title: Theater Listings: Oct. 15  21
description: Theater

title: Mine Coverage Taxes BBC News Budget
description: This is the reality of the television news business: when an unexpected event eats into the annual news-gathering budget, at some point there will have to be cutbacks elsewhere.

title: Photo of the Week
description: Two lovers are seen at sunrise on La Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France.

title: Favorite Spaces
description: Why will.i.am, Annie Leonard, Todd Oldham and other homebodies love their houses.

title: Chart: Gucci Manes The Appeal
description: The mush-mouthed Atlanta rapper Gucci Mane is back with his third studio album, The Appeal: Georgias Most Wanted, which features guests like Bun B, Nicki Minaj and Estelle. The artist Andrew Kuo dissects it, track by track.

title: Biden: Ill Be Obamas Running Mate in 2012
description: Is President Obama already thinking about his 2012 re-election campaign?

title: F.D.A. Admits Error, Will Revoke Approval for Knee Patch
description: The Timess Gardiner Harris writes in an article posted this afternoon that the Food and Drug Administration announced that it would rescind approval for Menaflex, a patch for knee injuries, and acknowledged that had erred. The account notes that approval was granted in 2008 after the agency was pressured by four New Jersey congressmen and its own commissioner.

title: Republicans Eat Crow on Hicky Ad
description: Talk about having to eat crow.

title: Le Music Subsidy
description: Last year we wrote about how France was subsidizing the ailing newspaper industry. Now it appears the French government has opened its coffers to another sector whose business model has been pummeled by the digital age: the music industry.

title: Rita Hayworth, Movie Legend, Dies
description: Rita Hayworth, the legendary Hollywood beauty who rose to international fame in the 1940's and 1950's, died Thursday night, of Alzheimer's disease, in her Central Park West apartment in Manhattan. She was 68 years old.

title: CAPONE CONVICTED OF DODGING TAXES; MAY GET 17 YEARS
description: Chicago, Oct. 17-- Al Capone was found guilty here tonight on five of the twenty-three counts contained in the two indictments brought against him by the Federal Government for income tax evasion from 1924 to 1929.

title: 2 Black Power Advocates Ousted From Olympics
description: Mexico City, Oct. 18--The United States Olympic Committee suspended Tommie Smith and John Carlos today for having used last Wednesday's victory ceremony for the 200- meter dash at the Olympic Games as the vehicle for a black power demonstration.

title: Pierre Trudeau Is Dead at 80; Dashing Fighter for Canada
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the long-serving prime minister of Canada who successfully defended his vision of federalism and a unified nation against the aroused forces of Quebec separatism, died yesterday in Montreal. He was 80.

title: Yankees-Rangers in Perspective
description: Rangers have a History

title: Neighborhood Joint | Central Art Supply
description: An East Village store has been a destination for creative spirits in need of paper, pencils, paint and brushes since 1905.

title: One Store, Five Floors, 6,000 Papers
description: PAPER is upstairs.

title: Shot in the Right Thigh. At Bellevue.
description: This is a raw feed from police reporters Al Baker and Karen Zraick on the shooting near Pennsylvania Station. It was sent to James Barron, who will incorporate it along with witness accounts and other reporting into his developing City Room post and story for Fridays newspaper. It is paraphrased from statements by Paul J. Browne, the main police spokesman.

title: Opera's Next Tenor?
description: The 33-year-old tenor Vittorio Grigolo is making his debut at the Metropolitan Opera in La Bohme.

title: How Close Is Cheap Clean Energy?
description: Tyler Cowen continues the discussion about the next steps for climate policy:

title: Tavern on the Green Visitors Center Opens
description: The former Tavern on the Green will reopen to the public on Friday, reincarnated as a $2.5-million visitor center, food court and retail shop, temporarily replacing the once-glittering landmark restaurant in Central Park, which shuttered on New Years Day.

title: Ristretto | Coffee With Tim Wendelboe
description: Last year, Tim Wendelboe, a former World Barista Champion (2004) and World Tasting Champion (2005) whose eponymous coffee shop and roaster in Oslo has become a destination for coffee pilgrims on the order of Lourdes or Fallingwater, wrote a book on coffee. It was released in English this summer as Coffee With Tim Wendelboe. The slim volume is the most complete portrait of this moment in coffee to date.

title: Yahoo Sale Speculation Loses Steam
description: The buzz Thursday morning was all about reports that AOL and buyout firms might cobble together a complicated bid for Yahoo.

title: Plaintiffs Bar Unhappy With Tip Process
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Got a beef against your broker? Regulators have made it easy for investors to come forward: Call one of their fraud hot lines and tell your story. The Securities and Exchange Commission may even give you cash if your tip pans out.

title: Living Rooms With a View
description: What is it like to live in a townhouse designed by Mies van der Rohe?

title: Judge Delays Resumption of Guantnamo Trial
description: WASHINGTON  A military judge on Thursday decided to delay the resumption of the first trial before a military commission under the Obama administration, giving government officials and defense lawyers more time to work on a potential plea deal.

title: Cue the Exterminators: Bedbugs at Lincoln Center
description: Bedbugs have made their debut at Lincoln Center. The pests were sighted in the dressing room of the David H. Koch Theater, the New York City Opera confirmed on Wednesday, and at the Metropolitan Opera. City Opera, whose fall season opens Oct. 27, shares the theater with the New York City Ballet, whose season ended on Sunday. The outbreak was reported online on Wednesday by The New York Observer, which quoted from an Oct. 8 e-mail from Mark Heiser, the theaters managing director, who said treatment was under way. Please understand that this is an epidemic, Mr. Heiser wrote. Any signs of bedbug activity should not be considered a sign of an untidy house. The pests were also found at the Metropolitan Opera. Bedbugs were discovered in some isolated locations but not in any public areas, a spokesman for the Met said in a statement, adding that the areas were being treated and monitored.

title: Dear FloFab: How Do I Tell the Chef This Needs Salt?
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Sponsors Also Star in School Makeover Reality Show
description: NBCs new Friday night show School Pride tries to tap the out-with-the-bums, everythings-broken mentality currently at large in the country and apply it to the popular home-makeover genre. In doing so it becomes a microcosm of both the good side (authentic, if totally random, charity) and the bad side (stunning superficiality, rampant commercialism) of this particular corner of reality television.

title: 52 Percent of Americans Flunk Climate 101
description: A new study by researchers at Yale University suggests that Americans knowledge of climate science is limited and scattershot, with some understanding of basic issues like the contribution of fossil fuels to global warming and some singular misconceptions as well.

title: Free Music, Documentaries and Vampire Bites
description: With lyrics like We would have never met, without the Internet and I left my wife and only child for a girl at the Renaissance fair, Ethan Lipton and His Orchestra tell tales of quirky, modern romance. On Saturday Mr. Lipton, joined by Eben Levy on guitar, Ian Riggs on stand-up bass and Vito Dieterle on saxophone, will be crooning for the hapless lovers of Park Slope, Brooklyn, in the back room of the bar Barbs, beginning at 8 p.m. Seating is limited, so arrive early, or stop by any other night of the week to hear a lineup that can range from Americana to Gypsy brass. (376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn; 347-422-0248, barbesbrooklyn.com; $10 suggested donation.)

title: Googles Income Rises 32%, Topping Forecast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has spent the last few months arguing to anyone who will listen that its new advertising businesses  including ads with images and video and on cellphones  will fuel its next phase of growth. On Thursday, the company finally gave some numbers to support the claim.

title: Comedy With a Bang
description: Robert Schwentke, the director of the action comedy "RED," discusses his use of guns and weaponry in the film.

title: Wheres That Bus? Check Your iPhone
description: A new experiment by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority allows riders on the M16 and M34 bus routes to check the real-time location of buses on the Web or a mobile device.

title: Rising Cost of Kimchi Alarms Koreans
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Even in the middle of a loud and bustling outdoor market, her voice drops to a whisper when she agrees to reveal the two secret ingredients that make her kimchi so popular with her customers.

title: Camaraderie on Ice
description: OUTSIDE it was fall, but inside, winter had already arrived. Huddled in the stands on a recent Friday night, a small group of fans yelled enthusiastically for the NY Lions hockey team. One of dozens of teams in the adult coed league run by Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, the Lions are also one of five that belong to the New York City Gay Hockey Association. On the ice a spirited match against a straight team called TBD was under way.

title: A Theater Is Shuttered and The Shows Wont Go On
description: The Theaters at 45 Bleecker Street, one of New Yorks diminishing number of commercial Off Broadway spaces, has closed indefinitely due to litigation between the theater producers and their landlord, the 45 Bleecker theater manager said in an interview on Thursday. Performances have been canceled for Thursday night, including for the two new Off Broadway productions running there, The Deep Throat Sex Scandal and Perfect Harmony.

title: Who Ya Callin Gramps, Junior?
description: If you are in the mood to revisit some of the bad movies of last summer  there was no shortage  then RED may be just the ticket. You might even say that this movie, directed by Robert Schwentke and based on the comic books created by Warren Ellis and Cully Hamner, represents a do-over, a moderately successful attempt to restore the entertainment potential of two much-abused genres.

title: Wallowing in Grief Over Maman
description: Roland Barthes  the French literary critic, theorist and philosopher  died an absurd death. In 1980 he was hit by a laundry van in Paris, while walking home from a lunch given by Franois Mitterrand, the future president of France, and died a few weeks later. He was 64 and as dashing as hed been at half that age.

title: Environmentalists Join Mountaintop Fray
description: Environmental groups from Appalachia moved Thursday to join the federal government in fighting an industry lawsuit that would weaken oversight of mountaintop coal mining.

title: BMW and Mercedes-Benz to Add Mounts for iPad
description: DVD monitors are just so pass. Mercedes-Benz and BMW have just announced devices  cradles, so to speak  that will house Apple iPads, allow them to swivel and even charge them via a dock connector.

title: Brahms for the Schumanns
description: Brahms set the agenda for the first concert of the Collegiate Chorales 69th season, presented at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. Yet almost perversely, at least from a historical perspective, the lure was a pair of Wagnerians: the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe, who played a resplendent Fricka in the Metropolitan Operas much-ballyhooed new staging of Das Rheingold, and the bass-baritone Eric Owens, whose dramatically shaded, unusually sympathetic Alberich in the same production stole the show.

title: On the East Side, Cooking Without Gas
description: To the clatter, pedestrian obstacle course and store closings created by the Second Avenue subway project, add one more affliction for more than 100 families living on the East Side: no gas.

title: House Tour: Barrytown, N.Y.
description: WHAT Three-bedroom Greek Revival house

title: Jets Revis Making Trip to Denver and May Play
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On Thursday, there were positive developments concerning the left hamstring of the injured Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis. That does not mean that Revis will play Sunday at Denver, but the possibility is now higher than earlier this week.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Lebanon, Afghanistan and Greece.

title: Chinas Elite Feel Winds of Change, but Endure
description: BEIJING  For Chinas small band of liberal intellectuals, this is the springtime of hope. Six days ago, one of their own, the writer and dissident Liu Xiaobo, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. On Monday, a score of Communist Party elders and scholars issued a scalding public attack on the governments censorship regime. Since mid-August, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao has endorsed political reform on at least seven occasions, including on CNN and at the United Nations.

title: Rare Books About New York
description: DO you think its too early for holiday shopping for New York-related books? Hardly! Indeed, you may be too late.

title: Rescue Bolsters Ratings for CNN and Fox News
description: The viewership for Fox News and CNN more than doubled Wednesday night as the final miner was rescued in Chile.

title: Quote Unquote | Siren Call
description: Joan Collins bemoans the lack of screen sirens today to Vogue UK. Poor Joan Collins, she doesnt know that Rosie Huntington-Whitely was cast in the next Transformers film.

title: Scenes From the Frieze
description: Images from the art fair in London.

title: Stressing Out Over an Urban Spa
description: THE concept was a model for future development: a nationally known spa paired with an urban luxury condominium that would give residents all the elements of a pampered vacation right in their own buildings. But since plans were unveiled in 2006 for Miraval Living, a residential tower and spa that would have been just such an urban sanctuary on the Upper East Side, the project has stumbled.

title: Somali-American Is Named Prime Minister of Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The Somali president on Thursday named a Somali-American to succeed the prime minister whose resignation last month brought the weak transitional government to a standstill.

title: The Days, Nights and Years of the Jackal: The Tale of a Terrorist
description: About 15 minutes into Carlos, Olivier Assayass excited, exciting, epic dramatization about the international terrorism brand known as Carlos the Jackal, the title character takes a long, loving, vainglorious look in the mirror at his naked body. Its 1974 and after a bungled assassination attempt and an ineffectual bombing, Carlos has just headed down the flamboyant career path  riddled with bodies, rutted by explosions and festooned with publicity  that will inspire pulp fictions, detailed biographies, hyperventilated conspiracy theories and lasting myths. As he luxuriates in his own image, you see how Carlos saw himself: the terrorist as pinup.

title: Rockefellers Selling Co-op for $6.5 Million
description: MICHAEL S. AND TARA ROCKEFELLER, the power society couple, are selling their four-bedroom apartment at 34 Gramercy Park, one of Manhattans oldest co-ops, for $6.5 million.

title: Sidney Weinberg Jr. and the End of an Era
description: Sidney J. Weinberg Jr. retired as a general partner from Goldman Sachs in 1988, but almost every week afterward until his death, he came into the office. He would meet with staff to give advice about Goldmans culture and values, hoping to leave a little of the firms past in the present.

title: Philadelphia Orchestras Principal Clarinetist to Perform With the Philharmonic
description: Could Philadelphias loss be New Yorks gain?

title: Philadelphia Orchestras Principal Clarinetist to Perform With the Philharmonic
description: Could Philadelphias loss be New Yorks gain?

title: On Mad Men the Thrills Are All in the Office
description: Risky behavior is the organizing principle of Mad Men, an immorality play built around those bad habits of the 1960s that we now try to abjure: drinking, smoking, promiscuity, and racial and sexual prejudice.

title: Saudi Prince Makes Offer for Trump World Tower Penthouse
description: THE Yankee shortstop Derek Jeters digs at Trump World Tower, with over 5,400 square feet of space and now on the market for $20 million, may be fit for a king. But a Saudi prince looking into buying a condominium in that building, near the United Nations, felt that the floor  described as being on the 88th but actually on the 70th  wasnt high enough.

title: Plug-In Cars Pose Riddle for E.P.A.
description: DETROIT  About two months before two new plug-in cars go on sale in the United States, the federal government is struggling with how to rate the fuel economy of mass-market plug-in vehicles.

title: A Museum Exhibition Assembled on the Fly
Lending Is Up, but Demand Is Lacking
description: Corporate lending by banks is rising. Finally.

title: Big Fish and Fresh Cash at London Fair
description: LONDON  The contradictions of the art world, as well as of the current economic moment, were in full view as the Frieze Art Fair began here in Regents Park on Wednesday. Despite what some called a more thoughtful, less flashy mood than during the boom years, a Damien Hirst fish-in-formaldehyde installation brought $5.6 million, according to his London gallery.

title: A Hike Into the Mystic, or Just a Walk in the Woods?
description: KENT, N.Y.

title: For Democrats, the Outlook Gets Better in the Senate and Worse in the House
description: The New York Times has changed its rating of Connecticuts Senate race from tossup to leaning Democratic, finding that Attorney General Richard Blumenthal has somewhat solidified his position against businesswoman Linda McMahon, the Republican candidate and former wrestling impresario.

title: With a Round to Go, Kramnik Retains Lead of Bilbao Masters
Obama Seeks Stay on Dont Ask, Dont Tell Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  Saying it would appeal a ruling striking down the law that bans gay men and lesbians from serving openly in the United States military, the Obama administration on Thursday asked the federal judge who issued the ruling for an emergency stay of her decision.

title: Shahn Art Collection and Home Are for Sale
description: The artist Ben Shahn and his second wife, Bernarda Bryson Shahn, spent much of their lives in a government-built cinderblock house. In 1939 the couple moved to Roosevelt, N.J., southeast of Princeton, where a federal relief program had created Modernist subdivisions. The Shahns surrounded themselves with lively collections: Indian illuminated manuscripts, ancient classical statues and 20th-century works by their friends, including the artists Robert Rauschenberg and Jacob Lawrence and the woodworker George Nakashima.

title: App Smart Extra: Patient Journal App
description: Apps highlighted in this weeks App Smart column are tailored to medical altruists who might like to help save another persons life.

title: The Dead Have Messages for the Land of the Living
description: The afterlife is not necessarily where you would expect to find Clint Eastwood, who at 80 shows no signs of tiring out or settling down. His latest film, Hereafter, is at once recognizably his  in tone and atmosphere  and a startling departure from his previous work.

title: Spanish Draftsmanship That Leaps Off the Page
description: In between Velzquez and Picasso there was Goya, and then there was everyone else. Thats exactly the way the Frick Collection has sensibly chosen to organize its thrilling exhibition The Spanish Manner: Drawings From Ribera to Goya.

title: Before the Rebellion, Playful Pop Art Novelty
description: Why have there been no great female Pop artists? Thats the question posed by Sid Sachs at the start of his catalog essay for Seductive Subversion: Women Pop Artists, 1958-1968, a revelatory time capsule of an exhibition that he has organized at the Brooklyn Museum. He is paraphrasing the title of Linda Nochlins monument of feminist art history, Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?

title: Heated Debate at Hearing on Smoking Ban in Parks
description: A New York City Council public hearing on a proposed smoking ban in city parks evolved into an hours-long, occasionally raucous showdown Thursday afternoon, touching on issues such as civil liberties, public health, big government and litter.

title: Still Traveling
description: Back on this side of the Pacific, but still not in a position to post.

title: Push to End Job Barriers Rattles Greece and Economy
description: ATHENS  Antonios Avgerinos, 59, a retired army pharmacist, always wanted his own pharmacy here. And why not? Greek law ensures that pharmacists get a 35 percent profit on all drugs sold, even over-the-counter medications.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Oct. 15-21
description: Pop

title: Second Sestak Comeback Is Unlikely
description: Theres been some excitement this week about Pennsylvania, where two internal polls commissioned by Democrats show a tight Senate race. One of the polls actually puts their candidate, Joe Sestak, ahead by 3 points; the other has him 1 point behind Pat Toomey.Further contributing to the buzz is the disclosure that Republicans are upping their ad buys in the state.On the other hand, Rasmussen Reports provides for a buzzkill of sorts, having released a poll this morning showing Mr. Toomey 10 points ahead  the largest advantage that Rasmussen has given him all year.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Oct. 15-21
description: Classical

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 15-21
description: Dance

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 15-21
description: Movies

title: One of 10 Accused in Bronx Beatings Is Released on Bail
description: One of the ten young men accused in the kidnapping, beating and sexual assault of three men in the Bronx was released on bail Thursday, as he and his nine co-defendants appeared before a judge in Bronx Criminal Court.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 15-21
description: Art

title: Challenging Health Care Law, Suit Advances
description: In a foreboding ruling for the Obama administration, a federal judge in Florida decreed Thursday that a legal challenge to the new health care law by officials from 20 states could move forward and warned that he would have to be persuaded that its keystone provision  a requirement that most Americans obtain insurance  is constitutional.

title: Clinton Tosses Out Political Football
description: Democrats have tried many ways to capture the attention of distracted voters before Election Day.

title: Seductive Subversion
description: Images from a new exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 15-21
description: Jazz

title: Spare Times for Oct. 15-21
description: Around Town

title: In East Village, One Store, Five Floors, 6,000 Papers
description: Paper is upstairs.

title: The Commonwealth Games Closing Ceremony
description: The closing ceremony of Indias Commonwealth Games, which opened 12 days ago with the world bracing for the worst, was a success.

title: Wall Street: 60 Goats and a Soft Shoe
description: If only the hotshot bankers who drove the global economy off a cliff had been playing with marbles instead of credit default swaps. Or merely trading tangible things, like shoes and loaves of bread and gallons of cider. The world might look a whole lot different today.

title: Film Riches, Cleaned Up for Posterity
description: Movies may seem a more permanent medium than ephemeral art forms like theater and dance. But films are fragile things that often exist only fleetingly in their definitive state.

title: Students Aim for Success With a New View of Vocational School
description: Buzzing with excitement, 72 11th graders sat in the auditorium of Austin Polytechnical Academy recently, waiting to board buses that would take them to the International Manufacturing Technology Show at McCormick Place, the largest show of its kind in the United States.

title: Spare Times: For Children for Oct. 15-21
description: MEET THE BREEDS

title: TPG and K.K.R. Make Approach to Seagate
description: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and PETER LATTMAN

title: Obama Fields Pointed Questions
description: President Obama was put on the defensive on issues from the economy and Washington partisanship to gay rights and race relations during a televised town hall-style forum on Thursday that captured the disillusionment taking root among younger voters who were a significant force in his election.

title: Walking the Campaign Trail as the Midterms Approach
description: Dispatches from the campaign bedlam:

title: Week 6 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 6. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: What Should I Do at CMJ?
description: Another year, another 1,200 bands looking for a breakthrough at the CMJ Music Marathon, which opens in New York on Tuesday.

title: Awaiting a Second Chance for a Dugout View
description: Bob Brenly has sometimes wondered if the sparkle from the ring he won for managing the Arizona Diamondbacks to the 2001 World Series title has faded into irrelevance.

title: Political Points: Two Years In
description: Click to Listen

title: The Pulse
description: Hospital Workers Feel Recessions Pinch

title: House Democrats Plan Ad Spending
description: House Democrats, who need every advantage they can get in the midterm elections, say they will have about $10 million more than their Republican counterparts to spend on television advertising in the final three weeks before Election Day.

title: The Caucus Click: Washington
Beirut Festival Pulled Film to Spare Ahmadinejads Feelings
description: As my colleague Robert Worth reports, a two-day visit to Lebanon by Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, seems to have passed off without major incident  or minor stone-throwing  but the presence of Irans best-known Holocaust-denying, 9/11-truther did have an impact on Beiruts film lovers.

title: Her Brothers Keeper, No Matter the Cost
description: For a while Conviction, based on the true story of a New England womans long struggle to win freedom for her imprisoned brother, feels as if it just might escape the stifling conventions of the crusader-for-justice melodrama. The film, directed by Tony Goldwyn from a script by Pamela Gray, starts in a chronological scramble: the lives of the characters have been shattered, and the filmmakers are sorting through the shards, offering us painful glimpses of adult anxiety and childhood pain.

title: F.D.A. Vows to Revoke Approval of Device
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it would rescind the approval of a patch for injured knees that it granted in error in 2008 after being unduly pressured by four New Jersey congressmen and its own commissioner.

title: Murphy Embraces Health Care in Ad
description: Even the Democrats who supported President Barack Obamas health care legislation last March arent exactly making the bill the center-piece of their re-election campaigns. Everyone, that is, except Rep. Scott Murphy of New York.

title: Knicks Trying to Figure Out Their Rotation
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Mike DAntoni is highly familiar with Amare Stoudemires offensive prowess and, as if to give a subtle reminder, Stoudemire scored 30 points on a thrifty 13 field goals in his first game as a Knick at Madison Square Garden.

title: Trying to Sniff Out a Rat Hiding in a Toxic World
description: The cramped, mildewed atmosphere of Ben Wheatleys deadpan crime comedy, Down Terrace, is so claustrophobic you can understand why its hapless characters are continually bickering. The grainy movie, filmed with a handheld camera, soaks up the fetid world of a criminal clan in which two of the members, Bill (Robert Hill) and his son, Karl (Robin Hill), played by a real father and son, were ratted out to the police by one of their own.

title: Controversy Over Mascots at Ole Miss
description: Colonel Reb, meet your replacement.

title: The Dark Art of Drawing Political Lines
description: Gerrymandering is an illustrated civics lesson that strains to make its complicated, shadowy subject  electoral redistricting  a political hot topic. Written and directed by Jeff Reichert and outfitted with a pounding soundtrack and flashy graphics, it examines the legal chicanery by which electoral districts are modified for political purposes. The word (with a hard g) was coined in 1812 after the governor of Massachusetts, Elbridge Gerry (pronounced Gary), signed a bill redistricting the state to his own advantage. One district was described as having the shape of a salamander; hence the term.

title: How Wall Street Hid Its Mortgage Mess
description: The conventional wisdom has it that the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission  the bipartisan group of wise men and women charged with uncovering what caused our recent economic meltdown and telling us what should be done to prevent a recurrence  is woefully out-of-touch and out-of-date. A Times article last month suggested that an exodus of senior employees from the commission and internal disagreements among those remaining could hamper efforts to produce a meaningful and useful report, which is due to be published in December.

title: Clubs Urge Locals to Come Hear the Music Play
description: An otherwise inconspicuous air duct at the back of the Fairmont Hotels ornate Venetian Room harbors an important piece of local cultural history. There, the names of Ella Fitzgerald, Nat King Cole, Tina Turner and other great vocal artists who performed in the club were etched  reportedly by a hotel technician  onto the surface of the ventilation conduit.

title: After Police Shooting, a Focus on How Mentally Ill Are Handled
description: On the morning of Sept. 26, a San Francisco police officer responded to a complaint about loud music at a residential hotel for seniors and the mentally ill in the Tenderloin District. The officer accompanied the hotel manager to Room 708.

title: Fehr, Nominee to Lead Union, Meets With Rangers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Donald Fehr, nominated to be executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, was at the Rangers practice rink Thursday to meet with players.

title: Proving Poverty Could Be Problematic at Area Food Pantries
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen

title: Hearts Full of Sorrow
description: Admirers of Nicole Krausss novel The History of Love (and they are many, and I am one) will want to know the answer to this question: How much does her new novel, Great House, resemble its predecessor? The good news is: very much indeed. And the good news is also: not so very much.

title: In Benicia, Emissions Measure Is Personal
description: In most of California, the arguments over Proposition 23, which would suspend the states landmark global-warming law, are dominated by theoretical claims about the measures potential effect on jobs and the environment.

title: Maximum Gross Outs in Sleazy, Queasy Stunts
description: It just might be that Americas favorite jackasses, having played around with sharks in their last big-screen effort (Jackass Number Two of course), have this time actually jumped one, and in 3-D no less. As aficionados of their previous feature-length compilations of gags and giggles have come to know, there is a certain, sometimes inexplicable, queasy pleasure to be had from watching Johnny Knoxville, Chris Pontius and the rest of these MTV-sponsored merry buffoons wreak semi-havoc on one another, themselves and an occasional rattled and confused onlookers (the two-legged variety, especially). But alas there are only so many times you can slurp from the same fetid well, or at least make like Krakatoa and blow.

title: Marketers Trade Tales About Getting to Know Facebook and Twitter
description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: After a Death, Friendships and Secrets
description: Its a puzzle why you cant see the face of the woman who bustles through the opening of Noras Will, her hands front and center  setting a table, locking away paper  while her features remain out of sight. By the time you finally see that face in full, its eyes are closed because Nora is now literally on ice, awaiting the burial that gives this slight, sentimental movie its narrative shape and clumsy comedy. That shes also a mystery meant to be solved helps explain why the director Mariana Chenillo keeps her carefully under wraps.

title: Post-Recalls, a New Way to Clean the Greens
description: The produce industry  rocked by several major recalls in recent years linked to outbreaks of salmonella, E. coli and other bacteria  has been searching for a better way to wash the lettuce, spinach and other greens it bags and sells in grocery stores and to restaurants.

title: Verizon Wireless Is to Sell Apple iPads
description: Apple said Thursday that Verizon Wireless would begin selling the iPad at its stores on Oct. 28.

title: Wordless and Lost, a Young Couple Flee
description: How do you know youre looking at a pretty good piece of filmmaking? When the director and actors can make you care about the central characters even though they exchange almost no dialogue. And when the movie holds your interest even though you lack the cultural reference points that show it off to best advantage.

title: Growing Interest, Despite Questions, in Jon Stewarts Rally
description: Though no one is quite sure what it is going to be yet, the Rally to Restore Sanity, organized by the comedian Jon Stewart and set for Oct. 30 on the National Mall in Washington, is drawing widespread national attention.

title: New Attitude Has Jacobs Running Hard
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Brandon Jacobs walked around the Giants locker room Thursday wearing slippers, sweat pants and a smile. He looked like a man at home.

title: A Heated Debate
description: Photos from the debate between Representative Loretta Sanchez and Van Tran for the 47th Congressional District in Orange County, Calif.

title: Medtronic to Settle Lawsuits Over Devices Tied to Deaths
description: Medtronic, the maker of heart devices, agreed to pay $268 million to settle lawsuits over claims that fractured wires in a line of its cardiac defibrillators caused at least 13 deaths.

title: Vietnam Human Rights Play Role in House Race
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.  The flagging economy came up, of course. So did the high unemployment rate. But it is not every Congressional debate that turns on the question of how to improve human rights in Vietnam.

title: Recognizing Israel as a Jewish State
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Beat Phillies Big Three
description: There was a time in Philadelphia  O.K., maybe for only a few months in 1982  when the term H2O referred to the most successful album of the local pop duo Hall and Oates. Now, it is the unmistakable nickname of the most celebrated pitching threesome in baseball: the two Hs and an O of the Phillies  Roy Halladay, Cole Hamels and Roy Oswalt.

title: Phillies Fans Refuse to Let Rain Ruin a Rally
description: PHILADELPHIA  This is the best of times for Philadelphia sports fans.

title: Colorado Candidates Brother Lies Low
description: TRINIDAD, Colo.  The Salazar family name has been a leading political brand in Colorado for years. It has also been shorthand for a big-thought Democratic Party strategy of carrying the West that the Salazar brothers, John and Ken, helped invent and articulate as shoulder-to-shoulder voices of deep-country Colorado, where they grew up and where John still runs the family potato farm. The Salazar formula: rural and urban coalitions around centrist, libertarian-tinged politics, mixing support for gun rights with an ability to look natural in a cowboy hat.

title: Milestones: John A. Boehner
description: The life and political career of Representative John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican and soon-to-be House speaker.

title: Boehners Path to Power Began in Small-Town Ohio
description: READING, Ohio  John A. Boehner, the House Republican leader, laments that the America he grew up in has been snuffed out by Democrats. Yet Mr. Boehners hometown seems virtually untouched by the decades that have passed since he lugged kegs of beer around his fathers bar, tossed a Friday night football and frightened a driving instructor by burning rubber in a GTO.

title: Romance in Brazils Wild West
description: Carmo, Hit the Road, a picaresque romance set (and filmed) in Brazils wild west on the borders of Paraguay and Bolivia, rambles through some beautiful jungle-and-river landscapes without really going anywhere. Its not a memorable ride, but theres enough rueful humor, tropical sensuality and borrowed style along the way to make it pleasant.

title: Mistake in Second Avenue Subway Work Cuts Gas Off
description: To the clatter, pedestrian obstacle course and store closings created by the Second Avenue subway project, add one more affliction for more than 100 families living on the East Side: no gas.

title: Mortgage Mess May Cost Big Banks Billions
description: One billion dollars? Six billion? Ten billion? More?

title: Where Tea Party Candidates Are Running
description: An examination by The Times identified Tea Party candidates in 129 House races and 9 Senate races.

title: In Waterfront Hearings, Accounts of a Unions Kickbacks and a Mafia Tie
description: Edward Aulisi was a dockworker  at least in theory. According to law enforcement officials, Mr. Aulisi, whose father led a longshoremens union local, knew of the locals kickback payments to organized crime, and he was in contact with a Mafia captain who was a fugitive from justice.

title: The Whitney Trims Its East Side Holdings
description: Cementing its decision to shift its focus from the Upper East Side to the meatpacking district, the Whitney Museum of American Art on Thursday sold the six brownstones next to its signature Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue as well as two town houses around the corner on 74th Street.

title: Tales of an Imaginary City
description: Urville requires some explanation, which the film itself, by the German director Angela Christlieb (Cinemania), does not provide.

title: Tea Party Set to Win Enough Races for Wide Influence
description: Enough Tea Party-supported candidates are running strongly in competitive and Republican-leaning Congressional races that the movement stands a good chance of establishing a sizable caucus to push its agenda in the House and the Senate, according to a New York Times analysis.

title: Accountability Behind the Plate
description: The Umpire in the Sky

title: Mother Nature Decoded
description: This is the fifth in a series.

title: Living With Mies
description: A few blocks east of Detroits downtown, just across Interstate 375, sits Lafayette Park, an enclave of single- and two-story modernist townhouses set amid a forest of locust trees. Like hundreds of developments nationwide, they were the result of postwar urban renewal; unlike almost all of them, it had a trio of world-class designers behind it: Ludwig Hilbersheimer as urban planner, Alfred Caldwell as landscape designer and Mies van der Rohe as architect.

title: Obama on Defensive at Forum
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama was put on the defensive on issues including the economy, gay rights and race relations during a televised town-hall-style forum on Thursday that captured the disillusionment taking root among younger voters who were a significant force in his election.

title: U.S. Uses Attacks to Nudge Taliban Toward a Deal
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Airstrikes on Taliban insurgents have risen sharply here over the past four months, the latest piece in what appears to be a coordinated effort by American commanders to bleed the insurgency and pressure its leaders to negotiate an end to the war.

title: The Mortgage Morass
description: American officials used to lecture other countries about their economic failings and tell them that they needed to emulate the U.S. model. The Asian financial crisis of the late 1990s, in particular, led to a lot of self-satisfied moralizing. Thus, in 2000, Lawrence Summers, then the Treasury secretary, declared that the keys to avoiding financial crisis were well-capitalized and supervised banks, effective corporate governance and bankruptcy codes, and credible means of contract enforcement. By implication, these were things the Asians lacked but we had.

title: From a Maine House, a National Foreclosure Freeze
description: DENMARK, Me.  The house that set off the national furor over faulty foreclosures is blue-gray and weathered. The porch is piled with furniture and knickknacks awaiting the next yard sale. In the driveway is a busted pickup truck. No one who lives there is going anywhere anytime soon.

title: Judge Says Key Figure in Embassies Bombing Case Isnt Credible
description: A key witness who was to testify in the first civilian trial of a former Guantnamo detainee was accused by the judge on Thursday of making false statements about why he decided to cooperate with authorities.

title: Francoeur Misses His Friends but Is Happy in the Playoffs
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Six weeks after the trade that liberated him from a sinking ship in Queens, Texas Rangers outfielder Jeff Francoeur still keeps in touch with his friends on the Mets. He called the former manager Jerry Manuel on Wednesday, and he said he heard from David Wright, Mike Pelfrey and the hitting coach Howard Johnson, among others, during the Rangers American League division series.

title: 3 Harvard Researchers Retract a Claim on the Aging of Stem Cells
description: Harvard researchers have retracted a far-reaching claim they made in January that the aging of stem cells might be reversible.

title: The Foreclosure Crises
description: Attorneys general in all 50 states have pledged a coordinated investigation into chaotic foreclosure practices by some of the nations largest banks. The Department of Justice is also looking into what happened, while some lawmakers are now calling for a nationwide moratorium on all foreclosures until the legal questions are settled. The Obama administration is insisting such a broad delay would hurt the economy.

title: Need a Lawyer? Good Luck
description: Across the country, programs that provide legal representation in civil cases to low-income Americans are so cash-strapped that they are turning away numbers of people. Hard-pressed Americans fighting foreclosure or seeking protection from domestic violence or access to medical care or unemployment benefits must often navigate the judicial system on their own or give up.

title: Taking a Vote on Union Construction
description: SAN DIEGO  Californias go-go construction industry came crashing to earth when the housing bubble burst. Ever since, union leaders and nonunion contractors have fought hammer and tongs for a bigger share of the shrunken business, much of which is public sector construction.

title: Rewards for Miners Rescued in Chile
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  The lucky ones now have more than $10,000 in the bank and a free vacation in Greece awaiting them. But for the moment, many of the family members of the 33 miners trapped under the hard volcanic rock here for more than two months seemed content to remain at Camp Hope on Thursday, tending to their tents and sweeping away the desert dust from their makeshift dining tables.

title: Seeking Vengeance in High Heels
description: The problem with reviewing a movie called Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives is that youre required to admit publicly that you have actually watched a movie called Ticked-Off Trannies With Knives. Thats the kind of damning tidbit that could be stumbled upon and misinterpreted by some future background-checker  a potential employer, for instance, or a vetting body for Nobel Prize nominees. Not to mention the personal implications. My mother could read this review, for gosh sakes.

title: N.B.A. Cracks Down on Whining About Foul Calls
description: In a recent preseason game against the Nets, Bostons Paul Pierce punched the air in frustration after being whistled for a foul. He then looked around in curiosity after hearing the whistle again. In a circumstance that could repeat itself all season, the official, Steve Javie, had assessed Pierce with a technical foul for his demonstrativeness.

title: Out of a Failed Drug Test Came Team Unity
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: Familys Effort to Clear Name Frames Debate on Executions
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  It was an unusual hearing. The subject at the center of it all, Cameron Todd Willingham, was not present. After being convicted of murdering his three children in a 1991 house fire, he was executed in 2004.

title: Would You Run?
description: Mark Kirk has had a brilliant career. He graduated from Cornell, obtained a masters degree from the London School of Economics and a law degree from Georgetown. He worked at the State Department, the World Bank and the law firm of Baker & McKenzie before becoming counsel to the House committee on foreign affairs. He has served for the past decade as a congressman from the northern suburbs of Chicago.

title: Waging a Campaign of Apology
description: Carl P. Paladino, the self-styled tough guy with a baseball bat, has turned into a serially apologizing cream puff, retreating from aggressively held positions more often than almost anyone since Napoleon hightailed it out of Moscow in 1812. His campaign for governor is defined in fair measure by his admissions of poor judgment.

title: Waiting for Something Big
description: 2012: Time for Change, 85 minutes of navet with the occasional interesting idea thrown in, gives Daniel Pinchbeck another chance to flog his 2012-theme books (2012: The Return of Quetzalcoatl) and the notion that a little over a year from now Something Big is going to happen.

title: Blackstone and Bain Plan Bids for Pfizer Capsule Unit
description: Several private equity firms, including the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital, are preparing initial bids for Pfizers Capsugel unit, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday. These people asked for anonymity because the talks are private and they are not authorized to discuss them.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,315 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Rangers Rookie Closer Could Be a Young Rivera
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ian Kinsler speaks about Neftali Feliz, the Rangers closer, in glowing terms. Kinsler admires his poise, his lack of pretense, his ability to compartmentalize and rebound after wobbly outings.

title: Merger Will Save Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, Officials Say
description: Long Island College Hospital, a financially troubled community hospital in Brooklyn, has been saved from the threat of closing or bankruptcy through a planned merger with SUNY Downstate Medical Center, a major public university and medical center, Gov. David A. Paterson and hospital officials said Thursday.
