title: Council Speaker Shelves a Sick-Leave Bill
description: Against the wishes of a veto-proof majority in the City Council, the Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, effectively shelved a much-debated bill that would have required all employers in the city to provide paid sick days to their workers.

title: 2 Pennsylvania Men Guilty in 2008 Killing of Mexican
description: WASHINGTON  A federal jury found two young Pennsylvania men guilty of a hate crime on Thursday in the 2008 beating death of a Mexican immigrant. The verdict was welcomed by Hispanic organizations, which saw the trial as a national test case for the treatment of Latinos.

title: Protecting School Reform in D.C.
description: It was inevitable that Michelle Rhee, the District of Columbias hard-driving schools chancellor, would resign after her boss, Mayor Adrian Fenty, lost last months Democratic primary. It was no secret that Ms. Rhee had a strained relationship with Vincent Gray, the presumptive mayor and chairman of the City Council.

title: Joyous Rescue
description: Like so many people around the world, we waited and prayed until the last Chilean miner and the last rescuer emerged from that improbably deep hole and was again free. In a world of so much division  and one where technology too often seems to be the enemy  the miners survival and rescue was truly deserving of national and global celebration.

title: Police Seek Staten Island Man in Parents Killings
description: He was, in the words of family friends, everything that his parents had raised him to be: smart and kind, a scholar-athlete who starred at Stuyvesant High School and graduated from Williams College, and an employee in the family business.

title: Selma Al-Radi, Restored Historic Madrasa, Dies at 71
description: On certain dark nights, as a Yemeni legend tells it, Sultan Amir ibn Abd Al-Wahhab would command his servants to set lanterns in the windows of the Amiriya Madrasa, the ornate palace complex he had commissioned at Rada, in southern Yemen. Then, with his daughter by his side, he would ride into the hills above town, to behold his vast edifice ablaze with light.

title: Canadian Doctor Who Treated Numerous Athletes Is Indicted
description: A federal grand jury in Buffalo indicted the Canadian doctor Anthony Galea on Thursday on five charges that he distributed performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes.

title: Hungry for Revenge
description: Making allowances for the enduring unpopularity of restaurant critics still cant begin to normalize the filmmaker Joe Maggios unbalanced response to Frank Brunis New York Times review of the London restaurant at the London NYC Hotel in 2007. Mr. Brunis seemingly mild complaint that the restaurant lacked excitement inspired Mr. Maggio to concoct a violent revenge fantasy of what hed do to the critic in the restaurateurs place.

title: Bond With Past Foe Is Fodder for Attack on Cuomo
description: Perhaps no man would become more important to Andrew M. Cuomos political and personal finances than the real estate magnate Andrew L. Farkas.

title: Friday: Zing
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  We have a pitchman and three pitchers in todays puzzle. No wonder this tough Friday crossword is no softball. I found it the most challenging Friday in weeks.

title: Juvenile Detention
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Chaos Rhyme With Class, Er, Gas
description: There are many contenders for the title of the most obnoxious person on Broadway. Im sure you could rattle off a dozen deserving candidates. But though its early in the season, one man has already put in his bid with such insistently annoying  and supremely entertaining  style that we may as well concede the honors to him right now. Mark Rylance, step forward and claim your crown.

title: 9/11 Workers Would Get $47 Million More in New Pact
description: More than 9,000 ground zero workers eligible for a settlement of up to $712.5 million from the city over health claims now stand to get another $47 million in a separate settlement with the Port Authority.

title: Tajikistan: Fighters Agree to Amnesty
description: The leader of an armed group in Tajikistan has told supporters that he agreed with the government to lay down arms in exchange for an amnesty, Russias Interfax news agency reported Thursday, assuaging fears that fighting in a remote mountain valley might destabilize the Central Asian nation that borders Afghanistan. The authorities had accused Mirzokhudzha Akhmadov of organizing an attack on a military column on Sept. 19 that killed at least 23 soldiers in the Rasht Valley east of the capital, Dushanbe. The valley was a stronghold of antigovernment forces in the civil war in Tajikistan from 1992 until 1997, and remains largely outside central government control today.

title: Rwanda: Opposition Leader Is Arrested
description: The Rwandan opposition leader Victoire Ingabire, left, was arrested over accusations that she is linked to rebel activities, the police said. Thursdays arrest was the result of an investigation into Peter Uwumuremyi, a former commander of the rebel Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, the police spokesman, Eric Kayiranga, said by telephone. Mr. Uwumuremyi was arrested Wednesday on charges of buying and distributing arms and ammunition to a group associated with Ms. Ingabires party, the spokesman said. Ms. Ingabire returned to Rwanda in January after being in exile for 16 years. She was arrested in April over accusations that she associated with a terrorist group and propagated genocide ideology, and she was freed on bail. She said her party had been blocked from registering candidates in Augusts presidential election, which was won by the incumbent Paul Kagame.

title: China: Plans to Build 30 Sea Vessels
description: China is building 30 sea vessels for maritime law enforcement over the next five years, adding to an expanding fleet of boats under civilian authorities that operates occasionally in disputed territorial waters, according to an article in Peoples Daily. The article quoted Li Lixin, director of the South China Sea Branch of State Oceanic Administration of China, as saying that China did not have enough vessels to enforce the law in its vast territorial waters. Japan has more than 100 such vessels at a weight class of more than 3,000 tons, while China does not have even half that, Mr. Li said.

title: Lottery Numbers
Hudson River Rail Tunnel
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Are Hovering Over the Rangers Again
description: Just to the left of the clubhouse door at Rangers Ballpark in Arlington, Tex., is a framed photograph of former President George W. Bush, inscribed with a message to the team he used to own: Im with you all the way.

title: Cuts at Murrow H.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Military and Fossil Fuels
description: To the Editor:

title: In Campaign for Governor, Paladino Pairs Fierce Talk With Spine-Cracking Hugs
description: To most New Yorkers, Carl P. Paladino is best known for his mouth, from which erupt the fiery language and provocative ideas and opinions that have characterized his campaign for governor of New York.

title: Ex-Convict Is Shot After Failed Holdup
description: One day after he was released from federal prison, a knife-wielding 69-year-old man was shot by a police officer after trying to hold up a bank branch steps from Pennsylvania Station on Thursday afternoon, police officials said.

title: John Boehners Ohio Roots
description: In 2010, The Times traveled to the hometown of the Republican House Minority Leader John Boehner to get a sense of how growing up near Cincinnati may have shaped him.

title: Carl Paladino Campaigns With a Hug
description: Though widely known for his provocative speeches, Carl P. Paladino is also becoming famous among supporters and journalists for his bear hugs.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Are Scoring, but Top Line Is Unsettled
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  It is still very early, but the statistics do not lie. Going into their home opener Friday, the Rangers are the most explosive team in the N.H.L.

title: Voting Machine Mangles an Illinois Candidates Name
description: An error on some electronic voting machines already in use in Illinois identifies Rich Whitney, the Green Party candidate for governor, as Rich Whitey.

title: Top Recruit for St. Johns
description: St. Johns added another top recruit from the class of 2011 with the commitment of the highly rated shooting guard DAngelo Harrison. He joins Jakarr Sampson and the swingman Maurice Harkless as top prospects who have committed to play for Steve Lavin, the Red Storms first-year coach. Meanwhile, Gene Keady, the former coach at Purdue, is expected to be announced as a member of the St. Johns staff.

title: New York Teams Listen to Leagues When Hiring
description: If the Mets hire Sandy Alderson as their general manager, a job for which he interviewed on Thursday and for which he is the early favorite, it would be with the approval and encouragement of Commissioner Bud Selig. But that would be nothing new.

title: How Hollywood Learned to Ride the City
description: A bike lesson from Dave Jordan, a New York coach who spent the summer showing Hollywood stars how to ride like messengers.

title: In Nevada Debate, a Clash of Philosophies
description: LAS VEGAS  The debate Thursday evening between Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, and Sharron Angle, the Republican running with Tea Party support, had been promoted as a climactic duel between two opponents for a Nevada Senate seat, locked in an exceedingly tight contest in what may well be the most closely watched race of the fall.

title: Settlement May Be Near in Countrywide Case
description: WASHINGTON  Talks over settling at least part of the securities fraud lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against three former executives of the Countrywide Financial Corporation have intensified, two people involved with the case said Thursday.

title: Sports Photo Replay: Oct. 14
description: While the Phillies and the Giants prepared for the start of the N.L.C.S. this weekend, a few hardy surfers hit the waves in Canada.

title: Asia Overlooked by Yahoos Chief
Hughes to Pitch Game 2, and Heres Why
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Phil Hughes may never pitch again this postseason at Yankee Stadium  at least, that is the Yankees hope. Hughes is scheduled to pitch Game 2 on Saturday at Rangers Ballpark and, if necessary, Game 6 right back here next Friday. Should the Yankees advance to the World Series, the same order would almost certainly apply.

title: Videos Help Groom a New Generation of Runners
description: The New York Marathon showcases not only the worlds best long-distance runners, but also tens of thousands of ordinary adult runners from around the world.

description: An 11th suspect was arrested on Thursday in connection with the antigay attacks that occurred in an abandoned apartment in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Fund Manager Doesnt Hedge His Bets on Tories
description: As the right-leaning British government prepares to impose some of the deepest spending cuts in a generation, it is doing so with the full-throated support of the London financial elite, Landon Thomas Jr. reports in The New York Times.

title: BofA to Hire 1,000 Small Business Bankers by 2012
description: Bank of America said on Thursday it would hire up to 1,000 small business bankers by 2012, expanding into an area once the exclusive domain of its smaller rivals.

title: Palestinian Parkour
description: WHAT is parkour?

title: Now Showing | Iron Men 2
description: On an unassuming side street in Paolo Sarpi, Milans burgeoning Chinatown, Mirko Pancaldi and Davide Grosso are flying the flag for designs future being in the past. Since 2001, the pair, who collaborate under the G | Lab name, have been drawing attention for their delicately ornate furniture and lighting fixtures made from discarded aged wood and laser-cut iron. We are known for breathing new life into traditional materials and forms, Pancaldi says in the G | Lab showroom, which occasionally doubles as a workshop for average Giovannis wanting to learn time-held wood-turning and ironwork techniques. All of our designs refer back to 18th-century French and Italian furniture traditions, and to patterns and shapes found in nature. And so a slab of industrial iron becomes a filigreed room divider that is as intricate as it is commanding, and a hunk of maple found in an abandoned sawmill has a second life as a Baroque cabinet. Is this work, which often has Oriental accents, a function of the showrooms location or the result of travels to Asia? Ive never been to Asia, enthuses the usually taciturn Pancaldi. Only the Asia of my imagination.

title: Brevan Howard Said to List Fund in December
description: Brevan Howard, Europes largest hedge fund firm, is seeking to tap the public markets for at least 150 million ($237 million) through the London-listing of a new credit fund, Reuters reported.

title: Titled Burn, but Printed on Paper
description: When David Alan Harvey started his online Web journal Burn in 2008, there were few opportunities for emerging photographers to display their work to a broad audience. Today, thanks partly to Burn, they have numerous showcases on the Web.

title: RBS Said to Sell $351 Million of Mezzanine Loans
description: Royal Bank of Scotland has taken advantage of resurgent debt prices to sell off a portfolio of European mezzanine loans worth about 250 million euros ($351 million), The Financial Times reported.

title: Last-Ditch Efforts in Dallas to Close Liverpool Deal
description: We have a binding contract. Will fight Mill Hicks Gillett attempt to keep club today. Their last desperate attempt to entrench their regime.

title: Elway Seeks Return of Money From Alleged Ponzi Schemer
description: This was not John Elways best play.

title: Signs of Recovery in Brooklyn Housing
description: Coming on the heels of reports showing that the Manhattan residential real estate market has stabilized somewhat, a third-quarter market report to be released Friday shows that the Brooklyn housing market has rebounded fairly quickly from the 2008 housing crash.

title: UBS Talks Hedge Funds With Proprietary Traders
description: UBS, the largest Swiss bank, says it has been in talks with dozens of proprietary traders worldwide who are considering setting up hedge funds as banks seek to comply with new rules in the United States aimed at curbing risk, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Republican Candidate Has Big Friend in Elliott
description: Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Republican candidate for New York attorney general, has one very big fund-raising pipeline: Elliott Management.

title: Vernon Biever Captured Packers and N.F.L. History
description: Fifth Down readers might be interested in the life of Vernon Biever, who made a contribution to preserving the games history. Biever died Wednesday at 87. Some excellent examples of his work are at the teams official site, Packers.com, among other places.

title: Headline-Grabbing, the Ackman Way
description: William Ackman is not exactly the shy, retiring type.

title: Asia Overlooked by Yahoos Chief
description: From Reuters Breakingviews:

title: Halloween Fun at Hong Kong Theme Park
description: For a few weeks every year, family-friendly Ocean Park transforms into a ghoulish nighttime experience with its wildly popular Halloween Bash. From now through Oct. 31, the entire Park will be open from 5.30 p.m. until midnight on selected dates, offering a host of macabre attractions.

title: Basing Pay-for-Performance on Outcomes
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: SAIC Considers Investing in General Motors I.P.O.
description: SAIC Motor of China is not ruling out the possibility of investing in General Motors initial public offering, the chairman of the Chinese automaker said.

title: As French Strikes Continue, Worries About Fuel Supply
description: PARIS  There was little sign of a softening by unions protesting planned pension reforms in France on Friday as industrial action and demonstrations moved into a fourth day, intensifying fears about fuel supplies as strikers continued to target the fuel industry.

title: Enel Sets Range for $4.9 Billion Green Power I.P.O.
description: In what will be the largest European initial public offering of the year, Enel, the indebted Italian energy producer, said Friday that it had set the price range for the I.P.O. of its Green Power arm at 1.80 euros to 2.10 euros per share, valuing the unit at up to 10.5 billion euros.

title: Campus Crest Flat in Debut
description: Shares of Campus Crest Communities, the student housing developer, remained little changed after their stock market debut Thursday.

title: The Most Accurate Fantasy Football Experts  After 5 Weeks
description: David Kim is the co-founder of FantasyPros, a site that aggregates and rates fantasy football advice so you can make better decisions in less time. You can follow FantasyPros on Twitter.

title: Memories of Vargas Llosa
description: When word came last week that the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa had won the Nobel Prize in Literature, it brought me back to a small, sun-splashed office with centuries-old books lining pine shelves and a papier mch pencil holder, the words Happy Fathers Day scribbled on it, sitting on the desk. That was my fathers office in our home in the suburbs of Syracuse, and it was there that my father, hunched over an old cassette player for weeks and months, became Vargas Llosas accidental autobiographer.

title: Memories of Vargas Llosa
description: When word came last week that the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa had won the Nobel Prize in Literature, it brought me back to a small, sun-splashed office with centuries-old books lining pine shelves and a papier mch pencil holder, the words Happy Fathers Day scribbled on it, sitting on the desk. That was my fathers office in our home in the suburbs of Syracuse, and it was there that my father, hunched over an old cassette player for weeks and months, became Vargas Llosas accidental autobiographer.

title: My Cup Holders Runneth Over
description: I was giving my Ford truck an overdue cleaning last week and was surprised to find that it had 12 cup holders. As I made my way through to the back, the cup holders kept multiplying like offers in a Ronco commercial: But wait, theres more!

title: Deal-Hungry Resolution Buys Bupa Unit
description: Resolution, the British buyout vehicle, said Friday that it was paying 102 million, or $163.7 million, to buy Bupa Health Assurance, in a bid to to broaden its range of employee insurance products.

title: Gripe Gives Bad Service Some Bad Publicity
description: Have you ever been stumped by bad service at a hotel, a restaurant, a car rental agency, or your local dry cleaner? A new website called Gripe, at the trick url gri.pe, lets you instantly badmouth businesses for free to everyone who follows you on Facebook and Twitter, in hopes the company will make amends to you.

title: V.C. Financing Drops in 3Q, Mainly in Clean-Tech
description: Venture capitalists poured less money into United States start-ups in the third quarter and split this among more companies, signaling that investors are trying to be more economical with their finances, Reuters reported.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: More from Dealbreakers ongoing coverage of hedge fund daughters greatest hits  Paul Tudor Jones may dislike publicity, but his daughter Caroline would like a little more.

title: Madoffs Palm Beach Home Close to Sale
description: Investors swindled by Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme may be happy to know that his 8,800-square-foot Palm Beach home is close to being sold  although the price tag is drop in the bucket compared with Mr. Madoffs $65 billion fraud.

title: HSBC Pulls Out of Bid for 70% of Nedbank
description: HSBC, Europes largest bank, has halted its discussions to buy a $7.3 billion controlling stake in the South African lender Nedbank, according to a news release from Old Mutual, the African insurer that owns 53 percent of shares in the bank.

title: Chinas Sinochem Is Said to Abandon Potash Bid
description: Chinas Sinochem Corporation will not offer a counterbid for the Potash Corporation, abandoning efforts to spoil BHP Billitons $39 billion (24.35 billion pound) bid for the Canadian fertilizer maker, Reuters reported.

title: Has the Rebound Lost Its Bounce?
description: Venture capital investments dropped 7 percent in the third quarter compared with same period last year  but the numbers fell a much bigger 31 percent compared with the last quarter.

title: Nascar Hall of Fame Is Losing Money
description: The $200 million Nascar Hall of Fame opened in May in Charlotte, N.C., to one glowing review after another. Stock-car fans have been overwhelmingly positive about how, well, fan-friendly it is. But it apparently has not attracted enough fans  or nonfans  and is contemplating budget cuts.

title: Helping Travelers Find Internet-Connected Flights
description: Ah, air travel: stripping down a few layers of clothing to pass through security, standing in a seemingly endless succession of lines and confining oneself to a tiny space for several hours.

title: No. 1, Without the Results
description: The latest computer rankings indicate that this is week one of the Caroline Wozniacki era. But the paradox  nothing novel to womens tennis  is that we are clearly not in the Wozniacki era, at least not yet.

title: A Dip in Profit and Soft Industrial Sales at G.E. Send Its Shares Down
description: General Electric has come a long way back since the financial crisis sent it reeling. The company has pared back its troubled finance arm, focused on its mainstay industrial business, cut costs and revived profits. But G.E.s credibility on Wall Street remains shaky, with any sign of weakness punished by waves of selling.

title: Chinese Christians Barred From Conference
description: BEIJING  More than 100 Chinese Christians seeking to attend an international evangelical conference in South Africa have been barred from leaving the country, some in the group said, because their churches are not sanctioned by the state.

title: Meet The Elite
description: Max Abelson in the New York Observer:

title: Week 6 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Ravens (4-1) at Patriots (3-1)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Patriots by 3

title: Big Spender Update
description: Menzie Chinn takes on the same territory Ive examined here and here. The key picture:

title: The Sound of Spirit
description: Emigrating from the Soviet Union to the West in January 1980 with his wife, Nora, and their two small sons, the Estonian composer Arvo Prt was stopped by border police at the Brest railroad station for a luggage search. We had only seven suitcases, full of my scores, records and tapes, he recalled recently. They said, Lets listen. It was a big station. No one else was there. We took my record player and played Cantus. It was like liturgy. Then they played another record, Missa Syllabica. They were so friendly to us. I think it is the first time in the history of the Soviet Union that the police are friendly. He was joking, but not entirely. Later, when I asked Nora about that strange scene at the border, she said, I saw the power of music to transform people.

title: Dr. Chu Talks Efficiency
description: As secretary of energy, Steven Chu has aggressively promoted energy conservation as one of the lowest-cost options for reducing carbon dioxide emissions and slowing climate change.

title: Legal Wrangling Over Defendant Interviews in Queens
description: Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, is attempting to prevent a justice in State Supreme Court from issuing a ruling that may accuse his office of an ethics violation  and possibly open the door to appeals and motions in many criminal cases.

title: Bernanke Weighs Risks of New Action
description: BOSTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, went further on Friday in outlining the risks the central bank was prepared to take by pumping more money into the flagging recovery.

title: Live, Twice, From New York, Its 30 Rock
description: One thing that can certainly be said about Thursdays live episode of 30 Rock is that it occurred. It was a stunt, one that NBC has tried with previous shows like Will & Grace and ER, and while the live 30 Rock may not have been life-altering television (these days, what is?), it wasnt the 10-car pile-up that some of its creators seemed to be masochistically wishing for, either. Even if it didnt advance the shows meta-narrative, and even if the laughter of the live studio audience was occasionally jarring, it had a certain frantic energy, like, say, the first half-hour of a decent Saturday Night Live.

title: I Am Lovely
description: Margareth Mad has had two roles to date, one in an epic by the director of Cinema Paradiso and the other playing Sophia Loren. Not bad for a Sicilian girl who felt like E.T. until she moved to Milan to model. Growing up, she gorged herself on Nonnas pasta as well as on old Hollywood films  Wilder, Hitchcock, Cukor, Mad says dreamily. When she goes home, her mother still tells her, Mangia! Mangia! You are too skinny! Mad says this is what she loves about Italy: This affection, the presence of your roots. Knowing where we come from allows us to move forward.

title: Baker vs. Scissors: A Debate on China
description: A goal of our recent series on the Chinese renminbi currency was to give readers  and, frankly, ourselves  a better sense of the different arguments out there. With that in mind, well put a coda on the series today with a back-and-forth debate between two economists on opposite sides of the issue.

title: Oprah Supports Jon Stewart Rally
description: Saying I think we need a little bit more sanity in the world, Oprah Winfrey endorsed Jon Stewarts coming rally by offering to send every member of his studio audience on Thursday night to Washington.

title: Key European Matchups: In Barca Attack,  Valencia Faces  Predatory Foe
description: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

title: For Midterm Voters, War Is Off the Radar
description: It has been going on there for nine years and counting. Nearly 100,000 American troops are currently deployed there. More than 1,300 American service members have lost their lives there. The United States has spent over $300 billion on the effort so far. Yet polling suggests that the war in Afghanistan is barely a blip on voters radars as the midterm elections approach.

title: Inflation Looks Tame, and Shoppers Take Heart
description: The economy continued to show little sign of inflation as consumer prices eased marginally in September, while consumers provided a glimmer of hope for the retail sector, government reports said on Friday.

title: Sharing a Table, and Much More
description: My friend Ellen works in an internists office where she encounters a procession of older widows. She hears them fret about the high costs and general aggravation of maintaining and paying taxes on the big old houses they still live in. She also hears them confide that its lonely to occupy these once-bustling spaces alone. And she wonders why they cant find some way to live together.

title: Complaint Box | Meetings Bring Out the Worst
description: When I was a 19-year-old college sophomore, I went to my first grown-up meeting. I was working several hours a week for a political science professor, and any escape from collating scholarly papers about demographic voting trends seemed exotic and terribly adult.

title: Israel Plan to Build Clouds Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Israel ended an unofficial construction freeze in Jewish neighborhoods in East Jerusalem on Friday, announcing plans to build 238 housing units. The move comes as hard-won peace talks are stalled over the question of whether Israel will extend its broader construction moratorium in the West Bank.

title: Chinese Dissidents Sign Letter Supporting Nobel Winner
description: Chinas spate of public agitation for political reform continued Friday, as more than 100 Chinese intellectuals and dissidents signed and posted an online letter asking that the Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo be released from prison and that government security officers stop harassing his wife, Liu Xia. In line with Charter 08, the pro-democracy manifesto that Mr. Liu co-authored and which led to his imprisonment, signers of the new letter also asked that government leaders make good on their oft-repeated promise to reform the political system.

title: Paladino as Hugger, Not Fighter
description: What were reading this morning: a Staten Island man arrested in Tel Aviv in the killing of his parents, and news from the campaign trail and New Yorks courtrooms.

title: Laptop Thigh
description: Rash caused by the heat from a laptop.In an article titled Laptop thigh skin rash warning, the BBC reported that heat generated by laptops can cause a rash, particularly when the computers are placed on bare skin for hours at a time:

title: Regulation Footwear | Stubbs & Wootton
description: Handcrafted in Europe and unconsciously self-conscious, Stubbs & Wootton slippers have attained a cultlike following among the nouveau preppy set. Not surprisingly, when Lisa Birnbach was working on True Prep: Its a Whole New Old World, a recent digital-era update of The Official Preppy Handbook, she had Stubbs & Wootton create a pair of gray flannel shoes ($425) to be featured inside. If you needed any more proof of the company being synonymous with entitled glamour, the embroidered English setter that appears on the shoes vamp also snagged the books cover.

title: The Early Word: Delaware-Bound
description: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. have been doing a fair bit of campaigning in this midterm campaign  and on Friday, they get to do it together.

title: U.S. Stocks Mixed on Fed Signal and Retail Sales
description: Stocks were mixed Friday as investors weighed encouraging retail news and signs of new Fed measures to bolster the economy against the impact of the tangled foreclosure process on the nations banks.

title: Man Sought in Parents Deaths Is Caught in Israel
description: An international manhunt ended Friday when a man being sought for questioning in the fatal stabbings of his parents in their Staten Island home was captured in Israel, the New York City police said.

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Vampire 2.0
description: American Vampire, another series about those bloodsucking monsters of the night, has landed at No. 1 on the hardcover list. The collected edition contains the first five issues of the monthly series and features two narratives. The main story, about a woman named Pearl who is turned into a vampire in the 1920s, is written by Scott Snyder, the creator of the series. The back-up story, written by Stephen King, is about Skinner Sweet, the first of a new breed of vampires born in the days of Americas Wild West. The series is illustrated by Rafael Albuquerque.

title: Foreclosure Crisis Trips Up a SPAC
description: The foreclosure crisis has an unusual capital markets twist. A law firm at the center of the controversy in Florida, the Law Offices of David J. Stern, sold its foreclosure-servicing business to a special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC, the Chardan 2008 China Acquisition Corporation, less than a year ago. The newly formed company is called DJSP Enterprises.

title: Middlebury Dean Says SAT or ACT Score Is Seldom a Deal Breaker
description: Mr. Clagett is dean of admissions of Middlebury College.

title: Sorting Myth From Fact as Volt Makes Its Debut
description: LAST week, General Motors began its press introduction for the 2011 Chevrolet Volt, which is scheduled to be in dealerships next month. The program included detailed engineering and marketing presentations, and journalists drove the cars about 200 miles on Michigan roads.

title: The Caucus: Oprah Supports Jon Stewart Rally
description: Saying I think we need a little bit more sanity in the world, Oprah Winfrey endorsed Jon Stewarts coming rally by offering to send every member of his studio audience on Thursday night to Washington, The Caucus notes.

title: Inside the List
description: LIBRARY SCIENCE: In A Short History of Nearly Everything (2003), which spent a whopping 76 weeks on the hardcover and paperback best-seller lists, Bill Bryson provided witty CliffsNotes on a panoply of natural phenomena, from supernovas to slime molds. With At Home, new at No. 6 on the hardcover nonfiction list, he aims to write a history of domestic life without leaving the house  in his case, an 1851 rectory in a quiet English village. Bryson wanders his rooms musing on subjects like the evolution of fish knives and the modernization of toilets, stopping in the library to marvel briefly at the revolution brought about by cheap books. When Thomas Jeffersons father died in 1757, Bryson writes, he left a library of 42 books, and that was regarded as pretty impressive. A library of 400 books  the number that John Harvard left at his death  was considered so colossal that they named Harvard College after him. Over the course of his life, Harvard had acquired books at the rate of about 12 a year. Jefferson, over the course of his life, bought books at the rate of about 12 a month.

title: The Italian Jobber
description: Federico Marchetti likes to compare himself to Caronte, the boatman who leads Dante into the underworld. Hes joking  sort of. Since June 2000, when he founded Yoox.com, the online merchant of discounted high-end clothes and accessories, Marchetti has been helping fashion labels navigate the Internets murky waters.

title: Read My Book? Tour My House
description: This past summer, I sat in Norman Mailers living room in Provincetown, Mass., as the sun beat on the windows looking out to the bay, listening to Mailers literary executor and longtime friend, J. Michael Lennon, tell stories about Norm, his wives and his writing habits. I was there as a writing fellow at the Norman Mailer Center, which is what the brick house on Commercial Street has become, and our group, Lennon told us, was going to have a special opportunity to tour the house, including Mailers attic study, which has been preserved in amber. Mailer was in the middle of writing a book when he died, and after his death nothing was touched. The plan is to have the room stay that way forever,  Lennon said.

title: Editors Choice
description: NEMESIS,  by Philip Roth (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) Set mostly in Newark in 1944 and suffused with tenderness, Roths novel tells the story of a military reject, a young phys ed teacher, who turns a polio outbreak into his own patriotic battleground.

title: Final Movement
description: Is there any genre convention John Lawton hasnt boldly disregarded, often to brilliant effect? While ostensibly grounded in post-World War II London, his elegant police procedurals featuring Inspector Frederick Troy of Scotland Yard succeed in traversing fluid timelines. His characters have solid fictional substance, even as they routinely interact with real-life figures to insinuate themselves into critical events in history. And although Inspector Troy observes the basic investigative procedures, Lawton is quick to discard them when he wants to expand his crime narratives into international espionage thrillers.

title: Paperback Row
description: COWBOYS FULL: The Story of Poker,  by James McManus (Picador, $18.) McManus, whose splendid earlier book Positively Fifth Street described his improbable rise to the final table in the World Series of Poker in 2000, here offers a lively account of pokers past and present. It is, he says, a particularly American game, combining Puritan values  self-control, diligence, the steady accumulation of savings . . . with what might be called the open-market cowboys desire to get very rich very quickly. McManus writes with verve and knowledge, our reviewer, Robert Pinsky, said, and the book is entertaining, informative and genial.

title: 3G Gets Nearly 94% of Burger King Shares
description: 3G Capital said on Friday that nearly 94 percent of the common shares of Burger King have been tendered into its $3.26 billion offer for the fast-food chain.

title: Jolie Defends Film After Permit Is Cancelled in Bosnia
description: Angelina Jolie said she hopes audiences will wait to see her coming film about a romance set against the Bosnian war before drawing any conclusions about it, Reuters reported.

title: Never Grow Old
description: An attempt to publish the inventory of Mickey Mantle iconography began in February 2009 and will continue well into next year. From Mickey Mantle vanity license plates to Mickey Mantle postcards to Mickey Mantle bobblehead dolls to Mickey Mantle postcards depicting him holding Mickey Mantle bobblehead dolls, the cataloged, photographed and priced relics will ultimately exceed 2,000, and will have filled 200 pages in the memorabilia industrys weekly Sports Collectors Digest. Included in the reckoning are at least 30 full-scale Mickey Mantle biographies, half a dozen of which carry the Mantle imprimatur as author, co-author or frontman.

title: Up Front: Keith Olbermann
description: Well into his 20s, Keith Olbermann was an insatiable Yankees fan.

title: Another Family Sedan That Is Firing on Fewer Cylinders
description: TESTED 2010 Buick LaCrosse CX

title: Hey, Candidates, Time to Man Up
description: Its official. The bipartisan phrase of the week, hands down, is man up.

title: Questions About the Chevrolet Volt
description: Earlier this week, Paul Stenquist wrote about some of the questions raised since General Motors officially unveiled the production version of the Chevrolet Volt:

title: Q. and A. With Tyler Kepner
description: With the league championship series about to begin, Tyler Kepner, The Timess national baseball writer, will answer readers questions today. The American League starts things off tonight when the Yankees return to Texas. Three times in the late 1990s the Yankees defeated the Rangers in division series, but this year, Kepner wrote, the Rangers have a weapon that may be unbeatable: Cliff Lee, a left-handed ace the Yankees covet and cannot seem to beat.

title: Friday Reading: The Biggest Potential Tax Policy Mistakes
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Regulators Oppose BHP-Rio Joint Venture
description: 10:43 a.m. | Updated

title: Its About Time to Check the Fine Print on Your Health Plan
description: BACK to the future  that about sums up this years open enrollment season.

title: Brooklyn Housing Market Is Rebounding
description: The Brooklyn housing market is on the rebound, according to a report being released Friday. Average sales prices during the third quarter increased by more than 7 percent over both the second quarter and last years third quarter, though they remain well below peak levels. And apartments were selling about a third faster than they were at the same time last year. Read more on the housing recovery in the Real Estate section.

title: Looking Ahead to Open Enrollment
description: In this weeks Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explains what this years open enrollment period means to consumers.

title: The Professor Goes to Washington
description: Sometime in the late 1980s, I had lunch with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The drug war was a hot topic of conversation, and at the start of the lunch I asked him how he thought it was going. To answer the question fully, he said, would require a little historical background.

title: Harvard Colleagues Clash Over F.D.A.
description: In a very public war of words, two Harvard colleagues have been debating the effectiveness of the Food and Drug Administration following publication of a new book, Reputation and Power: Organizational Image and Pharmaceutical Regulation at the F.D.A., by Daniel Carpenter, a professor at the university.

title: A Grisly Murder Trial, in 140-Character Bits
description: NEW HAVEN  Dr. William A. Petit Jr., whose wife and daughters were killed by two intruders in Cheshire, Conn., took the witness stand. It was one of the most expectantly intense moments of the three-week trial of one of two defendants in the case. Every seat in the courtroom was taken.

title: Obama Lesson: Shovel Ready Not So Ready
description: Even before President Obama entered the White House, he and his allies successfully used the allure of shovel ready infrastructure projects to help sell his $787 billion stimulus legislation to a resistant Congress and a wary public.

title: Exchange Student on the Honor Roll
description: WHEN a bankrupt General Motors realized it had to downsize its money pit of a house, tossing away Pontiac, Saturn, Saab and Hummer the way parents give away their childrens old toys, it surprised some people by keeping Buick.

title: Borough Skirmishes
description: Alfredo Batista, the 19-year-old drug-dealing hero of Matt Burgesss scorching first novel, Dogfight, a Love Story, is about to have the most nail-biting weekend of his life. Its June 2002, and in the next 24 hours, Alfredos older brother, Tariq, released from prison, will arrive at his familys apartment in Queens, where Alfredo lives with Isabel, who was Tariqs girlfriend when he was incarcerated, but who is now seven months pregnant with Alfredos child.

title: Despite Protests, Adam Lambert Calls for Love at Malaysian Concert
description: A concert performed by Adam Lambert drew fans as well as protesters in Malaysia, but the singer kept his word that he would follow the restrictions placed on the show, The Associated Press reported.

title: The Case of the Demon Mirror
description: ACURA steering racks that squeal and BMWs that emit strange noises or show signs of demonic possession are among the subjects of the latest technical service bulletins from automakers.

title: An A for Jean George
description: The pendulum has swung for Jean Georges, the four-star restaurant in the Trump International that was the subject of an embarrassing  (if popular!) post on Diners Journal earlier this week, after a wandering cockroach was spotted in the dining room.

title: Winking at the Apocalypse
description: When I realized (after Id agreed to write this review) that Fay Weldons latest novel, her 29th, is set in a totalitarian England after the fatal crash of capitalism, I considered looking to see if I still had any refills left for my old Wellbutrin prescription. Generally, I keep away from fiction or movies about the end of the world, even if its just about the end of the world as we know it. (I avoid stories set in prison for the same reason: guaranteed nightmares, often involving ferrets, a small cage and me.) In this case, however, I neednt have worried. Despite a surfeit of the genres requisite trappings (food rationing, secret police, universal surveillance, dopey government acronyms), Chalcot Crescent might be the least depressing  certainly its the most cheerful  dystopian fiction Ive ever come across, thanks to Weldons slashing wit and her refusal to suffer fools gladly, no matter how despotic. Even in a world without reliable electricity or real coffee, life worth living goes bumbling on. This is not quite 1984 with baggy pants, big shoes and a seltzer bottle, but close.

title: Living Down the Past
description: It cannot always be easy to be a German. How does one deal with a recent national history drenched in so much innocent blood? How does a German writer find the right tone to describe it, without escaping into mawkish self-flagellation or nervous apologetics? Whether Bernhard Schlink, a lawyer as well as a novelist, found the right tone in The Reader, his best-selling 1995 novel about the love affair between an illiterate war criminal and an adolescent boy, is open to question. But the combination of erotic allure and earnest moral soul-searching, about sex, growing up and the German past, made the book a worldwide hit.

title: 2011 Buick LaCrosse
description: The LaCrosse is a positive step in the effort to broaden Buicks appeal.

title: Mock Canadian Attack Ad of the Year
description: As Americans argue about the influence political attack ads made with secret special-interest money might be having on the upcoming midterm elections, a shadowy group in Canada has taken credit for trying to sway voters in a tight mayoral race in Winnipeg.

title: One Shining Moment Might Need Some Polishing
description: Preparation for the N.C.A.A. basketball season begins in earnest on Friday as most mens Division One teams hit the practice floor for the first time.

title: On the Origins of Island Life
description: Tuesday, Oct. 12

title: Before He Was Experienced
description: In 1967, a music critic called Jimi Hendrixs music robust and hellish in the same review, which is like describing God as outstanding and divine. Robust just doesnt cut it  that adjective might apply to a Sousa march, but not to such sulphurous anthems as Manic Depression and Foxy Lady.

title: U.S. to Investigate Chinas Clean Energy Aid
description: The economic tension between the United States and China escalated on Friday, as the Obama administration pledged to investigate Beijings subsidies to its growing clean energy industries while delaying a politically volatile report on the Chinese currency.

title: Seeing Things | Transformative Travels
description: The impact of global movement on local environments is examined in an exhibition that opens next week at the Canadian Centre for Architecture in Montreal. Journeys: How Traveling Fruit, Ideas and Buildings Rearrange our Environment, which is on view through March 13, 2011, tells 15 stories about migration and displacement, each associated with a specific place and time.

title: A Personal Look at Mario Vargas Llosa
description: Over on the Book Reviews Paper Cuts blog, Eric Lichtblau, a reporter in The Timess Washington bureau, writes of his familys personal ties to Mario Vargas Llosa, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature last week.

title: Path to Dissent
description: So whats happened to our Jews? the agronomist Koryako asks his neighbors, grinning slyly. Children, old men  I havent glimpsed a Jew all day. Its as if theyd never existed. And only yesterday they were all coming back from the market with 12-kilo baskets!

title: 2011 Buick Regal
description: The new Regal might be the best-looking sedan from any American automaker.

title: Under God . . . or Not
description: Todays conservatives often describe themselves as strict constructionists, seeking the original meaning of the nations founding texts. In the case of the Pledge of Allegiance, a much fetishized if not legally binding document, this approach is unlikely to yield the desired political result. As Jeffrey Owen Jones and Peter Meyer note, the original author of the pledge was a former Christian Socialist minister who hoped to redeem the United States from its class and ethnic antagonisms. Interpretations of its meaning have been growing more conservative, not more liberal, ever since.

title: When the Beat Came in a Box
description: In December 2001, while on assignment in Tokyo, the photographer Lyle Owerko came across a funky old boombox at an outdoor market. He was struck by its bulk and intrigued by its link to a vanished New York of break dancing and graffiti, and as soon as he returned home to New York he began scouring flea markets and eBay for more of them.

title: A Physicists Climate Complaints
description: Almost 20 years ago, Harold Lewis, a respected physicist who had advised the government and the Pentagon on matters ranging from nuclear winter to missile defense, included his assessment of climate change from the buildup of human-generated greenhouse gases in a book on technological risk:

title: Orpheus Chamber Orchestra Announces Winners of Commissioning Program
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which takes the populist view that musical interpretations can be shaped by the ensemble rather than by a conductor, has expanded on that concept in a commissioning program, Project 440. The orchestras goal was to commission four composers to help celebrate its 40th anniversary. Intent on getting its audience involved, it joined forces with WQXR, the classical radio station, which opened the process to its listeners.

title: The News From Shanghai
description: In the first four decades of the Peoples Republic, Shanghai existed in a strange limbo, a kind of ghostly half-life. No longer the jeweled sewer of decadence and corruption it had once been  a city of opium smokers and courtesans, millionaires and beggars, the high elegance of the Bund and the conspiratorial darkness of the foreign concessions  it lingered on under Communism as an industrial center, a vital source of taxable wealth, but symbolically something of an embarrassment, its foreignness a stain that couldnt be washed away. Then, after Deng Xiaoping liberalized its economy in 1991, Shanghai roared back to life and regained its place as a financial and cultural hub, a symbol of Chinas dizzying emergence on the world stage.

title: Sweetleaf Coffee Expands
description: Sweetleaf  is entering a new weight category. The Long Island City, Queens, coffee spot tripled in size after taking over the storefront next door and adding a pour over bar (where coffee will be brewed by the cup), and single origin espresso  right now its Stumptown Coffee Roasters Ethiopian Mordecofe.

title: Five-Link Friday: Twitter Police and a 404 Not Found
description: So the U.F.O. was probably a bunch of balloons freed from a Westchester wedding, or maybe from the feting in Times Square of a Spanish street, or both. Well, it was fun while it lasted, but never fear, we have plenty of uninvited guests appearing out of the blue all over the city, and they are real.

title: The Life She Fled
description: Travel back to another era, to another sensibility, to an age when fantasy and nightmare mingled in the air with the scent of lime blossom, when survival would soon come to depend on the capacity for selective forgetting. With her enthralling, richly imagined and remorseless novel, The Blindness of the Heart, Julia Franck, born in 1970 in East Germany but raised in the West, emerges on the literary stage with a work reminiscent of some grand regional forebears. Winner of the 2007 German Book Prize, her novel brings together the haunting folk echoes of Dinesens Winters Tales, the visual immediacy of Isherwoods Goodbye to Berlin, the narrative cohesion of Manns Buddenbrooks.

title: What Were Reading: PermaBear-Speak
Able to Take the Mound in a Single Bound
description: If you havent already, now is the perfect time to note how baseballs Supermen have changed. Once, in the last millennium, they had forearms the size of Volkswagens (with accompanying sketchy pharmaceutical histories) and everyone talked about the long ball and whether the parks were too small and how much Babe Ruth would so surely approve. But heading into the league championship series this weekend, any comparisons to Ruth will have to mention that he was also a pitcher and the only comparison involving a Volkswagen is whether the Yankees C.C. Sabathia would fit in one.

title: Afghan War Is Off the Voters Radar
description: Polling suggests that the war in Afghanistan is barely a blip on voters radars as the midterm elections approach, according to a report in The New York Times by Dalia Sussman and Megan Thee-Brenan.

title: New Ratmansky and Wheeldon Works Highlight American Ballet Theaters Spring Season
description: Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon continue their reign as the most in-demand choreographers in the ballet world this spring at American Ballet Theater. Two new works by the choreographers, as well as the premiere of a revival of Antony Tudors 1967 Shadowplay, are among the highlights of the companys spring season, which runs May 16 to July 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Egghead
description: David Susskind was an egotist, a womanizer, an intellectual, a charmer, a producer of high-minded television dramas and a talk-show pioneer. Now he is a giant roar from the past.

title: A Life Between
description: As of 2005, the United States had a black, female secretary of state, and yet black America has largely observed this more than celebrated it. There is a tacit sense out there that Condoleezza Rice isnt black in the real way, as we might put it. Not with us, perhaps.

title: Responding to Reader Comments
description: Its great to get the comments to my introductory post. Like pretty much all working human beings  and unlike our computers and gadgets, unless theres a new iPhone app Ive missed  I appreciate appreciation, so thanks much for the welcoming notes. I do, however, try to pay special attention to criticisms, concerns and requests, in the hopes that they can lead me to do at least an incrementally better job. To prove Im paying attention, let me respond to a few of those.

title: Everything Turns to Fire
description: The opening sentence of Amelia Grays Museum of the Weird  One morning, I woke to discover I had given birth overnight  could serve as a metaphor for the creation of a certain type of story. While many stories come into being through intense authorial diligence and cogitation, others spring into existence in an instant, discharging themselves onto the page almost by magic.

title: Actual Families on Virtual Pages
description: The humorous video I linked to earlier this week, about a fictional app that defends a childs Facebook profile from his mother, led to two very serious e-mails from readers struggling with the role of their actual family in their virtual life.

title: Chile y Todo el Mundo: Connecting the Chilean Miners Story With Universal Themes
description: Overview | Why did the rescue of 33 miners in Chile captivate the world? What universal themes are found in their story? In this lesson, students create a multimedia project that addresses curricular themes related to the will to survive and the ability to see ourselves in the struggles of others.

title: The Fashion Cycle | Linus Bikes
description: Long before gas-guzzling Western capitals did something of a backpedal by implementing safer bike lanes and investing in bike-for-hire schemes, Adam McDermott and Chad Kushner, the South African founders of Linus Bikes, spent years traveling bicycle-centric cities in Europe and Asia. We loved the simple, utilitarian bikes wed find in other countries, McDermott says, and wished there was a similar urban bike-as-transportation culture back home. Inspired by the elegant but basic designs of French city bikes of the 50s and 60s, Linus achieves the aesthetic of a modern vintage cycle: straight, clean lines, monochromatic colors and no excessive logos. Its new bicycle carryalls  crafted from wax canvas, oilskin leather and solid brass hardware that is designed to age nicely  are saddle bags you want.

title: Weekend Competition: Please Do Not Make Eye Contact with the Robots
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to invent warning signs from the future.

title: BMW Drivers Are the Angriest in Britain, Says Survey
description: If youre a BMW driver  now, dont get mad at this  you are the angriest motorist on the road, at least in Britain.

title: Pressing My Nose to the Glass in China
description: For the past week Ive been in Beijing, my first trip to China. Except for the citys famous traffic jams, the city is nothing like I had expected. And what did I expect of this remarkable, sprawling, fast-changing city? Today  Friday in Beijing  I had lunch with Angelica Cheung, the editor in chief of Vogue China, at the China Grill on the 66th floor of the Park Hyatt, and since I arrived at the restaurant a few minutes early, I took a moment to press my nose to the windows. The sprawl of new buildings  skyscrapers, hotels, apartment blocks  is almost unfathomable and seemingly endless.

title: iRead
description: In Lane Smiths new book, called, simply, Its a Book, a mouse, a jackass and a monkey  all drawn with the kind of early-60s geometric-minded stylization that requires a gentle reminder of which animal is which on the title page  discover a new thing. Flat and rectangular, with a hard cover and a soft, yielding inside, it baffles the jackass, while the behatted monkey tries patiently to explain its curious technology. Do you blog with it? the jackass says. No, its a book, the monkey explains. This only makes the donkeys exasperation keener: Wheres the mouse? Does it need a password? Can you make the characters fight? Can it text, tweet, toot? No, none of that, the monkey explains, and then Monkey hands the book to Jackass, who takes it worriedly, like a nut too hard to crack.

title: Early Fiction by Wes Anderson, Owen Wilson and Colum McCann
description: Perhaps the only place we expected to see Colum McCann side by side with Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson is at a Barnes & Noble where someone misfiled a paperback copy of Let the Great World Spin between DVDs of Bottle Rocket and The Royal Tenenbaums.

title: New Jersey Arts Center Sets Real Estate Venture
description: Performing arts centers typically present performances, not develop real estate.

title: How the West Was Won
description: Tarnation! Seems like a mules age since weve had a hero of American folklore worth wasting song and spit over, someone big enough to wear the boots of Paul Bunyan, Pecos Bill and John Henry, a giant who cuts canyons with his plow and seeds lakes with his tears.

title: Childrens Bookshelf
description: ALPHAOOPS!  H Is for Halloween.  By Alethea Kontis.Illustrated by Bob Kolar.  Candlewick. $15.99. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Iverson, Spurned by N.B.A. Teams, Considering Turkey
description: Its been a long-running relationship, spanning through good to bad times, from love to angry frustration.

title: Miners No Longer Forced to Order In
description: Among the grateful bear hugs and kisses the world didnt see on television after the Chilean miners emerged to life on the surface this week were those given to their chef. For more than a month, Edmundo Ramrez and a staff of 12 had sent five meals a day nearly half a mile underground to them.

title: TimesCast | October 15, 2010
description: What makes a true Tea Party candidate; buying a foreclosed home and a look at end credits of documentaries.

title: Miners Begin to Speak, Though Sparingly, of Ordeal
description: A first-hand account of how the 33 miners survived their emotional, physical and psychological trials while trapped for 69 days a half-mile under the Chilean desert has yet to emerge.

title: Taking Basil Beyond Pesto
description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman takes basil beyond pesto, offering fresh new ways to use the popular herb.

title: You Know Youre a Milan Insider When ...
description: 1. You have your own knife at Controvapore.

title: Happy Birthday to Us
description: One year ago today, The Learning Network was reborn as a blog.

title: Tate Modern Closes Access to Sunflower Seeds
description: When an installation by the Chinese conceptual artist Ai Weiwei opened on Tuesday at Turbine Hall, the cavernous entrance space of the Tate Modern in London, visitors were encouraged to touch and even walk on the 100 million hand-crafted porcelain sunflower seeds that gave the piece its name. But on Thursday this kind of intimate interaction stopped. Officials at the museum closed off access to Sunflower Seeds, and is now only allowing visitors to see it from a walkway above the hall.

title: Red Sox Owner Takes Over Liverpool Soccer Club
description: Long-suffering Liverpool F.C. fans clamoring for change can rejoice: the English soccer team officially has a new owner, the investor group that also owns the Boston Red Sox.

title: Georgia Shifts Leaders Powers, but Some See a Political Ploy
description: TBILISI, Georgia  The Georgian Parliament gave final approval on Friday to constitutional amendments reducing the powers of the president and strengthening the role of the prime minister after presidential elections in 2013.

title: Aging: Longer Life Expectancy Seen for Hispanics
description: Scientists call it the Hispanic paradox: despite high rates of poverty and relatively low rates of health insurance, Hispanics in the United States tend to outlive African-Americans and non-Hispanic whites.

title: Flanagan to Face Her Fears on the Streets of New York
description: As a first-time marathoner, Shalane Flanagan will confront a flurry of unknown factors at the New York City Marathon on Nov. 7. Her seven years as a professional track and field athlete running a variety of distances from the 1,500 meters to 10,000 on synthetic track surfaces will provide minimal comfort on the blacktopped roads of an urban marathon. Winning a bronze medal in the 10,000 at the 2008 Beijing Olympics has done little to ease her concerns.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nicole Krauss
description: This week: Nicole Krauss on her new novel, Great House; Steven R. Weisman on the fascinating life and letters of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Peter Jacksons Deal for The Hobbit Is Finalized
description: 1:43 p.m. | Updated

title: Penny-Pinching, N.H.L. Style
description: In the early days of the new N.H.L. season, it seems the accountants are having a bigger impact than the players and coaches. Whether its big name stars being demoted for cap purposes, or the Devils being unable to ice a full lineup, everything seems to revolve around dollars and cents.

title: Unnamed Sources in Tribune Story Lead Weigh on Readers Trust
description: I enjoyed David Carrs immense takeout on the Tribune Company Oct. 6 as much as the next reader. It detailed the unorthodox  and according to some, toxic  management style of top executive Randy Michaels and his crew, who were transplanted from careers in the wacky world of radio to the helm of a tradition-proud news organization known for its serious mien.

title: Hope for Human Fertility in a Study of a Worm
description: Modern medicine, a healthy lifestyle and a shot or two of Botox might leave a woman feeling youthful for decades, but by her early 30s, her reproductive ability is already in rapid decline.

title: McBride Looks Back, and Ahead
description: The notion of playing professional soccer until age 38 hardly seemed plausible to Brian McBride.

title: Virus Deadly in Livestock Is No More, U.N. Declares
description: In only the second elimination of a disease in history, rinderpest  a virus that used to kill cattle by the millions, leading to famine and death among humans  has been declared wiped off the face of the earth.

title: North Korea Threatens to Attack if South Resumes Propaganda
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In the first aggressive threat by North Korea since a new leadership hierarchy was announced last month, the North vowed to attack South Korea if the South resumed a propaganda war along their border, the Norths official Korean Central News Agency said Friday.

title: The Battle of Newtown Creek
description: Newtown Creek, the heavily polluted waterway recently chosen for a federal Superfund cleanup, equally burdens Queens and Brooklyn because it straddles both boroughs. But several Queens officials have written to the Environmental Protection Agency to make sure the agency doesnt play favorites.

title: An Astute Emancipator
description: To the Editor:

title: D.S.C.C. Has Record-Breaking Month
description: 4:09 p.m. | Updated The National Republican Senatorial Committee has now reported their September numbers as well. The Republican committee raised $8.3 million in September, and has collected a total of $86.4 million in the two-year election cycle.

title: Orientation
description: To the Editor:

title: Back to the Circus
description: It began in 2008, that improbably toxic year: an endless search for almost-jobs; the completion of an expensively worthless degree; a lying, cheating girlfriend; a crashed stock portfolio (bought with money from the Brooklyn home I flipped as a successful subprime borrower). I had to get away. I flew to Los Angeles, bought a motorcycle and rode for weeks as far as Seattle, only to be summoned overnight back to L.A., where my deaf aunt was dying of the leukemia she had managed for 23 years. According to her friends, she was dying because she quit her medical treatments after a Gypsy psychic convinced her that the doctors were lying to her.

title: Little Brother Is Watching
description: In George Orwells 1984, that novel of totalitarian politics whose great mistake was to emphasize the villainy of societys masters while playing down the mischief of the masses, the goal of communications technology was brutal and direct: to ensure the dominance of the state. The sinister telescreens placed in peoples homes spewed propaganda and conducted surveillance, keeping the population passive and the leadership firmly in control. In the face of constant monitoring, all people could do was sterilize their behavior, conceal their thoughts and carry on like model citizens.

title: Reality Lags the Football Dream at Rutgers
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  No one can blame Greg Schiano for believing he can build Rutgers into a national football power. When he arrived 10 years ago, the Scarlet Knights had appeared in a single postseason bowl game in 135 years of competition. This year, Rutgers is seeking its sixth consecutive bowl invitation.

title: The Queen
description: In your new biography of Cleopatra, you take issue with historians who have attributed her achievements to her looks and implied that she slept her way to the top. For reasons I am sure you can explain to me, it has always been preferable to attribute a womans success to her beauty rather than brains. We seem convinced that men strategize while women scheme. Men are authoritative while women are shrill.

title: E-Readers Collective
description: Any piece of writing thats for sale lives and dies by display copy  titles, subtitles, cover lines, jacket copy, blurbs, headlines, captions, pull quotes. Display copy frames most literary production, high and low, and instructs readers in how to interpret it.

title: Rough Patches
description: Hey, big guy, Dr. Wolffe Nadoolman called out in a friendly voice, why dont you come help me and your mom figure out where this rash of yours is coming from? The gangly 4-year-old boy clambered into the chair and sat down expectantly. The skin on his face was fair and unblemished. But according to his mother, it wasnt clear a week ago.

title: Hezbollahs Independence
description: To the Editor:

title: CNBC: Whitman on the Business of Calif.
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC interviewed Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for California governor.

title: Giving E-Books an Edge
description: To the Editor:

title: Quote Unquote | What Not to Wear
description: Rodartes Laura Mulleavy tells Opening Ceremony about the new collection. Is she the anti-Phoebe Philo?

title: The Anesthesiologists Game
description: I am an anesthesiologist. A few of my patients are children undergoing their first surgery  understandably nervous, sometimes in tears. Medications can calm them; developing a rapport with them also helps. One way I do that is to propose a contest. If they can pop the balloon (the bag an anesthetized patient uses to breathe), they will win a fabulous prize  a pony, a puppy, a motorcycle. This task is effectively impossible (but their deep breathing puts them to sleep faster). Some nurses complain that children in the recovery room are very disappointed when told they did not win a prize. Should I suspend the contest? MARK ISAAC, MANSFIELD, OHIO

title: Week in Pictures, Oct. 15
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: The Elusive Small-House Utopia
description: Every year, in conjunction with a big trade show, the magazine Builder creates something it calls its concept home. The house is an exhibition on a theme  the 2004 edition, for example, was called the Ultimate Family Home  but also a commercial venture. Attendees of the International Builders Show can walk through a model, and when the show is over, the concept is quite literally put to a test when the finished house is offered up for sale on the open market. During the last decades real estate boom, the annual demonstration kept up with the times: designs abounded with baronial features like colonnades, cathedral ceilings and observation towers, and they sometimes topped 6,000 square feet. But then the crash came, wiping out credit lines and shaking the industrys confidence. For this years show, Boyce Thompson, the editorial director of Builder, wanted a look more attuned to curtailed appetites, so he came up with a concept that he called a Home for the New Economy.

title: The Traditionalist
description: IN A BLUSTERY ECONOMIC climate, with waves of populist resentment thundering outside the thickest paneled doors, what do rich people want in a home? Is it their wish to be exposed in glass-and-steel boxes? Will they opt for precarious-seeming triumphs of cantilevered engineering? Or are they, perhaps, looking for something else? Last winter, I went on a fact-finding mission to 15 Central Park West. The project is the most successful high-end Manhattan residential development in recent memory, having gone to contract on all of its 202 units for approximately $2 billion, before its doors opened in late 2007. My guides were Robert A. M. Stern, whose New York-based architecture firm designed the building, and William Lie Zeckendorf, who developed it with his brother, Arthur. Both Zeckendorfs live there. So do Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs (alongside many of his generals; Goldman Sachs helped finance the venture); Sanford Weill, the former Citigroup chairman; and a smattering of bold-faced names (Denzel Washington, Sting).

title: Ask the Contractor
description: Im considering radiant heat for my bathroom. How does it work, and is it a good idea?DISALVO: You can only add radiant heat if you intend to renovate your bathroom or at least replace the floor. Once you have the floor up, however, radiant-heat systems are easy to install. You have them on a thermostat, and they heat up and heat the floor, which is very comfortable. The downside is that it takes several hours for the floor to warm up, but once it does it eliminates the need for a radiator. WIENER: There are two kinds of systems. The water system uses plastic tubing with warm water. The electrical uses mats of electrical coils. Water is mostly not allowed in apartment buildings because of the potential for leaks. Both systems are good. DARDICK: I havent done a master bathroom in the last three years that did not have a heated floor. Everybody loves them. I dont know anyone who doesnt like them. But if you live in a cold-weather climate, a heated floor may not be the entire solution for heating a whole room.

title: Keeping Score: Rangers Hitters Are Out of Order
description: Its impressive that the Texas Rangers knocked off the team with the best record in the American League for their first postseason series win in team history. Its even more impressive that they did so with a batting order that defies reason. If Ron Washington is serious about winning the pennant, he should read up on the latest research into lineup construction and give his order a makeover.

title: While England Moves Toward 2018, U.S. Focused on 2022
description: Americans will have to wait at least 12 more years to see a World Cup final game at home. The USA Bid Committee said Friday that it had withdrawn from trying to secure the 2018 World Cup and would instead focus on trying to win the 2022 event.

title: Pregame Huddle: Expecting the Unexpected
description: Coach Les Miles continues to work his magic for the undefeated L.S.U. and Ohio State faces its biggest test yet against Wisconsin.

title: When the Dust Blossom Clears in Kandahar
description: ZHARI, Afghanistan  I yelled to my men, ordering them to get down and take cover and orient their weapons eastward, halting our joint patrol with the Afghan National Army. A sniper had been terrorizing our small outpost in the middle of the Zhari district in Kandahar for three weeks. This menace had created a phantom persona, like the Ghost of Christmas Past who had followed us to the deserts of Afghanistan.

title: Robbing the Cradle Sitter
description: I have two little boys and a nanny who takes care of them twice a week. It took me months to find her. A neighbor asked for her number to see if she might baby-sit occasionally. I gave it to her because our nanny was always looking for more hours. Now, the neighbor has called to say shes gotten a job and has offered our nanny a full-time position. Our nanny is better off, but I cant help feeling betrayed by the neighbor. Could she have handled this better? M. D.

title: Reading the Fine Print in Health Plans
description: In this weeks Patient Money column, Walencia Konrad reminds all of us about the open enrollment periods for health insurance that accompany this season. The column offers some guidance as to what to look for and also outlines areas of anticipated increases in costs.

title: Oliver Haunted by 96 Playoff Loss to Yankees
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  In the household of Darren and Melissa Oliver, its never too early to teach your children the savvy skills of survival. So when Oliver pitched for the Mets, in 2006, he made sure that his two sons, Brock and Maxwell, learned something vital for navigating New York City  how to hail a taxicab.

title: Somali Militias Clash, Undermining New Strategy
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Fighting broke out in central Somalia on Friday between two moderate Islamist militias that the United States and others had been counting on, as part of a new strategy, to stave off the Shabab, the nations most powerful insurgents. Shortly before the clashes started, a Western aid worker was kidnapped from the same area.

title: Bedbugs Chomp Their Way Into the Fine Print
description: BEDBUGS have infiltrated more and more places in New York City, and now theyve even found their way into co-op and condominium contracts.

title: The Morning Skate: Bear Hugs and Blindside Hits
description: The N.H.L. general managers get together for their annual early season meeting on Nov. 9 in Toronto and among the agenda items, as Darren Dreger of TSN reported Thursday night (video), the Maple Leafs Brian Burke will again propose re-introducing legal holding.

title: D.N.C. Spokesmans Former Group Didnt Disclose Donors Either
description: Brad Woodhouse, spokesman for the Democratic National Committee, is the latest ally of President Obama to go after the dangers of undisclosed money in the political process.

title: A Deal? Tell It to the Judge
description: EVERYTHING about Jeanine Pirro is fast: the way she walks, the way she talks, the way she holds up a sweater in Filenes Basement and asks for your opinion, but declares, You dont like it. Youre not interested, because you paused to consider the question (and the sweater, which frankly wasnt bad).

title: City to Get Federal Disaster Money for Tornadoes
description: Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island were declared federal disaster areas for the purposes of tornado cleanup, the governors office announced Thursday night. That means the federal government will pick up three-quarters of the tab for emergency response, debris removal and repairs to public property resulting from last months destructive storm  about $22 million out of an estimated $27 million. The federal government has not yet acted on Gov. David A. Patersons request for individual relief for homeowners, renters and businesses.

title: What You Get for $2,000,000 in ...
description: Listings for New York, Sacramento, San Antonio and nine other locations.

title: Top Lawyer Leaving House Ethics Office
description: The staff director and chief counsel of the independent Office of Congressional Ethics in the House, Leo J. Wise, is stepping down in November to join the United States Attorneys Office in Maryland and perhaps sidestep an inevitable political fight over the future of the ethics office.

title: The Bombshell Squad
description: Black corsets, big hair, luscious lips: Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have a firm belief in what makes an Italian beauty  even if shes from Utah.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nicole Krauss
description: This week: Nicole Krauss on her new novel, Great House; Steven R. Weisman on the fascinating life and letters of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Book Review Podcast: Nicole Krauss
description: This week: Nicole Krauss on her new novel, Great House; Steven R. Weisman on the fascinating life and letters of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Book Review Podcast: Nicole Krauss
description: This week: Nicole Krauss on her new novel, Great House; Steven R. Weisman on the fascinating life and letters of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: The Caucus
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Kate Zernike discuss what makes a true Tea Party candidate.

title: Openly Gay in the Bronx, but Constantly on Guard
description: Keith Mitchell, a 24-year-old who likes to be called Sparkles, strolled down East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx, discussing what he would wear on a date that night. As he rounded a corner, a stocky man with baggy pants and arms covered in tattoos locked eyes on him.

title: A Subway, 4 iPhones and a Little Serendipity
description: Riding the subway in New York City offers its fair share of frustrations and randomness. There are the rats that act like theyre on the M.T.A. payroll, the packed cars and the unpredictability of the train schedules.

title: Wheelies: Pastor Terry Jones Edition
description: Weird car news from around the Web

title: Medvedev Names New Mayor of Moscow
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev appointed a loyalist to be Moscows mayor on Friday, solidifying the Kremlins control over political life less than three weeks after he ousted one of the countrys more colorful and independent politicians from the job.

title: Letters: Kafkas Last Trial
description: It simply wont do for Elif Batuman to epitomize Kafkas working life as working in an insurance agency (Sept. 26). That office was as fruitful a source of Kafkas work an any literary or Freudian critic can conjure.
