In his 14 years as a lawyer, he worked first in Prague for Il Assicurazioni Generali (a Jewish-founded insurance company based in Trieste that featured a menorah in its lobby), the insurer for Workers Compensation in Austria-Hungary before World War I. Before and after the war, he toiled in the same field for the Workers Accident Insurance Institute, the government agency administering benefits for work injuries (no occupational diseases then). Kafkas projection of what Max Weber called the iron cage of bureaucracy was literally lifted from the admittedly boring and unsatisfying work at the compensation agency. The Castle and The Trial are rife with examples, like the official of The Castle who assures the land surveyor that the confusion in question can be proved from the official papers. The response: The papers will not be found.

title: Tacos and Dumplings: Coming Soon to a Park Near You?
description: There it was, in a lineup at the eastern entrance to what was once the Tavern on the Green: the next generation of park food for New York City.

title: Self-Pity in the White House
description: Up to a point, Peter Bakers excellent Times Magazine piece on the mood in the Obama White House inspires a certain amount of sympathy for this administration. When Bakers sources complain that their boss is being unfairly maligned by foes and friends (or frenemies, perhaps) alike, they have a point: The most strident criticisms of the Obama presidency have almost all been at least somewhat unfair, whether its conservatives calling the president a socialist and a radical (when actually hes just a very conventional liberal), left-wingers claiming that hes a sell-out and a crypto-conservative (when actually hes accomplished more for the left than any president since L.B.J.), or D.C. insiders dismissing his political skills and salesmanship (hey, you try being a political salesman when the unemployment rate is 9.5 percent!). Im no great admirer of Barack Obamas policies, but some of the discontent swirling around the White House at the moment is the usual cult-of-the-presidency nonsense, in which the occupant of the Oval Office is held responsible for forces and events beyond his control, and everyone pretends that the world would be perfect if he werent so incompetent, so cowardly, or so evil.

title: Tarred by the Same Brush
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Online | Ts Milan Issue
description: In the Milan Issue, the Italian capital of fashion, design and business is explored to a T. The citys stars are showcased in a lavish portfolio, while a killer palazzo  Gi Ponti bathroom, anyone?  takes you behind the noble facades. Dolce & Gabbana talk about bombshells, Giorgio Armani pens a love note to his hometown, Janine di Giovanni writes on divorce in the age of Berlusconi, the next generation of Missonis share their city, and Maurizio Cattelan flips Milan the bird. Plus: designers to watch, restaurants to try, stores and galleries to explore, and signs that youve become an insider. On the cover: Margareth Mad, the starlet hot enough to play Sofia Loren.

title: 10 Questions for Meg Whitman
description: Meg Whitman, the Republican nominee for governor of California and a former chief executive of eBay, has invested more than $100 million of her personal fortune in a campaign that pits her against Jerry Brown, a Democrat and former governor. Heres a condensed, edited version of the interview that John Harwood conducted with her this week in Bakersfield, Calif.:

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Vittorio Grigolo, Clint Eastwood, Shakira and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Of Freaks, Christian Gentlemen and Brotherly Love
description: Greg W. Prince, co-author of the blog Faith and Fear in Flushing, is a member of the New York Baseball Giants Nostalgia Society.

title: Lending Magnate Settles Fraud Case
description: Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, once the nations largest mortgage lender, agreed to pay $67.5 million on Friday to settle a civil fraud case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission last year.

title: The Caucus Click: Farrell, Pa.
The Rewards of a To-Do List
description: FOR Michael Boots, relocating to the city felt like a now-or-never proposition. If he wanted to live in New York before he became too settled in his career, he needed to get moving. It hit me one day  what am I waiting for? he said. New York is the most exciting city in the world.

title: Video: Les Miles Magic and Other Unexpected Happenings
description: Coach Les Miles continues to work his magic for undefeated L.S.U. and Ohio State faces its biggest test yet against Wisconsin. Paul Myerberg and Connor Ennis with their weekly take on college football in the Pregame Huddle.

title: Ex-Countrywide Executives Settle S.E.C. Case
description: Three former Countrywide Financial executives, including the co-founder, Angelo R. Mozilo, agreed on Friday to pay more than $73 million to settle civil fraud and insider-trading charges from the Securities and Exchange Commission days before a trial was to start.

title: ESPN Slowly Introducing Online Brand for Women
description: In its three decades of existence, ESPN has built a vast sports empire that has aimed to attract nearly every slice of the American sports audience, from teenagers to Hispanics to college students to baby boomers. But it has done little to cater to one group that makes up a quarter of its television audience: women.

title: JetBlue Offers Live In-Flight NFL
description: Football fans who have to travel on Sundays have a reason to rejoice: its now possible to watch live professional football at 30,000 feet above ground.

title: David Susskind
description: Chapter 1

title: World Trade, Once Rising, Is Starting to Sag Again
description: THE rapid recovery in world trade after the financial crisis appears to have slowed this spring and summer, raising new concerns about the global economy. Exports of many countries have stabilized at levels well under the peaks reached before the crisis sent world trade into a tailspin.

title: TimesCast: The Tea Party Candidate
description: In the latest edition of TimesCast, The Timess Megan Liberman and Kate Zernike discussed what makes a true Tea Party candidate in the midterm elections.

title: Week 7 College Football Matchups
description: The college football season is a grind. The clear goal for the top teams is to stay undefeated and that means you have to bring your best game every week. Alabama showed us last week that the top teams cant afford to come out flat. The Tide traveled to face a tough South Carolina team that had a great day and now it no longer controls its own destiny. This week Ohio State, which took over the top spot, goes on the road to Madison for one of the toughest games on its schedule. Auburn hosts Arkansas with the goal of remaining unbeaten headed into next weeks game against L.S.U. (Would love to see both teams undefeated for that one.) Meanwhile, unbeaten Nebraska looks for some revenge as it hosts Texas in a rematch of last years Big 12 championship game. Even some of the lower ranked unbeatens like Michigan State and Missouri have challenging games. Every week we learn a little bit more. This Sunday the B.C.S. rankings come out and the debate gets ratcheted up a notch. Things are happening people. Every Saturday is important.

title: Lisa Lampanelli and Jimmy Cannizzaro
description: LISA LAMPANELLI immediately insulted Jimmy Cannizzaro when she first saw him on Valentines Day 2006.

title: Kate Pistey, Matthew Cruz
description: Kate Madeline Pistey and Matthew Joseph Cruz were married Saturday evening at Locust Grove, the former estate of Samuel F. B. Morse, in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Jesse Caudill, a Buddhist minister, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony.

title: A Little-Known Loan Program for Fixer-Uppers
description: BUYERS of distressed homes or any other fixer-upper not only face the daunting task of turning a run-down property into a livable one, but often worry about paying for it all.

title: When Athletes Investments Go Awry
description: John Elway had a knack for scouting out the weaknesses in defenses, but he does not seem to have the same acumen when it comes to investment advisers. The $15 million that he and a business partner gave to a hedge fund manager who has been accused of running a Ponzi scheme  an investment that was detailed in court documents this week  is only the latest of Mr. Elways numerous financial Hail Marys over the years.

title: Antoinette Priolo and D. J. Postles
description: Antoinette Theresa Priolo and Donald R. Postles Jr. were married Friday at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Bruno M. Shah, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Colosseum Renovations Opening to the Public
description: ROME  During the golden age of gladiatorial combat at the Colosseum, in the 4th century A.D., some 800 attendants were involved behind  actually below  the scenes, working to create a show that would wow the crowds.

title: Haesther Rose-Libbey, Scott Shnay
description: Haesther Rose-Libbey and Scott Gunther Shnay were married Saturday evening at the Wynn Resort in Las Vegas. Rabbi Felipe Goodman officiated.

title: Ariele Bianca, Jeffrey Sullivan
description: Ariele Beth Bianca and Jeffrey Stewart Sullivan were married in Short Hills, N.J., Saturday afternoon. The Rev. M. Christen Beirne performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Murdoch Says Political Donations In the Best Interest Of the Country
description: On Friday Rupert Murdoch defended his companys two large contributions  one to the Republican Governors Association, the other to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which largely supports Republicans  as in the best interest of the country.

title: Allison Berlin, David Berse
description: Allison Leigh Berlin and David Charles Berse were married Saturday evening. Cantor Martha T. Novick officiated at Gotham Hall, an event space in New York.

title: Sandi OConnell and Anthony DAvella
description: Sandi Lee OConnell and Anthony Nicholas DAvella were married Saturday at St. Peters Roman Catholic Church in Vergennes, Vt. The Rev. Benedict M. Worry performed the ceremony.

title: Dueling Developers Reach a Settlement
description: The long-running feud between the developer Sheldon H. Solow and the Fisher real estate family appears to be over, again.

title: Live Show Brings Viewers to 30 Rock
description: Going live added a jolt of excitement to the NBC comedy 30 Rock, and viewers apparently shared the feeling. The show scored its best rating of the season, bouncing up 48 percent from the prior week to a 3.1 rating among viewers between the ages of 18 and 49. (It had been a 2.1 a week ago.) It also increased 38 percent among total viewers.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The Hester Street Fair  with its retro bikes, vintage furniture and young designers  will be even more of a food lovers destination on Saturday when it joins with Grub Street, New York magazines food blog, for the Grub Street Food Festival. There will be stands set up by restaurants, food trucks and vendors at Hester and Essex Streets between 10 a.m. and 6 p.m., rain or shine. Some of those supposed to be on hand are: Purple Yam, Cheeky Sandwiches, Mile End Delicatessen, Pies n Thighs, Lukes Lobster, Cascabel Taqueria, AnChoi, Kickstand Coffee, Kelvin Natural Slush Company and Mexicue.

title: Artifacts | The Frieze Art Fair: Salvage Instinct
description: Trend-spotters at the Frieze Art Fair this week had an easy time finding the next big thing: the artist as clutter queen. During a V.I.P. preview attended by Keith Richards as well as the mega-collectors Dasha Zhukova, Steven Cohen and Charles Saatchi, I saw so much junk repurposed as found-object sculpture that I actually mistook a pair of fire extinguishers for an artwork. But when I reached the stand of Berlins Contemporary Fine Art, and a friend blurted a telltale alert  What the hell is that!  I knew we were onto something big.

title: What It Means to Manage the Mayors Money
description: Steve Rattners my friend, of course Id keep him on. Why would you not? If he can do anything to help, I value his advice and hes a close friend of mine, and you stick by your friends.

title: Pictures of the Day: The Swiss Alps and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Switzerland, Afghanistan, Germany and Washington.

title: Scrutinizing the Elite, Whether They Like It or Not
description: THE rich are sitting firmly in the public cross hairs, especially as the economy continues to stumble. Reports that Wall Street bonuses will again be high, and the debate in Congress over tax increases for the wealthy, just add to the outrage.

title: Princeton Endowment Posts a 14.7% Return
description: At a time when many of the nations largest endowments have generated returns below 12 percent, Princeton University said on Friday that its endowment had returned 14.7 percent last year, bringing its total to $14.4 billion.

title: E.P.A. Official Seeks to Block West Virginia Mine
description: WASHINGTON  A top federal regulator has recommended revoking the permit for one of the nations largest planned mountaintop removal mining projects, saying it would be devastating to miles of West Virginia streams and the plant and animal life they support.

title: Grading College Athletes
description: The stereotypes are (partly) true: College athletes do worse in school than their non-athlete counterparts.

title: Death of a Fulton Fish Market Fixture
description: THE fish men see her still, their Annie, in the hide-and-seek shadows of South Street. Shes telling her dirty jokes and doing anything for a buck: hustling newspapers, untaxed cigarettes, favors, those pairs of irregular socks shed buy cheap on Canal. Shes submitting to the elements, calling out Yoo-hoo to the snow and the rain and her boys.

title: First Pregnancies Are the Best?
description: When Marcella Gate was pregnant the first time, she remembers saying things like :

title: Can Happy Meal Meme Stand Up to the Scientific Method?
description: McDonalds has been taking a bit of a beating lately, what with the photographer Sally Daviess Happy Meal Project going viral this week. Each day for 137 days, she took a photo of the same hamburger and fries from a Happy Meal. Unnervingly, neither item rotted or even grew a feather of mold.

title: Liverpool Sale to Red Sox Owner Finalized
description: The battle for ownership of Liverpool F. C. ended Friday with the sale of the club to New England Sports Ventures, the owners of the Boston Red Sox, for about $480 million.

title: And The Winner Is
description: Design Miami has named the German designer Konstantin Grcic as its Designer of the Year for 2010. In this video by TheCrane.tv, which is exclusive to T, Grcic talks about how and why he designsand shows us an object he just had to have.

title: Avoid Foreclosure Market Until the Dust Settles
description: Are you out of your mind to even consider buying a foreclosed property right now?

title: In NASA Image, a Submerged Pakistan
description: New satellite images from NASA show the extraordinary scope of the continuing disaster in Pakistan, where thousands of square miles of land remain submerged two months after the country was hit by catastrophic flooding.

title: Coyotes Update, Gainey Talks Team and Buffalos Woes
description: From The Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out blog:

title: Despite Image, Union Leader Backs School Change
description: In Waiting for Superman, the new education documentary, the union leader Randi Weingarten is portrayed, in the words of Variety, as a foaming satanic beast.

title: E.P.A. Seeks to Revoke Mining Permit
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has announced that it plans to revoke a permit granted under the Bush administration for a vast mountaintop mining operation in West Virginia, saying it would bury streams and extinguish wildlife.

title: Pictures of the Day: Swiss Alps and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Switzerland, Afghanistan, Germany and Washington.

title: Share Your Foreclosure Purchase War Stories
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I offer up some tips for people who just cant resist a bargain and are determined to shop around for a good deal on a foreclosed home.

title: Obama Fills In G.O.P.s Blanks
description: WASHINGTON  In speech after speech lately, President Obama has vowed to oppose a Republican proposal to cut education by 20 percent, a reduction that would eliminate 200,000 children from Head Start programs and reduce financial aid for eight million college students.

title: At Bronx Science, a Nobel Homecoming
description: David Politzer donned a pair of safety goggles Friday morning and smiled as two soccer-playing robots whizzed around the floor of a classroom at the Bronx High School of Science.

title: From Boys to Men
description: HAS anyone seen the Dior man? You know the one, that scrawny rocker dude with a chicken chest, a size 36 suit and a face that seems to be sprouting its first crop of peach fuzz.

title: Toddlers Favorite Toy: The iPhone
description: THE bedroom door opened and a light went on, signaling an end to nap time. The toddler, tousle-haired and sleepy-eyed, clambered to a wobbly stand in his crib. He smiled, reached out to his father, and uttered what is fast becoming the cry of his generation: iPhone!

title: Hey, Thats Me Up on That Screen
description: THE opening scenes of The Social Network, in which Mark Zuckerbergs character embarks on a manic marathon coding session with his friends, rang eerily true to 23-year-old Jared Hecht. Thats because he lived through it  although not at Harvard and not in 2003.

title: Fox Stations Go Dark as Dispute With Cablevision Escalates
description: There have been new developments since this blog post was last revised. Here is the latest update on the Cablevision-Fox dispute.

title: A Skeptical Take on Gawkers Sale Prospects
description: This fall has apparently been the season of pieces on Nick Denton, and The New Yorker has now contributed not one, but two pieces on Mr. Denton, the Gawker Media impresario.

title: For a Child, Gods Back Story
description: NOT long ago, Eden, one of my 5-year-old twin daughters, bounded into my lap at bedtime and asked me if I would read her a book, Bagels From Benny. I had never seen this book before, nor had my wife. (I learned later it was a gift from her grandmother.) In the story, written by Aubrey Davis, Benny adores his grandfathers bagels so much he wants to thank God for them. He takes a bag of bagels to the synagogue, places them in the ark, and asks God to taste his bounty.

title: No Nuts? No Problem
description: When Janet Antico found out that her daughter, Arabella, had a severe peanut and tree nut allergy about 12 years ago, she did what many parents of children with food allergies do: she started obsessively reading labels.

title: A Menu That Changes as the Garden Grows
description: DAYS, even weeks after visits to A Toute Heure, Im still smiling. Im enamored of its small, sweet dining room, its earnest staff and its carefully sourced food. A Toute Heure  which translates to anytime  is a good restaurant that spikes to very good, with optimism on the plate and in the dining room.

title: A Tale of Two Remotes
description: Remote controllers for home electronics, be they weighty or featherweight, thick or thin, backlit by tiny bulbs or glow-in-the-dark buttons, have one bottom-line reason to live: functionality.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 15
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Gifts for the Broken-Hearted
description: THE Obama volunteer coordinator assigned to find me a canvassing partner walked me toward a busload of elderly people. She must have noticed my dismay, because suddenly she veered left toward a smaller group of mostly male twentysomethings from Brooklyn. The day began looking up.

title: Queens Wants Consideration in Creek Cleanup
description: Queens is fighting to make sure it gets its share of Superfund attention for Newtown Creek, whose effluent-laden waters lap the shores of both Queens and Brooklyn. Several Queens leaders assert that the federal Environmental Protection Agency has primarily focused on the Brooklyn side of Newtown Creek in studies and sampling of the waterway. That has to change, the officials wrote. Time after time, Queens has simply been forgotten  literally omitted from the studies, the documentation and the E.P.A.s attention. Read about the Battle of Newtown Creek on the Green blog.

title: Red Hook Community Farm Tries to Recover From Hail Storm
description: In less than 10 minutes on Monday evening, a storm swept through Brooklyn and unleashed nickel-sized hail, leaving the Red Hook Community Farms fields in tatters.

title: Jimi Hendrix Before He Was Jimi Hendrix
description: Photographs of the rock n roll legends early days.

title: Many Different Sounds In a Wide-Ranging Week
description: If you want to understand the ways that a modern orchestra must be all things to all people if it hopes to maintain a devoted audience, look at the New York Philharmonics schedule for the week just ended.

title: Jimi Hendrix, Innocence and Experience
description: I suppose I always imagined that Jimi Hendrix sprang directly from the head of a particularly freaky hippie Zeus, but Steven Roby and Brad Schreiber set me straight. Their book, Becoming Jimi Hendrix: From Southern Crossroads to Psychedelic London, the Untold Story of a Musical Genius  reviewed in this Sundays issue by David Kirby  mostly ignores Hendrixs days as a superstar to trace his improbable rhythm-and-blues rise, on the road with groups like Hank Ballards Midnighters, the Bonnevilles, Curtis Knight and the Squires, the Isley Brothers and the Tams. Hendrix got fired a lot. He couldnt play the music right, a fellow guitarist explained.

title: Jimi Hendrix, Innocence and Experience
description: I suppose I always imagined that Jimi Hendrix sprang directly from the head of a particularly freaky hippie Zeus, but Steven Roby and Brad Schreiber set me straight. Their book, Becoming Jimi Hendrix: From Southern Crossroads to Psychedelic London, the Untold Story of a Musical Genius  reviewed in this Sundays issue by David Kirby  mostly ignores Hendrixs days as a superstar to trace his improbable rhythm-and-blues rise, on the road with groups like Hank Ballards Midnighters, the Bonnevilles, Curtis Knight and the Squires, the Isley Brothers and the Tams. Hendrix got fired a lot. He couldnt play the music right, a fellow guitarist explained.

title: The Lobbyist
description: What your Milan hotel says about you.

title: Studying the Rich
description: The wealthy have become both a source of fascination and derision in America. But they have rarely been the subject of academic debate across various disciplines.

title: Gary L. Malin
description: Mr. Malin, 42, is the president of Citi Habitats, a division of the Corcoran Group and one of the largest residential rental brokers in New York City. The company opened for business in 1994 and was acquired by NRT, Corcorans parent, 10 years later.

title: Double Squeeze Helps Win a World Team Title
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Rosenblum Cup was won here on Wednesday evening by John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Eric Greco and Geoff Hampson. They defeated Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bob Hamman, Zia Mahmood, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell by 121 international match points to 78.

title: Weekly Pick Em: A New No. 1
description: There is a new No. 1 this week. And no, Im not talking about our race for the Quads top prognosticator. Despite a brutal 1-4 performance last weekend, Paul Myerberg still holds a slim, one-game advantage over Pete Thamel. The real new No. 1 is Ohio State, which faces its first true road test tomorrow night at Wisconsin. Camp Randall is always an intimidating atmosphere, but the Buckeyes hope Terrelle Pryor and a tough defense will be enough to overcome the Badgers stout running game. Auburn is one of the last two undefeated teams in the Southeastern Conference (Louisiana State is the other), but the Tigers looked shaky in beating Kentucky last week. They face a stiff challenge from Arkansas on Saturday. Nebraska knows what it feels like to fall from the heights of the Big 12, so the Cornhuskers could have some empathy for struggling Texas if they choose to. They probably wont though. Michigan is trying to bounce back from a loss to Michigan State, but is running right into an Iowa squad that would like to fight it out with Ohio State for Big Ten supremacy. Meanwhile, in the Pac-10, Oregon State is quietly looking to assert itself as one of the conferences top teams. It beat Arizona last week and will try to knock off a Washington squad that has already defeated Southern California. There is plenty to watch this week and much to predict. As always, if you agree, disagree or merely find our picks laughable, feel free to let us know.

title: Considering Existence From the Proper Angle
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  That Carolyn Carlson spent time dancing with the shape-shifting, technology-minded choreographer Alwin Nikolais is immediately apparent in her Double Vision, which had its American premiere on Thursday night in Montclair State Universitys Peak Performances series. It is clear, too, that Ms. Carlson, an American, has spent the last four decades in Europe, and chiefly France (where she has had a substantial career).

title: The Deal on Buying a Used Phone in 2010
description: In the car industry, the preferred term for used is certified pre-owned. It would appear the term is becoming popular in the phone industry as well. Heres the lay of the land.

title: Persistent Sunny Spells With an Occasional Cloud
description: The Avett Brothers have not, to my knowledge, made a childrens album. They should. Not because their music  reductively, a string-band hijacking of pop-punk, or vice versa  carries enough boisterous cheer for an iPod commercial. Not because the ruckus of their live show is harmless merriment, even when theyre asserting otherwise. Those things are true enough, but the bigger factor is the emotional landscape of their songs, an unwalled garden of wonderment and confusion. Judged by preadolescent standards, those songs are pretty deep.

title: A Novelists Voice, Both Exotic and Midwestern
description: Early in Dinaw Mengestus new novel, How to Read the Air, the main character, a troubled young Ethiopian-American named Jonas Woldemariam, goes to a job interview, only to be asked, Wheres that accent of yours from? by a prospective boss baffled by his seemingly alien provenance. Peoria, Jonas replies, puzzling his interviewer even further.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 15
description: More Photographs

title: College Cost Calculator
description: An interactive tool to estimate the future cost of higher education.

title: Surgical Errors Continue Despite Protocols
description: Despite a requirement that hospitals abide by a standard set of procedures to prevent surgical mistakes like operating on the wrong patient or the wrong body part, such errors continue to occur far too often, researchers are reporting.

title: Murdoch Defends News Corp.s Political Donations
description: The News Corporation chairman Rupert Murdoch said on Friday morning that his companys $1 million donations to the United States Chamber of Commerce and the Republican Governors Association were unusual but that they were in the interests of our shareholders and the country.

title: Sunday Preview
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Breathing Room
description: New Yorks small squares offer serenity, light and space.

title: Boozman Outraises Lincoln in Arkansas
description: Representative John Boozman outpaced Senator Blanche Lincoln in fund-raising last quarter for the the first time in his bid to unseat her, according to campaign finance reports filed Friday with the Federal Election Commission.

title: New Yorks Tiny Squares Offer Breathing Room
description: ABINGDON SQUARE PARK, a 0.222-acre triangle of greenery in the West Village, is not a place that requires much time for exploration. A lap of its curving byways, around a manicured garden island, takes just a minute or two. Indeed, most everyone there on a recent sunny Saturday was partaking in the squares main day-to-day activity: sitting on benches.

title: Bedbug Rider Looms in Real Estate Deals
description: Our colleague Vivian S. Toy reports that disclosure clauses involving bedbug infestation, a growing problem in New York City, are making their way into co-op and condo sales contracts.

title: The Nest Is Empty No More
description: MONDAY through Friday, Lisa Buck, director of a nonprofit group called the Bridge Fund of Westchester, works to keep people who have lost a job from also losing the roof over their head. Especially in economic times like these, her desk in White Plains is stacked high with case files.

title: What Will Apple Reveal Next Week?
description: When Apple makes an announcement about a coming press event it can sometimes feel like theNational Hurricane Center has identified a new hurricane.

title: A Housing Market Divided
description: IT seems that the story of what is happening in the real estate market has very nearly become a tale of two states: northern New Jersey and southern New Jersey.

title: Rolling Back the Power Meter
description: Hicksville

title: A Failed Bank Robbers Lifetime of Run-Ins With the Law
description: His nickname, on his rap sheet, is Johnny Shades.

title: For Sale: A Medal Worth More Than Gold
description: The news was jarring and slightly unbelievable. Tommie Smith, the former Olympic champion, was auctioning his gold medal.

title: U.S. Will Enforce Marijuana Laws, State Vote Aside
description: LOS ANGELES  The Department of Justice says it intends to prosecute marijuana laws in California aggressively even if state voters approve an initiative on the Nov. 2 ballot to legalize the drug.

title: Chic in Review | Tom Bradys Bad Hair Day
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Why Are You Voting? Tell Us in Video
description: What issue is driving you to vote this year?

title: Quick 'Preserved' Lemons
description: Mark Bittman demonstrates an easy method for getting the taste of Moroccan preserved lemons without weeks of waiting.

title: Echoes of Olde England
description: FOR those who envision Queens as stamped by cookie cutter  block after block of almost indistinguishable homes, like mood wallpaper for the 70s TV show All in the Family  Auburndale might come as a surprise.

title: On the Street | At Ease
description: A number of women in Paris were noticeably intent on putting together a practical solution to modern dress.

title: Art of Upheaval, and Cross-Pollination
description: Faith Ringgold, who turned 80 this year, is best known for the story quilts that she began making in the 1980s. But her paintings on canvas from the 1960s are also rather extraordinary. So its surprising that a comprehensive exhibition of these works is happening for the first time, with American People, Black Light: Faith Ringgolds Paintings of the 1960s, at the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase.

title: Roles Reconsidered
description: New Haven

title: For 15 Years, Cuisine That Comes With a View
description: FIFTEEN years after it opened, Splash Restaurant and Bar, always a treat, has gotten even better. The restaurant is situated on the grounds of the Inn at Longshore, the town-owned, open-to-the-public country club in Westport, and has a deck that overlooks Long Island Sound.

title: Yogurt Your Way
description: The hot pink and lime green signs at 16 Handles, a new frozen yogurt cafe in Jericho, N.Y., lend a cheerful energy to the space. They also serve a purpose: to give directions to customers as they move through the stations at this serve-yourself shop.

title: Seafood Specialties With Global Perspective
description: THE space that is home to Long Fin Seafood Restaurant on Hempstead Turnpike in East Meadow has been one of those places where restaurants come and go at a rapid clip. It was Louis & Marxx in 2007, followed by Rubys Famous B. B. Q. Joint, which closed in January, and then Ristorante Besi, which closed in July.

title: Moved by Music of the Tropics, A Composer Moves to Them
description: No one who has ever thrilled to the radiant shimmer and throb of a fine Balinese gamelan could have trouble understanding the composer Evan Ziporyns longtime preoccupation with finding ways to integrate elements of that magical tradition into his own music. A House in Bali, a two-act opera that opened at the Howard Gilman Opera House on Thursday night, is among Mr. Ziporyns most ambitious efforts at bridging Eastern and Western styles.

title: Small Place, Big Menu
description: The narrow storefront of Lubins-N-Links, a quality fast-food carry-out spot, is easy to miss. Just inside the door, the waiting area in front of the counter is marginally larger than an old-fashioned phone booth. But the menu is gigantic.

title: River Views and Boat Parking
description: THE COVE, the restaurant that took over the old Crystal Bay space on the Hudson River in Peekskill, has a lot going for it. The owners, Tom and Melissa Radocaj, have renovated with an eye toward the water, opening up the views with a wall of windows. There is a marina that makes parking your boat as easy as parking a car and a large deck for comfortable outdoor eating. And the prices  with most appetizers around $7 or $8 and entrees as low as $14 or $16  are welcome in these tough economic times.

title: Finding Wine Amid Marshes
description: Contrary to the idealized concept of a winery set among rolling hills of volcanic substrate, Saltwater Farm Vineyard is on flat land surrounded by a briny tidal inlet. And unlike the chateau-style production plants of Napa, Sonoma and the Loire Valley, Saltwater holds its tastings in a converted airport hangar, with a grass landing strip nearby.

title: The Killer Is Hot, The Hero Hotheaded
description: At first perusal, a drama about a tormented-but-brilliant cop whose ethics code doesnt require cleaning up as much as fumigation would seem like an old, familiar destination. You have made the journey here before, particularly if you got on board The Shield for its seven seasons. And yet, when the cop is played by Idris Elba (Stringer Bell of The Wire) and his mind-meld is happening with a murderer who looks like a gangsters moll, quotes Bertrand Russell and sounds like Judi Dench, the stamp on your passport starts to look decidedly novel.

title: Capturing Morocco in Its Sunny Pickle
description: PRESERVED lemons, a staple of Moroccan cooking, are pickles, and terrific ones. Made using the entire lemon  skin and all  theyre cured in their own juices, along with salt and sugar. Like most relishes, the recipe varies from cook to cook, so you might find garlic, shallot, bay leaves, coriander seeds, chili flakes or cinnamon sticks in a given batch.

title: Quick Preserved Lemons
description: Time: At least 3 hours, largely unattended

title: A Second Disease Vanquished
description: Quietly, almost under the radar, a United Nations organization announced this week that another disease  the first after smallpox  had been eliminated from the face of the earth.

title: Unlocking the True Flavor of Mackerel
description: MACKEREL escabche is one of those dishes I have always preferred to admire from afar. Its traditionally prepared by pickling the fillets in vinegar, but Ive never quite cottoned to its biting flavor. To me, it overwhelms the delicacy of a good fresh piece of fish.

title: Challenging the Wiis Supremacy
description: Slicing and thrusting through the air to control a virtual sword. Flicking your wrist to roll a digital bowling ball. Striking an imaginary golf ball down a tree-lined fairway.

title: Botox for Migraines Is Approved
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of Allergans Botox to treat chronic migraines, a little more than a month after the company agreed to pay $600 million to settle criminal and civil allegations that it had illegally marketed the drug for unapproved uses  including headache and pain  for years. Related Article

title: Perky Becomes Poignant
description: If you happened to see Circle Mirror Transformation in New York last fall and then heard about the cast that would be doing it at the George Street Playhouse this month, Sandy Duncan might be the last person you would think of to play the teacher. As hard as she tries, this is one actress who just cant shake her bright-eyed, giggly-girl persona. But she turns out to be quite good.

title: A Fast Route to Preserved Lemon
description: Preserved lemons take minutes to make, but they take weeks to cure. There is, however, a compromise, a way to enjoy something pretty close to the authentic preserved lemon experience in much less time. These quick preserved lemons are wonderful with fish and amazing with stews.

title: Bowling, Golfing and Shooting With the Sony Move
description: Move, Sonys recently released add-on for its PlayStation 3 video game system, is the companys expensive attempt to compete against Nintendos wildly successful Wii. Like the Wii, Move allows consumers to simply swing a small electronic wand in the air to control game action on a television screen, like a character swinging a sword, throwing a flying disc or hitting a tennis ball. Such technology has made the Wii the most popular of the current game systems because it allows players to avoid having to master the use of more than a dozen buttons, sticks and triggers on a modern console game controller. Meanwhile, the PS3 has languished in third place behind both the Wii and Microsofts Xbox 360.

title: Modern Dcor With African Touches
description: Claude Grunitzky lives in a luxury high-rise at 15 Broad Street, Philippe Starcks conversion of a structure that included the fabled House of Morgan.

title: Domestic Luxury, Artfully Accented
description: CLAUDE GRUNITZKY  jet-setter, media entrepreneur and all-around cool person  did not always live in the shadow of a 1,900-piece Louis XV crystal chandelier that once hung in the House of Morgan. Or just an elevator ride from a 5,000-square-foot roof garden complete with fountain and working fireplace. Or steps from both the New York Stock Exchange and Federal Hall, the site on which George Washington took the oath of office as the first president of the United States.

title: Frank and Personal Dont Rule Out Commercial
description: Soul jazz has been a nearly lifelong fascination for the saxophonist David Sanborn: a cause and a catalyst, if not always the center of his craft. Mr. Sanborn is best known for his long reign in the changeable realm of instrumental pop, and his related output as a session man. But with his two latest albums, both on Decca, he has fixated on the legacy of his first and most formative saxophone hero, Hank Crawford, who died last year.

title: CardStars Vision Problem
description: Progress is usually a good thing, but its spoiling a very nice free iPhone app.

title: Seven Winning Visions of a Suburbia Reborn
description: ITS just another day at a Long Island train station, where a trickle of off-peak commuters board the largely empty cars while the rest of the train is loaded with freight  mail, packages from small businesses, recyclables, you name it.

title: Lost in Their Own Worlds, Yet Performing Together
description: When a dancer is hurt and pulls out of a show before the premiere, theres no way of knowing how that presence might have shaped the final product. Such an unfortunate incident occurred with I Am Saying Goodnight, presented by the group Amanda Loulaki and Short Mean Lady on Wednesday evening at Performance Space 122. Rebecca Brooks, a long-limbed dancer both articulate and soulful, was forced to withdraw after an injury, yet its doubtful that her absence was the only reason I Am Saying Goodnight left the audience in the dark.

title: Rescuing Young Women From Traffickers Hands
description: CONSTANTA, Romania

title: Grappling With Grief, And Then With Bodies
description: I suppose you could call Ralph Lemon an interdisciplinary artist. But somehow the term seems flat and cumbersome in describing his output, which at this point feels more like a continuing set of questions and proposals than a series of distinct pieces. He is building a body of work in the truest sense, reaching for a poetics at once complex and simple and constructing a container to receive, if only for scattered moments, things that cant be kept.

title: Americans Need a Pick-Me-Up
description: Americans levels of well-being have been falling for the last four months, according to the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index.

title: Help for an Autistic Son Means Trouble for a Marriage
description: A young couple, struggling to secure the most beneficial education for their autistic 4-year-old son, disagrees on whats best for him. The separate paths the spouses explore eventually threaten their marriage in Love and Communication, a new drama by James J. Christy.

title: Growing Older With Less Empathy
description: There wasnt much provision for growing up in emo, the sensitive-guy punk-pop that emerged in the mid-1990s. Thats one reason that bands like Jimmy Eat World  a pioneer of emos earnest, churning confessionals and self-help manifestoes  hate the term. It doesnt promise any second act once adolescent angst and self-absorption start to wear thin.

title: Dylan, Channeled by Billie Holiday
description: For the jazz singer Paula West, the American songbook, from Irving Berlin through Bob Dylan, is a banquet from which she selects favorite dishes and stirs in her own secret ingredients to make them her own. Those added flavors include a sly sense of mischief that can quicken the pulse of a Berlin song like The Best Things Happen While Youre Dancing or turn Cole Porters Im in Love Again, into a delirious explosion of joy.

title: New Theater for Luna Stage
description: Luna Stage Theater Company moved into its new building in West Orange in July, but relocating has not been as easy as unpacking boxes of props and costumes.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: From Rent-Controlled to Market-Rate

title: Whos the Best Free-Agent Signing in Yankees History?
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The following question was posed by Marc Carig of The Star-Ledger of Newark in the beat reporters interview session with Joe Girardi: Is C.C. Sabathia the best free-agent signing in the history of the Yankees? Girardi acknowledged the impact Sabathia has made in his two seasons  40 regular-season victories, four more in the postseason, a World Series title  but, ever the diplomat, passed the question along to General Manager Brian Cashman, who was sitting on a couch nearby.

title: Sacrifice and Devotion in the Indian Tradition
description: Every autumn, many Indian women observe Karwa Chauth, a daylong fast on behalf of their husbands prosperity.

title: A.L.C.S. Game 1 Final: Yankees 6, Rangers 5
description: The Yankees scored one run in the seventh inning and five runs in the eighth to overcome a 5-0 deficit and beat the Texas Rangers, 6-5, on Friday night in Game 1 of the American League Championship Series in Arlington, Tex.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 15
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a cemetery in the East Village where explosives were found, photos from the campaign trail and a self-anointed saint.

title: A Night for Pagans Brings Out the Sexy
description: The Celts saw the end of October as a moment when spirits could slip from their world into ours. To ward off unwelcome visitors, wary mortals built bonfires, slaughtered livestock and donned scary masks. Those rituals, says the historian Nicholas Rogers, gave rise to the holiday now known as Halloween.

title: No Rest for a Long-Distance Runner
description: Her days of running marathons are over: her knees made that decision for her. But Mary Wittenberg, who entered and won her first race after a happy hour dare while attending college in Buffalo, still plans her life around the sport. As president of the New York Road Runners Club, which she has led since 2005, she is directing the New York City Marathon, to be held Nov. 7. Ms. Wittenberg, 48, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Derek, a banker, and their two sons, Alex, 9, and Cary, 8. ROBIN FINN

title: For Some Immigrants, Voting Is a Criminal Act
description: The way Joseph E. Joseph tells it, he was just doing his civic duty.

title: Top-Notch Drinks, and the Latest Gossip
description: THE prototypical destination lobby in a city now cluttered with them, Forty Four at the Royalton Hotel  called 44 when it opened in 1988, not long after New Yorkers first flocked to see Gordon Gekko wax fondly of greed  has emerged from yet another renovation that brings it closer to its nightclub roots.

title: In Truman Homes, Reflections of a City
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo.  Harry S. Truman once proclaimed that returning to this small city where he began his unlikely political ascent allowed him to forget he was president of the United States. That would be impossible today  his name and bespectacled image have become so omnipresent here that were he to make his ritual morning stroll through downtown he might conclude that his status is less favorite son than only son.

title: When Pangs of Love Are All Too Real
description: Love hurts  sometimes literally  and its no mistake that, as the idiom goes, we fall into it (and sometimes land on our faces). The following poems about pratfalls leading to, or resulting from, a romantic encounter were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; the titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

title: How Official Is Official?
Russia Plans Nuclear Plant in Venezuela
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Friday that Russia planned to build the first nuclear power plant in Venezuela, and that the United States should not object because Russias intentions were absolutely pure and open.

title: Bloggingheads: Friends Who Torture
description: Daniel Drezner, left, of Foreign Policy and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate U.S. allies who torture suspected terrorists.

title: Atheists Debate How Pushy to Be
description: LOS ANGELES  Energized by a recent Pew Research Center poll showing that atheists are more educated about religion than religious people, 370 atheists, humanists and other skeptics packed a ballroom at the Millennium Biltmore Hotel last weekend to debate the future of their movement.

title: Suspended Executive Resigns at Tribune
description: Lee Abrams, the Tribune Company executive who was suspended this week for sending out a companywide memo with sexual content, resigned on Friday, the company said in a statement.

title: Capturing the Facebook Obsession
description: Ben Mezrich is the kind of nonfiction writer we used to call a hype artist. He takes relatively mundane subjects  counting cards in Vegas, derivatives trading, the New York Mercantile Exchange  and turns them into high-octane page-turners, replete with sex, skullduggery and plot twists worthy of James Patterson.

title: Biotech Company Gains on Prostate Cancer Trial
description: Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology development company, reported positive results from a clinical trial of a treatment that detects prostate cancer, setting off a 65 percent gain in its share price. The company released the results of the early stage trial of the treatment, called Trofex, after the market closed Thursday. On Friday, shares of Molecular Insight, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., rose 50 cents, to $1.27. The news came a week after Nasdaq told Molecular Insight that it was in danger of being delisted because the companys stock had remained below $1 a share for 30 consecutive business days. Also on Friday, the company said it had reached an agreement to extend a waiver with bondholders to allow debt restructuring negotiations to continue until next Friday.

title: Rum Battle in Caribbean Leaves Tax Hangover
description: Rum and politics have made a fiery mix since Americas earliest days, when a young politician named George Washington won election to the House of Burgesses in colonial Virginia with the help of spiked punch at the polls.

title: Long Battle by Foes of Campaign Finance Rules Shifts Landscape
description: WASHINGTON  It was Thanksgiving break of 1998 at Capital University Law School in Ohio, and Senator Mitch McConnell was on the phone for Prof. Bradley Smith.

title: In Mumbai, Adviser to Obama Extols Indias Economic Model
description: MUMBAI  First, there was the pro-free-market development model known as the Washington consensus. Then came the Beijing consensus, which is used to describe Chinas state-led, export-powered growth.

title: Foreclosure Mess Draws in the Lawyers Who Handled Them
description: With the rash of foreclosures across the country in recent years, many lawyers have specialized in the lucrative business of handling cases for banks and loan servicers. And now that flaws are being acknowledged by big lenders in the processing of foreclosures, some of these lawyers are finding themselves in the cross hairs of investigators  and scorned by their former clients.

title: Setting a New Standard for a Long-Beleaguered Franchise
description: Philadelphia

title: Johnson Seems Unbeatable as Chase Nears the Midpoint
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Concession speeches have yet to be delivered in the 2010 Chase for the Sprint Cup, but an air of inevitability is beginning to hover over the Nascar garage. It is Jimmie Johnsons title to win. Again.

title: Larry Siegfried, Guard Who Won 5 Titles With Celtics, Is Dead at 71
description: Larry Siegfried, a stalwart guard on the great Boston Celtic teams of the 1960s, died Thursday in Cleveland. He was 71 and lived in Perrysville, Ohio.

title: Cable Dispute Could Leave Millions of Fans in the Dark
description: The much-anticipated matchup between the Phillies Roy Halladay and the Giants Tim Lincecum in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series Saturday at 7:57 p.m. Eastern may not be seen by Cablevisions 3 million customers in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Botox Shots Approved for Migraine
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved Botox, the anti-wrinkle shot from Allergan, as a treatment to prevent chronic migraines, a little more than a month after the company agreed to pay $600 million to settle allegations that it had illegally marketed the drug for unapproved uses like headaches for years.

title: Another Paladinos Views
description: BUFFALO  Cathy Paladino says she barely recognizes the Carl Paladino she hears about these days: fiery, volatile and seemingly unable to speak without offending.

title: While Azubuike Heals, DAntoni Fiddles
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  After lunging, hopping and backpedaling, Kelenna Azubuike stopped, grabbed a ball, dribbled a few times and gazed pensively across the room.

title: At Hearing on Fort Hood Attack, Few Clues
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, with a blanket draped over his shoulders and a watch cap pulled low over his dark eyes, listened impassively in recent days as several survivors of his murderous rampage a year ago rose and pointed to him as the gunman who had shot them.

title: 5 Officers Face Charges in Fudging of Statistics
description: A New York City police commander and four officers are facing internal charges based on a fellow officers allegations that crime complaints in the 81st Precinct in Brooklyn were manipulated, the Police Department said.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Alaskan Donors Step Up in Senate Battle
description: 9:21 p.m. | Updated As the latest fund-raising tallies roll in, some of Joe Millers first allies are sounding the alarm that the three-way race for Alaskas Senate seat could slip out of the Tea Partys grasp.

title: Harry S. Trumans Homes
description: Photos of some of Harry S. Trumans homes in Independence, Mo., the differing fates of which reflect the current circumstances of this city.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Exhibit on Hitler and the Germans
description: An exhibit offers a view of a Germany that was ripe for Nazi populism.

title: Hitler Exhibition Explores a Wider Circle of Guilt
description: BERLIN  As artifacts go, they are mere trinkets  an old purse, playing cards, a lantern. Even the display that caused the crowds to stop and stare is a simple embroidered tapestry, stitched by village women.

title: Obama and Biden Stump for Delaware Candidate
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  Chris Coons, the Democratic Senate candidate in Delaware, is far ahead in state polls, yet both President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. were here on Friday to give him a hand and to keep attention on his rival, Christine ODonnell, as a symbol of Tea Party Republican candidates across the country.

title: Universities in Britain Brace for Cuts in Subsidies
description: LONDON  For months, Britains universities have warned in apocalyptic terms about the devastating cuts they face as part of the governments grand plan to reduce public-sector costs. Now, with the government poised next week to announce its spending plans, their worst fears seem about to come true.

title: The World Banks Palm Oil Mistake
description: Lagos, Nigeria

title: Period Music, Played With Freewheeling Touches
description: The English Concerts performance at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening had plenty to recommend it, not least Rachel Podgers magnificent violin playing in a pair of Vivaldi Concertos, and intensely dramatic accounts of Monteverdi and Handel vocal works with the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote.

title: After an Enlightenment, a Return to Texas
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: Dont Mix Chili and Politics, South Dakota Official Says
description: In addition to arguing over health care and gun rights, Congressional candidates in South Dakota are engaged in a food fight. Democrats who served chili at campaign rallies on reservations in South Dakota this week got a chilly reception from state Republicans and the state attorney general, who warned party leaders not to offer food for votes.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,321 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: U.S. Shuts Banks in Midwest
description: Lenders in Missouri and Kansas were shut by regulators on Friday, bringing the total bank failures in the nation this year to 132.

title: Mets Interview Dodgers Assistant for G.M. Job
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets interviewed Logan White, the Dodgers assistant general manager, for their vacant G.M. position Friday, but Sandy Alderson remained the heavy favorite to get the job.

title: Attacks Fly at New York Debate for Senate Candidates
description: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York and the Republican seeking to unseat her, Joseph J. DioGuardi, questioned each others integrity in a debate on Friday filled with sharp exchanges.

title: Postseason Duels of Pitching Aces Can Go Awry
description: PHILADELPHIA  Dave Righetti, the San Francisco Giants pitching coach, knows what baseball fans are expecting in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series on Saturday. Tim Lincecum and Roy Halladay are scheduled to face each other in the most highly anticipated matchup of aces in years, and if their first appearances in the postseason last week are an indication, it could be something to behold.

title: In Iran, Future of University Is in Flux
description: TEHRAN  The future of Irans largest academic institution is in question after the supreme leader stepped into a tug of war this week between President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and his rival Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who was instrumental in vastly expanding and improving the university.

title: After Summer Together, Helping Set Columbia Apart
description: Alex Gross, a linebacker for Columbia, shared an apartment over the summer with Sean Brackett, a quarterback. Brackett had just finished his freshman year and, as Gross explains it, freshmen typically go home for the summer. But Brackett is no typical player.

title: Sudans Threatened Peace Deal
description: Time is running out on efforts to avert another civil war in Sudan. A United States-backed deal in 2005 ended two decades of fighting between the Arab Muslim north and the largely Christian south that killed two million people. That deal is now in danger of unraveling if two referendums set for early January do not go forward.

title: For New York Comptroller, Attorney General
description: Harry Wilson

title: Rangers Add Left-Handers to Combat Yankees
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Yankees have one left-hander, Boone Logan, in their seven-man bullpen. The Rangers, after making two revealing changes to their 25-man roster Friday, now have four in theirs. They added Michael Kirkman and Clay Rapada to join Derek Holland and Darren Oliver, giving Manager Ron Washington additional options to combat Robinson Cano, Brett Gardner and Curtis Granderson.

title: Accused G.I.s Were Isolated From Officers
description: WASHINGTON  Soldiers in an American Army platoon accused of murdering Afghan civilians for sport say they took orders from a ringleader who collected body parts as war trophies, were threatened with death if they spoke up and smoked hashish on their base almost daily.

title: Obama, Hitting the Trail, Still Looks for Ways to Make His Message Stick
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is preparing to wage the final weeks of the midterm campaign with a theme he has been hammering for months  a plea that voters not embrace the Republican policies of the past. But the specifics of his closing argument remain in flux as the White House searches for a way to frame the message that connects with voters.

title: Saturday: Expressions of Affection
description: Yet one smile more, departing, distant sun!One mellow smile through the soft vapory air,Ere, oer the frozen earth, the loud winds run,Or snows are sifted oer the meadows bare.

title: The Future of the Global Fund
description: Even in the midst of an economic downturn, the United States and other donors have increased their pledges to a global fund that is fighting three of the worlds most devastating infectious diseases. Unfortunately, the money will not be nearly enough to meet the rising health needs in developing countries.

title: Tough Lessons in a Free Press
description: Mayor Philip Amicone of Yonkers has just received what looks like a very expensive lesson in basic Constitutional rights.

title: France: Pension-Reform Protests Continue Amid Fuel Shortage Fears
description: Protests and industrial action against planned pension reforms in France continued for a fourth day Friday as fears about fuel supplies intensified. Production at the countrys 12 crude refineries remained stalled by striking workers, according to union officials. There were also concerns about a possible shortage of jet fuel at the main Paris airports after news reports had quoted Trapil, a supply company, as saying that pipelines carrying jet fuel to the airports had stopped operating because of industrial action. Trapil did not respond to calls for comment.MATTHEW SALTMARSH

title: Uganda: Drought and Famine Forecast by Parliament for 2011
description: More than half of Ugandas 31 million people face severe food shortages by February 2011 because of an expected drought, Parliament said in a statement on Friday, citing the minister for disaster preparedness, Tarsis Kabwegyere. The current rains, the statement said, will be followed by an unusual period of drought and severe water shortage that will spread famine and kill livestock in many parts of East Africa.

title: Zimbabwe: Robert Mugabe Seeks Elections and Vote on Constitution
description: President Robert Mugabe wants a referendum on a new constitution early next year and new elections by mid-2011, the state-owned Herald newspaper reported Friday. His rival in a power-sharing deal, Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai, has said that elections should be held only if there are safeguards to prevent the state-sponsored attacks on his supporters that led to widespread torture, beatings and murder in 2008 elections. Civic groups say that political intimidation of Mr. Tsvangirais party members has marred the process of creating a new constitution.

title: Richard Morefield, Held Hostage in Iran, Dies at 81
description: As throngs of Islamist militants surged into the American Embassy in Tehran on Nov. 4, 1979, Richard Morefield, the United States consul general to Iran, told colleagues around him to flee the compound.

title: Are the Democrats the True Extremists?
description: Its the duty (and, O.K., the bliss) of an opinion journalist to demonstrate that the Beltways conventional wisdom has far fewer garments than it supposes. But on one count  that the progressives are at the moment far more marginalized by their Democratic president and Congressional leadership than are the Tea Party enthusiasts by the Republican powers-that-be  its been hard to show contention. After all, the president who insisted that the day of his inauguration would be the moment when we ended a war, who confidently said that we are going to close Guantanamo, who promised to repeal the militarys dont-ask-dont-tell policy has shown, through deed if not word, that hes not exactly a hostage to the far left. Nor has the Democratic leadership: Senate majority leader Harry Reid is an apostate on a womans alleged right to choose  abortions should be legal only when the pregnancy resulted from incest or rape, or when the life of the woman is endangered  and Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi isnt exactly beloved.

title: The Mississippi Pardons
description: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi has to decide whether to show mercy to two sisters, Jamie and Gladys Scott, who are each serving double consecutive life sentences in state prison for a robbery in which no one was injured and only $11 was taken.

title: Bronx Neighbors Protest Planned Residences for Homeless
description: Even with the rumble of elevated trains overhead, Doreen Smith, a Jamaican immigrant, has worked hard for 17 years to maintain the cachet of her Beautopia hair salon in the modest neighborhood of Wakefield, about as far north as you can go in the Bronx without stepping into Westchester.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the major stories of the week from France 24 and The International Herald Tribune.

title: A Child Welfare Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dont Ask Debate Moves to the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Department of Childish Errors
description: How far back in a candidates history do we want to travel?

title: Threat Response
description: The president and fellow Democrats have taken a page from the Republican playbook. Theyre unabashedly using racial-solidarity politics to animate voters. In this case, the Democrats appeal is to black voters, the most unwavering portion of President Obamas base, and the message is simple: The president is under attack, and black voters must mobilize to protect him.

title: Giving Foreclosures Closer Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Midterm Election Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tax on Sodas
description: To the Editor:

title: Green Dry Cleaners
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Tormentors Live Just Outside Your Front Door
description: William Cruz, a shy homebody who moved to the Bronx in 2006, always kept his private life just that  private, for reasons of self-protection. I hear the news, about gay people getting stabbed, beat up, Mr. Cruz, now 47, said. You never know. It could be things like that that happen to you, you could bump into the wrong person.

title: Rangers Fall, but Real Loss Comes in 2 Injuries
description: There were silver linings to the Rangers wild 4-3 overtime loss in their home opener at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. But the clouds they lined were huge, dark and ominous.

title: Urban Cowboys
description: Ten professional riders rode bucking bulls in the middle of New York City.

title: Sports Photo Replay: Oct. 15
description: A look at the day in sports, from wrestling to golf to gymnastics and tennis.

title: General Johnson, Singer and Writer of Hit R&B Songs, Dies at 69
description: General Johnson, who provided the distinctive lead vocal for the Chairmen of the Boards 1970 Top 10 hit, Give Me Just a Little More Time, and went on to become a successful rhythm-and-blues songwriter, died Wednesday in suburban Atlanta. He was 69 and lived in East Point, Ga.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Simon MacCorkindale, Dashing British Actor, Dies at 58
description: Simon MacCorkindale, the dashing British actor who turned heads in the star-studded 1978 film Death on the Nile and went on to play villains and charming Englishmen on numerous television shows in Britain and the United States, died on Thursday in London. He was 58.

title: Lottery Numbers
Israelis Hold Son Sought in S.I. Deaths
description: An international manhunt ended Friday when a man being sought for questioning in the fatal stabbings of his parents in their Staten Island home was captured in Israel, the New York City police said.

title: A Nobel Laureate Returns Home to Bronx Science
description: David Politzer donned a pair of safety goggles Friday morning and smiled as two soccer-playing robots whizzed around the floor of a classroom at the Bronx High School of Science.

title: Eugene O'Neill Dies of Pneumonia; Playwright, 65, Won Nobel Prize
description: Boston, Nov. 27--Eugene O'Neill, noted American playwright whose prolific talents had brought to him both Nobel and Pulitzer Prizes, died today of bronchial pneumonia. His age was 65.

title: China Tests Atomic Bomb, Asks Summit Talk On Ban; Johnson Minimizes Peril
description: Hong Kong, Oct. 16--Communist China announced tonight that it had exploded its first atom bomb. Peking pledged that it would never be the first to use nuclear weapons in the future.

title: Yankees Rewrite Script With Outburst in Eighth
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Rangers still have never won a home playoff game, a truth their fans may find difficult to comprehend had they not suffered Friday night through one of the most torturous innings in the franchises 39 seasons in Texas. A crowd that pulsed with excitement fell silent in the eighth, when the Yankees crushed the Rangers visions of a superlative start to their inaugural American League Championship Series by pummeling five Texas pitchers in a five-run rally.

title: Bill Clinton Campaigns for Jerry Brown
description: For those wounds that time will not heal, there is always the salve of the campaign trail.

title: Baseball Replay: Oct. 15
description: Images from the Yankees 6-5 victory over the Texas Rangers in Game 1 of the A.L.C.S.

title: Republican Governors Association Raises $31 Million With Notable Contributions
description: A number of eye-popping contributions showed up in Fridays quarterly filing by the Republican Governors Association with the Internal Revenue Service, part of a $31 million haul over a three-month period.

title: Senate Dollar Sweepstakes
description: As Senate candidates revved up general election campaigns and raised money for the stretch run, there were some winners and losers apparent in the quarterly fund-raising reports due Friday.

title: Taking Times Square By the Horns
description: In Times Square Friday afternoon, 10 bulls bucked beneath their riders as part of the Professional Bull Riders Road to Las Vegas competition. Crowds in cowboy hats gathered at the temporary arena that sprang up on Broadway between 42nd and 43rd streets. Some craned their necks to watch from the street, while others looked down from the skyscrapers around.

title: Jets Prepare for the Air in Denver
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets stretched and warmed up on Friday morning to Joe Walshs Rocky Mountain Way blaring over the loudspeakers at the teams practice facility. The altitude in Denver is known to play strange tricks with the ball, from Steve ONeals 98-yard punt in 1969 to the home runs that fly out of Coors Field. But it isnt the ball soaring through the mile-high air that has the Jets being cautious; it is merely getting a chance to breathe.

title: Classic Ad: Buick Riviera
description: Sure, this ad for the 1964 Buick Riviera may claim that only a man can understand such a great and rare machine. But if theres anything weve learned from the fellas at Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, its that casual sexism was par for the Madison Avenue course in the 60s.

title: Too Much Touchdown Celebration: Is N.F.L. Being Excessive?
description: Article 1(d) prohibits players from engaging in any celebrations while on the ground  Rule 12, Section 3

title: Urban Forager | Free-Roaming Yeast, Brooklyn Bred
description: 10:14 a.m. | Updated When I first told a friend about my plans for foraging wild yeast in my Brooklyn apartment, he was dubious, predicting a moldy science experiment.

title: Consensus Points to 50-Seat G.O.P. Gain in House, but May Understate Uncertainty
description: FiveThirtyEights projection for the U.S. House shows little change from last week. Republicans are given a 73 percent chance of taking over the House, up incrementally from 72 percent last week. During an average simulation run, Republicans finished with 227 seats, up from 226 last week; this would suggest a net gain of 48 seats from the 179 they hold currently.

title: Brian Jones Previews Ohio State-Wisconsin
description: Brian Jones is a studio analyst for CBS College Sports Network. He can also be seen every Tuesday night during the season as part of The Tony Barnhart Show at 9 p.m. and Inside College Football at 10.

title: Presidential Contenders to Get a Head Start on White House Transition
description: President Obama signed a bill Friday that he hopes wont be really necessary until at least 2016.

title: The Nipponization of Ben Bernanke
description: Im with Brad DeLong on Bernankes speech: given Bernankes diagnosis of our problems, what he said about the policy response was astonishingly diffident:

title: The Boehnerization of Barack Obama
description: Why has stimulus become a dirty word? Many reasons, I guess: an inadequate plan combined with a wildly overoptimistic forecast was more or less guaranteed to create the impression of a failed program. But its also true that the president himself has had a deeply self-destructive tendency to echo his opponents arguments. My original invisible bond vigilantes post was inspired, in part, by Obamas decision to go on Fox News and declare that we needed to cut the deficit to avoid a double dip. Then, in July, he repeated almost verbatim John Boehners justly mocked claim that since the private sector is tightening its belt, the government should do the same.

title: A Fine European Whine
description: Here:

title: Benot Mandelbrot, Novel Mathematician, Dies at 85
description: Benot B. Mandelbrot, a maverick mathematician who developed the field of fractal geometry and applied it to physics, biology, finance and many other fields, died on Thursday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85.

title: Saturday Word: Up to Boston
description: President Obama travels to Boston on Saturday afternoon to lend his support to Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts, who is facing a tough battle for re-election. Then, hell speak at a Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee event at a private home west of the city.

title: Marzieh, Iranian Singer and Voice of Dissent, Dies at 86
description: Marzieh, the great diva of Persian traditional song, who was silenced after the Islamic Revolution in 1979 but who re-emerged years later outside Iran as a singer and a highly public supporter of the resistance, died on Wednesday in Paris. She was 86 and had defected to France in 1994.

title: In Mangold, Jets Have Connoisseur at Center
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The large man entered the small California winery in early October 2008. Nick Mangold wore blond hair past his shoulders and a scraggly beard. He stood 6 feet 4 inches, weighed more 300 pounds and looked, as one teammate said recently, as if he ran a biker gang.

title: Long Live the Mascot, Uga VIII
description: ATHENS, Ga.  Sonny Seiler stepped into the Uga Suite, Room 301, and turned past the framed jersey fit for a particular barrel-chested white English bulldog. The walls were filled with photographs of the various University of Georgiamascots that Seiler has owned and anointed since 1956, the seven dogs that Seiler deemed fit to be an Uga.

title: Torontos M.L.S. Team Is Testing Patience of Its Fans
description: TORONTO  In a sports bar one recent night, the bartender was giving away collectible beer glasses bearing the Toronto F.C. logo and motto, All for One. For some, those words are hard to swallow right now.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Numbers Are a Weak Spot in the B.C.S. Standings
description: The Bowl Championship Series will release its first standings of the year on Sunday. One-third of the formula that will eventually determine the matchup for college footballs national championship game comes from a compendium of six computerized ranking systems that deal in mathematical minutiae. The nerds did not just crash the jocks party. They were invited.

title: 21 Are Killed in Explosion at China Mine
description: SHANGHAI  A coal mine explosion in central China early Saturday killed 26 workers and trapped 11 others underground, Chinas state-run news media said.

title: Kick Returns Facing Weakened Resistance
description: Stefan Logan was about 30 yards into his kickoff return last Sunday when he knew he would score a touchdown. A member of the St. Louis Rams coverage team had briefly grabbed Logan and turned him, but when Logan brought his head up, he still saw the Rams end zone in front of him.

title: Lawmakers Sow Disillusion in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesias House of Representatives barely passed any laws in the first year of its current term, placing critical pending legislation on matters related to national security, welfare and natural resources on the back burner. Still, lawmakers recently managed to squeeze in trips to South Africa, Japan and South Korea for what they said were fact-finding missions to research a bill on this countrys Boy Scouts.

title: Versatile and Creative, Giants Limber Up for Race to the Quarterback
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Justin Tuck was named a Giants captain last month, a fellow defensive lineman placed a small figurine bearing his likeness in the units meeting room. It started as a cute way to poke fun at Tuck. Then the team lost back-to-back games in September, and something needed to change.

title: Microsoft Moves to Help Nonprofits Avoid Piracy-Linked Crackdowns
description: MOSCOW  Microsoft is vastly expanding its efforts to prevent governments from using software piracy inquiries as a pretext to suppress dissent. It plans to provide free software licenses to more than 500,000 advocacy groups, independent media outlets and other nonprofit organizations in 12 countries with tightly controlled governments, including Russia and China.

title: For the Nets, a Journey Toward Becoming a Global Brand Has Just Begun
description: BEIJING  Brett Yormark is talking about the incredible global marketing potential of the New Jersey Nets, a concept  New Jersey, the Nets and global marketing potential  that might seem unlikely until you hear his pitch, and remember that two years from now, they will probably be the New York Nets.

title: Using Technology to Find Flaws
description: Computerized analysis helps locate delivery problems that might be missed by coaches and trainers. Eight high-speed cameras surround the mound and track the motion.

title: Diagramless and Numberplay Challenge
description: Discussion of the diagramless crossword with a bonus challenge for the Numberplay set

title: Mystery of Lost M.P.H.: Pitchers Werent Hurt, Their Fastballs Were
description: Major League Baseball officials and fans are thrilled when they see radar gun readings flashing triple digits on stadium scoreboards. But for every one who threw a pitch 100 miles per hour or faster this season, other healthy, hard-throwing pitchers caused scouts to bang their radar guns and check their batteries.

title: The Giants Panda, Loved, but Benched
description: A look around AT&T Park says all one needs to know about Giants fans and their feelings toward Pablo Sandoval. There, adorning the heads of the San Francisco faithful, sits a mix of orange fright wigs, faux Brian Wilson beards and long, would-be Tim Lincecum tresses.

title: Rashomon in East Jerusalem
description: Updated | Sunday | 2:02 p.m. According to an online preview, an episode of 60 Minutes that will air on Sunday includes a report on the escalating conflict in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Silwan, where 70 Jewish families have settled among about 55,000 Palestinians.

title: For Some Embattled Democrats, a Campaign Against Their Leader
description: PERRY, Ga.  As if embattled Congressional Democrats did not have enough on their hands, some are opening up a new front in their fight to save their seats  against Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House and a leader of their own party.

title: A Kind of Hunt That Even Deer Can Get Behind
description: LAND BETWEEN THE LAKES, Ky.  The deer hunters returned to the tournament checkpoint tired and hungry, their camouflage clothing soaked with sweat. All were empty-handed  no big bucks for bragging rights, no fat does for venison. But that was the plan all along.

title: U.S. Had Warnings on Plotter of Mumbai Attack
