Questionable Calls to the Bullpen for Texas
description: One of Rangers Manager Ron Washingtons deviations from mathematically optimal baseball strategy  putting batters that are nowhere near his best atop his lineup  wound up working out Friday night, as both the leadoff man Elvis Andrus and the second-place hitter Michael Young reached base twice in Game 1 of their American League Championship Series against the Yankees. Another questionable strategic move, however  his choice of relief pitchers  did not go so well.

title: When Drugs Cause Problems They Are Supposed to Prevent
description: In the past month, the Food and Drug Administration has concluded that in some cases two types of drugs that were supposed to be preventing serious medical problems were, in fact, causing them.

title: Top American Runner Leaves the Pain Behind
description: ALBUQUERQUE  The morning sky was as clean and blue as a gas flame. Thin clouds hung like a fleecy collar over the Sandia Mountains, as if to warm against the lingering chill, as Dathan Ritzenhein set out for his run on feet that were famously fast and brittle.

title: Critical Assault by Allies Begins Near Kandahar
description: KANDAHAR AIRFIELD, Afghanistan  Hundreds of Afghan and American troops on Saturday made an air assault into the horn of Panjwai, a wide area that has served as the main base for the Taliban threatening Kandahar city, Maj. Gen. Nick Carter, the commander of coalition forces in southern Afghanistan, said.

title: Iranian Official Calls for Trial of U.S. Hikers
description: TEHRAN  Irans intelligence minister on Friday insisted that two United States hikers who remain in custody more than a year after their capture near the Iraqi border must be tried in an Iranian court.

title: Lincoln in Lonely Race in Arkansas
description: RUSSELLVILLE, Ark.  Senator Blanche Lincoln, the incumbent Democrat  a double-whammy of a handicap this year  was hanging around the Pope County Courthouse here, looking for someone, anyone, to talk to.

title: Roethlisberger Returns to Offense That May Rely on Him Less
description: Long before Milledgeville, Ga., became the center of the Pittsburgh Steelers off-season universe, the team had begun the move to a more run-based offense. Within days after the Steelers failed to make the playoffs as the defending Super Bowl champions last season, the team president Art Rooney II talked to Coach Mike Tomlin about reverting to a style that looked more like the Steelers teams of the 1970s and less like the pass-happy version that had emerged in recent years.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Louis Henkin, Leader in Field of Human Rights Law, Dies at 92
description: Louis Henkin, a legal scholar often credited with creating the field of human rights law and the author of classic works on constitutional law and the legal aspects of foreign policy, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Fighting Words
description: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, and Sharron Angle, the Nevada Republican running with Tea Party support for his Senate seat, squared off in a debate last week. What emerged was a vivid contrast in philosophy over the role of government in health care and other areas.

title: In Cable TV Fights, Consumers Wait to See Who Blinks
description: A few minutes into the early hours of Saturday, when three million Cablevision customers in the New York area were blocked from watching Fox because of a contract dispute, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission issued a statement expressing disappointment with both Cablevision and the owner of Fox, the News Corporation.

title: Prime Number
description: 5,300: The number of home and workplace electric-charging stations that General Motors and two of Michigans major utilities will install around the state to meet the demands of an emerging fleet of plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles.

title: Second Basemen Joined by Time and Miscues
description: If Braves second baseman Brooks Conrad felt any apprehension each time a ball came his way last Sunday  uh-oh, please dont hit it to me  it was perfectly understandable, Mike Andrews said.

title: The Key Was B Flat; the Beer Wasnt
description: Anyone popping in for a quick beer at the Happy Dog bar in Cleveland on Wednesday night and expecting the usual fare  polka, country or indie rock  would have been surprised.

title: Sis, Boom, Bah (Humbug): Cheer Squads Have No Place in the N.F.L.
description: On Sunday, the Giants host the Detroit Lions in a game between teams headed in opposite directions. The Giants are 3-2, the Lions, in the midst of another losing season, are 1-4.

title: Carp Invasion May Prompt Changes to Waterways
description: The battle over closing Chicago-area outlets into Lake Michigan is not only about preventing Asian carp from decimating the $7 billion Great Lakes fishing industry, experts said. It has also prompted efforts to re-engineer a century-old waterway system that Joel Brammeier, president of the Alliance for the Great Lakes, has compared to having left Michigan Avenue a dirt road while we built up a modern city around it.

title: Yankees Prepared All Season for Their Game 1 Comeback vs. Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  For the four Yankees who remain from Manager Joe Torres first world championship team in 1996, the details of many of their comeback postseason victories have dissolved so much over the years that even reminders do little to jog memories.

title: Return of the Secret Donors
description: To old political hands, wise to the ways of candidates and money, 1972 was a watershed year. Richard M. Nixons re-election campaign was awash in cash, secretly donated by corporations and individuals.

title: Gates Weighs Afghanistan and Leaks
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said in a private letter over the summer that while the release of 75,000 classified documents about the war in Afghanistan by the Web site WikiLeaks endangered the lives of Afghans helping the United States, the disclosures did not reveal any significant national intelligence secrets.

title: Splendor in the Grass
description: The San Francisco Patient and Resource Center, or Sparc, is not your average pot club. Theres no peephole or scary-looking security guy, no skunky couches or blackened windows. Instead, a collegiate community liaison stands by the door answering questions from passers-by and checking membership cards and paperwork. (Theres no fee to join, but you need a doctors recommendation to enter.) And with its minimalist oak tables and benches, and jazz on the stereo, Sparc could easily be mistaken for a Japanese teahouse. Welcome to the medical marijuana dispensary of the future.

title: The Chilean Mine Rescue, Hollywood Version
description: Life has been pleasant to Nando Parrado since he survived a 1972 plane crash along with his rugby team on an Andes mountaintop. He became an author and a successful television producer in Uruguay. Ethan Hawke played him in a movie. And he still attends an annual reunion with the 15 others whose tortuous survival story was depicted in the 1993 film Alive.

title: Off the Shelf to Keep Yankees in the Game
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Yankees did not need Joba Chamberlain or Dustin Moseley to sweep the division series. Without them, they may not have won Game 1 of the American League Championship Series.

title: A.L.C.S. Game 2 Final: Rangers 7, Yankees 2
description: The Yankees did not get a quality performance from their starting pitcher for the second straight game, and lost, 7-2, to the Texas Rangers on Saturday in Game 2 of the American League Championship Series in Arlington, Tex.

title: In Afghanistan, the Exit Plan Starts With If
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After nine years of war, the endgame here has finally begun.

title: Kramnik Wins Bilbao Final Masters
The X Factor of Economics: People
description: Economists  they certainly are a contentious bunch.

title: Unlikely Allies in Food Stamp Debate
description: Seventeen years ago, Ann Landers got a letter from Upset in Texas, a checker at a grocery store, complaining about customers on food stamps. One woman bought a fancy birthday cake for $17. Another bought a luxury bag of shrimp for $32.12, and so forth. Cant something be done about the freeloaders who are costing us taxpayers millions? Upset complained.

title: Your Comments on Tea in Kabul
description: My Sunday column, Tea in Kabul, offers a few vignettes to explain why I think were pursuing the wrong strategy in Afghanistan. Granted, any reader knows that Ive been critical for some time, warning since 2004 that we were losing ground in southern Afghanistan to the Taliban and strongly against the surge that led President Obama last year to triple our troop presence in Afghanistan. So fair warning that my reporting in Afghanistan may not have been entirely neutral. It confirmed my beliefs  humans always tend to find evidence to back up their preexisting ideas.

title: The Many Faces of You
description: The other day, Facebook suggested that I make a new friend: myself.

title: Magic by Numbers
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: The Feds Next Move
description: The economy isnt recovering fast enough. So what can the Federal Reserve do now? With short-term interest rates near zero, Ben Bernanke, the Feds chairman, said on Friday that he would have to use nonconventional tools to spur growth.

title: And a Pricier Renminbi
description: The Federal Reserve has yet to act, but officials in Europe and Russia are already complaining about the prospect of a much weaker dollar. More Fed intervention could ultimately do the global economy good  especially if it gets China to stop cheapening its currency and squeezing out the rest of the worlds exports.

title: Dont Stay the Dont Ask Ruling
description: The Obama administration has conjured up some inflated fears to justify its decision to appeal an injunction that brought a screeching halt to investigations and discharges of gay men and women serving in the military.

title: Running Against Food Stamps
description: Jobless and hungry, Anthony Jedvabny stood in a charity grocery line in Philadelphia, shocked at how far hed fallen from his well-paying career as a music producer. I never imagined this, he said, inching along North Sixth Street in a grateful crowd at a food center run by Philabundance. Im down to basic survival, said Mr. Jedvabny  a starkly human statistic in the news that Philadelphias poverty rate has hit 25 percent, worst among the 10 largest cities in the nation.

title: How Countrywide Covered the Cracks
description: ON June 27, 2006, Countrywide Financial, the nations largest mortgage lender, was about to close its books on a record-breaking six-month run. The housing market was on fire and Countrywides earnings were soaring. Despite all the euphoria inside the company, some executives noticed that Angelo R. Mozilo, the companys brash and imperious chief executive, seemed subdued.

title: Tea in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan

title: In Afghan South, U.S. Faces Frustrated Residents
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  As American troops mount a critical operation this weekend in the campaign to regain control in Kandahar, they face not only the Taliban but also a frustrated and disillusioned population whose land has been devastated by five years of fighting.

title: Sunnis in Iraq Allied With U.S. Rejoin Rebels
description: BAQUBA, Iraq  Members of United States-allied Awakening Councils have quit or been dismissed from their positions in significant numbers in recent months, prey to an intensive recruitment campaign by the Sunni insurgency, according to government officials, current and former members of the Awakening and insurgents.

title: Japan Goes From Dynamic to Disheartened
description: OSAKA, Japan  Like many members of Japans middle class, Masato Y. enjoyed a level of affluence two decades ago that was the envy of the world. Masato, a small-business owner, bought a $500,000 condominium, vacationed in Hawaii and drove a late-model Mercedes.

title: Our Choice: How to Save the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Erase the Lost Decade?
description: ITS been a rough decade for the stock market  even when considering its recent rally. But frustrated investors can at least fall back on a comforting thought: that the market will eventually revert to the mean, or snap back to its historical average returns.

title: Why Public Works Projects Are in Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Words About the Decline of Picture Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Here Comes a Turnover Storm
description: LAYOFFS, cutbacks and stress inflicted on employees in the economic downturn have left many of them discontented and disengaged. As this pent-up frustration is released, the impact on businesses, their work forces and their customers will be pronounced. A turnover storm is looming, and most businesses are ill prepared for it.

title: Who Needs Cash (or Borders)?
description: MUMBAI, India

title: The Non-Surge In Government Spending, Continued
description: A bit more on how government spending has not, contrary to what you hear everywhere, surged under Obama. Let me offer a calculation that will, I hope, make things a bit clearer. (Cue the usual suspects shouting that Im lying).

title: Barbara Billingsley, TVs June Cleaver, Dies at 94
description: Barbara Billingsley, who as June Cleaver on the television series Leave It to Beaver personified a Hollywood postwar family ideal of the ever-sweet, ever-helpful suburban stay-at-home mom, died Saturday. She was 94.

title: Core Logic, Again
description: Every once in a while it seems necessary to explain why, when considering monetary policy, we need to focus on inflation measures that exclude volatile prices like food and energy. So, read this.

title: Dont Lose That Start-Up State of Mind
description: This interview with Jenny Ming, president and C.E.O. of Charlotte Russe, a clothing chain, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. Ms. Ming is a former president of Old Navy.

title: After Service, Veteran Deaths Surge
description: In the six years after Reuben Paul Santos returned to Daly City from a combat tour in Iraq, he battled depression with poetry, violent video games and, finally, psychiatric treatment. His struggle ended last October, when he hung himself from a stairwell. He was 27.

title: Going Long Liberty in China
description: There has been a lot of buzz lately about investors shorting Chinas overheated real estate market, basically betting that it will go down. I say thats peanuts. There is a much more interesting shorting opportunity in China today. It is truly The Big Short, and that is betting that China cant continue to grow at this pace indefinitely by only permitting its people to have economic liberty without political liberty. Im sure Goldman Sachs would write you a credit default swap on that, and the Chinese Communist Party would take the other side. Are you game? It seems that the Nobel Prize Committee is. Id be, too.

title: Income Inequality: Too Big to Ignore
description: PEOPLE often remember the past with exaggerated fondness. Sometimes, however, important aspects of life really were better in the old days.

title: Times Link to Its Own Course Is a Lesson
description: READERS of The Choice, a blog by reporter Jacques Steinberg, encountered something unusual  and for some of them, something very disturbing  when they clicked on a link in the second paragraph of his Sept. 29 blog post.

title: Barbara Billingsley, Who Played June Cleaver (and Later Spoke Jive), Is Dead
description: Barbara Billingsley, televisions June Cleaver, died Saturday morning at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 94. In Ms. Billingsleys obituary, posted on The Timess Web site, Michael Pollak writes:

title: Sunday: Figure of Speech
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Patrick Blindauer seems incapable of constructing a normal crossword these days. Remember his most recent puzzle with something on the side? (Across Lite, Solution, blog.) Before that, he collaborated with Andrea Carla Michaels on an even more extreme mind-bender that our poor guest blogger Adam Langer had to tackle. (Across Lite, Solution , blog.) If youre completely stuck today, heres a huge clue. Its a rebus puzzle. Some squares contain a symbol instead of a letter. The title of the puzzle will help you here. Come back when youve figured it out.

title: Bus Drivers Take Appeal to Riders
description: Clarceen Caldwell, a retired Muni driver, approached Jesus Romero Jr. to try to convince him to vote against a November ballot measure that takes aim at the pay of San Franciscos bus drivers.

title: World Marathon Majors Offers Extra Incentive to Runners
description: True to its name, the World Marathon Majors offers the grandest financial prize for the top global marathoners. Since it started in 2006, male and female winners each claim $500,000 in a points series that comprises the top five competitive marathons as well as the world championship and Olympic marathon in two-year cycles. Samuel Wanjiru of Kenya secured the 2009-10 mens series Sunday when he won the Chicago Marathon. Liliya Shobukhova won in Chicago on Sunday and clinched the womens title.

title: Digital Maps Dont Always Tell the Whole Story
description: Thanks to Google Earth and MapQuest and GPS and all the other digital mapping products, an image of where we are, or where we are headed, is always just a click away. These geographical services are so omnipresent, in fact, it would be easy to assume that theres nothing left to map.

title: From Palaces to Hotels
description: I WAS born in Udaipur in Rajasthan in 1944, three years before India achieved independence. Udaipur was founded in 1559 by my forefather Udai Singh.

title: N.L.C.S. Game 1 Final: Giants 4, Phillies 3
description: Cody Ross hit two home runs, and Tim Lincecum pitched seven strong innings as the Giants beat the Phillies, 4-3, in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series.

title: Maybe Your Old Credit Card Is Smart Enough
description: YOU would think that a credit card with its own computer chip embedded in the plastic would be superior to one without a chip.

title: Organizers Influence Helped Shape Obama
description: When President Obama hosted a televised youth town-hall style meeting on Thursday, he cited the need to make a long-term commitment to reach policy goals and for citizens to look to one another, not just politicians, for change.

title: The Walls of Puebla
description: Puebla, Mexico

title: King of Beers, and a Slippery Throne
description: MANY Americans barely noticed two years ago when InBev of Belgium took over Anheuser-Busch, the maker of Budweiser, for $52 billion. But the deal transformed an industry and represented the failure of a proud but parochial American family dynasty to stave off a foreign threat, says Julie MacIntosh, author of Dethroning the King: The Hostile Takeover of Anheuser-Busch, an American Icon (Wiley, $27.95).

title: The Financial Time Bomb of Longer Lives
description: FIRST the good news: Were living longer, healthier lives than ever before.

title: Tijuana Reclaimed
description: Tijuana, Mexico

title: The Pulse | After a Star-Spangled Turn, an Homage in Miniature
description: The singer Jim Cornelison is among hundreds of support personnel who received a ring from the Stanley Cup champion Blackhawks, in recognition of the way his rousing rendition of The Star-Spangled Banner energizes hockey crowds at the United Center.

title: The Pulse | A Strong Endorsement, But Not a Replacement
description: Toni Preckwinkle said this week that she would not ask Mayor Richard M. Daley to appoint State Representative Will Burns, Democrat of Chicago, to replace her as Fourth Ward alderman if she is elected president of the Cook County Board of Commissioners.

title: Israel Becomes a Big Issue in the Ninth District Race
description: In case his campaign message is not clear enough, Joel Pollak travels with visual aides.

title: Ground Zero in Sinaloa
description: Culiacn, Mexico

title: Monterreys Habit
description: Monterrey, Mexico

title: In Massachusetts, Obama Stumps
description: BOSTON  President Obama sought to rally Massachusetts Democrats to help re-elect Gov. Deval Patrick, his close friend and political ally, whose 2006 campaign of hope and change presaged Mr. Obamas two years later, but who is struggling against voter anger in a weak economy.

title: In Mexico, Scenes From Life in a Drug War
description: Incidences of drug-related violence in Mexico and on the border continue to make news. We tend to hear about the crimes that touch American lives  like the reported killing of a man riding a Jet Ski on the Rio Grande. What we dont hear as much about is how drugs and violence shape the everyday lives of Mexicans. So here are dispatches from four writers on how drug trafficking has changed their parts of the country. They were translated by Kristina Cordero from the Spanish.

title: In Fervor for Voting, Retirees Hold a Key
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  In an election year of hype and hyperbole, one fact resonates across all contests and candidates: in midterm elections, many people tune out and stay home, but older voters vote. It is a deeply rutted pattern in American history that could swing race after race.

title: Playing All the Angles
description: LAS VEGAS

title: Stars Get Lessons in Life Out of the Bike Lane
description: Flying on my bicycle down the dotted line between lanes on Park Avenue, I had a decision to make. I could follow Dave Jordan as he rode between rows of slow-moving traffic. That would mean bobbing and ducking around rear view mirrors that jutted out from vans like reflective baseball gloves to catch any passing helmeted head. Or I could slow down and go with the flow of traffic.

title: Polls Show Voters Are Focused on Domestic Issues, Not War
description: It has been going on for nine years and counting. Nearly 100,000 American troops are currently deployed for it. More than 1,300 American service members have lost their lives in it. And the United States has spent over $300 billion on it. Yet polling suggests that the war in Afghanistan is barely a blip on voters radar as the midterm elections approach.

title: Come-From-Behind Victory in a Game Riddled With Errors
description: The chess world has so many colorful characters and interesting back stories, it is possible to forget that the biggest dramas occur at the board. The final round at the Continental Class Championships in Arlington, Va., which ended on Monday, provided that reminder.

title: The Rage Wont End on Election Day
description: CARL Paladino began his New York gubernatorial campaign by bragging hed clean out Albany with a baseball bat. When an ally likened his main Albany target, the (Jewish) leader of the State Assembly, to an antichrist or Hitler, he enthusiastically endorsed the slur. We also learned of Paladinos repertory of gag e-mails  among them a pornographic picture of a woman having sex with a horse and a photo of an African tribal ritual captioned Obama Inauguration Rehearsal. How blind we were not to recognize that his victory in a Republican primary under the proud Tea Party banner was inevitable.

title: Much Ado Over ... Notarization?
description: WASHINGTON  In some circles, President Obamas veto of an obscure bill this month has proved more controversial than the legislation itself. The White House called it a pocket veto. Some constitutional experts beg to differ.

title: Seeing Red in Hungary
description: Budapest

title: Rodriguez and Mets Try to Settle Contract Dispute
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets and closer Francisco Rodriguez have adjourned their grievance hearing scheduled for Monday and are negotiating a settlement to their contract dispute, a team spokesman said.

title: 2 Top Candidates Skip G.O.P. Rally

title: Script Looks the Same, but Rangers Dont Flinch
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ron Washingtons job title is somewhat deceptive. He is the manager of the Texas Rangers, but, at his essence, he is also a teacher  a beloved one, at that  and instruction is a responsibility that he takes very seriously. His latest teaching moment arrived shortly after 11 p.m. Friday, minutes after presiding over one of the most excruciating losses in franchise history. In the Rangers clubhouse, Washington addressed his team.

title: Auburn Is on Top When Scoring Finally Stops
description: AUBURN, Ala.  College football players the caliber of Tim Tebow, and with Tebows charisma, are supposed to come along only so often. But less than one full season removed from his college career, another SEC quarterback is offering up a campaign as captivating as the ones Tebow used to have.

Jurden of the Delaware Superior Court in Wilmington, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to perform the ceremony, officiated. Rabbi Howard A. Berman took part.

On Friday, John G. OConnell, the brother-in-law of Mr. Zullo, led a commitment ceremony before friends and family members at the Central Park Boathouse in New York.

Immediately before that, Karen G. Gartner, a friend of the brides family, led a ceremony that incorporated Jewish and Christian traditions.

Meier of Chickasha, Okla., and Robert S. Meier of Oklahoma City. The Rev. C. George Fitzgerald, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Memorial Church on the campus of Stanford University.

description: Katherine Diane Kinzler, the daughter of Carol and Thomas Kinzler of Darien, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Zachary David Clopton, the son of Jamie and Paul Clopton of San Diego. Judge Diane P. Wood of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago, for whom the bridegroom was a law clerk until August, officiated at the Harold Washington Library in Chicago.

title: Nyssa Fajardo, Christen Lee
description: Nyssa Michelle Fajardo, a daughter of Flora Fajardo and Dr. Bienvenido Fajardo of New City, N.Y., was married Saturday to Christen Edward Joseph Lee, a son of Grace Smith Lee and Dr. Edward L. Lee of Washington. Msgr. Robert T. Ritchie performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York, with the Rev. Ricardo Fajardo, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, taking part.

description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Wisconsins Muscle Unseats Ohio State
description: MADISON, Wis.  A quick look at the college football rankings shows an evolution toward speed and ingenuity. No. 2 Oregon is best known for its blur of a tempo, No. 3 Boise State for its mischievous creativity and No. 4 Texas Christian for its defensive versatility.

title: Will Black Voters Turn Out This Year?
description: In North Carolina's Eighth Congressional district, Representative Larry Kissell, a Democrat, is having trouble with African-American voters, especially after his vote against the health care bill.

title: Day After Letting Team Down, Rangers Bullpen Redeems Itself
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  A few minutes after their disastrous collective performance in the eighth inning Friday night, the offending members of the Texas Rangers bullpen  Darren Oliver, Darren ODay and Clay Rapada  huddled in the clubhouse to share their mutual disbelief. The gist of the conversation was this, according to ODay: How did all of us manage to stink on the same night?

title: Black Turnout Will Be Crucial for Democrats
description: LAURINBURG, N.C.  A flood of black voters in North Carolinas Eighth Congressional District two years ago helped Barack Obama become the first Democratic presidential candidate to carry this state since Jimmy Carter and lifted the partys Congressional challenger, Larry Kissell, to victory.

title: Pettitte Pulls Cap Down Low and Heads Out to Save the Day
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: Rutgers Wins, but an Injury Tempers the Celebration
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The moments after Rutgers 23-20 overtime victory against Army on Saturday did not feel like a celebration.

title: Pitching Duel Fizzles as Giants Beat Halladay
description: PHILADELPHIA  Neither pitcher had allowed a run in his playoff debut the week before, with one throwing a no-hitter and the other striking out 14 in a two-hit shutout that was nearly as dominant. With those command performances as the backdrop, expectations were high coming into Game 1 of the National League Championship Series. But the two aces, Roy Halladay and Tim Lincecum, wound up falling a little short in their encore presentations.

title: A.L.C.S. Game 2 Recap
description: Pictures from the Rangers 7-2 defeat of the Yankees in the second game of the American League Championship Series.

title: Columbus Keeper Scores a Goal, and Deserves a Hand
description: That Columbus goalkeeper Will Hesmer raced out of his own half in injury time Saturday to lend a hand (or, more likely, a head) in a last-ditch effort to tie a game at Toronto was not newsworthy. Goalkeepers do that all the time.

title: College Football Replay, Oct. 17
description: From belly-flops to bulldogs, the week in college football.

title: Rooney Benched Before Tie
description: The Manchester United star Wayne Rooney was dropped from the teams starting lineup without explanation and played only the last 20 minutes of a 2-2 draw with West Bromwich Albion in a home game in the Premier League. Rooney was left on the bench days after directly contradicting Manager Alex Ferguson by denying that he had missed games because he had been struggling with an ankle injury. Rooney played 90 minutes for England in a 0-0 draw against Montenegro on Tuesday.

title: Vows: Julia & Paul
description: Julia McCarthy met Paul Leeming in high school, but it was only years later, when they were reintroduced through mutual friends in Brooklyn, that the two had a chance to fall in love.

title: Letters
Familiar Setting, Familiar Result For Pat Burrell
description: PHILADELPHIA  In his last at-bat for the Phillies, in Game 5 of the 2008 World Series, Pat Burrell ripped a double and was replaced by a pinch-runner, who scored the final run for the winning team in a 4-3 victory.

title: Dual Shows Draw Art Lovers Out of Paris
description: It takes a lot to get Parisians out of Paris  but like Brooklyn and Manhattan, the banlieues, or outskirts, of that city are where cutting-edge art is booming, despite the neighborhoods sometimes rough reputation.

title: Vikings Cant Be Hostage to Favres Start Streak
description: Brett Favre is listed as questionable for the Minnesota-Dallas game later on Sunday, but the safe bet is that he will play. He has played in every other game, 289 straight in the regular season, so why should today be any different?

title: Some Yankees Free Agents Stood Apart
description: A colleague recently asked for suggestions for a list of the best Yankee free-agent signings. The answer, of course, depends on what one means by best.

title: Giants TV Coverage in Jeopardy for Many New York Area Fans
description: Many fans in the New York metropolitan area missed the Phillies-Giants playoff game on Saturday night because of the continuing skirmish between Cablevision and Fox. The next big target is the Giants-Lions game on Sunday.

description: Ral M. Grijalva. Bennie Thompson. Jan Schakowsky.

description: This year, signs are emerging that Baghdad is ready to do business.

description: Remember Philip Carlo, the tough-guy author from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, who has fraternized with Mafia hitmen, sexual predators and psychopathic druglords, only to fall prey to a killer within  amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., popularly known as Lou Gehrigs Disease? He was profiled in The New York Times last December.

description: Senate candidates for Delaware and Colorado tested their mettle on the Sunday TV talk shows. The New York Timess Janie Lorber listed the lineup.

description: With apologies to the Marx Brothers, here is the very clever introduction to CBCs Hockey Night in Canada telecast of Saturdays Senators-Canadiens game.

description: 4:21 p.m. | Updated  The contract dispute between Fox and Cablevision appears likely to drag into a third day.

title: Live Analysis: Giants 28, Lions 20, Final
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants 28-20 win over the Detroit Lions on Sunday ensured they will head to the taxing upcoming portion of their schedule on a high. They have won three in a row, and the previously troubled times seem like forever ago.

title: China Escalates Fight With U.S. on Energy Aid
description: BEIJING  A dispute between China and the United States over Beijings subsidies to clean energy industries escalated on Sunday when a senior Chinese economic official warned that Washington cannot win this trade fight.

description: With little more than two weeks left before the midterm elections, the White House on Sunday predicted that Democrats would hold onto their majorities in the House and the Senate.

description: The Yankees loss on Saturday to the Texas Rangers did more than send the American League Championship Series back to the Bronx tied at one game each. It also pushed down the price of tickets to Game 3.

title: Calling on Old Reliable to Breathe New Life
description: Philadelphia

title: Belva Plain, Novelist of Jewish-American Life, Dies at 95
description: Belva Plain, who became a best-selling author at age 59 and whose multigenerational family sagas of Jewish American life won a loyal readership in the millions, died on Tuesday at her home in Short Hills, N.J. She was 95.

title: Widespread Fraud Is Seen in Afghan Elections
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Although the preliminary results of the Sept. 18 parliamentary elections, expected to be announced Sunday, were postponed, interviews with Afghan and Western officials indicate that fraud was pervasive and that nearly 25 percent of the votes are likely to be thrown out.

title: Live Analysis: Jets 24, Broncos 20, Final
description: Live coverage and analysis of the Jets game against the Broncos. Greg Bishop provided updates from Invesco Field in Denver. Andrew Das and George Bretherton filled in the gaps from the Times office in Manhattan.

title: Oregon Is No. 1 for the First Time
description: Oregon is ranked No. 1 in the Associated Press Top 25 for the first time. The Ducks received 39 first-place votes and moved up from No. 2 after Ohio States 31-18 loss to Wisconsin.

title: Morals Without God?
description: I was born in Den Bosch, the city after which Hieronymus Bosch named himself. [1] This obviously does not make me an expert on the Dutch painter, but having grown up with his statue on the market square, I have always been fond of his imagery, his symbolism, and how it relates to humanitys place in the universe. This remains relevant today since Bosch depicts a society under a waning influence of God.

title: New York Job Offer for Philadelphia Orchestras Principal Clarinetist
description: The New York Philharmonic took a step closer to filling a key position this weekend, offering its vacant principal clarinet job to Ricardo Morales, who holds the post at the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: The Pace Years: When One Gallery Is Not Enough
description: Fifty years ago one of the 800-pound gorillas of todays New York gallery world was born. Now with four locations in Manhattan and one in Beijing, the Pace Gallery has real estate and a roster of blue chip artists that are eclipsed only by Gagosian Gallerys global empire, which in addition to three locations in New York, has satellites in Beverly Hills, London, Rome and Athens.

title: The Pace Gallery Looks Back
description: Highlights from the exhibition, at three locations, marking the mega-gallerys 50th anniversary.

title: At the Broadway Cabaret Festival, Kooks and Cutups
description: An incandescent kook, a swinging cool guy, a gregarious cutup, a neurotic sob sister and two tough ladies: the performers in Broadway Melody Makers, Fridays opening-night show of the three-day Broadway Cabaret Festival at Town Hall, made up a reasonable cross section of personality types you might find at a showbiz after party. The program  created, written, and hosted by Scott Siegel  was devoted to mostly familiar songs, by mostly American songwriters, mostly from the theater, sung by Broadway performers. Conspicuously absent among the composers were Jerome Kern and George Gershwin.

title: Left-Field Hip-Hop, Coherently Disjointed
description: Before the members of Shabazz Palaces took the stage on Friday night, they huddled off to one side, strapping on ornate black masklike headpieces and making sure they were perfectly vertical, towering several inches above the tops of their heads.

title: Monday: Officials Behind Batters
description: Since blogging for Wordplay, Ive never had a chance to talk about a Lynn Lempel puzzle. I finally do and, as usual, its very nice. Shes one of the best Monday constructors around  a master Id have to say (since calling her a mistress doesnt sound quite right).

title: Princes Fate, Entwined With Desire
description: The choreographer and director Matthew Bourne has said that as a child he found swans frightening, so its only fitting that in his theatrical mind they are as well  wild, menacing creatures, quicker on land than you might expect and poised to attack. They tip the scale more toward power than pretty; theyre also played by men.

title: The Met Makes Way for New Bohmians
description: Saturday was a night of multiple debuts at the Metropolitan Opera when Franco Zeffirellis popular production of Puccinis Bohme returned to the repertory. Three of the main characters, as well as the conductor, Roberto Rizzi Brignoli, were all appearing for the first time. But the focus of attention was on the fast-rising Italian tenor Vittorio Grigolo, making his Met debut as Rodolfo.

title: A Revolutionary of Arabic Verse
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Every year around this time the name of the Syrian poet Adonis pops up in newspapers and in betting shops. Adonis (pronounced ah-doh-NEES), a pseudonym adopted by Ali Ahmad Said Esber in his teens as an attention getter, is a perennial favorite to win the Nobel Prize in Literature. This year Ladbrokes, the British bookmaking firm, had his chances at 8-1, which made him seem a surer bet than the eventual winner, Mario Vargas Llosa, a 25-1 long shot. Why Adonis appeals to the oddsmakers, presumably, is that hes a poet, and poets have been under-represented among Nobelists lately; that he writes in Arabic, the language of only one Nobel winner, Naguib Mahfouz; and that as is the case with so many recent winners, most Americans have never heard of him.

title: Handels Old Testament Dramas Revived in New York
description: A particular delight of the New York classical music season at its teeming height is the way seemingly unrelated events intersect to produce a spontaneous minifestival, or at least a theme. It happened last week on consecutive evenings, when two of the citys finest professional church choirs presented contrasting Handel oratorios touching on more or less parallel Old Testament subjects.

title: A French Thinker Who Crossed Continents and Cultures
description: Patrick Wilcken first interviewed the celebrated French anthropologist Claude Lvi-Strauss in 2005. For Mr. Wilcken an audience with the great man must have been a daunting occasion: Mr. Wilcken had a biography in the works, and his subject was then well into his 90s. (He died in 2009, just short of his 101st birthday.) And even at that late date Mr. Wilcken wanted Lvi-Strauss to address some of the fundamental issues raised by his work.

title: Numerous Titles Are Awarded at World Championships
description: PHILADELPHIA  One world championship was decided here on Friday, and seven more titles were determined on Saturday afternoon.

title: A Linguist at a Loss for Words Regarding Love
description: Looking to brush up your Esperanto? Make sure to grab a ticket for The Language Archive, a new play by Julia Cho that offers theatergoers a rare chance to acquire a phrase or two of that little-used international tongue.

title: Why Have Deficits Exploded?
description: For all those commenters saying that we must have had a surge in government spending  I mean, look at the deficit!  a simple picture:

title: Jackass 3D Leads Weekend Box-Office Sales
description: Never underestimate the power of sophomoric humor at the American multiplex. Jackass 3D, left, produced for $20 million by Paramount Pictures, surpassed expectations to sell an estimated $50 million at the weekend box office. As the third installment in the franchise, this picture was helped by premium-priced 3-D tickets. But it also benefited from an enormous promotional effort by MTV, Paramounts corporate sibling and the home of the Jackass television series. Jackass: The Movie, made in 2002 for $5 million, opened to about $28 million (after adjusting for inflation). Jackass Number Two, made for $12 million 2006, opened to an adjusted $31.4 million. Finishing second this weekend was the sharply more expensive RED, with John Malkovich, an adaptation of an obscure graphic novel. Summit Entertainment spent about $60 million to make RED, which took in about $22.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. The Social Network (Sony Pictures Entertainment) ranked third in its third weekend, selling about $11 million for a new total of $63 million. Secretariat (Walt Disney Studios) was fourth with $9.5 million ($27.5 million total). The romantic comedy Life as We Know It (Warner Brothers) was fifth with $9.2 million ($28.9 million total).

title: Orpheus Announces Commission Winners
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which takes the populist view that musical interpretations can be shaped by the ensemble rather than by a conductor, has expanded on that concept in a commissioning program, Project 440. The orchestras goal was to commission four composers to help celebrate its 40th anniversary. Intent on getting its audience involved, it joined forces with WQXR, the New York classical radio station, which opened the process to its listeners. Orpheus and WQXR assembled a panel of more than 30 performers, composers and music executives, who nominated 60 composers. Listeners were invited to peruse the composers biographies, to listen to music clips on WQXRs Web site, wqxr.org, and to comment. The selection committee, taking listener comments into account, chose 30 semifinalists whose music was streamed for 24 hours on Q2, WQXRs Internet station. That marathon yielded 12 finalists, and 4 winners were announced at Orpheuss first New York concert of the season, on Thursday at Carnegie Hall. They are Alex Mincek, a New York composer; Clint Needham, who recently completed his doctorate at Indiana University; Andrew Norman of California; and Cynthia Lee Wong, who completed studies at Juilliard. At the concert Orpheus also introduced its new executive director, Ayden Adler. Ms. Adler, a former French horn player in the Rochester Philharmonic, joins the ensemble from the Philadelphia Orchestra, where she was director of education and community partnerships.

title: Roethlisberger Shakes Off Rust in Return
description: PITTSBURGH  There was a time last spring, perhaps a few weeks, when a segment of Pittsburgh Steelers fans wanted Ben Roethlisberger traded, their disgust over Roethlisbergers troubling behavior with a woman in a Georgia bar seemingly tainting forever the relationship between a two-time Super Bowl winner and one of the most devoted fan bases in the N.F.L.

title: A Spaceflight Attempts Almost-Instant Documentary
description: Few people are better self-promoters than Richard Branson, the tycoon and entrepreneur behind Virgin Records, Virgin Mobile and now Virgin Galactic. So, not surprisingly, he sees the value in having a television documentary series closely follow his companys efforts at commercial spaceflight.

title: Amid Cacophony and Rapture, a Plaintive Quality Prevails
description: Extremes of human nature, dire and exalted, are the subjects of Bradford Coxs songs for his band Deerhunter; and extremes of sound, consonant and bristling, are his vehicle. At Webster Hall on Friday night he sang, in a high voice that often stayed strangely serene, about murder, revelation, love, nightmares, memories, annihilation and regeneration. Playing guitar, he led Deerhunter through songs that used just a few rudimentary chords each but rode those structures toward cacophony and rapture.

title: New CDs
description: SUGARLAND

title: A Washington Senator Fights to Keep Her Seat
description: EVERETT, Wash.  Never mind Nevada. If you are among the party power brokers and political fortunetellers obsessed with Americas most elusive elected position, Senate seat No. 51, head to Washington  the real one.

title: N.L.C.S. Game 2 Final: Phillies 6, Giants 1
description: Jimmy Rollins hit a three-run double in the seventh, and Roy Oswalt allowed three hits in eight innings as the Phillies evened the National League Championship Series with a 6-1 win over the Giants.

title: Fox News Insinuates, but Investor Shrugs It Off
description: Some critics of the proposed Islamic community center in Lower Manhattan, including commentators on Fox News, have linked the project to terrorism by seizing on a Saudi princes past financial backing of the imam at the center of the controversy.

title: Amid Anger at Albany, Poll Shows Support for Cuomo
description: New York voters are profoundly pessimistic about the state economy, worried that they or someone in their household will be laid off in the coming year, and convinced that Albany is rife with corruption.

title: James E. Fuchs, Shot-Put Innovator, Dies at 82
description: James E. Fuchs, who developed a new way to heave the shot to compensate for a leg injury and used the technique to set world records and dominate shot-putting over two remarkable seasons, died in Manhattan on Oct. 8. He was 82.

title: With Film, Afghan-German Is a Foreigner at Home
description: BERLIN  It has been many years since a German film student had a feature-length movie shown in the competition at the prestigious Berlinale International Film Festival, a distinction that can launch a career. That is what Burhan Qurbani is enjoying at the moment, with his film Shahada.

title: Mexico Watches California Marijuana Vote
description: MEXICO CITY  In two weeks, Californians will decide whether to legalize small amounts of marijuana for recreational use, in a vote that polls show could be close.

title: Forced to Scramble, Jets Eke Out a Victory
description: DENVER  On the most improbable play of the Jets latest improbable victory, quarterback Mark Sanchez dropped back, scrambled left away from pressure and heaved a pass best described as the prayer in thin air.

title: U.S. Case Against Informer Bares a Tangled Bond
description: Abdelghani Meskini was the rarest of government informers, a reformed Algerian terrorist who was convicted in the failed millennium plot to blow up Los Angeles International Airport, but then became a valuable witness whose testimony helped convict two other plotters.

title: When Salacious Is Irresistible
description: In the last week, Ive gotten a very clear view of two things  the male physique purported to belong to Brett Favre and the inner workings of modern media. I wish I could un-see both.

title: Liverpools New Owners Take a Look, and the Sight Is Not Pretty
description: London

title: A New Quandary for the Federal Reserve: Grappling With Low Inflation
description: BOSTON  A situation the Federal Reserve has long feared has come to pass: the central bank, after spending three decades taming inflation, now needs more of it.

title: Find Jay-Zs Memoir at a Bookstore, or on a Billboard
description: PRINT advertising by publishing houses tends to boast about books that are being bold and original, but that can seldom be said of the ads themselves, which generally consist of ho-hum photographs of the book and author, a brief description of the subject matter and laudatory blurbs.

title: Israel Renews Bid to Free Soldier Held by Hamas
description: JERUSALEM Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday that Israel had recently renewed contacts with a German mediator to negotiate the release of a captured Israeli soldier, Staff Sgt. Gilad Shalit, who is being held by Hamas.

title: Redesigned, Self Adjusts Its Formula
description: As a competitive triathlete and the editor in chief of Self, a magazine that offers women exclamation-pointed tips on self-fulfillment (Banish the Blahs and Feel Happier! Leaner Legs! Tighter Tush! Be True to You!), Lucy Danziger is not prone to idling.

title: Even Under New Captain, Yahoo Seems Adrift
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The board of Yahoo, the ailing Web portal, hired Carol A. Bartz as chief executive to apply a little shock therapy.

title: French Report New Threat of Terrorist Attack in Europe
description: PARIS  Saudi intelligence officials have informed France that Al Qaedas affiliate in Yemen may be planning an attack in France or Europe, the French interior minister said Sunday.

title: 17-Term Democrat Faces Big Test in G.O.P. District
description: BLUE SPRINGS, Mo.  The unmistakable, zigzagging profile of the B-2 stealth bomber cut into view here suddenly, roaring above the field of assembled military veterans like a catchy campaign slogan belted at a political rally: Here it is, folks, the plane Representative Ike Skelton brought to town.

title: For Giants Rookie Punter, Blunders Are Mixed With Moments of Joy
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The performance of the rookie punter Matt Dodge in the Giants 28-20 victory over the Detroit Lions on Sunday was a reflection of his young career: at once great and ghastly. But the laid-back Dodge just shrugged and chuckled in the locker room afterward.

title: With Grant, NPR to Step Up State Government Reporting
description: NPR has received a $1.8 million grant from the Open Society Foundations to begin a project called Impact of Government that is intended to add at least 100 journalists at NPR member radio stations in all 50 states over the next three years.

title: Will Apples Culture Hurt the iPhone?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If you want a smartphone powered by Googles Android software, you could get Motorolas Droid 2 or its cousin, the Droid X. Then there is the Droid Incredible from HTC, the Fascinate from Samsung and the Ally from LG.

title: Traffic Bait Doesnt Bring Ad Clicks
description: Sure, articles about Lindsay Lohans repeat trips to rehabilitation and Brett Favres purported sexual peccadilloes generate loads of reader traffic, but do they actually make decent money for the Web sites that publish them?

title: With Rangers Ace Looming in Game 3, Yankees Stick With Their Rotation Plan
description: At 4:21 p.m. Sunday, C. C. Sabathia began a throwing session in the Yankee Stadium bullpen that put to rest, at least for a day, the unending conjecture about when he would start next.

title: Traffic Bait Doesnt Bring Ad Clicks
description: Sure, articles about Lindsay Lohans repeat trips to rehabilitation and Brett Favres purported sexual peccadilloes generate loads of reader traffic, but do they actually make decent money for the Web sites that publish them?

title: Google Is Determined to Crack the Social Code
description: Google has been stunningly adept at devising computer algorithms to help people search the Internet. But when it comes to building features for social networking, the company has been much less effective.

title: Adding Discipline and Control, Giants Resurrect an Old Winning Formula
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On the field before Sundays game, the Giants welcomed several dozen former players, a lineage that stretched from Andy Robustelli to Amani Toomer. Standing together, they represented decades of intimidating defense, a sturdy rushing attack and a timely, if controlled, passing game.

title: Fox-Cablevision Blackout Reaches a 2nd Day
description: What started as a routine contract dispute between Cablevision Systems and the News Corporation has become one of the longest and most talked about blackouts of television programming in years.

title: A Finish Line With a Real High: 8,000 Feet
description: ATOP MOUNT LEMMON, Ariz.  The New York marathon is a walk in the park compared with what took place up the side of this mountain on Sunday. Bostons famed Heartbreak Hill? A molehill.

title: New Tactic in California for Paying Pollution Bill
description: STOCKTON, Calif.  Officials who have tried and failed to clean the air in Californias smog-filled San Joaquin Valley have seized on a new strategy: getting millions of drivers to shoulder more of the cost.

title: New Spy Game: Firms Secrets Sold Overseas
description: Huang Kexue, federal authorities say, is a new kind of spy.

title: White House Urges Calm on Foreclosures
description: Amid a rising uproar over slipshod bank foreclosure practices, members of the Obama administration on Sunday expressed anger about the revelations, but urged caution as multiple investigations into the crisis unfold.

title: B.C.S. Upstarts Left Hoping for a Shake-Up
description: Ever since Boise State executed a brilliant fake punt to spark its come-from-behind victory over Texas Christian in the Fiesta Bowl last season, a single question has dominated the college football landscape: could the Broncos use that undefeated season as a springboard to crash this seasons Bowl Championship Series title game?

title: Kia Teams With the N.B.A. for a Big Ad Campaign
description: Kia Motors America is taking a larger role this year in its marketing partnership with the National Basketball Association, starting with a campaign called KIA NBA Tip-Off.

title: A Profusion of Magic Words
description: In legal parlance, they are called magic words, and their use has exploded in this years midterm races.

title: Informed Shopping, at a Price
description: In a market where many consider $2.99 a lot to pay for an iPhone application, $14.99 may seem downright steep.

title: Rutgers Player Is Paralyzed Below the Neck
description: The solemn expression on Coach Greg Schianos face and the nearly silent locker room after the Rutgers players overtime win against Army on Saturday indicated that their thoughts were with defensive tackle Eric LeGrand. They hoped that his outlook was not as grim as the hit that forced him to be carted off the field.

title: Denied Game at Home, Football Fans Go to Bars
description: On most game-day afternoons, identifying the enemy of a New York Giants fan is rather simple: Look for the guy in the opposing jersey.

title: Tough Job Awaits Yankees Next Manager
description: Foremost in the mind of Joe Girardi are the Texas Rangers and the task of finding a starting pitcher to last at least five innings against them in the American League Championship Series. Yet Girardi is human, and part of that condition is fretting about the future. No doubt lurking in his consciousness is the fact that he is a manager without a contract for next season.

title: Groups Push Legal Limits in Advertising
description: A recent television commercial sponsored by an Iowa-based nonprofit group, American Future Fund, attacking Representative Bobby Bright, an Alabama Democrat, could hardly have been more explicit in its closing: On Election Day, the narrator said, take the right path. Vote against Bobby Bright.

title: Louis F. Bantle, Chief of U.S. Tobacco, Dies at 81
description: Louis F. Bantle, who helped build the United States Tobacco Company into one of the most powerful brands in the tobacco industry, gaining an 80 percent share of the market for chewing tobacco, died Oct. 10 in Greenwich, Conn. He was 81.

title: Mission Is Control as Rangers Lee Limits Walks
description: He may end up a Yankee in 2011. Or not. But chances are, it may be a long time before anyone puts together as efficient a season as the one Cliff Lee just completed.

title: Obamas Rally for Democrats in Final Push
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is seeking to rally anxious Democrats for the final two weeks of the midterm election campaign, traveling to the heart of the electoral battleground to urge them not to be discouraged  Dont let them tell you that change isnt possible  even as resurgent Republicans continued to expand their sights with the help of deep-pocketed allies.

title: Lincecum Holds Steady and Laughs Off the Whistling
description: PHILADELPHIA  Shortly after Game 1 of the National League Championship Series on Saturday night, a group of reporters stood in front of Tim Lincecums locker, waiting to speak with him after he beat the Phillies.

title: Weary of Debris, Haiti Finally Sees Some Vanish
With Focus on Youth Safety, a Sport Considers Changes
description: From the N.H.L.s top goalie to the parent of a 12-year-old who sustained head and spinal concussions from a body check, calls are proliferating for changes to the culture of a sport that many see as too accepting of reckless body contact and serious injury.

title: In Climate Denial, Again
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney has to be smiling. With one exception, none of the Republicans running for the Senate  including the 20 or so with a serious chance of winning  accept the scientific consensus that humans are largely responsible for global warming.

title: For Our China Trade Emergency, Dial Section 301
description: Washington

title: Citis Uneasy Deal With EMI
description: Citigroup has the most to lose from its showdown over EMI, the British music company. Barring an 11th-hour settlement, the bank is scheduled to start defending itself in court on Monday against allegations that it tricked Terra Firma, the private equity firm led by Guy Hands, into buying EMI for 4.2 billion ($6.7 billion) in 2007. The only way Citi can avoid the confrontation is to agree to restructure the 3 billion it lent Terra Firma to finance the deal.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,327 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Stealth Money
description: We cant turn on the television these days without being assaulted by ads anonymously savaging candidates. Welcome to politics in post-Citizens United America. The Supreme Court allowed unlimited campaign spending by corporations and unions but didnt require the folks picking up the tab to stand behind their words.

title: Death, DNA and the Supreme Court
description: In an age when DNA technology can help identify the guilty and avoid grave miscarriages of justice, states should not be allowed to block testing of available biological evidence before executing someone.

title: Rescued Miners Secrecy Pact Erodes in Spotlight
description: SAN JOS MINE, Chile  Family members of the 33 miners who were trapped for 69 days had said a special Mass on Sunday would be a chance for the miners to find closure and understanding.

title: Maryland Foes Face Off in Changed Landscape
description: REISTERSTOWN, Md.  Former Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. of Maryland, the only Republican to have held that position over the last four decades, thought he was done as a political candidate after the 2008 elections.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: For a Suburban Tea Party, Anger Is All the Rage
description: A loudspeaker was blasting rebel songs along Jericho Turnpike on a day as crisp and perfect as fall gets on Long Island. A couple dozen members of the Conservative Society for Action, or C.S.A., a local Tea Party affiliate, with tricorn hats and yellow rattlesnake flags, held their positions on both banks of a river of cars. They waved signs and bellowed through bullhorns, oblivious to John Lennons mockery of revolution.

title: Keeping Agriculture Alive Near New York City (Yes, Really)
description: Suffern, N.Y.

description: Harvey Weinstein has hired the Oscar-winning producer Donna Gigliotti as the Weinstein Companys new president of production, a move aimed at recapturing his Miramax glory days.

description: Last month a Chinese trawler operating in Japanese-controlled waters collided with two vessels of Japans Coast Guard. Japan detained the trawlers captain; China responded by cutting off Japans access to crucial raw materials.

description: For more than 40 years, social scientists investigating the causes of poverty have tended to treat cultural explanations like Lord Voldemort: That Which Must Not Be Named.

description: Gilbert Arenas had already said enough in the last week, and arguably too much. He dispersed the encroaching crowd of reporters with a polite statement of policy: I dont talk before games.

description: The Broncos rookie Tim Tebow scored his first N.F.L. touchdown on Sunday, a 5-yard scamper on a direct snap in a 24-20 loss to the Jets. The question now is whether Coach Josh McDaniels will come to regret calling the play.

title: Brazil: No Green Party Endorsement in Runoff
description: The Green Party decided Sunday to remain independent in the presidential runoff election on Oct. 31, and the third-place finisher in the first round, Marina Silva, left, said she would not support either Dilma Rousseff, a former cabinet chief, or the opposition candidate, Jos Serra, a former governor of So Paulo. Ms. Silvas decision benefits Dilma Rousseff because an endorsement of Serra was expected, said David Fleischer, a political analyst at the University of Brasilia.

title: Cuomo Approaches Seven-Way Debate With Caution
description: Will the minor-party candidates gang up on him? Will his Republican rival, Carl P. Paladino, raise questions  again  about his former marriage? Will the discussion veer out of control, diminishing the front-runner along with the also-rans?

title: The Week Ahead

title: Matthew Weiner Closes the Books on Season 4 of Mad Men
description: One of the pleasures of being a dedicated Mad Men fan  and what are you doing here if you arent?  is connecting with other viewers whose knowledge of the show is as encyclopedic and as obsessive as your own. And no one fills that role better than Matthew Weiner, who created the show, oversees its production and would probably cater it if he had the time, and who is kind of like a walking Wikipedia of Mad Men (with a much higher rate of accuracy).

title: So Why Talk When You Can Text?
description: The average teenager sends more than six text messages in every waking hour, according to Nielsen, which analyzed mobile phone usage by 13- to 17-year-olds from April to June this year.

title: North and South Korea Restore Aviation Hotline
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North and South Korea reopened one of the three severed hot lines between them on Monday in response to a request from the North, its first apparent outreach since the youngest son of the leader, Kim Jong-il, was unveiled as his successor.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Movie That Made a Supreme Court Justice
description: Around the time that Justice Sonia M. Sotomayor was entering college, the man who would eventually become her husband took her to see a film by Sidney Lumet. It was 12 Angry Men, from 1957, about a jury deliberating on the case of a young man accused of murder.

title: In a Schizophrenics Trial, Both Sides Agree
description: The trial of David Tarloff, who is accused of hacking to death a psychologist on the Upper East Side, is the rare case in which both sides agree about what should ultimately happen: he should be locked up.

title: Phillies Break Out With Lift From Oswalt
description: PHILADELPHIA  They tried throwing at his chin, walking him and even booing him every time he came to the plate, but those in Philadelphia could not find a way to prevent Cody Ross from circling the bases at least once Sunday night. So the Phillies found another way to keep Ross, the hottest hitter in the playoffs, from beating them: they outslugged him.

title: In Brooklyn, Officer Injured in Exchange of Fire
description: A police officer was shot twice in the leg on Sunday night after an exchange of gunfire in a building in East New York, Brooklyn, the police said. The officer and a suspect, who was also shot three times, were in stable condition.

description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the Times article 10/10/10: They Love Just Thinking About It.

title: What is Your Favorite Place in Your House?
description: For will.i.am of the Black Peas, its his recording studio, while for skateboarder Tony Hawk, its the custom skate park he built behind his house. Though few teenagers have spaces custom-built to suit their talents, everyone has a place in their home where they feel most comfortable. Where is yours, and why? You might browse this slide show for inspiration first.

description: Barclayss chief executive, John Varley, in an interview with The Financial Times, has flown against popular opinion in banking circles by declaring that the proposals of the Basel III committee  expected to be adopted by the Group of 20 nations next month  are fair.

title: France Asks Airlines to Cut Flights Ahead of Strikes
description: PARIS  Weeks of protests over President Nicolas Sarkozys efforts to change Frances pension system were intensifying Monday in advance of a final parliamentary vote. But with approval expected, Mr. Sarkozy faces the possibility that winning will not offer much political gain.

title: CQS to List Fund on London Market
description: CQS, one of the biggest hedge funds in Britain, is expected to make its first public offering by listing a new fund on the London stock market, The Financial Times reported.

description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the American private equity group, has offered up to $1.73 billion in a nonbinding bid for Perpetual, the Australian financial services group.

description: The relative good will that greeted Carol A. Bartz when she started at Yahoo as chief executive almost two years ago is wearing thin.

title: Princeton Endowment Posts a 14.7% Return
description: At a time when many of the nations largest endowments have generated returns below 12 percent, Princeton University said on Friday that its endowment had returned 14.7 percent last year, bringing its total to $14.4 billion.

title: Madrid Art Fair Brings Prints to the Masses
description: One of the wonderful things about art prints is that you generally dont have to be rich to buy them. But whether you are buying or not, a visit to Madrids annual Estampa: International Print and Contemporary Art Edition Fair, from Oct. 20 to 24, holds seemingly endless pleasures.

description: BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto on Monday pulled the plug on their plans to form a $116 billion iron ore joint venture after regulators in Australia and elsewhere signaled they would block the deal because of competition concerns, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: Allianz Is Said to Plan $3 Billion Bid for Channel Rail Link
description: Allianz is about to join the list of suitors for the Channel tunnel rail link with a 2 billion ($3.1 billion) bid for the railroad put up for sale by Britains coalition government, The Sunday Times reported.

title: AIA Expected to Close I.P.O. Book Early on Strong Demand
description: The American International Group is set to close the institutional book for the $15 billion AIA Group initial public offering two days ahead of schedule, amid signs the offering has been swamped by orders from traditional funds and prominent Chinese investors, Reuters said.

title: Royal Bank of Canada to Buy BlueBay for $1.53 Billion
description: Royal Bank of Canada said on Monday that it had agreed to buy BlueBay Asset Management, an investment manager based in London, in a deal that values BlueBay at 963 million, or $1.53 billion.

title: This Week in Small Business: Taxes, Bankers, the Windows Phone
description: HONEY, IS THERE AN ELECTION SOON? Now that weve ended combat operations in Iraq, President Obama is being accused of declaring war on the Chamber of Commerce. A new scorecard from a small-business group suggests that Republicans are more business-friendly than Democrats. An analysis of polls by the FiveThirtyEight blog finds theres a 72 percent chance that Republicans will take over the House. Small-business advocate Jim Blasingame discusses ways our political leadership can encourage economic recovery. Unhappiness with the current administration is creating a business backlash, even in the presidents home state.

title: Are the Jets the Best Team in the N.F.L.?
description: Everyone has a plan until they get punched in the mouth.  Mike Tyson

description: Some new reports show that Americans have quickly moved beyond accessing the Internet on just desktop and laptop computers, and are now embracing a range of mobile gadgets including cellphones and e-readers.

description: For a president under siege, maybe this could help.

title: Trump Angry About Bid to Build at Jones Beach
description: After promising in typical Trumpian modesty to replace a restaurant at a landmark New York beach with the finest dining and banquet facility anywhere in the world, Donald Trump is seething four years later that visitors still must pass what he calls a rat-infested dump.

description: President Obama and the Democrats have spent much of the last several weeks complaining about outside groups  mostly financed by big business and wealthy donors  that they believe are interfering in campaigns across the country.

description: 3:16 p.m. | Updated  The New York Timess Andrew E. Kramer provides more details about BPs asset sale.

title: Shanghai Pharmaceuticals Hires Banks for Initial Offering
description: Shanghai Pharmaceuticals, the Chinese partner of Roche Holding, has hired China International Capital, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs to handle its initial public offering in Hong Kong, which could raise as much as $1.5 billion, Reuters reported, citing people with knowledge of the plan.

title: Northeast Utilities Plans to Buy Rival Nstar
description: In planning a $4.3 billion merger, New England power companies Northeast Utilities and NStar have sought to learn from past utility deals that have failed.

title: In Sumos Push for the Olympics, a Turn Away From Tradition
description: OSAKA, Japan  For years, promoters of sumo wrestling have been pushing for the sports inclusion in the Olympic Games. To get there, the International Sumo Federation has thrown its weight behind a form of the game that would offend purists and surprise most everyone else: womens sumo.

title: Ford Is Said to Be Planning to Cut Stake in Mazda
description: Ford is preparing to cut its remaining interest in the Japanese automaker Mazda from 11 percent to three percent, The Financial Times reported.

description: William Pesek: The hot money has fled low interest rates to seek out I.P.O.s in Asia.

title: St. Jude Medical to Buy AGA Medical for $1 Billion
description: St. Jude Medical, a device maker, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy AGA Medical for about $1 billion in cash and stock to gain access to an array of heart repair devices.

description: 8:35 a.m. | Updated The New York Timess Eric Dash has more on Citigroups earnings.

title: Citigroup Earns $2.2 Billion in Third Quarter
description: Two years after Citigroup became the symbol of all that went wrong in the financial system, its executives expressed confidence Monday that the bank would be healthy enough to start buying back shares or raise its dividend in 2012.

title: Obama Takes Science Push to Mythbusters
description: President Obama, following up on last falls White House astronomy night (above), is hosting a science fair at the White House today. Aides say he plans to honor students of all ages for pushing the boundaries of understanding of the world around us and announce that he has taped a segment for the popular show Mythbusters. Details will be posted later this morning on theWhite House science and technology page.At the tail end of this post, you can read some background issued by the press office overnight.

title: N.R.A. Starts Get-Out-the-Vote Effort
description: At this stage of a campaign year, the fight to get voters out to the polls joins at every level  in the air (that is, TV), on the ground (door-to-door canvassers), in cyberspace (e-mail, Twitter, text messages) and, yes, in old fashioned, but ever-reliable, mail boxes, which are about to start bursting with political pitches and attacks.

title: Michelin Guides Director Is Stepping Down
description: Jean-Luc Naret, the director of the Michelin guides since 2004, has announced that he will retire from that post at the end of the year. It looks like the New York Michelin Guide for 2011, which was published last week, then the San Francisco guide and the new Chicago guide will be his swan songs.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Persian Herb Frittata
description: This beautiful, verdant Persian-style frittata is made from a recipe that at first glance looks ridiculous. Its not the list of ingredients, which sound fresh and lovely with heaps of parsley, cilantro, scallions and lettuce. Neither is it the first three steps that involve simply chopping, whisking and cooking for 10 minutes.

title: Ritholtzs Questions for Mankiw
description: Greg Mankiws typically thought-provoking column in last weeks Times  in which he said he would work less if tax rates rose  spurred a lot of discussion. Barry Ritholtz, author of the Big Picture blog, is now out with a list of pointed questions for Professor Mankiw.

title: J.C. Penney Adopts Poison Pill

description: NEW HAVEN  In the first phase of the Cheshire triple-murder trial, which ended with his conviction two weeks ago, Steven J. Hayes was a shadowy figure to the jury, a man with little history who had confessed to unspeakable acts.

title: Alaska Race May Make for Long Election Night
description: Those of us hoping to get a good nights sleep on Nov. 2 might not be pleased with the latest developments in the Alaska Senate race, where polls suggest a drop in support for the Republican nominee, Joe Miller. That could enable either Lisa Murkowski  the incumbent who lost the Republican primary to Mr. Miller but is running a write-in campaign as an independent  or perhaps the Democrat Scott McAdams, to win the race instead.

description: Angelina Jolies directorial debut, a film about a love story between a Serbian man and a Bosnian woman on the verge of the 1992 Bosnian war, will be allowed to film in Sarajevo, The Associated Press reported.

title: Monday Reading: The Latest On Bedbug Disclosure

title: The Picasso Exhibit in Seattle Inspires Hotel Deals
description: Picasso: Masterpieces From the Muse National Picasso consists of roughly 150 paintings, drawings and sculptures from the Paris museum whose collection is drawn from the holdings of the artist himself. That museum is undergoing a three-year renovation and has sent many highlights globe-trotting. One of its stops is the Seattle Art Museum, which through Jan. 17 is displaying works ranging from Picassos early Blue Period to his late Cubist portraits.

title: Justices to Hear Appeal Over Liability for Detention
description: WASHINGTON  Abdullah al-Kidd, born in Kansas and once a star running back at the University of Idaho, spent 16 days in federal detention in three states in 2003, sometimes naked and sometimes shackled hand and foot.

description: MIAMI Californias big-ticket Republicans  Meg Whitman, the candidate for governor, and Carly Fiorina, the candidate for Senate  skipped a major rally with Sarah Palin last week, but Marco Rubio has different plans.

description: On a recent Sunday morning, Matt Lightner, the bespectacled 29-year-old chef of the heralded Castagna Restaurant in Portland, Ore., was hunched over a bed of salicornia at Netarts Bay on the Oregon Coast. Salicornia, also known as pickleweed, is a salty-tasting succulent that grows like a weed  wait, it is a weed!  in marshy, brackish areas.

description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously envisioned warning signs from the future.

description: OK, Im about to be unfair. But this article about how the Fed is gradually coming to realize that low inflation and a liquidity trap might be a problem fills me with despair.

title: Were Not China
description: In various comments and other places I keep seeing people compare European complaints about the weak dollar to American complaints about the undervalued renminbi. Its a false equivalence, which should be obvious if you think about the basics of the situation.

description: WASHINGTON

description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

description: When federal agents raided a home in central New Jersey on Wednesday, they discovered nothing short of a private armory, with pistols and rifles hidden throughout its 25-plus rooms. But they found something else  something, it would become clear later, that should give earthlings pause.

title: Chinese Promotion Puts Official on Track for Presidency
description: BEIJING  Xi Jinping, Chinas vice president, was named to an important military position on Monday, continuing his elevation to the top echelons of Chinas leadership and reconfirming that the Communist Party had selected him as the successor to President Hu Jintao.

description: Sometimes Kanye West gets what he wants and sometimes he doesnt: while a new film he has written and directed will soon make its television debut, the cover art he proposed for his new album will not be hitting stores any time soon. Well just have to assume hes O.K. with that.
