description: On Friday the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, made a case for further action from the Fed to try to grease the wheels of growth and combat high unemployment.

title: Sadly, the Scary Hits in N.F.L. Keep Coming
description: Today seems like a perfect day to stop and appreciate your job. For a moment, set aside everything that might stink about it and think: at least at no point today will the Steelers James Harrison or the Falcons Dunta Robinson launch himself full-speed and helmet-first at your head and threaten to turn your brain into something resembling Cream of Wheat.

title: Numberplay: The Puzzle Gourmet
description: Today and next week we have a couple of puzzles selected by a puzzle gourmet. They have a delicious and surprising quality that the very best puzzles  or dishes  have. Whats more, they are beautifully connected with puzzles recently presented on Numberplay. Therefore they belong to a rare category that Hollywood rarely masters: the perfect sequel or second course.

title: A Ceremonial Start for Moynihan Station
description: Gov. David A. Paterson is planning to swing a sledgehammer at a faux brick wall erected on Monday afternoon at the James A. Farley Post Office in a groundbreaking ceremony for Moynihan Station.

title: More on iPhones and Toddlers
description: Several of you have asked for a chance to weigh in on the article in the Styles section this weekend about toddlers and iPhones. It has become the most effective tool in human history to mollify a fussy toddler, writes Hillary Stout, much to the delight of parents reveling in their newfound freedom to have a conversation in a restaurant or roam the supermarket aisles in peace.

title: Keeping Score: How the Yankees Can Beat Cliff Lee
description: In July, the Yankees thought they had a deal to acquire a second bona fide ace behind C.C. Sabathia in Cliff Lee. Instead, the Mariners sent the southpaw to Texas. Now, Lee is not only not pitching for New York, but he will also face them in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series on Monday night. As dominant as Lee has been since 2008, he has been even tougher against the Yankees: between the regular season and the playoffs, he has compiled a 2.62 earned run average against them in 58 1/3 innings, compared with a 2.88 E.R.A. against all other opponents.

title: Facebook Acknowledges Privacy Issue With Applications
description: Facebook said on Monday that it was talking to application developers about how they handled some personal data, after a report said some applications had been improperly sharing the data with advertisers and Web tracking companies.

title: Pfizer Makes Move Into Biologic Drugs
description: Making a new move into the fledgling market for generic biotech drugs, pharmaceutical giant Pfizer has acquired worldwide rights to sell human insulin and insulin analogs being developed by Biocon, one of Indias largest biotech companies.

title: Mariinsky Takes Mahler to Russia
description: For generations now, a common argument goes, national styles of music making have been losing their distinctiveness to a global musical melting pot. International standards and tastes increasingly trump national heritage and culture.

title: Now Reading | The Finest Rooms
description: Thomas Jayne, the New York decorator, has always brought both a scholarly knowledge of design history and a quirky sense of the modern to his work, creating rooms that bridge the old and the new. And even though there is none of Jaynes own work in his new book, The Finest Rooms in America (The Monacelli Press), his sensibility is evident in his choice of what the books subtitle calls fifty influential interiors from the 18th century to the present. (Full disclosure: I am mentioned in the books acknowledgments, along with a number of other magazine editors, but was not involved in the book.) Any conversation with Jayne on the subject of decorating invariably touches on his passion for great interiors of the past, and indeed, nearly half the rooms in this book are historic, although Jayne includes 20th-century interiors  like the living room of Frank Lloyd Wrights Hollyhock House and that of Charles and Ray Eamess house  in this category, along with 18th-century spaces like the Tea Room at Monticello or the Large Dining Room at Mount Vernon. But seeing his broad-ranging eye at work is part of the pleasure of reading Jaynes book. His selection of contemporary rooms wont please every decorator  particularly given the books somewhat loaded title, an homage to the famous 1964 volume The Finest Rooms by Americas Great Decorators, which included interiors by now-departed greats like Rose Cumming, Sister Parish and Billy Baldwin  but it is as catholic as his tastes. So youll find the more-is-more drawing room of the jewelry designer Kenneth Jay Lane and Robert Couturiers classically inspired dining room sharing the books pages with an elegantly spare living room by David Kleinberg and an edgy studio by Christopher Coleman. While many of the rooms are fairly grand in scale and furnishings, it is one of the smallest that that makes your heart beat faster: Albert Hadleys Manhattan intimate sitting room, an object lesson in understated chic, which Jayne rightly saves for last.

title: Roadside Bomb Kills Baghdad Official
description: BAGHDAD  A roadside bomb during the Monday morning rush killed a member of Baghdads Provincial Council, the local governing body. The explosion, which wounded eight people, is the latest in a stream of small attacks aimed at the police and government officials.

title: Failures to Compute, or Web Behavior to Avoid
description: The week starts out with numerous reports of people acting in an official capacity  or aspiring to do so  fumbling, bumbling and stumbling into trouble via electronic communications.

title: The Claim: After Being Broken, Bones Can Become Even Stronger.
description: THE FACTS Just like muscle, human bone grows and strengthens under pressure, and weakens when barely put to use.

title: Jimmie Johnson Pads Nascar Sprint Cup Lead
description: As the Nascar Sprint Cup season winds down, it doesnt matter so much who wins or loses the individual races anymore. The series has turned into the Jimmie Johnson watch. And Johnson, who has won the last four Sprint Cup championships, continues to pull away from the rest of the pack. At Charlotte Motor Speedway in North Carolina on Saturday night, he finished third to push his overall lead in the series to 41 points.

title: The Battle to Recover From Lost Advances
description: Three years ago, Gary Barnett started writing checks to brokers who found him buyers for one of the glassy condominium towers he was building on the Upper East Side. The brokers cashed the checks, some in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, and paid taxes on them. Then they did what they wanted with the money: put it in savings accounts, paid off mortgages or simply spent it on what any person with spare cash would spend money on, like Christian Louboutins, French manicures, even frozen yogurt.

title: Questioning the Results of Medical Research
description: This week The Atlantic wonders if we should all be more skeptical of medical research. The magazine focuses on Dr. John Ioannidis, a Greek researcher who has spent his career challenging his peers by exposing their bad science.

title: The East Window
description: The filmmaker Jenny Carchman documents the installation of a new stained-glass window designed by Kiki Smith and Deborah Gans at the Museum at Eldridge Street.

title: The Long Road to New York
description: Simon Bairu, 27, will make his marathon debut in New York on Nov. 7. He won the 2005 and 06 N.C.A.A. cross-country titles at Wisconsin and holds the Canadian record for 10,000 meters at 27 minutes 23.63 seconds. He ran 1:02:08 in finishing fifth in the Philadelphia half-marathon in September.

title: Turkoglu Gets a Rough Reception in Toronto
description: Hedo Turkoglu probably figured he wouldnt be presented with a dozen roses and a hearty hug in his first return to Toronto since leaving the Raptors over the summer.

title: Liverpool Supporters Take Note  Advice From a Red Sox Fan
description: The sale of Liverpool F.C. to New England Sports Ventures, led by John Henry, represents a sort of harmonic convergence. Two waterfront cities, Boston and Liverpool, that share Irish connections, and two storied clubs, with all-time great stars, historic stadiums, rich traditions and huge payrolls are now linked through sport.

title: Scrambled Eggs: Not Just for Breakfast
description: Many of us think of scrambled eggs as breakfast fare, but to me they are the ultimate late-night post-theater supper. These perfect protein packages (each large egg has six grams of complete protein and just 71 calories) take minutes to prepare, and they always leave me feeling satisfied, never full.

title: What You Wouldnt Do if You Could Do It Again
description: Rare is the person who has made it through the past few years without looking back at least once and wishing he or she could have reversed at least one financial choice and received some money back. Perhaps it was the savings poured into foreign stocks, the Miami condo bought in 2006, or the meal at the four-star restaurant that ended in food poisoning.

title: What People Will Do for $5
description: It seems $5 is enough for some people to perform a lot of different services for others.

TimesCast | October 18, 2010

STOCKS PLUNGE 508 POINTS, A DROP OF 22.6%; 604 MILLION

description: Southampton, L.I., Sunday, Oct. 7--Charles Edward Merrill, a directing partner of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Beane, investment banking and brokerage firm, died at his home on Dune Road early last night. His age was 70.

title: Daimlers Car2go Sharing Program Continues to Expand
description: Car2go, Daimlers car-sharing operation in the United States and Germany, is growing rapidly, and now it includes a specially designed Smart. The company will announce expansion of the program to a major German city, Hamburg, next week, with new locations in North America following soon after.

description: Washington, Oct. 20--President Nixon, reacting angrily tonight to refusals to obey his orders, dismissed the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, abolished Mr. Cox's office, accepted the resignation of Elliot L. Richardson, the Attorney General, and discharged William D. Ruckelshaus, the Deputy Attorney General.

title: Dr. John Dewey Dead at 92; Philosopher a Noted Liberal
description: Dr. John Dewey, the philosopher from whose teachings has grown the school of progressive education and "learning by doing," died of pneumonia in his home, 1158 Fifth Avenue, at 7 o'clock last night. He was 92 years old.

title: Edison's Electric Light
description: There was no lack of enthusiasm or of confidence about Mr. Edison as he greeted the Times reporter who entered his laboratory at Menlo Park, N. J., yesterday. The inventor, a short, thick-set man, with grimy hands, led the way through his workshop, and willingly explained the distinctive features of what he and many others look upon as an apparatus which will soon cause gas-light to be a thing of the past. The lamp which Mr. Edison regards as a crowning triumph is a model of simplicity and economy. In the lamp the light is emitted by a horseshoe of carbonized paper about two and a half inches long and the width of a thread. This horseshoe is in a glass globe, from which the air has been as thoroughly exhausted as science is able to do. So good a vacuum is produced that it is estimated that at the utmost no more than a one-millionth part of the air remains. The operation of pumping lasts one hour and a quarter. At the ends of the carbon horseshoe are two platinum clamps, from which platinum wires run outwardly through a small glass tube contained within a larger one leading out of the glass globe. The small tube contains air. Within it the platinum wires are met by two copper wires connecting with the conductors of the electricity. The air is left in the small tube, because otherwise the copper wires would be fused by the electric current. The carbonized paper is capable of being made incandescent by a current of electricity, and while it allows the current to pass over it, its resistance to the heat is strong enough to prevent it from fusing.

title: Dizzy Gillespie, Who Sounded Some of Modern Jazz's Earliest Notes, Dies at 75
description: Dizzy Gillespie, the trumpet player whose role as a founding father of modern jazz made him a major figure in 20th-century American music and whose signature moon cheeks and bent trumpet made him one of the world's most instantly recognizable figures, died yesterday at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J.

title: Op-Ed: The Wars That America Forgot About
description: On The Timess Op-Ed page, Tom Brokaw, a special correspondent for NBC News, asks why the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are not featuring more prominently in the midterm election campaigns. An excerpt:

title: PRESIDENT GRAVE
description: Washington, Oct. 22--President Kennedy imposed a naval and air "quarantine" tonight on the shipment of offensive military equipment to Cuba.

title: Timothy Leary, Pied Piper Of Psychedelic 60's, Dies at 75
description: Timothy Leary, who effectively introduced many Americans to the psychedelic 1960's with the relentlessly quoted phrase, "turn on, tune in, drop out," died yesterday at his house in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 75.

Washington, Oct. 23 - President Reagan, voicing outrage over the ''despicable'' destruction of the Marine Corps headquarters in Lebanon, called on the nation today to be more determined than ever to keep a force in that country and resist ''the bestial nature of those who would assume power.''

title: John W. Heisman, Noted Coach, Dies
description: John William Heisman, all-around authority on athletics and former football coach, died yesterday in his home at 28 East Seventieth Street after a brief illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Hope Opera | Fabrizio Ferris Anima
description: Fabrizio Ferri is at it again. The renowned fashion photographer, architect, clothing designer and musician has composed an opera, Anima, which will be performed on Tuesday in Naples at the Teatro di San Carlo (Europes oldest opera house, dating from 1737). Ferri was initially contacted by Rosanna Purchia, the theaters newly appointed sovrintendente, to create evocative imagery for the coming seasons performances. For the theaters first ever promotional campaign Ferri shot dance students from the Teatros school in the volcanic surroundings of Mt. Vesuvius, above. Ferri, who had also been working for almost a decade writing, orchestrating and recording the score for a musical film, happened to play a selection of songs for Purchia, who convinced him to turn his film-to-be into an opera for the newly revived theater. Anima, which means soul, tells the story of North African immigrants who left their homelands behind for a better life in Europe. The music envelops the people like the sea, Ferrisays, sometimes soothing, like a mother or father, and sometimes angry and dangerous. An 80-person choir, a 50-person childrens choir and an 80-piece orchestra will be joined by some gifted friends of Ferri: the trumpeter Chris Botti, who also contributed recordings for the original score; Andrea Griminelli, a world-famous flautist; and Gil Goldstein, an orchestrator. (A surprise appearance by Sting, a longtime friend, is also anticipated.) Ferri credits the creation of this extraordinary event to Purchia and to the power of this theater, in a moment of crisis, to have the guts and strength to create the necessary energy so artists come to Naples to play this music, to raise their eyelids, to look ahead.

title: Coping With Economic Uncertainty
description: I started writing for this blog some 10 months ago  a time when just about everyone, including me, was trying to sort out what was going on in the economy. In the months since then, Ive shared many stories with you about how open-book management has helped propel SRC Holdings through at least three recessions and has set us up to take advantage of the recovery. Thats also why Ive written several times about our manufacturing facility in Lexington, Ky.  the plant we purchased not long before I started this blog. I chose to share the stories from Lexington because I thought it would help illustrate what happens when a traditionally run company opens its books.

title: Mistrial for Schizophrenic in Killing of Psychologist
description: A Manhattan judge declared a mistrial Monday in the case of David Tarloff, a schizophrenic man accused of hacking a psychologist to death in her Upper East Side office, after court-appointed doctors found him mentally unfit to stand trial.

title: Disease Branding
description: Hypingthe profile of a medical condition in order to sell its treatment.Writing for CNN, Carl Elliott compared the modern marketing of certain medicines with Edward Bernayss idea, in the 1920s, of selling pianos by popularizing the idea that sophisticates had music rooms:

title: Specific Media Acquires Online Video Company
description: In another sign of the growing role that online video is playing on Madison Avenue, BBE, a company that specializes in producing Web video clips and series for advertisers, has been acquired.

title: U.S. Sues Michigan Blue Cross Over Pricing
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department sued Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan on Monday, asserting that the company, the states dominant health insurer, had violated antitrust laws and secured a huge competitive advantage by forcing hospitals to charge higher prices to Blue Crosss rivals.

title: The Playoffs Through a Times Photographers Lens
description: While a batter who gets three hits in every 10 at-bats is considered to be a great success, James Estrin writes on the Lens blog, for a sports photographer covering a playoff or the World Series, getting a good shot three times out of 10 spells failure. He adds, Chang W. Lee, a staff photographer for The New York Times, aspires to a 1.000 average.

title: Now Reading | W.W.D. at 100
description: The truth is that Womens Wear Daily, at least in the beginning, was written for men. Not just any men, but important men in all departments of womens wear who are scattered everywhere over the earths surface and lose track of events and happenings. (Sounds like your typical fashionisto.) These words appeared in the first issue of Womens Wear (the Daily came later), from June 1910, in a mission statement titled Our Excuse for Being. The defensive pose actually makes some sense: its not easy to prove, as W.W.D. has, that you can write about an essentially frivolous enterprise without indulging in frivolity. This year marks the end of Patrick McCarthys reign over the newspaper but also its 100th anniversary. In celebration of that second, happier occasion, the paper has just unveiled W.W.D.: 100 Years | 100 Designers (Fairchild, $65), about its own history and the designers who have animated its pages for a century. The best part of the book are the reprints of old issues: sketches of Paul Poirets costumes for a Parisian revue; news of the D-Day landings competing for front-page space next to a report on handbag pricing; and a cover story on the 1999 John F. Kennedy Jr. plane crash that mourned as much for Carolyn Bessette  the former Calvin Klein saleswoman, style icon and fashion publicist  as for John Jr.

title: Canada Poised for 2011 Withdrawal From Afghanistan
description: OTTAWA  For decades, meetings between the leaders of Canada and the United States werent complete without some diplomatic chiding from the American side about Canadas limited military spending and its general lack of interest in military matters.

title: Fox Host Says He Misspoke About Muslims
description: A Fox News Channel host apologized on Monday for saying last week that not all Muslims are terrorists, but all terrorists are Muslim.

title: Does Michelle Obamas Wardrobe Move Markets?
description: Michelle Obama is a well-known trend-setter. But did you know that her fashion choices seem to move stock markets, too?

title: What Recent Deals May Say About M.&A.s Future
description: 3:28 p.m. | Updated Where is the market for mergers and acquisitions going? After a summer of prominent deal announcements and increased M.&A. activity, investment bankers are speculating that the market will grow 15 percent to 30 percent in the next year. Bankers tend to talk their book, but this time it looks like the market is likely to support a modest upswing, albeit one not as big as the bankers hope for.

title: Lake Mead Hits Record Low Level
description: Sometime between 11 and noon on Sunday, the water level in Lake Mead, the massive reservoir whose water fills the taps of millions of people across the Southwest, fell lower than it ever has since it was filled 75 years ago.

title: Now Play Freebird': Arizona Senate Candidate Sings His Stump Speech
description: Rodney Glassman, the Democrat who is running a long-shot campaign to unseat Senator John McCain of Arizona, lacks money, time and attention. But he does have his vocal chords and years of singing training. So why not sing his stump speech?

title: Ads Urge Fathers to Take Time to Be a Dad
description: A new series of public service ads, promoting greater involvement by fathers in their childrens lives and aimed at American-Indian, Asian-American and Hispanic fathers, will be introduced today by the Advertising Council.

title: Somali Government and Allies Attack Insurgents
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The struggling transitional government and its allies have undertaken a limited offensive against radical Islamist insurgents, attacking their positions in several places over the past few days, Somali officials and witnesses said Monday.

title: Bomb Plot Defendant Expresses Doubts
description: Mr. Cromitie talks to Shahed Hussain, the F.B.I informer who secretly recorded their conversations. Defense lawyers say that Mr. Hussain promised large sums of money to overcome Mr. Cromitie's doubts.

title: Change in Law Sharpens Ads
description: Nonprofit groups are now able to use corporate money to run ads explicitly urging votes for or against candidates. Previously, they had been mostly limited to so-called issue ads, which stopped short of directly calling for candidates to be elected or defeated. Some groups have aggressively taken advantage of this ruling (which could raise legal questions) while others have refrained. A look at ad spending from some of those groups and the portion spent on express advocacy.

title: Defendant Talks With F.B.I Informer
description: James Cromitie talks with Shahed Hussain, an F.B.I informer, about possible bombing targets. Prosecutors said the tape showed Mr. Cromitie was "pre-disposed" to commit a terrorist attack.

title: A Chess Player With a Swelled Head
description: Its not exactly a surprise that some chess players have big egos, but the guy who was recently photographed playing chess in Washington Square Park in Manhattan really had a swelled head. According to Brian Dube, the creator of New York Daily Photo, the blog on which the photo appeared, the player had only mediocre skills.

title: Now Showing | Mike Ballards Coat Tales
description: If you are like me, you could have avoided many of your life losses by keeping a more careful eye on your personal belongings. I still kick myself for my lack of vigilance over various wallets, an Ann Demeulemeester jacket, even my first purse, which I lost in a taxi at the age of 8.

title: Secrets of the Centenarians
description: What is it like to live till 100? Eight men and women, aged 99 to 103, speak about their century of life.

title: Marriage of The Daily Beast and Newsweek Is Not to Be
description: After weeks of talks between The Daily Beast and Newsweek about a partnership, and breathless speculation in the media  would they or wouldnt they  the union is not to be.

title: 100 Candles on Her Next Cake, and Three Rs to Get Her There
description: Esther Tuttle is nearing the end of the 10th decade of a remarkably productive and adventurous life. If all continues to go as well as it has to date, next July 1 she will join the rapidly growing clan of centenarians, whose numbers in the United States have increased to 96,548 in 2009 from 38,300 in 1990, according to the Census Bureau.

title: Living to 100 and Beyond
description: Want to know what its like to live to be 100? Be sure to check out our new multimedia feature Secrets of the Centenarians. Youll see pictures and listen to eight centenarians tell their stories of life in three digits.

title: BP Sale Raises $1.8 Billion to Help Pay for Gulf Spill
description: MOSCOW  BP raised $1.8 billion on Monday to help pay for the cost of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico by selling assets in Venezuela and Vietnam to its own joint venture in Russia.

title: 4 Convicted of Attempting to Blow Up 2 Synagogues
description: Four men were convicted on Monday on charges of planting what they believed were bombs outside synagogues in the Bronx and plotting to fire missiles at military planes.

title: Stone Power
description: Q. Ive heard that if a penny is dropped from the Empire State Building it could kill someone. But what about hail? Its often much larger and falls from much higher, so why do I never hear about any deaths caused by it?

title: Predicting the Vote: Analyzing Election Data
description: Overview | What do polling numbers and other statistics reveal about races for political office? How can we use data and quantitative tools to analyze and understand elections? In this lesson, students apply both quantitative and qualitative reasoning skills to profile a current election. Using polling and demographic data, they synthesize data, statistics and representations to investigate the mathematics of elections.

title: Introducing: American Speech
description: Schotts Vocab is delighted to be able to feature some gems from the archives ofAmerican Speech  one of the finest and most fascinating linguistic journals.

title: Freddys Pan Will Bang No More for Yankees
description: Freddy Schuman, who with one eye, one tooth and several old frying pans and spoons turned his love of the New York Yankees into a full-time occupation as the teams unofficial mascot, becoming one of the wackiest and unlikeliest cheerleaders of a baseball empire not known for wackiness, died Sunday afternoon at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: From Taft to Obama, Victrola to DVD: Secrets of the Centenarians
description: Centenarians alive today are older than the Titanic, crossword puzzles and Mickey Mouse. They have lived through 18 presidencies and two world wars. They saw the rise of motion pictures and radio, followed by the invention of television.

title: Angle Says Students Look Asian
description: Sharron Angle, the Republican candidate for Senate in Nevada, appears in a video to have offered a strange assessment of a group of Hispanic students at a meeting last week.

title: The Caucus
description: Carl P. Paladino and Andrew M. Cuomo are only two of the seven candidates running for New York governor.

title: What Were Reading
description: Too Many Hooks in the Water  National GeographicAn ominous study suggesting that a worldwide fisheries collapse may arrive sooner than expected, if fishing limitations arent established.  Glenn Collins

title: From Junk to Collectible, Shaped by Time and Tide
description: HYANNIS, Mass.  Laura McHenry started walking Cape Cod beaches searching for sea glass a few years ago, when her marriage was breaking up and she was looking for something she and her daughter Katie, could do together for fun.

title: Woody Allens Comma Collapse
description: Yes, this mostly has to do with movie titles, not books, but it is irresistible: Slates Copy-Editing the Culture columnist describes the rise and fall of Woody Allen, as seen through his use (and misuse) of punctuation.

title: Woody Allens Comma Collapse
description: Yes, this mostly has to do with movie titles, not books, but it is irresistible: Slates Copy-Editing the Culture columnist describes the rise and fall of Woody Allen, as seen through his use (and misuse) of punctuation.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the Philippines, Afghanistan and France.

title: Maybe You Shouldnt Invest Like Harvard
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.Correction: The original version of this sketch had the axes of the graph reversed.

title: 100 Years and Counting
description: In Tuesdays Science Times, columnist Jane E. Brody explores recent research on why some us live to ripe old ages.

title: Vision: A Quick High for Sex May Damage Vision
description: Users call them poppers: a class of chemicals called alkyl nitrites that can be inhaled for a quick high, or to enhance sexual pleasure. Now doctors in France are warning that they can also cause eye damage and impaired vision.

title: TimesCast: Race for N.Y. Governor
description: In the latest edition of TimesCast, The Timess Megan Liberman and Nicholas Confessore discuss the upcoming debate in the New York governors race.

title: Quote Unquote | Confidence, Man!
description: David Gandy describes how he has overcome his shyness towards the opposite sex. Um, Hi, I am a top model is probably a pretty good pick up line.

title: Aviation World at Odds Over Plane Loans
description: Back in the mid-1980s, Boeing and Airbus avoided a trade war by making a gentlemens agreement not to seek government financing to sell planes in each others home markets. The deal symbolized an aviation world dominated by the United States and Europe.

title: Pranksters Lampoon Chevron Ad Campaign
description: Updated at 3:50 p.m.

title: Critics' Picks: 'L'Avventura'
description: A. O. Scott looks at Michelangelo Antonioni's 1960 film about beauty, longing and emptiness.

title: L.I. Teenager Charged With Shooting Officer in Brooklyn
description: A Long Island teenager who the authorities say shot a police officer three times in a shootout in a Brooklyn row house on Sunday night has been charged with attempted murder of a police officer and criminal use of a weapon, the police said.

title: TimesCast: The Race for Governor
description: In the latest edition of TimesCast, Megan Liberman and Nicholas Confessore of The Times discuss Monday nights debate in the New York governors race.

title: Lexmark Introduces Slick Printer and Scanner
description: After the launch of the unprinterlike Envy 100 e-All-in-One from Hewlett-Packard, Lexmark has engineered its own slick all-in-one printer. The coming Lexmark Genesis is unmistakably a printer, albeit a handsome one, but it has impressive new technology under the hood: a digital camera that can scan documents and photos in a whizzy three seconds.

title: Is There an Effective Climate Narrative?
description: Keith Kloor, the journalist andCollide-a-Scape blogger, e-mailed me this morning asking if I agreed with his post noting an apparent narrative vacuum on energy and climate. He built his piece around a riff onthe need for serious research on geo-engineering by Dana Milbank at the Washington Post. I sent this reply (e-mail shorthand is cleaned up a bit):

title: Parody Trips Up Chevron Ad Campaign
description: A lampoon of Chevrons We agree advertising campaign seems to mock the ads emphasis on the oil companys community-mindedness, our friends at the Media Decoder blog report. Chevron is not amused.

title: The Phillies Optimal Lineup
description: ESPN.coms Rob Neyer recently wrote that by flip-flopping Plcido Polanco and Chase Utley in the second and third spots in the lineup, Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel had come up with the perfect lineup. Theres no doubt that the switch is a huge improvement.

title: What to Tell Children About God
description: Bruce Feiler ponders God for a living. After all, he has written four books on the subject. And yet, as he wrote in an essay in The Timess Styles section yesterday, he was thrown when his 5-year-old-daughter asked her first question:

title: Now Sparkling | Ralph Laurens Fine Jewelry
description: After two years of construction, Ralph Laurens 22,000-square-foot, four-story womens flagship is finally open, but the brightest sparkle perhaps comes from the 600-square-foot watch and fine jewelry salon on the ground floor. The simultaneous introduction of six fine jewelry collections exclusive to the store represents a new direction for the company, which plans to expand distribution next year in select markets. Standouts include the Equestrian stirrup pendants, the Signature Diamonds and Classic tennis bracelet and necklace, and a jaw-dropping Monogram necklace with akoya pearls and rose gold with diamond monogram (and a hefty $145,900 price tag to boot).

title: Building Ranks of Young  Voters, and Poll Workers
description: With two weeks left before Election Day, City University officials are hoping to mobilize New Yorkers who typically have been among the least likely people to vote: college-age young adults.

title: Mount Airy Lives On, But in Name Only
description: Anyone who watched late-night programming in the 1980s will be familiar with the Mount Airy Lodge. All you need to bring is your love for everything, went the jingle of one of the Pocono resorts famous commercials. After a heyday in the 60s and 70s, though, the resort had fallen into disrepair by the late 90s, and it finally closed in 2001.

title: Disney to Go It Alone With Superheroes
description: Paramounts deal to distribute Marvels superhero films will end two years early.

title: Lute Fanciers Meet 3 Stars From the Past
description: The lutenist Paul ODette has lately been fascinated by the music of Marco dallAquila, an Italian lutenist-composer who was born around 1480, worked mostly in Venice and died in 1544. Though he is barely known today, dallAquila had a stellar reputation in his lifetime. He was listed among the great musicians of his day in a 1519 poem by Filippo Oriolo, and nearly two decades later, another author, Francesco Marcolini, wrote rhapsodically of the sound produced by dallAquila and two lutenists who are more familiar now, Alberto Ripa da Mantova and Francesco da Milano.

title: DreamWorks Theatricals Plans a Touring Madagascar Show
description: DreamWorks Theatricals, which made its first attempt to transform a movie property into a Broadway show in 2008 with Shrek the Musical, is now teaming up with Broadway Across America for DreamWorkss first live family touring show based on its Madagascar film series, the two companies announced on Monday.

title: Prescription Drug Use Soared in Past Decade
description: If you are taking a prescription medicine and you are older than 60, it is probably a cholesterol-lowering drug. If you are 20 to 59, it is more likely to be an antidepressant.

title: Light and Color in an Undulating Cloud
description: In assuming the role of music director at the American Composers Orchestra, the conductor George Manahan inherits an institution whose stature and primacy are not what they were. A chamber orchestra in all but name, the ensemble has not fielded a full symphonic complement since 2007.

title: Top Canadian Commander Pleads Guilty to Murders
description: BELLEVILLE, Ontario  In April, Canadians reacted with shock after a top Canadian military commander, who frequently piloted planes for top political figures and dignitaries, including Queen Elizabeth II, was charged with rape, murder and an extensive campaign of perverse home break-ins.

title: On Our Radar: Nascar to Use Biofuel Blend
description: Starting next season, Nascar will use a 15 percent ethanol blend from Sunoco for its three national touring series. A Nascar executive says the use of American ethanol creates jobs in the United States, helps foster energy independence and continues the greening of our sport. [The Des Moines Register]

title: Video: A New East Window on Eldridge Street
description: Earlier this month the Museum at Eldridge Street unveiled a new stained-glass window designed by the artist Kiki Smith and the architect Deborah Gans for its 1887 synagogue, which re-opened in 2007 after a 20-year restoration. The filmmaker Jenny Carchman documented the installation of the window from start to finish for a short piece titled The East Window. Julie Bloom spoke to her about the film, watching Ms. Smith and Ms. Gans at work and the always-changing Lower East Side. Below is the finished film, along with edited excerpts from the interview.

title: Period Works, Played With Freewheeling Touches
description: The English Concerts performance at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening had plenty to recommend it, not least Rachel Podgers magnificent violin playing in a pair of Vivaldi Concertos, and intensely dramatic accounts of Monteverdi and Handel vocal works with the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote.

title: Bringing in Family to Combat Anorexia
description: At their first family therapy session, Rina Ranalli and her husband tried to coax their anorexic 13-year-old daughter to eat a bagel with cream cheese. What followed was a protracted negotiation.

title: The Night My Liver Started Running My Life
description: I first met my liver the night it tried to kill me.

title: Freddys Pan Will Bang No More for Yankees
description: Freddy Schuman, who with one eye, one tooth and several old frying pans and spoons turned his love of the New York Yankees into a full-time occupation as the teams unofficial mascot, becoming one of the wackiest and unlikeliest cheerleaders of a baseball empire not known for wackiness, died Sunday afternoon at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Pictures of the Day: Philippines and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the Philippines, Afghanistan and France.

title: Family Therapy for Eating Disorders
description: Parents often feel helpless in their efforts to cure a child of an eating disorder. Now new research shows a family-based therapy program may be the solution. The method, reports Roni Rabin in todays Science Times, is not only more effective than adolescent-focused individual therapy but keeps working even after the treatment ends.

title: Killings in Nigeria Are Linked to Islamic Sect
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  A rash of mysterious killings by gun-wielding motorcycle assassins of policemen, politicians and others in this city near the desert has led authorities to declare that a radical Islamic sect thought to have been crushed by Nigerian troops last year has been revived.

title: Yoko, Before Oh Yoko!  (and Other Origin Stories)
description: The art-world documentarian Chiara Clemente set her sights on seven creative personalities, whom she has profiled in miniature for Beginnings, a new film series debuting Tuesday at sundancechannel.com. All of the subjects  from Yoko Ono (the profile of her is embedded above) to the Blue Hill chef Dan Barber  hit the big time in New York, and in going back to their beginnings, Clemente reminds us that none of us  O.K., very few of us  fall off of the truck an instant star. Carmen de Lavallade returns to the 92nd Street Y, site of the 79-year-old dancers first performance in the city. The photographer Mario Sorrenti shows off his mothers art studio, where, as a young vandal, hed crash after long nights spent spraying graffiti. And the designer Carolina Herrera recalls her first meeting with Diana Vreeland, in which she explained her desire to go into fabric design. But how boring that is! Vreeland told her. Why dont you just do a little collection?

title: How to Push Past the Pain, as the Champions Do
description: My son, Stefan, was running in a half marathon in Philadelphia last month when he heard someone coming up behind him, breathing hard.

title: Harrahs Files Plan to Sell Shares
description: Harrahs Entertainment, the biggest casino operator in the world, disclosed on Monday that it planned to sell some $575 million worth of shares in an initial public offering.

title: Gov. Christie Expresses Concern Over Cable Dispute
description: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie weighed in Monday on the increasingly bitter cable television dispute that prevented three million homes in New Jersey and New York from seeing both the Giants football game and the second game of the National League baseball playoffs on Sunday.

title: The Sting of Salt Air, Old Loves and Honey Bees
description: Matthew Zapruders new book of poems is called Come On All You Ghosts, a title that could be slapped on almost any collection of poetry. Many of our finest poems are infested with ghosts  just ask Edgar Allan Poe or Emily Dickinson.

title: Critics Picks Video: LAvventura
description: How can people who have so much feel so empty and so lost? A. O. Scott poses that question with this weeks Critics Pick, LAvventura. Directed by Michelangelo Antonioni, the film follows a group of wealthy young Romans on a day trip to a volcanic island. During the trip, one of the women vanishes, but the films characters seem to pay her disappearance little concern. The film was booed at Cannes when it had its premiere there 50 years ago, yet was also awarded a prize by the jury. It has been debated among cinephiles ever since. Have you seen LAvventura? Please share your thoughts.

title: Pushing Past Pain to Improve Performance
description: How do elite athletes find the motivation to push past the pain and take their bodies to the limit? Thats an issue explored in todays entertaining Personal Best column by Gina Kolata. She writes:

title: Largest Bank Will Resume Foreclosure Push in 23 States
description: Bank of America announced on Monday that it would resume home foreclosures in nearly two dozen states, despite the running controversy over how banks handled tens of thousands of cases of homeowners facing eviction.

title: Sanctions Are Ending For Museum
description: When the National Academy Museum sold two important Hudson River School paintings in 2008 to pay its bills, the Association of Art Museum Directors came down hard with sanctions, making the academy a pariah in the museum world and a symbol for the evils of deaccessioning.

title: Complaint Box Recap: Meetings, and Those Who Hate Them
description: Its a pain known to almost every person who has ever held a job: the intense boredom of a useless meeting.

title: A Superstar Puts One of His Early Influences Back in the Spotlight
description: Early last year Leon Russell was at his home outside Nashville when his telephone rang. It was Elton John, calling from a safari vacation somewhere in Africa.

title: A Look at Lees Walks, the Intentional Ones
description: My article in Mondays Times about Cliff Lee and his remarkable control had plenty of minutiae, but I was not able to get into something intriguing. Two of Lees 18 walks this season were intentional.

title: Underwater Homes, Then vs. Now
description: Why the housing market is still a mess, in two maps:

title: Reliving Schuberts Classic Tussle With Death
description: Many composers, Stravinsky notably among them, have been inspired by earlier styles and works, which they weave through a contemporary prism. Daniel Kellogg is a current example, reimagining the scores of others in his works.

title: Two Minutes For Booking: Sports Illustrateds The Hockey Book
description: Michael Farber had to laugh. Sports Illustrateds lead hockey writer, who is likely the most erudite of the all those chronicling the game today, had just seen an ad for Sports Illustrateds new large-format The Hockey Book, which listed some of the best-known contributors. The ad listed Farber above the Nobel Prize winning author William Faulkner, whose 1955 Sports Illustrated essay An Innocent At Rinkside is included in the book.

title: South Africa: Condoms Star in a Sex Film With a Message
description: With three goals in mind  to score a political point, to convey a safe-sex message and to make money  a South African producer has made that nations first all-black pornographic movie.

title: Questioning the Guilt of an Executed Father
description: Frontline begins its 29th season in a relatively low-key manner. Rather than hot-button topics like the election season, the economy or the financial prospects of the Chilean miners, it looks at the 2004 execution of a Texas man convicted of killing his three children by setting fire to his home.

title: Sales and Profit Surge for Apple, but Its Margins Slip
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Strong sales of iPads, iPhones and even Mac computers produced record revenue and profit for Apple in its fourth quarter.

title: In Mad Men, She Would Have Been Peggy
description: Before she co-founded the National Womens Political Caucus, before she wrote How to Make It in a Mans World, and before she had three children, Letty Cottin Pogrebin was Peggy.

title: Google Car Home GPS App Gets Upgrade
description: With new improvements to a phone app called Car Home, Google is enticing drivers to say, Goodbye Garmin, uh-uh, TomTom, and get lost, Magellan.

title: Bank of America Plans to Resume Foreclosures
description: Curtailing a moratorium sooner than expected, Bank of America announced Monday that it would resume foreclosures by next week in 23 states where court approval was needed to go ahead, The New York Times reports.

title: I.B.M. Posts 12% Rise in Profit
description: I.B.M. said Monday its third-quarter profit rose by 12 percent as its revenue increased modestly, adding to the evidence that corporate customers are beginning to spend again on computer technology.

title: Healthy Jets and Happy Ryan Head Into Bye Week
description: Jets Coach Rex Ryan said Monday that he sent his team off into its bye week with hearty congratulations for its 5-1 start, which he said accomplished most of the team goals for the first part of the season. But I think this team can improve in a lot of areas, and that is whats so exciting, Ryan said.

title: Michelle Obama and Stock Market Fashion
description: In the Economix blog, our colleague Catherine Rampell writes that Michelle Obamas public fashion choices can boost the stock price of the companies making her clothes: That is the conclusion of an analysis by David Yermack, of the Stern School of Business at New York University, published by The Harvard Business Review. Ms. Obama wears an outfit, and in (oftentimes correct) anticipation that her get-up will become the latest New Thing, the company that makes those clothes gets a healthy boost in its stock price.

title: N.F.L. May Suspend Players for Harsh Hits
description: The N.F.L. will probably impose harsh penalties this week, possibly suspensions, on players involved in damaging hits to the head that left several with concussions and neck injuries on Sunday, Ray Anderson, the leagues executive vice president for football operations, said Monday.

title: Indie Scenes Uncomplicated Side
description: A couple of months ago Cults took the stage at the Knitting Factory as if theyd stepped out of a particularly smoky van in the mid-1960s. Their hair was long and stringy. The singer Madeline Follin wore a flowy, shapeless black Elvira dress and did a lot of swaying. She looked a little stern  mad, even  but enchanting. Cults are essentially a two-member band  Ms. Follin and Brian Oblivion, who sings and plays guitar  though during this show they swelled to six, making for a sound far bigger than the group needs. What it needs is basic: the singing of Ms. Follin, seductive and sweet; the chipper xylophone countermelodies that run through many of its songs; and strutting bass lines that recall the swing of 50 years ago. There are other parts to the bands songs, of which there are currently just a few, but in a short period of time Cults have refined their style, gotten it down cold, made it elegant.

title: Can a Good Stock Market Help Democrats?
description: The midterm election season has featured a very strong stock market. Since the end of June, the Standard & Poors 500-stock index is up 14.9 percent.

title: Proposed Law Could Limit Interstate Wine Shipping
description: SEATTLE

title: At Tate Modern, Seeds of Discontent by the Ton
description: LONDON  Last Wednesday I had a close encounter with Sunflower Seeds, the Chinese artist Ai Weiweis oceanic new installation piece in the cavernous Turbine Hall at the Tate Modern here. The work consists of roughly 100 million hand-painted porcelain sunflower seeds covering a vast expanse of floor to the depth of about four inches, and visitors were invited to wade right in. The black-and-white seeds crunched delightfully underfoot, and the whole thing resembled an indoor pebble beach, with people strolling about and then plunking down to sit or recline. One young man had buried himself.

title: Alderson Coming Back to Finish First Interview
description: Sandy Alderson was scheduled to return to Citi Field on Thursday to complete the first round of his interview process for the Mets vacant general manager position, but the team said the meeting was not part of the second round of interviews, in which select candidates will meet with Fred Wilpon, the principal owner, and Saul Katz, the team president.

title: Artifacts | Fair Trade-Off: Frieze Week in London
description: When Frieze week in London ended yesterday, a collector from New York asked what I liked best about the art fair. There were many reasons to like being there this year, but what stood out in my mind were two exhibitions I saw outside the fair. The Serpentine Gallery hit it out of the park (Hyde Park, that is) with its Klara Liden retrospective, the most affecting show I saw in five days of nonstop art viewing. The other great experience was Christian Marclays new 24-hour video, The Clock, at White Cube in Mayfair.

title: A Solid-State Drive for the Road
description: Combine the advances in capacity for solid-state drives with the increases in data transfer speed afforded by the new U.S.B. 3.0 platform, and the result looks something like Iomegas black slab.

title: More for The Event, Outsourced and Law & Order: L.A.
description: NBC has stepped up to back three of its new programs with full-season orders.

title: Robin Williams May Play Bengal Tiger on Broadway
description: Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, an Iraq War play by Rajiv Joseph that had an acclaimed production in Los Angeles, may come to Broadway in the spring with Robin Williams in the title role.

title: In Studying Haiti, a New Angle on an Earthquakes Intensity
description: When the magnitude 7.0 earthquake struck the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince, last January, the enormous destruction and loss of life were attributed largely to two factors: the proximity of the city to the fault that caused the shaking, and shoddy construction that allowed thousands of buildings to easily crumble.

title: Waking in the Clouds to a Chorus of Birds
description: Friday, Oct. 15

title: You Can Photograph That Federal Building
description: The right of photographers to stand in a public place and take pictures of federal buildings has been upheld by a legal settlement reached in New York.

title: Tackling the Last of Beethovens Sonatas
description: The character of many of Beethovens 32 piano sonatas can be evoked by titles like Tempest and Appassionata or by their witty, brilliant or jovial elements. But the final three sonatas, composed when he was completely deaf, resist easy categorizations.

title: News Editor Detained by Security Guards for Alaska Senate Candidate
description: 6:06 p.m. | Updated The tumultuous Alaska Senate race thrust itself into the national spotlight again over the weekend, when private security guards hired by Joe Miller, the Republican nominee, handcuffed and detained the editor of an online news site at a campaign event in Anchorage on Sunday.

title: Booker Prize Winners Jewish Question
description: LONDON  A funny thing happened when Howard Jacobson won the Man Booker Prize last Tuesday. Instead of the traditional audience reaction  euphoria from the winners entourage, anemic clapping underpinned by envy and bitterness from everyone else  the announcement, over dinner at the Guildhall here, was greeted by loud, sustained applause. A smattering of people who were not even related to Mr. Jacobson stood and cheered.

title: Not So Sudden Aspen Decline
description: Researchers say that sudden aspen decline, or SAD, appears to have stabilized.

title: Freud on Madison Avenue, Where Biology Appears as Destiny
description: Sunday nights season finale of Mad Men was so full of the unexpectedly bizarre that it seemed to belong to the world of dreams. Did Don Draper, the emotionally disabled advertising executive, actually cast aside his age-appropriate psychologist girlfriend, Faye Miller, and impulsively ask Megan, his beautiful young secretary of the easy manner and French Canadian heritage, to marry him? If you are a certain kind of Mad Men obsessive, like many readers posting comments on nytimes.com, you lost a good deal of your Monday evaluating this question.

title: Killer of Aspen Slows, but Worries About a Beloved Tree Remain
description: GUNNISON, Colo.  Aspen trees, with their quivering, delicate foliage and the warm glow of color they spread across the high country of the Rocky Mountains this time of year, have an emotional appeal that their stolid, prickly evergreen cousins do not.

title: A.L.C.S.: Game 3 Preview
description: Jay Schreiber, assistant sports editor of The Times previews Game 3 of the A.L.C.S. match-up between Cliff Lee and Andy Pettitte.

title: Ray Ozzie, Cloud Advocate, Floats Away From Microsoft
description: 4:16 p.m. | Updated  Added more details about Mr. Ozzies exit.

title: The Caucus Click: Reno, Nev.
The Eternal Question: Football or Baseball?
description: Viewers largely favored football on Sunday over the baseball playoffs on Fox, choosing to watch NBCs coverage of the Indianapolis Colts and Washington Redskins game. Although final ratings were not expected to be available until Tuesday, Nielsens preliminary overnight estimates for Sunday Night Football were up compared with the same night a year ago, when 18.2 million viewers tuned in. Fox, in third place, earned what appeared to be an average audience closer to 8 million for its coverage of Game 2 of baseballs National League Championship Series between the San Francisco Giants and the Philadelphia Phillies. Fox got a boost in the 7 p.m. hour from an overrun of its afternoon football broadcast. CBS was second on the night behind NBC, garnering 12.9 million viewers at 7 for 60 Minutes and 12.2 million at 9 for Undercover Boss. ABC was fourth.

title: Dexter Watch: Warring Impulses
description: Dexter has always been a series that gains more and more momentum as the season progresses, and this one is no exception. Sundays episode set off a psychologically intriguing battle between Dexter and the tortured young woman whom Fowler had been holding captive. It is a wise move on the writers part because it puts Dexters warring impulses of ruthlessness and protectionism in direct, high relief. He wants to save and take care of this bloodied young woman, but of course he cant just let her out the door and off to Miami General because she has witnessed him murdering her tormentor. He is forced to treat her like one of his victims, injecting her with sedatives and locking her up.

title: Seatmate, the Problem Wasnt the Tequila ...
description: I PROBABLY have one of the worlds most enjoyable jobs. I travel around the country talking about tequila.

title: A U.S.B. Charging Adapter for the iPad
description: If you have a lot of gadgets, you probably have to use a U.S.B. hub to keep all your devices plugged in. The problem is that some devices either wont wont charge on a hub.

title: Live-Blogging the Debate for Governor
description: Good evening, loyal readers, and welcome to one of the most anticipated moments of political theater in recent New York history. Seven  count em, seven!  candidates for governor of New York are set to meet face-to-face on Monday at Hofstra University on Long Island for the first and only scheduled debate of this years race for governor, and the potential for shock, revelation and self-immolation are high.

title: Signs That Business Jets Are Poised for a Comeback
description: ATLANTA

description: To the Editor:

title: More Trouble With Tylenol
description: The troubled McNeil Consumer Healthcare unit of Johnson & Johnson said on Monday evening that it was voluntarily recalling nearly 128,000 bottles of Tylenol eight-hour caplets.
