description: To the Editor:

title: Newton the Polymath (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Northeast in $4.3 Billion Stock Deal for NStar
description: 6:59 p.m. | Updated By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and THOMAS KAPLAN

title: Many Views on Recovery; Shared Hate for Glocal
description: HERE is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights from the 100th anniversary conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which a record 1,600 people attended from Wednesday through Saturday in Orlando, Fla.

title: Hotels Take Locally Grown a Logical Step Beyond
description: David Garcelon, a chef, says he enjoys checking on the little alpine strawberries, Malabar spinach, mojito mint and several varieties of wine grapes in his small garden. But he is not out in his backyard; hes on the 14th-floor roof of the Fairmont Royal York in Toronto, where the view is of the steel, glass and concrete of nearby skyscrapers.

title: Times in Deal to Expand Texas Report
description: The New York Times announced Monday that it had entered into another local news collaboration, this one with The Texas Tribune, a nonprofit news organization.

title:
Melvin Lane Powers Is Dead at 68;
Cleared of Murder With Lover-Aunt
description: Candy and Mel. She, the stylishly coifed Houston socialite with the little-girl voice. He, her nephew, half her age and movie-star handsome. In the mid-1960s, Candace Mossler and Melvin Lane Powers may have been the nations most notorious couple.

title: Agents Deported by U.S. Are Honored in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Russian sleeper agents, arrested in the United States this summer and deported to Russia as part of a prisoner exchange, received top government honors from President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Monday.

title: Mildred Jefferson, 84, Anti-Abortion Activist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Mildred Jefferson, a prominent, outspoken opponent of abortion and the first black woman to graduate from Harvard Medical School, died Friday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 84.

title: Obama in an Unusual California Ad
description: This is the political equivalent of a man bites dog story.

title: Citigroup and Terra Firma Clash at Trial
description: When the British financier Guy Hands, pictured, was devising plans to buy the EMI Group in 2007, he and his firm, Terra Firma, gave the deal the secret code name Project Dice.

title: Patricia Herzog, 88, a Lawyer Who Changed Marital Law, Dies
description: It was an advertisement on a matchbook cover that inspired Patricia Herzogs legal career and, eventually, led to a significant change in California marital law  allowing one divorcing spouse to be reimbursed for having helped the other obtain an advanced degree.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,416 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,329 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Some Sand in the Gears of Securitizing
description: Was the great securitization machine that made hundreds of billions of dollars in mortgage loans based on a legal foundation of sand?

title: Even More On The Origins of the Deficit
description: Ive thought of another way to present the data on GDP, spending by all levels of government, and taxes. Lets look at trends in GDP, spending, and revenues over two periods  one designed to capture normal growth, the other the economic crisis.

title: The Homeowner Wins, Without a Lawyer
description: In a column on Tuesday, I discuss legal arguments regarding whether MERS  Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems  has violated state real estate laws, and note a couple of cases where rulings have gone against it.

title: The Homeowner Wins, Without a Lawyer
description: In a column on Tuesday, I discuss legal arguments regarding whether MERS  Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems  has violated state real estate laws, and note a couple of cases where rulings have gone against it.

title: Newsweek and Daily Beast End Deal Talks
description: Is one media company big enough for Barry Diller, Tina Brown and Sidney Harman?

title: H&R Block May Not Provide Loans
description: H&R Block, the tax-preparation firm, said Monday it might not be able to provide refund loans next year because of a dispute with HSBC Holdings.

title: Rivals Not the Only Ones Delighted to See the Nets
description: NEWARK  Take a sports team with the worst record and worst attendance in its league. Move it to a new town with a rough reputation. Make it clear in advance that the franchise will stay just a couple of years before relocating again.

title: Defendant Unfit For Trial In Killing of Psychologist
description: The trial of a 42-year-old man charged with hacking to death an Upper East Side psychologist ended Monday before it had even started when a judge declared a mistrial because two court-appointed psychiatrists found the man mentally unfit to stand trial.

title: A Spray of DNA to Keep the Robbers Away
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands  When the McDonalds down from City Hall here was burglarized a few years ago, its managers decided they needed a new security system.

title: The Campaign: Into the Homestretch
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Call Him Bernanke-sama
description: Mark Thoma points us to a paper by Mary Daly of the San Francisco Fed, which contains this remarkable chart of core inflation in two episodes:

title: The Hitler Exhibit in Berlin: Facing Up to the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Citis Good News Proves Reassuring
description: Vikram Pandit, chief executive of Citigroup, has snatched some of Jamie Dimons market momentum. Mr. Dimon, who runs JPMorgan Chase, has lately been setting a comforting tone for the sectors earnings. But growing foreclosure-related fears overshadowed his banks latest decent results. Now, his counterpart at Citigroup seems to be the one reassuring investors.

title: Advising President Karzai
description: To the Editor:

title: Reuters Writer Resigns Over Ethics Policy Breach
description: Reuters Breakingviews, the financial news and analysis Web site, disclosed on Monday that one journalist had resigned and two others were under internal review after failing to disclose financial interests in companies they covered.

title: Lessons in a Life Well Lived
description: If you are fortunate enough to live to 92, you are also unfortunate enough to have few people left from your formative years. Funerals for people in their 90s tend to be sparsely attended affairs, with but a sprinkling of contemporaries and maybe some friends of the children and grandchildren on hand for moral support.

title: N.F.L. Agrees to Help Ex-Players Who Have A.L.S.
description: The N.F.L. and the players union announced Monday that they would expand qualifications for the 88 Plan, which since 2007 has assisted former players with medical expenses related to dementia, to include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrigs disease.

title: Seau Is Injured in Crash Only Hours After Arrest
description: The former N.F.L. star linebacker Junior Seau crashed his sport utility vehicle down a steep slope early Monday near Carlsbad, Calif., sustaining minor injuries less than nine hours after he was arrested on suspicion of domestic violence.

title: Sacrifice, for Fiscal Sanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisis of the Humanities  II
description: The outpouring of passionate, learned and thoughtful comments in response to my column about the demise of French, Italian, Russian, classics and theater at SUNY Albany is a testimony to the hold the idea of the humanities has on so many in our society. The respondents make a number of points, but two are made repeatedly: (1) The humanities not only pay for themselves but help fund the sciences and (2) I dismiss traditional justifications of the humanities  the transmission of the best that has been thought and said, the humanities enhance society, and so on; you could recite them in your sleep  but I myself either have nothing to offer or end by offering a weak version of what I have dismissed.

title: Rethinking School Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Favres Time in the League Begins to Feel Borrowed
description: Brett Favre was not clutching his elbow when he was frantically waving that the Dallas Cowboys loopy end-of-game lateral fest should not count. That was progress. How much longer Favre will be smiling and celebrating, though, is a question that may be answered this week.

title: Jobs Says Apples Approach Is Better Than Googles
description: On Monday, I wrote an article about the competition between the iPhone from Apple and smartphones running the Android operating system from Google. The article discussed some of the advantages and disadvantages of Apples vertically integrated and closed approach and Androids more open strategy. It concluded by quoting experts and analysts saying that while Android, and perhaps other systems, are likely to do well, Apple has little reason to worry.

title: Rutgers Players Road to Recovery Has Been Walked
description: When Adam Taliaferro sustained a career-ending spinal cord injury while playing for Penn State in 2000, doctors feared he would not walk again. A year later, he led the Nittany Lions onto the field, jogging in short bursts out of the tunnel.

title: In Kansas, Climate Skeptics Embrace Cleaner Energy
description: SALINA, Kan.  Residents of this deeply conservative city do not put much stock in scientific predictions of climate change.

title: Pooling Resources, Two Newsrooms Merge
description: The nonprofit investigative journalism world continues to expand with the announcement on Tuesday that the Center for Public Integrity will absorb the Huffington Post Investigative Fund, a nonprofit journalism arm of The Huffington Post. The move would bring the total headcount at the center to more than 50 employees, making it one of the largest nonprofit investigative newsrooms in the country.

title: John Force Out to Prove Drag Racers Can Win After 60
description: MOHNTON, Pa.  It was late, and John Force was working out after spending most of the day traveling from California to Pennsylvania for yet another National Hot Rod Association event. In the old days, he would have found another spot at the hotel to relax.

title: Slugger Who Just Wont Stop
description: WOODSIDE, Calif.  Willie McCovey is not bothered by the people who are already writing the Giants obituary in the wake of their 6-1 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies in Game 2 of the National League Championship Series. Instead, three decades after retiring as one of the Giants most beloved players, McCovey continues to set an example on how to quell the doubters.

title: Facebook Vows to Fix a Flaw in Data Privacy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When you sign up for Facebook, you enter into a bargain. You share personal information with the site, and Facebook agrees to obey your wishes when it comes to who can see what you post.

title: Negotiations Fall Apart for Telecom Deal in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  When the American company NII Holdings agreed in February to join forces with the giant media company Grupo Televisa to invest in the wireless communications market in Mexico, the partnership appeared to have the financial and political strength to shake up the Mexican mobile market.

title: Health Care and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
description: Welcome to Fixes.

title: Paamco Founders Statement on Judges Ruling
description: The hedge-fund investment firm Pacific Alternative Asset Management Company has long portrayed itself as being owned and run by women. But S. Donald Sussman, a financier who has stood behind the firm for years, has challenged that assertion, claiming in a lawsuit that he was due a 40 percent ownership stake. A federal judge ruled in his favor in August and said the firms arrangement with Mr. Sussman may have been designed to mislead. Here is an e-mailed statement from the firms parent company, Paamco Founders, taking issue with some conclusions made by the judge in his ruling.

title: A Hedge Fund Controlled by Women, So It Claimed
description: Jane Buchan is a rarity in the big-money boys club of hedge funds.

title: From Obama, the Tax Cut Nobody Heard Of
description: HUNTERSVILLE, N.C.  What if a president cut Americans income taxes by $116 billion and nobody noticed?

title: Democrats Are at Odds on Relevance of Keynes
description: WASHINGTON  A rift has emerged within the Democratic Party between liberal economists, who generally view the 2009 stimulus package as a success and say that Keynesian economics should remain the heart of the partys economic policy, and elected officials, who in growing numbers have shunned affiliation with the $787 billion effort and are expressing doubts about the effectiveness of fiscal intervention.

title: I.B.M. Rides Global Focus on Services to Deliver a 12% Increase in Profit
description: The leading high-technology industrial companies like Intel, General Electric and I.B.M., which have reported quarterly results in the last several days, are seen by analysts and economists as bellwethers of the economy, because their chips, equipment and services are used in so many industries.

title: Zambia: Two Chinese Managers Arrested in Mine Shooting
description: Two Chinese citizens  managers at a Chinese-owned Collum Mine  were arrested on Monday and accused of shooting 12 miners who were protesting wages and working conditions at the mine, about 200 miles south of Lusaka, the capital, on Friday. A district commissioner said the managers were charged with attempted murder, according to Agence France-Presse. Two miners were transferred to a hospital.

title: Israel: Benjamin Netanyahu Warns of Risks to Aircraft Flying Near Gaza
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Monday that Israeli aircraft had a tough time flying near Gaza because there are antiaircraft missiles there. His first public comments about the missiles came in a speech to Likud Party lawmakers about the need for appropriate security arrangements as part of any peace deal with the Palestinians. Without them, he said, aircraft at Israels international airport near Tel Aviv could be at risk. Israeli officials have pointed for some time to what they say is a buildup of advanced weapons, including antiaircraft missiles, in Gaza, which is governed by the militant group Hamas.

title: Germany: After Merkels Comments,president Makes Trip to Turkey
description: On the heels of Chancellor Angela Merkels comments about the failure of multiculturalism in Germany, President Christian Wulff traveled to Ankara, Turkey, on Monday for the first official visit in 10 years by a German president. Mr. Wulff, left  who has a history of reaching out to Germanys four million Muslims, most of whom are Turkish  will address Turkeys Parliament, where he is expected to focus on economic, cultural and religious issues. He also will visit Islamic sites and will hold talks with the Turkish official in charge of religious affairs. On Saturday, Mrs. Merkel told the annual meeting of young Christian Democrats that multiculturalism in Germany had utterly failed.

title: Democrats Remain Favored to Retain Senate
description: With only 15 days to go until the election, were going to be upping the frequency of our forecast updates somewhat.

title: Half-Dozen N.Y. Races May Help G.O.P. Win House
description: RYE BROOK, N.Y.  New York has turned into a major battleground over the future of the House of Representatives, with Democrats forced to defend at least a half-dozen Congressional seats from unexpectedly strong Republican challenges.

title: Many Questions on Killing of Pace Student by Police
description: It was the homecoming game, and a reunion of sorts for two childhood friends on the opposing teams. Danroy Henry Jr. was a junior defensive back for the home team, Pace University, in Pleasantville, N.Y. Everyone called him D.J.

title: Campaign Offers Help to Gay Youths
description: Middle school was the worst, Calvin Stowell says in a YouTube video he uploaded on Oct. 1.

title: James E. Fuchs, Innovator in the Shot-Put, Dies at 82
description: James E. Fuchs, who developed a new way to heave the shot to compensate for a leg injury and used the technique to set world records and dominate shot-putting over two remarkable seasons, died in Manhattan on Oct. 8. He was 82.

title: Familiar Debate: Use an Ace on Short Rest Or a Besieged Starter
description: On the eve of a pressure-packed Game 4, the manager of the Yankees again answered questions about his beleaguered starter. He trusted him enough to give him the ball for a critical postseason start. No matter how poorly he had pitched, the manager was not changing his mind: Kenny Rogers was going to start.

title: Meeting Pakistanis, U.S. Will Try to Fix Relations
description: WASHINGTON  As Pakistani civilian and military leaders arrive here this week for high-level meetings, the Obama administration will begin trying to mend a relationship badly damaged by the American militarys tough new stance in the region.

title: Sorkin: Felix Rohatyn Looks Back, and Sighs
description: In his DealBook column, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes about a conversation with Felix Rohatyn, the veteran investment banker who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s, advised RJR Nabisco on its sale to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in the 1980s and sold Columbia Pictures to Sony in the 1990s.

title: To Lower Violence, Escalate the Penalty
description: The violence in the N.F.L. continues. Week after week, season after season, we see debilitating injuries from crushing tackles and brain-rattling hits.

title: As Yankees Grit Teeth, A Ranger Just Smiles
description: Those tracking the angst over whether A. J. Burnett should start Game 4 of the American League Championship Series for the Yankees may be surprised to learn that there is another starting pitcher in the game.

title: Freddy Sez, the Yankees Pan-Banging Mascot, Dies at 85
description: Freddy Schuman, who with one eye, one tooth and several old frying pans and spoons turned his love of the New York Yankees into a full-time occupation as the teams unofficial mascot, becoming one of the wackiest and unlikeliest cheerleaders of a baseball empire not known for wackiness, died Sunday afternoon at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: Lottery Numbers
Officials Push to Bolster Law on Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON  Law enforcement and counterterrorism officials, citing lapses in compliance with surveillance orders, are pushing to overhaul a federal law that requires phone and broadband carriers to ensure that their networks can be wiretapped, federal officials say.

title: Californias Crystal Cathedral Files for Bankruptcy
description: Crystal Cathedral, the landmark megachurch in Orange County, Calif., where the Hour of Power is taped, filed for bankruptcy protection, church officials announced Monday.

title: Ruling on Health Law Is Due by End of Year
description: RICHMOND, Va.  A federal judge said Monday that he would rule by the end of the year on the constitutionality of the new health care law, as lawyers for the Obama administration and the Commonwealth of Virginia debated whether the entire 2,700-page act should be invalidated if a key provision is struck down.

title: Religion Moves to Forefront in Kentucky
description: Its fair to say things are getting increasingly hot in Kentuckys Senate contest.

title: Angles Edge in War Chest Evaporates
description: Sharron Angle, the Tea Party-backed candidate hoping to take down Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, shocked many in the political world last week when she announced she had raised a remarkable $14 million during the third quarter.

title: OReilly Embraces Role, Because It Puts Her on Field
description: At one time, Heather OReilly was the goal-scoring ingnue of the United States womens soccer program.

title: Tuesday: Crossword Face-Off
description: Weve got a double dose of Fred Piscop today  his Tuesday puzzle and another used for a contest with the New York Islanders (below).

title: Building a Clean-Energy Movement in the Heartland
description: Global warming has few believers in a deeply conservative region of Kansas, so a nonprofit group avoided the issue and instead invoked patriotism, thrift, job creation and religion to persuade residents to save energy.

title: Phillies in No Rush to Discuss Short Rest
description: SAN FRANCISCO  All through the Yankees postseason run, fans have fretted over A. J. Burnett, and whether he would actually make a start. For the Philadelphia Phillies, the right-hander Joe Blanton plays the part of Burnett. He may start Game 4 on Wednesday, or he may not.

title: Checking the Statements in the Debate
description: With seven candidates crammed on a stage, the format for the debate on Monday night among those running for governor of New York was hardly ideal for the kind of thrusting and parrying on issues that is usually the hallmark of such encounters. Still, there were enough moments in the 90-minute debate for Carl P. Paladino, the Republican nominee, and Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee, to make many claims  including some that were either exaggerations or deserving of additional explanation.

title: Binghamton Avoids Major Sanctions
description: Binghamton University acknowledged Monday that its mens basketball program had made mistakes but said that the N.C.A.A.s investigation had been closed with no major violations found.

title: Albany Governor Debate Verges on Farce
description: The moderators questions were frequently ignored. The candidates barely looked at one another. One wore black gloves and spoke of himself repeatedly in the third person. And Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic candidate and the races front-runner, at times struggled to suppress laughter.

title: Time to Talk to the Taliban
description: SPECULATION is growing both inside and outside Afghanistan that the government in Kabul is about to open reconciliation talks with the Taliban. Indeed, Taliban leaders, however hesitantly, are beginning to look at alternatives to fighting. They no doubt realize that a military victory is as remote and as hard to define for them as it appears to be for President Hamid Karzai and his NATO allies.

title: Good News and Bad for St. Johns
description: The long-term future of the St. Johns program received a glimmer of hope Monday, but the immediate future of this years team took a dark turn. The Red Storm got its fourth commitment from a top-100 recruit when Dom Pointer, a forward from Michigan, chose St. Johns.

title: Poll Shows Big Leads for Gillibrand and Schumer
description: Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand holds a significant lead over her Republican opponent, Joseph J. DioGuardi, in New Yorks United States Senate race, according to a New York Times poll.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: U.S. Agrees to Uphold Right to Photograph Near Its Buildings
description: It is O.K. to take photos while standing in public spaces near federal buildings, after all. In a settlement with the New York Civil Liberties Union reached Monday, the federal government agreed to instruct its employees in writing of the publics general right to photograph the exterior of federal courthouses from publicly accessible spaces and to remind them that there are currently no general security regulations prohibiting exterior photography by individuals from publicly accessible spaces, absent a written local rule, regulation or order.

title: Dont Follow the Money
description: Over the past few months, theres been a torrent of commentary about political donations and campaign spending. This lavish coverage is based on the premise that campaign spending has an important influence on elections.

title: China Plans to Reduce Its Exports of Minerals
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government plans a further reduction, of up to 30 percent, next year in its quotas for exports of rare earth minerals, in an attempt to conserve dwindling reserves of the materials, the official newspaper China Daily said Tuesday.

title: Bike Riders in New York Win Settlement
description: The city agreed on Monday to pay nearly $1 million to participants in the monthly Critical Mass bicycle rides who claimed they had been wrongly detained and arrested by police officers.

title: That Sinking Feeling
description: Barack Obama seems to think hes done a pretty terrific job as president, but maybe he hasnt trumpeted his accomplishments effectively enough.

title: A.L.C.S. Game 3 Final: Rangers 8, Yankees 0
description: For the Yankees Monday night, Andy Pettitte was great and the bullpen was dreadful. But the way Cliff Lee pitched for the Rangers, it probably didnt matter that the Yankees bullpen imploded by giving up six runs in the ninth inning.

title: Microsofts Top Software Architect, a Cloud Computing Advocate, Quits
description: Ray Ozzie, Microsofts resident software visionary, plans to leave the company.

title: Tough Road for Tea Party in Democratic Delaware
description: NEWARK, Del.  An unexpected win by a Tea Party candidate here has given Democrats hope of winning a seat that Republicans were once confident they could count in their column.

title: Links to Obama at Play in Race in Illinois
description: WINNETKA, Ill.  When Dan Seals, a Democratic candidate for Congress, attended an event for President Obama in Chicago a few months ago, someone suggested that if he stepped into the cordoned-off streets, the crowd might mistake him for the president.

title: Newcomers Money and Ads Grab Attention in California
description: RANCHO CORDOVA, Calif.  A year ago, Representative Dan Lungren said he had no idea who Dr. Ami Bera was, and he is pretty certain some of his constituents in Californias Third District are still confused.

title: Democrats Grip on the South Continues to Slip
description: JONESBORO, Ark.  The Southern white Democrat, long on the endangered list, is at risk of being pushed one step closer to extinction.

title: The Courts Pre-emption Test
description: In the Supreme Court last week, oral arguments in a case called Bruesewitz v. Wyeth turned on the meaning of the word unavoidable, but the real issue was something much bigger. The case is about whether the family of a girl, who they said was badly injured by a vaccine, can sue the manufacturer in a state court. Or are they barred by a 24-year-old federal law that blocks this sort of lawsuit if the injury or death resulted from side effects that were unavoidable?

title: Tribune Is Said to Seek Chiefs Resignation
description: The board of directors of the Tribune Company is expected to ask Tuesday for the resignation of Randy Michaels, the controversial chief executive of the company, according to a person directly involved in the matter.

title: France, the Unions and Fiscal Reality
description: France has been rocked by strikes and protest marches over President Nicolas Sarkozys plans to raise the legal retirement age from 60 to 62. Social Security reform is a difficult issue everywhere, and the brash and increasingly unpopular Mr. Sarkozy has not made much of an effort to woo union support. Yet raising Frances retirement age is an urgent necessity.

title: Since Big Branch
description: Nine American miners have been killed in eight little-noted accidents since April, when an explosion in rural West Virginia left 29 dead. Lawmakers, claiming to be scandalized by the failures in safety enforcement, vowed sweeping reforms. Thats all theyve done.

title: Hickory Rain
description: Its well before light, and Im listening to the rain, watching every now and then the flicker of headlights coming down the hill. I no longer have custody of Ethel the border terrier, so Im up early on my own.

title: The Southern Democrat
description: From Virginia to Florida and South Carolina to Texas, nearly two dozen Democratic seats are susceptible to a potential Republican surge in Congressional races on Election Day.

title: Yankees Put Up a Big Number, but Put It in the Wrong Column
description: The most startling moment of Cliff Lees masterful and unprecedented performance in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series happened in the fourth inning. Lee, who had retired the games first 11 batters, walked Mark Teixeira on a full count  his first walk in 20 postseason innings this season.

title: Against Lee, Yankees Swing and Miss, Again
description: In a detailed look at Cliff Lees regular season, a few numbers jump out. The seven complete games. Eighteen walks. A full workload of 212 1/3 innings. So does this nugget: He gave up eight runs to light-hitting San Diego, and eight more in a start against Baltimore.

title: With Gift, Harvard to Study Institutional Corruption
description: In this age of great corporate scandals, business schools have understandably ratcheted up their focus on corporate ethics in recent years. But what about when people generally follow the rules  and bad things still happen?

title: Word of the Day | nutrient
description: nutrient \n-tre-nt, ny-\ noun

title: California: Judge Signals Shell Let Ruling on Military Policy Stand
description: A federal district judge in California said Monday that she is inclined to deny the governments request to allow the Pentagon to enforce its dont ask, dont tell policy on gay and bisexual members of the military while her injunction against it is being appealed. My tentative ruling is to deny the application for a stay, Judge Virginia A. Phillips said at a hearing on the governments request, according to Reuters. She is expected to issue a ruling to that effect on Tuesday. The Obama administration has defended the law, arguing that change should come from Congress, not the courts; last week the Department of Justice gave notice that if the request for a stay was denied or not resolved by Monday at noon, it intended to appeal to the Ninth Circuit to allow the orderly litigation of the stay request before that court.

title: A.L.C.S. Game 3 Replay, Oct. 18
description: A look at Game 3 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium.

title: Nevada: Lake Mead Dips to a Low
description: The water level in Lake Mead, the massive reservoir that fills the taps of millions of people across the Southwest, has reached a record low, the federal Bureau of Reclamation says. Even as thunderstorms dropped rain on the Las Vegas area, Lake Meads level dropped to 1,083.18 feet above sea level just before noon on Sunday, and fell farther, to 1,083.09 feet, by Monday morning. Lake Mead is still eight feet above the level at which rationing could go into effect in Nevada and Arizona, and well above the levels at which Hoover Dams hydroelectric output might be seriously jeopardized. But Barry Nelson, a senior policy analyst for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said: This strikes me as such an amazing moment. Its three-quarters of a century since they filled it, and at the three-quarter-century mark, the world has changed.

title: Bloggingheads: Christians & Gay Suicide
description: Emily Bazelon, left, of Slate and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate the sources of recent suicides by gay teens.

title: At the Mayo Clinic: The Orthopedist and Hockey Parent
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.Dr. Michael J. Stuart, one of the organizers of this weeks conference on head injuries at the Mayo Clinic (the Ice Hockey Summit: Action on Concussion, the conference is officially called) has impeccable credentials to be among those in charge of such an important gathering of medical researchers and hockey officials. He is a professor of orthopedics and co-director of sports medicine at the Mayo Clinic, as well as chief medical officer of USA Hockey and team doctor for the 2010 mens Olympic team.

title: Test Yourself | English, Oct. 19, 2010
description: Test your grammar skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article Arizona Is a Haven for Refugees.

title: News Quiz | October 19, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: On Post-Marathon Monday, Please, Just Say Congratulations
description: Jim Axelrod, a national correspondent at CBS News, previously served as chief White House correspondent. His first book, In the Long Run, a memoir about the New York City Marathon, will be published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux in June 2011.

title: How Cliff Lees Start Compares in Postseason History
description: After Cliff Lee silenced the Yankees in an eight-inning, 13-strikeout masterpiece Monday night, Curtis Granderson was asked whether he had ever been part of a better-pitched game. Nothing specific came to mind, but Granderson said a few other performances trumped Lees. Maybe so, but lets take a look at just how dominant Lee was on Monday. With the help of Baseball-reference.com, I tried putting Lees outing in context in postseason history.

description: Jane Buchan is a rarity in the big-money boys club of hedge funds, Julie Creswell reports in The New York Times.

description: BP has raised $1.8 billion to help pay for the cost of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico by selling assets in Venezuela and Vietnam to its own joint venture in Russia, Andrew E. Kramer reports in The New York Times.

title: Amid Strikes, French Leader Vows Order
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy vowed Tuesday to guarantee order, restore fuel supplies and crack down on troublemakers, as a quarter of Frances gas stations ran dry and other disruptions built from nationwide protests and strikes.

description: While walking my dog a few mornings ago, I came across an old friend who has a freshman in college. Our brief encounter went like this:

description: MOSCOW  Heavily armed gunmen burst into the Parliament building of Chechnya, in southern Russia, on Tuesday morning, killing at least three people and wounding more than a dozen before the assailants were killed by police officers or by their own explosives, officials said.

description: Todays word, in association with the treasured Oxford English Dictionary, is

description: When the American company NII Holdings agreed in February to join forces with the giant media company Grupo Televisa to invest in the wireless communications market in Mexico, the partnership appeared to have the financial and political strength to shake up the Mexican mobile market.

description: Lehman Brothers Holdings says it has paid more than $1 billion to its lawyers, consultants and financial advisers since filing the largest United States bankruptcy two years ago, Reuters reports.

title: White House Science Fair
description: To answer todays questions, read the first two paragraphs of this Dot Earth blog post, then scroll all the way down to the list of student science projects under the heading Exhibits at the White House Science Fair.

title: Ivanhoe Mines Offering May Raise Tensions With Rio Tinto
description: Ivanhoe Mines has said it is starting a rights offering worth up to $1 billion, to raise money for its Oyu Tolgoi copper-gold project in Mongolia, but the plan may well escalate hostilities between the company and its partner, Rio Tinto, Reuters reports.

description: The board of directors of the Tribune Company is expected to ask Tuesday for the resignation of Randy Michaels, the controversial chief executive of the company, David Carr and Tim Arango of The New York Times reported, citing a person directly involved in the matter.

title: Hong Kong and Europe Discuss Hedge Fund Rules
description: Hong Kongs government is in talks with the European Union to help hedge fund managers in the city cope with proposed regulations that may make it harder to raise assets in Europe, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Santander Sells 5% Brazil Stake to Qatar
description: Banco Santander, the biggest Spanish bank, has agreed to sell a $2.7 billion stake in its Brazilian arm to Qatar Holding, the government sovereign wealth fund, adding to its capital reserves and opening the door to further partnerships with the emirate.

title: Luck and Aggressive Pricing Aid A.I.G.s AIA Offering
description: AIA has had an uncertain time of late, but now American International Groups attempt to sell the highly prized unit appear to have succeeded wonderfully, The Wall Street Journal reports.
