title: Rattner Says Underwriters Feel Good About G.M. Offering
description: The former head of the Obama administrations auto task force has said that investment bankers underwriting General Motors expected initial public offering are optimistic about G.M.s future as a public company, The Associated Press reported.

title: Do You Support or Oppose the Death Penalty?
description: A trial in which a man was convicted in a triple murder case has just entered the penalty phase. Jurors are deliberating between two sentences: life in prison without parole and and the death penalty. Do you support or oppose the use of the death penalty? Why?

title: CME Group Begins Clearing Interest Rate Swaps
description: The CME Group has begun providing clearing to the $400 trillion market for interest rate swaps, the largest of the opaque markets for which lawmakers are requiring more transparency.

title: Venture Capitalists Set Sights on Hollywood
description: Silicon Valley financiers got the Hollywood treatment in Social Network, the new film about Facebook, but the courtship between the technology and entertainment hubs has heated up with venture capital deal values in Los Angeles nearly doubling this year, Reuters reports.

title: Buffett Increasing Stake in Munich Re
description: It is a vote of confidence most companies can only dream of. Munich Re, the German reinsurance company, said on Tuesday that Warren E. Buffetts stake in the company had surpassed 10 percent.

title: A Better Way to Fix the Foreclosure Process
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: Reviewing Penalties in Jets-Broncos Game
description: Whether your perspective is shaded green or orange, the game-changing pass-interference penalty on Denvers Renaldo Hill at the end of the Jets 24-20 victory on Sunday seemed clear. As the Jets Santonio Holmes reached for the pass from Mark Sanchez, Hill tugged at Holmess facemask as the ball arrived. (The replay is above.)

title: Where to Find an Autumn Seafood Special in Hong Kong
description: Its autumn in Hong Kong, and that means peak season for a quintessentially Chinese delicacy: the hairy crab. As fall arrives, the crabs plump up, and restaurants stock them in huge numbers. Those cooking at home can buy live crabs, the little bundles bound up with bamboo strips, from specialty stores and even street vendors.

title: Investors Cautious on Enel Green Power I.P.O.
description: Investors say the initial public offering of Enels green power business would be attractive as a long-term investment only if priced at the lower end of the range, Reuters reported.

title: Morgan Stanley Said Near Approval to Sell C.I.C.C. Stake
description: Morgan Stanley has obtained regulatory approval for its planned sale of a 34.3 percent stake in the China International Capital Corporation, Chinese state media reported on Tuesday, according to Reuters.

title: A Wild and Crazy Sprint to Election Day
description: Full-blown political mania has seized the country just two weeks before an election that seems certain to dramatically reshape both the agenda and the personalities in the nations capital.

title: Candover Expected to Drop Parques Reunidos Sale
description: Candover is close to canceling its plans to sell or make an offering of Parques Reunidos, the Spanish theme-park operator, after a string of disappointing bids from rival private equity firms, The Financial Times reported.

title: Former Goldman Trader Said to Raise $1 Billion
description: Pierre-Henri Flamand, the former London-based head of Goldman Sachss principal strategies group, has raised more than $1 billion in capital and commitments for his new hedge fund, Edoma Capital, MarketWatch reported, citing a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: Seven Steps to Managing Your Online Reputation
description: A camera-store salesman recently steered me away from the compact, ultrahigh-tech camera I thought I wanted. Smaller is fine, he told me, but only if it fits in your pocket  any bigger will end up hanging from your shoulder anyway, so whats the advantage? And dont buy based on fancy features, he added; the differences between comparable models rarely result in better pictures for amateurs. The one feature youll really appreciate, he said, is how the camera feels in your hand.

title: Private Equity Group Starts Fund in Iraq
description: MerchantBridge, a global private equity group, has started an equity fund in Iraq and plans to close a deal in Saudi Arabia worth up to $100 million in early 2011, its chief operating officer has said.

title: Blacks Leisure of Britain in Takeover Talks
description: Blacks Leisure, the British outdoor goods retailer, said on Tuesday that it was in takeover talks  reportedly with two or more private equity firms  and its shares climbed more than 25 percent.

title: Bank of America Reports $7.3 Billion Loss, Citing Charges
description: Bank of America, the nations biggest bank, announced Tuesday that operating profit rebounded in the third quarter, helped by improved credit conditions among consumers and businesses.

title: For Goldman, a Problem of Trust?
description: Goldman Sachs, it appears, may have a slight trust problem.

title: BofA Posts $7.3 Billion Loss on One-Time Charge
description: 7:35 a.m. | Updated The New York Timess Nelson D. Schwartz has more on Bank of Americas third-quarter earnings.

title: China Fund Said to Plan Office in Hong Kong
description: The China Investment Corporation is opening a Hong Kong office, the funds first ever business operation outside of mainland China, Reuters reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Following Angelo R. Mozilos settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, David Weidner wrote for MarketWatch that regulators can look back on a decade where the biggest crook they outed and put behind bars was Martha Stewart.

title: Where Do You Draw the Line on Head Hunting in the N.F.L.?
description: Before the 2009 season, the N.F.L. put in new rules to protect defenseless receivers from head shots, then they expanded protections before this season. (Not that it guaranteed anything, given the hits by Brandon Meriweather on Todd Heap, Dunta Robinson on DeSean Jackson and James Harrison on Mohamed Massaquoi during Week 6.)

title: Tea Parties, Independents and Conservative Reform
description: In yesterdays column, I suggested that the Tea Party message in its anti-spending, anti-deficit form, at least, rather than its repeal the 17th amendment manifestation has a stronger resonance with swing voters and independents that some of the other, bygone irruptions of right-wing populism (the Liberty League, the John Birchers, etc.) to which the Tea Partiers are frequently compared. David Frum took issue with this argument, citing Jonathan Rauchs recent piece on the changing composition of independent voters to argue that many of the independents tilting Republican this election cycle are really just right-wing voters who were disillusioned with the G.O.P., rather than the kind of middle-of-the-roaders that the party needs to rebuild a durable majority. Heres Frum, summarizing Rauch:

title: New York Times Co. Posts $4.3 Million Loss
description: The New York Times Company on Tuesday reported a $4.3 million net loss for the third quarter as advertising and circulation revenue declined, and charges at The Boston Globe weighed on the bottom line. That result, which translates into a loss of about 3 cents a share, was an improvement from the period a year ago, when losses were 25 cents a share.

title: A Cheaper Route to Solar Cells
description: A company that secured a Department of Energy grant to pursue a breakthrough idea in the manufacture of solar cells plans to announce on Tuesday that it has raised $20 million to commercialize its technique, which it says will reduce the price of solar panels by 40 percent.

title: Parallel Problems
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Parallel Problems
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: The Next Great Schism: Faith of Cartoon Character Is Debated
description: Nobody tell the Reverend Lovejoy, but Homer Simpson, the patriarch of the animated clan on Foxs The Simpsons, is Catholic  at least, according to the official newspaper of the Vatican, Reuters reported. In an essay published over the weekend in the newspaper, LOsservatore Romano, Luca M. Possati writes: Few people know it, and he does everything to hide it. But its true: Homer J. Simpson is Catholic. As proof the essay cites a Jesuit priests study of the 2005 Simpsons episode The Father, the Son and the Holy Guest Star, in which Bart attends a Catholic school and Homer tries out the practice of confession. The study concludes that The Simpsons is among the few TV programs for kids in which Christian faith, religion and questions about God are recurrent themes. (Never mind that Homer has said he is a follower of that religion with all the well-meaning rules that dont work out in real life, which he explains to mean Christianity.)

title: Bring Your Questions on the Foreclosure Crisis
description: 12:10 p.m., Oct. 21 | Updated  Mr. Lawlers responses to reader questions are posted here and here.

title: James Cameron on Avatar, Titanic, Cleopatra and the Future of 3-D
description: Nearly a year after his movie Avatar broke box-office records and opened up a floodgate of big-budget 3-D features, James Cameron is still very much immersed in his budding science-fiction franchise and the medium of 3-D filmmaking. On Nov. 16 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment will release a special extended collectors edition of Avatar on DVD and Blu-ray, including a longer cut of the film and nearly an hour of deleted scenes, among other bonus features.

title: Shares End Sharply Lower on Wall Street
description: Stocks fell sharply on Wall Street on Tuesday and the dollar rose after a surprise interest rate increase by Chinas central bank suggested that growth in the worlds second largest economy after the United States could slow.

title: Video of Chechnya Attack Aftermath
description: As my colleague Michael Schwirtz reports, a deadly attack on the Chechen Parliament in Grozny on Tuesday showed that the capital city of a region where separatist rebels have been quelled is still not entirely safe for local authorities loyal to Russia.

title: Strikes Force Travelers to Weave a Tangled Web Through Paris
description: PARIS  International travelers passing through Paris faced disruptions on Tuesday because of strikes by public transport workers and air traffic controllers. But airlines said they were striving to maintain most, if not all, of their international flights to and from the French capital.

title: Outsiders Steal Show at Debate
description: What were reading about this morning.

title: Traffic Stopping | Freeway Eyewear
description: Sunglasses are symbolic of life in Los Angeles, says the California native and first-time eyewear designer Alex Israel. His collection, aptly called Freeway, includes five styles named after Route 1, Interstate 15, and the 10, 110 and 405 freeways. Each model was designed to literally represent the landscape, Israel says. Like, the 405 freeway covers territory from San Diego to Brentwood; the shape of the frame is a classic Kurt Cobain meets Jackie Kennedy. I envision the glasses on San Diego punk kids and Brentwood moms. If you cant beat the traffic, stop it. Grab a pair of modestly cool sunglasses from Freeway out of the glove compartment and have all eyes on you.Freeway Eyewear is available at Gagosian Shop, Barneys and Maxfield.

title: Tough Transit in Paris
description: Business travelers and tourists moving through Paris are used to the occasional and unexpected work stoppage interfering with their visits. But todays demonstrations and strikes are especially widespread, affecting all kinds of transportation in the city  and even tourists on foot, who might encounter police barricades and marchers blocking their path to well-known sights. Nicola Clark at The International Herald Tribune in Paris is keeping an eye on French travel activity.

title: The Early Word: 14 Days to Go
description: With two weeks left until Election Day, where are Democrats on the defensive as Republicans make a push to take over the House?

title: China Raises Rates
description: As if to illustrate my point about the non-equivalence of the United States and China: China raises interest rates.

title: Night Watch: New Yorks Debate
description: The Web was ablaze Monday night with reactions to the New York gubernatorial debate, which was alternately called a seven-ring circus and an SNL parody waiting to happen.

title: Treasury to Sell More Citigroup Shares
description: The great government clearance sale of financial stocks continues.

title: American Speech: Hotel Slang (1939)
description: by William Stewart Cornyn

title: All Is Not Lost for Texans, or  Cowboys
The Ultimate Formula One Slot-Car Track
description: Subsumed by the Nascar juggernaut, Formula One barely registers on the radar of most American motorsport fans, lending wheel-to-open-wheel racing a dose of underground cachet. It is so underground, in fact, that one Michigan man channeled his love of Formula One into a veritable basement fight club.

title: Musical Chairs: Morgan Eyes Goldmans Old Building
description: In its quest to consolidate its Manhattan office space, could Morgan Stanley choose its archrivals old headquarters?

title: Horrors! Adrien Brody Sues to Stop Release of Dario Argento Film
description: He didnt stand in the way of The Village or Predators, but Adrien Brody doesnt want anyone to see a new horror movie he stars in and which is slated to be released Tuesday on DVD. Mr. Brody, the Academy Award-winning star of The Pianist, has filed suit against the makers of Giallo, an Italian horror movie directed by Dario Argento, whose past films include Suspiria, The Hollywood Reporter said.

title: Tuesday Reading: The Latest on the Foreclosure Crisis
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Rooney Latest United Star to Split With Ferguson
description: In 2004, Wayne Rooney made his Manchester United debut against a Turkish team at Old Trafford in the Champions League and scored a scintillating hat trick, an audacious sign of things to come. Now, six years later, Rooney will sit out the teams Champions League group match against another Turkish team, Bursaspor, on Wednesday, and said he wants to leave the club where he has starred for six seasons.

title: Monserrate Indicted on Federal Corruption Charges
description: Former State Senator Hiram Monserrate, who was expelled from office earlier this year and whose conduct was held up as an example of Albanys dysfunction, was indicted on Tuesday on federal charges that accuse him of using workers at a Queens nonprofit group he financed to aid in his Senate campaign.

title: Jeter Vaguely Recalls Yanks Coming Back Before
description: In their glorious run in the past generation, the Yankees have come back from crushing losses and jolting injuries, but rarely have they suffered both on the same night.

title: Moktada, Moktada, Moktada
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs parliament has met for only 17 minutes since national elections in March, but that doesnt mean changes arent afoot in the great hall of government.

title: Asked & Answered | Leong Leong
description: The first collaborative project by the architects Chris and Dominic Leongs was a tree fort with their father in the backyard of their childhood home. Nowadays, using slightly more advanced forms of sticks and stones, the brothers behind the New York-based design firm Leong Leong are doing projects with the likes of Opening Ceremony and Phillip Lim.

title: Ariel Sharon Is Subject of Sculpture in Israeli Exhibition
description: A life-size sculpture of Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli prime minister who suffered a debilitating stroke in 2006, will be put on display in a gallery in Tel Aviv, BBC News reported. The sculpture, by the Israeli artist Noam Braslavsky, depicts Mr. Sharon in a hospital bed with his eyes open and his chest rising up and down as the work appears to breathe. Mr. Sharon, who never regained consciousness after his stroke, remains hospitalized in Tel Aviv.

title: A Ghost Town in China
description: In Ordos, China, there is just one thing largely missing in the citys new and extravagant central district: people.

title: A Gray Market in Real Estate
description: ORDOS, China  As the real estate action in Kangbashi New Area reached a fevered pitch last year, banks that are controlled by the national government, concerned about overbuilding, began restricting loans to property developers here.

title: Chinese City Has Many Buildings, but Few People
description: ORDOS, China  By many measures, this resource-rich city in northern China is a fabulous success.

title: Caregiving Without Siblings
description: In some ways, Regina Milgram-Bossong acknowledges, she has it easy. Her parents live nearby in central New Jersey. Despite the usual run of late-life health problems  her father, 84, is diabetic and has had a hip replacement; her mother survived ovarian cancer and last year underwent heart valve surgery  theyre still managing well in the house where Ms. Milgram-Bossong grew up.

title: After Sweat Lodge Deaths, Fewer Tourists With Spiritual Needs
description: SEDONA, Ariz.  There is negative energy in the air here, which the channelers, mystics, healers, psychics and other New Age practitioners of Sedona are grappling to identify and snuff out. It has to do with the recent dearth of visitors to this spiritual oasis in search of enlightenment.

title: What Were Reading
description: Video: Starbucks of the Future  USA TodayStarbucks, in its evolve-or-die mode, is targeting dinner. Actual food on actual china. Cheeses. Cured meats. Beer. Wine. (Everything roasted to within an inch of its life?)  Glenn Collins

title: At the Mayo Clinic: The N.H.L. vs. the N.F.L.
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.  For those who follow hockey closely but not the National Football League, the news that the N.F.L. is considering suspensions after a series of severely injurious helmet-to-helmet hits is astonishing  and highlights the comparatively progressive stance of the N.H.L. in its longstanding policy of levying suspensions for dangerous plays. The three-game suspension of Shane Doan of Phoenix, handed down Monday, for his egregious sideswipe of Anaheims Dan Sexton is an example of the N.H.L.s policy in practice  in particular its new rule against blindside hits to the head, for which this suspension is the stiffest so far:

title: China Raises Rates, Jolting World Markets
description: BEIJING  A surprise announcement by Chinas central bank that it would raise interest rates for the first time in nearly three years jolted world financial markets Tuesday, as investors worried that China, the worlds second-largest economy after the United States, could slow and crimp the global recovery.

title: A Question of Appearances: Obama Will Bypass Sikh Temple on Visit to India
description: NEW DELHI  The Golden Temple, a sprawling and serene complex of gleaming gold and polished marble that is the spiritual center of the Sikh religion, is one of Indias most popular tourist attractions. Revered by Indians of all faiths, it is a cherished emblem of Indias religious diversity. So it was no surprise when the gold-plated marvel was promoted as the likely third stop on President Obamas visit to India, scheduled for early November.

title: Hearing the Voice of a 51-Year-Old Man in the Essay of a 17-Year-Old Girl
description: When I worked in admissions at Duke, I said a lot of things on the recruiting trail that werent exactly genuine: Your combined SAT scores are in triple digits? Apply! We cant get enough kids from northern New Jersey! Apply! You got a bunch of Cs in high school  at least you got a B in weight-lifting! Apply!

title: At the Mayo Clinic: N.H.L. Concussions, Blow by Blow
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.  Some remarkable statistics were presented in Tuesdays morning session of the Mayo Clinic conference on concussion in hockey.

title: Preparing Kids for the Unknown
description: There are many reasons not to start the push toward college before your child is even in preschool. You know most of them, but heres one you might not have thought of: There is no point in pushing children, because by the time todays toddlers turn 18, college  along with the book-based world for which college prepares you  will be an obsolete relic.

title: Saudi Prince Convicted of Murder in London
description: Updated | 2:17 p.m. On Tuesday, a court in London found a 34-year-old Saudi prince guilty of murdering a man he described as his servant in a luxury hotel there in February, the BBC reports.

title: On Our Radar: A Super Typhoon
description: Super Typhoon Megi heads toward China after making landfall in the Philippines. Winds peaked at 178 miles per hour, making Megi the most intense tropical storm of the season; the cyclone is expected to regain strength as it crosses the South China Sea. [NASA]

title: Energy Action Amid Climate Discord
description: I encourage you to read In Kansas, Climate Skeptics Embrace Cleaner Energy, Leslie Kaufmans excellent story on enthusiastic energy-saving initiatives in a community largely resistant to the climate crisis.

title: Nature Called, and Paladino Answered
description: In a debate filled with bizarre moments, it was certainly among the strangest: Carl P. Paladinos clumsy waltz offstage in the middle of the closing statements in search of a bathroom.

title: A Photo-Sharing App With Bigger Aspirations
description: For many people, the iPhone camera  always in your pocket  is fast replacing digital cameras. And with the help of a bunch of applications, the pictures can look even better than typical photos.

title: Weighing Secured Lenders Recent Setbacks
description: Stephen J. Lubben writes about bankruptcy and debt issues for DealBook.

title: A Broadway Welcome to Normal Heart
description: Joe Mantello, Glenn Close, Michael Stuhlbarg and the rest of the cast of the Broadway reading of Larry Kramers Normal Heart drew a solid standing ovation after its performance on Monday night, which raised $150,000 for charity. But then the director Joel Grey stepped onto the stage half-tugging Mr. Kramer to come out for a bow, and a chorus of hosannas rose within the packed Walter Kerr Theater. Mr. Kramer hugged Mr. Grey, then Mr. Mantello, then took a step or two backward as if reeling from the adulation.

title: The Ethics of Using Airport Outlets
description: With all the electronic devices we now carry when we travel, finding a good seat at the airport gate is often all about making sure to be near an electrical outlet, if you can find one. But finding an outlet and actually being able to use it can be different stories.

title: The Readers Behind Bars Put Books to Many Uses
description: Avi Steinbergs memoir, Running the Books, about his job as a prison librarian at the Bay  the Suffolk County House of Correction in South Bay near Boston  gets off to an obnoxious start.

title: Letty, Groucho, Flirting and Sexism in the 60s
description: At the home of Letty Cottin Pogrebin, once a Mad Men-era up-and-comer in the publishing field, now a renowned feminist, are several scrapbooks that could well have been the basis for several of the shows plot lines. She shared them with me as we watched the final episode together Sunday night, which I wrote about in Tuesdays Big City column.

title: Fernandez Warming to Portland?
description: Rudy Fernandez hasnt been shy in letting the Portland Trail Blazers and the world know he is unhappy and homesick.

title: Youre the Boss: Seven Steps to Managing Your Online Reputation
description: The Youre the Boss blog, which is about running a small business, takes a look at how B&H, the online electronics store, manages its customer service department.

title: Notes From the Underground | Geo Wyeth
description: Geo Wyeth took the stage at Cameo in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, last week, performing a set of heartfelt, otherworldly tunes, accompanied by his band Jive Grave. Although he stuck mostly to the guitar and a microphone in this particular show, Wyeth is known for his chops on the piano, the accordion and an array of other instruments. A native New Yorker, Wyeth can be seen performing at venues all over the city with his various acts.

title: Doubting Homer Proclaimed a Catholic by Vatican Newspaper
description: As my colleague Dave Itzkoff reports on our Arts Beat blog, an author for the Vaticans newspaper, LOsservatore Romano, has been reading between the pixels of Americas most popular animated sitcom and come to the surprising conclusion that, Few people know it, and he does everything to hide it, but its true: Homer J. Simpson is Catholic.

title: Keeping Score: What the Future May Hold for Giants and Phillies Pitchers
description: Starting pitching captured much attention going into the 2010 National League Championship Series, and with good reason: Philadelphias top three starters (Roy Halladay, Roy Oswalt and Cole Hamels) are all current or former Cy Young Award candidates, while San Francisco has three young hurlers (Tim Lincecum, Matt Cain and Jonathan Sanchez) who combined for 42 wins and a 3.22 earned run average this season.

title: Your Health Benefits
description: As we head into the open enrollment season, were interested in hearing what you are finding as you review your companys benefit packages.

title: Ad Hits Reid for Living at the Ritz
description: If there was a political attack that could have been predicted, it has to be this one: national Republicans are hitting Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader from Nevada, for living at the Ritz-Carlton.

title: 2012 Nissan GT-R to Have Enhanced Performance
description: Nissan announced on Monday that its ultra-performance GT-R sports coupe would be getting a makeover for the 2012 model year.

title: Showdown in the Battle of Two Combat Games
description: Playing Medal of Honor, the new military combat game from Electronic Arts, I couldnt stop thinking two things. First, E.A. is supposed to be better than this. And second, Activision and Call of Duty dont have much to worry about.

title: Cliff Lees All-Thesaurus Pitching Performance
description: As the sports journalism world tries to produce words worthy of Cliff Lees latest otherworldly pitching performance  which has the unlikely Texas Rangers tripping panic buttons all over the Yankee dynasty  its hard not to wonder what Lee could accomplish if his talents transcended baseball. Perhaps he could tackle the health care system. Or the tax code. Solving the strikes in France? The Fox-Cablevision dispute?

title: Global Weirding: New York Non-Political Edition
description: The theme of the day is weird. As in: Jimmy McMillan weird. (He is certainly the favorite of the blogs. Mr. McMillan, a Vietnam vet, told the Daily Politics that his black gloves are worn as part of trauma he experienced with Agent Orange.)

title: Running the Books
description: Chapter 1: The up & up and low low

title: ODonnell Questions Church-State Separation
description: Click to Listen: WDEL 1150

title: Afghan Detainee Killed in Kandahar
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American soldier shot and killed an Afghan detainee in a district jail in Kandahar Province on Sunday, according to a statement from President Hamid Karzai that appeared to portray the shooting as unprovoked.

title: Mad Men Star Joins Same-Sex Marriage Effort
description: Roger Sterling, the character played by John Slattery on Mad Men, is no poster boy for marriage.

title: Should There Be Rules for Using Airport Outlets?
description: Over on the Bucks blog, Jennifer Saranow Schultz writes about the complicated ethics of using electrical outlets in airports.

title: Q&A: New York City on a Tight Budget
description: Q.

title: Stop Us If Youve Heard This N.H.L. Broadcast Before
description: Hockey fans love nothing more than to sit down in their most comfortable chairs and turn on a hockey game. But after awhile, have you ever felt like some of those broadcasts start to feel a little familiar?

title: TimesCast | October 19, 2010
description: France strikers protest government changes to pension plans; off-the-cuff campaign moments and a new restaurant tries to revitalize downtown Detroit.

title: Boom Times, at Least in Finance
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics is out with its quarterly report on employment and wages in counties around the country. The data comes from unemployment insurance premium payments, which means it is thorough and not subject to the vagaries of restatement. It also means that it is old when released. The report today is for March of this year.

title: Going on a Diet? Start Paying in Cash
description: Paying with credit or debit cards makes people more likely to make impulsive, unhealthy food purchases, according to a new study in The Journal of Consumer Research.

title: At the Mayo Clinic: The Ex-N.H.L. Player With 9 Concussions
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.  Jim Johnson, a fit 48-year-old who played 13 years in the N.H.L. before retiring in 1998, admitted he was nervous as he listened to Ann McKee, address the Mayo Clinic concussion conference here on Tuesday morning. McKee is the Boston University researcher who has done groundbreaking work with the donated brains of former athletes.

title: Garden Is the Worlds Second-Busiest Arena
description: The health of the biggest arenas in and around New York City seems to be rising and falling along with the professional basketball and hockey teams that are their main tenants.

title: Turning Pain Into Performance: Tricks of the Elite Runner
description: Among the qualities that set elite runners apart from those in the middle of the marathon pack is how effectively they manage the pain associated with running 26.2 miles.

title: Heirloom Variety
description: Kerrilynn Pamer, the owner of the stylish downtown clothing shop Castor & Pollux, always has eventual heirlooms in the back of her mind. These weighty brass bracelets were cast from vintage versions that belonged to her Aunt Maggie, who passed away last March. She always wore three of them  two thick and one thin, Pamer says. She had the most pitch-perfect style imaginable. The bracelets are $172 (for the thin style) and $182 at Castor & Pollux, 238 West 10th Street, or go to castorandpolluxstore.com.

title: Turning Asphalt Into Edible Education
description: When Celia Kaplinsky, a Brooklyn elementary school principal, visited a schoolyard garden project in Berkeley, Calif., a few years ago to see if it could work back home, something impressed her more than the lush rows of tomatoes and cucumbers.

title: A Landlord Learns From His Son
description: In his fathers house are many rooms. Roberto Fata has put sensors in a lot of them: Water sensors that warn when toilets are backing up. Temperature sensors that showed we were baking the tenants, he said  the average living-room temperature in one building was 96 degrees in the winter of 2004, when he installed the first ones. Oil-tank sensors that provide the evidence when a delivery is 200 gallons short.

title: Everyones a Designer
description: Mary makes honey  or the bees she keeps make honey  and when its too thick to pour, its the best honey of all. Her brother, Tom, is a big-time landscape architect whose credits are too voluminous and intimidating to list; just know that he has designed projects in New York, New Zealand, Jamaica and the Flight 93 memorial in Pennsylvania.

title: Buying Food With Cash or Plastic
description: The Economix blog today offers an interesting lesson on economics and eating behavior. People who buy food with cash make better choices than people who pay with credit and debit cards.

title: China Said to Widen Its Embargo of Minerals
description: HONG KONG  China, which has been blocking shipments of crucial minerals to Japan for the last month, has now quietly halted some shipments of those materials to the United States and Europe, three industry officials said this week.

title: Dimon on Regulation: We Can Handle It
description: Few banking executives have been more vocal about the financial regulatory overhaul  and what should and shouldnt be included  than Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase. And in an interview with Fortunes Duff McDonald, the outspoken Mr. Dimon again emphasizes that his firm can manage Washingtons new rules for the financial industry.

title: Weatherization Went Awry, Audit Shows
description: Money provided in the stimulus bill for making buildings more energy-efficient is finally starting to flow, the Department of Energys inspector general says. But in a report released Tuesday, his office says that in some cases it has been badly spent.

title: JetBlue Flight Attendant Accepts Plea Deal
description: The former JetBlue flight attendant who famously slid down an emergency chute after broadcasting his frustrations over the public address system managed to sidestep jail time on Tuesday, agreeing to a plea deal that calls for him to attend counseling sessions regularly for at least a year.

title: What Were Reading: Beauty Ads Are Bad for Your Self-Esteem
Citis Parsons Has a Leather Jacket That Works
description: 4:25 p.m. | Updated Daily Intel caught up with Richard D. Parsons, Citigroups chairman, on Monday night at the Jazz Foundation of Americas annual loft party on Sunday. Among the topics of conversation: Mr. Parsons leather jacket, an item of clothing he loved  hes worn it a lot  but didnt want written about.

title: Playoff Baseball by the Bay
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Baseball is filled with these timeless rituals, little bursts of flavor around the margins of the game. I suppose it is like this with other sports, too, that if youre partial to golf or boxing or auto racing, you will find yourself smiling at just as many sidelights. But to me there is nothing like baseball at playoff time.

title: For Carnegie Festival, What Would You Like to Hear? (But You Wont Hear It)
description: Power to the listener! But not too much.

title: In France, Protests Over Austerity Measures
description: Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets of Paris and other cities on Tuesday ahead of a parliamentary vote on the countrys pension system.

title: A Google-Apple Snipefest
description: Over the years, business battles between corporate titans have played out in several different media: through press releases and news articles, or throughmultimillion-dollar ad campaigns in newspapers and on TV.Argumentsmade in one medium were generally responded to in the same medium.

title: The All-Cash Diet
description: Economix has a report on a new study which found that people who purchase their groceries with credit cards are more likely to buy cookies, cakes and pies (vice items, in the researchers parlance) than consumers who pay cash. The design of the study, in the Journal of Consumer Research, does not control for all variables, but the findings offer an intriguing suggestion that shoppers might be able to curtail calorie-laden impulse buys simply by carrying a fat bankroll (which, you will be thrilled to learn, you can assemble yourself with an elastic taken from a bunch of broccoli.)

title: Tylenol Recalls Erode Johnson & Johnson Sales
description: Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday that its third-quarter sales this year fell by 0.7 percent to $15 billion, largely due to recalls at its McNeil Consumer Healthcare unit.

title: Now Baking | Haute Crumbs at Morini and Lincoln
description: In New York, two of the falls most discussed phenomena have been the openings of Lincoln and Osteria Morini; both restaurants take an almost obsessive approach to pared-down, classic Italian cuisine, and both are fronted by a well-promoted star chef with proven talent (Jonathan Benno and Michael White respectively).

title: Guy Hands Takes Stand in Battle With Citigroup
description: Guy Hands, the charismatic British financier, took the witness stand on Tuesday before a packed federal courtroom in Lower Manhattan to pursue his fight with Citigroup. Mr. Handss private-equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners, has sued the bank over its failed buyout of the EMI Group, accusing Citigroup of lying to him about the presence of another bidder during the auction of the music company.

title: Brooklyn Bridge, 11:25 A.M.
description: Hundreds of New Yorkers marched across the Brooklyn Bridge to Manhattan to attend a rally near City Hall organized by the immigrant advocacy group Make the Road New York. The group is urging the city Department of Corrections to stop cooperating with federal immigration authorities in roundups of immigrants.

title: Emanuel: Support Democrats for House
description: Who says exploring a run for mayor of Chicago takes up all of someones time?

title: I Am A Jelly Donut
description: On my way to Berlin and beyond. Posting will be erratic.

title: Saab Reveals 9-4X Ahead of Los Angeles Debut
description: Saab has previewed its new 9-4X model ahead of its introduction at the Los Angeles Auto Show media preview days, beginning Nov. 17. The medium-size crossover is a legacy from General Motors, the Swedish companys previous owner, to the new owner, Spyker. It gives dealers a much needed third item to display in their windows beside the 9-3X and the new 9-5  and one with available 4-wheel drive. A 9-5 SportCombi or station wagon is also due later.

title: Intel to Build New Chip Plant in Oregon, and Upgrade Others
description: The Intel Corporation said on Tuesday that it planned to invest $6 billion to $8 billion to upgrade manufacturing plants in the United States and build a new one in Oregon, adding as many as 1,000 new high-tech positions and thousands of construction jobs.

title: Are AT&T and Verizon About to Square Off Over Pricing?
description: While Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, and Andy Rubin, the vice president of engineering at Google, fire pot shots at one another over their rival cellphone platforms, the wireless carriers are engaging in their own snipefest behind the scenes.

title: The Morning Skate: Blackhawks, Bad Checks and Bag Skates
description: Its time to look in on the Stanley Cup champions, who, despite a young roster and very talented core, may not fare any better than every champion that has failed to repeat since the Red Wings won the last back-to-back titles in 1997 and 98.

title: Junot Dazs Run, Dont Walk Books
description: Junot Daz was here for an event at The Times last night, and in the course of the evening he rattled off the names of several authors and books that have greatly influenced his work  or simply flat-out floored him. Among them: Family Installments: Memories of Growing Up Hispanic, by Edward Rivera, a 1982 memoir noisily brimming with life, as Phillip Lopate described it in the Book Review; Poison River and The Death of Speedy, two collections of the Love & Rockets comics by Gilbert and Jaime Hernandez; The Keepsake Storm, a collection of poetry by Gina Franco; and The Housekeeper and the Professor, by the Japanese writer Yoko Ogawa, about a brilliant mathematician whose short-term memory is impaired after an accident, and who develops a close relationship with his caretaker and her 10-year-old son. (Dennis Overbye described it in the Book Review last year as deceptively elegant, written in such lucid, unpretentious language that reading it is like looking into a deep pool of clear water.)

title: Junot Dazs Run, Dont Walk Books
description: Junot Daz was here for an event at The Times last night, and in the course of the evening he rattled off the names of several authors and books that have greatly influenced his work  or simply flat-out floored him. Among them: Family Installments: Memories of Growing Up Hispanic, by Edward Rivera, a 1982 memoir noisily brimming with life, as Phillip Lopate described it in the Book Review; Poison River and The Death of Speedy, two collections of the Love & Rockets comics by Gilbert and Jaime Hernandez; The Keepsake Storm, a collection of poetry by Gina Franco; and The Housekeeper and the Professor, by the Japanese writer Yoko Ogawa, about a brilliant mathematician whose short-term memory is impaired after an accident, and who develops a close relationship with his caretaker and her 10-year-old son. (Dennis Overbye described it in the Book Review last year as deceptively elegant, written in such lucid, unpretentious language that reading it is like looking into a deep pool of clear water.)

title: CMJ Music Marathon: What to Expect
Flush With Cash, Will Apple Go Shopping?
description: Pulling in billions of dollars quarter after quarter, Apple has provided Silicon Valley with a seemingly endless guessing game about possible mergers and acquisitions  but one that has largely gone on up to now without the participation of Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive.

title: Reader-Submitted Photos: New York City Marathon
description: New York Times readers share their photographs of Sundays race.

title: Marathon of Surprises in New York
description: Derartu Tulu of Ethiopia edged the women's world record holder while Meb Keflezighi became the first American to win New York in 27 years.

title: Rooney Wants Out at Manchester United
description: LONDON  Wayne Rooney, the Kobe Bryant of English soccer, has said he wants to quit the most famous team in the land, Manchester United, according to his manager.

title: For McCain, Stimulus Money Questions
description: Senator John McCain found himself trying to recover  or at least explain away  a Recovery Act faux pas Tuesday on ABCs Good Morning America with George Stephanopoulos.

title: In Hiring Mike Quade, Cubs Pass Over Ryne Sandberg
description: SAN FRANCISCO  There is no way of knowing, right now, whether Chicago Cubs General Manager Jim Hendry made the right call Tuesday by hiring Mike Quade as manager. Quade, 53, paid his dues as a minor league manager for 17 seasons. The Cubs played hard for him this summer, going 24-13 after Lou Piniella resigned. He knows the Cubs, having spent four years as their third-base coach. He is personable and outgoing, and should handle the scrutiny well.

title: Lockheed Cuts Profit Estimate for Year
description: Lockheed Martin on Tuesday cut its earnings forecast for 2010, and said delays in the award of Pentagon programs would hurt its sales growth and leave profits flat in 2011.

title: Mosques Open Their Doors for a Week of Dialogue
description: Muslim organizations have kicked off a week of dialogue and mosque open houses across the United States, encouraging their members to invite neighbors and non-Muslim friends to attend Muslim prayers and question-and-answer sessions at mosques, and, in turn, to explore churches, synagogues and other houses of worship.

title: Intermission, at Best, in Battle Over Foreclosures
description: Bank of America may be trying to bring down the curtain on the foreclosure furor, but there were numerous indications Tuesday that the problems would not move off-stage so quickly.

title: The Fate of Interstate Wine Shipments
description: I sit comfortably in New York City, knowing that I can find just about any wine that interests me at one of our many excellent retail shops. On the rare occasion that they all fail me, I can quickly search stocks around the country using a convenient tool like wine-searcher.com. And, last week, some very good friends of mine were reveling: they had just received one of their twice-a-year deliveries from Garagiste, an unusual Internet wine retailer that makes it easy for people in 33 states and Washington to find the sort of esoteric wines that ordinary retail shops might not carry.

title: E.D.F. and Constellation Step Up Nuclear Battle
description: The romance is over for lectricit de France and the Constellation Energy Group, partners in a nuclear power joint venture. Their very public squabble was ostensibly set off by Constellations withdrawal of its application to the Energy Department for a loan guarantee for the Calvert Cliffs 3 nuclear project in Maryland. E.D.F. publicly responded with a letter scolding Constellation and asserting its willingness both to proceed with the Calvert Cliffs project and buy out Constellations 50 percent interest in their UniStar joint venture, the corporation formed to develop Calvert Cliffs.

title: Claiming Responsibility: Understanding the Rise and Popularity of Hitler
description: Overview | Did the German people elevate Hitler, or did Hitler victimize the Germans? How do historians formulate claims about complex historical events? In this lesson, students consider competing historical claims about responsibility for the rise of Adolf Hitler and then examine primary sources to generate and support their own historical claims. They also consider what the significance of these claims might be for contemporary society.

title: The Pedometer Test: Americans Take Fewer Steps
description: Americans are thousands of steps behind other countries when it comes to daily physical activity, according to new research that used pedometers to measure movement.

title: Pennsylvania Revisited
description: Ive been fielding a lot of questions about the Public Policy Polling survey in Pennsylvanias Senate race that gives Representative Joe Sestak, the Democrat, a 1-point lead over the Republican Pat Toomey.

title: Keeping Tabs on Tax Changes
description: Economists recently discussed on the Freakonomics blog what they think the biggest tax mistake of this year might be.

title: Murder Trial Puts Death Penalty in Spotlight in Connecticut Campaigns
description: If Dannel P. Malloys gubernatorial campaign had the authority to set Connecticuts court calendar, it probably would have scheduled the states most sensational murder trial for some other time. Like after Election Day.

title: Britain Announces Severe Military Cutbacks
description: LONDON  In a bid to streamline its armed forces and help reduce its daunting levels of national debt, the British government on Tuesday announced plans to cut its military personnel by 10 percent, scrap 40 percent of the armys artillery and tanks, withdraw all of its troops from Germany within 10 years, and cut 25,000 civilian jobs in its Defense Ministry.

title: Wealthfront Loses the Sound Effects
description: 10:03 a.m. | Updated Correcting how much Wealthfront managers outperformed the S&P index.

title: Answering Readers Questions About the Chevrolet Volt
description: As driving impressions and technical details of the 2011 Chevrolet Volt emerged from last weeks press introduction in Michigan, Wheels invited its readers to add their own questions to the topics covered in the FAQ article published last weekend.

title: Exploring Eataly
description: Inside the giant new Italian food hall in Manhattan.

title: Eataly Offers Italy by the Ounce
description: NEW YORKERS understand full-contact grocery shopping.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from France, Pakistan and Russia.

title: Breast Cancer Seen as Riskier With Hormone
description: Hormone treatment after menopause, already known to increase the risk of breast cancer, also makes it more likely that the cancer will be advanced and deadly, a study finds.

title: Eataly: Waiting for Supermarkets
description: Such are the vagaries of reviewing restaurants in a city still shaking off the terrors of recession: this weeks review isnt really a review at all, but a notebook about a grocery store, Eataly, that opened recently next to Madison Square Park, in the Toy Building. (More photos are in a slide show, and check out the floor plan here.)

title: The Caucus
description: Two off-the-cuff moments captured on video in Nevada and Kentucky show how intense the campaigns have become in the last days before the midterm elections.

title: New York Fed Urges BofA to Buy Back Loans
description: A group of financial institutions demanding that Bank of America repurchase $47 billion worth of loans packaged by Countrywide Financial has an unusual new member: the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Cars.com Rejoins Super Bowl Lineup
description: The roster of Super Bowl advertisers has grown again with word on Tuesday that Cars.com, which advertised during the last three Super Bowls, will be a sponsor of Super Bowl XLV on Feb. 6, 2011.

title: Student Accused of Slashing Cabby Is Freed on $500,000 Bail
description: Michael Enright, the film student charged with slashing a Muslim cabby in Midtown in August, was released on $500,000 bail Tuesday afternoon. The family of Mr. Enright, 21, secured the bond by putting up their house in Brewster, N.Y., and a certificate of deposit.

title: Watching the French Protests on YouTube
description: During another day of nationwide unrest in France on Tuesday, scuffles were reported between rock-throwing students and riot police firing tear gas in Nanterre, on the outskirts of Paris.

title: Mets and Francisco Rodriguez Resolve Contract Dispute
description: The Mets and Francisco Rodriguez resolved their contract dispute on Tuesday with Rodriguez admitting responsibility for his thumb injury and renouncing claims to lost salary, and the Mets agreeing not to convert his contract to nonguaranteed status.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from France, Pakistan and Russia.

title: Final: Giants 3, Phillies 0
description: Matt Cain pitched seven shutout innings and Cody Ross delivered yet another clutch hit as the Giants shut out the Phillies 3-0, taking a two game to one lead in the National League Championship series.

title: TimesCast: Off-the-Cuff Moments
description: In the latest edition of TimesCast, Michael D. Shear takes a look at two recent off-the-cuff campaign moments this election year.

title: Artful Books | The Island of Rota
description: Ted Muehling is known for designing objects, like jewelry, porcelain vases and crystal bowls, that are based on forms found in nature, like a lily pad, coral or a tortoise shell. His first foray into book design, a collaboration with the neurologist and writer Oliver Sacks and the photographer Abelardo Morell, is no exception. The Island of Rota is a mysterious and seductive book about the natural history of an island in Micronesia. Its text is taken from Sackss book The Island of the Colorblind; its rich, clich-verre photographs of ferns and cycads (very early plant forms that grow on Rota) are by Morell; and the book itself, a highly textured, handmade, sensual object, was designed by Muehling.

title: At the Mayo Clinic: Womens Hockey, a Most Dangerous Game
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.  In terms of concussions, womens ice hockey is the most dangerous N.C.A.A. sport.

title: Shaken Baby Syndrome Debate Moves Offshore
description: Sometimes a healthy debate takes place at some distance from the point of origin of a Times news story or column. That was the case with Anatomy of a Misdiagnosis by Deborah Tuerkheimer, an Op-Ed piece published on Sept. 21.

title: Indianapolis Symphony Names Music Director
description: The Indianapolis Symphony named a 28-year-old Pole, Krzysztof Urbanski, as its music director, starting in September. Mr. Urbanski, who succeeds Mario Venzago, graduated from the Chopin Music Academy in Warsaw just three years ago and was named chief conductor of the Trondheim Symphony Orchestra in Norway in 2009.

title: The Bulls Rose Also Rises
description: If the road to N.B.A. superstardom were paved with All-Star votes and YouTube highlight reels alone, Derrick Rose would already be a player of legend. He would be the subject of folk songs, star in countless tall tales, and be immortalized in bronze alongside Michael Jordan outside Chicagos United Center. Unfortunately for Rose, such are the spoils reserved for the games true elites, and while the young Bulls guard is among the brightest up-and-comers on todays N.B.A. scene, Roses rise hasnt quite mirrored the meteoric brilliance of, say, Kevin Durant.

title: Cervelli to Catch Burnett in Game 4
description: With the Yankees trailing by 2-1 in their American League Championship Series against Texas, Joe Girardi will start a battery that has not played since Oct. 2. As he has for most of the season - and each of his starts since Aug. 2 - Francisco Cervelli will catch A.J. Burnett on Tuesday night.

title: Bringing Business To Detroit
description: Melena Ryzik visits Detroit, where a young restaurateur is working to revitalize a section of the blighted city.

title: Is Pure Altruism Possible?
description: Who could doubt the existence of altruism?

title: Using Twitter to Predict Stock Market Swings
description: Forget Michelle Obamas wardrobe. Heres an even more deliciously unexpected stock market indicator: Twitter.

title: Yahoo Profit Rises, but Revenue Is Flat
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Almost two years after Carol A. Bartz took over as chief executive of Yahoo, the turnaround of the countrys biggest Web portal is still clearly a work in progress.

title: New Web Life for the Dead Sea Scrolls
description: JERUSALEM  The scribes who wrote the Dead Sea Scrolls could not have imagined their texts one day being Googled.

title: Eye-Popping for Arts Sake: An Advocate for 3-D Films
description: Nearly a year after his fantasy movie Avatar broke box office records and opened a floodgate of big-budget 3-D features, James Cameron is still very much immersed in his budding science-fiction franchise and 3-D filmmaking.

title: New Lab Complexes Make the City Ready for a Biotech Future
description: An initiative to develop a bioscience industry in New York City is starting to take root with the construction of two commercial laboratory complexes, one on the East Side of Manhattan and the other at the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park.

title: Can EMC and Dell Kiss and Make Up?
description: EMC felt like a jilted lover when Dell made an unsuccessful run at 3Par, EMCs rival in the data storage business.

title: Landmarks Says No to a Guggenheim Food Stall
description: Foodies take note: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday voted to deny the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museums application to install a food kiosk outside its entrance. The commission determined that the kiosk would disrupt the entryway and introduce a visual interruption to Frank Lloyd Wrights museum.

title: Microsoft Moves Office to the Cloud
description: It has been a busy year inside Microsoft: the company is getting ready to introduce anentirelynew mobile platform and a new type of Xbox gaming interface that uses the human body instead of a traditional controller. Now it is offering a new kind of Microsoft Office suite, called Office 365, which is based in the cloud.

title: Hunting for the Dawn of Writing, When Prehistory Became History
description: CHICAGO  One of the stars of the Oriental Institutes new show, Visible Language: Inventions of Writing in the Ancient Middle East and Beyond, is a clay tablet that dates from around 3200 B.C. On it, written in cuneiform, the script language of ancient Sumer in Mesopotamia, is a list of professions, described in small, repetitive impressed characters that look more like wedge-shape footprints than what we recognize as writing.

title: Sheepshead Bay, 2 p.m.
Officer Failed to Warn C.I.A. Before Attack
description: WASHINGTON  Three weeks before a Jordanian double agent set off a bomb at a remote Central Intelligence Agency base in eastern Afghanistan last December, a C.I.A. officer in Jordan received warnings that the man might be working for Al Qaeda, according to an investigation into the deadly attack.

title: Sales Decline, but Earnings Rise for Johnson & Johnson
description: A series of recalls of Tylenol and other popular brand-name medicines this year is largely to blame for a decline in third-quarter sales at Johnson & Johnson to $15 billion, a decrease of 0.7 percent, the company said on Tuesday.

title: Sylvan Sounds, Meant to Be Seen
description: Can a concert be too beautiful for comfort? The question seemed pertinent for a long stretch of a rare local performance by Ryuichi Sakamoto in the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University on Monday night. Mr. Sakamoto, 58, is a figure whose renown encompasses a plethora of disparate activities. Apart from being a skillful keyboardist, he is a pop-culture hero in his native Japan, a composer of film scores and symphonic works, a record producer and entrepreneur, an actor and, most recently, an environmental activist.

title: The Caucus Click: Plymouth, Mass.
Turkeys Rapidly Rising Currency Has Downside
description: ISTANBUL  Day after day, the Turkish stock market has been setting records, lifted by a flood of foreign capital in search of higher yields in Turkey and other fast-growing emerging markets.

title: A Date with Bruno Frisoni
description: Bruno Frisoni, the artistic director of Roger Vivier, has an important date in New York this week. Hes here to introduce his latest collection, the limited-edition Rendez-Vous. I wanted this collection to be more affordable than couture and more accessible in terms of design, says the designer, who played with a range of natural materials including wood, cord and horn. (Orders start in December and are limited to 10 per style.) New Yorkers will be the first to see the collection at a party tonight at Saks Fifth Avenues shoe mecca, 10022, hosted by Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, Lincoln Centers director of fashion. But this week isnt all business for Frisoni. He loves the old charm and the shabby chic suites, at the Carlyle Hotel and dining at the downtown bistro Da Silvano, for the Italian-like atmosphere and sunny terrace. Still, you never know when another bag or shoe idea will strike. His biggest inspiration, he says, comes from the graphic lines of the city and the crisp skies.

title: 3 Midtown Projects and How They Grew (or Didnt)
description: One of Manhattans newest skyscrapers is rising on a nondescript corner of the Avenue of the Americas and 32nd Street. In coming months, the building, once called Tower 111 and now tentatively renamed the Continental, will begin marketing its 338 rental units. Its developer is hoping that sweeping views of the Empire State Building, nine-foot ceilings and amenities that include an indoor swimming pool will draw renters to this mostly commercial stretch of the Garment District.

title: Longing for the Lines That Had Us at Hello
description: LOS ANGELES  Have we heard the last (truly memorable) word from Hollywood?

title: Where the Well-Heeled Dress Down
description: A RECENT article on ArtThreat.net examined the Internet mini-sensation of the graffiti artist Banksys animation intro for The Simpsons. In the clip, Banksy lampoons the outsourcing of Simpsons animation cels to South Korea by showing the characters being drawn by candlelight in damp underground sweatshops. ArtThreat quoted Naomi Kleins Twitter feed:

title: From the Garden to the Record Books, a Supersize Pumpkin
description: The largest pumpkin ever grown measures more than 15 feet around and is 4 feet tall. It weighs 1,810 pounds and contains enough flesh to make about 900 pies. On Friday, it left New Richmond, Wisc., in the back of a 2010 Dodge Ram pickup.

title: Clarence Thomass Wife Asks Anita Hill for Apology
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly 20 years after Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment during his contentious Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Justice Thomass wife has called Ms. Hill, seeking an apology.

title: An Ugly Duckling Gets Her Ginger Up Over Fitting In
description: Its hard to imagine that the actress Julianne Moore was ever an ugly duckling. And she wasnt, exactly: she was a freckleface strawberry.

title: In Five Different Lives, Many Ties That Bind
description: Its a small world, and for the disparate and troubled characters in Interchange, Ken Jaworowskis engrossing new play at the WorkShop Theater Company, their universe will be reduced to one degree of separation before the evening is done.

title: Lower Profit at Goldman Reflects Wall St. Slowdown
description: By SUSANNE CRAIG

title: Secretive Republican Donors Are Planning Ahead
description: A secretive network of Republican donors is heading to the Palm Springs area for a long weekend in January, but it will not be to relax after a hard-fought election  it will be to plan for the next one.

title: Sci-Fi Goosebumps and Aliens on a Mission
description: Lines were bungled. Light cues missed. The pacing wandered almost as much as the performances, which ranged from the wooden to the flamboyantly hammy. In other words, the stage version of Edward D. Wood Jr.s Plan 9 From Outer Space is just about perfect.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Eating Local: Discuss

title: A Taste of Detroits Future
description: The restaurateur Phil Cooley of Slows Bar-B-Q has brought the beginnings of a restaurant scene to the blighted city.

title: Sunsets Covers Through the Decades
description: Covers of the magazine over the years reveal much about how the West was fed.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Botellas Effective Wine Decanter
description: No decanter is simpler and more effective than this utilitarian model. It is like an elongated bottle standing more than 16 inches high, making for an impressive presentation on the table and allowing the wine to aerate as it travels downward, entering through its matching glass funnel.

title: Totto Ramen and Hide-Chan Ramen
description: JAPAN is dotted with wonderfully workaday ramen shops, places that are especially compelling when the weather turns cold. The lunch crowd squeezes into a narrow space shrouded in steam pouring from soup bowls, stock brews on open flames beyond the counter, and beside it a man pulls fresh noodles. The only sounds come from the bubbling pots and the clatter of chopsticks and spoons in bowls. Outside, the air is cold and thin; inside, the soup is hot and rich. Lunch at these places is, at once, otherworldly and comforting.

title: The New Brooklyn Cookbook
description: By calling it The New Brooklyn Cookbook, Brendan and Melissa Vaughan, husband and wife authors, clearly present a time frame: the last decade, give or take a couple of years. The cookbook opens with a nod to the old Brooklyn of Di Faras and Peter Luger, and then plunges right in with the place the Vaughans consider to be the game changer when it comes to Brooklyn food: Al di L in Park Slope, which opened in 1998. This is a history of the contemporary food scene with 70 restaurant recipes, including cocktails, and even a home brewers version of Sixpoint Craft Ales American Brown Ale.

title: In Chinatown, Cupcakes Frosted and Savory
description: If Michelin rated cupcake stores, Everything Frosted might qualify for an exceptional, worth a special journey for lovers of flavors like green tea, jasmine, red bean and black sesame. On tiny Mosco Street, its a tricky find, even by Chinatown standards. Instead of a storefront, it has just a hanging sign and a narrow flight of stairs up to a no-frills kitchen, office and counter where dozens of cupcakes with iced topknots are displayed.

title: Detroits Renewal, Slow-Cooked
description: DETROIT

title: The Original California Cuisine, Courtesy of Sunset Magazine
description: BEFORE Alice Waters picked her first Little Gem lettuce and Wolfgang Puck draped smoked salmon across a pizza, California cuisine meant something else.

title: When That Smile Is Too Perfect
description: IN this age of advanced aesthetic enhancement, subtlety is prized. The discerning get just enough Botox to unfurrow their brows, lest they become expressionless clones. Women dissatisfied with their breast size may get a surgical boost, but few aim to be as conspicuously colossal as Heidi Montag. And now dental patients are pursuing perfectly imperfect teeth.

title: Debit and Credit Cards and Diets
description: In a post on the Economix blog, Catherine Rampell writes about a new study that suggests paying with credit or debit cards makes people more likely to make impulsive food purchases.

title: Homes for $1.1 Million
description: A six-bedroom house in Maine, a three-bedroom house in Pennsylvania and a two-bedroom condo in California.

title: What You Get for ... $1.1 Million
description: BUCKS COUNTY, PA.

title: At Harvard, the Kitchen as Lab
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Osmond Joy: Donny and Marie Bringing Christmas Show to Broadway
description: One of the quirkiest, kookiest clans in popular culture is headed to Broadway for the holiday season: not the Addams family, which is already firmly entrenched in the theater district, but the Osmond family. The sibling entertainers Donny and Marie Osmond, who between them have dozens of gold records  not to mention dozens of the most lustrous teeth in show business  are headed to the Marquis Theater for a 12-performance run in December, publicists for the show said on Tuesday. Donny & Marie  A Broadway Christmas will be the first time that Mr. Osmond, the teen heartthrob turned Dancing With the Stars champion, and Ms. Osmond, the performer and lone sister to eight Osmond brothers, have shared a Broadway stage together. Mr. Osmond previously played Gaston in the Broadway production of Beauty and the Beast, and Ms. Osmond played Anna in a Broadway revival of The King and I in 1997. The limited run is from Dec. 9 (Donnys birthday!) through Dec. 19, and is produced by Greg Young, Jon B. Platt and Magic Arts & Entertainment in association with Eric Gardner and Greg Sperry.

title: Taliban Elite, Aided by NATO, Join Talks for Afghan Peace
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Talks to end the war in Afghanistan involve extensive, face-to-face discussions with Taliban commanders from the highest levels of the groups leadership, who are secretly leaving their sanctuaries in Pakistan with the help of NATO troops, officials here say.

title: Matt Cain Pitches the Giants Past the Phillies
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Just about every time he had faced the Philadelphia Phillies, Matt Cain had been treated like a piata.

title: Internet Is a Weapon in Cable Fight
description: In disputes between television programmers and distributors, the new battleground is the Internet.

title: Cablevision-News Corp. Fight Intensifies
description: The fight between Cablevision and the News Corporation which has led to a blackout of the Fox network in 3.5 million homes in Long Island and New Jersey for four days running does not appear to be getting less bitter. If anything, it is growing more heated.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell: A Gay Marine Writes
description: The author is an active-duty Marine sergeant in his mid-20s. He enlisted in 2002, served two tours in Iraq, and is now back in the United States. He has asked that his name not be published.

title: DealBook: Flush With Cash, Will Apple Go Shopping?
description: Thomas Kaplan over at the Dealbook blog raises the question of whats on Apples shopping list.

title: Brandy Lifts Dancing
description: The actress and pop singer Brandy topped the scoreboard on Mondays edition of Dancing With the Stars as the two-hour installment of that ABC reality show dominated the nights prime-time ratings with 19.3 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The competition easily led both the 8 and 9 oclock hours for the network, while providing a boost at 10 to Castle, which won its time slot with 11.6 million viewers, outperforming CBSs Hawaii Five-0 (10.6 million) and NBCs Chase (5.2 million). CBS earned second place for the night, posting strong results at 9 and 9:30 for its sitcoms Two and a Half Men (13.4 million) and Mike & Molly (11 million). Fox ranked third as House delivered a solid audience at 8 (9.5 million). NBC was fourth.

title: NBC Extends 3 Shows
description: NBC is backing three of its new series with full-season orders. On Monday the network gave a vote of confidence to its most talked-about new drama, The Event; the comedy it added to its Thursday lineup, Outsourced; and the new edition of its long-running Law & Order franchise, Law & Order: Los Angeles Not one has emerged as a hit, and all have ratings that might be labeled marginal. But NBC has fewer successful shows than the other networks, and all three series have shown at least some promise.

title: Russia Accepts Invitation to Attend NATO Summit Meeting
description: PARIS  President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia announced Tuesday that he would attend next months summit meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Lisbon and left the door open to the possibility of Moscow cooperating with the alliance on a European missile defense shield.

title: The House of Color
description: Marie Fabre and Frdric Escudier, a couple from France, settled in Siem Reap, Cambodia, where they built a two-bedroom, 3,000-square-foot home for around $300,000.

title: Opposing Excessive Rent, but Vague About His Own
description: Jimmy McMillan, running for governor as the candidate of the one-man Rent Is Too Damn High Party, stole the show at the debate on Monday night with his repeated and crystal-clear message: The. Rent. Is. Too. Damn. High.

title: How Government Helps Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Guilty Plea but No Jail for Ex-JetBlue Attendant

title: Just Knock It Off
description: Some of Israels worst critics are fond of saying that Israel behaves like Americas spoiled child. Ive always found that analogy excessive. Say what you want about Israels obstinacy at times, it remains the only country in the United Nations that another U.N. member, Iran, has openly expressed the hope that it be wiped off the map. And that same country, Iran, is trying to build a nuclear weapon. Israel is the only country I know of in the Middle East that has unilaterally withdrawn from territory conquered in war  in Lebanon and Gaza  only to be greeted with unprovoked rocket attacks in return. Indeed, if you want to talk about spoiled children, there is no group more spoiled by Iran and Syria than Hezbollah, the Lebanese Shiite militia. Hezbollah started a war against Israel in 2006 that brought death, injury and destruction to thousands of Lebanese  and Hezbollahs punishment was to be rewarded with thousands more missiles and millions more dollars to do it again. These are stubborn facts.

title: Privacy vs. Profits
description: The threat to privacy posed by digital technology is about to take a turn for the worse. At least, thats what were hearing about HTML 5, the latest version of the computer language that is used to create Web pages. In principle, HTML 5 will allow sites you visit to know your physical location and will make it easier for them to keep track of your browsing and shopping history.

title: Roadside Bombing in Iraq Strikes Convoy Carrying U.N. Diplomat
description: BAGHDAD  A roadside bomb struck the convoy of the top United Nations representative to Iraq on Tuesday after he had finished a meeting with the countrys senior Shiite cleric to discuss the continuing political deadlock, officials said.

title: 1 in 5 Americans Have Close Ties Elsewhere
description: Nearly one in five Americans are either immigrants or were born in the United States to at least one parent from abroad, the Census Bureau said Tuesday. The second generation was more likely to be better educated and earn more and less likely to be living in poverty. This suggests that the children of immigrants are continuing to assimilate over time as they have in past generations, said Elizabeth M. Grieco, chief of the bureaus Foreign-Born Population Branch. The bureau said that in 2009, 12 percent of the population, or 36.7 million people, were immigrants and that 11 percent, or 33 million, were the children of at least one immigrant parent. Among the foreign born, 29 percent had a bachelors degree and 31 percent earned more than $50,000. Among the second generation, 33 percent had a bachelors degree and 42 percent made more than $50,000.

title: Texas: Jordanian Sentenced in Bomb Plot
description: A Jordanian man who tried to blow up a Dallas skyscraper during an F.B.I. sting was sentenced Tuesday to 24 years in prison by Judge Barbara M. G. Lynn of Federal District Court. The man, Hosam Maher Husein Smadi, 20, had overstayed a tourist visa, married an American woman and began dabbling in radical Islamic politics. In September 2009, undercover F.B.I. agents drew Mr. Smadi into a fake plot to blow up the 60-story Fountain Place building. Mr. Smadi drove a truck that he believed carried an explosive device into a garage under the building and activated the false bomb, according to court documents. Facing life in prison, Mr. Smadi agreed to plead guilty to attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction in exchange for a reduced sentence. Defense lawyers had argued that he suffered from depression and had received a diagnosis of schizophrenia.

title: A Proposal to Address Rights Abuse in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Facing international pressure over abuses by his nations military, President Felipe Caldern has put forward a range of proposals to transform military justice here, including civilian trials for soldiers accused of some serious crimes like rape or torture.

title: China: Dissident Is Under House Arrest
description: Yu Jie, a prominent Chinese dissident writer, said in a cellphone text message sent to friends on Tuesday afternoon that he had been put under house arrest in Beijing. His latest book is Chinas Best Actor: Wen Jiabao, a collection of essays published in Hong Kong in August that criticized Prime Minister Wen Jiabao for talking about political reform without making moves toward reform. Mr. Yu said in his message that four security officers had been posted to his door, one in a police uniform and three in plain clothes, to keep him from leaving. He said his Internet service had been cut off.

title: Goldman in the Pack, Not Leading It
description: Goldman Sachs is coming down to earth with a bit of a bump. Sure, the third-quarter earnings of $1.9 billion handily beat what analysts had expected for the Wall Street giant, led by Lloyd Blankfein. Thats good news any time, and especially after talk of a summer slowdown. But Goldmans results usually lead the pack. Not this time.

title: China: A Call for the Return of Antiques
description: The managers of the old Summer Palace in Beijing are urging the owners of any antiques that were originally in the palace during the Qing dynasty to return them to the Chinese government, China Daily reported Tuesday. For many Chinese, the palace, called Yuanmingyuan, is a symbol of imperial aggression by the West  it was looted in 1860 by British and French forces and burned to the ground. China Daily quoted a park official as saying that 1.5 million relics had been looted or lost from old palace grounds over the years. Another official, Qin Jing, said more than 100 relics were scattered across Beijing because their current owners had refused to return them. Relics from Yuanmingyuan have sold at international auctions for millions of dollars.

title: Britain: Saudi Prince Guilty of Murder
description: A Saudi prince was convicted of murder on Tuesday for beating his servant to death last winter in a five-star hotel suite in London. Prince Saud Abdulaziz bin Nasser al Saud, 34, a grandson of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, also bit and strangled his servant Bandar Abdulaziz, 32, in an assault at the Landmark Hotel in the early hours of Feb. 15, the Old Bailey criminal court was told. The two men had just returned from a Valentines Day celebration.

title: Sports Replay: Oct. 19
description: Images from the day in sports, including Game 3 of the National League Championship Series.

title: Phys Ed: Do Women Sweat Differently Than Men?
description: Does a hard-working woman sweat like a man? That question, which has figured in many an antiperspirant commercial, has received surprisingly little scientific scrutiny. But a new study published this month in the journal Experimental Physiology provides persuasive evidence that women do sweat copiously during exercise. (Did anyone really believe they misted?) But fit women seem to sweat differently than unfit people of either sex, and quite differently than fit men, a fact that has implications for sports performance. It also may have some bearing on what it has meant, since prehistory, to be female.

title: Olympian Withdraws From New York
description: The United States Olympian Blake Russell dropped out of the New York City Marathon with a right calf injury, the New York Road Runners said. Russell, 35, who ran the marathon at the Beijing Games in 2008, was looking to make her first appearance in New York and first marathon since the birth of her first child in April 2009. Joining Russell on the sideline for the Nov. 7 race is Antonio Vega, the reigning United States half-marathon champion, who has hip injuries.

title: Night of Body Blows Leaves the Yankees Teetering
description: This is what exasperation looks like: A.J. Burnett standing toward the front of the pitchers mound, hands atop his head, blank stare on his face. This is what frustration sounds like: boos, loud and throaty, pouring forth from fans filing out of Yankee Stadium. This is what joy feels like: the Texas Rangers mobbing each other inside the dugout, an improbable trip to the World Series just one victory away.

title: British Bank Plans Middle East Private Equity Deals
description: Standard Chartered Bank plans to close a $100 million private equity deal before the end of this year, its first in the Middle East, a senior executive of the bank said on Wednesday.

title: G-20 to Weigh Ending Mandatory Debt Ratings
description: Financial regulators will recommend to the Group of 20 leading economies that they abolish, wherever possible, mandatory credit ratings for institutions or instruments accessing the public debt market, Mario Draghi, the Financial Stability Board chief, said on Wednesday.

title: How I Became a Head-Hunting Defensive Back
description: A reader, Peter from Brooklyn, in joining the debate about where to draw the line on head hunting in the N.F.L., spoke from personal experience:

title: Bloomsbury Festival Returns to London
description: Never say die. That should be the motto of the Bloomsbury Festival, which lost its funding after 2007, only to return this year, from Oct. 22 to 24, once again celebrating the London neighborhoods historic past and remarkably vibrant present.

title: Seeking to Revive European Subprime Market
description: Investec, the South African bank, is seeking to revive the market for subprime mortgage bonds in Europe three years after the securities were blamed for the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Under Spotlight, Goldman to Cut Compensation
description: Goldman Sachs will divide $3.8 billion among 35,400 employees in the third quarter, a pay pool reduced significantly from the period a year earlier, The Financial Times reported.
