title: Battered Landscape for a California Democrat
description: MANTECA, Calif.  When Jerry McNerney, a Democrat, was first elected to Congress in 2006, it was both an upset and, it seemed, a harbinger.

title: Foreclosures Profit Some Equity Firms
description: With a surge in lawsuits against law firms specializing in foreclosures, a case in Mississippi is casting light on another aspect of the mortgage mess  the connection between Wall Street private equity firms and those law firms, often known as foreclosure mills.

title: Afghan Election Commission Is Praised for Its Fairness, in Spite of Tainted Voting
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite rampant fraud in the parliamentary elections last month, whose preliminary results were announced Wednesday, the Afghan Independent Election Commission appears to have tried to do an honest job of counting the ballots, an effort that was lauded by the United Nations and even by some losing candidates.

title: Court Keeps Military Gay Policy for Now
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Wednesday temporarily stalled the landmark court decision allowing openly gay recruits to be accepted into the military.

title: Malpractice Methodology
description: The health care legislation that Congress enacted earlier this year, contrary to much of todays overheated rhetoric, does many things right. But it does almost nothing to reform medical malpractice laws. Lawmakers missed an important opportunity to shield from malpractice liability any doctors who followed evidence-based guidelines in treating their patients.

title: A Pharmacist With Dreams of Independence
description: Maria Frangos, 25, imagined a future as a careerist in snazzy business suits, ensconced in her own office, until she took a college-level class in business management and despised it. Inspired by her older brother, a pharmacy intern, she changed course. Six years of college later, she is a licensed pharmacist holding down two jobs in Brooklyn: at the Starrett City CVS, part of the national chain; and at the Fifth Avenue branch of Neergaard Pharmacies, a Park Slope institution since 1888. She lives in Park Slope with her parents and her brother, Minas, 27, also a pharmacist.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 20
description: A view of the day in sports, from the beam to basketball to baseball.

title: Dr. Greg and Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan

title: Trade Spats Are Driving a Wedge in the G-20
description: WASHINGTON  Representatives of the Group of 20 economic powers, who managed to cooperate during the financial crisis two years ago, will confront festering disputes over trade and currency this weekend, and try to reconcile diverging approaches for how to deal with them.

title: Climate Change Doubt Is Tea Party Article of Faith
description: JASPER, Ind.  At a candidate forum here last week, Representative Baron P. Hill, a threatened Democratic incumbent in a largely conservative southern Indiana district, was endeavoring to explain his unpopular vote for the House cap-and-trade energy bill.

title: Despite Speculation, Dolan Is Not Named a Cardinal
description: Italian newspapers were among the first  back in March  to float the rumor that New Yorks charismatic new archbishop, Timothy M. Dolan, was sure to be made a cardinal at the next big meeting of Roman Catholic prelates in Rome. The rumor sustained a robust life on its own, fed by Catholic news media and the eternal curiosity of many American Catholics about the nebulous world of Vatican power.

title: G.O.P. Odds of House Majority Now 3-in-4
description: The latest FiveThirtyEight projection for the House of Representatives shows little overall change from our previous update, released this weekend, but the Republican position has improved slightly. They are now given a 75 percent chance of winning the House on Nov. 2, up from 73 percent previously. During an average simulation run, the Republicans finished with a total of 228 seats (up from 227): this would reflect a net gain of 49 seats from their current position.

title: As Dollars Value Falls, Currency Conflicts Rise
description: Is this a currency war or what?

title: The Fury Failure
description: Rage is not working out.

title: Rejection by N.B.A. Gives New Shoes Even Greater Bounce
description: For the founders of a fledgling athletic-shoe company, there is only one thing better for business than having an N.B.A. star endorse your new shoes: have the league say the shoes will not be allowed on its courts at all.

title: Union Plans to Try to Block Release of Teacher Ratings
description: The citys teachers union said on Wednesday that it would request a restraining order to prevent education officials from releasing reports that rate thousands of city teachers based on how much progress students made on state standardized tests.

title: G.O.P. Ad in Alaska Hits Obama
description: With Election Day less than two weeks away, negative political advertisements are popping up on television screens all across the country.

title: Your Court in Action
description: Let me correct some things that Mr. Frederick said that were not true. That was as close as a Supreme Court lawyer comes to calling her adversary a liar. The speaker was Kathleen Sullivan, a formidable advocate and former dean of Stanford Law School, challenging David Frederick, just as impressive and well credentialed, at the court last week.

title: Tidal Power: The Next Wave?
description: Over the next few years, we can expect to see huge advances in our ability to harness power from the oceans waves and tides, a new report from IHS Emerging Energy Research, a Cambridge, Mass., consulting firm, predicts.

title: Ernest Gaines, Acclaimed Author at Home
description: Ernest J. Gaines, 77 is part of the fifth generation of his family to be born on a plantation in Oscar, La., where his ancestors were slaves.

title: Writer Tends Land Where Ancestors Were Slaves
description: OSCAR, La.  His ancestors were slaves. They worked this flat plantation land just west of the snaking Mississippi, chopping sugar cane with their machetes. They and some of their descendants lived in the plantations quarters. And when they died, most were buried here in a small patch of earth, for blacks only.

title: Thy Neighbors Duplex
description: Recently, when I was in Austin, Tex., I drove by a house with a helipad.

title: John Robertss America
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.  I wish Chief Justice John Roberts could spend a day and a night in the Rocky Mountains experiencing what his activist Supreme Court majority has dumped on the American voter in 2010.

title: Lee Looms Large for Yanks in Texas
description: Kerry Wood can tell us better than anyone how home field and the hottest pitchers do not necessarily make for the most secure safety net. He can tell us about the Cubs and the Marlins, himself and Mark Prior, Steve Bartman and the trapdoor a team can fall through just when it seems ready to take off for the stars.

title: Coalition Forces Routing Taliban in Key Afghan Region
description: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan  American and Afghan forces have been routing the Taliban in much of Kandahar Province in recent weeks, forcing many hardened fighters, faced with the buildup of American forces, to flee strongholds they have held for years, NATO commanders, local Afghan officials and residents of the region said.

title: At Detainees Trial, Insider Gives Glimpse Into Al Qaeda
description: A former military trainer for Al Qaeda choked up when a prosecutor asked him on Wednesday why he quit the terrorist group in the mid-1990s.

title: Lottery Numbers
L.S.U.s Record Says 7-0; L.S.U.s Fans Say, Lucky
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  There are fans here who want their 7-0 team to look more tidy. They want some polish, a little more shine. They do not know quite how to wrap their arms around this Louisiana State squad, especially its coach, Les Miles.

title: Timetable Is Set for the Only Civil Trial in a 9/11 Death
description: Eight months from now, the family of Mark Bavis will get what they have wanted since he died on Sept. 11, 2001: their day in court.

title: Our Culture, From Marilyn Monroe to Sarah Palin
description: To the Editor:

title: Efforts to Prosecute Blackwater Are Collapsing
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly four years after the federal government began a string of investigations and criminal prosecutions against Blackwater Worldwide personnel accused of murder and other violent crimes in Iraq and Afghanistan, the cases are beginning to fall apart, burdened by a legal obstacle of the governments own making.

title: Talking to the Taliban: Some Questions to Ask
description: To the Editor:

title: What Is Killing the Bees? Look to the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Posey Helps Giants Win With Offense
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: In No Trouble, Schumer Opens Coffers to Party
description: With his re-election virtually assured against a little-known Republican challenger, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York is using his campaign war chest to help other Democrats across the country running for the Senate get elected next month.

title: Carlsen Takes Early Lead in Pearl Spring Tournament
Rent Is Too Damn High, Set to Music
description: The synthesizer pulses with an urgency that fits the lyrics. The voice is at once smooth and aged, reminding the listener of Ted Hawkins playing for pocket change on Venice Beach, but shot through with a dash of Chuck D. The lyrics, meanwhile, are straight-up Woody Guthrie.

title: Keady Brings His Aura to St. Johns
description: Steve Lavin, the new basketball coach at St. Johns, sat with three of his players on folding chairs on a dais inside Madison Square Garden on Wednesday and talked for 90 minutes about the coming season. The players were excited. Lavin was much more measured.

title: Anthony Is Topic No. 1 As Trade Talks Percolate
description: PHILADELPHIA  Eight days before the start of the Amare Stoudemire era, the conversation was about Carmelo Anthony. It might be this way for a while.

title: Police Discretion Is Issue in Injured Bystanders Suit
description: After the gunfire ceased in Harlem one evening in 2005, it became clear that a 25-bullet fusillade by police officers had done more damage than intended.

title: Bob Guccione, Penthouse Founder, Dies at 79
description: Bob Guccione, who founded Penthouse magazine in the 1960s and built a pornographic media empire that broke taboos, outraged the guardians of taste and made billions before drowning in a slough of bad investments and Internet competition, died Wednesday in Plano, Tex. He was 79.

title: OTB Gets Relief
description: New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation, the bankrupt operator of 68 wagering locations across the city, will remain open after reaching a debt-forgiveness agreement with unsecured creditors. About $95 million owed by OTB, which in March was ruled eligible for Chapter 9 reorganization, will be resolved, according to a statement by New York Governor David Paterson. Creditors including Yonkers Racing Corporation and New York Racing Association will forgive about $65 million in exchange for some of OTBs wagering operations and changes to state racing laws to help video-lottery terminal operators generate revenue.

title: Paul S. Miller, Advocate for Disabled, Dies at 49
description: Paul Miller, a lawyer who was born with achondroplasia  dwarfism  overcame discrimination because of his disability and became a leader in the disability rights movement, died Tuesday at his home on Mercer Island, Wash. He was 49.

title: Thursday: Dr. Squish
description: Dan Naddor died last December, but not before submitting three crosswords to The New York Times. The first two ran on March 21 and May 6. He stops by today for his final Times visit and, as Will Shortz says, he goes out with a bang!

title: My Son, Not Myself
description: Dave Marcus went to Brown. Now he writes and lectures about the college admissions process, spreading the message that theres no best school, just a good fit, and parents shouldnt live their own dreams through their children, and that it all works out for the best in the end.

title: Experts Review Canadian Commanders Sadistic Crimes
description: OTTAWA  He had a privileged upbringing, a highly successful career and sadistic sexual urges that would qualify as extreme even by the morbid standards of serial killers.

title: Tiles, Farms and the Dead Zone
description: Every year, usually beginning in late spring, an oxygen-depleted dead zone forms in the Gulf of Mexico at the Mississippi Rivers mouth, killing off fish, shrimp and other marine life. By the time cooler weather restores life to the zone, the fishing industry has sustained substantial losses.

title: Mistakes Catch Up to Rangers in Game 5
description: While the Texas Rangers are still in command of the American League Championship Series, Wednesdays game at Yankee Stadium raised concerns for them, beyond the fact that the Yankees won, 7-2, to force Game 6 on Friday in Texas.

title: F.B.I. Computer System Is Late and Over Budget, Report Says
description: A computer system for the Federal Bureau of Investigation known as Sentinel is $100 million over budget and two years behind schedule, said a report released Wednesday by the Justice Departments inspector general. As of August, after spending about $405 million of the $451 million budgeted, only two of the four phases of the project had been completed, according to the report. Thomas J. Harrington, associate director of the F.B.I., said the report did not accurately reflect the bureaus management of the project, relied on outdated cost estimates and failed to credit the bureau with taking steps to stay within budget.

title: In the Series Undercard, Cano and Hamilton Are Slugging It Out
description: The cities are different, but the chants are the same. Josh Hamilton heard Rangers fans rhythmically shout M.V.P.! for him during the first two games of the American League Championship Series in Arlington, Tex. For the last three days in the Bronx, Yankee fans chanted the same for Robinson Cano.

title: Facing Runoff in Brazil, Candidate Backed by President Stays Ahead of Her Rival
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  With less than two weeks until the deciding second round of Brazils presidential election, Dilma Rousseff, the chosen successor to President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, is staving off a late push from her rival candidate.

title: White Knight Is Shaken by Dark Horse in Illinois
description: CHICAGO  Less than two years ago, when Patrick J. Quinn, a Democrat and the lieutenant governor of Illinois, was elevated to governor after a corruption scandal swirling around Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, he was hailed as a welcome, desperately needed respite from what had come before.

title: Hockey Urged to Ban All Blows to Head by Concussions Panel
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.  A conference on reducing concussions in hockey recommended prohibiting contact to the head at every level of the game, including the N.H.L., and banning body checking by 11- and 12-year-olds to reduce the high rate of concussions among youth players.

title: Somalia: British Aid Worker is Released Unharmed
description: The British aid worker kidnapped last week by Somali gunmen was released unharmed on Wednesday, aid officials said, after extensive negotiations with clan elders. The aid worker, Frans Barnard, left, a consultant for Save the Children, was taken at gunpoint last Thursday from a guest house in Adado. Clan elders there persuaded the kidnappers to free Mr. Barnard, said Anna Ford, a Save the Children spokeswoman. She denied reports from Somali residents that a $100,000 ransom had been paid.

title: A.L.C.S. Photo Replay: Oct. 20
description: A look at Game 5 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and the Rangers.

title: Water Scarcity a Bond Risk, Study Warns
description: The municipal bonds that help finance a major portion of the nations water supply may be riskier than investors realize because their credit ratings do not adequately reflect the growing risks of water shortages and legal battles over water supplies, according to a new study.

title: Q. & A. With the Rangers Owner Chuck Greenberg
description: Chuck Greenberg and Nolan Ryan were part of the group that acquired the Texas Rangers from Tom Hicks on Aug. 5 in a federal bankruptcy court auction. At the time, the team had a record of 63-45, good enough to be in first place in the American League West by eight and a half games. They beat Tampa Bay in five games to win the division series and were up 3-1 over the Yankees in the A.L.C.S. when Richard Sandomir talked to Greenberg by telephone before Game 5 of the series.

title: China G.D.P. Grew 9.6% Despite Cooling Efforts
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese economy continued to expand at a rapid clip during the third quarter, demonstrating that government measures aimed at reining in growth have not choked off expansion.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Mayo Clinic Calls for Tougher Head-Checking Rule in N.H.L.
description: ROCHESTER, Minn.  The Mayo Clinic conference on concussions in hockey called for the N.H.L. to completely outlaw all contact with the head, proposing a rule that would go far beyond the N.H.L.s current Rule 48 banning blindside hits to the head.

title: NPR Fires Analyst Over Comments on Muslims
description: NPR has terminated its contract with Juan Williams, one of its senior news analysts, after he made comments about Muslims on the Fox News Channel.

title: Grandmaster Plans to Play More Than 500 People at the Same Time
description: One of the feats that elite chess players can do that always seems to amaze people who do not play chess (or play it very little) is competing against many opponents at the same time. These simultaneous displays, or simuls, seem impressive, but as long as there are not too many participants (say more than 20 or 25) and none of them are too skilled, it is not all that difficult.

title: Dr. Georges Math, Transplant Pioneer, Dies at 88
description: In the morning of the atomic age, there was optimism that the nuclear genie could heal as well as kill. By the mid-1950s, researchers had cured mice of leukemia by destroying diseased bone marrow with near-lethal doses of radiation, then rescuing them by transplanting healthy marrow.

title: Word of the Day | assay
description: assay \a-sa, a-sa\ noun and verb

title: Giants Push Phillies to the Brink
description: SAN FRANCISCO  All around AT&T Park, there are reminders of the great Giants sluggers. There is a statue out front of Willie Mays and a cove out back named for Willie McCovey. Even Barry Bonds made a rare appearance when he bounced out of the dugout to throw out the first pitch when the National League Championship Series returned here.

title: China: Tibetan Students March To Protest Education Policies
description: More than 1,000 Tibetan students marched in peaceful rallies Tuesday in a town in Qinghai Province to protest Chinese education policies, according to reports from Tibetan advocacy groups Wednesday and photographs and video of the protests circulating on the Internet. The protests were in and around Tongren, known in Tibetan as Rebkong, on the edge of the Tibetan plateau. The town has one of the most prominent monasteries in the Tibetan world, and monks there have protested against Chinese policies in recent years. Some monks joined the student protesters, who shouted equality of ethnic groups and freedom of language, according to the International Campaign for Tibet.

title: Equatorial Guinea: Unesco Expected to Hold Award in Abeyance
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is expected to vote in plenary session Thursday to continue to suspend the awarding of a prize underwritten by President Teodoro Obiang Neguema Mgasogo of Equatorial Guinea, European diplomats said on Wednesday. The United States and other Western countries won agreement from African members on a compromise that mandates the continuing suspension of the Unesco-Obiang prize, some $3 million, for research in the life sciences until a consensus is reached among members, which is unlikely to occur. Mr. Obiang is suspected of being highly corrupt, and most of Equatorial Guineas residents are extremely poor, despite the countrys oil wealth.

title: Aid Groups Advice in Afghanistan
description: In connection with my Thursday column, I asked several NGOs for their advice on how to work in insecure or Taliban areas. Their advice was remarkably consistent, all about consulting local people and getting buy-in from them. And of course thats good advice whether its an aid organization in the South Bronx or in southern Afghanistan.

title: Marijuana Bonfire Celebrates a Fragile Calm
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  It is now the city safe enough for an Al Gore speech.

title: U.S. Tries to Ease Wider Worries Over Foreclosures
description: Administration officials renewed efforts on Wednesday to ease concerns about the integrity of the foreclosure process, saying that no evidence had emerged so far of any problems that threatened the health of the financial system, Binyamin Appelbaum reports for The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | October 21, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Battle Lines Forming in Clash Over Foreclosures
description: About a month after Washington Mutual Bank made a multimillion-dollar mortgage loan on a mountain home near Santa Barbara, Calif., a crucial piece of paperwork disappeared, Gretchen Morgenson and Andrew Martin report in The New York Times.

title: Foreclosures Profit Some Firms
description: With a surge in lawsuits against law firms specializing in foreclosures, a case in Mississippi is casting light on another aspect of the mortgage mess  the connection between Wall Street private equity firms and those law firms, often known as foreclosure mills, Barry Meier writes in The New York Times.

title: Wells Fargo Reports Higher Earnings
description: Within weeks of scooping up the failed banking operations of Washington Mutual in late 2008, JPMorgan Chase began phasing out the WaMu brand, replacing signs on retail branches. title: Renoirs Passion, on Display at the Prado
description: Passion is a concept constantly revisited in the work of Pierre-August Renoir. The popular Impressionist devoted his life to painting the female figure, nudes, landscapes, still lifes and flowers  all with a vibrancy matched by few. A master of form, light and color, he glorified bourgeois life, taking particular interest in feminine sensuality.

title: First Impressions From South Korea
description: I arrived today at the Yeongam circuit for the inaugural Korean Grand Prix. Let me start by admitting that this race was the one that I least wanted to attend this season, and I was not alone in that feeling. Many of the journalists who attend most of the races are not attending this one, and many others had said to me as well that it was the one they least wanted to attend. In fact, I am quickly coming to the conclusion that I am having a delightful time and that this could end up being a popular one  at least with the people within the Formula One circus.

title: Rocking the Vote, in the 1820s and Now
description: NOT long before Andrew Jacksons death in 1845, George P.A. Healy, the American portraitist, traveled south to Tennessee to paint Jackson and other statesmen  including Henry Clay of Kentucky, an implacable Jackson foe. Healy was expected at Ashland, Clays estate in Lexington, but overstayed his time at Jacksons Hermitage in Nashville. When Healy finally made his appearance in Kentucky, Clay knew that Jackson had won yet again. Clay did not bother hiding his jealousy and resignation, remarking to Healy, I see that you, like all who approached that man, were fascinated by him.

title: A Former Renegade Spirit Becomes a Headmistress

title: A Quiet Place Of Dysfunction And Dystopia
description: AS the motorcade carrying the body of Leonard Bernstein passed through Brooklyn on its way to Green-Wood Cemetery 20 years ago, construction workers removed their yellow hard hats and called out, Goodbye, Lenny! It was a gesture of affection unthinkable for any other classical musician. In death, as in life, Bernstein was the exception: capable of anything and, almost, everything. One of the great conductors of the 20th century, he was also a composer, educator, television personality and political activist who at one point hobnobbed with the Black Panthers.

title: Matters of Spirit In a World Of Hectic Clamor
description: MANY if not all of the answers to ones own life actually lie inside ourselves, a smiling professional said during a recent private session in a tidy Upper West Side office. I believe deeply in having access to, and spending time with, ones interior life.

title: Studio Kabul
description: At the age of 27, after 14 years of marriage, with seven children and a husband 30 years older than she was, a husband who was addicted to opium, who once deprived her of food because she gave birth to a girl and not a boy, who beat her when she took too long to conceive, who pulled out her hair and knocked out her teeth to make her too ugly to remarry, who beat her again when he couldnt find money for opium because he had spent it on phone cards for the mobile to call his lovers  after 14 years, Abada had had enough. She cried, screamed, pulled out her hair, desperate to die. She put her littlest daughter outside the room where she cooked. She turned on the gas and waited for peace.

description: Whats so great about Finishing the Hat, the new book on songwriting by Stephen Sondheim, is implicit in its title. This self-portrait of the artist as an obsessive lyricist is about a dynamic, unending process; its about finishing, not having finished. And the mental energy this process emanates is enough to give a reader a satisfying case of brain burn.

title: Geek Chic | Luxe City Guides for iPhone
description: Not that aLuxe City Guide ever took up much space in your pocket  its slim profile was always its genius. But these days its always a cause for celebration when a traveler can dispense with paper altogether (however gorgeously laminated it may be) and bring all his intelligence with him on his smartphone. Our friends at Luxe have rolled out a wide collection of their snappy directories for iPhone, covering 20 cities in total, among them Los Angeles, Florence, Venice and Beijing. Now the hotels listings come with pictures; there are GPS-enabled maps and automatic updates; and the whole guide can be searched and personalized with itineraries based on your favorites. What remains from the dead-tree versions, of course, are the cheekily concise summations of a smart selection of accommodations, restaurants, shops, clubs and culture  along with sundry raves, grievances and anecdotes. If theres one thing lacking, its that we might like to read more of what the Luxe founder Grant Thatcher and his team have to say about the three bistros were trying to decide between (seriously, Thatchers hilarious). In the Luddite version of the guide, each gets only a sentence. But now that were measuring in megabytes and not column inches, why not gas on a bit?

title: RNC Raises $10M in September, But Cash is Low
