I like them hurled at 50 miles an hour by a medieval weapon. Or perhaps shot out of an air cannon, to splatter with a satisfying Thwock! into brilliant orange shrapnel.

title: The Games People Play: Twist the Brain, Stretch the Body
description: Customers browsing at the Barnes & Noble store in Union Square last Saturday afternoon probably had no clue that circulating among them, skulking in the shadows and engaging in quick, furtive conversations, were more than a dozen people surreptitiously playing Ministry of Silence. Even bookstore employees didnt know.

title: Losing Touch With the Patient
description: Several years ago I helped care for a man who had been hospitalized with a severe infection of the abdominal wall. When his primary doctors discovered that the bacteria responsible was resistant to most antibiotics, they quickly isolated him, moving him into a single room with a sign on the door proclaiming Contact Precautions and directing visitors to put on gloves, mask and gown before entering.

title: Putting Barriers Between Doctor and Patient
description: Because of growing alarm about the spread of MRSA and other hardy superbugs, precautions like hand washing, physical isolation, gloves and masks have become a routine part of clinical life in hospitals. But despite their widespread use and acceptance, only a few studies have acknowledged that the rigidity and isolation inherent in such limitations may themselves lead to problems.

title: Dr. Pogue's Amazing Earbuds
description: There are various options for people who can't get earbuds to stay in their ears.

title: Diamond Rings Match Eye Makeup to Sports Jersey
description: The festival has barely gotten going, so its a bit early to make pronouncements, but Diamond Rings is almost certainly the only one-man band who matches his eye makeup to his sports jersey. (At CMJ or anywhere.) At the Stereogum showcase at Santos on Wednesday night, it was light blue and gold, to coordinate with his Toronto Blue Jays shirt and hat.

title: ODonnell Regrets First Political Ad
description: First Christine ODonnell dabbled in witchcraft, then she was emphatically not a witch. But apparently, the Republican candidate for Delawares Senate seat cant seem to leave the coven behind her entirely.

title: Name the One Who Treated a Guest the Best
description: Our pals at Diners Journal have a question for you: In the history of New York restaurants, who was  or is!  the greatest single host or hostess ever to work a room? Cast your vote on Diners Journal.

title: From Bill Gates, a Gift to Fight Proposition 23
description: Citing figures from the California secretary of state, Maplight.org reports that Bill Gates has donated $700,000 to the campaign against Proposition 23, the ballot measure that would repeal a California law related to reining in global warming. According to Maplights list, that would make him the 11th-biggest contributor to the opposition effort to date.

title: Hilton Introduces eforea Spa
description: Hilton Hotels and Resorts is introducing a new, separate spa brand, the eforea: spa at Hilton. The first of 80 planned outposts opens today, at the Hilton Short Hills, in New Jersey, and several others will follow in the coming month, in hotels in Pattaya, Thailand, and Melbourne, Australia, among others.

title: Next to the Big Three, the Heats Other Two Guys
description: MIAMI  They are the guys next to the Guys: the two sidekicks who will play supporting roles if the Miami Heat is to execute its plan on the court as skillfully as it did off it when it signed LeBron James and Chris Bosh and retained Dwyane Wade in the off-season.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Wick and Mortar
description: Cire Trudon, the cult candle maker that once dipped tapers for Marie Antoinette, has transformed the corner of Bond Street and the Bowery into a tiny version of Versailless Galerie des Glaces. The companys first Stateside outpost, which opens this week on the lower-ground level of the old Bouwerie Lane Theater, is filled with antique mirrors and historical French moldings and hardware  the perfect surroundings for perfumed candles, pillars and room sprays that conjure waxed palace floors and Madame de Pompadours boudoir. Cire Trudons 36-year-old owner, Ramdane Touhami, a forward-thinking classicist if ever there was one, invites customers to linger in the space for as long as they like. Choosing a scent for your home should be like choosing one for your body, he says. It takes time.

title: In a New Ad, an Organic Dairy Keeps It Real
description: If Spike Jonze were still making rap videos and met up with some young British dairy farmers, this is the video he would most certainly have made. Its an ad for the organic dairy company Yeo Valley in southwest England, part of a multi-million dollar marketing campaign, and its a complete work of rapperly art. (Thank you Grist for surfacing it.)

title: Toxins, Genes and Thyroid Cancer
description: Can environmental toxins be responsible for a cluster of thyroid cancer cases in one New York office? If your mother or father had thyroid cancer, are you at increased risk? These are among the questions posed last week by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. R. Michael Tuttle, an endocrinologist at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, responds.

title: Moon Crater Contains Usable Water, NASA Says
description: The Moon, at least at the bottom of a deep, dark cold crater near its south pole, seems to be wetter than the Sahara, scientists reported Thursday.

title: With Saks, Tods Founder Finds the Shoe Fits
description: The luxury retailer Saks is looking like a comfortable fit for the founder of Tods.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Italy, Mexico and Somalia.

title: Of Real-Life Police Work, and the TV Version
description: Critics are forever assailing police officers after fatal shootings  throwing out questions like: Hey, whyd you have to shoot so many times? Couldnt you have just shot the gun out of his hand?

title: Keeping Score: In a Game 7, Lee Would Be No Sure Thing
description: Contrary to what you may have heard, the Yankees do have a fighting chance of beating Cliff Lee if they can force a Game 7 against the Rangers.

title: No Net for the Man in Charge
description: GUILLAUME DUFRESNOY, the artistic director of the Big Apple Circus, has always worked close to the edge, one way or another.

title: Desiree Ficker, Marathoner and Triathlete, Is Taking Your Questions
description: 1:33 p.m. |Update: Fickers Responses

title: Answers About the Foreclosure Crisis
description: The Economix blog recently released its first batch of answers to reader questions about the foreclosure crisis, including queries on whether it will make lenders more likely to offer loan modifications and who actually initiates foreclosures. The blog is also taking more questions on the topic.

title: New Zealand Still in Hobbit Picture, for Now
description: LOS ANGELESThe tussle between producers of two plannedfilms based on The Hobbit and a New Zealand union is still going on, despite a move on Wednesday by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists to lift a ban that had kept members from working on the films. As of Thursday morning, according to a person briefed on the matter, Warners New Line unit, which is supervising the production for Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, was still considering a move to another country, in part because, in the studios view, the New Zealand actors, despite having withdrawn their call for an international union boycott, are continuing to insist that the Hobbit producers conduct discussions that would run afoul of New Zealand law. A team of Warner executives is expected to be in New Zealand by Tuesday, both to assess the situation and to consider plans for production elsewhere.

title: Special Section: Wealth
description: A special section in Thursdays Times on wealth includes a host of stories on the subject, including looks at three schools of thought on wealth management, a club to discreetly discuss wealth issues and why its now possible to bargain down legal fees.

title: Settlers Race to Build Units in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Less than four weeks since the end of Israels building freeze in the West Bank, hundreds of units are under construction in dozens of settlements there, settler leaders and anti-settlement advocates said Thursday.

title: Two Cities Chasing That Elusive First Championship
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Biological Siblings, Different Last Names
description: What to name the baby is not just about first names anymore.

title: European Court Fines Russia for Blocking Gay Protests
description: MOSCOW  The European Court of Human Rights ruled Thursday that Russia had violated the rights of gay activists by refusing to allow them to openly protest, and ordered the government to pay a fine and damages amounting to about $40,000.

title: Part 1: N.B.A.s Offensive Movers and Shakers: Who Will Improve?
description: The N.B.A. off-season provides teams with their best opportunity for pronounced change. Theres a reason, after all, that basketball articles at this time of year are littered with Dylanisms. If we cut through the timeworn metaphors invoking the wind, the tide and other natural mechanisms of change, the underlying message is still valid. At no other time are N.B.A. franchises given the same freedom to revamp their rosters and approaches.

title: From a Reader, a Defense of N.F.L. Players
description: Since my post this morning veered toward opinion, heres a dissenting view on the N.F.L.s crackdown on hits to the head, and the players reaction to it:

title: Pogues Posts: Office for Mac Isnt an Improvement
description: David Pogue writes on his blog that he is not impressed with the newest version of Office for Mac:

title: Getting the Best Out of Vegetables
description: A while ago, just on the seam between summer and fall, I had a good dinner at a blessedly calm London restaurant called Gauthier. My first dish, after the initial sequence of snacky things, was a pair of olive-oil crisps with vegetables sandwiched between them. Kind of like a ratatouille, to give you some sense of the intensity of flavor. But this set of vegetableswent beyond the usual summery Mediterranean standbys  eggplant, zucchini, peppers  to include things like carrots (which also grow in the summer, of course), all deeply flavorful both because theyd been carefully purchased and impeccably cooked. Im guessing that each element of the mixture had been prepared separately  how else to account for eggplant and carrots that were both optimal?

title: Bashing Spyglass Deal, Icahn Offers to Buy MGM Debt
description: 4:26 p.m. | Updated The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn offered on Thursday to buy senior debt from creditors of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in return for their voting against a proposed deal with Spyglass Entertainment.

title: Asian Restaurant Guide Ranks Top 20
description: The Miele Guide, which calls itself Asias first independent food guide, released its list of the regions top 20 restaurants today.

title: Letters: Times Link to Its Own Course Is a Lesson
description: Here is some reader response to my most recent column from last Sunday, Times Link to Its Own Course Is a Lesson.

title: Networks, Hipness and Unwitting Donations to the M.T.A.
description: Update, 5:31 p.m. | Correction Appended It turns out a lot of New Yorkers are donating money to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Or rather, many are leaving unspent funds to the authority by buying unlimited cards when they really should be opting for the pay-per-ride.

title: Oil Sands Effort Turns on a Fight Over a Road
description: KOOSKIA, Idaho  As U.S. Highway 12 hugs the serpentine banks of the Clearwater and Lochsa Rivers here, road signs bear the silhouettes of the 19th-century explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, with Mr. Lewis pointing off into the distance.

title: Mackerel: The Sustainable Fish
description: As Ive become more aware of the urgent need to eat more sustainable seafood, Ive been reaching for squid, clams, sardines, and especially mackerel whenevera fishy hunger strikes.Mackerel is a good fish thats gotten a bad rap, something I wrote about in my column yesterday. Many cooks have sworn off it, saying its too heavy, too oily. And when it comes to the canned stuff, theyre right. But mackerel can be mild and buttery, especially whenvery fresh.But, more importantly to me, its the oiliness of mackerel that imparts its uniquely briny flavor. When cooked just so, mackerel is a fish you can love to serve as well as eat. And its also relatively inexpensive. Check out these links from the Monterey Bay Aquarium and The Guardian about mackerel sustainability.Recipes:

title: Oligarchs Fight Over Nickel Company
description: MOSCOW  In a battle of Russian oligarchs, shareholders voted on Thursday to retain the current board at Norilsk Nickel, thwarting an effort by a minority owner to gain more seats and oust the management.

title: What Will Bank of America Do to Its Checking Accounts?
description: In its earning report and call earlier this week, Bank of America announced that it would begin testing new banking offerings in select markets in December as part of its new consumer bank strategy.

title: The New Norm in the Arctic: Change
Quote Unquote | Gossipmonger
description: The Gossip Girl costume designer Eric Daman enthuses over Leighton Meesters fabulous taste. No, what? He is talking about Blake Lively? Weird.

title: Photo of the Week
description: The sun sets over the Bay of Biscay in San Sebastian, Basque country, Spain.

title: Mad Men Versus Domesticity
description: Two of the most interesting things written about the current season of Mad Men (now sadly complete) both appeared on New York Magazines Vulture blog earlier this month. One was Emily Nussbaums provocative piece wondering (as her title put it) why the shows writers make Betty Draper such a monster. The other was this passage, from Logan Hills recap of the seasons 11th episode:

title: Reforming Medicares Payment System
description: In Wednesdays paper, David Leonhardt wrote about a proposal by Peter Bach of Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and Steven Pearson of Mass General to reform how Medicare paid for new treatments and technologies. Under the plan, they would be reimbursed in full for three years. If they hadnt proven to be more effective than previous treatments and technologies after three years, however, they would be reimbursed at the (lower) rate of those previous technologies.

title: (Name of City)s Sports Fans Are the Best
description: In most cities, sports fans love their teams unequivocally. You applaud your pitcher, even after he gets rocked. You stay to the end of the game, even in a blowout. Youre eternally, irrationally optimistic. New York was once that way. It wasnt that long ago when Wait till next year was an unofficial slogan of the Brooklyn Dodgers. But not anymore.

title: Distracted With Salem at CMJ
description: So the easy response to the heavy smoke and the flickering strobe lights during Salems show at Ramiken Crucible in the small hours of Thursday morning would be this: what a relief. Salems seemingly indifferent live shows have become part of the bands image as lethargic and detached and maybe not at all, you know, good.

title: The Inventory Begins, With Birds, Rain and More Rain
description: Saturday, Oct. 16

title: Young Voters Divided Over Obama, Poll Finds
description: Two years after young voters helped propel Barack Obama to victory, a new poll by Harvards Institute of Politics finds young adults divided over the job he is doing as president and not very likely to vote in the upcoming elections.

title: Big Brother vs. Little Brother: Updating Orwells 1984
description: Overview | How does George Orwells vision of technology and its uses in 1984 compare with todays reality? How have concerns about privacy and freedom expressed in the novel been manifested in the contemporary world? In this lesson, students compare and contrast the world, people and technologies of 1984 with those of today and create a treatment for a modern film, print or stage adaptation that revolves around current technologies.

title: Political Points: Frenzied Stumble to Nov. 2
description: Click to Listen

title: The Subway in Pictures
description: A gallery of New York Times photography documenting 10 decades of New York Citys subway system.

title: Carlsen Retains Lead at Pearl Spring
Patterns: Report Paints Portrait of Costliest Patients
description: Some of the sickest patients can run up hospital charges as high as $18,000 a day, with average stays of almost three weeks, according to a new government report on the cost of hospital care.

title: The Bakers Apprentice: Mustard Tart
description: Emily Weinstein, who wrote a series on this blog about learning to cook, is now learning to bake with the food writer and cookbook author Dorie Greenspan.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Italy, Mexico and Somalia.

title: For Wilson, Wall Street Is Asset and Liability
description: In the hyper-competitive and cutthroat world of Wall Street, Harry Wilson was a star. But in his first foray into elective politics, Mr. Wilson, the Republican candidate for New York State comptroller, has been bludgeoned with his own credentials, Sam Dolnick and Peter Lattman report in The New York Times.

title: The Quirks of Expeditionary Civilization
description: Sunday, Oct. 17

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 22-28
description: Dance

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Oct. 22-28
description: Pop

title: 660 Miles, 468 Stations, 106 Years
description: To mark the subways 106th birthday this week, Metropolitan (the Sunday section in The New York Times) sent photographers across the system to explore themes and images in which they found some special resonance.

title: Our Subway, Ourselves: Images Through the Ages
description: YOU can smell these photos, cant you?

title: New First Violinist for Juilliard String Quartet
description: The Juilliard String Quartet has named a new first violinist, only the fourth in its 64 years. He is Joseph Lin, 32, a Harvard University graduate who is a professor at Cornell University and an active soloist and chamber musician with a strong interest in Chinese culture. Mr. Lin will start with the quartet next year. He replaces Nick Eanet, who joined the quartet last season but had to withdraw for health reasons. Robert Mann, the founding first violinist, retired in 1997 and was succeeded by Joel Smirnoff, who was named president of the Cleveland Institute of Music in 2008.

title: I See a Makeover in Your Future
description: Elle Muliarchyk has seen enough psychics to take their soothsaying with a pinch of sodium chloride. A model turned photographer, she believes that the clothes she has worn on the day of her readings have influenced the prognostications she has received. During the making of Somnambuli, Ms. Muliarchyks fashion video, shot exclusively for T, about the power of clothes to affect our destiny, the model Meghan Collison underwent a series of high-fashion transformations and had her fortune read by various New York clairvoyants. The same psychic who told the model to clean up her act when she was dressed like a hippie, Ms. Muliarchyk recalled, saw Harvard in her future a few days later when she was dressed up like an Upper East Side lady. Spooky, huh?

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Oct. 22-28
description: Classical

title: Path Is Set for General Growths Bankruptcy Exit
description: 7:18 p.m. | Updated

title: Is Proposition 19 Going Up in Smoke?
description: Proposition 19, a ballot initiative in California that would give local authorities the ability to legalize and tax marijuana for personal consumption, appears to have lost ground in the polls.

title: A Penchant for Bruch (Since She Was Only 5)
description: What a difference a week, a few days and a change of scenery make. This month the violinist Sarah Chang was scheduled to perform Bruchs Violin Concerto No. 1 with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra. When that ensembles musicians called a strike, Ms. Chang announced a recital, proceeds from which would be donated to the players pension fund. But faced with what the orchestras management called threats, Ms. Chang canceled.

title: Bob Gucciones New York
description: Hugh Hefner had the mansion out there in California, with the bunnies and the bacchanalia. Bob Guccione had the house on a stiff-upper-lip street on the Upper East Side that was home to department-store heirs and doctors and lawyers.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 22-28
description: Art

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 22-28
description: Movies

title: Paul Thek: Diver, a Retrospective
description: Images from the show at the Whitney.

title: Believing Is Seeing (Or, the Meat Of the Matter)
description: Paul Thek, the subject of a ragged, moving and much-anticipated retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art, was only 54 when he died of AIDS in 1988. But by then he had already slipped through the cracks of art history. Or rather he had fallen into one of the deep trenches that divide that history into artificial islands with names like Pop and Minimalism.

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 22-28
description: Jazz

title: The Future of Long-Term Health Care
description: Laguna Honda, a skilled nursing and rehabilitation facility in San Francisco, suggests an inspired way of thinking about not only institutionalized care but of what a truly effective health care facility might look, feel and act like.

title: Braids: A Band Moving in Many Directions
description: Each time Raphaelle Standell-Preston curses, it comes as a surprise. It shouldnt, though, since it seems to happen quite a bit in the songs by her band Braids, which played Rock Shop in Brooklyn on Wednesday night.

title: At Brookyn Museum, African-American Artworks Pre-1945
Finra Names Defense Lawyer as Enforcement Chief
description: 5:00 p.m. | Updated Bradley Bennett currently defends Wall Street. Now the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, Wall Streets self-regulator, has hired him to police the Street. Mr. Bennett will soon become Finras new enforcement chief. Mr. Bennett replaces Susan Merrill who left Finra in March.

title: Yulianna Avdeeva Wins Chopin International Piano Competition
description: Yulianna Avdeeva, a 25-year-old Russian, won the top prize in the 16th Chopin International Piano Competition, officials in Warsaw announced on Wednesday. Second prizes were awarded to Lukas Geniusas of Russia and Lithuania and Ingolf Wunder of Austria. The event takes place every five years and is one of the most prestigious on the piano competition circuit. This years winner, Ms. Avdeeva, is scheduled to perform with the New York Philharmonic on Oct. 29 in Warsaw, where the orchestra will stop while on a European tour, and on Jan. 4 in New York.

title: A Singer From Everywhere Arrives Here
description: THE singer Buika was carrying a Spanish passport when she arrived in the United States last week to begin her first extended tour of North America. But her music, with its roots on four continents, draws on such a wide range of influences, from jazz and flamenco to pop, soul and African polyrhythm, that it sometimes seems as if she is from everywhere at once and nowhere in particular.

title: Spare Times: For Children for Oct. 22-28
description: ZOOZOO

title: The Caucus
description: Representative Joe Sestak, the Democratic candidate for Pennsylvania's Senate seat, is in a statistical dead heat with his Republican opponent, Pat Toomey.

title: Strong Gains for Amazons 3rd Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A sour economy failed to slow down Amazon.com, as the companys net sales climbed 39 percent in the third quarter.

title: Those Greek Heroes, Sometimes Behaving Badly
description: The ancient Greeks did not require perfection of their heroes, only greatness. They would certainly recognize some of our heroic figures (trapped miners, soldiers, quick-thinking pilots), but not our shock at the personal conduct of others (sports stars, politicians). Greek heroes misbehaved frequently, and when they did  Achilles dragging Hectors body behind his chariot, Odysseus boasting to the Cyclops Polyphemus  it was a matter to be settled between the hero and the gods.

title: Spare Times for Oct. 22-28
description: Around Town

title: Demand Rising for Rentals Among the Ultrarich
description: NEW YORK is a city of renters  about 75 percent of us, in fact. And lately, that includes more of the super-rich and the merely wealthy, as rentals of $10,000 to $100,000 per month are on the rise.

title: Theater Listings Oct. 22-28
description: Theater

title: Auction Hunters and Other Buy-and-Sell TV
Tweaking Tradition, Even in Its Temple
description: If John Baldessari: Pure Beauty is any indication, the Metropolitan Museum of Art may finally be catching up to the 21st century. Granted, the museum has never met a century whose art it hasnt embraced. But its relationship to the latest thing has often felt forced and out of it.

title: Bengal Tiger, With Robin Williams, Coming to Broadway in March
description: Confirmation arrived on Thursday that Robin Williams will indeed star next spring in a Broadway production of Rajiv Josephs play Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, and from the horses  or is that tigers  mouth?

title: 'John Baldessari: Pure Beauty'
description: Image from the exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Where Everybody Knows Your Name, and Other Things About You, Too
description: There was a fascinating post over at the Gourmet Live site today, about restaurant hosts using the power of the Internet to identify those who come into their establishments. (Hat-tip to Eater  for, as they say, surfacing the material.)

title: Cronkites Summer Home Under Contract
description: WALTER CRONKITE was a summer fixture in Edgartown on Marthas Vineyard, often spotted taking the Clintons and other political bigwigs out sailing in his 60-foot yacht Wyntje. Now the summer home of Mr. Cronkite, the CBS news anchor known as the most trusted man in America, who died last year at the age of 92, has gone into contract, according to brokers on both sides of the deal.

title: Calling Mr. Mom?
description: You could easily compile statistics to make the case that women  at least Western women  are already empowered. In the United States, we are 50 percent of the workplace (and 51.4 percent of managerial and professional jobs). We receive three college degrees for every two earned by men (along with 60 percent of all masters degrees, about half of all law and medical degrees and 43 percent of M.B.A.s). Working wives are coming close to bringing in nearly half the household income. Single, childless urban women under 30 actually earn 8 percent more than their male peers.

title: A Wave of Indie Angst Hits South Asian Cinema
description: Bollywood, until recently the home of fine romances with no kisses, now takes smooching in stride. Did anyone expect the younger generation of South Asian filmmakers to stop there? How could they, growing up not only with Bollywood  itself only a portion of the Indian film business  but also with Hollywood, Hong Kong cinema, indies and all the global culture the Internet can deliver.

title: TimesCast: The Senate Race in Pennsylvania
description: The Timess Marcus Mabry and Megan Liberman discuss how the union vote in Pennsylvania could influence the outcome of the Senate race between Representative Joe Sestak, the Democratic candidate, and Pat Toomey, the former congressman and Republican candidate.

title: Desserts, Literary Women and Broadway Babies
description: Get your week off to a good start. And I dont mean with a big bowl of whole-grain oats and a jog. Im talking about chocolate. Lots and lots of it. Which is what youll get on Sunday morning during the Chocolate Crazy Dessert Fest walking tour. Meet at Sweet Revenge, which claims the title of being New Yorks only beer, wine and cupcake bar, for a dark chocolate cupcake. Then head to Jacques Torres, to pop a truffle before devouring a pain au chocolat from Franois Payards new bakery, FPB. Those misers not already in a sugar-induced coma can finish up with a scoop of handmade Argentine-style white chocolate ice cream from Cones. (11:30 a.m., 62 Carmine Street, at Bedford Street, Greenwich Village; 917-842-4319, walkingtoursmanhattan.com; $5 suggested donation for the Food Bank of New York City, plus the cost of your treats.)

title: M.L.S.: Theres an App for That
description: In time for the playoffs, Major League Soccer (which launched a newly designed Web site at the start of the 2010 season, not without a few fits and starts), released on Thursday an application for users of iPhones and iPod Touch devices.

title: BBC Journalist Destroys Protesters Sign
description: As Matt Wells reports on the Guardians Web site, a senior reporter for the BBC snatched a sign from the hands of an antiwar protester on Wednesday night and destroyed it, moments after concluding a live television report on the governments new austerity measures  which will cut the BBCs budget.

title: Calling Mr. Mom
description: This weeks New York Times Magazine is about womens empowerment, and in an essay in that issue I argue that the empowerment of women, at least in the Western world, now depends on men. Not as in men have to give their permission but rather men must be empowered too.

title: Storming Statehouses With Plans for Growth
description: MIAMI  Few issues have inspired as much voter anger this campaign season, or as many caustic campaign commercials, as the issue of jobs and how to put Americans back to work.

title: A Life-Saving Journey to the Dark Side
description: Inhale, a shrill, feverish melodrama about illicit organ trafficking, stars Dermot Mulroney as Paul Stanton, a rising district attorney in Santa Fe, N.M., who is willing go to any lengths to secure two lungs for his ailing young daughter, Chloe (Mia Stallard). The girl is dying of a rare respiratory disease, and Pauls search is a race against time that takes him across the Mexican border to Jurez.

title: The Latest Sherlock Hears a Who
description: Benedict Cumberbatch  best known to Americans as the reprehensible houseguest in Atonement  is currently enjoying the privilege of playing two of British pop cultures greatest heroes. Hes being paid for just one of them, though.

title: The Caucus Click: Harrodsburg, Ky.
A Nook for Books, Underground
description: THEY call it the commuters secret, these denizens of the Terence Cardinal Cooke-Cathedral branch of the New York Public Library. It is located down a flight of stairs, just outside the turnstile entrance to the No. 6 train on the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 50th Street. The door is next to a MetroCard machine. There is no street-level sign announcing its existence.

title: Rene Fleming Dropping Publicist
description: The soprano Rene Fleming is dropping her longtime publicist, Mary Lou Falcone, and assigning public relations duties to employees of her own office, the singers representatives said on Thursday. Ms. Falcone, one of the classical music industrys main P.R. agents, said the parting  which becomes official at the end of the year  was entirely amicable. Its the conclusion of a very wonderful business relationship, which still remains in terms of friendship, Ms. Falcone said. Its just simplifying her business situation by putting everything in house. Ms. Fleming was in Germany for a performance and unavailable for comment, her representatives said.

title: What Were Reading: Bernie Madoffs Slippers
Young Men Are Adrift; A Girlfriend Is Missing
description: Early in James M. Hauslers morose psychological thriller, Kalamity, Stanley, the deranged baby-faced manager of an electronics and car parts store in Northern Virginia, vents his fear and loathing of the opposite sex to his best friend, Billy. Women run everything: us, the world, he fumes. The more even-tempered Billy, whose five-year relationship with Alice recently ended, is sympathetic. Still obsessed with Alice, he complains that he finds himself replaying their conversations in his head like an answering machine loop. His thoughts are so vivid that in several scenes Alice materializes beside him in his car.

title: Children and Their Thems
description: Dario DAmbrosi certainly makes Bong Bong Bong Against the Wall, Ting Ting Ting in Our Heads, his people-and-puppet fantasy about children with mental disabilities, interesting to look at. But considering that back home in Italy Mr. DAmbrosi has for years been exploring theater by and about the mentally ill and disabled, the play shows a disappointing lack of insight.

title: Institutional Investing, Along Central Park West
description: THE impassive neo-Classic facade of the New-York Historical Society at 77th Street and Central Park West, now covered by construction scaffolding, is an odd duck on a residential street. But the historical society, opened in 1910, is part of Central Park Wests shadow civic history, and the museums and similar structures now there predate almost all of its apartment houses.

title: Central Park West's History, Institutions Included
description: Before the apartments moved in, Central Park West was home to more institutions like hospitals, theaters and societies.

title: Eight City Ballet Dancers Headed to Cuba
description: Dancers from New York City Ballet will perform at the International Ballet Festival in Havana next month, it was announced on Thursday. For the trip, under the auspices of the New York-based Cuban Artists Fund, eight principal dancers are going: Jared Angle, Tyler Angle, Megan Fairchild, Joaquin De Luz, Abi Stafford, Tiler Peck, Teresa Reichlen and Andrew Veyette. The program includes George Balanchines Tarantella; pas de deux from his Chaconne and Stars and Stripes; and a concert version of Who Cares. The dancers will also perform Jerome Robbinss In the Night and Other Dances and Christopher Wheeldons Liturgy. The performances will take place at the Teatro Mella on Nov. 1 and 2. American Ballet Theater is also performing at the festival.

title: When Tea Party Tops Ticket, House Democrats Look to Scald
description: 5:52 p.m. | Updated

title: A Can-Do Attitude for the Giants New Fullback
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tight end Bear Pascoe has been the Giants resident cowboy, a cattle-roping Californian with a taste for country music and an appreciation for the wide-open space on his familys ranch.

title: On the Streets of Lisbon, Love, Romance and Desire
description: The Portuguese Nun, obliquely inspired by a book of 17th-century love letters of enigmatic authorship, is itself, among other things, a love letter to the city of Lisbon. The long, patient opening shot floats through battered, beautiful streets as a fado  the passionate music that is to this city what blues is to Memphis  plays underneath. Several later scenes take place on a hotel terrace with an appealing view of an old hillside neighborhood, and a climactic encounter takes place in a Baroque church. There is more music, moonlight dancing on the water, and much sun-bleached limestone.

title: Longer Phone Power, and a Light Case, Too
description: Phone cases with built-in batteries are certainly a great way to keep your handset running during marathon phone sessions, if you dont mind carrying around a brick-sized device.

title: N.H.L. Has No Plans to Modify Rules on Hits to Head
description: Bill Daly, the N.H.L. deputy commissioner, said Thursday that the league is comfortable with the steps we have already taken to reduce concussions and had no plans to modify its new head-checking rule.

title: Top Corporations Aid U.S. Chamber of Commerce Campaign
Full Vision of Metropolis Includes Langs Vivid Wit
description: Fritz Langs Metropolis, surely one of the most intensely studied and widely imitated films of the silent era, grows more complex and mysterious as time goes on. This is partly because the movie has not been seen in the form its director intended since 1927. The German studio UFA cut Langs ambitious science-fiction allegory shortly after its initial domestic release, and the American version (distributed by Paramount) was trimmed by an hour and effectively rewritten, with title cards that altered Langs meaning. Over the years new material has been discovered, and fresh restorations have been offered, so that the further Metropolis recedes into history, the newer it becomes.

title: Juan Williams Signs New Contract at Fox News
description: One day after being fired by NPR, Juan Williams other employer, Fox News, offered him a new and more lucrative contract, the Los Angeles Times reported.

title: Tragic Love Tale of Spirits and Samurai
description: Pools of deepest black nearly engulf, with strange beauty and mystery, the characters in Kuroneko, a Japanese ghost story from 1968 about two avenging spirits and the brutal samurai they tick off. Shot in widescreen in stunning black-and-white 35 millimeter film and directed by Kaneto Shindo, Kuroneko had a brief run in New York in 1971 and doesnt seem to have been back since. A Criterion DVD appears to be forthcoming, but for now a new print has been struck and is available for your delectation at Film Forum.

title: Ask an Elite Runner
description: Did you ever want to ask an elite athlete about his or her training? The best foods to eat? What they think about during a race?

title: A Long Year for Thomas O. Hicks
description: Few sports owners have had as rough a year as Thomas O. Hicks.

title: Final: Phillies 4, Giants 2
description: The Phillies needed a team effort to stay alive in the National League Championship Series, and they got one. They manufactured three runs in the third inning and got a strong performance from their bullpen in a 4-2 win that narrowed the Giants series lead to three games to two.

title: Office Depot Settles Fair-Disclosure Charges
description: Its not often these days that the Securities and Exchange Commission charges companies with violating rules concerning fair disclosure of information.

title: After Online Success, an It Gets Better Book
description: It has been one month since the creation of It Gets Better, the viral video campaign intended to speak directly to gay youths who are the subject of bullying and homophobia.

title: 36 Hours in Asheville, N.C.
description: WHETHER its culture, the great outdoors or homegrown food and beer, Asheville takes its pleasures seriously. Playgrounds are equipped with rock-climbing walls. Bumper stickers exhort the locals to buy local. Theres even a fund-raising drive under way to erect a museum named for Bob Moog, the synthesizer pioneer, who lived in Asheville, that will trace the intersection of science and music. All this connoisseurship unfolds, to the benefit of the casual visitor, against the backdrop of the seriously beautiful Blue Ridge Mountains.

title: A Weekend in Asheville, N.C.
description: Against the backdrop of the seriously beautiful Blue Ridge Mountains, Asheville takes its pleasures seriously.

title: Sweat, Blood and Philosophy to the Rhythms of the Sweet Science
description: Pugilists and philosophers of all kinds converge in Frederick Wisemans mesmerizing documentary Boxing Gym. Owned by a tight knot of muscles named Richard Lord, a trainer with a rasp in his voice and a rattail hanging down his neck, the gym is in a former warehouse with no heat and no air-conditioning. There are no frills here, just men, women and children of assorted colors, means, grace, beauty and abilities meeting among the heavy bags and peeling posters, their fists and feet drumming different time signatures.

title: Kindred Spirits, Young and Mature
description: T Bone Burnett didnt perform much in the Speaking Clock Revue, the rootsy benefit concert at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night. It featured musicians he has produced as well as kindred spirits: the duo of Elton John and Leon Russell, Gregg Allman, John Mellencamp, Elvis Costello, Jeff Bridges, Jim James of My Morning Jacket, Karen Elson and the bluegrass patriarch Ralph Stanley.

title: Recalling a Collector of Bold Art and Life
description: Here Rests Peggy, a new work by Ivy Baldwin Dance, was drawn from several disparate sources: German Expressionist film, Peggy Guggenheims extravagant life and art collection, and, as the news release puts it, the constant crashing of the Ligurian Sea, which Ms. Baldwin encountered during a research fellowship in Bogliasco, Italy.

title: City and Union Agree to Wait on Release of Teacher Data
description: In an agreement with the teachers union, the city Department of Education said Thursday it would delay releasing the internal performance reviews of some 12,000 teachers that rank them according to their students progress on standardized tests.

title: 25 Years of Glass Eye Pix
description: Larry Fessenden, the filmmaker behind Glass Eye Pix, narrates a look at some of the company's films.

title: Full Seasons Ordered for Five CBS Hits
description: CBS underscored the early success of its new batch of prime-time series by giving out full-season orders to all five of them on Thursday.

title: Somnambuli | Elle Muliarchyk
description: A model transforms, with the help of high fashion, and gets her fortune read by various New York clairvoyants in Elle Muliarchyk's exclusive video for T.

title: Hall Splits With Coach and Will Leave Mammoth
description: Ryan Hall, who set records as the fastest American-born marathoner before struggling this fall, has left his longtime coach, Terrence Mahon.

title: Week 7 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 7. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: The Subway in Pictures
description: To mark the 106th birthday of the New York City subway system, a look at 10 decades of the subway.

title: A Show Is All Cyber, Some of the Time
description: It may seem like a stroke of morbid journalistic humor that the New Museums Free, a show exploring the Internet as a public art space, coincides with another exhibition titled The Last Newspaper. On the third floor, artists are toiling in a makeshift newsroom; on the second, theyre dismantling the last traces of print culture.

title: Why Cant Middle-Aged Women Have Long Hair?
description: MY mother hates it. My sister worries about it. My agent thinks Im hiding behind it. A concerned friend suggests that it undermines my professional credibility. But in the middle of my life, Im happy with it. Which is saying a lot about anything happening to my 55-year-old body.

title: 2010 Campaign Ads
description: Candidates around the country are running campaign ads criticizing Wall Street, and the city around it.

title: A Nook for Books, Underground
description: This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Timess Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New Yorks subway system. Go to The Subway Issue

title: Profit Climbs 71% at American Express
description: The American Express Company said on Thursday that its third-quarter profit jumped 71 percent as cardholders spent more and the company wrote off fewer unpaid bills.

title: Europe Tested as War Crimes Suspect Remains Free
description: BELGRADE  After 15 years on the run  sometimes in plain sight at soccer matches and weddings and sometimes deep in the fabric of this secretive city  Europes most wanted war-crimes suspect, Ratko Mladic, is being hidden by no more than a handful of loyalists, most probably in a neighborhood of Communist-era housing towers, according to investigators and some of his past associates.

title: The Hunt for Ratko Mladic
description: Ratko Mladic led the armed forces of the Bosnian Serbs during the Balkan wars of the early 1990s.

title: City Will Crack Down on Scofflaw Cyclists
description: The New York Police Department plans to step up enforcement of bicycle safety in parts of the city that have seen a disproportionately higher rate of collisions involving bicyclists, city officials said Thursday.

title: For Chevron, 2 Giant Gulf Drilling Ventures
description: Just nine days after the Obama Administration lifted the deepwater drilling moratorium, Chevron announced on Thursday that it was going forward with a $7.5 billion project to develop two giant deepwater fields in the gulf. The Jack and St. Malo fields hold in excess of 500 million barrels of recoverable hydrocarbons, the company said. Thats roughly equal to the worlds oil consumption in about five days  nothing to sneeze at.

title: Q&A: Reintroducing Printer to PC
description: Q.

title: Two Takes at NPR and Fox on Juan Williams
description: NPRs decision on Wednesday to fire Juan Williams and Fox News Channels decision on Thursday to give him a new contract put into sharp relief the two forms of journalism that compete every day for Americans attention.

title: In Lambertville, N.J., a Modern Classic for Sale
description: HOW MUCH $1.299 million. Taxes: $8,936.

title: Salem, the Sound of Givenchy
description: Salem is infamous for its alienating approach to the independent music business. So it was a little surprising to see the trio  John Holland, Heather Marlatt and Jack Donoghue  dutifully play a short set for their labels humdrum CMJ showcase on Tuesday night at Santos Party House. But thankfully, the band returned to dissonant form with Wednesday nights absurdly exclusive, secretive, hard-to-find, smoke-filled basement show at Ramiken Crucible, a narrow basement gallery no ones ever heard of that sits south of East Broadway, deep in the Lower East Side.

title: Coming Out Illegal
description: Leslie, a history major at the University of California at Los Angeles and an aspiring marathon runner with three part-time jobs and plans for grad school, keeps a neatly folded dark blue T-shirt in her closet among her jeans and her U.C.L.A. Bruins sweatshirt. Like an intimate detail, she reveals it cautiously, wearing it to campus events but not on the streets of Orange County; to a rally with a group of friends, but not alone on a crosstown bus. A senior at U.C.L.A. and the only child of a single working mother, Leslie is brave but not reckless: in the wrong place under the wrong circumstances, the T-shirts two words across the chest  Im Undocumented  are provocative enough to upend her life.

title: Making Hospital Chapel Welcoming to All Faiths
description: Looking resplendent in red vestments, the Rev. John Jimenez conducted mass on Monday before about 20 congregants and reminded them the date was the Feast of St. Luke. Luke is the patron saint of doctors, he said, so it has some special meaning here in the hospital.

title: Predators Gone, Small Fish Get Bolder
description: Little fish are cautious and timid around big, hungry fish, and rightly so. But when populations of predators like tuna and shark shrink because of human fishing, small prey are more adventurous, according to a coming study in The American Naturalist.

title: Kleiner Perkins and Partners Create $250 Million Social Fund
description: Hoping to capitalize on the popularity of social networking, the well-known venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is teaming up with heavyweights of the social Web to create a $250 million fund to invest in social start-ups.

title: New Faces Enter Fray in Accounting
description: As the great accounting fight of the past decade moves near to a conclusion that seems likely to satisfy no one, the cast of characters is suddenly changing. The two most important accounting bodies in the world will be under new leadership as they try to move on from bruising battles that have pitted them against banks, bank regulators and politicians.

title: From Dangerous Home to Safe House
description: One day last spring , just a couple of weeks after I opened a safe house for victims of domestic violence in Glendale, Ariz., my cellphone rang. I was doing schoolwork with my kids at home. A young woman was on the other end of the line, and she was crying. I need someone to come get me now, she said. If I go back home, I might not ever get out.

title: Left Wing Shudders as Its Presumed Leader Endures a String of Recent Setbacks
description: Three months ago, Aaron Peskin seemed poised to be the boss of this one-party town, following in the footsteps of former Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr., the strong-armed patronage king who was his political nemesis.

title: The Hot New Sound on the Scene? Oh, Yes, It is the Clarinet
description: Since the end of the big band era, the clarinet has taken a backseat to its sexier woodwind cousin, the saxophone. But in the Bay Area, thanks to a fertile environment of classically trained clarinetists with experimental sensibilities, the oft-overlooked instrument is having a moment.

title: Minds Over Baseball
description: Survivor and Criminal Minds lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday night. According to Nielsens estimates, Criminal Minds was the most watched show with 14.3 million viewers. Survivor: Nicaragua drew 12 million viewers. Fox ranked second with Major League Baseball playoff coverage, drawing approximately eight million viewers. NBC edged placed third over all, though its new series Undercovers (5.9 million) struggled. As usual, ABC earned its best ratings with Modern Family (11.9 million).

title: Hes a Big Man on a Mission
description: World Wrestling Entertainment continues its effort to meld violent sport with gooey, throwback family comedy in the claptrap road movie Knucklehead. In Legendary, released last month, the W. W. E. star John Cena played a wrestler; in Knucklehead the behemoth Paul Wight (billed as the Big Show) fights his way across the South to win enough money to save his orphanage  the one where, at 35, he still lives.

title: The Ice Age
description: The award-winning fashion designer Richard Chai has partnered with Daniel Arsham and Alex Mustonen of the avant-design firm Snarkitecture to create an elaborately carved ice cavern for a new pop-up shop opening Thursday evening. Conceived by Boffo, an art and culture nonprofit group, and the architect/writer Spilios Gianakopoulos to promote visibility for designers and artists, the project  titled Building Fashion  consists of a series of five rotating installations in a space underneath the High Line (504 West 24th Street). The five participating fashion designers (Simon Spurr, Heather Huey, House of Waris, Richard Chai and Siki Im), none of whom has a freestanding store, were each given the opportunity to create a three-dimensional representation of his or her brand. Chai said he wanted to avoid the straightforward clothes-on-a-rack retail space in favor of creating an environment, a feeling, more of an emotional experience. The cave, which is hand carved from high-density Styrofoam, also allows for irregular crevices and crannies to display merchandise. The store will carry Chais mens and womens collections and will be open to the public until Oct. 31 (noon to 6 p.m.), so head over there quickly before it melts.

title: Album Sales Report
description: You hear a lot about digital music these days, but CDs  which make up the majority of album sales  still count for a lot. Two weeks ago Lil Waynes album I Am Not a Human Being (Cash Money/Universal Motown), which was first for sale only as a digital download, opened at No. 2 on the Billboard album chart, and in its second week  still digital-only  it fell to No. 16. But then it came out on CD, and so in its third week the album has shot to No. 1 with 125,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The album leads a number of high-charting new releases. Darius Rucker, the Hootie and the Blowfish frontman who has reinvented himself as a solo country singer, opened at No. 2 with 101,000 sales of Charleston, SC 1966 (Capitol Nashville). Big Time Rush, the teen band and star of a Nickelodeon show, opened at No. 3 with 67,000 sales of B.T.R. (Nickelodeon/Columbia). And the Band Perry, a country trio of siblings, bowed at No. 4 with 53,000 sales of its self-titled debut, released by Republic Nashville. Eminems Recovery (Aftermath/Interscope) fell one spot to No. 5 with 50,000 sales, and Kenny Chesneys album Hemingways Whiskey (BNA) is No. 6 in its third week out, with just less than 40,000.

title: New Way to Help Chickens Cross to Other Side
description: Shoppers in the supermarket today can buy chicken free of nearly everything but adjectives. It comes free-range, cage-free, antibiotic-free, raised on vegetarian feed, organic, even air-chilled.

title: Dolores Park Groups Are Upset Over Vendors
description: The San Francisco Recreation and Park Department did not expect its decision to permit two vendors inside the Mission Districts popular Dolores Park to raise many eyebrows.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,331 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Amid Talk of Anthony, Knicks Prepare to Start
description: MONTREAL  The Knicks have moved on to their fourth country of the preseason, carrying rumors along with their luggage to each stop.

title: The Myth of Consensus Politics
description: Two years after an election that seemed to portend a new era of comity, American politics has resumed what now appears to be its permanent condition of polarization, quite possibly worsened by widening rifts within the two major parties.

title: Obama Talks With Steve Jobs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  President Obama met Thursday with Steve Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, the White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs, said.

title: Wal-Mart to Add Nook to Inventory of E-Readers
description: Starting Sunday, there will be another front in the e-reader retail war.

title: Pretty Women and Plenty of Cows
description: Who knows why Milk and Money, a daffy, enjoyable little film from 1996, never got much of a look the first time around. But its a treat to look at now, with some great older actors, a few younger ones who went on to bigger things and a script that has nothing on its mind but seeing how many incongruities it can string together.

title: Goldmans Proprietary Trading Desk to Join K.K.R.
description: Wall Street is holding a garage sale, and private equity firms are showing up to buy.

title: The State of Liberalism
description: Its a sign of how poorly liberals market themselves and their ideas that the word liberal is still in disrepute despite the election of the most genuinely liberal president that the political culture of this country will probably allow. Progressive is now the self-description of choice for liberals, though its musty and evasive. The basic equation remains: virtually all Republican politicians call themselves conservative; few Democratic politicians call themselves liberal. Even retired Classic Coke liberals like Walter F. Mondale are skittish about their creed. I never signed up for any ideology, he writes in his memoirs.

title: Kansas Governors Race Seen Redefining G.O.P.
description: PAOLA, Kan.  This state has been painted, unwillingly at times, as a caricature of a certain brand of conservatism. It was here that the State Board of Education challenged the theory of evolution, that an abortion provider was fatally shot at his church, and that a writer set his polemic Whats the Matter with Kansas?

title: Office Depot to Pay $1 Million to Settle S.E.C.s Fair Disclosure Charge
description: WASHINGTON  Office Depot and two of its executives agreed on Thursday to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that they violated fair disclosure laws in a case in which some investors and analysts were alerted that the company would not meet earnings estimates for the second quarter of 2007.

title: The State of Conservatism
description: Within the space of a week last summer, one judge in Arizona, ruling in a suit brought by the Obama administration, blocked a provision in a new state law permitting police officers to check the status of suspected illegal immigrants, while another blocked the implementation of a California referendum banning gay marriage. The two decisions imposed liberal policies that public opinion opposed. These things happen, of course. Congress had acted contrary to measurable public opinion when it passed health care reform in March. What made the two judicial rulings different was that both seemed to challenge the principle that it is the people who have the last word on how they are governed.

title: New Bush Exhibit Opens Rift at S.M.U.
description: DALLAS  For the first two years, George W. Bush managed his return to private work in Texas as a quiet transition.

title: Gay Conservative Group Attacks Congressional Democrats
description: Just as The Real Housewives of D.C. is drawing to a close, the nation is about to get The Real Democrats of Washington, D.C.

title: For 7.8 Million Californians, an Earthquake Drill
description: SAN FRANCISCO  To the high-pitched whine of emergency sirens, Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco crawled under a school desk with a group of fourth graders on Thursday.

title: Average College Debt Rose to $24,000 in 2009
description: College seniors who graduated in 2009 had an average of $24,000 in student loan debt, up 6 percent from 2008, according to an annual report from the Project on Student Debt.

title: Providing Equal Justice for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hairy Love Situation
description: Of the crop of gay-centered features from TLA Releasing at the Quad Cinema of late (Is It Just Me?, the musical Fruit Fly), the romantic dramedy BearCity certainly shows the most complexity. A group portrait in the West Village-Chelsea nexus, it covers a fair bit of emotional territory, although without amounting to much especially profound.

title: The Home Video Rises to Museum Grade
description: Neither life nor art has been the same since the hand-held video camera became increasingly available in the 1970s. And theyve been even less like themselves since YouTube came along in 2005, giving the world a continuously expanding bulletin board for moving images to which anyone can contribute just about anything. By now the YouTube video universe is, like the real one, large and complex beyond comprehension, and the repercussions for video art are equally hard to fathom.

title: Gaza: Donated Vans Driven From Egypt
description: Hundreds of pro-Palestinian activists drove scores of donated vans into Gaza on Thursday after Egypt let them pass through. Kevin Ovenden of Viva Palestina, a group in London that sponsored the aid convoy, said at a news conference in Gaza that Middle East peace could be achieved only by including Hamas, the Islamist group that governs Gaza. The convoy of 140 vans started its journey last month in London. A ship picked up the convoy in Syria this week and docked in the Egyptian port of Al-Arish in the northern Sinai. Egypt is set to send the rest of the cargo to Gaza via ground crossings with Israel. Israel and Egypt have imposed an embargo on Gaza because of their dispute with Hamas, but international outcry, especially after the killings of nine activists in a Turkish flotilla last May, has caused some easing in the policy.

title: White House Promotes Economic Efforts for Women
description: WASHINGTON  As one of its closing arguments before the midterm elections, the Obama administration is highlighting the impact its economic policies have had on women.

title: Making Music With Comedy
description: If Punching the Clown seems more polished than the usual low-budget indie comedy  the jokes more finely honed, the timing better  thats only as it should be. Henry Phillips (writer and star) and Gregori Viens (writer and director) have been working on this material for more than a decade. They have even made this movie already, as a documentary, in 1997.

title: Where Are the Great Lines of Yesteryear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Muslims Meet Punk
description: The Taqwacores aims for a provocative, anarchic cool by juxtaposing Islam and punk rock. But the storytelling is so muddled and the filmmaking so unpolished  and not in a good way  that mostly this movie is just unpleasant. Its also not nearly as insightful as it thinks it is.

title: Justice Thomass Wife, and the Call to Anita Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: Veterans Reaching Out for Help Online
description: As Cpl. Ricoh Danielson of the Army and his buddies left an Oklahoma Wal-Mart with a 12-pack of Corona and a case of Keystone Ice for a Fourth of July celebration, they passed a Middle Eastern-looking man accompanied by a woman wearing a head scarf. Just then, someone ignited a firecracker.

title: Campaign Spending and Election Outcomes
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. Eyes Drastic Cut in Payouts to Players
description: The N.B.A. wants to slash player income by at least $750 million annually  a stance that could trigger a lockout next summer.

title: N.F.L.s Policy on Helmet-to-Helmet Hits Makes Highlights Distasteful
description: For more than two decades, a recurring opening sequence on Monday Night Football featured an image of two helmets crashing into each other and exploding into smithereens.

title: Stem Cell Research Skirts Hurdles, but Raises Ethics Issues, Too
description: In an academic-corporate partnership that may represent the future of stem cell research, Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago has teamed up with a biotech company to begin the first human trials of a therapy derived from embryonic stem cells.

title: Communists in India Fight to Hold On to Mission
description: CALCUTTA  Lenins statue still rises near the center of the city, and portraits of Stalin and Marx still hang inside the biggest union hall. Anyone doubting the local political dominance  and cold war humor  of Indias Communists need only visit the street in front of the United States Consulate: It was long ago renamed for Ho Chi Minh.

title: In the Twilight of a Noted Theologians Life, the Words Still Go Forth
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: Republicans Find Cash Through New Group
description: Two Party System Inc., a recently formed group, has quietly raised hundreds of thousands of dollars from a small set of prominent Illinois businessmen and is spending the money largely to help Republican candidates for the General Assembly.

title: A Campaign About Computer Security, Couched in Plain English
description: IN recent weeks, drivers on Route 7 near Minneapolis may have noticed something unusual: once a week, a painting crew has been hoisted up to repaint a section on the left side of a billboard, from green one week to red the next and finally to blue.

title: Louisiana Builds Barriers Even as Oil Disperses
description: Three months after BP capped its runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, the state of Louisiana is still building a chain of sand berms off its coast to block and capture oil even as federal officials and many scientists argue that the effort will prove pointless.

title: States Affirm Tough Limits on Insurers Use of Dollars
description: WASHINGTON  State insurance commissioners on Thursday unanimously endorsed tough new standards that would require many health insurance companies to spend more of each premium dollar for the benefit of consumers.

title: The Bank Wins ...
description: The Dodd-Frank financial reform law is supposed to correct the problems and abuses that led to the crisis. It could take years to implement. Meanwhile, Wall Street is still engaged in many of the same practices. That was abundantly clear in Louise Storys article in The Times this week on securities lending, a multitrillion-dollar activity, both before the crash and today.

title: Slow Markets, Slow Bonuses
A Favorite Villain in Election Ads: New York
description: A Georgia congressman is shown driving around New York in a convertible with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, soaking in cheers at a ticker-tape parade on Wall Street and then basking in the bright lights of Times Square.

title: Sikhs Lament Obama Plan to Bypass India Temple
description: WASHINGTON  Sikhs in the United States expressed their frustration Thursday that President Obama would skip a tentatively planned visit to their holiest site in India, while advocacy groups called on the White House to reconsider.

title: Demonize, Then Demoralize
description: This years crop of negative political ads is fresh and repellent and headed for the landfill on Nov. 3. At least they aim to motivate voters, however basely.

title: The Shadow Knows
description: This is the sixth in a series.

title: Elvis Andrus Leads Rangers Revolution of Savvy Over Slugging
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  In Venezuela, some families like to break with tradition and give their children foreign-sounding first names of famous people who are not of Spanish heritage. At first glance, this might be an esoteric explanation for why the shortstop for the Texas Rangers, who was born in the central Venezuelan city of Maracay, is named Elvis Andrus.

title: Harry Reid: Man Up? Me?
description: Man up? Please, says Harry Reid.

title: Credit Cards Soon to Get a Makeover
description: The simple credit card is about to get a makeover.

title: Buffalos Passion for Paladino Wanes
description: BUFFALO  On a patch of grass in West Seneca, a town just south of Buffalo, a yard sign announces in bold black and orange that this is Carl Country. The same sign sprouted like crabgrass on lawns all over the area after Carl P. Paladino, a wealthy Buffalo real estate developer, scored an unexpected and lopsided victory in the Sept. 14 primary to become the Republican nominee for governor.

title: U.N. Doubts Fairness of Election in Myanmar
description: UNITED NATIONS  With just over two weeks until the first elections in Myanmar in 20 years, a United Nations envoy on Thursday questioned the fairness of the vote.

title: Report Assails Haiti Officers in Prison Killings
description: After officers had quelled the prison uprising in Les Cayes, Haiti, in January, Jacklin Charles, an unarmed detainee, was killed by a bullet to the head as he stood beside a tree in the courtyard. Several witnesses said that the chief of the antiriot police pulled the trigger.

title: Waging a Campaign of Her Own
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  When Notre Dame Coach Brian Kelly introduced his future wife to his father, she was spirited and fearless. She teased Paul Kelly about his awkward comb-over, which was met with stunned silence. Not long after, he shaved his head.

title: Pakistani Troops Linked to Abuses Will Lose Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will withhold training and equipment for about a half-dozen Pakistani Army units that are believed to have killed unarmed prisoners and civilians during recent offensives against the Taliban, according to senior administration and Congressional officials.

title: For Final, Pac-10 Decides Location Isnt Everything
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The soon-to-be Pacific-12 Conference, somewhere on the fast track to challenging the Big Ten and the Southeastern Conference as a major player in college athletics, decided it was not quite ready to go full speed ahead.

title: Afghanistan Today
description: Voters dont seem to be paying much attention to the war in Afghanistan and President Obama certainly isnt making it an issue. His administration is doubling down on the fight against the Taliban and showing mixed results. That may not sound like much, but even mixed results are an improvement over the utterly bleak situation of several months ago.

title: Giants Scrappy Lineup Could Be Right Mix
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Is That a Dagger I See?
description: Weve been waiting a long time for technology to deliver us an alternative reality, like the future in H.G. Wellss Time Machine, Neos Matrix, or the universe of code navigated by the Neuromancer hacker, Case. The future has arrived, finally  by the prosaic hand of our cellphones. Chances are it will soon be sponsored by laundry detergent or a fast-food chain.

title: For Democrats, Aqueduct Report Complicates a Difficult Election Season
description: ALBANY  For many prominent Democratic campaigns across New York State, the release of the state inspector generals searing Aqueduct Racetrack report on Thursday raised a dilemma.

title: Gates Dont Ask Memo Limits Discharge Policy
description: WASHINGTON  In the growing legal confusion at the Pentagon over the dont ask, dont tell law, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates issued a directive on Thursday that appeared to be a near moratorium on discharges of openly gay service members.

title: A Great Line, Taken Badly Out of Context
description: That public figures can be influenced by movies is an old story.

title: New Role Added to UConn Stars Rsum: Leader
description: The other day at basketball practice, Maya Moore cut one way, then changed her mind and reversed herself, leading to a turnover. Moore has done a lot of remarkable things in her career at Connecticut, but her coach, Geno Auriemma, was impressed with what she did next.

title: Big Gifts to G.O.P. Groups Push Donor to New Level
description: WASHINGTON  When Bob Perry, a wealthy home builder from Texas, emerged six years ago as a prime financer of the Swift Boat Veterans attack ads against Senator John Kerry, the 2004 Democratic presidential nominee, the political strategist Karl Rove was there to vouch for Mr. Perry.

title: Calling John Roberts
description: As 1997 wound down, Bill Clinton was in the White House, the Republicans controlled the Senate, and the Clinton administrations judicial nominees were going nowhere. Nearly one in 10 federal judgeships was vacant, a total of 82 vacancies, 26 of which had gone unfilled for more than 18 months. In Democratic hands back in 1994, the Senate had confirmed 101 nominees. In 1997, under the Republicans, the number dropped to 36.

title: Panel Is Facing Deadline on Immigrants Pardons
description: In May, as the federal government increased deportations and some states sought to tighten immigration enforcement, Gov. David A. Paterson caused a national stir by announcing a push in the opposite direction: a state effort to speed the granting of pardons to immigrants facing deportation for old or minor criminal convictions.

title: Out to the Yankee Game, but Only for 4 Innings
description: A pair of prosperous businessmen, having rushed up from downtown Manhattan, settled into their box seats on Wednesday afternoon, two rows from the Yankee Stadium field.

title: Italy: Clashes Erupt Over Waste Dumps
description: Hundreds of protesters set fire to garbage trucks and threw projectiles at the police on Thursday as a garbage crisis flared up near Naples. Tensions are running high in the towns of Terzigno and Boscoreale, outside Naples, where residents have clashed violently with the police in recent days, protesting the opening of waste dumping sites that they say are contaminating their towns. This week, officers used tear gas to disperse protesters and made six arrests, the police said. The crisis is seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has called resolving a similar garbage crisis near Naples in 2008 an important accomplishment of his government.

title: Britain: Case of the Purloined Feline
description: A British court was the venue on Thursday for the arresting story of a lawmakers wife, her husbands lover and the theft of a family kitten. Christine Hemming, 52, whose husband, John Hemming, is a Liberal Democrat member of Parliament for Birmingham, has been charged with stealing the tabby kitten from the home of Emily Cox, a researcher with whom Mr. Hemming fathered a child in 2005. Mr. Hemming, who describes his domestic situation as unclear, has posted an appeal for the kitten, named Beauty, which remains missing. If anyone has seen this kitten, please contact me at the House of Commons, he said.

title: Lottery Numbers
An Inquiry Into the Breed of Paladinos Pet, and a Sharp Response From His Campaign
description: It seemed like a harmless and responsible journalistic task meant to settle a question that had hung over the race for governor  at least in the pages of The New York Times.

title: Campaign Donors Betting on a Big Step for Boehner
description: Cash is pouring into the coffers of Representative John A. Boehner this midterm election season as interest groups jockey for influence with the Republican leader who may be the next speaker of the House.

title: British Fashion Victims
description: In the spring of 2010, fiscal austerity became fashionable. I use the term advisedly: the sudden consensus among Very Serious People that everyone must balance budgets now now now wasnt based on any kind of careful analysis. It was more like a fad, something everyone professed to believe because that was what the in-crowd was saying.

title: New Law Allows Homeowners to Recoup Legal Fees in Foreclosure Cases
description: A new state law signed in Albany this week will allow homeowners who win foreclosure proceedings to have the lender pay their lawyers fees.

title: Friday: Racing Form Data
description: I kept wondering how the answer Havens for folkies? could be plural, given the last two letters I had  IE. That was a good reminder of how important shifting gears can be. Havens is also a singers name.

title: On Further Review, the Coach Stands
description: Granted, the man has a lot to do. Like instilling professionalism, heart and fierce dedication in a frozen winter field full of young men. Like transforming a losing football team into a winning one in the span of a single season. And then leading that team to a series of history-making championships, including the first two Super Bowl titles.

title: Top Official to Investigate Police Conduct
description: The New York City Police Department has assigned a ranking official to look into a wide array of allegations of misconduct, including charges that crime complaints were ignored or manipulated, in the 81st Precinct in Brooklyn, according to two law enforcement officials with knowledge of the investigation.

title: Subway Preachers
description: Portraits of four underground preachers in the New York City subway.

title: Speaking of God, as Souls Hurry By
description: The graffiti has been replaced by advertising. The tokens have been replaced by MetroCards. But the subway preachers are a constant. They were there before I was born and will likely be there after I die  unless, of course, their occasional prophecy of the exact date that the world will end turns out to be accurate.

title: Yankees Can Draw Inspiration From Teams of Yore
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Since 1996, the dawn of a wildly successful era in pinstriped history defined by Derek Jeters steady presence at shortstop, the Yankees have played 30 postseason series. In only five of them have Jeters Yankees  21-8, with their current matchup with the Texas Rangers still to be decided  ever trailed by more than one game. Thus, as they try to battle back from being two games down in the American League Championship Series, they are in a somewhat unfamiliar position.

title: Thomass Wife Is Off Memo List
description: Justice Clarence Thomass wife, Virginia, asked to have her name removed from a memorandum that called President Obamas health care overhaul unconstitutional, as she distanced herself from an issue that may come before the Supreme Court.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Red Bulls Go From Worst to First
description: Dane Richards scored his fifth goal of the season in the first half and Joel Lindpere added an insurance score in second-half added time as the Red Bulls defeated the New England Revolution, 2-0, Thursday night in Harrison, N.J., and clinched first place in Major League Soccers Eastern Conference. The Red Bulls (15-9-6, 51 points) completed a worst-to-first season after winning only five games in 2009, when they finished in last place in the conference and had the fewest points (21) in the league. The Red Bulls will open the M.L.S. playoffs next week.

title: No Hangover for Mel Gibson
description: LOS ANGELES  Oops, never mind. Despite a flurry of reports that Mel Gibson was pointed toward a cameo appearance in The Hangover Part II, Warner Brothers and Legendary Pictures on Thursday joined the director Todd Phillips in a statement declaring that he was not. I thought Mel would have been great in the movie and I had the full backing of Jeff Robinov and his team, Mr. Phillips said in the statement, describing support from Mr. Robinov, a member of Warners office of the president.

title: Democrats Try to Revive Female Voters Enthusiasm
description: SEATTLE  Women came out strong for Barack Obama in 2008. Now, with barely 10 days before the midterm elections that are looking increasingly perilous for his party, he is trying to win them back.

title: Big Networks Block Web Shows From Google TV
description: In the latest sign that Google may struggle to transform television viewing with Google TV, its new service for Internet-connected TVs, three major broadcast networks and Hulu are blocking people from using the service to watch full-length TV shows on their Web sites.

title: Iowa Keeps Opponents Thinking Pink
description: When the legendary Iowa coach Hayden Fry got to Iowa City, one of the first things he did was redecorate.

title: Incursions Into CMJ Territory?
description: What are the boundaries of the CMJ Music Marathon? Is the event comprised of just the official showcases and panel discussions, for which you need a $495 identification badge? Or is it the whole official and unofficial shebang, with all the daytime shows and unsanctioned parties, whose sponsors may or may not mention CMJ in their announcements?

title: The Flock Comedies
description: For most of television history, sitcoms have been about families. From The Dick Van Dyke Show to All in the Family to The Cosby Show, TV shows have generally featured husbands and wives, parents and kids.

description: Wherever his Hobbit movies get made, Peter Jackson wants you to know he has a cast to appear in them.
