description: WASHINGTON  Living small is the new living large, at least when it comes to candidates running for election in November.

title: 7-Day Disabled List Is Under Discussion
description: Major League Baseball is considering establishing a seven-day disabled list to help teams deal with players who have concussions, a league official said Thursday. The idea of the new, shorter D.L. will be examined by a committee started by M.L.B. to set protocols as part of a more comprehensive concussion policy.

title: After Watching Berkman Tumble, Teixeira Sounds Off
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As Lance Berkman took a not-so-graceful backward tumble in foul territory Wednesday, Mark Teixeira watched in the dugout and winced  and not because his tender right hamstring was acting up. The warning track around the Yankee Stadium grass had claimed a victim.

title: Senate Forecast Update: Dont Call It a Comeback?
description: Its silly season for election watchers, that time of year where every uptick or downtick in the polls is assumed to have great meaning: the first tip-off to a last-minute comeback, or the first sign that a candidate who seemed to have his race locked up wont be able to close the deal.

title: Phillies Foil Giants and Force Game 6
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Chase Utley, late on a jittery night, leaped into the air, he realized he had left his feet too early and launched himself from the wrong spot. But when Utley, the Phillies second baseman, reached across his body, the baseball off the bat of Aubrey Huff  the one that seemed destined to land in right field and keep a rally alive  found a home in the far reaches of the webbing on Utleys glove.

description: Robert Katz, an author and screenwriter who incurred the wrath of the Vatican by accusing Pope Pius XII of failing to act to stave off a Nazi massacre of Italians in 1944, died Wednesday in Montevarchi, Italy, northeast of Siena. He was 77.

title: Elizabeth L. Sturz, Salvaged Troubled Lives, Dies at 93
description: Elizabeth L. Sturz, who started and ran renowned programs to help troubled youths and people suffering from both mental illness and drug addiction  all to further her goal to be of use  died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: Video Shows Stealth Nuclear Submarine Stuck in Scottish Mud

title: Weekly Pick Em: Sorting It All Out
description: When Texas lost to U.C.L.A. earlier this season, it looked as if it might be a rough year for the Big 12. But then Oklahoma, Missouri and Oklahoma State kept on winning. Those three are still undefeated, but this is the weekend when the Big 12 promises to shake itself out. Texas knocked Nebraska from the ranks of the unbeaten last week. Will the Cornhuskers be able to bounce back from that loss and do the same to Oklahoma State? Oklahoma travels to Missouri as the No. 1 team in the Bowl Championship Series standings, and the Tigers would love to prove their legitimacy by knocking off the Sooners. Speaking of legitimacy, Texas Christian does not seem as if it will get a legitimate chance at the national title, even if it keeps dominating opponents. The Horned Frogs face Air Force, which had been ranked until a loss last week. In the SEC, Louisiana State and Auburn are undefeated and in the top 10, but both seem to be searching for respect. Many think it is simply luck that has kept Les Miless bunch undefeated, while Cam Newton has kept Auburn winning despite a woeful defense. In the Big Ten, Wisconsin is coming off a huge win over Ohio State. Now the Badgers travel to Iowa, where they hope the running back duo of John Clay and James White will continue their productivity. Its a weekend where many teams will find out where they stand, and so will our prognosticators. As always, if you agree or disagree with the picks, or merely find them laughable, feel free to drop in a comment.

title: For Fans of Vivian Girls, an Intimate Inside Look
description: Sometimes CMJ can turn into an unlikely science experiment, allowing listeners to see their favorite bands dissected, its moving parts left out for all to see. On Thursday night, there were performances by the side projects of the two steady members of Vivian Girls, a band that, for all its charm and instinctual acumen, has not always seemed to have constituent parts to be broken into.

title: Honda Is Recalling 470,000 Vehicles for Brake Fluid Problem
description: Honda is saying that 470,000 vehicles could be involved in its latest recall, for brake fluid leaks, reports The Detroit News. It is the same problem for which Toyota issued its latest recall, of 740,000 vehicles in the United States. Honda and Toyota use the same supplier, the Advics Company in Japan, for the parts.

title: 2011 Porsche Cayenne
description: The new Cayennes styling changes are subtle, but they work.

title: Less Weight and More Sport for Cayenne Turbo
description: A FEW years ago, I drove a Porsche Cayenne Turbo S in Dubai, climbing monstrous sand dunes before heading out to a desolate desert road and reaching autobahn-worthy speeds. Not many vehicles could handle those two assignments on the same drive, and the Cayenne was unquestionably a marvel of engineering. But to what end?

title: Five-Star Accommodations in the Touring Class
description: GLENDORA, Calif.

title: Reaction to Rooneys Reversal: Man United Striker Signs New Deal
description: In a stunning turn of events, performed almost as quickly as he turns around defenders, Wayne Rooney signed a new deal to stay at Manchester United, only two days after he said his ambitions were greater than the clubs and he wanted to leave.

title: Paladino Says Race Is Closer Than Polls Suggest
description: For all those New Yorkers who think he is too angry, too mercurial or too rash to be governor, Carl P. Paladino has a message: Im not a terrorist.

title: Ties That Bind, and Ties Iraqis Scrutinize on Their Leader
description: BAGHDAD  As Iraqs prime minister toured the region to court support for his political coalition, the buzz in the Iraqi city that lies closest to Iran has centered on what he was wearing  or not  around his collar.

title: Phantom Sequel Going Underground While Changes Are Made
description: Detractors of the Phantom of the Opera sequel, Love Never Dies  it has a few  who would like to see that Andrew Lloyd Webber musical shut down are about to get their wish, for a few days anyway. The West End production of Love Never Dies at the Adelphi Theater will close from Nov. 22 through Nov. 25 while its producers make changes to the show, the Web site Official London Theater reported.

title: A Familiar Brand, if No Longer for Motorcycles
description: AMONG those whose passions include vintage Japanese motorcycles, Bridgestone is a familiar name, usually as the brand of tires fitted to Hondas, Kawasakis, Suzukis and Yamahas from the 1960s. But keen enthusiasts, collectors and restorers know that Bridgestone the tire maker also produced motorcycles  innovative bikes that sold in small numbers when new, but are increasingly sought-after today.

title: How Porsche May Outmaneuver a Securities Suit
description: Porsche appears ready to speed away back to Germany.

title: Lotus of Siam Coming to New York
description: Feast gets the manager of Lotus of Siam in Las Vegas, which Jonathan Gold once called the single best Thai restaurant in North America, to confirm that it is taking over the former Cru location on lower Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, which had been previously rumored on Eater.

title: Im Too Sporty for My Freeway
description: THE ideal spot for a billboard advertising a new car is along a high-traffic road where lots of drivers poking along in grille-to-tailgate traffic have time to read it. Yet those same clogged thoroughfares would be the worst possible places to savor the performance features of a sporty sedan.

title: Dear FloFab: My Names Not Sweetie
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: 3 Hybrids By Porsche Tailored To the Task
description: SORTING through the choices among electric and hybrid drive systems to pick the type best matched to ones driving needs can be a formidable task for new-car buyers  and by all indications, its only going to get more complicated.

title: What Were Reading
description: Chicago Tribune: Did a woman try to murder her nut-allergic husband with hazelnut gelato? One of many horrifying tales in this round-up of scary customers, in time for Halloween.  Pete Wells

title: Inside the List
description: BIEBER SCHNITZEL: Forget the midterm elections. Lets talk about Justin Bieber (!), who, in Justin Bieber. First Step 2 Forever: My Story, overcomes childhood adversity and bad punctuation to land at No. 2 (!!) on the childrens hardcover chapter book list, presumably after a precision spin. (Ill admit, the copy I read on the subway was concealed inside the dust jacket of the more age-appropriate Rick Springfield autobiography Late, Late at Night, new at No. 13 on the grown-up hardcover nonfiction list.)

title: Slither Room
description: A fisherman, according to an old Russian proverb, can spot another fisherman from far away. This is true. And within the fishing clan there is a set of private yet shared moments that bond fishermen together in an almost spiritual communion. The explosion of spray and color when a big fish charges a topwater lure. The devastating ping of snapped line after that same fish makes a last desperate surge and claims its freedom.

title: Criminal Mind
description: The stranger wore a white rabbit fur toque for its symbolism of purity. Inside his hobo sack he carried necessary accouterments of the wandering class and various weapons, including a knife and wooden clubs. Eventually, he adopted a dog and a pet magpie, and toted an accordion. The instrument he could not play well. The animals he clubbed to death as a horrified witness looked on. He was Joseph Vacher, a former soldier who roamed the French countryside from 1894 to 1897, killing more than twice as many people as Jack the Ripper, and the antagonist of Douglas Starrs absorbing historical true-crime book, The Killer of Little Shepherds.

title: In the Eyes of Others
description: Western societies got weird in the 19th century. I mean that not as an insult but as an acronym. The cultural psychologists Joe Henrich, Steve Heine and Ara Norenzayan recently showed that many psychological processes work differently in people raised in Western, educated, industrialized, rich and democratic (WEIRD) societies. The normal, or default, mode of human cognition, for example, is holistic, given to seeing relationships among elements, but people in WEIRD societies think more analytically. They see a world full of discrete objects, like balls on a billiard table, whose properties are best analyzed individually.

title: Place of Last Resort
description: In his 1943 study of E. M. Forster, Lionel Trilling described Howards End, published in 1910, as a novel about the rights of property, about a destroyed will-and-testament and rightful and wrongful heirs. It asks the question, Who shall inherit England?  A century later, the British novelist Rose Tremain has given us Trespass, a dark and unflinching novel that is also about rights of property, in this case to a former silkworm hatchery called the Mas Lunel, in the Cvennes region of France. The question, however, is not Who shall inherit France? It is Shall France be inherited by its occupiers?

title: Just Win
description: The Washington Huskies werent breaking new ground here. Here is a college football program that sacrifices its players long-term well-being and its communitys dignity for the sake of winning; that looks the other way when stars are accused of violent crimes; that skirts ethics off the field while pursuing perfection on it. Which sounds bad, but in a boring way. What the investigative reporter Ken Armstrong and the higher-education correspondent Nick Perry have done, first in an award-winning Seattle Times series and now in Scoreboard, Baby, is lay out  in hard-boiled style and with the verve only real storytelling can supply  exactly whose lives were mangled in the course of the University of Washingtons historic 2000 season. Their idiosyncratic characters and plots ultimately indict a vast, impersonal system that has produced dozens of such teams. The Huskies didnt break new ground here, but in so comprehensively detailing them, the authors did.

title: Teen Spirit, Soured
description: Too often, our comfort zones are our tombstones. We settle into numbing patterns and thats that  wake me when its over. Not so in the frenetic world of James Franco, whose ambition over the past few years has manifested almost as performance art: hes been affiliated with multiple M.F.A. programs, in fiction, poetry and filmmaking; hes angling to add Dr. to his name, having recently become a Ph.D. aspirant at some shabby school called Yale. Oh, and in case your particular comfort zone is a cave, hes a pretty successful actor, too.

title: Final Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Rediscovering Philip Roth
description: To the Editor:

title: The Courage to Speak
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors Choice
description: GREAT HOUSE,  by Nicole Krauss (Norton, $24.95.) In this tragic vision of a novel, Nadia, a writer in New York, is faced with a wrenching parting when a young girl shows up to claim an enormous desk that has been in her safekeeping for decades.

title: Up Front
description: Midterm elections have become an occasion for recalibrating the balance of power between the major parties.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE PRIVILEGES,  by Jonathan Dee (Random House, $15.) In this contemporary morality tale, as our reviewer, Roxana Robinson, called it  assuming you can write a morality tale about people without morals  a young golden couple marry, have children and become incredibly wealthy from insider trading. Dees intelligent and ambitious book proposes that the family is essential to society, that we abandon it at our peril, Robinson said. She praised the elegance, vitality and complexity of Dees writing.

title: Dont Landfill That Goose. Braise It.
description: The key to delicious Canada goose, Jackson Landers says, begins at the moment of death.

title: Fabulous Dead People | Laura Ashley
description: People tend to think of Laura Ashley as being ironically fabulous; actually, she was genuinely fabulous. When Ashley introduced mix-and-match home furnishing fabrics in tiny florals in the 60s, it was the shot heard round the world. Prints with reversible ground and motif colors became her signature. Some of them were twee, but they raked in millions. Its a look the industry has been feeding off ever since.

title: Key European Matchups: Serbian Grudges
description: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

title: Halladay Earns Himself, and the Phillies, a Reprieve
description: If you feel some strange forces at work in these baseball playoffs, you are not alone. Just as both league championship series were speeding toward installing the plucky underdog in the World Series  much to the chagrin of television executives, the giant robot that calculates the Yankees payroll and Bud Seligs cardiologist  the big-bucks teams fought back, at least for a game. Like the Yankees a day before, the Phillies fought off elimination, cueing the conspiracy theorists and prompting all those television executives to put the paper bags away.

title: Off the Menu: Eolo and Ta Pol
description: Melissa Muller-Daka is serious about the cooking of her native Sicily. At Eolo she has devised a menu [pdf] as a showcase for dishes like maccu cu grancio (fava bean puree with ricotta, carb and wild fennel), tummala del gattopardo (a round of pastry filled with pasta and meatballs), pisci spada cu cus-cusu (swordfish with cous cous). She is in the kitchen and her husband, Tarek Daka, is running the little restaurant named for the Aeolus, god of winds of Greek mythology, in homage to Sicily in ancient times as Magna Graecia.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE MADE-UP SELF  Impersonation in the Personal Essay.  By Carl H. Klaus.  University of Iowa Press, paper, $19.95.

title: Doubts Persist on Gulf Sand Barriers
description: In Fridays paper I write about the construction of sand berms off the Louisiana coast, a project that began at the height of the oil spill and continues today, despite the rapid dilution of the remaining oil in the gulf.

title: Suffolk Police and Immigrants Meet at the Volleyball Net
description: BRENTWOOD, N.Y.  The police officers poured out of sport utility vehicles that looked barely large enough to contain their brawny frames. Then the day laborers arrived, their narrow shoulders as spindly as the old bicycles they rode.

title: Envisioning a Sustainable America
description: Im attending a meeting at my new home, Pace University, exploring the need for an increased focus within the study and practice of law focused on sustainable development.

title: How Porsche May Outmaneuver a Securities Suit
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: A Bertoia Sculpture Is Dismantled
description: A sculptural screen of 800 floating metal panels by the artist Harry Bertoia is being dismantled and moved from its home on the second floor of the Fifth Avenue building that is now owned by JPMorgan Chase. The 1954 building, which Gordon Bunshaft originally designed for Manufacturers Hanover Trust, is a landmark, but that designation protects only the exterior of the building, not the interior or Bertoias 70-foot-wide, 20-foot-high screen.

title: From Bomb to Bust
description: Theres been lots of ink and oceans of pixels spilled on the question of whether the Internet has killed film criticism, but the very short answer is that serious (if unpaid) criticism has thrived on the Web. The problem is that its all too serious: you dont have to strain your Google finger to find a knowledgeable enthusiast expending 8,000 words on Ozu or Leone. Locating someone who can write succinctly and intelligently on, say, the 1985 Christmasploitation extravaganza Santa Claus: The Movie is much harder.

title: U.S. Offers Pakistan Army $2 Billion Aid Package
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the Obama administration moved to stop training and equipping Pakistani Army units that have killed civilians in the offensive against the Taliban, the United States said Friday that it planned increased aid for Pakistans military over the next five years.

title: CHARTER BECOMES 'LAW OF NATIONS,' 29 RATIFYING IT
description: Washington, Oct. 24--The United Nations World Security Organization came into being when the Soviet Government in mid-afternoon deposited its instrument of ratification, the twenty-ninth necessary to bring this about, and James F. Byrnes, Secretary of State, then signed the protocol at 4:50 o'clock, Eastern standard time, formally attesting that the Charter of the United Nations has come into force.

title: Bob Kane, 83, the Cartoonist Who Created 'Batman,' Is Dead
description: Bob Kane, the cartoonist who created Batman the Caped Crusader and his sidekick, Robin the Boy Wonder, died on Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 83 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Picasso: Protean and Prodigious, the Greatest Single Force in 70 Years of Art
description: There was Picasso the neoclassicist; Picasso the cubist; Picasso the surrealist; Picasso the modernist; Picasso the ceramist; Picasso the lithographer; Picasso the sculptor; Picasso the superb draftsman; Picasso the effervescent and exuberant; Picasso the saturnine and surly; Picasso the faithful and faithless lover; Picasso the cunning financial man; Picasso the publicity seeker; Picasso the smoldering Spaniard; Picasso the joker and performer of charades; Picasso the generous; Picasso the Scrooge; even Picasso the playwright.

title: U.N. Awaits Peking Delegates; Taipei Clings To Affiliate Ties; Rogers Calls Ouster A Mistake
description: United Nations, N. Y., Oct. 26--A delegation representing Communist China, which was voted into the United Nations last night, is expected to arrive here this week to take its seat, diplomats close to the Chinese said today.

title: Mahalia Jackson, Gospel Singer, And a Civil Rights Symbol, Dies
description: Mahalia Jackson, who rose from Deep South poverty to world renown as a passionate gospel singer, died of a heart seizure yesterday in Little Company of Mary Hospital in Evergreen Park, Ill., a Chicago suburb. She was 60 years old, and had been in poor health for several years.

title:
THE JORDAN-ISRAEL ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW; ISRAEL AND JORDAN
SIGN A PEACE ACCORD
description: ARAVA CROSSING, Israel, Oct. 26 -- At this desert outpost along their border, desolate except for their hopes, Israel and Jordan signed a peace treaty today to put behind them 46 years of war, mistrust and fear for tomorrow.

title: Night Watch: Communications 101
description: At a Seattle backyard chat, President Obama suggested on Thursday that his administrations record had been distorted because of poor communication about what it had accomplished.

title: OUR SUBWAY OPEN, 150,000 TRY IT
description: Figures gathered by Times reporters at midnight:

title: Her Poetry, Not Her Death, Is Her Triumph
description: Great Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company is bringing an evening of Sylvia Plath to the Brooklyn Academy. Her work, including "Three Women," the only verse play she ever wrote, is to be in repertory with Shakespeare's "Richard II" starting Tuesday. This is prestigious indeed. Why Plath and why now?

title: Between Sisters
description: Danielle Evanss whip-smart first story collection charts the liminal years between childhood and the condition dubiously known as being a grown-up. Told from a close distance, these stories lack the rich patina of hindsight, their pleasures coming instead from an immediacy and an engaging voice. They evoke the thrill of an all-night conversation with your hip, frank, funny college roommate.

title: Ask an Expert About Gambling Addiction
description: As a growing number of states turn to gambling as a source of additional revenue, compulsive gambling is on the rise.

title: The Queen of Crafts and the Willowy Miss M.
description: OH, my God, Martha, said Bette Midler to Martha Stewart. Why am I not you?

title: Liberty's Great Statue
description: The statue of Liberty yesterday was seen through a mist darkly. Piercing winds blew around Bedlow's Island, and the numerous workmen, who were not in any way protected from the weather, worked uncomfortably. The speakers' stand, and that for the use of musicians above it, were in readiness yesterday. Planks were removed and a semblance of tidiness was given to the island. A big barge, which looked extremely dismal, with its legend in red characters, "Eat, drink, and be merry," stood at the Bedlow's Island dock to land visitors. It will be used for that purpose this afternoon.

title: Dr. Jonas Salk, Whose Vaccine Turned Tide on Polio, Dies at 80
description: Dr. Jonas Salk, who in the 1950's developed the first successful vaccine against poliomyelitis, the viral illness that had gripped a fearful nation with images of children doomed to death or paralysis, died yesterday at Green Hospital in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 80.

title: CNBC: An Interview With Harry Reid
description: John Harwood interviewed Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada about his challenging race against Sharron Angle, his Republican candidate and Tea Party favorite.

title: Justice Thomass Ex-Girlfriend Speaks Out
description: Just days after the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas left a surprise voice mail message for Anita Hill, Mr. Thomass former girlfriend is speaking out.

title: Serving Up Vegetables With Eggs
description: Egg dishes can be a great way to serve up more vegetables at dinner time, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Ali Regains Title, Flooring Foreman
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Wednesday, Oct. 30 -- Under an African moon in the darkness before dawn today, a bee battered a lion as Muhammad Ali registered an eighth-round knockout of George Foreman and regained the world heavyweight title at the age of 32 after a lapse of more than seven years.

title: Fred W. Friendly, CBS Executive and Pioneer in TV News Coverage, Dies at 82
description: Fred W. Friendly, the former CBS News executive who was a towering figure in the evolution of news coverage on television, died Tuesday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 82.

title: When A Child Moves to Nepal
description: In The New York Times Magazine this weekend, Nick Kristof has a story examining what he calls D.I.Y. Foreign Aid  what he says is the emerging trend of individuals creating their own philanthropies and setting out to change one small part of the world.

title: A New Resource for L.G.B.T. Seniors
description: Weve written in The New Old Age on occasion about the particular challenges that gay men and lesbians face as they age: the financial inequities that result from federal and state governments declining to recognize same-sex marriages; the fears of discrimination in senior housing and programs; the frequent reliance, when family support is missing, on friends who are aging as well.

title: Double-Fault
description: Everyone knows that pop culture is bonkers for brooding, romantic, dangerous types with underworld connections. I am speaking, of course, of vampires. But a long time ago, before Bella and Edward even started dating, there was another dark romantic hero who captured our imaginations. He was called a spy. He drank gin or whiskey, not blood. He was preferably English. Educated. And if he had to kill someone he did it like a gentleman, which is to say with a poisoned dart at the end of an umbrella.

title: Bad Company
description: I am a celebrity  broadly speaking  spokesperson for a company I always loved. I shop there, enjoy its aesthetic and admire its charitable giving. But Ive learned that its labor practices here and abroad are not so admirable, and Im ashamed I took the job. May I use my Web site to promote organizations that oppose such practices  anti-sweatshop groups, for example? Would donating some of my spokesperson money to charity offset any harm I do? And most important, may I keep this job? NAME WITHHELD, CALIFORNIA

title: Monetizing Motherhood
description: BlogHer 10, a conference focused on women and the blogosphere, offered two days of panels and discussions at the New York Hilton this past August. One panel that drew a standing-room-only crowd was about Federal Trade Commission guidelines regarding online advertising disclosures. While other discussions, about activist bloggers, Radical Blogging Moms and social- or community-change blogs, may suggest more obvious ideas (or at least hopes) about online empowerment, the intense interest in what the F.T.C. rules might mean to certain bloggers is telling. Web empowerment isnt always just about having your voice heard; it can also be about money.

title: Childhood Attachments
description: Its not hard to understand why an introspective writer like Myla Goldberg, who gravely examined a sensitive childs yearning to be special in her first novel, Bee Season, might want to switch to a genre format to write a going-back-home narrative of adult self-discovery. Within the conventional novel, it takes some tricky maneuvers to return a grown-up child to the family bosom. Traditional holidays and reunions still serve for short visits, although youre probably sick to death of those predictable flare-ups over the Thanksgiving turkey. But extended stays demand something more dramatic in the way of a plot. While the death of an elderly parent or an ailing sibling works in theory, it shifts the attention away from the prodigal child. And that can be a real problem when the writers primary interest is in sending the protagonist back to revisit his or her younger self, not to fuss over funeral arrangements and be upstaged by the dearly departed.

title: Party and Punishment
description: In April, after years of the online tabloids pushing photos of Lindsay Lohan looking undone in the back seats of limousines, Dr. Drew Pinsky, the TV addiction specialist, offered his opinion of Lohan to one of those Web sites.

title: Making Bette Midlers Costume
description: Martha Stewart and Bette Midler create Ms. Midlers Hulaween ball costume during a recent taping of The Martha Stewart Show.

title: A Glimpse Into the World of Shady Medical Billing
description: Gregory Vinarsky ran his business with a few ground rules.

title: Let the Sun Shine In
description: When I started writing this article a little more than a month ago, I hadnt yet had two bulging disks flare up, putting me in excruciating pain. I hadnt yet had a neck epidural where, as I sat in a hospital gown designed for someone three times my size, the R.N. inserted the IV into the arm on the side that was in such distress. I hadnt had to spend my half hour of recovery time in a Nightingale ward  those wards with rows of beds divided by the thinnest of sliding curtains that allow you to hear all the particulars of your neighbors condition and all the sounds of their discomfort. I hadnt had to sit in a row of wheelchairs (no other seating was provided) while waiting to consult with the surgeon after the procedure.The procedure went fine and Im slowly improving, but in my woozy post-op state I had ample time to think yet again about how the experience of health care could be so vastly improved.

title: The Many Colors of Kenyas Matatus
description: A couple of days ago, I wrote about Itasha, a recent car trend in Japan where enthusiasts cover their cars with characters from Japanese anime and video games, and comic book logos.

title: Weekend Competition: Define Middle Class
description: This Weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting definitions of middle class.

title: The Donor
description: As the co-chairwoman of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, whose $33 billion endowment makes it the largest private foundation in the world, youve focused your efforts on the health and welfare of women in developing countries.  Women and children. Its been a passion of mine for a long time, but now youre seeing the world do it.

title: How to Cook a Canada Goose
description: Our pals at City Room have been talking with Jackson Landers, a hunting instructor and locavore activist based in Virginia, who is coming to Brooklyn next Saturday to teach New Yorkers how to cook Canada geese. The visit was prompted by the federal governments disposal of some 400 Canada geese in Prospect Park, and subsequent comments about that act on the premises of the City Room blog. Mr. Landers will be cooking with another fellow with an interesting name, Leighton Edmondson, who has cooked at Jimmys No. 43, among other places.

title: On the Mend
description: The narrator of Thomas McGuanes new novel, Driving on the Rim, is a Montana doctor who was given the name Irving Berlin Pickett by his patriotic, evangelical mother, after the writer of God Bless America. Berl, as hes known, describes himself as irritable, hypercritical, obsessively orderly, claustrophobic, impatient, antisocial and agoraphobic, filled with objectless dread, pessimistic and fault-finding. All this might be true, but hes also a good doctor, and hes funny, sometimes with a sharp, sardonic wit and sometimes with a goofy self-deprecation. In the way of McGuanes earlier American quasi heroes, hes both competent and hapless, discovering, in his search for meaning, that I was remarkably unformed for a man of my age and experience.

title: The Grass Is Really No Greener Next Door
description: CHICAGO  The backyard barbecue, that homey symbol of suburban togetherness, occasions conflagrations emotional and literal in the terrific new play Detroit, by Lisa DAmour, at the Steppenwolf Theater here. This scary-funny comedy, set in a nameless housing tract possibly, but not necessarily, outside the city of the title, speaks to the fractious, frightened American moment more perceptively than any play Ive seen on a New York stage.

title: The Art of Social Change
description: In 1929, the Church of Scotland Mission, which had a long and successful history of missionary work among the Kikuyu in colonial Kenya, began a campaign to eradicate the practice of female circumcision. The results were hardly what church members hoped for. Large numbers of Kikuyu left the church, and Kenyas leading anticolonial political organization mounted a vigorous attack on the churchs policies. Female circumcision became a nationalist issue, and a custom that might have gradually disappeared grew further entrenched. Nearly 40 percent of Kenyan women today are estimated to have undergone some form of it.

title: An iPhone Artist Haunts the Subways
description: This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Timess Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New Yorks subway system. Go to The Subway Issue

title: An Uncompromising Woman
description: Tell them to stop leaning on the fence! Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, president of Liberia and the first woman ever elected head of state on the continent of Africa, ordered the leader of her security team. We were driving along one of the scarce paved avenues in her nations capital, Monrovia. With her convoy rode United Nations gunmen, part of a peacekeeping force of 10,000 charged with preventing a conflagration in the aftermath of 14 years of horrific civil war. The fighting ended in 2003, but outside the windows of Sirleafs S.U.V., the skeletons of abandoned buildings and the cries, at once thrilled and desperate, of the onlookers along the presidents route were signs of the countrys position near last on any list of how well the worlds nations are functioning.

title: Vain Glorious | Supersmile Tooth Polish
description: What: Supersmile Quickee No Brush/No Rinse Whitening Tooth Polish.

title: Creativity Before It Vanishes
description: This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Timess Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New Yorks subway system. Go to The Subway Issue

title: Going to the End of the Line
description: An interactive tour of the stops on the New York City subway beyond which you can ride no farther.

title: Riding the Q Train
description: Six reporters and four photographers from The Times boarded a subway car on the Q line in an attempt to take a demographic snapshot.

title: Bottle of Cristal, Please
description: A friend recently hosted a large dinner at an upscale restaurant. We were presented the regular menu, and the server advised us of some expensive specials as well. Most of us ordered moderately priced items off the menu, but some of our table mates ordered much pricier specials. Was that a boorish choice?

title: 10 Questions: Harry Reid
description: Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada and the majority leader, is battling the Republican challenger Sharron Angle in one of the most closely watched races of the 2010 campaign. Mr. Reid discussed his bid for a fifth term with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC at the Gritz Caf in Las Vegas. Below is a condensed, edited version of their conversation.

title: Pirate Latitudes
description: Whats up, you might ask, with the Sir David Lean-ish title? For 50 years, Elmore Leonard has specialized in hoodlums who ply their trade in tacky, unexotic locales: guys like Chili Palmer, the Miami loan shark whose moviemaking aspirations take him to B-list Hollywood in Get Shorty (1990), and Stick Stickley, the Detroit ex-con whose heisting aspirations take him to the gutter-ball precincts of Chilis Miami in Stick (1983).

title: Israeli Sets World Record by Playing 523 People Simultaneously
description: Alik Gershon, a 30-year-old Israeli grandmaster, set a world record on Thursday by playing 523 people simultaneously in Rabin Square in Tel Aviv.

title: Lohan Is Sent Back to Rehab
description: A Los Angeles judge ordered Lindsay Lohan to remain in a drug rehabilitation program until Jan. 3 after Ms. Lohan violated the terms of her probation, CNN.com reported. Judge Elden S. Fox of Los Angeles County Superior Court, who made the ruling on Friday morning, had previously ordered Ms. Lohan, the star of Mean Girls and Freaky Friday, to be sent to jail in September and to be held without bail after she failed a drug test she had been ordered to take as a condition of her probation. But that decision was quickly overturned and Ms. Lohan, after being freed on $300,000 bail, checked into the Betty Ford Center. Ms. Lohan, who faced up to 30 days in jail for the violation, was ordered to return to the court on Feb. 25.

title: In Potash War, Is Saskatchewan the New Venezuela?
description: The government of Saskatchewan has waded into the middle of Potashs takeover battle, officially opposing BHP Billitons $39 billion unsolicited bid.

title: TimesCast | October 22, 2010
description: Hidden campaign donations; baseball playoffs and sketching subway passengers in a new way.

title: The Windows Phone 7 Review Roundup
description: For a while it seemed that the competition in the smartphone space was going to consist of an unfair fight between the Apple iPhone, Research in Motions BlackBerry and a few bedraggled stragglers. But over the last year, new products have made their way into the marketplace, including Googles Android platform, and the competition has heated up.

title: Chris Rock Takes On Broadway in Hat
description: The comedian Chris Rock will make his Broadway debut this spring in Stephen Adly Guirgis new play The ________ With the Hat (obscenity deleted) as an Alcoholics Anonymous sponsor working with a recovering addict (to be played by Bobby Cannavale) whose long-time love (Elizabeth Rodriguez) remains in the grip of drugs and alcohol.

title: Paterson Fires Environmental Commissioner
description: Gov. David Paterson dismissed Alexander B. Grannis, New York States top environmental official, Thursday night in a dispute over budget cuts. Last spring, Mr. Grannis shared his views with the Green blog on the 40th anniversary of the first Earth Day, which he helped organize in his youth.

title: They Fetch, They Roll Over, They Aid Tumor Research
description: An operation commonly performed to remove brain tumors from the pituitary glands of humans is now available to dogs, thanks to a collaboration between a neurosurgeon and some veterinarians in Los Angeles. And that is turning out to be good for humans.

title: Rooneys U-Turn Requires Some Spin
description: LONDON

title: Bold Face Milan
description: MIUCCIA PRADA

title: Strip-Search Talk Roils Massachusetts Race
description: The candidate seen as the Republicans best chance of picking up a House seat in Massachusetts is back under scrutiny over whether he witnessed and covered up the assault of a female teenager when he was a police sergeant nearly two decades ago.

title: The Search for Gold in Congo
description: As the price of gold nears $1,000 per ounce, demand is strong. In Congo, workers mine gold by hand from open pits.

title: Obama Making National Security Appointment
description: 3:04 p.m. | Updated President Obama announced Friday that he will appoint his longtime foreign policy aide, Denis R. McDonough, as the new principal deputy national security adviser, a critical position that helps frame the policy choices that eventually work their way to the Oval Office.

title: 'Evening Primrose'
description: An excerpt from Stephen Sondheim's TV musical. (Video courtesy of Entertainment One)

title: Red Bulls Stunning Turnaround
description: Stunning is perhaps the most apt word to describe the transformation of the Red Bulls (15-9-6, 51 points) from Major League Soccers perennial doormat to one of the leagues model, and successful, clubs.

title: The Pros and Cons of the Tutor Stampede
description: IM well aware that many parents in my community assume that hiring tutors  whether to help their children with learning difficulties or to bump up already high scores  will be as much a part of the cost of school as backpacks and calculators.

title: Timing Seems Right for Hall to Move On
description: When I first met Ryan Hall, in the spring of 2007, his coach Terrence Mahon was at his side, literally, running next to him as the two jogged from their Midtown Manhattan hotel into Central Park to begin a training run on the 2008 Olympic trials marathon course. About a month earlier, Hall ran the second-fastest debut for an American in the marathon at London in 2 hours 8 minutes 24 seconds. Suddenly, Hall had become a favorite to win the trials, to be held the following November in New York. In fact, he went on to win that race, propelling himself to the top of the thin list of world-class American male marathoners.

title: Sony Reaches Out for Help with TVs
description: TOKYO  Sony has been a champion of networked televisions for years. These are the TVs that link seamlessly with other Sony gadgets, link to the Web and finally bridge the gap between PCs and the living room.

title: Excerpt: 'The Walking Dead'
description: The new AMC zombie series, based on a series of comic books, begins on Halloween.

title: A Beach Bungalow in Far Rockaway, Queens
description: Susan Anderson, an artist, was drawn to a home with lots of problems but a timeless spirit.

title: Want a Big Raise? Get a Wall St. Job
description: WALL Street incomes are surging back.

title: UPDATED: Rypien Suspended Six Games by N.H.L. for Attacking Fan
description: The National Hockey League announced early Friday afternoon it had suspended Vancouver forward Rick Rypien six games for this incident

title: The Catch
description: About 10 years ago, I was tending my used-book shop opposite Columbia University when a woman walked in, piled up every copy we had of The Bonfire of the Vanities, The Catcher in the Rye, Portnoys Complaint, The Liars Club and a dozen other representative titles by American authors. She asked if we had any more in the back, which we did. She cleaned us out and informed us that these books would be going to Russia, where they would give her Russian students a glimpse of life in America. (Hmm. Had to wonder what impression some of those would make.) Instead of producing the expected credit card, she proposed an unusual barter. I own a seafood company in Maine, she explained. How would you like to get paid in lobster? Ill phone in a credit in your name, and my staff will ship you lobsters.

title: Former President Bush to Appear on Oprah
description: Oprah Winfrey has scored the second television interview with former President George W. Bush as he embarks on a book tour.

title: Week 8 College Football Matchups
description: One of my favorite (and most delicious) things to compare the college football season to is a pint of Guinness. It takes some time to settle. You think youre ready for that first sip, but youre not. Patience, things are still settling. You stare at it. Still settling. Sometimes (often when you are thirstiest) it feels like it will never be ready to drink. (Anyone else getting thirsty?) Thats how this season is going. Its taking forever to settle. The picture is still hazy. Just when it seemed like we knew what was going on the No. 1 team started losing every week. Now it seems we know even less. Will Oklahoma be the third straight No. 1 to go down? Dont sleep on Missouri and its nasty defense. Who will remain as the last unbeaten in the SEC after Auburn hosts L.S.U.? Will Cameron Newtons stock continue to rise? Or will he pull a Taylor Martinez/Denard Robinson when he faces a tough L.S.U. defense? Can Iowa take control of the Big Ten? Can Nebraska bounce back? Lets all get a pint of Guinness and wait to see what happens.

title: Juan Williams Says NPR Was Looking for a Reason to Fire Him
description: Two days after being fired by NPR, Juan Williams is, as the NPR media correspondent David Folkenflik put it, now enjoying the full embrace of Fox News, which has given him a new three-year, $2 million contract and a guest slot, Friday night, as host of The OReilly Factor.

title: The Food Issue: Eating Together
description: It is a rare day that I sit down and read The New York Times Magazine cover to cover  a 2-year-old and a husband who steals the magazine for the crossword the moment it lands on our front step provide enough obstacles  but I saw Sundays cover and knew I needed it back once the crossword was wrestled into submission. Thank you so much; such beautifully written articles. I laughed, cried and stood in awe of the amazing things people are doing with food and creating community. When I finished, I passed the magazine back to my husband and said, Read everything.

title: Recipe Redux
description: I admire the magazines food-themed issues, which encourage readers to look at food as not just an object of consumption but also as an opportunity to make an impact, for better or worse, through our conscious decisions. The Times regularly reminds us that our food choices not only affect our physical health but also shape our social, environmental, economic and cultural identities. I thus find it paradoxical that the magazines Food Issue features a recipe for veal. This issue advocates taking a more holistic perspective on eating and food, and Amanda Hessers Recipe Redux extols the impact of The Timess classic recipes over the years. Yet by featuring a 1962 recipe for veal chops beau sjour, The Times fails to heed its own advice. The veal industry, which the ethicist Peter Singer calls the most morally repugnant of all factory farming, involves tethering calves in pens not wider than two feet so they are unable to stretch their legs from birth until slaughter, and deliberately feeding them a diet lacking in iron, so that their meat reaches a desired tenderness and complexion. Surely The Times can set a better example for its readers?

title: Pie + Design = Change
description: John T. Edge makes clear the disconnect that followed Project M from Maine to Greensboro, Ala., and how the groups original Pie Lab concept, though charming, shared the drive-by aspect that weakens so many American efforts to do good. Im sure many of the Project M folks who went to Hale County were drawn by the myth-making of Let Us Now Praise Famous Men, which is a fine work of literature but not a sociology text and one which has been criticized by Hale County people since its release for its drive-by qualities. You get a sense of what discomfits them by a quick glance through the Walker Evans archive at photos of the Burroughs (really Gudger) family that have not become iconic  the ones in which they are smiling and dressed in their nicer clothes. Its significant that one outsider depicted in Edges article who is still making a difference in Greensboro  Pam Dorr  made a life investment in the town by moving there and staying long enough to learn the nuances. This is something that rural people are likely to respect and relate to.

title: Keeping It Kosher
description: As an orthodox Jew who (alas, too infrequently) dines out, I am horrified by Rabbi Levys demand, reported in Frank Brunis article on Basil Pizza & Wine Bar, for video feeds from OK- certified restaurants. If in fact Rabbi Levy is correct that kosher consumers will not eat in establishments where inappropriate behavior or dress is tolerated, then market forces will prevail and the restaurant will go out of business. Neither the restaurant owner nor the diners need Big Brother to determine whether patrons were socializing for matrimonial purposes.

title: Kafkas Last Trial
description: In using the ambivalent notion of trial in the title of her cover story (Sept. 26), Elif Batuman connects the title and contents of Kafkas novel with the current (and past) legal procedures concerning Max Brods literary estate. She also associates one of Brods heirs, Eva Hoffe, who as a matter of fact is a key figure in this matter, with Kafkas famous doorkeeper in Before the Law. She suggests that a number of important papers may be locked up in her cat infested flat in Tel Aviv. I do not believe that this is the case for two reasons. First, I am quite sure that the considerable number of bank safes held by the Hoffes give enough space to preserve the most important documents. Second, the Hoffe family occupied two apartments at 23 Spinoza Street. The one in which Evas mother, Esther Hoffe, lived on

title: Animosity Farm
description: As one of the neighbors of the farm Bob Morris writes about in the Lives column, I hardly recognized the place he describes. I did, however, recognize the handsome Ivy League educated farmer with the blue green eyes . . . bright as bachelor buttons. I knew this was the organic farm right next door, one of two small farms we are fortunate to have in our community and one we want to encourage and nurture. The farmers and their staff of interns are more than competent at their jobs; they seem gifted. As Morris does mention, they do work terribly hard; the produce is beautiful and healthful.

title: F.C.C. Calls for Good Faith in Cable Dispute
description: 4:15 p.m. | Updated The Federal Communications Commission on Friday stepped up its pressure on Cablevision and News Corporation, signaling just how seriously the feud over retransmission payments is being taken in Washington.

title: Nevada Jobless Rate Still at Record High
description: Nevadas unemployment rate was 14.4 percent in August, the highest of all the American states. That figure also tied its rate in August as the highest ever recorded for the Silver State since the Labor Department began keeping track in 1976, according to a report released Friday.

title: Now Booking | Romeo Hotel, Naples
description: Naples, Italy, has been hard at work lately distancing itself from its reputation as a city of lawlessness and litter. It has invested millions in restoration and transportation projects, not to mention improving its tourism infrastructure with the likes of the new Romeo Hotel.

title: Client 9 and Other Interested Parties
description: CAN that really be Eliot Spitzer, the disgraced former governor of New York, smiling into the camera with his co-host, Kathleen Parker, on a new CNN talk show, or is it some kind of fever dream? Did that sordid call-girl scandal really happen?

title: In Jail or on the Run, Karadzic and Mladic Could Still Win Bosnias War
description: As my colleagues Dan Bilefsky and Doreen Carvajal report, European countries have apparently reduced the pressure on Serbias government to arrest Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb general still wanted on war crimes charges by an international tribunal in The Hague for his part in the massacre of 8,000 men and boys after forces under his command seized the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in 1995.

title: Rounding Up the Usual Suspects: Interpreting Famous Quotations
description: Overview | What do we say about ourselves when we quote lines from movies or elsewhere? Why do famous quotes from movies, literature and history resonate with many people? In this lesson, students consider the power of their favorite movie lines and other famous quotes, then write essays interpreting and commenting on a selected quotation.

title: The Reliable (Melodic) Drone of Suuns
description: Suuns, from Montreal (pronounced Soons and formerly called Zeroes), are drone scholars. They bear down on one chord, or just one repeated note, in all sorts of ways, as their lead singer, Ben Shemie, croons ominious thoughts in a high tenor with sociopathic gentleness: Dont you be yourself/you are someone else, he intoned.

title: G.M. Recalls 300,000 Chevrolet Impalas for Seat-Belt Problem
description: General Motors is recalling 303,000 2009-10 Chevrolet Impalas because the front seat belts could come loose in a crash. The recall comes more than a year after G.M. first learned of the problem.

title: Come for the Highway. Stay for the View.
description: BOULDER CITY, Nev.  It is an engineering marvel and an acrophobes nightmare. And even in its first week, it is a tourist attraction.

title: Cholera Outbreak Kills 150 in Haiti
description: A cholera outbreak in a rural area of northwestern Haiti has killed more than 150 people and overwhelmed local hospitals with thousands of the sick, the World Health Organization said Friday, increasing long-held fears of an epidemic that could spread to the encampments sheltering more than a million Haitians displaced by the January earthquake.

title: U.S. Prevails in Trade Dispute With China
description: WASHINGTON  The United States claimed victory Friday in a trade dispute with China, after a World Trade Organization panel largely upheld tariffs that were imposed on an array of Chinese-made steel pipes, tires and other products during the Bush administration.

title: Deadline Slips on an Oil Spill Report
description: The agencies conducting the main federal investigation into the BP Deepwater Horizon explosion and spill said Friday that they had asked for and been given extra time to complete their report.

title: N.R.S.C. Opens $10 Million Line of Credit
description: The National Republican Senatorial Committee has taken out a $10 million line of credit less than two weeks before the midterm elections, an indication of the large number of competitive  and costly  states that both parties are battling over.

title: Being Tony Curtis
description: In this portion of the January 15, 1970, interview with Dick Cavett, Tony Curtis discussed his films and his relationship with directors.

title: Shes Leaving Home; Grab a Camera
description: DOUG BLOCK has made a film about his daughter Lucys final year of high school without a mention of SATs, SAT IIs, AP courses, tutors, college counselors, recommendations, essays or acceptance rates.

title: Questions for Tony Curtis
description: In this portion of the January 15, 1970, interview with Dick Cavett, Tony Curtis took questions from the audience.

title: Pregame Huddle: Contending or Pretending
description: Oklahoma is undefeated and a top of the B.C.S. standings, but are they better than Boise State?

title: For the Record: N.H.L. Countdowns to Infamy
description: Hockey fans who like to keep an eye on the record book could be in for a treat this season. Several records have already fallen, and plenty of players will be closing in on historical achievements over the coming weeks and months.

title: Beyond Bullets and Berets, Life in Wartime
description: Im a soldier, Im not a martyr, Carlos the Jackal announces in Carlos, Olivier Assayass fictionalization of the life and brutal times of the Marxist turned mercenary. Carlos delivers this line in 1975 during a re-creation of a heated exchange with the radical true believers with whom he has taken OPEC ministers hostage. It was one of the more spectacular operations in his career as a self-professed professional revolutionary, and he had carefully dressed for the part in a black beret and leather jacket meant to invoke Che Guevara, pop martyr supreme.

title: Part 2: N.B.A.s Defensive Movers and Shakers: Who Will Improve?
description: Previously, we wrote that Washington and Milwaukee are the top candidates to improve on offense this season, with Cleveland and Toronto prepared for a tumble. Now, its time to look at whos headed up and whos headed down on defense.

title: Maternal Wisdom (5 Pounds Worth)
description: THE memo from the middle school came home in my daughters backpack on a Friday afternoon. Next week your sixth-grade child will participate in a flour-sack baby exercise, it said. All sixth graders were to report to school Monday with five-pound bags of flour dressed up as dolls, and carry them everywhere for the week. The idea was to teach them the responsibilities of teenage parenthood. We encourage parental participation to make this exercise a success, the note concluded.

title: L.I.R.R. Plans Service Suspensions
description: When subway riders grouse about periodic weekend service disruptions, they may be wise to consider what the Long Island Rail Road is about to do.

title: Underwriting a Childs Business Poses Pitfalls for Parents
description: Several years ago, Nathan Deal and his wife invested $2 million to help their daughter and son-in-law open an outdoor sporting goods store. They eventually doubled down by guaranteeing bank debt worth $2 million more. The business failed in 2009, the children filed for bankruptcy and their elders are now scrambling to avoid the same fate.

title: British Navy Seeks Inquiry After Nuclear Sub Runs Aground
description: LONDON  The Royal Navy hastened to assemble an official inquiry Friday evening to explore why Britains newest nuclear submarine, H.M.S. Astute, ran aground while undergoing sea trials off the coast of northwest Scotland on Friday morning and remained stuck on a bank of sand and shingle for nearly 10 hours before a tug pulled it free at nightfall. A spokesman for the Royal Navy said divers would be deployed at first light on Saturday to check concerns that the submarines rudder had been damaged.

title: How to Get Unfriended on Facebook
description: THE GIST People are most likely to unfriend those who post mundane or inflammatory status updates.

title: Hannelore Schmidt, 91, Wife of West German Chancellor, Dies
description: BERLIN  Hannelore Schmidt, a former schoolteacher and prominent conservationist who won the affection of Germans as the down-to-earth wife of Helmut Schmidt, the West German chancellor, died Thursday at her home in Hamburg. She was 91.

title: Kortrijk Report | Design Without the Traffic Jams
description: Courtesy of Junya Ishigama Junya Ishigamas Drop table for Living Divani.

title: Trial of Synthetic Mesh in Pelvic Surgery Ends Early
description: To repair the uncomfortable and potentially dangerous condition called pelvic organ prolapse  a weakening of the muscles and ligaments that support organs like the bladder and uterus  more gynecological and urological surgeons have been turning to a synthetic mesh that shores up the vaginal wall.

title: $200 Billion in Ads, Mr. Biden? Thats Real Money
description: Conservative groups have not dumped $200 billion in political ads on the heads of Democratic candidates.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kashmir and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kashmir, Haiti and Britain.

title: The False Friend
description: Chapter 1

title: Under Londons Railway Arches
description: A FEW years ago, if you were to take a late-night walk down the Gales Garden, a tiny alley of arches under the railway viaducts in the Bethnal Green area of London, you would have come across Studio 10. A sleazy after-hours club of dubious renown, it was a place where people were allowed to express themselves in almost any way they liked, as Jalle Rousku diplomatically put it.

title: Video: Who Is Contending, Who Is Pretending?
description: Oklahoma is undefeated and atop the B.C.S. standings, but is it better than Boise State? And can Auburn keep winning despite its problems on defense? Connor Ennis and Paul Myerberg break it down on this weeks edition of the Pregame Huddle.

title: 6.1 Million Tune In to Jersey Shore Finale
description: As it did the first time around, MTVs Jersey Shore ended its second season with more viewers than it started with.

title: Indonesia Debates Possibility of Honor for Suharto
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  To millions, Suharto, the military strongman who ruled Indonesia for 32 years, was a tyrant, a thief and a murderer.

title: Hotel Review: Rafayel on the Left Bank, in London
description: BASICS

title: Fight Breast Cancer? Ill Drink to That
description: Each October, Madison Avenue not only thinks pink, it turns pink, as marketers seek to show how much they support the fight against breast cancer. Products are re-dressed in pink packaging, appliances are sold with pink tints, pink ribbons festoon apparel and some newspapers even tint their pages pink.

title: LeBron James Shares Hateful Twitter Messages
description: Athletes have received nasty messages from fans since the day of the first sporting competition back in ancient Greece. Things have evolved from verbal taunts to written notes. Back in the day, athletes received hate snail mail.

title: Mets Narrow General Manager Search
description: The Mets have narrowed their search for their next general manager, inviting two candidates  Josh Byrnes and Sandy Alderson  for a second round of interviews that will be conducted next week.

title: The Gang That Couldnt Bomb Straight
description: IN Four Lions, the first feature directed by the British comedian Chris Morris, a group of British Muslim fundamentalists hatch a plot to blow themselves up during the London Marathon. From this decidedly unfunny premise the film finds multiple occasions for laughter.

title: Where Football Means Business
description: Saturday will be homecoming at Clarkson University in upstate New York, with part of the festivities including a football game against a team from Boston University.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Keith Richards, Taylor Swift, The Walking Dead and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Weekend Fare
description: Pots of chili, consomm, chicken noodle soup and more will be simmering during the Smith Street Soup Festival in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, on Saturday. Admission is $5 a person or $10 a family. Local restaurants will sell four-ounce samples of soups from 1 to 4 p.m. on Smith Street between Carroll Street and Atlantic Avenue. Proceeds will go to benefit a new culinary arts program at the High School for International Studies on Baltic Street.

title: The Devil Inside and the Demon in Disguise
description: The Exorcist

title: Does Rooney Deal Undermine Uniteds Ability to Compete?
description: Wayne Rooney was upset that his club, Manchester United, didnt want to win as much as he did. Despite Sir Alex Fergusons genius, his teammates talents and efforts, management wasnt willing to spend lavishly on international stars to complement Rooney.

title: This Old 'House'
description: A look inside House, a 1977 Japanese horror now releasing on DVD.

title: Changing Definitions of Green Alter Investment Strategies
description: Green investing has been getting a boost lately through a combination of increasing attention to climate change and low returns from traditional investments.

title: She Keeps Bees  In the Footsteps of P.J. Harvey
description: Jessica Larrabee, the guitarist and singer in the Brooklyn duo She Keeps Bees, has a gift for opening lines. Brick by brick, shes gonna take you down, she warned in one song. Dont follow me, honey, not the road you want to be on, went another. The songs smolder and ignite from there, as her voice rears up and she strums blaring, increasingly frenetic chords on her electric guitar.

title: Terra Madre Kicks Off in Turin
description: The Palasport Olimpico, built for the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin, Italy, saw the opening ceremony of another sort of worldwide delegation on Thursday: Terra Madre 2010. Instead of athletes, there were farmers, fishermen and artisanal food producers, along with other sustainable food idealists (young and royalty alike)  from Pavlos Georgiadis, a student from Thrace, Greece, who helped create an edible garden at his university in Stuttgart, Germany, to Alice Waters.

title: Countless
description: Should the word be used for things we can actually count?

title: Pictures of the Day: Kashmir and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kashmir, Haiti and Britain.

title: Store Review: Ioli, in Madrid
description: Over the last few years, if you saw a Madrilea wearing a pair of fabulous shoes  a pair of genuine ruby slippers like Dorothys, say, only a touch more urban, styled as a flat or a dOrsay pump, with red matte piping along the edge and a slightly more flattering rounded toe  the likely origin of the slippers in question was a bright turquoise shoe box of a shop on Calle Espiritu Santo in the Malasaa neighborhood. There, Cynthia Ioli, an Argentine transplant and former costume designer for theater and opera, is redefining whats cool on the feet of Madrids men and women.

title: In Papua New Guinea, Trek on a Trail of War
description: WE entered the jungle of Papua New Guinea equipped for an intrepid voyage into the heart of darkness, hauling a tent and a weeks worth of couscous and instant noodles. The wide cart track we were following soon narrowed to a footpath that slithered muddily through the trees, and the canopy above our heads closed in, blocking the sun.

title: Going to the Galpagos, and Trying to Limit the Footprint
description: WIND and waves tossed our inflatable dinghy as we circled Champion Islet, a craggy rock in the Pacific Ocean, in search of one of the worlds rarest birds. As the boatman steered the panga in and out of coves, our guide, Ernesto, made a call that was something between a chirp and a shhh. Ten of us intently scanned the arid islet, a last refuge for the Floreana mockingbird. This wasnt just any bird  its ancestors had inspired Darwins thinking on the origin of species.

title: Lost in Ireland
description: THE place was called Cronins Yard, and it was somewhere around here  it had to be. Off to my right, past the barbed-wire fences that bordered intense green pastures, rose the first russet foothills of Macgillycuddys Reeks, the highest mountain peaks in Ireland, swathed in a fog punctured in rare spots by the pale morning sun. In there  somewhere  was the Yard, supposedly the best starting point for hikers in the Reeks, and now, after four days of driving southwest from Dublin to County Kerry without a map, GPS or, really, any sense of Irish geography, I was so close. All I had to do was find it.

title: Getting Lost in Ireland
description: Coming to Ireland to lose myself, over the course of a week, in a country I knew nothing about.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Ideological Divide
description: This week: Jonathan Alter and Christopher Caldwell on political books and the midterm elections; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Responding to a Childs Request for Start-Up Money
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I use the saga of a Georgia candidate for governor, Nathan Deal, to discuss when (or if) parents should ever invest in the business ventures of their adult children.

title: Rocking the Classics
description: ON a recent Tuesday, the musician Esperanza Spalding was out searching for mildly androgynous vintage items to wear onstage.

title: Your Commute, Your Life, Your Personal Subway Map
description: This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Timess Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New Yorks subway system. Go to the Subway Issue Endlessley pored over, chronically criticized, instantly recognizable  the subway map is like the citys wallpaper. (Or, say, shower curtain; many versions available for under $30.) In June, the 1979 design got its first overhaul in a decade, with Manhattan magnified, Staten Island shrunk, and a lighter taupe background and new gray outlines to make it more readable.

title: LogMeIn Taunts Cisco and Citrix with Free Web Meeting App
description: Microsoft, I.B.M., Cisco Systems and Citrix have some new, plucky competition when it comes to Web meeting software.

title: Winning a World Series Share
description: Sports Editor Tom Jolly and Assistant Sports Editor Jay Schreiber discuss whether winning a world series share is a motivation for clubs that have smaller payrolls.

title: Reviewing the Porsche Cayenne
description: In this weeks Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2011 Porsche Cayenne, noting that the company has improved its popular crossover by addressing the original versions shortcomings:

title: Connecticut Home Builders Promote Energy Savings
description: BUILDERS are trying a bread-and-butter approach to promoting environmentally conscious construction, using previous buyers heating and cooling bills to persuade shoppers that buying new will save them money.

title: Cyclist Fatally Doored in East Harlem
description: Updated, 10:53 p.m. | A 27-year-old cyclist in East Harlem was killed Friday morning when a driver in a parked car opened his door into him and knocked him into the path of a truck, the police said. The rider, Marcus Ewing of Manhattan Avenue, was heading east on East 120th Street just west of Third Avenue around 8 a.m. when he was struck.

title: Echo and Delay  Too Much of a Good Thing
description: A stray thought: At this years CMJ, the new glockenspiel  that is, a nice sound in small doses that has become rampantly overused  is echo and delay effects on vocals. Ive heard it all over the place, in chillwave, psychedelia, folktronica, hard rock and whatever genre  witch house?  Salem is claiming this week.

title: The Caucus
description: Revealing sources for millions of dollars spent on campaigns.

title: Living in Pound Ridge, N.Y.
description: IT used to be that the only thing keeping Gary D. Warshauer up at night was the chatter of crickets and the howl of coyotes.

title: Living in Pound Ridge, N.Y.
description: Pound Ridge, a 23-square-mile municipality in northeastern Westchester, is rich in open space.

title: TimesCast: Donors Unveiled
description: The Timess Jim Rutenberg and Megan Liberman examine recently revealed corporate donors to the United States Chamber of Commerce, which is spending more money on campaign ads than any non-party group this cycle.

title: Plumb Beach, Brooklyn 3:14 P.M.
description: In 2006, a gay man named Michael J. Sandy was lured to a rest area off the Belt Parkway by three young men who tried to rob him and chased him onto the highway, where he was killed by a car. His attackers were convicted of hate crimes. On Friday, a park bench at the rest area was dedicated to Mr. Sandys memory.

title: Subway Sketches
description: Eric Molinsky draws people riding New York's subway using the Sketchbook application for the iPhone.

title: We Three Things | Interior Monologues
description: I find images of unpeopled interiors infinitely more satisfying than pictures of populated rooms. I love the way they appear to wait in quiet anticipation. This is probably why I never tire of looking through decades-old back issues of World of Interiors or Country Life. Empty rooms, especially other peoples, are like handwritten invitations, not to mention oblique self-portraits of the artists who make them.

title: This Cleo Is No Baby on the Nile
description: Kate Mulgrew is knowing, sensual, slithery and, with her throaty Katharine Hepburn-after-three-vodkas voice, slightly bawdy. And it all adds up to Cleopatra.

title: Redone Theater Fit for a Pharaoh
description: THEATERGOERS arriving at Hartford Stage this month to see Antony and Cleopatra will also get their first look at Phase 1 of the theaters ambitious renovation. Before the performance on the night of Oct. 16, a friend and I were given a tour of the theater, and I was glad to see that all the planned improvements, which took four months and cost $4 million, had become a reality.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Ideological Divide
description: This week: Jonathan Alter and Christopher Caldwell on political books and the midterm elections; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Book Review Podcast: The Ideological Divide
description: This week: Jonathan Alter and Christopher Caldwell on political books and the midterm elections; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Book Review Podcast: The Ideological Divide
description: This week: Jonathan Alter and Christopher Caldwell on political books and the midterm elections; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: In Clearing Bayou, Quagmire for Goldman
description: By SUSANNE CRAIG

title: Complaint Box 2 | More Subway Complaints
description: This post is part of the first-ever themed issue of The Timess Sunday Metropolitan section, which is devoted to New Yorks subway system. Go to The Subway Issue

title: New View of Green Investing
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about how green investing has been getting more attention, both because of increasing attention to climate change and because traditional investments have been generating low returns.

title: In Berlin, a Creative Wave
description: Berlins gritty, working-class Neuklln district is once again a destination for (modern) bohemians.

title: On the Market in New York City and the Region
description: Properties in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Cedar Grove, N.J.

title: The Defense Departments Response
description: Following is the response to the WikiLeaks documents from Geoff Morrell, the Defense Department press secretary:

title: The Iraq Archive: The Strands of a War
description: A huge trove of secret field reports from the battlegrounds of Iraq sheds new light on the war, including such fraught subjects as civilian deaths, detainee abuse and the involvement of Iran.

title: Iran Seized U.S. Hikers in Iraq, U.S. Report Asserts
description: Iran has accused three American hikers of illegally crossing into Iranian territory in July 2009 and is still holding two of them in prison. But a classified American military report made public by WikiLeaks, which describes the chaotic day when the hikers were detained, asserts that the hikers were on the Iraqi side of the border when they were seized.

title: A Grim Portrait of Civilian Deaths in Iraq
description: The reports in the archive disclosed by WikiLeaks offer an incomplete, yet startlingly graphic portrait of one of the most contentious issues in the Iraq war  how many Iraqi civilians have been killed and by whom.

title: Detainees Fared Worse in Iraqi Hands, Logs Say
description: The public image of detainees in Iraq was defined by the photographs, now infamous, of American abuse at Abu Ghraib, like the hooded prisoner and the snarling attack dog. While the documents disclosed by WikiLeaks offer few glimpses of what was happening inside American detention facilities, they do contain indelible details of abuse carried out by Iraqs army and police.

title: What Were Reading: Rainfall and Democracy
Leaked Reports Detail Irans Aid for Iraqi Militias
description: On Dec. 22, 2006, American military officials in Baghdad issued a secret warning: The Shiite militia commander who had orchestrated the kidnapping of officials from Iraqs Ministry of Higher Education was now hatching plans to take American soldiers hostage.

title: Letter: Getting to Turku, Finland
description: To the Editor: It might be a clich, but when it comes to traveling to Turku, getting there is half the fun. Two ferry lines (Tallink Silja and Viking) run giant ships between Stockholm and Turku twice a day, passing through beautiful archipelagos on both ends. The ships are equipped with varieties of cabins, food, entertainment and shopping and are quite inexpensive.

title: Letter: Sibelius in Turku, Finland
description: To the Editor: I just read Sundays article about Turku, A Finnish City Prepares for the Limelight (Oct. 10), and was saddened not to find mention of Jean Sibelius, Finlands greatest composer. Rather curious, since the city is being promoted as a Capital of Culture. The Sibelius Museum (www.sibeliusmuseum.abo.fi) is a gem where 300 musical instruments are on display, concerts are given and memorabilia from Sibeliuss life would fascinate any music lover. Lets not keep it a secret.

title: With a Name Like Beach Fossils, Can Sunny Be Far Behind?
description: Put Beach in a band name, and the word sunny will inevitably appear in descriptions of the music. Especially if its true, as it is with Beach Fossils, from Brooklyn. Theyre simply asking for it, with peppy, major-key songs and lyrics full of hopeful romance: I let the time pass by/Soon Ill be by your side. The guitars mesh and cascade, splashed in surf-rock reverb, through picking patterns of stuttering notes and arpeggios, stratified like the 1980s arrangements of New Order or the Cure, but much, well, sunnnier. New Order goes surfing?

title: In American Custody
description: John Moore of Getty Images has visited American-run detention centers in Iraq, including Abu Ghraib and Camp Cropper; prisons for Taliban fighters in Afghanistan run by that countrys National Directorate of Security; the Pul-e-Charki prison outside Kabul; and, more recently, the Guantnamo Bay detention center. He is gathering these images in a longterm project, Detained. James Estrin and David Furst interviewed him by telephone in August. The transcript of their conversation has been edited.

title: The War Logs: Newly Disclosed Iraq War Reports
description: The At War blog is following reaction to the release of classified American field reports from the Iraq War, which contain information about many episodes never made public in such detail. The New York Times had access to the documents and published a series of reports.

title: Chic in Review | The Mobama Effect
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Democrats Back Third Parties to Siphon Votes
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Seeking any advantage in their effort to retain control of Congress, Democrats are working behind the scenes in a number of tight races to bolster long-shot third-party candidates who have platforms at odds with the Democratic agenda but hold the promise of siphoning Republican votes.

title: N.J. Governor to Evaluate Tunnel as Cost Estimates Rise
description: New Jerseys governor, Chis Christie, has said he will spend the weekend contemplating whether to put a stop to the planned rail tunnel under the Hudson River. As he does so, he has some very big numbers to consider.

title: Michaels Out at Tribune; Replaced by Council
description: The Tribune Companys board today resolved what had been its preoccupation for at least a week: orchestrating the ouster of Randy Michaels, the chief executive whose boorish behavior and sexual antics became a dark sideshow to the bankrupt companys financial struggles.

title: A Search for Freedom in a Noisy, Wired World
description: One integral theme running through Trajal Harrells programming for his current Platform series, certain difficulties, certain joy," has to do with pleasure  or with works that flutter ever so lightly around the idea that play doesnt have to veer into stupidity. On Thursday night at Danspace Project, Mr. Harrell added a memorable addition to his growing pile of treasures: an old work shown in a new space.

title: Editor at Embattled Literary Journal Will Stay
description: The University of Virginia has released its audit investigating workplace conditions at the Virginia Quarterly Review, the prizewinning literary journal it oversees, but nearly three months after the suicide of its managing editor, Kevin Morrissey, the journal is still on hold.
