Carol Wood, a spokeswoman for the university, said on Friday that Ted Genoways, the editor of VQR, had been invited to stay on as editor, and Mr. Genoways confirmed in an e-mail that Yes, I will be remaining on as editor.

title: Once Cruel to Be Kind, Now Soft to Be True
description: Nick Lowe is feeding his audience some extremely fine new songs. His show on Wednesday at City Winery started with one of them, sung alone with acoustic guitar. Called Stoplight Roses, it uses cheap flowers at a smoggy crossroads as a stand-in for loves promise, convenience and perishability. The feel was maudlin, but he knew it and played it down and impaled the audience with it.

title: Surrendering to Muses, Poetry and Song Unite
description: The composer William Bolcom says he finds choosing poems for a song cycle an arduous task, as difficult as writing the music. With the help of Joyce Castle, the mezzo-soprano for whom he wrote this song cycle, The Hawthorn Tree, he eventually selected seven poems of contrasting character by American and English poets.

title: For Sustainable Wood, a New and Unloved Standard
description: Next week select members of the United States Green Building Council will begin casting ballots on whether to overhaul how the organization awards sustainability credits for wood products.

title: A Plush Voice Discovers Some Room to Be Frisky
description: There are no shortcuts to the kind of musical maturity that the jazz singer Jane Monheit displayed at Birdland on Wednesday evening. Although endowed with improvisatory skill and a voice of singular plushness, Ms. Monheit has often struggled to connect with the meanings of songs, letting the sheer beauty of her sound and her polished technique carry her performances. Like many young pop-jazz singers, she often seemed to be listening to herself and gauging her intonation instead of heeding the material.

title: South Park Apologizes for Lifted Material in Inception Parody
description: 5:29 p.m. | Updated

title: A Note From the Editors
description: Like a similar set of articles published in July about Afghanistan, the articles published today are based on thousands of United States military incident and intelligence reports from Iraq  records of engagements, mishaps, intelligence on enemy activity and other events. The New York Times, the British newspaper The Guardian, the German magazine Der Spiegel and the French newspaper Le Monde were given access to the material in June, on the condition that the contents not be made public until now.

title: App Smart Extra: A Glympse of Your Friends
description: This weeks App Smart column partly focused on the group-texting app Fast Society, which earns points for its self-expiration feature. Start a group text and within a set amount of time the group disbands.

title: Campy Ode to Film Noir and a Twist on Politics
description: Amanda McBroom is a gusher. By that, I dont mean an obsequious well-wisher brimming with feigned enthusiasm, but a singer and songwriter who overflows with warmth and good humor, tempered with a hard, clear-eyed wisdom. Ms. McBroom, whose most famous song is The Rose, writes in a plain, broad-based pop-country-folk style that has a theatrical heft. The best of her lyrics, many of which address the inner lives of desperate housewives, go the quick of experience with a visionary acuity.

title: Sfoglia and Its Founders Have Split
description: Ron Suhanosky and Colleen Marnell-Suhanosky, the couple who founded Sfoglia on Nantucket and its intimate offshoot on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where customers tended to fill up on her delicious bread before the rest of the meal arrived, are no longer involved with either restaurant.

title: Triathletes, 40-Somethings, Going for Youth
description: HE was 39 and thought he was in decent shape. But when Eric Goodman, an information technologist from Stamford, Conn., tried to run a mile on a treadmill, he could barely make it without feeling as if he were coughing up a lung.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Financial Statements for Shareholders

title: The Price of a No-Cost Loan
description: HOME buyers concerned about high closing costs in this tight economy might be tempted by a type of loan that requires no cash outlay in exchange for paying a higher interest rate, especially because rates are already at historically low levels.

title: Two Gold Coast Estates on the Market
description: Kings Point

title: A Place to Make Music, but Not Noise
description: AFTER graduating from the Juilliard School, Monica Ohuchi Bunch practiced and taught on her upright piano. Two years ago, she upgraded to a Steinway Grand, Model B, nearly seven feet long.

title: Steven D. Sladkus
description: Mr. Sladkus, 41, is a partner in the law firm Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz, which is based in New York. With a practice focusing on real estate, he represents co-ops and condominiums. His clients include the Cityspire Condominium in Midtown and the Parkchester North Condominium in the Bronx.

title: An Area on the Brooklyn Waterfront, Growing in a Family Way
description: NEW YORKERS have been rediscovering a small neighborhood in Brooklyn called the Columbia Street Waterfront District  and so have the real estate developers.

title: How a Tunnel Would Help New Jersey Home Values
description: WHAT is the real estate value of a one-seat train ride to Manhattan from a station close to ones home in New Jersey? Leave it to statisticians to come up with a figure.

title: Sometimes, Lucky Numbers Add Up to Apartment Sales
description: FOR some New Yorkers on the hunt for an apartment, the must-have item in the search is nothing as prosaic as a walk-in closet or a second bathroom. It is a number  a lucky number.

title: Strapped: A Bumpy Year
description: JAY H. WALDER, the imposingly tall 51-year-old chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, pointed approvingly at the giant flat-screen television installed this month near an entrance to the Atlantic Avenue subway station in Downtown Brooklyn. The screen presented a real-time, color-coded guide to what was happening on every line in the system  the type of basic information, commonplace in European transit systems, that the authority has struggled for years to provide.

title: Paranormal Activity 2: An Inside Look
description: Last year, Paranormal Activity proved itself to be The Blair Witch Project of its generation: a gritty, indie, ultra-low-budget horror picture that word-of-mouth powers into the box office stratosphere. Paranormal cost $10,000 to make and sold $193 million at the global box office.

title: Tough Times No Deterrent for This Ball
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Barbara Davis, dripping with dangerously large diamonds as only an 80-year-old society queen can, held court at the Polo Lounge here on a recent Monday afternoon. She touched on various topics  her friend Nancy Reagan has been struggling lately to find comfortable yet stylish shoes  but it was the Carousel of Hope Ball that Mrs. Davis most wanted to talk about.

title: Can Winnipeg Support an N.H.L. Team?
description: From The Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out blog, this post discusses two newspaper surveys on whether fans and corporations would pay higher costs for N.H.L. hockey and the plight of the Ottawa Senators.

title: Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 22
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 22
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the groundbreaking of Moynihan Station, a visit by Justice Sonia Sotomayor of the Supreme Court to the Fordham Law Film Festival, and the rising cost of printed textbooks in a digital age.

title: A Beach Bungalow With a Magnetic Pull
Among the Pads and Huddles, a Nudge Toward College
description: Tuesday night was busy and chilly on Gun Hill Road in the Bronx, even if most eyes and minds were focused a few miles south, where the Yankees were hosting a playoff game. Out of the darkness around 7:30, squeezing through the doors of crowded buses and descending the steps from an elevated train platform, about 40 football players walked one by one across uneven sidewalks lugging shoulder pads, cleats and brightly painted helmets.

title: City Critic: Patrolling the City
description: Ariel Kaminer, The New York Times's City Critic, takes a ride on a new scooter that the New York Police Department will use to patrol the subway.

title: All Games Are Decisive at Pearl Spring
Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE B AND Q SUBWAY STATIONS at Neck Road and Avenue U on the Brighton Line are to reopen on Monday after partial closings since mid-2008, and it is not hard to gauge how riders feel about it. Last week at the Avenue U station, a sign offering apologies for delays was defaced with a rebuttal: Apology Not Accepted.

title: The Mating Game
description: ON a misty late morning the Tuesday after Labor Day, Patti Stanger, namesake star of the popular Bravo reality program The Millionaire Matchmaker, was standing in her Marina del Rey, Calif., office  a raw industrial space with red-painted walls and matching red chairs shaped like lips  preparing to douse one of her clients in the cold water of her now-notorious realism.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 22
description: More Photographs

title: Abrahams Progeny, and Their Texts
description: The sweep of the new exhibition at the New York Public Library  Three Faiths: Judaism, Christianity, Islam  is stunning. It stretches from a Bible found in a monastery in coastal Brittany that was sacked by the Vikings in the year 917, to a 1904 lithograph showing the original Temple Emanu-El on Fifth Avenue. It encompasses both an elaborately decorated book of 20th-century Coptic Christian readings and a modest 19th-century printing of the Gospels in the African language Grebo. There are Korans, with pages that shimmer with gold leaf and elegant calligraphy, and a 13th-century Pentateuch from Jerusalem, written in script used by Samaritans who traced their origins to the ancient Northern Kingdom of Israel.

title: Anatomy of a Favorite Giants Play, 36/37 BOB
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. The Ahmad Bradshaw run is at the 40-second mark of the video at top.

title: Sometimes, Money Cant Buy You Votes
description: One group of candidates who have struggled of late are those who are largely self-financed:

title: What Change Could Look Like
description: Washington

title: Dont Spirits Ever Knock Anymore?
description: In a very nifty trick, Paranormal Activity 2 turns out to be both prequel and sequel to its 2007 parent (released in 2009), sliding this new story into the timeline and events of the first with considerable agility. And though the original films budget (less than $15,000) has swelled to just under $3 million, the aesthetic and concept  rudimentary in every way  remain rigorously enforced.

title: Where Does Adobe Go From Here?
description: Its been a bit of a rough year for Adobe Systems.

title: The Caucus Click: Fairbanks, Alaska
At CMJ, Some Get Spotlight; Others Get Lost in the Haze
description: For the last few days, often well into the wee hours, the music writers for The New York Times have been all around town, checking out some of the 1,200 acts performing at this years CMJ Music Marathon, which ends on Saturday. Heres a sampling of whom theyve seen and heard, excerpted from items posted on the ArtsBeat blog (nytimes.com/artsbeat).

title: Photo Diary | Lingerie New York
description: What did we learn last night? Among other things, that to compete on the catwalk with a poodle  especially one sporting a heavy metal hairdo  requires quite a lot of black latex. The latex was supplied by the Japanese lingerie designer Atsuko Kudo (a Lady Gaga favorite), who made her American runway debut as part of Lingerie New York, an event thrown at Ciprianis by the Seven Bar Foundation, a nonprofit organization that has helped poor women in India, Mexico and Brazil start their own businesses. Yes, it was all for a good cause (some seats sold for $25,000 a pop), a fact that was alluded to if not entirely conveyed by the events tagline: Empowering women on a g-string rather than a shoe-string. The Belgian-based designer Carine Gilson also offered up her own fantasy twists on linge de corps, which Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of French Vogue, has described as the most refined lingerie in the world.

title: Genzyme Makes Case That Sanofi Bid Is Too Low
description: Andrew Pollack, a DealBook colleague, reports:

title: Finding the Right Pace (and Support Crew) for a Marathon
description: Since becoming the head of the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 1988, Valery Gergiev has built the house orchestra into an important touring ensemble. Even so, playing six Mahler symphonies in five programs over eight days would test even orchestras that make a specialty of these still-daunting works.

title: Profiling for a Seat
description: LIKE many liberal-minded New Yorkers, I find racial profiling abhorrent. But there is one place that I, like many liberal-minded New Yorkers, profile people all the time, and not only by race but also by age, ethnicity and sartorial choices: on the subway.

title: Canadian Oil Company Fined for Duck Deaths
description: OTTAWA  Syncrude, the largest operator of oil sands projects in Canada, was ordered to pay $2.92 million on Friday for causing the deaths of 1,603 ducks.

title: To Serve and Protect, Perched on 3 Wheels
description: You may have seen them zipping along underground, seeming quite determined and purposeful on their way from this point to that. Or perhaps you spotted them standing alone by a subway exit, like kids who want you to see but not play with their awesome new toy.

title: The Diversity of Birds and Fishes
description: Monday, Oct. 18

title: Game 6 Analysis: Rangers 6, Yankees 1
description: The Texas Rangers scored four runs in the fifth inning to break a 1-1 tie and went on to beat the Yankees, 6-1, in Game 6 of the American League Championship Series on Friday night. The Rangers won the series, four games to two, and advanced to their first World Series. The franchise began play in 1961 as the Washington Senators.

title: CBS Maintains No. 1 Spot
description: CBS extended its reign as the No. 1 network on Thursday, leading the night with its crime shows CSI (14.7 million ) and The Mentalist (14.2 million), according to Nielsens estimates. CBSs sitcoms managed to stay strong despite competition from Major League Baseball coverage on Fox. Final audience figures for Game 5 between the Philadelphia Phillies and the San Francisco Giants were not immediately available. ABC was third with Greys Anatomy (10.8 million) while NBC ranked fourth, attracting modest ratings for its comedy lineup, including The Office (6.8 million).

title: U.S. Drops Criminal Charges Against UBS
description: Federal prosecutors on Friday dropped criminal charges against UBS, saying that the Swiss bank had gotten out of the business of selling offshore private banking services that allowed wealthy Americans to avoid billions of dollars in taxes.

title: Paris Review Editor Frees Menagerie of Wordsmiths
description: The first issue of The Paris Review under its new editor, Lorin Stein, hit newsstands recently, and its a thing of sober beauty. The issue doesnt contain many surprises  theres fiction from Sam Lipsyte, poetry from Frederick Seidel and work from other usual, if talented, suspects. But its a solid and auspicious start, worth having tucked under your arm for that 45-minute wait outside Eataly.

title: From Texas, Talk of Toppling Government
description: The themes of antigovernment revolution have occasionally seeped into comments of Tea Party-backed candidates or their supporters this campaign season, and now a Republican House candidate in Texas has added his thoughts.

title: Neiman Marcus to Open New Bargain Outlets
description: Neiman Marcus may be known as a place for Texas-size yearnings and price tags, but in a sign of the economic times for luxury retailers, the company is being drawn to a less haughty shopper.

title: For CMJ, a Slice of Stumptown
description: Depending on the realtor, the New York outpost of Alex Calderwoods Ace Hotel is either located in NoChe (short for North Chelsea) or NoMad (for North of Madison Square Park), but regular people just think of the area as a place to buy knockoff handbags. Inside the hotel its a different scene, like some dreamy Epcot Center version of the Pacific Northwest, especially on this Friday afternoon, when Colin Meloy, the frontman of the Portland-based Decemberists, began tuning up for a solo show, sponsored by KEXP, the great Seattle radio station that moved into the lobby of the hotel for three days during CMJ. Im so glad this pocket of Portland is here, Meloy said of the hotel, which was founded in Seattle but is now headquartered in Stumptown. Now I feel safe in New York. His set  which was prefaced by 15 minutes of lovely droning gibberish from Nick Uratas gypsy punk band DeVotchKa  began with a trio of appropriately transportative songs that Meloy called Pacific Northwest folk. Word. It was new stuff, from the bands forthcoming album, which sounded like a welcome return to the moody lyricism of Castaways and Cutouts, the 2003 record that launched 1,000 indie-girl obsessions.

title: Democrats Look to Clout of Unions as Vote Nears
description: SHARON, Pa.  Just up the hill from a huge, shuttered Westinghouse factory, three campaign foot soldiers from the United Steelworkers rang Ed Turoskys doorbell to urge him to vote for the Democratic candidates for the House and Senate here.

title: Preacher Sons Seek Their Fathers Voice, and Heart
description: On one of his periodic visits from New York to his father in Georgia, the Rev. David K. Brawley realized he was having trouble making out the older mans words. For the previous four years, ever since cancer was found in his chest, Don Brawley Jr. had gone through periods when his voice weakened, when its baritone clenched into a hoarse rasp.

title: For French Choreographer, a Night to Rattle the Audience
description: Dance Theater Workshop audiences tend to be pretty hard-core; it takes a lot for a show to rattle them, especially to the point of walking out midperformance.

title: Molding Sound to Behave Like a Solar Eclipse
Beyond Ribbon-Cutting
description: When we started Fixes, we were hoping that interested readers would write in with their own ideas and experiences. Anyone who read the comments on our debut column, Health Care and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance, knows that this is exactly what happened. Readers responded to our column on Riders for Health  an organization that maintains the motorcycles used by health care workers in rural Africa  with a variety of ideas for improving transportation on that continent. They also proposed many intriguing fixes of their own  some of which we will look into for future columns.

title: Economy and Environment: The World Banks View
description: To the Editor:

title: Navigating a Close Last Round to Win the Swiss Teams Title
description: The 13th World Bridge Series, held in Philadelphia this month, permitted transnational pairs and teams in all but the junior events. There were several such teams in the Mixed Swiss Teams, including the winners: Greg Hinze, Jo Ann Sprung, Connie Goldberg and Lynn and Dale Johannesen from the United States, and Daniel Lavee from Canada. (Hinze and the Johannesens were misidentified as Canadian in Mondays column.)

title: South Park Creators Apologize for Using Other Writers Lines
description: The creators of South Park, the animated Comedy Central series, apologized on Friday to the creators of a Web comedy video satirizing the summer blockbuster Inception, saying that they had used dialogue from a video on the Web site CollegeHumor.com.

title: Whats the Next Step for Israel and the Palestinians?
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Guidelines and Malpractice
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Families, Imperfect After All
description: To the Editor:

title: Boo! Who? Actors as Goblins, Thats Who
description: BELLEVILLE, N.J.

title: Days and Nights of a Thousand Screams
description: BELLEVILLE The State Scare Factory, 229 Main Street, is open on Sunday and from Wednesday until Halloween from 7 p.m. until midnight. Tickets: $18; $15 for children 12 and under. Tickets that allow front-of-the-line access cost $28. Not recommended for children under 10. For young ones, there is a matinee at 6 p.m. Friday and Saturday and from 2 to 6 p.m. Sundays. Tickets: $8. Information: statescare.com or (973) 450-1070.

title: Are Our Drug Laws Helping or Hurting Us?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Vegetables a Bath in Hot Oil
description: WHEN it comes to getting children to eat their vegetables, there are many possible strategies.

title: Tastes and Sounds of Poland
description: Walking along Nepperhan Avenue, youre likely to hear the sounds of many cultures: the lilt of a Caribbean accent, the music of Mexico, Puerto Rican-accented Spanish. But step into the Polish Deli and youre solidly in Eastern Europe.

title: Tribune Chief Accepts Advice and Backs Out
description: The Tribune Companys board resolved on Friday what had been its preoccupation for most of the week: sealing the fate of Randy Michaels, the controversial chief executive whose boorish behavior and cronyism became a dark sideshow to his bankrupt companys financial struggles.

title: Ricotta Cheese Gnocchi
description: Mark Bittman lightens up gnocchi by substituting ricotta for the traditional potatoes.

title: Fresh Bread, Made With Care
description: In the 14 months since Ross Bread opened, it has become something of a social hub in the Copps Hill Common shopping area in Ridgefield. That is less because of its large selection of excellent breads than the attentiveness with which almost everything else there is prepared and served.

title: An Airy Respite from CMJs Subterranean Scene
description: Friday was another windy yet gorgeously sunny afternoon for CMJ, which made trolling through dank, loud subterranean clubs all day feel that much more unnatural. I dont smoke, so my excuse for all the extra trips to the sidewalk was that the cell service is better out there. Well, it is!

title: Ricotta Gnocchi Are Sticky and Lumpy (and Just Right)
description: YOU think you know what gnocchi are: small, fork-tine-indented potato dumplings served with pesto or tomato sauce. Theyre starchy, thick and filling, and rarely made well enough at home to justify the work.

title: A Bistro Without Frills, but With Refinement
description: BAR BOUCHON is so hot it sizzles. Named after the small neighborhood restaurants in Lyon, France, called bouchons, this tiny, very French bistro in Madison opened quietly two months ago, with Jean-Pierre Vuillermet of New Havens Union League Cafe as the executive chef. It is already so mobbed that I felt lucky to snag a 4:30 p.m. dinner reservation one recent Saturday.

title: For First Time, Model Has G.O.P. Favored to Win 50-Plus House Seats
description: Republican chances of taking over the House are now up to 80 percent, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast model; they had been 75 percent two days ago.

title: A Universitys New Art Museum
description: IN an era when cutbacks and closings in arts and education are so prevalent, the opening of an art museum at Fairfield University borders on astonishing.

title: On the Street | The Cape Returns
description: As the first frost arrives, a fashion look has been revived: the cape. A new generation of women in New York and Paris is discovering its drama and convenience.

title: At a Long Island Middle School, a Course in What Unites and Divides
description: JERICHO, N.Y.  Fifteen eighth graders at Jericho Middle School were considering a fictional case of stereotyping by hair color the other day, or how a boy came to be prejudiced against people with green hair, or greenies. From there, they extrapolated to the stereotypes in their own lives: dumb football players, Asian math whizzes, boring bankers.

title: Big Problem for Banks: Due Process
description: Earlier this week, Bank of America, the nations largest consumer bank, reported its third-quarter earnings. It was a very good quarter; putting aside an accounting charge  a very large, $10.4 billion accounting charge, admittedly  the bank reported $3.1 billion in profits. It was the third consecutive quarter that Bank of America had earned more than $3 billion.

title: Google Toughens Privacy Controls
description: Google said Friday that it was strengthening its privacy controls after its mapping service mistakenly gathered e-mail messages and passwords from unsecured wireless networks.

title: Fan Advocate Seeks Edge in the Washington Game
description: WASHINGTON  Brian Frederick might be the countrys most important sports fan, but he rarely wears the colors of his favorite teams or can be heard cheering them on.

title: In Congressional Races, Nonprofits Outspend National Parties
description: When the United States Supreme Court allowed unlimited, and often anonymous, corporate political spending in its landmark Citizens United decision in January, many political analysts predicted that nonprofit groups would play a big financial role in several closely watched Congressional races in New York State.

title: Why We Gave Liu Xiaobo a Nobel
description: Oslo

title: Tamar Schiffman and Jonathan Lechter
description: MEETING the parents is always awkward for couples, but for Tamar Schiffman and Jonathan Lechter it was especially uncomfortable: her parents met her future husband in a Washington hospital, as their daughter recovered from a major operation.

title: Kentucky G.O.P. Candidate, Livid Over Opponents Ad, Lashes Out
description: HARRODSBURG, Ky.  At a news conference on Thursday, Rand Paul was asked whether he planned to attend a debate Monday with Jack Conway, his Democratic challenger in this increasingly nasty Senate campaign.

title: Fast-Food Employees Reject Union Effort in a Narrow Vote
description: In one of the few efforts to unionize workers in the fast-food industry, employees at 10 Jimmy Johns sandwich shops in the Minneapolis area narrowly voted against joining a union, the National Labor Relations Board announced Friday night after counting the ballots.

title: Witches Say Beers O.K., but Lose the Fire and Stake
description: She was not looking for controversy. Vicki Noble was just looking for a fine ale.

title: Bloggingheads: Feminist Islam?
description: Journalist Mona Eltahawy, left, and Claire Berlinski of City Journal discuss Islam and women's rights.

title: Dianna Douglas, David Burk
description: Dianna M. Douglas, a daughter of Becky Douglas and John L. Douglas of New York, was married Saturday to David Burk, a son of Dr. Jane M. Burk and Gary N. Burk of Columbus, Ohio. Brent K. Pratt, an elder, performed the ceremony at the Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Kensington, Md. That evening, the bridegrooms father presided over a Jewish ceremony at the Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md.

description: Langley Wilson Perer and Jonathan Eugene Huddle were married Saturday at the Parker hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Officiating was Judge Alan Penkower, a friend of the brides family and a retired Pennsylvania judge who was appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages for the day by Los Angeles County.

title: One President, Two Campaign Styles on West Coast Swing
description: LAS VEGAS  Two President Obamas have traversed the West Coast this week, attending rallies in Portland, backyard chats in Seattle, and posh fund-raisers in Palo Alto before arriving at a raucous campaign event here on Friday night to stump for Senator Harry Reid, the man the president desperately hopes will still be majority leader next year.

title: Use of Drug Challenged in Death Penalty Case
description: Arizona plans to execute Jeffrey Landrigan next week, but his lawyers are arguing that one of the drugs that the state intends to use to end his life may not be good enough.

title: Helping Schools Chefs Find Alternatives to Frozen Pizza
description: Mark Barrett, the 37-year-old chef at Henrys Restaurant on the Upper West Side, has big ambitions for the $20,000 Hobart food mixer that sits, unused, in the kitchen of DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx. Instead of serving frozen pizza out of a box, they could be making their own dough, Mr. Barrett suggested during a tour of the school kitchen this week.

title: At Mosques, Inviting Non-Muslims Inside to Ease Hostility Toward Islam
description: Brother Abdullah was working the sidewalk outside the Omar Ben Abdel-Aziz Mosque in Jamaica, Queens, on Friday, looking for the curious, fearful, idle and confused.

title: NPR Defends Firing Williams as Criticism Mounts
description: Of the thousands of complaints that have saturated NPR in the wake of Juan Williamss firing earlier this week, some of the most telling have been from callers describing themselves as long-time viewers of NPR who warn that they are going to stop watching.

title: Match Him? Not Likely
description: He was devilishly fun to be around.

title: Marketers Can Glean Private Data on Facebook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Online advertising offers marketers the chance to aim ads at very specific groups of people  say, golf players in Illinois who make more than $150,000 a year and vacation in Hawaii.

title: Laura Hines, Gregory Laufer
description: Laura Lynch Hines and Gregory Frederick Laufer were married Saturday at Sun West Studios, a loft space in New York. Larry J. Rosen, a retired Albany County Court judge and an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated. Chief Judge Curtis V. Gmez of the Federal District Court of the Virgin Islands, for whom the bridegroom was a law clerk from 2007 to 2009 at his chambers in Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, led the ceremony.

title: Kristen Luneberg, Matt Macleod
description: Kristen Jennifer Luneberg and Anthony Matthew Macleod were married Saturday. Darlene Shlesinger, a minister affiliated with Rose Ministries, officiated in a nondenominational ceremony at Belle Mer, an event space in Newport, R.I.

title: Laura Castellano, Jeffrey Richards
description: Laura Grace Castellano, the daughter of Denise Manners Miscavage of Lehman, Pa., and Dr. Thomas J. Castellano of Harveys Lake, Pa., was married Saturday to Jeffrey Sumner Richards, a son of the Rev. Anne F. C. Richards of New Canaan, Conn., and Lee S. Richards III of Greenwich, Conn. The bridegrooms mother, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York. The Right Rev. Andrew R. St. John, the churchs rector, took part.

title: Cuts in State Agency Are Troubling, Environmentalists and Gas Drillers Agree
description: Environmentalists and the gas-and-oil industry do not agree on much, but in New York they see eye-to-eye on one thing: both believe that cuts to the state environmental agencys staff will undermine plans for natural gas drilling in the Marcellus Shale, a controversial but potentially huge source of new revenue for the cash-strapped state.

title: Ex-Companion Details Real Thomas
description: WASHINGTON  Lillian McEwen is not one of the women whose name is generally associated with Justice Clarence Thomas and his contentious confirmation hearings for a Supreme Court seat.

title: October or April, Oswalt Is Prepared
description: PHILADELPHIA  With their season sliding toward extinction, the Philadelphia Phillies had one thing to feel good about going into Game 5 of the National League Championship Series on Thursday.

title: Mets Hunt for a G.M. Is Cut to 2
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets have narrowed the field in their general manager search to two, with Sandy Alderson, widely considered the leading candidate, and Josh Byrnes set to return to Citi Field next week for follow-up interviews.

title: Curing the Ills of Americas Top Foreign Aid Agency
description: WASHINGTON

title: Citing Species Act, Judge Spares Prairie Dogs
description: WICHITA, Kan.  A Kansas ranchers long battle against the poisoning of this states biggest prairie dog colony is being hailed as a significant victory for wildlife conservation.

title: Juan Williams Offends NPR
description: Let me suggest a broadcast journalism rule of thumb: if you start a statement with the words Im not a bigot, but  just stop talking. Trust me  its not going to end well. And for Juan Williams and NPR, things have not ended well at all.

title: Plunging Rates for Refinancing Aid the Thrifty
description: For those sober souls who were thrifty long before it became fashionable, the last few years have been intensely aggravating.

title: Defensive Tackle Wreaks Havoc and Steers L.S.U.
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  The Florida offensive linemen planned to double-team Louisiana State defensive tackle Drake Nevis, but he split the pair and dashed into the Gators backfield to disrupt a run play. Later, Nevis brushed aside a block and sacked quarterback John Brantley.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Smoke and Horrors
description: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr.s recent chest-thumping against the California ballot initiative that seeks to legalize marijuana underscores how the war on drugs in this country has become a war focused on marijuana, one being waged primarily against minorities and promoted, fueled and financed primarily by Democratic politicians.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Pompoms and Towels Are Free to Wave in Playoffs
description: Theyve become a standard part of the background at playoff games in baseball: the hand towels and pompoms and handkerchiefs given to fans, who then twirl them furiously in support of the home team.

title: Emboldened G.O.P. Takes On Calif. Fixture
description: LOS ANGELES  California might seem the last state President Obama would need to visit to campaign for Democrats just 11 days before Election Day: he won here by 24 points just two years ago, after all.

title: James F. Neal, Litigated Historic Cases, Dies at 81
description: James F. Neal, a lawyer who found success in nationally prominent cases on both sides of the legal battlefield, prosecuting Jimmy Hoffa and the Watergate conspirators and defending the Ford Pinto, the Exxon Valdez, the filmmaker John Landis, Elvis Presleys doctor and Vice President Al Gore, died on Thursday in Nashville. He was 81.

title: The Way We Treat Our Troops
description: You can only hope that the very preliminary peace efforts in Afghanistan bear fruit before long. But for evidence that the United States is letting its claim to greatness, and even common decency, slip through its fingers, all you need to do is look at the way we treat our own troops.

title: Elections: Oshkosh Shrugged
description: Im in Sheboygan! said Senator Russ Feingold over the phone. Its the bratwurst capital of the world!

title: Cuomo for Governor
description: It has been many years since New York State had a governor with the vision, judgment and authority that it needs now to turn Albanys budget from obesity, to resist powerful interests, to plot a course out of an ethical netherworld in which state the government has become a national embarrassment. For the states fed-up voters, the choices are Andrew Cuomo, the Democratic state attorney general, and Carl Paladino, the Republican businessman from Buffalo.

title: Rangers Molina Has 2 Shots at a Ring
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Among baseball players, only Bengie Molina could get this lucky.

title: Britains Austerity Overdose
description: There is a time and a place for aggressive deficit reduction. Now is not the time, especially not in Britain. The deep spending cuts announced by Prime Minister David Camerons government will hobble public services, strain poor families budgets and weaken Britains influence abroad. They could suffocate a feeble recovery.

title: Jimmying the Tax Code for Votes
description: Bare-knuckled political machines masquerading as nonprofit social advocacy organizations are romping through the tax code on the strength of their own avowals that their blind attack ads serve the public interest.

title: End of One Scourge
description: Its almost impossible for a modern American to imagine what an outbreak of rinderpest, a viral cattle disease, would have looked like. But when the disease was at its worst  in Britain in the mid-1860s and South Africa in the 1890s  the spectacle must have been horrifying. Rinderpest spreads rapidly and kills nearly every animals it infects.

title: When Elite Starters Become Star Relievers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  On his walks to the bullpen, C. C. Sabathia is usually joined by a catcher and the Yankees pitching coach, Dave Eiland. But that could not happen Friday, because the Yankees game against Texas had already started.

title: Lottery Numbers

description: Happiness is knowing the answer to the first clue you look at in a Saturday crossword puzzle.

description: The biotechnology company Genzyme argued strenuously on Friday that it was worth far more than the $18.5 billion that the French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis was offering in a hostile bid.

title: Stern Says Eliminating Teams Could Be Part of Labor Discussion
description: As the N.B.A. and the players union turn up the rhetoric in labor negotiations, Commissioner David Stern acknowledged Friday that contraction could become part of the discussion.

title: A Day Without a Train
description: For three decades, Gene Russianoff, the staff lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Groups Straphangers Campaign, has championed the rights of subway riders. Most days, he is one: He and his wife, Pauline Toole, the program director of the We Are New York Community Leadership Project, do not own a car. But on Sundays, Mr. Russianoff, 57, Ms. Toole, 54, and their daughters, Jennie, 14, and Natalie, 11, who all live in Park Slope, dash around Brooklyn on foot, by bus and, if they are late to a soccer game, by car service. Taking the train on the weekend, Mr. Russianoff said, is like Russian roulette.

title: NPRs Schiller Says Juan Williams Was Fired Because of Ethics Guidelines
description: The timing might not have been perfect. But firing Juan Williams was the right decision, the NPR chief executive, Vivian Schiller, said in an interview Friday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,332 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Rangers Overpower Yankees to Gain Series Berth
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Yankees lavished $243.5 million on starting pitching two winters ago, and the splurge returned them to glory. It restored that fall ritual in New York, the championship parade, but it might have had an expiration date. The rotation started to splinter in the second half this year, and it toppled an overmatched playoff opponent in the first round, but it was no match for the Texas Rangers, who outpitched, outhit and outplayed the Yankees all the way to the World Series.

title: Walking Hamilton Has Perks (Sometimes)
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  It is always a calculated risk, especially given the identity of the batter following Josh Hamilton in the Texas lineup. But until the fifth inning on Friday night, the inherent danger of pitching around Hamilton to bring Vladimir Guerrero to the plate kept working in the Yankees favor in the American League Championship Series.

title: U.S. Envoy in China Cites Progress on Climate Pact
description: BEIJING  The top American envoy on climate issues clung to the prospect of an international agreement to counter global warming, but reported no concrete breakthroughs after two days of closed-door negotiations with China.

title: Start Time? What Start Time?
description: PHILADELPHIA  So many baseball players like to have a specific routine to prepare for a game, beginning with the time they arrive at the ballpark. But because of the flexible scheduling, the starting time of Game 6 of the National League Championship Series was unknown until the outcome of the Yankees-Rangers game was determined.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 22
description: A view of the day in sports from the balance beam to the roller speed skating track.

title: Consuelo Crespi, Aristocrat of Fashion, Dies at 82
description: Consuelo Crespi, a New York girl turned Italian countess who helped shape postwar high fashion by modeling, editing Italian Vogue and, perhaps most important, wearing the chic new thing to exactly the right places, died on Monday in Manhattan.

title: A.L.C.S. Replay: Oct. 22
description: A look at Game 6 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and the Rangers.

title: Times Photographer Wounded by an Afghan Mine
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A New York Times photographer was severely wounded Saturday when he stepped on a mine while on patrol with American soldiers in southern Afghanistan.

title: Joao Silva, Times Photographer, Is Wounded in Afghanistan  Updated
description: Joao Silva, a New York Times photographer, was severely wounded Saturday when he stepped on a mine while on patrol with American soldiers in southern Afghanistan. Mr. Silva, 44, was wounded in his legs while moving through an area near the town of Arghandab. He was evacuated from the scene and taken to Kandahar Air Field, the American and NATO base. Three American soldiers sustained concussions (this post had previously stated that none had been injured).

title: How To Think About QE2 (Wonkish)
description: Still on the run, so no long posts. But with all the talk about further quantitative easing by the Fed  QE2, for quantitative easing, the sequel  I think its worth sharing one way of thinking about whats on the table  and why you shouldnt be too optimistic about its effects. This isnt original, although I dont know who deserves the credit.

title: Q&A: Organizing Photos on an iPad
description: Q.

title: Accidents, Happy and Not, at CMJ
description: With dozens of clubs hosting hundreds of bands on ludicrously tight schedules, its all but a guarantee that even the best laid CMJ plans will go awry. Last year, Id planned a night around catching a set by the Korean-American Los Angeles party-rap group Far East Movement, but when I arrived at the venue at the appointed time, they were still two hours from going on. In the meantime, I waited through one terrible act, who shall remain nameless, and stumbled on another, Chiddy Bang, who turned out to be fantastic. I never saw Far East Movement except for in the crowd, wearing matching silvery jackets. They currently have the number one single in the country, Like a G6. At least I can say I was (almost) there way back when.

title: Fabulous Qualifying at Fabulous, Festive Korean Grand Prix
description: I can only think of superlatives to describe this Korean Grand Prix for the moment. The qualifying session just ended with a sudden, huge change in the final seconds as Sebastian Vettel took the pole position on his final lap, Mark Webber moved into second on his final lap seconds later and Fernando Alonso dropped from virtual pole to third place.

title: Fabulous Qualifying at Fabulous, Festive Korean Grand Prix
description: I can only think of superlatives to describe this Korean Grand Prix for the moment. The qualifying session just ended with a sudden, huge change in the final seconds as Sebastian Vettel took the pole position on his final lap, Mark Webber moved into second on his final lap seconds later and Fernando Alonso dropped from virtual pole to third place.

title: At Rival Music Fest, Its Deradoorian vs. the Bowling Pins
description: Whats scribbled in Angel Deradoorians notebook? It was the first thing she looked at when she came on stage Friday night at Brooklyn Bowl, where she was playing as part of the #Offline festival, organized by the music website Pitchfork as CMJ counterprogramming/piggybacking.

title: Weekend Word: One Week to Go
description: Weekly Addresses:

title: The Worst Economist in the World
description: A thought: it has occurred to me that we could use an economics equivalent of Keith Olbermanns Worst Person in the World award. KO does not, of course, mean that the person he goes after on any given night really is the worst person in the world; he just uses the title to highlight some especially awful action or statement.

title: G-20 Vows to Avoid a Currency War
description: Moving to shore up the fragile and uneven recovery, officials from the worlds 20 biggest economies promised Saturday to refrain from weakening their currencies, agreeing to let the markets exert more influence in setting foreign exchange rates.

title: Governor Forecast Update: Chafees Chances Wax; Whitmans Wane
description: Here are the candidates for governor who find themselves in a materially stronger position from earlier this week.

title: Groups Rally Behind Grannis
description: Alexander B. Pete Grannis may have lost his job as commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, but hes being lauded as a hero in some quarters.

title: Use of Contractors Added to Wars Chaos in Iraq
description: The first shots sailed past Iraqi police officers at a checkpoint. They took off in three squad cars, their lights flashing.

title: Mix of Trust and Despair Helped Turn Tide in Iraq
description: The Iraq war archive, taken as a whole with its details of incidents small and large, offers a cautionary postscript for the current military strategy in Afghanistan.

title: Acrostic: In Search of Nines
description: Two weeks ago, the acrostic consisted entirely of eight-letter words. Did you notice todays was all eights again, this time mixing in some two-word phrases? The authors (and a few guests) have more to say about this in the notes below.

title: Bloggers Stylings in Hardwood Heaven
description: Baseball has its numbers and football has its hard hits, but basketball, more than those sports, has style. And no one has done more to try to capture that than the collection of bloggers known as FreeDarko.

title: Tensions High Along Kurdish-Arab Line
description: The new trove of documents released by WikiLeaks portrays the long history of tensions between Kurds and Arabs in the north of Iraq and reveals the fears of some American units about what might happen after American troops leave the country by the end of 2011.

title: WikiLeaks Founder on the Run, Trailed by Notoriety
description: LONDON  Julian Assange moves like a hunted man. In a noisy Ethiopian restaurant in Londons rundown Paddington district, he pitches his voice barely above a whisper to foil the Western intelligence agencies he fears.

title: U.N. Compound Attacked in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least two bombers dressed in burqas and another driving a car attacked the United Nations compound in the comparatively peaceful western city of Herat just before noon on Saturday, but no one working in the compound was injured, Afghan police officials said.

title: Fighting Words
description: After weeks of debate and national strikes, the French Senate voted Friday to raise the minimum retirement age to 62 from 60 and the age for a full pension to 67 from 65. The vote all but seals passage of the measure; violent protests continued.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JIMMY KIMMEL

title: Prime Number
description: 11: The percentage decline in private donations to the nation's biggest charities last year  the steepest one-year drop in 20 years, according to Philanthropy 400, an annual survey by The Chronicle of Philanthropy. Six of the 10 largest private charities reported a decrease, including the United Way (No. 1 ), the Salvation Army (No. 2), the American Cancer Society (No. 7), and the Y (No. 10). The survey reflected the sluggish economic recovery; contributions are not expected to rebound by the end of 2010.

title: Taste, Up in the Air
description: Airline passengers can stop blaming the chef for the bland food. According to The Independent, a British newspaper, scientists at the University of Manchester investigating how sound affects taste found that subjecting diners to loud noise decreased their sensitivity to sugar and salt. Scientists speculate that a planes roaring engines distract or stress passengers enough to dull their palates. But pleasant music sparked diners tastebuds, a finding that airlines, most of which are now charging for meals, might want to heed.

title: Game-Saver of 69 Mets, Ryan Is Back in the Series
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As a pitcher and a Texan, Nolan Ryan always had fire in his belly. Now, as the 63-year-old president of the Texas Rangers, Ryan has an ample belly to go with it.

title: N.F.L. Crackdown Tests Limits of Mayhem
description: When the enormous video screens at New Meadowlands Stadium showed a replay of two players smashing into each other and crumpling to the ground last Sunday, the fans boomed Oh! in unison, marveling at the impact that sent Atlanta Falcons cornerback Dunta Robinson and Philadelphia Eagles receiver DeSean Jackson to the bench with concussions.

title: Foreclosures: A Paperwork Fiasco
description: After months of horror stories, it seemed that the real estate mess could not get any worse. But now, the nation is in the middle of yet another foreclosure crisis.

title: At Home as an Exile in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  The cabbie was like thousands of other immigrants here: out in the dead of a Saturday night, ferrying club-hopping Muscovites so he could scrape up some money to send home to relatives in other, poorer former Soviet republics.

title: Leaked Reports Stir Political Disputes in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  The release of thousands of classified Iraq war records quickly became part of Iraqs fraught political terrain on Saturday, with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki denouncing the leak as a move to derail his bid for a second term.

title: Name That Freedom
description: So now we know that Christine ODonnell, the Republican candidate for senator in Delaware, isnt a constitutional scholar.

description: Thinking about putting money into your childs business? Read Ron Liebers Your Money column first. Heres an excerpt:

title: SAP Seeks to Muzzle Oracle in Case
description: SAP has asked a California court to impose what amounts to a gag order in the companys protracted legal battle with Oracle.

title: WikiLeaks Founder Gets Support in Rebuking U.S. on Whistle-Blowers
description: LONDON  Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, and Daniel Ellsberg, who leaked the Pentagon Papers, lashed out together on Saturday at the Obama administrations aggressive pursuit of whistle-blowers, including those responsible for the release of secret documents on the Iraq war.

title: Palestinians Sentenced for Civil Disobedience
description: This month, as a new documentary about a successful campaign of nonviolent, civil disobedience by Palestinian villagers in the West Bank screens in New York and Los Angeles, Israeli military courts have handed out jail terms to two men who led similar protests against the path of Israels security barrier near their village.

title: In Hurricanes Wake, but Still Standing
description: CREOLE, La.  They waited five years for a new school at South Cameron High, five years for a weight room, lockers in the hallway and plates in the cafeteria instead of plastic trays.

title: Thinking of Joao Silva in Afghanistan
description: A superb photographer for The New York Times, Joao Silva, was seriously injured today by a landmine near Arghandab, Afghanistan. Joao was accompanying an American patrol when he stepped on the mine. He has been evacuated and is receiving treatment in Kandahar.

title: Professional Petitioners Aid Ballot Initiatives
description: CASTLE ROCK, Colo.  At 5-foot-4, with a pot belly and graying beard, Charlie Chavez does not look particularly scary.

title: On Stump, Obama Takes Sharper Tone
description: SEATTLE  President Obama walked the campaign stage with the same familiar command, to the same music as 2008, same piercing cheers, same We love you cries from the crowd and I love you backs from the president and the occasional Yes we can chant.

title: In the Mideast, No Politics but Gods
description: BEIRUT  A line was uttered this month by Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, that drew little notice in between his stentorian asides but said a great deal about politics today for Israelis, Palestinians and the larger Arab world.

title: Choosing Bearhugs Over Big Hits
description: On Sunday, more eyes than usual will be on the N.F.L. as the league begins to strictly enforce safety initiatives that limit hits to the head, players launching themselves into opponents, and gratuitous hits against defenseless players.

title: The Range of Electronica, Cathedral to Jubilant
description: I bookended Friday night with electronica: two Englishmen, Gold Panda and Jon Hopkins, early and the laptopper Baths late. All three traded in disorientation nearly as much as dance beats, but the early shift was far more decorous.

title: The British Ax, if Imported to the U.S.
description: With British leaders announcing sharp government cuts, French workers protesting their governments decision to raise the retirement age, and Republican Congressional candidates promising to unplug the federal A.T.M. the minute they arrive in Washington, austerity is the falls dominant political trend.

title: In Losing the Midterms, There May Be Winning
description: WASHINGTON  Let there be no mistake: President Obama wants the Democrats to win next weeks midterm elections. His voice has gone hoarse telling every audience that from Delaware to Oregon. But lets also acknowledge this: Although he will not say so, there is at least a plausible argument that he might be better off if they lose.

title: No F.D.A. Approval for New Diet Pill
description: The Food and Drug Administration has declined to approve what would have been the first new prescription diet pill in more than a decade.

title: Girardis Numbers and Instincts Didnt Add Up
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The baseball axiom that managers are only as good as their players applies to Joe Girardi just as much this year, in the wake of a painful defeat, as it did last season, which ended in a Champagne bath.

title: A Little Real Estate and Rock n Roll
description: Sense of discovery: thats what people look for in a festival like CMJ (or South by Southwest). But when most acts have already received attention online, it can be hard to walk out of a bar or club feeling the thrill of the find  I liked Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr., but I didnt exactly unearth them; they played a Stereogum showcase.

title: Should You Watch Football?
description: We dont watch sports because we think it is the very best use of the precious time we are granted in this life. The games entertain us. Distract us from our troubles. We like speed, violence, a hint of threat and danger because those elements raise the stakes and enhance the excitement.

title: One Weekend Full of Tackles and Injuries
description: Injuries sustained in college and N.F.L. play on Oct. 16 and 17 drew new scrutiny the dangers of football.

title: Iran Is Said to Give Top Karzai Aide Cash by the Bagful
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  One evening last August, as President Hamid Karzai wrapped up an official visit to Iran, his personal plane sat on the airport tarmac, waiting for a late-running passenger: Irans ambassador to Afghanistan.

title: Equipment Standards Group Considers Changes to Helmet Testing
description: CHATHAM, Mass.  As thousands of college football players crashed and collided on Saturday in hundreds of games before millions of spectators, about 20 experts convened in a quiet Cape Cod hotel meeting room to discuss how some of those impacts might not result in brain injuries, specifically concussions.

title: Yankees More Than An Ace Away
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Two Years After a Killing, a Heftier Reward for Information
description: City Room readers may remember the story of Stephanie Guerra, a professional baby nurse from Hollis, Queens, whose son, Keron Agard, 24, was stabbed in Astoria on Aug. 18, 2008, and died five weeks later, on Sept. 27.

title: The N.F.L.s Head Cases
description: AFTER an unusually large number of brain-jarring tackles last week, the National Football League went on the offensive against players. Commissioner Roger Goodell doled out a total of $175,000 in fines to three players and threatened future suspensions for what a league official called devastating hits to the head.

title: Point Guard Becomes a Showcase for Talent
description: When people ask Chris Paul what it is like to play in the N.B.A., his standard response leaves out references to scoring points or fame. Instead, he tells of the nightly challenges his position presents.

description: Chiefs linebacker Mike Vrabel may take a fascinating stat line into retirement  if he ever retires.

description: Amani Toomer, back arched and chest heaving, inched across the asphalt in halting steps. He cocked his head and grimaced.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tight end Bear Pascoe has been the Giants resident cowboy, a cattle-roping Californian with a taste for country music and an appreciation for the wide-open space on his familys ranch.

title: Dick Miles, Record-Setting U.S. Table Tennis Player, Dies at 85
description: Dick Miles, whose powerful forehand and sterling defensive skills made him perhaps the greatest table tennis player the United States has ever produced, died Oct. 12 in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Fool Me Twice?
description: In 2004, Americas multinational corporations offered Congress a deal: They would repatriate hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign profits  to invest in new plants and create new jobs at home  in exchange for a break from the 35 percent corporate tax rate imposed on overseas profits when they are brought into the country.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: A Beltran Imitation From Rodriguez
description: The lasting image of Carlos Beltrans six years as a Met is, of course, the called third strike he took to conclude Game 7 of the National League Championship Series against the St. Louis Cardinals in 2006. Four years later, Beltran has some company.

title: John & Yoko, & NYC
description: John Lennon could have lived anywhere. He chose New York, and clung to his adopted city with a ferocious love. Yoko Ono, too: Theres such an incredible romanticism about being refugees, she said. We just felt like we returned to our motherland, which is New York, you know.

title: A Horse of a Different Color: Green
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  They are 80 strong, not 80,000, and the object of their affection runs on 4 legs, not 22. But their cheers sound the same.

title: Fly Anglers Are Drawn to a Toothy Adversary
description: Every few years, a new sport fish emerges as the it species for fly fishers, a creature that was previously unknown to fly anglers. The list has recently included taimen, golden dorado and mahseer. Though worthy of angler attention, these quarry require lengthy journeys to faraway lands  Mongolia, Bolivia and India.

title: Haiti Fears Cholera Will Spread in Capital
description: MEXICO CITY  With the number of dead rising above 200, health officials battling a cholera outbreak in Haiti grew ever more pessimistic Saturday that the disease could be contained to a rural area and braced for a medical disaster in the capital.

title: One Mess That Cant Be Papered Over
description: LAWYERS representing delinquent homeowners have been shouting for years about documentation problems in residential mortgages. Now that their complaints have gained traction with investors, attorneys general and some state court officials, the question of consequences looms large.

title: What Happened to Change We Can Believe In?
description: PRESIDENT Obama, the Rodney Dangerfield of 2010, gets no respect for averting another Great Depression, for saving 3.3 million jobs with stimulus spending, or for salvaging GM and Chrysler from the junkyard. And none of these good deeds, no matter how substantial, will go unpunished if the projected Democratic bloodbath materializes on Election Day. Some are even going unremembered. For Obama, the ultimate indignity is the Times/CBS News poll in September showing that only 8 percent of Americans know that he gave 95 percent of American taxpayers a tax cut.

title: Indias Smaller Cities Show Off Growing Wealth
description: AURANGABAD, India  For decades this central Indian city was vintage old India: crumbling Mughal-era ruins and ancient Buddhist caves surrounded by endless parched acres from which farmers coaxed cotton.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: Now Isnt the Time to Cut the Deficit
description: THE clamor to cut the budget deficit is deafening. Blue Dog Democrats, Tea Party Republicans and doomsday economists are calling for immediate action. And the demands for austerity coming from abroad are even louder.

title: China's New Wave: Music Festivals
description: China is experiencing an explosion of music festivals sponsored by local governments. The festivals are seen as a way to draw tourist dollars and youthful hipness to cities.

title: The Election That Wasnt
description: In the past two weeks, Ive taken the Amtrak Acela to the Philadelphia and New York stations. In both places there were signs on the train platforms boasting that new construction work there was being paid for by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, that is, the $787 billion stimulus. And what was that work? New lighting  so now you can see even better just how disgustingly decayed, undersized and outdated are the rail platforms and infrastructure in two of our biggest cities.

Performers took musical potshots at the countrys leaders, tattooed college students sold antigovernment T-shirts and an unruly crowd of heavy metal fans giddily torched a Japanese flag that had been emblazoned with expletives.

But Das Racists lack of piety has become an aesthetic of its own, he wrote in a review last year, with songs that are as much commentary on hip-hop as rigorous practice of it.

title: Dispute Over Succession Clouds Megachurch
description: GARDEN GROVE, Calif.  The 10,664 windows did not get washed this year at the Crystal Cathedral, the iconic glass church founded by the Rev. Robert H. Schuller, one of the original religious broadcasters. Volunteers are tending the churchs 40 landscaped acres, now that the gardeners have been laid off. And its renowned Christmas pageant  with live camels and horses, and angels flying overhead on cables  has been canceled for now.

description: MINNEAPOLIS  President Obama wrapped up a four-day campaign swing on Saturday, telling students and the Democratic Party faithful to seize the chance to win a Republican-held governors seat here next month.

title: Reader Comments on my Afghan Women Column
description: My Sunday column from Kabul argues that we do Afghan women no favors by prolonging an unsustainable war in their name. Yes, theres reason to worry about what will happen if the Taliban gain more influence. And, yes, Im particularly concerned that fundamentalist values will gain ground even in areas where the Taliban are not formally ruling. But as I write in the column, Afghan women themselves told me that they favor a peace deal with the Taliban because war victimizes them just as much as the Taliban does. And the present course is just not sustainable.

They did not look like a team that could be trusted with such a high national ranking when they relied so much on one player.

title: Bottle Ban? What Ban? Supervisors May Ask
description: In 2007, Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco banned the use of city money to buy bottled water for municipal employees. For the mayor, it was a point of principle: the local tap water, direct from Yosemite National Park, is among the best anywhere, and in a town where even plastic bags are regulated, water delivered in plastic dispensers appeared to be an unseemly use of resources.

title: To Get a Clear View, Take the Economists Out to the Ballgame
description: In sports, as in so many walks of life, economics has a way of vindicating its status as the dismal science. That shiny new baseball stadium must be good for the economy, right? Wrong. An appearance by the local team in the World Series, that has to be a boost for businesses, no? No. Isnt there intangible value in being a major league city, and having a winning team? Well, maybe  but the emphasis is on the intangible.

title: Crosses of Lafayette
description: The Crosses of Lafayette project was started almost four years ago by Jeff Heaton, a local building contractor, to recognize American service members who were killed in Iraq. The white markers of the antiwar site dot the hillside and are easily viewed from Highway 24.

title: Can Democrats Still Win?
description: IN September 1998, after months of coverage of Monica Lewinsky, Kenneth Starr and Bill Clintons impeachment, Republicans were confident that they would make historic gains in the midterm elections. Many Democrats agreed, predicting a big loss in the House and one in the Senate, which would give Republicans a filibuster-proof supermajority, their largest since Warren G. Harding.

title: A Reason to Smile
description: You see a lot of the indie-rock deadpan at CMJ  that look of studious indifference to both the audience and any pleasure from the music. But not from Morning Teleportation, a band from Portland, Ore., whose lead singer, Tiger Merritt, grinned beatifically through its whole set at Public Assembly on Friday, singing choruses like Why is love so hard to say?

title: All Politics Is Olfactory
description: JUST days before New Yorks Republican gubernatorial primary, Carl Paladino mailed out thousands of campaign ads impregnated with the smell of rotting garbage. Emblazoned with the message Something Stinks in Albany and photos of scandal-tainted New York Democrats like former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Representative Charles Rangel, the brochure attacked Mr. Paladinos rival, former Representative Rick Lazio, for being liberal and a part of the states corrupt political system.

title: Boot the Blue Dogs
description: IN 2008, Barack Obamas presidential campaign seemed to rewrite all the rules in electoral politics and herald a new progressive era in America. Democrats assembled a huge Congressional majority and, in the euphoria that followed the historic election, were poised to enact sweeping change. However, despite some notable successes  the stimulus package, health care reform, tighter rules for the financial industry  things have not gone according to plan. Just two years later, Democrats face a bad economy, a skeptical public, a re-energized Republican Party and a coming avalanche of losses in the midterm elections.

description: A look at todays notable moments in college football.

title: Mets Face a Deadline on Keeping Takahashi
description: Because of a relatively obscure major league contract rule, the Mets have less than one week to re-sign the left-handed pitcher Hisanori Takahashi or lose him to another team. If Takahashi is not signed by Oct. 31, he can become a free agent, and if he does, he is prohibited from signing back with the Mets until May 15, virtually assuring that he will join another team.
