title: Kanye West, a Party Spoiler That No One Minds
description: There are no secrets anymore. The Internet  and particularly Twitter  has done away with all that. In a festival the size of CMJ, with so many people involved, inevitably someone will spill the beans, or at least make a conjecture, which quickly spreads to rumor, which more often than not in these cases, proves true.

title: The Swing That Wasnt
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: More on Airport Outlet Policies
description: In a Bucks post on Tuesday, The Ethics of Using Airport Outlets, I discussed my frustration with the limited number of airport power outlets and the fact that people often plugged in their laptops into one of the few outlets and then watched a movie or played a video game, without regard for others who might need the outlets.

title: Will Credit Card Settlement Bring Fee Relief to Merchants?
description: Last summer, the Senate, while debating what eventually became the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, took a stab at reining in fees for debit and credit cards. The amendment, proposed by Democratic Senator Dick Durbin of Illinois, would have ended the card networks practice of preventing merchants from using incentives to steer customers toward other credit cards and credit card brands. When the bill reached the presidents desk, however, that provision had been replaced by one that allows merchants to offer discounts only for certain forms of payment.

title: Responsible Recycling: My E-Waste Odyssey
description: Most Americans know that e-waste is supposed to be recycled. Items like cellphones, batteries, televisions, digital clocks, video game systems and broken computers shouldnt be tossed in the trash because they contain dangerous chemicals and heavy metals that could end up in landfills that way, experts warn.

title: Brown and Boxer Have Significant Leads, New Poll Shows
description: LOS ANGELES  Two Democrats in top-level races in California  Jerry Brown, the candidate for governor, and Senator Barbara Boxer, who is seeking re-election  have established significant leads over their Republican opponents in a Los Angeles Times/University of Southern California poll released on Sunday.

title: In Haiti, Capital Braces for a Cholera Outbreak
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In the raggedy Sinai tent camp, a 7-year-old with a distended belly and missing front teeth struggled to dump a bucket filled with watery diarrhea in a putrid outhouse.

title: Importing an Impressive Machine of Sound
description: Dennis Keene has been learning some new French words lately. The forklift parked in the center aisle of the church where he is the music director is a chariot electrique. The hoist above the altar is a palans electrique.

title: Gary Numan, Kanye West and More Scenes From CMJ
description: Images from the fourth and fifth nights of the music marathon.

title: Gary Numan, Kanye West and More Scenes from CMJ
description: More Photographs

title: A Girardi Footnote: Why Was the Infield In?
description: Disgruntled Yankee fans are still sorting through the decisions that Joe Girardi made in the lopsided American League Championship Series.

title: The Doctor Is Back in Session on HBO
description: Therapy is out of fashion and almost off the air.

title: Party Leaders Predict Midterm Success
description: The leaders of the Democratic and Republican national committees took to the Sunday television talk shows to predict success in the midterm elections, nine days away. But each subtly acknowledged that the Republicans had a better chance of capturing the House, and the Democrats of retaining the Senate.

title: Home Runs and Demons for Hamilton and Mantle
description: Josh Hamilton keeps moving up in stature  day by day, as he reminds himself. His career, his life, is all so fragile. But right now Hamilton is being compared to some terrific players of the recent past.

title: Iraqi Court Issues Ruling for Parliament to Return
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs highest court on Sunday ordered Parliament, elected in March and convened only once for 18 minutes, to resume its sessions, adding another wrinkle to a lengthy crisis that has tested the countrys institutions and unsettled its people.

title: The Elephant to Hollywood
description: Chapter Twelve

title: At 43, Muster Tests the Limits of an On-Court Comeback
description: It has already been quite an October for tennis players in their 40s. Kimiko Date Krumm. 40, struck her latest blow for the middle-aged by reaching the final in Osaka, Japan, this month and nearly became the oldest singles champion in womens tour history.

title: Advocates Hope Transgender Identity Is Not a Defining One
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Theresa Sparks, a candidate for the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, is running on what some might see as a conservative platform: she is pro-development and anti-loitering, pro-police and anti-grime. She has been endorsed by the mayor, the citys firefighters union and the county deputy sheriffs association.

title: Readers Shoot CMJ
description: Times readers submitted their photographs from the CMJ Music Marathon in New York.

title: Angels in America Earns Place in Pantheon
description: Angels in America, Tony Kushners fever dream about Ronald Reagan and AIDS, love and abandonment, has emerged as the most influential American play of the last two decades. Now about to open in its first New York revival since an acclaimed Broadway run in 1993-94, the play has survived controversy and its own unusual, unruly structure to become a mainstay of the literary canon, produced on college campuses and taught in classrooms with the same reverence as Death of a Salesman and A Streetcar Named Desire.

title: Bush to Visit Oprah to Promote Book
description: Oprah Winfrey will conduct the second television interview with former President George W. Bush as he embarks on a book tour. The interview will be shown on Nov. 9, the day his book, Decision Points, is published by Crown. Mr. Bushs first sit-down TV talk will be with Matt Lauer of the Today show, and will be shown on Nov. 8 in prime time on NBC. Ms. Winfrey was an avid supporter of President Barack Obama during the 2008 campaign.

title: Ben Vereen to Lead Town Halls 90th Season
description: The musical veterans Ben Vereen, Linda Eder and Kelli OHara are to be among the performers headlining Town Halls 90th anniversary season, the theater announced. Mr. Vereen, right, will perform his one-man tribute to Broadway, Frank Sinatra and Sammy Davis Jr. on Feb. 18, followed by solo concerts by Ms. Eder (May 20) and Ms. OHara (June 3). Other season highlights include Don McLean (American Pie), joined by the folk-pop singer and songwriter Dar Williams, on March 25; and Dee Dee Bridgewaters Billie  Holiday show on June 24 (212-840-2824; the-townhall-nyc.org).

title: Footnotes
description: Pilobolus Dance Theater and the critic and historian Deborah Jowitt are among the winners of the 53rd annual Dance Magazine Awards. The honors, to be handed out at a ceremony next Monday, will also go to Matthew Rushing, a dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and Irina Kolpakova, a ballet mistress at American Ballet Theater. ... The Kneehigh Theater Companys adaptation of Nol Cowards Brief Encounter, playing on Broadway at Studio 54, has been extended four weeks, Playbill reported. The show, based on Cowards one-act play Still Life and featuring original music by Coward, was scheduled to close on Dec. 5 but will now run through Jan. 2. ... Sondheim! The Birthday Concert, which celebrated the 80th birthday of Stephen Sondheim at Avery Fisher Hall in March, will be broadcast on PBS televisions Great Performances series on Nov. 24. The concert was hosted by David Hyde Pierce and featured appearances by Patti LuPone, Audra McDonald, Mandy Patinkin, Bernadette Peters and Elaine Stritch, among others, accompanied by the New York Philharmonic, with Paul Gemignani conducting.

title: French Prince Wants Murakami Out of Palace
description: A descendant of the French king Louis XIV has requested a court order to end an exhibition of works by the Japanese artist Takashi Murakami  in the Palace of Versailles, Agence France-Presse reported. Prince Sixte-Henri de Bourbon-Parme said the large, brightly colored pieces, created in the style of Japanese manga comics and scheduled to be on view through Dec. 12 in the palaces stately salons, above, offend the memory of his ancestors. Were not against the modernity of art but against a way of thinking that denatures and does French culture no good, the prince told the news agency. He was joined in the suit by the Versailles Defense Coordination, which formed in 2008 when the princes nephew Prince Charles-Emmanuel de Bourbon-Parme filed a similar suit to try to ban the display of sculptures by the American artist Jeff Koons in the palace. That suit was dismissed by the court and the show was well received by the public.

title: Top Movies Almost Paranormal Feat
description: The low-budget horror film Paranormal Activity 2 pulled off a rare trick over the weekend: with $41.5 million in ticket sales at the North American box office, easily enough for No. 1  and another $22 million overseas  it was immediately profitable. The movie that hits the black in its first three days is almost nonexistent. Most Hollywood releases, with outsize production budgets, enormous marketing costs and a 50 percent split in revenue with movie theater owners, do not turn a profit for studios until the DVD release. But Paranormal Activity 2 was produced by Paramount Pictures for just $3 million and given a cheaper-than-usual marketing campaign that relied heavily on Web chatter. Paramount was doing cartwheels on Sunday, partly because it also had the second-place movie: Jackass 3D took in about $21.6 million for a two-week total of $87.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticket statistics. The ensemble action picture Red (Summit Entertainment) was third with $15 million for a new total of $43.5 million. Clint Eastwoods Hereafter (Warner Brothers) was fourth in its first wide-release weekend with $12 million. And The Social Network (Sony Pictures Entertainment) continued to show strong audience interest in fifth place, selling $7.3 million for a total of about $73 million.

title: A Zombie Invasion From Across the Atlantic
description: While vampires and werewolves battle to be our favorite scary monsters, a new contender lurches into view. Zombies, already a movie and video-game staple, are infecting television this Halloween season with the arrival of AMCs new series, The Walking Dead, on Sunday (Halloween night) and the unspooling this week of the British mini-series Dead Set on IFC.

title: Stories vs. Statistics
description: Half a century ago the British scientist and novelist C. P. Snow bemoaned the estrangement of what he termed the two cultures in modern society  the literary and the scientific. These days, there is some reason to celebrate better communication between these domains, if only because of the increasingly visible salience of scientific ideas. Still a gap remains, and so Id like here to take an oblique look at a few lesser-known contrasts and divisions between subdomains of the two cultures, specifically those between stories and statistics.

title: A Wayward Son Checks in With Mother Russia
description: MOSCOW  It was late in the Brezhnev era when a boy named Igor Semyonovich Shteyngart took up writing at the urging of his grandmother, who rewarded him for his labors with bits of cheese. Inspired by a statue of Lenin near his home, he scribbled a fairy tale called Lenin and His Magical Goose. Perhaps you will read it someday. The title characters meet, become friends and decide to invade Finland together to set up a glorious Soviet republic there.

title: A Sound Is Molded to Become an Eclipse
description: Matthias Pintschers music whispers far more often than it shouts. But when this imaginative 39-year-old German composer and conductor wants an ensemble to produce a big sound, he is not shy about asking its percussionists to supply a generous helping of thunder, sometimes supported by full-throttle, harmonically dense contributions from the brasses and woodwinds.

title: Madea Takes a Break, and Tyler Perry Gets Serious
description: LOS ANGELES  Is Tyler Perry capable of highbrow cinema? The studio behind his 10th movie is determined to make audiences and Oscar voters look beyond his track record and answer yes.

title: Public Housing Repairs Cant Keep Pace With Need
description: Public housing is falling apart around the country, as federal money has been unable to keep up with the repair needs of buildings more than half a century old.

title: 60s Sondheim TV Show Is Now on (Legal) DVD
description: Attention Stephen Sondheim groupies: Youve lost bragging rights to your bootleg copies of Evening Primrose.

title: Garden State Scandals
description: The Soprano State: New Jerseys Culture of Corruption strikes a lighthearted, if cynical, tone as it reviews some of the worst recent scandals. The documentary presents itself as a nightclub act, with Tony Darrow, who played small parts in The Sopranos and Goodfellas, narrating from a stage while lounge-lizard music is piped in. But the message of the film, based on the 2008 book of the same name by the longtime Trenton reporters Bob Ingle and Sandy McClure, is relentlessly bleak.

title: What It Was All About for Alfie, Now a Grandpa
description: Michael Caines Elephant to Hollywood is an unabashedly old-school celebrity memoir. Its tales sound oft-told because they probably are. Mr. Caine is a charming raconteur, specializing in anecdotes packed with famous names. In these stories all the famous people do their famous-people things, whether its Jack Nicholson grinning with that wolfish Nicholson grin or John Wayne striding into the lobby of the Beverly Hills Hotel in full cowboy regalia.

title: Monday: An Exciting Opening Number
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Wham! Boom! Bam! Pow! This Monday puzzle by Jonah Kagan reminds me of the old Batman TV series. The puzzle week STARTS WITH A BANG, and so do each of the theme answers.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: DARIUS RUCKER

title: Eagles Going Back to Vick
description: Eagles Coach Andy Reid announced after Sundays 37-19 loss to the Titans that he was switching quarterbacks  again. Michael Vick will replace Kevin Kolb when the Eagles return from their bye week on Nov. 7.

title: Bands Dream Globally, Play Locally
description: The sweetest white lie of the CMJ Music Marathon came from the folky songwriter Lia Ices, leading her band at the Lower East Side club Pianos on Thursday night. While half the crowd chatted indifferently, she sang, For only you I sing, for only you. Yet Ms. Ices, whose debut album is due in January, was playing CMJ, along with more than 1,000 other groups, for precisely the opposite reason. She was seeking a chance to be heard, sooner or later, by a larger audience.

title: Looking Back at CMJ 2010
description: Photographs from the festival, which ran in New York from Tuesday through Saturday.

title: Drug Testing Poses Quandary for Employers
description: LAWRENCEBURG, Tenn.  The news, delivered in a phone call, left Sue Bates aghast: she was losing her job of 22 years after testing positive for a legally prescribed drug.

title: Against Odds, Web Site Finds Niche
description: Something odd showed up last week in the mailbox of Choire Sicha, a veteran blogger who lost his job and started a Web site with a few pals two years ago: a paycheck.

title: A Frozen Moment in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Wife of American Held in Cuba Pleads for His Release and Apologizes to Castro
description: WASHINGTON  The wife of an American contractor detained in Cuba nearly a year ago has sent a letter to President Ral Castro, apologizing for her husbands actions and pleading for his release.

title: Death Toll in Jurez Attack Rises to 14
description: MEXICO CITY  The death toll rose to 14 in the weekend massacre at a boys birthday party in Ciudad Jurez, the Chihuahua State attorney generals office said Sunday.

title: Many Tables, but Only One Successful Defense
description: The winners of the Imp Pairs at the recent world championships in Philadelphia were Wolfe Thompson of Las Vegas and Marc Zwerling of Portland, Ore. They were 292.8 international match points ahead of Joao-Paulo Campos and Miguel Villas-Boas from Brazil, with Kelley Hwang of New York and John Zilic of Houston third.

title: Pitching Movies or Filming Shows, Hollywood Is Hooked on iPads
description: Last month at a meeting in Hollywood, it was time to plot out the sequel to Star Trek, last years blockbuster reboot of the sci-fi franchise.

title: App Makers Take Interest in Android
description: There was cold beer, hot pizza and shop talk at a recent informal gathering of Android programmers in downtown Manhattan. Inevitably the chatter turned to money.

title: In Colorado, Voters Voice Uncertainty and Anger
description: LOVELAND, Colo.  That Americans are angry and anxious heading toward the Nov. 2 elections has become a truism, an assumption built into candidate calculations from the lowest local alderman on up. Plot a voters place on the rage scale, and voil, out pops a prediction of the expected anti-Democrat, or anti-establishment, backlash.

title: Sports Replay: Oct. 24
description: The day in sports, from gymnastics to football.

title: Burton Roberts, 88, Tom Wolfes Model Judge, Dies
description: Burton B. Roberts, a celebrated former justice and chief administrative judge of State Supreme Court in the Bronx and a larger-than-life model for an irascible judge in Tom Wolfes 1987 best-seller, The Bonfire of the Vanities, died on Sunday. He was 88.

title: Distance Runners Are a Paradox for Insurers
description: Jennifer Frighetto is not a marathoner, but it is not for lack of trying. Had she crossed the finish line at this years race in Chicago, it would have been her first successful attempt at the 26.2-mile distance. But just as at the 2008 and 2009 Chicago Marathons, Frighetto was unable to finish because of injury.

title: Ruling on Fumble Rescues the Steelers
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Pittsburgh Coach Mike Tomlin could be heard in the locker room calling for the buses to be warmed up moments after the Steelers 23-22 victory over the Miami Dolphins ended Sunday.

title: TV Watchdog Group Is on the Defensive
description: LOS ANGELES  These are difficult days for the decency police.

title: Dog Days
description: Dogs in China now play with the best of them as dogs acquire a new status in the country.

title: Some Question Insistence on Israel as Jewish State
description: JERUSALEM  The more stridently Israel insists on Palestinian recognition of it as the nation-state of the Jewish people, the more adamantly the Palestinian leadership seems to refuse.

title: Newcomer Faces Hurdles in Challenging Rangel, the 40-Year Harlem Incumbent
description: It was the start of the 1981 season, and the New York Jets rookie, Michel J. Faulkner, was unlucky enough to be assigned a locker next to that of Mark Gastineau, a superstar.

title: MTV Is Looking Beyond Jersey Shore to Build a Wider Audience
description: The second-season finale of Jersey Shore last week was one of the highest-rated hours all year on MTV. There was, perhaps, no better time to promote another boozy, in-your-face unscripted show.

title: Once Banned, Dogs Reflect Chinas Rise
description: BEIJING  Xiangzi  Lucky, in English  is aptly named. A trim Siberian husky, his owner, a sports marketer named Qiu Hong, pampers him with two daily walks, a brace of imported American toys and grooming tools, $300 worth of monthly food and treats and his own sofa in her high-rise apartment.

title: I.M.F. Gains Sway, but Its Authority Is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON  Can the International Monetary Fund achieve what seems like a mission impossible: bridge the increasingly tense currency and trade disputes that threaten to set back the uneven global recovery?

title: Missouri Moves Into National Title Picture
description: For decades, Missouris football program seemed to exist solely to give the graduates of its esteemed journalism school a way to conjure new hyperbole for haplessness. A longtime doormat with little history and less national prestige, Missouri seemingly served only as a speed bump for the teams from Nebraska, Oklahoma and Texas on their inevitable drives to glory.

title: Jets Pryce Pursues a Hollywood Career
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The e-mail that arrived unexpectedly at International Creative Management in Los Angeles seemed so far-fetched, so unbelievable, the company at first considered it a hoax.

title: Cuomo Vows Offensive Against Labor Unions
description: Andrew M. Cuomo will mount a presidential-style permanent political campaign to counter the well-financed labor unions he believes have bullied previous governors and lawmakers into making bad decisions. He will seek to transform the states weak business lobby into a more formidable ally, believing that corporate leaders in New York have virtually surrendered the field to big labor.

title: Fox-Cablevision Dispute May Obstruct Customers View of World Series
description: The feud between Cablevision and the News Corporation has already resulted in an extraordinarily long blackout of programming. Now it threatens to shut Cablevision customers out of the World Series.

title: Carlsen and Bacrot Win Again at Pearl Spring
Charging, Ever So Carefully, Into a New Era
description: Baltimore

title: Cuomo and Paladino on the Issues
description: Nicholas Confessore of The New York Times sat down with the Republican and Democratic nominees for New York governor.

title: Debut for a Nimbler, Newsier National Journal
description: WASHINGTON  The conversation is a term of art in the media often associated with longing. Media companies want to join it, shape it, lead it.

title: To Giants Andrews, Music is a Consuming Passion
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In a small black bag, Shawn Andrews stowed the evidence of his dual lives. Inside were a Giants playbook thick with diagrams of blocking schemes and a silver laptop containing compositions of drumbeats.

title: Drug and Alcohol Abuse Growing in Iraqi Forces
description: BAGHDAD  A growing number of Iraqi security force members are becoming dependent on drugs or alcohol, which has led to concerns about a significant addiction problem among the countrys armed services as the insurgency remains a potent force and American troops prepare to depart at the end of next year.

title: When a Cancer Therapy Puts Others at Risk
description: WASHINGTON  Doctors told Ann B. Maddox that she had thyroid cancer and that the cure was to swallow radioactive iodine, to kill the malignant cells. She traveled 500 miles from her home in Fayetteville, N.C., for treatment at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.

title: Boise State or T.C.U.? No Comment
description: Not long after Oregon State lost at Boise State on Sept. 25, Oregon State Coach Mike Riley chuckled when a reporter asked how the Broncos compared to Texas Christian. Oregon State had opened its season against T.C.U., and Riley joked that he would be hearing the question comparing both teams for the rest of the year. So he dodged it.

title: At Stadium, a Quiet Fall Cleaning
description: A year after parading on Broadway after their 27th championship, the Yankees returned to a postseason ritual Sunday that has become more familiar over the past decade: cleaning out their lockers after being eliminated from the playoffs.

title: The Causes of Poverty, and the Cures
description: To the Editor:

title: Pregame Chatter Is Helmets and Hits
description: For decades, the N.F.L. and television networks have worked hand in hand to promote football and make money for the broadcasters and their advertisers. So perhaps predictably, many of the analysts and players on shows before and after Sundays games sided with the leagues decision to better enforce its rules against helmet-to-helmet hits.

title: The Power of Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Building Afghan Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Playbook After Nov. 2
description: WASHINGTON  It took President Obama 18 months to invite the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell, to the White House for a one-on-one chat. Their Aug. 4 session in the Oval Office  30 minutes of private time, interrupted only when the presidents daughter Malia called from summer camp to wish her father a happy 49th birthday  was remarkable, not for what was said, but for what it took to make it happen.

title: Pro-Republican Groups Prepare Big Push at End of Races
description: OVIEDO, Fla.  The anonymously financed conservative groups that have played such a crucial role this campaign year are starting a carefully coordinated final push to deliver control of Congress to Republicans, shifting money among some 80 House races they are monitoring day by day.

title: Stories of Hope and Hardship of Los 33
description: COPIAP, Chile  Jos Ojeda can barely sleep without the comfort of a miner nearby to confide in when dreams shake him awake. Omar Reygadas, a great-grandfather more used to comforting than being comforted, cries easily. And Edison Pea, the miner who kept himself grounded by running miles underground most days, was hospitalized last week for emotional distress.

title: The Democrats and Young Black Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Sales Resisted as Foreclosures Are Revived
description: PHOENIX  Bank of America and GMAC are firing up their formidable foreclosure machines again today, after a brief pause.

title: Long-Term Benefits and Side Effects of Medications
description: To the Editor:

title: Betty S. Murphy, a Leader of the N.L.R.B., Dies at 77
description: Betty Southard Murphy, a trial lawyer who became chairwoman of the National Labor Relations Board and the first woman to serve on the board, died on Oct. 16 in Washington. She was 77.

title: A Village in Italy Embraces Paladino
description: SANTA CROCE DI MAGLIANO, Italy  To many in this hilltop village in southern Italy, Carl P. Paladino is simply known as OMericano, or the American.

title: Bochy Again Takes Underdog to the World Series
description: PHILADELPHIA  At the end of his fourth year managing the San Diego Padres, Bruce Bochy led his team to the 1998 World Series. Now Bochy is doing the same thing at the conclusion of his fourth year managing the San Francisco Giants.

title: In Massachusetts Race, Ideology Isnt Only Issue
description: QUINCY, Mass.  Jeff Perry has a role model: Senator Scott Brown.

title: Fighting Disease in Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: In Triple-Murder Trial, the Exhausting Routine of Deciding a Killers Fate
description: NEW HAVEN  There is a morning chill now when people line up to get into the Cheshire trial. It is no longer balmy summer in the dark out on Church Street, as it was when the trial began on Sept. 13. But the full bite of fall is not here yet either.

title: Grasping for the Center in a Tight Connecticut House Race
description: Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Early Voter Enthusiasm Gap Appears Consistent With Polls
description: Theres been a lot of discussion recently about early voting data, which is already available in a number of states. In most parts of the country, indeed, a voter is already able to cast a ballot if she wants do.

title: Knicks Extend Contracts of 3 Players
description: The Knicks exercised the fourth-year options of forwards Danilo Gallinari and Anthony Randolph and the third-year option of guard Toney Douglas. All three have been mentioned as possible trading chips for the Knicks, and the options lock the players into another year under their rookie-scale contracts for potential suitors. The Knicks also waived forward Patrick Ewing Jr.

title: Tough as Nails, but Always Ready for a Bearhug
description: It is 8:30 a.m. at De La Salle Academy, a private school in Manhattan for academically talented poor children, and classical music is humming through a boom box that harks back to the 1980s.

title: Rangers Win Short-Handed as Devils Look for a Spark
description: Ilya Kovalchuk was the last Devils player to step on the ice Sunday night for a game against the Rangers, but at least he made it out there. One day after he was scratched from a game for reasons that remained a mystery, Kovalchuk tried hoisting the Devils out of a ditch.

title: Voting Early, but Not So Often
description: Madison, Wis.

title: Family of Pace University Student Killed by Police Seeks Clarity Amid Grief
description: In the week since a college student was shot and killed by the police outside a bar in Thornwood, N.Y., there has been a wealth of grief and accusations, but little clarity about whether the shooting was justified.

title: Declaring Independence, Even as Obama Stumps
description: LAS VEGAS  Through the blur of final campaign speeches and television advertisements, heres one thing voters everywhere can expect to see: the independence reflex.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Accounts, People and Miscellany
description: News From the Advertising Industry

title: Mad Men as an Echo of Reality
description: THESE days, BBDO has two client rosters. One is composed of the clients the agency actually handles, and the other lists the clients that the agency handles in the make-believe world of Mad Men.

title: The R.O.T.C. Myth
description: Gainesville, Fla.

title: Self-Publisher Comes to SoHo
description: To make a book using an online publishing service, you create the design, add text or images, pay the fee, and in a few days or a week, the finished product is delivered to your door.

title: Falling Into the Chasm
description: This is what happens when you need to leap over an economic chasm  but either cant or wont jump far enough, so that you only get part of the way across.

title: Clerks Killing Adds to History of Violence at a Queens Deli
description: Beneath the awning of the Lucky Grocery & Deli in Laurelton, Queens, on Sunday, the steel gate was drawn down, a cold backdrop for the various items of mournful remembrance: two handwritten notes, flowers, a stuffed red bear and numerous votive candles.

title: Globe and Mail Uses Old Weapons in Press War
description: TORONTO  Like many newspapers in North America, The Globe and Mail rushed out an iPad application. But the technology that the 166-year-old Globe is really staking its future on is not the sort that immediately comes to mind in an increasingly digital world. This paper has made a nearly $2 billion commitment over 18 years to new printing presses.

title: The Shadows of an Airborne Life
description: Jan Maxwell is an actress of such natural authority that she becomes the center of gravity in almost every scene in which she appears. Even when she does demented, as in the child-hating cartoon villainess in Chitty Chitty Bang Bang or the drab but deranged sexual flytrap of Entertaining Mr. Sloane, I always feel that her characters perspective is the sanest. I trust Ms. Maxwell to show me the world  or the world of a play  as it is.

title: An Indefensible Defense
description: It can be hard to distinguish between the Bush administration and the Obama administration when it comes to detainee policy. A case the Supreme Court agreed last week to hear, Ashcroft v. al-Kidd, is one of those occasions.

title: After the Spill
description: The six-month anniversary of the BP oil spill passed quietly last week. The well has been capped, and commerce in the Gulf of Mexico is slowly reviving. Much important work still lies ahead  figuring out how much oil is still out there, cleaning it up, measuring the damage to marine life, compensating victims. And Congress needs to pass an oil-spill bill that will reduce the chances of another drilling debacle.

title: In India, Workers Find Humor in Outsourced
description: GURGAON, India  The laughter was coming as fast as the stereotypes.

title: The Long Recovery From 9/11
description: Nine years after the attack on the World Trade Center, a crucial deadline is approaching for helping thousands of first responders, cleanup workers and volunteers suffering long-term medical and economic losses.

title: In Senate Debate, Jabs Sometimes Get Personal
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York and the Republican seeking to unseat him, Jay Townsend, sparred over health care, federal spending and Wall Street on Sunday in a debate marked by tart exchanges.

title: New Jerseys Governor and the Public Education Debate
description: New Jerseys governor, Chris Christie, has been bludgeoning the states teachers and their unions since he took office earlier this year. The name-calling has raised his profile nationally, and made him a darling of the right. It has also made rational conversation on school reform nearly impossible.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Blurring the Line Between Apps and Books
description: STEPHEN ELLIOTT, a 38-year-old from San Francisco, just introduced his first piece of software for sale: an app for the iPad and iPhone called the Adderall Diaries.

title: Tipping Point for Apps on Facebook
description: Users of Facebook can download free applications, which allow them, for example, to play poker with friends or compare each others taste in movies.

title: Sol Steinmetz, an Expert on Language, Dies at 80
description: Sol Steinmetz, a lexicographer, author and tenured member of Olbom (n., abbrev., < On Languages Board of Octogenarian Mentors), whose opinions on matters semantical, grammatical and etymological were widely sought by the news media, died on Oct. 13 in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Looking Ahead: Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include existing home sales for September from the National Association of Realtors (Monday); the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller index of home prices for August and the Consumer Confidence Index (Tuesday); durable goods for September and new home sales for September from the government (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and third-quarter gross domestic product (Friday).

title: Carlyle Bids to Take CommScope Private
description: 3:19 a.m. | Updated Updates with CommScope confirmation.

description: faction \fak-shn\ noun

title: The Great Bailout Backlash
description: Nothing in this election season, no program or party or politician, is less popular than the Troubled Asset Relief Program of 2008  a k a the Wall Street bailout. No policy has fewer public figures willing to defend it, and fewer Americans who believe it worked. No issue has done more to stoke the fires of populist backlash, and the rage against elites.

title: Lottery Numbers
Officer Is Praised for Conduct in Shootout at Brooklyn Salon
description: An off-duty police officer, who engaged in a shootout with a man who tried to hold up the Brooklyn beauty salon where she was getting her hair done, was being praised for her actions on Sunday. The police were still looking for the suspect, who was wounded in the confrontation.

title: NPRs C.E.O. Apologizes for Handling of Williams Episode
description: In the latest dispatch from the war between Juan Williams and NPR, Vivian Schiller, its chief executive, apologized to her colleagues for how she handled Mr. Williamss firing over remarks he made about Muslims. But she did not apologize for the firing itself.

title: Foreclosures Had Errors, Bank Finds
description: Even as Bank of America begins to restart foreclosure proceedings in 23 states on Monday, the bank confirmed that it had discovered errors, including incorrect data and misspelled names, in the paperwork it has reviewed.

title: A.I.A.s I.P.O. Is Good for Everyone Involved
description: Freedom is at hand at last for the American International Groups Asian business, A.I.A. The units $30.5 billion initial public offering in Hong Kong priced at the top of the indicated range. Factoring in the extra shares to be sold if early trading goes well, the float will cut the stake held by its beleaguered American parent company to just 33 percent. It is a much needed result for Mark Tucker, A.I.A.s new boss; A.I.G.; and Goldman Sachs, the I.P.O.s lead manager.

title: News Quiz | October 25, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: The Subway in Pictures
description: HOW old is the New York City subway system this week?

title: Singapore Bourse to Buy Australian Exchange Firm
description: The Singapore stock exchange said Monday that it would offer to buy its Australian counterpart for $8.3 billion, a purchase that would create a leading player in a region that has not yet seen the major consolidation that has taken place in other parts of the world, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

title: A Governor Can Be a Formidable Force
description: Nicholas Confessore, a reporter for The New York Times, interviewed the two major candidates for New York governor, Andrew M. Cuomo and Carl P. Paladino, to discuss their approaches to governing. Following are edited excerpts of the interview with Mr. Cuomo.

title: Owners Seek to Sell, but Banks Push Foreclosure
description: Bank of America and GMAC are firing up their formidable foreclosure machines again today, after a brief pause, Michael Powell reports in The New York Times.

description: Even as Bank of America begins to restart foreclosure proceedings in 23 states on Monday, the bank confirmed that it had discovered errors, including incorrect data and misspelled names, in the paperwork it had reviewed, Nelson D. Schwartz reports in The New York Times.

title: LVMH Takes Minority Stake in Herms
description: LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods giant, says it has bought a minority stake in the family-controlled handbag maker Herms but would not seek to take over the company or influence its strategy, Reuters reports.

title: Equinox Minerals to Buy Citadel Group for $1.2 Billion
description: Equinox Minerals, the Canadian-Australian copper miner, announced a 1.25 billion Australian dollar takeover deal on Monday for Citadel Resource Group of Australia, Reuters reports.

title: NuCaptcha Engage Puts Security Feature in a Video
description: Almost everyone who uses the Internet has been stopped at one time or another by a security feature called captcha, the wavy, distorted letters and numbers often found in a pixelated box that users are asked to type to prove they are human and not a piece of technology.

title: U.S. Drops Criminal Charges Against UBS
description: Federal prosecutors have dropped criminal charges against UBS, saying that the Swiss bank had gotten out of the business of selling offshore private banking services that allowed wealthy Americans to avoid billions of dollars in taxes, Lynnley Browning reports in The New York Times.

title: Judge Holds Greenberg Liable for Reinsurance Damages
description: A judge has held Maurice R. Greenberg, a former chief executive of American International Group, liable for damages on a reinsurance transaction that Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has said helped the insurer hide losses, Reuters reports.

description: Plum Willow, a new online shopping site for teenage girls, calls on a team of 15- and 16-year-old interns for advice about how to design and market the site. What business  whether on the Web, in the mall, or anywhere else  do you have some advice for? What would you want to tell them? Why?

description: The Bloomberg News reporter Mark Pittman, who died last November, asked the Treasury Department in January 2009 to identify $301 billion of securities owned by Citigroup that the government had agreed to guarantee.

title: Ex-Executives of Dubai Bank Face Heavier Penalties
description: A Dubai court has restarted a fraud trial against two former executives of Dubai Islamic Bank. The court changed their status to government officials on Sunday, making a stricter punishment more likely, Reuters reported.

description: Adobe Systems aims to grow independently, its chief executive told a German newspaper, after speculation that the company could become a takeover target for Microsoft, according to Reuters.

title: In Afghan and American Custody
description: John Moore of Getty Images has visited American-run detention centers in Iraq, including Abu Ghraib and Camp Cropper; prisons for Taliban fighters in Afghanistan run by that countrys National Directorate of Security; the Pul-i-Charkhi prison outside Kabul; and, more recently, the Guantnamo Bay detention center. He is gathering these images in a longterm project, Detained. James Estrin and David Furst interviewed him by telephone in August and then again briefly following his most recent visit to Guantnamo. The transcript of their conversation has been edited.

title: Air Products Gets F.T.C. Blessing for Air Gas Bid
description: Air Products and Chemicals is free to go ahead with its attempted acquisition of Air Gas, the Federal Trade Commission has ruled, provided that it addresses certain anticompetition concerns.

description: The Tribune Companys board has resolved what had been its preoccupation for most of last week: sealing the fate of Randy Michaels, the chief executive whose behavior and cronyism cast a dark sideshow on the bankrupt companys financial struggles.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  Freighters carrying aid shipments of rice and instant noodles are being sent to North Korea, the first food aid the South Korean government has sent to the North since President Lee Myung-bak was elected here in early 2008.

description: Perpetual, the Australian financial services group, said on Monday that the $1.73 billion offered by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts last week to take it private was too low, but that it would nonetheless enter into discussions with the private equity firm.

title: S.E.C. Plans to Streamline Complaint Process
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is planning to streamline its complaint process by electronically cataloging alleged securities violations, The Wall Street Journal reported.

description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: Focus on Middle East at London Poetry Festival
description: On the belief that poets, not politicians, can help bring about tangible political change, Londons Southbank Center will again host its biennial Poetry International festival, nine days worth of readings, music, translations and new poetry commissions.

description: Behold the Cleveland Browns  flippers of laterals, fakers of punts, takers of chances, tricksters without peer.

description: Apollo Global Management and CVC Capital Partners are planning to make a formal takeover offer for Brit Insurance Holdings, according to British press reports.

title: Analysts Expect UBS to Report 3rd-Quarter Profit
description: UBS, the biggest Swiss bank, will probably report a fourth consecutive quarterly profit on Tuesday and its lowest wealth management redemptions since 2008, Bloomberg News reports.

title: OGI Capital Hires Former Alfred Berg Manager
description: OGI Capital Partners has hired Marcus Blomberg, a former fund manager at Alfred Berg Asset Management, as a trader to help expand its global macro fund, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Banco Popolare to Raise Up to $2.8 Billion
description: Banco Popolare, one of the largest banks in Italy, has said it plans to raise up to 2 billion euros ($2.8 billion) in a rights issue set for the first quarter of 2011, causing its shares to fall more than 4 percent on Monday in Milan.

title: Fund-Raising Down in Third Quarter
description: Just $5.4 billion has been raised by 662 venture capital companies in the third quarter, a significant drop from the $7.7 billion raised in the previous quarter, TechCrunch said, citing figures released by Dow Jones on Monday.

title: Facebook Shareholder Mail.ru in $876 Million I.P.O.
description: Mail.ru Group, a Russian Internet company with stakes in Facebook and Zynga Game Network, is seeking as much as $876 million in an initial public offering in London, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Serbia Moves Closer to Joining E.U.
description: LUXEMBOURG  Serbia took a significant step toward membership in the European Union on Monday, despite the unions suspicions that the country could do more to bring Europes most-wanted war crimes suspect to justice.

title: Are Big Layoffs Coming at Man Group?
description: Is the Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund manager, preparing to hand out a swath of pink slips?

description: President Obama is getting out of Dodge within days of next weeks elections, one way or the other. But his reprieve from Beltway politics will be short-lived.

description: R.I.P. MR. C Small-business man and hardware shop owner Howard Cunningham died last week.

title: With a Healthy McFadden, Are the Raiders a Playoff Team?
description: It would be easy to discount Oaklands 59-14 victory at Denver on Sunday. After all, these are the Raiders, the team that opened the season with a 38-13 loss to Tennessee, and that last week lost to the 49ers (1-6).

title: Cuban Offers to Bankroll S.E.C. Lawyers to Speed Case
description: Mark Cuban, pictured, is offering to bankroll a team lawyers to help the Securities and Exchange Commission in its review of the agencys case against him.

title: Giga Omni Raises $2.5 Million in New Funding
description: Giga Omni Media, parent company of the GigaOm technology-focused blog, among others, has raised a fresh $2.5 million of funding, VentureBeat reports.

title: OMV Taking Over Turkish Fuel Distributor
description: OMV, the Austrian energy company, said on Monday that it was buying more than half of the Turkish fuel and lubricant distribution company Petrol Ofisi from Dogan Holding for 1 billion euros ($1.4 billion), raising its stake in Petrol to more than 95 percent.

title: Sam, Janet, and Fiscal Policy
description: One of the common arguments against fiscal policy in the current situation  one that sounds sensible  is that debt is the problem, so how can debt be the solution? Households borrowed too much; now you want the government to borrow even more?

title: Betfair Books a Strong Gain in Market Debut
description: Betfair Group, a British Internet gambling site, climbed 19 percent in its first day of trading after its London initial public offering raised 211 million ($332 million), Bloomberg News reported.

title: Catalina Weighs $100 Million Tech Fund
description: Catalina Ventures is weighing a move to raise $100 million for a technology and life sciences fund, which would be the firms first institutional fund, peHUB.com reported.

title: Last Call | Kate Moss for Topshop
description: As far as style role models go, well take Kate Moss over La Gaga any day. Her signature slinky party dresses, leather cigarette pants, downtown tees and fur jackets have become even cooler  and more accessible  since Topshop globalized the supermodels iconic style. So when rumors swirled that the Kate Moss for Topshop winter collection would be her last, sentiments went wild. (At least there is still Pete Dohertys jewelry line.). When we started the project we didnt have an end in mind but Im really proud of all 14 collections, says Moss. Ive learned a lot about the design and development process; experiences that Id only ever seen informally through being a model. Thats great, Kate, but whats in it for us? Well, come Tuesday, lots of sequined dresses and hot pants for the rock chick in Kate and, apparently, all of us, too. Other standout pieces include a tweed cape with a faux fur collar and boho vintage-inspired floral day dresses. Mosss personal favorite? If I had to pick one Id go for the pansy dress! Heres an exclusive peek.

title: Newsweek-Daily Beast: Anatomy of a Failed Deal
description: After talks about a deal to potentially merge Newsweek and The Daily Beast fell apart, it was widely put down to a conflict of personalities between Newsweeks new owner, Sidney Harman, Barry Diller, owner The Daily Beast, and Tina Brown, the editor who runs the online news magazine.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Raclette
description: Years ago, Terrance Brennan, the chef-owner of Artisanal, and also the chef-owner of Picholine, both in Manhattan, was in Gruyres, Switzerland, and ate his first raclette. The dish is named after a firm cow cheese used in this almost too-simple, but nevertheless hearty, tasty dish of melted cheese on cooked potato slices.

title: Kenneth Cole-Iconix Merger Talks Stall
description: 9:28 a.m. | Updated Merger talks between Kenneth Cole Productions and the Iconix Brand Group, the licensing company run by Mr. Coles brother Neil, have stalled and are unlikely to resume soon, people involved in the talks have told DealBook.

title: Inflation Bonds Are Sold With Negative Yield for First Time
description: Inflation-protected securities sold at negative yields for the first time ever on Monday as traders anticipate that the Federal Reserve will start a new round of asset purchases.

title: Gladwell: Who Really Rescued G.M.?
description: What makes Overhaul so unexpectedly fascinating, Malcolm Gladwell writes in his book review for The New Yorker, is that it is the product of someone so convinced of the value of his contribution, and of the private-equity model, that he feels no need to hide his condescension.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Bees beat computers at math, at least with the traveling salesman problem.

title: Childress Criticizes  Favres Decision-Making
description: Vikings Coach Brad Childress used some of his postgame news conference Sunday night to release steam, and he blew much of it in Brett Favres direction.

title: Former Oracle President Phillips Lands C.E.O. Gig at Infor
description: It took Charles E. Phillips Jr., the former co-president of Oracle, all of about six weeks to find a new job.

title: Afghan Leader Admits His Office Gets Cash from Iran
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai acknowledged on Monday that he regularly receives bags of cash from the Iranian government in payments amounting to millions of dollars, as evidence mounted of a worsening rift between his government and its American and NATO supporters.

title: Battle Over The Hobbit Spurs Rally in New Zealand
description: It will be several months, at least, before audiences are able to see a trailer for The Hobbit, the two-part film series that Peter Jackson intends to make from J. R. R. Tolkiens fantasy novel. But in the meantime moviegoers can sate themselves with the above promotional reel (which we were pointed to by the good folks at Vulture) announcing a rally to urge Mr. Jackson and the studios behind the Hobbit films to keep them in New Zealand.

title: Now Shopping | Mohawk General Store
description: When Bo and Kevin Carney opened the first Mohawk General Store two years ago in a tiny storefront in the Los Angeles neighborhood of Echo Park, the concept was simple: stylish essentials  nothing frivolous, says the elegant, Korean-born Bo. Tell that to the stuffed silk fox stole draped across a teak table in the new 1,400-square-foot lifestyle emporium the couple just opened in the citys Silverlake neighborhood with the European midcentury furniture dealer Amsterdam Modern.

title: Cuomo Promises to Stand Up to Unions
description: What were looking at on this Monday before the Monday before the election:

title: Morgan Stanley Picks Caterpillar Chairman for Its Board
description: Morgan Stanley said on Monday that it had expanded its board by appointing the departing chairman of Caterpillar, James W. Owens, as a director.

title: What Angels in America Meant to Them, and to You
description: For the film and theater director Mike Nichols the play changed how he thought about characters. For the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Doug Wright (I Am My Own Wife) it established a dividing line for gay-themed theater. For other dramatists like Lisa Kron (Well), Tarell Alvin McCraney (The Brother/Sister Plays) and Sarah Ruhl (In the Next Room, or the vibrator play) it was inspiration. And for academics and artistic directors, it became the last major stage work of the 20th century to wrestle with.

title: French Protests Ease, but Refineries Are Still Affected
description: PARIS  Amid ongoing fuel shortages and threats of more strikes this week and next, the French government warned Monday that protests against its pension bill were costing the country billions and were damaging its reputation.

title: Bailed-Out Firms Give to Candidates Who Fought TARP
description: Companies that benefited the most from the Troubled Assets Relief Program have given generously to political candidates this fall  in many cases, to Republicans who opposed the bailout, The Washington Post reports.

title: Knit Witty
description: Donna Wilson has become the Tim Burton of Londons knitting circle. Back when the designer was a student at the Royal College of Art, she began crafting dolls out of old jumpers, the British word for sweaters. The leggy dolls without noses or mouths were picked up by Couverture, a chic lifestyle shop. Today, Wilsons quirky menagerie includes 30-odd creatures, like the charming hybrid Cyril Squirrel-Fox and Puddle Man (essentially a pool of water with a face), all of which are made from knitted lambs wool in Wilsons East End workshop, not to mention cushions, throws, ottomans, sofas and rugs. Many of these are commissions from and collaborations with SCP, the British home furnishings manufacturer.

title: Monday Matchup, Giants at Cowboys
description: Giants (4-2) at Cowboys (1-4)Monday, 8:30 p.m.

title: Arrest in Brooklyn Hair Salon Shootout
description: A suspect in the Saturday shooting at a beauty salon in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, was arrested overnight, the police said.

title: Muddle Class
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously offered their definitions of middle class.

title: A Second Pass at Early Voting Totals: Now With Extra Skepticism
description: Ive gotten a lot of pushback on my post from Sunday night about early voting figures. Michael P. McDonald of The Huffington Post, for instance  whose work I referred to in my article  calls it fatally flawed and suggests I have erred by comparing early voting totals in each state to party registration figures. Instead, he thinks, the proper comparison is to early voting figures from past years.

title: CMJ 2010: Das Racist
description: At this year's CMJ Music Marathon, rap group Das Racist has been steadily gaining popularity with their unconventional style.

title: Monday Reading: The Airport Wish List
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Mortgage Modifications Slow in September
description: Even as banks, borrowers and regulators battle over how much faulty documentation by lenders should impede foreclosures, fresh evidence came Monday that the housing market remained very wobbly.

title: Metro-North Wants to Keep Horn-Testing Quiet
description: Memo to the good people of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.: Next time you ride a Metro-North train, make sure to thank your conductor.

title: Ladle of Love Food Truck Needs a Place to Sleep
description: Its brand new, its environmentally green (and literally green and white), it cost $92,500, and now it needs a parking space.

title: Democrat in Rhode Island Tells Obama Off
description: Talk about a not-so-warm welcome for the president of the United States and the leader of your party.

title: Dexter Watch: Bonded by Rage
description: Its a few weeks into the arrival of Julia Stiles on Dexter and we have yet to unpack the meaning of her characters name. For this I blame myself: I was too busy with my Mad Men decoder rings. But now that they have been shelved until the debut of the next season, lets take a look at what it might signify that her name is Lumen Ann Pierce. Raped and tortured by a gang of psychos led by Boyd Fowler, of the motivational tapes and roadkill-cleanup work, Lumen appeared in the opening moments of Sunday nights episode doing strange things to raw sugar packets in a diner. Free from Dexters captivity, she is unhinged.

title: On Upper East Side, Parking Laws Meet Parking Customs
description: New Yorkers blessed and cursed with cars have learned that there are few things more frustrating than trying to find street parking. Yet, in front of some of the citys priciest apartment buildings, often on the Upper East Side, there seems to be an abundance of spaces that drivers are not taking.

title: 'Riding a Rocket'
description: An architectural preservationist in Buffalo, N.Y., Timothy A. Tielman discusses the rapid rise of Carl P. Paladino to the New York political stage.

title: Advice for the College Interview: Girls, Dress Discreetly; Boys, Mind Those Hands
description: Something strange happens when teenagers sit down for college admissions interviews.

title: Seeking Crowd-Sourced Climate Pacts
description: A couple of years ago, the Center for Collective Intelligence (I wonder about the potential for this every day in running a blog) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology launched the Climate Collaboratorium.

title: Three First-Time Marathoners Preparing to Take On the World
description: Simon Bairu, 27, will make his marathon debut in New York on Nov. 7. He won the 2005 and 06 N.C.A.A. cross-country titles at Wisconsin and holds the Canadian record for 10,000 meters at 27 minutes 23.63 seconds. He ran 1:02:08 in finishing fifth in the Philadelphia half-marathon in September. Bairu, along with Tim Nelson and Shalane Flanagan, are part of the Web series Rookies Vs. the World, presented jointly by the New York Road Runners and Kimbia Athletics. New episodes are broadcast every Tuesday and Friday.

title: Newspaper Circulation Falls Broadly but at Slower Pace
description: Newspapers across the country broadly reported falling circulation from April through September, though the rate of decline slowed from the alarming pace in the same period last year, according to figures released on Monday by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

title: After a Crackdown, Few Crunching Hits
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  In the locker room after the Pittsburgh Steelers victory Sunday, linebacker James Harrison said that he played the game the way he had been taught since he was 10 years old. Except when he didnt.

title: When the Family Needs an Umpire
description: The home care aide didnt expect her new charge to be particularly cantankerous. After all, she had worked for the elderly womans sister for four years, and theyd gotten along well.

title: Should an 8-Year-Old Watch Glee?
description: On the spectrum of we dont own a television to my children can watch whatever they want, I tend toward the more permissive end. Once my sons reached their early teens, I gave in, deciding to view the ubiquitous sexual innuendo and gender stereotyping, among other things, as fodder for conversation and a means of inoculation against the real world. We regularly watched together, the boys and I, with them slightly mortified that their mother was seeing this inappropriate stuff, and me providing running counterpoint wherever possible.

title: Ask the Reporters: Iraq War Logs
description: The New York Times reporters who wrote about a trove of classified Iraq war military documents disclosed by Wikileaks last week are answering questions from readers. Please submit a question using the comments form below. We will continue to post selected questions and answers over the next few days. The most recent questions and answers appear at the top of this post.

title: On Our Radar: Meltdown on Greenland Ice Sheet
description: The Greenland ice sheet melted at a rate that was 25 to 50 percent higher this year than normal, according to Danish research scientists; about 500 gigatons of ice are estimated to have melted this summer. Some scientists express caution on the results but acknowledge that melting has indeed been above average. [Denmark.dk]

title: We Made It Ourselves | Snap Tonic
description: Steve Grasse is a Jedi distiller. As a Draper-league ad man and branding expert, he is able to convey an idea with a couple ofwords or a single image. As a creator of alcoholic potables, he ferments unexpected ingredients with logic-defying success. He cant practice one without the other. When he developed his tattoo-artist-inspired Sailor Jerry line of apparel, he had to include a rum; when William Grant & Sons wanted to produce a premium gin, the company hired Grasse not just to market Hendricks but to conceptualize the actual drink as well. (The integral cucumber? That has Grasses prints all over it.) And, when he launched a new lifestyle concept and retail shop in 2008, he had to do a spirit tie-in. First there was Root, and now Snap.

title: Unpopular Science
description: Whether we like it or not, human life is subject to the universal laws of physics.

title: Off the Menu: The John Dory
description: Not the John Dory redux, but a bigger, more informal space done in shiny black tile and covered with Ken Friedmans aquatic souvenir shop tchochkes, is set to open in the Ace Hotel on Nov. 1.

title: What Were Reading
description: Fox 19: Mmmm, beef sticks. Local TV reports Milwaukee plant has recalled 3,000 pounds of glass- and plastic-filled sausage.  Sam Sifton

title: CommScope Shares Pop Amid Carlyle Deal Talks
description: Shares in CommScope, the telecommunications equipment maker, jumped about 30 percent on Monday after the company confirmed a DealBook report that it was in talks to sell itself to the Carlyle Group.

title: 'A Pit Bull'
description: Mr. Tielman, an architectural preservationist from Buffalo, N.Y., discusses Carl P. Paladino's management style.

title: Amish Hackers Tell All
description: Last week, the techies were out in force when Kevin Kelly  a founding editor of Wired and currently the magazines chief maverick  came to the New York Public Library to talk about his new book, What Technology Wants. (See video of the event here.) There were plenty of smart phones and iPads in the audience, but the thing I was really looking for was some Amish beards. Beards? Yes. As Kellys book reveals, he is that rare high-technologist to engage with Americas most famous community of Luddites.
