description: Last week, the techies were out in force when Kevin Kelly  a founding editor of Wired and currently the magazines chief maverick  came to the New York Public Library to talk about his new book, What Technology Wants. (See video of the event here.) There were plenty of smart phones and iPads in the audience, but the thing I was really looking for was some Amish beards. Beards? Yes. As Kellys book reveals, he is that rare high-technologist to engage with Americas most famous community of Luddites.

title: Getting Revenge Against Your Insurance Company
description: Is it possible that one motivation for insurance fraud is to get back at insurance companies that provide poor service?

title: Are You Throwing to Me?
description: Perhaps it was overshadowed by that other memo the N.F.L. sent to its teams last week  the one politely requesting that players stop trying to kill one another with their helmets  but the leagues teams certainly got this message. It apparently declared Sunday to be National Throw It to the Wrong Team Day. And while the reaction to the anti-maiming directive was mixed, quarterbacks were all too happy to follow these orders, doing everything short of attaching gift cards to the ball.

title: Stong Management Skills
description: Mark H. Tuohey III, a fried of Carl P. Paladino's from college, discusses Mr. Paladino's management style and people skills.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: An Effective Outsider
description: Mr. Tuohey explains why he believes that Mr. Paladino's identity as a political outsider will help him accomplish his goals in office.

title: Numberplay: Happy Birthday, Bill
description: Last week, we had a pizza puzzle from Peter Winkler. It turned out to be a very tough puzzle, so Ill leave the discussion over the solutions open for another week and well postpone digging further into Dr. Winklers collection. Instead, lets take a break with some lighter numeric fare about the upcoming birthday of one of the worlds richest men. My partner in this numerical birthday extravaganza is Dr. Aziz Inan, who is a master at creating numeric curiosities involving dates, as he demonstrated in Some Light Number Music and Backdating.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Amy L. Andrews joined Media Networks Inc., Stamford, Conn., in a new post, director for publisher relations, working for MNI and its divisions Targeted Media and MNI MediaConnect. She had most recently been executive marketing director at Redbook, New York, part of the Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corporation.

title: Dont Park Here. (And Dont Ask Why.)
description: New Yorkers pride themselves on self-sufficiency and resourcefulness, especially when it comes to securing scarce urban commodities, and the on-street parking spot is a prime example. Our colleague Christine Haughney has an installment of her column, The Appraisal, today about fancy apartment complexes on the Upper East Side that set out signs mounted on brass stands politely asking drivers not to park out front and, at times, use doormen to get the point across in slightly less polite ways.

title: Our Forecast Calls for Lots of Lakers
description: The great thing about making predictions in October is that no one remembers them in June. Unfortunately, the Internet guarantees these things will live on in perpetuity. Here is how The Timess basketball writers, Howard Beck and Jonathan Abrams, see the N.B.A. unfolding this season.Howard Becks predictions:

title: Is Energy Efficiency Blue, Red or Both?
description: Recently I wrote about how people in six Kansas towns had been motivated to cut their energy use through intertown competitions. The residents were largely skeptical about the science behind climate change but were moved to act by values like thrift and patriotism. In some cases towns reduced their energy consumption by as much as 5 percent over a year, considered a giant drop in this field.

title: A Writing Stone: Chapter and Verse
description: For legions of Rolling Stones fans, Keith Richards is not only the heart and soul of the worlds greatest rock n roll band, hes also the very avatar of rebellion: the desperado, the buccaneer, the pote maudit, the soul survivor and main offender, the torn and frayed outlaw, and the coolest dude on the planet, named both No. 1 on the rock stars most-likely-to-die list and the one life form (besides the cockroach) capable of surviving nuclear war.

title: Fernando Alonso Wins in South Korea, Takes Formula One Lead
description: The first-ever Korean Grand Prix, held on Sunday in damp conditions, will be a memorable one. The Formula One race was delayed by heavy rain. It started behind the safety car for 17 laps and finished just before darkness fell. But perhaps more than any of that, the grand prix will be remembered as the day Fernando Alonso outlasted his rivals to take a lead in the championship, a position thought to be unlikely as recently as a month ago.

title: Thyroid Cancers Many Forms
description: The recent Times article When a Cancer Therapy Puts Others at Risk describes the unusual problems surrounding radiation therapy for thyroid cancer, which can pose an immediate risk to other people for up to a week.

title: The Claim: Lying on Your Left Side Eases Heartburn
description: THE FACTS For people with chronic heartburn, restful sleep is no easy feat. Fall asleep in the wrong position, and acid slips into the esophagus, a recipe for agita and insomnia.

title: New Beastie Boys Album Is a Lot Like Unreleased Beastie Boys Album
description: The bad news for Beastie Boys fans: it looks as though there will be no Hot Sauce Committee Part 1, the album that this hip-hop trio planned to release in 2009  its first since The Mix-Up, an all-instrumental record from 2007, and the first with any lyrical content since To the Five Boroughs in 2004.

title: MobileMe Needs a Diet
description: At last weeks Back to the Mac presentation, Steve Jobs touted the green aspects of Apples latest iteration of the MacBook Air. I have no doubt that the company is seriously committed to the environment; as Applenotes on its Web site, every one of its products meets or exceeds Energy Star standards.

title: Shop-Class Chic
description: At the London Design Festival in September, I came upon so many homespun, handmade objects and installations that within hours I was feeling guilty for not having made my own shoes. The prevailing aesthetic wasnt crafty, exactly  and it certainly wasnt decorative  but it was definitely hand-hewn, mostly in wood, with a less-is-more, whittled-down vibe (and I use the word whittled advisedly).

title: How a Pas5woRd Can Sink Your Company
description: Back in the 1990s fellow science and technology journalist Charles Mann and I wrote a book uncovering the true story of how a lone, young, cognitively impaired hacker with relatively few computer skills managed to perpetrate what was then the most extensive and scariest series of computer break-ins ever  government weapons labs, dam control systems and ATM networks were among the hundreds of networks compromised. At the end of the book, we predicted that no matter how much effort was poured into making the Internet safer, hackers would always be able to have a field day, partly for technical reasons but also because companies and individuals would never get it together to take simple precautions critical to safe computing.

title: Amid Cholera Outbreak in Haiti, Misery and Hope
description: ST.-MARC, Haiti  Inside the courtyard of St. Nicholas Hospital, beyond the gate with the handwritten sign stating Diarrhea Emergency Only, lies a grim but unusually orderly scene at the epicenter of this countrys unexpected cholera epidemic.

title: What to Do Now to Feel Better at 100
description: Many changes take place in physical abilities as we age. Try as I may, I simply cant swim as fast at 69 as I did at 39, 49 or even 59. Nor am I as steady on my feet. I can only assume my strength has waned as well  Im finding bottles and jars harder to open and heavy packages harder to lift and carry.

title: For Lighter Gnocchi, Turn to Ricotta
description: Gnocchi doesnt necessarily mean little flour-and-potato pasta but  actually  dumpling. They can be made with semolina or, in this case, cheese. The version in this weeks Minimalist column is light, easy and delicious.

title: Hoteliers Look to Shield Themselves From Dishonest Online Reviews
description: The 35 million hotel reviews posted on TripAdvisor reveal everything from snooty staff to filthy toilets, and sometimes the reviewers overly picky standards.

title: Keeping Score: How Good Are the Giants Starters?
description: The San Francisco Giants have so far proved the old adage that pitching wins in the postseason. Despite finishing ninth in the National League in offense, they squeaked into the tournament on the back of a vaunted starting rotation of Tim Lincecum, Matt Cain, Jonathan Snchez and Madison Bumgarner, who combined for a 3.19 earned run average in the regular season.

title: Ignoramity Triumphant
description: Wow. I guess I lead an intellectually sheltered life. Until I followed a link from Yves Smith, I had been blissfully unaware that the investment airwaves were full of people yelling that Bernanke is debasing the dollar because the dollar has fallen modestly in recent weeks.

title: Perspectives on Carl Paladino
description: Interviews with the former colleagues, challengers and friends Carl P. Paladino.

title: Eiland Will Not Return as Yankees Pitching Coach
description: Ben Shpigel is covering General Manager Brian Cashmans news conference following the Yankees ouster from the American League Championship Series. He reports, via Twitter, that Cashman will meet with Manager Joe Girardis agent on Tuesday to discuss a new contract, and that pitching coach Dave Eiland will not return as the Yankees pitching coach. Check back for more later.

title: No Quick Broadway Transfer for The Childrens Hour
description: While the theater producers Sonia Friedman and Scott Landis structured their current revival of La Bete to close in the West End on Sept. 4 and move unusually quickly to Broadway, where performances began on Sept. 23, dont expect the same swift transfer for their coming London production of The Childrens Hour by Lillian Hellman, starring Keira Knightley (Pride and Prejudice), top left, and Elisabeth Moss (Mad Men), bottom left.

title: Selling New Wine in Millennial Bottles
description: Theres a moment in a classic Warner Brothers cartoon when Bugs Bunny asks, Whats all the hubbub, bub? Now along comes a campaign that might encourage the wascally wabbit to inquire, Wheres all the HobNob, Bob?

title: TimesCast | October 25, 2010
description: Afghanistan receives bags of cash from Iran; the California races and using science to save art.

title: The Bailout and its Discontents
description: My column today defends the moral wisdom of the anti-TARP backlash against the suggestion that we should be happy with the bailout because it isnt actually going to cost us that much money. I thought this post from Stan Collender opens an interesting window on how voters are responding to the latter argument, and the news that TARP (or at least the Wall Street) might actually turn a profit for the government:

title: Well-Dressed Men, Pink Panthers and Paris on Hudson
description: Trying to guess at the lives of straphangers while riding the subway is an age-old pastime. It can even bear fruit, as Dvora Meyers writes in The Times, when such profiling leads to correct guesses about which seats may be vacated at which stops.

title: Taking Harder Stance Toward China, Obama Lines Up Allies
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, facing a confrontational relationship with China on exchange rates, trade and security issues, is stiffening its approach toward Beijing, seeking allies to confront a newly assertive power that officials now say has little intention of working with the United States.

title: Food and Drug Administration Recommends Food Safety Managers at Restaurants
description: After conducting a years-long study on food risk factors, the United States Food and Drug Administration has recommended that all restaurants provide on-site, trained and certified food protection managers, according to Nations Restaurant News.

title: Checkered History in Series for Giants
description: For the Giants, the World Series has too often produced more sympathy than success.

title: Massacre in Tijuana Recalls Worst Era
description: MEXICO CITY  Thirteen people were killed at a drug rehabilitation clinic in Tijuana on Sunday night, a sign that the relative peace there celebrated recently by the president himself might be fracturing. The killings in Tijuana, across the border from San Diego, follow the deaths of 14 young people in Ciudad Jurez, next to El Paso, who were gunned down at a party on Friday night.

title: New U.S. Standards Take Aim at Truck Emissions and Fuel Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government announced the first national emissions and fuel economy standards for heavy vehicles on Monday, one of a series of regulatory steps that the Obama administration is taking to increase energy efficiency and reduce atmospheric pollution in the absence of Congressional action on climate change.

title: Deal Averts Trial in Disputed Guantnamo Case
description: WASHINGTON  A former child soldier being held at the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, pleaded guilty on Monday to terrorism-related charges, averting the awkward prospect that he would be the first person to stand trial before a military commission under the Obama administration.

title: In DVR Ratings, Some Shows Find Good News
description: The DVR playback ratings for the third week of the television season arrived Monday and provided much good news for seemingly troubled shows like The Event and Parenthood on NBC and Fringe on Fox, while also sending many successful shows up to ratings well into hit territory.

title: The Benefits of Left-Side Sleeping
description: Todays Really? column explores how sleeping position affects heartburn pain. Studies show that sleeping on your left side is best.

title: It Gets Better
description: Internet campaign aimed at homosexual youths who may be feeling alone, or suicidal.

title: Tasting the Salone del Gusto
description: The Slow Food International founder and president Carlo Petrini has a very exacting definition of globalization. Its not using Romanian milk to make Italian cheese. His firm retort to anyone who calls that globalization: tutte balle (all lies)! His food-focused vision of the much-tossed-around term lies closer to two words interlinked by two symbols: Food +/= Places. Its the circular notion of terroir, of food being rooted to a specific place, and of that place expressing itself through its food. Its also the theme of the International Salone del Gusto 2010, the eighth edition of Slow Foods biennial celebration of foods from around the world, which opened on Thursday in Turin concurrently with Terra Madre.

title: Lustful Opera, Censored, Befuddles Chinese
description: BEIJING  As any artist or performer in China knows, it is impossible to predict what will set off the mercurial culture censors who have sweeping power over the content of film, music, television and print.

title: Share Your Short-Sale Experiences
description: As banks resume foreclosure proceedings, many hard-pressed homeowners are questioning why banks are making it so difficult to opt for short sales, according to an article Short Sales Resisted as Foreclosures are Revived in Mondays New York Times.

title: Pizza Without the Dough
description: Lavash is a flatbread, a staple of meals in Iran, Azerbaijan, Armenia and Georgia. Until recently Id never thought about using it as a pizza crust. It hardly resembles one  its much thinner. Still, Ive found its a great way to put together something like a pizza for a quick lunch or dinner. And its the easiest pizza youll ever make.

title: How Independent Are Barnes & Noble Directors?
description: Truly independent directors can be hard to spot. The reason is that the conflicts that create doubt as to a directors independence can be so subtle and hidden. It is easy to know that the spouse of the chief executive is not independent, but what about a best friend from high school? When do relationships, social or otherwise, arise to the level that a conflict is created and director independence is questionable?

title: The H.P. Slate Is Not Trying to Be an iPad
description: Consumers interested in buying a tablet computer are going to see a lot of devices in the coming months that resemble the iPad. A case in point is Hewlett-Packards Slate 500 Tablet PC.

title: Karzai Rails Against America in Diatribe
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai accused the United States on Monday of exporting killing to Afghanistan by giving contracts to private security companies. It was the latest chapter of a bitter battle between the president and his allies in the war against the Taliban that has taken on an increasingly anti-Western tone.

title: Emissions Rating for Chevy Volt Doesnt Consider Electric Driving
description: For people with typical commutes, the coming Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid is likely to be driven as an electric car, producing no tailpipe emissions, much of the time. That would make it effectively cleaner than most cars on the road.

title: Studying Disease in Dogs to Help Humans
description: Cushings disease is a rare condition in humans, but common in dogs. As a result, scientists are now hoping that a unique collaboration between veterinarians and human doctors will unlock clues for treating the disease.

title: McGrady Tries to Recapture Old Form  Again
description: The new Detroit Pistons swingman Tracy McGrady has asserted since the first day of training camp that hes strong, healthy and ready to play.

title: Birth Control Pills, 1957
description: Birth control pills  or at least the various attempts to develop them  were mentioned occasionally in The New York Times during the 1950s, but discussion of the possibility of a safe and effective oral contraceptive became heated in the summer of 1957.

title: Live Election Night Video
description: On Election Night, editors, reporters and columnists from The New York Times discussed race results and offered opinion via live video updates.

title: No Quick Fix? Developing Problem-Solving Skills
description: Overview | How can real problems be approached and analyzed in ways that lead to practical solutions? What distinguishes effective solutions from ineffective ones? In this lesson, students consider how to work through a practical problem. They identify problems in their school that need fixing, then devise viable solutions to one of those problems, using problem-solving models and drawing on strategies like the social science of behavioral change. They then test some of their proposed solutions in the field and propose them to the school.

title: A Food Truck Looking for a Place to Rest
description: The Ladle of Love food truck in Central Park runs on an electric engine, uses containers and utensils made of vegetable products, and serves up a mean goat-cheese salad. One thing it lacks is an overnight parking spot. The maximum speed of 25 miles an hour and limited cruising range make Brooklyn, nighttime home of many of Manhattans food-vending trucks, a reach. In Manhattan, the owners are having a hard time finding a garage with 10-foot high ceilings. Read the tale of the wandering food truck on Diners Journal.

title: The Improvised Remedies of an Art Healer
description: Eleonora Nagy remembers the first time she got a close look at Untitled, a 1966 sculpture by the artist Paul Thek. One of a series of works known as meat pieces, it looked like a fresh limb fragment that had gone bad  very bad.

title: The Caucus: California Races
description: A new poll from the University of Southern California and the Los Angeles Times shows that the Democratic candidates in gubernatorial and Senate races, Jerry Brown and Barbara Boxer, respectively, have the lead over their Republican counterparts, Meg Whitman and Carly Fiorina.

title: Godard Watch Ends: Director Wont Attend Honorary Oscars Ceremony
description: In a chaotic universe where all empirical stimuli is subjectively interpreted by imperfect observers, who is to say what does or does not happen? Jean-Luc Godard, for one: Mr. Godard, 79, the irascible filmmaker and a pioneer of the French New Wave movement, will definitely not be attending a special Oscars ceremony on Nov. 13 to pick up an honorary Academy Award, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Monday.

title: Highlights From Yankees News Conferences
description: Highlights of General Manager Brian Cashman and Manager Joe Girardis news conferences Monday after the Yankees four-games-to-two loss to the Texas Rangers in the American League Championship Series:

title: Social Media Campaign Takes Aim at Obesity
description: An organization seeking to address the issue of weight gain among Americans has chosen an agency to handle the social media elements of its efforts to reach consumers.

title: A Florida Battle Over Brooklynized Water
description: When is tap water so good its worth fighting for?

title: TimesCast: Democrats in California
description: In the latest edition of TimesCast, The Timess Michael D. Shear and Elisabeth Goodridge discuss the results from a recent poll on the Senate and gubernatorial races in California.

title: House Democrats Fight to Survive in Arizona
description: TUCSON  When it comes to endangered species in Arizona, there are the bonytail chub, the Sonoran pronghorn and, perhaps soon, the Congressional Democrat.

title: The Morning Skate: Banging Heads and Scratching Ilya
description: CBCs Hockey Night in Canada likes to emphasize the more physical aspects of the N.H.L., from making Don Cherry the shows centerpiece to their weekly opening, which uses Nickelbacks cover version (with Kid Rock) of Elton Johns Saturday Nights Alright For Fighting under fresh video of fisticuffs and some eye opening plays, like this one from a while ago:

title: Pelicans in Training
description: Q. How do pelicans learn to dive for fish?

title: Derailment Snarls Evening Commute Out of Penn Station
description: A partial derailment Monday morning on New Jersey Transit caused no injuries, but it has thrown the evenings commuting into chaos that cascaded over to the Long Island Rail Road and Amtrak, which share Pennsylvania Station with New Jersey Transit.

title: Juan Williams and the Partisan Cocoon
description: I have only this to add to the oceans of online ink spilled over NPRs firing of Juan Williams last week: Whatever you think of the particulars of the case, its a shame that the world will have one less pundit whose job requires him to communicate with both public radio listeners and Fox News watchers.

title: Trying to Follow the Trail of Missing AIDS Patients
description: KISUMU, Kenya  The young woman perched on the edge of the bed in her tiny hut. She was 29 years old, an AIDS widow who supported herself by frying and selling potato fries by the side of the nearby road.

title: How the King Cobra Maintains Its Reign
description: I can remember the first time I saw one, at the St. Louis Zoo, and the feeling that certain death was just on the other side of the glass. I could not get over the snakes size  this one was about 12 feet long. I was used to looking at giant snakes in zoos (I always made a beeline for the reptile house), but pythons did not seem so scary to me because they rarely moved. This sleek, agile and very alert snake was a king cobra, the largest venomous snake in the world and an icon to all snake enthusiasts, including this writer.

title: Power in East Moves to Florida
description: LeBron James took his talents to South Beach, joining Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh, and the rest of the Eastern Conference shook and reacted to the seismic shift. The move strengthened the Heat and weakened other teams. Some organizations scrambled, reset and readjusted their priorities, while others just complained.

title: Lakers Best in West, but Watch Out for Thunder
description: It was a noisy summer in the N.B.A., the airwaves jammed with enmity and resentment and interminable psychoanalysis. LeBron James stirred passions and practically swallowed the conversation while everyone fretted over a Miami superteam.

title: A Plea for More School Counselors
description: Robert Bardwell is director of guidance at Monson High School, a public school in Massachusetts, and an officer of the New England Association for College Admission Counseling.

title: India: Ambitious Study Indicates Malaria Deaths May Be Underreported Across the World
description: The number of malaria deaths in India far outstrips World Health Organization estimates, according to a study released last week. The authors argue that estimates should be revised upward for the whole world, particularly among adults.

title: Top Gear on 60 Minutes
description: Regular readers of this blog are likely to be among the 350 million people in 170 countries who watch Top Gear every week  numbers provided by 60 Minutes, which produced a segment on the British car show on Sunday night.

title: Breast Cancer Tales: The Inspirational vs. the Actual
description: Before penicillin came along, syphilis was known in medical circles as the great mimicker, a stealthy disease able to mangle the human body in virtually all known ways. Know syphilis and you know medicine, professors would tell their students.

title: Obama Vows to Push Immigration Changes
description: In the final week leading up to the midterm elections, President Barack Obama is encouraging Hispanic voters to turn their frustration over stalled immigration reform against Republicans on Election Day.

title: Anything Can Happen in a San Francisco Series
description: San Francisco

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
Why Sisterly Chats Make People Happier
description: Having a Sister Makes You Happier: that was the headline on a recent article about a study finding that adolescents who have a sister are less likely to report such feelings as I am unhappy, sad or depressed and I feel like no one loves me.

title: Jamess Newest Television Adventure
description: Leave it to LeBron James and the creative marketing machine that is Nike to make a clever commercial about his offseason melodrama.

title: Screening: Side Effects From Endoscopic Procedures
description: Patients rarely suffer serious side effects from endoscopic procedures like colonoscopies, but a new study reports that 1 in 100 experience complications serious enough to send them to the emergency room  a much higher rate than expected.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Mexico and France.

title: Live Long and Prosper (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Proceed With Caution (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Coming Back Stronger (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Runners, Consider the Ant (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Life as a Stone
description: A look at the career of the Rolling Stones and Keith Richards, who just released his memoir, "Life."

title: The N.B.A. Prepares to Tip Off
description: A look at the off-season and training camp before the N.B.A. opens the 2010-11 season on Tuesday with three games, including Miami at Boston and Houston at the Lakers.

title: Hybrid Model for Nonprofits Hits Snags
description: Since its founding in 2003, the GlobalGiving Foundation has used its Web site to channel more than $30 million to charitable projects like buying seeds for farmers in Zimbabwe and feeding orphaned chimpanzees.

title: Approach May Matter In Advice On Weight
description: People who are overweight are often counseled by their physicians to lose the extra pounds. But does such advice do any good? A new study suggests that it depends on the way it is offered.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Mexico and France.

title: How Doctors Can Motivate Patients to Diet
description: Does your doctor hound you to lose weight or motivate you to take better care of yourself?

title: Buffett Hires Manager for Big Part of Portfolio
description: By THOMAS KAPLAN

title: Artifacts | The Baldessari Variations
description: John Baldessari was not the first conceptual artist or appropriationist, but he has to be the funniest. Take his primitive 1971 video, I Am Making Art, in which the burly, 6-foot-5 Los Angeleno deadpans the title phrase while improvising mechanical hand and elbow gestures that lie somewhere between sign language for the blind and the body language of a traffic cop. Its hilarious. And somehow poignant.

title: Times Square, 3:15 P.M.
description: Lech Walesa, the former president of Poland, speaks to a rally of trade union members.

title: Encased in Amber, a Trove of New Species
description: An amber excavation in western India has led to the discovery of more than 700 ancient insects, arachnids and crustaceans, and many plant, floral and fungal remains.

title: Man Says Heinz Stole His Idea for Dippable Ketchup Packets
description: When Heinz came out with dippable/squeezable ketchup packets in February, Diners Journal said that the product could be a game-changer.

title: When Hormone Creams Expose Others to Risks
description: Veterinarians around the country are reporting a strange phenomenon: spayed dogs and cats, even some puppies and kittens, are suddenly becoming hormonal.

title: Critics' Picks: 'A Perfect World'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Clint Eastwood's 1993 film in which he co-stars with Kevin Costner.

title: Real-World Steps on Energy and CO2
description: The ripples are still spreading from a recently released game plan for a post-partisan approach to expanding humanitys energy menu without overheating the climate. The plan, aimed at filling the policy gap left by the death of a carbon cap and trading system, focuses on stimulating innovation and diffusion of non-polluting energy technology through direct investment and procurement policies.

title: The Newest Escape Artist
description: David Blaine, who has shivered inside ice blocks in Times Square and floated inside a water-filled sphere on Oprah Winfreys talk show, put the handcuffs on my wrists, talking about Harry Houdini the whole time.

title: Pandit Criticizes Some Basel III Bank Rules
description: Citigroups chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, criticized new global capital rules on Monday, saying that while the reforms are headed in the right direction, in some cases they dont go far enough or even make the problems that led to the financial crisis worse, Reuters reports.

title: Above It All: Tracing BPs Imperious History
description: Not long after the explosion that resulted in one of the largest oil spills in history, in the Gulf of Mexico this spring, the culprit BP committed public-relations gaffes, the most disturbingly memorable of which involved the companys chief executive at the time, Tony Hayward, proclaiming, Id like my life back.

title: A.I.G. Discloses Its Chief Executive Has Cancer
description: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

title: Just Sit Back and Immerse Yourself
description: Atlanta

title: Prez N the Hood: A Hip-Hop Parody Stirs Up Issues
description: Im the head of the state! President Obama shouts, with a blend of jubilation and indignation on his face.

title: Taking the Pepsi Franchise to an Ice-Cold Romania
description: IVE been a frequent business traveler for more than 20 years. I now live in Tel Aviv, but when I was a young executive, I was based in New York. My trips back then were short, mostly to the Midwest and sometimes to the West Coast.

title: Bankrupt Ultimate Escapes Wins Approval for Sale
description: 6:01 p.m. | Updated Members of Ultimate Escapes, the bankrupt provider of luxury vacations to places like Tahoe and Tuscany, neednt worry about losing their status.

title: Venmo Wants Its Users to Trust Each Other
description: In July, Zach Klein, a designer and entrepreneur, saw over the Foursquare service that a friend had just checked in to a Las Vegas casino.

title: Motivating Music Fans to Vote
description: Willie Nelson: Click to Listen

title: Joseph Stein, Fiddler on the Roof Author, Dies at 98
description: Joseph Stein, the Tony Award-winning author of Fiddler on the Roof and more than a dozen other Broadway musicals, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: Obama Gets a Caustic Welcome in Rhode Island
description: WOONSOCKET, R.I.  Welcome to Rhode Island, where Democratic politics are so quirky that the partys nominee for governor welcomed President Obama on Monday by declaring, on live radio, that the president could take his endorsement and really shove it.

title: Now Reading | What Was the Hipster?
description: Hipster is more than a noun  its a lifestyle. An overused, albeit elastic, coinage, it can describe everything from vintage T-shirt connoisseurs to anyone who kinda sorta maybe knows Cory Kennedy. And now its a subject of highbrow discourse. N+1, the Dumbo-based journal of politics, literature and culture, aims to shed new light on the phenomenon with the release of What Was the Hipster?: A Sociological Investigation (n+1 Foundation, $10), a pocket-size pop theory text on topics ranging from the aesthetics of party photography to the, ahem, hipster Other.

title: Jazz With a Humorist Urge and a Whiff of Mystery
description: The Respect Sextet stamps ambitious music with a smart-alecky affect, ranging broadly from the antic to the deadpan. Formed not quite a decade ago at the Eastman School of Music, it subscribes to the avant-garde humorist urge that has sustained the Art Ensemble of Chicago, the ICP Orchestra (of Amsterdam) and the Microscopic Septet (of New York). The jazz tradition, as a construct, interests the band. But so do the slippery aspects of electronic and new music, which explained its presence at the Greenwich House Music School on Thursday night, kicking off the 25th season of the North River Music series.

title: Forces of Darkness, Dressed in T-Shirts and Jeans
description: Dance Theater Workshop audiences tend to be pretty hard-core; it takes a lot for a show to rattle them, especially to the point of walking out midperformance.

title: Critics Picks Video: A Perfect World
description: In this weeks Critics Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at Clint Eastwoods 1993 drama, A Perfect World. The film focuses on the relationship between a young boy (T. J. Lowther) and the prison escapee (Kevin Costner) who takes him hostage. Mr. Eastwood plays the police officer in pursuit.

title: Restaurants Best Press: Bill Clinton Ate Here
description: BILL CLINTON has dined at Bukhara, an upscale restaurant in New Delhi, on just two occasions, but the afterglow of those visits has never worn off. The clientele, it seems, wont let it.

title: A Cultural Conversation Through Jazz
description: Chucho Valds began his late set on Friday night at the Allen Room with a sweeping solo piano introduction to the uptempo Cuban jazz hybrid Anabis, such a controlled detonation of music that it kicked through your defenses.

title: U.S. to Send Visual Artists as Cultural Ambassadors
description: In recent years the State Department has relied on performing artists to act as cultural ambassadors, sending dancers and musicians around the world to show people that America is more than just Hollywood movies, McEverything and two drawn-out wars.

title: Serving Up Feathered Bait to Attract Ecosystem Data
description: CAPILLA PEAK OBSERVATORY, N.M.  Mandy Weston stood on a ridge in the Manzano Mountains, 9,000 feet above sea level and about 4,000 feet above the Rio Grande Valley, grasping the talons of a juvenile northern harrier in her right hand.

title: Spears and Spandex: Wagner via World Wide Wrestling
description: Larger-than-life characters, titanic egos, brazen deceit, bloody combat: with such things is Wagners grandiose four-opera cycle, Der Ring des Nibelungen, concerned. That those characteristics are hardly specific to the Norse mythology of Wagners scenario, however, has endowed this lofty 19th-century creation with enduring resonance. Clever directors have long honored the salient points of Wagners epic while radically recasting his dramaturgical specifics to make points about contemporary society and its mores.

title: Claims of Good Faith, and Bad, in Cable Dispute
description: The high-stakes feud between the News Corporation and Cablevision reached the point of filing grievances before the Federal Communications Commission on Monday, with each side trying to prove that it had been bargaining in good faith  while charging that the other side had not.

title: The Caucus Click: Andrews Air Force Base, Outside Washington
The Presidential Seal of Approval
description: David Segal writes that despite President Bill Clintons fame as a junk-food connoisseur, and his recent health-related conversion to veganism, he is seen around the world as an arbiter of fine dining. A visit from Mr. Clinton seems as a good for business as a star or two from Michelin.

title: French Unions at Critical Point as Strikes Continue
description: PARIS  The French strikes and demonstrations over a proposed increase in the retirement age have lasted for weeks and attracted wide sympathy in a society whose work force is less than 10 percent unionized. But the proposal will soon become law, setting the stage for confrontations with Frances unions, which continue to starve the country of gasoline, diesel and other petroleum products, and are pressing for demonstrations afterward.

title: In Yemen, Water Grows Scarcer
description: Increasingly sharp water shortages could cost Yemen 750,000 jobs and slash incomes by as much as 25 percent over the next decade, warns a new report on Yemen, an increasingly troubled Middle Eastern nation.

title: Light Touch Brings to End a Marathon of Mahler
description: Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Orchestra spent the better part of last week working through some of Mahlers most titanic symphonies  first the Sixth, then the Second, Eighth and Fifth

title: Difficulties in Defining Errors in Case Against Harvard Researcher
description: The still unresolved case of Marc Hauser, the researcher accused by Harvard of scientific misconduct, points to the painful slowness of the government-university procedure for resolving such charges. It also underscores the difficulty of defining error in a field like animal cognition where inconsistent results are common.

title: Variety Show, With Arias Thrown In
description: In recent decades Baroque music has been the focus of much debate about authenticity and the importance of historically accurate performances. But in the Baroque era, musicians were far less reverential. In particular, operas known as pasticcios staged in the 17th and 18th centuries were freewheeling hodgepodges, offering fast-paced spectacles of music by several composers, with plot, action and libretto altered at whim. Irrelevant arias might have been thrown into the mix to satisfy the divas on hand.

title: Using Science to Preserve Art
description: Tuesday's Science Times profiles an art conservator who uses scientific techniques to bring contemporary art back to life.

title: Practice Gets Group Back to Carnegie
description: The concert the Parker Quartet presented at Weill Recital Hall on Friday was billed as a Carnegie Hall debut, yet anyone with a knowledge of the ensembles history might have been struck with a sense of familiarity.

title: Serving Two Masters: Shariah Law and the Secular State
description: A few weeks ago, the Cardozo School of Law mounted a conference marking the 20th anniversary of Employment Division v. Smith (1990), a case in which the Supreme Court asked what happens when a form of behavior demanded by ones religion runs up against a generally applicable law  a law not targeted at any particular agenda or point of view  that makes the behavior illegal. (The behavior at issue was the ingestion of peyote at a Native American religious ceremony.) The answer the court gave, with Justice Antonin Scalia writing for the majority, was that the religious believer must yield to the law of the state so long as that law was not passed with the intention of curtailing or regulating his or anyone elses religious practice. (This is exactly John Lockes view in his Letter Concerning Toleration.)

title: Testing a Bar Code Technology for Smartphones
description: SHARON BOLTON spotted those funky tags  known formally as two-dimensional bar codes  when she took her college-age daughter to catch a train at the Rensselaer rail station near Albany last week.

title: Return of the Shadow
description: Vikram Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, sounded a timely warning today at a New York conference sponsored by The Economist magazine.

title: Return of the Shadow
description: Vikram Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, sounded a timely warning today at a New York conference sponsored by The Economist magazine.

title: Texas Is Campaign Issue in California Ads
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In baseball, the San Francisco Giants and the Texas Rangers will meet in the World Series beginning Wednesday. In politics, California and the Lone Star State have been battling for a while.

title: Silver Lining in F.D.I.C. Deal
Riches May Not Help Papua New Guinea
description: TARI, Papua New Guinea  A founding myth in the Southern Highlands of Papua New Guinea is said to have foretold the arrival of ExxonMobil, the American oil giant that is preparing to extract natural gas here and ship it overseas.

title: Teenager Known for Hiccups Now Faces a Murder Charge
description: MIAMI  Floridians frequently become famous either for heinous crimes or odd achievements, like building the worlds largest rubber-band ball. Rarely, however, do the two intersect, which is why the Sunshine State marveled on Monday at the fate of Jennifer Mee.

title: Favre Delivers for NBC, Even if Not for Vikings
description: As Brett Favre led the Minnesota Vikings to a 28-24 loss on Sunday night to the Green Bay Packers, NBC earned a ratings bonanza, easily dominating the night in prime time. Though final audience figures were not available on Monday, preliminary estimates for the game easily exceeded last weeks overnight numbers for Sunday Night Football, which drew 19.2 million viewers. NBC said this weeks game posted the third-highest overnight ratings for Sunday Night Football on record, just behind a Dallas Cowboys-Washington Redskins game last month that attracted 25.3 million viewers. CBS ranked second over all, its prime-time schedule delayed approximately 15 minutes because of an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. CBSs 60 Minutes garnered the networks most viewers on Sunday, with an audience of roughly 16 million. CBSs reality competition The Amazing Race, and its reality series Undercover Boss, followed in the 8 and 9 p.m. hours, drawing audiences between 11 and 12 million viewers each, while CSI: Miami ended the night with closer to 10 million. ABC was third with Desperate Housewives at 9 (12.2 million) and Brothers & Sisters at 10 (8.4 million). Fox finished a distant fourth with reruns of its animated comedies.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,334 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Making Construction Beautiful in Brooklyn
description: Mauricio Lopezs Color Mesh, one of four designs selected in a recent city competition aimed at beautifying construction sites, had its debut on Monday on a construction fence at Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, above. The Urbancanvas competition, run by the Department of Buildings and the Department of Cultural Affairs, asked artists to submit designs that could be printed on vinyl or mesh and installed on construction fences, sidewalk sheds and scaffolds. Along with Mr. Lopez, the winning artists were Monika Bravo, Jen Magathan and Corinne Ulmann; each was awarded $7,500. The competition was financed with a $65,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation. Developers are to pay for the material and the cost of installing the designs but are allowed to seek sponsorship to offset expenses. While the winners have not been installed anywhere else yet, Robert LiMandri, the department commissioner, said there was interest from two other sites.

title: Politico, Seeing a Market Need, Adds a Paid News Service
description: To the rapidly growing field of Washington reportage, add one more entrant: Politico Pro.

title: Former ImClone Chief Acquires Drug Company
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the biotechnology executive whose insider trading landed him and his friend Martha Stewart in prison, is trying to make a comeback.

title: Latino Immigrants to Sue a Connecticut Police Dept., Asserting Racial Bias
description: When Yadanny Garca asked police officers in East Haven, Conn., why they were ordering him to the ground, they shocked him three times with a Taser gun, punched him and told him to go back to your country.

title: Navajos Hope to Shift From Coal to Wind and Sun
description: BLUE GAP, Ariz.  For decades, coal has been an economic lifeline for the Navajos, even as mining and power plant emissions dulled the blue skies and sullied the waters of their sprawling reservation.

title: In Haiti, Rush to Stem the Spread of Cholera
description: The cholera epidemic in Haiti is likely to grow and persist, and will probably reach the Dominican Republic, health officials said on Monday, as they rushed to distribute medical supplies in hopes of keeping ahead of the diseases spread.

title: Prison Threat by Killer of Cheshire Family Is Revealed
description: NEW HAVEN  The man convicted of killing three members of a Cheshire family had threatened to kill a prison guard months before his trial began here in September, the jury considering whether to impose the death penalty was told on Monday.

title: Favres Troubles Include Ankle Fractures, and Status Is Uncertain
description: The Minnesota Vikings visit to Foxborough, Mass., on Sunday was supposed to revolve around the rather awkward return of receiver Randy Moss to play the New England Patriots, who sent him packing Oct. 6 and whose offense has nonetheless flourished since.

title: Clinton Battles Repeat of 94 With Twist on 08
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich.  There comes a point about five minutes into Bill Clintons standard stump speech when he argues that this campaign is so important that it lured him out of retirement. I didnt need to do this, he said at a stop here over the weekend. Im not in politics anymore. I run a big foundation.

title: N.C.A.A. Sued Over One-Year Scholarships
description: A former Rice University football player who lost his scholarship for his senior year has filed a class-action lawsuit against the N.C.A.A., arguing that the one-year limit on athletic scholarships amounts to a price-fixing scheme between the association and member universities.

title: Amazons Kindle Sales Are Vague, but Strong
description: Amazon.com is more than happy to shout about the success of its Kindle tablet. But it always does so without disclosing specifics about the number of Kindles actually sold.

title: Filling the Gap Between Farm and Fair Trade
description: Weve all seen the ads for fair trade coffee with the beautiful photos of villagers hand picking coffee cherries in exotic regions around the globe. Fair trade is one of those ideas thats always in the air, but we dont often consider what it means. What does it really take to connect rural producers in the developing world with consumers in wealthy countries  so that everybody benefits?

title: An Unlikely Candidacy, Forged by Tragedy
description: If all had gone according to plan, Nicole Paultre Bell, 26, would not be running for City Council to represent a district in southeast Queens. She would be living in Atlanta with her husband, raising their two young daughters, possibly doing some part-time work at a collection agency, as she had in the past, or maybe studying for some kind of degree in health care.

title: Few Top Women Aides for Paladino or Cuomo
description: Carl P. Paladino has recruited his wife to hit the campaign trail and has put his daughter in a new commercial urging voters to get to know my dad. At the same time, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has rolled out an advertisement touching on abortion and has ferried his daughters across the state in an RV on a political tour.

title: Live Analysis: Giants 41, Cowboys 35, Final
description: A 41-35 whipping of the Cowboys on Monday left the Giants looking like perhaps the top team in the National Football Conference. In winning their fourth straight game, the Giants (5-2) claimed sole possession of first place in the N.F.C. East, and they looked the part, despite a sloppy finish that allowed the Cowboys to climb back on the scoreboard.

title: A Democrat in Idaho Not Hindered by Incumbency
description: MERIDIAN, Idaho  They say this race is an outlier. In one of the most conservative Congressional districts in one of Americas reddest states and amid strong Republican momentum nationwide, a Democrat  and an incumbent at that  may well win.

title: Help Stop Bullying, U.S. Tells Educators
description: In a 10-page letter to be sent on Tuesday to thousands of school districts and colleges, the Department of Education urges the nations educators to ensure that they are complying with their responsibilities to prevent harassment, as laid out in federal laws.

title: In Bond Frenzy, Investors Bet on Inflation
description: At a time when savers complain that they are earning almost no interest from their bank accounts, some investors on Monday bought United States government bonds that effectively had a negative rate of return.

title: Shift in Talent Fortifies Elite Teams
description: Three towering figures rise upon a stage, like Roman columns rising from the earth. They are clad all in white, their backs to the audience. Ominous music plays, and smoke shoots skyward.

title: Police Leader Had Help With Harvard Club Dues
description: Raymond W. Kelly, New Yorks police commissioner, can sometimes be found entertaining guests at the Harvard Club, a rarefied spot in Midtown Manhattan whose membership is exclusively for those who have an affiliation with Harvard.

title: Paladino Wants Tight Budget on Time, or Else
description: Carl P. Paladino promises to sue the federal government to overturn elements of the national health care law, to eliminate state bureaucracies, like the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, that he says are wasting taxpayer money, and to shut down New Yorks government if state lawmakers fail to negotiate a budget in a timely fashion.

title: Democrats Counting on Strength of Obamas Get-Out-the-Vote Network
description: MAPLE HEIGHTS, Ohio  Democrats have tried improving the political climate, discrediting their Republican opponents and asking Americans for patience in tackling the nations challenges, but the partys best hope of stemming deep losses on Election Day may now rest on loyalty and logistics, not persuasion.

title: An Unlikely Pairing Bears Fruit in North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Of all the fantastic tales to come out of North Korea  the countrys leader is injected with the blood of virgin girls, he made 11 holes-in-one during his very first round of golf, each grain of rice he eats is inspected by hand for imperfections, his youngest son and would-be successor has had cosmetic surgery to make him resemble his grandfather  not one of these seems as improbable as the event that took place on Monday, when a science university founded by American evangelical scholars began its first day of classes in Pyongyang, the capital of the secretive Communist state.

title: Naismiths Rules of the Game Set to Be Auctioned
description: The first rules of basketball, as set down by Dr. James Naismith, dont look bad for age 119. The two typewritten pages are yellowed, creased and a bit frayed. A tiny pinhole is visible on one page. Traces of tape that fixed a tear are visible across the top of the other.

title: With Aging Stars Come Hard Calls
description: The uncomfortable subject of age was front and center Monday when Manager Joe Girardi and General Manager Brian Cashman gave their post-mortems on a season that came crashing down in Texas.

title: Sylvia Sleigh, Provocative Portraitist and Feminist Artist, Dies at 94
description: Sylvia Sleigh, a British-born artist who put a feminist spin on the portrait genre by painting male nudes in poses that recalled the female subjects of Ingres, Velzquez and Titian, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Chile Miners Honored by President in Capital
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  They autographed soccer jerseys, received medals and posed with the Phoenix 2 rescue capsule like celebrities. They even battled the government in a friendly soccer match.

title: Chinese Telecom Giant in Push for U.S. Market
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  This spring, an executive from a Chinese telecommunications equipment company made an intriguing job offer to a Silicon Valley software engineer. The Chinese company, Huawei Technologies, wanted to get into the booming market for Internet-based computing, and it had just moved its United States research headquarters here to capture some of the best local talent.

title: Leo Cullum, New Yorker Cartoonist, Dies at 68
description: Leo Cullum, a cartoonist whose blustering businessmen, clueless doctors, venal lawyers and all-too-human dogs and cats amused readers of The New Yorker for the past 33 years, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 68 and lived in Malibu, Calif.

title: A Collection of Cullum Cartoons
description: Mr. Cullum, a classic gag cartoonist whose visual absurdities were underlined by captions reeled in from deep left field, published 819 cartoons in The New Yorker.

title: Iowa on Many Itineraries
description: Are Republican candidates in Iowa suddenly in trouble?

title: Google Promotes Susan Wojcicki, Advertising Executive
description: Susan Wojcicki, the Google executive who oversees advertising and who also supplied the garage where Google was founded, has been given a promotion.

title: House Forecast: 8 Days to Go
description: Democratic chances of retaining control of the House are essentially unchanged in todays FiveThirtyEight forecast. They have a 21 percent chance of doing so, up from 20 percent on Friday; that means Republicans have a 79 percent chance of instead claiming control.The average projection returned a result of 205 Democrats in the House and 230 Republicans, which would reflect a gain of 51 seats for the G.O.P.; this figure is unchanged.

title: Bloombergs Latest on Terms: 3 for Him, but Only 2 for Everyone Else
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg thinks that being able to serve three terms in office is a good idea  just not for anyone else.

title: A Labor Issue Ensnares The Hobbit
description: LOS ANGELES  Is Wellywood burning?

title: Deficit Divisions Likely to Grow After Election
description: WASHINGTON  A midterm campaign that has turned heavily on the issue of the mounting federal debt is likely to yield a government even more split over what to do about it, people in both parties say, with diminished Democrats and reinforced Republicans confronting internal divisions even as they dig in against the other side.

title: Female Ski Jumpers May Get Bid in 2014
description: Olympic officials announced Monday that they were looking favorably at adding womens ski jumping and other events to the winter program in Sochi, Russia, in 2014, but that they would wait until the sports hold their world championships next year to make their final decision.

title: In Salon Shootout, an Officers Well-Aimed Bullets
description: An off-duty police officer who got into a shootout with an armed robber as the officer was getting her hair done in a beauty salon in Brooklyn on Saturday night shot the gunmans revolver out of his hands, police officials said on Monday.

title: For Many, Wars Are Out of Sight, Out of Mind and Out of the Debate
description: Thousands of words were expended Sunday night in the lone debate between Senator Charles E. Schumer and the Republican businessman trying against all odds to defeat him, Jay Townsend. In all the verbiage, neither man found room for two words that youd think would loom large in a serious discussion of national policy.

title: Sudan: U.N. Ambassador Faults Arrests
description: The United States ambassador to the United Nations, Susan E. Rice, criticized Sudan on Monday for the harassment, intimidation and arrests of at least two Sudanese residents who spoke to Security Council ambassadors touring a camp for the displaced in Darfur this month, calling the arrests unacceptable. The Sudanese envoy, Daffa-Alla Elhag Ali Osman, denied that any arrests had occurred. The Security Council is concerned that delayed preparations for the Jan. 9 referendum on independence for Southern Sudan could reignite the fractious nations civil conflict.

title: China: Teachers Sign Petition in Support of Tibetan Language
description: Hundreds of Tibetan schoolteachers signed a petition recently that was sent to the government of Qinghai Province in western China, demanding that schools preserve the use of Tibetan as a main language of instruction. Parts of the petition, which was dated Oct. 15, were put up on a Tibetan blog, www.khabdha.com, on Monday and show that the protests over language policy led by thousands of Tibetan students last week in Qinghai had widespread teacher support. The petition demands that officials follow the Chinese Constitution, including Article Four: All ethnic groups have the freedom to use and develop their own spoken and written languages and to preserve or reform their own folkways and customs.

title: Afghanistan: Dutch Aid Worker and Driver Are Kidnapped on Road
description: A Dutch aid worker and his driver were kidnapped by five armed men on the highway between Takhar and Kunduz Provinces in northern Afghanistan on Monday, a spokesman for Takhars governor said. The worker, who was not identified, was with Streams, an organization that helps disabled people in Takhar and was about to close because it lacked funds.

title: On Legalizing Marijuana
description: The campaign behind the California ballot initiative that would legalize, tax and regulate marijuana has released its first television advertisement, one that seeks to convey a simple message: the current approach is not working.

title: Minor Parties See Threat in Ballot Quirk
description: Voters in New York cannot vote early, but they can vote often. And because of that, the Conservative and Working Families Parties fear for their very survival after Election Day.

title: Papua New Guinea Confronts Development
description: ExxonMobil is scheduled to start shipping natural gas through a 450-mile pipeline through the Southern Highlands, the most impoverished region in one of the worlds poorest countries.

title: An Unorthodox Challenger for an Upstate Senate Seat
description: As political fund-raisers go, this one was short on speeches but long on piano-playing. First, one of the guests, former Senator Alfonse M. DAmato, tried an amateurish but passable rendition of Debussys Claire de Lune on a spinet.

title: Cashman and Girardi Answer for Past Decisions and Yankees Future Concerns
description: Still smarting from the Yankees performance in a lopsided American League Championship Series, Joe Girardi and Brian Cashman took turns in the Yankee Stadium interview room Monday providing revealing disclosures regarding a pitching staff that crumbled in a six-game loss to Texas.

title: Gregory Isaacs, Reggae Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 60
description: Gregory Isaacs, reggaes Cool Ruler, whose aching vocals and poignant lyrics about love and loss and ghetto life endeared him to fans of Caribbean music, died on Monday at his home in London. He was 60.

title: Knicks Add Tequila to Roster of Sponsors
description: The Knicks have signed a marketing agreement with 1800 Silver Tequila, the latest deal between a hard liquor company and an N.B.A. team.

title: In Alaska Senate Race, Off the Ballot but on the Rise
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  The candidate treated like the front-runner in the Alaska Senate race is one not actually on the ballot.

title: Alex Anderson, Creator of Rocky and Bullwinkle, Dies at 90
description: Alex Anderson, the cartoonist who first drew Rocky the flying squirrel and his buddy, the bumbling moose Bullwinkle, television characters who captivated young baby boomers in the early 60s, died on Friday in Carmel, Calif. He was 90 and lived in Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Sorkin: So What Is Insider Trading?
description: As regulators extend their reach, insider trading is harder to define, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his DealBook column this week.

title: Tuesday: Event of 10/30/10
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  There is a certain timelessness about typical New York Times crosswords. They eschew topical references for several reasons: there is a long lag between construction and publication, syndicated solvers get the puzzles more than a month after that, and most important, puzzles live long and happy lives well beyond their birth dates. They are collected in books that may be sold many years later.

title: Stooped and a Bit Slow, but Still Standing Tall
description: Contrary to popular opinion, giants still walk that tired, old corner of the earth called Broadway. Times being what they are, these giants are often penned into cramped quarters, which prevent them from stretching to their full height. But giants of the theater belong to a magnificent species that is fast disappearing. And when one shows up in your neighborhood, you polish your eyeglasses and go for a look.

title: Lottery Numbers
Constance Reid, Biographer of Mathematicians, Dies at 92
description: Constance Reid, an English teacher who found a second career as a biographer of major 19th- and 20th-century mathematicians, died Oct. 14 at her home in San Francisco. She was 92.

title: Arizona Democrats on the Defensive
description: In next Tuesdays election, a number of Democratic members of Congress from Arizona are facing stiff challenges. Voters are listening to both sides at candidate forums and debates.

title: Thlme Hedge Fund Is Said to Raise Over $700 Million
description: Thlme Partners, a new hedge fund founded by a former Merrill Lynch banker, Patrick Degorce, has raised over $700 million, making it the largest equity hedge fund started since the financial crisis began, The Financial Times reported.

title: Paladino Says No More Secrets in Albany if Hes Governor
description: Nicholas Confessore, a reporter for The New York Times, interviewed the two major candidates for New York governor, Carl P. Paladino and Andrew M. Cuomo, to discuss their approaches to governing. The interview with Mr. Cuomo appeared Monday. Following are edited excerpts from the interview this month with Mr. Paladino; audio excerpts are at nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: Arizona: Drug Question Holds Up Execution
description: A federal judge has temporarily blocked a convicted murderers execution because one of the drugs that would be used is of undisclosed origin. A shortage of the drug, sodium thiopental, has delayed executions in some states; Arizona obtained the drug, but has refused to identify the source, citing state confidentiality laws. Judge Roslyn O. Silver issued a temporary restraining order to stop the execution on Tuesday of Jeffrey Landrigan, saying if the drug came from a source not approved by the Food and Drug Administration, it raises questions of contamination, "efficacy and possible side effects."

title: G.O.P. Senate Odds Slip on Colorado, West Virginia Polls
description: While Republicans position is holding steady in the House  where they are 4:1 favorites to win control of the chamber according to our analysis  their chances of also taking over the Senate declined in todays forecast. Those chances are now 16 percent, down from 19 percent in our forecast over the weekend.

title: Not on the Ballot, but Still a Contender in Alaska
description: Lisa Murkowski, the candidate often treated like the front-runner in the Alaska Senate race, happens to be one who is not on the ballot.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Iraq Files: Lessons and Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: A Remark About Muslims, a Stir About Journalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitzer and Harvard Club
description: To the Editor:

title: The Deadly Side of Tijuana
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumerism in Japan, and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Humans to Asteroids: Watch Out!
description: Sonoma, Calif.

title: Bloggingheads: Jon Stewarts Power
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of The American Prospect and Timothy Noah of Slate debate the political power of The Daily Show.

title: Governors Forecast Moves Toward Democrats in 3 Blue States
description: Democrats have made progress in several states in our latest gubernatorial forecast. Although it remains very probable that Republicans will control the majority of the nations governorships after Nov. 2, it is now more likely that Democratic and independent candidates can hold Republicans to victories in 20 to 23 of the 37 contests that will be held on Election Day.

title: No Second Thoughts
description: When times get tough, its really important to believe in yourself. This is something the Democrats have done splendidly this year. The polls have been terrible, and the party may be heading for a historic defeat, but Democrats have done a magnificent job of maintaining their own self-esteem. This is vital, because even if the public doesnt approve of you, it is important to approve of yourself.

title: American Songbook Lineup Is Announced
description: Barbara Cook, the longtime interpreter of Stephen Sondheims songs; John Doe, the veteran punk rocker; and the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe are among the eclectic mix of performers who will be featured in the 2011 season of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series, press representatives for Lincoln Center said on Monday. Ms. Cook, who recently appeared in Sondheim on Sondheim on Broadway, will open the season, which begins on Jan. 12 at the Allen Room of Frederick P. Rose Hall. Other artists who are to appear in the concert series, which runs through Feb. 20, include the indie-folk band the Low Anthem (Jan. 13); John Doe (Jan. 28); and Ms. Blythe, who will perform songs made popular by Kate Smith (Feb. 16). The lineup also includes Broadway stars like Anika Noni Rose (Feb. 5); Ral Esparza (Feb. 18) and Kate Baldwin (Feb. 19).

title: Treasury Hid A.I.G. Loss, Report Says
description: The United States Treasury concealed $40 billion in likely taxpayer losses on the bailout of the American International Group earlier this month, when it abandoned its usual method for valuing investments, according to a report by the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program.

title: The Corrosion of America
description: If you had a leak in your roof or in the kitchen or basement, youd probably think it a good idea to have it taken care of before matters got worse, and more expensive.

title: Word of the Day | levitate
description: levitate \le-v-tat\ verb

title: The Mortgage Morass
description: The mortgage mess just keeps getting messier. Last week, Bank of America announced that it had performed a thorough review of its processes, found nothing amiss and would soon restart 102,000 pending foreclosures. On Sunday, the bank acknowledged that it had in fact found errors in its filings, and would resume foreclosures only in a deliberate manner as new and corrected paperwork was submitted to the courts.

title: 48th Is Not a Good Place
description: The National Academies, the countrys leading advisory group on science and technology, warned in 2005 that unless the United States improved the quality of math and science education, at all levels, it would continue to lose economic ground to foreign competitors.

title: Congressional Choices
description: There is no shortage of voter anger out there, and with good reason. But there are races for Congress in New York, and in Connecticut, where rejecting talent and experience makes no sense.

title: Giants Knock Out Romo and Hold Off Cowboys
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Late in the second quarter of a game and a season slipping away from the Dallas Cowboys, the ostentatious video boards hanging over the field  60 yards of enormous, back-to-back heft and clarity  showed a large, shirtless man painted in blue.

title: Buffett Hires an Outsider to Oversee Investments
description: Warren E. Buffett announced Monday that his company, Berkshire Hathaway, had hired a young hedge fund manager to oversee a significant portion of its investment portfolio, adding a new name to the mix of players who are someday expected to take the reins at Berkshire.

title: Shadows And Fog
description: Im finding the foreclosure issue difficult to write about; its clear that there has been massive malfeasance on the part of the banks (again), but its less easy to say what should be done. One thing is clear, however: the main argument being made for turning a blind eye to the situation, and avoiding anything like a temporary freeze on foreclosures, is wrong.

title: Giants Defeat Cowboys, 41-35.
description: A dangerous Giants offense slid past the Cowboys after quarterback Tony Romo was knocked out of the game with a broken left clavicle.

title: Maturity Matters
description: A new memo from Goldman Sachs (no link) looks at quantitative easing by treating it as equivalent to a shortening of the maturity of federal debt; among other things, the memo answers the question of where I got it from: work by Jim Hamilton and Cynthia Wu.

title: Do Investors Expect Too Much From Bernanke?
description: Financial markets seem convinced that quantitative easing will be highly effective at solving at least one problem: inflation running well below the Feds 2-percent-or-so target. The chart above shows the difference between interest rates on 5-year inflation-protected bonds (which are now negative) and rates on unprotected bonds; implicitly, the market forecast of inflation over the next five years has risen half a point.

title: News Quiz | October 26, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: A Roving Sideline Reporter Who Really Roves
description: David Willey is not one to willingly accept a prone position during New York City Marathon weekend, but in 2009 he fought the predicament as long as he could before waving the white flu flag. Some 36 hours before he was to report for duty as an on-course reporter at the race for the third consecutive year, swine flu sucked the broadcast life out of him.

title: Polartec Said to Seek Buyer
description: Polartecs parent, Versa Capital Management, is seeking a buyer for the century-old maker of the Polarfleece material, two people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News.

title: Treasury Hid A.I.G. Loss, Report Says

title: Mad Men for Children (What Would Dr. Edna Say?)

The clever devils at thepoke.co.uk  the satirical British Web site that previously gave us the Wire-inspired Monopoly board  have turned their attention to another popular cable series. Theyve designed a series of childrens books that mashes up Mr. Men, the adorable, bodyless characters designed by Roger Hargreaves, with Mad Men, an AMC period drama you may have read a thing or two about. At their site (which we were pointed to by the good people at The Guardians Media Monkey blog), youll find covers for books like Mr. Draper and Little Miss Peggy, and a complete story called Mr. Sterling Gets Angry. That changed last week with the opening of the Thornwillow at St. Regis, an invisible store set up in collaboration with the stationer Thornwillow Press, based in Newburgh, N.Y. Founded 25 years ago by Luke Ives Pontifell (at the tender age of 16), the company uses traditional printing techniques to produce a variety of high-end paper goods, including stationery and invitations.

title: Picking Up the Tab at the Harvard Club
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly has enjoyed an unusual benefit while entertaining guests at the Harvard Club in Midtown Manhattan, an upscale establishment only open to those who, like Mr. Kelly, hold Harvard degrees. Over the past eight years, some or all of Mr. Kellys expenses at the club, including dues, drinks and meals, have been paid by the New York City Police Foundation, according to Paul J. Browne, a spokesman for Mr. Kelly. Mr. Browne insisted that the practice was lawful and intended for city business, but that Mr. Kelly may have erred by failing to report the foundations payments on his financial disclosure forms by the citys Conflict of Interest Board. (Also see The Daily News.)

As Lorraine (Baines) McFly (Tannen), she is a symbol of 1950s American wholesomeness and the mother-to-be of the time-traveling Marty McFly (played by Michael J. Fox). She is also the hot-to-trot teenager who spurns lovable George McFly (Crispin Glover) for the boy she doesnt realize is her own offspring. And thats not even counting the four different future incarnations of the role she plays in Back to the Futures I and II, as well as her Old West ancestor, Maggie McFly in Part III.

title: Arturo OFarrill to Play in Cuba, His Fathers Homeland
description: The Brooklyn-based pianist and bandleader Arturo OFarrill announced over the weekend that he would appear at the 26th annual Havana International Plaza Jazz festival, Dec. 16-19. Mr. OFarrill is the son of Chico OFarrill, the Cuban-born composer and arranger, who died in 2001. The elder OFarrill, one of the architects of Afro-Cuban jazz, who collaborated with Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie and others in landmark works of the 1950s like The Afro-Cuban Jazz Suite and The Manteca Suite, never managed to returned to his homeland after leaving it in 1960. His son, as leader of his fathers old band, the Chico OFarrill Afro-Cuban Jazz Orchestra, will be playing his fathers music, and more, at the Mella Theater in Havana and in the province of Matanzas. He will also lecture at the Amadeo Roldn conservatory and perform at a childrens class alongside his sons, Zachary and Adam.

title: Painting at 99, With No Compromises
description: Propelled by a scholarship to the Art Students League, Will Barnet, an aspiring artist with a portfolio heavy on seascapes and family cat portraiture, left Boston for New York City in 1931 with $10 in his pocket. It was summer, it was hot, and besides the Depression-era garbage rotting in the streets, the air was ripe with raucous political protest. He rented a room for a $1 a night, gorged on cheap baked beans at the Automat and started sketching the forlorn and angry faces he saw on every corner. He was 19 and radicalized by possibility.

title: Makers Marks
description: Hella Jongerius  Misfit, the title of the Dutch designers retrospective that opens Nov. 13 at the Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen in Rotterdam, refers not so much to her status in the design world but to the imperfect objects she has long championed. As the exhibition demonstrates, Jongerius has never had trouble finding sympathy for her ideas in the design industry, where companies like Vitra, Ikea and Maharam hired her to introduce beautiful inconsistencies into their sofas, vases and upholstery fabrics. As it turns out, the only people who ever took convincing were the craftspeople themselves. Royal Tichelaar Makkums artisans cringed when they were told to fire her 1997 B-Set pottery (above) at too high a temperature, while Nymphenburgs worried that her 2004 Sketches plates looked half-finished. Craft has a tradition of trying to make perfect things, says Louise Schouwenberg, the shows curator. Hella told them to stop trying, because industry can do that better, whereas their appeal is more humane. Jongerius persisted, and these days, evidence of the hand of the maker seems completely natural. The misfits have become the mainstream.

title: Tutu Urges South African Opera Company Not to Perform in Israel

But Archbishop Tutu, a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize who retired from his official duties earlier this month, said in a statement that the tour should be postponed until both Israeli and Palestinian opera lovers of the region have equal opportunity and unfettered access to attend performances.

title: Revising of Dalton Paper Raises Ire and Discussion

title: Think Ink
description: Cynics, or perhaps graphic designers, might argue that your average perfume is 99 percent packaging. Maybe more. A perfume is an image that you cannot see with your eyes, says Mathias Augustyniak, who, as one half of the design firm M/M (Paris), has worked on scent identities for Balenciaga and Narciso Rodriguez. When he and his partner, Michal Amzalag, approached Ben Gorham of Byredo Parfums with an idea for a fragrance, they were not following their noses. They gave Gorham three inspirations: a block of solid ink they bought in Korea, a photograph of a Japanese friend who is a calligraphy master and an oversized absurd formula that Augustyniak drew with ink on a piece of handmade Korean paper. We spoke about ink with Ben, who is properly inked since hes covered with tattoos, which added a layer of resonance, Amzalag says. The result, M/MINK Eau de Parfum, is represented by a sort of smear campaign  artworks made from existing images, by the photographers Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, that Amzalag and Augustyniak obscured with slicks of thick black ink. What the fragrance smells like is even more ambiguous. The artist Wolfgang Tillmans, a friend of the designers, described it to them as very manly, while a female friend declared that it reminded her of her grandmother, a comment that left Amzalag wondering if the friend had a manly grandmother. To me it feels like a roller coaster ride, he says, because it keeps changing once it is on your skin.
