title: Losing a Leading Lady While Gaining a New Theatrical Home
description: Amid all the hoopla last weekend as Arena Stage opened its new theatrical home in Washington, the team behind the inaugural production  a revival of Oklahoma!  was scrambling to find a new leading lady after Valisia LeKae departed the role of Laurey after the first preview performance on Friday night and the theaters celebratory open house on Saturday.Arena announced on Monday afternoon that Ms. LeKae had left because of pressing personal matters, and would be replaced by Eleasha Gamble. Representatives for Ms. LeKae did not immediately reply to a phone message Tuesday. An Arena spokeswoman said that Ms. Gamble was recruited to the show only over the weekend, giving her a few days to prepare for her first performance, on Wednesday, as Laurey, the farm girl courted by the cheery cowboy Curly McClain and brooding hired hand Jud Fry. The role was played on Broadway by Joan Roberts and Christine Andreas, among others, and in the 1955 film version by Shirley Jones.

title: Keeping Score: Which Players Have Made the Biggest Impact?
description: One of the tenets of sabermetric dogma is that there are no clutch players, only clutch events. Or if there are, the effect is so small as to be meaningless. Over the course of many seasons, youll see that almost all of the players perform as well in clutch situations as in normal situations. A particularly rough stretch for a player is probably just a random bad stretch rather than an innate inability to perform under pressure. After all, could you really make it to the major leagues if you couldnt handle pressure?

description: The Restaurant at Meadowood, the St. Helena, Calif., resort, has won a third star in the 2011 Michelin Guide to the San Francisco Bay Area & Wine Country. It is one of only two United States restaurants outside New York to hold that distinction. The other is the French Laundry in Yountville, Calif.

These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. R. Michael Tuttle, an endocrinologist at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, responds.

title: Could Bloomberg Make Palin President?
description: As a devout skeptic of both Michael Bloombergs presidential ambitions and Sarah Palins putative front-runner status in the 2012 Republican campaign, Im naturally completely unconvinced by John Heilemanns entertainingly bizarre scenario in which Bloomberg runs as an independent in 2012, peels off enough votes and states from Obama to hang the electoral college, and ultimately delivers the White House to Palin. But Ill confine myself to just one objection. To make his scenario work, Heilemann envisions Bloomberg winning states like New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, behind a combination of moderate Republicans, centrist Democrats and progressives disappointed with Obama. In a vacuum, these might be plausible constituencies for Hizzoner  but not in an election where Sarah Palin is the Republican nominee! How many northeastern progressives (or Lincoln Chafee Republicans, for that matter) would contemplate casting a vote for a third-party candidate knowing that it might deliver the White House to the woman they fear and loathe above all others? Not many, Id say. Nothing would be guaranteed to rally the Obama coalition quite like the specter of a Palin presidency: For months before the election, the drumbeat that a vote for Bloomberg is a vote for Palin would be well-nigh deafening, and Im pretty sure that even a weakened Obama wouldnt have that much trouble holding serve in that scenario, relegating Bloomberg to exactly the kind of John Anderson-esque performance that would be his most likely fate in any case.

title: Pharmacy Benefit Managers for Sale
description: It could be selling season for pharmacy benefit managers, those businesses that help insurers and employers have tighter control over their drug costs.

title: Q&A: Central America in December
description: Three medical students and I are planning a vacation to Central America in early December. We want to see a few countries, finishing in Guatemala, where we will work at a health clinic. How should we organize our trip and how do you propose we spend our time?

title: Gymnastica: Madonna Plans Her Own Fitness Franchise
description: As Madonna would be the first to tell you, there are all kinds of incentives to improve ones physical fitness, from increased energy and improved health to the possibility that your personal trainer might become the father of your first child.

title: U.S. and Europe Urged to Join Forces on Rare Earth Metals
description: BERLIN  The United States and Europe should work together with industry to reduce dependence on China for crucial minerals because global trade bodies are ill-equipped to solve the problem of withheld supplies, officials and executives said Tuesday at a high-level conference.

description: Consumer Reports released the results of its annual auto reliability survey on Tuesday and made special note of the improvement in General Motors vehicles.

description: With Election Day just a week away, the head of the citys embattled Board of Elections was dismissed on Tuesday following a series of missteps with new voting machines and other procedures.

title: The Bravest, the Finest, the Fastest
description: Thomas Grimshaw, a New York City firefighter, reached the 18-mile point of his 20-mile run in Central Park on Sept. 11, 2001, when he noticed smoke billowing in the direction of Lower Manhattan. A woman told him that a plane had hit one of the World Trade Center towers, and he knew it was a terrorist attack. He continued his run, returning to his starting point at the New York City Fire Academy on Randalls Island. From there he headed downtown, arriving minutes after the second building collapsed.

title: Children as a Campaign Tool
description: Mary Fallin, the Republican candidate for governor of Oklahoma, has quite a resume. The manager of a hotel chain, she entered politics to protest government regulation of small business, becoming first a state legislator, then lieutenant governor and most recently a member of the U.S. House of Representatives.

title: Glaxo to Pay $750 Million for Sale of Bad Products
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the British drug giant, has agreed to pay $750 million to settle criminal and civil complaints that the company for years knowingly sold contaminated baby ointment and an ineffective antidepressant  the latest in a growing number of whistle-blower lawsuits that drug makers have settled with multimillion-dollar fines.

title: New York City Board of Elections Chief Fired
description: With Election Day less than a week away, the head of New York Citys embattled Board of Elections was fired on Tuesday after a series of problems with a new computerized voting system and the ballots prepared for the general election.

title: Introducing Serkan Sarier
description: Serkan Sarier, another promising newcomer to New Yorks bustling young designer scene, waited until after all the buzz of the spring collections had died down to introduce his new collection, called Brood. Mr. Sarier held a small presentation in a West Chelsea art gallery Monday evening, showing about a dozen evening dresses in silk taffeta trimmed with zippers and drawstrings,which gave them the look and feel of athletic sportswear, or collapsed parachutes.

To get that space, Oakley is paying $1,375 a square foot  what some luxury retailers paid on Madison Avenues choicest blocks before the recession.

It had been the luxurious Palace, then the first edition of Sandros, then Bouterin and, very briefly, it was a Turkish restaurant. Next spring it is to become Morso, a new Italian restaurant from Pino Luongo, the owner and frequent cook at Centolire on the Upper East Side.

title: On Our Radar: A Panda Baby Boom
description: A record 19 giant pandas have been bred in captivity in China this year, bringing the countrys captive population to around 300, authorities say. The birth of twin female cubs at the Wolong Panda Reserve in Sichuan province last week broke the record of 18 births set in 2006. The giant panda is highly endangered, with only 1,600 thought to remain in the wild. So far, there have been no successful reintroductions of captive-bred pandas to their native habitat. [Sky News]

He and his partner, Sam Rivera, have hired Joe Vigorito, formerly at Lupa and dellAnima, to create a Mediterranean menu for the two-level space that has exposed brick in the ground floor dining room with an open kitchen. title: Shostakovich Quartets as an Intimate Diary
description: When the Pacifica Quartet was appointed quartet in residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art a year ago, it opted, sensibly, to introduce itself to the Met audience with a season of mixed repertory. But this group has a passion for completeness: its New York performances in recent years have included a Beethoven cycle (in 2007) and the five Elliott Carter quartets (in 2002 and 2008). And now that the introductions are out of the way, it is returning to the immersive programming it prefers. This season is devoted to Shostakovichs 15 quartets; next season the Pacifica will revisit Beethovens works.

Not only is she about to bring her fourth child into the world, shes also about to introduce a new collection specifically for the 12-and-under set. Pieces like cashmere blend pea jackets and floral dresses are designed to be both affordable and timeless, so you dont have to choose between dressing your child well and sending her to college. And the line even features shrunken versions of pieces from her main collection. Still, McCartney knows that as fashion consumers go, kids are as fickle as anyone.

title: Graffiti of New Yorks Past, Revived and Remade

On the wall of a brick warehouse there, visible from the parking lot of a furniture store, a huge mural unfurls itself, a loving, seemingly spray-by-spray re-creation of one of the more infamous pieces of graffiti ever to ride the subway: a 1980 work by the artist known as Seen that covered the length of a No. 6 train car with the ominous phrase Hand of Doom.

description: Tens of thousands of times over six years, the police stopped and questioned people on New York City streets without the legal justification for doing so, a new study says.

description: Representative Earl Pomeroy is introducing himself to North Dakotas voters  and telling them who he is not.

description: LONDON  UBS said on Tuesday that it had reversed a two-year outflow of cash from its private bank in the third quarter, but the shares dropped after the Swiss bank reported that its investment banking division had returned to a quarterly loss.

description: In the latest escalation in the battle that has left 3 million viewers without Fox programming, News Corporation Tuesday accused Cablevision of directing subscribers unhappy that they might not be able to see the World Series to illegal Web sites carrying the signals of the Fox network.

title: Horman Family Pickles Go Retail
description: Nick Horman Jr. took his family pickle business retail. His grandfather, father and uncle all made crisp classic pickles sold in bulk to delis and restaurants, and for private-label packing. But the younger Mr. Horman (at right, with his father), fresh out of college about eight years ago, started peddling the pickles at farmers markets and fairs, in plastic containers. Now, Allen Pickle Works in Glen Cove, N.Y., the family company, is packing the pickles in quart jars, which are being sold in stores for the first time. They are cold-cured with whole spices, garlic, peppers and the like. The refrigerated shelf-life is three months (each jar has a date).

title: Some Halloween Treats to Save for the Grown-Ups
description: Little white-chocolate ghosts filled with gianduja ganache by Larry Burdick are not for dumping into the bags of the Snickers and Reeses crowd. Save them for the grown-ups to nibble after dinner. Same goes for the sleek black coffin filled with an assortment of Burdick treats, including a few of the ghosts.

description: 142 West 10th Street (Greenwich Avenue); (212) 255-2330, lowcountrynewyork.com.

title: A Rustic but Refined Bottle Opener
description: What better way to open that bottle of locally micro-brewed artisanal beer than with this rustic-looking bottle opener? A block of walnut is fitted with a bent nail, with enough of a head and the correct distance to lever up the bottle cap.

title: Is Candy Evil or Just Misunderstood?
description: FOR Samira Kawash, a writer who lives in Brooklyn, the Jelly Bean Incident provided the spark.

title: Japanese Wineries Betting on a Reviled Grape
description: Koshu, Japan

title: With a Double Bill, a Return to Rarities
description: The stars were out in force at Carnegie Hall as the Opera Orchestra of New York opened its 40th-anniversary season with a gala double bill on Monday night. Not so long ago, the chances that this landmark might be reached seemed slim indeed. Facing financial difficulties in 2008, the orchestra suspended its long-running tradition of presenting operatic rarities in full concert performances. Since then, it has maintained a slighter profile with recitals.

title: Lotus of Siam, a Vegas Hit, Opening in Manhattan
description: LOTUS OF SIAM, a superlative-drenched Thai restaurant in Las Vegas, has been hiding in plain sight in New York for weeks.

title: Verjuice Makes Sour Grapes a Good Thing
description: LETS not stereotype power ingredients. They dont have to be brash  a gentle touch can liven up your cooking just as nicely. And they dont always have to swirl up from exotic cuisines. Even the familiar larder of provincial France can be a source.

title: Thoughts vs. Actions
description: Christina Romer, whom I mention in this weeks column, was among those White House officials who was most aggressive in arguing for more stimulus.

title: Judge Tells LimeWire, the File-Trading Service, to Disable Its Software
description: A federal judge in New York issued an injunction on Tuesday that will essentially shut down LimeWire, the big music file-sharing service that has been mired in a four-year legal struggle with the music industry. The company and its founder have already been being found liable for potentially hundreds of millions of dollars in damages.

title: The Sweet Science of German Rieslings
description: DESPITE endless efforts to explain, simplify and demystify, the riddle of German wines endures. Confronted with the bewildering nomenclature of so many German wine labels, many people simply shake their heads in confusion and give up. Rather than add to the babble, today we concede straight out that understanding German wines is hellishly difficult.

title: Jazz With Updates on the Past and Eyes on the Future
description: The music of Horace Silver doesnt exactly beg for reinvention. His compositions  especially those made famous from the mid-1950s through the mid-60s, when he was the high-spirited skipper of hard bop  come prefitted with guideposts and grace notes, an array of breezy embellishments that turn out to be essential. These are songs of brisk efficiency and elegant simplicity. You wouldnt want to mess any of that up.

title: A Musician Who Imparts a Glum Kind of Grandeur
description: In her directors statement for Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt and the Magnetic Fields, Gail OHara writes that this ones for the fans. Rarely has that been more true. If you respond to the morose grandeur of Mr. Merritts music or are drawn to his downtown gay-bard persona  owlish yet waspish  then its likely that youll be engrossed by this documentary, directed by Ms. OHara and Kerthy Fix, which was more than a decade in the making and is sometimes uncomfortably intimate. If not, you might be better off picking up that Keith Richards memoir.

title: Warhol Board Lawsuit Is Finally Dropped
description: A long-running lawsuit charging the Andy Warhol Foundation and the board that authenticates Warhols work with fraud and other misconduct is over, the Web site Artinfo.com reported. Joe Simon-Whelan, a filmmaker who bought a silk-screen Warhol self-portrait in 1989 only to see it later declared inauthentic on two occasions by the board, contended in the suit that the foundation and board had conducted a 20-year conspiracy to inflate the prices for Warhol works by denying the authenticity of a certain number as a way to create artificial scarcity. The board and foundation have denied the accusations. Mr. Simon-Whelan told Artinfo that he had decided to abandon the case because he lacked the money to pursue it. The foundations lawyers issued a statement saying that Mr. Simon-Whelan had dropped the suit because Mr. Simon-Whelan and his lawyers have utterly failed to uncover a single shred of evidence to support his allegations after more than three years of litigation.

title: Saudi Border With Yemen Is Still Inviting for Al Qaeda
description: ON THE SAUDI-YEMENI BORDER  The five Yemeni men, all of them rail-thin, clutched their knees as they sat staring across the sand at the narrow road, which separates the Arab worlds poorest country from its richest.

title: The Caucus Click: Atlanta
When Sweet Wines Belong
description: It may be an old wine industry clich, but there remains truth in the saying, Americans talk dry but drink sweet. That is the reason that the best-selling mass-market chardonnays tend to have a little residual sugar to them, and that Moet & Chandon, the big Champagne house, adds extra sweetness to its White Star Champagne, which is made especially for the American market.

title: Needing Students, Maine School Hunts in China
description: MILLINOCKET, Me.  Faced with dropping enrollment and revenue, the high school in this remote Maine town has fixed on an unlikely source of salvation: Chinese teenagers.

title: Carriers of the Torch, in a Chorus of Red Hair
description: LAST June, in the middle of her Last Girl on Earth tour, the R & B pop diva Rihanna strutted onto the Rock in Rio stage outside Madrid with the sides of her head shaved and a bowl cut of hair dyed matador red  the color of blood and passion and showmanship. Since then, Rihannas red has evolved further, from a voluminous Elmo-red wig while shooting the Whats My Name video on the Lower East Side in September to fire-engine-hued extensions during Paris Fashion Week this month.

title: Versa Is Said to Seek a Buyer for Polarfleece Maker
description: Versa Capital Management, the owner of Polartec, the century-old maker of the Polarfleece material, is seeking a buyer for the company, Bloomberg News reports, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,337 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Jets Jenkins May Be Hobbled, but Vows to Play On
description: Days after knee surgery, Kris Jenkins stopped three times because of a rapidly deflating tire on the drive from New Jersey to Washington to see his agent. Imagine a 6-foot-4-inch, 360-ish-pound nose tackle on crutches, fiddling with an air hose next to his BMW.

title: A Week at the Airport
description: Chapter 1

title: Carly Fiorina Is Hospitalized
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Carly Fiorina, the former Hewlett-Packard chief executive who is the Republican nominee for the Senate from California, was hospitalized Tuesday in Los Angeles with an infection stemming from reconstructive breast surgery she had in July, her campaign said.

title: Rabbit Ears Redux
description: Since television extended its reach from coast to coast in its early days, the properly equipped baseball fan was not likely to miss the World Series. Those rabbit ears or roof antennas had to be tilted the right way. And the reception might have been snowy. But no dispute between giant news media companies was going to thwart the fan from watching the Series.

title: Governor Bans New Gas Wells on State Land
description: Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania signed an executive order on Tuesday effectively banning further natural gas development on state forest lands.

title: In Motion
description: Deep Travel

title: Q. and A. With Samira Kawash of Candy Professor
description: In this weeks Dining section, Julia Moskin writes about Samira Kawash, right, who has made a study of the American relationship with candy through history on her blog, Candy Professor. The big idea behind Candy Professor is that candy carries so much moral and ethical baggage that people view it as fundamentally different  in a bad way  from other kinds of food, Ms. Moskin writes.

title: Tonights House Forecast: 52-Seat Gain For G.O.P.
description: If Democrats were hoping for a late surge to improve their chances of retaining control of the House, there isnt any evidence of it yet. Instead, Republicans have generally had the better of the polls in individual House districts released in the past 24 hours.

title: Manhattan, 4:35 P.M.
description: Volunteers at Organizing for America, a phone bank in Manhattan, called voters before Vice President Joseph R. Biden made a visit.

title: Giants Go From Finished to N.F.C. Front-Runners
description: The Giants returned home for their bye week a confident bunch after demolishing the Dallas Cowboys, the preseason darlings, Monday night and making their case as the best team in the National Football Conference.

title: Massey Energy Posts Loss Despite Higher Coal Sales
description: The embattled coal producer Massey Energy reported a bigger-than-expected loss for the third quarter on Tuesday despite increasing coal sales.

title: A Banner Year for Political Spending
description: With $188 million spent by and for Democrats and $178 million by and for Republicans, this election cycle will be one of the most expensive in Congressional history.

title: The Last Two Years, in Historical Context
description: For someone judging the Obama administrations first two years of policy making, the biggest black mark would be the current state of the economy. The administration  along with the Federal Reserve  succeeded in breaking the back of a huge financial crisis. But the administration  and, again, the Fed  also turned too timid this year. That timidity seems all but certain to cost the Democrats next week.

title: Developers Wage Battle Over a Tower Deemed Ugly
description: From his office at Time Warner Center, the developer Stephen M. Ross looked directly across Columbus Circle to a nearly vacant, financially troubled and, in his view, ugly, 26-story building. This being New York, where real estate is often a blood sport, he decided to do something about it. His firm, Related Companies, bought the $250 million mortgage on the property in September, intending to foreclose on the owner, demolish the building and erect a sleek skyscraper slightly taller than his 750-foot, two-towered Time Warner Center.

title: Cablevision Asks for F.C.C.-Run Meeting With Fox
description: The president of the Cablevision Corporation has asked the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission to hold a meeting in his office with the top executive from News Corporation in an effort to find a last-minute solution that could solve the fee dispute that threatens to leave 3 million Cablevision subscribers unable to see the World Series, which begins Wednesday night.

title: Sharing the Burden, Beyond the Few
description: To the Editor:

title: On Earth and on Venus
description: To the Editor:

title: World Series Backdrop Comes in Red and Blue
description: The men who manage the metropolises that will be competing when the World Series begins Wednesday night have played a little baseball in their time. In the case of the Dallas mayor, Tom Leppert, it was a few innings on the mound for the junior varsity at Claremont McKenna College in Southern California.

title: Herbert Hoover, Redux
description: To the Editor:

title: In Mideast House of Cards, U.S. Views Lebanon as Shaky
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, already struggling to stave off a collapse of Middle East peace talks, is increasingly alarmed by unrest in Lebanon, whose own fragile peace is being threatened by militant opponents of a politically charged investigation into the killing in 2005 of a former Lebanese leader.

title: Acne Cream? Tax-Sheltered. Breast Pump? No.
description: Denture wearers will get a tax break on the cost of adhesives to keep their false teeth in place. So will acne sufferers who buy pimple creams.

title: Credit Card Gimmicks
description: To the Editor:

title: The White iPhone Is Delayed Again
description: The elusive white iPhone has been delayed yet again.

title: Celts Rain On Heats Future Parade
description: BOSTON  Paul Pierce picked himself off the parquet floor in the third quarter and hobbled to the locker room. In the fourth, he was a hero. Ray Allen flicked in picture-perfect 3-pointers. Kevin Garnett produced a double-double. Rajon Rondo had 17 assists.

title: Risk for Rivals in Cable Fee Fight
Public Sector Pay: A Union Leaders View
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dark Horse in Buffetts Stable of Successors
description: By THOMAS KAPLAN

title: Pre-emptive Charges of Bias in a City-Financed Wage Study
description: Advocates for workers plan to charge on Wednesday that a New York City-financed study is likely to conclude falsely that more harm than good would come from mandating higher minimum wages for employees of companies that receive city subsidizes.

title: Adviser to Consumer Agency Had Role in Lending
description: WASHINGTON  A senior adviser to Elizabeth Warren, hired to help start the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is an investor in and, until recently, served as a director of a company that helps to arrange low-documentation loans for consumers with often-spotty credit histories.

title: Islamophobia and Homophobia
description: As if we needed more evidence of Americas political polarization, last week Juan Williams gave the nation a Rorschach test. Williams said he gets scared when people in Muslim garb board a plane hes on, and he promptly got (a) fired by NPR and (b) rewarded by Fox News with a big contract.

title: A Feast of Innards Nourishes French Nostalgia
description: LIMOGES, France  While the French may be renowned for their refined culinary tastes, they have another side. It was on full display this month in this city in central France known for its expensive porcelain but with another side of its own.

title: Gorbachev Says Putin Obstructs Democracy
description: MOSCOW  Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who once supported Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, is voicing growing frustration with Mr. Putins leadership, saying that he had undermined Russias fledgling democracy by crippling the opposition forces.

title: Lincecum and Lee Are Two of a Kind
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Secret Money in Iowa
description: Bruce Braley, a Democrat from northeastern Iowa, has been a popular two-term congressman and seemed likely to have an easy re-election until the huge cash mudslide of 2010. The Republican Party had largely left him alone, but then a secretive group called the American Future Fund began spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on distortion-heavy attack ads.

title: Former City Resident Is Accused of Trying to Join Terrorists
description: A former Staten Island man who prosecutors said made repeated attempts to join the Taliban and other extremist groups overseas, even though he apparently knew that federal agents were closely watching him, has been charged with making false statements in a terrorism case, the authorities said Tuesday.

title: Haitis Latest Misery
description: The cholera outbreak in Haiti  the first in 50 years  has layered fresh anxiety atop long-standing misery. By Tuesday the disease had sickened more than 3,000 people and killed more than 250. While the authorities have expressed cautious hope that the outbreak might soon stabilize and remain largely confined to the rural Artibonite region, there is still fear that the disease could overwhelm the shattered capital, Port-au-Prince.

title: Flu Vaccine, Then and Now
description: Last year many Americans, fearful of a new swine flu virus, clamored for vaccines that were often hard to find or even unavailable in their area. This year there should be plenty of vaccine for everyone who wants it.

title: San Francisco Becomes an October Baseball Town
description: San Francisco

title: The Movie Isnt Even Out, But Producer Eyes Stage Version of  The Kings Speech
description: If the highly anticipated Colin Firth film The Kings Speech performs well this awards season, chances are a stage version will come about relatively quickly on Broadway, in Londons West End, or both.

title: Lottery Numbers
Moose and Squirrel
description: In the Wayback Machine, its a very short trip to 1959 and the debut of Rocky and His Friends  the cartoon series featuring characters originated by Alex Anderson. Mr. Anderson died Friday at the age of 90 after a life spent mostly in advertising.

title: In California, an Encounter 2 Candidates Had Avoided
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  With less than a week until Election Day, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California has become a chunk of kryptonite that the candidates to succeed him lob at each other. But even as the candidates, Meg Whitman and Jerry Brown, scrambled to distance themselves from the governor, they shared a stage with him on Tuesday for the first time this election cycle.

title: Knicks Reach Out, Seeking a Connection to Disillusioned Fans
description: MAYBE, as the saying goes, it is a clich because it is true. For instance, to prove the veracity of Hope springs eternal, consider that the New York Knicks are introducing on Wednesday a campaign to stimulate interest in the team for the 2010-11 season.

title: Nets Top Attraction May Be Prokhorov
description: The Knicks have had a lot of reason to cheer Timofey Mozgov, their new Russian center who had an impressive preseason and figures to play a prominent role on the team this season.

title: Fed Wont Join Appeal to Keep Its Loans Secret
description: The Federal Reserve will not join a group of leading commercial banks in asking the Supreme Court to allow the government to withhold details of emergency loans made to financial companies in 2008.

title: Polls Show Wider Boxer Lead, Narrowing G.O.P. Takeover Path
description: We have been noting for several weeks that, with Republican chances having dwindled from slim to virtually none in a few East Coast Senate contests like Connecticut, Delaware, and the New York special election, their prospects of the party winning a 51st Senate seat on Nov. 2 instead boiled down to winning either California or Washington (while sweeping the other competitive contests). Today, they have gotten bad news in one of those races.

title: Turning the Taliban Against Al Qaeda
description: FOR the last week there have been widespread news reports that NATO is facilitating talks between the Afghan government and Taliban leaders, even as it routs Taliban forces from their main stronghold in Kandahar. The United States plan seems clear: allow for preliminary talks to end the war through a broad-based reconciliation process, but dont get serious about a deal until beefed-up coalition forces have gained the initiative on the battlefield.

title: Cant Keep a Bad Idea Down
description: I confess, I find it dispiriting to read the polls and see candidates, mostly Republicans, leading in various midterm races while promoting many of the very same ideas that got us into this mess. Am I hearing right?

title: Officer in Salon Shootout Is Promoted to Detective
description: The officer who engaged in a shootout with a man who tried to hold up a Brooklyn beauty salon was promoted to detective on Tuesday at City Hall in a ceremony presided over by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.

title: Fox TV Blackout Tests Old Giants Fans Ingenuity
description: Among old-time baseball fans in New York, rooting for the Giants always required a bit of resilience and resourcefulness. The Giants faithful were outnumbered by Yankees fans, and dwarfed at least in spirit by Dodgers loyalists.

title: Charges Dropped Against 3 in Bronx Antigay Attacks
description: Citing insufficient evidence, the Bronx district attorneys office on Tuesday dropped charges against 3 of the 11 young men accused of kidnapping, torturing and sexually assaulting three men who they thought were gay.

title: Lees Wife Is No Fan of Yankee Stadium
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When the millions start piling up at the negotiating table this winter, the behavior of a few rowdy Yankees fans will probably make no difference to Cliff Lee, the Texas Rangers ace and a pending free agent. But Lees wife, Kristen, was disturbed by the fans at Yankee Stadium during Game 3 of the American League Championship Series last week.

title: Wednesday: Makes Less Than a Killing
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Bram Stokers title character from his 1897 novel simply refuses to die. I guess thats appropriate. Every generation reinvents him to fit its needs. Teenagers today have a descendant out in twilit Forks, Wash.  a virginal vampire with sparkly skin. Even the thinly veiled eroticism remains.

title: Four Seven Whiskey, Weve Got a Problem: A Controllers Life in a Tailspin
description: A spatter of weird jargon comes thick and fast in the opening minutes of Spirit Control, a new play by Beau Willimon that opened on Tuesday at City Center in a Manhattan Theater Club production.

title: Another Long and Winding Detour
description: Another boomer theme park ride has been installed on Broadway, conveniently just opposite the peppy musical about those crooners from New Jersey. Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles on Broadway, a tricked-up cover band concert that opened on Tuesday night at the Neil Simon Theater, gives audiences a chance to sing along, twist and shout, and generally make like swooning teenyboppers from the 1960s as the hits roll by and the endorphins kick in.

title: In Far Over Their Heads: Life at the Pools Bottom
description: There they fester on the floor of that empty swimming pool, four men in Speedos, past their prime. Once they were legion, but they have dwindled to these lucky (or unlucky) few, and their days pass in a blur of sun-bleached sameness. Yet after 20 years, they remain gripped by the same fever of anticipation. They are waiting  hold for it  for Odysseus.

title: Prosecuting the States Business
description: ENVIRONMENTAL CASES Upholding a tradition that goes back to the days when Attorney General Robert Abrams made it his business to clean up the Love Canal toxic waste site, Andrew M. Cuomo has displayed sharp elbows when it comes to environmental protection. He filed lawsuits against the Bush administrations Environmental Protection Agency over global warming and American Electric Power, the nations largest power producer, when emissions from its Midwestern plants were blowing into New York. Just as telling are the less glamorous cases he brought forcing operators of mobile home parks to fix conditions that were imperiling the health of residents.

title: A Republican Leader Visits a Democratic Stronghold
description: There was an unusual sight in Harlem on Tuesday. A bright red tour bus pulled up outside a restaurant on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard. The words Fire Pelosi were written on the side, and the man who stepped out from the bus was Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: Recovery Going Well, Rangers Gaborik Expects to Start Skating Soon
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers forward Marian Gaborik said Tuesday that he was happy with the progress in recovering from the left shoulder separation he sustained in an overtime loss to Toronto on Oct. 15 and that he was on schedule to return to action by mid-November.

title: A Painter Forges Ahead
description: Will Barnet makes no concessions to age or anything else.

title: A Volcano Erupts in Indonesia
description: As Indonesian rescue workers sought survivors of a tsunami off Sumatra, Mount Merapi erupted in Java, sending thousands fleeing for their lives.

title: Candid Talks by Detainee Were Caught on U.S. Tapes
description: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the former Guantnamo detainee now on trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan, has been interrogated repeatedly over the years: by the Central Intelligence Agency, by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and by the Defense Department.

title: Mixed Views on Cuomo as Attorney General
description: The letter arrived in the New York State attorney generals office in late 2006  a desperate note from a woman in Yonkers with ovarian cancer. Her health insurers reimbursements were so inexplicably low she was drowning in unexpected bills.

title: F.C.C. Tells Cablevision: Fewer Stunts, More Talks
description: Cablevision Systems on Tuesday tried a new tactic to get the government to intervene in its dispute with the News Corporation, which is threatening to prevent three million homes from seeing the World Series starting Wednesday night. But the effort met with a swift and stinging rebuke from a senior Federal Communications Commission official, who dismissed the move as a stunt.

title: Expand the Playoff Field? No Thanks
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The last time the World Series was here, in 2002, both teams were wild-card entrants into the postseason. The Angels beat the Giants in a riveting seven-game series, the last World Series to go to the final game. Eight years later, no one seems to care that neither team finished in first place.

title: Democrats Retain Edge in Campaign Spending
description: Lost in all of the attention paid to the heavy spending by Republican-oriented independent groups in this years midterm elections is that Democratic candidates have generally wielded a significant head-to-head financial advantage over their Republican opponents in individual competitive races.

title: When a Pirate Is the Voice of Chivalry
description: WASHINGTON

title: Lobbyists Court Potential Stars of House Panels
description: WASHINGTON  Ernst & Young, the global accounting firm, hosted a fund-raising breakfast late last month for Representative Dave Camp that drew so many donors the firms lobbyists had to pull extra chairs into their largest conference room.

title: A Budget Travel Pioneer in a Time When $5 a Day Was Real (Frugal) Money
description: It was the first handwritten letter Id received in 5 years. Or maybe 10. Signed by John Wilcock, a man Id never heard of, and postmarked Ojai, Calif., it was waiting for me when I returned from my So Paulo-to-New York summer trip. Mr. Wilcock wrote that he had been an assistant editor at The Times Travel section back in the 1950s, and had written the first editions of Mexico on $5 a Day, Greece on $5 a Day and Japan on $5 a Day for Arthur Frommer in the 1960s.

title: Mets Could Name Alderson G.M. on Friday
description: The Mets top three owners met with Sandy Alderson at Citi Field Tuesday, and all indications continue to point to Alderson being named the teams next general manager, perhaps as soon as Friday.

title: Knicks Secret Workouts Violated Rules, Report Says
description: On the eve of a promising new season, the Knicks were again confronted with the mayhem of their recent past and the possible misdeeds of the previous administration.

title: Big Man in Little Odessa
description: The Sunday shoppers at the St. Petersburg Trade and Publishing House hardly noticed the remarkably tall man flipping through compact discs. The old men playing cards by the boardwalk never looked up.

title: Small Efforts Add Up in Colorado Senate Race
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  The Senate race in Colorado has seen as intense a barrage of television attack ads as any race in the country, tens of millions of dollars worth, numbing voters with the din.

title: Health Care Vote Puts Democrats on Defensive
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  At the start of their debate here last week, the Republican challenger for Congress, State Senator Robert Hurt, paused only long enough to thank the League of Women Voters before ripping into Representative Tom Perriello for voting for government-run health care. Mr. Hurt returned to the topic seven times over the next hour, despite being asked only once.

title: Bloggingheads: A Witch in the Senate?
description: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Jeff Sharlet, author of "C Street," debate Christine O'Donnell's remarks about witchcraft.

title: Caffeine and Alcohol Drink Is Potent Mix for Young
description: Mixing alcohol and caffeine is hardly a new concept, but a rash of cases involving students and others who landed at hospitals after drinking beverages that combine the two in a single large can has alarmed college and health officials around the country.

title: A Mix Attractive to Students and Partygoers
description: It has long vexed club-hoppers and partygoers: how do you stay awake while drinking alcohol late into the night?

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Toxic Metals Tied to Work in Prisons
description: Inmates and employees at 10 federal prisons were exposed to toxic metals and other hazardous substances while processing electronic waste for recycling, a four-year investigation by the Justice Departments inspector general found.

title: Knicks Mozgov Tours Russian Enclave in New York
description: The Knicks rookie Timofey Mozgov finds some familiarity in a visit to Brighton Beach.

title: Phys Ed: Do Cortisone Shots Actually Make Things Worse?
description: In the late 1940s, the steroid cortisone, an anti-inflammatory drug, was first synthesized and hailed as a landmark. It soon became a safe, reliable means to treat the pain and inflammation associated with sports injuries (as well as other conditions). Cortisone shots became one of the preferred treatments for overuse injuries of tendons, like tennis elbow or an aching Achilles, which had been notoriously resistant to treatment. The shots were quite effective, providing rapid relief of pain.

title: Model Now Has Whitman as Big Underdog in California
description: While there was an interesting set of polls in Senate and U.S. House races today, the polling load was lighter in gubernatorial contests, with most surveys confirming current assumptions about the races.

title: Word of the Day | fleck
description: fleck \flek\ noun and verb

title: 3 Are Wounded in a Shooting on a Lower East Side Street
description: Three people were shot when a gunman, apparently upset over an argument with at least one of his victims, opened fire on a Lower East Side street Tuesday night, the police said.

title: Alaska Senate Candidate Once Disciplined for Computer Misuse
description: Joe Miller, the Republican Senate candidate from Alaska, was disciplined for using three co-workers computers for political purposes and initially lying about it when he worked as a part-time lawyer for the Fairbanks North Star Borough in 2008, personnel records released on Tuesday under a court order showed.

title: Buyout Keeps Plan Alive for Maryland Nuclear Plant
description: A compromise intended to preserve the possibility of building a nuclear plant in Maryland was announced late Tuesday by Constellation Energy, the Baltimore-based company that had given up on the project, and lectricit de France, which wants to proceed.

title: Anbar Province, Once a Hotbed of Iraqi Insurgency, Demands a Say on Resources
description: RAMADI, Iraq  As Iraqs political blocs remain unable to form a national government, lawmakers and residents here in Anbar Province are challenging central control of the natural resources within their territory.

title: S. Neil Fujita, Innovative Graphic Designer, Dies at 89
description: S. Neil Fujita, a graphic designer who used avant-garde painting and photography to create some of the most striking album covers of the 1950s, and who designed the visually arresting book jackets for In Cold Blood and The Godfather, died on Saturday in Greenport, on the North Fork of Long Island. He was 89.

title: Indonesia Struggles After Tsunami and Volcano
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia moved to count the costs and help survivors on Wednesday after a tsunami and volcanic eruptions struck separate parts of the country, killing at least 340 people and driving tens of thousands from their homes.

title: Lamont Johnson, Emmy-Winning Director, Dies at 88
description: Lamont Johnson, an Emmy-winning television director known for bringing an understated touch to delicate subjects, died on Sunday at his home in Monterey, Calif. He was 88.

title: Brazil: Conviction in 2006 Plane Crash Over Amazon
description: An air traffic controller, Jomarcelo Fernandes dos Santos, has been convicted of a crime equivalent to manslaughter and sentenced to 14 months in prison in connection with the crash of a Gol Airlines flight that killed 154 people over the Amazon in 2006, Brazilian news media reported on Tuesday. Four other controllers were acquitted, the reports said. Mr. dos Santos remains free pending appeal. He and the other four controllers were on duty when the Gol Boeing 737-800 collided with a private Legacy jet flown by two pilots from Long Island. The Gol plane crashed into the jungle, killing everyone on board.

title: Assembly Again Urges U.S. to Lift Cuba Embargo
description: The annual General Assembly resolution calling for the United States to lift its longstanding economic embargo against Cuba passed by the lopsided vote of 187 to 2. Only the United States and Israel opposed the nonbinding measure, the 19th such resolution in a row, while three Pacific island allies of Washington abstained. The Cuban foreign minister, Bruno Rodrguez Parrilla, accused President Obama of promising to change relations with Cuba but falling under the thrall of the exile community in the United States. In response, the United States said that it had expanded trade and other ties with the Caribbean nation but that improved relations hinged on greater domestic freedom.

title: Arizona: Court Upholds Stay on Execution
description: A federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld a decision blocking the execution of an Arizona inmate because of questions about the quality of one of the drugs that would be used. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld the order from Judge Roslyn O. Silver, who demanded information about the origins of the drug, sodium thiopental, in order to know whether there were risks of impurity or efficacy that could cause undue pain and suffering to the inmate, Jeffrey Landrigan. Arizonas attorney general has stated that the drug came from England, but has not identified the maker or explained how it obtained the drug. Late Tuesday, the full appeals court refused to rehear the case.

title: Arizona: Citizenship Proof For Voting Is Struck Down
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit struck down a state law that requires people to provide proof of American citizenship to register to vote, saying the law conflicts with the federal National Voter Registration Act. Nina Perales, national senior counsel for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said that few illegal immigrants tried to register, but that 30,000 citizens had been rejected for registration under the law, which voters passed in 2004.

title: Pennsylvania: Governor Bans More Gas Development
description: Gov. Edward G. Rendell signed an order Tuesday effectively banning further natural gas development on state forest land. He said the action was needed in part to prevent unchecked industrialization of public lands in a state that has seen an boom in natural gas development. Roughly 660,000 of the states 2.2 million acres of public forest have been leased, according to the state. The moratorium comes just days after a breakdown in negotiations between the governor and State Senate Republicans over a severance tax on natural gas production, favored by Mr. Rendell, a Democrat.

title: News Quiz | October 27, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Lees Wife Is No Fan of Yankee Stadium
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When the millions start piling up at the negotiating table this winter, the behavior of a few rowdy Yankees fans will probably make no difference to Cliff Lee, the Texas Rangers ace and a pending free agent. But Lees wife, Kristen, was disturbed by the fans at Yankee Stadium during Game 3 of the American League Championship Series last week.

title: Harvard Man May Be Winner on Winless Bills
description: At 0-6, the Bills are the leagues only winless team. It would be flip to say that they are on the clock for the 2011 draft, but barring a major turnaround, they will be well positioned to select a franchise quarterback. Ryan Fitzpatricks play, however, might make them consider other options.

title: I.B.M. Approves $10 Billion Stock Buyback
description: I.B.M. has approved an additional $10 billion in stock buybacks, representing nearly 6 percent of its outstanding shares, The Associated Press Reports.

title: Fed Wont Join Appeal to Keep Emergency Loans Secret
description: The Federal Reserve will not join a group of leading commercial banks in asking the Supreme Court to allow the government to withhold details of emergency loans made to financial companies in 2008, Bloomberg News reports.

title: BHP Challenge to Potashs Poison Pill Is Set
description: Saskatchewans securities regulator will hear BHP Billitons challenge to Potash Corporation of Saskatchewans shareholder rights plan on Nov. 8 and 9, assuming that the Canadian government allows BHPs $39 billion bid to proceed.

title: Creditors Back Dubai World Debt Restructuring
description: The state-owned investment enterprise Dubai World has secured support from all its creditors for a $25 billion debt restructuring plan, a spokesman said on Wednesday, helping it to avoid a drawn-out battle with a special tribunal, Reuters reports.

title: The Write-In Challenge
description: WHO is Lisa Murkowski? WHO is she running against in the race for United States senator from Alaska?

title: JPMorgan Said to Face Scrutiny on Silver Trading
description: The American commodity futures regulator is looking into claims by a trader in London that JPMorgan Chase was involved in manipulative silver trading, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person close to the situation.

title: Lee and Lincecum Have Hat Issues
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Rangers pitcher Cliff Lee has gotten a lot of scrutiny for his uniquely worn-out hat, with blotches of rosin on the bill and the back. But his opposite number in Game 1 also wears a studiously worn-in hat.

title: Daily Lexeme: Pruniferous
description: Todays word, in association with the cherished Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: For Myspace, a Redesign to Entice Generation Y
description: SAN FRANCISCO  All but eclipsed by Facebook and Twitter, Myspace is aiming for a comeback.

title: Ellison Claims Proof of Wrongdoing by New H.P. Chief
description: Oracles chief executive, Larry Ellison, said he can prove that Hewlett-Packards incoming C.E.O. oversaw an SAP scheme to steal Oracles software, Reuters reports.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Oct. 27, 2010
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Oana Pascu at Math for America from the Times article Retired Space Shuttle May Come to Manhattan, After All.

title: Deutsche Bank Reports Loss, Citing Takeover Costs
description: Deutsche Bank said on Wednesday that it had lost money in the third quarter as the costs of acquiring Deutsche Postbank, Germanys largest retail bank, added to the effects of a slump in stock trading, Jack Ewing of The New York Times report.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Female founders, influencers and deal makers on the New York Scene.

title: Is ASX Bid Too Much for SGX to Handle?
description: Magnus Bocker, who stitched together eight European stock exchanges and sold them in a bidding war, is running into a wall with shareholders and politicians over his plan to acquire Australias main exchange, Bloomberg News reports.

title: E.D.F. Buys Constellations Stake in Nuclear Venture
description: lectricit de France and Constellation Energy have announced a deal under which E.D.F. would buy out Constellations share of what had been a joint venture, UniStar Nuclear Energy, for $140 million.

title: JPMorgans Highbridge to Buy Gvea of Brazil
description: JP Morgan Chase said on Wednesday that it would acquire a controlling stake in Gvea Investimentos, a $6 billion hedge fund founded by Arminio Fraga, former head of the central bank of Brazil.

title: Consumer Protection Agency Adviser Had Role in Soured Loans
description: A senior adviser to Elizabeth Warren, pictured, hired to help start the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is an investor in and, until recently, served as a director of a company that helps to arrange low-documentation loans for consumers with often-spotty credit histories.

title: A Street Photographers Nimble Tread
description: Neal Boenzi is the Fred Astaire of photojournalism  a master of his craft who was classy enough to make it all look so easy. Though he retired years ago (hell turn 85 on Nov. 15), those of us who were his colleagues can still picture his seemingly effortless footwork.

title: European Union Adopts Hedge Fund Rules
description: After drawn-out negotiations, the European Union has agreed to new rules for hedge funds, having gained the approval of the European Parliament to regulate more thoroughly the 2 trillion euro ($2.8 trillion) industry.

title: What Would You Risk Your Life For?
description: Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times who has photographed wars in numerous countries, was seriously wounded recently while covering the conflict in Afghanistan. What drives people like Mr. Silva to risk their lives to report the news? What are you so committed to that you would take considerable risks, including putting yourself in harms way?

title: SGX-ASX Merger Seen as Threat to Hong Kong Exchange
description: A merger between Singapore Exchange and ASX will make it harder for Hong Kong to win offerings by commodity companies and achieve an expansion plan announced this year, the chairman of the Hong Kong exchange said.

description: Shares of Mecox Lane soared in their first day of trading on Wednesday.

title: Expensive Ways to Save Money
description: One of the keys to making money is to keep your costs down. Sometimes, in the effort to save money, a company can be the victim of unintended consequences. You save some money by putting off machine maintenance, and a machine breaks down and stops production. You save some money by changing insurance companies, and you find out after you make a claim why the new company is cheaper. You save money by not doing safety training in your factory, and someone gets hurt doing something the wrong way.

Tolkiens fantasy novel The Hobbit, to be produced and directed by Peter Jackson, in their country, Jonathan Hutchison reports for The New York Times.

title: 5-2 Starts Are Common for Giants, but Where Do They Finish?
description: Predicting how the Giants season will unfold is like trying to spell out a hidden phrase on Wheel of Fortune. No matter how many times you are spotted the same five letters (R-S-T-L-N) and a vowel (E), the phrase isnt easy to figure out. The Giants are 5-2 for the sixth time in seven seasons under Coach Tom Coughlin. Giants finishes after 5-2 starts under Coughlin have ranged from winning the Super Bowl in 2007 to the total collapse in 2004, when their record was 6-10.

Bank of America laid off a third of its prop trading desk last month.  UBSs prime brokerage is fielding inquiries from other banks traders looking for an exit so they can make the leap to their own hedge fund.

description: WASHINGTON  The most noted trend leading up to next weeks elections, of course, has been the emergence of a new generation of conservative leaders  so-called Tea Party candidates who have overturned the old political order in states like Kentucky and Nevada and who vow to confront the aging establishments of both parties in Washington.

title: BlueMountain Fund Said to Return About 9%
description: BlueMountain Capital Management, the hedge fund whose founders helped create credit-default swaps, returned 8.5 to 9 percent this year in its main fund, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the results.

title: Global Warming and the Tyranny of Boredom
description: My discussion of the newsroom tyrannies that impede effective media coverage of human-driven climate change elicited a provocative response from Randy Olson, the marine biologist turned filmmaker and communication coach for scientists. Ive long described what I call tyrannies in talks to journalists and students  including the tyrannies of (limited) time and space, balance, the lure of the front-page thought and conflict, the need need for a news peg (a reason for a story to run today, not next month, next year or never).

title: James Cameron Announces Avatar Sequels
description: LOS ANGELES  Its official: James Cameron is going back to Pandora not just for his next film, but also for his next two. Mr. Cameron, the filmmaker behind the 3-D blockbuster Avatar, joined 20th Century Fox in announcing that he would make Avatar 2 and Avatar 3 as his next two movies, with the first of the sequels scheduled for release in December 2014, and the second for December of the following year. That assures a lot of fantasy-filled Decembers, as Peter Jackson has already scheduled a pair of Hobbit films for Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in that month in the years 2012 and 2013. Avatar was released on Dec. 18 of last year and became the highest-grossing film in history, with almost $2.8 billion in worldwide ticket sales. Mr. Cameron and the top Fox film executives, Jim Gianopulos and Tom Rothman, jointly said they aimed to begin production next year on the first sequel. The film is not yet officially titled, they said.

title: Over Tutus Objections, South African Opera Company Says It Will Tour Israel

title: Space Craft
description: As a set designer, Gary Card is used to pouring his creativity into a wildly elaborate mise-en-scne, only to see the whole thing dismantled or destroyed once the project is finished. So when the creative director John Skelton and his partner, Dan Mitchell, approached him to design the interiors of LN-CC, a new concept store (think meticulously curated avant-garde fashion, rare books and vintage vinyl) in the scrappy east London neighborhood of Dalston, Card jumped at the chance to create something permanent. He used his surrealist sensibility to transform the space, a former boxing gym, into a hipster fun house. To enter the store, visitors navigate Cards deconstructed forest, only to find themselves in the belly of a beast  a wooden tunnel that resembles a crudely assembled whale skeleton. The rest of the 6,000-square foot-space is divided into individual rooms, like a gallery hung with mannequins (above) and a library lined with asymmetrical shelving. Every room needed a distinct atmosphere, tone and temperature, Card says. The idea was to move from organic to industrial, from warm to cold. And always keep it open to change. The main attraction is the private club space, with its sound system by the legendary sound guru Mickey Boyle. For Cards sake, we hope the parties dont get too out of hand.

title: Latest Poll Shows Cuomo Ahead by 20 Points
description: With six days to go before the election, Andrew M. Cuomo leads Carl P. Paladino in the race for governor by 20 percentage points, 55 percent to 35 percent, according to a Quinnipiac University poll of likely voters conducted last week and released Wednesday morning.

title: The Worst Economist in the World, 10/27/10
description: In my first WEITW post, I went after the claim that quantitative easing, by weakening the dollar, could actually hurt recovery  because, you see, a weaker dollar leads to higher commodity prices. As I tried to explain, a weaker dollar is also a stronger euro (and other currencies), so what raises prices in terms of one currency lowers them in terms of others, and the whole thing makes no sense.

description: For years, my family and neighbors have shared a joke about our little dirt road in the center of Kigali. Rue de Progrs (Road of Progress), we chuckle, has really been Rue de Non Progrs (Road of No Progress).

And so, this unsigned (of course) review of the new Richard Mabey book: Weeds: How Vagabond Plants Gatecrashed Civilization and Changed the Way We Think About Nature, praises this delightful and casually learned book as a defense of the despised weed.  Glenn Collins

description: Chris Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, put a second and final stop on Wednesday morning to the most expensive public works project under way in the country, a proposed rail tunnel under the Hudson River that could have doubled commuter-train service to Manhattan.

He names Jerry Brown, the Democrat and two-term former governor, mayor and attorney general who is running in Californias race for governor, as just one example of this crop of resurrected office-seekers.

title: Face Values | Inge Grognards Radical Chic
description: The 1980s were a time of general excess, especially in fashion. But the emergence of a band of Belgian designers dedicated to a radically deconstructed vision of dress signaled a mucking out its Augean stables. Out with pouf skirts, in with sweaters made of old socks! Abetting this brave new look were the makeup artist Inge Grognard and her photographer husband, Ronald Stoops. Working on magazine shoots and runway shows for Dries Van Noten, Dirk Bikkembergs, Walter Van Beirendonck, Dirk Van Saene and perhaps most famously, Martin Margiela, the couple created some of the most arresting images of the 90s. The couples long-awaited first book, Inge Grognard Ronald Stoops (Ludion), out at the end of the month, gathers their favorite images in one coffee-table-ready volume. The Moment recently caught up with Grognard via phone from her home in Antwerp  Stoops and the designer An Vandervorst could be heard chatting in the background  to talk about how fashion has changed since the 80s, her definition of beauty and the problem with red lipstick.

title: New Bin Laden Tape Threatens France

title: Leaked Reports Prompt Questions About Civilian Casualties
