title: Moncler, Where the Parkas Need a Bouncer
description: FIRST, the good news: Moncler is hiring. I witnessed it myself, retail reporters and seekers of employment. Two young people went into the store last week, dressed unflamboyantly, carrying sheaves of rsums probably meant for every boutique south of Union Square. One got an impromptu (informational?) interview on the spot. None of the on-duty salespeople seemed ruffled by the intrusion. Maybe they were a bit relieved.

title: Take My Bulgarian Joke Book. Please.
description: GABROVO, Bulgaria  The sign leading into town, faded but still readable in Bulgarian, was as I remembered it. Welcome and good riddance, it said. Gabrovians, like Borscht Belt comedians or Delaware Republicans, pride themselves on their sense of humor. Before the Wall fell, this hard-luck but endearing city at the foot of the central Balkans was regarded as the Communist capital of humor.

title: For Charity, a Cross-Country Trip on 2 Wheels
description: Its fair to say that as Credit Suisses co-chairman of mergers and acquisitions, Steven Koch is well traveled. But his latest journey isnt exactly a typical business trip.

title: D.S.C.C. Likes John Raese   in Florida
description: The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee thinks that John Raese, the Republican candidate for Senate in West Virginia, might actually make a decent senator  for Florida.

title: Cuddle Class
description: A row of economy class seats which converts into a flat bed or couch.

title: Google Searching Gets More Local
description: This week Google is introducing two new features. One is a new way to search  Place Search, for finding local businesses along with maps and reviews. The other is a new type of ad for local businesses, which Google calls Boost; its an effort to make it easier for small businesses to place ads that show up when people search for local places.

title: Medical Marijuana Raises Tough Questions for Nursing Homes
description: Every night before bed, Norma Winkler, 82, opens a small jar of cannabis oil and measures out a quarter-teaspoon to mix with homemade applesauce. Soon after she eats it, she drifts off to sleep.

title: Gingrich, Liberty University and the White House: Dj Vu
description: Is Newt Gingrich playing us all over again?

title: The Velvet Rope Comes Down
description: WHEN Cobi Levy showed up at the Boom Boom Room on a recent Wednesday night, he didnt have to worry about velvet ropes or door policies. Looking like an 1960s Italian movie star in a gray pinstripe suit and black Dior oxfords, Mr. Levy waltzed right in  hes on the permanent guest list  and emerged on the 18th floor, where a hostess whisked him to a corner table marked reserved that offered stellar views of the Empire State Building.

title: Recommended Reading: Bad Science
description: Ben Goldacre is a skeptic after our own hearts.

title: Majority Disapprove of Incumbents, Poll Shows
description: In sobering news for incumbents in Congress, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that a majority of voters say their own representatives do not deserve to return to office.

title: Oversharing a Childs Story
description: A recurring theme here on Motherlode is the intersection, overlap and separation of our childrens lives from our own. Where is the line between helping and hovering? Between caring and smothering? Protecting and snooping? Letting go and abandoning? Sharing and betraying?

title: Friday Is the Day to Introduce Alderson as Mets General Manager
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Mets are planning a news conference for Friday to introduce Sandy Alderson as their new general manager. The team made the decision to hire Alderson on Tuesday after he met with the Mets three-headed ownership group. They then notified the runner-up candidate, Josh Byrnes, of the news later in the day, according to a person who has spoken with one of the people involved in the decision.

title: Kennedy Center Follies Gets Its Phyllis
description: The Broadway veterans Jan Maxwell and Linda Lavin and the British musical theater star Elaine Paige have been cast in major roles, alongside previously announced Bernadette Peters, in the spring 2011 revival of the Stephen Sondheim musical Follies at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, executives there announced on Wednesday.

title: Legislative Approval Final for French Pension Bill
description: PARIS  The lower house of Frances parliament, the National Assembly, gave final approval on Wednesday to a bill that raises the minimum retirement age from 60 to 62 and the age for a full pension from 65 to 67.

title: The Opening of Ferrari World Is Delayed
description: Ferrari World, the extravagant 40-acre theme park on Yas Island in Abu Dhabi, is at long last complete and was scheduled to open to the public on Wednesday night. But according to the site Emirates 24/7, the opening has been postponed because of the death on Wednesday of Sheikh Saqr bin Mohammed al-Qasimi, the ruler of Ras al Khaymah, one of the seven members of the United Arab Emirates.

title: Looking Back and Looking Ahead: Week 8 in Fantasy
description: Chet Gresham blogs about fantasy football at Razzball. You can follow him on Twitter @Chetrazzball.

title: Dubai Faces Environmental Problems After Growth
description: DUBAI  Dubais skyline is the most sparkling in the Middle East. But down on the ground, the environmental problems of a quickly erected city built on sand look a lot less alluring.

title: Lin-Manuel Miranda to Close Out Broadway Run of In the Heights
description: After a Broadway run of more than two and a half years that included four Tony Awards and a Grammy, the hit musical In the Heights will close on Jan. 9. Its the right time, one of the producers, Kevin McCollum, said Wednesday, citing the implacable economics of Broadway. If we ran into another year, it wouldnt make sense.

title: For Democrats, Losing the House Is Not Inevitable. (Just Very Likely.)
description: Pretty much every time that we issue a House forecast  like last night, for instance, when we projected that Republicans gains were most likely to be on the order of 52 seats  we point out that the forecast has a lot of uncertainty in it.

title: Velour Still Has Some Juice
description: WHEN we last heard from Juicy Couture, the maker of velour tracksuits that all but defined the California casual sportswear look of the last decade, things were not looking so good. Retailers began scaling back their orders after its founders, Gela Nash-Taylor and Pamela Skaist-Levy, announced in January that they were reducing their involvement in the company to non-operating creative consulting roles.

title: 36 Hours in Venice
description: WITH its picture-perfect canals and waterside palazzi, Venice is a romantic idyll. No wonder 18 million tourists pile onto the floating city each year. But what is surprising is that the embattled residents still manage to carve out a hometown for themselves  a pastiche of in-the-know restaurants, underground bars, quiet piazzas and calmer, outlying islands. And thats not counting all the cultural offerings that Venetians take full advantage of. The cool art scene now goes beyond the Biennale. And instead of sinking, architectural icons have re-emerged as new landmarks.

title: The Hurdles to Suing Outside Advisers for Fraud
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: States With the Best, and Worst, Business Tax Climates
description: From a tax perspective, South Dakota is the most hospitable state for businesses, while New York is the least, according to the Tax Foundations latest ranking.

title: At the Edge of Death, and of Fashion
description: WE had a rule, David Blaine, the illusionist and endurance artist, said Monday evening. Dont hurt the sharks.

title: The Morning Line: Spanning the Continents for the Breeders Cup
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

title: F.T.C. Drops Google Inquiry on Street View Data
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced Wednesday that it would cease its inquiry into Googles collection of consumer data transmitted over wireless networks by its Street View cars.

title: Bnter Offers a Way to Share and Save Text-Message Conversations
description: Everyone sends text messages they later regret  just ask Brett Favre.

title: Its a Trad, Trad, Trad World
description: Hickey Freeman has been synonymous with clean tailored suiting for the past 100 years, so its no surprise that Opening Ceremony turned to the august brand for its latest mens-wear collaboration aimed at neo-traditionalists. Combining the Hickey Freeman heritage with Opening Ceremonys youthful aesthetic, the retweaked classics include slim-line pants ($300) and suit jackets ($1,395) available in hounds-tooth, herringbone, pinstripes and tweeds.

title: 'The Seagull'
description: A scene from the Goodman Theater production of "The Seagull." (Courtesy of the Goodman Theater)

title: Ideas in Motion: Illustrating Basic Science Concepts
description: Overview  | What can we learn from comics or graphic novels? How do visual representations of science concepts aid our understanding of them? In this lesson, students explore different ways of representing topics in science. They address whether entertainment can also be educational, and write their own comic strips that explain science concepts.

title: Charter School Is Approved, Despite Opposition
description: The State Universitys trustees unanimously approved an application on Wednesday to place a new charter school on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Virginia Man Is Charged in Plot on Capital Subway
description: WASHINGTON  A Virginia man was arrested Wednesday and accused of trying to help men he believed to be militants plot bombings at Washington-area subway stations, the Justice Department announced.

title: Home Inspections During Divorces
description: Paying for a home inspection isnt just for potential home buyers. There are good reasons that those going through a divorce would also want to hire a home inspector.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Charlie Sheens Plaza Hotel rampage consists mostly of throwing pillows and tipping chairs. Eloise would eat him for breakfast.

title: Surprising Islanders Mixing Vets and Youth
description: From The Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out blog:

title: Basketball Heads to Bahamas Resort
description: Atlantis, Paradise Island, in the Bahamas, will host the first Battle at Atlantis, a four-team Division I doubleheader featuring Mississippi State, Virginia Tech, Georgia Tech and the University of Richmond on Dec. 18. The resort is spending about half a million dollars to convert its conference center  usually host to big-name pop concerts featuring the likes of Rihanna and the Jonas Brothers  to create a temporary 4,200-seat arena with live broadcasting capabilities.

title: Wingtips: Beloved, Classic and Now Trendy
description: MEN are from moors, women are from Paris.

title: Trading Up: Wingtips
description: A fresh look at a beloved fashion classic: wingtips.

title: Variations on the Vegetable Fritter
description: It is no secret that I possess a deep love for deep-fried food. The carrot and zucchini fritter recipe that I wrote about will work beautifully for any kind of vegetable: onions, sweet potatoes, shredded winter squash and pretty much anything so long as its cut up into little pieces for uniform frying. In fact, fritters are a great way to use up the bounty of seasonal vegetables you may be getting in your C.S.A. box (broccoli, broccoli, broccoli; turnips, turnips, turnips).Fritters demand to be dipped, says I, but you can also use them as a base for a thick spread of hummus, baba ganoush or chutney. And, when the temperature starts dropping, I love them on a plate with beef stew ladled on top.

title: Where in the World Is Lo Apotheker?
description: There are things you can muzzle, like dogs and guns. And then there is Lawrence J. Ellison.

title: Credit Suisse May Cut 250 Jobs in New York
description: 3:43 p.m. | Updated Credit Suisse may lay off as many as 250 employees in New York City in the next few months, the bank has told state labor officials.

title: Handicapping the European Juveniles
description: Jessica Chapel blogs about racing as Railbird. She is the developer of Breeders Cup 360; and a contributing editor to Hello Race Fans.

title: 'Candide'
description: A scene from the Goodman Theater production of "Candide." (Video courtesty of Goodman Theater)

title: European Officials Broadly Criticize U.S. Airport Security Methods
description: LONDON  Several European officials questioned American requirements for airport security on Wednesday, a day after the chairman of British Airways criticized Britain for bowing too quickly to Washingtons demands.

title: New Zealand Bends and Hobbit Stays
description: LOS ANGELES  New Zealand will remain the middle of Middle-earth, at a price.

title: Finding Pictures When Youre Not Looking
description: Kirsten Luce, a 28-year-old photographer living in Brooklyn, is a regular contributor to The New York Times. She spent two years photographing along the Mexican border and has freelanced in Mexico City and Atlanta. She is the coordinator for the Foundry Photojournalism Workshop, a nonprofit program for emerging photojournalists. Amanda Rivkins conversation with Ms. Luce has been edited.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Indonesia, Israel and Romania.

title: Maverick or No?: Dueling Ads in Wisconsin
description: Senator Russ Feingold: Im independent. Ron Johnson, his Republican opponent: Eh, not so much.

title: Comcast Loses More Subscribers Than Expected, but Its Earnings Top Estimates
description: Is it the economy, competition or the Internet that has consumers cutting their cable television service?

title: Fixing a PC That Cant Keep the Right Time
description: Printing

title: The Candy Professor Answers Readers Questions
description: Samira Kawash, of the blog Candy Professor, replies to readers questions  about Americans relationship with candy.

title: Airline Unions Seek a Share of the Industry Gains
description: The glamour of working for an airline long ago lost its luster.

title: Humor to Restore Sanity
description: David Brooks: Gail, are you coming down to Washington for the Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert Rally to Restore Sanity? Im pretty sure Ill go out of curiosity and because Ive never seen 100,000 Priuses in one place.

title: A New Opening Number (But No Finale Yet) for Women on the Verge
description: With opening night (and performances for the critics) fast approaching, the creators of the new Broadway musical Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown added several changes for Tuesday nights audience, most noticeably a new number at the top of the show that had been the Act II opener.

title: Seeking Sylvia Plath, in Her Own Words and Someone Elses
description: The French have Jerry Lewis, the Germans have David Hasselhoff, and now its the Britons turn to make the case for an American. Not that Sylvia Plath needs the help, although her status as the archetypal Wronged Woman has managed both to canonize and to ghettoize her.

title: What Were Reading: Why Women Live Longer Than Men
Carlsen Misses Win but Widens Lead at Pearl Spring
What Else Could the White House Have Done?
description: A couple of good  and different  takes on whether the White House and Democratic leaders in Congress could have done more to help the economy over the past two years:

title: Allowing Children, of All Ages, to Choose
description: Unlike Ilie Ruby, Caitlin Hamilton Summie is not an adoptive mother. She has lived every moment of her sons and daughters lives in tandem with them. And yet she wonders, as Ruby does, where the lines are between where she ends and her children begin. And it makes her wonder how her own parents managed to so regularly hold their tongues.

title: Prosecutors Defend Wiretaps in Galleon Case
description: Federal prosecutors filed a brief on Wednesday asking a judge to deny Raj Rajaratnams request to exclude thousands of wiretapped conversations from his upcoming insider-trading trial.

title: Shea, Billy Joel and a Lot of Brenda and Eddies
description: Most years, the World Series makes Mets fans wistful. With rare exception, the team will have played its last game weeks earlier, often in dispiriting fashion. The falling leaves and chillier weather are reminders that spring training  and hope for a fresh start  are months away.

title: How To Ruin Baseball
description: Nothing spoils an excellent baseball postseason like this kind of rumor:

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Indonesia, Israel and Romania.

title: TNTs Heat-Celtics Game Viewed by 7.4 Million
description: TNTs heavily promoted opening night game between the Miami Heat and the Boston Celtics on Tuesday night attracted 7.4 million viewers, the most for a regular-season N.B.A. game on cable. It surpassed the 7.27 million for a Bulls-Lakers game in February 1996.

title: The Whitney Gears Up for Downtown
description: CHANGE was in the air at the Whitney Museum of American Arts annual gala on Tuesday night, where the topic of conversation was the boards recent vote to break ground on a space in the meatpacking district.

title: Which Team Has World Series-Winning Characteristics?
description: Carlton Chin, a fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method. They have previously written about the N.B.A. finals, the N.F.L. playoffs, and the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Even the Undead Play Chess
description: Street chess hustlers are famous for taking on all challengers, but they never know who might show up and want to play a game. Tuesday, during a promotion in Union Square in Manhattan for a new AMC series, The Walking Dead, one of the zombies evidently found something more diverting to do than eating brains.

title: Fielders Choice: Gloves of the World Series
description: The game of baseball requires you to keep your eye on the ball, but the fielders mitt deserves our attention too. Photographs by Dan Winters for The New York Times Magazine showcase some of the mitts used in the World Series from 1910 to 2000. Examine the details of the gloves used by Babe Ruth, Joe DiMaggio, Brooks Robinson and others.  Explore more.

title: Late-Night Double Feature: The Rocky Horror Glee Show Reconsidered
description: Apparently The Rocky Horror Glee Show  an innocent episode of Glee in which a squad of high-school students tries to stage a simple musical about an oversexed transvestite from outer space and the two virgins he seduces in his castle of hedonistic delights  was a rather tender subject, provoking all kinds of responses around the Web. So: another slice, anyone? In this IM conversation, Dave Itzkoff, a culture reporter for The New York Times who writes about Glee for ArtsBeat, and Rebecca Milzoff, a reporter for New York magazine who writes about Glee for Vulture.com, discussed their reactions to the episode and their histories as Rocky Horror fans. It was a chat they would remember. For a very. Long. Time.

title: Price of Justice for Stanford: Cheaper Lawyers
description: Yet again, the jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford is getting a new set of lawyers. This time, price definitely came into play in the legal defense of Mr. Stanford, who is accused of of swindling investors out of $7 billion in a Ponzi scheme.

title: An Artsy Party
description: Photos from Tuesday nights gala at the Whitney.

title: Carly Fiorina Released from Hospital
description: Carly Fiorina, the Republican candidate for Senate in California, was released from the hospital on Wednesday, a day after she was admitted for an infection related to breast cancer treatment.

title: A Sideways Strategy for a Flawed Chess Board
description: On a recent Saturday, Jean Manas and his son, Mateos Haile-Manas, were playing chess on one of the three public tables on the East River promenade, a raised platform on the Upper East Side between the water and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. There were plenty of distractions  the strong October wind, the traffic hurtling by  but another factor was affecting their game more: They were forced to play sideways.

title: Thrashers Dont See Race, Just Opportunity
description: The Atlanta Thrashers are trying something new in their struggle to draw fans. But if they keep playing the way they did Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, where they snapped the Rangers three-game winning streak with a wild 6-4 victory, their job could be a lot easier.

title: Animal Cruelty Caught on Camera
description: A New York City Housing Authority security camera mounted inside an elevator captured a man violently yanking the leash of a small dog in an Upper Manhattan apartment building.

title: Strides Made Toward Early Diagnosing of Pancreatic Cancer
description: Researchers have made significant progress in understanding the biology of pancreatic tumors, suggesting that there may be ways of identifying the usually fatal cancer at a much earlier and more treatable stage.

title: The Dance of the Mean Girls
description: The students of the Constance Billard School for Girls, the fictional alma mater of the catfighters on Gossip Girl, have been known to perch on the steps of the Met as they go about their undermining ways. But in a coming episode of the television series, a crosstown arts institution is muscling in.

title: Witchs Shrieks Urge Vote Against ODonnell
description: Voters in Delaware are about to get an extra treat  or trick, depending on their political inclinations.

title: Fabulous Lodging, Clothing Optional
description: There is a moment in Skin Deep, the Foolish Theater Company production at Theater 54, when it all falls together  a scene about two-thirds of the way through this would-be sex comedy of manners that slides smoothly into place like tumblers that click.

title: Scouting Report
description: HITTING THE SHELVES

title: A Collections First E-Sale
description: CAMEL, fake fur and mens wear are represented in a capsule collection culled from Club Monaco by Kate Ciepluch, the fashion director for the online retailer Shopbop. Shopbop.com Winter shorts have replaced last years mini and can be worn with ribbed opaque tights for work and with bare legs and heels at night. At left are Jacqueline shorts ($119) and wool thigh-highs ($24); the Hannah coat ($295); Samarie top ($89); and Audrey leather shoulder bag ($249). Customers can view the whole collection at Clubmonaco.com.

title: A Classic Shoe, Restyled
description: THE first offering from New Balance for the J. Crew collection, the 1400, is named for a style number originally released in 1994. The unisex suede shoe comes in two colors, navy and what is called classic pine, a dark moss green (left, $130), and was manufactured in New Balances factory in Skowhegen, Me. Available via the J. Crew catalog, online at jcrew.com and at select stores, including J. Crews Men Shop at 1040 Madison Avenue (79th Street); (212) 453-2677.

title: For the Boots of Fall, Fur Rules
description: FOUR QUESTIONS FOR BETTY WANG, right, senior buyer for designer shoes at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: A Pop-Up Showcase
description: PROJECT No. 8, which has two stores on the Lower East Side and an outpost at the Ace Hotel, is extending its clothing-rather-than-fashion message to a temporary satellite store on Duane Street, starting today. The temporary boutique, which will be open until mid-February, will showcase designers like the London-based Zowie Broach and Brian Kirkby, who began by showing their collaborations in galleries before starting their label Boudicca. (At left is one of their dresses, $1,725). Project No. 8 is popping up in Paris on Thanksgiving weekend. 186 Duane Street (Greenwich Street); (212) 966-3904, projectno8.com.

title: Courier Replaces Patrick McEnroe as U.S. Davis Cup Captain
description: Back when Jim Courier was playing Davis Cup matches in the 1990s, Patrick McEnroe remembered thinking that he would make a good captain one day. That is what happened Wednesday, when the United States Tennis Association named him to the job to replace McEnroe, who stepped down after 10 years.

title: Android App Forwards Private Text Messages
description: 8:13 p.m. | Updated  Adding that the app was pulled from the Android Market.

title: Tennis, Anyone?
description: In yet another East-meets-West mash-up, the California-based K-Swiss has created a capsule collection with Brendon Babenzien, the creative director of the downtown skate shop Supreme. The first output from the collaboration, California Tennis, a limited-edition line of T-shirts, polos and perfectly worn-in collegiate sweatshirts, pays homage to 1970s courtside style. Inspired by Tennis Girl, the saucy Martin Elliott poster image, the tops in the collection have a bicoastal ease to them and are as appropriate with a pair of swim trunks as they are with skinny black jeans. The pieces are available starting Nov. 1 on beams.co.jp, with prices ranging from about $75 for a T-shirt screen-printed with the Elliott image to about $270 for a windbreaker. For a preview of the line, check out Jake Daviss video, above.

title: Hustlers and Lovers Endure the Civil War Era
description: The hive of activity on the tiny Irish Repertory stage in the opening of Banished Children of Eve includes a Fulton Street fishmonger cleaning the catch, a tottering drunk, a Yankee sharpening his dagger, an actress applying makeup, a maid scrubbing stairs, an urchin rattling a tambourine and a Bowery barker inviting audiences to step up for a minstrel show. All this is accompanied by a sad piano scratching out the popular melody of Beautiful Dreamer.

title: Video Shows Man Abusing Dog in Harlem Elevator
description: Updated, Oct. 29 | A man abusing a dog in a housing-project elevator in Harlem was caught on videotape, the police said.

title: The Juice Cleanse: A Strange and Green Journey
description: A MONTH ago I went on a juice cleanse. You know what it cleans out of you best? The will to live.

title: A Wealth of Options for Election Night Viewers
description: At least 10 television channels will be competing for viewers as the midterm election vote is counted next Tuesday.

title: Obama Decries Domestic Violence
description: President Obama decried domestic violence against women and promised more help for victims in a White House ceremony on Wednesday.

title: A.I.G. Sets Possible C.E.O. Backup Plan
description: The American International Group said on Wednesday that its chairman, Robert S. Miller, would step in as interim chief executive if the firms current chief, Robert H. Benmosche, is unable or unwilling to stay in that role.

title: The Big Apple Circus
description: Dance On!, the 33rd edition of the circus, is at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center.

title: Limber Up Your Sluggish PC
description: As we get older, most of us tend to put on weight. We bulk up in all the wrong places. Over the years we ingest a lot of things that are bad for us. We may still suffer the effects of long-gone viruses. Our gait slows, and were not as sharp as we used to be.

title: In Ontario, Sailing the Lake of the Woods
description: ARE you claustrophobic? my friend Leif Larsen wanted to know.

title: Old World but Oil Rich in Azerbaijan
description: TO the north of Baku Boulevard, the namesake promenade that separates the capital of Azerbaijan from its Caspian Sea waterfront, stands the Maiden Tower. The eight-story stone structure, which dates back to at least the 12th century, is thought to have once been a lookout against invading armies. Today, it is the centerpiece of the walled Old City in Baku. The 15th-century buildings within those walls are made of a honey-hued sandstone and, since 2003, have been painstakingly restored, leaving behind a movie-set veneer. A maze of winding lanes runs throughout, and tucked inside is the unadorned Palace of the Shirvanshahs, the seat of Azerbaijans ruling dynasty during the Middle Ages. Today, carpet merchants, hawking their wares, sing out the usual chorus of Hello! and Where are you from?

title: Hotel Review: The Hotel Monaco in Baltimore
description: THE BASICS

title: Restaurant Review: Rino in Paris
description: Restaurant-mad Parisians love to hunt, so its no surprise that the February opening of Rino, on a hip little street behind the Bastille in the 11th Arrondissement, instantly became hot local news.

title: Mumbai Seizes Its Next Moment
description: ON a recent Sunday, crowds of mostly Indian day-trippers milled around the monumental basalt arch of the Gateway of India at Mumbais harbor, along with the usual contingent of snack vendors, balloon salesmen and roving photographers who snap tourist portraits for a few rupees.

title: In Northern Vietnam, a Region of Beauty and Ethnic Traditions
description: MY first glimpse of the place that some call Shangri-La came on a brisk spring afternoon as we were careening along a narrow road hemmed in by sheer limestone walls. Our driver made a hairpin turn and all at once the landscape erupted into a sweep of dazzling slopes, serrated ridges and hanging valleys. In the pocket of a mountain pass called Heavens Gate, Hoang Tuan Anh, who also served as our guide, stopped his pickup truck so we could gaze at the vista of radiant sky that had opened up before us. This was only the beginning, Mr. Anh said, as we resumed our upward drive. We will go as high as the clouds!

title: Baltimores Harbor East Adds to Its Allure
description: AGAINST a backdrop of squat row houses and tall industrial buildings on a dim corner in Baltimore, laughter, soft music and the intoxicating smell of oven-roasted burgers drift out to the sidewalk. The sounds and smells are spilling over from new restaurants and bars in Harbor East, a burgeoning neighborhood that has undergone an extensive transformation in recent years.

title: Motor City District Regains Its Luster
description: Despite the decline of the auto industry, Detroits Grand Circus Park district, long a hot spot with its opulent movie palaces and clubs, boasts a spruced up park and thriving restaurant scene.

title: A Jet Set Emerges in Baku, Azerbaijan
description: Gucci and sushi take their place in an ancient civilization.

title: Vietnam, Above the Clouds
description: In Vietnams north, ethnic minorities thrive in a region of slopes and cliffs that is just being discovered by visitors.

title: At Goodman Theater, Glitter and Be Gloomy
description: CHICAGO  With this citys airwaves choked with finger-pointing political ads, its favorite son fighting for the future of his presidency and its leading newspaper shell-shocked from executive turmoil, it would be pretty hard for Chicagoans to argue that they are living in the best of all possible worlds. So the moment is peculiarly ripe for the Goodman Theaters revival of the 1956 musical Candide, adapted from Voltaires cackling satire deriding the folly of unthinking optimism in the face of mans  and natures  brutalities.

title: Chess 101: How to Set Up the Board
description: One of the first things people learn about chess is that the near right-hand corner on each side should be a White square. Evidently, not everyone at the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, which is responsible for maintaining the citys chess and checkers tables, knows that rule. City Room has a post on Wednesday about several tables on the East River promenade, on the Upper East Side, that were stenciled incorrectly, so that the near right-hand corner squares were Black.

title: Mobile Travel Guides Can Help, but Trust Books
description: As with so many smartphone apps, it is tempting to look at the current spate of mobile travel guides and proclaim the end of their paper counterparts as we know them.

title: Strong Arms, Fast Hands, Supple Spines and, of Course, Clowns
description: Fast, funny, filled with feats and fancy footwork, Dance On!, the colorful 33rd edition of the Big Apple Circus, is winning applause that pays tribute to the rich array of talent in its familiar single ring and behind the scenes under its little big top.

title: Meet the Ladle of Love
description: The Diners Journal blog introduces readers to an electric-powered food truck in Central Park that bills itself as New York Citys most environmentally friendly mobile noshing vehicle.

title: The Caucus Click: Port Clinton, Ohio
Calling a Ghost Town Home
description: The writer Antonya Nelson and her husband own several pieces of property in an old southern Colorado mining town that is mostly abandoned.

title: Living in a Ghost Town
description: I OWN a ghost town. Well, not all of it. My husband, Robert, and I first bought the three town blocks at the intersection of Main Street and First Avenue, where the old post office sits, five years ago, but thats hardly the whole place. Later, we bought an abandoned mine on the local stream, and then the spot where the town entrance sign sits, and also the graveyard. But I dont think were actually majority owners, yet.

title: Of Birds and Insects (and a Coral Snake)
description: Saturday, Oct. 23

title: Nostrums: Caution Urged on Cholesterol-Lowering Supplement
description: Americans trying to avoid cholesterol-lowering drugs are spending tens of millions of dollars each year on Chinese red yeast rice, a supplement found to lower LDL, or bad, cholesterol.

title: Philharmonic Renews Effort to Visit Cuba
description: If they cannot go as tourists, put em to work.

title: Pop-Up Window Shopping
description: Another day, another pop-up store. Fortunately, the latest shopkeepers to hang out a temporary shingle are Elizabeth Beer and Brian Janusiak, the married duo behind the eclectic boutique Project No. 8. Says Beer of the companys latest venture, a 100-square-foot former gallery in TriBeCa: We heard about this space on Duane Street, which has always been one of our favorite blocks in the city, and thought it would allow us to do a series of mini-shows featuring several designers at a time. In addition to Kostas Murkudis, the Berlin-trained designer who hosted an intimate presentation at the unopened store during New York Fashion Week, the location will feature a constantly rotating selection from labels like Natalia Brilli, Boudicca and Christian Wijnants, as well as pieces from the house label, Various Projects. The TriBeCa space will be open through Valentines Day 2011, and Beer and Janusiak are opening another pop-up store in Paris next month.

title: Telling Your Children Too Much
description: Speaking of oversharing, Stephanie Thompson certainly shares openly in The Brooklyn Paper last week. She is thinking of divorcing her husband, and in an essay last week she dissects her reasons  and her childrens reactions to the increasing tension in the house.

title: Food Association Plans a Package-Front Label Showing Nutritional Data
description: Responding to pressure from federal regulators, a major food manufacturers organization said Wednesday that it would develop a labeling system for the front of food packages that would highlight the nutritional content of foods, including things like calories, unhealthy fats and sodium that many consumers want to limit.

title: Agitated Rhythms and Other European Motions
description: Under the artistic direction of Benoit-Swan Pouffer, Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet has become a repository of work by European choreographers that strives to epitomize that embarrassing phrase in dance: cutting edge. While a good portion of its repertory subsists on a certain manic jitteriness, there is little daring about it. Contrived and derivative  iterations of William Forsythe are still going strong  its new crop of dances have traveled quite a distance from the companys previous nuanced productions of works like Ohad Naharins Decadance and Jill Johnsons Copier.

title: A Nano-Solution to Energy Vampires
description: Vampire power, the electricity consumed by devices that are plugged in but not in use, costs American homeowners some $4 billion every year and accounts for 5 to 10 percent of all residential energy use, according to estimates from the Department of Energy. Studies in Europe have found similar amounts of energy waste in residences and businesses.

title: A Crooner Serenades His Loyal Friends
description: Everyone is familiar with the AIDS charity anthem, Thats What Friends Are For, sung by an all-star coalition, Dionne and Friends, that became a No. 1 single in 1986. But how many remember another song with the same title, written by Paul Williams, that was a minor 1972 hit for B. J. Thomas?

title: Online Video Takes Another Small Step, but Giant Leap Remains Elusive
description: The battle for the living room? Oh, its on, all right.

title: American Idol Owner CKX Ends Buyout Talks
description: American Idol is not heading into the hands of private equity after all.

title: Sheriff Wont Run for Chicago Mayor
description: Rahm Emanuels showdown with the sheriff has been averted. The Cook County sheriff, Tom Dart, who posed the strongest potential competition to Mr. Emanuels bid for Chicago mayor, announced he would not seek the office on Wednesday.

title: A Vanishing and a Chance to Do Penance
description: Dennis Lehanes 1998 Gone, Baby, Gone was a taut, exposition-packed novel about the apparent kidnapping of a 4-year-old girl. It was part of Mr. Lehanes top-notch series about a pair of lovebird private investigators, Patrick Kenzie and Angie Gennaro. But the whole weight of its story fell onto Patricks shoulders.

title: Big Picture in Schumann Vignettes
description: Andras Schiff has become the piano worlds long-distance runner. Even when his recital programs are the standard two hours  and given his penchant for hefty encores, they are typically longer  they have grand ambitions that make them almost heroic. Lately they have been installments in a Beethoven cycle, played in chronological order over two seasons at Carnegie Hall, and a Haydn program offered as part of a campaign to restore Haydns sonatas to the active repertory.

title: A Visit to Harry Reid's Hometown
description: The Times's Adam Nagourney visited Searchlight, Nev., the hometown of Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and suddenly, the center of the political universe.

title: Letters
description: Female Candidates Look

title: Angle Turns Corner in Nevada, but G.O.P. Senate Odds Drop
description: Sharron Angle, the Republican candidate in Nevada, has been improving her position in our forecast in recent days, and for the first time since the spring has better than a three-in-four chance to win her race against Harry Reid, according to the FiveThirtyEight model.

title: Letter: In Wine Country
description: To the Editor: In Overnighter: California Farmland, Known for Its Drinks (Oct. 17), Freda Moon captured the flavor and essence of the Anderson Valley: hills shrouded in straw with green vineyards creeping up their sides ... a fierce, rural independence.

title: Letter: Amazon Revelations
description: To the Editor: Andy Isaacsons Amazon Awakening (Oct. 17) article on the Ecuadorean Amazon was fascinating and moving. Nearly every sentence or paragraph was dense with sensory detail and revelation. This is exactly the kind of insightful writing that has been missing from travel pages of late, which seem to focus on the latest luxury destinations  nourishing neither the wallet nor the traveler. Ideally, we travel to adventure outside of our safety zones, to learn about other cultures, to question our countries and ourselves and to better find our place in the world.

title: The Caucus
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Nate Silver discuss FiveThirtyEight's forecast for next week's midterm elections, and what the results may mean to both political parties.

title: Breeders Cup Overflows, Led by Zenyatta
description: Zenyatta is a perfect 19-0. The mare might even be invincible. She beat the boys in this race last year. There is a long line of accomplished contenders, however, intent on making her earn her immortality in the $5 million Breeders Cup Classic. They are salty bunch, seven Grade I winners, that include a colt named Blame, who has lost only once this year; Gio Ponti, last years reigning champion older male horse; and Espoir City, one of Japans most highly regarded runners.

title: Bobbing for a Lost Apple
description: The drum of horror holds her sound,Which will not let me sleep,When ghastly breezes float around,And hidden goblins creep.George Moses Horton,The Fearful Traveler in the Haunted Castle

title: TimesCast: Next Weeks Forecast
description: In the latest edition of TimesCast, The Timess Megan Liberman and Nate Silver discuss what could happen to the political makeup of Congress when voters head to the polls next Tuesday.

title: Students Feel Peer Pressure to Donate
description: Nonprofits have long used the honor roll, a list of benefactors prominently displayed, to inspire others to make gifts.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 21 through 26 with 1,173 adults throughout the United States, including 1,073 who said they were registered to vote.

title: A Phone of Promise, With Flaws
description: What on earth is Microsoft doing, bringing out its iPhone competitor now, in 2010?

title: Obama Coalition Is Fraying, Poll Finds
description: Critical parts of the coalition that delivered President Obama to the White House in 2008 and gave Democrats control of Congress in 2006 are switching their allegiance to the Republicans in the final phase of the midterm Congressional elections, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Obama, Jon Stewart and Change
description: President Obama took his campaign get-out-the-vote blitz to The Daily Show on Wednesday, telling the host, Jon Stewart, that he never promised transformational change overnight.

title: A First Look at The Rent Is Too Damn High, the Album
description: Tuesday is a very big day for Jimmy McMillan. Not only will Mr. McMillan, the candidate on the Rent Is Too Damn High ticket, learn whether he is the next governor of the state of New York, but it is also the release date of his newest album.

title: In Utah, a Clash Over Slashing Government
description: Mike Lee, the Republican candidate for United States Senate in Utah, has caused a late-race stir by suggesting that the federal government may need an immediate 40 percent cut in spending to get the budget deficit under control.

title: For the First Time, The Daily Show Hosts a Sitting President
description: President Obama on Wednesday became the first sitting president to appear on The Daily Show, the news satire show on Comedy Central. On The Caucus, Sheryl Gay Stolberg recaps Jon Stewarts interview of the president:

title: Gloves of the World Series
description: Keep your eyes on the ball, but the mitt deserves our attention too.

title: For World Series, Cablevision Steers Customers Online
description: 8:02 p.m. | Updated  The first game of the World Series was blacked out in three million homes serviced by Cablevision on Wednesday night, because of a continuing dispute between the cable company and Fox, which is broadcasting the championship series.

title: Fla. House Candidate Faces More Questions
description: MIAMI  Politics is bloodsport in the heavily Cuban congressional district that includes Miami, and Republican David Rivera is looking pretty banged up.

title: Levinsohn Replaces Schneider at Yahoo
description: Yahoo, which has seen a steady stream of its executives depart, has hired Ross Levinsohn, a former executive with Fox Interactive Media, to lead its operations in the Americas.

title: In Paris, a Threadbare Home From the 1800s
description: A couple fell in love with a house in the 14th Arrondissement that had once been a haberdashery.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Adoring Your Computer
description: Whether you realize it or not, you may be relating to your computer as if it were human. On this weeks New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein chats with Clifford Nass, a Stanford University professor who studies the interaction of people and technology. He has found that the connections we have with computers and other electronic devices are fundamentally social. Professor Nasss new book, with Corina Yen, is called The Man Who Lied to His Laptop: What Machines Teach Us About Human Relationships.

title: Bold Trovatore, Inspired by Goya
description: Many singers have classically beautiful voices that appeal to almost everyone. There are also excellent singers whose voices may not be generically beautiful but whose vocal artistry is exceptional. Two such  the soprano Patricia Racette and the baritone Zeljko Lucic  were in the cast on Tuesday night when the director David McVicars production of Verdis Trovatore, introduced in the 2008-9 season, returned to the repertory at the Metropolitan Opera. Its a starkly effective, boldly updated staging, with images inspired by Goya sketches of civil war.

title: TPG Giddy Over Rangers-Giants World Series
description: Truth be told, this DealBook reporter is having a tough time getting excited over a World Series between two teams not from the Bronx. Anecdotal evidence suggests that the interest across Wall Street is also pretty low.

title: 10 Writers Receive Whiting Awards Honor
description: The Whiting Writers Awards are usually given to people who are not yet known even in literary circles. But the recipients are young and talented, and often go on to fame and acclaim, as did winners from years past like Jonathan Franzen, Sarah Ruhl, Colson Whitehead and Michael Cunningham. The 2010 recipients, who were to be announced at a ceremony in Manhattan on Wednesday night, are three fiction writers, three nonfiction writers, three poets and one playwright. The prizes are administered by the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, established in 1963 by Flora E. Whiting. The winning fiction writers are Michael Dahlie (A Gentlemans Guide to Graceful Living); Rattawut Lapcharoensap (Sightseeing); and Lydia Peelle, author of a collection of stories, Reasons for and Advantages of Breathing. The nonfiction winners are Elif Batuman (The Possessed); Amy Leach, who is writing a book of essays about animals, plants and stars; and Said Sayrafiezadeh, author of the memoir When Skateboards Will Be Free. The poets are Matt Donovan (Vellum); Jane Springer (Dear Blackbird); and L. B. Thompson, whose chapbook is Tendered Notes. The playwright is David Adjmi, whose Stunning had its premiere at the Lincoln Center Theater. The prizes have been given annually since 1985, with a cash award of $50,000 each.

title: Shopping With Lindsey Adelman
description: An industrial designer shopped for reading lamps, perfect for this time of year, when days are getting shorter.

title: Reading Lamps
description: L INDSEY ADELMAN, a New York industrial designer with a special interest in light fixtures, creates elaborate chandeliers of blown glass bubbles that fundamentally change the feel of a room. I like the idea of transforming a space in a dramatic way through lighting, she said, noting that much of her work is about creating a mood and beauty, and people looking great at your dinner party.

title: Footnote
description: The Cleveland Orchestra has received a promise of $20 million to help provide discount and free tickets to children and young adults. The Maltz Family Foundation made the pledge, which will go toward a $60 million endowment to finance what the orchestra is calling a Center for Future Audiences.

title: Sales on Artemide Lamps and More
description: During Richard Schultzs first warehouse sale, Nov. 5 and 6, limited quantities of the designers pieces will be marked way down; items can be reserved in advance, by phone or e-mail, with a deposit during the presale, beginning on Nov. 1 (the Topiary bench, regularly $2,550, will be $500; the 1966 Collection dining set, which includes a table and eight chairs, regularly $17,140, will be $2,500); 806 Gravel Pike, Palm, Pa.; (215) 679-2222, richardschultz.com.

title: New Doors by Dror Benshetrit, David Rockwell and Robert A. M. Stern
description: Doors rarely get the kind of attention that furnishings do, something Lualdi, an Italian manufacturer, is trying to change. Its like having a very nice painting  they contribute to the environment, said Alberto Lualdi, the president of the company. Why not consider a door as a piece of furniture, and an element for decoration? To prove the point, Lualdi is introducing three doors created by American designers, catering to different tastes.

title: Sustainable Furnishings in Philadelphia
description: When Jaime and Isaac Salm, the brothers who run Mio, a design firm specializing in sustainable home furnishings, moved their studio into an old fortune cookie factory in Philadelphia, passers-by didnt know what to make of it. People would walk in off the street, wanting to know who we were, Jaime Salm said. They didnt really get it. Now that the first Mio store has opened in that space, though, they probably will.

title: A High-Design Retreat on a Newfoundland Island
description: The Long Studio is the first of six modern artists residences to be built in what some might consider an unlikely location  on Fogo, a 91-square-mile island off the coast of Newfoundland. Designed by Todd Saunders, a Newfoundland-born architect based in Norway, and financed by the Shorefast Foundation, a local charity, the studios will range from 200 to 2,000 square feet. Theyre very expressive forms that reflect the Newfoundland architecture  theyre on stilts like a lot of the houses on the coast, Mr. Saunders said. For the locals, its strange and familiar at the same time.

title: Marital Issues Buried in the Sofa
description: IT all came down to a coffee table.

title: Nordic Models + Common Ground Opening at Scandinavia House
description: Nordic Models + Common Ground: Art and Design Unfolded, an exhibition of 41 objects, including furniture, architectural models, photos, lighting and textiles by 35 Nordic designers, will open on Friday at Scandinavia House in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Eddie Ross on Shopping at Flea Markets
description: Eddie Ross has been trolling flea markets for years, first on his own and later as an editor at Martha Stewart Living and House Beautiful, where he wrote a column about flea markets.

title: Simplifying Their Garden
description: In the gardens at Page Dickeys home in North Salem, N.Y., where perennials are being replaced with shrubs and ground covers.

title: Reining in a Runaway Yard
description: NORTH SALEM, N.Y.

title: Down a Paris Alley, a 19th-Century Dream House
description: PARIS

title: NCIS Is Back on Top
description: Tuesdays episode of NCIS attracted that crime shows largest audience since January as CBS dominated the night. According to Nielsens estimates, 19.9 million viewers tuned in to the CBS series at 8 p.m., easily outperforming all other programming and helping to elevate the rest of the networks schedule. A Dancing With the Stars elimination episode at 9 (15.5 million) helped lift ABC to second place. Foxs Rocky Horror episode of Glee ranked second in the 8 p.m. hour with 11.5 million viewers while topping the nights ratings among viewers 18 to 49. Fox ranked third over all, and NBC was fourth.

title: A Reassured F.T.C. Ends Google Street View Inquiry
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The Federal Trade Commission announced Wednesday that it had ended its investigation of Googles collection of Internet users personal communications by the companys Street View cars.

title: Seeing Opportunity in Health Care
description: IN another demonstration of the increasing importance of health and wellness advertising to Madison Avenue, a leading agency is forming a unit that will specialize in marketing to health care professionals like doctors and managed care organizations.

title: He Takes Advantage, Then Takes a Title, Too
description: The World Bridge Federation puts a lot of effort into junior events. At the championships in Philadelphia this month there was the inaugural young womens team championship, as well as two team and two individual events, one each for players under 27 and under 22.

title: Meningitis Booster Urged for Teenagers
description: ATLANTA  Federal vaccine advisers recommended on Wednesday that 16-year-olds be given a booster dose of a vaccine against meningococcal meningitis and that people ages 11 to 64 get a booster to protect against whooping cough, diphtheria and tetanus.

title: Wells Fargo to Amend About 55,000 Foreclosures
description: After several weeks of insisting its foreclosure processes were sound, Wells Fargo & Company said on Wednesday that it planned to correct and resubmit up to 55,000 improperly filed documents by mid-November.

title: Chandler Said He Did Not Take Part in Improper Workouts With Knicks
description: TORONTO  Knicks forward Wilson Chandler said Wednesday that he never took part in improper workouts with the team before he was drafted in 2007.

title: From a Rally to a Phone Bank
description: President Obamas political organization is seeking to capitalize on Saturdays Rally to Restore Sanity and March to Keep Fear Alive by convening volunteers for a phone bank at the Democratic Partys national headquarters once the events, headlined by Comedy Central hosts Stephen Colbert and Jon Stewart, is over.

title: Lazard Posts $62.2 Million 3rd-Quarter Profit
description: 7:52 p.m. | Updated

title: Sanctuary in Custody Fight Over Elephant
description: HOHENWALD, Tenn.  Theyre fighting like elephants.

title: New Jersey Governor Says He Wont Budge on Scrapped Rail Tunnel
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey put a final stop on Wednesday to the most expensive public-works project in the country: a proposed rail tunnel under the Hudson River that could have doubled commuter-train service to Manhattan.

title: Marijuana Web Names Snapped Up, in Case of Legalization
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was just about a year ago that Kevin Faler came up with his get-rich-quick marijuana scheme. No, he does not plan to sell the drug, even if Californians vote next week to become the first state in the nation to fully legalize it. He intends to sell the Internet real estate that could one day lead to marijuana Web sites.

title: Obama Set to Offer Stricter Nuclear Deal to Iran
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and its European allies are preparing a new offer for negotiations with Iran on its nuclear program, senior administration officials say, but the conditions on Tehran would be even more onerous than a deal that the countrys supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, rejected last year.

title: Eva Ibbotson, Childrens Book Author, Dies at 85
description: Eva Ibbotson, an English writer for children whose comic novels of enchantment  which rumble with wizards, ghosts, ghouls and mustached elderly aunts  anticipated the work of J.K. Rowling, died last week at her home in Newcastle upon Tyne. She was 85.

title: Gulfstream Orders Suggest Recovery in Business Jets
description: General Dynamics said Wednesday that its Gulfstream unit received orders for more business jets in the third quarter than in any comparable period since mid-2008, another indication of recovery in the market for corporate planes.

title: Storm Spreads Its Problems From the Midwest to the East Coast
description: CHICAGO  A major storm that slammed the Midwest continued to cause problems on Wednesday as thunderstorms and strong winds reached the East Coast.

title: Homeowners Facing Foreclosure Demand Recourse
description: Ricky Rought paid cash to the Deutsche Bank National Trust Company for a four-room cabin in Michigan with the intention of fixing it up for his daughter. Instead, the bank tried to foreclose on the property and the locks were changed, court records show.

title: M.T.A. Board Raises Bridge and Tunnel Tolls
description: Drivers who pay cash to traverse many of the regions major tunnels and bridges will pay significantly more by the end of this year, while E-ZPass users will see more modest increases, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Wednesday approved the final stage of this years big toll and fare increases.

title: Tax Shortfalls Spur New Fear on Europes Recovery Bid
description: LONDON  The mathematics of austerity are getting harder.

title: A Hudson Tunnel That Goes One Way
description: Trenton

title: Childhood Abuse Is Cited for a Convicted Killer of 3
description: NEW HAVEN  The man convicted of killing three people in Cheshire, Conn., grew up in a very dysfunctional family, with a violent father and an alcohol-abusing mother and was sexually abused as a child, jurors who will decide whether to sentence him to death were told on Wednesday.

title: Goat vs. Man
description: OLYMPIC NATIONAL PARK, Wash.  You come to this pork chop of land in the Far West, even with the first lashing storm of the season, on the off-chance of seeing something as nimble as a 300-pound, snow-white mountain goat in all its bewhiskered hauteur.

title: Harry Reid's Home Town
description: Scenes from Searchlight, Nev., where residents are divided about the Senate Majority Leader.

title: Even in His Hometown, Reid Is Source of Anguish
description: SEARCHLIGHT, Nev.  This shrinking town in the desert has endured its indignities over the years. It has been referred to as a ghost town, a description that galls the 800 or so people who still call it home. It was once famous for its brothels, a reputation that, though hard to quarrel with, is not exactly something to brag about.

title: In Spain, Homes Are Taken but Debt Stays
description: MADRID  Manolo Marbn, 59, is still living in his house in Toledo and going to work in the small pink-and-aqua pet grooming shop he bought here in 2006, when he got swept up in Spains giddy real estate boom.

title: Handling of Abuse in Chilean Church Questioned
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  In April of last year, the Rev. Juan Esteban Morales, the head of a Roman Catholic parish here, visited Dr. James Hamilton at his clinic to make an unusual request: that he stop pursuing an annulment to his marriage.

title: Cavaliers Set Bar Low but Keep Heads High
description: Cleveland

title: G.O.P. Now Projected to Gain 53 House Seats
description: After a day that contained some scary polling for incumbent Democrats, todays indicators were more equivocal.

title: Treasury Links Foreclosure Ills to Lower Housing Prices
description: WASHINGTON  The uncertainty over the legal status of foreclosed homes in the nation could further depress home prices and delay the recovery of the housing market, the Obama administration said on Wednesday.

title: Cuomos Former Boss, Bill Clinton, Is an Admirer
description: The faces were the same, but the body language could not have been more different.

title: Lazard Lives On After Wasserstein
description: Bruce Wasserstein left behind a healthy Lazard. During his nearly decade-long tenure, he whipped into shape a firm that had been mired in internecine warfare.

title: If They Only Knew What Was in the Cards
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was 5 a.m. in the casino at the Ritz-Carlton beside the balmy beaches of San Juan, P.R. Two ballplayers sat at the blackjack table and laughed at what they thought was their amazing good fortune. The cards were smiling upon them that morning in June, and both players walked away with a few extra dollars in their already well-filled pockets.

title: Ignoring the Planet Wont Fix It
description: Its hardly surprising that a study released the other day by a scientist with the National Center for Atmospheric Research didnt register on any political radar screens, amid Kentucky foot stomps, dead wrestlers, $2 billion in campaign spending and the pitched battles for control of Congress.

title: In Daily Show Visit, Obama Defends Record
description: WASHINGTON  If you are president of the United States and you take your campaign get-out-the-vote blitz to a fake news program, do you get tweaked, or do you get a pass?

title: An Afghan Corridor Cloistered From War
description: The rules that apply to the rest of Afghanistan are often irrelevant in the Wakhan Corridor.

title: Plan to Tighten Control on Trades
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is poised to ban brokers from letting clients make unsupervised trades on stock exchanges, reflecting its concern that a rogue transaction could upset markets.

title: In Icy Tip of Afghanistan, War Seems Remote
description: BOZAI GUMBAZ, Afghanistan  As the pickup truck bounced toward a remote village deep in northeastern Afghanistan, the young woman was told by her companions that she could toss her burqa aside.

title: Why the Democrats Are Struggling
description: To the Editor:

title: A Well-Dressed Dry Cleaner, Just Like Dad
description: John-Claude Hallak knows the proper way to press trousers, coax a spot from a wedding gown, or restore a carpet to its original glory. He is a second-generation dry cleaner; his parents, Joseph and Marie-Louise, opened Hallak Cleaners on the Upper East Side in 1966. (His mother, widowed in 1992, is the president.) Mr. Hallak, 54, who has a masters degree in economics from Rutgers University, joined the company in 1982; he and his younger brother, Joseph, 49, are both vice presidents. He lives in Basking Ridge, N.J., with his wife, Michelle, and their 16-year-old twin sons.

title: Nakamura Poised to Defend Title at Cap dAgde
Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,417 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,338 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:

title: Rangers Followed Michael Youngs Example
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Recalling a New York Character, in Fiction and Real Life
description: Tom Wolfe said Burton B. Roberts, the model for a cranky character in Mr. Wolfes 1987 best-seller The Bonfire of the Vanities, had such a huge impact on my life, its hard to know where to start.

title: Clinton Rallies for Cuomo
description: Bill Clinton spoke at a rally for Andrew M. Cuomo in the gym of a downtown Brooklyn college.

title: And Now, a Word About Candidates Parenting Skills
description: For weeks, voters in Connecticut have gotten to know two Republican candidates, Linda E. McMahon, who is running for the Senate, and Thomas C. Foley, the partys nominee for governor, thanks to their relentless television advertising.

title: New Federal Rules Set on Career Colleges
description: After receiving 90,000 public comments, and making 82 changes, the Department of Education will release its final rules Thursday to require career colleges to disclose graduation and job placement rates, end misleading recruiting practices and ensure that only eligible students or programs receive federal student aid.

title: Weather Watch in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Rain has delayed or postponed a game in three of the last four World Series, a trend that could be continued Thursday for Game 2.

title: Balloon Boys Father Tries a New Gimmick
description: DENVER  Having tried to convince a worried nation that his 6-year-old son had drifted across Colorado in a makeshift balloon, Richard Heene is now trying to convince the world that everyone needs his latest invention: a wooden back scratcher.

title: Paladinos Handling of Aunts House Involved a Curious Chain of Transactions
description: In 1992, when Alzheimers disease had begun stealing the faculties of his Aunt Anna, the widow of his beloved Uncle Pasquale, Carl P. Paladino was appointed to safeguard her affairs. Mr. Paladino had significant credentials to serve as his aunts financial guardian: he was an established real estate developer and lawyer, someone who would become rich enough to bankroll his own campaign for governor.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Age of Alzheimers
description: OUR government is ignoring what is likely to become the single greatest threat to the health of Americans: Alzheimers disease, an illness that is 100 percent incurable and 100 percent fatal. It attacks rich and poor, white-collar and blue, and women and men, without regard to party. A degenerative disease, it steadily robs its victims of memory, judgment and dignity, leaves them unable to care for themselves and destroys their brain and their identity  often depleting their caregivers and families both emotionally and financially.

title: Favre Holds Out Hope of Playing With Injury
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Minnesota Vikings quarterback Brett Favre normally wears nondescript sneakers to his midweek news conference. On Wednesday, he limped in with his battered left ankle in a walking boot.

title: Changeups Arent Part of Washingtons Repertory
description: San Francisco

title: PolitiFact: Truth Is Out There, Barely
description: A well-known political fact-checking group has pored over the 2010 election and come up with a rating for the year: barely true.

title: Lessons Learned. Already.
description: It is not too soon to consider what weve learned from the 2010 elections.

title: End the War on Pot
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Fact-Checking Group Finds Campaign Year Barely True
description: Brian Stelter of The New York Times has word on The Caucus blog on how PolitiFact, a fact-checking operation at The St. Petersburg Times, has pored over the 2010 election campaign and come up with a rating for the year: barely true.

title: Remember Renewable Energy?
description: Global warming, energy independence and good 21st-century jobs are three compelling reasons why Washington must do a lot more to promote renewable energy. Congress seemed to get it in 2005 when it directed the Interior Department to approve enough wind, solar and other projects on public land to produce 10,000 megawatts by 2015  enough to heat, cool and light five million homes. Not much has happened since.

title: Boiling Point in Kentucky
description: The Kentucky Senate race has been particularly childish and nasty  even by this years dispiritingly low standards. So we suppose we should not have been surprised when a county coordinator for Rand Paul, the Republican candidate, stomped on a MoveOn activist outside Monday nights debate in Lexington. The politicians need to cool it and they need to urge their supporters to cool it.

title: Thursday: Halloween Riddle
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Do you love puns? If not, its perfectly appropriate in this Halloween puzzle to shout BOO.

title: At the Polls, With Fingers Crossed
description: The list of failures by New York Citys inept Board of Elections just keeps growing. The primary election was chaotic, with long waits and workers who had not been trained to use the new optical scanner voting machines. Then the board was late sending absentee ballots to military personnel. Incredibly, we are now hearing that the instructions on next weeks ballots include a glaring error: they tell voters to fill in the circle above or next to a candidates name instead of below.

title: Sport and Spectacle: The Gladiators of Football
description: To the Editor:

title: Alderson Set to Get to Work on Mets
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sandy Alderson was in the Dominican Republic on Wednesday, attending to his duties for Major League Baseball in its efforts to clean up the player procurement process. But he has already begun working on his next assignment, which may be equally as challenging  resurrecting the Mets.

title: Stoudemire Era Begins With Vim, Vigor and a Win
description: TORONTO  Amare Stoudemire never tried to mask his happy fervor. He skipped around the court. He winked at a young fan. He sprinted into timeouts.

title: The Courts and the Mandate
description: Health care reform is being challenged in the courts by 21 state governments, as well as by private groups and individuals. They contend Congress has no constitutional authority to require virtually everyone to carry health insurance starting in 2014 or pay a penalty.

title: TV at the Supreme Court?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobless and Frugal
description: To the Editor:

title: Karzai Delays Order to Ban Private Security Companies
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Under intense pressure, the government of President Hamid Karzai announced Wednesday that it would extend, if briefly, a contentious deadline for banning most private security companies in Afghanistan.

title: Liability and Evidence-Based Standards in Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: AARP To Sponsor Gordons Car
description: Jeff Gordon, 39, a four-time champion in Nascars top series, said he had picked up the AARP Foundation and its Drive to End Hunger campaign as his main sponsor for 22 Sprint Cup races each over the next three years. A cause has never been the main sponsor for a top stock-car racing team. Gordons Chevrolet has been mainly sponsored by DuPont since he broke into the top series in 1992, but DuPont has reduced its commitment. AARP plans to use its sponsorship to raise awareness of hunger in the United States, especially among older people.

title: Attacks (Again) Punctuate Illinois Senate Forum
description: CHICAGO  Well, its official now. With but a few days left until the vote, the race to fill the Senate seat vacated by President Obama  one of the nastiest and most bitterly fought races around  is right on the verge of turning positive. Or at least Alexi Giannoulias, the Democratic Party candidate who wants this seat from Illinois, announced during a candidate forum on Wednesday night that he is going positive for what is left of the campaign.

title: In Texas, a Front-Runners National Twist
description: BEAUMONT, Tex.  Gov. Rick Perry waded into a crowded room at Raos Bakery recently, full of conservatives and Tea Party members, and delivered his pitch with a sunny twang: Texas has one of the strongest economies in the country right now, and his small-government, low-tax policies are the reason.

title: Energized Base Tilts Rightward in Maine
description: SANFORD, Me.  For a while this fall, Paul LePage, the Republican running for governor, appeared too combative to win in this low-key state.

title: A Campaign of Few Details, but Questions Keep Coming
description: NAPLES, Fla.  The question for Rick Scott at last weeks debate had been asked countless times: Why was he qualified to be Floridas governor when his tenure as a chief executive of Columbia/HCA led to $1.7 billion in fines for defrauding the government? Was he involved, or too out of touch to know what was going on?

title: Nets Win Opener Over Pistons but Admit Its Still Early
description: NEWARK  The Nets accomplished a feat Wednesday night that took 3 coaches, 19 games and 38 days at the start of last season.

title: Governor Forecast Update: Live, Automated Polls Split on Tancredo Chances
description: Perhaps this years mostintriguinggubernatorial contest is in Colorado, which had once looked safe for the Democratic nominee, Mayor John Hickenlooper of Denver. A series of recent polls, however, have shown sharp gains by Tom Tancredo, the former Republican Congressman, who is running on the ticket of the American Constitution Party.

title: Activist Tells of Torture in North Korea Prison
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An evangelical activist from Arizona, imprisoned by North Korea last year after he illegally entered the country on Christmas Day, appeared Wednesday on South Korean television and spoke for the first time about his treatment by his captors.

title: Coming Off Heavy Workload, Sabathia Will Have Surgery
description: SAN FRANCISCO  C.C. Sabathia threw 3,903 pitches in 2010, and perhaps just as many in spring training, while warming up and between starts.

title: Gunmen Kill 15 in Mexico; Gang Link Seen
description: MEXICO CITY  At least 15 young people, several of them in treatment for drug addiction, were shot and killed Wednesday at a car wash in western Mexico, the third mass shooting with apparent connections to organized crime in less than a week.

title: Charges Dropped Against Fourth Man in Bronx Antigay Attacks
description: The Bronx district attorneys office announced on Wednesday that it was dropping charges against a teenager accused of taking part in the antigay attacks in an abandoned apartment building this month.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 27, 2010
description: A view of the day in sports, from a handball court in Russia to a soggy soccer pitch in northern Spain.

title: Final: World Series Game 1  Giants 11, Rangers 7
description: The Texas Rangers Cliff Lee, one of the most dominant postseason pitchers in recent memory, faced Tim Lincecum, a two-time National League Cy Young Award winner, in the most-hyped playoff pitching matchup since, well, last week, when Lincecum started for the San Francisco Giants against Roy Halladay of the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Kenya: Foreign Minister Resigns
description: Foreign Minister Moses Wetangula abruptly stepped down on Wednesday amid allegations that his ministry had stolen millions of dollars in a dubious land deal in Japan. Mr. Wetangula, a close ally of President Mwai Kibaki, is accused of trying to cover up a transaction in which Kenya overpaid by millions of dollars for land in Tokyo for a new embassy. Mr. Wetangula said that he was resigning to give room for the investigation, which involves other questionable embassy deals, and that he was confident that he would be cleared and would return to the cabinet. The government, which has long turned a blind eye to corruption, seems to be cracking down on it. In the past month, the mayor of Nairobi was arrested on corruption charges, and the agriculture minister was suspended and ordered to stand trial on corruption allegations.

title: Yankees Turn Down Contract Options
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Yankees began their off-season makeover by declining 2011 contract options for Nick Johnson, Kerry Wood and Lance Berkman, as expected.

title: Stores Push Black Friday Into October
description: Attention bargain shoppers! It is October  and Black Friday specials are here.

title: As College Fees Climb, Aid Does Too
description: As their state financing dwindled, four-year public universities increased their published tuition and fees almost 8 percent this year, to an average of $7,605, according to the College Boards annual reports. When room and board are included, the average in-state student at a public university now pays $16,140 a year.

title: Tuition Rises, But So Does Financial Aid
description: The average cost of tuition and fees for four-year, public universities, many of them grappling with budget cuts, rose almost 8 percent this year, to $7,605, according to my colleague Tamar Lewins reading of the College Boards annual Trends in College Pricing report. When room and board are factored in, Ms. Lewin writes of the just-released report, the average in-state student at a public university will pay $16,140 this year.

title: Word of the Day | disquisition
description: disquisition \dis-kw-zi-shn\ noun

title: Charmed Giants Take a Big First Step
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A gray-haired Juan Marichal stood beside the 300-game winner Gaylord Perry. Willie McCovey steadied himself against a walker as Orlando Cepeda offered support. Watching from the stands at AT&T Park was Barry Bonds. Few teams have as many living legends as the Giants, who somehow have not won a World Series title in 56 years. It was never Marichals turn, or McCoveys or Bondss. Baseball is funny like that.

title: Quake Was Both Aftershock and Foretaste
description: Since the devastating Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami in 2004, Ive been reporting on the potent seismic activity along the Sunda Fault, a dangerous seam in the seabed off the coast of Sumatra. All along, a critical source has been Kerry Sieh, who recently moved from the California Institute of Technology to the Earth Observatory of Singapore and has spent a couple of decades doing field work in the region.

title: Statutory Realignment at Tribune Company
description: Not long after Sam Zell, the real estate mogul, took over the Tribune Company, he installed a sculpture in the headquarters lobby titled Bureaucratic Shuffle, a six-legged man going in circles and nowhere fast. But what was intended as a commentary on the existing culture at Tribune Towers came to be seen as a metaphor for the new management after the company tipped over into bankruptcy and a new, non-linear approach to management failed to gain traction.

description: MARSEILLE, France  Several hundred thousand people demonstrated again on Thursday to protest changes in Frances retirement age, but the numbers were down significantly from previous national days of protest, and it appeared that President Nicolas Sarkozy and his government had won an important victory.

description: After several weeks of insisting its foreclosure processes were sound, Wells Fargo said Wednesday that it planned to correct and resubmit up to 55,000 improperly filed documents by mid-November, Eric Dash reports in The New York Times.

description: Banco Santander, the largest Spanish bank, posted a third-quarter profit of 1.64 million euros ($2.28 million) on Thursday, its lowest in four years, and said that earnings had fallen short of expectations for 2010,.

title: The TV Watch: Access and the Plight of the Political Comedian
description: The country long ago stopped wondering whether a president demeans his office by appearing on a late-night comedy show. The more immediate question posed by President Obamas appearance on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart on Wednesday is whether a political satirist loses credibility when hobnobbing with a sitting president.
