description: Through support from the East New York Clubhouse, Karen McBroom is learning to cope with the death of her youngest son, who killed himself last May.

title: Beards, Wigs and Panda Heads: Its Giants Baseball
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The fall colors here are worth a long look, and on Wednesday, AT&T Park provided a spectacular viewing spot. Without traveling farther than an infield grounder, one could see a young redhead tugging at his fake black beard, an adult dressed in orange from his top hat to his spats, a man with a gray ponytail wearing a tie-dyed Giants T-shirt, and people of all ages and persuasions wearing white panda caps.

title: Evercore Has Robust Quarter
description: Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, reported a 33 percent rise in third-quarter earnings on Thursday, buoyed by higher fees for advising on mergers.

title: Low-Profile Banker, Meet High-Profile Car
description: The name is Yeaggy, Harry Yeaggy, and hes now the proud new owner of what may be the worlds most famous car.

title: Some Pre-Election Perspective
description: I dont agree with everything in Will Wilkinsons explanation of why the midterms dont actually matter all that much, but its still a useful corrective to the vast effort currently underway to persuade you that this election (like the election before it, and the election before that) is a world-historical hinge moment, and that nothing in American life matters more than how many seats the Republicans gain or dont gain next Tuesday:

title: Smitten With a Cocktail Called Frisco
description: Are you familiar with the Frisco? I asked a bartender at Rye House, near Union Square, who in turn asked me to repeat myself, then had me spell the two syllables I had twice uttered. Still he was baffled. He took out his iPhone and sought to Google his way to illumination. But the recipe he found didnt match my rough memory and sense of what a Frisco should be: a bracing blast of whiskey, tempered to a very particular degree by undercurrents of an opulent sweetness. The drink he made disappointed me.

title: The View From France: Assessing the Europeans
description: Your attention please. We interrupt this Zenyatta-fest with a bulletin from Europe, where another distaff superstar is packing her bags for America, with a string of top-class companions in tow. Goldikova leads the challenge from across the pond in what the Racing Post is referring to as the Equine Ryder Cup. The Breeders Cup is starting to catch on over here, and now that the organizers have offered to pay the travel costs, you can look for more and more top horses to make the trip.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Wall Street Journal: Roxbury Russett. Cornish Gilliflower. Ralls Genet. They are heritage apples, some going back to colonial times, and they are undergoing a renaissance.  Glenn Collins

title: The Insider | El Guincho
description: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here the Spanish musician El Guincho (real name: Pablo Daz-Reixa) shares his essentials. El Guincho is currently on tour in Europe promoting his latest album, Pop Negro, a chaotic mix of Afro beat, tropicalia and dub.

title: Rehearsal Video of 'Amer'
description: A rehearsal video of the film "Amer," with the co-director Hlne Cattet standing in for the lead role.

title: With Basketball Season on the Horizon, A.C.C. Endures Football Schedule
description: It has been one of those autumns in the Atlantic Coast Conference that prompts the pleas for the quick arrival of basketball, which is still considered the strong suit of the A.C.C. There has been scandal (North Carolina) and disappointment (Miami) and little national buzz about the conferences football teams.

title: A Scene From 'Amer'
description: A scene from the film "Amer," an homage to Italian giallo horror films.

title: Finding a Way Around the Press?
description: 4:14 p.m. | Updated The first question is in, and its pretty much of a softball. Mr. Gibbs chose to answer the question What is the purpose of the India trip. That gave him a chance to talk about the presidents upcoming trip to Asia, including the economic summits he will attend. (As a bonus, he also answered a question about whether the presidents Secret Service code-name is now dude, since thats how Jon Stewart referred to him on his show. Its not, Mr. Gibbs said. Its still Renegade.) But instead of answering the question at the podium, Mr. Gibbs recorded it on video from a webcam in the White House.

title: The Terminator Team Reunites for the Environment
description: The director James Cameron and the actor-turned-governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, who worked on the Terminator films together, have teamed up again, but this time to shoot a political ad urging Californians to vote against Proposition 23, a ballot initiative that would put Californias Global Warming Act of 2006 on hold.

title: Carlyle Offers $2.6 Billion for Syniverse
description: Does Carlyle Group have a grand telecoms strategy?

title: On Dooring of Bicyclists, and Experts Fees
description: Cyclists sometimes call it the door prize, or simply being doored.

title: Night Watch: Analyzing Obamas Daily Show Appearance
description: Keith Olbermann presented a closing argument of sorts for Democrats on MSNBC on Wednesday night, in the form of one of his longest special comments ever. (Hes been reading the commentaries on-air for four years.)

title: Plane Sequence From 'Monsters'
description: A sequence from the film "Monsters" where characters find a plane in the river. (Magnet Releasing)

title: Governors Association Complains Again About Fox News
description: A newly amended complaint by the Democratic Governors Association, filed this week before the Ohio Elections Commission, asserts that Fox News used corporate funds to make a prohibited contribution of $169,389 in violation of Ohio law when it provided one minute and 30 seconds of free political advertising to John Kasichs campaign on August 18, 2010.

title: An Accidental King Finds His Voice
description: LONDON

title: Crossing Delancey
description: Even hipsters have to grow up  or, in this case, move farther downtown. A fixture on Ludlow Street since 1992, TG170, Terri Gilliss quirky-cool clothing store, has moved down the street into more streamlined digs designed by the architect Philip Otto. More Chelsea gallery than boho hangout, the store remains true to its curatorial spirit, with artwork by Rich Jacobs and Mike Mills interspersed with Gilliss collection of concrete garden animals, and signage by the graphic designer Chris Rubino. On the racks: indie labels like Corell & Corell, Hazel Brown, Mociun and Hengst.TG170, at 77 Ludlow Street; (212) 995-8660, or tg170.com.

title: Inside a Trauma Ward in Iraq
description: In 2007, a surgical team tried to save the lives of three wounded Marines.

title: China Is Said to Resume Shipping Rare Earth Minerals
description: BAOTOU, China  The Chinese government on Thursday abruptly ended its unannounced export embargo on crucial rare earth minerals to the United States, Europe and Japan, four industry officials said.

title: Opposites Attract as Paula Abdul Takes on American Idol
description: Paula Abduls new dance show, Live to Dance, will be scheduled against her former singing show, American Idol.

title: Giants Fans Dont Stop Believin
description: There were more than a few fans dressed in panda suits for Game 1 and a stunning number of jet-black beards in the stands as the World Series opened in San Francisco. And perhaps one guy dressed as Cliff Lee. That couldnt possibly have been the Texas ace on the mound for four and two-thirds innings, could it?

title: A Hundred Ways to Be a Frog
description: Sunday, Oct. 24

title: The Legality of Buying Knockoffs
description: In a recent Bucks post, How to Bargain at Markets, I shared some of the tips my business school classmates and I learned while bargaining for knockoffs and counterfeit goods on a class trip to China.

title: Keeping Score: What Does a Blowout in Game 1 Mean?
description: Game 1 of the World Series was anything but the taut, well-pitched contest we had been sold during the run-up to the World Series. The Giants especially were quick to shed their label as a no-hit, pitching-centered team. From Sept. 1 through the National League Championship Series, the Giants had played 39 games and had scored five or more runs only 10 times. In contrast, the Rangers had done it 20 times. But the Giants pitched so well over that stretch that they won 26 and lost 13 of those games, so their anemic offense hasnt really hurt them.

title: Poetry Pairing | Oct. 28, 2010
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Theory by Olivier Theyskens
description: The clothes, under the label Theyskens Theory, reflect Mr. Theyskenss signature drainpipe style, but also look like Theorys urban wardrobe.

title: Blumenthal and McMahon Take Campaigns to Main Street
description: Richard Blumenthal had two members of Congress in tow Tuesday afternoon as he swept into El Jibaro barber shop on New Havens main Latino commercial strip. Severiano Burgos took a break from cutting a customers hair. In the final weeks before Election Day, Mr. Burgos has gotten used to these visits from politicians.

title: Olivier Theyskens and Theory: Q & A
description: After introducing his first capsule collection for Theory in September, the designer Olivier Theyskens broadened his relationship with the contemporary sportswear powerhouse this week by signing on as its artistic director. In his new role, Mr. Theyskens, formerly the designer of the luxury labels Rochas and Nina Ricci, will oversee the design of mens, womens and accessories collections that now have sales of more than $500 million annually. (Istvan Francer, who was the design director of the womens Theory collection, is expected to move to another role within Theorys parent company, Fast Retailing.)

title: Times Popcast: Taylor Swift, Dierks Bentley and Wrapping CMJ
description: Country music is the focus this week on Popcast, the music podcast of The Times.

title: Airgass Strategic Blink
description: The plight of the three independent Airgas directors selected by Air Products and Chemicals is fascinating.

title: Labor Law Is Broken, Economist Says
description: In a new paper, Richard B. Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard, said he had some harsh and impolitic news for the National Labor Relations Act on its 75th anniversary. He declared that the law has become an anachronism irrelevant for most workers and firms.

title: S.C. Write-In Candidate Says Hes Not a Total Moron
description: Karl Fornes has chosen a pretty direct slogan for his write-in campaign for Senate in South Carolina: Hes not a total moron.

title: Amid Criticism of the M.T.A., a Show of Support
description: The Republican outsider says it should be abolished. The Democratic insider says no one is in charge of it.

title: Cuomos Running Mate Fills Quiet but Scrappy Role
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y.  The 6-foot-5-inch, 225-pound man behind Andrew M. Cuomo emerged from a black Chevrolet here to a crowd of puzzled looks. He stood to the side, gazing at the ground and fiddling with his sleeves as Mr. Cuomo basked in the attention of cameras.

title: Pee-wees Comeback
description: Images of from the career of Paul Reubens.

title: Candy-Colored Bow-Tied Redemption
description: THE Pied Piper was nowhere to be heard, and Santa Claus wouldnt be coming to town for a few more weeks, but something irresistible had drawn a small crowd to the West Fourth Street basketball courts in Greenwich Village on a recent Thursday morning. Huddled in groups of two and three, a few dozen men and women in their 20s and 30s glanced at one another and at their smartphones, rereading the Twitter and Foursquare messages that directed them here, waiting for something to happen.

title: Cliff Lees Off Night
description: The one thing we thought we knew about baseball this year was, its the year of the pitcher. And in the year of the pitcher, Texass Cliff Lee was king. Unbeatable. Teams might as well not even try. So, naturally, the score of Game 1 of the World Series is 11-7 and Lee gets shelled. Next theyll be telling us there is no Santa Claus and playing Powerball is not, in fact, a good retirement strategy.

title: The Morning Line: In Racings Galaxy, Zenyatta Stands Out
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

title: Ristretto | AeroPress
description: This morning I made coffee with an AeroPress, a device that reminds me of a horse syringe without the needle. At its most basic, it works like a French press crossed with a Melitta filter: you put coffee grounds and hot water in one plastic cylinder, then plunge it into a cup or kettle with the other. Its inexpensive (about $30), easy to use and even if it has no mechanical charisma  it looks like it was pieced together with parts from a Habitrail set  its actually a carefully engineered tool that addresses some of the more obsessive issues concerning extraction, grind and temperature.

title: In 2010 Campaign, War is Rarely Mentioned
description: WASHINGTON  The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have dominated American foreign policy for the past nine years, but debate about them is all but absent from this years midterm election campaigns.

title: Death and Memory
description: When I tell stories about Iraq, the ones people react to are always the stories of violence. This is strange for me. As a public affairs officer in 2007 and 2008, I never saw combat, only its aftermath. I saw women and children wounded or dying in trauma centers. Ruins left by explosives in towns and cities across Anbar province. I saw surgeons who could do no more because the body they were trying to repair was too badly destroyed. I stood in formations as the bodies were taken away.

title: Q&A: Portugal for the Holidays
description: My wife and I are planning to travel to Portugal for a three-week trip that will include Christmas and New Years. We would appreciate suggestions as to how we might best enjoy these holidays while we are there. We also wonder if any regions of the country have particularly distinctive celebrations.

title: TimesCast | October 28 2010
description: Illinois Senate barbs; the latest New York Times/CBS poll and award-worthy political ads in New York region.

title: HBO Announces End of Big Love
description: For years, Bill Henrickson and his three wives on the HBO drama Big Love have skated on some precarious ice  at least until they changed what was a perfectly good opening-credit sequence for that series  but they wont be able to keep it up for much longer. On Thursday, HBO said the coming season of Big Love, which stars Bill Paxton as a Utah polygamist, and Jeanne Tripplehorn, Chlo Sevigny and Ginnifer Goodwin as his wives, will be the shows last.

title: Somali Islamists Kill Two Girls Branded Spies
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somalias most powerful Islamist insurgents, the Shabab, executed two teenage girls on Wednesday after deciding they were spies, setting off fears among residents, officials and witnesses said.

title: Binghamton Coach Gets $1.2 Million to Resign
description: The tumultuous tenure of Kevin Broadus, the coach who oversaw the Binghamton basketball programs first N.C.A.A. tournament berth and also its subsequent implosion, has ended.

title: Courage, Recognized: The Infantry and Joao Silva
description: During a few frantic minutes late in 2006, Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times, made a series of photographs of a Marine sergeant, Jesse E. Leach, retrieving from the line of fire a radio operator, Lance Cpl. Juan Valdez-Castillo, who had just been shot by a sniper on a foot patrol in Karma, Iraq.

title: Senator Gillibrand Has New York Home on the Market
description: SENATOR Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York, who filled the seat vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton when she became secretary of state, is running for a full term in a special election next month against Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican and former congressman. And perhaps anticipating an extended stay in Washington, Ms. Gillibrand, a Democrat, has been trying to sell her five-bedroom home on 13 acres in Hudson, N.Y.

title: In Marseille, Bipartisan Calls for Strikes to End
description: MARSEILLE  The strikes and protests against a seemingly inevitable pension change may be waning here, as elsewhere in France, but much of the port remains blocked, nearly 11,000 tons of uncollected trash remain piled in the streets, and residents remain embarrassed and exasperated, if somewhat unsurprised.

title: Theater Talkback: Better Off Off Broadway?
description: Broadway or death. The reigning wisdom of theater producers these days is that if a play is ever going to grow up  that is, be taken seriously, receive lots of attention and, above all, make money  it can do so only on Broadway. I know that there are incontrovertible economic reasons for this theory. (Off-Broadway shows are highly unlikely ever to turn a profit.) And I suppose that as a New York theater lover, I should be grateful that the neon imprimatur of Broadway still holds a hypnotic glamor for people around the world.

title: Panel Says Firms Knew of Cement Flaws Before Spill
description: WASHINGTON  Halliburton officials knew weeks before the fatal explosion of the BP well in the Gulf of Mexico that the cement mixture they planned to use to seal the bottom of the well was unstable but still went ahead with the job, the presidential commission investigating the accident said on Thursday.

title: Linda Somers Smith, 49 and Still Among the Elite, Is Taking Your Questions
description: 10:15 p.m. |Update: Somers Smiths Responses

title: Yankees, Girardi Agree on Contract
description: The Yankees acted quickly to retain Manager Joe Girardi, rewarding him with a three-year, $9 million contract. The framework of the deal is in place, but because the Yankees did not want to make the announcement on the day of a World Series game, the new deal will not be announced until Friday. Girardis three-year, $7.8 million contract is set to expire on Sunday, but there was little doubt that he would return. General Manager Brian Cashman, minutes after the Yankees season ended last Friday night in Texas, said he absolutely expected Girardi to come back, a sentiment echoed Monday at their post-mortem news conferences at Yankee Stadium.

title: Halliburton and BP Knew of Cement Flaws
description: The chief investigator of the presidential commission investigating the gulf oil spill says that Halliburton and BP knew of flaws in the cement used to seal the oil well weeks before the spill. Here is his letter to the full commission.

title: But Judge, Who Knew the Rangers Would Advance?
description: 9:47 p.m. | Updated with comments from Cook

title: What Were Reading: Pot Domains, and Throwing Pies at Bees
Leaked: Obama Mentors Blunt Advice on Court Choices
description: In May 2009, after Justice David Souter announced his retirement from the Supreme Court, Laurence H. Tribe, the prominent Harvard Law professor, wrote a two-page letter to President Obama that bluntly laid out his views about several justices and potential nominees.

title: Reader Rejoinders
description: An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words  generously emailed by co-vocabularists.

title: Babylon on Hudson?
description: As if it werent bad enough for the city to see itself caricatured in political ads around the country, Animal New York dredges up a video from one of the many fretfully conspiratorial corners of YouTube that dares to ask the following question: Is New York actually the affluent and wicked city known as the mystery Babylon?

title: Let There Be Light, and Elegance
description: Elegance is refusal, Diana Vreeland declared. But not always. She would have had a tough time selling that line of logic to the financier and elegance addict J. P. Morgan, a notable nonrefuser in practically every area, including art. He bought porcelains by the pound, drawings by the ream, bucketsful of Near Eastern cylinder seals and box upon box of rare books, chucking the junk and keeping the gems. Such was his way.

title: Hispanics Cite Bias in Survey
description: More than 6 in 10 Latinos in the United States say discrimination is a major problem for them, a significant increase in the last three years, according to a survey of Latino attitudes by the Pew Hispanic Center, a nonpartisan research group.

title: The Paul Reubens Show: Meet the Man Behind Pee-wee Herman
description: The sign on the marquee at the Stephen Sondheim Theater may read The Pee-wee Herman Show, but the man at the center of it, and behind more than 30 years of fascination with that antic, perpetually adolescent character, is the actor and comedian Paul Reubens. The popularity of Pee-wee Herman, at the Groundlings and in his original stage show, led Mr. Reubens to portray him in hit movies like Pee-wees Big Adventure, and on a Saturday morning television series, Pee-wees Playhouse. Two sex scandals could have cost Mr. Reubens his career, or made it unthinkable that he could plausibly portray the childlike Pee-wee  instead, he successfully revived The Pee-wee Herman Show earlier this year in Los Angeles and is now about to open it on Broadway.

title: Indonesias Largest Mosque Is on Obamas Itinerary
description: President Obama will mix childhood reflections with Muslim outreach when he travels to Indonesia, the worlds largest Muslim nation, next month. White House officials said Thursday that his visit would include a stop at Istiqlal Mosque, the nations largest, and a major address in Jakarta, where he lived for four years as a boy and remains hugely popular.

title: City Considering 47 Schools For Closing
description: Its school closing season: Let the battles begin.

title: Cavaliers Owner Proclaims No Regrets
description: Dan Gilbert, the owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, said Wednesday he has no regrets about laffaire LeBron James.

title: G.M. to Pare Down Debt Before I.P.O.
description: 4:30 p.m. | Updated Susanne Craig of The New York Times discusses the General Motors financial makeover in a video on the jump. And Nick Bunkley of The Times has more details about G.M.s plans.

title: Graduate Pays Back Cornell With $80 Million Gift
description: Cornell University must surely be pleased that one of its graduates, David R. Atkinson, made a fortune on Wall Street. Mr. Atkinson, Class of 1960 and a retired money manager, and his wife, Patricia, are giving the university $80 million  the largest individual gift that it has ever received.

title: A Love Letter to a Camera
description: Dear Canon S95,

title: Taking Genetic History to the Grave
description: Has the death of a loved one left you wondering about your own genetic risk for cancer?

title: The Morgan, Restored
description: The 1906 McKim building at the Morgan Library & Museum will reopen on Saturday after a $4.5 million restoration.

title: Responding to Reader Comments on Password Security
description: In response to my recent post on password security, a number of readers put up comments that provided other suggestions for good password security, put password security in a different perspective, or just emoted about this sometimes frustrating issue. Thanks to all for taking the trouble. Here are my responses to some of them:

title: High Jobless Rates Persist Among Blacks and Hispanics
description: Since the depths of the recession, unemployment has been persistently high for blacks and Hispanics in New York City, while it has declined among whites and Asians, according to an analysis released on Thursday by the citys comptroller, John C. Liu.

title: New DNA Tests Aimed at Reducing Colon Cancer
description: Two new DNA-based tests, one of them described at a meeting in Philadelphia on Thursday, hold the promise of detecting early  and sharply reducing  colon cancer, a disease that afflicts 150,000 people a year in the United States and costs an estimated $14 billion to treat.

title: Print vs. Digital: Analyzing and Designing Book Apps for Works of Literature
description: Overview | How has digital technology changed the way we read? How might e-books and book applications enhance our reading experiences? In this lesson, students consider the ways that new ways of reading have changed the nature of reading and design book apps for literature they have read in print. They then reflect on and compare the experiences of reading in print and in digital formats.

title: Robert Duffy on the Stump
description: Mr. Duffy introduces Andrew M. Cuomo at a campaign stop at a steak house in Batavia, N.Y. as part of a tour of Western New York on Monday.

title: 4 Nations With Child Soldiers Keep U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON  In 2009, the government of Chad conscripted refugee children for unlawful use as guards and combatants in its desert battles against rebel forces; the army of the Democratic Republic of Congo forced children to carry ammunition and supplies through the jungle, and some died under their weight; hundreds of boys and girls were forced into the army of southern Sudan, despite a commitment to release them; and in Yemen, children as young as 14 make up perhaps half the ranks of both the governments forces and the rebels opposing them.

title: Streetscapes | J.P. Morgan's Library
description: The library of 1906 was also a place where the financier retreated to smoke cigars, play solitaire and on one occasion, to save New York.

title: Le Toux Among Most Valuable, but Hes Not on the List
description: There is an old baseball story that loosely informs a soccer story in Major League Soccer this season.

title: Gebrselassie Racing Marathon Course, Not Clock
description: Having won world championships or set world records from the metric mile to the marathon, Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia is considered by many the greatest distance runner of this or any generation.

title: The Architect Charles McKim, Designer of the Morgan Library
description: THIS weekend the Morgan Library and Museum marks the opening of its refurbished centerpiece, J. P. Morgans severe, jewel-like library of 1906, one of the signature works of the architect Charles McKim. And on Tuesday Knopf released Triumvirate: McKim, Mead & White: Art, Architecture, Scandal, and Class in Americas Gilded Age," by Mosette Broderick. This 581-page history serves as the only modern work to examine the career of the reflective, often depressed McKim, perennially in the shadow of his flamboyant and equally troubled partner, Stanford White.

title: Brooklyn Condo in Historic Graham Home for Old Ladies Is for Sale
description: AS the citys housing market soared over the last decade, many abandoned buildings and old factories were developed into condominiums. Few of those conversions, however, have as rich a history as the condo at 320 Washington Avenue in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, which was built in 1851 as the home of the Brooklyn Society for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females.

title: Money Transfer Site Attracts Venture Capital
description: PeerTransfer, a Web service based in Boston that specializes in international money transfers and payments, said Thursday that it had secured a first round of venture financing worth $1.1 million.

title: Verizon Deal Ends Inquiry Over Fees
description: WASHINGTON  Verizon Wireless, the nations largest mobile phone carrier, will pay $25 million to end an investigation into complaints that it had charged 15 million cellphone customers unauthorized data fees over the last three years, the Federal Communications Commission announced Thursday.

title: How to Save a Third of Your Income
description: In her new book, Generation Earn: The Young Professionals Guide to Spending, Investing, and Giving Back (Ten Speed Press), the author Kimberly Palmer recommends that young adults try to save at least a quarter of their annual income.

title: Reviving Haitian Revelry in Greenwich Village
description: BARRYTOWN, N.Y.  Didier Civil stood in the center of the dilapidated barn, surrounded by skeletons, horse heads and other costumes that will form part of Sundays Halloween parade through Greenwich Village. He wrapped a piece of white lace around the colossal head of Gran Brigitte, a Haitian voodoo spirit of the dead. When she is complete, the papier-mch Brigitte will stand 18 feet tall. Swathed in a purple robe and headscarf, she will join her husband, Baron Samedi, at the front of the parade.

title: Dressing Up for Halloween, and Election Night Beers
description: Everybody has a dark side, and the Miser can think of no better time than Halloween weekend to help you explore it.

title: Two Sides of 'Amer'
description: A scene from the rehearsal video for the film Amer, then the same scene as it appears in the completed film.

title: Candy of All Stripes, in Stores in New York City
description: YOURE never too old to dress up for Halloween, but after about 13, if you turn up at an unsuspecting someones door looking for candy, you could end up in the back of a squad car.

title: Shrinking the Climate Problem
description: Ive written here before about the substantial part of the climate challenge that isnt out in the world of greenhouse gases and coal furnaces, but within the human mind.

title: Senator Gillibrands Hudson Valley House on the Market
description: Our colleague Sarah Kershaw has the lowdown on Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrands Hudson Valley home up for sale: a five-bedroom, four-and-a-half bath house on 13 acres in Hudson, N.Y. The listing over at Halstead Property notes the propertys spectacular Hudson River views and delightful guest cottage.

title: New York High School Students Will Get Chance to See Scottsboro Boys for Free
description: In a rare move, the Theater Development Fund  a nonprofit group that runs Broadways TKTS discount booth and an array of arts education programs  has bought all of the seats to two performances of a Broadway show for nearly 1,800 New York City high school students to attend.

title: The Success of Political Nostaglia: Answers From Matt Bai
description: In his Political Times column on Wednesday, Matt Bai wrote that we may see the election of several venerable politicians to offices they held before, including some who havent governed since the days when apple and blackberry referred primarily to fruit.

title: New DNA Tests Aim at Reducing Cancer
description: Nicholas Wade of The New York Times reports on two new DNA-related tests in an article recently posted on our Web site. The tests, he notes, one of them described at a meeting in Philadelphia on Thursday, hold the promise of detecting early  and sharply reducing  colon cancer, a disease that afflicts 150,000 people a year in the United States and costs an estimated $14 billion to treat.

title: G.M. Moves to Clean Up Its Books Before I.P.O.
description: DETROIT  Preparing for its highly anticipated public offering next month, General Motors said on Thursday that it would repurchase $2.1 billion in preferred stock held by the federal government, contribute at least $6 billion to its pension plans and pay down debt to a health care fund for union retirees.

title: Mets Get More Time to Negotiate With Takahashi
description: The Mets and the new agent for Hisanori Takahashi have received permission from Major League Baseball and the Players Association to push back the deadline for signing him, probably for about another week, although the exact date has not been determined.

title: Blue Dog Democrat for Speaker?
description: Heath Shulers political aspirations may go well beyond netting a third term as the congressman for his conservative western North Carolina district.

title: Do Dogs Like to Dress Up for Halloween?
description: Like many pet owners, I have, on occasion, dressed up my dog. One Halloween, Fluffy was a pink princess. Another time, she was Batman.

title: A Heliport, Kingfishers and River Dolphins
description: Monday, Oct. 25

title: Inquiry Puts Halliburton in a Familiar Hot Seat
description: Halliburton is back in the spotlight, and once again, in an uncomfortable way.

title: The Morning Skate: Coaches Challenges? MacLean in Trouble? Rangers Reverting?
description: During the second intermission of the Islanders-Montreal game, TSNs Darren Dreger reported that he had surveyed N.H.L. coaches on whether theyd like to see a challenge system instituted in the league, much like the N.F.L.s, where head coaches can request a review of an officials decision. (video and here on his blog).

title: Coffeehouse Cool Amid the Stroller Scene
description: MY mother never let me have Pop-Tarts  breakfast shouldnt involve frosting, was the theory  but she would approve of the version sold at Ted & Honey, a snug cafe on Clinton Street next to Cobble Hill Park in Brooklyn.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Ted & Honey
description: Ted & Honey, a cafe next to Cobble Hill Park in Brooklyn, has become something of a neighborhood institution since it opened in 2008.

title: Cond Nast Moves One Executive Out, Another Up
description: Carol Smith, the former Elle brand chief who made waves in the publishing industry this spring when she jumped ship for Cond Nast, is leaving, saying her partnership with the company was not the right fit.

title: City Plans to Push Repairs for Set of Bronx Buildings
description: The city will begin aggressively cataloging violations in ten decrepit Bronx buildings, make emergency repairs and issue liens if not repaid, officials said on Thursday, in the hopes of forcing the firm controlling the portfolio to fix the buildings and usher them into responsible new ownership.

title: Death to the Double-Dip Forecasts
description: Dont worry about a double-dip, but dont stop worrying altogether.

title: How Many Parents Is Too Many?
description: How many parents can a child have?

title: Now Riding | Herms and Yamaha
description: Herms is more synonymous with horse riding than with motorcycling. But the haute leather goods house has once again collaborated with Yamaha, having upholstered the new VMAX Concept Bike in buffalo leather. (Herms and Yamaha worked together on a similar project 15 years ago.) The waterproof matte leather is available in black and chocolate, and is a sleek complement to the bikes brushed aluminum fixtures. A matching helmet is also available, upon request. The price tag for the bike is approximately $62,000 and delivery takes from one to four months, but  hey  its quicker than a waiting-list Kelly bag.

title: Revamped Nets Feel Like a Good Fit in Striving Newark
description: Newark

title: Liberty Island, 1:07 P.M.
description: Thursday marks the 124th birthday of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Strange Tales in the Land of No Return
description: Now the government really is selling bonds that deserve the label certificates of confiscation.

title: Pfizer Hopes to Pair Cancer Drug, Gene Test
description: Pfizer plans to submit its proposed new lung cancer drug to the Food and Drug Administration in the first half of next year at the same time that it submits a gene diagnostic test being developed with Abbott to identify patients most likely to benefit from the drug, company officials said Thursday.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Indonesia, Afghanistan and Haiti.

title: Notre Dame Students Death at Practice Under Investigation
description: Jack Swarbrick, Notre Dames athletic director, said Thursday that an extraordinary burst of wind roared across the football practice fields Wednesday, toppling a video tower and killing Declan Sullivan, a 20-year-old student manager for the team.

title: Name This Face
description: Gerald Ford, perhaps. But upon closer, and further, inspection, the portrait of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani unveiled Tuesday at City Hall turns into a veritable celebrity Rorschach, bringing to mind any number of actors, politicians and cartoon notables (as well as, of course, Mr. Giuliani himself, who sat for the portrait artist Everett Raymond Kinstler in 2006).

title: Fields Study | Strange Powers
description: Tonight, at Other Music, the ever-brooding Stephin Merritt will be manning the turntables for the opening of All Our Friends Are In New York, a photo exhibit of which he and his band, the Magnetic Fields, are the principal subjects. About the nights musical program, Merritt told The Moment, I suppose Ill be playing the bubblegum and psychedelic music that I generally play. Maybe with an Octoberish slant  if I show up and there are skeletons hanging over the place. The exhibit itself, which is on view through Nov. 14, is tied to the release of Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt and the Magnetic Fields, a documentary, 10 years in the making, which Mike Hale reviewed this week in the New York Times. The exhibit features candid photos of the band, including one of Merritt taking a smoke break on the fire escape at Spin Magazine, where he once moonlighted as a proofreader. Asked what he thinks of music journalists today hes a critical darling who in 2006 was the butt of some very bad press  Merritt said: I think that working for a magazine is the highest possible calling and that all rock journalists are saints that are governing the country. Yes, Merritt can be sharply sarcastic, and also blunt, as in his appraisal of the documentary itself: Its boring  its just me and my friends, talking about me.

title: Can Saints-Steelers Outdraw Game 4 Sunday Night?
description: The N.F.L. does not regularly challenge the World Series with Sunday games in prime time.

title: The Caucus: Obama Coalition Is Fraying
description: Results from a New York Times/CBS News poll show that critical parts of the coalition that delivered President Obama to the White House are now switching their allegiance to the Republicans.

title: Unearthing New Clues To Primates Origins
description: The ancestors of humans and other primates like apes and monkeys may have originated in Asia, not Africa, a new study in the journal Nature reports.

title: This Weekends Top European Matchups
description: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

title: Week 8 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 8. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: James Bond Aston Martin DB5 Sells for $4.6 Million
description: LONDON  The Ohio collector Harry Yeaggy brought home the top prize from Thursdays RM Auctions Automobiles of London sale, a 1964 Aston Martin DB5 James Bond film car from Goldfinger and Thunderball.

title: General Motors Ready for I.P.O. Roadshow
description: The once troubled automaker has returned to profitability, and will soon make its shares available to the public.

title: At Churchill Downs, Barbaro Lives On
description: Those attending the Breeders Cup this year will have the opportunity to see the Barbaro Memorial statue, which is situated just outside the main entrance to Churchill Downs, and close to the Kentucky Derby museum. Actually, I should rephrase that, those attending this years Breeders Cup will see the Barbaro Memorial statue; it is unavoidable.

title: Samantha Bees Laughing Pad
description: Samantha BeeAge: 41Occupation: ComedianProject: Returning this month to The Daily Show from maternity leave

title: N.F.L. Taking On World Series Sunday Night
description: On the Fifth Down, Richard Sandomir writes about an interesting competition for sports viewers on Sunday night, when NBC will broadcast the Pittsburgh-New Orleans N.F.L. game and Fox will carry Game 4 of the World Series, featuring Texas and San Francisco. It will be the first time since NBC started carrying Sunday Night Football in 2006 that it will compete against the World Series.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Indonesia, Afghanistan and Haiti.

title: Americans Want Disclosure and Limits on Campaign Spending
description: In a year of record campaign spending, Americans overwhelmingly support limits on corporate and advocacy group funding of campaign advertisements, strongly support limits on how much campaigns can spend and favor full disclosure of spending by both campaigns and outside groups.

title: The Illinois Senate Race
description: The race to fill President Obama's Illinois Senate seat is one of the nastiest and most bitterly fought contests in the nation.

title: Still Few Women at the Top in Most Big U.S. Companies
description: Even though women represent about half of the nations work force, most companies in the S.&P. 100 have no female or minority representation in their highest-paid executive positions, Calvert Investments concluded in a report released Thursday.

title: Palin Refuses to Repudiate Beck
description: David Brock, the C.E.O. of the liberal group Media Matters, said in an interview with the Caucus that he was disappointed with Sarah Palins refusal to repudiate the Fox News host Glenn Beck.

title: Sales of Video Game and Flagship Software Lift Microsoft
description: Microsofts profit engine is humming along nicely, even if most investors remain unimpressed and the software giants stock price is stagnant.

title: Cold Case Files
description: Ian Fraziers Great Plains, published in 1989, was a tour de force of travel writing: a 25,000-mile jaunt from the Dakotas to Texas that stripped away the regions seemingly bland facade. From Sitting Bull to Bonnie and Clyde to the Clutter family, whose murder was chronicled in Truman Capotes In Cold Blood, Frazier revisited American archetypes, and in some cases reinvented them. Later, in On the Rez, he drew on his 20-year friendship with Le War Lance, a beer-swilling Oglala Sioux, to describe life at the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. In both books, Fraziers skillful storytelling, acute powers of observation and wry voice captured the soul of the American West.

title: Travels in Siberia
description: Chapter 1

title: Capturing an Escape Artist
description: An exhibition at the Jewish Museum gives new insight into the life and career of Harry Houdini.

title: TimesCast: Barbs in the Illinois Senate Race
description: Monica Davey, The Timess Chicago bureau chief, takes a look at the race for Illinoiss Senate seat, one of the nastiest and most bitterly fought contests in the nation.

title: TimesCast: Poll Finds Obama Coalition Is Fraying
description: On the latest episode of TimesCast, Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss the results of the latest poll from The New York Times and CBS News.

title: A Literary Romance, Rich in A-List Names
description: The three words that make up the title of Antonia Frasers fond and affecting new memoir were spoken to her by Harold Pinter, the playwright, at a party in London in the winter of 1975.

title: A Flash of Bachs Brilliance Before Lincoln Centers White Light Festival
description: As preconcert lectures go, it was pretty pre-. But it was excellent.

title: The Boys With the Band
description: The fledgling mens-wear label Tuesday Night Band Practice was born out of harmonic convergence. The founding foursome  Robin Graves and Mark Murder, who are from Britain, andBen Bones and Dan Danger, who hail from Australia  first met up in Bali over weekly jam sessions and started turning out illustration-heavy, verse-inflected T-shirts. (Graves is an illustrator by trade with a penchant for songwriting.) But as they soon discovered, making music is one thing and making clothes is another entirely. Bones and Danger splintered off. Its a similar situation with bands, Graves said. People have certain directions and visions, and mine and Marks are both coming from U.K. Were very art-directioned, and when youve got your ideas, you can work quite rapidly and leave other people behind.

title: Award-Worthy Political Ads
description: The Times's David Chen hands out the unofficial awards for best political ads from the New York metropolitan area.

title: Making Music Like a Pro. Sort of.
description: Music-minded Mac users have GarageBand, which is bundled on all new Macs, to create and edit music. Windows computers, by comparison, dont include music-creation software, and that has left some users singing the blues. Unaccompanied.

title: Voters Are Encouraged to Report Any Problems With Machines
description: The citys new electronic voting machines, are definitely, definitely going to work fine on Election Day, but just in case, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg urged New Yorkers to call 311 and to use Twitter to report any and all problems they observe at voting sites.

title: Solar Power Projects Face Potential Hurdles
description: NIPTON, Calif.  The long-promised solar building boom in the desert Southwest is finally under way. Here in the Mojave Desert, a dice throw away from the Nevada border, giant road graders and a small army of laborers began turning the dirt for BrightSource Energys $2 billion Ivanpah project, the first large-scale solar thermal power plant to be built in the United States in two decades.

title: Coffeehouse Cool Amid the Stroller Scene
description: My mother never let me have Pop-Tarts  breakfast shouldnt involve frosting, was the theory  but she would approve of the version sold at Ted & Honey, a snug cafe on Clinton Street next to Cobble Hill Park in Brooklyn.

title: Soaring Above Indias Poverty, a 27-Story Home
description: MUMBAI  The newest and most exclusive residential tower for this citys superrich is a cantilevered sheath of steel and glass soaring 27 floors into the sky. The parking garage fills six levels. Three helipads are on the roof. There are terraces upon terraces, airborne swimming pools and hanging gardens in a Blade Runner-meets-Babylon edifice overlooking Indias most dynamic city.

title: Jazz Listings for Oct. 29-Nov. 4
description: Jazz

title: Must You Go?
description: Chapter 1

title: For Daimler, A Big Jump In Both Profit And Revenue
description: Daimler, the German maker of Mercedes-Benz cars, on Thursday reported a third-quarter net profit that handily beat market expectations and said it was raising its 2010 forecasts.

title: K.K.R. Leans Against Bid for Seagate
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is leaning against joining a bid for Seagate Technology, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday, as talks to take the storage company private hit snags.

title: Theater Listings: Oct. 29  Nov. 4
description: Theater

title: Nearly 3 Million Watch as Obama Visits Daily Show
description: About 2.8 million people tuned in for President Obamas interview on The Daily Show Wednesday night.

title: In Sheep, an Upside To Immune Weakness
description: A weak immune system makes an animal vulnerable to disease and parasites, but strangely, natural selection does not always weed out creatures that have what appear to be severe disadvantages, according to a new study.

title: House Tour: Strasburg, Pa.
description: WHAT Three-bedroom, one-bathroom farmhouse.

title: Bay Area Maps Out Bike-Sharing Effort
description: The San Francisco Bay area, long a center of cycling aficionados and Zipcar enthusiasts, is about to play host to a $7 million pilot bike-sharing program that will blend the two popular commuting alternatives.

title: Large Media Interest For Sanity Rally
description: More than 1,000 individuals applied for credentials to the Rally to Restore Sanity on Saturday in Washington, and various broadcast news organizations applied for as many as 40 passes to cover the event.

title: Upside-Down King as Art Muse
description: Any man who can thread 30 needles inside his stomach using a swallowed strand of black string is someone to be reckoned with. If he can also free himself after being tied in ropes and bound in a straitjacket, while dangling upside down 30 feet above Times Square, he might even possess abilities well out of the ordinary.

title: Movie Listings for Oct. 29-Nov. 4
description: Movies

title: A Tidy Home, Cluttered With Weighty Emotions
description: Grieving parents have become such a movie staple that the theme is now a demonstrable clich. Such grief isnt new in movies, but the preponderance of these stories  recent examples include The Lovely Bones, Creation, Antichrist, Ive Loved You So Long and the forthcoming Rabbit Hole  suggests that filmmakers believe that theres something compelling about the agony of others. To this strange canon add Welcome to the Rileys, about a middle-aged couple and the young stripper who comes between them with platform heels and the kind of sad eyes you used to see on the side of milk cartons.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Oct. 29-Nov. 4
description: Pop

title: Sarah Palin Offers Herself for 2012 Bid
description: Sarah Palin cracked open the door to a presidential bid just a little bit wider Thursday, telling Entertainment Tonight that she would run in 2012 if theres nobody else to do it.

title: Grant Wood
description: Sometime in the late 1930s, Grant Wood confided to his sister that he had a double. Mistaken for the artist by Wood's lifelong friends and even his Aunt Jeanette, this shadowy figure had appeared as far away as Omaha and as uncomfortably close as the painter's home in Iowa City. The story of Wood's doppelgnger appears only briefly in his sister Nan's memoirs  the reference is casual, the mystery left unsolved  yet it raises related questions about the impression Wood made on those who knew him best, and reveals, to use Nan's words, one of the many "strange by-products" of her brother's fame. Typically more amused than alarmed by his own celebrity, Wood confessed that in this instance "the matter makes me feel a little queer."

title: Streetscapes | Charles McKim
description: The reopening of the J.P. Morgan library, and a new book, cast a spotlight on the architect Charles McKim.

title: Gothic American
description: American Gothic has been described as the most reproduced painting in this country, which is not necessarily high praise. What artist would be elated to hear that one of his paintings had been appropriated in an advertising campaign for General Mills country cornflakes, or Coors beer? For most of his life, Grant Wood endured the scorn of leading art critics, who failed to recognize his refinement. He was known for one painting only, that image of a pale, homely farming pair posed in front of their white house, looking as if their dog just died.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Oct. 29-Nov. 4
description: Classical

title: Roger Rees to Replace Nathan Lane in The Addams Family
description: In one of the weightiest decisions facing a big-budget Broadway musical this season, the producers of The Addams Family announced Thursday that their leading man and biggest box-office draw, Nathan Lane, would be succeeded in the role of Gomez in March by Roger Rees, the Tony Award-winning theater and television actor.

title: Dance Listings for Oct. 29-Nov. 4
description: Dance

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 29-Nov. 4
description: Art

title: Ogled and Threatened on a Journey to Womanhood
description: Sex, death and schlock: Hlne Cattet and Bruno Forzanis Amer (the French word for bitter) is a surreal cinematic tone poem that pays slavering homage to Italian giallo horror films of the 1970s. Its three parts, which dissolve into one another, observe a female protagonist, Ana, played by three actresses  in childhood, adolescence and adulthood. The movie has almost no dialogue, and its cheesy soundtrack (some of it borrowed from vintage giallo films) is punctuated with aural shocks and effects, including heavy-breathing gasps.

title: Fiorina Back on the Trail
description: Carly Fiorina, the Republican candidate for Senate in California, was back on the campaign trail Thursday after being hospitalized.

title: Spare Times for Oct. 29-Nov. 4
description: Around Town

title: The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Trainer?
description: Lisa Grimm blogs about racing as Superfecta, and craft beer as WeirdBeerGirl. She is a contributing editor to Hello Race Fans.

title: Spare Times: For Childen for Oct. 29-Nov. 4
description: HALLOWHOA!

title: Dear FloFab: My Brothers Girlfriend Hijacked Thanksgiving
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: The Eye of Mrs. Vreeland
description: With Balenciaga: Spanish Master opening in mid-November at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in Manhattan, a new edition of Diana Vreelands Allure seems strangely well-timed. The first edition appeared in 1980, when Vreeland was special consultant to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she organized costume shows of Balenciaga and Yves Saint Laurent, among other legends. She worked on Allure with Christopher Hemphill, a process that took three years as Vreeland sought the elusive quality of personality in images of celebrities and models, in their gestures and sometimes violent expressions  a special condition for pictures of Maria Callas  and Mr. Hemphill did his best to oblige her. He recorded their conversations as they went along.

title: The Fall Auction Season
description: Before the big sales, the auction houses will be filled with multimillion-dollar masterpieces and are open to everyone, not just the art elite.

title: Other Peoples Children
description: My 6-year-old daughters best friend has a very physical younger brother, who often hits and pushes. Their mother has difficulty handling him. Recently, as we were walking down a flight of stairs, he pushed my daughter, almost causing her to fall. The mother told him meekly to stop. When he pushed her again, I grabbed him by the arm and yelled, No pushing on the steps! He cried. They left, and the mother has been unfriendly since. My wife thinks I should apologize, but I dont. Verdict?

title: Auction Houses as Museums: Art on Display Presale
description: THE New York City Marathon isnt the only race this town is bracing for. The beginning of November is also the start of the fall auction season, that twice-yearly endurance test when collectors and dealers from all over the world arrive here with comfortable (though fashionable) shoes to see and perhaps buy a painting, a drawing or a sculpture at the important Impressionist, Modern and contemporary art auctions.

title: Lions Gate Sues Icahn Over MGM Deal
description: Lions Gate Entertainment is still angry at the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, even if they now agree that the movie studio should merge with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

title: Photo of the Week
description: An Indian woman gets her hand decorated with henna paste as part of Karwa Chauth festivities, in Allahabad, India.

title: The Opulence of the Underworld
description: As visually sumptuous as it is dramatically inert, Persephone, a multimedia production from the Ridge Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, at least presents a lush feast of imagery for the eye to savor. At its bewitching best the production evokes a French neoclassical painting that has magically bloomed into three dimensions.

title: Tourism to Mexico Is Up
description: Undeterred by travel warnings and frightening headlines about safety in Mexico, an increasing number of international tourists are flying to the country, according to the Mexico Tourism Board. The number of international tourists who flew to Mexico from January to August increased 19 percent over the same period last year, according to the board, and most were from the United States. More than four million American citizens flew to Mexico, an increase of 15 percent over the same period last year, and about 61 percent of international tourists to Mexico are Americans.

title: The Caucus Click: Basehor, Kan.
Governors Aide Steps In for Ousted Environment Chief
description: Gov. David A. Paterson is replacing a Pete with a Peter. On Thursday he announced that his deputy secretary for the environment, Peter M. Iwanowicz, was taking over as acting commissioner of the state Department of Environmental Conservation after the dismissal of Alexander B. Grannis, better known as Pete.

title: The Whitneys Good Old Friend Is Joined by Some of His
description: Its Edward Hopper time again at the Whitney Museum of American Art. A little more than four years ago the museums 75th-anniversary celebration, Full House, devoted an entire floor to his work.

title: Period Rooms Take on a Modern Gloss
description: They have their charms, but the 18th-century period rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are not the first place visitors are likely to go. Stocked with antiques that barriers prevent you from studying up close and dimly lighted in the interest of historical authenticity, they may be invaluable for decorative-arts wonks, but they cant compete for popularity with the Impressionist and Ancient Egyptian galleries.

title: On Fortepiano, the Subtle Intimacy of Schumann
description: With Andras Schiffs extraordinary Schumann recital at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday still echoing in a listeners memory, the tenor Mark Padmore and the fortepianist Kristian Bezuidenhout offered a very different view of the composer on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall.

title: Forget a Playoff and Focus on Scheduling
description: College football fans across the country have been trying to make sense of the Bowl Championship Series standings since they first came out two weeks ago. Its like trying to understand Les Miles clock management.

title: Potash Shares Fall on Worries About BHP Deal
description: OTTAWA  Investors seem to be growing nervous about the future of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan.

title: Robopolls Significantly More Favorable to Republicans Than Traditional Surveys
description: I mentioned in passing in last nights post that surveys that use automated scripts rather than live interviewers  what are sometimes called robopolls  have shown more Republican-leaning results this year.Given how sensitive forecasts can be to fairly minor variations in the polling, it is worth going into more detail on this.

title: The Undead Are Undaunted and Unruly
description: The one good thing about the walking dead is that they dont drive.

title: Dude, Can I Have My Parody Back?
description: The country long ago stopped wondering whether a president demeans his office by appearing on a late-night comedy show. The more immediate question posed by President Obamas appearance on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart on Wednesday is whether a political satirist loses credibility when hobnobbing with a sitting president.

title: Bill Clinton Tried to Get Meek to Drop Out
description: Former President Bill Clinton last week tried to convince Kendrick Meek, the Democratic candidate for Senate in Florida, to drop out of the race  but Mr. Meek changed his mind at the last minute, a spokesman for Mr. Clinton said Thursday evening.

title: Tension and a Stern, Deep-Focus Note on Bass
description: Michael Formanek played the first notes at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, his double bass clamped in a bear hug. The notes came fast and hit squarely, with articulate force. Mr. Formanek was flanked by several partners  the alto saxophonist Tim Berne, the pianist Craig Taborn, the drummer Gerald Cleaver  but for the moment it was just his roomy, rubbery tone filling the air, preceding the formation of a theme.

title: A Very Zen Robust Emptiness, Set to a Work by Cage Inspired by Thoreau
description: Most choreographers find a style and stick with it, but in the case of the French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj, youre never exactly sure what youre going to get. There are the twists on classics (his Romo et Juliette is set in a police state) as well as the dances that are as overwrought as they are overworked (Paysage Aprs la Bataille, or Landscape After the Battle, which pitted Marcel Duchamp against Joseph Conrad).

title: Politics Podcast: Polls, the President and Jon Stewart
description: Click to Listen

title: A Familys Misery, a Composers Moment
description: It has been hard for supporters of New York City Opera to see this essential company humbled by administrative and financial crises in recent years. But George Steel, City Operas tireless general manager and artistic director, has argued that it is more important now than ever for the institution to have a clear mission and to do adventurous work.

title: Creating 'Monsters'
description: Gareth Edwards, the director of "Monsters," discusses how he also built the special effects for the film on his computer. The film is now on DVD.

title: Betrayed by a Mafia Underboss
description: Salvatore Vitale, a former underboss of the Bonanno crime family, helped put away 51 organized-crime figures through his testimony as a government witness, 38 of them for murders.

title: Assistance Trickles to Indonesian Islands
description: Indonesian rescue workers struggled to reach tsunami victims on Thursday as the death toll continued to rise from the natural disasters that hit the archipelago nation this week.

title: A Flawed Cement Recipe
description: After a well is drilled, engineers pump cement in to seal the gap between the drill hole and the pipe, preventing oil and gas from the reservoir from escaping to the surface. Recent tests showed that the cement mixture used in the Macondo well was unstable.

title: Potential Titian Buyers Get an Advance Look
description: Although images of Titians Sacra Conversazione: The Madonna and Child With Saints Luke and Catherine of Alexandria appear in much of the literature on that Renaissance master, the painting has not left the walls of its Swiss home for more than 30 years. The last time it made a public appearance was in 1978 at an exhibition in Geneva.

title: Worries Grow About BHP Deal for Potash
description: Investors seem to be growing nervous about the future of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, The New York Times reports.

title: In Trilogys Finale, Tough Girl Rages Against Villains of Society
description: Lisbeth Salander can finally wipe the blood off her face. After being repeatedly beaten and raped, tied up like a pig being prepped for the knife and shot one, two, three times (in one go), the little woman with the large tattoo can sit back in her cool digs and enjoy a much deserved smoke. Its been a long time coming, literally, what with seven hours of art house pulp craziness  Nazis and child molesters, an evil psychiatrist and a prostitution ring  which, among other things, proves that women in trouble never go out of style.

title: A Luxe Designer, Restored to Glory
description: Joseph Urban, the Vienna-born architect and interior and set designer, was so renowned in the 1930s that when he was dying of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, he checked in as Mr. John Smith to keep away gossipers and stalkers.

title: Blagojevich Defenders Looking For Help
description: As they hunker down for a long winter sorting through the evidence from former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevichs first trial, members of a thinned-out defense team are hoping that free help is on the way.

title: Judicial Retention Vote Could Change Course of Politics for Decade
description: Its fitting that a $150-a-head fund-raiser for Thomas Kilbride last week was in the basement of a Loop restaurant and that most of the attendees cant even vote for him.

title: Preckwinkle Promotes Her Independence as Some Question It
description: It is a longstanding practice for Cook Countys Democratic Party heavyweights to dismiss would-be reformers as weaklings and phonies.

title: Citys Skyscraper Title Is Going, Going ...
description: Chicago is facing another Second City moment: It soon will not be able to boast about having the tallest building in America.

title: A Detective Who Solves Crimes for a Living, and as a Pastime
description: In the newest edition of his Biographical Dictionary of Film David Thomson writes that the French filmmaker Claude Chabrol could go on forever, the last great pro. The book had already gone to press when Chabroldied, at 80, on Sept. 12, but the posthumous American release of his last film, Inspector Bellamy, seems, if anything, to support Mr. Thomsons judgment. The ease and professionalism that distinguished this prolific directors later work is very much in evidence, as is an insouciant attitude, at once resigned and dismissive, toward mortality. The first thing you see is a graveyard, and the first sound you hear is whistling.

title: Giants, Rangers Win
description: Despite somewhat lackluster ratings for Game 1 of the World Series between the San Francisco Giants and the Texas Rangers, Foxs coverage, amid its dispute with Cablevision, led the night in prime time on Wednesday. Final audience figures for the game were not immediately available, but Nielsens preliminary estimates for the broadcast were considerably below those for last years first game between the New York Yankees and the Philadelphia Phillies, which drew 19.5 million viewers, and closer to Foxs Game 1 ratings in 2008 (14.6 million), when the Phillies played the Tampa Bay Rays. CBS trailed Fox to rank second over all, garnering 11.6 million at 8 p.m. for Survivor: Nicaragua followed by Criminal Minds at 9 (13.9 million) and The Defenders at 10 (9.9 million). ABC was third with Halloween-themed episodes of its comedy lineup including The Middle (9.4 million) and Modern Family (13.1 million), both of which attracted their largest audiences ever. NBC finished fourth with reruns from 9 to 11 following Undercovers at 8 (5.4 million).

title: Vow Against Attack Ads Resonates in Colorado
description: IDAHO SPRINGS, Colo.  In his appearances around the state, the No. 1 applause line for John Hickenlooper, the Democratic candidate for Colorados governor, comes when he talks about running a positive campaign.

title: In Sharp Rise, 47 City Schools May Close Over Performance
description: The New York City Department of Education said Thursday that up to 47 schools could be closed for poor performance, a huge increase from previous years if all remain on the chopping block.

title: Giants Place Kiwanuka on Injured Reserve
description: When the Giants announced Oct. 1 that Mathias Kiwanuka was out indefinitely with a neck injury, it was an ominous sign for a team, and a defense, seemingly on the verge of disarray.

title: Beyond ABCs of Lady Gaga to the Sociology of Fame
description: Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta may not sound famous, but the University of South Carolina is offering a course next spring devoted to her  and the sociology of fame.

title: 4-Year-Old Can Be Sued, Judge Rules in Bike Case
description: Citing cases dating back as far as 1928, a judge has ruled that a young girl accused of running down an elderly woman while racing a bicycle with training wheels on a Manhattan sidewalk two years ago can be sued for negligence.

title: Refreshing Series Provides Hope
description: San Francisco

title: Razors? We Dont Need No Stinkin Razors
description: The San Francisco Giants have undergone major growth and change over the season  in their play, sure, but maybe even more significantly in their hair.

title: From the Past, a Future Blank and Open
description: One interpretation of The Kids Grow Up  a plausible if not necessarily generous reading of the film  is that its about how difficult it can be to live with a documentary filmmaker. Or at least with Doug Block, the director of this one.

title: Indulging an Obsession With Motors and Muscle
description: Every afternoon in the affluent suburb of Armonk, N.Y., an indistinguishable blur of black sport utility vehicles and silver sedans line up outside Byram Hills High School to retrieve students.

title: Election Is Critical, but Try Telling That to Gay Voters
description: Proposition 8, the referendum that ended same-sex marriage in California in 2008, is not officially on the ballot again this Election Day. Gay rights advocates say it might as well be.

title: Republican Sees Hope for Victory in San Jose
description: Larry Pegram is trying to mount a comeback.

title: Criticized in Years Past, The Giants G.M. Rebounds
description: From 2004 through 2009, a grim six-year run of playoff-free baseball in San Francisco, Giants fans routinely took to the airways to call for the head of General Manager Brian Sabean.

title: G.M. Pares Down Its Balance Sheet
description: General Motors has chosen an ideal time to pare down its balance sheet. Executives are gearing up to go on the road after next weeks elections to start promoting the automakers shares ahead of a mid-November initial public offering. Reducing its balance sheet by $11 billion should encourage prospective investors to focus less on G.M.s financial liabilities and more on its core asset.

title: Bernankes Reluctance to Speak Out Rankles Some
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is all but certain next week to begin a multibillion-dollar effort to coax the recovery along, but privately, Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman, worries that more is needed to turn the sluggish economy around and revive employment.

title: Sales Rise 23% at Dow, Easing Loss in Earnings
description: The Dow Chemical Company said Thursday that its third-quarter earnings fell less than analysts had expected as sales of specialty products and commodity plastics increased.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,340 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: The Tricky Business of Halloween Sunday
description: The date of Halloween has always been one of the easy ones to remember: Oct. 31, plain and simple. No first Tuesday-after-the-first-Monday-of-November nonsense (thats Election Day), no fourth-Thursday-in-November (Thanksgiving), no second-Monday-in-October (if you dont know, ask a Canadian). Just the last day of October.

title: From a Universe of Trash, Recycling Art and Hope
description: We are not pickers of garbage; we are pickers of recyclable materials, Tio, an impoverished Brazilian catadore, or trash picker, declares to a talk-show host in Lucy Walkers inspiring documentary Waste Land.

title: In House Race in Texas, a Spotlight on the Hispanic Vote
description: SAN ANTONIO  Representative Ciro D. Rodriguez, a Democrat from the working-class streets of south San Antonio, was buttonholing voters outside a library where early polling was being held, asking them for support in flawless Spanish.

description: An assortment of health studies released this week are providing near-incontrovertible evidence that New York might be the most researched city on Earth.

title: Roy Halladay and Cliff Lee Were No Match for Weak-Hitting Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  How is it that the San Francisco Giants put some dents in Roy Halladay in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series against Philadelphia and then did the same thing on Wednesday night to Cliff Lee in Game 1 of the World Series?

title: A Novel Whose Plot Seems Oddly Familiar
description: WASHINGTON  A mysterious hedge fund takes aim at weak currencies from Colombia to Ukraine. Finally, it succeeds in Turkey and a panic ensues as investors dump government debt, the currency dwindles and Ankara defaults on its obligations.

description: Victor Maynard, the very proper English assassin for hire at the center of Wild Target, is nothing if not professional. He approaches his work with meticulous attention to protocol and detail, and also with unmistakable panache.

title: Region Fouled by Trash Loses Faith in Berlusconi
description: TERZIGNO, Italy  In 2008, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi won the national elections in large part by promising to clean up the garbage that had been piling up on the streets of Naples. With much fanfare, he called in the army, opened new dumping sites, built a waste treatment plant and declared victory.

title: Dont Aid Hariri Tribunal, Hezbollah Warns
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The leader of Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, issued a stern warning on Thursday night against any cooperation with the international tribunal investigating the 2005 assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, putting new pressure on Lebanons fragile coalition government.

description: NEW HAVEN  Even his own brother would not defend the Cheshire killer.

title: Brenda, Eddie, Billy and Friends Bury a Ballpark
description: History isnt just a bunch of facts. For those who live through it, it is a collective experience  a shared mood, if you will  that is so personal, changeable and complex that it cant be fully conveyed to someone who wasnt around when the events took place.

title: Killing for the Mob, Then Decimating It in Court
description: Of all the life lessons that Salvatore Vitale took from a boyhood friend he idolized, two of them became practically second nature: as a child, he was taught how to swim; as an adult, he was instructed how to kill.

title: F.D.A. Rejects Qnexa, a Third Weight-Loss Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration rejected another new diet pill on Thursday, the latest setback in the quest to develop treatments for overweight Americans amid the nations obesity epidemic.

title: Obama Visit to Indonesia Will Include a Speech
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will visit one of the worlds largest mosques and deliver a major address to the people of Indonesia when he visits that island nation next month, in a  long-delayed trip that White House officials say will mix childhood reflections with outreach to the Muslim world.

title: The Three Amigos
description: This is the seventh in a series.

title: F.B.I. Examining Prison Ward Death
description: Federal prosecutors and the F.B.I. have opened a criminal investigation into the death of a mentally disturbed man whose bruised body was found in a holding cell in the prison ward at Bellevue Hospital Center after a struggle with correction officers.

title: On Wall Street: All Reward, No Risk
description: For the life of me, I cant figure out why Wall Street bankers, traders and executives get paid so much money year after year for doing jobs that rarely require them to innovate, enlighten or put their own capital at risk, and have the nasty habit of periodically sinking our economy.

title: Even the Tiniest Actions Can Change Entire Lives
description: A Small Act would have been a pretty good documentary even if things had merely gone the way the filmmakers probably envisioned at the start of the project. But when unforeseen developments rewrote the script, as it were, the film took on a depth that made it all the more remarkable.

title: Path From Corner Office to Political Office Eludes 2 G.O.P. Women
description: LOS ANGELES  At one point, it appeared that 2010 might be the year of the female Republican chief executive in California. Two of them  Meg Whitman, a candidate for governor, and Carly Fiorina, a candidate for Senate  have presented themselves as credible, competent and wealthy products of the corporate world in a state that, while decidedly Democratic, nonetheless seemed tired of the status quo and hungry for reform.

title: U.S. Accuses Syria of Destabilizing Lebanon
description: The United States unleashed a unusually brusque diplomatic fusillade at Syria on Thursday, with Susan E. Rice, the American ambassador to the United Nations, accusing Damascus of working in cahoots with Iran to destabilize Lebanon by arming Hezbollah with ever more potent weapons.

title: Remembering Rabin, Some See His Legacy Fading
description: TEL AVIV  In the 15 years since Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated by a Jewish militant after a peace rally here, blood seeping onto a song sheet in his breast pocket as he lost consciousness, his legacy in Israel has seemed clear  warrior turned peacemaker, symbol of a tough nation with an outstretched hand.

title: Betrayed by an Underboss
description: Salvatore Vitale, a former underboss of the Bonanno crime family, helped put away 51 organized-crime figures through his testimony as a government witness. Among those imprisoned were these five crime family bosses:
