title: Lottery Numbers
Churchill During the War, Armed With Inspiration
description: Winston Churchill: Walking With Destiny is a handsomely produced, television-scale documentary with a split personality. Over all its a glowing biography of Churchill the wartime prime minister, with sonorous (and nearly constant) narration by Ben Kingsley, extracts from the famous speeches and periodic emotional crescendos  Dunkirk, the Battle of Britain, the Blitz  marked by surging strings and crashing cymbals. No mention here of the undeniably great leaders imperialist dark side.

title: Kiwanukas Time With Giants Could Be Over
description: When the Giants announced Oct. 1 that Mathias Kiwanuka was out indefinitely with a neck injury, it was an ominous sign for a team, and a defense, seemingly on the verge of disarray.

title: Searching for Stability
description: The heroine of Jolene, a freckled nymphet with tumbling ginger curls, might well have been the inspiration for Dolly Partons famous song. Seduced at 16 by a smitten uncle-in-law (Dermot Mulroney), Jolene (Jessica Chastain), a survivor of sequential foster-home abuse, embarks on a 10-year search for stability and happiness.

title: Senate Update: Washington Is the New Florida
description: Back during the 2008 presidential campaign, we coined a term called tipping-point states. A tipping-point state was one that might potentially put Barack Obama (or John McCain) over the top to his 270th electoral vote, thereby winning him the presidency. States like Colorado, Virginia, Florida and Ohio were ranked highly by this metric.

title: U.S. Judges Ruling May Return a Convicted Terrorist to Prison
description: A judge in Manhattan has ruled that a convicted terrorist who was given a chance to rebuild his life after cooperating with the government violated the terms of his release by possessing a handgun and trying to buy an AK-47 assault rifle.

title: A Little Bollywood, a Lot American Indie
description: Walkaway, a breezily schematic Indian movie about relationships in the big city  New York, that is  feels like a hybrid: a little Bollywood, a lot American indie from the lets-talk-about-romance division. The film mostly eschews the pumped-up emotionalism of Hindi movies and very nearly dispenses with Hindi too. (English is mostly spoken here, with smatterings of French, Tamil and, yes, Hindi.)

title: Facing Off Against a Childhood Dream
description: Giants first baseman Aubrey Huff went to high school in Fort Worth, Tex., and wanted to be a pitcher when he grew up. His favorite player was Nolan Ryan, and he said he had tickets to one of Ryans historic performances.

title: As Reid Falters, Schumer Subtly Stands in the Wings
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Charles E. Schumer shipped $500,000 to Nevada in recent weeks to help Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader and Mr. Schumers political patron and close friend, as he fights for his political life.

title: Obamas Re-election Could Be Tied to Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  The most politically important state in America, at least in the eyes of the White House, is Ohio. President Obama arrives this weekend for one last rally of the campaign season, his 12th visit since taking office and his second in only two weeks.

title: Bill Clinton Urged Florida Democrat to Quit Bid
description: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton last week almost succeeded in persuading Kendrick B. Meek, the Democratic nominee for the Senate in Florida, to drop out of the three-way race  but Mr. Meek changed his mind at the last minute, a spokesman for Mr. Clinton said Thursday evening.

title: Paladino Calls Senator Gillibrand Schumers Little Girl
description: There he goes again.

title: Inquiry Finds U.S. Official Set Up Spy Ring in Asia
description: WASHINGTON  A senior Pentagon official broke Defense Department rules and deliberately misled senior generals when he set up a network of private contractors to spy in Afghanistan and Pakistan beginning last year, according to the results of an internal government investigation.

title: Killing Prompts Push for Bodega Owners to Get Gun Permits
description: Fernando Mateo has mostly garnered attention for two causes: ensuring the safety of livery drivers and getting illegal guns off the streets.

description: Images from Signature Theater Companys revival of Angels in America.

title: This Time, the Angel Is in the Details
description: The angel has landed again, and shes looking a little less fierce. When one of the title characters in Tony Kushners epic Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes hit town 17 years ago  crashing through the ceiling of a Manhattan apartment  she wore an intimidating scowl, the kind that makes mortals quake.

description: ATLANTA  Federal vaccine advisers on Thursday began the delicate task of deciding whether a vaccine against sexually transmitted infections that can result in genital warts and cancers should be used more widely in boys and young men.

title: Referendum Sticks Voters With a Fork
description: For New York voters, the referendum that awaits on Tuesday is a splendid example of Mortons fork.

title: Report Shows Plight of Puerto Rican Youth
description: Theirs was the first Latino group to settle in New York City in large numbers. Most speak English, and they are United States citizens, entitled to the benefits and security that new immigrants can only dream of.

title: Details Emerge on Man Charged in Plot on Subway
description: Farooque Ahmed, who was accused of trying to help men he believed to be militants plot bombings at subway stations in the Washington-area, told an undercover F.B.I. agent that he had used firearms, and practiced at a shooting range, according to an affidavit filed in federal court on Thursday as part of a search warrant. Mr. Ahmed, a 34-year-old naturalized American citizen of Pakistani origin who lives in Ashburn, Va., was arrested in a sting operation on Wednesday. He also told the agent that he planned to go fight Americans in Afghanistan and Pakistan, after traveling to Saudi Arabia for the hajj, a Muslim pilgrimage. Federal agents began tracking Mr. Ahmed in January, after he and a friend spoke of their interest in carrying out jihad.

title: Putins Left Eye Appears to Need a Cold Compress
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin has long cultivated a tough-guy image, whether going shirtless on horseback or tossing aside a foe on the judo mat.

title: Civilians Falling Victim to Mexico Drug War
description: MEXICO CITY  During its nearly four-year crackdown on major drug trafficking organizations, the Mexican government has repeated the mantra that most of the nearly 30,000 people killed have some association with the illicit trade.

title: Ratings Suffer Without a New York Team
description: The audience for this years World Series is looking like the one for the 2008 Series.

title: As Ohio Goes...
description: President Obama makes his 12th trip to Ohio, a Republican in the Ohio governors seat could make his re-election to the presidency in 2012 that much more complicated.

title: Knick Earns a Big Role by Doing Little Things
description: BOSTON  When Landry Fields is talking basketball, his speech mirrors his game: steady, measured, basic, effective, rarely colorful or provocative.

title: No Justification
description: Two years ago, when a splintered Supreme Court approved lethal injection as a means of execution in Baze v. Rees, Justice John Paul Stevens made a prophecy. Instead of ending the controversy, he said, the ruling would raise questions about the justification for the death penalty itself. Since then, evidence has continued to mount, showing the huge injustice of the death penalty  and the particular barbarism of this form of execution.

title: Divided We Fail
description: Barring a huge upset, Republicans will take control of at least one house of Congress next week. How worried should we be by that prospect?

description: Albany needs sweeping change. Gerrymandering and anything-goes campaign finance rules guarantee that most of the hacks will be back next year, working to ensure nothing ever changes.

title: Looking Ahead to the 2012 Race
description: The 2012 presidential campaign is well under way  if President Obamas effort to save Ohios governor, or the train of Republican contenders rolling through Iowa, are any indication. This week alone, former Speaker Newt Gingrich, former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi and Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana are scheduled to campaign on behalf of Republicans in Iowa, and several others, including Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota and former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, have made recent appearances.

title: The Latest Gulf Outrage
description: We have known for some time that a flaw in the cement used on BPs Macondo well contributed to the disastrous April 20 explosion in the Gulf of Mexico. What we did not know, until now, was that both BP and Halliburton, the company BP hired to cement the well, appear to have been aware that the mixture was prone to failure  and went ahead anyway.

title: Wheres the Game?
description: More than three million cable subscribers in the New York City area couldnt watch the first game of the World Series on Wednesday night. Thats because of the continuing brawl between Cablevision Systems and the Fox networks over who should get a bigger share of subscribers fees. As of our deadline Thursday, the blackout was still going on.

title: Hall Thompson, Who Stirred Golf Controversy, Dies at 87
description: Hall Thompson, the founder of the championship-hosting Shoal Creek Country Club in a Birmingham, Ala., suburb, who sparked a nationwide controversy 20 years ago when he said the club would not be pressured into admitting black members, died Wednesday. He was 87.

The wooden courtroom chairs, with rods underneath the seats for men to hang their cowboy hats, are gathering dust.

title: The G.O.P.s Moneyman
description: Over the last decade, two Republicans with the last name Perry have dominated the Texas political landscape. One is Rick, the states longest-serving governor. The other is Bob (no relation), the states largest individual political donor during that time. There is no close second.

title: Serbia: Reward for Capture of Mladic Increased
description: Days after the European Union urged Serbia to increase its efforts to capture Ratko Mladic, left, the fugitive accused of masterminding the massacre at Srebrenica in 1995, officials there increased the reward for information leading to his capture. The government said in a statement on Thursday that it had raised the reward to $14 million from $1.4 million. Serbia is determined to get rid of that burden, Verica Kalanovic, the nations infrastructure minister, said, according to Reuters.

title: The Quiet of War
description: To most people, the word war is likely to conjure dramatic images of combat. Soldiers ducking for cover. Helicopters swooping low. Medics treating the critically wounded. But for deployed troops, life at war is also filled with many quieter moments. Mundane, perhaps; but those moments may carry powerful memories, bitter and fond. They may evoke a vivid sense of place. They may even define a deployment in some intensely personal way.

description: Hollywood, Calif., May 29--Fanny Brice, stage and screen comedienne and the Baby Snooks of radio, died at 11:15 A. M. today at the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. Her age was 59.

title: Other Ace Puts the Giants in Command
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Giants best-known starting pitcher keeps his unruly mop of black hair beneath a dirt-stained cap he has worn every game since his rookie season of 2007. Their closer dyes his beard black, and his hair marries a Mohawk and a mullet. After each save, his arms contort violently into a symbol of an X. Im just trying to fit in with these morons, first baseman Aubrey Huff said.

description: Credit Suisse jumped to the No. 1 adviser on consumer mergers and acquisitions this year, putting it on pace to return to the top five dealmakers for the first time in eight years, Bloomberg News reported.

title: What Would You Ask President Obama?

title: European Central Bank Still Props Up Banks
description: Greek, Irish and Spanish banks are falling behind their counterparts across Europe in reducing their dependence on emergency central bank financing because they cant find investors willing to buy their bonds, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Polls Track Governors Races
description: A Field Poll out Thursday on the California governors race shows Jerry Brown, the Democrat, with a 10-point lead among likely voters over Meg Whitman, the Republican and former eBay executive. That marks a significant change from the last Field Poll, in September, which found the two candidates tied. Mr. Brown is helped in the latest poll by support among independents, women and Latinos. The poll was conducted Oct. 14 to 26 among 1,092 likely voters, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

title: Creeper! Rando! Sketchball!
description: When Liana Roux, a junior at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, was reading a Facebook event page for her friends birthday party recently, she noticed a terse proviso at the end of the announcement: No randos. The friend wanted only people she knew to come to her party and thus sought to bar any random strangers, or randos, in collegiate parlance.

title: A Creative Way to Sell Your Business
description: One of the positive byproducts of this recession may be that it has forced many of us to consider different ways to operate our enterprises. Business as usual has been replaced with ingenuity, fresh thinking and alternative solutions.

title: Putting Volcker Back Into the Volcker Rule
description: Paul A. Volcker is looking to steer the rule that bears his name.

title: Iran Says Its Ready to Return to Nuclear Talks
description: BRUSSELS  Iran said Friday that it would resume talks with the West about its nuclear program in November, according to officials at the European Union.

title: North and South Korea Exchange Border Fire
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korean troops fired two machine-gun bursts at a South Korean guard post across their heavily militarized border on Friday night, and soldiers from the South returned fire with three rifle shots, a Defense Ministry official said in Seoul.

title: Warren Says Financial Industry Still Aims to Block
description: The financial industry continues trying to thwart the Obama administrations effort to set up an effective consumer protection agency, though one is needed now more than ever, the new consumer czar, Elizabeth Warren, pictured, charged on Thursday.

description: United States home foreclosure sales are slowing in the states hardest-hit by the real estate crash as banks review their practices and delay seizures, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Valuing the Taxpayers A.I.G. Stake
description: Taxpayers have an unusual reason to watch stock prices this fall. The Treasury is in the process of selling its stakes in three of the companies that it spent the most money bailing out in 2008 and 2009, and much will depend on how those stocks perform in coming months.

description: The United States economy is a bit like a jetliner short on fuel these days, waiting for something to give it the oomph needed for takeoff.

description: BEIJING  Liang Congjie, who was one of the founders of Chinas first legally recognized environmental group and who came to be honored by international agencies and the Chinese government alike, died here on Thursday. He was 78.

title: EMI Trial Judge Slams Lawyers for Hands
description: In a startling sideshow to the courtroom battle over the buyout of EMI Group, Judge Jed S. Rakoff, pictured, erupted at lawyers for Guy Hands on Thursday, saying that he had serious questions about whether an attempt was made to mislead the court over the job title of a colleague of Mr. Handss.

title: Khan to Settle S.E.C. Galleon Charges for $1.9 Million
description: Roomy Khan, one of the key witnesses in the governments insider trading case against the former hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam, has agreed to pay nearly $1.9 million to settle civil fraud charges filed against her, according to a court document.

title: Defiant Bernie Ecclestone Turns 80
description: There was a great deal of publicity surrounding Bernie Ecclestones 80th birthday last Sunday before the Korean Grand Prix. But Thursday, in fact, was his actual birthday. But as he said, What difference does it make?

title: Defiant Bernie Ecclestone Turns 80
description: There was a great deal of publicity surrounding Bernie Ecclestones 80th birthday last Sunday before the Korean Grand Prix. But Thursday, in fact, was his actual birthday. But as he said, What difference does it make?

title: Pacino Wants to Be Fair to Shakespeare
description: SOME stars get their names above the title. Others appear in lights on the marquee. Then theres Al Pacino. A giant photo of his weary-looking face in the new production of The Merchant of Venice towers above West 44th Street, high above signs for Phantom of the Opera and American Idiot. The Public Theater production of "Merchant," staged by Daniel Sullivan at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, received glowing reviews last summer, but this simple, unadorned portrait explains why the show is transferring to Broadway at the Broadhurst Theater: star power, pure and simple. And, sure enough, ticket sales have already been brisk.

title: How the Horror Can Serve the Hilarity
description: NEAR the close of The Coward, Nick Joness play set amid the dueling culture of 18th-century England, most of the characters lie prostrate on the stage. Dead or dying, they whimper and groan as they smear the set with blood. A father takes a tender farewell of his son. Two lovers bid adieu. One noblewoman declares poignantly: If I die, I die for something larger. For honor. Then she uses a handkerchief to dab at the viscera spilling from the front of her dress.

title: By Any Means Necessary: Gawker and the ODonnell Post
description: We get it. Its a dirty, terrible world out there and anything and everyone is fair game. So when some guy was willing to trash Christine ODonnell, the Republican candidate for United States Senate in Delaware, for the small money Gawker paid for the scoop, it was just one more step down the road to clickable perdition. Except even as she was being fed into the digital wood chipper, various other parties on the Web began to step back and wonder why a pretty average night between seemingly normal people was being pathologized.

title: Night Watch: One of the Most Interesting Elections
description: In my lifetime, this is one of the most interesting elections Ive seen.

title: Me and Dr. Fager
description: Joe Meagher writes from New Hampshire, where he hopes against hope that his beloved California Golden Bears will somehow make it to the Rose Bowl before hes forced to leave this mortal coil.

title: Samurai Shopper | Decades Dance
description: Few shopping outposts in America possess the pampered-poodle patina of Decades, a vintage shop on Melrose Avenue that dresses Hollywoods fish-lipped set in mint-condition, 20th-century couture. DecadesTwo, established in 1999 as a 21st Century designer consignment shop  not to be confused with the designer-purgatory pit stop Century 21  was the sequel. And last week, DecadesTwo, the first internationally branded luxury consignment business with sales surpassing $5 million (whew), introduced DecadesTwo.1, an e-commerce Web site for those who prefer to rock vintage boots that are not made for walking without risking a single blister.

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Charles Burns on Xed Out
description: Five years after his graphic-novel magnum opus Black Hole, Charles Burns returns to the medium with his first full-color work, Xed Out, which lands at No. 1 on the hardcover list.

title: Nocturnalist | Terror at Blood Manor
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Google Ventures Invests in HomeAway
description: Google Ventures, the investment fund that Google started last year, is getting into vacation rentals.

title: Labor Bill Promised for Hobbit Films Is Passed
description: Though it doesnt take particularly large obstacles to impede a hobbit, a film adaptation of that J. R. R. Tolkien novel cleared a crucial hurdle on Friday as New Zealands government passed a new labor bill promised to the Hobbit filmmakers, despite the objections of some legislators, Reuters reported.

title: The Long and Short of It
description: When Workforce muscled his way to the front of the field to win this years Prix de lArc de Triomphe, he had 800 meters to do it. When he runs at Churchill Downs, hell have less than half that distance to get the job done, since the home stretch there is only 376 meters long.

title: Wind Power Growth Slows to 2007 Levels
description: In July, the American Wind Energy Association reported that it was having a lousy year. It appears the third quarter of 2010 wasnt much better.

title: Combat Duty, Close to Home
description: Returning from an assignment in Brooklyn on Nov. 5, 1988, the photographer ngel Franco had a message for his editors on the picture desk of The New York Times. He added it to the caption notes on the back of the 8-by-10 contact sheets with the days take: Important. Please do not show faces. Puts our source in danger. Life and death situation. For both of us. Our colleagues at Lens remind us with a gallery of photos from the 1960s through the 1980s that When Drugs Ruled New York Streets, a picture assignment could be a tricky  and risky  business.

title: Nudge the Vote
description: Over the past few days, thousands of Democratic-leaning voters nationwide  including the young people, minorities and unmarried women who were a crucial part of Barack Obamas 2008 coalition and whom the party is desperate to rouse again on Tuesday  received a message in their mailboxes that effectively said: were keeping an eye on you. The mailers are the handiwork of Hal Malchow, a political consultant who is acting on a theory that first intrigued him four years ago. Before the 2006 Michigan gubernatorial primary, three political scientists isolated a group of voters and mailed them copies of their voting histories, listing the elections in which they participated and those they missed. Included were their neighbors voting histories, too, along with a warning: after the polls closed, everyone would get an updated set.

title: Be Alert to Protect Yourself Against Medicare Fraud
description: THIS month, more than 40 members of what is said to be an Armenian-American crime syndicate were arrested and charged in an extensive Medicare fraud. Prosecutors say the suspects stole the identities of doctors and thousands of patients, using them at more than 100 bogus health clinics in 25 states to bill Medicare for more than $100 million.

title: Hondas Latest Weapon in the Battle of the Minivans
description: THE conventional wisdom is that the minivan is on life support, a victim of drive-by shootings by marauding gangs of part-truck, part-car crossover wagons. But some automakers just wont pull the plug.

title: Pregame Huddle: Who Stays Undefeated?
description: Missouri, Michigan State and Oregon are all undefeated, but all face tough opponents in the coming weeks.

description: An actor in the coming Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark was injured last week during a demonstration of one of the many flying and acrobatic effects in the $60 million show, whose creators have promised an unprecedented aerial spectacle while also going to lengths to ensure safety.

description: The new Odyssey replaces a version that made its debut as a 2005 model.

title: New York Outleans Boston at the Tape
description: Just because the Yankees and the Red Sox failed to advance to the World Series this year does not mean now is not a good time to reflect on the heated sports rivalry between the two cities. New York and Boston feature two of the most prominent and historic marathons in the world. With the New York City Marathon days away, here is a comparison of the two classic competitions presented as a contest from someone who has run both races from the middle of the pack.

title: Friday Reading: The Latest on Verizon Data Charges
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: A Case for Rangers to Start Julio Borbon in Center
description: To the extent that Rangers Manager Ron Washingtons choices in his outfield have been discussed at all during this World Series, the debate has focused on the trade-off between Vladimir Guerrero and David Murphy in right field.

title: Suzuki Recalling 70,000 SX4s Because Mirrors May Fall Off
description: Suzuki is recalling almost 70,000 SX4 compact cars because the outside mirrors may fall off. The recall covers some 2007 SX4 hatchbacks, all 20089 SX4 hatchbacks and sedans and some 2010 hatchbacks and sedans. Suzuki told the agency it became aware of the problem in 2009 after discovering a supplier had stopped using thread lock on the screws.

title: Tractors Are Vintage, but Ready for Dirty Work
description: FROM Pebble Beach, Calif., to Greenwich, Conn., and at dozens of picturesque settings in between, shows for vintage vehicles offer enthusiasts the opportunity to rub elbows with historic machinery in country-club surroundings.

title: Union Effort Is Grooming Candidates in New Jersey
description: SADDLE BROOK, N.J.  Ballots cast throughout New Jersey on Tuesday will list hundreds of candidates, their parties and the offices they seek. But for 53 candidates, the ballots will not say one of the most important things they have in common: union-approved.

title: More Closing Jitters
description: THE final weeks before a mortgage closing can be nerve-racking for any borrower, but new guidelines from Fannie Mae calling for an 11th-hour inspection of finances may mean even more headaches.

title: The New Momism
description: They make for strange bedfellows, Sarah Palin, leading her pack of mama grizzlies, and Michelle Obama, now touring the country on behalf of beleaguered, largely female Democratic candidates as the self-described mom in chief. The former beauty-pageant flutist dead set on undoing health care reform and the working-class Harvard law grad intent on consolidating her husbands legislative triumphs couldnt be further apart in their political goals or in their personal histories. But each is doing the mom thing  big time  tapping a vein of sentiment and belief, practicing a special form of political sympathetic magic, hoping clearly that by invoking the image, inveighing the glorious beloved power of all thats maternal, they will warm and rally the hearts of voters enough to get them to the polls and determine the outcome of the midterm elections.

title: What Were Reading
description: Canadian Press: Biggest lobster harvest ever for Prince Edward Island.  Sam Sifton

title: The New Momism
description: Are mothers, de facto, warmer and wiser than everyone else? Are politicians more qualified for being moms?

title: Seeing Red
description: Images from the 2010 Red Power Roundup of tractors in Laporte, Ind.

title: Kerry Fraser Hated You, and Other Revelations
description: Kerry Fraser has always been a polarizing figure. Whether its a controversial call or his recent hard-line stance on head shots, the N.H.L.s all-time leader in games refereed can be counted on to generate a passionate reaction among hockey fans.

title: Finished Probation in 80s, but Now Facing Deportation
description: Eligio Valerio left his home in Washington Heights before dawn on Oct. 20, as he does every morning, to begin his shift driving a livery cab.

title: Letters: What Does He Do Now?
description: Peter Baker, in his insightful appraisal of the president, quotes Governor Rendell of Pennsylvania as grading him D-plus or C-minus on communication. Alas, this may be true. But it is very odd indeed, given that a major factor in Obamas election was his extraordinary ability to communicate. Here, many of us thought when he was elected, was an ace of eloquence. Since then, it appears he has neglected the legendary bully pulpit to his great disadvantage. Perhaps in the next two years he ought to take a page from F.D.R.s notebook and begin a series of regular fireside chats on television to speak directly to the American people.

title: Lights Go Down in San Francisco
description: Remember how the baseball cognoscenti waxed poetic about how thrilling this World Series was going to be, finally free of the evil influence of the big-money behemoths, allowed to be fun, competitive, well pitched to the extreme?

title: Casting a Vote for Engine No. 2
description: TESTED: 2010 Cadillac SRX Turbo AWD Premium

title: Toying With the Stars
description: As the host of Fashion Group Internationals annual Night of Stars awards gala, Simon Doonan traditionally delivers an opening monologue that lightly, and hysterically, skewers the honorees. For this years routine, at the event on Wednesday night, Mr. Doonan revisited a subject from one of his New York Observer columns  in which he discovered the joys of an online spoof called the Jersey Shore Nickname Generator, which randomly assigns silly MTV-style aliases for anyone.

title: Egyptian Author Objects to Hebrew Translation of His Novel
description: Alaa Al Aswany, the best-selling Arabic-language novelist, has objected to the translation of one of his novels into Hebrew as protest of normalized relations between Israel and Arab nations, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Drunken Driver Sentenced in Death of 11-Year-Old Girl
description: A Bronx woman was sentenced on Friday to 4 to 12 years in prison for a drunken-driving accident that led to the death of an 11-year-old girl.

title: 2010 Cadillac SRX

description: Readers sent in photographs of their Halloween costumes for this year and their favorites from years past.

description: TORONTO

title: Letter: The Sound of Spirit
description: I am a great admirer of Arvo Prts music in spite of the mystic Christianity surrounding it. To my ears, Prt is about architecture and spatial ordering rather than theology. But whatever it takes him to compose his beautiful sounds is his business and fine with me. Religion has already poisoned the well of politics; it would be a shame for it to do the same for our understanding of music.

title: Letters: The Medium
description: If the implications of the e-book trend hadnt already given me pause (and they had), Virginia Heffernans recent column about the Kindle feature that highlights text found notable by other readers would have iced the job. Ive never been enamored of reading used books marked up by their former owners, and here now, it seems, is the e-version of that bugbear. Despite a users ability to disable the intrusive feature, many will not. As a result, they will encounter text produced not by its author but by a vast community of the opinionated. Is this, then, the future of e-literature and  perish the thought  of all literature? A world where, to access the virgin text, readers must disable features and fight the temptation to read a book littered with the signposts of what others have found noteworthy? Is too much freedom, in the publishing industry and elsewhere, not necessarily a good thing? As an author, should I feel that my work  punctuated with underlined phrases I chose deliberately not to emphasize  has been bowdlerized or enhanced?

title: Is the Move to Hybrids Hyped?
description: How popular will electric and hybrid cars be in 10 years? Depends on whom you ask.

title: London Underground | The Pleasure Seekers
description: Hedonism is not just about all-night partying, it is the pursuit of pleasure in everyday life, Fleur Britten tells me as we sip our herbal teas in the sun outside the hipster/gay hangout Dalston Superstore. As the editor of A Hedonists Guide to London, Britten has made it her job to know how to enjoy living in that city, and is taking me on a design tour of some of her favorite hangouts.

title: Letters: The Old World
description: Ted Fishmans article paints an unnecessarily bleak picture of the future of aging around the world, concluding that global power rests on how willing a country is to neglect its older citizens.

title: Letter: Little Brother Is Watching
description: I was disturbed and disheartened to see Walter Kirn, in an otherwise discerning essay on our loss of privacy, describe the behavior of Tyler Clementis roommate (taping an intimate encounter and putting it online) as prankish and silly juvenile troublemaking. We are not talking about an 8-year-old here; we are talking about a college student, someone surely old enough to be expected to make reasonable judgments about what might be upsetting or painful to another person, and then refrain from acting purely on impulse. Just because the technology is there doesnt excuse a person from using it indiscriminately.

title: Real-Life Golden Girls
description: At a talk in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., last week, I was describing co-housing and shared housing and other ideas weve discussed here  slowly emerging alternatives to the existing forms of senior housing that so many older people find inadequate, unaffordable or simply unpalatable.

title: Is the Move to Hybrids Hyped?
description: From our colleagues at the Green blog:

title: Letter: The Traditionalist
description: Arthur Lubows article fails to mention perhaps the greatest influence on Robert A. M. Stern: the ultraluxury apartment buildings like 1040 Fifth Avenue and 740 Park Avenue designed by Rosario Candela, with the latter structure developed in 1929 by James T. Lee, maternal grandfather of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. Candelas high-end apartments sported abundant bathrooms (even for servants), innovative floor plans including multiplexing, graceful spiral staircases, private terraces (the effective response to set-back requirements) and many wood-burning fireplaces. The sweeping chimney stack of 1040 is the direct antecedent for Sterns 15 Central Park West. A careful study of Candelas work reveals a genius eclipsed by the Depression yet brought to life again by Stern.

title: Frightful Medicare Scams
description: Medicare scams cost taxpayers billions of dollars every year and cause vexing problems for patients seeking legitimate care, reports Walecia Konrad in todays Patient Money column.

title: Inside Outsider
description: As a presidential historian and emeritus professor at Northwestern, youre well aware that the Democrats are facing the likelihood of an electoral setback this Tuesday. Yet President Obama continues to be the object of scathing criticism among Democrats, including yourself. Why wont you give him credit for getting things done?  He gets things done in a very crippled way. The health care plan and the finance plan  he made so many bargains along the way.

title: End-of-Life Duty
description: At 65 years old, I am facing a final diagnosis for lung cancer and the prospect of a 15 percent survival rate. If this is confirmed, would it be ethical to put myself through painful long-term treatment and to have the people who love me endure this? At my age, is it ethical to consume the health care dollars involved? What is the tipping point to elect aggressive care? Thirty percent? Sixty percent? G.M., JACKSON HEIGHTS

title: Microscopic Microeconomics
description: In the last decade or so, the American economy has been undone by a series of bubbles. First there was the dot-com boom, in which start-ups without business models were suddenly worth billions of dollars. Then after a brief recession, we began speculating about real estate, so that Las Vegas tract homes tripled in value before they even had roofs. The latest suspect for a bubble is gold, which has doubled in price over the past three years.

title: The Cancer Sleeper Cell
description: In the winter of 1999, a 49-year-old psychologist was struck by nausea a queasiness so sudden and strong that it seemed as if it had been released from a catapult.

title: Confessions of a Helicopter Mom
description: Hi, my name is Rene, and Im a helicopter mom.

title: Good News, Bad News
description: When the Gap unveiled a new logo earlier this month, the reaction was swift, intense and very, very negative. In fact, some people detested the look so much it actually inspired them: somebody set up a Twitter account (@GapLogo) that purported to speak in the unpopular designs voice, and someone else built a site called CrapLogo.me that made it easy to convert any short text into an imitation of the brands new style. The Gap tried to pivot off the negative buzz by asking the online hate mob for advice, in a sort of crowd sourcing gimmick, but that didnt go over well, either. In just four days, the company capitulated and announced that it would not change its logo after all.

title: Funeral for a Friend
description: I started to distrust telephones the instant they stopped working. I cant pinpoint when that was  the first time I dropped a call, or someone said, Im losing you  and I dont know why the telephone, the analog landline telephone, was never formally mourned. I do remember clearly what life was like when telephones worked.

description: Earlier this week, City Rooms James Barron described some Halloween costume disasters remembered by members of the Broadway world. (We figured  who better to ask than those who dress up for a living?) Then he asked readers to recall some of the worst costume experiences they could remember, whether worn or witnessed. Here of some of our favorites, lightly edited.

description: Michael Powell, a business reporter for The Times, occasionally sends City Room dispatches about his beloved, bemoaned Knicks. Here are his opening-night impressions.

description: GENERAL MOTORS has made such significant improvements in its products that Chevrolet, Buick, Cadillac and GMC are now ranked as more reliable brands than Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Audi, according to a survey released last week by Consumer Reports.

description: NO one likes to be left out. But when it comes to financial matters, excluding one spouse from the decision making can, at the least, lead to unease but, at the worst, cause distrust.

title: Oh No! New Museum to Take Down Distinctive Outdoor Sculpture
description: An exuberant, colorful exhortation on a drab stretch of the Bowery in downtown Manhattan will not greet pedestrians strolling by the New Museum of Contemporary Art for much longer. On Friday the museum said that this weekend it will take down Hell, Yes!, a sculpture by the Swiss artist Ugo Rondinone that spells those words in rainbow-colored letters on its second-floor ledge, and begin preparations to replace it with a new work by Isa Genzken called Rose II. Hell, Yes! was unveiled on the museums facade when its new building at 235 Bowery was opened in December 2007, and the sculpture became so closely associated with the institution that it was acquired by trustees and donated to the museum. Though nothing could replace it in our hearts, well try to keep an open mind about Rose II, a 28-foot-tall depiction of a flower that is expected to be fully installed by the end of November. The museum said it would put Hell, Yes! in a new location, but did not yet know where or when this would take place.

title: Carlsen Wins Pearl Spring With a Round to Spare
Immigration Reform? Really?
description: Richard Wolffe has the scoop on how the White House plans to take the fight to the Republicans in a brave new post-midterm world:

title: A Shifting at the Top of Columbia Pictures
description: LOS ANGELESTheres been some moving and shaking among the movers and shakers at Columbia Pictures. Matt Tolmach, who had been jointly overseeing Columbia Pictures in a co-presidency with his fellow executive Doug Belgrad, is leaving the executive team for a choice assignment as one of the producers of the next Spider-Man film. Mr. Belgrad becomes Columbias sole president, while Hannah Minghella was named production president of Columbia. Ms. Minghella was previously the production president of Sony Pictures Animation. Michael Lynton remains the chairman and chief executive of Sony Pictures Entertainment, which includes Columbia, and Amy Pascal remains the co-chairwoman of Sony Pictures. I couldnt be happier for or prouder of Matt, Doug and Hannah, Ms. Pascal said in a statement on Friday.

title: Asked & Answered | Alex Gartenfeld and Haley Mellin
description: Its perhaps the biggest thing to hit New Jersey since the Situation. At least as far as the art world is concerned. On Oct. 24, the New Jersey Museum of Contemporary Art opened with an exhibition curated by two wunderkinder of the downtown scene: Alex Gartenfeld, 23, the online editor of Interview and Art in America, as well as the curator of the West Street Gallery; and Haley Mellin, a 30-year-old artist whose curatorial work has included shows at Palais de Tokyo in Paris and Rental Gallery in New York. The theme? Made in America. Gartenfeld and Mellin bring more than a fresh perspective; their deep connections in the art community brought out a glittering roster to the kickoff, including Aurel Schmidt, Ryan McGinley and Rita Ackermann. T caught up with the dynamic duo via e-mail to find out how they are keeping all of the balls in the air and what they learned about the Garden State.

title: Super Bowl Ad Slots Sell Out Early
description: In another sign of the strong demand among advertisers for commercial time during so-called big TV events, Fox Broadcasting has sold all the spots it plans to run in Super Bowl XLV on Feb. 6.

title: Russia Joins Drug Raid in Afghanistan, Marking Advance in Relations With U.S.
description: MOSCOW  Russian counternarcotics agents took part in an operation to eradicate several drug laboratories in Afghanistan this week, joining Afghan and American antidrug forces in what officials here said Friday marked an advance in relations between Moscow and Washington.

title: When to Ask Parents for a Business Investment
description: In a recent Your Money column, Underwriting a Childs Business Poses Pitfalls for Parents, Ron Lieber offered advice for parents considering investing in their childs business.

description: This week: A conversation with Ian Frazier about his Travels in Siberia; Deborah Soloman discusses a new biography of the artist Grant Wood; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Book Review Podcast: Ian Fraziers Travels in Siberia
description: This week: A conversation with Ian Frazier about his Travels in Siberia; Deborah Soloman discusses a new biography of the artist Grant Wood; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Inside the List
description: PERSIAN PERPLEX: Joel C. Rosenberg first crashed the hardcover fiction best-seller list in 2002 with The Last Jihad, a thriller, written before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, that begins with a hijacked airplane dive-bombing the presidents motorcade and ends with American nukes raining down on Iraq.

title: Choosing Between Life and Limb
description: HERES a not very promising idea for a movie: A young man goes hiking alone, gets his arm stuck under a boulder in a crack in the ground and after five days, during which nothing much happens except a few hallucinations, extricates himself by performing a self-amputation.

title: The Ethics of the War Logs: Debating the Pros and Cons of WikiLeaks
description: Overview | What is WikiLeaks, and why did it distribute hundreds of thousands of secret United States government documents about the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq? What ethical questions arise from the work of WikiLeaks? In this lesson, students answer these and related questions as they read primary documents and news analyses from and about WikiLeakss war logs in preparation for a class debate over whether WikiLeaks is a champion of freedom of information or an instigator of trouble.

title: Editors Choice
description: DRIVING ON THE RIM,  by Thomas McGuane (Knopf, $26.95.) The rambling plot of McGuanes novel is held together by its pleasurable, acutely observed episodes, and by the sardonic Montana doctor at its center, sympathetic in his dissociated journey.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MUSEUM OF INNOCENCE,  by Orhan Pamuk. Translated by Maureen Freely (Vintage International, $15.95.) A privileged Istanbul resident becomes the anthropologist of my own experience to describe his lifelong obsession with a shopgirl, his distant cousin. He begins to collect mementos of their affair  a hair clip, a cup, cigarette butts  and a character named Orhan Pamuk plays a significant role in the story. Questions of class and of East and West, raised by the narrators position as a wealthy Turk, make this, as Pamuk writes, not simply a story of lovers, but of the entire realm, that is, of Istanbul.

title: Paladino Still Believes Gillibrand Is Schumers Little Girl
description: ALBANY  Carl P. Paladino meant what he said.

title: World Cup Votes to Proceed Despite Corruption Allegations
description: FIFA President Sepp Blatter offered a rare sign of vulnerability Friday when he acknowledged it was a mistake to decide the hosts for the 2018 and 2022 World Cup tournaments at the same time. Still, the votes will proceed on Dec. 2 as scheduled, despite allegations of corruption.

title: The Candidate Is Not My Type
description: DURING the 2008 presidential campaign, Barack Obamas choice of Gotham  an elegant 21st-century font  for his campaign signage was praised by graphic designers for its modernity and implicit message of change. Critics derided John McCains font, Optima, which was developed in the 1950s, and recalled the printing on a remedy for gastric distress.

title: Book Review Podcast: Ian Frazier
description: This week: A conversation with Ian Frazier about his Travels in Siberia; Deborah Soloman discusses a new biography of the artist Grant Wood; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Book Review Podcast: Ian Frazier
description: This week: A conversation with Ian Frazier about his Travels in Siberia; Deborah Soloman discusses a new biography of the artist Grant Wood; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: A New Trick for Making Pizza Treats
description: For the easiest pizza youll ever make, try lavash, a thin flatbread that makes a great substitute for traditional pizza dough. Martha Rose Shulman explains:

title: Rethinking Early Retirement in Europe
description: IF early retirement brings happiness, France should be the happiest place in the world.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: '127 Hours'
description: Danny Boyle discusses a scene from his film about the mountain climber Aron Ralston.

title: Roths True Nemesis
description: To the Editor:

title: Globalizations Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: There for All to See
description: To the Editor:

title: Movements Out of Step
description: To the Editor:

title: Drop the Weapons
description: Since the detonation of nuclear weapons over Japan, American presidents havent learned to love the bomb, but rather have worried about it. In 1946, the Truman administration presented the United Nations with the Baruch Plan for international control of nuclear weapons, which Stalin, working on his own bomb, rejected. Four decades later, Ronald Reagan almost signed a deal with Mikhail Gorbachev to eliminate nuclear weapons, but this time missile defense proved an insuperable stumbling block. Now that President Obama and senior statesmen like George Shultz and Henry Kissinger have endorsed the abolition of nuclear weapons, the issue has assumed a fresh prominence.

title: Dream Sequence
description: This absorbing novel  the first from the distinguished Spanish author to be translated into English  is full of mild sensations. Mild humor (bacalao soaked for dinner in the toilet tank) gives way to mild horror (a woman bends over anothers baby with the posture of certain all-consuming insects), which in turn yields to mild philosophizing (on the admiration that denizens of the rural world feel for folding things). At times, the mildness turns to provocation, as when the main character, a simple yet baffling woman named Mara Antonia Etxarri, watches a troop of soldiers and has a feeling that one of those soldiers, if not more than one, was going to rape her. The placidity with which she faces this prospect is galvanic. But de Lopes languid sentences, artfully translated by John Cullen, continue to unfurl, and you find yourself sinking back into the narrative as if it were quicksand.

title: Nation-Building
description: On Sept. 17, 1787, the convention that had been sitting in Philadelphia for four months to design a new form of government for the United States adjourned, offering its handiwork to the nation. Almost a year later, on Sept. 13, 1788, Congress declared that the Constitution had been duly ratified, and prescribed the rules for the first presidential election the following year. Pauline Maiers delightful and engrossing book shows how America got from the first date to the second  and ultimately to today, since we still live with the same document, however modified.

title: Sailing Alone
description: I grew up loving Joshua Slocums Sailing Alone Around the World. It was Walden without the training wheels. Whereas Thoreau made so much of his precious solitude in a shack only a couple of miles from his home in Concord, Slocum actually put himself at risk. In his 50s, pistol-whipped by fate, he set out in a largely self-built 36-foot sailboat and somehow managed to circumnavigate the earth. He might have been without a crew, but he was hardly alone; he had the magical Spray for a companion: a vessel that could literally steer herself for hundreds of miles at a time while he reclined contentedly in his book-lined cabin eating salt cod and reading Don Quixote. For a landlocked teenager who had both nautical and literary ambitions, Slocum was almost too good to be true.

title: Arms and the Man
description: The Soviet Union did not often make a product superior to the American alternative. Nobody in his right mind would have chosen to drive a pokey Lada over a speedy Corvette or even a stolid Packard. One of the few exceptions was in the military sphere, where the Soviets devoted a disproportionate share of their resources. In the long run, their greatest engineering triumph may not have been the construction of an atomic bomb in 1949 (based on stolen Western secrets) or the lofting of the first satellite into orbit (1957) or even the first man in space (1961). Far more enduring, if more low tech, was the development of the worlds most ubiquitous firearm: the AK47, or as it is often called, after its designer, the Kalashnikov.

title: Abnormal Psychology
description: God on the Rocks is so charming a novel that you dont want to give away a single one of the many twists of its plot. As its central character might ask: Why cant she just  not? But Jane Gardam must be shared. Shes a find whos just beginning to be found, at least on our side of the Atlantic (thanks to the novels Old Filth and The Man in the Wooden Hat), although more than 20 of her books have been published in England and she has won numerous prizes. Now at last comes the American publication of her early novel God on the Rocks, which was a finalist for the Booker Prize back in 1978.

title: State Court to Exchange Guidance With a Foreign One
description: The concept is novel and, as far as New York States chief judge can tell, unprecedented: a state court agreeing with a court system in another country to provide each other with legal guidance.

title: Trick or Treat on the Street
description: By ERIC DASHWhat might be a scarier sight on Wall Street than Elizabeth Warren in a mortgage modification center? More ghastly than a Goldman Sachs C.D.O.? Packed with more skeletons than Citigroups balance sheet?

title: Discussing Finances as a Couple
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan discusses an issue thats often not discussed by couples  their finances. In particular, he writes that one partner is often making all the financial decisions, leaving the other in a difficult position if he or she ends up managing the familys money at the worst possible time: after death, disability or divorce.

title: What It Takes to Buy a House in Foreclosure
description: ATLANTA  As in any economic downturn, the wave of home foreclosures has attracted voracious opportunists  investors among them who are buying, fixing and then renting the places out.

title: In the Beginning
description: Lucy Bergmann sits in front of a little fire in the South of France, thinking of Wordsworth, the Bedouins and the ancient document  an alternative rendering of the Book of Genesis  that her friend Pierre has just read aloud. She is about to express her admiration for pantheism when a gang of intruders bursts into the room, one brandishing a gun. The reader, desperate to be spared Lucys musings on religion, thinks: not a moment too soon. I suppose youve come for the manuscript? Pierre asks the men. And for your pendant, Lucy, one of them demands. Ah, yes, the pendant  a USB flash drive that Lucy wears around her neck containing evidence, discovered by her late husband, of extraterrestrial life.

title: Finding His Voice, the Slow, Steady Way
description: IF we have heard it once, we have heard it a hundred times: The opera singer who hopes to last must learn to say no. The American tenor Brandon Jovanovich, at 40, has not always had that luxury.

title: Coal Industry Spending to Sway Next Congress
description: WASHINGTON  The coal industry, facing a host of new health and safety regulations, is spending millions of dollars in lobbying and campaign donations this year to influence the makeup of the next Congress in hopes of derailing what one industry official called an Obama administration regulatory jihad.

title: Tough Love
description: Bruce Macharts impressive first novel, The Wake of Forgiveness, opens with a scene of a pioneer woman dying in childbirth on a homestead on the South Texas plains. Her husband, a Czech farmer named Vaclav Skala, carries her body into a hayloft so his three older boys do not wake to find their mother dead, then burns the gore-spattered mattress upon which his fourth son was born and stares into the flames to avoid looking at his hands, stained with the blood of the only woman hed ever been fond of.

title: Athens Marathon Is a Siren Call Hard to Ignore
description: Not much in this world can celebrate a 2,500th anniversary. And certainly not much in the way of sporting events.

title: Weekend Competition: Terrifying Titles
description: This Halloween weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting shuddersome, spooky and spine-chillingre-workings of book titles.

title: Speed Limits Exhibition at the Wolfsonian-F.I.U. Museum in Miami Beach
description: A new exhibition at the Wolfsonian-Florida International University, the museum in Miami Beach devoted to design, propaganda and the decorative arts, looks at a century of the modern idea of speed  and its limits.

title: Paul Kolton, Who Led the American Stock Exchange, Dies at 87
description: Paul Kolton, who became the first full-time paid chairman of the American Stock Exchange without ever having worked as a stockbroker, died on Wednesday in Stamford, Conn., where he lived. He was 87.

title: Keeping Them Company at the End
description: IT was the second time in two days that Harriet had called me. The first time she had simply wanted some advice. Her husband, Sid, had a rare degenerative neurological disorder called progressive supranuclear palsy. At 81, he could not move and could barely communicate, and he was running a fever.

title: Scientists Spar With Defender of Palm Oil and Pulp Firms
description: 8:18 a.m. | Updated

title: Bits Pics: Video Calls From the Top of the World
description: In 1924 George Mallory was asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest, the worlds highest peak. Mr. Mallory, a quick-witted and seasoned English mountaineer, responded: Because its there.

title: Halliburton Rejects Blame for BP Cement Job
description: WASHINGTON  Halliburton, whose failed cement job on the BP well in the Gulf of Mexico was identified as a contributing factor to the deadly blowout by a presidential investigative panel on Thursday, is defending its work and assigning the blame for the accident to BP.

title: The Long, Winding Road to a Foreclosure Purchase
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I tell the epic tale of Jennifer Kuzara, who spent about 1,000 hours finding, buying and fixing up a foreclosed home in Atlanta.

title: Defending the Right to Long Hair
description: An essay by Dominique Browning last Sunday about her decision to keep her hair long in her mid-50s (Flying a Long Flag of Rebellion) drew an unusually large response from readers, with more than 1,200 comments posted on the Web site of The New York Times. Here is a sampling.

title: Stuff Nightmares Are Made Of
description: Theres nothing quite as creepy as a creepy drawing: almost real, but just wrong enough to suggest its wearing only the torn-off skin of reality. Charles Burnss comics are fluid, smooth and as solidly built as a vintage TV set, but they shudder with the chill of the uncanny. His slim graphic novel XED OUT (Pantheon, $19.95) filters William S. Burroughss body-loathing and disjunction through the iconography of Hergs Tintin comics. (Hergphiles will notice a string of allusions, beginning with the front covers visual paraphrase of The Shooting Star.)

title: Clinton Is Urged to Confront Vietnam on Human Rights
description: BANGKOK  The Vietnamese government has arrested or convicted a half-dozen dissidents and bloggers in the days before a visit to Hanoi by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, according to the United States Embassy and human rights groups.

title: Motherless Child
description: FX Antoine, the 39-year-old narrator of Susan Straights latest novel, is an accomplished travel writer whos reluctant to speak about her own hometown. If youve driven to Palm Springs, she bluntly tells someone in Los Angeles, you passed Rio Seco. This fictional working-class town figures in many of Straights novels, and Antoines mixed-race family settled in its orange groves after fleeing Louisiana, where their women were hunted by a white rapist.

title: Hot Plates | Israels Creative Cooking
description: The creative streak coursing through many a Tel Aviv kitchen has spilled over to Jaffa, its ancient and often aesthetically unruly sister. Fittingly for a place that has served as a port since the Bronze Age, one of the new entrants sits in a retrofitted relic by the water: Container (Warehouse 2, Jaffa Port; 011-972-3-683-6321; entrees about $20 to $27) makes its home inside a hangar that dates from the 1920s, when Jaffa was part of the British Mandate of Palestine. The space fuses Red Hook grit with Levantine glam, incorporating a sweeping, 45-seat horseshoe-shaped bar under a warehouse-high ceiling that affords nice views of both the oversize wood oven in the open kitchen and the rotating exhibits on the walls. Adding to the mix is a three-times-a-week D.J. set.

title: Harlem Troupe Prepares for Act II
description: HOW long can a company remain on hiatus until it disappears for good? In 2004 Dance Theater of Harlem, facing debt of about $2.3 million, was forced to shutter its 44-member professional company. Months turned into years, and it seemed as if the vibrant group, formed in 1969 by Arthur Mitchell and Karel Shook after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., would end up a footnote to dance history.

title: Majoring in Violin With a Minor in Piano
description: FOR a demonstration of comprehensive musicianship and instrumental mastery, few artists have topped the performance that the German violinist Julia Fischer gave at the Alte Oper in Frankfurt on Jan. 1, 2008.

title: In Concert: Home-Grown New York Water Music
description: In one composition, the gurgles and pops picked up by a microphone placed 10 feet deep in the Gowanus Canal duet with a double bass. In another, heavily processed trickles from the Red Hook waterfront and ambient noise from the Coney Island Boardwalk pulsate behind an echo-y marimba.

title: He Doesnt Comp (Much)
description: IT was Thursday night at the Lambs Club, and Geoffrey Zakarian, the chef, stood in the center of the kitchen, peering into an iPhone app called Total Control, which was streaming live video from his security cameras. Mr. Zakarians attention to detail, it seems, is rivaled only by his gusto for control.

title: Hockeys Most Decorated
description: Some of the most famous hockey masks of a bygone era.

title: Meet Todd Combs (the Teenager)
description: 5:03 p.m. | Updated The mysterious Todd Combs is faceless no more.

title: Sounds of Jazz, Classic and New
description: Mary Halvorson Quintet

title: On Hard-Times TV, Dumpster Diving and Rsum Rehab
description: CINDERELLAS fairy godmother arrived bearing a magic wand by which she produced the ball gown, pumpkin coach and glass slippers that made possible a gala night on the town.

title: Eddy Hellebuyck Comes Clean
description: Athletes have been seeking an edge through the use of performance-enhancing substances for decades. But a sustained, systematic and widespread effort to combat cheating in sports has been around only since the International Olympic Committee created the World Anti-Doping Agency in 1999. Since then, a number of sports, including some that are not under the purview of WADA, have taken meaningful steps to tighten their testing procedures and have imposed stern punishment.

title: Another Spiritual Seduction
description: METAL has traditionally been a genre in which definitions matter. Its all deep, dark and dire, but evolves through its subgenres: death metal (torrid); black metal (cold); doom metal (lumbering); grindcore (frantic); and onward into smaller divisions. But some of the best new metal comes from widening the rules and deepening the sound.

title: Especially for the Inner Ear
description: TWO new CDs  a live recording of A Crimson Grail, Rhys Chathams mammoth meditation for 200 electric guitars, 16 electric basses and percussion; and Treasure State, a collaboration between the instrumentalist-composers of So Percussion and the electronica group Matmos  draw in varying degrees on the notion that sound trumps content as the most crucial element of a composition. This is a time-honored idea in a particular corner of the avant-garde where conventional elements like melody, rhythm, harmonic movement and phrase structure are regarded as less fascinating than timbre, texture, duration, volume and intensity, particularly when these qualities change slowly, if at all.

title: Week in Pictures, Oct. 29
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Habitats: A Roomy Park Slope Apartment
description: William and Lucille Harris moved into a roomy Park Slope apartment after World War II. Three children and about 60 years later, they are still there.

title: Milo: Works by Bridge, Britten, Turnage
description: A WEB of musical connections among several generations of teachers, pupils and friends inspired this disc of works by three British composers, vividly interpreted by two other Britons, the cellist Guy Johnston and the pianist Kathryn Stott.

title: The Election Will Be Tweeted (and Retweeted)
description: In the final days before Tuesdays elections, Twitter users interested in politics have increased their bursts of 140 characters.

title: Living in Cranford, N.J.
description: A onetime playground for corporate chieftains, this Rahway River town has an eclectic housing stock, ranging from Victorians to midcentury ranches to new condominiums.

title: Excerpt: 'The Larry Sanders Show'
description: The talk show satire receives a DVD release on Tuesday.

title: Warp Speed for Risky Solar Ventures
description: In an article in Fridays paper, I write about the solar thermal power plant building boom now under way in Californias Mojave Desert. The looming expiration of crucial federal financial support for the multibillion-dollar projects, though, could turn the boom to bust.

title: Gas Station Worker Shot Dead Over Candy Bar
description: The police are searching for a man who shot and killed a gas station attendant after a dispute over a candy bar in the Bronx Thursday.

title: Reviewing the 2011 Honda Odyssey
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Cheryl Jensen reviews the updated Honda Odyssey, the best-selling minivan in the United States for the last two years. As Ms. Jensen notes, several automakers have cut minivans out of their lineups  partly, one suspects, because consumers have begun buying more crossover vehicles. Of the Odyssey, she writes:

title: The Caucus: Florida Senate Race
description: Former President Bill Clinton last week almost succeeded in persuading Kendrick B. Meek, the Democratic nominee for the Senate in Florida, to drop out of the three-way race.

title: Garry and Larry and Jeffrey and Hank
description: HISTORY has been doubly unkind to The Larry Sanders Show, the enormously influential, deeply neurotic HBO comedy that starred Garry Shandling as the anguished talk-show host of its title and Jeffrey Tambor as his bombastic but insecure sidekick, Hank Kingsley. First, the series ended its six-season run in 1998, before its cinematic, laugh-track-averse style (and its meta-fictional show-within-a-show) became the norm. Then, for years, only a handful of its episodes were available on home video. At least one of those wrongs will soon be righted. On Tuesday The Larry Sanders Show: The Complete Series will be released as a 17-DVD boxed set by Shout! Factory.

title: Oligarchs and Absinthe Shots
description: The elevator doors opened to a phalanx of black-clad waiters offering champagne flutes, white wine, and water with lime. The Hudson River stretched out before the full-story windows. The Empire State building loomed close enough to touch from the 14th floor balcony. And in every corner  by the raw salmon bar, the grand staircase and the willowy model looking past her hefty suitor  the conversation was in Russian.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Pee-wee Herman, Al Pacino, Garry Shandling and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: TimesCast: The Florida Senate Race
description: The Timess Megan Liberman and Frank Bruni discuss the recent revelations that former President Bill Clinton unsuccessfully urged Kendrick B. Meek, the Democratic candidate for Floridas Senate seat, to drop out of the three-way race last week.

title: Artifacts | The Amazing Collapsible Family Muscle Car
description: Bikini-clad babes have been fixtures of auto shows since the Mad Men era, when cars became objects of desire for a predominantly male audience. Women like cars too, of course, and they go for the stylish ones even more. But they arent known for tinkering under the hood.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Iran and China.

title: The Visual Design of 'Megamind'
description: A look at some of the visual development paintings for the 3-D animated comedy "Megamind."

title: Analyzing the Heat by the Numbers
description: Rob Mahoney is an obsessive student of professional basketball, dedicated to the minutiae, the overarching themes and everything in between. You can read more of his work at TheTwoManGame.com, HardwoodParoxysm.com and ProBasketballTalk.com.

title: The Dark Art of Statistical Deception
description: Will sprinters one day break the sound barrier? Do Olympic athletes win more medals if they wear red? And can a simple formula predict happiness?

title: Conjuring Tatis Spirit With Animation
description: IN the spring of 2003 the animator Sylvain Chomet found himself on a train from Paris to the south of France, where his new film, The Triplets of Belleville, was to be shown at the Cannes Film Festival. I had something like five hours to kill, Mr. Chomet said recently on the phone from Paris, so he took out a script he had put off reading for years.

title: Week 9 College Football Matchups
description: Lets say this right now: Its hard to go undefeated in college football. After about the third or fourth week of the season, we all start to worry about what happens if all these teams go undefeated. Then teams start losing. Thats the way it works. Suddenly, every week is like a playoff. Missouri and Michigan State are essentially playing playoff games on Saturday. Oregon as well. All those teams are on the road against ranked conference opponents with a lot to prove. A loss would knock any of them out of the national title conversation (some further out than others). This is why I am not in favor of a playoff system. (Soapbox alert.) Not that I like the B.C.S., but I do not like the idea of a playoff.

title: Big Cats, Tapirs and a Mysterious Bat
description: Wednesday, Oct. 27

title: Pontiac, 84, Dies of Indifference
description: DETROIT  Pontiac, the brand that invented the muscle car under its flamboyant engineer John Z. DeLorean, helped Burt Reynolds elude Sheriff Justice in Smokey and the Bandit and taught baby boomers to salivate over horsepower, but produced mostly forgettable cars for their children, will endure a lonely death on Sunday after about 40 million in sales.

title: Awareness: Blood Pressure Check With That Haircut?
description: Barber shops often serve as a pipeline for health information in African-American communities. Now, a study reports a striking success: when barbers checked their male patrons blood pressure on every visit, the men were far more likely to see a doctor and get high blood pressure under control. (There was also a financial incentive: a free haircut for those who returned with a prescription.)

title: U.S. Nuclear Plants Get the Iraq Treatment
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency, perhaps best known to Americans for inspecting nuclear sites in Iraq, has spent the last two weeks in the United States. Rather than Tuwaitha, the notorious facility south of Baghdad, it has been passing time in Limerick Township, Pa., and Lower Alloways Creek, N.J. And in general, it liked what it saw, said Jukka Laaksonen, director general of Finlands nuclear safety authority and the head of the delegation.

title: Risks: Smokers Found More Prone to Dementia
description: Middle-aged smokers are far more likely than nonsmokers to develop dementia later in life, and heavy smokers  those who go through more than two packs a day  are at more than double the risk, a new study reports.

title: On Project Runway, a Final Plot Twist
description: WELL, I was wrong.

title: Whitman: Housekeeper Should Be Deported
description: Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor in California, has been dogged for weeks by the issue of her employment of a housekeeper who was not in the country legally.

title: The Morning Line: We Hardly Knew You, Super Saver
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Evil May Prevail, but Then Whats a Villain to Do?
description: WHEN it comes to superhero movies, todays audiences come loaded with certain expectations: an emotional origin story, a menacing villain and the dynamic triumph of good over evil. The filmmakers behind the 3-D animated comedy Megamind, who have feasted on a steady diet of these movies over the years, embrace the genres staples in their creation but still manage to find an original twist: Their film is not based on a prior comic strip and it puts a superheros archenemy front and center.

title: The Week Ahead: Oct. 31-Nov. 6
description: Pop

title: Raising a Crop of Tractor Preservationists
description: Forthis Sundays Automobiles section, I wrote about my visit to the Red Power Roundup, an annual meet for collectors of International Harvester products, especially tractors and other farm equipment. The event took place in June in LaPorte, Ind.

title: Crime and Punishment, Afghan-Style Crime and Forgiveness, Iraqi-Style.
description: By Alissa J. Rubin and Sharifullah Sahak

title: Another Actor Speaks of Spider-Man Injuries
description: 6:12 p.m. | Updated

title: More On Friedman/Japan
description: I had some graphics problems with my previous post on this subject  it turns out that what looks like a permanent link at the BOJ website isnt; plus I had some more to say about the subject.

title: Meaty Roles for Actors to Chew On
description: Lesley Manville, 'Another Year'

title: Barnes & Noble Changes Poison Pill Plan
description: Barnes & Noble appears to be bowing to shareholder pressure and is changing its shareholder rights plan, The Associated Press reports. The change would limit further stakes by its chairman, Leonard Riggio, and his family, the bookseller said Friday.

title: Chic in Review | Sarah Palins Unmentionables
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Drawing to Cool Down
description: Ted Loos, arts writer for The Times, speaks with Thomas Nozkowski about the artists paintings and drawings.

title: Drawing as an End, Not a Means
description: HIGH FALLS, N.Y.

title: Rock Critic Mines A Catholic Boyhood And Gets a Memoir
description: For the rock stars that Rob Sheffield writes about, there is a lot of God, but not much church attendance. From Depeche Mode or Bob Dylan, you learn that God is a big deal  but you will not find much support for weekend rituals that require fighting a hangover to rise early.

title: Mafia Killer Is Sentenced to Time Served
description: Salvatore Vitale, the former Bonanno crime family underboss who became perhaps the most significant mafia turncoat in nearly two decades and pleaded guilty to 11 murders, was sentenced on Friday to time served.

title: Directors Touchstones
description: The Poseidon Adventure (1972)

title: Bargain Hunters Will Want a Cold Snap
description: The folks at the Weatherproof Garment Company are at it again, with a promotion meant to get the attention of bargain-conscious shoppers.

title: Answering Readers on DIY Aid
description: My Sunday magazine piece a week ago on young Americans engaging in do-it-yourself foreign aid projects sparked a good bit of reaction, including some thoughtful criticisms. You can read the comments below the previous blog post to get a flavor. Let me try to address some of the complaints.

title: ODonnell and Coons Denounce Gawker
description: Christine ODonnell and Chris Coons havent agreed on all that much as they have campaigned for Senate in Delaware.

title: Wasserstein Estate Selling Co-op in Building Where Hawks Raised Hullabaloo
description: The 12-unit co-op at 927 Fifth Avenue has been home in recent years to some rather famous people, including Mary Tyler Moore, the shoe designer Kenneth Cole and the CNN news anchor Paula Zahn. The list also includes celebrities of another species: two red-tailed hawks named Pale Male and Lola, whose nest on the 12th-floor cornice caused a hullabaloo on the co-op board, with city and federal officials stepping into the fray.

title: Microsofts Push Into Gesture Technology
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Prepare for Windows 8: Minority Report Edition.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Iran and China.

title: Conrad Blacks Fate Is Murky After Court Ruling
description: The onetime newspaper baron Conrad M. Black may be headed back to jail  or maybe not.

title: Self-Managed Buildings Turn Tenants Into Supers
description: AUTUMN is in the air. Up next will be winter frost, colored lights, fancy windows, the ball dropping in Times Square  and, quite possibly, yet another annual increase in monthly charges for co-op and condo residents.

title: Obama: Explosives Found in Cargo
description: President Obama spoke to reporters on Friday afternoon about a widening investigation into suspicious packages shipped to the United States by air from Yemen. Follow the developments.

title: Furnished With Pixels
description: ANY broker will tell you that selling an empty apartment is much harder than selling a beautifully furnished one.

title: Finders, Keepers
description: A PHOTOGRAPH of an Army cadet pilot hangs on a wall in the apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, where William and Lucille Harris have lived nearly their entire married life. He wears a bomber jacket, goggles pushed up over his hair and a milewide smile. The fledgling pilot must have been a heartbreaker; not surprisingly, an insurance company clerk a decade his junior fell hard for him a few years after he returned from World War II.

title: A Wall Where It Matters
description: FOUR years ago, Margo Simcox rented a large studio  650 square feet  on East 65th Street. Though she was not unhappy there, for the long term what she really wanted was a true one-bedroom.

title: Cranford, N.J.
description: THIS is the kind of place that no one wants to leave. And those who do often find themselves angling to come back.

title: Microsoft Is Buying Canesta
description: 6:29 p.m. | Updated Microsoft said late Friday that it was buying Canesta, a small Silicon Valley company that specializes in gesture recognition technology.

title: Online World Series Is No Stand-In for Broadcast
description: In extending a $9.95 rebate so that aggrieved fans can watch the World Series on MLB.coms Postseason.tv service, Cablevision told them on its Web site that they would be able to view the World Series games online live.

title: Less Luster on the Gold Coast
description: IN Hudson County, the once-shining Camelot of New Jerseys housing market, condominiums are still king. In every month so far this year, 5 to 10 times as many condos as single-family houses were sold.

title: Frederick W. Peters
description: Mr. Peters, 58, is the president of Warburg Realty Partnership, an independent residential brokerage firm that specializes in luxury property. Warburg is involved in several new developments, including Twenty9th Park Madison, a condominium near Madison Square Park, and 555 Lenox Avenue in Harlem.

title: Broker Tech, Version 2.0
description: Woodbury

title: Good Girls Gone Wild
description: IT happened again this month, a familiar pop culture cycle: the provocative pose, the righteous fuss, the blushing assurance that no offense was intended. This time around it involved actresses from Glee in GQ magazine, tapping into their inner tramps.
