Not long ago it was Miley Cyrus in Vanity Fair, giving the world a glimpse, or rather a glimmer, or really just the slightest insinuation, of her breasts.

title: Teen Idols, Before and After
description: Young actresses often find themselves in a familiar culture cycle where their image evolves from relatively straight-laced to trampy.

title: Old-House Blues
description: THERE were instances in the bygone market when a renovation might actually have impeded a sale, so eager were buyers to create their very own dream homes.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Turning a Co-op Into a Condo

title: Android, Asylum and Fierce Matriarch
description: Shock Corridor/The Naked Kiss (1963/1964)

title: November Release Schedule
description: NOVEMBER

title: Semifinalists Set at Cap dAgde
December Release Schedule
description: DECEMBER

title: Obama Cites Credible Terrorist Threat
description: Calling it a "credible terrorist threat," President Obama said explosive materials were found in two U.S.-bound packages from Yemen. (Video: NBC)

title: Newsweek Offers iPad App With Subscription Option
description: Newsweek released an  iPad application this week that allows readers to buy subscriptions using Apples in-app purchasing system, seemingly resolving a major frustration that magazine publishers have had with the iPad.

title: Sunday Preview
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: New Deal Ends Channel Blackout on Dish Network
description: Dish Network and News Corporations Fox Networks unit announced a new distribution agreement on Friday, restoring Foxs regional sports networks in Dish households after a four-week blackout.

title: Ending a Lethal Game and All Its Gory Details
description: The people behind the Saw movies have made us a promise: no more Saw movies. Before they pack up the bear traps and latex flesh, though, theyve left us a digestif: Saw 3D, the seventh and presumably last film in the series.

title: Profiteroles With Raspberries
description: Mark Bittman makes an easy and impressive pastry for dessert and tops it with raspberry pure.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week. A news program produced by France24 in collaboration with The International Herald Tribune.

title: A Sphere of 40 Voices, Opening the White Light Festival
description: If you  like the rest of us  are trying to get a handle on what, exactly, the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center is about, you should probably start with Janet Cardiffs sound-art installation Forty-Part Motet, as the festival itself did on Thursday evening.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Halloween festivities take over many restaurants and bars across New York this weekend. Here are some highlights:

title: Drawing on Stop Rupp Experience for Marathon Fund-Raising
description: Running a marathon requires good legs, strong lungs, discipline and determination. But with the New York City Marathon, sometimes the hardest part is just gaining entry.

title: Profiteroles to Dazzle, Made at Home
description: BECAUSE profiteroles are served with a degree of fanfare in restaurants, you might not think of making them at home. Which is a shame; theyre easy and quite a bit of fun, even for a novice. I know this because I made them as a novice, with a recipe much like this one, and I experienced success, elation and praise.

title: IPad Cases Are the New Trapper Keepers
description: My colleague Nick Bilton wrote about iPad cases a few weeks ago. One of the cases he had in the office, from iLuv, caught my eye.

title: The Great Unwashed
description: A DAILY shower is a deeply ingrained American habit. Most people would no sooner disclose they had not showered in days than admit infidelity. But Jenefer Palmer, 55, of Malibu, Calif., cheerfully acknowledged recently that she doesnt shower or shampoo daily and doesnt use deodorant. Ever.

title: The States Take on Foreclosures
description: Have you noticed that the lead dogs investigating the mortgage foreclosure mess are not any federal prosecutors or national bank regulators, but rather the state attorneys general? I sure have. I cant think of a more encouraging development.

title: The Call No Politician Wants to Make
description: WHAT do you say to a guy who just crushed you in 49 states? Not much, apparently.

title: Tender Beans, Without Soaking
description: FOR years, there was a nearly insurmountable barrier between me and a truly excellent pot of beans: the seemingly simple act of soaking the beans, a requirement of nearly every recipe I read.

title: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 29
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include stumping politicians in the race for governor, a 99-year old working painter, a chef making healthier school lunches and a birthday for the Statue of Liberty.

title: Pumpkin Many Ways, Except From a Can
description: NORWALK, Conn.

title: Media Decoder: Newsweeks iPad App Offers Subscriptions
description: Newsweek released an iPad application this week that allows readers to buy subscriptions using Apples in-app purchasing system, seemingly resolving a major frustration that magazine publishers have had with the iPad, Joshua Brustein reports on Media Decoder.

title: Making Profiteroles at Home
description: Think profiteroles are strictly restaurant fare? Think again  theyre fun and simple to make, even for beginners. Check out this weeks Minimalist column for an easy and slightly different take on them.

title: With Serious Tone, Alderson Takes Over Mets
description: With an air of authority, the former Marine Sandy Alderson officially took over stewardship of the Mets baseball operations Friday by promising to develop a team that strives for the highest standard.

title: Awkward Test for Scott if He Wins in Florida
description: If his bid to be Floridas next governor is successful, Rick Scott could find himself in the awkward position of choosing his own inquisitor. New documents show that complaints into a chain of clinics he ran have been referred to the state health department, whose head is appointed by the governor.

title: Plenty of Food to Go With the Wine
description: FORK & VINE in Glen Head epitomizes the current trend in small plates and wine bars. The long, sleek restaurant, which opened in June, also adds full-size entrees to the mix. Theres something for everyone, and nearly all of it works well.

title: An Italian Festival Indoors
description: Gary DAngelo, 48, and his wife, Angelina, 50, have been selling sausage and peppers at street festivals all our lives, he said. With the opening in 2007 of DAngelos Sausage & Pepper House in Huntington Station, he said, we wanted to bring the Italian festival to the restaurant.

title: Obamas Remarks on U.S.-Bound Explosives
description: The following is a transcript, provided by the White House, of President Obamas remarks on Friday about the suspicious packages originating in Yemen and bound for the United States:

title: The Real Danger on Halloween
description: So often the risks we worry about most are not the risks we actually face.

title: Ruing Oaklands Use of Steroids
description: Sandy Alderson, the Mets new general manager, presided over the Oakland Athletics as president and G.M. in the late 1980s, when that team was considered an incubator for the use of steroids in baseball. After the former Athletics slugger Jose Canseco wrote a book detailing his and teammate Mark McGwires use of performance-enhancing drugs, Alderson was interviewed by Congress and former Senator George Mitchell for a report on the subject.

title: Abraham Lincoln and Sojourner Truth
description: Writing corrections is seldom a proud chore, but it is often eye-opening and, dare I say, educational. In an Oct. 3 review of Eric Foners book The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery, we incorrectly described an enigmatic portrait of Lincoln and Sojourner Truth examining a Bible. (By the way, our reviewers are not responsible for captions, and the reviewer in this case, David S. Reynolds, a distinguished professor at the CUNY Graduate Center, kindly helped steer us to the truth.) The portrait, a painting by Franklin C. Courter (1854-1947), is a wonderful piece of Americana and well deserves more generous treatment.

title: Abraham Lincoln and Sojourner Truth
description: Writing corrections is seldom a proud chore, but it is often eye-opening and, dare I say, educational. In an Oct. 3 review of Eric Foners book The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery, we incorrectly described an enigmatic portrait of Lincoln and Sojourner Truth examining a Bible. (By the way, our reviewers are not responsible for captions, and the reviewer in this case, David S. Reynolds, a distinguished professor at the CUNY Graduate Center, kindly helped steer us to the truth.) The portrait, a painting by Franklin C. Courter (1854-1947), is a wonderful piece of Americana and well deserves more generous treatment.

title: A Standout Stands in for Staging
description: As the New York City Opera continues its resurgence after a period of administrative and financial struggles, it is offering just five full productions this season. The first, Christopher Aldens engrossing staging of Leonard Bernsteins neglected opera A Quiet Place, which opened on Wednesday night, was a triumph.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 29
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Oct. 29
description: More Photographs

title: Despite an Illness, a Special Theater Role
description: As the Christmas party number, Turkey Lurkey Time, got cooking at a recent performance of Broadways Promises, Promises, the evenings sign-language interpreter, Alan Champion, rose from his front-row seat and faced his deaf and hard-of-hearing audience from the right of the stage. Fifteen feet behind him were three dancers vamping onstage as 60s-era secretaries, twirling as they sang about a mistletoey Christmas.

title: Menagerie Family, Moving Once Again
description: Before watching Faith Healing, you might imagine several reasons the choreographer, Jane Comfort, cast Mark Dendy as the inimitable matriarch of The Glass Menagerie, the Tennessee Williams play that is her main source material.

title: A Smorgasbord of Latin American Fare
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: A Look Back to a Time of Feral Play and Fear
description: New York has always been a city that favors big, splashy events and institutions. In such a world a small, scruffy theater like Performance Space 122 and the artists it has presented for the last 30 years are often overlooked.

title: Flitting the Globe Over in Torment and Lyricism
description: Famous musicians can sometimes sound jaded. But Yo-Yo Ma, one of the few classical artists to attain household-name status in America, still seems to consider performing a privilege.

title: The Fashion at CMJ
description: The influential fashion looks  both on stage and off  sported by some of the bands performing at CMJ this year.

title: Prize in Hand, He Keeps His Eye on Teaching
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Five days after the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa won the Nobel Prize in Literature, he walked into a Princeton classroom where 25 students awaited their weekly seminar on the magical realism of the Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges.

title: Doughnuts and Cider: Wonders of Autumn
description: FRESH apple cider is one of autumns great glories, from the first bracing batches, made with early-ripening types like McIntosh and Jonamac, to the last sweet blends, made with late-hanging Winesaps, Yellow Russets and Idareds. Right now, were in the thick of cider season, which begins around the time children start planning their Halloween costumes and ends between Thanksgiving and Christmas.

title: YouTube Chief Hurley to Step Down
description: Chad Hurley, a YouTube co-founder who helped broker the sale of the online video behemoth to Google, will step down as chief executive, according to The Associated Press.

title: Otherworldly Sounds at a Spiritual Retreat
description: When Meredith Monk performed her Click Song No. 1 on Thursday, it sounded as if she was accompanied by an array of percussion. But she was alone onstage as she offered a taste of her remarkable extended vocal technique, a petite figure framed by an enormous bright blue screen that changed colors throughout the program.

title: The Caucus Click: Oshkosh, Wis.
From a Mariachi Band, a Happy Ay Yay Yay
description: THEY have performed at Lincoln Center and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They played for Bill Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton at the White House, and at Teatro Degollado in Guadalajara for President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico and his wife, Nilda Patricia Velasco de Zedillo. They accompanied Linda Ronstadt on two of her albums, and Beck on one of his. They even had a cameo role in the film Sex and the City.

title: British Inscrutability You Can Dance To
description: Im going to make you shake, Karl Hyde sang as Underworld started its set at the Roseland Ballroom on Wednesday night, over a four-on-the-floor beat and pumping keyboard chords aimed straight at dancers. He was in motion himself, moving across the stage with angled elbows and twitching hips like a jumpy stick figure. The rhythm, the rhythm, the rhythm, the rhythm, went the next song, Always Loved a Film.

title: With New Home Page, AOL Tries to Entice Advertisers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For years, AOL has tried and largely failed to make its main Web site a bigger hit with Internet users. The number of visitors to the site has eroded, as has the companys overall revenue.

title: Suspicious Packages Trigger Global Response
description: A commercial passenger jet carrying cargo from Yemen was escorted from the Canadian border to New York City by two military fighter jets amid global scrutiny of packages sent from the Middle Eastern country.

title: Smiling Skeletons, With Lives to Lead and Issues to Raise
description: THEIR limbs crisscrossed at wild angles, their mouths puckered around toothless gums, their eyes deep black pools  the grinning skeletons in Nicols De Jesss etchings are busy. Some are riding the subway, some are meeting in a cafe or attending an art opening, and others, throngs of them, are gathered to partake in Da de los Muertos, the Mexican celebration of the Day of the Dead.

title: Rebuilding Panthers Face Challenges
description: From The Montreal Gazettes Habs Inside/Out blog:

title: In This Family Battle, the Throne Is at Stake
description: Its Christmas. Dad has brought his new, much younger girlfriend to the country place. Mom, who is living apart from the family, is making a special trip to be with them. Three sons are battling for parental affection and for prized possessions they hope to inherit.

title: Dreaming of Second Bolt of Lightning
description: It became the most successful world-music album in history, but Buena Vista Social Club happened by accident.

title: Was It the Music Marathon or Fashion Week?
description: AFTER last years CMJ Music Marathon, the annual five-day festival sponsored by the College Music Journal, all anyone could talk about were the barely 20-year-old British youngsters who make up The xx. And while their haunting, minimalist debut album placed them on everyones best Best Of lists, from Rolling Stone to Pitchfork, their matching sartorial style  black on black on black  may have left an even greater impression.

title: Split Personalities and a Double Motive
description: THE musical Jekyll and Hyde, about a 19th-century London doctor who develops a split personality, explores the idea of duality. A new production of it also has a dual nature, according to its executive producer, Beverly J. Bell.

title: After a Leap, a Strong Defense by Poland
description: The World Young Ladies Championship for the Rona Cup in Philadelphia this month had a disappointing entry of four teams. Not surprisingly, because the Polish Bridge Federation runs many training sessions during the year, the 48-board final was won by Poland, Ewa Agnieszka Grabowska, Natalia Sakowska, Magdalena Holeksa, Joanna Taczewska, Danuta Kazmucha and Justyna Zmuda. They defeated France by 131 international match points to 97.

title: When Is Gambling an Addiction?
description: When is gambling an entertaining pastime, and when does it become a compulsive addiction? Is stock trading a form of gambling addiction? How common is compulsive gambling, and is there a gambling gene? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog in Ask an Expert About Gambling Addiction.

title: From Avant-Garde to Resurgent Realism
description: Theres a loud, rowdy conversation going on at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, but you wont hear any words. You will sense the energy, though, as the drawings, pastels and watercolors of American Moderns on Paper argue and cajole and campaign for form over color, or imagination over reality. You will feel the winds of the dawning 20th century pushing artists outward into teeming urban streets and bellowing factories and pulling them inward toward the bizarre landscape of dreams and the virgin territory of abstraction.

title: A Traveling Storyteller Weary of the Awfulness of War
description: Among the oldest tales in Western culture, The Iliad is attributed to Homer, but this ancient saga of the tragic last days of Troy likely was developed through earlier versions told by many other bards.

title: Fear of Profit
description: Almost 20 years ago, when I was reporting on the then-emerging field of microfinance (now a $25 billion industry), I discovered that different people would often look at the same set of facts and come to opposite conclusions about whether they revealed something positive or negative. At the time, most of the funding for microloans came from foreign aid and philanthropy, and no lenders had yet turned profits. For some business-minded people, this was awful. It demonstrated that microfinance was an illegitimate kind of banking, worse  a form of charity. For those who were socially concerned, it was a saving grace. If microfinance ever became highly profitable, they feared, it would attract the wrong kind of people  profit-seekers  who would ultimately abandon the poor.

title: Georgia Democrat Proves Hes Not Pelosi
description: Representative Jim Marshall, a Georgia Democrat, has come up with a new prop to distance himself from Speaker Nancy Pelosi: his drivers license.

title: McDonalds Workers Are Told Whom to Vote for
description: WASHINGTON  When workers in a McDonalds restaurant in Canton, Ohio, opened their paychecks this month, they found a pamphlet urging them to vote for the Republican candidates for governor, Senate and Congress, or possibly face financial repercussions.

title: Gunman Has Grievance With Marines, F.B.I. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The perpetrator of a string of shootings of buildings near the capital this month is believed to have a grievance with the United States Marine Corps, Federal Bureau of Investigation officials said Friday.

title: Disarray in Service of Deconstruction
description: At the start of Patricia Hoffbauers Para-dice (Stage 1), performed on Thursday night at Danspace Project, the audience stopped chatting as a young woman stood up, intent on making an announcement: Im actually really good friends with Patricia and George and I came to the dress last night and I just feel like if I dont say something Im going to regret it.

title: John Harwood Interviews Jeb Bush
description: Jeb Bush, a Republican and the former Florida governor, sat down to discuss President Obama's leadership, presidential politics, and the Senate campaign of his successor, Gov. Charlie Crist.

title: The Price of a Ponzi: 40 Years in Prison
description: In this post-Madoff era, judges are showing little mercy to Ponzi schemers.

title: Bondholders Approve MGM Bankruptcy
description: LOS ANGELES  Bondholders of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. have approved a long-awaited restructuring plan, clearing the way for a bankruptcy filing that would eliminate some $4 billion in debt and put the studio under the management of the Hollywood executives Gary Barber and Roger Birnbaum.

title: G.O.P. House Projection Steady at Plus-53 Seats
description: FiveThirtyEights House projection is unchanged over the past 48 hours.Over the course of its simulation runs, our model found Republicans gaining an average of 53 seats, which would bring them to 232 total.Democrats are given a 16 percent chance of holding the House, down slightly from 17 percent on Wednesday.

title: Meskini, Millennium Plot Terrorist, Is Sentenced Anew
description: A convicted terrorist who cooperated with the government and who relocated to Georgia after being released was sent back to prison on Friday for trying to buy an AK-47 assault rifle and possessing a handgun.

title: Ten Questions for Jeb Bush
description: Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush sat down at his Miami office with John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC to discuss President Obamas leadership,Republican presidential politics, and the Senate campaign of his successor, Gov. Charlie Crist. An edited transcript of their conversation:

title: Detroit Reins In an Annual Halloween Revelry
description: DETROIT  The arts community here is abuzz over the potential dismantling of the site of Theatre Bizarre, an 11-year-old party and macabre neighborhood carnival that is part Ringling Brothers, part Dawn of the Dead, and features makeshift rides, punk rock bands, over-the-top costumes, a haunted house, burlesque sideshows and other performances, some of them involving fire.

title: A Carl Paladino Volunteer Shares the Anger
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, an old man living near the airport called Carl P. Paladinos campaign headquarters in downtown Buffalo.

title: Volunteer for Andrew Cuomo Is Calm Under Fire
description: THE phone calls roll into Andrew M. Cuomos campaign headquarters all day long, each one a tinder box: Why do no African-Americans live in Westchester? How dare Mr. Cuomo take his daughters to a gay pride parade? Does Mr. Cuomo know that hydrofracking will destroy upstate New York, and what is his position?

title: No Halloween at Hedge Fund Haven
description: By PETER LATTMAN

title: World Series Ratings Are Scary but Sufficient
description: Game 2 of the World Series posted ratings that were mediocre but likely enough to have lifted Fox to No. 1 on Thursday. Final figures for the live baseball game were not immediately available on Friday, but Nielsens preliminary estimates show the broadcast attracted slightly fewer viewers than Wednesdays opening game, which garnered 15 million viewers. The estimates indicate that Fox probably led the night narrowly ahead of CBS, which drew strong ratings for its crime shows CSI (14.1 million) and The Mentalist (14.6 million) as well as its sitcoms. ABC was third, beginning the night with its annual special Its the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown (7 million), followed by Greys Anatomy (10.7 million) and Private Practice (7.8 million). NBC was fourth despite solid ratings for the networks Halloween special Scared Shrekless at 8 (8.2 million).

title: Footnote
description: Ethan Stiefel, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will become artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet, the New Zealand company said on Friday. Mr. Stiefel takes over in September.

title: Jon Stewart on the Hustings
description: UPDATED: The reviews are in! Summaries at the bottom of this post.

title: Bondholders Approve MGM Bankruptcy
description: Bondholders of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have approved a long-awaited restructuring plan, clearing the way for a bankruptcy filing that would eliminate some $4 billion in debt and put the studio under the management of the Hollywood executives Gary Barber and Roger Birnbaum, The New York Times reports.

title: Becoming Han Solo
description: In Brooklyn, New York, a nearly paralyzed boy, who cannot talk, uses an iPad to tell his mother what he wants to be for Halloween.

title: For Red Bulls, Renovation Started at Top
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls playoff opener in California on Saturday night could not be farther from the clubs sparkling new home or more distant from last seasons stunning debacle.

title: The New Face of the G.O.P.? Grizzled Veterans
description: WASHINGTON  Christine ODonnell, the Tea Party favorite and Republican Senate nominee from Delaware, is trailing badly in the polls, but her every utterance seems to win national attention. Meanwhile, John Hoeven, the three-term governor of North Dakota, remains largely unknown even though he is virtually certain to win a Senate seat next week  not to mention that he was recently named a finalist for the American Mustache Institutes Mustached American of the Year award.

title: Bruce Springsteen: 'Save My Love'
description: The song is from an upcoming album called "The Promise," which contains tracks from the recording sessions for his 1978 release "Darkness on the Edge of Town."

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 25 at Cafe in Iraqs Diyala Province
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber struck a crowded cafe in one of Iraqs most restive provinces on Friday night, killing 25 people in the deadliest attack here in more than a month.

title: Missouri Dynasties Go Head to Head in a Senate Race
description: COLUMBIA, Mo.  The names on the ballot here are so well known that it is hard to believe that there are any undecided voters, especially after the assault of months of campaign commercials. But at a homecoming parade last weekend, the candidates were out nevertheless, flashing those familiar brands as they trolled for the undecided vote, estimated at 2 percent.

title: After Chinas Rare Earth Embargo, a New Calculus
description: BAOTOU, China  When Japanese mineral traders learned in late September that China was blocking shipments of a vital commodity, the word came not from a government announcement but from dock workers in Shanghai.

title: U.S. Hears Echo of Japans Woes
description: TOKYO  In the annals of economic policy blunders, the one in which Hiroshi Kato played a hand in early 1997 ranks among the biggest in recent Japanese history.

title: Nikki Haley No Longer a Sure Winner in S. Carolina
description: BEAUFORT, S.C.  She tours the state in a 34-person bus, has had her face on the cover of Newsweek and received endorsements from Sarah Palin and Mitt Romney.

title: IPad Opens World to a Disabled Boy
description: OWEN CAIN depends on a respirator and struggles to make even the slightest movements  he has had a debilitating motor-neuron disease since infancy.

title: Heat Begins Meeting Forecasts in a Rout of the Magic
description: MIAMI  The basketball changed hands in seconds, from Chris Bosh to LeBron James to Dwyane Wade. By the time Wade crashed it into the rim, the lucky piece of leather spent time with 17 All-Star selections, 2 N.B.A. most valuable players, 2 scoring champions and a finals M.V.P.

title: DealBook Debate: Are Foreclosure Ills Overblown?
description: The New York Timess Joe Nocera and Andrew Ross Sorkin discuss the role of banks in foreclosures in this DealBook Debate video. Document problems in the foreclosure process have raised questions about the culpability of banks. Aside from legal concerns raised by this issue, there also may be a wider impact on the economy.

title: 'Memento Mickey'
description: A short Halloween film by Jeff Scher.

title: Europe Plans System to Handle Debt Crises
description: BRUSSELS  European Union leaders decided Friday to create a permanent rescue system to handle sovereign debt crises like the one that threatened Greece this spring, but argued openly over whether private investors should share the burden of future bailouts.

title: A Saint, and an Inquiry Into the Sins of His Brothers
description: MONTREAL  At least 50,000 Quebecers are expected to gather Saturday for something most rarely do: attend a religious service.

title: A Hidden Minefield at Pregnancy Centers
description: I had barely finished signing in at the Expectant Mother Care counseling center in Downtown Brooklyn when a staff member ushered me into a darkened room for a sonogram. As we both watched the flickering image of what looked more or less like a tadpole, she called my attention to every anatomical detail, from eyes and nose to hands and toes. Staring at the little bugger wriggling around inside me, a tear slid out of my eye.

title: ESPN to Make Decision on Miller and Morgan
description: Jon Miller and Joe Morgans fates as ESPNs announcers on Sunday Night Baseball will be decided soon after the end of the World Series, which they are calling on ESPN Radio.

title: Drug For Neurological Disorders Cleared By F.D.A.
description: Avanir Pharmaceuticals won approval for a drug that curbs bouts of uncontrolled laughing or crying in patients with neurological disorders, regulators said. The medicine, Nuedexta, is the first approved to treat patients with multiple sclerosis or Lou Gehrigs disease who develop symptoms known as pseudobulbar affect that causes loss of emotional control, the Food and Drug Administration said. Avanir, which has no other products on the market, said it planned to begin selling the drug in the first three months of 2011. Shares of Avanir, which is based in Aliso Viejo, Calif., more than doubled in after hours trading to $5.17.

title: Obama Campaigns for Perriello in Virginia
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Representative Tom Perriello squeaked his way into Congress two years ago with a 727-vote victory over his Republican opponent  after a recount. Friday night, with his political future hanging by a thread, President Obama tried to come to his rescue. It was payback, in part, for the Democratic congressmans support of the presidents landmark health bill.

title: Family First, Baseball a Close Second
description: Neal Shapiro believes in the power of television to make people smarter and the power of baseball to forge family bonds. He offers himself as proof of both. Mr. Shapiro, 52, is the president and chief executive of WNET.org, parent company of the public television stations Channel 13 and Channel 21 (WLIW). Before joining WNET in 2007, he was the president of NBC News and executive producer of Dateline NBC. He lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Juju Chang, 45, a Good Morning America news anchor, and their three sons, Jared, 10; Travis, 7; and Mason, who turns 3 on Monday.

title: City Views: Gardens, Postcards and History
description: GARDENS are hardly the first thing that comes to mind when you think about New York (after all, its New Jerseys 19th-century vegetable farms  not New Yorks  that inspired the nickname Garden State). But in New York City Gardens (Hirmer Verlag, $49.90), Veronika Hofer and Betsy Pinover Schiff offer up a visually inviting respite from the city of steel, glass, concrete and asphalt. They celebrate the citys luxuriant public and private spaces  including one real estate companys office terrace, which required 98 tons of planters, dirt, trees and material delivered over six months.

title: Support for Paladino From a Few Florida Neighbors
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  One would think that after almost 25 years of owning a condominium here, Carl P. Paladino would be able to rely on a little support from his neighbors in his underdog quest to be New Yorks next governor.

title: Bill Clintons Role in Florida Senate Race Seems to Cost Democrat Some Black Votes
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Former President Bill Clintons political bank shot appears to have hit its mark with many black Democrats who were lined up at the polls here Friday.

title: Yemen Emerges as Base for Qaeda Attacks on U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Not long ago, most Americans had scarcely heard of Yemen, the arid, Texas-size country in the southern corner of the Arabian peninsula.

title: Where Financiers and Families Gather
description: With the long-promised notion of the financial district as a 24-hour neighborhood coming ever closer to reality, this Irish-inflected brasserie, open about three weeks, is already generating buzz. Under Donal Crosbie, the executive chef, who has worked in first-class kitchens like Spago and Danube, the menu at Bailey offers updated versions of classics that include coq au vin, bangers and mash and a lobster roll. In a nod to the areas growing family population, there is also a childrens menu that comes with free ice cream. With dark wood floors, red leather banquettes and big plate-glass windows overlooking the corner of William and Pine Streets, the restaurant offers breakfast, lunch and dinner. At midday on Wednesday, there were three business associates out for a quasi-social gathering.

title: Explosives in Cargo Renew Debate on Screening
description: The discovery of two explosive devices shipped by cargo planes has reignited a long-running debate about how thoroughly cargo needs to be screened on its way into the United States.

title: Juror Dismissed in Sentencing on 3 Murders
description: NEW HAVEN  A juror on the panel deciding whether to impose the death penalty in the home-invasion murders of a mother and her two daughters in Cheshire, Conn., was dismissed on Friday after making a derogatory comment in court about the defense.

title: A Surge in Democratic Spending
description: Groups aligned with Democratic candidates have unleashed a last-minute paroxysm of spending in competitive House races in the final days of the campaign that has them outpacing Republicans, reversing the trend of the past few months, according to an analysis of campaign finance data by The New York Times.

title: Driver in Crash That Led to Tougher Law Is Sentenced
description: A drunken driver was sentenced to 4 to 12 years in prison on Friday for killing an 11-year-old girl.

title: Tracey Moskowitz, Stephen Amdur
description: Tracey Lynn Moskowitz and Stephen Barrett Amdur were married Saturday. Rabbi Daniel H. Liben officiated at the InterContinental hotel in Boston.

title: Rachel LeFevre, Henry Snee II
description: Rachel Elizabeth LeFevre and Henry Thom McClelland Snee II were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Galen Guengerich, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Church.

title: Elizabeth Steffey, Nathaniel Vinton
description: Elizabeth Nason Steffey and Nathaniel Vinton were married Saturday evening at the United Church of New Marlborough in Southfield, Mass. Peter Coviello, a professor of English literature at Bowdoin College and a friend of the couple, received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the ceremony.

title: Audrey Christopher and Trevor Austin
description: Audrey Lisa Christopher and Trevor Robert Austin were married Saturday at Duke University in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Milton Brasher-Cunningham, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated in the Sarah P. Duke Gardens.

title: Raymond Murphy, Joel Nichols
description: Raymond Domico Murphy and Joel Arthur Nichols were married Saturday in Middlebury, Vt. The Rev. Erica P. Baron, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated at the Town Hall Theater, a community theater and event space.

title: Alicia Buchwalter, Christopher Trimble
description: Dr. Alicia Roddy Buchwalter and Christopher Koenig Trimble were married Saturday at the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. Patrick J. Lynch, an uncle of the bride and a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Jamie Bland, Loren Flaum
description: Jamie Grodd Bland, a daughter of Stacey Grodd Bland and Robert J. Bland of Woodbridge, Conn., was married Saturday evening in New Haven to Loren Robert Flaum, a son of Ilene L. Flaum and David M. Flaum of Rochester. Rabbi Richard Eisenberg officiated at the New Haven Lawn Club.

title: Jenna Adelberg, Andrew Silver
description: Jenna Susanne Adelberg and Andrew Haspel Silver were married Saturday evening at the Please Touch Museum at Memorial Hall in Philadelphia. Rabbi Mayer W. Selekman officiated.

title: Rebecca Lynch, Christopher Rutherfurd
description: Rebecca Phillips Lynch and Guy Christopher Rutherfurd were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. James L. Burns, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Angela Ottomanelli, Michael Hubbs
description: Angela Jean Ottomanelli and Michael Silvio Hubbs were married Saturday by Msgr. Joseph C. Pfeiffer at St. Helen Roman Catholic Church in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: Erica Hutchins, James Coe
description: Erica Christine Hutchins and James Gregory Coe Jr. were married Saturday. Brother James J. Konchalski, a cousin of the bridegroom who is a Roman Catholic deacon and a Benedictine monk, performed the ceremony at the Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Atlanta.

title: Rachel Sirak, Jeremy Haft
description: Rachel Anna Sirak and Jeremy Nathan Haft were married Saturday evening in Aliso Viejo, Calif. Arie A. Galles, the bridegrooms stepfather, who is a Universal Life Minister, officiated at Athenaeum Garden at Soka University of America.

title: Staci Siegel, Barry Ritz
description: Staci Ellen Siegel and Barry Alan Ritz were married Saturday evening at the Biltmore Ballrooms in Atlanta. Rabbi Ilan D. Feldman officiated.

title: Allison Schwartz, Brett Pearlman
description: Allison Meryl Schwartz, a daughter of Judith Schwartz and Daniel A. Schwartz of Denville, N.J., was married Saturday to Brett Adam Pearlman, a son of Ilene Pearlman and Paul S. Pearlman of Jericho, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Katz performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, N.J., with Cantor Kalman Fliegelman taking part.

title: Gillian Groarke, Jason Burns
description: Gillian Patricia Groarke and Jason Matthew Burns were married Saturday in Garden City, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Vetter, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Church.

title: Ellen Fisher, Isaac Klein
description: Ellen Williams Fisher and Isaac Andrew Klein are to be married on Sunday in Brooklyn. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik is to officiate at the Picnic House in Prospect Park.

title: Gretchen Zwickl, Peter Tirschwell
description: Gretchen Christine Zwickl and Peter Moyse Tirschwell were married Saturday evening at the Manhattan Penthouse, an event space in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated.

title: Magali Slater and Matthew Swanson
description: Magali Jeanne Slater, the daughter of Marie-Christine Slater and Richard J. Slater of Pasadena, Calif., was married Saturday to Matthew Elias Swanson, a son of Barbara M. Swanson and Robert E. Swanson of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. Msgr. Clement Connolly, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the California Club in Los Angeles.

title: Jennifer Goodman, Steven Calechman
description: Jennifer Elise Goodman and Steven Hart Calechman were married Saturday evening at the Lyman Estate, an event space in Waltham, Mass. Rabbi Eric Gurvis officiated.

title: Jennifer Short, Scott Evens
description: Lt. Col. Jennifer Marie Short and Scott Christopher Evens were married Saturday at Loews Ventana Canyon Resort in Tucson. The Rev. John C. Tittle, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Katherine Weiss, John Romano
description: Katherine Marie Weiss, the daughter of Colleen M. Weiss and James R. Weiss of Oreland, Pa., was married Saturday to John Frederick Romano, the son of Richard A. Romano of Levittown, N.Y., and the late Helene J. Romano. The Rev. Gavin W. Muir performed the ceremony at St. Lawrence Roman Catholic Church in Riegelsville, Pa.

title: Anna Ziegler, William Miller
description: Anna Ziegler and William H. Miller were married Saturday evening at All Souls Unitarian Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Alison Miller, a Unitarian Universalist minister and the bridegrooms sister, performed the ceremony.

title: Brian Carchedi, Raymond Lutzky
description: Brian Aldrich Carchedi and Raymond Allen Lutzky were married Saturday at Crane Lodge, part of the Jiminy Peak Mountain Resort in Hancock, Mass. The Rev. Kent Douglas Trievel, a Moravian minister, officiated.

title: Toni Herron and Mark Savage
description: Toni Herron and Mark Savage were married Saturday evening at the Intercontinental Hotel OHare in Rosemont, Ill. The Rev. Terry W. Herron, who is the brides brother and a nondenominational minister affiliated with the Rehoboth Word of Life Fellowship Church, officiated.

title: Caroline Donohue, Alexi Mantsios
description: Caroline Sarah Donohue and Alexi E. Mantsios were married Saturday afternoon. The Rev. Michael J. Sheehan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Stonington Lighthouse Museum in Stonington, Conn.

title: Kristen Cole, Gregory Gaul
description: Kristen Elizabeth Cole and Gregory Martin Gaul were married Saturday in Rio Verde, Ariz. The Rev. Lloyd D. Powers, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Rio Verde Community Church.

title: Christin Cho and Andrew Hires
description: Christin Kyungsik Cho and Samuel Andrew Hires were married Saturday afternoon in Los Angeles, Calif. The Rev. Dennis McCarty, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Bel-Air Bay Club, an event space.

title: Stacey McKeever and Charles Fogelman
description: Stacey Elizabeth McKeever and Charles Joseph Fogelman were married Saturday evening at reBar, a restaurant and event space in Brooklyn. Andy Grotelueschen, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Amelia Seewann, Vladimir Brankov
description: Amelia Katherine Seewann and Vladimir Brankov are to be married Sunday afternoon by the Rev. Anthony P. SooHoo at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Molly Fahner, Benn Calhoun
description: Molly Beauchamp Fahner and Robert Benn Calhoun III were married Saturday evening at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago. The Rev. Sarah Johnson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Joan Giambalvo, Milton Hutson
description: Joan Elizabeth Giambalvo and Dr. J. Milton Hutson were married Saturday at the Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Linda Tarry-Chard, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

title: A Final Bid to Pretty Up an Ugly Senate Race
description: CHICAGO  Something remarkable has happened in the Senate race here: Gentle, gauzy ads  with no scary music, no sarcastic narrators, no actual meanness at all  are turning up.

title: Mob Killer and Defector Receives Time Served, and Will Live in Hiding
description: By his own account, Salvatore Vitale took part in 11 murders during his 30 years with the Bonanno crime family. But Mr. Vitale, a former underboss who became perhaps the most significant Mafia defector in nearly two decades, will not have to serve any more than the seven years he has already spent in prison.

title: Climbing High, at No Small Risk, to Capture the View
description: Around 4 a.m., Luis D. Rosado began making his descent from the huge History Channel billboard in the South Bronx, 10 good shots of the city at night digitally stored on his camera. He climbed down from his perch about 100 feet in the air, made his way through the vacant building below and, before stepping out, peered through a hole in scaffolding he had climbed a few hours earlier.

title: A Polish-American Papers Final Edition
description: After 51 years and countless articles about Polish parades, banquets in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and, especially, polka, The Polish American World confronted readers with an editorial recently that was as sad as it was inevitable.

title: 2 Linked to Suicide Case Withdraw From Rutgers
description: The two Rutgers students charged with invading the privacy of a fellow freshman who killed himself after his romantic encounter with another man was streamed on the Internet have withdrawn from the university, their lawyers said on Friday.

title: On the Street | It's Halloween
description: Earlier this month, the Anime Festival and Comic Con combined to fill the Javits Center, and many of the visitors were costumed as their favorite comic-book subjects.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Lebanon: International Tribunal Says Hezbollah Tried to Obstruct Justice in Prime Ministers Killing
description: The international tribunal investigating the 2005 killing of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, left, issued a statement on Friday saying that calls to boycott cooperation with the tribunal constituted a deliberate attempt to obstruct justice. The statement came a day after the leader of Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, called on the Lebanese not to assist the tribunal, which he has labeled a political tool of Israel and the United States. Hezbollah is waging a public campaign against the investigation amid reports that the tribunal is set to issue indictments of Hezbollah members.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Confidence in Abundance, Despite an E.R.A. of Infinity
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  When the Texas Rangers clubhouse opened for reporters after Game 2 of the World Series in San Francisco on Thursday, the only player talking was Derek Holland. Five minutes after the home clubhouse opened Friday, before a workout at Rangers Ballpark, Holland was back at his locker, ready for more.

title: The Rangers Clean and Sober Batting Champion
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If anybody is equipped to lead a team back from a two-games-to-none deficit in the World Series, it is Texas Rangers outfielder Josh Hamilton, who has climbed out of a deeper and darker abyss.

title: Malnourished 4-Year-Old Girls Death Is Ruled a Homicide
description: A 4-year-old Brooklyn girl who weighed 18 pounds when she was found dead last month had toxic levels of antihistamines in her system, the citys chief medical examiners office said on Friday in ruling the death a homicide.

title: Reflecting on a Lawsuit Against a 4-Year-Old
description: That children under the age of 5 make it through the day, more often than not, without grievous bodily injury is something of a miracle, one of the many that present themselves to people once they become parents. But even young children have an instinct for self-preservation, which is why I find it even more mystifying how rarely those creatures  stick-wielding, stone-chucking, body-flinging  actually harm others.

title: Trick or Treat! Its Little Ron Washington!
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  One of the tough things about covering the World Series these days (O.K., the only drawback) is that you have to miss your kids Halloween parades. But Im pretty sure the costume Texas Rangers Manager is not too popular back in the New York area  especially after the Rangers eliminated the Yankees from the playoffs.

title: Going to Extremes to Give Others the Creeps
description: Few theatrical productions, if any, offer a prize to audience members who have wet themselves. At Blood Manor, an elaborate haunted house on West 27th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues in Chelsea, a handful of spectators claim a souvenir T-shirt for that reason each season. On Thursday night, the actors, students and even a supermarket clerk who make up the spectacles macabre cast seemed intent on terrifying people into winning that prize.

title: Ruling Sought on Suit Over 9/11 DNA Software
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has been asked to determine if a lawsuit can proceed that accuses the New York City Medical Examiners Office of stealing the secrets behind a computer program used to identify the remains of 9/11 victims.

title: In Wake of Inquiry, Selig Resets Precedent
description: In the final weeks of the 2008 season, Commissioner Bud Selig was forced to confront a troubling situation: a valuable relief pitcher on a team contending for the postseason had tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug.

title: Mary Emma Allison, Who Inspired Charitable Ghouls, Dies at 93
description: Six decades ago, on a fall afternoon, a young woman caught sight of a childrens parade. She followed the children, in bright native dress, as they wended their way through the streets of the town. They entered a store, with the woman behind them, and inside the store she encountered a cow. She followed the cow, and she came to a booth.

title: Bedbugs? Theres an App for That.
description: Bedbugs are as likely to settle in luxury hotels as youth hostels. So, travelers may wonder, is there a way to figure out whether a hotel (or theater or restaurant) is infested? Well, now theres an app for that.

title: U.N. Sets Goals to Reduce the Extinction Rate
description: UNITED NATIONS  After years of wrangling, most United Nations member states agreed early on Saturday in Japan to set significant new goals to reverse the extinction of plant and animal species. As part of the accord, they also agreed that rich and poor nations would share profits from pharmaceutical or other products derived from genetic material.

title: Artist Puts Hercules, and Himself, on Pedestals
description: BERLIN

title: In Nevada, a Battle for Every Vote
description: Will the tea party wave swamp Harry Reid's organization? The answer lies in the hard-hit suburbs of Las Vegas.

title: Alderson Ascension May Not Please All
description: Three weeks shy of his 63rd birthday, Sandy Alderson would appear to be at the perfect stage of life for the task of running a Mets organization that has been simultaneously  and sorely  lacking in youthful discipline and adult erudition.

title: Gaza: Palestinian Islamic Jihad Vows Resistance
description: Tens of thousands of supporters of Palestinian Islamic Jihad gathered Friday to mark their movements 23rd anniversary and chant Death to America and Israel and slogans supporting armed resistance. The motto of every honorable one should remain that Israel must be eliminated from life, said Abdullah Shallah, the top Islamic Jihad leader, addressing the event by telephone from Damascus. Mr. Shallah attacked the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank for continuing peace talks with Israel. Any negotiated settlement to the conflict is forbidden religiously and politically, Mohammed al-Hendi, another Islamic Jihad leader based in Gaza, said at the rally. Islamic Jihad, which is heavily supported by Iran, is the third largest Palestinian faction, an ally and sometime rival of the ruling Hamas party in Gaza.

title: France: Oil Workers Vote to End Their Walkouts
description: Workers voted Friday to end walkouts Friday at major French oil terminals and six of the countrys 12 refineries, after as many as 33 consecutive days on strike. The walkouts, most of which were in protest of President Nicolas Sarkozys proposed increase in the national retirement age, have caused gasoline shortages across the country and cost Frances oil industry several hundreds of millions of dollars, according to the French Union of Petroleum Industries. Gasoline shortages were expected to all but end this weekend, officials said, and refining operations were to begin again in the coming days. Frances lower house of Parliament gave final approval to the pension reform on Wednesday, and it is expected to become law in mid-November.

title: Uncertain Return for Giants Kiwanuka
description: When the Giants placed Mathias Kiwanuka on injured reserve Thursday with a herniated disk in his neck, General Manager Jerry Reese and Coach Tom Coughlin each expressed hope that Kiwanuka would be healthy in 2011.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Baghdads Shiite Heart Beats Freely as War Ebbs
description: BAGHDAD  Is it too early to declare a Sadr City Spring?

title: Sports Broadcasts Return as Fox and Dish End Dispute
description: Dish Network and the News Corporations Fox Networks unit announced a distribution agreement on Friday restoring Foxs regional sports networks in Dish households after a four-week blackout.

title: In Nevada, Its Hold Nose and Cast Vote
description: HENDERSON, Nev.  The knock on the front door elicited the annoyed yapping of an unseen dog, followed by the appearance of a gray-haired man busily eating chips from a bag. His callers were two union workers, canvassing the neighborhood on behalf of Democrats, especially Senator Harry Reid.

title: For Unsung Islander, Tough Jobs Are a Staple
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Not long after he joined the Islanders, Zenon Konopka decided the team needed a new goal song. Their song was being used by other teams after a score, plus his teammates thought it was boring. The Islanders needed to start over, in more ways than one.

title: Confidence in Abundance, Despite an E.R.A. of Infinity
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  When the Texas Rangers clubhouse opened for reporters after Game 2 of the World Series in San Francisco on Thursday, the only player talking was Derek Holland. Five minutes after the home clubhouse opened Friday, before a workout at Rangers Ballpark, Holland was back at his locker, ready for more.

title: Anne Erdmann Solves the Saturday Crossword
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Ive been wanting to interview Anne Erdmann for a long time. Shes a fascinating person and one of the fastest solvers on the planet.

title: Back on Board, Girardi Acknowledges Hurdles
description: The Yankees season came crashing down a week ago, but Brian Cashman, the general manager, has not wasted time working on next years squad.

title: U.S. Says Genes Should Not Be Eligible for Patents
description: Reversing a longstanding policy, the federal government said on Friday that human and other genes should not be eligible for patents because they are part of nature. The new position could have a huge impact on medicine and on the biotechnology industry.

title: Lottery Numbers
Girardis New Deal Carries Challenge of Handling Aging Stars
description: The Yankees season came crashing down a week ago, but Brian Cashman, the general manager, has not wasted time working on next years squad.

title: Cost Cuts Help Merck to Avert Revenue Losses
description: The drug maker Merck reported third-quarter profit on Friday that rose more than analysts had estimated, as reduced costs helped overcome revenue losses from drugs facing generic competition.

title: Rangers Stay With Lineup
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  With the Giants starting Jonathan Sanchez in Game 3, Rangers Manager Ron Washington said he would go with his usual lineup against a left-hander.

title: Knicks Lose, but They Dont Go Down Quietly
description: BOSTON  With two minutes left on the clock Friday night, the Knicks faced an 11-point deficit and a familiar fate: an unsightly loss to the Boston Celtics.

title: Nevadas Bleak Landscape
description: In these last frantic days of an extremely tight and unpleasant campaign, two candidates are united by the same problem: the voters of Nevada do not particularly like either of them.

title: Trying a Home Remedy
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  C.J. Wilson loves to cook, read and surf. He plays guitar, practices martial arts and races cars. Wilson is also an expert in finger care, thanks to the occupational hazards of his day job, pitching for the Rangers. Over the last year, Wilson has developed a comprehensive routine to manage a blister on his left middle finger, which opened and started bleeding during the seventh inning of Game 2, knocking him out with the Rangers trailing San Francisco, 1-0.

title: Pontiac: Cars and Culture
description: Pontiac brought Americans the Bonneville, GTO, Firebird and other venerable nameplates.

title: How to Keep Agents Off the Field
description: THIS college football season, the play on the field has often been overshadowed by the steady reports of players being held out of competition while their contacts with agents are investigated. The confessions of one former agent, Josh Luchs, who told Sports Illustrated that he had given money to at least 30 college players, gave a sense of the depth of the problem. Im all too aware of the damage done by agents who tamper with student-athletes: the football program at the University of Southern California, where I was a player and later athletic director, now faces a two-year bowl ban and three years of N.C.A.A. probation for violations stemming from such tampering.

title: A New Attitude in Sadr City
description: Baghdads Sadr City neighborhood is shifting from militiamen and Islamic codes to weddings and music.

title: The Power Broker
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chamber of Commerces Secret Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Update: California May Be Out of Reach for G.O.P.
description: A new poll from Field Research, highest-rated polling firm in our database, gives Barbara Boxer an 8-point lead, 49 to 41, over her Republican challenger, Carly Fiorina. While Ms. Fiorinas chances had already been on the decline  California has been very widely polled, and most of the surveys have shown Ms. Boxer holding a lead in the mid-single digits  the new poll on Friday harms her odds somewhat further. Given the robustness of the polling (and how close we now are to Election Day), our model gives Ms. Fiorina just a 4 percent chance of making a comeback, down from 7 percent on Thursday.

title: Nos. 41 and 43 on the Roster
description: ARLINGTON, Tex. The former presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush will throw out the ceremonial first pitches before Game 4 of the World Series on Sunday. The Hall of Fame pitcher Nolan Ryan, the Rangers president, will do it before Game 3 on Friday.

title: Sharp Changes in Maine, Oregon Governor Forecasts
description: I noted on Thursday that our forecasting model  even though it had shown an increase in Republican Paul LePages chances to be the next governor of Maine  still seemed to be underestimating him, given that the Democrat Elizabeth Mitchell was rapidly losing support to independent Eliot Cutler and that neither she nor Mr. Cutler were good bets to achieve the roughly 40 percent of the vote that Mr. LePage seems bound to achieve.

title: Rebuilding Our Aging Water Systems
description: To the Editor:

title: A TV Groups Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: Private School Civility Gap
description: Education reform is all the rage these days.

title: Enough Game-Playing
description: Israeli-Palestinian peace talks have been suspended for four weeks, about as long as they were on. The more protracted the impasse, the harder it will be for the parties to get back to the negotiating table. More delay only plays into the hands of extremists.

title: The Shame of New York
description: The whole notion of the rule of law, critical to a democracy, is sabotaged when the guardians of the law  in this case the officers of the New York City Police Department  are permitted to violate the law with impunity.

title: The Noise About Public Radio
description: NPRs ham-handed firing of Juan Williams, one of its senior news analysts, after he made foolish and hurtful remarks about Muslims on the Fox News Channel has emboldened conservative Republican leaders in Congress to demand  once again  an end to federal support for all public broadcasting.

title: Name That Candidate
description: The end of an election season is always thick with regrets. Do you think Meg Whitman is contemplating all the other things she could have done with $141 million? Does the Republican candidate for the United States Senate in West Virginia kick himself for allowing his wife to establish a voting residence in Florida?

title: Judges and Money
description: This falls round of state judicial elections is setting records of the wrong kind. Extravagant spending by interest groups out to influence judicial decisions and snarling television and radio attack ads have long become routine. This year, the virus has spread to retention elections, in which states ask for a yes-or-no vote on whether to grant sitting justices another term.

title: Voting on the Fine Print
description: Add this to the challenges for New York Citys voters on Tuesday: On the back of the ballot, in excruciatingly fine print, are two yes-or-no questions about changing the citys charter.

title: The Democrats and the Health Care Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Steps by Bank of America
description: To the Editor:

title: Ehud Netzer, Archeologist Who Unearthed Herods Tomb, Dies at 76
description: JERUSALEM  Ehud Netzer, one of Israels best-known archeologists who unearthed King Herods tomb near Bethlehem three years ago, died on Thursday after being injured in a fall at the site. He was 76.

title: Photo Replay: Oct. 29
description: From the womens volleyball world championships to the N.B.A.s courts, scenes from the day in sports.

title: Weekly Pick Em: The End Is In Sight
description: Theres still a long way to go in the regular season, but not that long. For Michigan State and Missouri  both unbeaten and among the biggest surprises in college football  Saturday could be a day of reckoning. Both face stern tests on the road (with the Spartans at Iowa and the Tigers at Nebraska). But if they get past this weekend, both will be favored in their remaining games, not counting a potential Big 12 title game for Missouri. Of course, they both have to get past Saturday.

title: For Campaign Workers, Its Their Busy Season
description: For all the artifice and attack ads, political campaigns still rely on dedicated workers who set aside their lives, sometimes without pay, to drive the elderly to the polls, to network with wealthy donors, to pipe up on their behalf in remote precincts  to believe, sometimes when few others do.

title: Despite Money, Medals and Records, Gebrselassie Remains Motivated
description: Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia has no chance of lowering his world record on the tough, undulating course at the New York City Marathon, but that does not mean he is finished, even at age 37, with attempting to limbo under his current mark of 2 hours 3 minutes 59 seconds.

title: A Dark Transformation to Strains of Swan Lake
description: WHEN I started thinking about Swan Lake, said Darren Aronofsky, whose new film, Black Swan, is about a young dancer wrestling with the demanding lead role in that ballet, a dancer, I think Julie Kent, said to me that the story is really about a girl who gets caught by an evil magician who turns her into a swan during the day and a half-swan, half-human at night. It popped into my head, Oh, a were-swan. And I realized I was making a werewolf movie.

title: The Weekend Word: Last Pitch
description: From Todays Times:

title: Rex Ryan on the Cablevision-Fox Dispute
description: Its Rex Ryan. Just unwind him, and presto: blog post.

title: U.S. Hunts for More Suspicious Packages
description: WASHINGTON  Two packages containing explosives, shipped from Yemen and addressed to synagogues in Chicago, were intercepted in Britain and Dubai, setting off a broad terrorism scare on Friday that included the scrambling of fighter jets to accompany a passenger flight as it landed safely in New York. On Friday, President Obama said the explosives represented a credible terrorist threat to the United States while Janet Napolitano, secretary of the Homeland Security, said on Saturday morning that the plot has the hallmarks of Al Qaeda.The discovery of the explosives packed in toner cartridges for computer printers, based on a tip from Saudi intelligence officials, began an urgent hunt for other suspicious packages in the United States and other countries.

title: The Moral Equivalent of Stagflation
description: Martin Fackler and Steve Lohr have a good article this morning on parallels between the United States and Japan; regular readers know that Ive been on this for more than two years. And the possibility of such a parallel was the main theme of the original version of The Return of Depression Economics, which I wrote way back in 1999. Domo arigato, Bernanke-san.

title: Did Obama Really Cut Small-Business Taxes 16 Times?
description: On Monday, President Obama visited yet another small business, American Cord & Webbing, which manufactures hardware for outdoor gear in Woonsocket, R.I. He was there to talk about his two principal accomplishments on behalf of small businesses  easier access to loans and tax relief. He told the audience, and the assembled reporters: Weve now passed, with the help of these outstanding members of Congress, 16 different tax cuts for Americas small businesses over the last couple years.

title: Q&A With John Elway
description: John Elway, the former Denver Broncos quarterback who won two of the five Super Bowls he played in, was enshrined into Pro Footballs Hall of Fame in 2004. Elway, 50, owns two steakhouses in Denver and three auto dealerships in California. He is also helping to promote the Topps Gridiron Giveaway, in which collectors can win vintage Topps football cards and memorabilia.

title: U.S. Sees Complexity of Bombs as Link to Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON  The powerful bombs concealed inside cargo packages and destined for the United States were expertly constructed and unusually sophisticated, American officials said Saturday, further evidence that Al Qaedas affiliate in Yemen is steadily improving its abilities to strike on American soil.

title: A Big Bet on Natural Gas
description: Exxon Mobil is the biggest publicly traded company in the world, but its stock price has been lagging over the last year chiefly because a lot of people wonder why its making such a big bet on natural gas.

title: Distilling the Human Element in the Climate Challenge
description: Michael Schlesinger, a climate scientist at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, with decades of experience studying and teaching about global warming, read the post on psychoanalysts exploration of the human response to climate change and responded with a query, as follows:

title: Carl Banks Says Giants Had Leaders All Along
description: When fans, commentators and former players were criticizing the Giants for a lack of leadership early this season, another former Giant thought the team had found two players to show them how to win.

title: Tracking the News on Air Cargo Explosives
description: This post will follow Saturdays news developments around the world  as well as storylines on the Web  regarding the plot to send explosive devices via air cargo from Yemen to two Chicago synagogues.

title: Planning for a First Trip to Churchill
description: Matt Carothers is the host of :58 Flat and Blinkers Off on TVG, as well being one its regular analysts. He started playing the horses long before the law allows.

title: A Pill to Control Laughing and Weeping
description: It is laughter devoid of inner joy, and weeping without sorrow.

title: Democrats Recruit Volunteers Outside Stewart-Colbert Rally
description: Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert may not want an overtly political rally on Saturday, but the Democratic National Committee is doing everything it can to capitalize on the event.

title: World Cup 2018: The New Cold War
description: The imbroglio over which European nation, or nations, will host the 2018 World Cup is turning into a shouting match between England and Russia, two of the top bidders.

title: U.S. Works to Ease China-Japan Conflict
description: HANOI, Vietnam  With tensions between China and Japan spilling out at an East Asian summit meeting here, the United States is trying to defuse an escalating diplomatic row over their competing claims to a cluster of small islands in the East China Sea.

title: Accounting Identities
description: Peter Dorman has a good post on the meaning of deficit misses in Europe, This Is What Accounting Identities Look Like. It meshes with the way Ive been trying to explain our mess lately; so let me go back to Sam and Janet  that is, to how to think about the role of debt in our problems.

title: Koreans Reunite at a Red Cross Gathering
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Hundreds of South Koreans, separated from family members in North Korea for more than half a century, were reunited with their relatives on Saturday as a Red Cross gathering got under way at the Diamond Mountain resort in the North.

title: Plenty of Fighting Spirit on Final Day of Pearl Spring
Zenyatta Shows Old Ways Still Work
description: Jane Smileys most recent young-adult novel, A Good Horse, was published this month.

title: Cryptic Beast From the East
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  This cryptic crossword is tricky enough that Im going to explain several of the answers. Dont read on if you wish to avoid spoilers.

title: Obama Walks Fine Political Line on Terror Threat
description: WASHINGTON  Trying to manage a terrorism threat in the middle of an election campaign, the Obama administration is walking a political and national security tightrope.

title: Urban Forager | Tomato-Pumpkin Mash-Up on a Tree
description: This time of year, persimmon trees across the five boroughs are abundant with fruit. The day that I visited the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to take a look at their very healthy-looking Diospyros virginiana, which the recent hailstorm had stripped of many of its leaves, the tree was filled with tiny, intact, mango-colored clusters of persimmons.

title: Serenade Rings Out for a Favorite of Giants Fans
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Wearing his ever-present smile, Juan Uribe plopped into a chair in the Giants clubhouse Friday night, stretched his wrists and reached for a ballpoint pen. Awaiting his signature were 252 baseballs, roughly one for every clutch hit or sparkling defensive play that has elevated him to the status of folk hero in San Francisco over the last three weeks.

title: Toeing Line, Not Rubber, and Fulfilling Expectations
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As he watched Game 3 of the World Series on Saturday from his home in Jonesboro, Ark., Tommy Raffo recognized the pivotal at-bat by Mitch Moreland of the Texas Rangers. He had seen it before.

title: For-Profit Schools, Tested Again
description: LAST week was challenging for the Apollo Group, the big for-profit education company that runs the University of Phoenix, Western International University and other institutions. One reason is that the Obama administration instituted new rules barring pay-for-enrollment deals among student recruiters at for-profit colleges  a development that is likely to cause significantly lower enrollment levels at Apollo and its peers.

title: Finding Her Way a Step at a Time
description: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz.  Alicia Shay occasionally finds herself across town, crying in front of the house that she and her husband once shared on Ponderosa Parkway. She cannot bring herself to pull their two favorite George Strait compact discs out of the changer in the Ford pickup. They have been in there for years.

title: Putting Himself Up for Re-Election (by His Staff)
description: This interview with Arkadi Kuhlmann, chairman and president of ING Direct USA, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Aggressive Compulsive: Harrison Walks Alone
description: PITTSBURGH  He finally learned the complex Pittsburgh Steelers defense a few years ago with the help of two wristbands, base defenses scribbled on one, Dick LeBeaus myriad blitzes on the other. But when the N.F.L. told linebacker James Harrison 12 days ago that the way he thought he had always tackled was wrong, he reacted not with the studied determination it took for him to make it to the league, but with the ferocity that has propelled him to the elite of defensive players.

title: Making Sure Nickelodeon Hangs With Cool Kids
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Heat Is Not Yet on the Same Page in an Edited Playbook
description: MIAMI  Erik Spoelstra scaled back his 400-page tome of offensive plays to a more manageable length shortly before the Miami Heat began its season.

title: A Cartoonists Take on Climate and the Couch
description: Marc Roberts, the worlds best (and only?) climate blogtoonist, has reacted to the recent post on psychoanalysts exploring the roots of human responses to climate change:

title: Fighting Words
description: The former Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev complained last week that Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, whom he once supported, had undermined Russias fledgling democracy by crippling the opposition forces.

title: Sex And Drugs And Markets Role
description: Kevin ORourke has a post, What do markets want, raising the same issues Ive been discussing about debt, austerity, etc.

title: Why Twitters C.E.O. Demoted Himself
description: San Francisco

title: Obama Urges Democrats: Knock on 20,000 Doors
description: PHILADELPHIA  President Obama kicked off a final, furious leg of campaigning here Saturday morning with a seven-minute pep talk to Democratic canvassers, imploring them to knock on 20,000 doors over the next four days.

title: Bloggingheads: Is Washington Broken?
description: Ana Marie Cox, left, of GQ and Rich Lowry of National Review debate the idea that Washington is broken.

title: Hes Back to Baseball Cards
description: My father, Michael, was a former volleyball player who competed in the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo. He worked for the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee .

title: Whimsy (and Clothes) for Sale
description: TO understand the thinking behind Chris Lindlands company, Betabrand, you need to keep three seemingly disparate ideas in your head at the same time: 1) Its a challenge for Web-only businesses to sell clothing. 2) Most people want to be witty. 3) Some shoppers go crazy for limited-edition goods. (Think Beanie Babies.)

title: Tea Party Kingmaker Becomes Power Unto Himself
description: On election night last year, South Carolinas freshman senator, Jim DeMint, convened a conference call with 4,000 supporters to declare the next battle: conservatives had to rally behind Marco Rubio, a relative unknown who was trailing the establishment candidate in the Republican Senate primary in Florida.

title: Chinas Fast Rise Leads Neighbors to Join Forces
Jets Kicker Is Cured of the Yips
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Dozens of times at each Jets practice, Nick Folk follows the same procedure. His success depends on precision and repetition, on consistency, on nerves long steeled.

title: Mario Vargas Llosa Lectures at Princeton
description: The Nobel Prize-winner Mario Vargas Llosa gives a lecture at Princeton University on Jorge Luis Borges's book El Zahir.

title: When the Assembly Line Moves Online
description: DO one assigned task on your computer. It shouldnt take you more than two seconds. Repeat 14,399 times. Congratulations! Your eight-hour work day is complete.

title: Me And e. e. cummings
description: A couple of readers have asked about my occasional use of the term Nipponized in posts; its from e.e. cummings:

title: The Morning Line: All Zenyatta, All the Time
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: How Immigrants Create More Jobs
description: IN the campaign season now drawing to a close, immigration and globalization have often been described as economic threats. The truth, however, is more complex.

title: A Runner Finds Her Inspiration in the Example Set by Joe Montana
description: Even after running the New York City Marathon three times, watching the start on television still makes me cry. Tears of joy, pride, awe. All those runners pouring across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the hard work behind them and glory ahead. Thousands of new stories soon to be told.

title: Innovation: It Isnt a Matter of Left or Right
description: AUTHORS quickly find a certain predictability to many of the questions they encounter on a book tour. But a few weeks ago, during the second stop on the tour for my new book, I found myself being interviewed in front of a Seattle audience and responding to an opening question that I had never been asked before: Are you a Communist?

title: Raising a Caution Flag on Corporate Revenue
description: INVESTORS may need to start worrying about corporate revenues again.

title: Army Studies Thrill-Seeking Behavior
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Airman Michael Kearns had been back from Iraq for only two months when he was pulled over on a Florida highway for going more than 120 miles per hour on his new Suzuki. He knew his motorcycle riding was reckless, but after living through daily mortar attacks on his base in Iraq, he said he needed the adrenaline rush.

title: I Asserted Myself, and Got the Job
description: WHEN I was hunting last summer for a job in search engine optimization, I started by applying for positions advertised on major online job boards. I looked for openings in San Diego, where I was living, and used one rsum. I didnt research the companies or consider gearing the rsums focus toward a particular job.

title: Worry, Blame, Anger  and a Little Optimism
description: How voters of all kinds are feeling before the midterm election, as shown in a New York Times/CBS poll.

title: Roy Skinner, Who Recruited First Black Basketball Player in SEC, Dies at 80
description: Roy Skinner, the Vanderbilt University coach who recruited the first black athlete to play varsity basketball in the Southeastern Conference and who led the Commodores to more victories than any other coach, died Monday in Nashville. He was 80.

title: When to Shrink the Budget Deficit?
Petke Departs, Certain He Gave All That He Could
description: When Mike Petke was a rookie, he would coast down the bridges of New York to save gasoline, filling up in New Jersey because gas was a few pennies cheaper over there.

title: Reluctantly, Koufax Steps Back Into the Light for a Film About Jewish Ballplayers
description: You could make a documentary about Jewish ballplayers without interviewing Sandy Koufax.

title: Portugal Ends Long Standoff Over Budget
description: MADRID  Portugal avoided a possible collapse of its government after the countrys two leading parties ended on Saturday a monthlong standoff over next years budget.

title: Karzai Protests Russian Agents in Drug Raid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A raid on drug laboratories in eastern Afghanistan came under fire from the nations president on Saturday because Russian counternarcotics agents had been involved, along with those from the United States and Afghanistan.

title: D.I.Y. Populism, Left and Right
