description: PROVO, Utah  Generally speaking, Tea Party enthusiasts dont think much of East Coast media types, and it was hard not to consider this fact as David Kirkham slammed his roadster into fifth gear, topping out at more than 100 miles per hour as we hurtled toward another curve. Chunks of rubber  marbles, the drivers call them  flew off the tires as the car violently slowed and banked, the acrid smell of burning brake pads rising from the cement.

title: Transit Frustrations at Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear
description: The mass transit system in Washington was swarmed by Comedy Central rally-goers on Saturday, frustrating thousands of travelers who were late to the event on the National Mall.

title:
GANDHI, SLAIN, IS SUCCEEDED BY SON; KILLING LAID TO 2 SIKH
BODYGUARDS; ARMY ALERTED TO BAR SECT VIOLENCE
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 31 -- So thoroughly had Prime Minister Indira Gandhi dominated Indian politics over the last two decades that even some of her critics said she was what held the fractious country together. Many called her Madam, Madamji, Mrs. G., Indiraji, Amma (Mother) or just ''She.'' Not everyone thought of her in kind terms, but all knew who ''She'' was, and her assassination leaves an incalculable void in the life of the country. Her sudden disappearance from the public scene represents a considerable challenge to the future of the Indian experiment in democracy.

title: The Life of Chiang Kai-shek: A Leader Who Was Thrust Aside by Revolution
description: Twenty-two years after rising to the leadership of China in a bloody coup against the Communists in 1927, Chiang Kai-shek lost the . . . gained. And . . . maintained. . . . Communist revolution. Thrust aside at the age of 62 by the convulsion that shook half a billion people and an ancient culture, he spun out his long life on the small island of Taiwan in the East China Sea 110 miles from the mainland.

title: EXPERIMENTS FOR HYDROGEN BOMB HELD SUCCESSFULLY AT ENIWETOK; LEAKS ABOUT BLAST UNDER INQUIRY
description: Washington, Nov. 16--The Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight "satisfactory" experiments in hydrogen weapon research amid informed speculation that this meant a super-atomic bomb had been exploded in recent United States tests.

title: Stephen Crane Dead
description: BADENWEILER, Baden, June 5.--Stephen Crane, the American author and war correspondent, died here to-day, aged thirty years.

title: Carter Victor In Tight Race; Ford Loses New York State; Democrats Retain Congress
description: Jimmy Carter won the nation's Bicentennial Presidential election yesterday, narrowly defeating President Ford by sweeping his native South and adding enough Northern industrial states to give him a bare electoral vote majority.

title: Harding a Farm Boy Who Rose by Work
description: Nominated for the Presidency as a compromise candidate and elected by a tremendous majority because of a reaction against the policies of his predecessor, Warren Gamaliel Harding, twenty-ninth President of the United States, owed his political elevation largely to his engaging personal traits, his ability to work in harmony with the leaders of his party and the fact that he typified in himself the average prosperous American citizen.

title: Roosevelt Sweeps The Nation; His Electoral Vote Exceeds 500; Lehman Wins; Charter Adopted
description: Accepting the President as the issue, nearly eight million more voters than ever before had gone to the polls in the United States--about 45,000,000 persons--yesterday gave to Franklin Delano Roosevelt the most overwhelming testimonial of approval ever received by a national candidate in the history of the nation.

title: Walker Evans Dies; Artist With Camera
description: Walker Evans, the photographer noted for his bleak, abstinent pictures of American life, died yesterday of a brain hemorrhage at Yale-New Haven Hospital in Connecticut. He was 71 years old and held the title of professor emeritus of graphic arts at Yale University's School of Art and Architecture.

title: Obama Elected President as Racial Barrier Falls
description: Barack Hussein Obama was elected the 44th president of the United States on Tuesday, sweeping away the last racial barrier in American politics with ease as the country chose him as its first black chief executive.

title: Adventure Marked Life of Humorist
description: Will Rogers had what it takes to tickle the national funny bone. His wry countenance, with its occasionally wistful expression, was comical to see, and his consciously cultivated drawl lent a rustic savor to his sophisticated quips. Most important of all, he had the knack of translating into trenchant phrases the inchoate thoughts of masses of "average" Americans.

title: Nixon Wins By A Thin Margin, Pleads For Reunited Nation
description: Richard Milhous Nixon emerged the victor yesterday in one of the closest and most tumultuous Presidential campaigns in history and set himself the task of reuniting the nation.

title: Ida M. Tarbell, 86, Dies in Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 6--Miss Ida Minerva Tarbell, noted biographer and dean of women authors in this country, who won fame for her expose of the Standard Oil "trust," died at 7:28 o'clock this morning of pneumonia in Bridgeport Hospital. Her age was 86.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION
description: The canvass for the Presidency of the United States terminated last evening, in all the States of the Union, under the revised regulation of Congress, passed in 1845, and the result, by the vote of New-York, is placed beyond question at once. It elects ABRAHAM LINCOLN of Illinois, President, and HANNIBAL HAMLIN of Maine, Vice-President of the United States, for four years, from the 4th March next, directly by the People.

title: John Philip Sousa, Band Leader, Dies in Hotel at Reading
description: READING, Pa., Sunday, March 6.--John Philip Sousa, famous American band conductor and march king of a generation ago, died unexpectedly early this morning in his room in the Abraham Lincoln Hotel from an attack of heart disease.

title: Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear
description: Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert, the Comedy Central television hosts, opened the rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear in Washington on Saturday by praising members of the crowd for their moderation.

title: Will Lincoln Prevail?
description: The story of the Civil War will be told in this series as a weekly roundup and analysis, by Jamie Malanowski, of events making news during the corresponding week 150 years ago. Written as if in real time, this dispatch will, after this week, appear every Monday. Additional essays and observations by other contributors, along with maps, images, diaries and so forth, will be published several times a week. For another perspective on the war, see this op-ed by Tony Horwitz.  The Editors

title: Live Blog: At the Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear
description: Thousands gathered on the National Mall with the comedians Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert on Saturday for the Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear. Below is the live blog of the event. [Related Article]

title: Elitism: The Charge Obama Cant Shake
description: WASHINGTON  In the Boston-area home of a wealthy hospital executive one Saturday evening this month, President Obama departed from his usual campaign stump speech and offered an explanation as to why Democrats were seemingly doing so poorly this election season. Voters, he said, just arent thinking straight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Champagne Ritual, Made a Little Less Intoxicating
description: This postseason, the baseball clubhouse has seen a twist to its ritualized, made-for-television Champagne celebration: the ginger-ale spray.

title: Explosive on Planes Was Used in Past Plots
description: Pentaerythritol tetranitrate, or PETN, the explosive found in two bombs hidden in printer cartridges that were being shipped via jets from Yemen to the United States, is a hallmark of earlier Qaeda-linked terrorism attempts on airplanes.

title: Iraqi Golds Glitter Dims for Dealers Under Siege
description: BAGHDAD  Inside Amjad Abeds tiny gold shop, the display cases sit half empty, and the memories of his two grown sons are in the bullet holes that gouge the walls. Last spring, three gunmen burst in and ransacked the store, scooping up rings that brides choose for weddings and necklaces that husbands buy on credit for anniversaries. They killed Mr. Abeds sons, who had been tending the shop.

title: Caffeine and Alcohol: Wham! Bam! Boozled.
description: I found a biliously colored cache of it easily enough, just a block and a half from my Manhattan apartment, in an unremarkable bodegas back refrigerator case, veritably screaming for attention among the more prosaically packaged Heinekens, Anchor Steams and Sapporos.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: At Rally, Thousands  Billions?  Respond
description: WASHINGTON  It was part circus, part satire and part parade, and the crowds that flooded the National Mall Saturday for Jon Stewart and Stephen Colberts Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear made it a political event like no other.

title: Prime Number
description: 105.50: The dollar amount investors paid at a $10 billion government auction last week for every $100 of bonds sold  agreeing, in effect, to pay the government for the privilege of lending it money. Why do that? These bonds offer a guaranteed protection against inflation. If inflation soars  as some economists worry might happen, with the government seeking to give the economy a boost by flooding it with money  the value of the bonds will go up accordingly. The auction marked the first time since the government began selling these so-called Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities in the 1990s that new ones were sold at a negative yield.

title: Scariest Sight on Halloween? Grown-Ups
description: Since I write scary books for kids, Im asked to do a lot of weird things. A couple of years ago, a magazine asked me to tour some of the haunted houses that were popping up around New York City. They had names like Blood Manor, Draculas Dungeon and Nightmare: Bad Dreams Come True.

title: Angels and the Politics of Fear
description: Tony Kushners Pulitzer Prize-winning two-part play, Angels in America, opened last week at Off Broadways Signature Theater Company, the first revival in New York since the original, acclaimed Broadway run in 1993-94. Set mainly in the mid-1980s during the Reagan presidency, the play assesses the impact of AIDS on seemingly disparate characters. Susan Cheever spoke with Mr. Kushner in September 1992, a few months before it opened on Broadway:

title: Music Videos Expand Literacy
description: Gathering to watch Bollywood music videos is a Sunday ritual in small Indian villages. Now researchers believe that it may be responsible for a surge in literacy across rural India, The Boston Globe reports. The reason for this success, those researchers believe, is that the videos are subtitled in Hindi, the language the actors sing in and the villagers speak. The idea for the same-language subtitles is a twist on an old technique of teaching students a foreign language by having them watch foreign movies with subtitles in their native tongue. Indian state television began broadcasting the videos nine years ago. Today, the program reaches 200 million viewers across 10 states, and functional literacy in those areas has more than doubled. Other governments are interested. The success complicates the conventional wisdom that TV makes us stupid.

title: Memory of a Stricken Teammate Inspires the Rangers Moreland
description: ARLINGTON, Texas  If youre a first baseman from Mississippi State, chances are youll wind up playing for the Texas Rangers. Rafael Palmeiro and Will Clark are former Bulldogs, and so is the Rangers current first baseman, the former pitcher Mitch Moreland.

title: Obama Is Heckled by AIDS Protesters
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  President Obama was heckled Saturday by AIDS protesters, who interrupted a rally here, forcing the president to temporarily suspend his remarks to a stadium of 9,000 Democrats.

title: Zenyatta Is the Star, but Blame Also Shines
description: Lane Gold, the former director of Derby spin at Churchill Downs, is based out of New York and is still actively involved in racing. He co-hosts a weekly radio show, the Kentucky Winners Circle, and has a blog called Lane One.

title: Democrats Fight to Retain Senate Majority
description: PHILADELPHIA  The battle for control of Congress rolled into a frenetic final weekend as Democrats fought to preserve the Senate as their power center on Capitol Hill, trying to hold off a Republican surge that could reshape the political order in Washington.

title: The Grand Old Plot Against the Tea Party
description: ONE dirty little secret of the 2010 election is that it wont be a political tragedy for Democrats if a Tea Party icon like Sharron Angle or Joe Miller ends up in the United States Senate. Angle, now synonymous with racist ads sliming Hispanics, and Miller, already on record threatening a government shutdown, are fired up and ready to go as symbols of G.O.P. extremism for 2012 and beyond.

title: Looking to 2012, but in the Senate
description: The results of this years Senate elections are not even in the books, but senators and political analysts are already looking ahead to 2012, when the Senate math adds up to a daunting prospect for Democrats.

title: Its Morning in India
description: New Delhi

title: Final Days of an Unlikely Run for Senate
description: AIKEN, S.C.  Alvin Greene asked the ticket seller at the Western Carolina State Fair here if political candidates could get in free. No. Military veterans? No. People wearing green T-shirts (his said Greene Senate)? Nothing worked. Reluctantly, Mr. Greene forked over the $6 entry fee.

title: Can the Dude Abide?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Give Obama a Break
description: In politics as in finance, markets overshoot. Traders and voters swoon over stocks or politicians one week, and then rage at them the next.

title: Drowning in Campaign Cash
description: Shrill political attacks have saturated the airwaves for months, but behind them is the real problem of this demoralizing election: the dark flow of dollars, often secretly provided by donors with very special interests.

title: Reader Comments on my Obama Column
description: I dont write all that often about American politics, because plenty of other people do that already. And I think I can often be most useful shining my spotlight on things that arent being illuminated, and thus help project them onto the agenda. But Ive been struck by the degree to which almost everybody across the political spectrum seems to think that President Obama is a disappointment  and it strikes me as way too early to reach that conclusion. All in all, as I write in my Sunday column, I think the infatuation with Obama in 2008 was a bit overdone, as is the rejection of him today. As in the financial markets, the political markets regularly overshoot in both directions.

title: Politicians Are Fighting Mad, at the News Media
description: This year will likely go down in the history books as the year of the angry voter. But 2010 will also be an election year notable for another kind of ire: when politicians let their contempt for the news media boil over.

title: Sandoval to Be D.H. for Giants in Game 3
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  With the designated hitter back in effect for Game 3, Vladimir Guerrero rejoined the Rangers lineup Saturday. The Giants do not have a 29-homer, 115-R.B.I. guy just sitting around on their bench. Their best D.H. option Saturday night was Pablo Sandoval, whose playing time diminished as his production waned.

title: Bomb Suspect Tracked By U.P.S. Label
description: A woman is arrested in Yemen for sending mail bombs on U.S. cargo planes.  MSNBC reports.

title: The 150-Year War
description: MY attic office is walled with books on Lincoln and Lee, slavery and secession. John Brown glares from a daguerreotype on my desk. The Civil War is my sanctum  except when my 7-year-old races in to get at the costume box. Invariably, he tosses aside the kepi and wooden sword to reach for a wizard cloak or Star Wars light saber.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Oct. 31
description: Two days before voters head to the polls, the architects of Republican and Democratic election strategies offer last-minute messages on Sundays political talk shows.

title: Arizona Immigration Law Divides Latinos, Too
description: PHOENIX  Arizonas immigration law, which politicians have debated in the Legislature, lawyers have sparred over in the courtroom and advocates have shouted about on the street, has found its way up a driveway in central Phoenix, through the front door and right onto the Sotelo familys kitchen table.

title: Sunday: Fangs for the Memory
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  If youve been working the daily puzzles this week, you probably have the notion that Halloween is coming soon. If youre a longtime solver, though, a holiday isnt official until we see an Elizabeth C. Gorski crossword commemorating it. The hallowed evening is considerate enough to fall on a Sunday this year and sure enough, Ms. Gorski doesnt disappoint us. We get one of her patented connect-the-dots themes. She didnt literally patent it, but perhaps she should have. Its a form she created that has caught on with several other constructors.

title: Where Parties Look for an Audience
description: WASHINGTON  Dancing With the Stars, where Bristol Palin hopes to fox trot and quick step her way to a disco ball trophy, has the most political ad purchases on prime-time television among both Democratic and Republican media buyers. But the bipartisan consensus on Americas TV habits apparently ends there.

title: Rebalancing China
description: Chinas artificially cheap exports are flooding foreign markets, undercutting industries, threatening the global recovery, and angering many. Beijing has resisted demands to allow its currency to rise against the dollar.

title: Negative Spots Reach New Highs
description: Tucked inside Sundays Week in Review is an interesting nugget readers are unlikely to find anywhere else: two graphs showing the rise in the use of political attack ads over the last decade, based on an analysis made available to The Times on Friday. They are reproduced here, along with their explanatory text:

title: Ads Use Medicare Cuts as Rallying Point
description: WASHINGTON  The backdrops differ  a cactus for Arizona, some lovely fall leaves for Pennsylvania  but the message, delivered by a series of nervous-looking older Americans, is uniform: Democratic Congressional candidates voted for billions of dollars in cuts to Medicare (or, if they were not in office, would have) and let their constituents down.

title: Director George Hickenlooper Dies at 47
description: 10:48 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES  George Hickenlooper, the film director whose movie Casino Jack is set to open in December, died last night in Denver, a publicist for the film said on Saturday. Mr. Hickenlooper was 47.

title: Elementary School Reclaims Link to King of Pop
description: LOS ANGELES  Outside the chain-link fence of Gardner Street Elementary School, Gregory Son and Laura Uselton celebrated, snapping pictures of the silver Michael Jackson Auditorium sign that gleamed on the schools stucco facade.

title: Virtual Failure on the Border
description: It is past time to pull the plug on the virtual fence that the federal government has been trying to erect on the border with Mexico. The Secure Border Initiative Network  a series of towers with radar and cameras that is supposed to spot trespassers along most of the 2,000 miles of border  is a costly failure.

title: The Prince and Mister Pointy
description: We obviously cant know what Louis XIV would have made of the sculptures of Takashi Murakami now on display at Versailles. We suspect the Sun King might have liked them, faulting them only for not enough gilding and mirrored surfaces.

title: Battle Over California Marijuana Initiative Goes Down to the Wire
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  It is the home stretch in the battle over Proposition 19, the ballot initiative that would legalize and regulate marijuana in California, and at Yes headquarters in downtown Oakland last week, young volunteers were hustling for votes.

title: Old Foes Square Off Over Issue of Puppies
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  This is an agricultural state, home to more than 100,000 farms and exporter of an outsize share of the nations yearly haul of beef, pork, milk and soybeans. But this year, attention has focused on another local commodity: puppies.

title: Leading Brazil, Facing Unfinished Tasks
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  From the moment their political paths crossed, Dilma Rousseff began solving problems for President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva.

title: Favre Expects to Start, and Belichick Expects It, Too
description: Brett Favre told ESPNs Ed Werder on Saturday afternoon that he expected to start for the Vikings on Sunday at New England.

description: To the Editor:

Weighing Radiation Risks

title: World Series Game 3: Rangers 4, Giants 2, Final
description: The Giants are an up-from-nothing collection which has won hearts and games with its plucky style. But the Rangers showed that they have their own sense of fight that had been absent so far in the World Series.

title: Fox Returns to Cablevision
description: The Fox network flickered back to life in three million homes serviced by Cablevision on Saturday night, signaling an end to an unusually long and bitter feud between the cable company and Foxs parent company, the News Corporation.

title: Leigh Van Valen, Evolution Revolutionary, Dies at 76
description: His beard, it was said, was longer than Gods but not as long as Charles Darwins. Thousands of books teetered perilously in his office, and a motion-sensitive door startled visitors with cricket chirps. He took notes on his own thoughts while conversing with others.

title: Proposed Road in Serengeti National Park
description: Scientists and conservationists fear that a planned road cutting through the Serengeti will disrupt animal migrations with potentially catastrophic results.

title: Serengeti Road Plan Offers Prospects and Fears
description: SERENGETI NATIONAL PARK, Tanzania  Every spring, out here on this endless sheet of yellow grass, two million wildebeest, zebras, gazelles and other grazers march north in search of greener pastures, with lions and hyenas stalking them and vultures circling above.

title: Sharing Secrets at Arms Length
description: THE two stories stood side by side: one said that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, was on the run, in fear of Western intelligence agencies and seen by some colleagues as delusional, erratic and imperious. The other story? A chilling account of war in Iraq, for which Mr. Assange and his organization were the primary source.

title: Highway Across the Serengeti
description: Jeffrey Gettleman examines a planned road that would bisect Tanzania's Serengeti National Park. Environmentalists claim it will disrupt the Great Migration while others say its an economic imperative.

title: Emerging Details on the Terror Scare
description: Two packages containing explosives were shipped from Yemen and addressed to Jewish sites in Chicago.

title: Mets Offer to Takahashi Is for Only a Year
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Unless the Mets significantly increase their initial offer to the left-hander Hisanori Takahashi, he is almost certain to leave the team. Takahashi wants a two- or three-year deal, but the Mets original incentive-laden offer was for only one guaranteed year.

title: How the Banks Put the Economy Underwater
description: IN Congressional hearings last week, Obama administration officials acknowledged that uncertainty over foreclosures could delay the recovery of the housing market. The implications for the economy are serious. For instance, the International Monetary Fund found that the persistently high unemployment in the United States is largely the result of foreclosures and underwater mortgages, rather than widely cited causes like mismatches between job requirements and worker skills.

title: Well Ahead, Cuomo Wraps Up 62-County Odyssey
description: BALLSTON LAKE, N.Y.  When a black Chevrolet Suburban carrying Andrew M. Cuomo pulled into the gravel-packed lot at Lakeside Farms just after noon, it had the feel of an ending.

title: If Rangers Face Elimination, Lee Could Be Irresistible
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Cliff Lee has made 227 major league starts in his career, but never on three days rest. He is next scheduled to pitch in Game 5 of the World Series on Monday, but there was some discussion about whether the Rangers might have asked him to move up a day if the Rangers had lost Game 3 and faced elimination in Game 4 on Sunday.

title: Saturday Night Forecast Update: Calm Before the Storm
description: We have entered information from around 50 new surveys into our database. But most of them were either in less-than-critical states (two pollsters, for instance, decided to survey all three House races in Utah), or tended to confirm our existing impressions of the races.

title: With Bulldozing Runners, Penn Seizes First Place
description: PHILADELPHIA  Pennsylvania quarterback Billy Ragone planned to throw a rare deep pass in the second quarter Saturday, but his receivers were covered. He figured it would probably be a good idea to do something else. So he ran. He can always run.

title: Corrections
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Saudi Help in Package Plot Is Part of Security Shift
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As new facts emerge about the terrorist plot to send explosives from Yemen to the United States by courier, one remarkable strand has stood out: the plot would likely not have been discovered if not for a tip by Saudi intelligence officials.

title: Jews in Chicago Feel Safe, but Are Cautious
description: CHICAGO  Even to a block that is arguably one of the safest and most secure in the country, the news that two parcels containing explosives were shipped from Yemen and addressed to synagogues or Jewish community centers in the city gave some residents pause on Saturday.

title: Paladino Improvises His Final Swing
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y.  A cold drizzle pelted Carl P. Paladinos black trench coat as he arrived, 40 minutes late, at the headquarters of the local Republican Party in this faded industrial town near the Canadian border.

title: Money Woes Can Be Early Clue to Alzheimers
description: Renee Packel used to have a typical suburban life. Her husband, Arthur, was a lawyer and also sold insurance. They lived in a town house just outside Philadelphia, and Mrs. Packel took care of their home and family.

title: Obama Campaigns to Keep a Democrat in His Former Senate Seat
description: CHICAGO  If there is one Senate seat that President Obama does not want Democrats to lose, it is the one he occupied in Illinois until he became president.

title: Beyond Final Score, What Political Experts Will Be Watching for on Election Day
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Mayoral Race Bares Division Among Hispanics
description: Once a month, about 35 young Hispanic professionals gather to take a United Neighborhood Organization class that has become a leadership incubator for the citys fastest-growing ethnic community. The most recent session of the course, Tuesday night at the East Bank Club, came as Juan Rangel, the organizations chief executive, emerged at the center of a dispute over how Hispanics should approach the succession fight for City Halls top job.

title: Parking Matter Still Festers
description: The money from privatizing Chicagos parking meters is almost tapped out, but fights over the handovers legality and fairness are still simmering.

title: Series Looks Different From This Fans View
description: The Yankees couldnt survive the second round of baseballs postseason, and the Mets and the Red Sox didnt qualify this year, leaving the World Series to a Texas team and a squad from the West Coast. Theyre going to play it anyway.

title: Beyond Election Day
description: Ah, the governors race: It has sucked all the air out of the room this election cycle, hasnt it? In fairness, the nasty, costly contest between Rick Perry and Bill White was always going to be the heavyweight fight, and all of us sitting at ringside have been sufficiently entertained. But theres an undercard as well  there typically is  and even if its received scant attention by comparison, dont think it doesnt matter. To the contrary, the outcome of races other than the one at the top of the ballot has serious implications for a great many matters of politics and policy that will affect every Texan. Here are six well be thinking about on Election Day.

title: Back in Texas, Rangers Dig In Their Heels
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Fluttering high above Rangers Ballpark on Saturday night were 36 state flags of Texas. Another, this one the approximate width of the Central Time Zone, covered the grassy berm beyond the center-field fence. Fans were urged to make some Texas-size noise and to sing along to Deep in the Heart of Texas. Just in case anyone had forgotten, the 106th World Series shifted to the Lone Star State, where subtlety is not in the vocabulary.

title: Double-Dipping (and Doing Well) in a Tough Economy, With Perhaps a Pang of Guilt
description: From his tidy office tucked behind an elementary school in the quiet town of Tiburon, Police Chief Michael Cronin warily greeted a visitor.

title: World Series? Who Cares. Chess League Playoffs Are On.
description: The United States Chess League is in its sixth season, and it is thriving.

title: Star-Studded Premiere at Garden Is Spoiled for Knicks by a Rerun
description: The air was filled with smoke and lasers and Michael Buffers booming baritone  the obligatory theatrics that accompany opening night at Madison Square Garden. The show was ultimately stolen by a flat-screen video monitor.

title: Farmer Johns Pumpkin Farm
description: Half Moon Bay, where farmers have grown squash since the 1930s, has declared itself the World Pumpkin Capital.  They do not all become jack-o-lanterns though; pumpkin meals are popular, with varieties available at Farmer Johns Pumpkin Farm by Highway 1. HANK PELLISSIER

title: Campaign Ads Portray Liberal Demon by Bay
description: The commercial could be mistaken for a low-budget San Francisco tourism advertisement, with images of Fishermans Wharf, the Golden Gate Bridge and AT&T Park.

title: Facing a Giant of an Election
description: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: No Shots Can Find Their Way Past Lundqvist and the Rangers
description: TORONTO  Blocked shots, Henrik Lundqvist and skating instruction were the themes going into Saturday nights Rangers-Maple Leafs game at Air Canada Centre, and they were the themes coming out of it, too.

title: Memento Mickey
description: Wide-eyed and always smiling, skulls are the most recognizable bone(s) in your body and easily the scariest. They once whispered, kissed and dreamed, just like us, but now, the life is gone, the soul inside vanished and only a generic symbol of death remains.

title: Oct. 30: College Football Photo Replay
description: The days action saw Michigan State and Missouri fall from the ranks of the unbeaten.

title: Postseason Showings Will Weigh on Giants
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  After the Yankees won the World Series last November, General Manager Brian Cashman insisted that the players performance in the postseason would not affect his decision to bring them back. Sure enough, Johnny Damon and Hideki Matsui starred in the World Series but were not retained as free agents.

title: Fox and Cablevision Deal Returns Signal
description: The Fox network flickered back to life in three million homes served by Cablevision on Saturday night, signaling an end to an unusually long and bitter feud between the cable company and Foxs parent company, the News Corporation.

title: Hes Back to Baseball Cards
description: MY father, Michael, was a volleyball player who competed in the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo and worked as an executive for the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee.

title: The Reason on Guillen
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Giants Manager Bruce Bochy insisted that outfielder Jose Guillen was left off the postseason roster because of a neck injury, not because he was tied to an investigation into shipments of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Sanchezs Velocity Concerns Giants
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Giants pitching coach, Dave Righetti, said he was concerned about the drop in starter Jonathan Sanchezs velocity recently, and thinks it could be attributable to fatigue at the end of a long season.

title: World Series Game 3 Replay
description: Photos from the Rangers 4-2 defeat of the Giants.

title: Oregons Late Surge Jolts U.S.C. Back to Reality
description: LOS ANGELES  For a good portion of Southern Californias game Saturday night against No. 1 Oregon, fans of the No. 24 Trojans were able to turn back the clock.

title: Vows: Isaac & Ellen
description: Isaac knew Ellen was special when she struck him out at a softball party.  Their competitions then moved from the from the field into the kitchen, where Isaac lost again, but he won Ellen's heart.

title: Running for the Sheer Pleasure of It
description: Dr. Thomas Farley, 54, is New York Citys health commissioner.

title: With Deadline Approaching, Knicks Still Working on Chandlers Deal
description: Wilson Chandlers agent is trying to negotiate a contract extension by Mondays deadline, but he acknowledges that circumstances  from the N.B.A.s uncertain labor situation to the Knicks salary-cap concerns  may prevent it.

title: In Mumbai, Finding the Perfect Fit
description: Walk through a market in Mumbai, and the brilliant colors, intricate designs and variety of fabrics on sale at even the smallest stall will captivate you. Indias clothes  like the countries bangle-clad women  sparkle and dazzle.

title: Bomber Wounds 32 in Attack in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  A suicide bomber wounded 32 people in an attack on the police in the busiest square in the heart of Istanbul on Sunday, government officials said.

title: The Ultimate Hour-by-Hour, District-by-District Election Guide
description: Were gearing up for what is certain to be a very exciting and  given that there are a number of crucial races on the West Coast, particularly for the Senate  very long Election Night.

title: New Help for Figuring Retirement Savings
description: The AARP recently released a new retirement calculator aimed at making it easier to figure out how much people need to save for retirement, whether they are on track to retire when they want, what they can do to ensure a better retirement lifestyle or if they can retire earlier.

title: Obama Closes for Democratic Committee in Last Ad
description: The Democratic National Committee is using President Obama as its final, get-out-the-vote messenger, spending several hundred thousand dollars for an ad on cable television channels nationwide urging people to cast their ballots on Tuesday.

title: How Ochocinco Embraces Fans of the Enemy
description: On a Friday afternoon before a road game, there are plenty of things Chad Ochocinco could be doing with his time while waiting for the Bengals charter flight to taxi down the runway at Cincinnati International Airport. He could be like any one of his teammates, curled up with a neck pillow and dozing or joining in a poker game.

title: Cap and Trade, the California Way
description: Months after federal cap-and-trade legislation died in the Senate and days before California voters will decide on a fiercely fought ballot initiative to deep-freeze the states global-warming-prevention law, state regulators released hundreds of pages of rules on Friday for how the law is to be applied, industry by industry.

title: Bomb Plot Shows Key Role Played by Intelligence
description: In the middle of last week, a woman who claimed her name was Hanan al-Samawi, a 22-year-old engineering student, walked into the U.P.S. office in the upscale Hadda neighborhood of Sana, Yemens sprawling capital city. She displayed a photocopied identification card, and dropped off a bomb hidden inside a printer cartridge with a Chicago address listed as the packages destination. A few blocks away, another package concealing a homemade bomb was dropped off at a FedEx office, also seemingly headed to Chicago.

title: Personal Finances and Alzheimers
description: The Times reports this morning on the difficult questions raised for lawyers, doctors and financial advisers when a client begins to show signs of dementia.

title: Airport Hassles Dont Discriminate
description: Youd think a VIP passenger like Goldikova would get a little special treatment at the airport. Not true. Goldikova, Behkabad and Plumania were supposed to leave Le Bourget airport outside of Paris at 10 a.m. Saturday, but their flight was delayed more than two hours by a combination of over-zealous customs agents and an equipment glitch, according to the Jour de Galop.

title: On the Campaign Trail
description: Some marquee names, both Democrats and Republicans, have been traveling the country supporting candidates in the two months leading to the midterm elections. Former President Bill Clinton and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. have appeared at fund-raisers across the country and made multiple visits in support of Gov. Ted Strickland of Ohio and Congressional candidates in Pennsylvania.

title: A Star at the Public Library: A Little Yellow Bird
description: For birders, the great prothonotary show has apparently ended.

title: Republicans Try to Lower Expectations
description: Even as surveys predicted a huge night for Republicans on Tuesday, leaders of the party on Sunday sought to play down expectations.

title: A House Divided Over Immigration
description: S.B. 1070, the controversial Arizona law that requires strict anti-immigration measures, has divided the Sotelo family into supporters and opponents.

title: Live Analysis: Packers 9, Jets 0, Final
description: The Jets rolled into the bye week on a high, winners of five straight and owners of the best record in the N.F.L. The only thing that could stop them was their scheduled time off.

title: Down From the Heights
description: Take 6,800 bamboo poles, 70 miles of colorful cord and plans for an art installation that will change every day over a six-month period and ultimately grow to 50 feet high. Add two artists and a bunch of rock climbers who like to listen to the Rolling Stones while they add to the piece, and drink pilsner when theyre done working. And then stick the whole thing on the roof of the esteemed, establishment Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Europes Plagues Came From China, Study Finds
description: The great waves of plague that twice devastated Europe and changed the course of history had their origins in China, a team of medical geneticists reported Sunday, as did a third plague outbreak that struck less harmfully in the 19th century.

title: A Glimpse of What the Knicks Had, and Are Lacking
description: There was Marcus Camby, a long-limbed testimony to better Knicks times, in the way of a proper Madison Square Garden launch to the spanking new Amare Stoudemire era.

title: Two Days Rest? No Sweat for Australian Horses
description: The first time I visited a tavern in Melbourne, Australia, a bitterly cold James Boags ale in my hand and a betting window in the corner doing brisk business, I thought Id died and gone to horseplayer heaven. Stakes races, many of them Group I, flickered from the extra-large flat screens, and the slap of programs to palm offered the soundtrack to thunderous stretch runs where horses spread nine across on the lush green.

title: Tracking the Printer Bombs
description: As the initial bomb-plot panic subsides, and the results of investigations in Washington, London and the Middle East are analyzed, a consensus is emerging on the details of the attack  along with fears that we may not have seen its end.

title: Wag The Dean
description: A few weeks back I had fun with people who tried to turn my assertion that World War II ended the Great Depression into an accusation that I was a warmonger. Heh.

title: The Morning Line: Breaking Down the Workout
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Thin Crowd for Cleveland Campaign Rally
description: CLEVELAND  President Obama wrapped up a weekend of last-minute campaigning in Ohio on Sunday, addressing Democrats in an indoor arena that, in a sign of the enthusiasm gap that the president is working so hard to close, was little more than half full.

title: Frank
description: EXTRA ADDED ATTRACTION, was indeed how the Paramount first billed him: fourth on the program, beneath Benny Goodman and His Famous Orchestra, under a comedy trio called the Radio Rogues and a comedy duo called Moke and Poke, and just above DON BAKER at the PARAMOUNT ORGAN. Frank Sinatras name was, however, the only one besides Goodmans in boldface, and in type only slightly smaller. And beneath the name, the slogan: The Voice That Has Thrilled Millions.

title: And When Im Gloomy, You Simply Gotta Listen to Me
description: He provided the soundtrack for several generations of Americans trying to navigate the rocky shoals of romance and grapple with love and heartbreak. And he became one of 20th-century pop cultures quintessential men of contradictions: the bullying tough guy whose singing could radiate a remarkable tenderness and vulnerability; the ring-a-ding-ding Vegas sophisticate with an existential outlook on life; the jaunty urbanite who could deliver a torch song like no one else. Fans could recognize his voice from two or three perfectly phrased syllables, and they knew him instantly from his style: the rakishly tilted hat, the coat slung over one shoulder, the Camels and Jack Daniels.

title: Fearing Election Losses in New York, National Democrats Enlist Cuomos Help
description: Anxious national Democrats are pressing Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo to try to stave off significant losses for the party in New York, as even more Democratic incumbents than expected find themselves imperiled in the campaigns final days.

title: Theodore C. Sorensen, 82, Kennedy Counselor, Dies
description: Theodore C. Sorensen, one of the last links to John F. Kennedys administration, a writer and counselor who did much to shape the presidents narrative, image and legacy, died Sunday in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: The Last Word: Theodore C. Sorensen
description: Theodore C. Sorensen, who died Sunday, was President John F. Kennedy's political strategist, confidant and his favorite speechwriter. Mr. Sorensen helped craft some of the president's most memorable lines.

title: Last Word: Theodore C. Sorensen
description: Theodore C. Sorensen was President John F. Kennedy's political strategist, confidant and his favorite speechwriter.  Mr. Sorensen helped craft some of the president's most memorable lines.

title: Reid Promises Immigration Vote After Election
description: Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader fighting to hold his seat in Nevada, said on a taped television appearance on Sunday he planned to bring legislation that would create a path for some illegal immigrants to gain legal status to a vote in the post-election session of Congress.

title: Theodore C. Sorensen Dies at 82
description: First hired as a researcher by John F. Kennedy in 1953,  Mr. Sorensen became a political strategist and a trusted adviser on everything from election tactics to foreign policy.

title: Philosophers Through the Lens
description: I have spent almost a quarter century photographing philosophers. For the most part, philosophers exist, and have always existed, outside the public spotlight. Yet when we reflect upon those eras of humankind that burn especially bright, it is largely the philosophers that we remember. Despite being unknown at a time, the philosophers of an era survive longer in collective memory than wealthy nobleman and politicians, or the popular figures of stage, song and stadium. Because of this disconnect between living fame and later recognition, we have less of a record of these thinkers than we should. Our museums are filled with busts and paintings of long-forgotten wealth and beauty instead of the philosophers who have so influenced contemporary politics and society. My aim in this project has been the modest one of making sure that, for this era at least, there is some record of the philosophers.

title: The Last Ordinary Day
Iraqi Forces Storm a Church With Hostages in a Day of Bloodshed
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi antiterrorist forces stormed a church where gunmen had taken close to 100 hostages on Sunday in an afternoon of chaos that became a bloodbath. At least 30 hostages and 7 security officers were killed, and 41 hostages and 15 security force members were wounded, according to a source at the Ministry of the Interior.

title: Modernism Celebrates Its Incubator
description: Judson Dance Theater has long since entered the canon. In the early 1960s this avant-garde collective of choreographers and other artists radically reshaped the worlds understanding of what dance could be, beginning investigations that, to some extent, continue.

title: Haunting in Prt, Terror in Bartok
description: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra has long prided itself on the reputation for versatility it has built through its recordings and its frequent visits to Carnegie Hall, particularly in the nine years Robert Spano has been its music director. Mr. Spanos fondness for 20th-century music serves him well in upholding that reputation, and on Saturday evening he led a program of modern classics  familiar but by no means overplayed scores by Arvo Prt, Bartok and Janacek  that seemed built to show off the ensembles resources.

title: Artful and Abundant Cool With Dollops of Quirk
description: In the video for All I Want Is You, one of the years most alluring R&B songs, Miguel plays the role of tortured modern soul man flawlessly. His girl has abandoned him, but for much of the clip he remains remarkably still, as if his mouth were delivering lyrics that his head wasnt quite ready to process. He sings each wounded line  Trying to do right by you got me here/Now all I am is alone  as if pulled away from it, the meaning too overwhelming to bear, even if he never actually breaks a sweat, or a tear.

title: Going Down to the Last Board at the World Junior Teams
description: The 64-board final of the World Junior Team Championship (for players under 27) for the Ortiz-Patio Trophy last month in Philadelphia was between France (Thomas Bessis, Frederic Volcker, Christophe Grosset, Cdric Lorenzini, Nicolas Lhuissier and Quentin Robert) and Israel (Eliran Argelazi, Alon Birman, Lotan Fisher and Bar Tarnovski).

title: In Ads, Candidates Make Final Pitches to Voters
description: WASHINGTON - Sharron Angle, the Republican candidate for Senate in Nevada, wants the states voters to know that Harry Reid had his chance, but its her turn now.

title: Johnny Meatballs Plans an Over-the-Top Wedding
description: It has been suggested that the French anthropologist Claude Lvi-Strauss could not have spent more than a few weeks each with the different native peoples observed in his 1955 book, Tristes Tropiques. If true, this would mean that cable television has already devoted more time documenting meathead Italian-Americans of the New York metropolitan area than a celebrated researcher spent studying tribes of Brazil and beyond for one of the classic texts of 20th-century social science.

title: Portraits of Hollywoods Founding Power Players
description: Those of us who hold Turner Classic Movies dear  who consider it the one indispensable channel among the 200 or 500 or 1,000 snaking into our televisions  dont necessarily watch it very often. It can be enough to know its there, commercial-free and aspect-ratio-conscious, showing a silent movie in the wee hours of every Monday morning or classing up Halloween with The Leopard Man and Cat People (Jacques Tourneur, 1942, as if you had to ask).

title: Playing on Musical Hybrids
description: From the audience perspective most of the action in a Buke and Gass show happens down by the players feet. And so a clump of fans rammed themselves into the area near the stage at Zebulon in Williamsburg on Wednesday night, near the low stage, and looked downward.

title: Monday: Senate Gofers
description: Holden Bakers theme, consisting of four different cane spellings, is just right for a Monday. But wait, theres a fifth  COCAINE in the very center. I almost didnt notice.

title: A Final Push Out of the Ditch?
description: At his final campaign rally before the election, President Obama returned to one of his favorite metaphors. It might be the last time though.

title: Fluid Voice With a Fluid Persona Firmly Attached
description: This is how it must feel to be an ovum, the singer Antony Hegarty said with a tone of gentle amusement as latecomers flooded down the aisles of Alice Tully Hall during the concert he presented there on Saturday night. It was the second time this singer, who goes by his first name, stopped to let stragglers find their seats. Earlier he had abruptly cut off a song just started  Ghost, from his rapturously lovely new album, Swanlights  then tried to smooth over an awkward silence by whistling Saties Gymnopdie No. 1.

title: Sibelius, Faster Than Speeding Bee
description: Surely Christian Tetzlaff is too serious an artist to take a run at the speed record recently set by the British violinist Oliver Lewis in Rimsky-Korsakovs Flight of the Bumblebee. Or is he?

title: Earthquakes and Seismic Suffering
description: To call Aftershock a melodrama doesnt really do it justice. Shortly after Feng Xiaogangs film begins, a woman whose husband has just died in the devastating 1976 Tangshan earthquake looks up and screams: God! You bastard! And things go downhill from there. Before you know it, she has a Sophies choice to make involving her two trapped children and a concrete slab.

title: A World of Silliness, but No Winking This Time
description: Even on a chilly autumn night in a subterranean theater, the Shakespeares Globe production of The Merry Wives of Windsor breathes the air of springtime. This sparkling show, which runs through Sunday at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University, brims with a joy in pranks and japes and silly jokes that suggests the devilish feeling that possesses people on the first bright, balmy day after a long winter.

title: Donna Murphy to Lead Roundabout Musical
description: The Roundabout Theater Company has announced plans for a new musical starring Donna Murphy, below. The show, The People in the Picture, with a book and lyrics by the novelist Iris Rainer Dart (Beaches), tells the story of a New York grandmother, to be played by Ms. Murphy, who was once a Yiddish theater actress in Poland before World War II. Bubbie now longs to tell her Holocaust tales to her granddaughter, despite her daughters desire to leave the past in the past. Ms. Murphy, who is also an accomplished film and television actress, last appeared on Broadway as Lotte Lenya in the Manhattan Theater Clubs production of LoveMusik, for which she received a Tony nomination. The show features music written by the early rock n roll songwriter Mike Stoller (Smokey Joes Caf) and Artie Butler, who wrote and arranged music for artists like Louis Armstrong and Joe Cocker. Leonard Foglia, whose recent work includes Let Me Down Easy, Anna Deavere Smiths one-woman show about health care and the body, will direct, with musical direction by Paul Gemignani (Pal Joey) and musical staging by Andy Blankenbuehler (In the Heights). Previews are scheduled to begin at the American Airlines Theater on April 1, with an opening on April 28.

title: Saw 3D Takes Top Honors in Horror Genre
description: Saw 3D, the seventh and final installment in Lionsgates horror-rific franchise, took the No. 1 spot at the weekend box office, beating its Halloween-theme competition with $24.2 million in sales in its debut week, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. This week Paramounts sequel, Paranormal Activity 2 dropped to No. 2, with $16.5 million, and a total of $65.6 million in sales in its second week. RED, the adaptation of the graphic novel by Warren Ellis and Cully Hamner from Summit Entertainment, held steady in the third spot, with $10.8 million and a total of $58.9 million in its third week. Jackass 3D, the prankster comedy from MTV Films and Paramount Pictures, followed in fourth place, bringing in only $8.4 million in its third week but crossing the $100 million mark, with $101.6 million in cumulative sales. Clint Eastwoods supernatural thriller, Hereafter (Warner Brothers), finished in fifth place this weekend, earning only $6.3 million and a total of $22.2 million in its second week of wide release.

title: James Faces Jeering, but Little Competition
description: NEWARK  The Nets are introduced before their games in a Vegas-like spectacle, with blue and red flashing lights, green lasers and thumping club music that seems to turn the Prudential Center into a giant subwoofer.

title: Gabriel Garca Mrquez Is Writing New Novel
description: Gabriel Garca Mrquez, the 83-year-old Colombian author and Nobel Prize winner, below, is at work on a new novel, Agence France-Presse reported. Cristobal Pera, his Random House Mondadori editor, spoke at a presentation in Mexico City on Thursday for Mr. Mrquezs newest release, a book of essays titled I Didnt Come to Give a Speech. He said Mr. Mrquez was busy completing a new novel to be called Well Meet in August. No publication date has been set. The current release, the first for Mr. Mrquez since Memories of My Melancholy Whores in 2004, is a compilation of speeches, beginning with his high school commencement in 1944. It is to be published in Spanish on Nov. 9.

title: Ren Pape Withdraws From Next Ring Installment
description: The German opera singer Ren Pape, right, has withdrawn from the highly anticipated production of Wagners Die Walkre, the next installment of the Ring cycle, from La Scala in Milan and the Staatsoper unter den Linden in Berlin, that is scheduled to open at La Scala on Dec. 7, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Pape, who sang the title role in the Metropolitan Operas production of Mussorgskys Boris Godunov recently, said in a statement that he needed to take a break from rehearsals and performances, but that he was not having problems with his voice. The Ukrainian singer Vitalij Kowaljow will replace Mr. Pape in the role of Wotan for the performances in Milan. Mr. Pape plans to rejoin the production for performances at the Staatsoper on April 17. His next scheduled performance will be with the Munich Philharmonic in January, singing Verdis Messa da Requiem.

title: Bloody Bloody Offers Tickets for $50
description: Producers for the Broadway show Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson have announced a special offer on tickets in the spirit of the midterm election season. Their Jackson for a Grant initiative offers $50 tickets to the show through Nov. 24. Tickets can be purchased at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater box office (242 West 45th Street, Manhattan); by calling (212) 947-8844; or at BroadwayOffers.com (with the code BBJVOTE). In addition Benjamin Walker, who plays Andrew Jackson in the production, will host a free performance of Find the Funny, a show featuring comedians as well as other actors from Bloody Bloody, on Nov. 2 at the Tank performance space; 354 West 45th Street, Clinton; thetanknyc.org. No tickets are necessary.

title: Video: A Final Push Out of the Ditch?
description: CLEVELAND  At his final campaign rally before Election Day, President Obama compared the economy with a car that had been driven into a ditch. The Republicans, he said, hadnt helped push it out but instead had watched from the side while sipping Slurpees. Its one of his favorite lines and, according to Mark Knoller of CBS News, the president has used it 35 times so far this election cycle but Sunday could have been the last. Indeed, voters will soon decide whether to give Congressional Republicans the keys to the car back.

title: Excitement Builds for the Breeders Cup
description: David Buc Geier helps run the Corner Cocktail, a tavern in the horse-racing hinterland of Kansas City, Mo. He has as many opinions and ideas on the Sport of Kings as he does uncashable tickets in his desk drawer.

title: A Reminder of the Beautiful Game
description: LONDON  The longer that FIFA takes investigating its own allegedly corrupt officials, the more the sport needs to be reminded of why grown men play it and love it.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: 5 Reasons Republicans Could Do Even Better Than Expected
description: Dawn breaks over New York City on Wednesday, Nov. 3. Democrats catching the early train to work are thinking about adding a little whiskey to their morning coffee. Because the headlines they are reading are truly terrible.

title: Somali-American Becomes Prime Minister of Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  A Somali-American became the prime minister of Somalia on Sunday after winning a vote of confidence in Parliament.

title: Giants Drop Struggling Burrell Out of Lineup
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The only other time Pat Burrell played in the World Series, in 2008 with Philadelphia, he went hitless in his first 13 at-bats. Burrell is not quite in that dire territory, but his quest for his first hit against Texas will have to wait at least another day. Burrell was pulled out of the Giants lineup for Sundays Game 4 after striking out in all four plate appearances Saturday night. Through three games, he is 0 for 9 with eight strikeouts.

title: Early Start May Have Hurt Game 3 Ratings
description: The Rangers 4-2 win over the Giants in Game 3 of the World Series on Saturday night was seen by an average of 11.5 million viewers.

title: For Elite Runners, Baby Steps Can Take Precedence
description: PACIFIC GROVE, Calif.  Gone were the sinus infections that plagued Blake Russell during the final months of her pregnancy, the additional 40 pounds she packed on her 5-foot-5 frame, the awkwardness she felt when she resumed running five weeks after the birth of her son, the raccoon eyes from sleep deprivation.

title: Nations Political Pulse, Taken Using Net Chatter
description: When a Rasmussen poll last month showed Representative Roy Blunt opening a double-digit lead over Robin Carnahan in their Senate campaign in Missouri, John Hancock was not surprised.

title: Spielberg and DreamWorks Energize the Magic Machine Anew
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  In the perfect little town of Paradise, Ohio, a pretty-faced new kid has a crush on the sweet blonde who is showing him around. By the way, the kid is also a space alien, on the run from some other aliens who are anything but pretty.

title: The Ghosts of New York Subway Stations Past
description: The site of the Underbelly Project is one of dozens of abandoned spaces throughout the New York City subway system where a hidden relic of the past can lie behind any door or staircase. Platforms, tracks, entire stations have been left behind as the system expanded over the years; most are covered with graffiti and dust, but some are better maintained.

title: The Underbelly Project
description: In a secret underground art project, a group of artists created large-scale works in an abandoned subway station.

title: After Bye Week, Jets Are Off, and Winning Streak Is Over
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Late in the fourth quarter, the stands at New Meadowlands Stadium emptied as fans streamed by the hundreds toward the exits. The pockets of people that remained wore blocks of cheese atop their heads and chanted, Go, Pack, Go!

title: Jets replay: Oct. 31
description: The Jets five-game winning streak was snapped when they fell to the Packers, 9-0.
